column2: Archie Moulton Andrews of Greenwhich, died at his home, Freestone Castle, here this afternoon following a short illness. His age was 59. Mr. Andrews was associated with various business enterprises, among them being the Dictograph Products Co., Progress Lekto Shaver

The bandit Navy Department joined four other government agencies today to oppose construction of a canal across Nicaragua at this time. It recommended, however, that the $1,000,000,000 project be studied further.

Syracuse and Navy toda joined the rowing colony on th Hudson, preparing for the interco legiate regatta June 27. Syracuse, arriving this morning went out for a long row down stream in the afternoon. The was ter was rough and the Orang eights made no effort at speed Navy didn't arrive until late in the afternoon and is scheduled for it first drill tomorrow.

The marriage of Miss Irene D.. MacGregor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Waldo Emerson MacGregor of Crestwood, in this community, to Raymond J. Mathewetz, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Mathewetz of Ashland, Wis., took place this afternoon at All Saints Episcopal Church, Great Neck. The Rev. Alexander R. McKechnie officiated.
The Reichsbank's statement as of June 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:
For the first time in -many centuries Vienna's traditional Corpus Christi procession was not attended by army and civil leaders and the usual volleys were not fired by army detachments.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs fair and prices somewhat stronger; fresh pork business fair; other classes slow. Steer cuts steady to lower; lamb higher; other classes unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be higher; veal steady; lamb higher.

Further general rains throughout the great cotton-producing area west of the Mississippi River caused another advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and July contracts touched 8.41 cents, or 74 points above recent low levels.

Bobby Riggs was primed today for defense of the national clay courts tennis championship he won in 1936 and 1937. Riggs was seeded No. 1 for the annual tournament which gets under way tomorrow at the River Forest Tennis Club.
The United States has rejected the thesis of the German Government that the latter is not obligated to assume the debts of the Austrian Government, and is insisting upon payment.

Getting off to a fine start and leading all the way, Cornelius Shields's Aileen won the weekly International Class yacht race today. Aileen crossed the finish line 1 minute and 1 second ahead of Susan, the property of Emil Mosbacher, with James Brickell's Allegra third.

Miss Geraldine Storm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond William Storm of this place, was married to Joseph 0. Kremer, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Brainerd Kremer a Jr. of Montclair, N. J., this afternoon in the Huguenot Memorial Church here by the Rev. Dr. Willard P. Soper.

Eliot Cabot, actor, died yesterday afternoon in Morrisania Hospital from injuries received Monday when he fell down a twenty-foot embankment of the old Croton Aqueduct on Burnside Avenue, near University Avenue, the Bronx. He would have been 39 years old next Wednesday.

An 85 posted by the earliest Class A starter, Mrs. Archer U. Rodney, easily withstood the challenges of 135 women golfers at the Metropolis Country Club today and gave the Quaker Ridge representative the low-gross cup for the second time in three years in the Westchester Fete links tourney.

Our State Department revealed yesterday that on June 9 it protested vigorously against Germany's repudiation of Austria's external debt. The speech of Walther Funk, German Economics Minister, defending the repudiation, was a striking instance of misstatements and false analogies.
George M. Cohan was installed yesterday afternoon as the twenty-fifth president of the Catholic Actors Guild at a meeting in the Hotel Astor. His father, Jerry Cohan, was the president of the Guild.
A wisp of hair clipped from the head-of Lord Nelson, Britain's famed sea dog who coined the slogan England expects every .man to do his duty," was sold at auction here today for [pound]11.

Robert McLean, president of The Philadelphia Bulletin, will receive the class of 1913 loving cup from his former classmates at Princeton University tomorrow in honor of his recent election as president of The Associated Press. The presentation will be a part of the program for the third and final day of alumni festivities.

Conditions were quiet in the sto?k markets today, but, following some end-ofthe-account profit-taking, a number of good features developed. Gilt-edge securities held around yesterday's levels and in the foreign section Austrian bonds staged a small recovery.

Cincinnati Street Railway Company--Five months to May 31: Net income after expenses and charges, $37,483, equal to 8 cents a share on the outstanding capital stock, compared with a net of $121,573, or 26 cents a capital share, in the first five months of 1937. May net income was $6,878, against $27,025 in May, 1937.

The Board of Electors of the International Typographical Union announced tonight that Claude M. Baker of San Francisco had defeated Charles P. Howard of Chicago, incumbent since 1926, for international president of the union by almost 14,000 votes.
Mrs. Mary E. McCabe Perine, temperance worker for more than sixty years, died here last night at her home, 29 North Essex Avenue, headquarters of the local branch of the W. C. T. U. Her age was 89.

Thomas A. Jobbagy, president of the Pacific Hotel Supply Company, with offices at 352 West Fourteenth Street, died yesterday at the Park West Hospital at the ae of 55. Born and educated in Hungary, Mr. Jobbagy came to this country as a young man and became associated with Swift Co.

BAYERSDORF--Rose, beloved mother of Florence Rothschild, sister of Sadie Hurwitz. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St.-Amsterdarn Ave., Sunday. June 19, 11 A. M. BIRNBAUM--Arthur, darling son of Fred and Anna, dear brother of Morton. Services Sunday, 11 A. M., Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1,283 Coney Island Ave.,

Herbert and Stuart Scheftel of Sands Point led a field of ninetyseven teams in the qualifying round of the best-ball golf tournament of the Piping Rock Club today with a four-under-par 67. They showed the way by three strokes.

Father's Day will be commemorated tomorrow in some of the city's churches. There will be celebrated tomorrow throughout the English-speaking world the four-hundredth anniversary of the first use of the Bible in English in a church service.
An amazing political career, even in the United States, where the highest public office is open to every one, ended with the death of United States Senator Royal S. Copeland.
The new Cornell University directory living alumni lists names of 61, men and women living on May 1938. The total compares with 825 names published in the 1 directory.

Warners have opened negotiations with Elisabeth Bergner for the starring role in James Hilton's "We Are Not Alone," the studio announced today. While Miss Bergner always has declined Hollywood offers, indications have been given Warners that she now looks favorably on the idea.

Trade practice rules for the fur industry, which has a production valued at $150,000,000 annually, were promulgated today by the Federal Trade Commission. The rules, embracing twenty-nine Group 1 and two Group 2 regulations, supersede those promulgated on March 7, 1928.

Johnny Allen had his pitching stuff today and beat Connie Mack's Athletics, 8 to 1, for his eighth victory of the season to give the Indians their third straight triumph and lead of one game over the idle Yankees.
YESTERDAY'S RESULTS New York 10, St. Louis 3. Cincinnati 4, Brooklyn 3 (lst, 11 innings). Cincinnati 12, Brooklyn 10 (2d). Boston 1, Chicago 0 (lst).

The marriage of Miss Agnes Pruyn Linder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred E. Linder of West New Brighton, S. I., to Dr. William Allan Monkhouse of Lovell, Me., son of Mrs. Bertram L. Monkhouse of Toronto and the late Mr. Monkhouse, took place last night in the First Presbyterian Church of Staten Island, Stapleton.

Mayor La Guardia welcomed the new flagship Oslofjord of the Norwegian America Line as a "regular commuter" between the ports of Oslo and Bergen by way of the North Atlantic to New York, at a luncheon yesterday under the auspices of the Norwegian American Chamber of Commerce, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The California and Cornell varsity crews finished a week of practice on Lake Cayuga today and tomorrow will meet in an "informal" three-mile race, their final test before going on-to the regatta at Poughkeepsie.

The Manchester division of the Pacific Mills Corporation, which was established here in November, 1936, will close down permanently on June 30, according to H. G. Simonds of Boston, vice president of the corporation. From April to September of 1937 the mill operated at peak production of 1,000,000 yards of textiles weekly.

Several hundred persons, including leaders in finance, politics the legal profession, attended funeral services yesterday for Thomas L. Chadbourne, corporation lawyer, in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Housh, daughter of Mrs. Walter J. P Enright of New Preston, Conn.; S New York and Delray Beach, Fla.; D and the late Carter Frederick Housh, to Henry van Dyke Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Hamilton Gibson of Washington, took place here tonight in St. John's Church. The bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. Tertius van Dyke, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Floyd Tomkins.

The State of North Dakota will be in the market on July 6 with $900,000 certificates of indebtedness, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent. The certificates will be dated July 6, 1938, and will become payable on July 6, 1939.

Miss Maureen Orcutt, metropolitan champion, who did not compete in the tournament for four years, won the women's Eastern golf championship for the fifth time with a record score of 228 for the fifty-four holes of medal play when she added her third 76 today at the Spring Mills course of the Philadelphia Country Club.

Exerimental studies in the action of Ilfanilimide, the new drug being sed to combat a variety of disases,. showed that it is transmitted infants in possibly deadly doses given to mothers during the preg to a report today to the Amerian Medical Association.

Irving G. Warshaw, former City Judge and Corporation Counsel of Long Beach, died today. Judge Warshaw had practiced law here and in New York for many years. He was active in various good government drives, and represented the Long Beach Loyal Citizens party, during his earlier days as a lawyer.

August Aakesson, president of the board of the Swedish-American Steamship Line, died today at the age of 49. Mr. Aakesson was business manager of Nytid, the organ of the Social Democratic party, in which he was active in his native city of Gothenburg.

In a three-to-two decision, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court ruled yesterday in effect that the dollar devaluation act released the Bethlehem Steel Company from an obligation to pay interest to foreigners on multiple currency bonds issued by subsidiaries at the exchange rates that prevailed

In St. Bartholomew's Church yesterday afternoon Miss Mary Dake Mairs, a descendant of several old New York and New England families, was married to John Francis Smith Jr., son of Mrs. John F. Smith of Frederick, Md., and the late Mr. Smith. The Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, the rector, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Edmund J. Lee of Chatham, Va.

Railroad bonds sold off to new w levels yesterday on the New ork Stock Exchange. The tradg pace, however, was quiet. Weakness in many of the highade carrier loans was conspicu.s to the point that the market r rail bonds generally appeared times almost on the verge of colpse.

The body of Irving G. Warshaw, 41 years old, former city judge of Long Beach. who lives at 116 Riverside Boulevard, was found in the kitchen of his father-in-law's home at 612 West Walnut Street, here, shortly after 7 o'clock tonight.

The Charge against Captain Stanley Scott, master of the British freighter Stancroft, of carrying munitions to Spain was dismissed today, the : court upholding the contention of the defense that the provisions of the British act do not apply to ships

Rear Admiral Yancey Williams, commander of the Special Service Squadron, sailed on the flagship Erie from San Jose, Guatemala, today on a Central American cruise. Dudley G. Dwire, TJnited States consul, also is making the cruise.

Complete returns from the general election in Eire yesterday will be slow to come in. When Mr. de Valera dissolved the Dail near the end of May after the defeat of his Government by a single vote, he seemed to have everything in his favor.

Houghton Mifflin has received the complete manuscript of Herbert Agar's story of the Democratic party, which will be published as one of their Fall non-fiction leaders under the title "Pursuit of Happiness."

Franklin Atwood Park of New York, vice president and director of the board of the Singer Manufacturing Company, died tonight at his Summer estate. He was 70 years old. Mr. Park was stricken with coronary thrombosis Saturday and physicians tonight attributed his death to pneumonia.

A plan of reorganization for the Spokane International Railway Company and the Coeur d'Alene Pend d'Oreille Railway Company, calling for the merger of the two properties, the wiping out of capital stock and unsecured claims and the issuance of 4 1/2 per cent income bonds

Tonight, as the crews of Yale and Harvard drew toward the close of their last week of driving training for their regatta on the Thames next Friday, it became known that a change had been made in the Elis' varsity.

NEW FRONTIERS OF RELIGION, by Arthur L. Swift Jr. (Macmillan, $2.) A study of the relation between religion and social change. Professor Swift surveys the basic patterns and enduring effects of primitive religions, the development of the church as a social institution and its present status in America.

T. V. Soong's unheralded arrival at Hong Kong today by plane from Hankow, coupled with his refusal to confirm or deny that he is about to take a more active part in the Chinese Government, tends to confirm persistent reports that he is likely soon to become Finance Minister again,

Glenn Cunningham and Archie San Romani, running mates from Kansas, will again hold the spotlight in Palmer Stadium's invitation track meet tomorrow, this time carrying their rivalry into the three-quarter mile field as well as the mile run. They, like the 20,000 expected to attend, are hoping for new records.

The death of re Royal S. Copeland has. in the opinion of politicians and observers, upset the entire political picture in this State as far as the Fall campaign is concerned. It will be the first time in many years that the State will be electing two Senators and a State ticket at the same time.
By ANNE O'HARE McCORMICK The King of Sweden, at 80 as straight, slender and supple as a tall sapling, might be a figure on the prow of a viking ship as it cleaves the fresh waters of the north seas.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh ruled today that the Federal Government should have sued a California company and the Pennsylvania Railroad in New York instead of in Pennsylvania on charges of making rebates on freight rates. He dismissed indictments returned in 1937.

In a punishing, nerve-racking finish to a two-hour struggle, Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio averted defeat by a stroke to overcome Miss Edna Smith of Cleveland yesterday in the New York State championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

New devices and refinements in television sketched here yesterday at the annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers indicate that enormous progress has been made in the last year in laboratories in the evolution of apparatus that some day may be assembled into an electrical sight channel almost as efficient and capable as the human eye.

Miss Eulalie Pepper, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. O. H. Perry Pepper of Ithanlea,- Ithan, was married this afternoon to Francis A. Lewis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Lewis of Bryn Mawr. The ceremony was performed by Canon Ernest Earp in the Church of the Redeemer Brvn Mawr.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has reopened the hearing and will take additional evidence on July 7 on applications by the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, Ltd., under the Holding Company Act with reference to the manner

The Bears increased their International League lead to eight and a half games tonight by vanquishing Rochester, 9 to 4. Jimmie Gleeson's seventh home run of the year with the bases full in the sixth was the climax of a seven-run outburst and enabled

Twenty-one cadets and officers from the United States Military Academy at West Point sailed yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Clara for a cruise of Caribbean ports and a visit at the army post in Panama. They will return on the liner Santa Rosa in a month.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the City College, announces yesterday the names of twelve stu dent members of the graduating class who will receive prizes, awards and honorable mentions for out standing scholarship and characted at the ninety-second annual com mencement exercises in the Lewi sohn Stadium next Wednesday.

Such a crowd as Chinatown probably never had seen before filled its narrow, winding streets last night in a "Bowl of Rice" party to-- aid civilian war refugees in China. From 8 o'clock until far into the morning hours thousands of persons--police estimated that probably 85,000 either participated in or viewed the party for a time

The third marriage of Ursula Parrott, novelist, ended in divorce here today when Judge Edwin C. Dickinson of the. Superior Court granted her an uncontested decree from John J. Wildberg, New York theatrical lawyer, on grounds of intolerable cruelty.

The marriage of Miss M. Britta Furlong, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William G. Furlong, to Donald M. Terry, son of Dr. Minor J. Terry, took place this afternoon in St. Vincent de Paul's Church. The Rev. William H. Charles officiated.

Testimonial luncheon in honor of Max Schonberg, principal of P. S. 70, Bronx, upon his elevation to the principalship of the new Joseph H. Wade Junior High School, Hotel Astor, 1 P. M. Speakers: Jacob Greenberg, William Rabenort and William A. Hannig.
Dr. J. Edgar Park, president of Wheaton College, delivered the commencement address to ninety seniors, their families and guests in the Bingham Auditorium of the Taft School this morning.
The sweeping proposals for park areas, major highways and commuter and railroad systems which the Regional Plan is issuing this week illustrate the vitality of an idea.

The Bureau Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 15: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Taylor, G. W., Med. Corps, Philadelphia, Pa., and Ferguson, R. A., Dental Corps, Washington, D. C., when discharged from treatment at Naval Hospital, ordered home, relieved all active duty.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The Max Schmeling board of strategy was augmented today, with the arrival of Doc Casey, famous trainer from Detroit. Casey, who has appeared in Schmeling's corner in all except two of the German's fights in this country, arrived late last night, but it was not until today that he and Max Machon went into a secluded session of "skull practice" with the challenger.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and Crown Princess Louise of Sweden sailed today for Wilmington, Del., accompanied by other members of the official Swedish and Finnish delegations to the tercentenary celebration of the founding of New Sweden in America.

Representative Allard H. Gasque of Florence, S. C., chairman of the House Committee on Pensions, died today in Walter Reed Hospital of heart disease after an illness of several months. He entered the hospital on May 25. His age was 65.

Noteholders of the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, bankrupt Insull investment company, were notified today that a payment of 4% per cent of the face value of their claims would be made after July 11 by Sam Howard, trustee.

Charles M. Warner died in Greenwich Hospital today of pneumonia at the age of 35. He was associated with Waintford Co., sugar brokers. Born in Syracuse, his father, the late Grove E. Warner, was an executive of the Malt Diaston Company.

Plans are being made by the Navy Department, with the approval of the President and the State Department and presumably at their instance, to hold extensive fleet manoeuvres in the Atlantic this Summer, bringing the fleet through the Panama Canal from the Pacific Ocean for that purpose.

When Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived in Boston today, smiling and happy over the marriage of her youngest son tomorrow, she told reporters that John Roosevelt and Anne Clark should be permitted to run their own lives like any other young couple.
Colonel Leonard T. Baker, U. S. A., retired, died at the Station Hospital at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, today at the age of 58, according to word received by the War Department.

Nine hundred women attended the first events here today of the eighth annual two-day fete of the Westchester chapter of the women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities. Golf, bridge and other games were played at the Metropolis Country Club.

Mrs. Mary F. Oppenheimer, 30 years old, a patient at the Hastings Hillside Hospital, Hastings-uponHudson, who had come to New York in care of a nurse to do some shopping but had become separated from her at the Grand Central Station, was found dead, a suicide by hanging, in a room at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza, Fifty-eighth Street and Sixth Avenue, early yesterday. She left several notes.

A proposal that the forthcoming expenditure of $10,000,000 by the WPA for the purchase of men's, women's and children's clothing be made through retail channels instead of manufacturers was made today by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

A blanket denial of charges that Governor Earle and thirteen fellowDemocrats, several of them high officials of his Administration, conspired to "cheat and defraud" the Commonwealth was laid before the State Supreme Court here today.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City spent his fifth day on the witness stand before Judge William Clark in the United States District Court in Newark yesterday, undergoing cross-examination by his counsel, John A. Matthews. Although he is a defendant in the injunction action, Mr. Hague has been called as a witness by the plaintiffs.
Rochambeau Ave (12-3335), e s. 131 ft s of Van Cortlandt Ave, 160x100; Sadie Kaplan to Enle Realty Corp, 384 E 149th St; mtg $166,000.

Fresh out breaks of anti-Jewish excesses developed today in the northern section of Berlin, in the heart of a crowded workers' quarter. The outbreaks were so widespread and occurred with such apparent toleration on the part of the police

Policeman Ernest L. Keen took a leave of absence today to help "forget" his robber son, who died fighting the law his father upheld. Harold Keen, 23, an ex-convict who went wrong as a youngster, was shot to death last night

James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for Goodyear Sill Corporation, distributors of sil?? fabrics. Barent Ten Eyck, assistant district attorney of New York Count, in charge of the fraud bureau, will speak on the bureau's activities a a dinner meeting of the board a governors of the clothing and furnishings division of the Credi Clearing House on Thursday at th Hotel New Yorker.
The marriage of Miss Mary Armstrong, daughter of Mrs. N. S. Wyckoff Vanderhoef of 1,192 Park Avenue and of Daniel W. Armstrong, also of this city, to Robert Amory Jr. of Milton, Mass.,

The United States Coast Guard opened officially yesterday afternoon its new, modern, eastern sea nett Municipal Airport. Mayor La Guardia. attended the exercises dedicating the $1,000,000 combined hangar, machine shop and administration headquarters on the shore of -Jamaica Bay.
Airtight pitching and fielding enabled the Bees to take both ends of the Bunker Hill Day double-header with the Cubs today, 1-0 and 3-2, before 12,645.
Miss Elena Hodgson and Isaac Ollis, Americans, were attacked by sharks and drowned when the schooner Elizabeth sank in the San Juan River recently, according to a report received here.

In behalf of the copper-producing companies operating under the restriction scheme, it was announced officially today that from July 1 production would be decreased from 105 per cent to 95 per cent of the agreed basic tonnages.

Seven thousand marchers, thir- that 106 applications ty-five floats and twenty bands will appear tomorrow afternoon in New Rochelle's 250th anniversary parade, it was announced tonight. Police said-all traffic on the Boston Post Road would be detoured for two hours and travelers were urged to avoid trying to pass through -the city.
Horses entered by the New York City Police Department captured the first and third awards in the pairs jumping class during the second day of the nineteenth annual Troy horse show today.

Stagehand, leading money winning horse of the year, and the one with the best claim to the threeyear-old championship, will make his first start at Aqueduct today since being withdrawn from the Kentucky Derby through illness. This is the colt who scored the Santa Anita grand slam, capturing the Derby from Dauber and the Handicap from Seabiscuit in the richest double in the history of racing.

The annual commencement exercises of the Hill School will be held tomorrow, when 114 members of the class of 1938, representing twenty-two States, the District of Columbia and one foreign country, will be graduated.

THERE was a rumor once that Erskine Caldwell was out to destroy the literary tradition of mammies and magnolias. His works have increasingly shown, however, that he had nothing so sweeping in mind. He still writes only about the people and the part of the country he thoroughly knows.

Those who expect the Japanese armies to occupy Hankow within two months will be disappointed unless the Chinese forces should decide to evacuate that area and mass south of the Yangtze River for long-time resistance.

With live snakes, lizards, tortoises Hasidic and other forms of desert reptile life, Charles M. Bogert of the department of herpetology of the American Museum of Natural History has returned from a twogions of Arizona, California, Nevada and Utah, according to an announcement made-- at the museum yesterday.

With the usual informality St. Paul's School held its graduation exercises this evening. The speaker was Reeve Schley of New York. After presentation of diplomas, certificates and prizes, the "Last Night Service" in the chapel ended the year.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $17,345,166, to be represented by one State and fifty-five municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $30,426,579 for this week. The weekly average of -new offerings for the year to date now stands at $28,007,069.

Miss Meredith Haines, first of the debutantes of the 1937-38 season here to become engaged, was married yesterday to Donald Frederick Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Frederick Taylor of Melrose, Mass.,
Thirty years ago in New York City one baby in every eight died before reaching its first birthday.

Three officials of Hoaglund Allum, Inc., the brokerage house which crashed in April with losses of $636,000, were indicted by a Federal grand jury before Judge John P. Barnes today on charges of using the mails in a scheme to defraud and violation of the security and exchange laws.

The 106 Macdougal St Corp, George J. DeMartini, president, gave to Pietro Porrini and his wife a mortgage for $15,000. due June 1, 1943. at 5% per cent, on 106 Macdougal St. Four mortgages held by the Central Savings Bank from Ella Hassel have been consolidated as one lien for $23.000 on 575-77 Hudson St and extended for five years at 5 per cent.

When he makes his bid against Joe Louis for the world heavyweight title next Wednesday night in the Yankee Stadium, Max Schmeling will be without the services of Joe Jacobs, his American manager, for the first time in any of his American ring struggles, unless some unforeseen development removes existing official opposition to issuing a license to Jacobs.

Department store sales in the week ended June 11 were 15 per cent below sales for the same week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. For the four-week period ended June 11 the sales were 16 per cent lower than for the same comparable weeks in 1937. The weekly figures are based on reports from about 265 stores located in all sections of the country.

Appeals for Palestine to be thrown open to free immigration in order that it may be a haven of refuge for Jews persecuted in European countries were submitted to the White House, State Department and British Embassy today by a delegation

The struggling White Sox, who have not scored a victory at home since May 25, found a new starting pitcher no solution to their woes today. The Red Sox peppered Jack Knott, formerly of the Browns, for ten hits in his White Sox debut and defeated Chicago, 5-1, in the opener of a four-game series.

Charles Weber has sold the ninefamily apartment building on the southwest corner of 164th Street and Eighty-sixth Avenue, Jamaica, known as 162-30 Eighty-sixth Avenue, to a client of Hosinger Bode, Inc., brokers, for cash above a purchase-money mortgage of $18,000. The house stands on a plot 60 by 100 feet.

The General Sessions jury which since 5:20 o'clock Thursday afternoon had been trying to reach a verdict in the trial of two women and nine men in the alleged $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy had failed to agree early this morning and was locked up for the night.

Father's Day, which will be observed tomorrow, has been promoted on a larger scale than ever before, it was reported yesterday by William H. Weintraub, chairman of the newly organized National Council for the Promotion of Father's Day.

Musically speaking, Lee Shubert contemplates a pretty active season next year. He would establish a partnership with the busy Vinton Freedley for one of the musicales, this being in addition to Mr. V. F.'s two other projects, "Greek to You" and "The Flying Ginzburgs." An item which has-been on his schedule for some time, "Balalaika," is also scheduled to be brought to Broadway by Mr. Lee.
The Association of Harlem and Bronx Properfy Owners, Inc., will hold the last meeting for the current season on Tuesday evening, June 21, at the Bronx County Court House.

An intensive effort to obtain large gifts for the Greater New York Fund was under way yesterday. James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign for $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of private welfare and health agencies, announced that more than 150 business leaders had enrolled in eleven teams to solicit special gifts.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler is expected to arrive here Sunday to attend the last performance of the present theatre festival-"Lohengrin" at the State Opera.
The Northern States Power Company (Minnesota) and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $7,076,293 for the year ended on April 30, against $5,398,649 the year before.

The Australian trade delegation conferred today with Walter S. Morrison, Minister of Agriculture, and Oliver Stanley, President of the Board of Trade; and urged discussion of the possibility of a three-cornered trade pact among the United-States,

Democratic leaders in the fight for a constitutional ban on wiretapping with "teeth in it" rejected today the compromise amendment prepared by Justice Harry E. Lewis of the Supreme Court and made public last night in New York by District Attorney Dewey.

The annual report of the North American Edison Company to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today that Sylvester B. Way, director and president of various subsidiaries, received aggregate remuneration of $69,900 in 1937, compared with $52,239 in 1936.

Mrs. Margaret Emerson of New York sailed on the Matsonia tonight for Honolulu to be with her daughter Gloria (Mimi) Baker, who is ill. Mrs. Emerson said she also would see her son and daughter-inlaw, Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt, who also are in Honolulu.

Morris L. Ernst, C. I. O. counsel, asked Federal Judge William Clark this afternoon to hold Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in contempt of court for making a press statement during a recess on matter which the court had excluded from the trial. Judge Clark held the motion in abeyance until next week, and told Mr. Ernst to file a brief by next Tuesday.

America scored another victory today as Ascot's meeting closed, Marshall Field's 4-year-old Foray winning the King Stand Stakes. Heavily played at 3 to 1, Foray finished the five furlongs threequarters of a length in front of Shalfleet, 7-to4 favorite. Knight's Armor was another length and a half back for third place in the field of eight.

Retailers continued last week to hold to the cautious policy of buying only immediate necessities, and as a result wholesale volume was disappointing, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Income paid to labor by the automobile industry is being maintained to a much greater degree than is the net profit accruing to the industry itself, according to the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics in a report to the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

Pensioned On His Own Application-To take effect 12 midnight. June 15: PATROLMAN-Alexander McKittrick, 61st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 26, 1913. On Police Surgeon's Certificate: PATROLMAN-Joseph F. Anseimin, office of the Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner, Division of Licenses, at $2,250 per annum. Appointed May 5, 1922.

Insurgent dispatches said tonight that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's eastern armies had smashed Spanish Government resistance along the Mijares River and resumed a general advance toward Valencia, thirty-five miles to the south.
Captain Thomas Isabel, retired chief of the University of Wisconsin boathouse, who is credited with saving more than 600 lives on Lake Mendota, died in a Madison hospital today. He was 75 years old.

Deals reported yesterday in Brooklyn included sales of houses by savings banks. A client of Louis Greenfield, broker, has purchased for occupancy from the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn the one-family house at 1,200 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, for cash above a first mortgage. There are nine rooms in the building, which is on a plot 50 by 100 feet. It is said to have been held for S14.000.

Confident that they will win the Pan American ski championship again, five members of the United States squad left on the Grace liner Santa Barbara yesterday for the second annual tournament, to be held July 30-31 at Farellones del Cerro Colorado, near Santiago, Chile. Adams Carter, Edgar A.
A disagreeiment over the production of the Covent Garden ballet reached the High Court today.

Awards were distributed this afternoon at the graduation exercises of the Lawrenceville School in the Edith Memorial Chapel. Headmaster Allan V. Heely presented the prizes and awarded diplomas to 137 members of the graduating class.

Espionage, wire - tapping and search and seizure are dangerous weapons employed by dictators to curb the rights of citizens, Governor Herbert H. Lehman declared here today at the seventeenth annual state convention of the Disabled American Veterans of the World War.

Cincinnati Street Railway Company--Five months to May 31: Net income after expenses and charges, $37,483, equal to 8 cents a share on the outstanding capital stock, compared with a net of $121,573, or 26 cents a capital share, in the first five months of 1937. May net income was $6,878, against $27,025 in May 1937.

A group of New Jersey municipal officials accused the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, today of seeking to becloudd the real issue" in proceedings in the road's efforts to increase fares between Jersey City and Hoboken and the Hudson Terminal in New York.

Federal Judge H. Church Ford directed four verdicts of acquittal today for four defendants in the Harlan County coal conspiracy case, but ruled that the remaining fifty-eight defendants--coal operators, corporations and former peace officers accused of plotting against labor unions-must take their chances with the jury.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,173,000 bales, against 1,169,000 a week ago, 1,173,000 two weeks ago, 1,203,000 three weeks ago and 913,000 a year ago; of which American 758,000 bales, against 769,000 a week ago, 777,000 two weeks ago, 797,000 three weeks ago and 360,000 a year ago.

The Munson liner Southern Cross is due to sail at noon today from her pier at the foot of Furman Street, Brooklyn, on her first voyage as a government ship since court action was taken by the Maritime Commission to keep her and three other Munson Line ships in operation.

The possibility of harmony in the meeting of the general council of the Congregational and Christian churches appeared to have ended today with the announcement that the controversial proposal of Roger W. Babson, the moderator, to re-establish democracy in the denomination-by permitting each church to send a delegate to the biennial meetings would come before the council for a vote tomorrow.
Close contests featured the English county cricket series of matches concluded today. Leading teams were unchanged, Lancashire retaining first position although engaged in a non-county game.

Breaking out of their slump with such violence that the Fordham seismograph recorded a few puzzling temblors, the Giants flattened the Cardinals under a sixteen-hit barrage at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 10 to 3, and with one motion increased their lead over the twicebeaten Cubs to three games.

Two armed and masked men stole jewelry, silverware, dental supplies and other articles valued at $5,000 from the home of' Miss Ida M. Deane on Hunterbrook Road, four miles east of here, early this mornin.

BUNYAN, ANNE (June 12). Estate, lees than $5,000. To Alexander J. Bunyan, husband, executor, 101 W. 55th St. FISHER, MAX (April 29). Estate, $1,500 To Florence Leehane, executrix, 121 Madison Ave., residue. FRANSSON, ANNA (Feb. 26). Estate, $12,150. To Lars Tullbarg and Enar Tullbarg, Molndal, City of Gottenberg, Sweden, one-half residue each. James F. Egan, Public Administrator, executor.

Amherst defeated Wesleyan, 2 to 1, before several thousand commencement week-end guests today, Williams downing Grosvenor in a hurling duel. Amherst scored a run in the fourth when Meyers was passed, and took second on Goodell's fly.

Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the five WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city, announced yesterday that one member of the box-office staff at the Lafayette Theatre in Harlem had been dismissed in connection with the investigation of irregularities in the administration of WPA ticket sales.

93d St. 313 E. 5-story tenement, 25x100. Parcel 1: also 93d St. 315 E. 5-story tenement, 25x100.8, Parcel 2; Dry Dock Sayings Institution against Gerwy Realty Corp; due, on Parcel 1, $13,363; on Par- $450 cel 2, $13,364; to plaintiff for $1,000 each.
Sixtyfive members of the Opposition walked out of Parliament today in protest against the government's methods during the debate on the speech from the throne.
Mrs. Julia M. Barker, former Detroit real estate operator, was sentenced today to serve ten to fifteen years in the House 'of Correction for the fatal shooting of Mrs. Edith Mae Cummings, Jan. 15.

A nine-point program for which the Republican party fought in Congress (the platform on which its candidates for Congress will stand in the November campaign) was presented in a joint statement issued today by Senator Clarles L.
St. Louis at New York--Weiland (4-5) vs. Gumbert (6-4). Chicago at Brooklyn -- Carleton (7-4) vs. Fitzsimmons (2-3). Pittsburgh at Philadelphia--Bauers (1-5) vs. LaMaster (1-3).

Cold storage holdings of frozen fish in the United States on May 15, 1938, totaled 45,810,000 pounds, an increase of 13 per cent over the same date a year ago, and of 67 per cent over the five-year average for May, the Bureau of Fisheries stated today.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as applied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The three-family dwelling at 733 Park Avenue, Hoboken, N. J., has been sold by Hinrich Krudener to Richard J. Berardi, who will renovate the building and occupy one of the apartments when the alterations are completed.

Retail trade made a substantially better showing here last week as weather conditions and special promotions stimulated te sale of Summer merchandise. Department store executives estimated that the reduction in dollar volume under the same week last year has been cut to around 9 per cent, compared with declines of more than 11 and 19 per cent, respectively, in the two preceding weeks.

John Ringling North, president of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Combined Shows, Inc., today said a 25 per cent wage reduction affecting all 1,600 employes of the mammoth circus would go into effect Sunday.

Miss Mary Paul Henderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul George Henderson of this place, was married here this evening in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church to Henry Brewster Barr of Plainfield, son of Mrs. Raymond Van V. Miller and Frank Seymour Barr. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Walter Ovid Kinsolving.

Prepa- staten rations were under way today by organized labor and the Bureau of Labor Statistics to complete as early as possible some of the tasks requisite to the operation of the new Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department.

Simon Guthmann, Argentine race horse owner, died suddenly today at his Paris home. The 66-year-old South American was a prominent figure in European sporting circles. He attended the races at Longchamps yesterday

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 16: COLONELS McCa. e. . R. W. (F. A.), General Staff Corps, four days leave, June 21. Thomas, R. E., Engs., orders detailing as a member of the General Staff Corps, revoked; to duty as district engineer, Washington District, Washington, D. C., about July 19.

It can scarcely be denied that, as Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, pointed out in his letter to Senator Vandenberg, there has been a lack of coordination between national monetary policies and bank supervisory policies.

Cotton-mill activity increased last week, but daily average operations showed a contra-seasonal easing, and the adjusted index has receded to 90.1 from 92.1, the revised figure for the preceding week. The index was 141.9 for the week ended June 12, 1937.

Several thousand university students in Sao Paulo have founded the University Institute of Brazil and the United States, sponsored by the university faculty, by Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha and former Foreign Minister Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares.

Two of the country's up-and-coming young players, Willie Turnesa, recent graduate of Holy Cross, and Frankie Strafaci, a student of Wiffy Cox when the latter was pro at the old Marine and Field Club in Brooklyn, will meet in tomorrow's thirty-six-hole final round that will determine who is to be king of metropolitan golfers for 1938.

A special warning to keep "hands off" primary, and election campaigns was given to government agencies today by the Senatorial Campaign Expenditure Investigating Committee set up yesterday in the closing hours of the Seventy-fifth Congress to police the battle of ballots.
The American Newspaper Guild closed its fifth annual convention today with re-election of Heywood Broun as president and adoption of resolutions against fascism and for an anti-Japanese boycott.

Frederick Van Lou Price Jr., a grandson of the late State Senator James T. Willey and an automobile distributor here, died today in his home. Born in this city, he attended Pingry School. He was a founder of the Elizabeth Auto Trades Association.

Mrs. Lucy E. Cook died yesterday at her home, 114-07 Eighty-fourth Avenue, Richmond Hill, at the age of 76. Mrs. Cook, the widow of George Cook, was the daughter of the late Captain Henry Dawson, formerly an Alderman of the city of Brooklyn. In 1931 Mr. and Mrs.

The Dunrovin Music Festival, presented by William Matheus Sullivan, will give its first performance this afternoon at the Dunrovin Playhouse, Ridgefield, Conn. The program will enlist the services of the Motet Singers of the Dessoff Choirs, conducted by Paul Boepple; a chamber orchestra; Amri Galli Campi, soprano, and Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichordist. Music of will be heard.

The annual golf tournament and outing of the municipal bond traders of Wall Street, known as the Revelers, was held here today at the Winged Foot Golf Club, with 138 attending. George Waldmann of the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo presided at the dinner tonight.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Business in the Eastern wool markets continues slow and unsatisfactory. The trade is noting with interest the proposed purchases by the government of $10,000,000 worth of clothing for relief purposes.

Apartment buildings still in the Brooklyn, course of construction attracted a effect" on number of the new tenants listed landlords in the leasing reports submitted by who may brokers and agents yesterday. tenements.
Savings banks continued yesterday to play a leading part in sales of housing and business properties in Manhattan.

Two wild pitches today cost Al Hollingsworth a victory over the Pirates in his first start for the Phillies. His second wild heave came in the tenth inning with two out and permitted Lee Handley to score from third to give Pittsburgh a 4-3 triumph:

Miss Margaret Louisa Osborn, a descendant of John Jay and- Commodore Vanderbilt and a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Church Osborn and Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin, was married this afternoon to Josiah Macy Erickson in St. Philip's Church-in-the-Highlands here.

Miss Margaret Carter Baylis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell Spencer Baylis of Huntington, was married to John Anthony Hrones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hrones of Boston, this afternoon in the Old First Presbyterian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Carter, the bride's uncle,

MANHATTAN BUCKINGHAM, LAURA A. (Dec. 6, 1937). Gross assets, $36,255; net. $32,721. To Ella J. Buckingham, cousin. $1,200 annuity; Helen B. Gregory, niece, residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $34,407. Gregory, Stewart Montgomery, attorneys. 25 Broadway.

Guert Gansevoort Jackson, a commission shipping merchant long in business here, died yesterday at the New York Post-Graduate Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Jackson, who lived at 151 East Nineteenth Street, was 77 years old.

Signing of a formal order creating a new board of directors for the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., and putting the concern under the provisions of Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act were deferred tonight

The Morris Plan Industrial Bank of New York, 60 East Forty-second Street, New York City, has filed with the State Banking Department an application for permission to move a branch office from 7 Union Square to 5 Union Square, it was announced today.

The competitive battle between tea and coffee will be sharpened during the week of June 26 when producers of both commodities hold simultaneously a special week designed to promote their products as Summer drinks. "Iced Coffee Week" will start on June 26, while "Iced Tea Week" will begin a day later.

Turpenine firm, 22 1/4c; sales, 13 barrels; receipts, 409 barrels;shipments, 12 barrels; stock, 36,007 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 221; receipts. 1,601: shipments, 290; stock. 142,745. Quote: B, $3.35; D, $3.65; E, $3.75; ?? $4.25; G. H, I, K, $4.45: M, $4.50; N. $5.02 1/2; WG, $5.55; WW, X, $6.25.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 17, unless specified: At New York: Arkansas. Roper. Newport to New London: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. Fred Talbott. At San Diego: Kanawha, Sonoma. Acushnet, Dahlgren to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk.

The Celotex Corporation announced yesterday that its net profit for the three months ended on April 30 was $109,128 after all charges, compared with $8,403. in the preceding three months and with $447,600 for the quarter with April last year.

The St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railroad, which obtained a ninety-day extension when $400,000 interest fell due on May :1, submitted to Federal Judge Charles B. Davis today that business had improved to such a degree it now is able to make the payment.

Phillips Academy held its annual commencement exercises today with alumni taking a conspicuous part in the events of the day. In the morning the class of 1898 held a special ceremony at the grave of former Headmaster Cecil Bancroft, followed- by a special memorial service in the Cochran Church in memory of departed classmates.

St. Mark's School closed its year's activities with the annual Prize Day exercises and the presentation of diplomas to thirty-seven seniors. The exercises, at which William R. Castle, former Under-Secretary of State, was the speaker, followed services in the chapel. William B. Parsons Jr. of New York was valedictorian.

Prince Fumitaka Konoye, son of the Premier of Japan, said here today that lie had "flunked" his senior year at Princeton University and would not be among the recipients of diplomas at the commencement exercises Tuesday.

Marburg University announced officially today that it had canceled the Doctor of Philosophy degree bestowed on Rudolph Breitscheid, one-time leader of the Social Democrats in the republic and now in exile abroad.
To Sport Editor of The New York Times On listening to the Ross-Armstrong fight a short time ago, an announcement was made of the coming Joe Louis-Max Schmeling bout.
President Roosevelt early this morning expressed his regret at the sudden passing of Senator Royal S. Copeland, whose death was communicated to the President aboard the yacht Potomac.

Paul Keres of Estonia moved to within half a point of the lead in the international chess masters tournament today when he won his adjourned game from the fifth round from Paul Schmidt, the other representative of that country.

A gift of eight figurines of Jewish types in the Ukraine, made by Issachar Ryback, European artist who died in 1935, has been made by Edward M. M. Warburg to the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway at 122d Street.
Royal S. Copeland, Senator from New York since 1922, died at his apartment here at 7:45 P. M. tonight, twenty-four hours after he had suffered a circulatory collapse with kidney complications.
Merchandise ranging from billiard balls to airplane blind landing gear now finds specific opportunities for sales abroad, according to representatives of this government abroad.

Officers of the Industrial Real Estate Brokers' Association of the metropolitan area have been elected for one year as follows: President, Bernard L. Hegeman; vice president, A. W. Coffin; treasurer, Howard Gregory; secretary, Joel L. L. Schlesinger.

Strangly in-different, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody lost to Frau Hilda Krahwinkel Sperling of Germany, today in the semi-final round of the London lawn tennis championships and immediately gave up her position as Wimbledon favorite to Miss Alice Marble. The score was 8-6, 6-2.

As indicated by new car registrations, sales of Plymouth automobiles in metropolitan New York were greater during May than those of any other car and exceeded sales of the nearest competitor by more than 50 per cent, according to a statement made yesterday by W. D. Stewart, president of the Chrysler New York Company, Inc.

Miss Elizabeth Chatterton Grant, daughter of Robert McQueen Grant of New York and Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married toJ. Dudley Clark Jr. of New York, son of J. Dudley Clark of Boston and the late Mrs. Clark yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, who is trying to impose a $2,000,000 tax on the ninety bookmakers operating at Aqueduct and Jamaica race tracks, told the Council Finance Committee yesterday that the bookmakers had tried to make a deal with the city to save themselves fines and imprisonment as violators of the General Business Tax Law.

A sum of $4,372,600 was spent for property renovations receiving tax exemptions during the first nine months of 1937, and the amount of such work done in Manhattan was two and one-half times as large as that done in all the other boroughs, Bernard F. Hogan, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, pointed out yesterday.
The Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph and The Pittsburgh Press suspended publication today when members of the Business Office Workers Union, after several weeks of negotiation, refused to return to work.

While many Counsel, members of both Houses were breakfasting on coffee and sandwiches in cloak rooms and others in the Assembly Chamber celebrated by throwing paper cups, the Legislature recessed at 4 o'clock this morning until Oct. 17.

Its population swollen by a vanguard of excursionists seeking a glimpse of the President and the bridal couple who will figure in the ceremony tomorrow in historic Union Church, this rock-bound island resort was preparing today for the greatest influx of New England citizenry since Theodore Roosevelt visited here thirty-six years ago.

The decision of Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Brooklyn, imposing the first "substantial" fine or jail term thus far meted out to any tenement owner or agent ignoring the orders of the Department of Housing and Buildings to vacate a condemned building, was a source of gratification to the officials of that department.

The decision of Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Brooklyn, imposing the first "substantial" fine or jail term thus far meted out to any tenement owner or agent ignoring the orders of the Department of Housing and Buildings to vacate a condemned building, was a source of gratification to the officials of that department.

While 12,494 paying guests looked on with increasing annoyance, the Dodgers yesterday dropped a double-header to the high-riding Reds at Ebbets Field for their third straight setback by Mild Will McKechnie's boys and their ninth consecutive defeat at home.

Settlement of differences in the interdepartmental committee that is studying proposals for a standardization of bank examinations by government agencies was discussed today by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; Leo T. Crowley,

Court action seeking to oust Joseph Jablonower, recently appointed member of the board of examiners and only successful applicant in a field of 114 for the $11,000-ayear post, was started yesterday by seven of the sixteen candidates who failed in the final oral test.

Miss Helen Margaret Haselmayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Haselmayer of this place, and Edward Gilman Slingerland, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. F. Slingerland of Millburn, N. J., were married tonight in the First Methodist Protestant Church, Newark, N. J., by the Rev. Dr. John N. Link.

The State Department of Education imposes many "silly rules" that "not only are not helpful but actually hamper education,'," Mayor La Guardia charged in addressing the graduating class of the Manhattan High School of Aviation Trades, 220 East Sixty-third Street, yesterday morning.

Manhattan Alterations 3d Ave. 972; to 5-Story tenement and store; Lyman G. Realty Corp, 1,000 3d Ave, owner; Levy Berger, architects; cost, $8,000. 79th St, 109 E: to 5-story tenement; City Bank Farmers Trust Co, trustee, 22 WilHam St, owner; R. Telchman, architect; cost, $7.500.

Despite small salable receipts, hog prices declined unevenly today with the major part of the break accruing on hogs scaling over 220 pounds, according to United States Department of Agriculture. Lambs sold higher in active trade, but bearishness continued to permeate the cattle market.

A Quares for Srings by Douglas Moore has been chosen for publication by the Society for the Publication of American Music, A. Walter Kramer, president, it was announced yesterday. The quartet, which will be published in the Autumn, was written in 1933 and is dedicated to the Roth Quartet, which gave it its first public performance at the Library of Congress in Washington two seasons ago.

Among those here last night who paid tribute to Senator Copeland were the following: Governor LEHMAN-I was inexpressibly shocked at the sad news. Senator Copeland served his city, State and nation for more than twenty years with great devotion.
The governments of Peru and Ecuador have agreed to free prisoners and withdraw troop reinforcements they mobilized on the Napo River after a border clash in the Oriente region June 1.

The wheat market was erratic today and there was less willingness by traders to follow the upturns. In many quarters the belief is held that actual crop damage to date has been well discounted, especially as the market still has to feel the effect of hedging sales, which undoubtedly will increase substantially from now on.

If you are one of those veterans who long for the fishing to return as it was in "the good old days," you'd be interested in looking over the ancient registers of the Crossmon House, the oldest existing hostelry in the Thousand Islands area.

Joseph F. Wade, who had been in the hardware business in Coney Island for fifty years, died on Thursday at his store, 2,923 West Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, of a heart attack. He was 72 years old and lived at 1,466 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn.

William C. Chanler, Corporation Counsel, told the Appellate Division, First Department, yesterday that the city would be brought to the verge of bankruptcy if the judiciary ordered the payment of unreasonable and excessive salaries its attaches and clerical staffs. He attacked particularly the pay scales of court clerks.

Terms of the agreement which marl ended the threat of a strike of 1,400 employes of the Long Island Lighting Company were made public yesterday by Arthur S. Meyer, acting chairman of the State Board of Mediation.

A jury before Common Pleas Judge Thomas F. Meaney here awarded today $15,000 damages to Mrs. Mary C. Healey of 207 Baldwin Avenue, Jersey City, for the loss of her right eye. It also awarded $1,500 to her husband, Phillip J. Healey, for medical expenses and loss of his wife's services.

Blackett-Sample-Hummert. Inc., in 247 Park Ave: Fred William Bruckert, advertising, in 51 E 42d St; Richard F. Vidaver Sr, advertising, in 1,819 Broadway: Max Bleich, designer, in 43 W 34th St; William A. White Sons, brokers.

Charles Lincoln's Peaches annexed the weekly yacht race for Atlantic Class craft today, defeating Miss Mary Chapman's Guess Again. Brice Kirk's Clown was third and Petrel, owned by Jimmy Moxham, the only other boat in the race, was last. No times were taken.

Former Ambassador Morgenthau had a right to be proud last Thursday as he saw his son Henry receive an honorary degree from Temple University and heard him speak out for "the decencies and amenities of civilized life." As business man, philanthropist and diplomat the elder Morgenthau served his generation well.

The Yankees' advance, which saw the White Sox leveled in three straight games in Chicago as the world champions extended their latest winning streak to six in a row, struck a snag today when noon showers induced the Browns to call off the opening contest of their five-game series with the McCarthy forces.

No one would suspect it to look at the calm countenance of the very matter-of-fact Mr. Asa Bushnell, the regulator of the Eastern Intercollegiate Athletic Association, but behind his spectacles the man is a dreamer. He broke down and confessed yesterday.

Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, New York's so-called Public Enemy No. 1, who has a record of scores of arrests and eight convictions since 1915, was found guilty last night of causing a reign of terror in the city's fancy fur-dressing industry, which does an annual business of $75,000,000.

As part of a regular high school course that extends the classroom into the street, students in New York City will be taught how to drive an automobile and how to handle it safely in traffic jams and under other adverse conditions.

The United States ranks far behind European countries in number of research workers, Maurice Holland of New York, director of the National Research Council's division of engineering and industrial research, told the opening session of a two-day convention of the Industrial Research Institute at the Hotel Dennis today.

Ward's Reports, Inc., today estimated that output of automobile factories for this week is 41,790 cars and trucks, a contra-seasonal. gain over last week's 40,175 units. Comparative production a year ago was 111,620 cars and trucks.

Japanese airplane bombers are likely soon to meet strong aerial resistance over Canton and other Kwangtung Province cities because China's air force, which recently was greatly depleted, is again being built up rapidly.
The Tigers and Senators divided a double-header today. Washington hammered out fifteen hits to win the first game, 12 to 10, but dropped the nightcap, 4 to 3, despite a threerun ninth-inning rally.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is regrettable, in my opinion, that Dr. Ephraim Cross, in his letter on democratic administration in our municipal colleges, neglected to mention two points.

Experts in the field of industry, finance and transportation drew today graphic word pictures of depression ills and their possible remedies at the annual meeting sessions and a dinner of the Harvard Business School alumni.

Cardinal Hayes will preside at a solemn high mass commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the death of the Rev. John C. Drumgoole, founder of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, which will be celebrated tomorrow at 11 A. M. in the chapel on the grounds of the institution, Mount Loretto, S. I. Tomorrow in the Archdiocese of New York will be known as "Drumgoole Day."

After almost 300 years of playing hide-and-seek with the sun on commencement day, Harvard has bought a brand-new circus tent, with almost two acres of canvas, to cover the temporary outdoor theatre in Sever Quadrangle.
Effective relief pitching by Ed Chapman enabled Montreal to even the series with Jersey City at one game each tonight, the Royals winning, 6 to 2.

The Navy Personnel Bill, passed in the closing hours of Congress, increases the number of officers of the navy to an authorized total of 8,249, as against an existing authorized total of 6,531, an apparnet increase of 1,718 officers.

When the 125 employes of Henry Romeike, Inc., a press clipping bureau at 220 West Nineteenth Street, reported for work yesterday morning they found the office padlocked and cleared of its furniture. The firm, without a word to the men and women it employs, had moved during the night to 561 Park Avenue in West New York, N. J.

Prince and Princess Dominique Radziwill, who have been at the St. Regis since arriving from Paris, where they were married on May 30, will leave today for the Pacific Coast. Later, they will go to Newport. Princess Radziwill is the former Princess Eugenie of Greece, and is also a Princess of Denmark.
The Department of Commerce reported today that imports of gold into United States in the week ended on June 10 aggregated $32,129,019, an increase of $17,789,090 over the previous week.

Stopping a pile-driving machine from operating seventeen hours a day to erect a building on the World's Fair site "would affect a great many more people," than residents in the neighborhood, who have complained about it, Magisrate Hockert ruled in Flushing ourt, Queens, yesterday.
The Department of National Defense has ordered an intensified antsbandit campaign throughout thE nation, the newspaper Grafico asserted today.

Following the adjournment until October of the French Parliament today without voting a pay rise to civil servants, the Central Committee of Public Services tonight called on its members to be ready for a strike order.
The four-day convention of the Catholic War Veterans closed here yesterday with the installation of national officers. The final sessionwas held at 14 East Sixtieth Street.
OGDEN NASH is not only the most quoted poet of the day, but the hardest to get away from. His style is contagious and it is amusingto see who is smitten. Edna St.

Al though President Roosevelt has not yet announced signature of the Relief-Recovery Bill, the Public Works Administration stated today that it had already received applications for projects totaling $350,000,000 to be constructed under authorizations contained in that act.

Modifications in the subdivision review procedure has enabled the Federal Housing Administration to handle cases more rapidly in spite of the recent increase in the number of projects submitted for review.
Steps taken this year by various agencies of the government to create unprecedentedly easy money conditions have failed to reopen the capital market to the extent desiredor expected.

THE most significant fact about the life of Words-worth is its almost total absence of incident. After the usual course at Cambridge, which in common with a great many other poets he found not at all to his liking, he went onthe continental tour.

America's back to-the-farm movement continues un diminished, the Bureau of the Census reports. A definite trend of persons mlgrating to farms was established in 1935 through a census of all farmsin the nation.

About 5,000 persons attended the New York Athletic Club's annual outdoor carnival and dance last night at Travers Island. Prior to an outdoor floor show and dance, which was attended by invitation, members of the club and some guests held a dinner in the clubhouse.
The marriage of Miss Sherli Jane Weaver, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bruce S. Weaver of Noroton, to Robert Thatcher Wheeler, son of Mrs. Robert C. Wheeler of Chicagoand the late Mr. Wheeler,

AN all-Gershwin concert com memorating the first anniversary of George.Gershwin's death is being arranged for WABC's network on July 10 at 3 o'clock. Paul Whiteman's band and symphony orchestra, conducted by Howard Barlow, will be merged forthe hour-and-a-half concert.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your -issue of May 29- contained a Setter to -the editor in which the subject of the application of the Sherman Law to concerted price-fixing was discussed. The letter stated that the Supreme Court declared in- the 1911 Standard Oil case that price-fixing was-not in violation of the Sherman Law, whenthe prices thus fixed were reasonable.

Several bungalows modeled on the Southern California style have been erected this season at Lake Packanack, in the Boonton section of New Jersey and are proving 1 very popular among the new Sum mer residents, reports Ira C. Jones,manager of the development.
The first results of yesterday's general election, announced tonight, certainly do not indicate that the country is turning away from the Fianna Fail, the party of Prime Minister Eamon de Valera.

Edwin S. Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, today told the Harvard Business School Alumni Association that Mayor Frank Hague's activities in Jersey City are an indication of how employers' "anti-union propagamda" maythreaten democracy.

With Congress adjourned, one of the most important events in sight, from both the political and the business points of view, is the coming investigation of monopoly and the concentrationof economic power.

Miss Eleanor Millar Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Updike Sherman, was married here this evening to August William Nagel of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles August William Nagel.

Miss Janet Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Carter of this city, was married to John Cheney An drews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Andrews of Cazenovia, N. Y., this afternoon in the Church of theGood Shepherd here.

Scandinavians are much more stubborn than Americans when it comes to strikes and the Japanese, Swiss and Canadians have lost the least time through strikes, according to the figures for sixteen countries published in the monthly InternationalLabor Office Review;

The Blackfriar Institute of Dra matic Art will open its second Summer session at the Catholic University of America in Washington June 27. As insurance that the current outbreak of philosophical and religious plays on Broadway will not perish through lack of disciples, offacials at the university have started courses in the drama as aregular part of the curriculum.
William McChesney, motion-picture boker for the Walter Reade theatre chain, died today in Monmouth Memorial Hospital at Long Branch, following an operation.

A remarkable new invention, the "torpedo rocket," which he is confident will provide an impregnable defense against bombing attacks, has been revealed to THE NEW YORK TIMES by Harry Grindell Matthews who was a pioneer in the development of talking pictures and radio-controlled ships.
MOST large group exhibitions leave the visitor with mixed emotions and a welter of speculations.

T is one thing to say, as does Dr. Schilder, that "psycho therapy is not an art but a technical procedure based upon scientific principles" and that "it is part of the science of psychology and psychopathology," but it is quite another thing to prove that either psychology or psychopathology themselves aresciences.

" MAY FLAVIN" is a story bathed in sentiment, swaddled in tenderness, signifying tolerance among the children of men, one with another. Its people are, however, very real, very human. The Flavins are not an ordinary, not a representative, family after the manner of naturalistic fiction, but they are alive and wholly credible; and their world is a realistic one.

The New York Board of Trade, through M. D. Griffith, executive vice president, announced yesterday that it had informed delegates to the State Constitutional Convention that it was opposed to any change in the Constitution to extend the debt limit of New York City to permit the city to acquire transit properties.

The amateur gardener, building his first rock garden, soon realizes the necessity for plants to cover bare ground and rocky ledges. Dwarf campanulas, such as C. caes pitosa (C. pusilla), C. poscharsky ana and C. rotundifolia var. olym pica, all blue shades, serve excellently for this purpose. They arealso useful for dry wall plantings.

Shoe production in May was about 30,000,000 pairs, according to unofficial estimates in the trade last week. The figure, which compares with 32,859,000 officially reported in April and 35,411,000 pairs in May, 1937, is consistent with the constantly narrowing decline from a year ago that has been developingsince the first of the year.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Maria King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William King of Jamaica, Queens, to Eugene Francis Rector, also of Jamaica, took place yesterday morning in the First Baptist Church of Jamaica. The ceremony was performed by theRev. John C. Wiley.

The Independent Order Brith Abraham, Jewish philanthropic and fraternal organization, will begin fifty-first annual convention at the Garden Pier here tomorrow, according to an announcement today by Grand Master Samuel Goldstein.

SPECIAL releases require some thing out of the ordinary to justify them. Victor's latest is by no means commonplace. The album contains Mozart's quintet for clarinet and strings in A (K. 581), played by the Budapest Quartet and Benny Goodman, idolextraordinary of the swing fans.

THE annual festival at Szeged, Hungary, to be held from July 23 to Aug. 15, will lay stress on Hungarian operas and those by Verdi and Puccini. Guest artists will sing leading roles In the foreign works but the native operas will be presented by Hun gary's chief vocal and orchestralforces.
LESSONS learned during field tests since the first of the year have encouraged the engineers to take the NBC television station in the Empire State Building off the air for several weeks.

Several hundred officers, enlisted men and nurses who served on the United States Army Medical Corps staff at the Base Hospital, Camp Upton, L. I., in the World War, will hold "their first reunion in twenty years" next Saturday andSunday at the Hotel Taft.

A criticism of the conservative policy planned by many retail stores in making initial purchases of Fall coats was expressed yesterday by Dave Bellsey, president of Dave Bellsey Company, coatmanufacturers.

INFORMATION, PLEASE" is one of the more recent additions to the rapidly growing list of broadcast quizzes. To qualify for wattage and a place on the wave lengths, again the quiz is presented with a. novel twist to make it different from other programs in the riddlecategory.
Labor and social legislation passed by the last Congress, taken in conjunction with other New Deal laws, indicates that the outlines of a Federal social and labor code have begun to takeshape.

What is said to be the first full-length industrial film ever produced in sound and color will be shown Wednesday at the Hotel Commodore, when the United States Steel Corporation will present its new technicolor film, entitled "Steel, Man's Servant," at a luncheon; meeting of the New York BuildingCongress.
WHEN in this day and age you run across a Carmen to write home about--that's news! Such a Carmen--hence such a piece of newsflourishes at the Opera Comique under the name of Jennie Tourel.

BINGO BAN: The United Lutheran Synod of New York last week outlawed in its churches bingo and other games of chance. William Eck of St. John's Lutheran Church of Albany, commenting on the use of the games to raisepastors' salaries, said:

The marriage of Miss Janet Marie Bascom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Melvin Bascom of 24 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, to Robert William Cowles Bascom took place last evening in Grace Church-on-theHeights, Brooklyn.

According to Stewart McDonald, FHA Administrator, the single long-term amortized mortgage, representing a high ratio of the appraised value of the property, is in dispensable to the maintenance of a sound home financing system under modern economic conditions.

The Soldier's Medal has been awarded by the War Department to twelve officers and enlisted men of the Fifteenth Infantry for heroic conduct during fighting between Chinese and Japanese troops at the East Station in Tientsin on July29, 1937.

The following significant symposi um on business and industrial man agement is submitted by the presi dent of the Johns-Manville Corpora tion, who is chairman of the com-' merce and industry committee of the Seventh International ManagementCongress.
Seeds of the pink lotus of the Orient (Nelumbium Nelumbo to the botanists) probably three to five centuries old were sprouted when properly treated by scientists of theField Museum, Chicago.
GDEN NASH, whose new book of verse, "I'm a Stranger Here Myself," has just been published by Little, Brown Co., claims that he has 10,000 cousins in NorthCarolina.

The permission of the Govern ment of Burma has been obtained to permit an expedition sponsored by the American Museum of Nat ural History to enter a section ?? Northeastern Burma that never be fore has been entered by a scientific expedition to obtain botanical and animal specimens, it was announcedyesterday.

Ameriacn home are the best-heated in the world, a recent survey by the National Warm Air Heating and Air Conditioing Assocation disclosed. Russia heats the majority of its homes with primitive clay stoves,

Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio went down in defeat at the hands of an unranked player in the New York State tennis championships yesterday after opening with a steam-roller attack that made heropponent's plight seem hopeless.

Chief Harold Wonson, sophomore right-hander, hung up his eighth pitching victory in the Eastern In tercollegiate League today as Dart mouth defeated Harvard, 6-4, and assured itself of at least a tie forthe championship.

As a witness Mayor Hague is a "wow." He holds his audience enthralled in his great dramatic scenes with Morris L. Ernst, C. I. O. counsel, the "Red" villain of the piece. He "knocks them in the aisles" withhis humorous quips and sallies.
Some Washington observers are saying that the New Deal has handed the Republicans the best issue of the campaign by refusing to take a strong stand against politicsin relief.
The Treasury reported today that $274, 268,509 in income taxes had been received by it up to June 16 as the second quarterly installment, compared with $253,949,097 in the sameperiod last year.

Every political party in the State has attempted to get the membership rosters of unions to use them for political advantages, George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, asserted in a statementissued here today.

Mr. and Mrs. David Dunkelman of Toronto have announced here the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Ronny Dunkelman, to Walter H. Annenburg, vice president of ThePhiladelphia Inquirer.
