THE seventeenth annual season of opera and concerts sponsored by the Southern California Symphony Association at the Hollywood Bowl will open July 15 with a performance ofWagner's "Die Walkuere."

ARANOLD--BBAUNSCHWEIG--Mr. and Mrs. Herman Braunschweig announce the marriage of their daughter, Carrie, to Max Arnold. BAUM-SECKLER-Mr. and Mrs. Robert Seckler, Scarsdale, N. Y., announce the marriage of their daughter, Georgette, to Mr. H. James Baum, son of Mr. Joseph Baum and the late Mrs. Baum of White Plains, N. Y., taking place on SundayJune 19,'at the Savoy Plaza Hotel.

Mrs. Joan Hill-Wood of London, England, has accepted an invitation to officiate as guest judge at the annual field trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club to be held in the Shinnecock Hills of Long Island, Nov. 2, 3 and 4. She will be assisted by one or more Americanjudges to be named later.

An extraordinary career has been brought to a close through the death of Royal S. Copeland. With no previous experience in politics, he was elected to the United States Senate on the occasion of his first candidacy forpublic office.

Displaying the superior ability and power which gave them "slam" victories in the Poughkeepsie regatta the last two years and a string of twenty-two consecutive triumphs, the University of Washington defeated the Wisconsin varsity, junior varsity and freshman eights on Lake Mendota today.

Stocks drifted aimlessly and closed firm and mixed in slowest trading since August, 1918; turn over, 104,530 shares. United States Government and other bonds steady and dull in the second smallest trading session in twenty years; transactionss,. $2,168,100.

The dollar failed today to rally or to maintain the overnight rally in quiet trading in the foreign exchange market here. The rate weakened under Continental European offering from $4.9613-16 to $4.971-16 to the poundsterling.

Stanislaw Car, president of the Sejm (lower chamber of Parlia ment) since 1935, died last night of uremia.- He was 56 years old. Dr. Car was one of the principal au thors of the Polish Constitution of 1935. He headed the Ministry ofJustice from 1928 to 1930.

Miss Claire Babette Touart, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maximin De Mouy Touart of this place, was married to Lieutenant Harlan Keith Holman, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Floyd Holman of Norway, Me., this afternoon inthe Touart home here. The Rev.
A new silver issue of $20,000,000 was approved early this morning by the Senate as a part of the government's plan to balance the 1938-1939 budgetwhich goes into effect on July 1.

Importation of looms and warping and weaving machinery has been suspended for one year from June 9. Exceptions will be granted only after consultation of the Treasury, Public Works Department, Chamber of Commerce and National Industrial Society.

Miss Vivien Roberta Turl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur John Turl of New York, was married to Myron V. Murgatroyd, -son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Murgatroyd, also of this city, last night in the North Presbyterian Church in West 155thStreet.

I AM delighted at the enthusiastic support given by Messrs. Lescaze, Churchill and Horn to the idea of collaboration between. architects and sculptors, and at their realization that buildings need sculpture and sculpture needs buildings.

Milburn Shoffner, veteran southpaw rookie of the Bees, whitewashed the Reds for eight innings today, only to be driven from the mound by a four-run assault in the ninth. But Boston had too much of a lead,and took the series opener, 7 to 4.
The issue of State-controlled medicine so dominated the proceedings of the American Medical Association that little attention was paid generally tothe scientific reports.
State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh remained noncommittal today on the subject of a "Desmond for Governor" boom started last night by the Orange CountyRepublican Committee.
Dr. Charles M. Courboin, Belgian organist, presents his final broad-cast of the season at the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He plans to resume his recitals onSept. 11: WOR, 12 M.

New low levels for monthly consumption of Lake Superior iron ore and for the number of blast furnaces in operation, and a new high mark for June 1 for the amount of ore on hand in the Great Lakes lower lakes district, were shown today in a report issued by the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association.

Pretty Miss Beatrice Bar rett finally shot her "dream game" of golf and won the women's Western open tournament today. The 21-year-old Minneapolis girl defeated young Miss Helen Hofmann of Salt Lake City, 6 and 4, in the championship match scheduled forthirty-six holes.

By suspending five officers of the United Automobile Workers of America, Homer Martin, U. A. W. A. president, precipitated a major crisis within the Committee for Industrial Organization, for the auto union is regarded as one of themost promising C. J. O. affiliates.
Charles E. Case of Summit, N. J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Dorothy Case, to Charles P. Clark Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles P. Clark, also ofSummit.
EWPORT, R. I.-With the activity accompanyingg the graduations at the two boys' schools here, St. George's and the Portsmouth Priory, over, Newport is settling down to its real season.

Former Governor Harold G. Hoffian endorsed the position of Mayor 'rank Hague of Jersey City in oposing extremists in political beliefs nd declared today that when lague "stands up as an American itizen for the rights of this nation and to protect lives and property of people of his community he deserves the support of every Rebulican and Democrat in thisstate."

THIS vigorously written book analyzes uncertainties, national and international, on which depends the future of civilization. The volume is crowded with detail and, like rocks falling with an avalanche, many of the scattering incidentsseem to be unrelated.

The clear golden yellow calla lily with white spotted foliage (Zante-deschia elliotiana) adapts itself to spots where there are partial shade and rich moist soil. Its color is a pleasing highlight under trees; it also combines delightfully with ferns and perennials, such as the lavender flowered funkia and asters, which prefer shade too.

Greater finanial difficulties for Germany are foreshadowed in the trade returns for the first four months of this year published today in the monthly statistics bulletin of the League of Nations. All figures are given in gold. dollars on the oldbasis;
18.-At the annual Williams College alumni meeting today it was announced that gifts totaling $365,266 had been received by the collegeduring the year.

Commenting upon the survey for the 1935-1936 period made by the United States Public Health Service and recently published in Washington, Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonald points out that the results provided. conclusive proof of the vital need for new housing accommodations, particularly for families in the mediumand low income classes.

Joseph D. Barrett, 19, of 2,990 Perry Avenue, the Bronx, a student at Manhattan College, died of a bullet wound inflicted, Medical Examiner Russell Lowe said, when a 22-caliber rifle being handed to him by a friend was accidentally discharged.

The marriage of Miss Esther Gurney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. Gurney, to William Cruikshank, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Morris Cruikshank of Garden City, took place here this afternoon in the garden of the home ofthe bride's parents.
Seventeen hundred passengers sailed for Mediterranean ports yes terday on the Italian motorship Conte di Savoia and 7,000 visitors paid 10 cents each to see themaway.

Charles W. Morrison, vice president of the Cross Brown realty firm takes issue with the statement frequently made that the East Side park and parkway improvements will necessarily increase land values, especially in the Lower East Side area.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has amended its rules to provide that any securities shall be exempt from the operation of Section 16(c) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to the extent necessary to render lawful under such section a broker's execution of an order for an account in whichhe has no direct interest.

At 9:09 P. M. Thursday, June 16, Eastern standard time, this city of more than half a million souls, and some who, Republicans aver, have no souls, leaned back in its collective easy chair and breathed a long and simultaneous sigh. Congress hadadjourned.

Entries of forty-four sailing yachts for the race to Bermuda, starting from Newport on Tuesday, are in the hands of the sailing committee. An hour after the gateway the craftwill be in the lap of the gods.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--More than 2,000 youngsters are expected here to attend the children's week celebration which the Chamber of Commerce, city, hotel, restaurant and amusement men's associations cooperate in staging annually.

IT is a Summer in which prejudices count for naught when it comes to silhouette. If you are young and want to float into a room like a cloud, a petti-coat-buttressed gown is considered the thing; if you are sophisticated (here age counts nothing) and are conscious of your good figure at every move, there is a pillar-slimcreation.
Mr. and Mrs. Austin Cheney of Manchester, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mabel Austin Cheney, to Nathaniel Waite Smith Jr. of NewYork.

The forgotten man of baseball was remebered yesterday. Base, Ruth, all-time idol of thousands of dyed-in-the-wool fans as well as thousands of casual fans, and the greatest single attraction the game has ever known, was signed to a contract to act as a coach of the Dodgers for the balance of this season.
MOST contract bridge players use the word "amateur" to denote the novice, and refer to experts as "professionals." Tournament players have foryears objected to this distinction.

Glenn Cunningham defeated Archie San Romani in the mile feature at the Princeton invitation track meet in sun-drenched Palmer Stadium today in 4:07.2, time that has been surpassed only twice outdoorsin the long history of foot racing.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred Kershaw of Canandaigua, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eugenia Kershaw, to Warren Conrad Smith, son of Mrs. Conrad T. Smith of Garden City, L. I., and thelate Mr. Smith.

With "standard" or tree-shaped plants marking a trend in gardens these days, garden makers are on the lookout for plant material which can be grown in this effective manner. Many of the plants ordinarily used-such as heliotrope, lantana and geraniums-are not hardy, and present the problem of keepingthem over Winter.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago had dismissed a petition by the Resources Corporation International to review an order of the SEC refusing the company permission to withdraw a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of1933, filed on Feb. 28, 1938.

A "RADIO WORKSHOP" will be A added to the curriculum of the National Music Camp at In terlochen, Mich., which opens on July 6. Dr. Joseph E. Maddy, di rector of the camp, explains that the new course is designed to train teachers and school officials in thetechniques of education by radio.
All Republican counter-attacks against Villareal, on the east coast, yesterday and today were repulsed with heavy losses in men and war materials, according to Insurgentsources.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in the Hamilton (Ont.) General Hos pital of Michael Kaufman of 650 West End Avenue. Mr. Kaufman, who succumbed to injuries received in an automobile accident four days ago, was 63 years old and had been a member of the New York bar forthirty years.

Canadian gold production in April amounted to 368,439 ounces, compared with 376,023 in March, according to the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. Production for the first four months of this year was 1,446,386 ounces, against 1,288,231 in the same periodin 1937.

Athletes of the Park Department successfully defended their titles as interdepartmental champions yesterday afternoon in track and field games at the annual New York Municipal Athletic Meet at Macomb's Dam Park, 161st Street andRiver Avenue, the Bronx.

There was plenty of cause for celebration yesterday at the Polo Grounds, where the Giants spotted the Cardinals three runs in the second and proceeded to get them back with interest,- while Frankie Frisch, viewing the encounter from a clubhouse window, remained powerless and perhaps speechless.
THE role of college professor is lush with comic opportunities of the absent-minded "where on- earth - are - my - glasses?" (business of finding them parkedon the forehead) genre.

VERY village has its idiot and every city its picturesque eccentric "characters." New Orleans had an army of them and "Fireman George" was one of the best. He was a mellow-mannered old Negro who in his younger days had polished and paraded with the fire engine of a crack volunteercompany.

The Advertising Federation of America will conduct an intensive follow-up on its campaign to achieve a more harmonious relationship among labor, industry and government, launched at its annual convention in Detroit last week, Mason Britton, vice chairman of the board, McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, who was re-elected chairman of thefederation, announced yesterday.

" Bacillary dysentery, or enteritis, is a completely preventable disease which has no more justification for its existence than typhoid," is the opinion reached by Dr. Joseph Felsen of New York, probably the leading authority in the country on thesubject.

Retail trade, while making some gains from recent weeks, still was sharply under a year ago in most districts. Industrial districts again reported the sharpest declines from a year ago, and farm districtsmade the better showings.

Miss Mary Kaye Phelps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Zack Phelps of Wawaset Park, was married to Robert R. M. Carpenter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carpenter of Mont chanin, this afternoon in Immanuel Protestant Episcopal Church by theRev. Charles W. Clash, the rector.

Incorporation papers for the New Jersey unit of the Protestant War Veterans of the United States were filed with the County Clerk of Bergen County today, with a statement that the organization was composed of Protestant veterans- of all American wars and was formed to "combat the various 'isms,' Including fascism and. Nazism."

The New York Curb Exchange will suspend dealings in Public Service Company of Northern Illinois old $60 and no-par value common stocks on Tuesday. Certificates of deposit of the bondholders' committee for Republic and Colombia dollar bonds issued by the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, representing twenty-five issues, will be admitted to Curb Exchange dealings on July 1.
Funeral services for Royal S. Copeland, senior United States Senator from New York, will be held at his Suffern, N. Y., estate at 3 o'clock Tuesday afternoon, itwas announced last night.

Details of uniformed patrolmen and detectives will guard the various East River bridges this afternoon as the Presidential yacht Potomac, with President Roosevelt and his party aboard, passes down the East River on the way to the Hudson. Two police launches, Nos.9 and 10, will escort the Potomac.

THE Federal Theatre has re ceived its first movie money from Harold Orlob, veteran composer, for the screen rights to ". . one-third of a nation ." The amount involved in the deal, which was completed Tuesday, wasnot divulged.

The directors of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware, controlled by the Standard Gas and Electric Company, announced dividend reductions yesterday on the company's two classesof preferred stock.

The Rev. Charles J. Deane, vice president and dean of studies at Fordham College of Arts and Sciences, was promoted yesterday to the newly created post of secretary general of Fordham University, according to an announcement by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university.

Several representatives of the Bronx Joint Committee, composed of more than thirty civic and taxpayer organizations In that borough, will attend "the public hearing on the easterly approach of the Tri borough Bridge to be held by the Board of Estimate Thursday afternoon, Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board. of Trade and chairman of the. committee, announced yesterday.

Dr. George Otis Smith of Skowhegan, formerly of Washington, D. C., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Louise Coburn Smith, to Robert Velten of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. K.Velten of Port Orchard, Wash.

Ten painters were arrested yesterday afternoon after they had forcibly attempted to attend a campaign meeting of a faction of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America, an A. F. of L. affiliate, at Irving Plaza, Fifteenth Street and Irving Place.

THE production of Verdi's "Macbeth" at Glyndebourne has succeeded beyond expectation. It seemed more than a little hazardous to bring to light an opera of Verdi's early days ("Macbeth" was first performed in1847),

Consumption of gasoline this month has caused such a reduction of the stocks of the fuel as well as of crude oil that the oil industry in Texas will be restored on July 1 to its former seven-day-a-week production instead of the five-day program under which it has operated for several weeks, the Oil and Gas Division of the Railroad Commission announced today.

A week ago Japan's armies, having conquered one major Lung-Hai Railroad junction at Suchow, were marching confidently upon another major junction at Chengchow, 200 miles to the west, from which they planned to follow the Peiping-Hankow Railroad down to the Chinese Nationalist Government'swartime capital at Hankow.

When children swarmed into the Mary Harriman Rumsey play-ground in Central Park near the East Seventy-second Street gate yesterday they greeted with shouts of recognition old Mother Goosepresiding at the entrance.

THE season of the Philadelphia TOrchestra at Robin Hood Dell, Philadelphia, will open on Thursday, like the Stadium concerts in New York. Eugene Ormandy will conduct the openingconcert.

The annual Craftsmen's Fair of the League of New Hampshire Arts and Crafts will be held here Aug. 8 to 13. The first fair was held in 1934 in the stables of the Crawford Plai House at Crawford's Notch. The men succeeding fairs were at Hancock,Rye Beach and Laconia.

The annual Summer Day Fair at St. Johnland, Kings Park, L. I., incorporating an extensive rummage sale, refreshments, games, carnival attractions and divertissements for children, will be held during the afternoon and early evening of June 28. The fete will beclimaxed by a barbecue supper.

First to bat in the ninth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday, and in a rage at Umpire Lee Ballanfant, big Babe Phelps lined Tex Carleton's second pitch far into Bedford Ave nue for his third homer of the year to give the Dodgers a 2-1 victory over the Cubs and break a losing skein of ten straight on the homegrounds.
Terrorist casualties in Palestine are increasing after a lull of several weeks. Three Arabs--one a woman-were slain today in villages in the Tulkarem district, which is inhabitedonly by Arabs.

Plans for consolidating the Upper Montclair Building and Loan Association and the Edgemont Building and Loan Association, and a proposal to liquidate the Hillside Building and Loan Association were revealed in statements issued today.

In an effort to determine the most effective ways of promoting safety on the highways and city streets of the nation, working newspaper men from fifty American cities of 50,000 or more population will gather at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow morning for the opening of the second Commercial InvestmentTrust Seminar of Safety.

THE MacDowell Club announces its seventh annual Young Artists Contest, to be held in October. The purpose of the contest is to provide a public aperance for young professional artists in this city.

Expert bookkeeping was needed to find the winner in the shoot over the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. It was a Pick Your Own Handicap, in which R. H. Helsel, L. Hunt and B. Doerrer finished in a tie for the High-Over-All Cup. In the first shoot-off, Helsel and Hunt again tied, at 24, then the former won the second extra string by 25to 23.
Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., reported yesterday a net profit of $323,939 for the first five months of this year. The net was after depreciation charges but before Federalincome taxes.

Pell of Great Barrington. The Rev. Edward K. Thurlow performed the ceremony in a setting of mountain laurel and peonies at Christ Episcopal Church.
