The report of the General Investment Corporation for the fiscal year ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows a profit of $17,489, before a net loss of $1,075,520 on sales ofsecurities.

PARIS.-The next world war will be fought with oil. The allied coun tries in the war which have the most oil will have an overwhelming advantage on their side. If they can hold out against the assaults of the first months, the lack of fuel oil will cost their adversaries thewar.

Last April a shipment of rhesus monkeys-the kind that organ grinders used to carry with them to collect pennies-arrived in New York from India. When one large wooden cage of six females was opened three baby monkeys were found that seemed to belong to onemother.
Under the auspices of the New York State Chapter of the American Gold Star Mothers of the World War. a card party will be held Friday night at the Manhattan Opera House.

Miss Geraldine Avis MacLaren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Drysdale MacLaren of Brooklyn, was married to John Edward Shea Jr., son of Mr. Shea, also of Brook lyn, and the late Mrs. Shea, yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev.Joseph A. Tytheridge.
IT is very reassuring in these troubled days, with so large a part of the civilized world at the crater's edge again, to come upon evidence of scholarship's quiet pursuit of its goal.

The investigation by a special House committee of the diffusion within the United States of subversive and un-American propaganda of foreign as well as of domestic instigation will be in many respects different from any other investigation ever madeby a committee of Congress.

UNSCHEDULED: London's Covent Garden was crowded one night last week for "La Boheme." The audience--it included members of the royal family--was listening to the Italian tenor Beniamino Gigll in the Paris garret scene.

The former Panama-Pacific liner California is expected to sail today for Newport News to be recondi tioned for the government's new service to South America, it was announced yesterday. The other ships of the fleet, the Virginia and Pennsylvania, will be moved tomorrow to the Brooklyn plant of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, where they will be refitted onsimilar lines.

The most astonishing condition in China is that despite the long series of military defeats and the loss of the largest seaports and the richest sections of the country, the Chinese leaders are more cheerful than theywere before the fall of Nanking.
ON SS. NIEUW-ZEELAND, Surabaya, the move again and with the welcome, breezy tang of the seas tickling the old larynx.
The Freehold Racing Association of Freehold, N. J., of which H. S. Gould Sr. is president, has been admitted to membership in the Central Fair Circuit, Secretary CharlesW. Swoyer announced today.

TWO full seasons have gone by since Lynn Riggs fetched in a play, wherefore the minutes of this morning's meeting may properly begin with the news that he is planning a double-barreled attack on Broadway.
Henri Guilbeaux, French revolutionary writer and pacifist, died Wednesday of a cerebral hemorrhage, friends announced today. He was 54 yearsold.

C. A. B. Halvorson, General Electric lighting expert, would probably be the last to hold that no improvements in overhead highway lighting are possible. On the other hand, he thinks that pavements have beenneglected.
Though WPA research and survey projects employ' only 36,000 workers, for the most part classified as "white-collar," these workers have covereda wide field.
A session of Congress that began well by reforming the tax laws ended in a scramble in which politics triumphed over economics at almostevery point.

The marriage of Miss Anne Cummings King,--daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lewis King of this place, to the Rev. Walter Robert Hampshire, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Watson Hampshire of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, took place here this morning in St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Helium, one of the Audwill Stable's entries from Southboro, Mass., captured three blue ribbons at the Troy Horse Show today. Helium captured the Olympic Equestrian Team Fund Sweepstake for open jumpers, the Scurry Sweepstake and theknockdown-and-out event.

Princeton's costumed alumni, 4,000 strong, wound across the campus today in the annual alumni day parade, ending up at University Field where they swelled to 12,000 the crowd of spectators watching the 180th Yale-Princeton baseballgame.

The first apartment house in New York to be constructed with light steel or bar-joist floor beams is nearing completion on the south-west corner of Sixty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, and will beready for occupancy in July.

The Southern Cross of the Munson Line, which was recently placed in receivership after the United States Maritime Commission filed libel proceedings based on a mortgage held by the government, sailed for South America yesterday for the first time since economic difficulties took her out of operation.
The new Real Estate Taxpayers Federation has elected a board of directors consisting of twenty-five leaders of realty and trade organizations and lending institutions.

Prospect Presbyterian Church here was the setting this evening for the marriage of Miss Carolyn Keyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonhard A. Keyes of this place, to Thomas Sidney Cadwallader 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Augustus Cadwallader of Yardley, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. ArthurNelson Butz.

The marriage of Miss Maude Kramer Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Riley Lee of this city, to John Bradley Bliss, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Bliss Jr. of Yonkers, took place here this evening inThe Contemporary Club, Ridgeway.

Christian Nielsen, Danish leader and editor of the Danish Pioneer, national Danish newspaper, died today in the Norwegian Hospital at the age of 77. A native of Denmark, Mr. Nielsen was knighted last year by King Christian of Denmark for his active participation in Danish affairshere.

America and other democracies have probably become unduly alarmed over the possibility of the spread of fascism in the Latin-American nations, Dr. Whatley W. Pierson, dean of the Graduate School and head of the Department of Political Science in the University of North Carolina, told the Carolina Institute of InternationalRelations in an address today.

Three thousand persons, most of them women, squirmed, craned their necks and argued with nearly a hundred policemen outside the old Union Church here today to make the wedding of John Roosevelt and Anne Lindsay Clark a spectacle that will be long remembered byresidents of this little town.

The purpose of the Fair Labor Standards Act passed by Congress last week is to establish minimum Wages and maximum hours for industrial workers. It covers all industries in and affecting interstate commerce and goes into effect fourmonths after passage.

Daniel Eisenberg of the Seward Park High School, Manhattan, won first prize of $25 in the fifth annual interscholastic short-story contest conducted by the Department of English of Washington Square College of New York University, Dr. Rufus D. Smith, acting dean, announced yesterday. His story wasentitled "Substitute Teacher."

Four thousand alumnae, students and friends of the college witnessed the dedication of the $250,000 Alumnae House of Smith College today. The program included a pageant, "The Symbols of Completion," which marked the success of thirty years of planning and effortby the alumnae.

The New York Constitutional Convention is engaged in consideration of the problem whether invasion of an individual citizen's privacy, particularly through wiretapping, is warranted by the protection of the public afforded in thereby obtaining evidence of crime.

When Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain rose .n his place in the House of Commons Tuesday and expressed the opinion that there was nothing Great Britain could do about the bombing of British ships in Spanish waters it was-symptomatic of

ADOZEN architects in the Roanoke office of the Na tional Park Service are push ing forward steadily with plans- and designs for the 490-mile Blue Ridge Parkway, which will connect the Shenandoah National Park in Virginia with the Great Smoky Mountains National Parkin North Carolina and Tennessee.
Six Americans, who said they had fought in Spain with. the Loyalist forces, came home yesterday on theUnited States liner President

The American Federation of Musicians voted today to contribute an unspecified amount to aid in the fight for release of Tom Mooney, imprisoned for the San Francisco pre-paredness parade bombing and now seeking freedom through an appealto the Supreme Court.

Ionospheric storms that often blot out radio signals, some of the problems involved in spreading a television wave over a city like New York and the latest mode in ship-to-shore "dial" radio telephone systems, which are said be operated as easily as a telephone number is clicked off at home on the ordinary dial instrument, were described here yesterday at the final sessions of the Institute of Radio Engineers thirteenth annual convention in theHotel Pennsylvania.

The Federal Treasury suffered today a reverse in its efforts to reduce the number of tax-free securities, when the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that interest on special-assessment bonds of the city ofChicago was not taxable as income.

Roger W. Babson, Moderator of the Congregational and Christian Churches, brought before the General Council of the denomination today his plan to restore the practice of early Con gregationalism by giving to each church a direct voice in the affairsof the national body.

Bonds called last week before maturity were in somewhat smaller voulme than in the preceding week. Except for one fairly large idustrial redempiton and some small amounts of municipal issues called this month, the notices were for payment in future months.

The 1.6 per cent profit on 1937 sales of department stores and apparel specialty shops, reported last week by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, has been turned into an average loss of about 2 per cent for the first half of this year, according to calculations made hereyesterday by retail executives.
According to Sunday newspapers, a new approach by Italy, designed to obtain early operation of the Anglo-Italian pact by agreed modification of the "Spanish clause," has been made in Rome.
Four teams of the Negro National League will see action in a double-header which will be played for the benefit of the Greater New York Fund next Sunday afternoonat the Yankee Stadium.
Here is a complete list of the persons invited to the Roosevelt Clark wedding ceremony or tothe reception which followed:
OUR knowledge of Mark Twain's early life grows apace. "Mark Twain's America," by Bernard DeVoto, and "Mark Twain, Son of Missouri," by Minnie M. brashear, establishd themselves some time ago.
A grim reminder of the drift to war andwhat it means In pain casually

A correction, please! In THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, May 29, 1938, on page 1, the re viewer of the Life of Governor Altgeld of Illinois, in mentioning briefly the famous trial of the Anarchists, adds there is no re maining doubt that all of the men convicted for the Haymarketbombing were innocent."

With plans completed for two surveys to be made during the Summer months, the Industrial Research Institute, newly formed group which hopes to coordinate the efforts of the 30,000 research workers in this country and avoid duplication, closed its two-day sessions in the Hotel Dennis here this afternoon.

Threats of "drastic measures" against Czechoslovakia were made by Minister of the Interior Wilhelm Frick today in a speech at Koenigsberg, where last night Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels also warned the world that Germany would not tolerate"constant provocation."

With the Saturday attendance in the financial . district unusually small, trading on the Stock Exchange amounted to only 104,000 shares, smallest since 1918. Prices fluctuated within a narrow trading range and most of the list showed net changes of .only fractions onthe day.

A reception on Tuesday at the home of Mrs. Alexander Lamport, 315 Central Park West, will commemorate the twentieth anniversary of the sailing of the American Zionist Medical Unit to Palestine and honor Miss Alice L. Seligsberg, who was vice chairman of the executivecommittee of the undertaking.

The International Harvester Company announced today that its plants at Milwaukee and Rock Island, Ill., would be closed throughout July to prevent further accumulation of inventories and to permit the company to get employes' paid vacations out of the way in preparation for any increase in business that may develop in the Autumn.

This is compass-pelorus-cruising chart-and-binnacle week for several vacht clubs, and mooring buoys are going to bob lonesomely in deserted anchorages. Fleet captains and committees are calling all hands on deck and telling them it is high lime they blew the cobwebs off heir navigating instruments andwent to sea for blue-water cruises.
The Tigers climbed into the first division of the American League for the first time this season today when they downed the Senators, 5 to. 3. The defeat dropped Washington to fifth place.
A report of a committee of the American Bar Association noted today a shift "from the old-style bankruptcy to the moratorium or reorganization type, commonly known as the debtor-relief sections."

PRIZE award requirements for the ninth annual soaring contest to open here June 25 have been made the most stringent in the history of the local meets, officials believing that pilots have gained sufficient experience towarrant the change.
The marriage of Miss Janet Katharine Law daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Houk Law of Brooklyn, to Richard Hiller Amberg, son of Mrs. Max W. Amberg of New York and the late Mr. Amberg,

Presbyterian Webb Memorial Chapel was the scene of the marriage today of Miss Ruth Elizabeth Triggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Triggs of this place, to Harrington Vose Ingham, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel...

ANY one who receives upward of 150 pieces of mail daily, most of it publicity from United Artists, is apt to develop the habit of reading with one eye while glancing for the wastebasket with the other.
The International Labor conference has unanimously adopted a resolution intended to secure uniform world statistics on hours and wages.

A gavel banged last Thursday night in the House of Representatives. It was nine minutes past 9. The Seventy-fifth Congress of the United States, a Congress whose 420 days in session had been filled with stormy debate, at thatmoment passed into history.

James O'Rourke of Vermont has leased the colonial residence of John S. Painter in Mount Kisco, through James F. Greene, broker. The Spring golf outing of the Long Island Real Estate Board will be held on Tuesday at the North Hills Golf Club, Douglaston. C. Otis Smith is chairman of theevent.
In the face of the general trade recession of the past twelve months, occupancy averages for office buildings throughout the country appear to be making anencouraging showing.

Officials said today that it was unlikely there would be any postponement or substantial modifications made in the specifications for bids for the construction of two cruisers for the Chilean navy and that on June 27 the offers from foreign shipyards would be openedin the Marine Ministry here.

Predicting that Brooklyn will receive its share of the influx of visitors into New York City expected during the World's Fair, George S. Horton, president of the Bulkley Company of Brooklyn, advises real estate men to organize a clean-up campaign to add to theattractiveness of that borough.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va.-This resort town and every near-by community are filled to overflowing with visitors who have come to witness the four day celebration of the 160th anniversary of the founding of Greenbrier County.

Two pitchers who have -been opposing each other in the American League for fourteen years battled twelve innings today before a break in the White Sox defense gave. 38-year-old Lefty Grove and the Red Sox a 4 to-3 decision over 37-year-old TedLyons.
First annual award to Governor Lehman by the National Council of Young Israel, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria,10 A. M.
TWO countries contend for the 350-year-old mummy of James Hepburn, fourth Earl of Bothwell, Duke of Orkney and Shetland, who married Mary Queen of Scots.

Considerable attention has been given in recent years by various realty interests to the problems of preserving the best features of existing neighborhood communities and of proper planning in new communities so that something of the old-time living comforts characteristic of the early neighborhoodarea might be maintained.

J. Willison Smith, president of the Land Title Bank and Trust Company, Philadelphia, announces that the bank, except in cases of short-term mortgages, has adopted the direct reduction loan for allits mortgage financing.

By virtue of a 68 with his own ball, Jess W. Sweetser, former United States and British amateur golf champion, and his partner, Juan T. Trippe, were still in the running tonight as play was con cluded in the opening rounds, of the annual Piping Rock invitation bestball tournament.

Mexico's 18,000 oil workers have lost ground, economically and socially, in the three months since the expropriation of United States and British owned oil properties, despite the fact that it was their demand for betterment that led to President Lazaro Cardenas's action.

WASHINGTON. -- Boasting of their ability-to taste foods, many Housewives and husbands are offering their services -to Uncle Sam. Applications poured in when word went out that the Department of Agriculture was having difficulty finding persons with the desired gradations of tastefor use in cookery research.

The sudden death of Royal S. Copeland, senior United States Senator from New York, has changed the local political situation and made the election in this State next November of even greater importance than it was before, leaders of both major parties declared yesterday.

Daniel Harris, 92 years old, of 231 Woodbine Street, Brooklyn, sole surviving member of the G. K. Warren Post, G. A. R., who has occupied every office in Richmond Hill Post 75, Jewish War Veterans of America,

Miss Eileen Burke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Burke of South Orange, and Lee J. Marino, son of Mrs. James M. Marino of Plainville, Conn., were married this morning in Our Lady of Sorrows Church here. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev.William F. Grady.

W HEN Sir Walter Raleigh was Professor of English Literature at Oxford he used to tell us, who were undergraduates, that English liter ature stood in need of a novel writ ten from the point of view of theservants' hall.

The list of the Cunard White Star motorship Georgic, arriving today from France, England and Ireland, includes Dr. and Mrs. Simon Flexner, John Goodman, Misses Louise and Elizabeth Hallett, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Logan, Mrs. Graham Hill, Miss Doris Mudie, Mrs. H. RayPaige and Burton J. Wyman.
WITH Jose Iturbi conducting the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and with Albert Spalding as violin solosit, the twenty-first season of the Stadium concerts will begin Thursday night.

To the growing list of music festivals that are beginning to dot the landscape like the Summer theatres, another is being added here at Dunrovin, the estate of William Mathews Sullivan, lawyer andpatron of music.

Peter Grimm, who headed the last study of the efficiency of the city's home relief administration, said in an interview yesterday that he was impressed by the safeguards against "chiseling" and the general excellence of the work of the municipalrelief authorities.
Lynn Nelson held the league-leading In dians to an average of one hit an inning today and got three singles himself to lead the Athletics to an 8-4 victory.

Miss Ruth Virginia Sargent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Worcester. Sargent of Crow Roost, Penn Valley, was married this afternoon in St. David's Church, Radnor, to Edward Rotan Sargent, son of Mr. and Mrs.Winthrop Sargent Jr. of Haverford.

The thirty-ninth Summer session of Columbia University will open on July 6 and continue through Aug. 13. More than 12,000 persons are expected to attend the session, at which more than 1,050 courses will be given. One of the courses will be a new one on "The Evolution of Man," conducted by Professor James H. McGregor.

The marriage of Miss Cheryl Eveleen Ellsworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Le Roy Ellsworth of Dubuque, Iowa, to Robert Emerson Lawther, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lawther also of Dubuque, took place here yesterday morning in the garden of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in Waverly Place.

TO the outward eye of the casual observer and to the inward torment of many a visiting theatrical manager, the stage in such towns as Cleveland appears to be withering away toward extinction. Fifteen years ago there were four legitimate thea tres in Cleveland and they played afull season of traveling dramas.

First reports yesterday from the "bowl of rice" parties held in New York City and elsewhere in the United States Friday night for the benefit of Chinese civilian war refu gees, led Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., chairman of the United Council for Civilian Relief in China, to revise upward his estimate of1,000,000 participants.
THERE is more incident packed in this book of ad ventures of a British scientist than can be found in many a narrative of those who deliberately seek adventure.
The engagement of Miss Jean Richardson Stewart, daughter of Mrs. Fenwick Stewart of this place and the late Mr. Stewart, to Gordon Brinkerhoff Turner of New York hasbeen announced by her mother.

Miss Lucy Wilcox Dominick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Dominick Jr. of this place, was married here this afternoon to John Rodney Wilson, nephew of Hugh R. Wilson, United States Ambassador to Germany.

Miss Betty McClure of Westfield, N. J., sister of Mrs. Winthrop Huntington Hall of Westfield and daughter of John B. McClure of Brooklyn, was married here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration to Paul Terhune Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Garner Wood of Flushing, Queens. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. HaroldF. Lemoine of the church staff.

BARON-Mr. and Mrs. Saul J. Baron, 1,070 Park Ave., announce the bar mitzvah of their son. Alan, on Saturday, June 25, at the Park Avenue Synagogue. BUBTON--Arnold Sachs. Bar mitzvah, Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83d St., New York. At home Saturday, June25, 1938, 336 Central Park West.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Therese Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Kelly of New York, to John G. McDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay J. McDonald, also of this city, took place, yesterday morning in the Roman CatholicChurch of St. Nicholas of Tolentine.

THE Federal Music Project's plans for its Summer season of outdoor concerts and operas will utilize the services of more than 10,000 persons during the next three months insome hundred cities and towns.
Mr. and Mrs. W. Gordon Coogan of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothea Potter Coogan, to Thomas R. Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. RayClark of Ridgewood.

The Times editorial today, taking the publication of the American note to Germany on the Austrian debts as a text for a sermon on the restriction of international trade, once more stresses the advantages and the necessity of an Anglo-Americantrade treaty.
Arthur E. Cook, Assistant Secretary of Labor for two years during the Coolidge Administration, and an authority on citizenship and immigration/laws, died today of heartdisease. His age was 42.

Wet turf today caused the postponement until tomorrow of the inaugural contest in the annual Spring twenty-goal polo competition of the Meadow Brook Club between Mike Phipps's Gulf Stream riders and Sonny Whitney's Old Westbury four. Originally listed for Hitch cock Field, the game will take placeon Whitney Field.

The Regional Plan Association presented to the City Planning Commission yesterday its contribution toward the "master plan" for the city, in the form of a long-range program for unified systems of major highways, parks, suburban rapid transit facilities and railroads.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H.--White Mountain resorts thorughout have an interesting season in prospect. The United Forestry Department still is building new roads at scenic points within the White Mountain territory, and improving exisitng ones.

A report to the Department of Agriculture from its attach in Berlin, made public today, said that, despite drought conditions, Europe may not need a larger than normal amount of American wheat thisyear.

Thwarted in an attempt to scale Mount Everest, the highest mountain in the world, five members of a British expedition led by H. W. Tilman have decided on another effort in early Autumn when, it is believed, weather conditionswill be more favorable.
Since Britain gave India a new Constitution a year ago, a complete political metamorphosis has taken place in the vast subcontinent with its 350,000,000 people.

The S. O. S. (Save Our American System), an organization of non-partisan women, issued an invitation today to "all women who wish to unite in an effort to check the forces which are distracting the country" to attend a mass meetingTuesday night at the Y. W. C. A.
Five thousand New York City Boy Scouts are expected to camp this Summer at the Ten Mile River 12-000-acre reservation of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater NewYork in Sullivan County.

L. Garmise, sales director of the home community at East Thirty-eighth Street between Avenues S and T, Brooklyn, reports that only three houses remain unsold. They are one-family, two-story dwellings. The locality is in the Flatbush section.

Bounding into the lead at the head of the stretch, Chance Ray, 6-year-old son of Chance. Play and Ex-Ray, won the $6,070 Lincoln Handicap before 15,000 spectators at Lincoln Fields today, beating the heavily played favorite, Mucho Gusto, by ahead.

The very cautious policy pursued by most retailers is causing a condition in the wholesale market which may at least temporarily counterbalance the price drop, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES byKirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Mosler Pearce, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew C. Pearce of East Orange, to William H. Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Potter of Orange, took place this afternoon, the wedding anniversary of the bridegroom's maternal grand-parents, Mrs. L. C. Hillman ofOrange and the late Mr. Hillman.

SOME fortunate cameras will go up the gang-plank with their owners when cruise ships are making ready to sail to the North Cape at the end of this month. Unusual pictorial scenes will lie ahead for them to capture, and splendid prints will be the reward of photographers who pay proper respect to the sun in the matter of carefully calculated exposures.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders to day, dated June 16: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Flanagan, H. C., 12th Naval Dist., to offi cer in charge Naval Radio Station, Marf Island, Calif. Mattox, R. H., on discharge treatment Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y., to NavaTraining Station, Newport, R. I.

Nearly $3,717,000 was spent to settle German Jews in Palestine between October, 1933, and March, 1938, according to an announcement by Harold Jacobi, co-chairman of the United Palestine Appeal for $4,500,000 for the colonization in Palestine of oppressed EuropeanJews.

THE giant Republic of Brazil, most populous of all Latin States save Italy, has approximately doubled its population every thirty years since it achieved its independence in 1822. Were it as densely populated as England.

Now that the two major women's tournaments for this season are out of the way with the metropolitan and the Eastern championships decided for another year, the sectional battles will get under way this week.

President Roosevelt's enthusiasm for the work of Pare Lorenz, who wrote and directed "The River" and "The Plow That Broke the Plains," may result in establishment of a permanent federal agency for the production and distribution of government documentary films, it was indicated at the White House this week.

There will be another outdoor art show next week in Greenwich Village. It will differ from the regular Spring and Autumn ones in that it will be held in Washington Mews instead of round the Square, its exhibitors instead of being struggling unknowns will be well-established artists.

Close of play scores in cricket matches started today fol low: Kent 270 runs for seven wickets (Ames 73, Chalk 71, Todd 62 not out) vs. Notting hamshire at Nottingham. Gloucestershire 238 for seven (Hammond 110, Neale 54) vs. Derbyshire at Burtonon-Trent.
Interest in British professional golf has been revived during the week by the "league tournament" here among twelve leading players. It was finally won today by Percy Alliss.

Jersey City captured its series with the Royals today, taking the third and rubber game, 7 to 3. Hy Vandenberg went the route for the Litthe Giants, limiting the Royals tonine hits for his fourth victory.

Miss Jean Miriam Ackland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Ackland of this place, was married to Lieutenant William A. Johnson Jr., U. S. A., who was graduated on Tuesday from the United States Military Academy at West Point. The ceremony was performed in the Huguenot Memorial Church here by the Rev. Willard P. Soper, thepastor.

THE trim steamer Catalina is filling up now on its morning run -of twenty-seven miles from Los Angeles Harbor to Avalon. Soon its decks will be jammed with crowds bound for this lovely isle, the nearest thing to a principality that exists on Americansoil.

An income distribution of $2 on each $100 of certificates will be made on June 30 to holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates in Series of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, according to an announcement by trustees for the issue serving under appointment of Supreme Court Justice AlfredFrankenthaler.

The Cities Committee of the Constitutional Convention will consider Tuesday a new draft of a proposed home rule amendment to the Constitution, which, its sponsors hope, will meet the objections raised in the committee to other home rule proposals,

With so many nations preparing for war, the Bureau of Mines is giving increasing attention to the problem of war materials. The War Department has classed nine minerals as "strategic," including aluminum, antimony, chromium, manganese, mica,nickel, mercury, tin and tungsten.
Hopeful lawmakers introduced 17,092 bills and resolutions during the Seventy-fifth Congress, but only one out of ten became law.

Miss Margaret Elizabeth Austin, daughter of Captain Charles Morrison Austin, U. S. N., and Mrs. Austin of this city and Knoxville, Tenn., was married this afternoon to Dr. Joseph Wilson Johnson Jr. in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Williams, daughter of Mrs. Lewis K. Haggin of Lexington, Ky., and the late W. Graddy Williams, to Joseph Mead of New York. son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Mead of New Haven, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon in theChurch of the Ascension.
The Dutch are reluctant to make any prophecies about trade in the United States for the Autumn.

A "tree census" to evaluate Britain's forest wealth is now being undertaken by an offi cial Forestry Commission, which has as its object the planning of a timber reserve for use in the eventof a "national emergency."

THEY are shearing the sheep in Scotiand now, a little band of hand-shearers going with their clippers from sheep fold to sheepfold. Often one glimpses them from the Edinburgh-to-Inverness coach, swiftly working.

Scoring all its runs in the fourth inning, the St. John's Prep bas ball team of Brooklyn downed S Peter's H. S., 3 to 1, yesterday in closely fought encounter to captur the C. H. S. A. A. baseball chan pionship at Sisco Park, Staten I land, before a crowd of 2,000 pesons.

The Summer vacation airline trip via Bookland as introduced by the Des Moines Public Library in cooperation with the public schools last Summer is on its second cruise it is announced by Forest Spaulding,librarian.

Scoring four times in the last two innings, Wesleyan came from behind to upset Williams College, 5 to 4, in the final Little Three baseball game today. Reaching Hadley for nine hits, the Cardinals bunched four in the eighth for three runs and, after Williams had tied it up, scored again in the ninth on a walk, a stolen base, a passed ball and anInfield single by Bottjer.

Imperial and Yuma cantaloupe growers announced. yesterday an agreement to plow under one-third of the unharvested crop of melons in the Arizona-California valleys. "Serious overproduction" was givenas the reason.

Depositors of the Crestwood National Bank of Tuckahoe, closed since the banking holiday of 1933, will receive not only their deposits in full but also 3.55 per cent interest, according to Edward D. Loughman, receiver.

A study of the termite problem indicates that one of the best methods of protecting frame houses against this pest is the use of non-corrosive metal sheets over the foundation walls, reports the Illinois Zinc Company.
A merciless official campaign against Jews, reinforced by mob action, was extended to all Germany today by secret police orders.

The present economic depression in Palestine is caused by three factors, the uncertainty of the political future, the continuing disorders by Arab terrorists and the restriction of immigration, according to Julius Simon, president of the Palestine Economic Corporation, who reported to a meeting of stockholdersof the organization last week.

Angelo Trulio, former national champion, will attempt to repeat his victory of last season when he d: spots Edward Linz, co-holder of the national doubles crown, four points in the final-round match of the second annual Ravenhall A. C. invitation A. A. U. four-wall handball handicap tournament at Ravenhall,Coney Island, today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Valentine Mitchell of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Sage Mitchell, to William H. Blake, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Blake of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J.
The captain of Czechoslovakia's ship of state is steering a danger ous course on which successful cir cumnavigation of one danger point ,only brings him nearer the next.

JUST a hundred years ago tomorrow--on June 20, 1838--there was engraved and colored in Robert Havell's shop, 77 Oxford Street, London, the last of a set of bird pictures to complete the original elephant folio edition of John James Audubon's famous work, "Birds of America."
Roosevelt, informed persons said today, has reduced to about twenty-five an original list of hundreds of names suggested for appointmentto the Civil Aeronautics Authority.
HOLLYWOOD BEHIND Samuel Goldwyn's abandonment of production of "The Exiles," a story dealing with the flight of an Austrian Jew to America, is a series ofevents characteristic of Hollywood.

Asserting that the State and nation rose upon a foundation of religious freedom, Federal Judge Albert B. Maris ruled today that it was unconstitutional to require school children to salute the American flag in contravention of their religious beliefs.

All morning yesterday and late into the afternoon Columbus Park on the lower East Side echoed with the joyous shouts of more than 500 Chinese youngsters. It was the third annual field day and baby contest held under the auspices ofthe Chinese Community Committee.

Commodity Flow and Capital Formation: By Simon Kuznets. Report of a five-year investigation of available data relating to the production and distribution of commodities, covering the period from 1919 to 1935. (National Bureau of Economic Research, 1,819 Broadway, New York, N. Y. $5.)

Screen doors may not fully qualify as things of beauty, but they need not necessarily mar the out ward appearance of a home. A screen door amounts to a necessity in warm weather if a myriad of insects that want to takeup residence is to be kept out.

Another remarkable success for the new group of drugs known collectively, if not quite accurately, as the "sulphanilamide group," was claimed by two doctors at St. Bartholomew's Hospital, who recount their experiencein the current issue of The Lancet.

Bruce Hobbs, the youth who rode Battleship to victory in the Grand National at Aintree last March, stole the show at the Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association today. Before a crowd of 5,000 he piloted Louts E. Stod dard Jr.'s Blackeock home first in the Cedarhurst Grand National to win an ovation such as few' ridersget on the amateur circuit.

The service units of the New York National Guard, the 102d Engineers, of Manhattan, and the 102d Medical Regiment, so called because of their duties of getting all in order for the incoming infantry units that follow, concluded their first week of training today with virtually every man of the 1,100 members of the units free from illness despite the coldand -rainy weather.

TIME will turn back 300 years, if colorful pageantry can reverse the calendar, in this me dieval hill city on July 2 when Siena will celebrate its annual Palio festival in the shadow of the statuesque Palazzo di Signori, in commemoration of the miracles of theMadonna di Provenzano.

Ground wood pressed into boards is nothing new either to Americans or Europeans. Short of timber, even with the acquisition of Austria's forests, Germany is systematically exploiting the process withimprovements.

The Chandler Act, which Congress passed last week, has simplified, speeded up and improved bankruptcy administration in many respects, according to an analysis prepared by Jacob I. Weinstein of Aarons, Weinstein Goldhaber,Philadelphia.

Princeton alumnii crews of the classes of 1918 and 1936 rowed to victory in two of today's fifth annual "downhill regatta" races over a quarter-mile course on Lake Carnegie. Captain Phil Le Boutillier's 1938 varsity scored an easy decision over a 1934 boat in the finalevent.

The National Front, an extreme Right organization, held a rally here today attended by several thousand persons. Speakers, while acknowledging the Imredy Cabinet's sincere desire for reforms, insisted these good intentions were valueless without corresponding deeds.
New York City's students, as well their teachers, will have a part in the convention of the National Education Association, beginning next Sunday.

EW LONDON, Conn., is getting out its gay bunting of crimson and blue, for this is its week of weeks. Once each year the colorful old seaport at the mouth of the Thames finds its population more than doubled, as about 75,000 visitors are drawn to the Connecticut city by the spectacle of the Harvard-Yale regatta.
LEADING the way in sixteen-meter broadcasting from Europe to America, London now turns its 17.79 megacycle beam toward the Eastern seaboard between 7:20 and 9:30 o'clock, daylighttime.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.-- An unusually early demand for es states and cottages, the early arrival of many members of the Summer colony, the return of former residents after a long ab sence and the addition of a large group of new colonists-all these, combined with anunusually full program of social and sports events, augur favorably for the most successful season this resort has experienced in a number of years.

The magazine Aeroplane, which generally is regarded as the spokesman for British aircraft manufacturers, publishes a vitriolic attack on the Air Ministry for its decision to purchase 400 planes for the Royal AirForce in the United States.

Plans for a broad re-examination of the foreign policy of this country for possible revision by the next Con gress were announced today by Senator Pittman, chairman of .theForeign Relations Committee.

Two years ago tonight Joe Louis suffered the only setback in a matchless career when he was knocked out in twelve rounds by Max Schmeling. Today the same Joe Louis, now world's heavyweight champion, will finish training for the defense of the title against the same Max Schmeling, who aspires to be the first man in all the long historyof boxing ever to regain the crown.

Dr. Richard M. Brickner of this city reported last week to the American Medical Association in San Francisco that a patient of his who had the whole front part of his brain removed teaches much about the way we think. Dr. Brickner's patient was unable to storeup memories.

Miles A. Glidden, superintendent of the Providence Police Depart ment, died today at the Jane Brown Hospital, at the age of 60. He had been a member of the department since 1902 and only recently had handed in his resignation, which would have become effective June26.

In honor of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden and his consort, Crown Princess Louise, a dinner will be given in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on July 6. The event will be linked with the New Sweden tercentenary celebration to be held in Wilmington, Del., and Philadelphia, commemorating the 300th anniversary of the establishment of New Sweden in the Delaware Valley in 1638.

Beginning on Saturday, June 25, New York City's Board of Education will give 3,000,000 parents and he thousands of visitors to the National Education Association convention an opportunity to see what more than a million children ofNew York do in their school work.

As the civil war in Spain, seems to be approaching its final phase, with all evidence Pointing to the probability of vic tory for General Francisco Franco and his German and Italian allies, the issues,
Townsend B. Martin's Cravat finally entered the select circle of stake-winning 3 year-olds today when he accounted for the $15,000 added Yankee Handicap at Suffolk Downs.
CHAPTER. HEADING Lest you should think this story true I merely mention I Evolved it lately. 'Tis a most Unmitigated misstatement. Rudyard Kipling.

The radioactive man is to make his first public appearance at the Golden Gate International Exposition in 1939. He is to be set up by the University of California as one of the outstanding features of its $200,000 exhibit in the Hall of Science to show how science can hang a headlight on every atom that he consumes and just wherethose atoms go.

For the fifth consecutive session, quotations on the Cotton Exchange closed higher than the preceding day. Final prices yesterday being 7 to 9 points higher than Friday and at the highest level of the week, All months, with the exception of July, went into new high ground with March and May above 8 1/2 cents, and a final quotation of 8.42 cents for October comparedwith 8.19 the previous Saturday.

The month of May showed a marked increase in real estate activity as based. upon the number of transactions, reports the Real Estate Board of New York in its monthly sales analysis, in spite of the fact that the aggregate value of the sales was somewhat less thanin April.

To keep rhododendrons in good health through the Summer a mulch of peat moss or hardwood leaves is kept on the soil, This helps retain moisture, providing the natural condition to which the plants are accustomed when growing in the wild.

A realty deal in Newark, N. J., which indicates, according to the brokerage firm of Leslie Blau of that city, confidence in the future stability of business on Market Street, was announced yesterday in the purchase by Louis Oshman, head of the Roberts Shoe Repair, Inc., of the three-story building at181 Market Street.

Disease in flowering dogwood trees has caused concern among gardeners and tree experts in the vicinity of New York City. Research on the malady has been conducted at Arnold Arboretum, the results of which have been set forth by Dr. D. B. Creager in The Journal of theArnold Arboretum.

The marriage of Miss Joann Ganey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Matthew Ganey of this city, to Arthur Richard Cushman, son of Mrs. John Clifton Lusk, also of New London, took place this morning in St. Matthias Church, Flanders, East Lyme.
THIRTY years ago, on June 21, Nicholas Rimsky-Korsakoff went to his rest. Seventy-five years ago he visited the United States as a midshipman on the clipper Almaz of the Russian Navy.

THE growing excitement of weeks is reaching a peak here as thousands gather for Tuesday's 150th anniversary Of one of the State's great moments. On June 21, 1788, New Hampshire became the ninth State to approve the national Constitution, thereby making it binding onall thirteen States.

Bent on exploiting the riches of the frozen North, the Soviet Academy of Sciences has established a laboratory to determine the physical properties of the soil at temperatures as low as minus 150 degrees, which is far lower than thisplanet ever reaches.

MOST sections of the country put in more favorable reports on trade in the week. The gains were small but cut the sharp losses previously registered with last year's figures. Improved weather, hard-driving promotions and Father's Day preparations combined to lift sales.

The Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bai ley combined circus--"he greatest show on earth"-headed toward a Sabbath layover here with the choice ahead of it of straightening out financial problems or folding its tents for an early return to Winterquarters.
A second place in the running broad jump by Roy Kearney enabled the Chippewa A. C. of Yonkers to capture the team Prize at the annual Westchester A. A. U. track and field title meet today.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth George Boehmer, daughter of Milton William Boehmer of 18 East Sixtieth Street and St. Louis, to Edward John Rohn, son of Mrs. Emma C. Rohn of Woodhaven, Queens, took place yesterday morn ing in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Fractional changes ruled yesterday in the foreign exchange market. Despite the nervous fluctuations of the week, caused by the European feeling that devaluation of the dollar was imminent, the net result in actual changes was small. For the week,

The Chief, stablemate to Stage-hand, injected himself more power-fully into the 3-year-old picture by capturing the $12,400 Dwyer Stakes yesterday before 20,000 persons, who watched an amazingly fast mile and a furlong over a sloppy trackat Aqueduct.
GAETANO GAUDIO, whose Gaetano has been shortened to Tony ever since he left Rome for America, is unique among Hollywood toilers, holding a record unequaled by any other manalive.

LONDON. EVEN with "Test Pilot" break ing records at the Empire, the screen's most famous dog-star arriving at Southampton, and Victoria marrying Albert all over again in the presence of 124 assorted journalists, the greatest film stir of the month has been provided by television, and the old die-hards are still wonder ing how they are going to live itdown.
Staten Island defeated the Crescent A. C. in a New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association championship fixture at Livingston, S. I., yesterday, 68 to 67.

If they were high-class citizens and they met in peaceful, orderly manner, why, certainly, they have perfect rights; but if prior to that they were advocating the overthrow of the government, they were dissatisfied with everything that America offered to them, why, of course, I don't assumethey have any right.

Two Chinese children, Francisco Hitler Chang, 5 years old; and Vittorio Hindenburg Chang, arrived here yesterday bound for Hong Kong. They were accompanied by their father, a prosperous Guayaquil merchant.

The first section of the report of the Securities and Exchange Commission on its study of investment trusts and investment companies appears to be little more than a "curtain-raiser" to later-parts of the extensive survey, launched atthe start of 1936.

Dr. New William R. Collett, a psychiatrist, died today while working in the laboratory of the Philadelphia Gen eral Hospital. His age was 31. A native of St. Paul, Minn., Dr. Collett attended the University of Washington and was graduated AMSTERfrom Jefferson Medical College.

American industrialists wouldlike to see a religious revival and un less it materializes the country is faced with a minority group dictatorship, the Rev. Dr. J. Frank Norris, "flying pastor," who commutes by air between his two Bapitst Fundamentalist churches in Detroit and Fort Worth, Texas, said yesterday in an interview at theHotel Pennsylvania.

The ordinary fresh-water angler seems to have the belief that the State game protectors are little more than official ogres, with their only joy in life attained when they find an angler guilty of a violation. This is far from true and a week never passes without some word reaching this desk of some outstanding work done by one of thesemen.

Sixteen homes in Kings, Queens, Nassau and Westchester Counties were sold during May by the Easy-to-Own Homes organization, bringing the total number of sales made since the first of the year up to forty-eight with a dollar volume of $273,100, it was announced yesterday by Russell Page, sales director.

AT a thousand more or less nostalgic class suppers this week-end on campuses all over the country "old grads" from Wall Street to Main Street are telling each other how life has been treating them. Ten years out, twenty-five and fifty, financier and farmer, teacher and housewife,

WITH the legislators in forty-eight States constantly on the alert to solve their problems by making new laws and with tensof thousands of cities, towns and hamlets doing likewise, motor toursits have found that life is somewhat simplified for them if they confine their travels to their own or adjacent States.

DR. GRAUBARD, a biologist of note, has written an unusual, clear and sane volume on the biological basis of human behavior. His is an important contribution. Moreover, it stands out as doubly important because of the contrasting mediocrity of the usual utterances of successful scientists concerning human nature, cultureand ethics.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Saunders of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Saunders, to Appleton Adams Mason Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mason of Larchmont and Crescent Lake, Me.

The Rev. George Herbert Grout, former Episcopal archdeacon of the diocese of Susquehanna, Albany, N. Y., died in Toronto General Hospital today. Archdeacon Grout retired in 1926 because of ill health and passed his Winters in Toronto and Summersin suburban Oakville.

EVERYTHING about this scatterbrained voyage from Tahiti to Cannes seems utterly incredible. But incredible things do happen once in a whille, and Morton Gill Clark assures his readers that although he has set his chronicle in the terms of fiction he has nevertheless held close to the truth.

EVERY year more Winter wanderers realize that the sunpainted deserts of the West hold great scenic beauty and opportunity for relaxation. In the Far West that peculiarly American institution, the dude ranch, is at itsbest.
An 18-year-old adopted son led officers today to the body of his foster father, whom he confessed he shot May 31 because of resentmentover a scolding.

Among the principal' speakers at the forty-fifth annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association which is to open next Saturday at the Saranac Inn, Upper Saranac, N. Y., will be J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, Dr. O. C. Carmichael, chancellor of Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tenn., and Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.
Returned recently from a Euro Orchestra, will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Music fromYale on Wednesday.

FOR the first time the International Labor Organization, established in 1919, has chosen an American as its director. John G. Winant, former Governor of New Hampshire and first chairman of the United States Social Se curity Board, is the man. He takes officenext January.

Passage of the Doughton bill revising administrative provisions of the customs law in many important respects was greeted with satisfaction last week by importers who have been advocating such arevision for more than three years.

Mrs. William Fahnestock, who has been at the Savoy-Plaza, has gone to her Summer home in Katonah, N. Y. Mrs. Frederick Sterling of Wash ington, D. C., is at the Ambassador. Mr. and Mrs. William C. Alexander have arrived at the RitzCarlton from Haverford, Pa.

Again showing that he has a mind of his own, King George VI has just brought great distress to those shopkeepers who boast the right to display the royal coat of arms, complete even to the "Dieu et Mon Droit" on their store, windows, their goods and letterheads.

Protests of Catholic organizations against the motion picture "Block ade," now playing. at the Radio City Music Hall, charging it with "subtle pro-Loyalist propaganda," were answered yesterday by Walter Wanger, producer of the film, in astatement from Hollywood.

Daniel Beard has had many birthday parties, but those who had attended others declared this afternoon's celebration on the estate of Charles A. Pace came nearest to being genuinely worthy of the nation's First Scout.

A total of 134 years of service by the members of one family in the library of Columbia University will end on June 30 with the retirement of Frank C. Erb, it was announcedyesterday by the university.

ROM the farthest banks of the sta dium the dim faces strain toward the square white glare of the ring. The ordered rows seem to press in like a tide. And the night air is filled with a murmur, restless and confused, the overtone of many voices. A great crowd iswaiting for the bell.

Demanding the unconditional release of two Polish anti-Fascists recently condemned to death on charges of killing a Fascist agent at Chelm, Poland, thirty-five representatives of Polish. Ukrainian and Jewish organizations here picketed the Polish. Consulate at 151 East Sixty-seventh Street for an hour yesterday morning.

In the locker rooms of Brooklyn Technical High School hang hundreds of costumes of many colors waiting for the New York City school pageant which will be given three times for the meeting of theNational Education Association.

Tom D. Taggart's Marica, champion mare of the West last year, beat five Eastern horses of her sex today in the second running of the $10,000 added one mile and a six-teenth Newcastle Handicap at Delaware Park. Making her first start since last October, Marica carriedton weight of 125 bounds.

'" There be many kinds of Iris, or flower de Luce, whereof some are tall and great and some little, small and lowe." wrote John Gerard in his "herbal" shortly before the death of Queen Elizabeth. Well might this old botanist have been writing of native Americanirises.

A graduating class of more than 1,600 men and women will receive degrees, diplomas and commissions from City College at the ninety-second annual commencement exercises in the City College StadiumWednesday evening.
The engagement has been announced of Miss C. Elaine Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. J. E. Brown of West Englewood, N. J., to Philip Eugene Costa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Costa of Yonkers,N. Y.

The Rev. J. Albert Weagle, retired rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, died yesterday in Episcopal Hospital after an illness of five days. He was 67 years old. Born in Nova Scotia, he studied at King's College there, at General Theological Seminary in NewYork and at Columbia University.

An analysis of problems involved in the seizure of foreign-owned oil properties by the Mexican Government shows that any unnecessary delay in their settlement is tend ing not only to add. to the internal perplexities of Mexico but may lend encouragement to other Latin-American republics to adopt thesame procedure of confiscation.

For twenty-five years the research engineers of the University of Illinois have been experimenting with air conditioning, part of the time in a test residence. As air condition ing is expensive in Summer, they decided to find out how small an air-conditioning unit may be andstill meet expectations.

The old-fashioned Mary Ann of the English kitchens has mysteriously disappeared, and for several years now a number of very earnest search parties have set out at regular intervals in an effort to find her and bring her back to herplace at the kitchen sink.

A property owner has a civic duty in making a definite contribution to the good appearance of his city, declares Charles C. Platt of the architectural firm of F. P. Platt Bro. and a member of the archi tect's subcommittee of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement.
EVERY time Jimmy Cagney has a tiff with the Warner Brothers you read in the papers that he is going to retire permanently from the screen, form an Irish repertory companyand tour the hinterland.

THIS is one about a gang of gnomes. Seems that one Princess Pitiful was walking in the woods and she saw a seedy old gentleman named Male-factor and a tattered youth named Amnesia come staggering up a path carrying a goldfishbowl between them.

WHO was the man in gray who was murdered in his bed at the Duke of York, Westingborough's best hotel? Did his death have any connection with the theft of an important document from thehouse of Ralph Enthwaite?

High costs of operation have proved the most effective brake in halting the worst outbreak of price-cutting in the history of the food industry this Spring, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., asserted yesterday.

William ,P. Bleakley of Yonkers, former Supreme Court justice, unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor in 1936 and vice president of the New York State Constitutional Convention in session at Albany, implied in an address here today that Governor Lehman's speech against wire tapping yesterday was intended to create a campaign issue in the 1938 Gubernatorial election.

The nation's acute wheat situation caused Administration officials, at the direction of President Roose velt, to scan foreign markets this week in the hope of reducing what may -prove the greatest wheat surplus on record.
The marriage of Miss Florence Kendrick Hoban, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. E. Hoban of Forest Hills, Queens, and Daytona Beach, Fla., to George Neall Bartlett, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs.

Bob Seeds got his twenty-six homer of the campaign and Ji Gleeson hit No. 9 as the Newar Bears swept their series with t?? Rochester Red Wings today, wi ning 9 to 2, and increasing thevictory streak to nine games.

Seven crews from Navy, Columbia and Syracuse held routine workouts today on the Hudson in preparation for the intercollegiate regatta June 27. Navy, a late arrival last night, rigged the varsity shell and Coach Buck Walsh sent his boys on a two mile practice row merely to test therigging.

Labor relations and the "natural" fiscal year basis of accounting for industrial and business organizations are two of the topics scheduled for discussion at the fifth annual regional chapter conference of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, to be held at Inlet, N. Y.,Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

The marriage of Miss Anna Ranken Mattern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Briscoe Mattern, to John McArthur Harris Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Germantown, Philadelphia, took place here this afternoon at Riverview Manor, the homeof the bride's parents.
Miss Aubry Lee Hill of this city, daughter of Mrs. Rufus Daniel of Knoxville, Tenn., was married this morning to Earl A. Graham of New York, son of the late Mr. andMrs. William A. Graham of Kelly,

SOVIET RUSSIA is looking forward to another big crop this year. Last year's harvest was huge, and the Winter brought heavy snows over the entire grain area, protecting the Winter wheat and leaving an abundance of moisture for the Spring wheat. Even should there be a bad drought this Summer, still probably there would be an adequate harvest.

California announced yesterday that it had reluctantly withdrawn from participation in the New York World's Fair of 1939. The reason given was that New York State had failed to keep "a gentleman's agreement" to take part in the Golden Gate International Exposition at San Francisco 'nextyear.
Sixty students of the Sraubenmiller Textile High School, where they have been studying merchandising and salesmanship, yesterday tested their training in the arena of realbusiness.

Eighty-six years ago on a lake in New Hampshire, Yale and Harvard men who had taken to the new sport of rowing accepted the invitation of a resort proprietor to spend a few days on Lake Winnepesaukee and end their stay with an intercollegiate race.

In traditional Alumni Day style, Princeton's baseball nine fell victim, 5-2, to an invading Yale team before a crowd of 4,000 gayly clad alumni and 8,000 other fans on Uni versity Field today. The loss left the Tigers with seven victories in twelve league starts and the Blue at the .500 mark.

Senator Alben W. Barkley fired the opening gun of his campaign for re election here today, sounding a de fense of the Roosevelt Administration's record, supporting its actions and declaring its spending beneficial to all Americans.
Lawrin, making his first start since he captured the Kentucky Derby, won the $15,000 added Hollywood Trial Stakes today before acrowd of 50,000 at Hollywood Park.

The Apawamis Club opened its beach club here today with a dinner dance with more than 200 members and their guests attending. Among the hosts were Mr. and Mrs. John H. Bassett, Mr. and Mrs. Clair Maxwell, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Swift, Mr. and Mrs. J. E. Swift, Mr. and Mrs. Eckhardt, Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Collins, Mr. and Mrs. J. D. Danforth, Mr. and Mrs. Warren C. Agryand Miss Eleanor Crow.
Some important dividend meet ings this week by companies listed on the New York StockExchange follow:

Several insulation methods are available for the home, points out an official of the FHA. The chief value of such equipment, he points out, is the increased comfort provided in Summer and Winter, although the saving usually made in reduced fuel consumption is an important factor.

Walter Granget Kammerer, vice president and treasurer of the Rietmann-Pilcer Company, custom house brokers, of 32 Broadway, died yesterday morning at his home, 433 Bement Avenue, Staten Island, after an illness of four weeks. He was 70 years old.

Within the nation's smallest State there will be a still smaller State this Summer. This political mite, known as the Little Rhody Boys State, will exist on the campus of Rhode Island State College for ten days, July-5to 15.

Judge Robert P. Patterson of the United States District Court granted yesterday the application of Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for creditors of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, for permission to disaffirm the company's 999-year lease of elevated lines in Manhattan and the Bronx and to return the properties to their owner, the Manhattan Railway Company.
TOWARD the red-and-gray bulk of the United States Northeastern Penitentiary, in its thousand-acre reservation in the Susquehanna Val ley, a man in a car with Virginia licenseplates comes driving.

The continuing problem of unemployment relief can be coped with only by a permanent integrated program of insurance, public work and public assistance, according to conclusions drawn from a Works Progress Administration survey of relief and security programs made public today by Harry L. Hopkins,WPA Administrator.

Eunice L., black mare owned and driven by William Brundage of Armonk, captured the Class A trot and pace at the Driving Park here today. The Class B event was taken by Deborah, C. M. Gruelock's baymare, in straight heats.
Supply contracts valued at $9,372,763 were awarded In the week ended on June 16 by fifteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department ofLabor announced today.

Mayor La Guardia and the five District Attorneys in the city joined yesterday in favoring a constitutional provision against unreasonable search and seizure and permitting the use of wiretapping against criminals only under reason able court supervision, but strongly opposed the proposal before the Constitutional Convention, supported by Governor Lehman, to bar the use of illegally obtained evidence inprosecutions.

WITH the receipt of two ore stamps of Bulgaria's say he national economy" series, ublicizing industries and products, it is evident that the completed set will be one of the most twelfth attractive the Balkan country hasever issued.
Joseph W. Catherine, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, has named George Horton Jr. of Brooklyn as a member of the association's committeeon housing.

The collection of art and furniture of the late Frank W. Savin will be shown at a special exhibition today, from 1 to 6 P. M., at Winchester Hall, his late residence, on the Boston Post Road, Port Chester,N. Y. Admission is by card only.

Any one in search of a wedding present or something of beauty for her own home might like to pay a visit to a new Swedish shop in town, its opening inspired by the SwedishTercentenary now being celebrated.
The Domei news agency reports that a squad of twenty Manchukuoan soldiers on border patrol were machine-gunned by Soviet troops on heights at Nanbetsuri, which is in thevicinity of Hungchung.

An ancient fire engine, borrowed from the Volunteer Fire Department in the near-by town of Cromwell, was drawn in the alumni parade at Wesleyan University todaye Craf by the members of the class of '13, who wore firemen's helmets andwhite duck suits.

Comments by purists on pronunciation used by Postmaster General James A. Farley, as reported in "Better English," serve to call attention to the fact that one thing President Roosevelt may do without authorization by Congress or even of an Executive order is to pronounce hisname just as he pleases.

After battling valiantly against a big deficit in the early stage of the match and against a recalcitrant driver that had him constantly playing the odd shot, Frankle Stfrafaci, 22-year-old automobile salesman from Brooklyn, today won as brilliant a victory in the metropolitan amateur golf championship aswas ever gained.

With the announcement that more than $16,000 had been raised, the two-day Westchester fete of the Westchester Chapter of the Women's Division of the New York and Brooklyn. Federations of Jewish Charities closed tonight with a dance at the Beach Point Clubhere.
Announcement has been made by Mrs. Elizabeth Hefferan of New York and Garden City, L. I. of the engagement of her daughter, MISS Lynn Hefferan, to Charles A. McLauchlan of Danbury, Conn.

The engagement is announced here of J. Clyde Marquis, permanent United States delegate to the International Institute of Agriculture, to Mrs. Bonner Semple Dunkerson of Louisville, Ky., niece of Francis B. Keene, former United States Consul Generalin Rome.

Edward Holle, 24-year-old automobile mechanic, was found guilty of murder in the second degree this afternoon after a week-long trial before Common Pleas Judge Richard Hartshorne on charges that he killed Sophie Kujat, 22, for fear his bride would learn of his relationship with the girl.

TILL awaiting final confirma tion of an order from Great Britain for 400 medium bom bardment and basic combat planes, two Los Angeles aircraft manufacturing plants last week be gan laying plans for local expan sion and the possible erection of assembly units in England.

The Foreign Office, through its organ the Diplomatische Politische Korrespondenz, today calls on Secretary of State Cordell Hull to give a clearer definition of the principles of the United States' foreign policy, in order to avert "arbitrary interpretations."

Miss Betty Jenckes, daughter of Mrs. Robert Johnson Jenckes of Providence, R. I., and Santa Barbara, Calif., was married to Robinson Smith of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Goodwin Smith of Hartford, Conn., here this afternoon in the garden of the countryhome of the bride's mother.

An exhibition of marine photog raphy. comprising pictures from ?? Rosenfeld collection, will open to morrow on the men's floor at ?? and Taylor. The subjects will cove all phases of yachting from out board motor racing to cup competietions. During the Summer.

PARIS. ALBERT THIBAUDET was cut off too early from his fruitful and brilliant career of literary critic. We welcome theposthumous publication in volume from by the N. R. F. press of hs articles on novels:

Citing the experience of the Home Owners Loan Corporation in reconditioning many of the homes which it has been compelled to acquire, The Federal Home Loan Bank Re view recommends a wise spending of money to put previously unsalable. houses in good condition.

A suspect in a hold-up, who, according to the police, has an imposing criminal record at the age of. 20, took the wrong road yesterday after he allegedly had robbed a shoe store at 7,190 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, and fled with $60 and a pair of brown and white sportshoes.

Banking executives from all parts of the United States began arriving at Rutgers University today for two weeks of study at the Graduate School of Banking conducted in cooperation with the university by the American Institute of Banking section of the American Bankers Association. Enrollmentthis year is 627.

Nine hundred Wellesley alumnae, representing classes graduated between 1879 and 1937, realized an ambition of thirty years' standing this afternoon as they watched the cornerstone of the college swimming pool slip into place in the foundation of the new RecreationBuilding.

In THE TIMES Magazine today Mr. L. H. Robbins describes a Federal prison-the United States Northeast ern Penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa. built for prisoners who can be re claimed, or "cleaned up," as WardenHenry C. Hill puts it.

Miss Fidelra Richards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus D. Richards of Winnetka and William Winston Roper Jr. of Philadelphia, son of the late Princeton football coach, were married this afternoon in the Congregational Church in the suburb.
Two large properties: in New Hampshire were reported yesterday as having been purchased by New Yorkers from Harris H. Rice, operator, through the Batson FarmAgency, brokers, of New York.
Foreign Minister Kazushige Ugaki, who has become the virtual ruler of Japan under the Emperor since his appointment to the Cabinet, said yesterday afternoon in reply to aquery:

A pair of fencers, shown by Rufus Finch's Sundown Stables of Sea bright and skillfully ridden by Miss Louise Finch, a former national horsemanship champion, were su preme in the hunter classes during the second day of the seventh an nual Plainfield Horse Show at Vinebrook Farm today.
George Washington Lethbridge, president of Lethbridge Cornwell, marine insurance agents with offices at 90 John Street, New York, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. His agewas 64.

In a basement apartment at 76 starred Edgecomb Avenue, crammed with items of Liberian art such as carvings of sacred bush cats and ebony crocodiles, Mwalimu, a movement to recreate African culture in Harlem, celebrated its tenth anniversary yesterday.

Echoes of the bitter fight in Congress over the Wages and Hours Bill and the attempts to amend the Walsh Healey act to "blacklist" employers found guilty of labor law violations were heard today in statements from John L. Lewis of the Committee for Industrial Organization, William Green of the American Federation of Labor and the Chamber of Commerce of the UnitedStates.

MUCH attention was given at the Summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers last week at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., to matters of the motor car which relate primarily to comfort and pleasure of drivingand riding.

AMSTER-To Mr. and Mrs. Sol Amster, a daughter, June 14, at Beth Moses Hos pital. CINES--Mr. and Mrs. Arnold H. (nee Fan nette Aul), 240 West End Ave., announce the arrival of a daughter, June 10, Hark ness Pavilion. FILOMENA-Mr. and Mrs. John, announce birth of a son, June 14, 1938, at PolyclinicHospital.
ROAD building by totalitarian States has of late received so much attention that visitors are surprised to learn that France still has the most complete roadsystem in Europe.
Miss Louise Jacobs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacobs of Casamia, Bryn Mawr, was married this afternoon to Hubbard Phelps, son of Mrs.Louise DeKoven Phelps of Chicago.

Sharply reversing its recent trend, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has risen 1 1/2 points for the week ended June 11. It now stands at 76.5, compared with 75.0, the revised figure for the preceding week, and 107.0 for thecorresponding week last year.

Two bystanders were wounded shortly after 11 o'clock last night by policemen firing at two burglars fleeing after an attempt to break into the home of Charles H. H. Gristede, president of Gristede Brothers, Inc., chain grocers, at2,186 University Avenue, the -Bronx.

There are now thirty to forty million unemployed in India, the Indian workers' delegate told the International Labor Office conference today, basing the figure on an estimate by the Premier of Mysore. Sir Frank Noyce, Indian Government delegate, said that the figure must include farm workers and even sowas "very exaggerated."

The annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers will open tomorrow at the Hotel Schroeder, Milwaukee, Wis., for a discussion of new methods and changing trends in the handling of business andapartment properties.
The Steady drone of worker bees in the 5,000,000 colonies throughout the countrty is a reminder that the new Spring crop of honey will be harvested within a few weeks.

Dr. Ward C. Halstead, experimental psychologist of the Otto S. A. Sprague Memorial Institute of the University of Chicago Clinics, has developed a "ticker-tape" method of recording eye movements whilethe lids are closed.

THE next philatelic show of importance in the East will be what its sponsors, the Associted Stamp Clubs of Southeastern Pennsylvania and Delaware, have titled "SEPAD"-a national stamp exhibition to be held in Phila delphia's Convention Hall on Tues day through June 28 in conjunction With the Swedish-American Tercentenary Celebration.

Byron (Whizzer) White, Colorado Uni- versity's All-America back, an nounced tonight he definitely had declined a $15,000 offer to play professional football with the Pittsburgh Pirates and would go to England to accept a Rhodesscholarship at Oxford University.

DETROIT. WHILE not essentially automotive, topics for discus sion at the annual meeting of the Advertising Federation of America here were distinctly of such automotive flavor that they have woven themselves definitelyinto the fabric of the industry.

Mr. and Mrs. Wesson Seyburn of this city today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Seyburn, to Edward M. McIlvain Jr. of New York. Miss Seyburn is a granddaughter of the late John F. Dodge, one of the founders of Dodge Brothers,automobile manufacturers.

Miss Stella Walsh, Cleveland Olympic ace, ran the 100-yard dash in 10.4 seconds today, four-tenths of a sec ond faster than the world record she set in 1930. She also ran 60 yards in 7 seconds flat, four-tenths of a second better than the Ameri can record set by Miss Helen M.Filkey in Chicago in 1928.

OMORROW is the day when the new Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, a merger of the three chief contemporary units of so-called Russian ballet, is announced to begin its public exist ence with the opening of its season at Covent Garden, but apparentlythingss are not altogether tranquil.

If there was any change in business or financial conditions last week, it was well-nigh imperceptible. Security prices worked lower and commodities were irregular. Trading was extremely dull. The week's turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was less than 2,000, 000 shares, the smallest for a fullweek since 1921.
A storybook ceremony in a picture post card church, in a setting and amid friends known since child hood, was Anne Lindsay Clark's marriage today to John A. Roosevelt, youngest son of the President.
Miss Rose Greenhut, daughter Mrs. Benedict J. Greenhut of 1,160 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Greenhut, was married to Ernst B. Kaufmann, also of this city, on Friday at the home of her mother.

Clarence P. Houston, director of athletics, recently announced that Joe Weeks of Cornish, Me., would captain the Tufts baseball team next year. The captain-elect, who succeeds Bennie Collier of Lynn, was rated by Coach Ken Nash as the team's outstanding performerthis Spring.

The Abraham Lincoln High School handball team successfully defended its P. S. A. L. city championship yesterday when it swept all five matches in defeating Seward Park on the James Madison High School courts. All the matches were onesided.
A wire-tapping bill was among the proposed leg islative measures which died in Washington.

Those mighty Trojans of Southern California, clinching the right to recog nition as one of the most finely balanced collegiate track and field teams of all time, won their fourth consecutive national championship at Minnesota's Memorial Stadiumtoday.
Winning in twenty-six moves from Rudolph Spielmann, one of the two Austrian competitors, Paul Keres of Estonia assumed the lead in the international chess masters' tournament tonight.

The Phillies turned the tables on the Pirates today, winning, 5 to 3, in an exciting game that saw twenty-five men left on bases. Hugh Mulcahy, given a lead in the first inning on Phil Weintraub's two-bagger,

SOME sixteen to eighteen operas Swill be presented during the Cincinnati Summer opera season, June 26-Aug. 6, at the Zoo in Cincinnati, Ohio. Fausto Cleva, chorus director of the Metropol itan, who last Summer directedopera in Caracas, Venezuela,
