Bumble Bee of Delwin, Kerry blue terrier owned by John Mulcahy of the Bronx, was named best in the Troy Dog Show, conducted in conjunction with the Troy Horse Show and Country Fair today. There were 543 dogs in the exhibition.

BELISKOWITZ--DENKER--Mr. and Mrs. Max Denker, announce the betrothal of their daughter, Ruth, to Morris Bells-kowitz. BIRENBACH--GOLDBERG--Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Goldberg, 515 West End Ave., announce engagement of their daughter, Bernice (Bunny), to Dr. Herbert Birenbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Birenbach.

Cleveland baseball fans will observe "Connie Mack Day" tomorrow as a preliminary to a Cleveland-Philadelphia game. President William Harridge of the American League will present to the Philadelphia manager a scroll containing tributes frombaseball dignitaries.

Members of society were out early this morning to see the children's hunter and jumper classes in the opening session of the two-day Cedar Valley horse show being held on the Townsend F. Bailey estate here for the benefit of Hope Farm. The largest crowd the show has ever had was in attendance thismorning.

OMORROW noon a gun will bark from a committee boat off Brenton's Reef, outside of Newport, R. I., and send some forty-odd yachts of various sizes and rigs away on their 600-mile race across the Gulf Stream tothe Bermudas.

Twenty-five boats, carrying the colors of yacht clubs along the Connecticut and Long Island shores, answered the starting gun off here tonight in the Riverside YachtClub's annual Stratford Shoal race.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open tomorrow an exhibition of the work of students of the art classes of the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education. More than 400 pieces will be on view in one of the museum's classrooms until July 1.

Commencement exercises for thirty-five graduates of the School for Printers Apprentices were held last Wednesday night at the school, 461 Eighth Avenue. Twenty-one of the class received also diplomas from the affiliated School for Machine Typesetting.

Edward William Ashley, retired importer and resident of Orange since 1874. died this morning at Maplewood. He was 95 years old. For almost half a century before his retirement in 1928 Mr. Ashley was associated with Starkweather Co., wine merchants of 20 SouthWilliam Street, New York.

Nine women passengers were injured slightly and a brakeman was burned severely on the hands and face when a minor explosion, followed by fire, caused a panic among the passengers aboard Train 109, a local bound for Croton-on-Hudson, as the train was about to start-north from the Spuyten Duyvil sta tion in the Bronx at 4:39 P. M. yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD'S decision to reduce the number of musicals in future production schedules marks another turning point in the strange history of the music film.
Farm Bureau leaders from North eastern States, ending a two-day conference, today urged further devaluation of the dollar to help raiseprice levels.
Term settlements of transactions in securities are being discussed by a committee of the New York Stock Exchange. There is nothing new about the idea. It is common elsewhere in the world.

Mr. and Mrs. A. Bertram Holmes of Douglaston, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jessianna Louise Holmes, to William Dickson John ston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Alan Johnston of 40 East Eighty-eighth Street, New York, formerlyof Norfolk, Va.

WE are all critics. Every man who has selected one thing instead of another has exercised criticism. We are all art critics. There is no man alive who has not preferred this to that because this looked or sounded better to him.

Hollyrood Perry, owned and driven by Eugene Carpenter of this city, trotted to a brilliant victory over Sun Dial, 3-year-old star from the Newbrook Stables, in the matineefeature at Weequahic Park today.

IT s a curious tale they tell of the reason a show closed not long ago while it was still doing a satisfactory business. The star, a fellow not unaware of himself, had consented to allow one of the other principals to use the No. 1 dressing room because the actor was required to make some very quickchanges.

A new home community is being opened in Nassau County, L. I., just beyond the.New York City line of Queens County, by Eli Tilles and Hyman Rosen, builders, who have recently completed a development project in Woodside and who have operated in Fiushing, Elmhurst andJamaica.

SCOUNTING provides boys with opportunities to serve othrs. Every Scout is pledged to do his best "to help other people at all times" and to observe the Scout law which requries him to do at least one "good turn" to somebody every day.

Colin J. Sabiston, chairman of the board of directors of the International Educational Publishing Company, died here this afternoon in the Mercy Hospital, to which institution he was taken last night. He was76 years old..

MOUNTING statistics are establishing the Mammoth Cave National Park in Kentucky as a popular tourist rendezvous. Last year there was a 35 per cent increase over the preceding year and indications are that 1938 will see more than 150,000 travelers stopping over for a tourof the cave and park.

The United States Lines an nounced yesterday that 5,000 tons, or about 30 per cent, of the steel required for the hull of its new passenger and freight ship had been delivered and was being fabricated at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding. and .Drydock Company.

LAKE PLACID.-The seventh d annual midsummer ice skat ing season, which has been increased this year to seven weeks to continue through Aug. 14, will open in the Olympic arena on Saturday. The season will reach its climax in the annual midsummer figure skating operetta Aug.4, 5 and 6.
" IN AND OUT OF DOORS" is closely packed with suggestions for all manner of entertaining and useful ways of employing one's time, something for all tastes and all ages.

Prediction pare that the Schenectady home of Dr. Charles P. Steinmetz, "electrical wizard", would soon become a State museum was made this week by Lithgow Osborne, State Conservation Commissioner, under whose jurisdiction the museum will beplaced.

Mr. and Mrs. Earl Maltby Benson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Benson, to William Henry Gilman, son of Mrs. William L. F. Gilman, also of Wellesley, and thelate Mr. Gilman.

The sale of American merchandise has increased considerably in the last year in Selfridge Co., Ltd., according to a survey made today by THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in those departments handlinggoods from the United States.
The American Southern Baptist Mission property in Pingtu, Shantung Provice, was twice bombed by Japanese naval planes Wednesday, according to reports received today fromTsingtao.

FTER three years of prepara tion and several months of preliminary celebration, Delaware will mark the high point of its tercentenary in Wil mington on Monday, June'27, when the Crown Prince of Sweden, on be-half of his people, presents a monument which the President of the United States is expected to accepton behalf of his.

Miss Frances E. Farnham, daughter of Professor Charles Sherman Farnham of Yale University and Mrs. Farnham, was married this afternoon in the United Church to John Hewitt Mitchell, son of Professor Sydney Knox Mitchell ofYale and Mrs. Mitchell.

The marriage of Miss Margaretha Kimmerle Minder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Minder of South Orange, to Lieutenant Paul C. Davis, son of Mrs. G. C. Davis of Chatham and R. J. Davis of North Arlington, took place this afternoon in the chapel of the United States Military Academy, West Point. The ceremony was performed by the chaplain, theRev. Fairfield Nelson Butt.
According to testimony in the High Court today, certain ballets scheduled for the Covent Garden opening Mondayhave been sold twice over.

The East Side Real Estate Brokers Soft Ball Association opened its 1938 season last week with a game at East End Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, in which the team of William A. White Sons defeated Douglas L. Elliman Co.,9 to 3. Clarke G. Dailey,
Principals-Joe Louis, Detroit, champion, vs, Max Schmeling, Germany, challenger. Title at Stake-World heavyweight championship. Date-Wednesday, June 22.
Retail liquor package store own ers endeavored to stimulate demand among consumers here last weekthrough direct mail advertising.

A breath-taking sight, now that the climbing roses are in bloom, is the little Flushing garden of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Smith. The term "a bower of roses" is usually employed in a figurative sense, but here one can apply it in its liberal meaning and still be guilty of understatement.

JUST outside of Greater New York lies a still greater New York, of which the average city resident is profoundly ignorant. Secluded in the valleys of northern Westchester and Putnam counties, landlocked by densely-wooded hills, the chain of lovely lakes which form the Croton watershed is New York's own Lake District rivaling in beauty its famous namesake yet lying within a radius of from thirty to sixty miles fromthe heart of the city.
Bernardino Molinari, director of the Augusteo concerts in Rome, conducted his third and last broadcast with the National Broadcasting Company Symphony Orchestralast night at Radio City.

THE current rage for biographies of periods with stabler standards and better manners is a reflex of times with a dislocated perspective. Physical science has so far outrun average human capacity that the machine which sets the pace has nine-tenths of the world spellbound and the remaining tenth driven back for comfort and things that made sense upon ages less hurried and more human.

The twentieth annual convention of the New York County Organization of the American Legion will be held on Wednesday and Thursday evenings at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-third Street. Six hundred and fifty-three delegates from 115 posts in thecounty are eligible to attend.

Stimulated by the-parkway, plaza and parking improvements being 'made along the Rockaway ocean frontage under the direction of Park Commissioner Moses, the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways reports that more than $100,000 is being spent at the present time on new buildings and improvements.

The first League of Nations activity which the United States Government en tered seriously was its anti-nar cotics work, for it seemed the farthest removed from politics. Since then the United States Government,
A minimum wage of $75 a month for WPA workers in this city was demanded yesterday by the Workers Alliance. The present minimumis $60.50.

ANGER signals are flying along the northern coast of Africa, where the colonial empires of France and Italy meet. The recent manoeuvres of Mussolini's Libyan army along the frontiers of French Tunisia may very likely have been a dress rehearsal for something more serious in the daysto come.
One hundred and twenty-five employes, left jobless by the precipitate departure of the press clipping bureau of Henry Romeike, Inc., for West New York, N. J., got theirfinal week's pay yesterday.

THE prize fight as an entertainment, like the ether itself, was recognized long before Marconi showed sci entists how to "stand the wireless egg on end." In fact, looking back through the records, the championship battle idea started in 1790 when Dan Mendoza, "the Spaniard," knocked out Dick Humphriesof Doncaster, England.

An invisible "third skin" for the hands to protect them against dirt, grease, paint, oil, ink or gasoline is the invention for which a patent (No. 2,120,569) has been granted toOsmer F. Oliver of Akron, Ohio.
A suggestion was presented by P. H. Parrott, Portland (Ore.) broker, at the Southwest regional convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in Salt Lake City,

In connection with its applications for unlisted trading in sixteen securities having an active primary market on the New York Stock Exchange or the New York Curb Exchange, the Boston Stock Exchange has filed with the Securities and Ex change Commission a brief stressing the need for obtaining the round-lot as well as the odd-lotprivilege.
Mayor La Guardia has asked the Federal Government for $153,000 in WPA funds to carry forward the work of the Mayor's Committee onProperty Improvement.
Commander Howard Douglas Bode, U. S. N., returned yesterday on the United States liner President Roosevelt after a three-month furlough during which he traveledfrom Shanghai by way of Europe,

To celebrate facts that have been before the public for half a century and that will shortly be seventy-five years old, a prodigious love feast in honor of Yvette Guilbert will be given at the Salle Pleyel here on Tuesdayevening, June 21.

Hollyrood Perry, owned and driven by Eugene Carpenter of this city, trotted to a brilliant victory over Sun Dial, 3-year-old star from the Newbrook Stables, in the matineefeature at Weequahic Park today.

The star, a fellow not unaware of himself, had consented to allow one of the other principals to use the No. 1 dressing room because the actor was required to make some very quickchanges.

A new home community is being opened in Nassau County, L. I., just beyond the.New York City line of Queens County, by Eli Tilles and Hyman Rosen, builders, who have recently completed a development project in Woodside and who have operated in Fiushing, Elmhurst andJamaica.

SCOUNTING provides boys with opportunities to serve othrs. Every Scout is pledged to do his best "to help other people at all times" and to observe the Scout law which requries him to do at least one "good turn" to somebody every day.

Colin J. Sabiston, chairman of the board of directors of the International Educational Publishing Company, died here this afternoon in the Mercy Hospital, to which institution he was taken last night. He was76 years old..

The Golden Bears of California rowed to three decisive victories over Cornell on Cayuga Lake today with their varsity setting a new course record for the three miles. The varsity, displaying power to spare at a low beat, swept to afive-length victory in 15:51.

BEFORE he went into pictures, Sam Levene had his own dress business and if you think he regrets it now, you ought to see him in the role of the shoestring producer in "Room Service" (at the Cort)--comfortably be yond the reach of the InternationalLadies' Garment Workers' Union.

Edgar J. Kaufmann, head of a group of Pittsburgh citizens, received word of the ratification by the national Jewish organizations, the American Jewish Committee, the American Jewish Congress, B'nal B'rith and the Jewish Labor Committee, of a resolution for a coordination plan adopted by their respective representatives at an all day conference held in this city Monday.

The Yankees' gay dash through the West was interrupted with a splash today when the Browns, with their left-handed Howie Mills on the mound, wrenched a 1-0 decision from a greatly astonished Lefty Gomez to bag the opening contest of the afternoon's scheduled double-header before a jubilant ladies' daygathering of 7,500.

Sam Houston, widely known bar-becue cook in the South, will arrive tomorrow from Montgomery, Ala., to prepare a barbecue for city officials as part of the celebration on. Wednesday to inaugurate the season of operettas at Randalls Island.

Striking employes of the Collier Service Corporation and three subsidiary companies chose the United Carders and Billposters Industrial Union, Local 811, C. I, 0., as their bargaining representative in a State Labor Relations Board election yesterday.

More than 2,500 persons, including notables of the screen and stage, attended a fashion show here this afternoon on the Henry Adams Ashforth estate, formerly the Milbank property. The event was a benefit for the Greenwich children's campfund.

Mr. and Mrs. C. R. Ashbee of Godden Green, Kent, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Christobel Ashbee, to Thornton Leigh Page, son of Professor Leigh Page of YaleUniversity and Mrs. Page.

Eight art scholarship and about ninety medals will be pre sented at the semi-annual exer cises of the School Art League. The ceremonies will be in the au ditorium of the Metropolitan Mu seum of Art at 3 o'clock on Friday afternoon.

Miss Eleanor Wynne of Long Beach today retired the Addie M. Babcock Memorial Challenge Tro phy, a prized event for junior riders on the opening program of the fifth annual Cedar Valley Horse Show. The exhibition is being presentedfor the benefit of Hope Farm.

With the thermometer slowly climbing, the United States Bureau of Home Economics has issued a bulletin telling housewives how to get the utmost refrigeration from their ice boxes. The coldest spot should be dedicated to dairy products and meat, the bureau says. In the old-fashioned ice box this is in line with the down current from the cake of ice in the back of the box.

Superior in virtually every department of the game, Harvard's well-balanced quartet swept to a 7-to-1 victory over Yale on Schley Field today to capture the intercollegiate outdoor polo championship for thesecond time in three years.

The thirtieth annual convention of the Federation of Polish Jews in America opened at the Hotel Scarboro here tonight with 300 delegates attending. Speakers included Benjamin Winter, president of the federation; Zelig Tygel, executive director, and Abraham I. Kandel, chairman of the convention committee.
Four seeded players moved with ease to day into the second round of the national clay court tennis tourna ment at the River Forest TenniClub.

LONDON. IN opening a new library at Liverpool University Earl Baldwin made an intimate personal confession which is of unusual literary interest. When, a year ago, he went out of office after a long period of continuous strain, he found that he had lost so much strength, physical and mental, that for months he feltunable even to read.

The United States Army has selected 2,300 young men, most of them residents of the metropolitan areas, to attend the Citizens Military Training Camp at Camp Dix, Wrightstown, N. J.- it was announced yesterday by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding theSecond Corps Area.

State unemployment insurance checks have put $41,508,805 into the pockets of more than 600,000 jobless New Yorkers since the beginning of the year, but tens of thousands still find their claims enmeshed in disputes and delays, a survey disclosed yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the courses which will be given at the Summer session, June 28 to July 27, at Pendle Hill, Wallingford, Pa., where a graduate center for religious and social study is maintainedby the Society of Friends.

A bank merger was announced today in the local edition of the Voelkischer Beobachter involving the Zentral Europaeische Laenderbank, the Austrian branch of the Czechoslovak Zivnostenska Banka and the Mercurbank.

A committee of judges of the first Macy Thanksgiving Day Parade feature Contest, conducted by Macy's department store, has selected the first, second and third-place winners. The contest ended June 4. Honorable mention prize winnerswill be announced at a later date.
PARIS. WE open the newspaper. "Can ton was bombarded," we read. "There are about 1,500 victims." We sigh, yawn, turn the page, read another report: "The little town ofGranollers in Spain * * *"

Fitzgerald Hall of Nashville, Tenn., president of the Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis Railroad, said today that the railway industry "is as a whole about to go to the wall" because "certain labor union leaders and politicians have tried to do things that would make inevitable government ownershipand operation."
The Glen Riddle Farm's War Admiral and C. S. Howard's Seabiscuit today drew top weight of 130 pounds in the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap' at Suffolk Downs onJune 29.

FINDING of the lost TWA airliner near Yosemite, Calif., last week brought to an end three and one-half months of suspense suffered by officials of the airline and by relatives of the ninepersons aboard.

A plea for adherence to the traditional belief in education, unadulterated by the demand of the business world, was made by Judge Learned Hand of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in an address today before 1,200 guests at the annual alumni banquet at Amherst College.

ALTHOUGH the mere quantity of concerts during a single New York season is by no means a complete measure of that season's achievements, it is at least a contributing factor and,for concert hall managers,

A woman and eight men were convicted in General Sessions just before midnight last night in the $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy in Suffolk County, L. I. Another woman and a man werefound not guilty by the jury.
THE stern-wheelers which ply our inland waters are taking vacationists on leisurely trips this Summer; not for years has 01' Man River offered so richa fare.

More than 3,500 owners of independent retail grocery stores will attend the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers of the United States, opening in Cincinnati tomorrow and continuing through Thursday. Discussions of the proposed Federal chain store tax, Fair Trade Acts, price wars and the technique of merchandising quick frozen foods are expected to feature the convention.
Mrs. Woodin Miner of 2 East Sixty-seventh Street, New York, and Dune House, East Hampton, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Woodin Miner, to William Hamilton Phipps.

AR HARBOR, Me.-Extensive yachting activity n the waters of Mount Desert Island is expected this season. Plans are being made for races between the Northeast Harbor fleet, the Long Island fleet and the Eastern Yacht Club of Marblehead, the races probably to be started themiddle of July.

Twenty-two events will comprise the program of the ninth annual horse show of the Bronxville Riding Club, which is to start at 11:15 o'clock this morning at Tuckahoe. Special jumping and horsemanship classes as well as several sweepstakes have been scheduled.

The vacation Max Schmeling has been enjoying of late ended today when the ex-heavyweight champion of the world resumed his boxing chores. For the first time since Wednesday the German's training schedule included something more than road work, and the news that he was to go into the ring attracted a crowd of more than 2,000 fans from thesurrounding countryside.

THIS is Erskine Caldwell's fourth volume of short stories, and it is by far his weakest. There is no single story here that can compare to "Candy-Man Beechum" as a fine, terse folk tale, to "Kneel to the Rising Sun" as biting social tragedy, or to "The People's Choice" as solidnative American humor.

Track and Field--Glenn Cunningham won the mile run in 4:07.2 at the Princeton invitation meet yesterday, but lost in the three-quarter-mile event to Wayne Rideout, Texas star, who set a new world record of 3:00.3.

United States Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, it was learned yesterday, will act as attorney for Austin Furey and William Campbell, Delegates of Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers of America at their forth-coming trial under the Anti-Racketeering Act.
A somewhat better undertone ruled among the main body of rail road issues yesterday in an extraordinarily dull session on the New York Stock Exchange.

Following a study by traffic experts of the Police Department, Commissioner Valentine designated yesterday 240 streets, avenues and other public thoroughfares in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond as "special zones" where qualified personsmay learn to drive automobiles.
Perhaps the most promising attack on the problem of safer highways, from a long-range point of view, is the ever widening campaign of education in safedriving directed at American youth.

FURNITURE design and interior decoration, almost as sensitive to style influences as dresses are, echo this season a perceptible interest in the art of the Swedes and theirearly settlements in this country.

Ferns, palms and white Spring flowers provided a decorative back-ground in St. Paul's Church here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Marjorie Kenyon to Richard Channing Moore, grandson of the late Colonel T. W. C. Moore, U.S.A., who served on General Sheridan's staff during the Civil War.

Thirteen art and music courses are being offered by the Summer Session of Hunter College this year, putting special emphasis on appreciation, according to an announcement by Professor a. Broderick Cohen, director of the Evening and Extension Division at Hunter.
BOLTON LANDING.-About 350 members will attend the sixtieth annual convention of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association beginning today at the Hotel Sagamore and continuingthrough Wednesday.

His face wearing a typical scowl, his fighting ire aroused in flashes, Joe Louis today went through four rounds of sparring as the feature of his next to last training workout for the defense of his world heavyweight title against Max Schmeling-and didn't look atall impressive.

" New Jersey retail business was very good last week," G. E. Wilson, president of the Retail Merchants Association of New Jersey, said in a statement issued today from the organization's headquarters in Newark.

The Wages and Hours Bill leaves control over minimum wages and maximum hours of intrastate retailers with the States, according to the analysis of the measure, issued yesterday by the AmericanRetail Federation.

Making his first racing start since he laid up the America's Cup defender, Ranger, last year, Harold S. Vanderbilt returned a winner today in the championship regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, and he sailed the oldest sloop in the class against her newer sisters, one of,which was launched onlyon Thursday.

The New York Young Men's Christian Association has obtained a State license for its trade and technical school, Edgar M. Stover, educational director, announced yesterday. Under the law approved last year by Governor Lehman, the Commissioner of Education is given the authority to determine the standards and practices of privatetrade schools in the State.
The Kansas City stockyards rate case which recently involved Secretary Wallace and Chief Justice Hughes in a legal feud, may find itself back in the Supreme Cout.

Opposition to the use of the public library as a "pawn" of either the public school system or of organized labor was expressed by Dr. Milton James Ferguson of Brooklyn in his inaugural address as president of the American Library Association thismorning.

The arrival in London of former Premier George Tatarescu of Rumania and Sir Reginald Hoare, British Minister to Bucharest, aroused speculation today over possible important British-Rumanian economic andpolitical negotiations.

Bravo, 4-year-old son of Volomite, owned by George F. Benham of Cedarhurst, L. I., and driven by 'his son-in-law, Harry Whitney, trotted a mile in 2:041/2, the fastest of the season, to win the featureevent at Good Time Park today.

THERE is one particular in which fashion bears no possible resemblance to spinach: fashion is always interesting. It is so interesting that books abot it--whether history or comment--are virtually sure to make good reading, no matter how many such books there may be.

David J. Balkert, 29 years old, an official of the Fifth Avenue Hotel in New York, and Walter McClus key, 24, of Toms River, a chauffeur, were rescued from the sea here this afternoon by James Wartham, graduate student of Princeton University.

A NATIONAL campaign of free safety-check service which covers all of the danger spots of the automobile was announced last week as a part of the safety crusade now being conducted by the Tide Water Associated Oil Company.

Head Football Coach Earl Blaik, his assistants, Harry Ellinger and Andrew Gustafson, and Trainer Rolan Bevan have signed five-year contracts with the Dartmouth Athletic Council, William H. McCarter, graduate manager of athletics, announced today.

Miss Dorothy Provence Mullins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Walker Mullins of this city and Woodstock. Vt., was married at noon yesterday to Edward Morton Holland in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Miss Eleanor J. Mixsell, daughter of Mrs. Austin D. Mixsell of this city and the late Mr. Mixsell, who was a vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Company, was married here today in the Pro-Cathedral of the Nativity to Stuart E. Hockenburg,

Buying enthusiasm in wheat ebbed rapidly today, and with further profit-taking by longs, increased hedging pressure, and only a limited outside demand, prices sagged throughout the session. The lowest prices for theday were recorded near the close.
Miss Margaret Bair of Williamsport, Pa., and Clay A. Nice, nephew of Governor Harry W. Nice, were married today. The Governor and Mrs. Nicewere present.

Miss Jeanee Jackson Kennard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Mortimer Kennard of this palce, was married this evening to A. Gardiner Layng, os of Mr. and Mrs. John Mortgue Layng of Montclair. The ceremony took place in Christ Episcopal Church of Bloomfield and Glen Ridge with the rector, the Rev. John James Kirkpatrick officiating.
The remodeling work on the former three-story studio building at 746 Madison Avenue, near Sixty-fifth Street, has been completed and the structure is ready for occupancy.

Summer homes in the South Shore colonies of Lawrence, Hewlett and Woodmere were filled with house parties today and last night and many large luncheons were given before the Spring race program of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association this afternoon on the turf course of the Rockaway HuntingClub here.
Lela Hanover, trotting mare owned by Horace Conover of North Plain-field, annexed top honors in the featured Class A trot or pace at theBorough Park track today.

At the close of his first term in Congress, Bruce Barton took a look at his job and found it good. Being an advertising man and an inspirational author, the most celebrated new member of the House has atendency to look at the sunny side.

Buying enthusiasm in wheat ebbed rapidly today, and with further profit-taking by longs, increased hedging pressure, and only a limited outside demand, prices sagged throughout the session. The lowest prices for theday were recorded near the close.

Miss Jeanee Jackson Kennard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Mortimer Kennard of this palce, was married this evening to A. Gardiner Layng, os of Mr. and Mrs. John Mortgue Layng of Montclair. The ceremony took place in Christ Episcopal Church of Bloomfield and Glen Ridge with the rector, the Rev. John James Kirkpatrick officiating.
The remodeling work on the former three-story studio building at 746 Madison Avenue, near Sixty-fifth Street, has been completed and the structure is ready for occupancy.

Cruising yachtsmen are beginning to amend an age-old query and ask each other "what is so rare as a sunny day in June?" But because cold weather and rain are bound to stop some time-at least they always have-it wouldn't be surprising this year to see the coming week-end extended over to include Monday.There's a good and sensible reason.
Aviation authorities announced tonight that France would start the first trial flight next month to explore a route for Paris-New York air service.
One of the consequences of the clash of idealisms and races in Europe has been a growing increase in the amount of written propaganda flooding newspaper offices here.

The Yankee Stadium is slowly drifting into the orbit of German fight fans, but speculation on the outcome of Wednesday's heavyweight championship bout between Max Schmeling and Joe Louis is still chiefly confined to the professional fraternity.
The bill for the organization of France in time of war, passed by the Senate and Chamber of Deputies before adjournment yesterday,

Mayor La Guardia, in a letter to William G. Fullen yesterday, called to the attention of the chairman of the Transit Commission that Frederic W. Frost, 15 South Bay Avenue, Amityville, L. I., is both an inspector of buses at $2,900 for the commission and also a justice of the peace at home at a salary of$2,700.

The award of Charles Hayden scholarships at New York University to 104 young men of "exceptional ability" from New York and vicinity was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

A total of $2,125,000 has been contributed to date by 1,100 communities in the United States and Canada in the Spring phase of the 1938 national campaign for $5,100,000 of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national campaign chairman, announced yesterday. The money will be used to aid distressed Jews of Eastern and Central Europe.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,939,943,450. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

The pennant-bound Newark Bears extended their victory streak to eleven games by conquering the Montreal Royals today in both ends of a double-header, 6 to 3 and 10 to 5. Newark now has won twentytwo of its last twenty-five starts.
Two survivors of the wreck of the Milwaukee Railroad's Olympian told of their experiences as follows:

India was described as a dark prison-house of sin, but one into which the light of Christian religion finally was penetrating, by the Rev. A. F. Schmitthenner, missionary to India, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway at Ninety-third Street.

Four pavilions, dominated by a 100-foot illuminated tower, will be built by Standard Brands, Inc., at the New York World's Fair, according to announcement issued for publication today by Thomas L. Smith, president. Construction work is scheduled to start within a few days.

The Senators climbed back to the first division of the American League today, defeating the Tigers, 10 to 6. A six-run blast in the first gave the Senators a lead the Tigers were unable to overcome, despite home runs by Don Ross and Rudy York.
The stock markets continue slack, partly because of important social functions, and business is mainly in gilt-edge and gold mine securities.

All good things must come to an end, so Debs Garms, Bees' third baseman, picked out a nice two-and-one ball and slashed a clean single to short left centerfield with one out in the fourth inning today to end young Johnny Vander Meer's-sensational string of hitless innings at 21 2-3.

The charge that a stream of "unregenerate ministers, equipped only with a mild enthusiasm for the social teachings of Jesus and a pleasant personality," is being poured into the various Protestant denominations by "modernistic seminaries" was made yesterday by the Rev. John H. McComb, the pastor, in his sermon in the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street.

A complaint has been issued by the Federal Trade Commission charging the K K Supply Company, Inc., 146 Chambers Street, New York, with unfair competition in connection with the interstate sale of bicycles which it allegedly assembled from frames and parts imported from Japan and from other parts manufactured in the United States.
Germany's crop-condition report for June 1 shows that Winter wheat and Winter rye are somewhat better than on June 1 of last year, but the weather improvement had less effeet than had been expected.

Activity in the grain pits on the Board of Trade here last week was much larger than in the preceding week, but was still much smaller than a year ago. Interest centered mainly in wheat, but the corn trade broadened considerably, especially late in the week when there was free buying of the December delivery on unfavorable weather over the Corn Belt.

Miss Mildred Price Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Evans Smith, was married here yesterday at the home of her parents to Furman Joseph Finck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Finck of Glenolden. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Clement W. De Chant of the Reformed Church here.

The Olympian Special of the Milwaukee Railroad is the oldest through train from Chicago to the Northern Pacific Coast. Since its first run in 1911 it has carried hundreds of thousands of passengers West to Seattle and Taeoma.

Trading in stocks here this week was abnormally dull and prices were lower for the most part. Although the annual reports of the Hapag and North German Lloyd lines and the Karstadt Department Store were received favorably and some dividend increases were announced, professionals as well as outsiders held aloof from the market and the smallest offers caused declines.

Cardinal Hayes presided at solemn high mass yesterday in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the death of the Rev. John C. Drumgoole, founder of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, a home for dependent boys and girls at Mount Loretto, S. I.

John W. Hicks, father of John W. Hicks Jr., vice president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., in charge of foreign distribution, died on Saturday at his home in Sedalia, Mo., at the age of 75, according to word received here yesterday.

The Rev. J. Elmer Cates, pastor of Calvary Methodist Church, 1,885 University Avenue, the Bronx, in his sermon yesterday morning replied to what he termed an "attack" on the Protestant churches a week ago by Mgr. J. F. A. McIntyre, chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York.
A new purge of considerable severity has been begun in Ukraine, where anti-Soviet sentiment and activity have been Intensely stubborn since the first days of the revolution.

Unemployment insurance laws provide even less protection for the jobless than "totally inadequate" home relief, the American Association for Social Security reported yesterday after a nation-wide survey of the operation of State unemployment insurance systems.
Baccalaureate Sunday at Smith College today included a service, at which President Neilson addressed the seniors; two special services in the new chapel, two musical programs and two receptions.

Savings banks disposed of houses on the upper West Side and in Harlem in deals announced over the week-end. The Franklin Savings Bank sold to Irving Krauss for altering into apartments the four-story dwelling on a lot 16.8 by 100 feet at 214 West Seventy-eighth Street.

The French wholesale price index for May was 643, compared to 619 for April and to 529 in May, 1937. The index for retail prices in the Paris region was 698 in May, compared to 691 in April and to 586 in May, 1937.
The new $115,000 building of the Deborah Sanatorium conducted here by the Deborah Jewish Tuberculosis Society was dedicated today in the presence of 1,000 perSons.
A reception and entertainment in honor of Alexander Granach, distinguished.actor of the German and Soviet Russian stage and screen, was given last night at the New School for Social Research. Mr.

The National Salesmen's Crusade, based on the theory that "Sales Mean Jobs," will get under way in Chicago on Tuesday when about 1,500 Chicago business leaders and sales executives will hold a luncheon meeting in the Stevens Hotel.
President James K. McConaughy in his baccalaureate address to Wesleyan seniors today criticized Jersey City's program as "a gravel menace to American ideals and freedom." He added,

Representatives of sixty Roman Catholic parishes in the Bronx attended the fifth arinual Eucharistic rally of the Bronx Nocturnal Adoration Society yesterday afternoon on the quadrangle of Fordham University.

In a match filled with sparkling skirmishes, Mrs. Richard Stark of New York, the former Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles, defeated Mrs. Carolyn Swartz Hirsch of Scarsdale, also an erstwhile Californian, to win the New York State tennis championship yesterday.

The celebration of the 250th anniversary of the founding of New Rochelle by the Huguenots closed today when Vice Mayor Erik Morch of La Rochelle, France, laid a wreath on the World War memorial on East Main Street.

As a result of extremely poor demand abroad for Netherland Indian kapok, the Department of Commerce has announced, the Netherland Kapok Manufacturing Association, meeting in Samarang, Java, recently petitioned the government of Netherland India to buy $1,110,000 of the 1937-38 crop which had not been sold.

The Public Utility Holding Company Act does not mean a "death sentence" or "dictatorship" for the public utility industry or the utility holding company, but marks "a return to old-fashioned American conservatism and fair dealing from which we strayed in the roaring twenties," Robert E. Healy, member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, asserted in a statement today.

The New York Board of Trade made public yesterday a resolution it is sending to the Constitutional Convention at Albany expressing its opposition to the proposed establishment of a single house, or unicameral, legislature. The resolution asserted that "property rights and social rights are more secure under a system of checks and balances."

John M. Franklin, chairman of the maritime division of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday that the shipping industry operating in and out of New York Harbor was organized for solicitation by fund workers and that $22,000 had been contributed to date by maritime interests.

Unfavorable weather for the corn crop and generally smaller country offerings of that grain recently, braced the corn market to some extent last week, giving the market an independently strong tone for the last few days.
A 10.7 per cent increase in employment and an 8.8 per cent rise in payrolls were reported today for New York's construction industry in May by State Industrial. Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.

Dr. John R. Mott of New York returned to Cornell today on the fiftieth anniversary of his graduation to preach a baccalaureate sermon, urging the class of '38 to follow the lead of Jesus Christ "in seeking to augment the leadership of the constructive forces of the world."
Flags in the town here were flown at half-staff today in respect to United States Senator Royal S. Copeland, whose body lay in state at his home here and was viewed by neighbors and friends.

The Jewish Council of Greater New York ratified at its ninth annual meeting yesterday in the Park Central Hotel the resolution adopted in Pittsburgh last week, proposing that four national organizations, the American Jewish Committee, the American Jewish Congress, the B'nai B'rith and the Jewish Labor Committee, coordinate their activities in defense of Jewish- rights, wherever they are threatened.
Under a barrage of tear gas and swinging riot sticks, 500 jobless men, who had been camped almost a month in Vancouver's Postoffice and Civic Art Gallery, were ejected by police early today.

The annual Flag Day program of the Queens County Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars, was participated in by about 1,000 members of veteran organizations and their auxiliaries yesterday afternoon on the parade grounds at Fort Totten, Bayside.

John Morrison, veteran of the labor movement, died yesterday at his home, 585 West End Avenue, at the age of 74. A friend of the late Samuel Gompers, Mr. Morrison was president of the Carpet Weavers International Union in the Eighteen Eighties.

Former Magistrate. Hyman J. Reit, chairman of the American Pro-Falasha Committee, will visit Italian colonial officials in Rome next month in an attempt to arrange for a continuation of the welfare and educational work undertaken by the committee on behalf of Jews in Ethiopia.

Five government executives, who are directing the expenditures of billions of dollars directly or indirectly as part of the Administration's recovery and relief program, told how they believe the spending of this money will benefit the country in a symposium broadcast tonight over the Mutual System.
Four men returning from a Gulf Coast fishing trip were killed today when their airplane crashed into a thick forest near here during a heavy rainstorm. All were from Greenwood, Miss.
While the French press was publishing accounts of a renewed wave of antiSemitism in Berlin, France made an official demonstration of tolerance and good-will toward the Jewish people today.

President Clarence A. Dykstra of the University of Wisconsin declared last night at the annual alumni-senior banquet that he was not looking for another job. "I say to you that I shall devote myself as wholeheartedly and as industriously as I know how to this institution, perhaps for the indefinite future," he said.

Robert Maisel. in 116 E. 63d St.: Mrs. Martha Bernheim. in 64 E. 86th St.; Samuel t A. Herzog, broker. Mrs. Sidney C. Lee, in 169 E. 69th St.; Charles G. King 3d, in 333 E. 37th St.; d Walter Samuels, Inc., brokers.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Jenkins Foster, daughter of Mrs. John R. Foster and the late Mr. Foster, to Shattuck Weston Osborne of West Newton.
According to The London Spectator, what finally brought Germany up with a round turn in Central Europe was a railway

Two Cunard White Star liners arrived yesterday and docked at the foot of West Fourteenth Street after being delayed by fog. The Scythia from Liverpool was six hours late. The Georgic from the Channel ports was delayed three hours.

Unless present plans are changed, the next Olympiad, the twelfth in modern times, will be held near Tokyo in September, 1940, with American athletes competing under the auspices of the American Olympic Committee.

Announcement was made here today of the engagement of Miss Charlotte Eugenia Conway, daughter of Mrs. Lysander B. Conway, to Dr. Frank J. Curran of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Curran of Minneapolis.

Captain Bob Bartlett sailed from New York yesterday on his twelfth annual expedition to Greenland and Polar regions. On his Gloucester fishing schooner, the Effie Morrissey, he took with him eleven college students, a crew of twelve, and a cow for his mother in Newfoundland.

The present condition of the Jewish population of Vienna and the sad fate almost certainly awaiting the Jews still left are discussed by a correspondent of The Times of London in a long article that naturally bears no dateline. Although acknowledging that
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James F.Garrett of Cranford, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Marilyn Garrett, to Richard W. Baker of the same town.
TO THE EDITOR OF TEE NEW YORK TIMES: In connection with the discussion of' wiretapping, reference is made to a speech by Macaulay in the House of Commons June 24, 1844:

A novel track and field meet was conducted by the East Flatbush Community Council yesterday afternoon on the grounds of Samuel J. Tilden High School, Tilden Avenue and East Fifty - seventh Street, Brooklyn.
Despite all denials, the question of dollar devaluation has continued to hold the conversational spotlight in financial circles here, and there certainly was some gold buying in France this week.

Joe Moore stumbled as he was carrying in what would have been the winning run in the tenth inning of the first game of yesterday's double-header at the Polo Grounds. The Giants tripped right over him and dropped both end of the twin bill to the suddenly rampant Cardinals.
The money market here was dull last week and closed liquid, with a demand for Gold Discount Bank promissory notes. The rate today on day-today loans was 2 7/8 to 3 1/8 per cent.

WHEN and if, ten, twenty, thirty years from now, some one consults a descriptive bibliography of the works of Kenneth Roberts, he will no doubt find the item called "Trending Into Maine"* listed under the heading Non-Fiction, Very Minor. Constant Reader rather enjoyed it,

The Australian trade delegation headed by Sir Earle Page, Deputy Prime Minister, now in London negotiating with the British Government for a new trade treaty, will come to Canada in July, it was announced here tonight.

" Education at its best and its most is no solo of individual ability and achievement, but a symphony of shared experience, whose genius is its reconciliation of variety and harmony," Dr. Charles W. Gilkey, dean of the Chicago University Chapel, told the baccalaureate audience in the Wellesley College Memorial Chapel this morning.

" You looked swell in there today, Joe. How did you feel?" Joe Louis was thus congratulated and queried this afternoon when the world heavyweight champion, with four brisk though abbreviated rounds of sparring, closed his training for the defense of his title Wednesday night against Max Schmeling, German ex-champion, in the Yankee Stadium.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.0, which compares with 80.7 a week ago, 80.5 two weeks ago, 80.8 three weeks ago and 81.4 four weeks ago.

Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader, and Frank C. Walker, former chairman of the National Emergency Council, were mentioned yesterday as possibilities for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Royal S. Copeland.

May trade in Great Britain averaged lower than in April and the general trend was downward. Declines were the rule in textile exports, and of a total decline in manufactured exports of [Pound]3,735,000 compared to 1937, textiles alone accounted for [Pound]3,383,000, the heaviest shrinkage being in cotton goods.

Stocks irregularly lower, in smallest weekly turnover since July, 1921; turnover, 1,792,530 shares. United States Government issues generally higher; rail bonds down to new lows; other loans Irregular.; transactions, $25,184,775.

After being in litigation for eleven years, the $42,000,000 estate of Henry E. Huntington, railroad man and philanthropist, was closed by the Probate Court with a final accounting filed by counsel for Mrs. Caroline H. Holladay, a sister, and the Security First National Bank, the executors.

F. Nathaniel Currier of Maplewood, head of an engineering equipment business with offices at 39 Cortlandt Street, New York, died suddenly of a heart attack shortly before noon today while playing tennis on the private court of J. Ward Woolley of 677 Prospect Street. His age was 49.

Major Arthur G. Hilliard, New Jersey National Guard Medical Corps officer and a former practicing Trenton (N. J.) physician, died here today at the age of 50. He saw overseas service with the Twentieth Machine Gun Battalion, Seventh Division, A. E. F., and was commissioned a captain before the armistice.

Dr. Nelson Hume, for the twentythree years of its life headmaster of Canterbury School a private Catholic preparatory school for boys at New Milford, Conn., has had conferred upon him by Pope Pius XI the honor of Knight of the Order of St. Gregory the Great.

Rochester opened a four-game series with Jersey City today by winning a double-header, 4 to 3 and 3 to 1. The Little Giants outhit the Red Wings, 13 to 9, in the opener, but were unable to come through in the pinches. Rollie Stiles started,

The appointment of Kenneth F. Sutherland, Democratio leader of the Coney Island district for many years, as general clerk of the Supreme Court in Kings County at $9,000 a year by the Board of Justices was denounced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in a letter to Justice Charles B. Sears, chairman of the Committee on Judiciary of the Constitutional Convention.

Without calling time out for the Summer, the Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixty-seventh Street, will start its third season tomorrow afternoon when it opens a preview of its thirty-first exhibition by resident artists.

Play for the Meadow Brook Club cups and the annual twenty-goal championship got under way today, with Templeton, East Williston and the Gulf Stream riders registering victories in the three matches. contested.

More than 151,600 claims totaling $5,055,560.33 had been certified for old age insurance payments by the end of May, the Social Security Board said today. During --May 17,311 claims were certified, totaling about $806,091.48.
Five Arabs and two Jews were killed today in village raids. A band entered an Italian mission at Jaffa and beat and robbed a priest.

Immediate intensification of the joint efforts by the city and the Transit Commission to put through a unification of rapid-transit lines under municipal ownership and control will be the first result of the ruling made on Saturday by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson, giving the receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company the right to disaffirm the company's 999-vear lease of its elevated lines.
The Yankees strove for nearly six hours today to impress their importance as world champions upon the tail-end Browns, only to finish with a total loss to show for all their tremendous exertion.
Mayor Hague's court testimony last week at least made more explicit than before the grounds on which he thinks his suppression of free speech in Jersey City can be defended. "Communists," radicals...

Only if economic freedom can be provided for a large percentage of the population without creating economic and industrial anarchy will a renewed faith in democracy arise, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, declared this afternoon in his baccalaureate sermon before 850 seniors and their relatives and friends in the memorial church.

A letter received at Kalimpong, India, from the British party attempting to climb Mount Everest stated that W. H. Tilman, leader of the group, three other climbers and four porters were nearly caught in an avalanche.
Twenty-five new airplanes, seven of them multi-motored ships, were exhibited today at the annual air demonstration and show at the Long Island Aviation Country Club here.

Bullish sentiment in wheat was modified late last week, and prices suffered a sharp reaction from the recent tops. The market in the last few days was extremely choppy, and, at best levels, prices were as much as 15 cents above the low points of two weeks ago.
Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, is to arrive today from London on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Among other passengers on the liner are:
Labor experts said today that the present unsettled economic conditions would help to ease the strain of the new Wage and Hour Law upon industry. Here is how they sized up the situation:

Harry J. Laragh, lawyer and former Corporation Counsel who was the Republican nominee for Mayor of Yonkers in 1931, died this afternoon at his home here after a tenday illness. His age was 51. Mr. Laragh was the brother-in-law of County Judge Frank Coyne of Westchester County Court.

In several directions, last week's industrial reports produced slight changes for the better. They were slight, but attracted notice because interrupting a downward trend. Production of power, lumber and motor cars shared in this.

Erich Eliskases of Vienna today regained the lead in the international chess masters tournament by winning his - game in the eighth round from Paul Schmidt of Estonia. Eliskases, who has an adjourned game from the seventh round, played the queen's gambit.

Designation of thirty-five students at City College as research investigators in problems of city government was announced yesterday by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation. His plan to appoint these interness in public service" had been announced several weeks ago.

Yachting parties desiring to attend the performances of GalloSchubert operettas at Randall's Island this Summer may land from their launches at the Marine Dock of the New York River Police at the west end of the island. A dock at the powerhouse is available to persons arriving by seaplane.

An indictment and a defense of Mayor Frank Hague's actions in denying permits to political opponents for public meetings in Jersey City were delivered last night by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, and John A. Matthews,

The annual pilgrimage to the grave of President Theodore Rooseevlt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery here was made today by members of the Nassau County Veterans of Foreign Wars and the Army and Navy Legion of Valor.
Allan A. Ryan Jr., grandson of Thomas Fortune Ryan, may become a candidate for office on the Republican ticket in the Fall campaign, it was reported here today.

The Rev. Thomas F. Maher, C. N., former dean of the College of Arts and Sciences of St. John's University, died last night in St. Catherine's Hospital, Brooklyn, of heart disease, after an illness of fifteen months that began with a stroke. He was 44 years old.

Where To, 8-year-old bay gelding owned and ridden by Robert Lee Henry of New York, took the blue ribbon in the featured open hunter event at the sixth annual Lawrence Farms amateur horse show today. Where To was third in the working hunter division and fourth in the open jumping.

Individual application of the Beatitudes contained in the Sermon on the Mount and the "seven corporal works of - mercy" enumerated by Christ would rid the world of the troubles which new leaders, dictators and "modern thinkers" vainly and belligerently strive to remedy,
All forty-four of the ocean-going yachts entered for the race to Bermuda that starts on Tuesday afternoon were at anchor here tonight.

Miss Roberta McDougall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lorne McDougall of Ottawa, was married to Paul Mason, assistant on the staff of the British High Commissioner in Canada and former secretary to Sir Samuel Hoare, British Cabinet Minister, yesterday at the home of the bride's parents.

Premier Daladier asserts that it is indispensable to increase French production, and consequently the number of hours worked. Leon Jouhaux, leader of the trade unions, who represents French workers at the International Labor Bureau in Geneva, also has said that if other countries refused to adopt the forty-hour week, France could not subject herself alone to this imitation.

Chachani, the 21,000-foot volcano near Arequipa has claimed another victim. Two Germans, accompanied by a guide, climbing the volcano, camped the first night just below the snowline, continuing the following day to the summit.
Financiers and the trade press here are discussing the United States business outlook mainly from the point of view of the political position at the close of Congress.

After beginning poorly, the week ended on a better tone here. Feelings were much calmer about Czechoslovakia, where the air has cleared still further, while the latest news from Spain affords hope that the war there will end sooner than was expected.

A display of rare Bibles from the collection of the General Theological Seminary and a sermon on the history of the English Bible commemorated yesterday the 400th anniversary of the order by which an English Bible was set up in every church in England for the use of the people.

In line with the recent action of the Allied Printing Trades Council of Greater New York, objecting to the encroachment of the Newspaper Guild on the mechanical departments of newspapers Typographical Union No. 6, at a-meeting yesterday in Stuyvesant High School, First Avenue and Fifteenth Street,

Frank Buck, 53 years ola, ana Nathan Nesselowitz, 46, both of 146 Myrtle Avenue, were critically burned early today when an explosion occurred in the kitchen of Buck's apartment. Both men were removed to the Medical Center with second and third degree burns of the face, body and back.

Moreland's Maid, last year's national champion saddle horse, captured the Troy Horse Show title today. The mare, owned by Mr. and Mrs. L. Victor Weil of Elberon, N. J., won the Bonesteel Challenge Trophy, with Wild Honey, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Reed A. Albee of Larchmont. an resp.rvt chamnion.
The Rev. D. Wilmot Gateson, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Saviour, sought today in a baccalaureate address to tell seniors of Drexel Institute of Technology "how to get a job."
Senator William G. McAdoo said in an address here today that the "misuse of economic. power is the greatest single menace to the security of the nation."

-Don Budge of the United States was favored and forgotten today as Mrs. Helen Wills Moody's imperiled comeback dominated the preliminaries to the opening of the Wimbledon tennis championships tomorrow.

The subject of housing will be dealt with in two books soon to be published. First to appear will be "The Challenge of Housing," by Langdon W. Post, former chairman of the New York City Housing Authority. Farrar Rinehart will publish it on Thursday.
Six thousand members of various Nationald Socialist party organizations paraded in the Ringstrasse today to celebrate the fifth anniversary of the Austrian prohibition of the party.
Thomas Hand Ball, a manufacturer and broker of worsted yarns for many years, died today at his home in Mount Airy after a week's illness. He was 75 years old.

One ill-advised play probably. prevented the Babe Ruth-coached Dodgers from winning a doubleheader before a crowd of 28,013 at Ebbets Field yesterday and running the Cubs' losing streak to six straight. As it was, the Dodgers

The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that Dr. Harold E. Vokes, assistant curator of invertebrate palaeontology, and William 0. Sweet of Harvard University had left on a two-month fossil-collecting tour through the Middle Western, Western and Southwestern States.
A definite trend among manufacturers to give retailers more latitude in the use of advertising allowances is now developing, according to the sales manager of a large department store.
Although outhit, 12-5, the New York A. C. baseball team conquered the New York Police Department, 7-4, at Travers Island yesterday.
Anglo-German trade negotiations, which were deadlocked in Berlin a fortnight ago, will be resumed in London this week, it was learned tonight.

Youth must bring the philosophy of intelligence and generous goodwill into the fields of national and international affairs unless its generation-is to become "engulfed in disaster," Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University, declared at the baccalaureate service today.

Up in New England they have a number of "still" fishermen, those members of the old school who regard fishing as a contemplative pastime. With this group there is none of the bustle and excitement which are so much a part of the sport of the ardent trout and bass angler.
The conflict between the Confessional Synods and the State church authorities is rapidly heading to an impasse destined to leave the Evangelical church situation in a state of complete chaos.

Iugh Rankin, a retired railroad financial commentator, died here yesterday in a sanitarium after a long illness. He was born fifty-seven years ago at Nassau, N. Y., a son of the late Rev. Isaac Ogden Rankin and Martha Clark Rankin, and a descendant of early settlers of this part of the State.

At least thirty persons were killed and sixty-five injured early today when the Milwaukee Railroad's crack Olympian passenger train plunged through a flood-weakened bridge into an Eastern Montana creek. About ten persons were missing.

Frank Magini, 28 years old, an unemployed pressman of 652 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, who robbed a store of candy, cigarettes and soda water Friday morning and left a note identifying himself, was held in $5,000 bail for the grand jury yesterday by Magistrate Edgar Bromberzer.
It would probably be a good thing if every permanent resident of New York City could have a two weeks' vacation in the country. Since this isn't yet

America must experience a religious revival if it is to avoid a dictatorship such as obtains in certain foreign countries, the Rev. Dr. J. Frank Norris, "flying pastor," who commutes by plane between two Baptist Fundamentalist churches in Detroit and Fort Worth, Texas, declared yesterday afternoon at an evangelical mass meeting in Car- tio negie Hall.
President Roosevelt's efforts to pull the United States out of the depression are being closely watched here, and it is assumed that pump-priming is to be applied vigorously.

A great deal of unfavorable propaganda is being spread against the Jews in this country, as well as abroad, Samuel Goldstein. Grand Master of the Independent Order of Brith Abraham, said in opening' the fifty-first annual convention here today.
Henry Wilder Keyes, former Governor of New Hampshire and former United States Senator, died today at his estate in North Haverhill after an illness of five weeks. He was 76 years old.
H. R. Kester, advertising manager of The Miles City (Mont.) Star, was one of the first to view the Olympian wreck from the air. Here is his account of the disaster.

Gold imports in May amounted to [pouns]27,437,216, against [pound]20,587,989 in April and [Pound]11,725,575 in May, 1937, while exports were [pound]7,813,313, against 38 [Pound]9,910,586 a month before and [pound]21,658,848 a year before.
State and church officials in Mexico have come to a mutual understanding that -all problems and difficulties between them i the future will be discussed in an amicable manner.
It is believed here that France and Britain will make a joint announcement tomorrow concerning the bombing of civilian population.

William St, 264, 18.10x72.2; exers will of Frances Commlossy to Francisco S, Esquiaga, 53 Cherry St: consideration, $2,500. Ludlow St, 52, 20x87.6; Beckie Warshawsky to Esther Bernstein, 52 Ludlow St; mtg, L $10,000 ($1).

Motorists were warned today by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, regarding "faked" lenses for headlamps on automobiles, the use of which, he said, not only causes headlamps to glare badly but subjects the owner to arrest for operating a car with improper lights.

Alms-giving and charity only scratch the surface of the problem of helping those less fortunate, the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine, curate of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, "the Little Church Around the Corner,"1 East Twenty-ninth Street, said in his sermon there yesterday morning..

Several hundred experts in building operation and maintenance, including a large delegation from- New York, began gathering in Milwaukee today for the annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers, which opens here tomorrow.

Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, blamed overproduction and occupational monotony for the present abuse of leisure, in his annual baccalaureate address today before an audience of 2,100 graduating seniors, relatives and faculty in the university chapel.

Prices of lard showed a steady tone last week until late, when a sharp recession developed on commission house selling. Disappointment was registered over the fact that the small increase in local stocks has exerted so little strengthening influence.

Representative Woodruff of Michigan asked today in a statement issued through the Republican National Committee what had happened to the "useful public purpose" to which White House secretaries said President Roosevelt would devote the proceeds from his writings.

Miss racess Perkins, Secretary of Labor, said here today that she would seek to establish advisory councils in the various industries to aid the administration of labor legislation in the United States.

Dean Luther A. Weigle of the Yale Divinity School told members of the graduating class of Dartmouth College today that the world had a fighting chance to solve its problems if it approached them in the spirit of faith.

Industry in Germany continues dull. In an a analysis of business trends the Trade Research Institute emphasizes that the boom in the FourYear Plan's enterprises--mainly raw materials-has outstripped the boom in the machinery and shipping field.

Mrs. Harrison Eustis, president of the Seeing Eye at Morristown, N. J., which trains dogs to guide the blind, appealed yesterday to the public not to try to help blind men and women to cross streets when they are accompanied by Seeing Eye dogs.

A unique train rolled in from the north today and ground to a stop about a mile north of Poughkeepsie to let the personnel of ten crews, their coaches, managers and handlers get off. An hour later beneath the cliffs of the highlands the Hudson River boathouses had their quota of the men who are to make the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association on June 27.

Whether timed for the occasion or not, a hot debate on the Anglo-American trade agreement broke out in the House of Commons just as Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy embarked for the United States with the reported object of discussing in Washington practically every issue, from war debts to the neutrality policy, bearing on the relations between the United States and Great Britain.

T;HOUGH he didn't plan it exactly that way, T Laughing Larry MacPhail's night-baseball inaugural at Ebbets Field turned out to be a thrilling drama and a record success. Nothing like it ever before! The second no-hit game in succession by one pitcher, and practically a rookie, at that.

Ernest Haberle has been elected president of the H. C. Bohack Company, Inc., operating several hundred stores in Brooklyn and Long Island. He succeeds Fred Hildebrand, head of the company since Nov. 5, 1935. Mr. Haberle has been associated with the Bohack Company for twenty-four years.

Colonel George Stanton Tiffany, a retired officer of the American Army who served in the Philippines during the insurrection and also took part in the World War, died suddenly at 4:30 A. M. yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, the Hotel Windsor, 100 West Fiftyeighth Street. He was born in Flushing, Queens, sixty-two years ago.

Princeton University's Senior Promenade will be held in the university gymnasium tomorrow night. For this closing social event of the college year 134 young women, many of them students at colleges throughout the East, are expected as guests.

The death toll taken in the railroad accident yesterday in Miles City, Mont., was the greatest in the United States in recent years. Only twenty-seven passengers were killed by Class I railroads last year, the lowest number per million passenger miles since records were one first made available by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

One hundred and forty- four awards approved for Winter and Spring sports at New York University were announced- yesterday- by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics. The list,. approved by the 'Board of Athletic Control and the undergraduate.Athletic Association Board, includes fifty-eight major and thirty-eight minor letters, as well as forty-eight sets of freshman numerals. .
Breaking tradition, Amherst College conducted its commencement exercises tonight out-of-doors in the gymnasium quadrangle for the first time in the history of the college.

In sending eager young men into a world disordered by clashing ideas and atrophied by enforced idleness it is hard to strike the right note of high courage. Baccalaureate advice this year tends to become a little bewildered or downright gloomy.

Something new in the line of armament was disclosed by Max Schmeling today. The German battler, whose fight with Joe Louis for the heavyweight championship of the world is only three days away, went through his last full-length training session for the encounter, doing an eight-mile turn on the road, six rounds of boxing with three sparring partners and the equivalent of five rounds of muscleloosening calisthenics.

Houghton-Mifflln Co, publishers, floor In. 432 4th Ave; Grath-Mund Hat Co. store at 281 Mercer St: Benjamin Sosne, leather sportswear. in 135 W 36th St through Adams Co; J. H. Hoge Co. in 280 Madison Ave: Hunter Baltimore Rye Distillery, Inc. in 155 X 44th St; Cross Brown Co, brokers.

The Harlem Savings Bank sold to the Abrok Realty Corp. Abraham Brown, president, the 12-story Brixford apartment at 140 W 79th St, for a consideration shown as $375,000, taking back a purchase money mortgage for that amount together with a building loan mortgage for $60,000, both due according to the bonds.

Bradley Collins, an ace of tne Yale golf team only a few years ago and now one of Piping Rock's better players, and Sumner Waters of the near-by Nassau Country Club continued their successful teamwork at the Piping Rock Club today to win the annual invitation best-ball tournament.

Samuel Max Melamed, author and editor, who was head of the Chicago branch of the Zionist Organization of America, 1921-24, died yesterday in the Sydenham Hospital following an operation performed on Thursday.

Dr. and Mrs. Walter P. Anderton will give a dinner on Wednesday in the Persian Room of the Plaza for their niece, Miss Marian Kingsland, and Count Hans Seherr-Thoss, who will be married Saturday at Hicksville, L. I.

Mail orders diminished last week as Summer- business slackened off in the New York wholesale market. Men's and women's active sports and swimming apparel continued to se11 in good volume. Price softening developed in a few lines, with close-out merchandise available in women's dark-colored Summer suits and in cotton dresses.

Rebel, owned and skippered by Paul Shields, crossed the finish line I first today in the race for six-meter yachts over a nine-and-one-thirdmile course off Plum Point. The weather was clear and the wind west to northwest, sending the sixes along briskly.

Annual prize day exercises of the Peddie School were held today on the front campus here. Seventyfour prizes were presented, Dr. Wilbour E. Saunders, headmaster, giving the honor awards and faculty members presenting the prizes won in activities under their supervision. The school glee club and band gave a concert.

Ninety-one graduates of Xavier High School of New York, 30 West Sixteenth Street, received diplomas last night at exercises in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The Rev. Vincent J. Hart, rector of the school, presented the diplomas.
W. H. Woelbel's cutter Dream, carrying the colors of the Manhasset Yacht Club, tonight won the Riverside Y. C. Stratford Shoals overnight race on corrected time.

Grace Moore, the Metropolitan soprano, will be heard in several popular numbers from her repertoire when she appears as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, which will be directed by Jose Iturbi, next Monday night at Lewisohn Stadium.

Five persons, including four members of one family, were drowned early today when the automobile in which they were riding plunged into eight feet of water in a dredge cut from the Jacob Road in Dover Township.
Richness of character is the only important form of wealth, the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming said in his sermon yesterday morning in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

Germany's repudiation of liability for the Austrian loans is not regarded here as final but simply as a public reiteration of her attitude during the negotiations. There is slight hope even of an eleventh-hour arrangement.

Ten thousand persons, seated on the grassy slopes near Washington's grand parade ground at Valley Forge, were told by Governor Earle this afternoon that democracy would survive "because deep in the heart of us Americans lies the spirituality born at Valley Forge, the symbol of American Sacrifice for liberty."
Wearing gray trousers, a gray sweater and a white shirt, Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, played first base for the Sing Sing Prison School baseball team today.
Ten thousand fans saw the hardhitting Pirates score thirty runs today to take both games of a doubleheader from Philadelphia. The Pirates won the opener, 14 to 4, and the second game, 16 to 3.

Today being the half-way mark in the two weeks of training for New York National Guard units at Camp Smith here, visitors' day was observed. Nearly 5,000 persons were welcomed by the 102d Medical Regiment and the 102d Engineers.
The Chinese reported officially today that four war vessels of the Japanese fleet in the Yangtze River had been sunk above Anking in a raid by eight heavy bombers.

The movement toward unity among the Protestant denominations received a strong impetus today from three church leaders, each of whom advocated the plan in addresses, before the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches.

The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Cdngress during the period from June 11 to 16, when the session adjourned, are given in the following tabulation:

Webster Ave (12-3353). w s. 100 ft n of 204th St, 100x112: Harg Realty Corp to Wolf Hyman. 426 South Park Ave. Bridgeport. Conn. Belmont Ave (11-3082); n w cor of 181st St, 29x79; Irving M. Rosen, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

UNITED STATES PHOTOENGRAVER, $1.44 an hour, 40hour week, Government Printing Office, Washington, D. C.- Applications must be on file not later than the following dates: (a) July 18, 1938, if received from States other than those named In (b) below. (b) July 21, 1938, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Neveda, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington and Wyoming.
Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., and Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., won their matches today in the national clay courts tournament at the River Forest Tennis Club.
Luis Gonzales Obregon, noted Mexican historian, died today at his home on a street named in his honor. He age was 72. He was the author of many books and articles on Mexico.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 26 per first cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week and from two weeks before.

The indications are for generally fair weather today and probably tomorrow. Little change in temperature is expected, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (E. S. T.) last night.

Belief is growing that the steel market has touched bottom and the first indications of the expected late Summer revival are being felt, without definite evidence beyond a slight increase in operating rate and strengthening in the price of steel-making scrap, according. to the magazine Steel this week in its summary of the industry.

Brig. Gen. Walter Campbell Short, new commander of the First Infantry Brigade of the First Division, United States Army, was guest of honor yesterday of a reception at the Officers Club at Fort Hamilton, where he has his headquarters.

Elaine Barrie Barrymore, wife of John Barrymore, whose screen career has been limited to the film, "How to Undress in Front of Your Husband," has been engaged by Twentieth Century-Fox for an important role in "Hold That Co-ed" in which her husband also appears.

Mgr. Pascal Maljian, pastor of the Armenian Roman Catholic community of New York, marked his sacerdotal silver jubilee yesterday by celebrating a solemn mass of thanksgiving in the Church of St. Stephen, 142 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James P. O'Connor of 42 Hamiton Terrace of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Winifred O'Connor, to William J. Harnisch, son of Mrs. William J. Harnisch of East Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Harnisch.

Passenger officials of steamship companies expressed agreement yesterday that the current travel season had shaken off the lethargy that marked the early period and would be as successful as last season.
Harold Landy, 21 years old, of 1,217 Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, and Evelyn Schoenfeld, 19, of 130-02 230th Street, Laurelton, Queens, met while vacationing last Summer at White Lake.
