The marriage of Miss Shirley Eron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Eron of 418 Central Park West, to Sidney Sukoenig, son of Mrs. Abraham Sukoenig, also of this city, and they late Rev. Sukoenig, took place yesterday afternoon at the Park Royal Hotel, 23 West Seventy-third Street.

The weakness of the United States dollar is considered here as one of the many temporary waves of distrust in a currency which has been a feature of the foreign exchange markets for the last few years.
The announced results of the quarterly Treasury financing illustrate both the magnitude of the operations involved and the very peculiar character of the market for United States Government bonds.
Richard Barthelmess, the motionpicture actor, has returned to the scene of his first dramatic triumphs to receive the bachelor's degree he missed by leaving college after only three years of study.

Gunnar Gollberg, 35 years old, of 61 East 127th Street, who was arrested as one of the two men who attempted to break into the home of Charles H. H. Gristede, grocery chain executive, at 2,186 University Avenue, the Bronx, was discovered yesterday to be an undesirable alien who had been deported to Sweden several months ago.

A group of 137 European women, delegates to the second quadrennial convention of the Soroptimist International Association, arrived here today after landing in New York. Sessions will begin at the Hotel Claridge tomorrow and continue through Wednesday.

London was interested in but not excited by the gold-buying rush, which now is showing signs of abatement. Responsible quarters here did not believe the rumors on dollar devaluation, as it was difficult to see how it could be effected without a similar movement in sterling.

From 62 to 87 per cent of 9,000 white nonrelief families living in 140 "representative" villages of the country owned refrigerators in 1935-36, according to the consumer purchase study conducted by the Agriculture Department's Bureau of Home Economics.

An American Bar Association committee on administrative law noted today a tendency in the whole English-speaking world for administrative agencies to yield to political pressure at the expense of the law.

Selection of a committee of ten to evaluate the junior high school program of New York City and determine the future Board of Education policy in regard to this. type of school was announced yesterday by James Marshall, president of the board.

Crop reports on oats continue favorable, the cool wet Spring being helpful for this grain. Price changes on the Board of Trade were small last week and the daily swings narrow. Receipts are small and the cash demand moderate. Prices for the week were % cent off to % cent up.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Julianne Acher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Acher of this place, to Philip Moore Carpenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. William N. Carpenter, also of Scarsdale.

Eleven-year-old Miss Carol Jane Adler of Port Chester enjoyed one of the most successful afternoons of her competitive career today, carrying off the premier honors in four events at the Bronxville Riding Club's ninth annual horse show on the club's grounds.
THE ACCIDENT OF BIRTH, by the editors of Fortune. (Farrar Rinehart, 75 cents). Aninvestigation of the birth-control "industry."

" Whatever the outcome of the undeclared war now being so ruthlessly waged against the Chinese by the Japanese, the cessation of the warfare will find the Chinese politically and nationally more united than they have ever been before," said Dr. C. T. Wang, Ambassador of China to the United States, in the principal address at the annual meeting of Yale-in-China tonight.
An official bill-drafting agency for the City Council to end the present flood of improperly drawn local legislation was urged yesterday in a report made public by the City Club.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against COHEN ROSENTHAL, clothing manufacturers,, 142 5th Ave.-By Commercial Factors Corp., for upward of $500; Meinhard Greeff Co., Inc., upward of $500; James Talcott, Inc., upward of $500. Frank A. Carlin was appointed receiver under $2,000 bond by Judge Clancy. Liabilities about $46,000; assets about $20,000. The members of the firm are listed as Sydney Cohen and Solomon Rosenthal.

With pardon appeals pending before Governor Chandler for four men convicted of murder in connection with the so-called Battle of Evarts, that famous encounter between striking miners and deputy sheriffs faces a review in Federal District Court here this week.

In a statement issued yesterday Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, accused heads of motion picture studios with "deliberately withholding their important films until Autumn" and criticized his fellow-producers for "foolish and willful" conduct which, he declared, was largely responsible for the current slump in theatre business and other branches of the industry.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Basil G. Kodjbanoff of Wilton, Conn., and Middlebury, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Kodjbanoff, to David M. Keiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Keiser of New York and Cannondale, Conn.

The New York Symphonic Choir of thirty mixed voices, under William C. Elkins, was presented by Andrew A. Copeland in its initial concert last night at the Renaissance Casino. Sonoma C. Talley, pianist, and Langston Hughes, reader, were scheduled as assisting artists.
Malta's defenses against a "lightning" sea and air attack have just been tested in the most extensive manoeuvres in the island's history.

The New York City chapter of the American Association of Social Workers set forth yesterday its belief that the proposed City Council investigation of home relief was "unwarranted" since a committee appointed by Mayor La Guardia had completed recently an exhaustive survey of the relief administration.
Princess Irene Youssoupoff, daughter of the man who is reputed to have killed the monk Rasputin, was married here today to Prince Nicolas Scheremieteff.
After a six-month dispute within the National Tuberculosis Association, a design by Rockwell Kent today won acceptance for the 1939 Christmas seal of the organization.

The motion picture "Blockade" was characterized as an "excursion of the motion-picture industry into the field of Leftist propaganda" in. a telegram sent early today to Will Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors Association, by the supreme board of directors of the Knights of Columbus, holding their regular quarterly meeting here.
John A. Roosevelt tonight brought his bride-of-a-day, the former Miss Anne Lindsay Clark, to this Canadian island for an indefinite stay at the pretentious Summer home of President Roosevelt.
Moritz Eisner, a retired chemist, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 55 Central Park West. He was 84 years old and had been ill for six weeks.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Holland gave a tea at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Holland, to Cornelius Vas Reypen Bogert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bogert of Bogota.
Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Rieger of Garden City have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Naomi Rieger, to William J. Kennedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy of New York.

A plan to create a federation of reform Jewish congregations in the New York metropolitan area, thus forming a close-knit union of 50,000 reform Jews, was approved by the executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations in one-day session at the Ritz-Carlton here today.

When the Constitutional Covention resumes its sessions tomorrow night, interest will again be concentrated on the Bill of Rights Committee which was forced last week by Senator John J. Dunnigan to report out his amendment to the Bill of Rights seeking to restrict the search and seizure powers of law enforcement officers, particularly with regard to wiretapping activities.

General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano arrived in Seville this morning from the Cordoba front and in the main plaza presented title deeds to tenants of 124 houses that have just been completed by the Franco government for wounded soldiers and poor workers who have large families.

International events had little influence on this week's business here. It was noticed that the official German agistation against Czechoslovakia had temporarily abated and that Prime Minister Neviile Chamberlain's statement in the British House of Commons concerning shipping to Spanish ports had allayed fears of any immediate conflict with General Franco.

The German wholesale price index on June 8 stood at 105.3, unchanged for the la week. In the first five months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.8 on March 2.

Premier Benito Mussolini has sent twenty carloads of Italian grain for distribution among the residents of several Albanian districts where the crops have been severely damaged by floods. Albanian newspapers published enthusiastic articles praising Mussolini for his kindness to Albania.

News was received yesterday from Liverpool of the retirement of Dr. Thomas W. Atkins, senior medical officer of the British mercantile marine, who served on some of the larger liners of the Cunard White Star Company.

Means of improving Franco-Italian relations so as to smooth the way for a resumption of negotiations between the two countries were, it is understood, discussed by Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, and the Earl of Perth in a half-hour conversation today.

In collision with another automobile, a car driven by Frederick Kerbstat, 52 years old, of 1,419 113th Street, College Point, Queens, took fire after the gasoline tank exploded at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, causing the death of his sister-in-law, Miss Klara Schultz, 28, of the College Point address and injuries to Kerbstat.

The Turkish Governor of Antioch and the French commandant of the troops in the Sanjak of Alexandretta, which is under martial law, summoned representatives of the Armenian community today and promised them that a Turkish occupation and administration of the Sanjak would not be detrimental to the Armenians.

Miss Lillian Somoza, 16-year-old daughter of President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua, arrived here for a visit yesterday and confided that her father, "strong man" of the Central American republic, who has achieved and held office during turbulent passages of Nicaraguan history, forbade her to go home by airplane because he considered it "too dangerous."

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth R Street, decried in his sermon yes- to terday morning the tendency he so saw to follow deceptive slogans and the ease with which we are "infected with red herrings."

As a result of the recent unification of the three largest branches of the Methodist Episcopal Church under the name of the Methodist Church, the new York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at a special session held here Friday, decided to abandon in the sey churches of the conference the use of the word Episcopal on signs, stationery, calendars, publications, literature and advertisements.

ABRAHAMS-Joseph, at his residence, 175 Riverside Drive, beloved husband of Aimee (nee Schwab), devoted father of Shirley and Maurice. Funeral services at The West End Funeral Chapel, 200 West 91st St., Monday, June 20, at 11 A. M. ABRAHAMS--We record with deepest sympathy the passing of Joseph Abrahams, beloved husband of our former Board Member, Amy Abrahams.

Samuel Del's snakes, which were supposed to attract the curious, had the opposite effect yesterday in front of 50 Mott Street. Del, 48 years old, of 21 East 114th Street, who sells snake oil for the treatment of corns, saw fifty persons scurry for safety when he displayed the reptiles.
Senator Barkley last night declared in a radio broadcast that American business "for more than two years has been in a large, whole-hearted, unconscious conspiracy" to deprive customers of cash.

About twenty men and women were injured tonight when the planking over an old, abandoned rifle pit at the Plattdeutsche Volkesfest Park caved in while a crowd of 2,000 attending the annual Plattdeutsche Volksfest Verein celebration was watching a fireworks display.
Miss Jessie M. Evangelista, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Evangelista of this city, was married this afternoon to Dr. Joseph J. Martini, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Martini.

Cotton prices advanced every day last week except Monday. The gains from day to day were relatively small, but the total rise for the week was about 1/4 of a cent a pound. Active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 23 to 27 points.

This was Connie Mack Day today, but the Indians gave no quarter and handed the veteran's players a 5-to-4 beating in the final game of the series before 20,000 spectators. The victory gave the league pacesetters the series, 2 to 1.
Yale's varsity oarsmen, taking a yacht trip today as a respite from the training grind for the annual battle with Harvard, waved greetings to a distinguished alumnus of their rival.

The people of Ireland have endorsed Eamon de Valera's policy with an overwhelming majority in the election now drawing to a close and the Prime Minister will return to office with the strong government that he asked for.

Mrs. Edna Eaton Wilson, the Falls City, Okla., correspondent for the weekly Stillwater Gazette, whose column of news and comment on her farming neighbors won her the title of best country newspaper correspondent of 1938, entertained reporters yesterday afternoon in her suite at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where she is staying as guest of Country Home Magazine, sponsor of the contest.
Following is a partial list of the casualties in the wreck of the Olympian of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St, Paul d Pacific Railroad yesterday, received from The Associated Press and other sources:

The annual report of the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church reveals the average age allowance that the fund has been able to pay to ordained ministers on retiring at 68 has increased steadily in the twenty years of the fund's existence. It is now about $1,000, compared with the $600 minimum level at which the fund was started.

Lump-sum payments totaling $118,367 were distributed to 2,195 persons in this State last month under the Federal old-age insurance program, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, announced last night.

The New York Civic Orchestra, under Cesare Sodero, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the WPA Theatre of Music, with Arthur Filippi, tenor, as soloist. Louis Biancolli, music reviewer of The New York World-Telegram, was the commentator.

There are primary elections in two States today. From Maine we will not learn much; the New Deal beats in vain against her rock-ribbed coast. But in Minnesota the New Deal is an acute issue in a fairly complete jumble of confusion.

Many hours behind schedule, President Roosevelt was aboard his yacht the Potomac with younger members of his family last night, cruising leisurely for the Hudson River while Secret Service operatives and members of the White House staff wondered for a time where he might be and when he would arrive here.
Yale's varsity oarsmen, taking a yacht trip today as a respite from the training grind for the annual battle with Harvard, waved greetings to a distinguished alumnus of their rival.

The people of Ireland have endorsed Eamon de Valera's policy with an overwhelming majority in the election now drawing to a close and the Prime Minister will return to office with the strong government that he asked for.

Twenty-nine young musicians from the five boroughs of New York City played yesterday for several thousand persons on the Mall in Central Park in the finals of a competition arranged by the Department of Parks. The instruments used included eight pianoaccordions, a few violins, a trumpet, a xylophone, drums, and a piano.

Otto G. Wismer, president of Bondholders Management, Inc., reported yesterday that for the period from Jan. 1 to June 10 the corporation's net surplus earnings were $58,717 and surplus, after cash dividends, was $20,143.

Calling upon the democrati forces within Poland" to help restore democracy to that country. and denouncing the anti-Semites there, the thirtieth annual national convention of the Federation of Polish Jews in America adopted plans here today for increasing "political, moral, and economic aid" to Poland's 3,500,000 Jews.

Men of prominence from cities in the East paid tribute today to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Joseph I. Krauskopf, founder of the National Farm School here. The occasion was the annual Founders' Day ceremony at the school, attended by 400 persons.

By the margin of one stroKe, Tne Inwood Country Club took possession of the Arthur Lehman Memorial Trophy today as the Long Island contingent showed the way to twenty-one other metropolitan clubs in the third annual golf tournament sponsored by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City at the Metropolis Country Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ballantine of Hewlett have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Ballantine, to Emlen Williams Holmes, son of Jabish Holmes of 7 Gracie Square, New York, and the late Mrs. Holmes.

Without having won a previous blue, Golden Tiger, youngest of the three fencers with whom Rufus Finch's Stables of Seabright swept the hunter classes. won the $200 championship hunter stake during the.final program of the seventh annual Plainfield Horse Show at Vinebrook Farm today.

A landscaped open-air theatre where popular radio programs will be staged will be included in a group of buildings of modern design to be erected at the New York World's Fair by Standard Brands, Inc., it was disclosed yesterday by Thomas L. Smith, president of the company.

Young Jim Bagby's seven-hit pitching, combined with a 14-hit attack gave the Red Sox a 6 to 1 victory in the nightcap of a double bill with Chicago today after Boston had lost the opener, 3 to 2, when Gerald Walker smashed a two-run homer.

The moment is appropriate to review the whole C policy of the British Government in Europe, for Premier Edouard e Daladier of France has sent Parliament on a long Summer holiday and the French Government can begin cooperating with Britain without running daily into trouble with its parliamentary opponents.
The latest bank return shows a gain of [pound]7,821,300 in the Banking Department, which is assumed to represent the 10 per cent first call on the defense loan. The reduction of f4,984,000 in
Miss Betty Jane Ferguson of Huntington today captured two championships at the closing session of the two-day Cedar Valley Horse Show for the benefit of Hope Farm.

A daylight ride down Berlin's main shopping streets today revealed a thousand or more crudely decorated Jewishowned shops and stores that had been victims of one of the most sinister but also one of the most clumsily executed anti-Jewish demonstrations undertaken in the German metropolis since the advent of the Nationalist Socialist regime.

A grant of $35,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for new buildings and modern equipment at the University Hospital of West China Union University, Chengtu, Szechwan Province, China, was announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph Beech, chancellor of the university, at the institution's yew York office, 150 Fifth Avenue. Of the total $25,000 will be spent for the buildings and equipment. for the out-patient departments and $10,000 for modern hospital equipment for both out-patient and in-patient deDartments.

Students who have been receiving college training during the past year under the sponsorship of the National Youth Administration have been making outstanding records, according to reports submitted to Aubrey Williams, executive director, by his assistant, Richard R. Brown.

The bathing season reached full swing yesterday with more than 1,000,000 men, women and children at the water's edge within the city limits. About half of them went into the water and found it a pleasant cure for a hot day.
One of Rome's most famous art treasures, the Lancellotti copy of The Discus Thrower by the Grecian sculptor Myron, has been sold to Germany.
The Grand Steeplechase of Paris, opening the fashionable "Grande Semaine," was won today by Count d'Outlre's Heve, an outsider paying 179 to 5, before 100,000 at Auteuil.

Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, told graduates of Atlantic City High School in a baccalaureate address today that "academic pessimists" were having "a field day" this commencement, but that their fears were overemphasized.

Two Italian church edifices were dedicated yesterday by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn. One ceremony took place in the morning at St. Anthony of Padua's Church, 128th Street and 135th Avenue, South Ozone Park, Queens.

The special Federal grand jury that has been investigating espionage in the United States is to reconvene this morning and is expected to file from fifteen to twenty indictments later in the day or tomorrow.

The Lancashire cotton mills and the Chamber of Commerce of Manchester have requested the British Government to negotiate a new commercial treaty with Colombia, according to reports received here from London.
Three prisoners, convicted auto thieves, escaped tonight from the Walkill State prison and one was captured a shot while later about eight miles away on the road to New York City.

The church cannot preach to the world a brotherhood in religion when it does not practice it, the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, executive secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue-and Seventy-third Street, where he once was associate pastor.

More than 1,800 children in hospitals and convalescent homes in and near New York City, who have been attending specially conducted public school classes, will be promoted or graduated this week, David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, announced yesterday.

With the occupation of the town of Peraleda de Zaucejo, twenty miles northwest of Penarroya, yesterday General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano has now straightened out a salient thirty miles wide that has jutted into General Francisco Franco's territory since the beginning of the war.

Tom Lawrence's goal in the closing seconds of play enabled the Pegasus Browns to top the Ramapo Blues, 7-6, yesterday at Tallman, N. Y., for their third victory in as many Eastern Polo League starts. Bud Combs excelled for the winners with four goals.

In the first quarter of the current year when domestic purchases of automobiles showed a marked decline, shipments of automobiles, parts and accessories to other countries formed the leading item in the export trade of the United States, according to a foreign trade analysis made public today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Mexico, where internal policies have recently caused grave concern to investors in the United States, ranked fourth among all countries in the size of American direct investment at the end of 1936, according to an official study of such investment abroad made public today by the Department of Commerce.
A pilgrimage of crippled and incurable disease sufferers estimated by local authorities at more than 12,000 came to this village today to worship on the annual day set aside for St. Anthony.

The cornerstone of a $250,000 building being constructed to increase the capacity of Brooklyn's Jewish Sanitarium and Hospital for Chronic Diseases was laid yesterday at Rutland Road and East Forty-eighth Street.
The inauguration of General Alfredo Baldomir as President of Uruguay this afternoon developed into the most enthusiastic outburst of popular acclaim accorded any incoming President in fifty years.

Pleading for a firm stand in the defense of democracy, Governor Lehman, in an address yesterday morning at a special meeting of the National Council of Young Israel in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, denounced fascism and communism as "twin evils with common objectives.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 2d Lt. Kenneth M. Gunkel, Ord.-Res., 780 Mountain Way, Rutherford, N. J., is ordered to active duty, effective June 26, at Raritan Arsenal, N. J., for training. He will revert to an inactive status June 26. Each of the following Reserve officers, is ordered to active duty, effective June 26, at Camp Dix, N. J.. for training:
French Huguenots 250 years ago in New Rochelle make their exit from the news as the Swedes in Delaware 300 years ago prepare to make their entry on the front page.

Trading in most classes, though generally only fair to slow, was improved over the past several Mondays. Veal continued very weak, steer lamb and fresh pork cuts steady to slightly higher. Other classes unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated all classes to be about in line with last Friday's close.
Sun Celerina was never headed in the mile and a sixteenth Wilmington Monarch Club Purse, at Delaware Park today, marking the first victory ' of the meeting for Willis Sharpe Kilmer's silks.

The Mexican Senate appointed a "Petroleum Investigating Committee" today with the intention, according to the Mexico City press, of proving that the United States and British petroleum companies that Mexico has expropriated owe Mexico money instead of-vice versa.

Automobile production increased last week against a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index advanced to 43.1 from 41.2. For the week ended June 19, 1937, the figure was 115.0. The week's output amounted to 41,790 units, according to the estimate of Ward's Automotive Reports.

Senator Josiah W. Bailey of North Carolina, honored today by Colby College with the degree of Doctor of Laws, denounced in his commencement address the Court Reorganization Bill as a "blow against that process of democracy most essential to its existence, the constitutional check on executive and legislative power."

A tourist sleeper that railroad officials estimated contained twelve more unrecovered victims of the worst American railroad wreck in a decade, slipped down tonight into the mucky bed of Custer Creek and balked recovery of the bodies for several more hours.

The Rev. Dr. Anthony N. Petersen, Protestant chaplain at Sing Sing prison, will give up at the pastorate of the Scarborough Presbyterian Church tomorrow to devote his entire time to his prison activities and to writing.
The French people believe that Adolf Hitler is mad, and "you cannot count on what a madman will do," Mme. Marcelle Kraemer-Bach, Paris attorney and former member of the French Cabinet, said today.

At the annual meeting of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., held yesterday, William B. Falconer, heretofore executive vice president of the firm, was elected president to succeed Charles F. Noyes, who becomes chairman of the board of directors.

The guillotine fell four times today in the countryard of Ploetzensee prison, beheading Stefan Lovasz, Joseph Streidle, Liaselote. Hermann of Stuffgart and Arthur Goeritz of Manzell Lovasy was convicted of an attempt to form a communist party in Southern Germany and the other than of military espionage and communist activist.
The stock market here was quiet and generally firm today and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues were steady, while among the foreign loans Chinese bonds were lower.

The American Labor party is willing to fuse with another party, presumably the Democratic party, for the coming State election but will insist on a place on the joint State ticket, Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the Labor party, announced last night at a meeting of its State Committee.

The activities of all title guarantee and mortgage companies in the State of New York, it was believed, may eventually be affected by a decision yesterday by the Special Sessions Court in Queens, which found The Lawyers Title Corporation guilty of the illegal practice of law.

The Census Bureau reported today the cotton spinning Industry operated during May at 89.3 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 85.7 per cent during April this year, and 137.7 per cent during May last year.
Miss Geraldine Clare Bassett, social service worker, died on Sunday at her home, 83 Hillcrest Avenue, Great Kills, S. I., after a long illness. Her age was 33.

After emphasizing the difficulty of forecasting the city's relief needs for the next year, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson told the council finance committee yesterday that his best estimate was a total of $137,228,000 for the fiscal year 1939, an increase of $17,633,927 over the budget for the fiscal year ending on June 30, 1938.
Bob Pastor, New York heavyweight, gained a unanimous 10-round decision over Al McCoy of Boston, the New England titleholder, in a bruising feature contest tonight at the Boston Garden.

A new by-law designed to grant tenure of office to more than 1,300 teachers of the four city Colleges and to reorganize the structure of the faculties and departments of the municipal institutions was adopted by a large majority last night at the monthly meeting of the Board of Higher Education in the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Sidney Arnold, also known as Nat Arno, who said he was in the insurance business, was arrested today in the police investigation of the riot at Military Park on the night of June 4, when Norman Thomas was pre- talk vented from exercising his right to jobs speak under a permit issued by the sing city authorities. Deputy Chief Brex.

Samuel H. Van Horn, former probate judge of Kalamazoo, died today at his home at the age of 65. Judge Van Horn had practiced law here for forty years. He served two terms as probate judge and at one time was assistant prosecutor.

Six persons were injured, one seriously, when a speed boat crashed into a motor launch loaded with sightseers here today. At Glens Falls Hospital, where the injured were taken after being brought ashore in other power boats, Patrick G. Graham of 149 Manhattan Avenue, New York City, a passenger on the launch, was reported in a serious condition. His wife was treated for lacerations of the face.

Princeton University will confer 570 degrees at its 191st commencement exercises here tomorrow morning If the weather permits, the exercises, which will close three days of traditional commencement festivities, will be held in front of Nassau Hall. In the event of rain they will be transferred to Alexander Hall.

The Fayette County grand jury reported today that most employee of rights i the Eastern State Hospital and the shall Greendale Reform School here had contributed to Governor A. B. The Chandler's campaign fund and that workers in the local WPA office had received requests to contribute mbney to Senator Alben W. Barkley's campaign.

The new campaign in Germany against Czechoslovakia has resulted, it was stated here today, in a protest visit to the Foreign Office by the Czech Minister in Berlin. He referred particularly to the violent attacks by Rudolf Hess and the bad effect produced by this "uncalled for campaign."

Opening of bids for the sale and demolition of the old Postoffice Building in City Hall Park was postponed for the second time yesterday because the city has not yet received title to the building from the Federal Government.

Dr. Alan Morris, formerly research engineer, has been namedchief metallurgist of the Bridgeport Brass Company. He will be in charge of the physical and chemical laboratories as well as research activities.
A sixyear Federal and State spending program to bring about the rigid control of tuberculosis was approved by the board of directors of the National Tuberculosis Association here today.

Norman H. Davis, president of the American Red Cross, today called on the International Red Cross organization to use all its influence to curb "revolting and needless slaughter of helpless women and children" in air raids on unfortified cities.

A marriage of interest to society in New England, New York and Chicago took place here this afternoon when Miss Joanne Bass of Boston became the bride of Marshall Field Jr., great-grandson of Marshall Field, founder of the Chicago merchandising house bearing his name.

Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes will return today from Europe on the French liner Ile de France with his bride, the former Jane Dahlman of Milwaukee. Others aboard the ship, coming from Havre via Southampton, include Mrs. Newbold Morris, Mr. and Mrs. Neil H. Swanson, Mr. and Mrs. B. E. Levy, Mr. and Mrs. Kent Taylor and Mr. and Mrs. Pedro Obregon.

The name of Martin W. Littleton, former District Attorney of Nassau County, was added yesterday to the list of possible candidates for the Republican nomination for Governor in discussions among Republican leaders regarding the State ticket.

The Belt Association, Inc., comprising ninety-one union manufacturers of belts for women's garments, voted at a meeting last night at the Hotel New Yorker to authorize a committee to ask the Belt Makers Union to waive some of the provisions of the industry's labor agreement in order to meet the competition of eighty-two non-union

Mrs. Emilie Kopff of New Rochelle, who died on June 6, left bequests to nine public organizations, according to her will, filed for probate today in the Westchester County Surrogate's Office. Mrs. Kopff, a widow, prospered as a the liquor shop proprietor before prohibition.
Babe Ruth in uniform in the firstbase coaching box once again was an inspiring sight to 5,603 paying fans at Ebbets Field yesterday, but his inspiration couldn't communicate itself to the Dodgers.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the nation's largest producer of tracktype tractors and a leading manufacturer of Diesel engines, today sharply reduced its prices on tractors and Diesel engines in an attempt to stimulate business.
The apparel and allied trades were well represented in yesterday's leasing reports, with rentals of store space by retailers and upper-floor units by manufacturers and processors.

The second annual convention of the Super Market Institute will be held in the Hotel Sherman, Chicago, Sept. 19, 20 and 21, it was announced yesterday. Operators of super markets in all sections of the country are expected to attend.

While April imports into Poland of raw cotton were below those of March, figures for the first four months of the year show an increase of 3,887 tons over the corresponding period in 1937, the Department of Commerce made known today.
The Treasury approached the end of the fiscal year today with 80 cents collected for every $1 spent, the largest proportion of receipts to expenditures since the lean years began.
An impressive rally in railroad loans was the outstanding feature of a more active bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

To elevate the standards of book production, the editors of The Colophon, 229 West Forty-third Street, are releasing today an unusually handsome volume devoted to the manufacture of books under the title "The Annual of Bookmaking."
Well, it is beginning to look as though the long-awaited bluefish is on his- way, and several Freeport fishing boats reported small catches of these scrappers on Sunday.

Bobby Riggs of Chicago, defending champion and No. 1 seeded player in the national clay courts tennis tournament, won his initial match as expected at the River Forest Tennis Club today, but Charles Hare of England was not so fortunate.

Five thousand dollars was contributed yesterday to Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, for its Youth Aliyah (immigration) fund, which is used to transport Jewish children to Palestine from Austria, Germany and Poland.
A supplemental summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations, issued today by the Securities and Exchange

A complete investigation of the effects of State fair trade laws will be undertaken by the special survey committee appointed by the President, which has a WPA grant of between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000, Augustus H. Martin Jr., director of the survey, told the New York State Pharmaceutical Association at the opening session of its three-day convention here today.

Wheat futures in North American markets closed at their best prices today following- a moderate decline on selling on the Board of Trade here earlier in the session. Strength in securities and commodities more than offset the effect of generally favorable weather conditions for harvesting in the Southwest and weakness in foreign markets.
Ueorge F. Conant, retired civil engineer and descendant of Roger Conant of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, died today at his Cambridge home at the age of 85.
Second Lieutenant Caldwell Russell, captain of the 1938 Military Academy team, won the allArmy tennis championship today by defeating his former team-mate, Cadet Arthur Tindall, 6-4, 6-3, 6--2.
Indications tonight were that fortythree yachts, the same number as competed in the last contest two years ago, would start tomorrow on the race from Breton Lightship, off this port, to Bermuda.

Standard Oil of New Jersey announced yesterday a reduction of 10 cents a barrel in bunker C fuel oil at all North Atlantic ports. The new price here will be 95 cents a barrel for the domestic fuel and 85 cents for the bonded foreign oil.
Miss Degna Marconi, a daughter of the late Marchese Guglielmo Marconi, pioneer wireless inventor, was married today to Professor Gabrielle Paresce, press attache of the Italian Embassy at London.

Dr. Samuel H. Vehslage, retired New York physician, died here on Saturday at his home at the age of 89. Born in New York, he attended public schools there and was graduated from the New York Homeopathic Medical College in 1879.
Benjamin Malvin of 1,583 Moffat Avenue, Hewlett, L. I., a lawyer, died Sunday night in St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, following an operation for appendicitis performed five days previously.

A plea to Americans to be neutral in the Spanish civil war is made in a statement by the editorial directors of The Commonweal in the coming issue of that periodical, published next Friday. In the same issue Michael Williams, former editor, takes issue with this point of view.

The names of historical and otherwise famous streets of old New York and other American cities have been duplicated at the New York World's Fair of 1939, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

The executive committee of the Newspaper Guild of New York, C.I.O. affiliate, issued a statement yesterday indicating that it would continue to seek members among newspaper employes not eligible for membership in existing craft unions.

To facilitate carrying out of the Federal Government's new construction relief program, the PWA will open temporary offices in principal cities of Maryland, Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York and the six New England States.

Beginning tomorrow, all odd-lot transactions on the Chicago Stock Exchange in issues also listed on the New York Stock Exchange which are traded under the optional odd-lot system of the Exchange here will be printed on the ticker tape, it was announced today. Hitherto,

William Brevoort Potts Jr., 36 years old, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Weed, Hall, Berndt Co., 40 Wall Street, was arraigned as a hit-and-run driver before Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in the Homicide Court yesterday.

Dr. Walter A. Jessup, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, was elected to the board of directors of the Johns-Manville Corporation yesterday at a meeting of the board.

Two kinds of letters have been sent out by Representative Rayburn, majority leader of the House, to all Democratic members, praising them for their work in Congress, regardless of their stand on controversial administration measures.

Sir Hubert Wilkins, the polar explorer, said on his arrival from Europe yesterday that plans for a submarine exploration of Arctic waters were progressing rapidly and that he might build the submarine this Winter and hold trials in the Spring. If so, he added,

Manhattan Alterations 35th St, 4-16 W; to 10-story department store: -James McCreery Co, premises, owner; Starrett Van Vleck, architects; cost, $15,000. 3d Ave. 964; to 1-story theatre; RKO Proctor Corp, 1.270 6th Ave, owner; S. W. Mitteldorf, architect; cost, $10,000.

Seventeen organizations of New York postal employes, combined in the Albert Goldinan Community Chest, gave $10,000 yesterday to the Greater New York Fund at a noontime rally on the Eighth Avenue General Postoffice steps.

Mayor Frank Hague's effort to link the C. I. 0. and the American Civil Liberties Union with the Communist movement by bringing into court their books and records, together with those of various Communist and radical organizations, received a setback here today.

" Haiti," the Federal Theatre's production of the William DuBois play, will move from the Lafayette Theatre in Harlem to Daly's, leaving the one on Wednesday, June 29, and opening at the other on Monday, July 11.

Pensioned On his own application; to take effect 12 midnight, June 19: PATROLMAN Joseph P. Mulvey, 19th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum, Appointed July 5, 1906. ' Assignment To take effect 8 A. M., June 21: SERGEANT Francis J. M. Robb, 18th Division, M. 0. D., Brooklyn, designated as acting lieutenant.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, announced yesterday the names of ninety-four graduates and students of the college who will receive medals, prizes, scholarships and honors at the ninety-second annual commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow evening. The names of other prize winners will be released today.

William Goldbeck of Lawrence Farms, one of Westchester's most consistent professional golfers, had his game well controlled today and posted a score of 35, 34-69, three under par, for the Winged Foot Golf Club's east course in the Westchester pro-amateur one-day tournament.

R. N. Watt, president of the Canadian Lawn Tennis Association, announced today-that July 28, 29 and 30 have been approved by the Japanese tennis team as dates for the coming Davis Cup matches between Japan and Canada.

When a steel-girder bridge resting on concrete is swept away and one of the crack trains of the country plunges into the torrent below, the public naturally wonders whether the designing and constructing engineers were at fault. That the structure had served its purpose for thirty years and seemed good for many more speaks for itself.

America faces two kinds of dictatorship, one of. political and economic regimentation, and the other of crime, alumni of Brown University were warned this afternoon at their annual alumni meeting in Sayless Hall, which ended the commencement exercises.

Red Star, the official army newspaper, disclosed today an-intensive purge in the political ranks of the army in the drive to bolshevizee" Russia's soldiers. The paper reported that the "offspring" of Marshal Jan Gamarnik, former Vice Commissar of War and Navy, General B. M. Feldman and General Bulin had been "uprooted" during the last four months.

Eighteen eight-oared crews moved over placid water under a blistering sun in double workouts today as the complete flotilla of seven colleges began final preparations for the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association a week from today.

Among the properties in Brooklyn reported yesterday as having been sold was the six-family house at 282 Sumpter Street, which was purchased by William Kruger from the Laffel Realty Company through Paul A. Bogossian, broker. Mudge, Stern, Williams Tucker, attorneys, represented the seller.

By a vote of 310 to 70, the quarry workers of the New York Trap Rock Corporation chose the A. F. of L. over the C. I. O. as their sole bargaining agent in an election here today under the direction of the National Labor Relations Board.

The American Art Association-Anderson Galleries announced yesterday that in the 1937-38 art auction season their sales realized $2,020,974. More than a quarter of this, $535,220, was netted by parts one and two of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop.

The military situation took second place in the news today when Premier Juan Negrin returned from a two-week visit to Madrid and Valencia and gave out a statement to the newspapers accusing his political opponents of "cowardice and treason."

Election of Ashby T. Harper, '39, of Trenton,' as captain of the Princeton baseball team for next year was announced today. Harper, who prepared at Blair Acdemy, played second base and in the outfield this year and was considered one of the team's most dependable hitters.

The marriage of Miss Gloria Braggiotti of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Braggiotti of Boston, to Emlen Etting, wellknown artist of Philadelphia, took place yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

BRITAIN AND THE DICTATORS, by R. W. Seton-Watson. (Macmillan, $3.50.) A survey of post-war British policy. THE COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL, by V. I. Lenin. (International Publishers, $2.75.) Writings and speeches on the Third International.

Trade on Set strictly choice and prime fed steers and yearlings finished up steady but the bulk of supply grading good-and choice broke 15 to 25 cents. Hog. prices opened steady to strong, but closed no-better than steady on a slow, weak cleanup.'Lamb prices were strong to sharply higher. with clipped old crop offerings getting the most upturn, the United States. Department of Agriculture reported.
The influx of fight fans for the battle in which Joe Louis will defend his heavyweight title against Max Schmeling in the Yankee Stadium tomorrow night began in earnest yesterday.

Emanuel Seideman, 42 years old, and Harry -Rower, .40, so-called "bucketeer twins" in the operation of numerous' bogus brokerage offices in the financial district-in.recent years; were sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge William Allen to terms of ten to twenty years each.
The Yale Senior Promnenade was held tonight at the New Haven Lawn Club. It featured an entertainment in which the Whiffenpoofs were guest artists. There was also a supper.
His last day's work in preparation for the big fight found Max Schmeling in just the frame of mind his adherents have been hoping he would assume.

Edward M. Crone, secretary of the Texas Corporation and of several of its affiliated oil companies, died here tonight in the Lawrence Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage which resulted from injuries received in a fall on Friday. He was 45 years old.

While shoe retailers in the West and Midwest have fairly full stocks, stores in the East have comfortably liquidated their holdings -and in some instances have inventories so thin as to run the risk of sales losses, E. L. Boneau, sales manager of the Brown Shoe Company, St. Louis, said here yesterday. Mr.

Jersey City took the third of its four-game series with Rochester tonight, 7 to 5. Glen Gabler, who started, restricted the Red Wings to nine hits in eight innings. He had to have help in the ninth, but was credited with his third victory of the season when Rollie Stiles stopped a rally cold.

The formation of the House Magazine Institute of America, through which editors of house magazines over the country will meet to discuss problems of production and exchange ideas, was announced yesterday. Headquarters will be opened later in the week at 56 West Forty-fifth Street.

Firing an impressive salute of three home runs, one of them Lou Gehrig's tenth of the campaign, the Yankees finally managed to wrench a game from an exasperating band of Browns today, 8 to 4, and then pushed resolutely on to Cleveland for a hand-to-hand conflict with the front-running Indians.

Stocks closed strong with gains of 1 to 5 points; turnover, 1,087,050 shares, largest since April 22. Rail bonds recovered 1 to 5 points, United States Government and other obligations steady and mixed in heaviest dealings since May 13; transactions, $5,900,400.

Mrs. Edna Eaton Wilson of Ripley, Okla., champion country correspondent of 1938, has been visiting New York. She covers a rural district for The Stillwater Gazette and its associate newspaper, The Daily Press.

A national insurance bill received its third reading in the Australian House of Representatives today. The vote was 33 to 28. The measure provides medical benefits under a contributory scheme whereby medical treatment may be obtained by insured persons after twenty-six weekly contributions of 1 shilling, 6 pence, employers paying the same amount and the government paying [Pound]2,000,000 the first four years.

Prime Minister Eamon de Valera was swept back into power with the clear majority that he demanded. The standing at 12:30 A. M. today showed his Fianna Fail party with seventy-six seats against fifty-six for all .other parties and only six,seats to report from Friday's general election.

Citing the results of his first. six months of office, Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands declared last night in the Hotel Astor that "at last we can undertake to explore the inner mysteries of government which have been guarded so long by the vestal virgins of Tammany Hall."

Negotiations that have been going forward in international diplomacy all this month have now reached the point where the French Foreign Ministry is expecting an agreement over the Spanish war when the Non-Intervention Commission meets in London tomorrow.

A team of cricketers from the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, now in port, lost to an eleven from the Staten Island Cricket Club at Walker Park, Livingston, S. I., yesterday by a margin of 39 runs, with three wickets to spare.

President Roosevelt rested at his Hyde Park home tonight after during which he approved thirty including the $37,000,000 Rivers Harbors Bill, and rejected seven others, among them two measures to increase pensions of World War and Spanish War veterans.

William Wyler has been removed as director of "The Lady and the Cowboy" and dropped from the payroll by Samuel Goldwyn for "economic reasons." With the substitution of H. C. Potter, shooting progressed today without interruption.

Mike Belloise of the Bronx, one of the nation's leading featherweights, gained a close decision over Al Reid, also from the Bronx, in the main bout of eight rounds at the New Dyckman Oval last night before a crowd of 3,000.

A fair amount of business developed in the local merchandise markets yesterday, chiefly on hot weather items in the women's field, according to manufacturers and resident offices. Cotton dresses were particularly active.
Dartmouth College today conferred honorary degrees upon nine men, headed by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, and President James B. Conant of Harvard.

Colonel Peter A. Mironoff, president of the Society for the Relief of Russian War Invalids Outside of Russia, Inc., died of a heart attack yesterday at the factory of the Lion Match Company in Long Island City, where he was employed. He was 56 years old and lived at 48-34 Ninety-first Place, Elmhurst.

Three alumnae of Smith College and a Bryn Mawr graduate who is Professor of History at Mount Holyoke received honorary degrees at today's commencement exercises. President Neilson also conferred 457 bachelors' degrees and 36 masters' degrees. Professor George Lyman Kittredge of Harvard gave the address, "Shakespeare and His Critics."

Operations in the steel industry in the United States are scheduled at 28 per cent of capacity this week, compared to 27.1 per cent last week, a gain of 0.9 point, or 3.3 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This is the third weekly gain from 26.1 per cent in the week of May 30.
Turpentine firm, 22 1/4c; sales 74 barrels; receipts 600 barrels; shipments 81- barrels; stock 37,057 barrels. Resin firm: sales 654: receipts 2,107; shipments 10: stock 146.223.

For the second consecutive year Miss Katherine Strikol, 17-year-old Wilmington golfer, captured medal honors in the annual Philadelphia junior girls' go tourney today. Her card of 83 represented 42 strokes out and 41 in.

The mortgages aggregating $101,000 covering the 5-story buildings at 953 and 957 Anderson Ave, Bronx, have been extended for five Years at 4 1/2% for Overbeck Properties, owner. Nehring Brothers, Inc. were the brokers. Two $4,000 mortgages, one covering 833 Prospect Pl and another covering. 2,072 64th St, Brooklyn. were purchased by the Godfrey Investing Corp.
William R. Spratt Jr., chief of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment trust study, died here today of pneumonia and complications following an operation. He was 47 years old.

Miss Mary Louise Hayes, daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hayes of West Point, was married in the Cadet Chapel this afternoon to Lieutenant William P. Brett, United States Army, son of J. Henry Brett of Statesboro, Ga. Colonel Clayton E. Wheat, United States Army, was the officiating clergyman.

An angry crowd of about fifty persons menaced United States Deputy Marshal George J. Reiss yesterday in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn as he was seeking to serve bench warrants in a contempt-of-court proceeding against two men whose identities were not disclosed.

All Jones, a steamship companies tonight joined in an ultimatum to steamship workers who today called a strike against the Porto Rico Line to return by 7 o'clock tomorrow morning or the companies would consider void the recent arbitration award granting substantial wage increases retroactive to the ending of last January's strike.

Few of the scores of boating enthusiasts who crowded the yard of the Consolidated Shipbuilding Corportion yesterday to witness the launching of a graceful, stream-lined, 112-foot yacht paid any attention to a squat, ugly tug idling in the Harlem River.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 17: CAPTAINS Irvine, W. L., Med. Corps, Coco Solo, C. Z., to Naval Hospital, Mare Island, in Sepmember.

Necessity for informed public support of local public officials in carrying on the campaign to reduce the highway accident rate was stressed yesterday by leaders of the safety movement at the first session of the second seminar of safety under the auspices of the Commercial Investment Trust, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Although the withdrawal of Misses Maureen Orcutt and Charlotte Glutting made the women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship a wide-open affair, only fourplayers seemed to have much chance of winning the title when the first round was concluded today at the Montclair Golf Club.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals confirmed yesterday the ruling of Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson refusing to enjoin the city from selling on June 30 to the highest bidder its $9,000,000 lien on the property of the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines now operated by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

The already extensive holdings of Harry Colen and his associates in the Riverdale section of the Bronx were increased by twenty-five acres in a deal closed last night, one of the largest purchases of recent years in that part of the Bronx.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates June 20, unless specified: Boston to New Haven: Arkansas, Roper, Tillman. Skagway to Juneau: Barry, Hopkins. San Pedro to Seattle: California, Maryland,
Vyse Ave (11-3130), e s 90 s of 178th St. 85x108; Mollie Blum to Rebecca Lieberman, 864 Fox St. Mace Ave (16-4427), n s 50 w of Barker Ave. 50x100; Eva Zeiderman to Alfonso Cianelli, 705 E 179th St.

The Rev. Donald MacOdrum, recently elected Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, died suddenly at his home today of a heart attack. He had been minister of the First Presbyterian Church here since 1925. His age was 75.

Mrs. Dorothy Smith Raynolds, wife of Harold Raynolds of Red Bank, N. J., an executive of the Devoe Raynolds Company, paint manufacturers, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after a brief illness.
The first phase of the espionage investigation that was ended yesterday by a special Federal grand jury got off to a small start in Dundee, Scotland, early last January.

The New York Stock Exchange revealed yesterday that hereafter a monthly summary showing the short interest in individual issues, where the short interest is substantial or where a significant change has occurred in the month, would be released instead of publishing only one aggregate figure for all issues.
The national A. A. U. track and field championship meet, scheduled for Buffalo July 2 and 3, looms as one of the finest in the fifty-year history of the organization.

The wholesale price level advanced last week, according to the commodity price index compiled by the Na- 4 tional Fertilizer Association. This index in the week ended June 18 stood at 74.5 per cent of the 19261928 average, against 74.4 in the preceding week, 74.7 a month ago and 86.4 a year ago.
Lyman Epps, whose youthful tenor voice sounded "Blow Ye the Trumpets, Blow" at the funeral of John Brown here in 1859, sang the same song on what he believes was his ninety-eighth birthday.

Princeton University's humanistic program took a major step forward today when Thomas Mann, selfexiled German writer, was appointed lecturer in the humanities at the annual commencement meeting of the university board of trustees. Fifteen other appointments on the faculty were made.
A demonstration by anthracite miners from Morea, New Boston and Mahanoy City on the tracks of the Reading Railroad delayed a passenger and mail train for 15 minutes today.

A message has been received here from W. H. Tilman, leader of the 1938 British Mount Everest expedition. It was written May 26 from Camp Three and states that the north col has been occupied by four Europeans and fifteen porters.

Announcement has been made of the marriage Sunday in Baltimore of Miss Eleanor Lancaster, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs: Edwin W. Lancaster of New York, to Donald F. White, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John L. White of Rochester, N. Y. The ceremony took place in the Towson Presbyterian Church and was performed by the pastor, the Rev. James M. Barnett.

Leaaing members of the Republican majority in the Constitutional Convention are seriously considering tonight a proposal, which has taken form over the week-end, for the creation of a steering committee which would map policies and party strategy for the future conduct of the convention.

They were packing up in the Louis camp here today, but Shufflin' Joe was excused from any of the heavy lifting. All they want him to pack is his punch. Joe was in and out of camp through the day. He went off on his roadwork in the morning. He took an auto ride about noon.

A subcommittee' of the House Interstate Commerce Committee, through its chairman, Representative Lea of California, today invited "constructive criticism" of a wool labeling bill on which it hopes to get favorable action by the next Congress.

Under the skillful handling of Sammy Renick, a mild sensation with his victorious long shots at the meeting, Herman Philips's Scrooge got up in the last jump or two to gain a photo decision over the Paragon Stable's Indomitable in the featured fifth race at Aqueduct yes- J terday. Scrooge paid 9 to 2, after having been played down from 6 to 1.
Georgette Davenport in 411 E 53d St: J. W. Lindau, in 301 E 38th St; Beatrice Durward, in 43 E 52d; Mack Gordon, in 68 E 56th St: J. F. Blood, in 971 1st Ave; Charlotte Andrews. broker.

Carl Hubbell, southpaw ace of the Giants, will go after his 200th victory today when the Reds start a three-game series at the Polo Grounds. He will be opposed by Jim Weaver, who has proved a consistent winner for Bill McKechnie since the Reds' leader claimed him via the waiver route this Spring.

A special Federal grand jury revealed yesterday the activities of the German espionage service in the United States and indicted eighteen persons, two of them women, in one of the bluntest documents castigating a friendly government since the tense days of the World War.

With more than seventy, varieties of lilies in which red, bronze and yellow blooms almost crowded out the more conventional white specimens, the Horticultural Society of New York opened a two-day lily show yesterday in its rooms at 598 Madison Avenue.

The controversy between the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Board over uniform bank examinations reached the ultimatum stage this afternoon when Secretary Morgenthau announced that he was giving the Reserve Board until Wednesday midnight to agree, after which he would make his report to President Roosevelt.

An effort to hasten an agreement on withdrawal of volunteers in Spain was made in a long talk in Rome yesterday between the British Ambassador and the Italian Foreign Minister. Italy was ready. to .make a "token withdrawal" or, apparently, to have her troops put in reserve. Guarantees by France to halt supplies to the Loyalists was the main condition demanded. [Page 1.
