Steiner, mtg $150,000. 3d Ave. 1,380, 25.6x100; Samuel Kridel et al to William R. Sidenberg, 1,165 Park Ave, conveys their 1/2 interest ($20).

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended June 16 was 247 compared with 273 in the preceding week and 166 for the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Apparently encouraged by his successful tilt with Dputy Mayor Henry H. Curran over the use of the word "contact" as a verb, Borough President James J. Lyons, the Bronx Cicero, gathered about him his faithful army of jibes and epigrams and launched a-new campaign to bait the Cato of City Hall.
Edwin J. Bell, president of the Bell Machine Company here, and an inventtor, died at his home at PauKo-Tuck here today following a long illness. He was 65 years old.

Mrs. Dorothy W. Anderson has been named merchandise manager and style supervisor of coats, suits, dresses, furs, millinery and sports apparel for women, misses and juniors at the John Wanamaker stores in New York and Philadelphia, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Marion Turpie and three-timed winner of the title, led the qualifiers with a record 77 in the women's Long Island match play golf championship at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

Miss Agnes L. Barnum, a teacher in the commercial department of the high school for twenty-five years, died at the Greenwich Hospital this morning. She was born in Binghamton, N. Y., and was graduated from Binghamton High School and Vassar College.

The one-story building containing 20,000 square feet of floor space at 19-19 Twenty-fourth Avenue, Long Island City, L. I., was leased by the General Steel Products Corporation, manufacturers of metal cabinets, shelving and kindred products. Arthur J. Goldsmith and the Cross Brown Company, co-brokers, negotiated the lease.

The current safety campaign of the police. and the city's motorists continued to bear fruit last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods of 1937, when tables of the safety bureau of the Police Department, made public yesterday, showed marked declines in accidents, deaths and injuries in city traffic.

The sudden activity and strength in stocks yesterday came as a most welcome surprise to the financial community where sagging prices and dull trading have been the rule for several months. There were no news developments to account for the rise. The consensus, however,

A picture of American conditions sharply contrasting with the general European view of them was drawn today by A. D. Lewis, brother of John L. Lewis, when the question of generalizing a shorter working week throughout the world came up in the International Labor Conference, preparatory to a vote tomorrow.

In an attempt to prevent automobile loads of workers from entering the plant of the Eagle Pencil Company at 712 East Fourteenth Street, 150 strikers and sympathizers hurled eggs and stones and swung wooden standards in a 20-minute battle with forty policemen soon after 8 A. M. yesterday.

The New York Central Railroad, a creditor of the Fonda, Johnstown Gloversville Railroad Company, was permitted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene as a party to the reorganization of the latter short line.
Jock Hutchinson Sr. and Jock Hutchinson Jr. qualified today in this area for the National Professional Golfers Association tournament at Shawnee-on-Delaware, Pa.
Several single family residences and a five-story multi-family dwelling in New Jersey were among the properties involved in deals reported by brokers yesterday.

A strong finish in the last two rounds enabled-Jack Sharkey Jr., 134 pounds, of Union City, N. J., to draw with Al Davis, 133 3/4, Brownsville, in the feature last night at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, before 5,000.

Richard R. Rogers of Mayfair House has sailed to pass the Summer in Cannes, France, with his son-in-law and daughter, Prince and Princess Christian of Hesse. Captain Carlisle Allan, U. S. A., and Mrs. Allan have come from Montgomery, Ala., and will be at 435 East Fifty-seventh Street until Sept. 1, when they will sail for Hawaii. They have been joined by Mrs. Allan's son, Michel Bouvier.
Scoring two runs off Johnny Lanning in the thirteenth inning, the Reds today beat the Bees, 3 to 1, to retain their slim second-place margin over the Cubs.

Miss Virginia Dunne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Dunne of this city, will be married to John J. Kirby, son of Mrs. John J. Kirby of New York and the late Mr. Kirby, on Saturday morning in St. Paul's Church here by the Rev. Charles M. Coveny, the pastor.
Henry Corwin Flower of Kansas City, a retired banker, died at the Greenwich Hospital this morning. He had been visiting his son, Henry C. Flower Jr. of Lake Avenue, for the past week.

The Treasury Procurement Division today reinvited bids, to be opened June 25, on a total of 626,500 yards of textiles, for shipment by Sept. 1, except as may be otherwise indicated on the bid. The invitations,

An expenditure of $12,500,000 for national defense in the current financial year was provided in the budget given to the Egyptian Parliament today. Egypt wants a standing army of at least 50,000 in -order to keep step with big neighbors across the Mediterranean and because of uncertainty concerning Italy's intentions in neighboring Libya.

Rumors of devaluation of the dollar were spiked with emphasis this afternoon by Secretary Morgenthau at his press conference, when he appeared to lose patience with those who persist in crediting the rumors which, last week, the Secretary said were inspired by speculators.
New York City's office buildings are maintaining a higher rate of occupancy than the average for the country as a whole, despite its burden of excess -space developed during boom years.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $41,500,000 of one-year 1 per cent consolidated debentures, Series E, of the Federal Home Loan Banks, due on July 1, 1939, it was announced yesterday by Preston Delano, Governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

The report of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company of Delaware and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on April 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,523,806 after interest, depreciation, taxes and amortization of flood expense, against $1,501,144 in the preceding comparable period.

In two nights and two and a half days Samuel Frank Houston drove the 1,180 miles from Selma, Ala., to New York with two Negroes so that New Yorkers might know how barbecue and Brunswick stew are prepared.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of June 10 on the Remington Rand case and the Wagner act called forth a letter from me in which, as I thought, and still think, I exposed a glaring error in your argument.

Yorkshire overwhelmed Surrey by an innings and 202 runs in a county cricket championship match concluded today. The southern county collapsed, making only 52 and 162 in reply to the champion county's 416 runs,

A sixth religious revolt faces the Protestant Church of the twentieth century and makes essential the replace ment of church methods with an improved technique, Roger W. Babson'told delegates to the General Council of the Congregational and Christian Churches today in his official address as moderator.

Frank Seremba's Pin Money, which had failed to win in its last six starts, captured the Winnetka purse at Lincoln Fields today by six lengths. Madison was second in the six-furlone event. with Aba third.

Maine Republicans renominated Governor Lewis O. Barrows and the State's three Republican Representatives in Congress at today's primary. Governor Barr6ws and Representatives James C. Oliver, in the First District, and Clyde H. Smith, in the second, won easily.

Contrasting features of recent changes in United States foreign trade have been the sharp decline in imports and the maintenance of exports at a relatively high level, according to a review issued today by the United States Tariff Commission.

Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived yesterday from London on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, declaring emphatically that he would not consider being boomed for President in 1940. He added that any such move would be a breach of faith with the President.

The Japanese Government has formally sent a circular statement to foreign envoys asking them to advise their governments to take precautionary measures for the protection of the lives and property of their nationals in a delimited zone in China.
The international stock market indices for June 18, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Cesar Teran, retired New York civir engineer and architect, died of a bullet wound in his bead at 4:55 o'clock this afternoon in the bathroom of his home at 49 Milburn Street here. Police said they found a .38-caliber revolver near his body and that it was "obviously a case of suicide."

The attorney for. Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's outstanding tennis player, announced today that his client had withdrawn his appeal against the sentence of a year's imprisonment imposed on his conviction May 14 on a morals charge.
Yale seniors of the college, the Sheffield Scientific School and the School of Engineering held their first- joint class-day program this afternoon, an arrangement which is to be followed hereafter.

Cafeteria Employes Union, Local 302, A. F. of L., has refused to obey the dictum of George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, to quit the.American Labor party, William Mesevich, president, and Sam Kramberg, secretarytreasurer, declare in an article in The Cafeteria Call, official organ of the local, published yesterday.

Kenneth F. Sutherland, Coney Island Democratic leader, charged yesterday that Mayor La Guardia was inconsistent with his own policy on public appointments when he attacked Mr. Sutherland's appointment to the general clerkship of the Brooklyn Supreme Court.
The published street plans of the World's Fair promise that Manhattan Islanders will feel at home next year when they make the journey to Flushing Meadows. City Hall Square,

Compromise prices for property to be taken over by the city in Long Island City for the Queensbridge Housing projects were revealed yesterday in condemnation hearings before Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood.

Ordway Puller, long an active figure in public life here, died today of an acute heart attack at the age of 64. He was a former member of the Virginia House of Delegates, the Bbard of Aldermen and more recently was Assistant City Attorney.

MANHATTAN ALBEE, HARLEY C. (May 30, 1937). Gross-assets, $58.811; net, $46,147. To Leonora Albee, widow, residue; Male E. Christensen, sister; Charles Albee, brother; Emma A. Mead, sister-in-law; Eva Albee, sisterin-law; Ivah Gardner, Harvey, Donald and Ronald Albee, nephews; Marjorie E. Reynolds, Mary Miller, nieces, stock bequests, value unknown. Chief assets,

Mrs. Charles Eastman of Greenwich led a field of seventy-eight starters in the sixteenth annual Westchester and Fairfield women's match play golf championship to win the gold qualifying medal with a score of 44, 40-84 over the Woodway Country Club course today.
French naval ceremony yesterday marked the annual official visit to New York of the French naval good-will ship d'Entrecasteaux, which is docked at the French Line pier, West Forty-eighth Street.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading I cities shows the following principal changes or the week ended June 15:
Motor vehicle receipts dropped to $2,182,126.46 in April, a loss of $150,259.80 from $2,332,386.26 in April a year ago, Charles A. Hartnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, announced today.

Clarence K. Reynolds testified here yesterday that he now recognized that the purchasers of the Reynolds Investing Company paid the Reynolds family group in part with $822,000 actually belonging to the public, which had been attracted by the Reynolds name to invest in their company.

Since 1919 the actual number of deaths from tuberculosis in the United States has dropped by more than onehalf. Meanwhile there has been an increase of more than twenty million in our population. We are defeating,

THE more one reads about European affairs, the more sick and frightened one is likely to become. Even the leading statesmen and experts don't seem to know what should be done. Take the case of Robert W. Seton-Watson, for the past fifteen years..Professor of Central European History at the University of London, and before that a member of the Intelligence Bureau attached to the British War Cabinet.
The Federal Trade Commission today announced that two New York State medicinal products dealers have entered into stipulations to stop certain false advertising practices.

The sales quota of tin for the quarter beginning on July 1 was fixed yesterday in London by the International Tin Committee at 35 per cent of basic tonnages, according to an announcement here by the International Tin Research Development Council.

Thomas. J. Bohan, 39 years old, the taxicab chauffeur who was convicted last week by a General Sessions jury of murder in the first degree in the shooting of Lucas Mardesich, 38, in the poker game holdup at 309 -West Twentieth Streettin the early morning of Dec. 12, 1929.

The town of Greenburgh, Westchester County, sold about 150 lots and eleven acreage parcels for $55,000 at the auction sale held Saturday at the Westchester County Center, White Plains, according to a check-up of the results made yesterday. Fred Berger was the auctioneer.
An indication of the extent to which the old "Left Front" in France has broken rank was given by the election yesterday of Raymond Laurent as Deputy for Saint Etienne.

Dr. Florence Barbara Seibert of the Henry Phipps Institute at the University of Pennsylvania received tonight the Trudeau Medal, given annually by the National Tuberculosis Association for distinguished research. The presentation was made at the annual dinner by Dr. J. Arthur Myers, president of the organization.

Second Grade- Detective Mary A. Smartly of the Pickpocket Squad had her reasons for stopping a smartly-dressed man outside Macy's at noon yesterday, so she stopped him. "Just a minute," she said. "I'm a police officer."

MANHATTAN BELETSKY, VLADIMIR (May 20). Estate, $500. To Ann Kuzmiek, 117 E. 7th St. Valdemar T. Kruglak, 151 Avenue A. executor. BURNETT, JACOB B. (June 11). Estate, more than $10,000. To Annie B. Wolf, sister, executrix, 200 W. 90th St., threeeighths residue; Jessie B. Cohn, sister,

In consonance with higher foreign quotations and strong outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply yesterday to end with gains of 10 to 13 points. Heavy general rains over the week-end TEX from Eastern Arkansas to the At- Cot lantic Seaboard continued to bring Pri excessive moisture in many sections, with reports of increasing insects in fields lacking cultivation.
The State Supreme Court today refused to grant Governor Earle a writ of prohibition preventing the proposed Dauphin County grand jury investigation of his administration.

Miss Beatrice Barclay Chard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Chard of New York and Cazenovia, and a descendant of the Barclay, Schuyler and Livingston families, was married in St. Peter's Church here this afternoon to George Benjamin Carpenter, son of Judge and Mrs. George A. Carpenter of,Chicago. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ivol Curtis, rector of the church.

New regulations for licensing of beauty schools will be put into effect soon. Copies of license requirements have been mailed by the State Education Deapartment to schools of the State and 130 training schools have already filed applications.

Compensations of the trustees and counsel for the bankrupt Erie Railroad were fixed today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The maximum compensation of C. E. Denney was fixed at $30,000 a year, and that of John A. Hadden at $15,000.

Daniel H. Killing, secretary of the Dembcratic State Committee and assistant secretary of the Constitutional Convention, died yesterday morning in Union Hospital, the Bronx, following an abdominal operation. He was 48 years old.

The United Mine Workers of America rather than the coal operators of Harlan County was to blame for the lack of union contracts in that rich soft-coal field, the first witness for the defense testified here today in the Federal trial of operators and former peace officers accused of using force and violence to block organization of the miners.

Dr. Mahmud Azmi, principal of the Baghdad Law School, and Dr. Hassan Abu Saud Saif, a lecturer, were shot and seriously injured today by a student who was infuriated over his failure to pass a recent school examination.
A banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co. received the award yesterday of a new issue of $2,400,000 of bonds of the Hartford, Conn., Metropolitan District,

At the Con- inve stitutional Convention tonight the field of controversy between the Democrats and the Republicans Dun over a proposed search and seizure clause for the State Constitution was narrowed to the question of whether evidence obtained by prose restrictions should be admissible in court.

" Hathaway," the late V. Everit Macy estate, consisting of a thirtyfive room Colonial house and 550 acres of land at Tannersville, N. Y., was sold at auction Saturday for $12,500, it was learned yesterday. Isadore Malvin of Manhattan and Max Reizen of Detroit were the successful bidders.

Dr. Ignatz Griebl fled to Germany May 10, aboard the liner Bremen, after a subpoena had been issued for his appearance before the Federal grand jury. Landing at Bremerhaven, he was arrested for traveling without a passport and was fined 60 marks.

Warrant Officer John Donahue personally conducted David Schwartzer, 36 years old, of 42 East Twentyeighth Street, manager of a restaurant at 145 West Forty-first Street, to Traffic Court yesterday because he allegedly had failed to answer seventeen summonses for parking violations between Feb. 11 and June 8.

Scribner's has announced two books by Ernest Hemingway for September publication. "The First Forty-Eight" is a collection of all his published and three new short stories. "The Fifth Column: A Play," his first full-length play, deals with the Fascist organization that works inside Loyalist lines in Spain.

Overpowering M. San Pedro's Pordina with a bristling display of speed down the back stretch, the Rosedale Stable's Kentucky Blues stayed on top all the way home to annex the Fitchburg Purse, six-furlong feature at Suffolk Downs today. A 7-10 choice, Kentucky Blues scored her second straight victory.
Rosie, a 14-year-old, 3,000-pound hippopotamus in the Central Park Zoo, is-the mother of a fifty-twopound daughter, Park Department officials announced yesterday.

Jimmy Hines, metropolitan open champion, who returned last week after unsuccessful attempts to capture the national and Western open crowns, took two prizes in the Long Island P. G. A. one-day event at the St. Albans Golf Club yesterday.

The Danzig The Danzing Diet met today after an interval of nearly a year to celebrate the fifth anniversary of Danzig's National Socialist government. Seventy Nazi Deputies appeared in brown shirts while only two representatives of the Polish minority wore ordinary clothes.

Grand Rabbi Samuel Kaufman of the Congregation Beth Samuel Miropol, 182 Henry Street, died Sunday night at his home at that address. Funeral services were held yesterday and several thousand Jews of the East Side attended. Burial was in Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield, L. I.

Summoned by the clanging of the town's old alarm bell, citizens joined with State troopers and forest firefighters tonight in a search for an 18-year-old girl believed lost in treacherous Weymouth Swamp.
If Dr. Townsend is in penumbra, his Plan goes marching on. In his campaign for renomination Senator Pepper of Florida clung tenderly to the Townsendites.

The Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corportion signed contracts yesterday for the renovation of the Panama Pacific liners Virginia and Pennsylvania and will remove them this morning from their Hudson River piers to drydock at the Morse plant In Brooklyn.
Funeral services for Senator Royal S. Copeland, senior Senator from New York State, will be held at his home here at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

In the drawing room of the Polish Embassy at Washington there stands on a charming French table the pastel portrait of a man His hair is clubbed behind, and he wears a frilled collar and eighteenth century coat.

The fifty-seventh all-England lawn tennis championships were opened today by Donald Budge of the United States, who, as the 1937 triple champion here and the oddson favorite to repeat this year, was assigned to the first match on the center court.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

" Hathaway," the late V. Everit Macy estate, consisting of a thirtyfive room Colonial house and 550 acres of land at Tannersville, N. Y., was sold at auction Saturday for $12,500, it was learned yesterday. Isadore Malvin of Manhattan and Max Reizen of Detroit were the successful bidders.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that the fact that it had failed to make its report to Congress on the investment-trust study under the Holding Company Act prior to January, 1937, as specified in the law, did not invalidate a continuance of the study beyond that date.
Japanese reports declare that flood waters nea Chungmow and Weihsi on the LungHai Railway sector are now subsiding, but they admit an increase in Chinese guerrilla warfare.
Meeting of the Kiwanis Club of Brooklyn, Towers Hotel, Brooklyn, 12:30 P. M. "The Work of the Adolescent Court," Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto.

Mrs. Christopher Wren of 229 East Forty-eighth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Curtis Wren, to Lawrence Lanier Winslow Jr., son of Mrs. Winslow of East House, Wickliffe, Ohio, and the late Mr. Winslow of this city.

Matthew F. Kenney, former Deputy Purchase Commissioner in the preceding Tammany administrations and confidant and political adherent of James J. Hines, lower West Harlem Tammany leader, awaiting trial with eight others in the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy monopoly, was cited yesterday for contempt of the Supreme Court extraordinary grand jury's investigation of the racket.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 15, aggregated $8,629,000,000, or 2 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 11 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The Harvard varsity crew, continuing its policy of tapering off training in the last few days before the regatta with Yale Friday, rowed four miles tonight on the Thames River, devoting much of the short session to racing starts and sprints.

Warnings were issued today to American exporters by the Department of Commerce suggesting that they should have in hand a "confirmed irrevocable letter of credit" before accepting orders for shipment to Japan.
Dean V. and Donald J. Hanscom, 20-year-old twin sons of Dean J. Hanscom, general passenger agent of the Dollar Steamship Lines, were separated by the wreck of the train Olympian in Montana Sunday.

Proposals have been made for the following changes :n partnerships in New York Stock Exchange firms: Albert J. Wright, Exchange member and special partner in Abbott, Proctor Paine, to retire on June 30; Walter W. Price, general partner, to become a special partner on the same date.

Game Postponed The baseball game which was scheduled to be played in Philadelphia, on Tuesday, June 21. by teams representing Philadelphia and New York, has been postponed until Thursday, June 23. Notice Special Order 116, dated June 17, relative to the Department Band reporting at the 7th Regiment Armory, on June 23, is revoked.

Cooperative promotion of a new color in order to stimulate Fall business will mark the activities of the coat affiliates of the Fashion Originators Guild.of America, Inc., it was announced yesterday at the guild offices. The new color,

Anticipating demands from many industries to be exempted from payment of overtime rates under the Wage and Hour Law, the Labor Department began today a detailed study of seasonal industries as far back as 1919.

The Bermuda Assembly today rushed through three readings of a bill to overcome a liquor "drought" at the Castle Harbour Hotel, where 175 guests are experlencing without relish a reminder of prohibition days.

Miss Lydia Patricia Mathews Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Drelincourt Mathews Martin of 163 East Seventy-first Street, has completed plans for her marriage to-Dr.John Lawrence Pool Saturday in St. James Church.

Restaurants and cafeterias in Greater New-York, which participated in yesterday's "Restaurant Day" to aid the United Palestine Appeal and Joint Distribution Committee in their campaign for the settlement of European refugees in Palestine, contributed $7,000 to the S. food division of the two organizations.

Representative Wright Patman, who introduced drastic anti-chain store tax legislation in the last Congress, promised members of the National Association of Retail Grocers here today "on my honor" that voluntary and cooperative groups of independents were not included in the

The Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Scholarship prizes of $150 each to a boy and girl graduate of Manhattan elementary schools on the basis of character, conduct, record and proficiency will be awarded this morning in the office of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions for Reorganization J. GLASSMAN SONS, INC., hotel and and restaurant supplies, 707 8th Ave.Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Laws, with liabalities of $8.188 and assets of $13,844.
Senator Frank Durand of Monmouth County was sworn in today by Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis Speakers as State Auditor. He succeeds Walter R. Darby.

Miss Jane H. T. Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Perry of 139 East Sixty-sixth Street, was married to John W. Vandercook, writer and explorer, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection by the rector, the Rev. Gordon Wadhams.

Kreutzer Hall, the four-story structure at 228 East Eighty-sixth Street and the three-story building adjoining it in the rear, which is known as 227 East Eighty-fifth Street, have been leased by the Cabaret-Restaurant Rheinland, Inc., which also leased store space in 225 East Eighty-fifth Street.

One of the largest congresses ever held in this country opened at Scheveningen today-the eighth International Road Congress-under the presidency of Dr. J. A. M. van Buuren, Minister of Waterways, in the presence of Prince Bernhard.
Manuel Garcia was resting yesterday with friends at 619 West 136th Street after driving a bus with fifty Mexicans from Mexico City to New York to see the Joe LouisMax Schmeling match.
Dispatches from Sabtang in Batanes Province in the north of Luzon Island told today of a brush between Sabtang police and the crew of a Japanese launch that anchored at Sumnanga without permission.

Although held to a draw by E. D. Bogoljubow of Dresden in their adjourned game from the seventh round, Erich Eliskases of Vienna retained first place in the international chess masters' tournament today.
Augustus Graves Ely, a member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Ely Co., 120 Broadway, died at his home here today at the age of 64 after a long illness.
The State Education Department will endeavor to enforce health and physical education regulations in the Fall term to permit participation in competitive sport by all public school pupils.

Miss Priscilla Reed Wadhams of this city, daughter of Judge William H. Wadhams of Paris, France, and the late Mrs. Wadhams, was married yesterday to Carl Baker Avery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Olin M. Avery of Morganton, N. C., in the Church of the Resurrection. The Rev. Gordon Wadhams performed the ceremony.

A number of properties in the Bronx were reported yesterday by brokers as having changed 'hands. Included were the two apartment houses at 3,010 and 3,014 Holland Avenue, near Burke Avenue, which were sold by the Rossam Land Corporation to a client of Elroy-Clark Co., Inc., broker in the deal.

All his life Captain Bob Bartlett has been getting along to far places-once, with Peary, almost to the North Pole. At 63 he is really getting along. Now it appears that he has finally settled down, not just as most people would, perhaps, but in his own way. He has settled down as an Arctic commuter.
The talk between King Carol of Rumania and President keman Ataturk of Turkey on Sunday was warmly received in the Yugoslav press today.

Quincy Ave (18-5545), ??, 418' ft n of Randall Ave, 31x100; also Quincy Ave, e s, 394 ft e of Randall Ave 24x100; Marcel Levy to Frank Zampino, 2,517 St. Raymond Ave. 142d St, 300-302 E (9-2322); Gluseppe' DI Pasqua to Emllio Dorazio, 674 Morris Ave.

The so-called Lyons residence law was declared valid yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Ro-. senman in two decisions sustaining the action of the Civil Service Commission in refusing to certify for appointment two otherwise eligible men who did not meet the requirements of the statute.

An insatiable demand on the part of the American gardening public for more and better flowers was made evident in reports to the convention of the American Seed Trade Association being held here. The session is marked by a record-breaking registration from all sections of the country.

Enactment of a city occupancy tax ranging from $1 to $6 a year on rented business properties was voted by the City Council yesterday at its meeting in City Hall to raise $600,000 which will guarantee interest on a $20,000,000 fund for slum clearance and construction of new housing.

Mrs. Francis M. Whitehouse has returned from Stockbridge, Mass., and is at the Ambassador before going to her home at 340 Park Avenue. Mr. and Mrs. Rush Sturges and Miss Alice Sturges of Providence are at the Ritz-Carlton.

Contributions from the employes of 447 public schools and departments of the Board of Education to the Greater New York Fund now total $39,500, it was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign to collect $10,000,000 for the private social welfare and health agencies of this city.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 1,802,817 common shares of $1-par value of Hecker Products Corporation in substitution for voting trust certificates for outstanding common shares upon the expiration of the

Competing in perfect golfing weather, all the favorites in the sixteenth annual Westchester and Fairfield women's championship came through the first round of match play over the Woodway Country Club course today.

The government has reduced the period of compulsory military service -from a year to eleven months with the provision that conscripts spend one month working on national highways -and irrigation projects. Conscripts in such service will be under the direction of the Minister of Public Works.
Steel ingot output increased last week, countering the normal seasonal trend, and the adjusted index moved upward to 35.9 from 33.9. For the week ended June 19, 1937, it stood at 108.6.

Governor Lehman announced. tonight his candidacy for the United States Senate to succeed the late Royal S. Copeland. By so doing, he inferentially disclaimed any intention of remaining in Albany for another four years as Governor.

A vocal recital by pupils of Irma Swift will be given tonight at Steinway Hall. The Charlotte Lund Opera Chorus will hold auditions tonight from 6 to 10 o'clock at the Academy of Allied Arts, 349 West Eighty-sixth Street. The chorus is preparing to give an English version of Gounod's "Faust."

The structure and methods of the German espionage, propaganda and secret police forces were described yesterday, following the indictment of eighteen persons as spies, by Albert Grzesinski, who was Prussian Minister of the Interior and twice Police President of Berlin between 1926 and 1932.

At the end of a month and a half of active campaigning the Greater New York Fund found itself with a little more than four million dollars pledged out of the ten million it had hoped to raise to supplement the too scanty funds of hundreds of essential private charities in this city.

Summer began officially at 10:41 o'clock last night; ushered in by the longest day of the year. The sun rose at 5:24 o'clock yesterday and set at 8:31, giving New Workers fifteen hours and seven minutes of daylight.

Thirty-two villages in Nassau and Suffolk Counties elected yesterday Mayors, trustees or other village officers. Many incumbents were returned to office and save in two communities in Nassau and three in Suffolk the elections were uncontested.

The Interstate Commerce Commission will consider tomorrow an application of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad for increased rates between Jersey City and Hoboken, N. J., and Hudson Terminal in New York City.
Frankie Cavanna, 149, East Side, outpointed Joe Pennino, 146, Brooklyn, in the main bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena in Long Island City last night. A crowd of 3,000 saw Cavanna triumph.

Miss Betty Rafter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Raymond Rafter of this place, was married today to John Vincent Higgins, son of John A. Higgins of New York and the late Mrs. Higgins, in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here. The Rev. Joseph McCann performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Hudson River Country Club, Yonkers.
Three men thumbed their way today to a scheduled appointment with President Roosevelt, and none had ever tried hitch-hiking before.

Totalitarian governments, the forces of atheism and organized purveyors of immorality present the greatest challenge the church has faced since the first century, Dr. P. O. Bersell, president of the Evangelical Lutheran Augustana Synod of North America, declared last night at the opening of the seventy-ninth annual convention of the synod at the Bethlehem Lutheran Church, Third Avenue and Pacific Street. Brooklyn.
Gene Sarazen today announced he had decided to passup the British open golf championship for another try for the national professional title here, July 10-16.

Major A. Elliott Ranney, sportsman, crack pistol, rifle and shotgun marksman and World Warveteran, died yesterday at Doctors' Hospital, after a long illness. Major Ranney, who made his home at the Hotel Elysee, 56 East Fifty-fourth Street, was 62.years old.
The dollar continued to recover strongly in the foreign. exchange market on the assurance given by Henry Morgenthau, Secretary of the Treasury, that no devaluation was contemplated.

Agreement was reached this afternoon by fiscal officials of the Federal Government on a uniform bank examination which virtually assures the liberalizing of bank policy toward financial aid to small business organizations which cannot obtain
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 18: Bryan, Capt. G. H., to duty as hydrographer, Navy Department, Washington, D C., in June.

Chinese reports said four Japanese divisions were being concentrated in the vicinity of Anking, in Anhwei Province, for a push west against the provisional capital. An additional 20,000 men and 200 tanks were said to be on their way to Anking from the Lung-Hai area, where vast floods have prevented a Japanese advance.

The action of Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. in refusing a license to the Great Lakes Fish Shippers, Inc., for the sale of fresh fish at Peck Slip was sustained yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter.

While most of the favorites moved safely into the quarter-finals of- the women's Long Island. golf championship by taking their firstround matches at the North Hempstead Country Club today, there was a surprise when Mrs. W. R. Kirkland Jr. of Women's National defeated Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Queens Valley, 4 and 3.

Foreign Minister Kazushige Ugaki is seriously considering a declaration of war against China for the dual purpose of forcing powers who are neutral to observe neutrality and to facilitate the advance on Canton if such an advance becomes necessary.

Commercial and industrial fallures in the United States in the week ended June 16 increased in four out -of five trade divisions, as compared with the same week of 1937, according to the weekly summany prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Adjutant General released the- following orders today: Stewart, Capt. Leslie M., assigned to headquarters, 107th Inf., as assistant plans and training officer. McMillan, 2d Lt. Thomas R., assigned to 107th Inf..; for further assignment to Company H.
Governor Herbert H. Lehman's entrance into politics was as campaign manager for Alfred E. Smith in the latter's successful campaign for Governor in 1926.

George B. Gibbons Co., Inc., and Adams, McEntee Co., Inc., obtained yesterday $625,000 of sewer bonds of Westchester County, N. Y., on their bid of 100.632 for 2s. The bonds, to be dated July 1, 1938, and maturing serially from July 1, 1939 to 1951, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.35 per cent for the 1939 maturities to about 2.22 per cent for the final maturities.

More than one trusted and well-loved Governor has wished to round out in the national capital his career in public service. The deep interest of Herbert Lehman in national affairs has long been evident. And for many friends his announcement last evening that he is willing to stand as a candidate for the seat left vacant through the death of Senator Copeland will occasion no surprise.

Miss Jane Robb Murdoch gave a dinner last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre for Miss Marian Kingsland and her fiance, Count Hans C. Seherr-Thoss, whose marriage will take place next Saturday at Manetto Hill Farm, the home of Miss Kingsland's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar W. Leonard, in Syosset, L. I.

Charley Root's relief pitching today gave the Cubs a 4-to-3 victory over the Phillies. Root replaced Rookie Paul Epperly in the sixth after the Phils had scored two runs on Morrie Arnovich's home run with Phil Weintraub on base.

Mrs. Esther S. Goldfrank, seven rooms, in 125 Riverside Dr; M. Morgenthau-Seixas Co, Inc, broker. Drs. Arpad Lux and Leigh F. Sturges, in 1,225 Park Ave; Dr. Harry Beller, in 65 Moehler, in 205 W 54th St; Byrne Bowman, Inc, brokers.

Major John A. Warner, Superintendent of State Police, warned automobile drivers today that after July 1 his department would rigidly enforce the new traffic regulation that requires drivers to keep to the right.

More than 600 delegates representing 115 posts in New York County are expected to attend the twentieth annual convention of the county organization of the American Legion, which -opens tonight at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
Authorization of a new Southeastern district with a laymen membership of several thousand marked today's session of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod of Missouri (United States and Canada).

Carrying out a plan believed to have been in her mind for many years should the time ever come when she could not see economic security ahead, Maude Woodcock, who for thirty years had given San Juan children their first music lessons, shot herself through the heart early this morning.

President Roosevelt signed yesterday the new pump-priming bill which is intended to aid business. Today the National Industrial Conference Board publishes a report which throws light on one of the really fundamental factors in the present business situation.

Scoring an 83 today over the No. 2 and 4 nines of the Montclair Golf Club, Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol increased her lead to four strokes in the fourteenth annual women's New Jersey Golf Association closed championship.

Replying to the British Government's last protest on the sinking of a number of her merchantmen, General Francisco Franco, Insurgent leader, today declared that more than 200 ships flying the Union Jack had attempted to carry contraband to Republican [Loyalist] ports since the first of the year.

Carter Goodrich, speaking for the United States Government in the International Labor Conference today put the force of American example behind a proposal before the conference for world-wide consultation of governments with a view to generalizing shorter hours for labor.

Honorary pallbearers who will serve at the funeral of Daniel H. Killing, secretary of the Democratic State Committee, today at 10:45 A. M. at St. Joseph's Church, Bathgate Avenue and 178th Street, the Bronx, were announced today.

Jersey City's Little Giants earned an even break in their fourgame series with Rochester today as they closed their home stand with a 3-to-2 victory. Hy Vandenberg went the route for the Jerseys, scattering ten hits in effective fashion to garner his fifth straight victory. He walked two and struck out two.

Two former defendants in the Harlan coal conspiracy case testified today that they were unaware that the coal operators' association to which their companies belonged used its general fund to finance a reign of terror against union organizers and union members.

Councilman Anthony J. Di Giovanna, Brooklyn Democrat, said yesterday that his local law barring the display of "Press" except upon written permission from the Police Commissioner was designed to end the misuse of such term by unauthorized persons.

During a closed session in which only members of-the National Association of Retail Grocers participated this afternoon, a strong resolution in approval of the objectives of the proposed Patman Chain Store Tax Bill was unanimously approved, then withdrawn, later resubmitted, and then held over until tomorrow morning for action.

Twenty-one members of the Police Department received a total of $1,250 in prizes and fourteen gold, silver and bronze medal pins and bars at a ceremony yesterday morning at Police Headquarters. The presentations were those of the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York, which selected the men for rescues from drowning made during 1937.

Dr. Ferdinand A. Kertess, dwelling on Scarborough Rd, Briarcliff Manor, Westchester; Prince Ripley, Inc, Brokers. Eugen Becher, the Dr. Robert E. Gillie residence on Ridgewood Drive, Apawamis, Rye; E. V. Siedle, broker.

The report of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges of $12,794,162, equal, after preferred dividend charges, to 11 cents a share on the outstanding common stock.

Vincent Dailey, political aide of Postmaster General James A. Farley, is slated to become secretary of the Democratic. State Committee to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Daniel H. Skilling, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. Laura Prime Jay Wells, widow of Frederic De Witt Wells of New York, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at her country home in New Canaan, Conn. She was born in Fairhaven, Conn., sixty-three years ago, a daughter of the late Rev. Peter Augustus Jay and Julia Post Jay, and a greatgreat-granddaughter of John Jay, first Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
The Bees combined one solid hit with two errors today to defeat the Cardinals, 3 to 1, and give Righthander Jim Turner his seventh triumph. All the Boston runs, made in the third, were unearned.
Edwin Kingsley of Salt Lake City won medal honors today in the qualifying round of the Trans-Mississippi golf - tournament with a sizzling 68, four under par.

Philip Hauser, for more than half a century organist and choirmaster of the Sixty-eighth Street German Evangelical Reformed Church, died early yesterday morning in New York Hospital after an illness of two months. He was 67 years old.

Sunshine splashed through tall trees upon a green campus- today as Princeton University conferred 570 degrees at its 191st commencement and gave honorary degrees to Cordell Hull, Secretary of State; Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey and eight others.

Backed very heavily in the closing minutes, Great Union sustained his backers by scoring decisively at 3 to 1 in the Whorler Handicap, six and a half furlong feature at Aqueduct yesterday. At the finish Charley Kurtsinger had the son of Sir Gallahad III two lengths clear.

Rivington St, n w cor Ludlow St, 25x66.1; Mary Levy to Riviow Corp, 18 Hillside Ave, Williston Park, N. Y. ($2.50). 18th St, 523-527 E, 61x86.3; Williams Fuerst, Inc, to Emigrant Bank, which holds a mtg. for $31,850.

With fight fans gathering in the city from all parts of the country and also from abroad to see the Joe Louis-Max Schmeling battle at the Yankee Stadium tonight, New York will entertain the largest crowd of visitors it has had since the American Legion took over the town last year.

Knopf will bring out early in Au-. gust an American edition of Lancelot Hogben's new book, "Science for the Citizen." Printings of the English edition, published in London on May 27, totaled 40,000 copies in the first three weeks.

A special collection of highly styled apparel and accessories, designed to stimulate consumer interest in luxurious Fall costumes, was presented yesterday at a fashion show held at the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center.

Dr. Carl Eggers of New York City has been elected president of the Alumni Association of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. Other officers elected were Dr. Martin de Forest Smith, vice president; Dr. Rudolph M. Schulliner, treasurer, and Dr. Louis M. Rousselot, secretary.
Dr. John J. Fralinger, physician and pharmacist, died at his home here today after a short illness. His age was 54.

The indictment of active German naval officers in high positions in their native land on charges of directing an espionage conspiracy in the United States created a most painful impression in government quarters here.

Edwin L. Weisl, counsel, and John W. Hicks Jr., vice president in charge of foreign affairs of Paramount Pictures, Inc., were elected yesterday directors of the company and the retiring directors were reelected by more than 71 per cent of the votes at the annual meeting of stockholders.

Citing the existing situation in the city of Knoxville, whereby the Tennessee Public Service Company is faced with "destructive competition" from both the municipality and the Tennessee Valley Authority, R. W. Lamar,

Retired Engineer of Steamer Thomas J. Boyle, formerly a member of Engine Co. 52, residing at 210 West 262d-St., Bronx, died June 20. Trial Decisions The following members of the Department having been tried before Francis X.

Mr. and Mrs. Alvin F. Sortwell of Twin Cedars, this place, have announced the engagement of their third daughter, Miss Frances Augusta Sortwell, to John Hazen Perry, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Prince Hazen Perry of Rosebrook Farm, New Canaan, Conn.

In a brief ceremony in his office yesterday morning, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, awarded the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Scholarship prizes to two elementary school children for excellence in character, conduct, record and studies.

Nick Camarata, 133 1/2, New Orleans, and Lew Feldman, 134 1/4, Brownsville, battled to a draw in the main eight-rounder at the Canarsie Arena in Brooklyn last night. In the semi-final of six rounds, Dewey Anderson, 146 1/2, Harlem, outpointed Frankie (Kid) Bruno, 150 1/2, Brooklyn.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today regulations regarding Puerto Rican sugar to become effective on June 27.
Charles Heling, who was Mayor of Lindenhurst for three terms, 1931 to 1937, died today at his home here from a stroke suffered a few hours earlier. 'His age was 57.

Der Angriff, organ of Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, today complained bitterly of the "unsportsman-like" attitude of the American press toward tomorrow's championship fight between Max Schmeling and Joe Louis.

With Jimmie Gleeson and Bob Seeds sharing batting laurels, the Bears tonight ran their victory streak to twelve games by defeating Montreal, 7 to 2. Gleeson had a triple and two singles, one of which drove in a couple of mates, while Seeds blasted his twenty-eighth homer of the year, a 390-foot-drive in the fifth with Keller aboard. Gleeson's hitting extended his streak to thirteen games.

The three three-story multi-family buildings with stores at 235-45 Wolfs Lane and 651 Third Street, Pelham, Westchester, on a corner plot .190 by 95 feet, have been sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to an investing client of Lewis R. Schwartz, broker.

Unless the political aspects of the New York situation persuade the Democratic leaders in this State and Senator Wagner that he should run for Governor, the Senator will be a candidate for re-election.

An interesting resume of the view taken in prominent quarters concerning the relations between Czechoslovakia and Germany was gathered by the writer in conversation with responsible politicians at a reception for the foreign press given this afternoon by Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta.

George D. Haskell, president of the Baush Machine Tool Company, who was called as a government witness in the trial before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey of a suit to enjoin the Aluminum Company of America and its affiliates from alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-trust Law, was examined again. yesterday by defense counsel,

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Queens on Monday made awards aggregating $202,000 to owners of property in Long Island City, Queens, taken by the city in connection with the Queensbridge housing project.

FOR the last couple of years I have noticed that a about this season my colleagues on The Courier, The Daily Gazette, The Advertiser and The Globe-Bee begin to allude to a mysterious something called Summer fiction, exactly as if it were a perennial phenomenon like daylight-saving time or light underwear.

Production of steel in England in May, at 957,000 tons, was 18,000 tons better than in April, which month, however, included the Easter holidays. Last month's output was only 90,000 tons less than that of May, 1937, while the April production was 141,000 tons less than the comparative figure for 1937.
The Citizens Housing Council will hold a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Commodore on Thursday, June 30, when a report on a housing program for New York will be presented.

The diplomatic corps in Washington will be well represented here on Thursday of. next week at the grounds of the New York World's Fair of 1939. A total of 157 diplomatic officials of sixty-four foreign nations participating in the fair will participate in the program which will mark President Roosevelt's visit to the fair grounds in the afternoon.

Women are no longer an "ornament of the home but a vital part of society, business and industry" and their talents are needed in these as much as those of the men, Mrs. Mary Roebling of Trenton, only woman bank president in New Jersey, told the Soroptimist International Association in the Hotel Claridge here today.
Turpentine firm, 22 1/2c; sales 65 barrels; receipts 1,016 barrels; shipments 130 barrels; stock 37,043 barrels. Resin firm; sales 429; receipts 3,280; shipments 655; stock 148,848.

Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of mammals and reptiles at the Bronx Zoo, will celebrate his sixtysecond birthday today by starting a long-cherished task. For many years Dr. Ditmars has dreamed of producing a complete, up-to-date and authoritative account of the reptiles of North America.

Although the extraordinary Supreme Court grand jury held no session yesterday in its investigation of politicians and "judicial officers and others" alleged to have been involved in the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy game monopoly since 1931, there were reports the grand jurors had turned to interrogating members of former District Attorney William C. Dodge's prosecuting staff.

Mme. Curie-Joliot, daughter of the discoverer of radium, is at work on ores from Canada's subArctic radium deposits, it was disclosed today by F. B. Friend of Port Hope, Ont., radium physicist, who arrived here to speak before the Society of Chemical Industry.
Another "the show must go on" notice was issued today to employes of Ringling Brothers Barnum Baily Circus by John Ringling North, president.
As usual, there was only a thin vote in the Maine primary and the results were as expected. On the Republican side, Governor Barrows was renominated by about 3 to 1 over State Senator Fernald,
An investing client of William A. Krahe Son, Inc., brokers, has purchased from the Lawyers Trust Company, as trustee, the three-story building at 29-02 Twenty-fourth Avenue Long Island City, Queens.

The executive committee of the Johnstowners, Inc., a flood control organization, approved today the erection of a statue of the late Senator Copeland to commemorate his work in obtaining flood control legislation.

Forty per cent of the net receipts will be donated to the Greater New York Fund when four Negro baseball teams meet in a double-header at the Yankee Stadium next Sunday. The New York Black Yankees will oppose the Pittsburgh Crawfords in the opening contest,

The stock market here was cheerful on the whole today and most sections advanced. Gilt-edged issues were steady, while among the foreign loans German bonds did well. Transatlantic stocks had good support and United States Steel and International Nickel went ahead.

Oral Hildebrand gave only five hits and struck out seven today as the Browns won the first of their threegame series with the Athletics, 5 to 2. Home runs accounted for two Brownie tallies and one of Philadelphia's runs.

Riding roughshod over all sorts of obstacles, including another erratic exhibition of hurling by their youthful Bob Feller, the front-running Indians went on the loose today to deal a smashing blow to the invading Yankee horde.
The first act of terrorism in Tel Aviv, a 100 per cent Jewish city, took place tonight when a bomb was thrown near a movie theatre. It seriously injured a child.

Secret meetings of industrialists, some of whom might meet President Roose- per velt's definition in his April message on monopoly of the powerful few who "manage the economic life of the nation," have been held in Washington in the last month with New Deal policy-makers in the antitrust field, it was learned today.

Edward L. Ballard, chairman of the executive committee of the Merchants Fire Assurance Corporation of New York, left a net estate of $1,937,010 when he died-on last Dec. 31, according to a transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday.

A resemblance between the present generation of youthful artists and writers and those in the years immediately following the Civil War, was pointed out today by Van Wyck Brooks, author and Pulitzer prize winner, in an address before the Harvard Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa at the annual literary exercises of the honorary scholastic society.

Imperio Argentina, star of "Morena Clara," the Spanish film that had its New York premiere at the Teatro Hispano last Friday, is said to be a supporter of the Rebel cause. When this report became known in Harlem, pro-Loyalist elements there proceeded to picket the Teatro Hispano.

Directors of the Shell Union Oil Corporation yesterday declared an interim dividend of 35 cents a share on the company's 13,070,625 outstanding shares of common stock. Last year the company paid interim dividends on the common stock of 50 cents on July 15 and Dec. 20.

To take effect 8 A. M., June 22: PATROLMEN-George A. Kevil, 25th Precinct, assigned to duty as attendant. David S. Drayton, from 60th Precinct to Traffic Precinct B. Joseph F. Schoppmeyer, from 17th DIvision to Traffic Precinct C, assignments to clerical duty discontinued.

Under the stimulus of tax exemption for improvements, FHA insurance of loans and preparation for next year's World Fair, the value of alterations and renovations to properties throughout New York City's five boroughs is expected to approximate $75,000,000 for 1938, according to a report made public yesterday as submitted to Mayor La Guardia by William Stanley Miller, president of the city Tax Commission.

Stuart J. Fuller, United States member, told the League of Nations' Opium Advisory Committee today that he had just received telegraphically the "startling" information that "an armed Japanese vessel" had reached Macao, Portuguese colony in South China, about April 3 from Iran with more than 2,000 chests of raw opium.

The Federal Government's claim for more than $3,000,000 for 1931 income taxes against the estate of the late Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, was settled today for approximately $668,000, Gug T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced.

The problem of assisting homeless and helpless Jews under European dictatorships is one in which the international Red Cross should take a hand, Rabbi, Max C. Currick of Erie, Pa., president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, said here tonight. s, said here tonight.

A contract which ended the threat of a strike of 1,400 employes of the Long Island Lighting Company was signed yesterday by Edward F. Barrett, president of the company. The contract is with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. of L. affiliate.

Led by blankets and comfortable with a rise of 52.6 per cent, seven sections of local department stores had sales increases in May over the same month last year,, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Fifty-nine departments,

" I will give you an honorable discharge," said Magistrate Leonard A. McGee in Felony Court yesterday to Mrs. Ethel Tarnanovich, 34 years old, of 227 East 121st Street, in dismissing a complaint charging her with violation of the Sullivan Law.

Miss Thelma Redfield, 18-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Redfield of 44 Delaware Avenue, Woodbury, who became lost in the swampy woods here Sunday afternoon, was found by her father and other searchers today near the Black Horse Pike, about two miles from the point where she disappeared.
Robert F. Pierson, 19-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Frank Pierson of 33 Park Street, Bloomfield, was found dead today hanging from the Hillside Avenue Bridge over Toney's Brook here.

For the best names..... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months paper. Buyers' Registrations Higher Registration of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was well ahead of the preceding week.

The marriage of Miss Nina E. Maresi of 270 Park Avenve, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Pompeo Maresi, to Christopher Campanari of Genoa, Italy, formerly of New York, will take place today in Lugano, Switzerland.

The Interstate Commerce Commission discontinued today its investigation into rate schedules for freight deliveries filed by leading rail carriers in the New York district and at the same time vacated its suspension of the schedules.

Gertrude Rose has sold the threestory dwelling at 145 St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, to Rosa Bargraser, thus ending an ownership which lasted seventy-three years. The property was originally bought by the grandfather of the seller for his home.

The curb now said to be put on the excesses of anti-Semitic violence that marked the week-end in Berlin disposes of the explanation that the outrages against defenseless citizens were the work of irresponsible elements in the Nazi party. If the explanation is true,

Harold K. LaRowe, purchasing agent of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., was elected president of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the annual meeting, held last night in the Administration Building of the World's Fair grounds.

The strike of C. I. O. clerks against the Porto Rico Line continued today, with A. F. of L. stevedores remaining out despite the ultimatum signed by all steamship companies that the men were to return this morning or the recent arbitration award would be considered voided.
Clarence M. Rudel, president of Canadian Vickers, Ltd., until his retirement about a month ago, died here today in his sixtyfourth year. He had failed to recover after an appendectomy.

This country's role in "a sadly troubled and a tragic world" was declared here today by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, to be that of sharing "through peaceful means of cooperation" with other nations, "before it is too late," the task of bringing about "a new observance of the principles of international law and of humanity upon which the continuation of modern civilization depends."

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sails today for Plymouth, Cherbourg and Southampton with 1,800 passengers. Among them are Mr. and Mrs. Simon Guggenheim, Nicholas Biddle, Dr. and Mrs. Attilio H. Giannini, Dr. Alexis Carrel, F. D. Ascoli, Mr. and Mrs. P. J.

A demand for properties along Ninth Avenue in the Chelsea section of Manhattan was indicated by deals reported yesterday. A large plot was rounded out at the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street when Benjamin Lowenstein, wholesale butcher, bought the three-story building on a lot 19.9 by 65 feet at 256 Ninth Avenue, about sixty feet north of the corner,

Approval of a compromise plan for the reorganization of mortgage and equity interests in the Benenson Building at 165-67 Broadway and three other structures under the same ownership was recommended yesterday by Referee John J. Cray in a report-filed in Suprem Court.

That Vinton Freedley-Lee Shubert proposed project for next season, first mentioned in these columns last Saturday, turns out to be none other than a musical version of "Clear All Wires," by Samuel and Bella Spewack, which, as a straight, comedy in 1932, enjoyed a run of ninety-three performances.

A plea that all Americans unite to preserve the Constitution was made tonight by Arthur T. Vanderbilt, president of the American Bar Association, in a special address heard over the National Broadcasting Company networks as part of a program commemorating the 150th anniversary of New Hampshire's ratification of the Constitution.

Miss Hope Hamilton Kaufman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Kaufman of the Congress Hotel, was married there this afternoon to Gordon Raymond Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Hugo Smith of Detroit. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Clifford Le Due.

The marriage of Miss Hildegarde Portner Graham, daughter of Mrs. Augustine L. Humes and of Lieut. Commander Lorimer C. Graham, U. S. N., to Robert Dudley van Roijen took place at noon yesterday at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. Humes, at 960 Fifth Avenue.

Stocks extend Monday's advance, but close below best prices; turnover, 1,457,030 shares. Railway bonds strong, United States Government and other obligations generally higher; transactions, $7,055,825.

The Bill of Rights Committee of the 'Constitutional Convention today voted to report to the convention, for consideration, the Hirschberg amendment, which would remove -the constitutional ban on gambling and put complete control of that subject in the hands of the Legislature.

Forecasts of victory were made by the principals in tonight's title bout in statements prepared yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES. Joe Louis again said he would score a knockout within two rounds if Max Schmeling will "stand up and fight."
The War Department released the following orders to day, dated. June 18: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Quinnell, A. D., Med. Corps; 7 days' leave, June 20, with permission to visit foreign countries.

Isolated Poza Rica, lying between the eastern seaports of Tampico and Veracruz, is regarded by the Mexican Government as a Valley Forge in the struggle to maintain possession of expropriated United States and British oil companies and to attain Mexico's "economic independence."

The first default by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company on its first and refunding 5 per cent bonds is indicated in a petition by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, which will be heard today by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Writing under caption "What the Real Problem Is," Philip E. Ryan deprecates the City Council's proposed appropriation of $50,000 for a fact-finding investigation in the interests of the municipal taxpayer. I quote:
For the first time since he came here in 1928, Max Schmeling, German ex-heavyweight champion of the world, tonight will fight in an American ring unattended by his American manager, Joe Jacobs.

Because of difficulties said to be unsurmountable in obtaining dollar exchange, the Rumania Monopolies Institute, through Radu Irimescu, Rumanian Minister to the United States, yesterday notified the City Bank Farmers Trust Company that the institute had been unable to make provision for the payment here of the Aug. 1, 1935, ...

Miss Jacqueline Bird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Montgomery Bird of Merion, was married this afternoon to George Pownall Orr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Orr of Berwyn. The ceremony was performed by Dr. D. Wilmot Gateson in All Saints Church, Wynnewood.
A basis for peace in the "common prosperity" and mutual social interests which the United States and Canada possess was presented here. today by Professor James T. Shotwell of Columbia.
The sixteen-story Central Syndicate office building on the northeast corner of Broadway and Pearl Street was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms.

Winning four of the singles engagements and all three of the doubles, the representatives of the East defeated the Carolinas Center netmen, 7 to 2, in the Junior Davis Cup match at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

The final results of Eire's general election, announced. this evening, show that Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's Fianna- Fail party- will have seventyseven seats, William T. Cosgrave's United Ireland pary forty-five, Labor nine and Independents seven.

Modernization of old commercial and apartment buildings is being carried out on a wide scale in nearly all sections of the country in order that these structures may compete successfully with newer buildings for tenants, delegates attending the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers were told today.

Associated Companies, a Massachusetts affiliate of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, in connection with similar proceedings pending for Postal.

President Roosevelt signed the $3,753,000,000 Recovery-Spending Bill today and signalized the occasion with a prediction of an upswing in business activity, which he maid would be implemented by a flood of Federal funds for public works and relief.

Progress toward beating out the flames of Spain's civil war was made yesterday when the major non-interventionist powers, including Russia, accepted Britain's proposals for the shutting off of munitions supplies to Spain and the withdrawal of foreign fighters.
One of the last places in the world where one would look for a poisoned atmosphere is a park. Moscow's latest purge now embraces the famous Park of Culture and Rest in the Soviet capital.
According to the reports we have been receiving lately, it is evident that Guaymas, Mexico, is working toward a record as a light tackle fishing port.

The eleventh annual McMillan Cup series of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association is scheduled to start here tomorrow under the auspices of the Wianno Yacht Club, and most of the sixty college yachtsmen had checked in before sunset. Several of the crews took trial spins in the Wianno senior knockabouts, which will be used in the series.

The Strafaci family of Brooklyn continued to hold sway in Long Island golfing circles today, with Ralph of Shore View easily walking off with highest honors in the Long Island Golf Association's oneday amateur tourney at Bethpage State Park.

Frankie Parker ranked No. 3 nationally, was eliminated today in the second round of the national clay courts tennis tournament by George Pero of Miami, Fla. Parker lost in three sets, 5-7, 6-1, 6-4, to the unseeded Southerner.

A committee of men's clothing manufacturers was appointed yesterday to meet with Captain Collins of the Procurement Division of the WPA tomorrow at 70 Columbus Avenue, to discuss the proposed government purchases of surplus clothing.

The American Car and Foundry Company announced yesterday that the Rebel, the first streamlined motor-driven passenger train to begin operation in. the South, had completed its first 1,000,000 miles of operation over the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad.

The women's singles, which, it is generally conceded, will provide the most drama in this year's Wimbledon tennis tournament, started as was expected today with victories for all seven seeded players who took the court.

The Yugoslav naval training ship Jadran arrived yesterday in New York Harbor for a two weeks' visit. It was the first time a man-of-war had carried the Yugoslav flag into this port, and the craft was the recipient of much attention as she passed slowly up the Hudson to an anchorage off West Seventy-ninth Street.

A tax dispute growing out of the sale by President Harding of his interest in The Marion (Ohio) Star reached the Supreme Court today. The Brush-Moore Newspapers, Inc., owner of The Star, filed an appeal challenging a $3,350 Federal income tax deficiency assessment for 1930 and 1931.

With Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, the defending titleholder, enjoying a day of rest, Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York and Miss Florence Le Boutillier of Old Westbury led the advance to the round before the quarter-finals in the New Jersey State tennis championship today at the Oritani Field Club.

Samuel Goldstein, assistant district attorney of Brooklyn, N. Y., was reelected today Grand Master of the Independent Order of B'rith Abraham, world's largest Jewish fraternity, at the close of its annual convention.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Associtation, announced last night that he would protest to President Roosevelt against the order of the National Labor Relations Board for an election among longshoremen in the port of New Orleans.

While Conservatives were launching a bitter attack. in Parliament today on the 1935 Canadian - American trade treaty on the ground that it had injured Canadian business and employment -because of imports from the United States, reports were current here that the new trade pact now under negotiation would greatly enlarge the scope of the first.

Price-cutting by retailers was attacked sharply yesterday' by W. W. Wachtel, president of the Calvert Distillers Corporation, who declared that such tactics contribute directly to unemployment and business recession.

The First Congregational Church here, which this year is celebrating its 100th anniversary, was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Josephine Jerome Sands to Thomas Ewart Marston of Cornwall, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Wallace Mast performed the ceremony.

Thirty years of segregated publicschool education for crippled East Side youngsters, carried on with privately paid for orthopedic care, ended yesterday when the Crippled Children's East Side Free School, 157 Henry Street, closed with the graduation of 19 of its 114 pupils.

McGraw Ave (15-3880), s e cor of Leland Ave, 50x42; Walcroft Realty Corp to Raymond Rubin. 125 E 170 St, three years, 5 per cent; $13,000. Tremont Ave (11-2863), n w side at e s Davidson Ave, 98x120; Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to Reconstruction Finance Corp, 33 Liberty St; 400,000.
Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at Ridgefield, Conn., of Theodore Houston Solley of 114 East 84th Street, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fred P. Solley. also of this city.

The Consumers Advertising Council, aimed to break down many of the prejudices and antagonism towards advertising which have developed in recent years, will probably be ready to start operations in the early Fall, John Benson, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, which originated the plan, said yesterday.

The close primary race between Governor Elmer A. Benson and Hjalmar Petersen for the Farmer-Labor Gubernatorial nomination in Minnesota upset the calculations of the national Administration and presented it with a new problem as to the best course to follow politically in that State.

Revers ve, 264; dwelling 25x99; Home Owners Loan Corp against Stefanos Skarkas; due $7,455; to plaintiff for $2,500. By GEORGE J. KEARNS Corlear Ave. 3,431; 2-story dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Mary I; due $7,660; to plaintiff for $500. $500.

The Wisconsin Supreme Court, reversing its previous decision by a 4-to-3 ruling,. today held the Wisconsin Development Authority, sometimes called the "Little TVA," constitutional, but curtailed powers of the corporation to use State funds for promoting public ownership of utilities.
President Roosevelt received today a check for $1,010,000 as the principal installment on the largest fund ever raised for a national campaign against infantile paralysis.

The New Jersey American Civil Liberties Union held a meeting tonight in a basement room assigned to them in City Hall by Commissioner Joseph M. Byrne, Director of Parks and Public Property. About 200 persons- filled the room and a few overflowed into a corridor.

With the conflict which has arisen between Democrats and Republicans in the Constitutional Convention over search and seizure proposals still in progress, a new battle on purely partisan lines is impending.
Harry Kelley, the right-hander Washington purchased from the Athletics last month, scored his first 1938 victory today by shutting out the White Sox 7 to O. Kelley yielded five scattered hits.
For many readers of the news the first impression produced by the ramifications of the spy case now revealed in Federal indictments is the extraordinary ineptness of the operatives engaged.

" The Night of January 16" by Ayn Rand, which ran on Broadway for 235 performances with Walter Pidgeon and Doris Nolan in the leading roles, has been purchased by RKO. While a star has not been determined, the play is regarded as a. probable vehicle for Claudette Colbert.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company authorized dividends yesterday and announced that its consolidated earnings for the first five months of this year were estimated at $1,056,218 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges.
Funeral services for Senator Royal S. Copeland, senior New York Senator, were held here this afternoon in the rambling white farmhouse where he made his home.

Steamship operators in foreign and intercoastal trades will save several hundreds of thousands of dollars annually in the operation their ships as a result of a reduction of 10 cents.. a barrel in the price of bunker oil announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

The Yale-varsity crew, in one of its last tuning-up tests before the race with Harvard Friday, paddled six miles tonight on the Thames River. The junior varsity, freshman and combination boats also were put through a similar light workout.

Radio reporters abroad should receive the same facilities as newspaper correspondents, according to the League of Nations committee of experts on broadcasting in the interests of peace, which has now finished its session here. The committee wants an international convention to this effect.

A triple challenge was delivered to the Christian churches of the world today by the Rev. Dr. Albert Peel of London, editor of The Congregational Quarterly of England and Wales, who asked if the church was ready to give a practical answer to the threat of war, to use in the interest of God the resources created by modern science and to meet the "new paganism" which confronted it.

For the seventh successive session, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced into new high ground to end the day with a net gain. Yesterday's rise carried the July -to 8.63 cents a pound, or 96 points above the low figures reached at the end of May, and the list closed with gains of 8 to 10 points.

The vigilance of a construction foreman who, working on the Carrousel Bridge, saw smoke rising from the roof of the Louvre tonight, saved France from a fire in which part of the priceless art collection might have been destroyed.

Principals-Joe Louis, Detroit, champion, vs. Max Schmeling, Germany, challenger. Title at Stake-World heavyweight championship. Place - Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, Bronx. Distance-Fifteen rounds. Time of Bout-10 P. M. Postponement Date-Tomorrow.
Dr. Carl F. Steinthal, retired physician and surgeon, died on Sunday in his home at Stuttgart, Germany, of pneumonia, according to word received here yesterday. His age was 79.

The Caravan Theatre will perform at the following .public stands tonight in the metropolitan area: The Bronx, "The Milky Way," at Crotona Park; Brooklyn, "Treasure Island," at Gravesend Park; Queens, "Mississippi Rainbow," at Forest Park; Richmond, "Showing Off,"
Eighteen Japanese air raiders, it was reported today, bombed property of the American-owned Texas Company in an attack on Wuchow, in Kwangsi Province.

Mgr. William F. Dittrich, for the last three years pastor of Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church here, died this afternoon in St. Peter's hospital, New Brunswick, after two weeks' illness. His age was 70.

In a speech before a cheering National Socialist crowd that packed the stadium where the Olympics were held two years ago, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels foreshadowed tonight new edicts to expel Jews from Berlin.

BALLARD, EDWARD LATHROP (Dec. 31, 1937). Gross assets, $2,030,265; net, $1,937,010. To Sumner Ballard, Alice C. Phelps, Emma B. Ballard, Rosamond B. Phillips and Virginia B. Anthony, $2,500 each; Elizabeth B. Ballard, widow, household, personal effects and life estate in residue; Anna B. Dann and Elizabeth B.

Business, seriously retarded for months, is expected to improve with an announcement of Gabriel Martinez, Minister of Finance, that he is opposed to exchange and import control. He said that the temporary relief afforded by such restrictions produced disastrous effects later.
Frank (Pinky) Higgins, veteran Red Sox third baseman, marched into baseball's hall of fame today by cracking his twelfth consecutive hit while Boston and the Tigers split a double-header.

Miss Madeleine Evans McAlpin, daughter of Mrs. David Hunter McAlpin 2d of this place and the late Mr. McAlpin, was married this afternoon in the chapel of St. Peter's Church to Wynant Davis Vanderpool Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderpool, also of Morristown. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David K. Montgomery, the rector, assisted by the Rev. Thomas W. Attridge, rector of the Church of the Redeemer.
