They warned me of an ancient day--Before the first Joe-Max affair--When odds ran wild the other way, And yet the Tortoise beat the Hare. So Schmeling Would--and were they wise! Beat Louis down. But even though It happened right before me eyes, I still like Joe.

No new emergency taxes for unemployment relief would have been necessary if all taxes due the city under the Sales Tax Law and the Business Tax Law had been colelected, it was asserted yesterday in a presentment handed up by the December Kings County grand jury, which has been investigating the evasion of such taxes in Brooklyn.

Henry H. Heimann of New York, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, urged business men today to shoulder a greater responsibility for the determination of governmental policies as a step in solving the nation's economic problems.

The final portion of the famous Ham House library of rare books realized [Pound]19,502 at Sotheby's today, making the total f38,202. As expected, a volume of Shakespeare's plays brought the highest bid of [Pound]3,200.

Unleashed on the elbow of the turn. into the stretch, Mrs. Emil Denemark's War Minstrel sailed by the favored Fair Knightess from the C. S. Howard stable to win by a length and a half in the Shriners Handicap, mile and seventy-yard feature at Suffolk Downs today, and pay $13.20 for $2.
Historic Gettysburg, orchard city of Southern Pennsylvania, will become the seat of the State Government during the seventy-fifth battlefield anniversary observance, June 29 to July 6.

Miss Mary Louise Fleming, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church, and Mrs. Fleming of 1 Lexington Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in Trinity Chapel, West Twenty-fifth Street, to Eugene Joseph McVoy, son of Mrs. Fortunato Jerace of Rome, Italy, and Chicago, and the late Eugene J. McVoy of Chicago. The bride's father performed the ceremony.

The governing committee and advisory council of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., meeting here today, adopted resolutions expressing the belief that a national association of investment bankers and security dealers should register with
James Roosevelt arrived here today by plane for treatment for what Mayo clinic physicians described as a small gastric ulcer.

Frederick Bodell, co-founder of the investment banking firm of Bodell Co. with his brother, Joseph J. Bodell, and a prominent figure in manufacturing and civic affairs, as well as in the financial field, died at his home here last night in his fifty-fourth year.

Thomas B. Pratt, 49 years old, of 16 Chester Street, and his brotherin-law, Berniss B. Sheldon, 51, of 248 Lenox Road, both in Brooklyn, admitted dupes of Emanuel Seideman and Harry Rower, the socalled "Bucketeer twins" who were sentenced Monday to ten-year Sing Sing terms for operating a bucket shop in the financial district, escaped with suspended sentences on the same indictment yesterday in General Sessions.

Trading was generally only fair to slow. Prices were very irregular. Steer hinds and ribs were strong, veal weak to sharply lower, lamb strong to shade higher, fresh pork steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and veal prices to be weak and lamb lower. Conditions as reported by United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Critical comment upon the trend of power policies of the United States was voiced to the Society of Chemical Industry today by J. B. Challies of Montreal, president of the Engineering Institute of Canada.

George F. Naphen and Franklin E. Mayer testified yesterday at the continuation of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment trust hearing. The former explained how stock in the Delta Oil Company was available for inclusion in the portfolio of Burco, Inc.
Interest in tomorrow's Schmeling - Louis fight reached the zenith over the weekend in Berlin. Today several papers carried front page reports from the

The German Foreign Institute at Stuttgart now is engaged in compiling a "German world migration register" in which will be recorded all German emigrants of the past few centuries together with their descendants so far as is learned in an effort to recapture the latter for German Volksturm, or race, it is announced in the German press.

The New York School of Applied Design for Women yesterday announced the five winners of its.yearly scholarship competition in the city's high schools. Each winner will receive a year's instruction at the school. The winners are Edith Koliner, 57 West Eighty-fourth Street;
Frank G. Lawson of the brokerage firm of Moss, Lawson Co. was elected today president of the Toronto Stock Exchange. He succeeds Norman C. Urquhart.

ALVINO, MARGARET BARBOUR (Feb. 18). Estate, less than $10,000. To Ruth Barbour Lamb, sister, 199 Indian Road, Piedmont, Calif., life estate in residue; Jessie Lemont Tursel, mother, 620 E. 116th St., $1,500; several varying bequests; Carmine D. Alvino, husband, executor, 124 Ft. Washington Ave., $2,500.

The campaign of Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. against jewelers who falsely advertise wares in their establishments netted three convictions in Special Sessions yesterday and a guilty plea by another. All but one have stores on West Fourteenth Street.

Carl Hubbell, who seldom makes a mistake, made two yesterday at the Polo Grounds, where 10,509 fans gathered in anticipation of seeing him record his 200th major league victory at the expense of the inspired Reds.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that two New York concerns had entered into stipulations agreeing to cease certain "false and misleading representations" in regard to their products.

Persons anxious to find a reason for the rise in railroad securities, which continued yesterday, naturally picked on the labor outlook. Experience has shown that nothing is better to touch off a rally in these obligations than a rumor that unionized forces are about to accept a cut in wages.

Harry B. Breckwedel and others gave to Byron C. Hanna and Harold C. Morton, all of Los Angeles, a mortgage for $10,250, due June 8, 1940, at 6 per cent, on the n w cor of East Broadway and Scammel St.

Thomas W. Spencer, for thirtythree years in charge of the New York Yacht Club's station at Twenty-sixth Street and the East River, until the club closed the station on May 1, died here today of a heart ailment in his home. His age was 54.

A well-earned surprise victory by East Williston and single-point triumphs by Greentree and the Pelicans were the high spots today as five matches were played in the Meadow Brook Club competition for twenty-goal polo teams.

Four little girls raced along a ledge in Highbridge Park in the Washington Heights section yesterday. Their voices were shrill and joyous and reflected a complete indifference to the scorching rays of the sun. One of the girls, all around 7 years old, apparently bolder than her companions, ventured to the very edge of the twenty-five-foot cliff.

Wheat futures in domestic markets fluctuated today in an erratic manner in a range of about 2 cents a bushel. A small decline early was followed by an advance of more than 1 cent from the inside figure When shorts covered on the development of independent strength at Minneapolis and Winnipeg.

Yale blanked Harvard, 5-0, today in the sports feature of its Commencement Week program. Two thousand jubilant alumni and 5,000 other spectators were thrilled by the baffling pitching of Monroe Jubitz, and the brilliant fielding of Rollie Cooke, Paul Wargo, Harry Bolt and Bill Loveday.

With a light southwest breeze filling their clouds of canvas, the fortythree yachts in the race to Bermuda started from Brenton Lightship today. Once under way and out on the open ocean course of 635 miles, Rudolph J. Schaefer's new yawl Edlu II appeared to be leading.

With negotiations on the individual railways for a 15 per cent wage decrease virtually completed without result, the Carriers Joint Conference Committee today formally proposed to the nineteen standard railroad unions a meeting on a national basis, to be held in Chicago on June 28.

Federal Judge William Clark refused permission to Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City today to attack Morris L. Ernst, C. I. O. counsel, in a statement from the witness box in the "free speech" injunction suit brought against him and other city officials by the C. I. O. and the American Civil Liberties Union.

Broad activity in the cotton goods market led trade observers yesterday to predict a forward movement for the Summer in consumer goods lines generally. The cotton-goods trading was led by printcloths, which have usually in the last twenty years set the pace for textiles, and of which more than 40,000,000 yards were sold Monday and yesterday.

Three underprivileged New York City elementary school children-a frail girl of 12, blind since birth; a sandy-haired lad of 14, deaf as far back as he can remember, and a chubby girl of 14, crippled by infantile paralysis-voted yesterday the "happiest" day of their lives.

The general decline in daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and -rural areas for May, as compared with the corresponding month last year, was relatively less in the Far West than in other parts of the country,

All seeded players advanced into the third round today in the girls' intercollegiate tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club, while one entrant, Miss Dorothy Bruno, Radcliffe freshman, pressed into the quarter-finals.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; the Lee Higginson Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co. purchased and reoffered yesterday after the close of the market 10,000 shares of capital stock of the International Business Machines Corporation.
Building plans filed yesterday included specifications for a new building for the Church of the Epiphany at York Avenue and East Seventy-fourth Street.

For the Lewisohn Stadium concerts, which begin tomorrow night, John Corigliano will be concertmaster of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Emonts will be first 'cellist, Joseph Vieland will be first violist and Arthur Schuller will head the second violins.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are June 21, unless specified: At Bangkok: Alden, Black Hawk, Barker, J. D. Edwards, Paul Jones, Whipple. San Pedro to Seattle; Astoria, Chicago, Indianapolis, Pensacola, Vincennes.
In what is expected to be a million-dollar setting, Joe Louis, the ring's famed .Brown Bomber, tonight will defend his world heavyweight title against Max Schmeling of Germany at the Yankee Stadium.

The present "preeminent" economic position of New York State will be lost, "possibly beyond recall," unless the Constitutional Convention writes into the new State Constitution provisions which will relieve business of oppressive taxes by providing a more equitable system of taxation,

Winding up with a notable victory over Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, former chess champion of the world, whom he defeated in a finely played game lasting fifty moves, Erich Eliskases of Vienna, the junior member of the Austrian delegation, emerged tonight as winner of first prize in the international masters tournament at the Hotel Rembrandt.

Colonel Fred Glover of the United Specialties Company, Detroit, chief of motor transport for the United States Army during the World War, was announced today as the new president and general manager of the Reo Motor Car Company.

Universal Art in the High Court today obtained an injunction restraining Colonel W. de Basil from producing or in any way dealing with four ballets: "Coq d'Or," "Symphonie Fantasque," "Boutique Fantasque" and "Tricorne."

Many of the complex problems that confront the New York Police Department in its traffic functions were outlined yesterday by John J. Seery, First Deputy Police Commissioner, before executive and staff members of newspapers in fifty key cities who are attending the second seminar of safety to which the Commercial Investment Trust, Inc., through the C. I. T. Safety Foundation, is the host at the WaldorfAstoria.

Another day of burning sunlight kept most of the crews in training for Monday's Poughkeepsle regatta marking time today. In one or two of the camps, notably Syracuse, the coach ordered only a single workout and in others the morning session was easy and the men were then held ashore until well into the evening.
The play and the players received a tremendous ovation when the curtain fell on tonight's opening of "Golden Boy" at St. James's Theatre.

An urgent appeal for food for about half a million Spanish children was cabled yesterday from Barcelona to the Spanish Child Welfare Association, 9 East Fortysixth Street, by Jo Davidson, American sculptor.

An increase in membership of 2 per cent in the last year and a greater interest in spiritual matters was reported yesterday at the seventh annual convention of the Eastern District of the American Lutheran Church, held at the Fordham Lutheran Church, 2,430 Walton Avenue, the Bronx.

Alone with reporters assigned to the White House, except for his secretary, Marvin H. MacIntyre, President Roosevelt told the news men with evident satisfaction today of being very well up on his end of the work of running the Federal Government.

Gains in ideals were cited byPresident Charles Seymour of Yale today in an address to graduates of three colleges. Speaking to the 606 members of 'the senior classes of Yale College, Sheffield Scientific School and the Yale School of Engineering, he declared that Yale is undergoing a sweeping change in its student estimates.
Two automobile drivers who tooted their horns impatiently in a crowded Brooklyn street yesterday learned that impatient haste may cause prolonged delay, particularly when a policeman is near.
The United States has regained first place in exports to Brazil, a position held for the last two years by Germany. A gradual decline in German exports to Brazil set in early this year.

A decrease of 3.4 per cent in the retail prices of 106 of "the most important drug store items protected under fair trade contracts," compared with prices prevailing prior to application of the Fair Trade Act, was reported for New York State by John F. O'Brien, chairman, and Milton S. Malakoff, secretary of the fair trade committee of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association, at the group's convention here today.

Rentals of full-floor units and stores in midtown furnished the bulk of the commercial leasing activity announced yesterday. The entire twelfth floor in the building at 164-6 West Twenty-fifth Street was taken by Morris Slote and Joe Shapiro, manufacers of celluloid novelties, through Holmes Douglas, Inc., and the Cross Brown Company.
Secretary Harold L. Ickes and his bride of less than a month, the former Miss Jane Dahlman of Milwaukee, arrived from Europe last night on the French liner Ile de France.

ALEXANDER--On Tuesday, June 21, 1938, Adelaide B. (nee Blindenhofer), of 867 East 24th St., beloved wife of Aaron G. Alexander. Services at the Fairchild Chapel. 86 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, on Wednesday at 8 P. M.
Spanish Insurgent and Government troops fought to a deadlock today in handto-hand battling under a broiling sun in the vital Castellon sector of Eastern Spain.

Matthew J. Merritt, Representative at Large from New York, has written to Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, and Dr. Herbert Putnam, head of the Library of. Congress, to continue making special phonographs for the reproduction of "talking books" for the blind, according to officials of the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street;

Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, a leader in the fight against the President's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court, came here yesterday and accused the Administration of seeking to undermine the principle of collective bar-. gaining which it professes to champion.

The State Department called Great Britain's attention today to a pending bill in the Bermudan Parliament that it said would discriminate against American ships. The department instructed the United States Embassy in London to say that this government hoped the bill would not be enacted.
THE ANNUAL OF BOOKMAKING. (Colophon, $6 to July 15, $7.50 thereafter.) A study of a decade of American book production. A CHALLENGE TO CAESAR, by Saul Saphire. (Covici, Friede, $2.50.)

Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice gave a garden party this afternoon at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown, for representatives of thirteen garden clubs comprising the Southern New England zone of the Garden Clubs of America. There were seventy guests.

The bulk of the realty activity yesterday was scattered through the Harlem and Washington Heights sections. An investor purchased from the Title Guarantee and Trust Company the three-story brick building on; a lot 14 by 99.11 feet at 630 West.188th Street, between Riverside Drive and Broadway.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today an application made by Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Inc., a Canadian corporation, to withdraw from listing and registration as of July 1 its 4,897,144 $1 par value shares of capital stock
The appointment of Miss Helen M. Harris as director of the National Youth Administration for New York was announced today by Aubrey Williams, executive director of the NYA.

College boxing must be "dignified," rule-makers for the sport decided today. Opening a four-day meeting at the Naval Academy, the Boxing Rules Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association dedicated itself to an ambitious revision of its existing -regulations to eliminate taints of professionalism,

Favorable weather in the early part of this year brought the general death rate for New York in the first twenty-four weeks of 1938 to the lowest point ever recorded for a similar period in this city, ...

Clinical and social problems which will have to be met and overcome in the operation of a broad national scheme for control of the disease were taken up in sessions of the National Tuberculosis Association here today.

Lewisohn Stadium is expected to attract an audience of about 17,000 persons tonight to witness the ninety-second annual commencement exercises of City College, at which 2,138 degrees, diplomas and commissions will be conferred.
J. P. Morgan, largest individual taxpayer in the city of Glen Cove, filed a protest today against the 1938 assessment levied on his real estate by the Nassau County Board of Tax Assessors.

Vigorous protest against the nomination of Governor Lehman for the Senate seat made vacant by the death of Royal S. Copeland was made to President Roosevelt last night by friends of Mayor La Guardia, after announcement by the Governor of his candidacy.

For the first time since the world-wide protests on the bombing .of civilian populations in Spain and China, the German press refers to the bombing of Karlsruhe by French military planes on June 22, 1916.

As it never has been officially admitted here that the Spanish frontier has been wide open at different times to arms traffic-although the French themselves have sent in little or nothing--it is not officially admitted that the frontier has been closed.
The Dodgers played and lost their second nocturnal game at Ebbets Field last night, going down -before the Pirates, 9 to 3, while 25,527 paying patrons watched with audible dissatisfaction.
Slowness featured the cattle and fat lamb trade today, but most classes held to steady price levels. Hogs broke 10 to 20 cents, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

A sharp debate between representatives of the American Legion and Milton Cohen, National Commander of the Disabled American War Veterans, over the question of veterans' preference marked the public hearing of the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Civil Service today.

Allotments totaled over $77,814,628 for 590 approved PWA projects, including thirty-five in New York State and nineteen in New Jersey, were made today by Secretary Ickes, with the total completed cost of these projects estimated at $148,795,895.

Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol, who made her tournament debut in the national championship at Shawnee in 1919, won her first State championship today when she captured the Women's New Jersey Golf Association closed title with a 54-hole total of 250. Playing the difficult Nos. 2 and 4 nines of the Montclair Golf Club, Mrs. Goss added an 82 today to her first round 85 and second round 83.

De La Salle Institute will hold its eighty-ninth commencement exercises at 8:30 o'clock tonight at Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, '69, vicargeneral of the archdiocese of New York, will preside. John F. Brosnan, '09, will give the address.

Miss Peggy Porter, who has several distinguished United States Army and Navy officers among her forebears, was married here yesterday afternoon to Nicholas Vedder Poole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Poole of New York and Franconia, N. H. The ceremony was performed in the Church of the Resurrection by the rector, the Rev. Gordon Wadhams.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By FRANK E. BENJAMIN, park attendant, Mamaroneck.-Liabilities $23,024, no assets. The HOLC is listed as a Judgment creditor for $16,689. JOE BURNS, music manager. unemployed. 35 E. 9th St.-Liabilties $1,615, no assets. JOSEPH COWLEY, patrolman, 29 Highland Ave., Tuckahoe.-Liabilities $13,642; no assets except realty subject to mort. gages.

The relation of production, income and purchasing power to real estate value will be discussed by Dr. Willford I. King, Professor of Economics at the New York University, at a luncheon meeting on June 28 of the Manhattan Chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
Major L. C. Mitchell, military attache of the United States Embassy in Brazil, will leave Rio de Janeiro Friday by plane to act as United States observer in the Chaco.

One hundred families in the three main limited-dividend projects of the State Board of Housing will have to find new living quarters next Fall because the board has decided that prosperity disqualifies them from the benefits of its lowincome model developments.

Loans financing new housing construction in Queens were announced yesterday by mortgage brokers. Ten loans aggregating $65,000 were placed by Monroe Miller, broker, for Fair Site Homes, Inc., on the ten one-family dwellings under construction at Sixty-second Drive and Sixty-third Avenue, corner of Yellowstone Boulevard, North Forest Hills.
A bill declaring the coming Fourth of July a national holiday was introduced in the House of Representatives last night by Paul de Cardenas, Representative from Havana Province.

Contracts for business space reported yesterday in Manhattan included several leases of stores in scattered sections. The activity also involved the renewal of leases of store locations in the downtown section.

The Countess of Strathmore, Queen Elizabeth's mother, died early today at her London home, Cumberland Mansion, in Portman Square. In her seventy-sixth year, she had been gravely ill of heart trouble for two months.

Construction of an exhibition building of the General Electric Company at the World's Fair was begun yesterday noon with Owen D. Young. chairman of the board of the concern, at the throttle of a steam pile driver sinking the first pile ninety feet through the earth to bedrock.

The crowd came to the Yankee Stadium last night in waves, much like billows bounding toward an ocean shore. Every train disgorged a full cargo and each joined the onward sweep toward the Stadium goal.
Sir Harry Foster, former member of Parliament and close friend of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, died Monday, it was announced today. He was 83 years old.

Announcement was made here last night of the death Tuesday at his home in Cleveland Heights, Cleveland; of Raymond T. Sawyer, since 1913 chief counsel for the Cleveland Trust Company. Mr. Sawyer, who had been ill for a year and a half, was born in Cleveland on April 29, 1879, a son of the late Dr. Pascal H. Sawyer.

An appeal for $12,000 to provide Summer vacations for the sightless was issued yesterday by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard, chairman of the board of directors of the New York Association for the Blind. The money will be used to

The Socialist-controlled city administration of Reading and the C. I. O. will soon sign a working agreement under a resolution passed by City Council today over the protests of the two Democratic members.

A perfectly conditioned Yale varsity crew, eager for the start of Friday's race with Harvard, let off steam tonight by rowing two and one-half miles downstream on the Thames River and putting on a two-minute burst of speed on the return run.

Tenhour transcontinental schedules with great air liners flying in the substratosphere, non-stop seaplane schedules between New York, London and Paris, and forty million persons instead of 400,000 using the air regularly for travel, are among the achievements to Which aviation is looking forward with confidence, according to Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

ON HIS OWN APPLICATION-To take effect 12 midnight, June 21: PATROLMAN-Roy J. Dickson. Appointed Oct. 8, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., June 23: PATROLMEN-John E. Brandle, from 73d Precinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur: Lawrence H. Flair,
The War Department released the following orders today dated June 21: MAJOR GENERAL Reed, W. L., Inspector General, ten days' leave, July 5.

A League of Women, "the finest league of nations in the world," was urged at a peace forum which closed the second quadrennial convention of the Soroptimist International Association in the Hotel Claridge here today.

ASSISTANT LIGUTHOUSE KEEPER$1,140 to $1,560 a year (depending upon the station to which assigned)-United States Lighthouse Service, Department of Commerce (for filling vacancies in the Third and Tenth Lighthouse Districts).

Louis B. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, told graduates of the Army War College today that "Americans hate war but they will not stand for peace at any price." "By experience and tradition they are opposed to large standing armies which to them represent militarism," he said.

The Navy Department opened bids today for the construction of four 1,500-ton destroyers, three submarines, three fleet tugs and the propelling machinery of one submarine tender. Bids were submitted on

Miss Margaret E. Mathieu, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mathieu of Bronxville, N. Y., was married to Frank S. McGee, son of Mrs. Patrick McGee of this city, yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, has watched scores of picketing demonstrations without comment, but when he saw relief workers driving up to his office in automobiles yesterday to picket against wage cuts he decided it was time to do a little protesting on his own account.

The Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixty-seventh Street, which gives self-organized groups of resident artists the opportunity of free exhibition, is conducting its first show by a group of American-Japanese painters.

Mansfield Freeman, chairman of the board of the United States Life Insurance Company, announced yesterday gains of 40.4 per cent in new ordinary insurance and of 30.9 per cent in all forms of new business for the first five months of 1938, compared with 1937.

Two new incidents involving British merchant shipping were reported here tonight, in addition to the sinking of two British freighters by an aerial raider outside Valencia harbor. The British merchantman Gloxinia was said to have been attacked at sea, after leaving Valencia last night. There was, however, no definite confirmation.

An application by the New York Stock Exchange for permission to delist the German Central Bank for Agriculture farm loan secured 6 per cent sinking-fund bonds, Series A, of 1928, was made today the matter for a public hearing before Charles S. Moore, examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Miss Edith Rose McLaughlin, daughter of Supreme CourtJustice and Mrs. Charles B. McLaughlin of 2,613 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, was married to Francis Joseph O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. O'Brien of Brewster, N. Y., yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Refuge, the Bronx.
The first 1938 Summer jewel robbery in the North Shore area of Long Island was reported to the Nassau County police today by Edgar S. Auchincloss of Shelter Rock Road here.

The lamb market broke sharply today, fully 50 cents a hundredweight lower. Increased supplies, both locally and in the aggregate principal markets, furnished the bearish pressure, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Hogs sold higher. The cattle market was fully steady.

Speakers of many sorts at the second Seminar of Safety, being held this week under the auspices of the Commercial Investment Trust, have found a common ground in the importance of the public attitude toward safety on the road and the useful role which the newspapers of the country can play in helping to shape this attitude.

Massachusetts Institute of Technology, invincible in college dinghy racing last Winter and Spring, took the lead in the intercollegiate sailing championship series today with 46 points, an advantage of 2 3/4 points over the Williams crews.

It will be a dry Summer in about a dozen parks under the jurisdiction of the State Department of Conservation and Development, Director Charles P. Wilber said today, but he was not making a long-range weather prediction. He referred only to the sale and use of alcoholic beverages on such reservations.

The United States Weather Bureau issued yesterday its weekly report of crop conditions, as follows: The weather was somewhat more favorable for development of cotton in the central States of the belt, but in some Eastern and Western portions rains were again unfavorable.

Police used tear gas to quell a riotous crowd tonight in the Negro section here celebrating Joe Louis's victory over Max Schmeling. Charity Hospital was filled with injured and attendants notified police to take others to other hospitals.

After three years of hard study while in sickbeds and wheelchairs in hospitals and in his home, Richard Albert Match, 18 years old, of 2,070 East Thirty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, received his high school diploma yesterday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I cannot refrain from sending you a word of hearty commendation of your editorial, "Olympiad at Tokyo."
A successful double steal in the first inning, with Lou Finney scoring, set the stage in a 7-to-1 victory for the Athletics over the Browns today.
Judge and Mrs. Peter Woodbury of Bedford have announced the engagement of Mrs. Woodbury's sister, Miss Janet Reed, to Edvard Lindstrom of Boston and Wilmette, Ill.

Thousands of Harvard graduates jn a crowd of 5,000 here for class day ceremonies. today, saw the New Deal and a fellow alumnus, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, satirized in one of the most unusual demonstrations in the long traditions of the event.

Former Premier Valery Slawek today was elected president of the Polish Diet, succeeding Stanislas Car, who died last Saturday. Colonel Slawek, together with his predecessor, drafted and carried through all the parliamentary stages Poland's authoritarian Constitution of 1935.

Pulling a revolver from a holster sewed inside his coat, Arthur Emil Hanson, 38-year-old farmer, today shot and killed two attorneys in Superior Court on the eighth floor of the Hall of Records. His victims were J. Irving Hancock and R. D. McLaughlin, who had opposed him in a court action.

Fish Ave (16-4386), n e cor of Astor Ave, 100x100; Gorson Corp to Samuel Spiselman, Inc, 642 Pelham Parkway South. Decatur Ave (12-3332), w s, 125 ft s of 204th St, 50x110; Home Owners Loan Corp to Solomon A. Victorson, 3,105 Decatur Ave.
The 1938 Summer Social Register, which is being distributed to subscribers, shows a decline in families living abroad, as well as a slight decrease in the number of Summer addresses listed.

The Sherman Anti-Trust Law and the so-called Federal Anti-Racketeering Law never were intended to be used to suppress labor organizations, Burton K. Wheeler, United States Senator from Montana, argued yesterday, asking Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell to dismiss an indictment charging breach of those laws by Local 807 of the Teamsters Union and other defendants.

Unless the American Labor party is permitted to name its candidates for the rest of the term of the late Royal S. Copeland in the United States Senate and for Lieutenant Governor in coalition with one of the two major parties, the Labor party will go it alone and name its own slate this Fall.

Publicly owned municipal power systems are facing three principal sources of trouble, Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, former head of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said tonight in an address at the annual conference of municipal electric utilities of New York State.

Miss Clarissa Halstead Stem, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Stem of 34 Gramercy Park, this city, and Cincinnati and the late Mr. Stem, has completed the plans for her marriage to E. Fontaine Broun Jr. of New York, which will take place the afternoon of June 30 in the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

All Germany, clustered about its short-wave radio sets in the early morning hours, was thunderstruck and almost unbelieving at the un expected news that "Unser Maxe' Schmeling had failed in his -heavy weight comeback try, and failed by the knockout route.

Woonsocket police posted a "Communists Keep Out" sign today, defying critics who charged that they were making Woonsocket "another Jersey City." "We will break up any future attempted meeting the same as we did Monday night," said Chairman Wilfred Rivet of the Police Commission.

The dispute of Governor Eccles of the Federal Reserve with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Controller of the Currency, over the criterion to be observed by bank examiners concerning bank loans and investments, appears to have been settled, presumably by compromise, through personal intervention of the Secretary of the Treasury.

John W. Hanes, member of the Securities and Exchange. Commission, moved yesterday to get the New York Stock Exchange and the Committee for Industrial Organization to cooperate in aiding the unemployed of Wall Street.

Investors were active yesterday in the purchase of business and residential properties in Manhattan. A deal in the Madison Avenue shopping zone involved the fivestory building at 21 East Sixtyseventh Street, near the avenue, which was sold by T. Sloane Young to an investing client of Sullivan Cromwell, attorneys.

Frederick Mohrman has bought for investment the six-story elevator apartment house on a plot 66.7 by 100 feet at 3,312 Perry Avenue, the Bronx. The seller was the N. V. Building Corporation, Nicolai Scarano, president. Morris Sax was the broker.

A $40,000 State legislative inquiry into the operations and purpose of the local Nazi movement was opened here yesterday in the Supreme Court Building under the chairmanship of Senator John J. McNaboe.
A discovery that may open the way to a method of treating tuberculosis by die was reported to the National Tuberculosis Association here today by Dr. C. H. Boissevain of Colorado Spring Col.

Mrs. Sylva, Annenberg Leichner from Fresh Meadow moved into the semi-final round today in defense of her women's Long Island match play championship as she easily turned back Mrs. J. C. Dey Jr. of Women's National, 8 and 7, over the links of the North Hempstead Country Club.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, with Rudolph Thomas as conductor, will be heard in the fourth of the new series of "pop" concerts tonight at the Federal Music Theatre. Tom Emlyn Williams, baritone, will be soloist.

In Tampico, the chief center of Mexican oil production ever since Mexico's first petroleum boom twenty years ago, a vivid picture was obtained of the Mexican Government's chief problem with regard to the expropriated foreign industry-selling oil abroad.

Greater economy for the city and more efficient handling of supplies destined for city institutions on Welfare Island and elsewhere are expected to result from the construction of a new six-story warehouse in Long Island City, plans for which were filed yesterday.

The American I. G. Chemical Corporation authorized an interim dividend of $2 on the common A and 20 cents a share on the common B stock. On Sept. 13, 1937, the common A received $3 a share and on Sept. 28, $2, making total distributions on this issue last year of $5. On the common B stock the

When Joseph P. Kennedy was sent by the President to be Ambassador to the Court of St. James certain misgivings were expressed in some quarters. He might be dazzled by titled British society, being but an Irish lad from East Boston.
The William Manna property at the corner of Hance Road and Poplar Avenue, Fair Haven, N. J., has been purchased by John J. Kennedy of New York City through the Ray Van Horn Agency of Fair Haven.

The champion Newark Bears equaled their longest winning streak when they trounced the Montreal Royals today 9 to 4, for their thirteenth consecutive triumph. It marked their twenty-fourth decision in the last twenty-seven starts.

Edward G. Selden of Scarsdale, vice president of the Selden Worsted Mills, with New York offices at 51 Madison Avenue, died yesterday morning of heart disease in the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian 'Medical Center, after an illness of four months. He was born in Lawrence, Mass., thirtyseven years ago.

Governor Lehman will not appoint a United States Senator to succeed Royal S. Copeland, who died last week, unless President Roosevelt should call a special session of Congress before the vacancy can be filled by election.

After hearing Mayor La Guardia extol higher education and declare that the safety and security of a democracy depends upon an enlightened people, more than 2,000 graduates of City College stood in the center of Lewisohn Stadium last night and repeated the ancient Ephebic oath of good citizenship.

There are all sorts of theories as to the fascination of prizefights, and no doubt most of them are correct. The most intriguing of them is the notion that most of us would like to hit somebody and don't dare.

Railroad bonds continued to move forward in heavier trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The persistent strength of securities in the carrier group overshadowed the wide gyrations in local traction issues which followed reports that the Interborough-might default on its 5 per cent refunding

Many priests from various parts of the country will attend a solemn high mass this morning at 10 o'clock in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, in celebration of the silver jubilee in the priesthood of the Very Rev. Terence S. McDermott.

While approval of Fall advertising budgets is coming through slowly from large companies, advertising agencies said yesterday that the prospects for fairly sizable schedules in the last four months of the year are becoming brighter.

Countess Haugwitz-Reventiow, the former Barbara Hutton, Woolworth heiress, broke into the news again today as London buzzed with rumors that her 2-year-old son Lance was under guard against kidnapping.

A new development in fight weather forecasts was introduced yesterday in, connection with the Louis-Schmeling fight-and with discouraging results. At the request of Promoter Mike Jacobs, who wanted to allay his fears with a special forecast, the United Air Lines sent W. B.'Beckwith, one of its meteorologists, 'aloft in a plane at noon to the 12,000-foot level, where he could get a forecast based on upper air-temperatures and the structure of clouds above this level.

Edward Peter Pierce, retired justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Court, died here late this afternoon in his home after several weeks illness at the age of 85. He retired last Oct. 29, after thirty-seven years of uninterrupted service in the high courts of the commonwealth.

Led by outfielder Henry Steinbacher, who tied a modern major league record of six hits in as many times at bat in a single game, the White Sox snapped out of their long batting slump today and routed Washington, 16 to 3.
The continued firmness of securities in Wall Street bolstered stock-market sentiment here today and most sections were cheerful. Gilt-edge issues were quiet while foreign bonds were generally firm.

With city tax totals what they are, any new tax is a bad tax. However, the occupancy tax voted by the City Council to guarantee interest on a $20,-. 000,000 fund for slum clearance and rehousing seems as innocuous as any that could be devised.

The owners of Mexico's silk and rayon factories notified the Federal Labor Board officially today that they were willing to hand over the industry to union workers unless they were permitted to reduce operations to three days a week.

Mrs. Fannie Briggs Houghton Bulkeley, widow of Morgan G. Bulkeley, former Governor of Connecticut, United States Senator and Mayor of this city, was found dead in bed at her home here today. She had been ill a short time. Her age was 77. She was a native of Vallejo, Calif. A son and a daughter survive.

The Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade made public yesterday the names of nine Americans recently killed in Spain. They were: Lieutenant David Reiss of Paterson, N. J.; Irving Keith of New York, former district organizer for the Young Communist League in Boston and Philadelphia; Lieutenant James Cody of New York,

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that in May 290 direct loans to industry aggregating $24,959,610 had been authorized. In addition, the corporation agreed to purchase participations of $7,231,782 in loans to seventy-six businesses.

In addition to notifying the League of Nations that it no longer recognizes the status of the League commission in the Sanjak of Alexandretta, the Turkish Government has asked the French Government to do likewise.
Stocks strong, with gains of 1 to 3 points at close; some issues up 4 and 5 points; turnover, 1,713,050 shares, third largest trading of year.

New peace moves to halt the spreading Chinese-Japanese warfare were reported under way today. Emissaries of the Japanesesponsored North China provisional government were said to be holding preliminary negotiations with representatives of the Hankow Government of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

Tentative discussions have been held recently between officials of the United States Steel Corporation and of the Steel Workers Organiz??ing Committee. C. I. O. affiliate, on the possibility of a readjustment of wages that would promote increased production and employment in the steel industry.
Jorge Brescia of the Argentine outpointed Al Kettles, South Bend, Ind., heavyweight, in the six-round semi-final at the Yankee Stadium last night. Brescia scaled 211% pounds and Kettles 205.

The marriage of Miss Patricia Williams O'Donoghue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. O'Donoghue of 27 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, to Joseph John Ryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph John Ryan of Brooklyn and Northport, L. I., took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Refuge in Brooklyn.

Shipping from Delaware especially for the $6,300 Gazelle Stakes at Aqueduct, Trainer Andy Schuttinger, former star rider, saddled the winner yesterday in J. M. Roebling's Invoke, a daughter of Teddy from Appeal.

Mrs. Alice Goodsell Cann of Rye, widow of Frank H. Cann, director of athletics and physical training at New York University for thirty years, died here yesterday in the United Hospital after an illness of ten weeks.

Luncheon, Rotary Club of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Industry and Human Relations," Roy W. Moore. Luncheon, American Polish Chamber of Commerce and Industry in the United States, in honor of Ambassador Count George Potocki, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, 1 P. M.

It was hot and murky on the Hudson today and the eighteen crews preparing for the intercollegiate regatta Monday did not extend themselves in their double workouts, their efforts being confined to racing starts and paddling.

Hall and Warrender's Natty Boy galloped home by three lengths in the Medford Purse, six-furlong feature at Suffolk Downs, today before a crowd of 12,500 to pay 6 to 1. Second was the 3-to-5 favorite, Accolade, who paid $2.60 for $2 to place while finishing a half length in front of the late charging Marson, who returned $4.20 to show.

Net profit of the Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended on May 31 amounted to $2,446,631 after depreciation, amortization, interest, Federal and State income taxes and other charges.

Headed by Governor Lehman, Senator Wagner and Postmaster General Farley, the leading public officials and politicians of the State gathered in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church yesterday at the funeral services for Daniel H. Skilling, secretary of the Democratic State Committee and assistant secretary of the Constitutional Con-vention.

Charles Gordon Smith of 14 Oakway, Scarsdale, manager of the New York State Insurance Fund, died here last night in the Hotel Commodore of a heart attack. He had gone to the hotel on business in the afternoon and remained there after becoming ill.

Unseeded Miss Elaine Fischel of the University of California provided the girls' intercollegiate tennis tournament with its first major upset by eliminating second seeded Miss Virginia Hitt of Lake Erie, 6--1, 4--6, 6--2, today in the quarter-finals at Longwood.
Mrs. Emma K. Hardy, Brooklyn clubwoman who was a leader in musical activities here, died on Tuesday in her home at 618 Madison Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness.
William Oliver Wettlaufer of this village, who. was a lieutenant of the New York Police Department on his retirement in 1920, died last night in Mather Memorial Hospital, Port Jefferson.

District Judge Thomas Francis Moran, 70, who has granted thousands of divorces during his more than twenty-seven consecutive years as a Reno jurist, announced today that he would not seek re-election when his term expires the end of this year.

Mexico has begun an active campaign in Latin America in line with a recent speech to Cuba by President Lazaro Cardenas in which the Mexican President urged Latin American nations to stand together in eliminating "economic imperialism."

Secretary of State Hull was inducted into the William and Mary College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa at a ceremony in his office today. The chapter is the mother one of the honorary scholastic fraternity, having been organized in 1776.

President Roosevelt today completed the selection of a study group of nine members representing business, industry, labor, the general public and the law to investigate industrial-labor Conditions in Great Britain, and added employer-employe relationships in Sweden to the group's field of inquiry.
The twenty-first season of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts will begin tonight under the direction of Jose Iturbi. The orchestra will be, as usual, that of the PhilharmonicSymphony Society.

Staverton Estates, Inc., bought for investment the business property at 22 Broad Street, in the Fleetwood section of Mount Vernon, N. Y. The deal was negotiated by Prince Ripley, Inc., brokers, for the Central Westchester and Fairfield Realty Company.

The Harvard battery of Tom Healey, the big sophomore right-hander, and Catcher Paul Doyle was outstanding as the Crimson squared the Yale series at one victory apiece and gained undisputed possession of second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by coming from behind to defeat the Elis today, 6 to 3.

Desperately striving to arrive at a combination that will put a stop to all talk about front runners and backsliders, Colonel Bill Terry made one change in the Giant lineup yesterday at the Polo Grounds and the result was indeed gratifying.

Testimony by James Callanan, self-styled "finder" of Wall Street deals, and George J. Mitchell Jr., "dummy" officer in various companies, yesterday closed for the time being the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of investment trusts here.
Seven Breton Autonomists who greeted the court with Nazi salutes when they went on trial for defacing monuments were sentenced to varying prison terms today.
Building plans filed yesterday consisted principally of projects for the construction of small dwellings in Queens and Brooklyn and for alterations to many existing buildings in Manhattan. In Queens,

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 20: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Abernethy, E. P., to Naval Gun Factory, Navy Yard, Washington, D. C., instead Bureau of Navigation, Navy Department, previous orders modified.

Prices of both zinc and lead were advanced 1/4 cent a pound yesterday. The American Smelting and Refining Company increased the price of lead 25 points to 4.25 cents a pound at New York. The St. Joseph Lead Company increased its price to 4.25 cents at New York and 4.10 cents at St. Louis.

Gross assets, $72,399; net, $64,853. To Anna A. Murray, Elizabeth A. Hood, Margaretta A. Keedy, daughters, and William J. Ahearn, son, one-fourth residue each. Chief assets, real estate, $34,600. Hyman Turchin, attorney, 270 Broadway.
Checks for bigger amounts have appeared in the news, but no better checks than two recent ones presented to President Roosevelt and King
What is reputed to be the first salmon derby on the Atlantic coast will be held on July 3-4 at the Dennys River, Maine, under the auspieces of the Dennys River Salmon Club.
The American Federation of Actors, the vaudeville performers, union, has preferred against the Burlesque Artists Association a charge that the B. A. A. has been negligent in organizing its field.

The bank examination policy of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which may be modified somewhat by the new plan for uniform bank examinations which is expected to be submitted to President Roosevelt tonight or tomorrow by Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury, is set forth in the annual report of the FDIC, made public today.
Dr. George Evans Jr. and his wife gave a mortgage for $5,000, due in three years at 5 per cent, on their home and its furnishings, etc., at 54 Park Ave, to Herminla Barrard of the same address.

William Gaxton and Victor Moore, last seen together in "Anything Goes!" and before that in "Of Thee I Sing" and "Let 'Em Eat Cake," will be reunited next season in one of the musical shows now on Vinton Freedley's schedule, Mr. Gaxton says.
Our Sailor, owned by C. Mahlon Kline and ridden by H. W. Clements, was a surprise whiner today of the $6,000 added Georgetown Steeplechase Handicap, first jumping race ever run at Delaware Park.

The members of the American Legion in this State must be "mobilized" to win preference for veterans of the World War in the filling of government jobs where the civil service applies, Jeremiah F. Cross, State Commander of the American Legion, told the opening session last night of the twentieth annual meeting of the New York County American Legion.

The recent abundant rains have greatly improved the agricultural situation. Harvesting already has begun in the southern provinces which are the least affected by the drought and most of them report that the crops are well up to average.

S. M. Waters, president of the mortgage banking firm of M. R. Waters Sons, Inc., Minneapolis, will be the next president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, the organization's nominating committee, headed by James W. Collins of Salt Lake City, announced here today.

Max Baer had a very good vestpocket criticism of Max Schmeling's tactics when the fight was over. In a few thousand wellchosen words the voluble Livermore Larruper discoursed on the battle. The gist of his remarks is found in one sentence.
There will be a conference tomorrow between the Cabinet's Political Committee over which Premier Milan Hodza presides and a Henlein party committee of five led by Ernst Kundt.

There were twenty-two starters in the American Yacht Club's race to New London that started off Scotch Caps tonight, a sizeable fleet considering that forty-two deep-water craft are in the Bermuda contest. There was only a faint nor'easter to get them away.

Dr. Alexis Carrel, French scientist associated with the Rockefeller Institute, who collaborated with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in keeping alive organs through use of the "Lindbergh pump," sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star Liner Queen Mary for Europe to pass the Summer at his home on Saint Gilda's Island off the coast of Brittany.

Despite sharp drops in taxes reflecting the business recession, Federal revenue from internal sources through May exceeded receipts during the same period last year by $1,085,757,052, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today.

The street and highway traffic safety problem was attacked on three fronts yesterday as the second C. I. T. Seminar of Safety swung into the third day of its five-day meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch returned from Italy today and went to Bled, in Slovenia, where he will have an audience tomorrow with Prince Paul, the chief regent. Official quarters express considerable satisfaction over his meeting with Premier Benito Mussolini.

Debonair and dapper as ever, former Mayor James J. Walker visited Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday. He said his call was in the interest of several clients who have business dealings with the city.

A $50,000 trust fund for Stony Wold Sanitarium for Working Girls at Lake Kushawua, N. Y., is provided for in the will of Mrs. Elizabeth Newcomb, its founder, offered for probate today in Franklin County Surrogate's Court. It disposes of an estate valued at more than $75,000.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered eleven manufacturers of industrial rivets to cease and desist from entering into and executing any price-fixing agreement or understanding among themselves or with any members of the industry for the purpose or with the effect of restraining, monopolizing or eliminating competition in the sale of their products.

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange has approved the listing application of Cable Electric Products, Inc., for voting trust certificates representing 56,047 additional shares of common stock without par value.

Three navy vessels threaded their way through the East River late yesterday afternoon to complete a remarkable feat of seamanship. Two of them had been inseparable, literally, for thirty-nine days and over 6,100 miles of water, some of it turbulent.

Despite weakness in the last quarter, 1937 was a good year for department stores, with both percentage and dollar earnings higher than for any year since 1929, with the exception of 1936, according to the eighteenth annual report on the operating results of department and specialty stores published today by the bureau of business research of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

The Commonwealth Government has decided that the new capital of the mandated territory of New Guinea will be Salamaua, on the mainland, instead of Rabaul on the island of New Britain. The latter was declared to be unsafe following last year's volcanic eruption.

The Tokyo municipal assembly, according to reports received by the Commerce Department and released today, has appropriated 12,130,000 yen (about $3,517,700) for the 1940 Olympics. Of this amount about

Contract lettings for building and construction in New York City, Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties rose 150 per cent in May over the figures for April, as against a gain of 28 per cent in the thirty-seven Eastern States, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.
The combination of Ducky Medwick and Lon Warneke was too much for the Bees today and the Cardinals gained a 4-2 victory despite four fielding miscues.

Pressing irresistibly forward on the crest of a wave of civic enthusiasm that swept a record week-day crowd of 67,459 into the magnificent Municipal Stadium, the rampant Indians scored a double knockout over the Yankees today.

A gasoline price war is spreading over Chicago. It started several weeks ago, when isolated stations began rebating 2 cents a gallon on gasoline to customers, and has continued until the rebate has reached as much as 4 cents a gallon.
Another step in the program of modernizing St. Patrick's Cathedral was taken yesterday, when the trustees filed plans for a new approach to the edifice from the. Fifth Avenue side.

Captain John Hayston, vice president and a director of the Morton Sundour Company, Inc., drapery fabrics, died on Tuesday in his home at 9 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He was 51 years old.

John M. Allison, consul in charge of the United States Embassy, made representations to the Japanese at Nanking today regarding the slapping of Dr. J. C. Thompson of New Brunswick, N. J., by a Japanese sentry.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, released yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $22,819,715.
Many names were added yesterday to tenant rosters of apartment buildings on the East Side. Agents also reported several leases on the West Side.

W. C. Beschorman, executive vice we president of the National Lead Company, has resigned as a director of the Doehler Die 'Casting Company, and Fletcher W. Rockwell, president of National Lead, has been elected to take his place on the board.

The moderate improvement in steel operating schedules is interpreted by The Iron Age in its weekly review as a growing feeling that business generally this Summer will not be so slack as expected and that a foundation for a fair measure of recovery in the Fall is slowly being laid.

A building program for 1939 recommending a capital outlay budget of $50,402,420, to include twenty-three elementary and eight high schools, was approved yesterday by the Board of Education at its regular meeting.

French views as recently expressed in the Temps that Budapest is the center of anti-German activity were repudiated today in the semi-official Pester Lloyd, which comments that recent events proved that the Rome-Berlin axis is stronger than ever and that the Little Entente is considerably weaker than last year.

After binding a lone clerk in the office of the Empire City Optical Company at 20 West Twenty-second Street at 11:30 A. M. yesterday, three armed men, two of whom wore masks, looted the shop of gold-filled merchandise valued at $1,000.

New York City's one-cent tax on each package of cigarettes appeared likely to bring in $9,000,000 a year, three times the estimate of the original yield, when collection figures made public yesterday showed that $1,525,305 had been collected since the tax went into effect on May 1.

The British Government calmly ignored the sinking of two more British merchant ships in the Mediterranean today and continued to canvass the possibilities of a truce in Spain and early operation of its friendship pact with Italy.

Abraham Goldsmith, a former partner of Henry Morgenthau Sr. in the law firm of Lachman, Morgenthau Goldsmith, died yesterday, after a long illness, in his apartment at the Hotel Gotham, Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

By a small majority that included Protestants as well as Catholics the lower house today rejected a Leftist motion asking a parliamentary inquiry of the alleged halting of an investigation of a moral offenses case by Minister of Justice Carel Maria Goseling, a Catholic, when it appeared that priests were likely to be involved.

Expansion of buying in primary consumer goods lines continued yesterday, with printcloths still leading, but with good activity reported also in several other markets. The first instance of delivery delays, which have been threatened in several markets, developed in men's wear wool goods, where clothing manufacturers who had postponed buying in the hope of pushing prices downward ran into a delivery jam which will delay the beginning of their Fall operations for about a month.
Raffaele Marino, 34 years old, for many years known in underworld circles as "Jimmy Meehan," was sentenced to Sing Sing for ten to twenty years yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions.

Told that corporate taxes in this Commonwealth were from 15 to 5,598 per cent higher than those in eleven other industrial States, the Pennsylvania Bar Association today recommended the creation of a permanent tax commission of three members to adjust levies criticized as inequitable.

" Centralization of ownership of American business by monopolycontrolled corporations" was attacked here this morning as the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers passed its controversial resolution in support of the proposed Federal Chain Store Tax Law sponsored by Representative Wright Patman of Texas.

Harlem's celebration of the victory of its hero, Joe Louis, over Max Schmeling started off deliriously but more or less peacefully after the fight ended last night, but wound up early this morning with a wholesale throwing of bottles, tin cans and other missiles from roof tops and windows in the vicinity of Seventh Avenue and 130th Street that resulted in slight injuries to twenty policemen and ten civilians.

Miss Emily Gertrude Stull of Leonia, N. J., and William Hotchkiss Potter of Buffalo, whose engagemert was announced last February in Northampton, Mass., where Miss Stull was studying at Smith College, were married here yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

A decrease of 60 per cent in the arrivals of Oriental rice in Cuba and an increase of 267 per cent in American rice imports during 'the first five months of 1938 have been reported to the Commerce Department by the Commercial Attache at Havana.

Estate, about $14,000. To Lawrence H. Adriance, nephew, executor, Federal Place, Riverdale, N. J. BERMAN, BESSIE (June 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Louis Berman, brother, 288 Exeter St., Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, N. Y., $1,000; six charitable bequests

After advancing for seven consecutive trading days, cotton prices developed a reactionary tendency yesterday, but after a sharp setback they rallied almost $1 a bale and ended only 2 to 5 points lower than on Tuesday.

Richard Malcolm Adler, former president. of the Adler Veneer Corporation and .first president of Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, L. I., died on Tuesday night of a heart ailment in his home at the Regent Hotel. He was 65 years old.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins announced yesterday that he would appoint a referee to determine whether Schenley Distributors, Inc., had employed reasonable diligence to prevent price cutting on its products since it obtained injunctions under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act last December.
Performers and workers of Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey circus refused to put on the show tonight, saying they had not agreed to take a reduction of 25 per cent in wages.

Registration statements made under the Securities Act of 1933 and which became effective in May, again were at a low level, aggregating only $93,634,000, including $8,358,000 registered solely for reserve against conversion of other securities, according to an analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This left $85,

A sharp debate on the question of an Episcopal administration in the Lutheran Church flared up yesterday at the second day's sessions of the seventy-ninth annual convention of the Evangelical Lutheran Augustana Synod of North America at the Bethlehem Lutheran Church, Third Avenue and Pacific Street, Brooklyn.

The Power Memorial Academy, a Catholic school conducted by the Christian Brothers Institute, will move from Harlem to the upper West Side, where the institute has purchased from the Society of the New York Hospital a large group of buildings at Amsterdam Avenue and Sixty-first Street, it was learned yesterday. The property,

The exploding fists of Joe Louis crushed Max Schmeling last night in the ring at the Yankee Stadium and kept sacred that time-worn legend of boxing that no former heavyweight champion has ever regained the title.

Members of the City Planning Commission voted unanimously yesterday to make Avenue-J between East Sixteenth and East Seventeenth Streets in Brooklyn a business area instead of a residential area, thus ending a six-year fight by residents of the section to keep it for residence use .

Here in this ancient capital which was the cradle of Catholicism in the New World north of the Spanish colonies, Canada's National Eucharistic Congress opened officially tonight at a ceremony in the Quebec Armory.

The Supreme Court of Errors yesterday held constitutional the charter of the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company under which the company is condemning land in the Saugatuck Valley for reservoir purposes. The company's condemnation of land in Weston and Redding has been the subject of bitter litigation for months.

New York will join with eighteen other States in providing a program for study of State government by high school students. The national organization of the American Legion has made the arrangements, Frank C. Love of Syracuse, chairman of "the boys' State" committee for New York, announced yesterday.
-George Herbert Higbie, retired real estate and insurance broker, temperance worker and member of an old Long Island family, died yesterday at his home here after a short illness. His age was 79.

Miss Louise Seyms Thomas, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Edmund C. Thomas of Hartford, Conn., was married to James Newman, son of Stephen Lang Newman of New York, this morning at the Thomas Summer home here.

The great powers of the world should take steps "speedily" to limit aircraft attacks to clearly defined military objectives and to end the bombing of "congested areas of open cities," Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring said today at the commencement exercises of the John Marshall College of Law at the State Normal School here.

Banks were among the sellers of houses in deals announced yesterday in Brooklyn. The Bowery Savings Bank sold for cash over a mortgage of $30,000 the three three-story -flats at 1,304-8 Avenue U through Grattan MacMahon, Inc., broker.

Dr. Nelson K. Fromm, attending neurologist at the Albany Hospital, died today at the, age of 56. He received his A. B. degree from Dartmouth in 1905, was graduated in 1908 from the Albany Medical College, where he later taught, and studied in Europe.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of paragraph 3, Special Orders 131, dated 7, 1938, as relates to Second Lieutenant Julius Merchant, Engr. Res., is revoked. (2nd M. A.). So much of paragraph 8, special Orders 138, dated June 15,1938, as relates to First Lieutenant Charles A. Grennan, Engr.-Res., is revoked. (2d M. A.).

The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold -to Josephine Di Giore the one-family house at 60-67 Sixtieth Avenue, Maspeth, L. I., through Jacob M. Aufrecht, broker. D. L. Haring bought from Alimy Realty, Inc., the one-family dwelling at 18-48 Steinway Street, Long Island City.
Lawyers took off their court wigs and clerks went without vests today, with the temperatures. in the seventies, marking a week-long heat wave.
Vernon Kennedy chalked up his tenth victory of the season today as the Tigers defeated the Red Sox, 8 to 3, and climbed above the .500 mark in the percentages.

Rowland Campbell, chairman of the board of the Reo Motor Car Company, said today that the resignation of Donald E. Bates as president and general manager and the election of Colonel Fred Glover of Detroit to succeed Mr. Bates would not halt Mr. Campbell's campaign to oust "all old officers" of the company.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 22: Acushnet, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Dahlgren. Barry, at Sitkoh Bay. Gridley, Guantanamo Bay to Canal Zone. Hopkins, at Sitkoh Bay. Kewaydin, at Quantico. Pennsylvania, at San Francisco.

The recommendation of the Committee on Stock List of the New York Stock Exchange that application be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to remove from listing and registration the Capital stock of the Consolidated Textile Corporation, which has been reorganized, was approved yesterday by the Board of Governors of the Exchange.

Frank J. Coyle, a former assistant corporation counsel and a member of the New York State bar for twenty years, died' at noon yesterday of a heart attack while in the safe-deposit department of the Chase National Bank branch in Rockefeller Plaza.

The international chess masters' tournament was concluded today, when E. D. Bogoljubow of Germany and Paul Schmidt of Estonia finished their game adjourned from last night's ninth and final round. The result was a draw in sixty moves.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Loretta Gates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Gates of White Plains and Chicago, to Earl Martin Schara 2d of New Rochelle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl M. Schara, took place here this afternoon at Park Drive South, Westchester Country Club grounds.

The largest graduating class in the history of St. Francis Preparatory School, 41 Butler Street, Brooklyn, will attend commencement exercises in Bishop McDonnell Memorial High School, Classon Avenue and Eastern Parkway, tonight at 8:30 o'clock. The class numbers 133. St. Francis was established in 1920.

An eighteeen-month investigation by the Civil Service Commission of the New York Navy Yard's Labor Board and the United States Naval Clothing Depot, where the official uniforms of thousands of sea-going enlisted men are manufactured, has resulted in the resignation of the board's recorder, -the suspension of four depot section heads and the dismissal of ten uniform workers, it was learned yesterday.

Two banking groups headed respectively by the Chase National Bank and Lehman Brothers purchased yesterday at private sale from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $60,000,000 of Metropolitan Water District of Southern California Colorado River Water Works 4 per cent refunding bonds. Both groups paid a price of 107 for the bonds.

Governor Lehman's announcement of his willingness to be a candidate for Senator raises the interesting question of who owns the Democratic party in New York. There is one group of Democrats which seems to believe that the title is now vested in Washington.

" Now I feel like the champion." These were Joe Louis's first words on his arrival in his dressing room. "I've been waiting a long time for this night," he added, "and I sure do feel pretty glad about everything. I was a little bit sore at some of the things Max said.

The cost of all types of public and private relief in this city declined by $1,393,041 last month, according to a compilation made public yesterday by the Welfare Council. The aggregate relief bill in May was $21,216,986, against $22.610.027 in April.

LANGDON POST has played an important and controversial part in stimulating Amierica's much needed rehousing program. He discusses his ideas 'frankly in an able book called "The Challenge of Housing."* First of all, says Mr. Post, it should be understood that private enterprise can't manage the main job. It not only can't but won't;

James P. Quinn, former general manager and treasurer of the Taylor-Friedsam Company, silk ribbon manufacturer in New York, was found dead this morning in his automobile, parked in woods near Kensico Dam, town of North Castle.

Our gardener at the convention of the American Seed Trades Association in Detroit reports that the demand for flower seeds is growing, and the demand for vegetable seeds has been going down for the last two years.

Hiland Garfield Batcheller, president and a director of the Ludlum Steel Company of Watervliet, N. Y., was elected yesterday a director of the New York Telephone Company at a meeting of the board. He is also president of the Forging and Casting Corporation and chairman of the board of the Wallingford Steel Company.

With a collection of stamps and covers issued in Jamaica, C. Brinkley Turner of this city, won the grand prize today at the National Stamp Exhibition, which opened yesterday in connection with the Swedish tercentenary celebration.

Attorneys for the Eagle Pencil Company, 710 East Fourteenth Street, and a C. I. O. union conducting a strike against it and its subsidiary Niagara Paper Box Company, were urged yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo to agree privately on a basis for the settlement of the dispute.

THE storm over Tokyo and the Olympic Games of 1940 is getting worse, which was to be expected. Just the other day THE NEW YORK TIMES had a leading editorial in which Japan was indicted as a government "whose present activities are totally opposed to the whole Olympic idea" and the concluding paragraph of the editorial ran:

A welldefined national labor policy and a code of fair practice to guide business men and labor in settling their problems were proposed today at the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

The indications are for partly cloudy weather, possibly with seattered showers, today and tomorrow. Little change in temperature is expected, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (E. S. T.) last night.

ADLER-Richard M., beloved husband of Eva, devoted father of Richard M., Jr., and Louise A. Kamsly, brother of Herbert S. and Paula Adler Kohn. Funeral services at the West End Funeral Chapel, 200 West 91st St., Friday, June 24. at 11 A. M.

Mrs. Martha Barkley Ryan of Morgantown, N. C., filed notice yesterday in Supreme Court that she would ask Justice Cotillo tomorrow to set her suit for separation from her husband, Basil Allen Ryan, grandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, down for trial this month. Her attorney said that Mr.

The aggregate net operating income of the first six railroads to report for May was $2,479,000, against $3,384,000 in May, 1937, a decline of 26.7 per cent, and against $3,415,000 in May, 1936, a drop of 27.4 per cent. In April,

The seventy-first and perhaps the last encampment of the New Jersey department of the G. A. R. was held today at the Hotel Madison here, with only seven of the State's thirty-one veterans able to attend.

John Clyde Oswald, president of the National-Arts Club, printer, publisher and outstanding authority on Benjamin Franklin, died early yesterday morning after a lingering illness at his home in Pelham Manor. He was in his sixty-sixth year.
The recovery in the dollar turned irregular in the foreign exchange market yesterday and some important European currencies rallied, while a few others continued to fall.

Electric power production showed a nominal decline last week. The rise in daily average output was less than anticipated on the basis of normal trends, and the adjusted index eased to 90.7 from 90.8. The figure was 106.4 for the week ended June 19, 1937.

The Long Island golf Association held its first mixed Scotch foursome event at the Rockville Country Club today, with a field of seventeen teams taking art. Premier honors in both the gross and net competition went to Miss Betty Harper and Dr. C. J. Robinson of Wheatley Hills with a score of 78--10--68.

Two men were wounded by bullets today in a clash police said occurred between C. I. O. and A. F. of L. teamsters after a strike was called against nine trucking companies by a C. I. O.-affiliated union.

The Foreign Policy Association has signed a contract with Shepard Stone for a Headline Book on Germany to be published in the early Fall. Tentatively entitled "Shadow Over Europe," the book will be devoted to a comprehensive discussion of pan-Germanism, and more particularly to the Nazi program for expansion in the East.

The Washington of the United States Lines will arrive today from the Channel ports. Among her passengers are Hugh S. Gibson, United States Ambassador to Belgium; Major John P. Ratay, Mrs. Vinton Chapin, Mr. and Mrs. David A. Moscovitz, Dr. William W. Skinner, Mrs. Arthur Duckworth, Lady Constance Foster-Fraser, Mr. and Mrs. Whittemore Littell, Mrs. Elizabeth La Plante, A. J. Cormack, Mr. and Mrs. A. K. Paris, A. H. Russell and P. P. Cosgrove.

Calling upon the members of the Newark City Commission to "vindicate" this city, Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, asked the commission today to designate Military Park as the site for his scheduled speaking appearance here next Saturday afternoon. City Commissioner...

The House of Representatives early this morning approved a bill authorizing the issuance of $20,000,000 in silver currency. The measure already has the approval of the Senate and the President is expected to sign it without delay.

The Securities and Exchange Commission handed down today its long-. awaited decision in the case of White, Weld Co., ordering that Faris R. Russell, a partner in the firm, be suspended for ninety days from membership in the New York Stock and New York Curb Exchanges and the Chicago Board of Trade.

Percy Goldman of Brooklyn was unanimously elected president of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association at the concluding session of the organization's convention at the Hotel Sagamore today. Other officers elected

4th St, 69 E, 25x100; Annie Paul and George Hoffspiegel and wife to Hymanlieba Realty Co., Inc., 46 E 21st St, care G. Hoffspiegel (50 cents). 11th Ave, 500, 24.8x100; Joseph S. Dorfmuller to Port of N. Y. Authority ($31.). 6th Ave, 797, 20x60; Samuel M. Katz to William H. Fischer et al., 228 W 71st St, consid $6,000, foreclosure.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody marked her return to the Wimbledon championships after a three-year absence by scoring a 6--3, 6--4 victory today ??ver Mrs. Harry C. Hopman of Australia.

Miss Anne Cuttle Callan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Callan of Mount Vernon, was married to Charles Russell O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. O'Brien of Harlingen, N. J., at noon today in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here by the Rev. Joseph L. McCann.

An issue of $375,000 city of Austin, Texas, school bonds, due serially up to twenty years, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising the Boatmen's National Bank, St. Louis; Braun, Bosworth Co. of Toledo, Ohio; the Dallas Union Trust Company and the Dallas National Bank.

A decree issued today by the Greek Government provides that henceforth all those found guilty of espionage or conspiring against the State shall be liable to the death penalty or to life imprionsment with hard labor. There is to be no appeal to courtmartial sentences.
Sam Houston, Alabama barbecue king-through the courtesy 'of the Shuberts and Fortune - Gallo, operatic impresario - staged his long-awaited barbecue yesterday afternoon at Randalls Island.

The tentative discussions between the United States Steel Corporation and the Committee for Industrial Organization on the possibility of a revision of the basic wage rate called for in the union contract involve a triangle of perplexing interrelationships.

Three successive days of rising prices in the stock market, each session passing the 1,000,000-share mark, have caused Wall Street to emerge from its long pessimistic mood and to change entirely its mental attitude toward the immediate future as well as the Autumn.
