A plea that "real Southern Democrats" join the Republican party as the champion of "Jeffersonian philosophy" was voiced today by John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

Charles Anderson Urner, one of the leading field ornithologists of the United States and an expert on the economics of marketing and distributing in dairy and poultry products, died here early this morning of a heart attack on his way to his home in this city. He was 56 years old.

Jed Bull, who made "Harlem-on the Prairie," and currently is filming "The Terror of Tiny- Town" with an all-midget cast, today announced "Follies on Horseback." Reversing the horse opera routine of forty cowboys and one leading woman, Bull is negotiating, with Harry Langdon to play a lone male among forty feminine cowpunchers.
Thirty-two matches started many a blaze in the first round of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today, and when the smoke had cleared the title hopes of several favorites were ashes.

The generalization of a shorter week through the labor world moved a step forward today when the International Labor Conference voted, 92 to 27, with 19 abstentions, to consult the governments on this point with a view to definite treaty action at the next session of the conference in June, 1939.
Representative Lea of California, chairman of the House Interstate Commerce Committee, asked a sixman subcommittee today-to study possible changes in the government's regulation of transportation.

Redmond Co., one of the leading member houses of the New York Stock Exchange, will be censured by the chairman of the board of the Exchange for infraction of Federal margin regulations. The action was voted yesterday by the board of governors.

The C. I. O. won a major victory over the A. F. of L. today when its affiliate the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, District No. 1, was certified by the National Labor Relations Board as the exclusive bargaining agency for all longshoremen in thirty-one Pacific Coast ports.

The Board of Education has approved the following appointments of teachers in various branches of the school system for a probationary period of three years to take effect Sept. 9, 1938, except where otherwise indicated:

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad will meet interest payments due on July 1, a director remarked after the board meeting yesterday. Net revenue of the company from railway operations before railway accruals, equipment rents and joint facility rents was about $2,100,000 in May, against $1,800,000 in April.
In his dressing room after one of the quickest knockouts on record in a heavyweight title fight, Max Schmeling claimed that he had been hit by a foul kidney blow, the second punch that Louis landed.

Miss Louise Davies Greenwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Morris Greenwood, was. married here today in the home of her parents to Charles Warren Lippitt of Providence, R. I., by the Rev. George Young of the Middletown Baptist Church.

Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee in 1936, told the nation's editors tonight that a "propaganda machine, the like of which this country never before has seen," was in full operation in America.
The Philadelphia Company and its subsidiary, the Pittsburgh and Wes Virginia Gas Company, have registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
Milwaukee Railroad officials indicated a belief tonight that the final toll of the crash of the line's Olympian train Sunday would be fortysix.

Here in old New England, where formal education in America began, Yale University heard Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, suggest that Canadians and Americans be less self-conscious about their friendship and awarded hononary degrees to him, to Walt Disney and to nine others at the 237th commencement exercises.
Secretary Roper expressed a belief today that the business recession was "scraping the bottom" and that there were definite indications favorable to an early business upturn.

Frank Strafaci continued his winling ways in the annual William Rice Hochster memorial tournanent at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today . Strafaci, who recently captured the metropolitan amateur title by defeating Willie Turnesa, former champion , in the final at Ridgewood, also had to vanquish Turnesa today in a play-off, after they had finished the thirty-six holes of medal play tied at 141.

The principle of church participation in social action, through inquiry into social issues, development of lay thought on such questions and the formulation and execution of specific programs, was reaffirmed today by delegates to the General Council of the Congregational and Christian Churches as they brought their biennial meeting to a close.

Released from the discipline of the classroom, nearly 1,250,000 boys and girls will swarm into the streets tomorrow afternoon, eager to begin their Summer vacation. Because of the National Education Association convention, the city schools are to close one week earlier than usual.

With record agricultural production in many lines pushing prices lower almost daily, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today expanded authorizations for purchases of surpluses to the fields of vegetables and cheese.
The Dartmouth Athletic Council today announced the awarding of varsity letters to the baseball team, champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate League, and the track team.
Intense Japanese activity in the vicinity of Swatow, 200 miles west of Canton, for the past two days resulted in the occupation of Namoa Island this morning after reported weak Chinese resistance.

Secretary Roper was urged yesterday by the Smaller Business Association, sponsor of a "Buy Today Crusade," to tell the country that "the time to. buy is now" and that prices will not go lower. A message signed by Henry Modell, chairman of the campaign, said:

Continuing the pace she set when she won the gold qualifying medal on Monday in the Westchester and Fairfield championship, Mrs. Charles Eastman of Greenwich won her quarter-final match from Mrs. Earl Ross'of the Westchester C. C., over the Woodway course today, 6 and 5.

Both medicine and pharmacy are overcrowded in the United States and the host of professional men that are coming to. this country to escape the troubles in Europe should be welcomed only after close inspection.

Adoption of the round-table technique by government and business to obtain a rapid solution of common problems was advocated today by W. O. Douglas, chairman of the Security and Exchange Commission, in an address here before the Foundation for the Advancement of the Social Sciences.

Mrs. G. Arthur Duckworth of London will arrive today on the Washington to visit with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Hammond. Mrs. Newbold Morris of Lenox, Mass., who returned on the Ile de France, is at the Sherry-Netherland.

Chicago's Negro section, with a population of 232,000, staged a gay celebration of Joe Louis's one-round victory over Max Schmeling tonight. Shots were fired in the air, firecrackers set off, trolley poles jerked from street cars and some windows broken.

THE CHALLENGE OF HOUSING, by Langdon W. Post. (Farrar Rinehart, $3.50.) A study of tenements and of the forces that brought them into being. A CRUISING GUID TO THE NEW ENGLAND COAST. edited by Robert F. Duncan. (Kemp, $5.) A new edition, revised and enlarged.
Death Announced Retired Captain John Hughes (1), formerly a member of H. L. 40, residing at 90 Morningside Dr., Manhattan, died Tune 19.
Turpentine firm, 22 3/4c; sales, 23 barrels; receipts, 588 barrels; shipments, 306 barrels; stock, 38,225 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 239; receipts, 2,377; shipments, 215; stock, 151,010.

The close of play scores In first-class cricket matches started today: Kent 279 for five (Todd 118, Woolley 57) vs. Gloucestershire, at Gloucester. Nottinghamshire 208 for two (Gunn 102 not out, Heaton 90 not out) vs. Northamptonshire, at Nottingham. Somerset 125 (P. Smith four for 31, R. Smith four for 37) vs. Essex 33 for none, at Bath.

The four-day sale of pictures, furniture, tapestries and other art objects collected by the late Mortimer L. Schiff over a thirty-year period began in Christie's Galleries today. Most of the important British and Continental dealers, as well as many representatives of American firms, took an active part in the day's dealings, which realized a total of [Pound]31,435.

A brochure entitled "The Threat Against Your Chain-Store Customers," asserting that the Patman Chain-Store bill attempts to destroy the retail chain-store system of distribution, is being sent out by the American Manufacturers Institute, Inc., 200 Fifth Avenue.

The interparochial Eucharistic Congress conducted by twenty-five Roman Catholic churches having Italian congregations in the Diocese of Brooklyn opened last night with approximately 20,000 worshipers. An order of service observed throughout included the words of welcome of the respective pastors.

Representatives of the Aqueduct and Jamaica racetracks told members of the Council Finance Committee yesterday that operation of these tracks would cease if the city imposed its pending 2 per cent tax on the gross incomes of bookmakers, to raise $2,000,000 a year for relief.

Over the protest of counsel for the Manhattan Railway Company and its receiver, Federal Judge. Patterson directed yesterday Thomas E. Murray. Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, to pay all of the July 1 interest due on the company's publicly held 5 per cent bonds and on such of its 5 per cent bonds as are held as collateral for its 7 per cent secured notes.

The State Railroad Commission has authorized the Los Angeles Railway to issue 5 per cent notes aggregating $423,026 to acquire thirty-five additional surface cars of a new type of which sixty were installed recently.

George J. Gillespie, national head of the St. Vincent de Paul Society, received from Cardinal Hayes the medal awarded annually to the outstanding layman in Catholic Action at a ceremony held yesterday afternoon at the Cardinal's residence, 477 Madison Avenue.

A few nights ago Mrs. Ethel Tarnanovich, a respectable housewife, accompanied by her husband, boarded a Second Avenue bus. She found a loaded pistol on the seat. The couple agreed that it was their duty to turn it over to a policeman. This Mrs. Tarnanovich did. She was thereupon

WHITE BANNERS, based on the story by Lloyd C. Douglas; screen play by Lenore Coffee, Cameron Rogers and Abem Finkel; music by Max Steiner; directed by Edmund Goulding for Warner Brothers. At the Strand.
Before the Constitutional Convention adjourned today for the week-end the Republicans took action to insure a firmer control over decisions reached in that body.

The marriage of - Miss Annette Beardsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glover Beardsley of 31 East Seventy-ninth Street, to Charles Franklin Wagner, soil of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Wagner of Dayton, Ohio, took place here yesterday afternoon in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Governor Philip F. La Follette said today that he found Eastern States "enthusiastically open-minded" toward his new political party, the National Progressives of America. The Governor returned Saturday from a vacation and speaking tour in the East.

Canton had enjoyed four days and four nights of freedom from the horrors of Japanese aerial raids when the writer left Shameen Island this morning, crossed the bridge at 5:40 o'clock and walked up Canton's Bund to catch the steamer Fatshan for Hong Kong.

Selected as examples of what can be done, under adverse conditions, three physically handicapped children -received yesterday the M. Samuel Stern Memorial Prizes in a brief ceremony in the - office of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

Negro residents of Detroit's "Paradise Valley," who had confidently petitioned the City Council two weeks ago for permission to do so, danced and sang in roped-off streets tonight in celebration of Joe Louis's knockout victory over Max Schmeling.

The only two singles matches of the day saw Miss Eunice Dean of Texas, the defending champion, and Miss Edna Smith of Cleveland, win their way into the quarterfinals of the women's New Jersey State tennis championships today at the Oritani Field Club.

A police emergency squad and a compressed-air drill crew broke down part of a brick wall to extricate 10-year-old Peter Prenciford of 1,143 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, yesterday at 2:15. P. M., an hour after the boy became wedged'between the walls of the buildings at 1,035 and 1,037 Forty-fourth Street, near Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn.
Fifty-two young Spanish pilots who have completed their course of training took an oath of fealty to General Francisco Franco at the airdrome here yesterday.

Invitations to the marriage of Miss Carlota Saint-Gaudens, daughter of Homer Saint-Gaudens, director of fine arts at the Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, to John E. Dodge, son of Mrs. Frank F. Dodge of Stonington, Conn., have been recalled because of the recent death of the prospective bridegroom's father.

The WPA sewing projects and the decision to purchase some $10,000,000 worth of clothing will not suffice to supply relief apparel needs, the International Association of Garment Manufacturers asserted yesterday in a special bulletin to its members.
The Greek Theatre, Inc., made its New York debut last night at the Guild Theatre in "The Song of Daphnis," described in the program as "a Dionysian dithyramb in modern Greek."

The official gazette today announces that among twenty-nine Germans who have just been deprived of German citizenship is Gottfried Trebiranus, member of the Cabinet under Chancellor Heinrich Bruening, who, in the Nazi massacre of June 30, 1934, escaped the fate of General Kurt von Schleicher and his wife only by jumping a. fence as pursuers entered his driveway. Since ,then he has lived in England.

Breath by breath in the Bronx. Down in front! The show is about to begin. Major Gen. John J. Phelan has arrived at the ringside wearing a shining straw skimmer and herding a couple of preliminary fighters ing the ring. If anybody cares, their names are Bill Comiskey and Joe Lubin. Wonder what Max and Joe are doing or thinking right at this moment?

Close hauled on the starboard tack, the fleet of forty-three yachts was making a good course to Bermuda tonight. The wind was southsouthwest, the sea smooth and the barometer falling. The Division B craft were bunched while those in Division A were scattered.

" Water buses" powered with heavy oil engines and carrying from sixty to eighty passengers are fast replacing the small lake excursion steamers in Swedish waters, the Commercial Attache at Stockholm reports.

The committee appointed to study proposed amendments to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange providing for permissive incorporation of member firms reported yesterday to the board of governors of the Exchange.

If the country is in the grip of a recession it was not evident at the Yankee Stadium last night as one of the largest crowds that has seen a fight in New York nearly filled the arena to see the Joe Louis-Max Schmeling battle.
The Bank of Brazil today posted a notice suspending, "until further orders," purchases of German compensated marks, the currency Germany uses in trading with Brazil. It is reported that

Hedging pressure and a continued lack of an aggressive export demand for wheat more than offset today the effect of strength in securities and les favorable crop comments from the Southwest and Northwest and prices ranged lower, closing within small fractions of a cent a bushel of the bottom with net losses of 1 to 1 1/4 cents on the Board of Trade.
Evidence began to accumulate tonight that the violent anti-Semitic manifestations of the past week here were proving a boomerang.
Great Britain's desire to make an amicable arrangement with Germany for the future political alignment

United States Attorney Lamar Hardy obtained yesterday a court order preventing The New York Post from publishing the revelations of Leon G. Turrou, special agent of the Department of Justice, chief investigator in the German espionage inquiry.

Trial of Dr. William Lathrop Love, former State Senator, who is under indictment charged with sending defamatory postal cards through the mails, was adjourned yesterday by Judge Clarence G. Galston in Federal court, Brooklyn, until July 6.

Five French air officers, all directly attached to the Air Ministry, and two sergeants were killed at 2 o'clock this morning when a big new bombing plane they were testing exploded and crashed near Tours.

The tariff value of passengers carried free on air-mail carriers in. 1937 was reported today by the Bureau of Air Mail of the Interstate Commerce Commission as $3,885,933, compared with $2,851,550 in the preceding year, an increase of about $1,000,000.

After a year of investigation by Federal agents, Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today ordered a widespread investigation.by the Summer Federal grand jury into an alleged national milk monopoly. The jury will convene on July 15.

Three large loans-two by the RFC and one by the Mutual Life Insurance Company-helped raise the aggregate of mortgage financing in this city last month to $7,292,867, as compared with $3,536,178 in April, according to the monthly report of the Real Estate Board. of New York.
The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today dated June 21: CAPTAINS Thibault, L. F., to duty Twelfth Naval District, San Francisco, Calif., relieved duty as inspector.

By way of impressing their arch tormentors that the remainder of the journey to a pennant may not be as smooth as it set out to be, the Yankees today gave something of a flashback to their days of former greatness.

At a price indicated as $19.600 the Emt grant Bank sold to Paullne Auster of 1.120 Ward Ave, Bronx. the parcel at 180 Prince St. 25x100, taking back two demand mortgages; a p m for $19,377 and a building loan for $6,000.

There was a shortage of approximately $60,000 in the amount necessary to meet the interest due on June 1 on the Republic of Panama thirty-year 5 1/2 per cent external bonds due on June 1, 1953, the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee for the issue, reported yesterday.

The course of prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was almost an-exact duplication of that on Wednesday, a relatively steady opening was succeeded by a recession which gave way to a sharp upward movement that left the list with gains of 5 to 9 points.
Revived rumors of a coming devaluation of the dollar caused late yesterday an abrupt fall in the dollar in the foreign-exchange market.

With Japan abstaining, the League's Opium Advisory Commission unanimously adopted today a resolution on the Far Eastern situation to the same effect as the resolution last year, but more diplomatically put because of the fear of Japan withdrawing.
Nathan Goldstein, attorney, will reside in the Beresford Apartments, 211 Central Park West, where he has leased a duplex terrace suite of ten rooms through Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

Bank clearings for the latest period receded moderately from the total of the previous week, but were 10.5 -per cent below the- corresponding week of last year. After two successive weekly advances the volume in this city failed to show a gain over the 1937 total.

Unleashing a strong second-half attack, the Bostwick Field quartet routed Greentree, 11 to 5, in the Meadow Brook Club Cups polo competition today, while Templeton, East Williston and the Aiken Knights each triumphed by the slim margin of a point in tournament matches.

Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, commander-in-chief of the United States Asiatic Fleet, sailed today on the 710-ton naval yacht Isabel for an inspection voyage on the Lower Yangtze River, now under Japanese domination.

William C. Daly of 532 West 142d Street, former judge of the City Court of Indianapolis, Ind., and for thirty-five years a practicing attorney in New York, died yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Hospital after three weeks' illness. He was 70 years old.

Charles E. Hennemann, former world record holder in the, discus throw and chief of the Keokuk Police Department for twelve years, died here today at the age of 72. As a member of the Chicago Athletic Association, Mr. Hennemann established a new world discus mark of 118 feet 9 inches in the national championship held in New York in 1897.

Miss Helen Reade Thompson, daughter of Howard B. Thompson of North Hoosick and the late Mrs. Thompson, was married here today in St. Mark's Church to Fielding Simmons Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Simmons of Ruxton, Md., by the rector, the Rev. J. C. Potts.

Two weeks and two days remain of the Broad way career of "I'd Rather Be Right," meaning that it will wind up at the Music Box on Saturday night, -July 9. After a Summer's rest-Mr. Cohan, for one, is going to London and Paris-the musical will start its tour in Philadelphia on Oct. 3. Two weeks there.
Home runs by Hank Greenberg, Rudy York and Chester Laabs aided the Tigers today in a 10-to-2 victory over the Red Sox, their third triumph in the four-game series.

While seated on a bench in Morningside Park about 7:30 o'clock last night, Ralph Giccone, 24 years old, Of a truck driver, of 1,225 Virginia Avenue, the Bronx, was stabbed to death by an unidentified. assailant.

Miss Phyllis Dickinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philemon Dickinson of Philistia, Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to George E. Harrison of Port Arthur, Texas, son of William Gordon Harrison and of Mrs. Sarah King Harrison of Richmond, Va. The Rev.
Representatives of New York Stock Exchange firms and of a group sponsored by the Committee for Industrial Organization met yes

The high level of prices that prevailed at yesterday's opening of the four-day sale of-art objects collected by the late Mortimer L. Schiff was well maintained at Christie's this afternoon, bringing the total receipts thus far to [pound]48,411.

The British Government today announced the appointment of a "dictator" for air raid precautions and he was confronted immediately with charges that too much prominence had been given to society women in this work.

The directors of the Empire Trust Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share, against 25 cents a share paid in the preceding quarter. The 25 cents a share rate had been in effect since April, 1934.

American owners of embroidery and linen plants in Swatow, China, cabled orders yesterday for immediate collection and shipment of about $2,000,000 of materials which are "in work" at the plants and in the hands of home sewers in and around Swatow when news reached here of the Japanese occupation of Namoa Island, off Swatow.
Secretary Ickes announced today allotments totaling $61,342,346 for 556 approved PWA projects, including twenty-one in New York State, fourteen in Connecticut and nine in New Jersey.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today again told the House of Commons, which was incensed-over the recent sinkings of British ships by Insurgent Spanish planes, that there was nothing the British Government would do to protect its ships in Spanish territorial waters.

The Rev. E. Briggs Nash, former New York and Vermont minister, died today at the age of 64. The Rev. Mr. -Nash was a graduate of Columbia University and General Theological Seminary. He had served as a member of the staff of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York.

Three boys of Santa Cruz, Calif., who sailed bravely from that port on May 25 in the $25,000 sea-going yacht Tira, bound for Cocos Island and buried treasure, reached a stopping place in their sea adventure last night.

Chiefs of the nineteen standard railway unions notified the Carriers Joint Conference Committee today that while they would be able to meet the committee on June 28 in Chicago, as had been suggested, they would not be prepared to. take up the proposed 15 per cent wage reduction before July 20.

The body of Robert Gair Sweeney, 24year-old son of Mrs. Edward F. Sweeney of Westhampton Beach and 215 East Seventy-second Street, Manhattan, was found this afternoon behind his automobile on Scrub Oak Road outside this village.
Governor Lehman, in a speech here tonight, his first since he announced his candidacy for Senator, called for. a purge of relief rolls throughout the State.
Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 18 exceeded sales by 12,716 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium, which constitute one of New York's most Successful enterprises in the field of fine music for the masses, began their twenty-first season last night. The orchestra was again that of the PhilharmonicSymphony Society, Jpse Iturbi was the conductor and Albert Spalding the violin soloist.

Although the construction of tall office buildings now is practically at a standstill in all parts of the country, the day of the skyscraper has not passed and more such structures may be erected in the future on a conservative basis, in the opinion of realty observers who addressed the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers today.

Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., went out in 31, a new competitive record for the Kenwood course, and shot eighteen holes in 66, five under par, to lead fourteen other ranking pros with a plus seven rating in the round robin scoring as the $5,000 Goodall invitation golf tournament opened today.

Parliament today ratified the protocol extending for ten years the Turco-Afghan treaty of friendship and non-aggression made in 1928. Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras reviewed the relations between Turkey and her Eastern neighbors, the basis of which, he said, was the mutual desire to promote goodwill and cooperation in the cause of peace between the countries of Western Asia.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered fire large distillers to cease and desist from maintaining resale price agreements in the District of Columbia, but closed a similar case without prejudice against six retail liquor trade associations, including three operating in New York.
For the first time the committee of political Ministers today received five leaders of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten Germart party, headed by Deputy Ernst Kundt, and commenced negotiations with them.
Butter remains at 31 cents a pound this week despite increasingly liberal supplies. Behind this fact lies a new development in government financed purchasing that is vital to the consumer.

Nikolai Ognyeff, former school teacher and author, whose real name was Mikhail Rosanoff, died yesterday at the age of 50. He was best known for his "Diary of a Communist Schoolboy," written in 1927, which described life in Soviet Russia's schools.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, vicar general of the Archdiocese of New York, said last night that he was "worried by the constant hammering at communism," and went on to cite the low registration and ballot with figures of the Communist party in State and nation.

The five Firestone brothers, all executives of the international rubber concern founded by their father, visited the World's Fair yesterday to see the site of the Firestone exhibition building, to show a model. of the structure, and to predict an increasingly important place for rubber in the "world of tomorrow."

Officials of Akron, Ohio, will offer for sale on July 14 $268,000 of city school district bonds to bear interest at the rate of 6 per cent. The bonds are to be dated May 1, 1938, and will mature serially from Nov. 1, 1939 to 1951.

Story Ave (14-3692). s s 191 ft w of Havemeyer Ave, 28x103; Albert H. Joost to Home Owner's Loan Corp. Patterson Ave (14-3474), s s, 75 ft w of White Plains Road, 50x100; Thomas A. Carberry to Sophie Goldberg, 741 Noble Ave.

The general contract for a twostory addition and alterations to the building of the Ridgewood Savings Bank, at George and Forest Streets, Ridgewood, Queens, has been awarded to Roberts Nash Construction Corporation, according to Brown's Letters, Inc.

Movements of vessels folloW, all dates are June 23, unless specified. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Kewaydin, Acushnet. Barry, Sitkoh Bay to Prince Rupert. Cuyama, at Navy Yard, Pearl Harbor. Hopkins, Sitkon Bay to Clarence Straits. Isabel, Shanghai to Nanking.

The Lavelle School for the Blind, formerly known as the Catholic Institute for the Blind, held its twenty-second annual commencement exercises yesterday afternoon on the lawn of the school, at 221st Street and Paulding Avenue, the Bronx.

There are few stranger boat rides to be taken in the world than that between Barcelona and Valencia. When it is made on a little tugboat, one of whose -two motors functions spasmodically or not at all, there is additional spice if less pleasure.
There was intense activity today in Swatow, where additional Chinese troops were reported to be massing as Chinese military leaders feared that a major landing attempt by the Japanese was imminent.

Maintaining the form he showed as a member of the British Walker team at St. Andrews, James Bruen, wonder boy golfer from Cork, retained his Irish closed amateur championship today when he defeated another Corkonian, Redmond Simcox, in the thirtysix-hole final, 3 and 2.

The Duke of Windsor passed his fortyfourth birthday quietly here today. He received a phone call from London in the morning, presumably from his mother, Queen Mary. The Duke wired a message of sympathy to Queen Elizabeth on the death of her mother, the Countess of Strath more.

Mr. and Mrs. Archibald E. Stevenson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Winifred Ewing Stevenson, to Anice Mogabgab, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. A. H. Mogabgab of Farmagusta, Cyprus.
The semi-annual awards of scholarships and medals by the School Art League will take place at exercises to be held at 3 P. M. today in the auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Hogs sold actively higher today with receipts smaller than trade requirements. Cattle were firm and supplies small. Lambs showed further weakness although there were hardly

The stock markets, although quiet, were generally firm today. Sentiment was assisted by further improvement in Wall Street. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, while among the foreign loans Brazilian bonds advanced on a hope of early resumption of debt service.

Struggling all last night and today in alternating breaths of air and calms, with the changing tides and through dense fog, the racing fleet of the American Yacht Club completed its run of eighty miles from Rye, N. Y.,with George Lauder's Class M sloop Windward,
Babies born to mothers hospitalized in their home communities are most likely to survive, according to a survey in St. Lawrence County.

Prodigious storm belts sweeping across Mars and Jutpiter, ranging in extent from 75,000 to 300,000 square miles of their strange surfaces, were revealed in photographs taken at Lowell Observatory, Flagstaff, Ariz., and shown today at a meeting of celestial and laboratory physicists at Yerkes Observatory of the University of Chicago.

A contraseasonal advance in lumber production last week raised the adjusted index to 65.4, its high for the year. This compares with 62.1 for the preceding week and 96.6 for the week ended June 19, 1937.

Considerable interest was aroused in diplomatic circles here today by President Mikhail Kalinin's speech at a preelection mass meeting in Leningrad, reviving the old Bolshevist cry against capitalism and restating the role in which Russian Communists conceive themselves as the vanguard of the world preletariat on the road to universal communism.
The Romeike press clipping bureau, which moved to West New York, N. J., last week in the midst of a dispute over wages, agreed yesterday to return to its former offices at 220 West Nineteenth Street.
Dr. Thomas Hanna McMichael, president of Monmouth College for thirty-three years, who retired July 1, 1936, and was named president emeritus by the Senate, died tonight. He was 75 years old.

For the second and final game of the series with the Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday Burleigh Grimes benched Buddy Hassett, replacing the Bronx Thrush with Goody Rosen as lead-off man, and the results were more than gratifying.

Using two kinds of automobile horns alternately below the walls of Sante prison, a young man accompanied by his mother was arrested today for communicating with his father, who is a prisoner behind those walls.

Allotments under the provisions of the War Department civil Appropriations Act for the fiscal year 1939 totaling about $20,000,000 were announced today by Secretary Woodring. All allocations are for new work on rivers and harbors.

Wheat prices fluctuated in an erratic manner within a range of nearly 2 cents a bushel today. Traders were impressed at times by the strength in securities and other commodities, but the buying was not aggressive and sufficient selling developed from houses with Eastern connections to prevent the rallies from being sustained.
A world's record for holding onto a pair of license plates has been awarded by the Bureau of Fisheries. to a couple of Peconic Bay weakfish.

Miss Kate Cary, founder of Meadow Place, Lenox unit of the Berkshire County Home for Aged Women at Pittsfield, had charge of a garden party and tea at the home this afternoon. She was assisted in receiving by Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs and Mrs. Robert H. Davenport.
Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Smith Whelan of 1,220 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Georgette Whelan, to Guy Gerard Rutherfurd of Allamuchy, N. J.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We now have five separate criminal courts of superior jurisdiction in New York City, with five separate clerical establishments, each operating within a county. They are among the last remaining evidences of the legal fiction of county government still .maintained in this city.

In a telegram expressing serious concern over the losses to all sides involved in the strike of employes of the BigelowSanford Carpet Company, Governor Lehman today requested the employer and employes to submit their troubles to an arbitrator.
Further indications of a growing recession abroad were apparent from last month's reports, according to the monthly review of foreign economic conditions in the current issue of The Annalist.

The joint legislative committee to investigate the petroleum industry was defied yesterday by H. A. Inness-Brown, publisher of The Gasoline Retailer, who had been sought first by invitation and then by subpoena to appear at a hearing at 14 Vesey Street.
The Regent, Prince Paul, received Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch at Bled today. The Premier reported on his interview with Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister.

The combination of Clarence and Merritt Buxton, both former riders of note and now the proprietors of an extensive training ground at Columbia, S. C., was successful in yesterday's feature at Aqueduct, won by Knight's Haven.

Bright business prospects for the South in the near future, together with large sc crop movements, were reported today by the Southern Railway Systern in a letter to the Interstate Commerce Commission in support , of its application for an equipment loan of $14,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Mel Mazzera scored the Browns' only run with a ninth-inning homer and spoiled Lynn Nelson's chance for a shutout today. The Athletics, however, easily won the rubber game of a series of three, 7 to 1.

Mias Jean Boulware, University of California junior who won first prize in the nation-wide essay contest conducted by the Students International Travel Association, is having New York City for Europe after a hurried two-day visit without the least bit of regret.

Representatives of more than 300 private welfare and health agencies met in the hall of the State Chamber of Commerce at 65 Liberty Street yesterday to hear reports on the progress of the $10,000,000 campaign of the Greater New York Fund and to pledge their continued allegiance to the fund idea.

Formation of a committee to represent the New York Stock Exchange at round-table discussions of the bond market was announced yesterday. The committee, suggested on June 9 by William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is headed by Joseph Klingenstein of Wertheim Co. Howard B. Dean of Struthers Dean has been elected vice chairman.
Cambreleng Ave, 2,411, 2-story dwelling, 16.8x100; Title Guarantee Trust Co, trustee, against Frank Rizzo; due, $3,179; taxes, etc, $275; to plaintiff for $2,800.

Four persons were killed and at least a dozen seriously wounded in a series of shootings in Jaffa today. With heavy police reinforcements, scores were beaten by police clubs. Many bystanders were roughly handled by crowds.

Ten years after its Broadway presentation, eight years since Ann Harding was- doing it for the screen, Philip Barry's "Holiday" came to life again yesterday at the Music Hall in a smooth, workmanlike and thoroughly entertaining film.

A new junior high school science programs extending the teaching of general science to 300,000 pupils in the seventh, eighth and ninth grades of the New York City school system, has been adopted by the Board of Superintendents to go into effect with the opening of the Fall term, it was announced yesterday.

The annual awards of the American Institute of Steel Construction for the most beautiful steel bridge built in the United States last year were announced last night at a dinner to the jury of award, engineers and architects in the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street.
With the tenth annual Great Eastern Skeet championships opening this morning at Lordship, we could not help thinking of the manner in which this sport has grown during the past few years.

The Senators, soundly beaten by the White Sox yesterday, turned the tables on the Chicagoans today and, with Emil Leonard scattering eight hits for a shutout, banged out sixteen blows for a 12-to-0 runaway. The triumph gave the Senators the series, two games to one.
Medill McCormick, 21, scion of the harvester family, was the object of an intensive search tonight in the rugged. Sandia Mountains, ten miles east of Albuquerque.

A bee buzzing. around the head of Martin Flattery. of 189-18 Thirtyfifth Avenue, Flushing, resulted in an automobile accident in which Irving: Levy, 32 years old, of Avenue S, Brooklyn, was taken to the Queens General Hospital yesterday.

After being three down at the end of the first six holes, Mrs. W. R. Kirkland Jr. of Women's National staged a superb uphill battle to eliminate the defending champion, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg Leichner of Fresh Meadow, in the semi-final round of the women's Long Island match play competition on the North Hempstead Country Club links today.

A new titleholder will be crowned tomorrow when Mrs. James Robbins of Lawrence Farms meets Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill-in the thirty-six-hole final of the sixteenth annual Westchester and Fairfield golf championship at the Woodway Country Club course..
Nine persons were drowned and a baby was missing tonight in cloudburst floodwaters that surged into NorthCentral Montana rivers out of normally dry coulees and gulches.

About 300,000 workers were laid off between April 1 and May 1 in private industry and regular government employment, according to Charles V. McLaughlin, Acting Secretary of Labor. He said today that the drop was largely due to further curtailment of factory, mine and railroad forces.

Some of the young people coming out of college today are apt to complain that they have no cause in which to enlist, no crusade on which to embark. That is not true. There are causes aplenty in which youth may enlist and crusades awaiting volunteers.

A drop of 10 per cent in income payments for May of this year under May, 1937, was revealed today in The Weekly Supplement to the Survey of Current Business published by the Department of Commerce. The total for the month was $4,891,000,000, as compared to $5,407,000,000 in May, 1937.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Capt. John K. Borneman, Chap.-Res., 202 58th St., Niagara Falls, N. Y. (D), 28th Infantry (lst Division) (RA), is ordered to active duty, June 18, at Fort Hancock, N. J., for training. Date of rank: June 18, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status July 1.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended June 23 were announced today: COLONELS Horton, J. R., Washington, D. C., to Fleet Marine Force, San Diego. Smith, J. C., Washington, D. C., to First Marine Brigade, Quantico, Va.

Andre Maurois, well-known French author and frequent contributor to special sections of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was elected to the French Academy today to fill the seat made vacant by the death of Rene Doumic.

Following an increase of 1/4 cent a pound on Wednesday, lead and zinc prices continued their advance yesterday. The heavy inquiry for zinc at 4.25 cents a pound, a price set on Wednesday, led sellers to raise their offering price to 4.40 cents for the prime Western grade at East St. Louis.

Roger D. Babson, vice president and general manager of the Baush Machine Tool Company, testifying yesterday as a government witness at the trial of a suit to enjoin the Aluminum Company of America and its affiliates from violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law, told Federal Judge Caffey of efforts he had made in the Fall of 1929 to buy aluminum abroad.

The Republic of Cuba, through its Ambassador, Dr. Pedro Martinez Fraga, will announce today the offering, by means of a prospectus, of $44,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent bonds of- the republic, together with coupons due on and after Dec. 31, 1937, in exchange for the outstanding $40,000,000 of Republic of Cuba public works 5 1/2 per cent bonds due on June 30, 1945, together with interest coupons due on and after Dec. 31, 1933.

Cardinal Hayes yesterday named one new pastor and one new dire tor, transferred thirty-six assistants a and appointed as assistants to a parish or camp forty young men who a fortnight ago, on completing their studies in St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N. Y., were ordained to the priesthood in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Reports that mail from this country bound for Germany and other parts in Europe had been tampered with on German ships were denied today by Harllee Branch, second assistant postmaster general.

Miss Cornelia Weston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Faraday Weston of Montclair, N. J., and Philip H. Cummings of Harwick, Vt., a member of the faculty of Northwood School, at Lake Placid Club, were married this afternoon in the club chapel by the Rev. Dr. Henry B. Master of Devon, Pa.

Miss Jane Agnes Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Kennedy of this place, was married to Louis A. Schmitt of St. Louis, son of Mrs. Louis A. Schmitt of Pelham and the late Mr. Schmitt, this morning in St. Catherine's Catholic Church here.
Members of the Nassau Country Club here will give two subscription dances this season. The first will take place Saturday and the second on Sept. 6.

A new candidate for American and international honors in the sixmeter class slid down the ways of the Henry B. Nevins shipyard in City Island yesterday when Goose, the yacht built for George Nichols from the designs of Sparkman Stephens, Inc., was launched.

The Marine Studios, Florida's $500,000 project eighteen miles south of this city, were formally opened to the public this afternoon. Late tonight more than 10,000 automobiles were jamming the highways on the trek homeward;

A sensational decree introducing universal conscription for short-term labor service for all German "State members," irrespective of race, creed, sex or present occupation, to provide workers for "nationally urgent tasks" was issued, today by Field Marshal Hermann Goering as commissioner for the Four-Year Plan.

The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company of St. Louis, a subsidiary of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $30,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, Series C, due on July 1, 1968.

Alfred Hurrell, vice president and general counsel of the Prudential Insurance Company and former Mayor of Glen Ridge, died today at his home, 170 Ridgewood Avenue, Glen Ridge, after a long illness. His age was 64.
Welfare Island, opposite East 61st St: 79x166 for 2-story bakery; Department of Hospitals, City of New York, owner; Leroy P. Ward, architect; cost $235,650.

Martin T. Manton, presiding judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, denied yesterday an application for a stay of the city's proposed sale of a $9,000,000 tax lien on the franchises and real estate of the Manhattan Railway Company, advertised for June 30.

Delegates to the seventh annual convention of the American Lutheran. Church in the eastern' district voted yesterday to put aside. "doctrinal differences" with other branches of this denomination and unite "in fellowship of pulpit and altar" with them.

Generalissmo Francisco Franco's export council recently invited American importers of Seville green olives to take up their outstanding contracts before June 30. The importers responded and accordingly by the end of the month five' vessels loaded with olives will have left Seville for New York.

Cecil Chapman, for many years famous as a London magistrate, died today on the eve of his eighty-sixth birthday. For twenty-five years he administered justice at the Clerkenwell, Tower Bridge, Lambeth and Westminster police courts,

Commencement exercises marking the fiftieth anniversary of the naming of the school will be held tonight for the graduating class of the Dwight School in the auditorium of the Chanin Building, Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Keep calm now. The patient is doing as well as could be expected. Roughly speaking, those celebrated "transverse processes" are nothing but short ribs. They break rather easily. It's a common injury in football, as Dr. Marvin A. Stevens of N. Y. U. will testify and prove by photographs.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., June 24: THIRD GRADE DETECTIVE Walter J. McBride, from 18th Division, 1st Detective District to 77th Precinct, designation as Third Grade Detective revoked.

Howell Merriman Haydn, Professor of Biblical Literature at the Flora Stone Mather College of Western Reserve University and for nearly forty years a member of its faculty, died on Tuesday in Cleveland after a short illness, according to word received here last night. He was 65 years old.

Close-of-play scores in English first-class cricket matches started yesterday: Kent, 404 (Todd 118, Spencer 68, Woolley 57); Gloucestershire 238 (Wilson 59, Crapp 54) and 54 for three wickets; at Gloucester.

Call loans in Canada made by chartered banks in May were $1,835,973 higher than in April, but were $51,244,142 lower than in May, 1937, according to the monthly statement to the Finance Department made public today.

Louis Weinstock, secretary-treasurer of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, an A. F. of L. affiliate, was expelled from membership in the brotherhood yesterday by the general executive board of the international nion.

With fifty yachts already anchored in the blue waters alongside the Thames River course, Yale and Harvard oarsmen tonight resumed the oldest rivalry in American intercollegiate sport. Over the upper two miles of the four-mile course, the combination crews began the seventy-sixth Yale-Harvard regatta, a rivalry that was started eightyfive years ago.

Miss Alice Marie O'Hare, daughter of Assistant District Attorney William H. O'Hare of Glendale, Queens, and the late Mrs. O'Hare, was married to Assistant District Attorney Edward H. Potter of Woodhaven, Queens, last evening at the home of her father by Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr.

The exclusion of Communists, Nazis and Fascists from membership in the New York County American Legion, the largest group within the national organization, was voted last night at the closing session of the twentieth annual convention of that body at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

On the Plains of Abraham, where some of the bravest blood of France and England was shed two centuries ago to decide the fate of Canada, 50,000 descendants of those nations gathered this morning to celebrate the peaceful sacrifice of the mass.

Pointing out that hundreds of changes have been made in the United States Tariff Law in the last eight years, importers here are preparing a request to the United States Treasury Department to have a new and up-to-date copy of the law printed immediately after the Anglo-American trade agreement is announced.

The Chandler act amending the Federal Bankruptcy Law, which was signed by President Roosevelt today, was viewed by the Securities and Exchange Commission as a victory of major importance in a long fight which the agency has been making to afford greater protection in reorganization proceedings under Section 77b of the act to the investors.

Luncheon, West. of Central Park Association, Hotel Empire, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Reuben A. Lazarus, Albian N. Van Vleck, Joseph E. Platzker, Edward B. Bell. School Art League award of scholarships and medals, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 3 P. M. Speakers: Lu Kimmel, Forest Grant,.Mrs.

More than 1,000 persons attended a solemn high mass yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, to commemorate the twentyfifth anniversary of the ordination to the priesthood of the Very Rev.
BREATHE FREELY! by James Kendall. (Appleton-Century, $1.50.) A chemist discusses poison gas and air bombing. BRIGHTON ROCK, by Graham Greene. (Viking, $2.50.) A novel about a young criminal.

The Holland-America liner statendam will sail today for Plymouth, Boulogne and Rotterdam. Passengers include Prince George of Russia, J. J. Vincent, the Princess de Braganca, John H. Bruins, David C. de Jong, Mr. and Mrs. Bancroft Gherardi, Dr. Herbert S. Gasser, Cornelia van Auken Chapin, Charles Belknap Henderson, T. J. Oakley Rhinelander, Mrs. Anne Rosenberg, Judge and Mrs. van Vechten Veeder, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Law and Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lyon.

Mrs. Susie Eckstein, former president of the Ladies Democratic Club of Edgemere, died yesterday at her home in Far Rockaway, after a brief illness. She was 50 years old. She was a member of the Senior Hebrew Guardian Infant Home, Hebrew Convalescent Home,
Mexican labor unions intensified their battle today to obtain control of Congress and through it the various government agencies.
The royal visit to Paris has been postponed from next week until July 19 to 22 because of the death of Countess of Strathmore, mother of Queen Elizabeth, it was announced at Buckingham Palace today.
A large Charles II silver punch bowl, the property of the College of Vicars Choral of Hereford since 1680, was sold privately- for pound980 at Sotheby's today.

Archie M. Palmer, executive secretary of Cornell University's Cornellian Council, fund-raising agency, announced-his resignation today to become president of the University of Chattanooga. He is 42 years old, a graduate from Cornell in 1918 and took an M. A. degree at Columbia in 1927.

Federal Judge Albert B. Maris issued today a permanent injunction against the Capital Savings Plan, Inc., and its subsidiary, the Independence Shares Corporation, both of this city, restraining them from practices contrary to the Securities Act of 1933.

MANHATTAN BEATTIE, ROBERT HOWARD (March 26). Estate, $500.' To Belle W. Beattie, widow, petitioner, Hotel Plaza. trust of stock of Bettie Manufacturing Co., and residue. BLACKMAN, ISIDORE (June 11). Estate, less than $5,000. To Rose Blackman, widow, executrix.

Miss Euphemia Brower, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wyckoff Brower of this city, was married this evening to Charles Todd Newberry Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Todd Newberry of Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y., in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Turpentine firm, 231/2c; sales 27 barrels; receipts 353 barrels; shipments 125 barrels; stock 38,453 barrels. Resin firm; sales 436; receipts 2,391; shipments 325: stock 153,076. Quote: B, $3.40; D, $3.65; E, $3.90; F, $4.30; G, H, $4.50: I. K, $4.521/2; M, $4.55; N, $5.10; WG, $5.60; WW, X, $6.25.

Plans for plant inventory and model changes involving shut-downs averaging three weeks longer than last year were announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation in a statement issued in Detroit by William S. Knudsen, president.

Poland will spend $1,000,000 for her exhibition at the New York World's Fair, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by Count George Potocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States.

A national railway equipment trade-in plan whereby the Federal Government might help the carriers "turn an annually recurring liability of $30,000,000 into a cash asset" was submitted today to Secretary Ickes by Senator Shipstead of Minnesota.

The theory that high hourly wage rates and short working weeks make for full employment and are advantageous to labor- was characterized as a dangerous fallacy by Professor Willford I. King of New York University at the opening session of the Tamiment Economy and Social Institute here tonight, devoted to discussion of problems of recovery.

Defending Champion Don Schumacher of Dallas, Texas; Rodney Bliss Jr. of Omaha, Verne Stewart of Oklahoma City and Bill Holt of Syracuse, N. Y., were among those eliminated from the trans-Mississippi golf tournament today.

A group of thirty manufacturers of men's and boys' clothing, meeting yesterday with government officials to discuss the proposed $10,000,000 purchases of clothing for the needy, was whittled down to a committee of three in order to expedite matters.

Harvard at the age of 302, the oldest institution of higher learning in the United States, heard a new call for academic freedom today from President Conant, who told the Harvard Alumni Association this afternoon that "to-yield on the question of independence before threats from any quarter is to- start down the road which ends in Tack of freedom as surely as If-the university were to be taken over by an arbitrary and corrupt government.
Arrests of Jews continued today, with large numbers being sent to the Dachau concentration camp. This new series of arrests has resuited in renewed appeals to consulates for visas.

The Electric Bond and Share Company was accused of using "spite line tactics" to defeat objectives of the government's rural power program in a telegram sent tonight by John M. Carmody, administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration, toC. E. Groesbeck, chairman of the company.
The Bermuda-bound racing yachts were sailing early this morning in a thirty-knot south-southwest wind in long seas, with the barometer rising.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs was good. Demand for steer cuts and other classes continued only fair to slow. The lamb market was weak to slightly lower and other classes showed little change from Wednesday. Early trading in kosher lamb was light at lower prices;...

Fritz Kuhn explained at a State legislative inquiry in the Supreme Court Building here yesterday the doctrine he is spreading as national leader of the German-American Bund, through ninety-four locals in the principal cities of the country, twenty-two Summer camps, four newspapers, a business men's league and other affiliated organizations.

P. M. Mohrman, former member of the New York Stock Exchange, declared today he was "genuinely concerned about the possibility that in the not-too-distant future installment credit may be the principal cause of an inflationary boom and collapse."

Miss Janet Sykes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emery Howe Sykes of St. George, S. I., was married last night to Dr. James Poulton of Grymes Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Poulton of Salt Lake City, in St. John's Church, Clifton.
Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau made clear at his press conference today that he did not intend to reply to recent criticism of the Treasury Department by the Committee of the Nation.
As a resident of Glen Ridge for nearly twenty-five years he was closely identified with civic affairs. He became a member of the borough council in 1920, and was Mayor for two terms-1928 to 1932.
MANHATTAN BOYD, SAMUEL F. (Aug. 4, 1937). Gross assets, $46,609; net, $43,505. To Jennie E. Boyd, window. Chief 'assets, jointly owned property, $43,826. Breed, Abbott Morgan, Attorneys, 15 Broad St.

Expansion plans based upon an anticipated. revival of active stock market trading were announced yesterday in connection with the leasing of quarters for a new branch office by Loeb, Alsberg Co., brokers, in the remodeled building at 144 East Eighty-sixth Street. Yorkville.
Farr Co. have withdrawn as clearing members of the New York Stock Exchange. Their open exchange contracts have been guar anteed by Hoppin Brothers Co.

Charles Richard Murray, twice Canadian open golf champion and dean of the Dominion's professionals, died tonight, two weeks after an operation for a stomach ailment. His age was 56. The veteran golfer, pro at the Royal Montreal Club for the last thirty-three years, won the open in 1906 and repeated five years later.

A client of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., has purchased from Rose S. Giffard of Guernsey, in the English Channel, the four-story apartment and store building at 77 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, for cash.
The piling up of member bank excess reserves continues apace. Like the postman, nothing in the seasons seems to stay this course--not even the season of taxes.

Frederick R. Crane, Marcel Levy and Clarence Horwitz, trustees liquidating Series Q-1 of the former New York Title and Mortgage Com pany, announced yesterday that on June 30 they will pay $140,479 to about 1,300 holders of certificates inthe issue.

The rift between Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow and her Danish husband is no more than a minor marital tiff and should be smoothed over just as easily, her father, Franklyn Hutton, told the writer, this afternoon.

After disposing of another large batch of bills, among them measures providing complete Federal regulation of civil aviation and for the first general revision of the National Bankruptcy Law since 1898, President Roosevelt was headed back to Washington tonight where, at the White House tomorrow evening, he will address the nation on the record of the recent Congress.

Official calls were paid yesterday on army, navy and civic officials by the commanding officer of the Royal Yugoslav naval training ship Jadran, the first Yugoslav man-of-war ever to visit American territorial waters.
For the second consecutive week business in the Pittsburgh district showed a moderate advance, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore has filed with the Public Service Commission of Maryland an application for approval of an issue of $10,440,000 of first refunding mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, Series O.
Beattie Feathers, former Tennessee star and holder of the professional ground-gaining record, yesterday became the property of the Brooklyn Dodgers of the National Football League.
Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. and John Kennedy, sons of the Ambassador to the Court of St. James, gave Harvard the lead in the intercollegiate sailing championship series for the McMillan Cup today.

Religious instruction in the public schools as a means of fighting communism and fascism, limited to pupils whose parents give consent, is advocated by the New York State Catholic Welfare Committee in a memorandum sent to delegates to the Constitutional Convention.
3d St, 302-4 E, 2 5-story tenements and stores; 45.2x106; United States Trust Co, trustee, against Leah Solomon Realty Co: due, $26,449: taxes, etc, $1,929; to plaintiff for $9,000.

A leading apartment rental on the East Side yesterday was reported by Douglas L. Elliman Co., who leased the nine-room suite of Mrs. Paul Hammond in 117 East Seventysecond Street to Philip L. Spalding of Boston.

William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks and president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, has assured the Treasury of the approval of State bank supervisors throughout the country of the plan for uniform bank examinations which the Federal bank examining agencies will submit to President Roosevelt tomorrow.

New orders for furniture increased 18 per cent last month compared with April, according to the monthly report on industry conditions issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants specializing in furniture accounts.

A memorandum suggesting that the government underwrite a 50 per cent increase in steel, automobile and building material production has been laid on the President's desk by Dr. Paul Gourrich, chief economist of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Japanese Government issued a statement today which amounts to implementing part of the national mobilization law, especially in relation to the necessity of lifting bans on imports essential to the war industries and export materials.

Miss Margaret Jane Lafean, daughter of Mrs. Wilbur L. Lafean of Wynnewood and the late Mr. Lafean of New York and Chicago, was married this afternoon to Denis Newton Parker Batty, son of Mrs. John Wilkinson of Worksopp, Notts, England, and of the late George Batty of this city.

The will of United States Senator Royal S. Copeland, who died in Washington, D. C., on June 17, was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. It named the widow, Frances Spalding Copeland, as sole legatee. The value of the estate was not disclosed.

Ave A, 71-73, 49x100; Leah Bell Lowenstein et al to -Berl Realty Corp, 522 5th Ave, care Edwin Kessler (two quitclaims); same property, exrs wills of Feist and Solomon Berliner to same; mtges, $32,250.

The Treasury Procurement Division has telegraphed invitations to bid by wire or letter on 238,900 yards of textiles, for shipment by Sept. 1 to WPA consignees listed below. The bids are to be opened at 10 A. M., June 25, and are subject to the specifications and conditions on Invitation 735-T. The invitations are:

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company, a subsidiary, are negotiating with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Prudential Insurance Company for private placement of $9,515,000 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures of the Yonkers company, F. N. Nickerson, vice president of Consolidated Edison, testified yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.
Mayor La Guardia headed a delegation of 125 New Yorkers who came here this afternoon to attend a baseball game between the Philadelphia police team and a team from the New

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Otis E. Gray of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Isabelle Gray, to Bethuel Phelps Thompson of Bay Shore, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Ludlow Thompson.
Pat Malone bested Tom Baker and Bob Carpenter in a mound duel tonight and enabled the Orioles to defeat Jersey City, 6 to 3. Malone allowed only six hits, while the victors secured eight.
The general level of wholesale prices rose again in the week ended on June 18, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

While circus people, the man on the flying trapeze and the iron-muscled roustabout, roamed the streets and rubbed shoulders with the town folk because of the strike which closed the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus here last night, circus and union officials, still deadlocked on the question of an emergency pay-cut, sat in a smoke-filled room late tonight and heatedly rejected a compromise plan proposed by the Mayor of Scranton.
A cheerful news item bearing on the future of American liberty is what Governor Murphy of Michigan said to Joe Louis in

Miss Helen Bernhard, 16-year-old New York girl, provided the first upset of the women's annual New Jersey State singles tennis championship today at the Oritani Field Club when she defeated Miss Millicent Hirsh, seeded second in the draw and a finalist last year, 6-2, 6--4. Miss Bernhard reached the semi-finals in 1937, but was eliminated by Miss Eunice Dean of Texas who went on to turn back Miss Hirsh.

Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today he would lay before the commission soon the question of promulgating rules for distributing time to political candidates by licensed stations, an action directed by law, but never taken by the FCC.

The American Express Company has been appointed official custom house broker for the Golden Gate International Exposition, which will open at San Francisco Feb. 18 and continue until Dec. 2. The company is acting in a similar capacity for the New York World's Fair.

In the heaviest trading so far this year domestic corporation bonds moved upward vigorously yesterday on the New York Stock Exhange. Railroad obligations continued to hold the market leadership, as pivotal issues in that group gained 1 to 7 points.

The Wagner Labor Relations Act is rapidly broadening out from precedent to precedent. The Labor Board has just handed down a decision certifying the I. L. W. U., the C. I. O. union headed by Harry Bridges, as the sole bargaining agency for all longshoremen in thirty-one Pacific Coast ports.

Dr. James A. Merrill, former president of Superior State Teachers College and until last year Geography and Geology Professor there, died today at his home. He was 77 years old. Dr. Merrill had taught for forty- of six years at the college and was president emeritus at the time of his death.

Both sales and sentiment in retail circles here improved this week, lending support to the view of some executives that the awaited turn in the business situation is developing. Sales are still under last year, because of the 6 per cent price difference under 1937, but the showing for the week is expected to rank as one of the best in several months.

Special Notice Forms 300a, 300b and 300c are forwarded to deputy chiefs for distribution to the commanding officers of the several units in their divisions. Form 300a is to be filled out by the company commander, who shall furnish the required information for each piece of apDaratus located in his company quarters,
The test of Governor Lehman's address at annual conference of the New York State Public Welfare Officials Association was as follows:

Forty-four graduates received the degree of Bachelor of Science in Engineering at the 191st commencement of Princeton University last Tuesday. The names of twelve of these men were inadvertently omitted in the list of candidates for degrees published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Tuesday.

A bill for the formation of a Council of National Economy will be sent to congress next week, it was announced today, in view of the pressure brought to bear on the government for the creation of a non-political organization to deal with technical, industrial and trade problems.

Solstices don't count. Summer begins this afternoon for the most important members of the community. The school- children start their vacation a week earlier than usual. This would once have been worth an extra whoop, but we forget that the old red schoolhouse was a stuffy and uncomfortable place, getting out of which into the air and sun was a release to be celebrated with rude verses:

Despondent over losses in betting on the Louis-Schmeling fight, Charles Wahlers, 28 years old, of 76 Hollywood Avenue, here, a porter in an apartment house at 67 South Munn Avenue, plunged to his death early today from the roof of the ten-story apartment building.

The marriage of Miss Janet B. Wolff, daughter of Mrs. Oscar Wolff of 270 West End Avenue, to Robert Jay Misch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Misch of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at the Plaza.

As Franklin Pierce McCall awaits the electric chair for the kidnapping and murder of 5-year-old Skeegy Cash in Princeton, Fla., American public opinion believes that this country should have a law such as Canada has, making it a crime for any one to pay ransom to a kidnapper.

The United Press Associations and the American Newspaper Guild, a C. I. O. affiliate, signed an openshop contract yesterday covering the wages and hours of 450 news department employes in continental United States.
Senate investigators were arranging today to send a questionnaire to all candidates for the Senate in an effort to detect any political use of public money.
An increase of $4,054,000 in Dominion Government deposits was shown today in the statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. Deposits of chartered banks increased $847,000.

Summer, just two days old, played high jinks yesterday on sea and land, bringing a thick fog that held up six incoming passenger liners, a tanker and a freighter at New York's doorstep and inflicting discomfort on the city's millions with hot. humid weather.

Joseph P. Ryah, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, charged yesterday that the decision of the National Labor Relations Board in designating a C. I. O. union as spokesman of Pacific Coast long-shoremen did not reflect the sentiments of the pier workers.

Theodore Edward Lyon or Montclair, N. J., died early today from injuries received yesterday when his automobile left the road and struck a tree as he reached to straighten out a parcel on the seat. Mr. Lyon was on his way to Camp Barnard for girls at Mallett Bay, of which he was part owner.

Wilfred Garretson, silver-haired golfer from Raritan Valley, who will celebrate his sixty-fifth birthday July 5, captured the' metropolitan senior championship over the course of the Siwanoy Country Club today.

The City Council's relief investigating committee was subjected to a triple attack yesterday as Abner C. Surpless its chairman, called the committee into executive session to consider the choice of a counsel and to fix dates for its hearings.

LAST night was the night for a midsummer nightmare. And Graham Greene's "Brighton Rock"*--an eerie, gory and baroque novel of murderous skulduggery at England's most famous and most stained resort--is as elegant a nightmare as you will find in a book this season. Just the thing for cold chills in a tropic time.
Thomas R. Putnam, for Clifford R. Morrow, in 25 Ridgecrest West, Scarsdale, Westchester; William K. Breeze, the residence of Bessie M. Crone of 263 Madison Rd, Scarsdale; Prince Ripley, Inc, brokers.

Edward F. Gray, an ordnance engineer who was associated with the Bethlehem Steel Company for. thirtynine years, died of a heart ailment in St. Luke's-Hospital, Bethlehem, Pa., on Tuesday, according to word received here last night. He was 72 years old.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

With Plymouth currently running one of the most extensive newspaper schedules in the automobile industry, the Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that, new car registrations show Plymouth moving up to first or second place in fifty important cities.
Opposition to six proposals which would change the constitutional provisions dealing with the State's forest preserve was expressed today by Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner.

Still pale and shaky after her collapse yesterday, Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Calif., called on all her court lore today to pull out her second round match with Miss Joan Ingram of England, 9-7, 6--3, in the all-England tennis championship.

Asserting that too few general hospitals in the country are equipped to handle tuberculosis patients, the NationalTuberculosis Association ended its annual session here today by starting a program designed to correct the condition.

Jockey. John (Red) Pollard, 29, of Butte, Mont., who was to ride C. S. Howard's Seabiscuit next Wednesday in the $50,000 Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs, suffered a fractured left leg today while exercising a 2-year-old for friend.

It was announced today by order of Heinrich Himmler, chief of all German police, that all Catholic student and alumni organizations had been prohibited and attempts at their reorganization had been made subject to punishment.
Westchester Ave, 2,112-22 (14-3814); 2,114 Westchester Ave., Inc., to Florence A. Carmichel, trustee, 390 West End Ave; installments at 3 to 4 per cent; $13,750.

A hearing has been called for July 13 on an application by the Utilities Elkhorn Coal Company, the Central Service Corporation and James G. Culbertson, with reference to fees in- connection with the reorganization of the Utilities Elkhorn Coal Company.

In a surprise move today John A. Matthews, trial counsel for Mayor Hague of Jersey City, rested his defense without calling any witnesses in the suit brought by the C. I. O. and the American Civil Liberties Union for an omnibus injunction against further denials of permits for street meetings,

In a final crowded session here this morning delegates to the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers elected Gerrid Vander Hooning, Grand Rapids, Mich., president of the organization, selected Kansas City for their 1939 convention, and talked of going to New York City in 1940.

George C. Hager of Chicago supported by an assertedly insurgent group which charged that a reactionary machine was being built up within the organization, was elected president of Rotary International today oyer Allen Street of Oklahoma City.

Lillian Elavati, 20 years old, who killed her father last Christmas Day and pleaded guilty to a charge of second degree manslaughter, was sentenced yesterday in Bronx County Court to serve five to ten years by Judge Lester W. Patterson, who then stayed execution of- the sentence pending the defendant's good behavior.

The sale of private brands in the drug and cosmetic fields has not gained as a result of the enactment of fair trade acts, nor has the volume of sales of nationally known goods been affected, except to an extent directly due to the general business decline, H. L. Brooks,

A committee of three was named tentatively last night by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo to arbitrate the strike of Local 1,224 of the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers Union, C. I. O., against the Eagle Pencil Company of 710 East Fourteenth Street and its subsidiary, the Niagara Paper Box Company.

Sales in the Bronx announced yesterday consisted mainly of multifamily residential properties. Louis Katz sold to the A. M. Management Corporation the sixstory apartment on the northeast corner of Unionport Road and Sagambre Street.
The two-story building at 1,023 Bergenline Avenue, North Bergen, N. J., has been purchased by Louis C. Harris from the Hudson Trust Company, through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. There are two four.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Johnny Vander Meer failed to bring his press clippings into the Polo Grounds yesterday and the Giants treated him just as though he were a very ordinary mortal. They hammered the sensation of the season off the mound in the eighth inning but that was the extent of their victorious gestures for the day.

Mr. Hurrell was born in Fort Erie, Ont., on Feb. 12, 1874. After attending the village school and a business college in Buffalo, he entered-the insurance business as a bookkeeper, and later worked for the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad. Desiring to become a lawyer, he gave up his railroad position and entered the Buffalo Central High School at the age of 22.

Chief Justice Brogan of the Supreme Court upheld today the action of Town Clerk Charles Swensen of West New York in rejecting petitions for a special election on recall of three Town Commissioners. The petitions required 3,963 valid signatures.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member I anks of the Federal Reserve in New York City fell $209,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $7,584,000,000, according to the condition statement of the banks published yesterday.

Various tax bills proposed by President Federico Laredo Bru to balance the new budget were passed by the House of Representatives at a session that ended at 4 o'clock this morning. These measures already have the Senate's approval and, despite reported protests by commerce and industry, will undoubtedly be signed by the President.

Modernization and extension of anti-aircraft coast defenses, with mobile guns capable of being transported rapidly from one point to another, is about to start with funds provided by the new War Department Supply Bill.

Seven men, including a banker, were killed and five seriously injured today in the premature explosion of a nitro-glycerin charge with which a drilling crew was preparing to "shoot" an oil well near here.
Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, today said that capital and labor had given "whole-hearted support" to War Department efforts to gear industry into national defense plans.

Fenimore C. Goode, an active broker in New York City real estate for twenty years and formerly head of the brokerage firm bearing his name, has been appointed vice president in charge of brokerage and renting activities of the Junior Leasing Corporation, a subsidiary of the Trinity Church Corporation.

The State Labor Relations Board certified yesterday the New York Hotel Trades Council, comprising six A. F. of L. unions, as collective bargaining representative for 2,774 employes of the Hotels Pennsylvania, McAlpin, Park Central, Park Crescent, Victoria, Brittany and Kimberly.

The marriage of Miss Helen Shields, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Shields of this city and Mobile, Ala., to John Perry Boruff Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Boruff of Ossining, N. Y. took place here yesterday noon in the chapel of the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

Disorderly conduct charges against Thomas Bradley, 16 years old, and Thomas Dunne, 17, both of 100 West Ninety-sixth Street, for allegedly participating in a disturbance on an I. R. T. train on May 23, were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Overton Harris in Jefferson Market Court.

Although only six of the thirty-one G. A. R. veterans of New Jersey were able to attend the seventyfirst State encampment, those six demonstrated at the business meeting this afternoon that they were not lacking in energy.

By and for the President it has several times been emphatically stated that, in asking a group of citizens to go to Britain and Sweden to study employer-employe relationships, Mr. Roosevelt has no thought in mind of a legislative redefinition of American labor's responsibility to management and the public, and management's responsibility to both.

Harold Lamb has completed arrangements with his publishers, Doubleday, Doran, for his new book to be called "The March of the Birbarians," which will be a companion volume to his "Genghis Khan" and "Tamerlane."

Mrs. Sadie Leslie Monssen, widow of a naval hero, in despair over the decision of the Home Owners Loan Corporation to carry through foreclosure proceedings against her home at 1,756 West Tenth Street, Brooklyn, said last night that she would get an American flag, take cover beneath its folds and "dare them to put me out."
