A crowd of 7,000, one of the largest in the history of professional boxing at the Fort Hamilton Arena in Brooklyn, last night saw Jerry Mazza, 127 1/2, Bensonhurst, outpoint Nicky Jerome, 126 1/2, Williamsburg, in the feature eight-round bout.

Headed by last year's finalists--Bobby Riggs of Chicago, the champion, and Joe Hunt of Los Angeles, the runner-up--seven seeded players swept into the singles quarter-finals of the national clay courts tennis tournament today.

There is no reason for undue optimism over reports of the possibility of a truce in the Spanish war. These reports recur as the struggle drags on, always nearing an end but never ending as each fresh drive of the Insurgents is slowed down at a crucial point by another "last stand" of the Loyalists.
The huge expansion in the world-wide armament race, which began in 1933, is illustrated forcibly in a survey by the Business Research Institute, which was issued today.

All seeded players won in straight sets to survive their opening round in the first singles session of the National Collegiate A. A. tennis District 2 playoffs on the Church courts today. Rain stopped the morning matches with one to go, and all afternoon contests were washed out.
Mrs. Charles E. Merrill has returned to the Carlyle from Southampton, where she had been visiting Mrs. Goodhue Livingston.

A pretty, dark-haired young woman of 28 died yesterday afternoon in a fall from an eleventh-floor window of the Time and Life Building in Rockefeller Center. By chance, the tragedy was witnessed and followed with a television camera by Ross Plaisted, who had been picturing ordinary scenes in Rockefeller Plaza.

Engineering construction lettings in the current week, with a total of $33,572,000, are 15 per cent above the figure for last week, but are 71 per cent less than the awards made in the corresponding week of 1937, according .to The EngineeringNews-Record.
Newark's Bears set an all-time club record by winning their fourteenth. straight game tonight, 11 to 9. The best previous Newark record was thirteen, made in 1926.

On Thursday of next week the Federal Government will close its books on another fiscal year, and it is now certain that the record will show the smallest deficit for any similar period since the current series of unbalanced budgets began in 1931.

Miss Marjorie A. Goldwasser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Edwin Goldwasser of 135 Central Park West, was married to Wilfred Wyler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Wyler, also of this city, last evening at the home of the Rev. Dr. Solomon Lowenstein, 55 East Seventy-second Street, who performed the ceremony.

Barent Ten Eyck, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the Frauds Bureau, recommended to the board of governors of the clothing and furnishings division of the Credit Clearing House last night that it go after "flagrant violators" in an attempt to cut down fraud losses.

The free-press principle that a newspaper may not be restrained in advance from publishing what it deems fit was argued yesterday before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert against the government's contention that The New York Post can be prevented from publishing the espionage revelations of Leon G. Turrou, resigned Federal agent, before the end of a grand jury inquiry.

The necessity for an organized defense against anti-Semitism was stressed at a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall last night, at which speakers urged a united defense of the rights of Jews in Germany and other sections of Europe where they are threatened.
Democratic and Republican leaders opened negotiations yesterday with the American Labor party with a view to arranging coalition tickets for the Fall campaign.

Members of the Council finance committee who have been hearing objections to Mayor La Guardia's relief tax program for weeks got an unexpected and pleasant surprise yesterday when spokesmen for the city's banks expressed their willingness to contribute about $2,000,000 a year to relief through an increased State income tax.

The long-delayed "Gone With the Wind" will go before the cameras at Selznick-International in December. with Clark Gable as Rhett Butler and Norma Shearer as Scarlett O'Hara, it was learned authoritatively today.

While reports of his death spread like wild-fire through the country and penetrated even to other continents, Max Schmeling, German heavyweight, whose bid to regain the world heavyweight title was crushed in one round last Wednesday night at the Yankee Stadium by Joe Louis, was confined to bed in Polyclinic Hospital, his back securely strapped.

A General Sessions jury, after deliberating half an hour, returned a verdict of guilty of grand larceny yesterday against Rabbi Zeide M. Schmellner, 59 years old, formerly of 150 Riverside Drive, and Miss Mary Berd, 38, his secretary, formerly of 80 Riverside Drive.

The Japanese military machine is sinking in the morass of China as that country's leaders refuse to admit defeat, and there is united opposition, by force or by noncooperation, to any submission in occupied or unoccupied areas.

An "enlightened accord between those interested" was held out by the American Bar Association's Committee on Cooperation Between Press, Radio and Bar today as the alternative to legislation to control the' press in connection with court trials.

Plans for spending $120,000 to modernize the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 140 West Seventy-ninth Street were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Harlem Savings Bank to the Abrok Realty Corporation.

Spanish Government dispatches tonight said the Insurgent offensive against Valencia had been broken. They reported that on both wings of the front in Eastern Spain, below Castellon de la Plana and Teruel, government defenses withstood Insurgent assaults.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler sent a message of sympathy today to Anny Ondra, blonde actress wife of max Schmeling, and Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels sent a bonquet of flowers.

Approximately 500 Boy Scouts, representing twenty-five troops of the Stuyvesant District of Manhattan Council, Boy Scouts of America, filled the auditorium of the Seward Park High School, Ludlow and Grand Streets, last night for the twenty-fifth annual District Court of Honor.
Donna Jane Bourbon del Monte, American-born Princess of San Faustino, who for forty years gave Roman society one surprise after another, died of pneumonia today at the age of 75.

Signs of slow or sudden upturn in general business and industrial production usually come when the business community had. nearly given up hope of industrial recovery. Probably that is why last week's signs of betterment in the industrial indices made the impression which they did.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I attended the championship fight and want- to register a protest. I insist that Louis should have been disqualified because, during the count after the third knockdown, his handlers and seconds climbed into the ring.
George James Short Broomhall, wheat expert and the man who helped make Liverpool wheat futures the world barometer of wheat values, died here late last night at the age of 82.

In a letter published on this page this week former Corporation Counsel Paul Windels summarized the arguments for amending the State Constitution to simplify the court system of Greater New York. This city has, as he said, "five separate criminal courts of superior jurisdiction"--General Sessions for New York County (Manhattan), a County Court apiece for Kings, Queens, the Bronx and Richmond.

Almost half the theological students at the Moslem School at Lucknow have gone on strike as a protest against an edict issued by the trustees banning football, hockey and other games. key and other games.

To prevent a complete collapse of the United Automobile Workers of America, C. I. 0. affiliate, because of factional warfare, four Detroit union presidents today issued a call for A conference, to be held in Detroit Saturday afternoon.

An old landmark in Queens Village, Queens, will give way to a group of modern homes as the result of a deal announced yesterday. Said to be one of the oldest buildings in the community, the twenty-room Parkill mansion, on the northeast corner of 212th Street and 102d Avenue, has been sold to Michael Skodnick by Harry Tankoos, broker.

Reports of an outbreak of typhoid fever and foot-and-mouth disease in Northern Catalonia, Spain, near Bourg Madame, caused French health authorities to clamp a strict control today on persons crossing the border.

George C. Foster, secretary of the Illinois Racing Commission, today called for "a few more jockeys at 112 pounds instead of infants who are half-starved to death trying to reduce, and powerless to hold their horses because of their weakened condition."
Arnold Constable of Plainfield, N. J., who joined the staff of Arnold Constable Co. in 1935, was advanced yesterday to the post of assistant to Meyer Liberman, vice president and treasurer.
The American public and the American newspapers are certainly creatures of habit. It is the warmest night I have ever seen in Washington. And yet this talk will be referred to as a "fireside talk."

Thirty issues of New York City 4 per cent bonds aggregating $5,079,000 were included by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today in a list of 139 issues of municipalities, counties and school districts of thirty-seven States, amounting to $14,705,800, for which it invited bids up to noon on July 12.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Lichtenstein of 770 Park Avenue and Red Bank, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Boyd Lichtenstein, to John Denny Dale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Colgate Dale of Cold Spring-on-Hudson, N. Y.

School truants who because of adverse home conditions had developed serious anti-social tendencies were changed from "problem cases" into normal, wholesome boys and girls through special treatment, according to the annual report of the New York. City Association of Visiting Teachers, made public yesterday.
Magistrate Overton Harris was relieved of all future connection with the case of the boy sentenced to be spanked, Thomas Bradley, 16 years old, yesterday.
An unsuccessful attempt to argue the German American Bund out of anti-Semitism was made here yesterday by Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, speaking as a Jew whose parents were born in Germany.

New bond financing this week again was restricted to tax-exempt issues, although the appearance of two major loans lifted the total of new offerings to $105,548,000. This compares with only $8,790,000 last week.

A clause proposed for the new State Constitution designed to remove-the 50 per cent cost of grade crossing elimination from the railroads and place it on the State was attacked today as a direct financial award to the roads.
Metro will star Robert Young in "It's Now or Never," a remake of "White Collars." replacing Franchot Tone, who was scheduled for the part. Ruth Hussey will be seen in the feminine lead.

Burwell M. Crosthwaite, New York insurance broker with offices at 80 William Street, died here today at his home at the age of 57. He was born in Buffalo, a son of John L. and Elizabeth Morgan Crosthwaite, and was a graduate of Yale in 1902.

Holders of the $1,706,500 of ten-year collateral trust 6 per cent bonds of Woods Brothers Corporation are being asked to assent to the reorganization plan for the company proposed by the bondholders' reorganization committee, headed by Edwin M. Stark.
The City Council adopted a bill yesterday already approved by the Board of Estimate exempting registered nurses from the provisions of the Lyons Compulsory Residence Bill for a two-year period.

Three Argentine military planes joined the search today for a Pan American-Grace Airways plane missing since early last Sunday morning, when it left in a thick fog bound north with mail for the United States.

Registering what is regarded here as a new victory for its policy of breaking up collective security by neutralizing the little States, the German Government publishes today an exchange of notes with Switzerland in which the latter notifies Germany of her decision to resume unconditional neutrality and Germany in return pledges herself to "acknowledge and respect" that neutrality at all times.

Virtually conceding, that the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, halted in midtour here Wednesday by a union strike, was headed back to Winter quarters in Sarasota, Fla., circus officials were ready early this morning to complete an agreement with union officials covering terms of the disbanding.

Henry Sears's new sloop Actaea was believed to be leading the fleet beating to Bermuda in the biennial ocean race from Newport today. Her noon position was estimated to be 150 miles from the finish off St. David's Head and she was thought to be to windward of the rest.

The body of Richard Whitmer, 20, was found tonight in the Sandia Mountains, but mystery still shrouded the fate of his mountain-climbing companion, Medill McCormick, 21, heir to a Chicago publishing fortune.

A buffet luncheon was given by Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Ream and their daughter, Miss Carolyn Ream, of Greenwich, at their home today in honor of Miss Phoebe Whittemore Knapp and James Burbank Knowles, whose marriage will take place tomorrow in St. Bede's Chapel, Rosemary Hall, here. Mr. and Mrs.
The populace of this city gave a great reception today to the first 1,000 members of Yugoslav Sokols arriving to take part in Sunday's celebrations by the Slavic gymnastic societies.
Five acres on Nannyhagen Road, near Thornwood, in the town of Mount Pleasant, N. Y., have been sold by the Midfield Realty Corporation to a client of L. J. Phillips Co., brokers.
Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff and the latter's daughter and son, Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems and Chester P. Siems, are at The Corners, Southampton, for the Summer.

Stocks closed higher for fifth consecutive day; gains ranged from fractions to 2 points; turnover, 2,290,540 shares. Bonds mostly higher in quieter trading, rails in demand, United States Government issues lower; transactions, $8,083,600.

At a hearing yesterday before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal Court, Brooklyn. on a plan submitted by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for reorganization of the Prudence Company, Inc., William P. Palmer, representing the RFC, told the court that creditors holding approximately $60,000,000 of the $120,000,000 of claims against the Prudence Company had signified their intention to approve the plan.
A Commerce Department release today announced that more chewing gum, by value, was sold in the United States last year than in any year since 1927.
Miss Elisabeth Adams Manchee, daughter of Mrs. Wilfrid Arthur Manchee of this city, was married tonight to Ralph Waldo Dawson, son of Mrs. Thomas W. Dawson, also of Newark.
J. Howard Denny of St. Louis was elected president and director of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., at a meeting of the board of directors of the Fifth Avenue specialty shop, held here yesterday.

Subscriptions to the Commonwealth Edison Company's offer of $39,113,600 of convertible 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1958 amounted yesterday to $37,500,000, or approximately 96 per cent, it was announced. Subscriptions received yesterday totaled about $8,400,000.

A new pension program for employes of the B. M. T. system under which they will receive 1 per cent of their wages for each year up to Jan. 1, 1937, after twenty-five years of service and reaching the age of 65 years, was agreed upon yesterday by the B. M. T. and the Transport Workers Union and other unions.

Changes in the methods of property taxation in this country and a more active participation of realty owners in governmental affairs will be among the major objectives of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers during the next twelve months.

The crimson banner of Harvard, run to the masthead in victory last night in the combination crew race, stayed there all today and was still aloft in the dying sunlight of a Summer day as Spike Chace's Harvard varsity completed a clean sweep of the river.

Tightening its rules for control of specialists, the New York Stock Exchange committee on floor procedure ruled yesterday that, beginning on July 15, members would not be permitted to act as specialists unless registered as regular or relief specialists or unless they have authorization for that day only.

Yale emerged the winner in its annual baseball series with Harvard today mainly through the relief pitching of Dudley Humphrey, who replaced Monroe Jubitz in the fourth inning. He checked a Harvard rally in which the Crimson had snapped a Yale lead of 5-2 and tied the score. Yale finally triumphed, however, 7--6.

Superior Court Judge D. J. Quinlan absolved John B. Wright, 40 years old, North Madison sportsman, today charged with attempting to kill his wife, but sentenced him to serve three months in jail and to pay a $150 fine on lesser charges arising- from a stormy domestic quarrel.

James R. Anderson of the Northwest Gun Club, Chicago, took top honors today in the "tenth anniversary special" all-bore handicap event that opened the tenth annual Great Eastern skeet shoot championships.

President Roosevelt has approved plans of the navy to speed up construction of the 4 battleships, 4 light cruisers, 1 aircraft carrier, 8 destroyers and 6 submarines for which Congress provided funds in the last session.
Mrs. Anna Herrick, mother of C. Judson Herrick, Professor Emeritus of Neurology at the University of Chicago, died yesterday at her home here. On Jan. 16 she celebrated her 104th birthday.

An early beginning of the investigation of monopolies authorized by Congress at its last session was forecast today when the departmental members of the Joint House-Senate-Administration Committee were selected in a conference of Cabinet officials with President Roosevelt.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 18 amounted to 555,569 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,715 cars, or 0.3 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 197,218 cars, or 26.2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 135,147 cars, or 19.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on June 11 totaled 297,197,000 barrels, according to figures compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 22: CAPTAIN Fyffe, J., San Diego, Calif.; about Aug. 31 ordered home, relieved all active duty.

The marriage of Miss Alma James, daughter. of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Larson James of East Orange, to George Henry. Kolb of South Orange, took place this evening in Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church here. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. Robert Brewster Beattie, officiated.

Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow, husband of the former Barbara Hutton, has decided to remain in Paris while what his father-in-law, Franklyn L. Hutton, terms "just a marital tiff" is being ironed out, it was indicated today.
Japan's export trade for May this year was 18 per cent under May of last year, while her import trade decreased 36 per cent, the Commerce Department announced today.
The problem created by the expropriation of the properties of American and British oil companies in Mexico is by no means simple, either for the Mexican Government or for the United States.
Led by Freddy Fitzsimmons, who pitched and batted with commendable skill, the Dodgers took the first session of the four-round battle for sixth place that opened at Ebbets Field yesterday.

One Chinese was killed and five were wounded last night in two further attacks reflecting hostility to the Japanese. Two gunmen entered a downtown law office and shot and fatally wounded a young Chinese lawyer who was said to have been associated with the Japanese-dominated provisional government of the Shanghai district.

Favored by weather conditions and the increasing business optimism, retail sales here scored further improvement this week. Department store volume was estimated as running only 7 per cent under the same period last year, against 8.3 and 11.5 per cent, respectively, for the two preceding weeks.

Fred M. Patchen, who was taken on by A. M. Kidder Co. for a three-week trial as a stenographer in 1888, the year of the blizzard, today is celebrating the completion of fifty years of continuous service with the firm. He is in his seventy-second year.

The Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday a Summer List of One Hundred Approved Books. The survey of literature in all fields is issued quarterly by the committee at its headquarters in the Cathedral College Building, Madison Avenue and Fifty-first Street. The approved books follow: :

Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg pleaded tonight for a new "breathing spell" for business, free from arbitrary regulation, unbalanced budgets and labor-capital warfare to achieve "the swiftest recovery pace this chastened land has ever seen."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order consenting to withdrawal of applications for exemption from the Public Utility Holding Company Act by the Philadelphia Company and the Pittsburgh and West Virginia Company, subsidiaries of the Standard Gas and Electric Company.
British Army officers have discovered a plot among Waziristan warriors, led by a fanatical Mohammedan priest, to overthrow the reigning dynasty in Afghanistan. gning dynasty in Afghanistan.

Harvard's yachtsmen today won the eleventh annual McMillan Cup series of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association in impressive fashion. The Crimson skippers out-sailed the Williams stars, their most dangerous rivals, in two contests which practically amounted to match races.

An immediate start toward construction-in this city of twenty-eight schools, hospitals, health centers, bridges and other projects, involving a total cost of $31,328,500, was authorized yesterday by the Public Works Administration.

With the injunction suit of United States Attorney Lamar Hardy against The New York Post still undecided, that newspaper announced yesterday it would not publish the espionage expose of Leon G. Turrou, resigned Federal agent, until the current investigation of a German spy system is completed.

An industrial medical board that would serve as a court to which job-rejected persons more than 40 years old might appeal was suggested as a possibility yesterday by Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth, chairman of the joint legislative committee investigating discrimination in the employment of the middle-aged.

President Roosevelt was represented today by close political advisers as ready to endorse the candidacy of Governor Herbert H. Lehman to succeed the late Senator Royal S. Copeland when the situation in New York crystallizes and the party leaders are in agreement as to the entire ticket, including the candidate for Governor.

Senator E. W. Tobin, newsprint and pulp manufacturer, died today after a heart attack at the age of 72. He had been a member of the Canadian Senate since 1930 and for thirty years before that sat in the House of Commons as Liberal member for Richmond and Wolfe.

The American Crayon Company will move to 9 Rockefeller Plaza on Tuesday. Sales of air travel by the American Express Company in May exceeded the figure for a year ago by 169 per cent. In bookings to Bermuda, South America, Honolulu and the Orient the increase was considerably higher.

Liquor advertisers and agency executives will be invited to a meeting here next week to consider the problem of advertising regulation simplification and to submit a program to State liquor administrators, according to William Margolies, publisher of the American Wine Liquor Journal.

Reuben Fink, author and editor, resigned yesterday as a member of the administrative committee of the American Jewish Congress in protest against the conduct of its campaign in preparing for elections to be held tonight, tomorrow and Monday of delegates to a special session this Fall "to formulate a program to protect the rights of oppressed Jews."

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, back from a trip to the Pacific Coast, indicated today that he had found investment bankers in the West eager to cooperate and organize under the provisions of the Maloney Act, which provides for the registration with the SEC of a national association and affiliates of over-the-counter brokers and dealers for self-regulation under supervision of the commission.

Louis Stellman, civilian engineer of aeronautics for the Navy Department and former chief engineer of the Frankin Motor Car Company, testified at the trial of the government's suit to enjoin the Aluminum Company of America and its affiliates from alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.
Miss Mary Colgate, Yonkers philanthropist and church worker, who died Oct. 24, 1936, left a net estate of $9,050,695, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24.-Department store sales in the week ended June 18 were 10 per cent lower than for the same week in the previous year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. For the previous week and also for the four weeks ended June 18 the sales were 15 per cent below those of the comparable weeks in 1937. 37.

In an address critical of "the new system of politically primed prosperity," Colonel Leonard P. Ayres said tonight that "we are now probably at or near the bottom of the present depression" and that moderate business improvement is likely in the last quarter of this year and in 1939.

Miss Esther. Stuart Morton, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dudley Joy Morton of 21 Claremont Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon to Dan Curtiss Anderson in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Miss Francesca Anne Ramus, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Ramus of 42 East Seventy-eighth Street, was married to George Sears Greene yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James Church.

President Roosevelt tonight brushed aside all doubt that he would take an active part in the coming Democratic primary campaigns, saying in the course of a nationally broadcast "fireside chat" that "as head of the Democratic party"--not as President-he had "every right" to speak out where New Deal principles were involved.

Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: 1st Lt. Richard A. Fitzgerald, Inf.-Res., (1st M. A.), Jan. 6, 1939. Ensign Kenyon Spalding, E-V (g) USNR, Jan. 9, 1939. Captain Frank J. Turck, QM.-Res., (1st M. A ), Jan. 18, 1939.

Little improvement was recorded by the principal wholesale markets this week as large buyers continued to defer Fall commitments, causing fear of delivery congestion in some branches, according to the weekly survey by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Charging failure to file returns on intangible personal property for 1937 and 1938, this city has filed a complaint with the Union County Board of Taxation and Petition against the Great Western Sugar Company of Denver, Col.

More than ?50,000 was realized today at the final session of the sales of the Mortimer L. Schiff art collection at Christie's auction rooms, bringing the total for the three-day auction to the handsome figure of [pound]100.000.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson approved yesterday a general program under which the city may acquire the Sixth Avenue elevated line by paying $3,874,475 in cash and cancelling a tax lien for $8,625,524 which it holds against the entire Manhattan Railway system.

Dr. Archelaus Ewing Turner, former president of Lincoln College at Lincoln for more than twenty-five years, died yesterday in Vandalia at the age of 77 years. He left Lincoln College in 1931, was ordained a minister in the Presbyterian Church and had served pastorates at Sullivan and Vandalia.

Harvard and Yale players gained the finals in both singles and doubles In the New England district Intercollegiate tennis championships today on the Yale courts. Howard Stephans of Yale and D. Burt of Harvard gained the singles final, each by defeating a player from the rival school in semi-final matches.

Hardly had the Home Insurance Building of Chicago been reared to what seemed in 1884 the dizzy height of ten stories, when architects, business men, regional planners and municipal officials began to debate the economic and social merits and defects of skyscrapers.

In army and navy circles here it was said yesterday that President Roosevelt's statement advocating higher appropriations for counterespionage touched on a long-felt need for enlarging the facilities of the intelligence sections.

George McClellan Powers, Chief Justice of the Vermont Supreme Court, died tonight following an illness of several months. His age was 76. Justice Powers was born in Hyde Park, Vt., Dec. 19, 1861, a son of Judge Horace Henry Powers and Caroline Waterman Powers.

Members of the board of the Reo Motor elect Car Company opposing efforts of Rowland Campbell, their chairman, to call a special stockholders' meeting for July 12 for reorganization purposes, issued today an appeal to stockholders for proxies to nullify those obtained by Mr. Campbell.

Closing its five-day sessions, the second Seminar of Safety heard yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel reports on the practical effect of safety campaigns in cities of today and on new provisions, through engineering, for greatly increased safety in the cities of tomorrow.
Mrs. Mary F. Elwes, widow of Herbert C. Elwes, former vice president of the American Express Company, died yesterday in her home at 128 West Seventieth Street after an illness of two months.

After three consecutive seasons under the Guthrie McClintic banner, Burgess Meredith has agreed to appear next season in "Five Kings," the Shakespearean chronicle series which the Mercury Theatre and the theatre Guild will combine to present.

Mrs. Rachel Beck, the "grand old lady" of the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, where she was one of the first to register when the institution opened its doors in 1914, died early yesterday at the age of 95.
President Roosevelt will spend Sunday night at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont near Wilmington, Del. The Eugene du Ponts are the parents of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

Unless the establishment of unregulated rooming houses in the area west of Central Park is checked, that section soon will lose its character as a fine residential community, speakers at a luncheon of the West of Central Park Association in the Hotel Empire warned yesterday.

Publishers of Pittsburgh's two afternoon papers, The Press and Sun-Telegraph, announced tonight that an agreement had been reached with representatives of ten unions which would permit resumption of publication of next Sunday's editions.

The fourteen-story apartment house on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 130 West Fifty-seventh Street was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street Salesrooms for $300,000. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff, was the purchaser.

Under the auspices of the Metropolitan Federation of Daily Vacation Bible Schools, 272 schools will open on Monday in the New York area. Of these, seventy-seven will be in Manhattan. The others will be distributed as follows: Bronx, sixteen; Brooklyn, fifty - nine; Queens, thirty-six; Staten Island, twenty-five; Westchester, nineteen; Nassau, fourteen, and Suffolk, twenty-six.

Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., stretched his lead today as the fifteen pro golfers in the $5,000 Goodall invitation tourney steamed around to the fifty-fourth on the 126 holes they are to play at Kenwood.
Frederick W. Becker of 680 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, vice president of the Brooklyn Brass Works, died on Wednesday night of a heart attack at the age of 51.

On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight, June 30: PATROLMEN--Gerald G. Morrissey, 32d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 5, 1912. Patrick R. Tobin, 90th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 28, 1911.

The Minister for Overseas Affairs, Count Sonyu Otani, resigned today and his post was taken by General Kazushige Ugaki, the Foreign Minister. This shift is interpreted to mean that Central China will remain under the control of the Foreign Ministry, at least while General Ugaki is the dominant personality in the Japanese Government.

The New York Stock Exchange committee on admissions will consider on July 7 the application of John H. Brooks Jr. to be admitted to J. H. Brooks Co. on that date. Concurrently, James W. Brooks will retire from the firm.

With play moved up from September to June England will meet the United States for the historic International Challenge Cup next year, it was announced yesterday by he United States Polo Association. The competition will be held at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury. L. I.

Leaf tobacco exports from the United States totaled $46,267,395 for the first five months this year, the Commerce Department announced today, as against $31,443,797 for the corresponding period last year and $39,018,445 for the 1936 period.

Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, stood one point from defeat today in defense of her title in the women's New Jersey State tennis championships at the Oritani Field Club, but her opponent, Miss Edna Smith, 100-pound entrant from Cleveland, could not score the decisive marker and Miss Dean won, 6-3, 3-6, 8-6.
World production of tin in the first four months of this year was 57,800 tons, compared with 62,300 the 1937 period, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.

Still playing far below the form that she will have to regain if she is to win the Wimbledon tennis championship again, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, American star, today defeated Mrs. P. F. Glover of England, 6-4, 7-5, in the third round.

Angered by the "failure of Port Chester officials to raid and close several known gambling houses within their village," District Attorney Walter A. Ferris of Westchester County brought Mayor W. Burdell Banister, three trustees and Police Chief A. Leo Brogan to the grand jury room here today on subpoenas.

Yarnall Abbott, painter, writer and lecturer, president of the Philadelphia Art Alliance for the last two years, died at his home here today after an illness of more than a month. He was 67 years old.

Imports into Argentina in May yesterday to amounted to 110,831,148 pesos, compared with 116,733,359 in April and 144,403,619 in March, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. The adverse trade balance in May was 102,938 pesos, against 13,000,000 in April and 25,000,000 in March.
Adding to new industrial investments in Austria since the country's absorption by Germany, the Alpine Electric Works Company was organized today.

The upward surge In bond values which has featured trading this week lost yesterday most of its momentum and aggressiveness and the more speculative issues, particularly in the rail list, were forced to withstand considerable profit-taking.

The Brighton Town Council has just decided, by a vote of 30 to 25, to sell furniture at cost price, plus a charge for expenses, to tenants of municipal houses who have been transferred from property classed as unfit for habitation. Fifteen per cent will be added to the wholesale price of the furniture to meet the expenses of the, Council in rendering this service.

That this week's sudden and unexpected rise in the stock market should have become an outstanding topic of conversation, that it should largely have changed the atmosphere, in the business community particularly, merely repeated experience.

Mrs. Ethel Sohl and Miss Genevieve Owens, who already are serving life terms for murder, got additional prison sentences of ten to twelve years each in Bergen County Quarter Sessions Court here today on robbery charges. The young women are in Clinton Reformatory.

Neither rain nor the Cubs bothered the Giants yesterday. They outlasted both. Sprinting along strongly in possession of a 3-1 lead when a steady downpour of rain started at the Polo Grounds, Colonel Bill Terry's athletes were overtaken at 3--all in the eighth inning.
Turpentine firm, 23 1/2c; sales, 31 barrels: receipts, 563 barrels; no shipments; stock, 39,016 barrels. Rosin firm: sales. 139; receipts, 1,751; no shipments; stock 154,827.

Orders for 4,000 tons of tin-plate and 2,700 tons of miscellaneous steel products, involving expenditure of an estimated $500,000, were announced today by the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, while steel company officials predicted ingot production in the Birmingham district would hold at 42 per cent of capacity next week.
Vacationists could do much worse than pack a copy of Henry David Thoreau's "Walden" or "The Duty of Civil

In a surprise move, subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation cut prices yesterday on a wide range of products by $2.50 to $8.50 a ton--or from 6 to 17 per cent--hardly a month after the same companies had reaffirmed the prices on virtually all products to the end of September.

A TRAGIC yet enormously informing background to the news from Spain is provided in "Burgos Justice," * a remarkable personal narrative of life in Nationalist territory. This is a book so authoritatively and so moderately written that it should be read by every one who is truly interested in arriving at a clear understanding of the war.

The strike of 6,000 employes of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company Was settled last night, twenty-four hours after Governor Lehman asked the company and the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O. to submit their differences to arbitration.
August J.worowski, retired president of the Manayunk Bottling Works, died today of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 57. Born in Poland, he came to this country as a boy.
The Automobile Manufacturers Association announced yesterday that railroads in the United States moved 1,361,848 carloads of petroleum oils, refined and all other gasolines, in 1937.

Alexis Voroniesk, 23 years old, of 21 East Eighty-fourth Street, who says he is -a count and member of a family of the old Russian nobility, pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to an indictment accusing him of the theft of three watches. valued at $1.500.
Weakness in grains and petroleum carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices from 80.7 to 80.4 in the week ended on Wednesday.

Investors continue an active interest in Manhattan properties, deals reported yesterday indicated. The building at 340 East Fifth Street was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Louis Kandel, an investor, for altering into apartments and stores.

The New Jersey Power and Light Company challenged today the right of the Federal Power Commission to require it to show cause why its acquisition of 341,350 common shares of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company was not a violation of the Federal Power Act.

The engagement of Miss Constance Benedict Torney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Walter Torney of 134 East Seventieth Street Land Southampton, to William Sylvester McCornick of this city has been announced by her parents.

Wheat prices on the Board of Trade and in Kansas City showed little change at the close today, compared with yesterday, but highly beneficial rains in the American Northwest and parts of the southern sections of Alberta and Saskatchewan had a depressing effect on operators in Minneapolis and Winnipeg and brought in sufficient pressure to send prices off sharply.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of license for service as teacher of music in junior high schools, as of June 21, 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:
Having found nearly all other methods equally unsatisfactory, our harassed Yankees went back to their old system of trading blows directly with the enemy today.
The extent of foreign participation in a market which verges radically one way or another is always a matter of speculation in brokerage circles, and one seldom finds two observers who agree.
The Department of Commerce reported today that $6,057,601 of gold was sold to the United States in the week ended on June 17 in spite of a strong demand for the metal in London in the same period.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Huntington McKelvey of Road's End, Sagamore Estates. Cortez. Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Fairchild McKelvey of this city, to Walter Thurston Oakley, also of New York.
Joseph P. Kennedy, Ambassador to Great Britain, who returned to this country early this week on a brief leave of absence, arrived here today for conferences with officials.

The reply of the German Government to the American note of May 9 concerning the German decree ordering registration of Jewish property was received at the State Department tonight from Hugh R. Wilson, United States Ambassador to Berlin, and was taken under consideration.
With nearly 700 entries, the Ox Ridge Hunt Club today opened its twelfth annual horse show, which will be concluded tomorrow.

Miss Kathleen Denniston Crawford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Victor Crawford of this place, was married here this evening to George Edward Gillespie Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gillespie of Upper Montclair, in St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Luke White.

The Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren, associate pastor, with the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, will spend his Summer vacation in preaching in leading non-conformist churches in England.

Charles C. Van Deusen, president of the Adirondack Trust Company since 1924, died here today at the age of 71. He was the first to introduce fresh fruit here as a major branch of the grocery business a half century ago.

Lancashire dropped two notches to third position in the English County cricket championship today. The Lancastrians, who took first-innings' points from Worcestershire, were deadlocked with Middlesex for leadership as the three-day series of matches started Wednesday.

Charles Amandoles of Latourette, Staten Island, toured the Aviation Golf Club course today in 73 to win the qualifying medal of the Metropolitan Golf Association public links championship. Amandoles was two over par.

Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Miss Marion Turpie, gained her fourth women's Long Island match-play championship day when she overwhelmed Mrs. W. R. Kirkland Jr., 9 and 7, on the picturesque North Hempstead Country Club course in the final scheduled for thirty-six holes. holes.
The Erie County Board of Supervisors forwarded to Governor Lehman today a protest against the "unfair competition" of State-owned and State-operated grain elevators at Oswego, Albany and Brooklyn.

According to a report from a usually authentic source, but thus far not confirmed officially, the French Government today informed the British Government that it had been warned by its naval forces in the Far East to expect a landing by Japanese troops on the large island of Hainan, at the extreme southern end of China. uthern end of China.
The Rev. Charles C. J. Carpenter was consecrated Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Alabama today in ceremonies attended by eight other Bishops and more than fifty visiting clergymen.

Captain Harry Manning, hero of spectacular rescues at sea and the late Amelia Earhart's navigator Ion an unsuccessful attempt to fly around the world, was critically injured this afternoon when his private plane, which he was piloting. alone, went into a spin near Roosevelt Field and dived into the ground from an altitude of about.700 feet.

An offer from Benjamin E. Greenspan, former magistrate, to pay for a pair of glasses broken during a softball game brought freedom yesterday to his son, David Greenspan, 15 years old, of 720 Riverside Drive, in Washington Heights Magistrates Court.

The marriage of Miss Ena Hourwich, daughter of Mrs. Isaac A. Hourwich of 14 Washington Place East and the late Mr. Hourwich, economist, author and lecturer, to Edward Kunzer took place yesterday afternoon in the chambers of City Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky in the Magistrates' Court in the Bronx.

The twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Credit Retail Association ended today with the election of--officers and several informal addresses. Officers selected were Leo M.- Karpele, president, Birmingham; vice president, W. P. Ross, Dallas; second vice president, Erwin Kant, Milwaukee.

Activity in security markets held attendance yesterday to 200 at the fifth annual outing of the New York Security Dealers Association at the Westchester Biltmore Country Club, Rye, N. Y. Many of those in attendance, however, conducted business by telephone.
Philip Livingston, retired lawyer and member of one of the earliest American families in New York, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 47 East Eighty-eighth Street. He was 76 years old.

Mrs. Frances Rowles Conklin, daughter of Mrs. Walter D. Rowles of this place and the late Mr. Rowles, was married today to Peter Van Brunt, son of Mrs. John H. Van Brunt of New York and the late Mr. Van Brunt.

Mayor La Guardia's liking for cigars sold at the rate of two for 5 cents figured in the Board of Estimate's action yesterday in approving the cigarette tax, when Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx argued that the Mayor should not escape the levy.

BOWERS, MARTHA STEWART (June 16). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mary Bowers Coppel; niece, 112 E. 74th St., $1,400 and one-half residue; Martha Danridge, niece, 326 Plaza Junipero, Santa Barbara, Calif., $7,000; Henry Myer Bowers, nephew, "Ostego," Tonbridge Rd., Wareringbury, Kent, England., $1,400:

MEMBERS of the medical profession must be enjoying a large laugh at the excitement caused by the Schmeling case history. A split in the transverse process of one of the lumbar vertebrae of a huge and husky gent, a trained athlete, a professional pugilist. Shucks!

Captain Louis P. Reimuller of Engine 285 died June 24. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 101-20 123d St., Richmond Hill, Queens. at 10:30 A. M., Monday, June 27, Interment at Evergreen Cemetery.

The Summer season of Gallo-Shubert operettas begins tonight at the Jones Beach Stadium with' "Three Waltzes," featuring Everett Marshall and Lucy Monroe. Others in the cast are June Havoc, Dean Dickens, Ulita Torgerson, Fred Sherman, Len Mence, Louis Sorin, Henry Rabke and Ralph Bunker.
It is not as easy to find employment for the vocational school graduates this year as it was a year ago, Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools, reported yesterday.

In a statement issued here yesterday, National Distillers Products Corporation announced that the Federal Trade Commission order to terminate resale price maintenance agreements on their products in the District of Columbia was issued with the company's consent.
President Roosevelt disclosed today that he favors larger appropriations for the Army and Navy Intelligence Services for the expansion of counter-espionage activities within the United States.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Thresher, daughter of Mrs. Louis M. Ream of this city and of Dean. Thresher, also of Providence, to John Leavitt Ahbe of Wellesley Hills, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic R. Ahbe of Clover Croft, Athens, Pa., and Coral Gables, Fla., took place here this afternoon in the Central Congregational Church.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
A crowd of 31,000, including the King, watched England's cricketers again assert their superiority over Australia's attack as the second test match got under way at Lord's today. oday.

Tyndall Ave (13-3423S), w s, 586 ft n of 261st St. 119x94: Joseph . Berry, referee, to Nanking Realty Corp, 150 5th Ave. Quincy Ave, 245 (18-5592); Margaret M. Mangan, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

The Toledo Edison Company, a major utility unit in the Cities Service Company system, has completed plans for the issuance and sale of $30,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent bonds and $36,500,000 of 4 per cent debentures to refund indebtedness, it was disclosed yesterday.

Above the rumble of heavy trucks, the cries of street peddlers and the rest of the usual bedlam that plagues the lower East Side of a Summer day, two self-proclaimed "slum boys," 12 and 14 years old, raised their voices in protest yesterday against the adverse conditions in their neighborhood.

The Cuban Navy Band, conducted by Captain Armando Romeu Marrero, made its first local concert appearance last night at Town Hall before a large audience. The band is engaged in a good-will tour of this country.

Charles Scribner's Sons announce the publication of the three final volumes of the limited edition of the works of Ellen Glasgow-"The Voice of the People," "The Romance of a Plain Man" and "Life 'and Gabriella."
The Orioles pushed across a run off Relief Pitcher Tom Baker in the ninth inning tonight to defeat the Jersey City Giants, 7 to 6, for their second straight decision.
Michael Lerner, who has just returned from a big-game hunt in Indo-China and other points East, will hardly have time to relax before he leaves on another expedition.

ADAMS, MABEL E. (Feb. 28, 1938). Gross assets, $21,848; net, $6,573. To Dorothy Adams Dalley, niece. Chief assets, real estate, $18,000. Leslie, Holt, Halstead Frost, attorneys, 120 Wall St. ALTMAN, SAMUEL (May 12, 1936). Gross assets, $61,358; net. $55.458.
The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Jose Iturbi, was heard last night in the second program of the new season at Lewisohn Stadium.

Dispatches reaching here today said United States Consul Louis H. Gourley at Tsingtao had reported to the State Department that a Japanese sentry had slapped the wife of a United States naval officer.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation; after many months of negotiating with banking interests for financing, has completed arrangements for the private sale to life insurance company interests of a block of bonds which will net the company $25,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

The fifty-two-pound hippopotamus, the five-day old son of Rosie, the 15-year-old two-ton hippo, is dead. The news became known yesterday when a terse announcement from the Central Park Zoo disclosed that the carcass was turned over to the Museum of Natural History for scientific research and an autopsy.

It took eighteen innings of hard-fought play to end Newark's fourteen-game winning streak tonight as the Chiefs finally came through with two hits, a double by Glossop and a single by Richards, for a 3-to-2 victory in the season's longest International League game.

Newton B. Hobart, a member of the Taft School faculty for twenty years, died today at his home here at the age of 84. A graduate of Western Reserve College, Hudson, Ohio, he received an LL.D degree from the college in 1934.
The Indians' pennant fever spirit downed the Red Sox, 7 to 6, today and sent the Tribe four and a half games ahead of the Yankees, who lost at Detroit.

Charles E. Foote, retired district judge, was buried today in Mayaguez, where for many years he served on the bench. Judge Foote died in Baltimore on June 13 at the age of 65, his body reaching here today.

Declaring that there must be some limit to the right to picket, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins yesterday granted Weil Co., Inc., a furniture store at 2,252 Third Avenue, an injunction restraining members of three unions from picketing it for using a neon sign manufactured in a non-union shop.
The stock markets were generally cheerful today, although business was on a small scale. Gilt-edge issues eased slightly, while among the foreign loans Brazilian bonds were higher.

Modern civilization and the inability of city dwellers to imitate their forebears in obtaining emergency rations from woods and lakes are largely responsible for the steady increase in Westchester County welfare expenditures, which reached a new high of $4,264,521 last year, the County Department of Public Welfare said today in its annual report for 1937.
The setting for the Yale-Harvard regatta on the Thames today was a banking of four miles of the course with about everything that would float, and an overflow as well.

Reporting rumors that Archduke Otto of Habsburg intends to settle in South America, the newspaper Nemzeti Ujsag declares today that they originated with his desire to marry a student whom he met during his studies at the University of Louvain in Belgium.

With champions listed to defend their titles in nineteen of the twenty-one events, the annual track and field championships of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U. will be staged at Glen Park, Yonkers, this afternoon.

Stricter protection will be given to humpback and baleen whales by a protocol to the international whaling treaty, signed today at the close of the international whaling conference, of which the United States is a member.
Plans to form Commodity Distributors, Inc., a nation-wide security distributing organization, were announced yesterday by Hal F. Lee, who is to be president of the organization.

The Trade Union Committee on Unemployment and WPA, comprising sixty A. F. of L. and C. I. o. unions, challenged yesterday the assertion of the American Association for Social Security that the distribution of millions of dollars in unemployment insurance had had no appreciable effect on relief rolls.

The runner-up Reds kept pace with the leading Giants and pulled away from the third-place Cubs by defeating the Phillies, 6 to 4, today before a ladies' day throng of 5,000. Although outhit, 13 to 12, the Reds took an early lead and were never headed after Ernie Lombardi cleaned the bases with a long single in the first inning.

Plots in the East Bronx that have been held by estates for many years passed -into the hands of builders in deals reported yesterday. A lot 25 by 100 feet on the east side of Murdock Avenue, 100 feet south of Edenwald Avenue, was purchased by a builder from the estate of Rosina Heinzman.

Jeff Podesta, Princeton's top-seeded star, bowed by 12-10, 6-2, to Caldwell Russell of Army in a stirring upset today on the Church Courts as fourteen District 2 netmen qualified for the national collegiate tennis championships July 4.

Drought conditions in the Adirondacks have caused a serious fire hazard in the Forest Preserve, according to reports received today by the Conservation Department from district rangers. The entire Adirondack region, with the possible exception of the area surrounding Big Moose, is affected, Commissioner Osborne said.

The only pair to break par, Winthrop and Everett Hoyt, combined for a 71 to lead a big field in the annual Cherry Valley Club best-ball invitation golf tournament today. The Hoyts missed pars at only two holes and bagged birdies at three others.

Trading was good to mostly slow. Steer cuts sold steady to stronger, lamb weak to lower, other classes unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats was slow and prices showed little change from Thursday. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Defending the Japanese sentry at Nanking, who Dr. J. C. Thomson, acting president of the Shanghai branch of the American Presbyterian Nanking University, alleged slapped him on June 15, a Japanese Embassy spokesman here declared today:

The fifty-ninth season of North-field Summer Conferences started by Dwight L. Moody, began today with the arrival of 500 to attend the thirty-eight girls' conference, which continues until Friday. which continues until Friday.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Adia Weaver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Ray Weaver of this place, to Walter Weldin Talley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Talley of Terre Haute, Ind., took place here tonight in the Church of St. James the Less.
Scouting out weak points in the government's fortified lines from Teruel to the Mediterranean, the Insurgents resumed their advance south after their offensive had been halted temporarily.

The election of the Very Rev. John T. Sheehan, pastor of St. Nicholas Catholic Church, Atlantic City, as provincial of the Augustinian Order for the province of the United States and Cuba was confirmed today at Villanova College, where delegates met for the election.

Police Commissioner Valentine made public apology yesterday to Mrs. Ethel Tarvanovich, the East Side housewife who was arrested last Monday and lodged in jail overnight when she turned over to a policeman a loaded revolver she found on the floor of a Second Avenue bus.

Miss Madge Blanding Taliaferro, eldest. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Carson Taliaferro of this place,-formerly of Charlotte, N. C., and Atlanta, Ga., was married here tonight in Trinity Church to Carl Gettus Morrison of Elizabeth, only son of Mrs. May Morrison of Pittsburgh.

The War Department released. the following orders today, dated June 23: COLONELS Holiday, M. G., Q.M.C., four months and four days' leave, June 27. Miles, S. (F.A.), General Staff Corps, five days' leave, June 25.
The Long Island Daily Star of Long Island City, according to an advertisement in its columns yesterday, will discontinue publication today.
The commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

A new anti-Semitic campaign got under way in Mexico today as the official press and organized labor sought to blame small Jewish operators for the crisis in the national textile industry, which is threatening the jobs of 20,000 Mexican workers. 00 Mexican workers.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange rose again yesterday into high ground and for the ninth session out of the last ten closed at an advance, the gains being 4 to 9 points.
Miss Mary Louise Vetterlein, daughter of Mrs. D. Pearson Pearce of Bryn Mawr, was married this afternoon to William Campbell Posey Jr., son of Mrs. Posey of Radnor.

Fifty-one radio frequencies between 30,000 and 60,000 kilocycles are made permanently available to municipalities, States, forestry services and interzone police and marine fire stations in a decision made public today by the Federal Communications Commission.

Charges of "recklessness, partiality and outrageous conduct" were made yesterday by Miss Adele I. Springer, admiralty attorney, against four of five lawyers who, as members of an award committee, recommended payments amounting to $1,386,766 to claimants for damages arising out of the Morro Castle disaster in September, 1934.

An investor represented by Pillion Voss, brokers, has purchased from the Wandmacker Estate the three-story apartment building at 827 St. John's Place, Brooklyn. There are accommodations for six families in the house, which is on a plot 27 by 157 feet.

17th St, 152 W, 24.3x92. Gun Hill Apartments, Inc, to Emigrant Bank, which holds mtg. for $16,800. 73d St, 208 and 202 E, 25x102.2 and 24.4 1/2x 76.8, Bryan J. McKeogh to Beatrice G. Smith. 1,220 Park Ave (50 cents).
Few discussions of the problem of relief have had the breadth and balance of Governor Lehman's address before the New York State Public Welfare Officials Association.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4130--S. Yamada v. United State. Motion of appellee to extend time for filing petition for rehearing to July 11, granted. ed.

The four-man Harvard Alaskan expedition, which during the past month has been exploring the unmapped heart of the Great Chugach mountain range, was returned safely here today by Pilot Bob Reeve in two trips from its 6,000 foot base camp.
The Connecticut Foot Guards individual match was won at the State Rifle Range here today by Lieutenant James K. Bell of the Gate City Guard at Atlanta, in a field of forty competitors.
With Pompoon and Stagehand among the entrants, ten have been named for the running of the historic Brooklyn Handicap today at Aqueduct.

Fifty-five per cent of reporting stores with sales under $75,000 annually operate on a merchandise budget or plan, according to the report on the first research project issued yesterday by the bureau of smaller stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Pierce W. Bradley of the Securities and Exchange Commission's legal enforcement staff announced yesterday that he had resigned to engage in the- private practice of law.

J. E. Harrington, a former Brooklyn boy, who has been publisher and general manager of The Irish Press, a Dublin, Ireland, daily newspaper, has been named assistant publisher of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, according to an announcement yesterday by the management.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as applied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association. Inc.:

Although all the non-intervention powers are now agreed on the new British proposals for getting foreign troops out of Spain and closing her frontiers to foreign munitions, the Non-Intervention Committee today got practically nowhere on the question of how to raise the [pound]2,250,000 which it is estimated the scheme will cost.

As the result of an agreement between Chilean authorities and a German film producer, Dr. Arnold Fank, fifteen technicians and a number of German actors will arrive from Berlin in a few days in order to commence production of a dozen full length pictures here for world distribution as well as descriptive films of national landscapes and life.

National Educational Association Sunday will be observed in the churches tomorrow, marking the opening of the seventy-sixth annual convention of that organization in this city. Special services have been arranged for the thousands of delegates.

Russell V. Adams of Adams Mueller, Newark, has been elected president of the Bond Club of New Jersey for the next year, to succeed Charles E. Reed of Kean, Taylor Co. Arthur R. Robinson of Colyer, Robinson Co. was elected vice president.

Sensationally reopening the strangulation death case of Dr. and Mrs. James G. Littlefield, elderly South Paris couple, the Oxford County grand jury today indicted former Deputy Sheriff Francis M. Carroll, 43, for the murder of the 67-year-old physician.
Benjamin M. Berger, of the stock brokerage firm of B. M. Berger Co., 67 Wall Street, died last night after a brief illness in his home at 25-41, Thirtieth Road, Astoria, Queens. He was 59 years old.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,153,000 bales, against 1,173,000 a week ago, 1,169,000 two weeks ago, 1,173,000 three weeks ago and 886,000 a year ago, of which American 742,000 bales, against 758,000 a week ago, 769,000 two weeks ago, 777,000 three weeks ago and 352,000 a year ago.
The motives behind the edict for universal conscription of labor in Germany, like the reasons for the new wave of Jewish persecution, lie hidden in the convolutions of the Nazi brain.

The information the extraordinary grand jury investigating the policy racket was unable to obtain from Matthew F. Kenney, political adherent of James J. Hines, Tammany leader, was disclosed yesterday afternoon at a hearing before Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the Supreme Court, before whom Kenney appeared to answer charges of contempt.

Building projects submitted yesterday by architects included the plans for the first unit of the Red Hook housing development in Brooklyn. The unit will consist of seven six-story apartment houses to cost $2,631,900. Alfred E. Poor, architect, filed the plans for the New York City Housing Authority.

The United States Employment Service made 238,654 job placements in May, an increase of 12.2 per cent over April, according to an announcement today by Charles V. McLaughlin, Acting Secretary of Labor. cretary of Labor.

Receipt of permission from the French Government to land at Le Bourget Airport stimulated yesterday plans of Howard Hughes, one of America's outstanding sportsman pilots, to fly non-stop from New York to Paris within the next two weeks.
The executive board of the International Fur Workers Union in the United States and Canada, a C. I. o. unit, opened its semi-annual meeting at the Hotel President here today.

Jews and Christians "are again in the catacombs together and the old comradeship of martyrdom resumes its strength," Dr. Solomon B. Freehof of Pittsburgh told the Central Conference of American Rabbis at its forty-ninth annual meeting in the Hotel Chelsea here today.
Shirley Temple and President Roosevelt talked about lamb chops today. while Secretary Morgenthau cooled his heels in an anteroom.

The right-hand hitting outfielder whom Bill Terry has been seeking since he traded Wally Berger to Cincinnati has been found. The Giant manager announced yesterday he had purchased from Newark the home-run sensation of the season, Bob Seeds.

Following a meeting yesterday afternoon between Ketchikan packers and the C. I. O., the refusal of the former to sign a closed shop pact resulted in the union leaders declaring they would call on the National Labor Relations Board to settle the question.

Operating plans have been completed and preliminary action begun in an $80,000,000 campaign by the Federal Government which is expected to carry forward a considerable distance the "planned economy" for which the Administration had been striving for more than six years. re than six years.

Hotel income increased 7.25 per cent last year but wage costs rose 12 per cent, according to the annual statistical review of 250 hotels in 100 cities, issued yesterday by Harris, Kerr, Forster Co., accountants and auditors. Hotel business, as measured by room occupancy, the report pointed out, increased 1.86 per cent last year compared with 1936, maintaining a trend above that of other general business.

Having rejected all bids on June 21 for $617,000 of various-purpose bonds, officials of Des Moines, Iowa, announced yesterday that they had sold the issue at private sale to Carlton D. Deh Co., and Shaw, McDermott Sparks, Inc., at a price of par for 31/4s.

By holing a fifteen-foot putt for a birdie 3 on the final green, Chester T. Birch of the host club today registered a par-equaling 72 to tie Edward Searle, unattached, for the qualifying-round honors in the annual Briar Hills Golf and Country Club invitation golf tourney.
The outbreak of violence on the Jaffa-Tel Aviv boundary. yesterday has not yet subsided, as further instances of stabbing and bomb-throwing flared up again today.

Harvard's varsity crew beat Yale's eight by a little more than a length on the Thames at New London early last night to complete a sweep of the annual regatta. The sweep was the first for the Crimson since 1916.
The boxing committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association ended its session today by adopting specifications calling for twelve-ounce instead of ten-ounce gloves for all college boxers.

In reopening the oratorical war on the capitalistic countries, President Kalinin of the Soviet Union put forward one very strange argument. He spoke of the bad quality of the goods so often turned out in his country. In the capitalist world, he tells us, the explanation would be easy:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It must be apparent to any thoughtful person that our whole tax structure must ere long collapse of its own weight, for it is complication running mad, representing cost, wasted effort and injustice fast becoming beyond endurance.

Graduation exercises for Margaret Raeling, 19-year-old infantile paralysis victim, were held yesterday at her home, 274A Ninth Street, Brooklyn, with a number of her friends, relatives and teachers in attendance.

Anthony Ave, 1,646 (11-2888); Ekay Realty Corp to State Mortgage Commission; extends mtg. to May 6, 1941, at 4 1/2 per cent; $98,000. Webster Ave, 2,358-60 (11-3031); Frances Green to State Mortgage Commission; extends mtg. to June 1, 1940, at 5 per cent; $37,250.

The racing and hunting stables, registered Ayrshire cattle, other livestock and miscellaneous chattels of Richard Whitney were sold at auction at his Riverside Farm home today for the benefit of his bankrupt stock Exchange firm and his personal creditors in bankruptcy.

Miss Friday Kondrup Frazer, daughter of Mrs. Randolph Leigh and granddaughter of Mrs. E. H. Tillman and the late Commander Tillman, U. S. N., was married today to Walter Thatcher Winslow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Nickerson Winslow of Boston.

Possible abandonment of the retailing of merchandise above. 25 cents is being considered by S. H. Kress Co. at meetings now being held of its district managers, and a decision on the question may be reached by the end of next week, according to an official of the company.

Fog, heat and unusual mugginess continued yesterday for the second successive day to play havoc with shipping schedules and the comfort of city dwellers. Partly cloudy and continued warm weather was forecast for today.

Max Schmeling was considerably improved yesterday and even had a visitor. The German heavyweight, who was sent to the Polyclinic Hospital last Wednesday night by Joe Louis's punches, was up and about in the afternoon, though he did not leave his quarters. He entertained the German Ambassador to Washington, Hans Dieckhoff.

Three American diplomatic representatives abroad were among the 787 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the United States liner Washington. Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Russia, who is being transferred to Belgium, arrived on the ship with Hugh S. Gibson, who retired from the Brussels post after serving more than thirty years in the diplomatic service.

The new billions the Federal Government is about to spend for pump-priming may not be sufficient to achieve recovery, and before this objective is attained the government may have to spend much more as an employer and investor, Dr. Leon Henderson, economic consultant to the Federal Works Progress Administration, told the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute here today.

Plans for six new ski trails in the Adirondacks and Catskills will be discussed at a Conservation Department hearing next Thursday. The new trails, as mapped out, would add about seventeen miles to the existing trails in the forest preserve of the State. e of the State.
The American Car and Foundry Company reported yesterday in its thirty-ninth fiscal statement net earnings of $753,407 for the year ended on April 30.

After a sharp clash yesterday which almost resulted in defeat of the city cigarette tax, members of the City Council adopted Mayor La Guardia's five-point relief tax program for another year, with the proviso that the cigarette tax extend only for the next six months and end on Dec. 31, 1938.

President Roosevelt today issued executive orders extending the merit system to every one in regular Federal employment except the highest policy-making officeholders or persons specifically exempted by law.

Senora Eudoxia Castro Fernandez Iglesias, widow of President Demetrio Iglesias, died here today at the age of 94. "Ocnita," as she was known by Costa Ricans, was the only woman who was a granddaughter, daughter, wife and mother of Presidents of Costa Rica.

Cattle prices were fully steady at the close today when supplies almost reached the vanishing point. The hogs market showed evidence of weakness from the opening and at the close prices were generally 15 to 25 cents lower on weights 230 pounds up. Saleable supplies of fat lambs were small with prices steady to weak, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
Lewis E. Pierson, chairman of the board of the Irving Trust Company, has leased a large apartment in the building at 550 Park Avenue through Douglas Gibbons Co., the latter announced yesterday.

Miss Mary J. Duke Biddle, daughter of Mrs. Mary Duke Biddle of this place and 1,009 Fifth Avenue, New York, and of Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., United States Ambassador to Poland, was married here this morning at the home of her mother to Dr. Josiah Charles Trent of Okmulgee, Okla.

Canada's first National Eucharistic Congress will be remembered both as a religious triumph and a signal demonstration of organizing genius. No one failed to find a place to stay or a chance to participate in its occasions.

Sixteen men arrested on Monday and Tuesday in connection with strike disorders at the Eagle Pencil Company, Fourteenth Street and Avenue B, were fined on disorderly conduct charges yesterday by Magistrate Joseph De Andrea, sitting in Essex Market Court. Charges against two other men were dismissed.

The $80,000 mortgage held by the Metropolitan Savings Bank from the Barnard School for Girls on the plot on the east side of Fort Washington Ave, 587 feet north of 183d St and facing on Overlook Terrace 103 feet, was extended to Sept. 1, 1958, at 4 per cent.

Trading in round lots by members on the New York Stock Exchange for their own account in the week ended on May 28 fell to 16.14 per cent of total volume from 19.08 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on April 30, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses and charges, of $8,899,425.
Prospect Ave. 671-81. 3-story hall and store, 100x95; East River Savings Bank against 671 Prospect Ave Holding Corp; due. $148,374; taxes, etc, $2,322; to plaintiff for $50,000.

For the third successive day, prices of both zinc and lead moved higher yesterday. Prime Western zinc was advanced from 4.40 to 4.50 cents a pound at East St. Louis, making a rise of a half cent this week.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, indicated yesterday that members of his union employed on piers in Atlantic and Gulf ports would be ordered to withhold service from ships loaded by C. I. O. longshoremen on the Pacific Coast if a recent decision of the National Labor Relations Board remained unchanged.
After several weeks of negotiations between Premier Mohammed Mahmoud Pasha and leaders of the Saadist party, headed by Dr. Ahmad Maher, the latter agreed today to join Premier Mahmoud's Cabinet.

The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company of St. Louis, Mo., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $30,000,000 or first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds due on July 1, 1968.

Miss Marion Stubbs Purcell, daughter of Mrs. Clifton Purcell of Townsend, Ga., and the late Mr. Purcell, was married to Dr. Peter Willis Henderson, son of Peter Henderson of Kitchener, Ont., and the late Mrs. Henderson, yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Dr. Victor A. Menard.

BEFORE he took to art, Shakespeare,etc., Eddie Doweling was a vaudevillian of no little experience, as all but the very late arrivals must ..know; wherefore there should be less sur-~ prise than interest in the report that it will be he who presents "Here Come the Clowns," by Mr.

THE work that Cummings has set himself to do, and has done with singular constancy, is a poet's work. It will never be remembered as current topics versified or political propaganda. It is in the tradition of romantic individualism, and Cummings is decidedly one of the few who can say "great God" with some conviction

IN his well-timed book, which is the "outgrowth of travel and investigation in the Far East during 1937," T. A. Bisson of the Research Department, Foreign Policy Association, deals with the changes and crises in China and Japan in recent years, with the relations between the two countries, and with the armed conflict now going on in China.
MR. M'CLURE analyzes a rich boor. Henry Pickering, his main character, was physically strong, handsome, moneyed, but he lacked intelligence, imagination, good judgment, diligence and determination.

Governor Elmer A. Benson barely escaped defeat in the Minnesota primary election this week and now enters the final campaign against a strong Republican opponent with the Farmer-Labor party crippled by the schism between the left and right wings.

" The danger and absurdity of the principles of liberty and equality" were proclaimed by Minister of Education Bernhard Rust in his programmatic oration at the 550th anniversary of the University of Cologne.

Miss Constance White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nelson White became the bride yesterday afternoon of Richard Glover of Cambridge, England. The ceremony was performed in the garden of the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. George Hugh Smyth of Scarsdale, N. Y., uncle of the bride.

Economic self-sufficiency was attacked tonight by Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, as a costly program which forces living standards inevitably downward to lower and lower levels, and results in increasing regimentation and bureaucratic control.

James G. McDonald, formerly League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees from Germany, doubts that the exodus of political minorities from Germany and Austria to this country will reach such proportions as to lead to a change in American immigration laws.

Although the trading volume in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was large yesterday, the advance in prices did not keep pace with the share market. Strength, however, continued to dominate the list generally, with only a few spots exhibiting real weakness.

A charge that Senator Joseph F. Guffey, campaign manager for the Democratic ticket in the Fall campaign, was planning to "knife" Governor Earle, the Senatorial nominee, was made today by Arthur Colegrove, member of the Public Utility Commission.

WITH but four days to the Fourth's long week-end, vacationists are on the jump from travel bureaus to steamship, train and bus offices. Despite depression doldrums, all signs point to a record crowd leaving this coming Friday for sea, woods, simple camp or gay hotel. Many foresighted travelers have already made reservations for this peak holiday of the year;

By the end of this month the Secret Service hopes to have completed its project of teaching moneyhandlers in the 100,000 retail and service establishments in New York City how to' detect counterfeit currency, according. to Frank J. Wilson, Secret Service chief.

Representative Sumners of Texas, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee and opponent of the President in the Supreme Court reorganization fight, has acceded to a request by the President that he serve on the Monopoly Investigating Committee, it was affirmed at the White House today.

The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that designation of-the C. I. 0. maritime union as bargaining agent for all longshoremen working on Pacific Coast docks "may have serious consequences, to industries operating on a national scale."

The entire slate backed by the United Rank and File Clubs of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paper Hangers of America, A. F. L., for offices of District Council 9, which includes Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, was elected yesterday at balloting in the 369th Infantry Armory at Fifth Avenue and 143d Street.
