100 Yards-Ben Johnson, New York Curb Exchange A. A. *220 Yards - Robert Rodenkirchen, New York A. C. *440 Yards-James B. Herbert, New York Curb Exchange A. A. 880 Yards-Glenn Cunningham, New York Curb Exchange A. A. Mile - Leslie MacMitchell, unattached. 3 Mile-John Chamos, Lenox Hill A. A.

Charles Granville Jones, an architect, who designed most of this town's public buildings, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home. at the age of 73. Born in Brooklyn, Mr. Jones received his professional training in the office of his father, the late Richard C. Jones, and as a draftsman in New York.

Three blocks from Military Park, in the heart of Newark, where on June 4 he was stoned and spattered with eggs, Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, addressed an orderly meeting of more than 3,500 persons in Washington Park tonight. The meeting proved, he declared, that Newark did not, like Jersey City, approve of the violation of the Bill of Rights.

Grace Episcopal Church here, which was given to this community by the late John D. Wing, was the scene of the marriage this afternoon of his great-granddaughter, Miss Carolyn Whitman, to her second cousin, Clarence Whitman 2d. The ceremony was performed by the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop of the New York Diocese, and the Rev. Ross Greer, rector of the church.

Deferring action until Thursday night on the application of Marshall Van Winkle, a Jersey City lawyer and former Congressman from Hudson County, to erect a threestory, twenty-four-family apartment house at the northwest corner
Considerable concern is being manifested here over alleged German economic penetration of Iran, which is believed to have definite political and military motives threatening to the Soviet Union.

Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, told the New York State Commercial Secretaries Conference that "fulminations against business concerns and business interests should.cease," and the government must "keep hands off" legitimate business if the depression was to end.

RUMANIA'S series commemorating the eighth anniversary, June 8, of the .the accession of King Carol II, proves more extravagant than had been expected, as the eleven denominations present portraits of nine men and two women identified with the kingdom's history across the centuries.
AMONG first-class books on life in foreign countries "The Coconut Monkey" can easily take its place, for without sacrificing any of the exotic strangeness of her setting Mrs. Morse contrives

Work has been started on the development of the Silver Brook Colony, comprising 621 acres fronting on Reeves Bay facing Great Peconic Bay and running through to the Quouque-Westhampton Road, at Flanders, near Riverhead, L. I. The engineering work is being done by Wallace Halsey.

E. F. Sullivan, 60-year-old director of the Kiltie Band of Carnegie Institute of Technology, died today, having burst a, blood vessel in his neck while blowing a horn yesterday at a rehearsal of one of his bands at Western Penitentiary.

THE annual championship tournament of the International Bridge League begins today at Oslo, Norway. The attendance will be much lower than in recent years, partly because of the unsettled political condition in Europe and partly because of the restriction many European countries have placed on the spending of money outside the. country.

Mayor FranK Hague or Jersey City was denounced by Mary VanKleeck, director of industrial studies at the Russell Sage Foundation of New York, who addressed the second session of the Friends General Conference here today.

Somebody in Chicago has been committing grand larceny on a grand scale. The loot consisted of ten buildings, one of them a three-story structure. The crimes were discovered by WPA crews authorized to wreck the condemned structures. When they arrived on the sites they found nothing else.

THE festival of contemporary music organized by the International Society for Contemporary Musio which is to begin shortly here has had a prologue in the "Music and Life 1938 Congress" held a few days ago.

The fourth annual Carmel Each Festival will be held July 1824 in the Sunset School Auditorium at Carmel-by-the-Sea, Calif. Gastone Usigli will direct. Sascha Jacobinoff will appear as guest conductor.

Three hundred and sixty-five Austrian Jewish refugees, mostly young boys but including some women, who had spent virtually all their money for transportation before leaving Vienna, have sailed from the small port of Oropos on the Euboean Gulf for an unspecified country that they hope may offer a permanent home.

Burt J. Denman, vice president and general manager of the United Light Power Company, was found dead in bed on the New York Central's Commodore Vanderbilt this morning as the train was approaching Chicago. He was returning from a business trip to New York. Physicians said he had apparently died of heart disease as he slept. His age was 62.

The NBC Symphony Orchestra brought its first season of weekly concerts to a close last night at Radio City with a program directed by the German conductor, Hans Wilhelm Steinberg. This was the thirty-third concert of the series which opened last Christmas night with pomp and circumstance under Arturo Toscanini's baton.

In planning a new home or the modernizing of an existing house the owner is advised to make a careful check of the light and power equipment. Such a check is doubly recommended in old dwellings, where the installations may have become worn or damaged as well as outmoded. It should be done with the aid of a competent electrician.
A week of rising prices in the security and commodity markets and an unmistakable upturn of business sentiment set the stage auspiciously for the President's radio address on- Friday evening.

The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, created by Congress four years ago, is the greatestt factor in the development of the savings and loan movement, according to George E. Palmer, secretary-manager of the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association. In 1937,

President Manuel Quezon, answering Catholic criticism over his veto of a bill to require religious instruction in public schools, declared today he would not tolerate any church interference in matters "within the province of the government."

Miss Alice Elsa Guttman, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Guttman of this place, was married this afternoon in the garden of her home in Boonton Park to Robert Thomas Brunton, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Brunton
The British Government is now hurriedly completing plans for high-speed evacuation of its metropolitan. citizenry in the event of attack from the air.
A STRANGE short-wave station, believed to be connected with the anti-Stalin prop-aganda waves which during the recent May Day celebrations in Moscow were reported to have rained down warning messages
Dr. William Clinton Johnson, head of the Department of Pathology of the University of Colorado Medical School here, died today of cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 53.

Miss Jean Carter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. G. Herbert Carter of Huntington, was married to Dr. John Cannon, son of Mrs. Charles Madison Cannon of New York, this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church here.

One of the cheapest means of cooling is. to replace the hot air which accumulates in a house in the daytime with cool night air drawn in by a powerful electric fan placed in the attic, states The Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.

The first Lily Field Day to be held in the United States is being planned by the lily committee of the National Horticultural Society. All interested horticulturalists are invited to meet Saturday morning either at the New York Botanical Garden at 9 o'clock; or at the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research at Yonkers, where the meeting will reconvene at 10 o'clock.

THE advancing interest of American audiences in early music and instruments, unmistakably shiwn by the past concert season, is an encouraging sign of the growth of a genuine musical culture in this country.

LAKE MOHAWK, N. J.-A busy calendar-of social and sports events is scheduled for the July Fourth week-end here, including four sailboat races, two dances and athletic contests. Lake Mohawk Country Club will hold its annual fireworks display on Monday evening, July 4.

GRADUALLY, as family records of reticent Victorians are released from hiding places decades deep, the modern world is forced to revise its opinion of the nineteenth-century woman as-the fainting female who divided her time between childbed and the invalid divan. Such women existed, for so the men wanted them.
Using literally gallons of serum, authorities have inoculated more than a million persons against cholera in Shanghai's International Settlement and French Concession within the past two months.

The democratic republican form of government won its second important victory of this year in South America last Sunday with the inauguration of General Alfredo Baldomir as President of Uruguay. The first recent victory has been signalized by the inauguration of Roberto M. Ortiz as President of Argentina in February.

Is the Canadian Government, for fear of French-Canadian opinion, opposing the desire of the British Government to establish in Canada a training school for British fliers and to place large long-term orders for aircraft and munitions with Canadian factories?

A pair of Chinese alabaster horses attributed to the Ming Dynasty, which were taken from a tomb in Northwestern China in 1932, have been placed on exhibition for the first time at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center, it was announced yesterday.

The newspaper Politiken says that Henning Repsdorph of the legal firm of Repsdorph Repsdorph has flown to London to receive instructions from Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow, the former Barbara Hutton, Woolworth heiress, who, according to the newspaper, is seeking a divorce in the Danish courts from Count Court HaugwitzReventlow.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H.--In preparation for mountain-climbing, a leading sport in the White Mountains, eollage students are now doing maintenance work on the Appalachian Mountain Club's trails, over 300 miles

The official report of the Olympic Games at Berlin in 1936, published by the German Organizing Committee, is ready for distribution, a twovolume, 1,224-page affair that is the finest thing of its kind ever produced.

A third man was shot today in. the dispute of striking C. I. O. truck drivers with A. F. of L. members. Soon after the shooting police raided C. I. O. headquarters for a second time and arrested twenty-six persons. Eighty-four were arrested in the. first raid yesterday.

PARIS - Faith of British and French naval authorities in sea power has never been so complete as it is today. As the first result of the BritishFrench alliance they are coordinating their fleets to maintain their mastery of the sea.

BAR HARBOR, Me.-The coming week will be marked by the opening of the two most active social organizations of the Summer season, the Bar Harbor Club and the Shore Club; both of which are situated on the shores of Frenchmen's Bay.
Donald R. Richberg, former NRA Administrator and counsel for railroad unions, will represent the American Rolling Mill Company

John G. Miller, judge of the Peoples Court, died last night at the age of 59. A son of the late SheriffAugust L. Miller, and a graduate of the University of Maryland, Judge Miller had been Circuit Court auditor and president of the Allegheny County Bar Association.

A home run by Virgil (Spud) Davis off Joe' Cascarella into the leftfield bleachers gave the Phillies a 7-6 triumph over Cincinnati in twelve innings today. Trailing by 6-3 in the ninth, the Reds tied the score after two were out on an error by Buck Jordan and four successive hits.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, issued to 160,000 WPA workers last week the first in a series of monthly "thought starters" intended to inspire them to higher and finer things.
In anticipation of the closing of schools and hot weather, the Parks Department has made arrangements for setting aside forty lawns totaling 140 acres in Central Park for "passive recreation."

The passing of another landmark in Times Square was indicated yesterday when tenants in the Fitzgerald Building, at the southeast corner of Broadway and Forty-third Street, revealed that they had been notified to vacate their quarters about July 1. A modern two-story theatre, office and store building is expected to replace the old structure.

In the belief that women's contributions to radio broadcasting are "not sufficiently appreciated" and that "men get more than their share of credit," the radio committee of the National Federation of Press Women announced yesterday that steps had been taken to remedy the situation.

Thirty-six advanced scholars from twenty-five universities in eight countries arrived at Princeton University today for the official opening of the second Summer seminar in Arabic and Islamic studies which will continue for a six-week period ending Aug. 5.
The Nebraska Supreme Court ousted Lieut. Gov. Walter H. Jurgensen from office today, ruling his position was vacated last March 7 when he was sentenced to serve two to five years for embezzlement.

Industrial Commissioner Andrews made a bid today for the nomination for Lieutenant Governor on the Democratic and American Labor party tickets. A press release from the State Department of Labor reads as follows:
IN a fine patriotic fervor, Vincent Lopez, the band leader, has dedi cated himself to the task of popularizing "The Star-Spangled Banner" among American citizens.
A one-year survey of the care of crippled children in New York City, as a base on which to plan improvements in such services, has just been started by a Commission for Study of Crippled Children.

United States Attorney Lamar Hardy announced yesterday that the special Federal grand jury investigating the German espionage system operating in this country would reconvene on Tuesday instead of tomorrow. as originally planned.

Rabbi Joseph L. Fink of Buffalo, N. Y., told the Central Conference of American Rabbis in the Hotel Chelsea today that the synagogue cannot seek to remain an institution that conserves tradition in an age that is non-traditional in spirit.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.-Sports and social activities in this resort have stepped up to midsummer stride. With cottages and hotels filled to capacity, the coming three-day Fourth of July holiday promises to be the biggest in the history of this area.

To give brokers and salesmen easy access to homes listed for sale, several suburban realty boards have adopted the plan of installing key boxes, containing the keys to the front doors, on the outside of such homes.

Making new track records is getting to be a habit with James Cox Brady's War Magic, 3-year-old son of Pharamond II and War Feathers. Before 15,000 fans at Delaware Park today, War Magic won the second running of the $5,000 added Diamond State Stakes and his time of 1:52 was a new record for a mile and a furlong. On June 17,...

Charles P. Taft, son of the late President, has accepted the chairmanship of the 1938 Community Mobilization for Human Needs. Allen T. Burns, New York City, executive vice president of Community Chests and Councils, Inc., making the announcement of the opening sessions of the national conference of chest

Predictions of an exceptionally fine bass season in New York State, opening July 1, came -today from the conservation department. "Weather and water conditions favorable to bass have prevailed throughout the State for the past several years," the department said.

The Administration's monopoly investigators disclosed today, on the heels of a price flash by the United States Steel Corporation, that "big steel" probably would be the first company haled to public hearings. They said they expected to start hearings in September. In the meantime, data will be gathered and preparations made for the most extensive inquiry of this generation into trusts, price-fixing and allied subjects.
Senator Norris said today he was studying a proposal to issue $1,000,000,000 in new currency and make it available to States, counties and cities for construction of public works.
KINGSTON.-Throughout the Catskills resort officials are directing their efforts now toward the biggest, Fourth of July week-end in a decade.

From the days of ancient Greece, when slaves often were the only teachers, all the way to modern times, the history of education was traced here yesterday by 1,000 high school students in a preview of a colorful and elaborate pageant.

Lewis G. Stapley, former Assemblyman, who sponsored the legislation which resuited in the present Bureau of Motor Vehicles, died today in the Albany Hospital. He was 59 years old and had been ill for several months.

Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador to Mexico, who returned to this country on leave of absence and remained several weeks for conferences at the State Department and the White House on the Mexican oil expropriation, left by train late today to resume his post in Mexico City.

Although France is trying to check absolute occupation of the Sanjak of Alexandretta by the Turks, to which France's ally, Syria, objects, nevertheless at the same time France is desirous of placating the Turks in every way possible.

The finals of the Park Department's fourth annual interborough folk-dance contest were held yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park. Three hundred and twenty girls participated and all three prizes were won by Brooklyn groups.

" Molly Mollison," a frequent stowaway in the last two years, sailed for England. yesterday on the Cunard White Star motorship Georgic with a pre-paid tourist ticket and a new United States passport. The document bore her correct name, Catherine E. Schwartz, 22 years old, of Chicago.

A widening and deepening of the cleavage between conservative and New Deal Democrats is viewed here today as the almost inevitable result of President Roosevelt's strictures on his political opposition in his radio address last night.

IN order to extend the safety island which has proved so salu tary in reducing accidents on U. S. Route 1, Highway Commissioner Sterner of New Jersey had work started last week from Bakers Basin to the Brunswick Avenue traffic circle at the Trenton-Lawrence line.

Miss Mary Fell Jordan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Jordan of Jordan's Pond, Glenside, was married this afternoon to Alfred Ogden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred T. Ogden of Kinderhook, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Malcolm E. Peabody in St. Paul's Episcopal Church at Chestnut Hill.

With only minor changes and omissions, a new constitution was approved yesterday by the seventyninth annual convention of the Evangelical Lutheran Augustana Synod of North America for its 1,200 congregations. The Synod, attended by 400 pastors from all parts tof the nation, is meeting in the Bethlehem Church, Third Avenue and Pacific Street, Brooklyn.

The Cubs did not waste their hits and the Giants had practically none to waste at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Clay Bryant yielded only three well-spaced singles in shutting out the embattled forces of Colonel Bill Terry, 5 to O.

Mrs. T. Charlton Henry of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julia Rush Biddle Henry, to Philip D. Armour Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Armour of Lake Forest. Ill.

The first anniversary of the East Harlem Health and Teaching Center, at 158 East 115th Street, will be marked Wednesday by a joint meeting of the East Harlem Council of Social Agencies, the East Harlem District Health Committee and the health center staff. The center was the first of nine new buildings that have been opened during the last year.

Many Protestant clergymen of this country, including two Episcopal Bishops, will preach abroad this Summer and several Protestant clergymen from Europe will preach here. The arrangements have been made by the Committee of Interchange of Preachers and Speakers between America, Great Britain and France, with headquarters at 70 Fifth Avenue. The list was announced yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would not be a candidate for United States Senator this year, leaving open the assumption that he might wish to run for that office in 1940.
Nicholas Pirro, chairman of the License Committee of the Syracuse Common Council, announced today that his committee is "seriously considering" passage of a resolution to ban night baseball.

Examples of work done in the New York City schools were placed on display last night in the Port Authority Building,. Eighth Avenue near Fifteenth Steet.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

Miss Emily Bogert Boyce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gale Boyce of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Dutch Reformed Church to Dr. James C Sutherland Frame, son of the Rev. Professor James Everett Frame of Union Theological Seminary, New York, and the late Mrs. Frame.

The German Government has agreed to exempt American Jews permanently domiciled abroad from the necessity of registering their properties in Germany but will not grant this waiver to former German nationals who have emigrated for political reasons since 1933 when Adolf Hitler became Chancellor. Despite the wide use of bathtubs in this country, a recent survey, according to the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau, reveals the fact that only approximately il,000,000 of the 25,200,000 dwelling units in the United States are equipped with bathtubs.

Denny Shute, National Professional Golfers Association champion -for the past two years, tonight accepted a challenge from Ralfph Guldahl, United States open titleholder over the same period, for a 36-hole "winner-take-all" match for the "unofficial" American championship.

A list of sixty-three internationally known professors and physicians who have been arrested, committed suicide or dismissed from their positions in Austria since the German annexation has been made public here.

Redirection of Jewish economic life into productive industry and agriculture would mitigate growing anti-Jewish discrimination In Poland and Eastern Europe; Dr. David Lvovitch, vice president of the International ORT Union, concludes in a study just published here.

Chicago banks are refusing to accept large savings deposits from individuals who seek interest on funds that normally would be left in commercial accounts on which little or no interest is paid, inquiry disclosed today.

Conceived as a center for gathering together "those stirred by a fundamental curiosity to know," and in the belief that new knowledge arises not only from books, the classroom and laboratory but from the informal intercourse of minds as well, the new building of the Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies at the University of Miehigan was dedicated this month.

From the fountainhead of two housing agencies of the United States Government more than $100,000,000 a month is flowing into commercial channels to contribute to the recovery program to which President Roosevelt gave added impetus this week when he signed the $3,753,000,000 Relief-Recovery Bill.

The expert driving of Artnur J. Wullschleger of Cornell University placed his school in the lead today for the Samuel A. Kane Trophy in the team competition of the ninth annual regatta of the Eastern Intercollegiate Outboard Association.

The marriage of Miss Edith Gould Anderson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles A. Anderson of Brooklyn, to George Theodore Mascott of Chicago took place yesterday afternoon in the Memorial Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Ralph Conover Lankler. Mr. Mascott, is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Mascott of Burlington, Vt.

UTILIZING some 700 unpublished letters which Puccini in the last twenty years of his life addressed to Mrs. Sybil Seligman in London, this sympathetic sketch of the most popular opera composer of modern times adds much to the current information.

Each of the following Medical Department Reserve officers. assigned or attached to the 302d Medical Regiment, is ordered to active duty, July 9, at Camp Dix, N. J.. for training: Col. Curtis F. Claassen, Med.-Res., 57 Grove St., Brooklyn, N. Y.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine made public yesterday a letter of apology he had sent to Mrs. Ethel Tarvanovich, 227 East 121st Street, who was arrested Monday and held overnight in a police cell when she turned in a revolver she had found on a bus.
The ninth annual national soaring competition opened here this afternoon on Harris Hill followed by a series of short flights that ended abruptly when heavy rain hit this area.

PARIS.-The French, who have a habit of hoarding gold, were furnished with a striking example of the merits of hoarding, and those who would write in the manner of de Maupassant were provided with a plot, when workmen recently demolished a sixteenth century house in the rue Mouffetard.
THE current exhibition of the Decorators Club is an attempt to bring to the attention of professionals some of the more promising students recently graduated from schools of interior decoration.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Andrews Barrett, daughter of Mrs. Ashleigh Drake Halliwell of this city, and of Colonel Leonard Lovering Barrett of New York, to Giles Newton Montgomery, son of the Rev. Dr. George Redington Montgomery of Stamford and the late Mrs. Helen Perkins Montgomery,

The New York Navy Yard received $885,000 in a list of 113 projects with total allotments of $27,883,000 for the navy, made public by the Public Works Administration today, after approval by President Roosevelt.

Led by two recent acquisitions to their strong hunter stable, the Claredda Farm of Mr."and Mrs. Edwin V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, N. J., today dominated the hunter division of the twelfth annual horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club. The Quinns took the title and reserve award in addition to other honors.

The diminishing demand for United States products, in evidence for several months, was particularly noticeable in May, when for the first time in eighteen months exports were smaller than in the corresponding month of the previous year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

In the manufacture of filament and staple rayon, New England will find new opportunities for expanding its textile operations, Nathaniel M. Mitchell, president of the Barnes Textile Association, Inc., told the fifty-first quarterly meeting of the NewEngland Council at the Woodstock Inn here today.

A new high monthly production record was established by Ontario's gold mines in May, when output was valued at $8,252,574, compared with $7,748,169 in April and $8,013,494 in March, the best previous month on record.
On His Own Application-To take effect 12 midnight, June 23, 1938: PATROLMAN-Daniel F. Haggerty, 18th Division, M.O.D.D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 14, 1905.

A report has just been presented by the home building and home owning committee of the United States Building and Loan League stating that during the first three months this year the building volume of one-family homes was 15 per cent less than for the same 1937 period. On the- other hand,

Building activity is under way in several new sections of Flushing, L. I. The old Winston farm fronting on Kissena Boulevard and running from Horace Iarding Boulevard to North Hempstead Turnpike has been purchased by Harry Bonuck, builder, who announces that he has started construction of the first unit of the 240 low-priced private homes he plans to erect there.

THE exhibition of the Pittsfield Art League is to open on June 29 at the Berkshire Museum, Pittsfield, and will continue to July 24. Drawings, prints and sculpture by Kaethe Kollwitz, lent by the Hudson Walker Gallery of New York, will be shown at the museum from July 1 to July '24.

The steady upswing in commodity prices last week, encouraging forward commitments on materials by manufacturers, brought a sharp rise in the number-of inquiries coming into banks and warehouses for field warehousing services, according to reports by executives of both the lending institutions and the public warehouses.

President Roosevelt set the example for Leon G. Turrou, the former FBI investigator who arranged to sell a series of stories on the activities of a spy ring, it was charged today by John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

A constitutional amendment designed to assure a five-day, forty-hour week for State employes "will not work" in the opinion of a majority of 400 delegates to the New York State Civil Service Association convention here.

District. Attorney Thomas E. Dewey has been appointed to the board of visitors of Columbia University Law School for 1938-1939. Others appointed were Judge John M. Woolsey, Arthur T. Vanderbilt, president of the American Bar Association;

Feeling they had suffered enough, indignities of late, the.Yankees turned with considerable violence upon their Western tormentors. today and under. cover of a fourteen-hit barrage, which included a pair 'of circuit belts by Joe DiMaggio and . Bill Dickey, the world champions bowled over the Tigers, 9 to 3, to the great discomfiture of a gathering of 22,500.
The State Research Laboratories on the Isle of Biems announce the discovery by Professor Waldmann and Dr. Koebe of an immunizing serum against hoof and mouth disease.

The reduction of prices of steel products by an average of 7 per cent or more, announced 'late on Friday by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation and followed yesterday by the remainder of the industry, virtually carries the price structure of the industry back to the level of 1927, thus bringing into sharp relief the problem. of wage adjustments.

A large crowd is expected at the Yankee Stadium this afternoon when four of the strongest baseball clubs in the Negro National League clash in a double-header for the benefit of the Greater New York Fund.

Morris C. Trooper of Brooklyn, N. Y., president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, reported improving prospects for a business upturn at a roundtable session today of the annual regional chapter conference of the Society at Holl's Inn here.

Mrs. Kathleen Eileen Barry, writer, lecturer and former newspaper woman, died yesterday in her home, at 12 St. Charles Place, Brooklyn, of a heart ailment. She had returned Friday night from Manchester, Vt., where on Thursday she had delivered an address before the American Library Association Convention.

LENOX, Mass.-In a red-painted barn supported by hand-hewn timbers, on the edge of a 340acre reservation at Lenox, the ninth annual meeting of the Pleasant Valley Bird and Wild Flower Sanctuary Association will be held on Wednesday afternoon.

A thirty-mile southerly wind greeted a fleet of seventy-eight craft from the seven Mnember clubs comprising the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association in the opening championship regatta of the season today.

A denial that any official of the United States Steel Corporation had pledged that no wage cuts would follow Friday's reduction of steel prices by $2.50 to $8.50 a ton brought immediate recovery to a faltering stock market and gradually reduced the flood of telephone and telegraph messages exchanged between steel men and other leaders in business or finance throughout the morning.

Miss Inez Christine Goff of 19 East Eighty-eighth Street, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Peyton Goff of Kansas City, Mo., was married to Carl Reed Weidenmiller of this city, yesterday morning in he chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church by the Rev. Lynde Eliot May of the church staff. After the ceremony there was a wedding breakfast in the Pillement Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mayor La Guardia will hold a statutory hearing on the relief taxes passed Friday by the City Council on Thursday in City Hall at 9:30 A. M., The City Record announced yesterday. At the same time he will hold a hearing on the occupancy tax for the payment of interest on bond issues for new housing under the New York City Housing Authority.

The abrupt suppression of the anti-Jewish excesses that left a trail of tar and vermilion and battered, disfigured shop fronts along Berlin business streets during the past fortnight leaves unsolved the mystery of their origin and immediate purpose.

DJOCJA, Java. WE had been in Djocja-or Jogjakarta, as it is often spelled-a couple of days and seen the famous Buddhist Stupa, the Borobudur, made a quick trip to Kalioeran, that minature bit of Switzerland almost at the base of the treacherous volcano of the Merapi,

Scarcely had the National Labor Relations Board announced its decision in the Pacific Coast longshoremen's rivalry between the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O. than a flood of speculation was unloosed concerning the implications of the ruling.
More than 2,000 retailers are expected to attend the midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which opens tomorrow in Cincinnati at the Netherland-Plaza Hotel.

NEW YORK is entertaining the nation's teachers this week. For several days they have been pouring into the city, from all corners of the country-a host of 15,000 delegates to the sixty-ninth annual convention of the National Education Association.

AFRENCH timetable, almost a century old, has just been discovered in Rouen, capital of Normandy, and it furnishes striking, even amusing evidence of the progress made by railroads in both speed and comfort.

The marriage of Thomas Edison Sloane, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Eyre Sloane of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, to Miss Elaine Bernice Levy, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Henry Levy of New Haven, Conn., was announced here today hv both families.
POPE PIU8 XI AND WORLD PEACE. By Lord Clonmore. Foreword by Arthuri CardinalZ Hinsley, Archbishop of Westminster. With frontispiece portrait. 306 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton 6 Co., Inc. $3.
The City Board of Elections has the right to let contracts for the purchase of materials without interference by the Commissioner of Purchase, the Appellate Division decided unanimously yesterday.
With Corneliu Zelea Codreanu imprisoned, the Rumanian Government today continued its drive to stamp out his outlawed Fascist Iron Guard with prosecution of eighteen of Codreanu's followers.

Several orchestral, choral, chamber music and solo programs will be offered by students of the music department of the High School of Music and Art during the convention of the National Education Association.

MOTORISTS headed north for a Canadian holiday during the latter part of June and early July will do well to take in the St. Lawrence International Peace Centennial at Prescott, Ont. International in character, the celebration will include pageants, a marathon race, street dances, religious ceremonies, massed band festivals, musical competitions, concerts, fireworks displays, a carnival and a naval demonstration on the river.

Settlement of the two-month-old Propper-McCallum Hosiery Company labor dispute, which has kept 750 persons out of work, was announced today by the company in a statement which disclosed the retirement of four trustees in favor of a new board.
The American Beverage Corporation has taken no action on a dividend on the preferred stock The last previous payment was 8 3/4 cents on Jan. 3.

A national competition will be held to select a bronze panel for the doorway of the main entrance of the Associated Press Building now under construction in Rockefeller Center. The decoration will be the first one in the Center to be selected by the competition method.

Fordham's powerful football center during the past Fall, Alexander Franklin Wojciechowicz, has been signed to play with the Eastern College All-Stars in their benefit game against the New York Giants of the National Football League at the Polo Grounds on the night of Sept. 7, it was announced yesterday.

The annual Fathers Association luncheon and the Dramatic Club presentation opened today the seventy-second commencement season of the Peddie School. At the baccalaureate service tomorrow, Dr. Whitney S. K. Yeaple of Rochester, N. Y., a member of the Peddie board of corporators and father of one of the graduates, Whitney S. Yeaple, will preach the sermon.
Major Philip B. Taliaferro, U. S. A., retired, died in Walter Reed General Hospital today at the age of 46. Born in Gloucester County, Va., he was graduated from Rock Hill College, Marylnd, in 1913.

SINCE Daedalus, of Greek mythology, and Icarus, his son, escaped from the Island of by Crete on home-made wings of feathers and wax, man has sought he answer to human-powered flight. Equally intriguing to experimenters in aeronautics have been theprospects of achieving vertical flight, whether by motor or manPower.

America's delegation to the Third International Congress of Business and Professional Women at Budapest early in August will comprise fifty representatives of various units in this country, some of whom will sail on Saturday aboard the Carinthia.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration said today that benefits paid to farmers and administrative expenditures between July, 1937, and June, 1938, totaled $279,075,741.

HERE is source material for a year's installments of thrilling Westerns-road agents, vigilantes, cattle men, prospectors, mine owners, clown politicians, copper barons and that remarkable 600 acres of Butte Hill which furnished
Trenton of the Eastern League today announced the signing of Dallas O'Neall, right-handed pitcher, and the release to Greenville of the South Atlantic League of Johnny (Red) Marion.

Two properties in Connecticut have been sold, reports Previews, Inc. One was the eighteen-acre estate containing a fifteen-room Colonial-style dwelling erected in 1790 in the Chestnut Hill Road section of Litchfield. It was purchased by Henry A. Hoffman of Barrington, R. I., from the estate of A. H. Pierce.

The Broad Channel Bathing Park in Queens will be the scene of the opening A. A. U. outdoor swim-. ming meet for men and women today. Representatives from the St. George Dragons, the Women's Swimming Association, the Shelton Dolphins and the Park Swimming A. A. as well as the home organization are to participate in the aquatic carnival.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ruth Macloon, daughter of Mrs. William Foster White of Belle Haven, to Eugene L. Belisle of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hector
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from James French published recently in THE TIMES reflects public misconception concerning the railroads.

Bonds called last week before maturity were light in volume and consisted mainly of foreign dollar issues, parts of municipal loans and one sizable public utility issue. Almost all the payment dates were in future months.
Supply, contracts valued at $5.794,927 were awarded in the week ended on June 23 by fifteen Federal agencies under the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

PROTESTS against the allocation of nineteen channels to experimental television in the ultrahigh frequency bands were heard by the Federal Communications Commission during the past week, in a move to clear the way for making its frequency allocations between 30,000 and 300,000 kilocycles effective in October.
A new model home was opened yesterday in-the Chester Hill-Manhasset home. community being developed in part of the D'Oench estate on Plandome Road, Manhasset, L. I.

ALTHOUGH nothing definite has come of their talks thus far, the Warners are hopeful that Elisabeth Bergner, who has never been to Hollywood, will accept an offer to make the picturization of James Hilton's "We Are Not Alone."

With residential units representing about 90 per cent of the total, more than 1,500,000 homes, small business establishments and institutional properties have been modernized and repaired under the FHA property improvement program, since its inception in the Summer of 1934.

Miss Catherine Hansell Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Patperson of Haverford and niece of Governor and Mrs. George H. Earle, was married this afternoon to William Innes Forbes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Innes Forbes of Scrooby Villapove.

Charles A. Jones, general manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, called attention to the fact, on the recent fifth anniversary. of the organization, that dn its rolls at the present time are the names of more than 750,000 borrowers who are making satisfactory
A monthly review of business conditions in twenty-five Pennsylvania cities will be published by the Department of Economics at the Pennsylvania State College beginning in July.
With "adventure in safety" as the keynote the annual trek of Girl Scouts to camps in and around New York will commence Thursday with the opening of Camp Andree at Briarcliff Manor, N. Y.
The French liner Paris sailed last night for the Mediterranean and Northern Europe on a thirty-twoday cruise with 458 tourists.

A handsome weeping-beech norms the focal point in the garden of Mrs. Oliver B. Jacobs in Morristown, N. J. It was because of this beech that Mr. and Mrs. Jacobs bought the property. About it the garden has been built during the last twelve years, and its atmosphere gives a feeling of restful simplicity to the entire property.
Stanley I. Filip of Scarsdale, N. Y., a member of the trust department of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, died today in the White Plains Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 49.

THIS Summer's trailer travelers will find the national parks and forests far better prepared to accommodate trailer homes than they were a few years ago. Many have set aside separate camps or separate sections of camps for parking purposes.

SARANAC.-Particular interest attaches to the midsummer meeting of the New York State Bar Association at- Saranac Inn on Friday and Saturday, July 1.and 2, because Of the discussion of judicial matters likely to come before the Constitutional

OTIS SKINNER, dean of the American stage, will be 80 next Tuesday. In the last month he has been ill, but the invalid's role is strange to him. His habit is to keep as young in spirit and almost as vigorous in body as when he and John Drew, Ada Rehan, May Irwin and Edith Kingdon filled Augustine Daly's with fashionable crowds at first nights in the Eighteen Eighties.
Helen and Cornelia Storm, who are believed to be the oldest unmarried twins in the East, celebrated their eighty-fourth birthday anniversary here today at an informal garden party.

Although the news that the United States is considering maintaining a 35,000-ton limit for capital ships in its new naval program received scant publie attention here, nevertheless it caused interest because of the fact that the decision runs counter to everything that has been decided between the United States

While men who fought one another in the Civil War prepare for brotherly reunion on the field of Gettysburg next week, a new echo of the conflict that rocked the Union is sounding about the capital. It is the noise of verbal bombs being fired between Maryland and Virginia over the nice question, seventy-three years after the surrender at Appomattox, whether Marylanders are Yankees or Southerners.

In the face of President Roosevelt's demand for a Congress favorable to his policies, Senator Bennett Champ Clark of Missouri insisted today on his right of political independence. Opening his campaign for Democratic renomination in this "Lead Belt" city, where he delivered the first address in his successful bid for office in 1932, Mr. Clark asserted:

Mike Jacobs took a day off from the ardors of running things at the New York Hippodrome yesterday and remained at his home in Fair Haven, N. J. There he spent the afternoon in his extensive gardens, pruning a petunia here, clipping a rose there and spraying insect powder wherever he thought it might do the most good.
If Mrs. Helen Wills Moody succeeds in winning the Wimbledon singles this year, she will create a record. It is difficult to judge her form on the tournaments she has-played in thus far.

Facing a gloomy prospect on the city's relief problem for the next twelve months, the City Council last week enacted a program of emergency taxes designed to raise $86,579,200 as the city's share of a relief expenditure which will amount to $137,22,000 for the coming year.

The marriage of Miss Nile C. Clemens, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Wilbur T. Clemens, to the Rev. Alan J. Perrine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Perrine of Crestwood, N. Y., took place this afternoon at the Madison Avenue Church.

The Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade yesterday opened the New York campaign in a two weeks' old nation-wide drive to raise $250,000 to bring home and give medical treatment to wounded Americans who have fought in Spain.
AS a by-product of her campaign to develop the' Arcic,. Soviet Russia: is establishing Summer arid Winter resorts on the tundra and organizing cruises on the recently' charted northeast passage,

WHILE not a common place operation even today, nevertheless the removal of foreign bodies from the bronchial tubes, even the lungs, of children is successfully performed with sufficient frequency as to attract only passing notice.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman's announcement of his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat made vacant by the death of Royal S. Copeland and the demand of the American Labor party for a place or places on the State ticket of either the Democratic or Republican party as condition for fusion, have combined to create a confused situation.

ANCHELL-Ida H. (nee Gompertz), beloved wife of the late Oscar, devoted mother of Stella Kellner and Joseph Anchell. Funeral services, at Chapel, 187 South Oxford St., Brooklyn, on Sunday, June 26, at 10 A. M. Interment Acacia Cemetery.

BETWEEN wholly new exhibitions, retrospective and other events, one is inclined to wonder if a new phenomenon is in the making--a Summer season in the New York art world. A dozen shows went on the ways last week and several more are about, to open.

Norway maple shade trees in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx are infested with an insect pest described as the worst in many years. Leaves coated with a sticky white mold are falling prematurely, dropping on cars and clothing and discoloring the sidewalks.

Displaying a smashing game, Captain Cliff Baker'and Captain-elect Jeff Podesta of Princeton fought through two final-round matches to win the District 2 doubles championship of tho national collegiate tennis play-offs on the Church courts today.

Summer homes in all of the popular lake resorts in the. metropolitan territory will be well occupied this week and in 'practically all of the communities special features, ineluding athletic events, have been arranged for the Fourth of July holiday period.

Many of the leading appraisers in the country have accepted positions on the faculty under whose direction the annual courses in real estate appraisal methods will be given this Summer beginning early in July under the auspices of the American Institute of Real Estate
AMERICAN fanciers of Mozart's operas complain, and not without Justice, that not enough performances of enough of the master's lyric works are done in this country in the course of a season.

CAHN-Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cahn (nee Pearl Abel) announce the birth of a girl, Susan Roberta. on June 24, at South Nassau hospital. CARUSO-Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Caruso announce the birth of a son at Hunts Point Hospital.

Six destroyers of the midshipman coastal cruise detachment of Squadron 10 were lying at Piers 72 and 73 last night after a visit to the United States Military Academy at West Point, carrying 160 midshipmen on an annual training and instruction cruise.
Miss Josephine San Fillippo of New York, -top-seeded entrant in the Anne Cummings Memorial tournament for the New Jersey girls' singles tennis championship, led the field into the third round today.

One of the latest houses to be erected in Essex Fells, N. J., has just been completed for Harold F. Reindel, New York attorney. The residence, occupying a large landscaped plot in a wooded hillside section of that community, was designed by the architect Hunter McDonnell and presents an interesting example of the Provincial French type.

AMID eighteen Lindbergh perfusion pumps in the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, each enclosing a vital organ or piece of tissue, officiates Dr. Alexis Carrel, high priest of biology. White-clad women enter, glance at a pump occasionally,
The Browns hammered five pitchers for thirteen hits, including four doubles, a triple and a pair of homers, in defeating the Senators, 12 to 9, today.

BAKST-ROSOW-Mr. and Mrs. Max Rosow wish to announce the marriage of their daughter, Anne, to Mr. Hyman Bakst, taking place this afternoon. BERNSTEIN-WOLF-Mr. Alex Wolf anounces the marriage of his daughter, Alene, to Raymond J. Bernstein, June 24, 1938.

FROM Victor comes another ample re-pressing from the English Sibelius Society. On seven disks, album M-446 contains the Fourth symphony, in A minor.- (Op. 63); "Lemminkainen's Homeward Journey" and six of the seventeen incidental numbers composed for the 1926 Copenhagen production of "The Tempest." All three are played by the London Philharmonic under Sir Thomas Beecham.
BARTON'S Night Hawks will clash tonight with the Brooklyn 'Royal Colored Giants at the opening of the new Barton's Stadium at' 2,000 Jericho Turnpike, New Hyde Park, L. I. Red-hot frankfurters,
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.-Plans are already under way for the coming week-end; which traditionally marks the formal opening of the season here. The length of the Independence Day
Dealings in leading currencies were restricted today in the foreign exchange market here and sterling varied but little.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for June 15 showed that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation had increased from-122.43 per cent on May 31 to 123.80 per cent. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities rose from 85.72 to 87.16 per cent.

Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, and Miss Helen Bernhard of New York gained the final round of the women's New Jersey tennis singley/championship with victories today on the clay courts of the Oritani Field Club.
The Social Security Board reported today that unemployment benefits paid to insured jobless persons in twenty-four States and the District of Columbia totaled $38,105,943 in May.

JULY is"request month" for classical music. at WQXR, whose announcer, through brief announcements for four' days,. recently invited listeners. to submit, the selections they would like to hear. As a result 3,286 ."votes"' for composers and compositions have been -tabulated.

After trying for nearly a year to run a "civilized" program of transient relief without any assistance from the national treasury, the State Department of Social Welfare warned yesterday that it would have to move into a "much more restricted" program unless the Federal Government set up a system of grants-in-aid to help this and other States to care for persons lacking a legal residence.

Miss Marjorie Saltonstall, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Robert Saltonstall of Milton, was married to Joseph Henry Bragdon of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. Henry Bragdon of New Rochelle, N. Y., this afternoon in the First Parish Church of Milton by the minister, the Rev. Vivian T. Pomeroy.

The board of directors of the New York State Federation of Farm Bureaus, meeting today for the first time on Long Island at the home of Ellwood V. Titus, 85-year-old honorary head of the Nassau County Farm Bureau, adopted a resolution calling upon President Roosevelt to raise the price of gold under the authority granted by Congress in order that commodity prices may be restored and business and industry enabled to produce and employ workers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Of more than ordinary significance is the fact that on one day alone in THE NEW YORK TIMES--June 18-on a single page, appeared an editorial, a reader's letter and Anne O'Hare McCormick's column devoted to democracy. Other lays on other pages of THE TIMES democracy frequently keys news and features headlines.
New York's new trade-mark law, designed to help farmers recapture lost markets and give the consumer "what he pays -for" in State agricultural products, becomes effective July 1.

Through the FHA the Electric Water Systems Council points out, insured loans are available for the installation of electric water systems in. many rural homes whichare without running water at present.. The electric water system, ineluding the drilling of a well, is in the eligible list for an insured loan.

EACH of the many radio quiz programs coming on the air are described as "a new and different. kind; and with that promise WNYC joins the parade with the Civil Service Commission cooperating with the station to present a weekly series entitled "The Civil Service Quiz." The opening date is July 1; the time 8 P. M.
Supply, contracts valued at $5.794,927 were awarded in the week ended on June 23 by fifteen Federal agencies under the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.
The Cuban Navy Band gave a concert last night on the Mall in Central Park in honor of Mayor La Guardia. -The Mayor, who was not able to attend, was represented by Colonel William H. Rankin
A SOMEWHAT better face has been put on the automotive Industry during the last week with an increased demand for cars from the field and steady, if not sharp, reduction in dealer inventories.

Captain Harry Manning, who suffered fractures of the jaw and both legs and chest injuries when his private plane crashed near Roosevelt Field yesterday, was reported somewhat improved at Nassau Hospital tonight.

The following Foreign Service changes since June 10 were announced today by the State Department: The assignment of Fletcher Warren of Wolfe City, Texas, as Consul at Kobe has been canceled and. he has been assigned to the Department of State.

Ven Savage and Ed Kingsley of Salt Lake City will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final of the Transmississippi golf tournament. Kingsley, the medalist, eliminated Harry Kaufman of Lincoln today, 3 and 2, and Savage defeated John Kraft of Denver, 2 up.
The new transatlantic mail plane Nordstern was catapulted for its first trial flight from the catapult ship Schwabenland at Hamburg today.

The oval room of the White House, a room decorated with the portraits of past Presidents, with a bust of Lafayette and a clock from the-1906 San Francisco exposition, is periodically, filled with radio apparatus, for here President Roosevelt makes his "fireside chats" to the nation.

BASED on the dollar volume of sales during the twelve-month period ended May 1, Buick was awarded third choice of space in Grand Central Palace for the 1938 Automobile Show Nov. 11 to 17 at the recent drawings for space held by the Automobile Manufacturers Association. Chevrolet drew first place and Plymouth second. W.
IN casual talk and in their fietion Norwegians have a way of dwelling insistently on their skjebne; but although this word means fate or destiny, it must not be confused with fatalism.

After three days of bitter wrangling, officials of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus signed an agreement tonight accepting the American Federation of Actors proposal to move the show back to Winter quarters at Sarasota, Fla. The circus,

Miss Lenore Audrey Haucke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August H. Haucke of this place, was martried this afternoon to Allen Hazen Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hazen, also of Dobbs Ferry, in the Zion Episcopal Church here. Bishop Benjamin' Washburn of Newark performed the ceremony, assisted by the Dr. Charles E. Karsten, rector of the church.
EACH year, as Poland's stature waxes and her strategic importance becomes more obvious, an increasing number of Americans cast about for reliable information about this Phoenix of the nations.

THE Cotton Club folk have moved to Long Beach, L. I., where they have equipped Surfside, a pretty lavish Summer spot, with some new decorations and a first-rate Negro revue. The revue is a compilation of better items once seen In various Cotton
The Noroton Yacht Club Race Week for the John Taylor Arms Trophy for Star Class boats began today with forty-four craft crossing the starting line in a strong southwesterly breeze.

The marriage of Miss Anna Frances Frear, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wright Frear of this city, to Lieutenant (j. g.) William Campbell Gibson Church, U. S. N., son of Captain Albert T. Church, U. S. N., and Mrs. Church of Washington, took place here at noon today in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. A. Abbott Hastings.

The Murray Prior Lien Law, which permits the city to make essential repairs to old-taw tenements and tax the cost against the property was declared constitutional yesterday by the Appellate Division in a unanimous decision.

After a bad start, Miss Lois Kemp of New York, seeded third, survived the women's second round with an 0-6, 6-2, 64 victory today over Miss Katherine Sitterly of Madison in the sixth annual Mountain Lakes Club invitation tennis tourney.

In the last two years more than $10,600,000 was paid to holders of $90,000,000 in eight of the large certificate issues of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, according to a report filed yesterday with Justice Alfred Frankenthaler of the Supreme Court. The trustee praised Justice Frankenthaler for his cooperation.
THE Summer's black cloud looms on the horizon. It is a pleasurable one, bringing with it hot-weather freshness in the way of daytime frocks that really have something different to say for themselves.

Giant presses rolled again tonight and heralded the end of a nine-day strike which kept some 2,000 newspaper workers idle. Settlement of the strike at The Sun-Telegraph and The Press assures more than 500,000 families their home-town Sunday newspapers tomorrow.

Seventy-five young men and women will be commissioned as probationary lieutenants tomorrow night at the annual commencement exercises of the Salvation Army Training College in Mecca Temple. For the first time in the history of the college one of the cadets to be graduated is a fourth generation Salvationist.

Many gardeners these days are learning to start from seed such perennials as may be grown by this method. Some varieties, of course, must be grown from cuttings if they are to come "true"-that is, to be exactly like the parent plantbut the grower wishing to try his hand with the former method will find a long list of excellent sorts to experiment

The marriage of Miss Erminia Occhipinti, daughter of Mrs. Salvatore Occhipinti of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Mr. Occhipinti, to Anthony Joseph Graziano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Graziano of New York, took place yesterday morning in the Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis R. Donovan.

The marriage of Miss Deborah Virginia Wolcott to Charles Williamson Lueders Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Lueders of Cynwyd, Pa., took place here tonight at the home in Colonial Village of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Darwin Stanton Wolcott. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry C. Mitchell.

Vacations for more than 15,000 children and their parents have been arranged through the Summer by the 116 agencies affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, acting president.

Gifts to the University of Pennsylvania for all purposes during the eleven months which ended May 31 amounted to $2,298,514, according to a report made today by President Thomas S. Gates. This sum is more than three times the total of gifts made in the same period of the previous year.

The third season of musical comedies and operettas was inaugurated here tonight on the mammoth marine stage on Zach's Bay. by Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company, and the Shuberts, Lee and J. J., with the aid of the Long Island State Park Commission.

Superior. qualities of Americanmade gloves over foreign products will be emphasized in a national publicity and advertising campaign approved today by the annual convention of the National Association of Leather Glove Manufacturers.

A wind that blew like a desert sirocco through this heat-blistered river valley today curtailed the last real workouts of the eighteen crews in training here for Monday's renewal of the Intercollegite Rowing Association regatta, but did no real harm to the oarsmen.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Carolina, Clinchfield Ohio Ry. Holly Sugar Corp. Interchemical Corp.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Barstow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Byron Prescott Barstow of this place, and Charles Ruch, son of Mrs. Louis Ruch and the late Mr. Ruch, also of this place, were married this afternoon in the First Methodist Episcopal Church here by the Rev. O. C. Nelson, pastor, assisted by the Rev. J. T. Hoogstra of the Christian Reformed Church of Englewood.

Despite a rise of 44 per cent In commercial failures since the start of this year over the corresponding period of 1937, the total for 1938 will be small in comparison with other years, according to estimates by credit executives yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. S. Sloan Colt gave a barn dance tonight at Boulder Point, their estate here, in honor of their daughters, the Misses Marion and Catherine Colt, who will make their debut at the Tuxedo Autumn Ball, and Miss Mary Dickey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Dickey of Chestnut Hill. Pa.

There was too much Curt Davis and not enough Babe Phelps in yesterday's Cardinal-Dodger game at Ebbets Field, so the somewhat deflated Gas House Gang won, 3-1, to even the series and give Davis his seventh victory of the year.

Plans for term deliveries of equity securities on the New York Stock Exchange are virtually complete. Members of the legal staff are whipping them into shape for presentation to the board. of governors on. July 13 as constitutional amendments.

Fourth of July brings a long weekend, and those who are planning to entertain guests are beginning to think of ways to amuse them. There are some new outdoor games in the shops to keep visitors happily active out in the sunshine.
HERE in Paris women are seeking holiday clothes that look as cool as they feel and vice versa.

LAKE GEORGE, N. Y.-The Lake George area is to have another queen, the most popular girl of the many communities which are, helping produce a historical pageant spectacle for July 17, 18, 19 and 20 at Lake George village. A contest to decide who will be queen will begin officially tomorrow under sponsorship of the Lake George Chamber of Commerce.
The United States is balancing the budget--from the bottom up. That fact was disclosed last night in a compilation by The Associated Press from the capitals of the fortyeight States.
Members of the Remington Rand Employes Association called today for an "immediate" National Labor Relations Board election to decide the bargaining agency for employes of the concern in four cities.

The expansion of buying which developed last week in several maJor consumer goods lines marks a definite turning point and probably is the signal for the end of the 1937-38 depression, in the view of traders.

The heat wave that has kept the city sizzling for a week continued unabated yesterday with a high temperature of 87 that lingered for more than an hour in the afternoon before a slow drop last night. It was the eighth consecutive day in which the mercury touched 80 or more.

Seldom has any new scientific development touching the wide field of plant culture received so much publicity as the discovery of the socalled "root-growth" substances. Since the first announcements concerning them, amateur gardeners as well as professional growers have been intrigued by their apparently wonderful powers.
When Hollywood offers a film for the export market it has to be pretty careful. It couldn't expect to sell "It Can't Happen Here" in Germany.

The engagement of Miss Barbara May Stursberg, daughter of Mrs. Albert H. Stursberg of 35 East Seventy-sixth Street and the late Mr. Stursberg, to William H. Harding of Overbrook, Pa., has been announced by her mother.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, Pittsburgh, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $13,500,000 in bonds. Of the net proceedr, the corporation will use $8,500,000 to repay loans from the Union Trust Company and the Mellon National Bank of Pittsburgh.

The initial invitation regatta of the Bay Shore Yacht Club for the 1938 season was marked by a thirty-knot southwester today that forced the thirty-two starters to reef sails and take aboard ballast to keep from upsetting.

THESE are hectic days Indeed for Martin J. Lewis and his associates down at the little 265-seat Fifth Avenue Playhouse, where final preparations are being rushed' for the opening on Friday of Mr. Lewis's one-man show, somewhat euphemistically labeled "First International Film Festival."

One of the chief problems facing the realty industry today lies in the trend toward decentralization of metropolitan business centers, and one of the main hopes for activity in the immediate future lies in modernization of outmoded office structures.

Four years ago the non-fraternity college students at the University of Oklahoma organized the first Independent Men's Association in the United States. Now the movement has spread to thirty-eight colleges and has more than 60,000 members.

The Rev. Conrad F. Rebesher, pastor of St. Joseph's Catholic Church, died last night at the age of 60. Father Rebesher, who had been the spiritual leader of the Negro Catholics of Wilmington for eleven years, had been in poor health since a heart attack four years ago.

The United Mine worKers or America protested in Federal court today against the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company proposal to abandon part of its widespread operations in Pennsylvania's anthracite fields.

Chancellor, New York University and Chairman of the World's Fair Committee on Education The New York World's Fair set up the Committee on Education late in January and requested it to produce a comprehensive plan by the end of June. It was decided, in the interest of speedy planning and efficient administration to keep the membership small and largely local.

Railways of the country are facing a crisis in their affairs. With the adjournment of Congress, the hopes that the requirements for RFC loans to the railways would be liberalized seem for the present to have vanished. Congress will not meet again until next year-unless the railway situation becomes so serious as to compel an extra session-and the railways meanwhile will have to continue to carry on somehow without help from that quarter.

After halting in the first hour yesterday under profit-taking, prices on the Cotton Exchange resumed the upward movement under way in the last two weeks, pushed into new high ground above 8 3/4 cents a pound and .ended at the highest figures since May 13, with gains of 3 to 7 points.

H. George Reinecke of Old Greenwich, export manager for the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company of Stamford, died last night in Philadelphia as the result of a heart .attack. He was 49 years old and had been with the Yale Towne Company for thirty years.

Preparatory to a proposed 5,000,mile non-stop solo flight to Bucharest, Captain Alex Papana, 31-yearold officer of the Rumanian Royal Air Force, announced yesterday that he would take off from Floyd Bennett Field this morning on an experimental trip to New Orleans and Miami. If the test is satisfactory he intends to start the Bucharest flight within a week.

The Nassau Driving Club held its second regular matinee program of the season at the Fair Grounds today, With Allie Cornwell driving Robert Magee's trotters to victory In the first two races.

A NEW outdoor exposure guide as an inexpensive yet practical aid to the wandering photographer has been announced. Selling for only 10 cents, the guide is a sturdy card, one side of which bears a moveable dial.
American and British missionaries - helped direct relief measures today for the suffering thousands pouring into Chengchow from Yellow River flood areas.

Reversing its previous unanimous decision knocking out the Wisconsin Development Authority Act, the State Supreme Court surprised and pleased Governor Philip F. La Follette on Tuesday by upholding the Progressive Administration's power program measure 5 to 2.

Miss Janet Ewing Charles, adopted daughter of Miss Emily L. Charles of Inverdale, this place, was married this afternoon in the garden of the latter's home to Robert Hine Reynolds, son of Dr. and Mrs. Rollo G. Reynolds of New York.

There is definite hope, though qualified-at least in government quarters-that the Spanish situation has been eased somewhat, and some British politicians and diplomats have begun to allow themselves to play with the idea that so far as Spain is concerned there is blue in the European sky.

From The Herald Tribune (Rep.) The President's fireside speeches have become stereotyped in form by this time. They remain as fresh and original in phraseology and emotional appeal as ever. By every standard the Friday night chat was one of his best. If he had ever last Winter faltered in his self-confidence or hesitated as to his political course, here was an end of doubts.

A belief that the European war clouds were dissolving and "the worst is over" was expressed here this evening by Fulvio Suvich, the Italian Ambassador, the guest of ItalianAmerican Societies of Philadelphia at a testimonial dinner.

The Grand Steeplechase, held at Auteuil, brilliantly opened the Grande Semaine. Big velvet hats made their first appearance in all-black or rich colors. In sharp contrast were white pique hats; many were shaped like an American gob's hat with a lofty brim,

Plans are virtually completed for the formation of the "Latin American Workers' Federation," to embrace the labor elements in all parts of Central and South America, the Popular, organ of the Mexican Federation of Workers (C.T.M.) reports today.

Members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, who are employed by the B. M. T; will hold section meetings within the next three weeks to ratify the pension program upon which the union and the company agreed on Friday, Charles H. MacMahon, international vice president of the union, announced yesterday.
Suits with two pairs of trousers will not be included in the $10,000,000 worth of surplus clothing the Works Progress Administration plans to distribute to men and boys on home relief.

Miss Ruth C. Lovell, daughter of Earl Brink Lovell of Montclair and the late Mrs. Lovell, was married this afternoon to Charles R. D. Hemmersley, also of Montclair. The ceremony was performed in the First Baptist Church, here, by the pastor, the Rev. Albert B. Cohoe.

Eugene R. Tappen, secretary of the New York Curb Exchange since 1928 and associated with it since 1912, has resigned, effective on Aug. 31, on account of ill health. The board of governors of the.Curb has adopted resolutions of appreciation and regret.

To teach the multitude something about Mendel's laws and hence how we inherit blue eyes or black hair from our parents and grandparents the University of California has made a series of dolls and slides for the Golden Gate Exposition to be opened next year at San Francisco.

Miss Florence Margaret Shoemaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Shoemaker of Caldwell, was E married to William Sherman Corwin Jr., son of- Mrs. Lola T. Corwin of Newark, today in St.Aloysius Church here by the Rev. James Foley.
John F. Montgomery, United States Minister to Hungary, and Mrs. Montgomery arrived on the Washington and are at the SherryNetherland.

HOLLYWOOD. IF the customers want to draw a parallel between the social and economic problems treated in "If I Were King" and those of today, that is their affair. Paramount is insistent that no propaganda is involved and that the picture,; which is based upon a highly fictonized and romanticized conception of the life of Frangols Villon, is entertainment, only that and nothing more.

The thirtieth semi-annual golf tournament of the Pease Elliman organization will be held at the North Hills Country Club, Douglaston, L. I., Tuesday. Robert A. Granniss, S. R. Firestone and Lawrence B. Elliman Jr. comprise the committee.

BENJAMIN GROSBAYNE, who since 1931 has been Professor of Music and chairman of the Music Department of Brooklyn College, has been granted a sabbatical leave in order that he may fulfill engagements to conduct leading orchestras in a series of concerts in Europe next Fall. Mr.
David Burt, Harvard ace, captured the New-England district intercollegiate tennis singles championship today by defeating Howie Stephens of Yale, 6-4, 6-3, 2-6, 6-2..

The most desirable house for a family to buy and the one which at the same time best secures the purchaser's equity and the lender's investment is one that meets certain fundamental standards, states the fourth annual report of the FHA.

Miss Louise Raymond of Smith College returned the girls' intercollegiate tennis championship to the East today as she downed Miss Elaine Fiscliel of the University of California at Los Angeles at the Longwood Cricket Club, 2-6, 3, 6-2.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt arrived today to inspect Beaulieu, which is being opened and which she and General Vanderbilt will occupy shortly. She came from New York on the Winchester, and had among her guests Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice and William S. Burden.

Susan Glaspell, dramatist and Pulitzer Prize winner, will be the speaker tonight at the commencement exercises of the Robert Louis Stevenson School, to be held at 8 o'clock in the Town Hall, 113 West Forty-third Street. Jane Baumann, 15-year-old daughter of Ludwig Baumann, will be valedictorian, and Patty Harris,

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bartlett Lee announced this evening at a dinner in their home here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Newcomb Lee, to William Esmond Rowley, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Esmond Rowley, of Newton Center, Mass.
Two Viennese musicians known to American theatre audiences entered this country last week as immigrants under the Austrian quota. They were accompanied by their wives and will seek citizenship here.

Mail orders were lighter in volume last week than in the preceding week, according to a summary of wholesale market activity prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

Although improvement in major industrial indices has thus far been of minor proportions, according to monthly Industries Service review published by Fenner Beane, New York Stock Exchange members, basic price and other adjustments under way suggest that the long awaited revival in business activity may not be far off.

A special meeting of shareholders of the National Power and Light Company has been called for July 8 to ratify the sale of the Tennessee Public Service Company, a subsidiary serving Knoxville, to the city and the Tennessee Valley Authority, it was announced yesterday by P. B. Sawyer, president of National Power and Light.

Charles Amandoles of Latourette in Staten Island, open champion and medalist in the Metropolitan Golf Association public links title tournament, moved into the semi-finals at the Aviation Golf Club today, beating Eric Lenaeus of Branch Brook, 1 up.

Tanned and in fine physical condition, 1,150 members of the "service" units, the 102d Engineers of Manhattan and the 102d Medical Regiment, made up of units from up-State, completed at Camp Smith here at noon today the first two weeks of Summer training for the State National Guard.

Two justices of the Appellate Division asserted in a decision yesterday that the sub-metering of electrical current was subject to the emergency utility tax laws and that the laws were constitutional. Their declaration was made in connection with a suit brought by the 1,024 Third Avenue Corporation for a judgment declaring it exempt from the tax on sub-metered current.

Depression has not reduced in number those who will attend Summer school at the colleges this year. On the contrary there are increases in registration in many places. In Boston, for example, the largest enrollment in the history of Boston University's Summer session is expected.

HOLLYWOOD. UP to a year ago there was prospect that opera was at last to marry the films. Attaches were dashing to and from Milan and Hollywood. Large woodwardia ferns, Easter lilies and a profusion of white snapdragons decorated the Church of the Messiah here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Jane Travers, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edward Schofield Travers, to Burrows Sloan Jr., son of Mrs. Burrows Sloan of New York, Philadelphia and Watch Hill, R. I., and the late Mr. Sloan.

A new yachting crossroads of the western world swung into full operation last week, so close to Broadway that high buildings almost cast shadows across the decks. Tied up at the same bulkheads may be found craft from the fresh water of Lake Michigan gently rubbing strakes with those encrusted with the tropic brine of Biscayne Bay.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody drew on her incomparable reserves of skill rnd courage today to overcome a 5-1 deficit and defeat Mrs. Bobbie Heine Miller of South Africa, 8-6, 6-4, in the fourth round of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

License Commissioner Paul Moss is without authority to deny a license for the erection of a theatre on the ground that it would cause adverse traffic conditions, the Appellate Division held in a four-toone decision handed down yesterday.

Cooperation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the financing of real estate renovation projects costing $100,000 or more in this city is being sought by the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, the latter announced yesterday. Thomas Ahearn,

Opening yesterday 'with a discussion of the uses of radio in education, and closing on June 30 with an address by President Roosevelt and a demonstration of the civic activities of New York, the convention of the National Education Association of the United States will engage the attention of thousands of New Yorkers and will bring other thousands from out of town.

Announcement was made yesterday that Miss Marion Hollins, administratrix of the estate of her mother, .the late Mrs: Harry B. Hollins, wife of the former banker, is placing on the market several of the properties owned by the Hollins family in and- around East Islip, L. I., for many years.

The Taconic State Park Commission announced acceptance today of a 130-acre estate at Staatsburg, Dutchess County, once the home of General Morgan Lewis, a former Governor of New York and signer of the Declaration of Independence.
