With search and seizure and wiretapping still the leading topics, the Constitutional Convention has arrived at a stage where the scene of its principal activities shift from the seclusion of committee rooms to the broader forum of the convention floor and where all the delegates will become participants in debates and decisions, preparatory to a general revision of the State's fundamental law.

Following the completion of two large apartment houses on Elwood Place and West Elm Street here, comes the announcement that a sixstory apartment house is to be built on the Joseph Christiano tract on West Elm Street. Permisson has been granetd by the Board of Appeals of the Zoning Commission for the project.

The defeat of Yale's crews at the hands of Harvard oarsmen yesterday seemed to have an adverse effect on Winthrop C. Hoyt and his brother,E. W. (Red) Hoyt, two exElis, in the annual Cherry Valley four-ball invitation golf tourney today.

A marriage of international interest took place this afternoon at Mannetto Hill Farm, the historic Montfort homestead here, when Miss Marian Kingsland and Count Hans Christoph Seherr-Thoss were married in a garden on the hill before an altar of garden flowers.

PERHAPS we have been wrong in blaming the Hays office and the commercially minded producers for the screen's reluctance even to tiptoe along the jagged edges of contemporary problems.

The old homestead, erected about seventy-five years ago, on the northwest corner of Bergen Avenue and Bergen. Square, in the Journal Square section of Jersey City, N. J., is being demolished to make way for a three-story and basement store and office building.

Two parties were given in New Jersey last night and one on Long Island to introduce four young women to society. They were among the earliest of the festivities planned for the debutantes of the 1938-39 season.

A fierce counter-attack was being launched by Chinese troops yesterday against the Japanese force that landed on the south bank of the Yangtze River Friday about ten miles from Matang, where the river is blocked by a boom. Chinese reinforcements were joining the attack.
Japanese control of communications in North China leads to many irksome and to some few amusing conditions for railway travelers.

CIVILIZATION has arrived at a centenary. It is just a hundred years next Tuesday since a slim young girl was arrayed in gorgeous vestments and seated in an old wooden chair while a golden crown was placed upon her head. Princes, peers and people cried in a loud voice, "God save Queen Victoria!"

Beginning today, brief religious services will be held each Sunday at 8 A. M. at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church, Henry Hudson Parkway and 247th Street, for loose families who wish to spend the day in the country and yet do not wish to neglect their religious duties."

There is a multiplicity of indications that Japan has bitten off more in China than she can chew. Military victories sne has won, to be sure, and she will probably win more battles. But for Japan it is not primarily a matter of defeating Chinese forces in pitched conflict. That will not win her war for her.
Irving C. Treat, founder and president of the hardware and sporting goods firm of Clapp Treat, died today at the age of 75. He suffered. a nervous breakdown in Florida last March.

Fenimore C. Goode, formerly head of the firm beating his name, who tomorrow takes office as vice president of the Junior Leasing Corporation, a subsidiary of the Trinity Church Corporation, has had a long career as a real estate man. He will have charge of its brokerage and renting activities.
Speakers, including former Governor Harold G. Hoffman, were named today to address the thirteenth annual League College of the National League of Teachers Associations, July 4 to 15.

How the British freighter African Trader narrowly escaped being "kidnapped" on the high seas by a Rebel seaplane and forced to proceed to Majorca is told by Captain William Frederick Wilkinson and his crew.

Due to the increasing popularity of the shower cabinet, manufacfacturers this year are offering fourteen different models in more than fifty sizes, reports the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. The sales volume, it is stated, showed a 50 per cent advance in 1937 over 1936.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marie Snyder, daughter of Dr. Rex Garfield Snyder of New York, and of Mrs. Teresa O'Neil of Lausanne and Cannes, to Dr. Ernesto Vallenilla y Diaz, son of Vicente Vallenilla of Caracas, Venezuela.

The marriage of Miss Ada Everett Waddell, daughter of Mrs. Winfred Everett Reynolds of this city, and the late N. Everett Waddell, to Kenneth Fuller Rolph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philo Fuller Rolph, also of New York, took place last night in All- Angels Church. Miss Monica Rainbault, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Victor Rainbault of Sao Paulo, Brazil, was married to John Ogilvy Rennie of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ogilvy Rennie of Seamore Court, Park Lane, London, here yesterday morning in the chantry of St. Thomas Church.

Mr. and Mrs. William John Welsh Jr. of 14 Fairway Close, Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arla Burnley Welsh, to Edward L. Dame of Merion, Pa., son of Mrs. Frank L. Dame of Garden City and the late Mr. Dame.

Four years of successful operation in providing means for' home owning and financing have just been closed by the Federal Housing Administration and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The latter marked the fourth anniversary last week, while the FHA will formally round out its four years of activity tomorrow.

As the result of recently received financial support, the Loomis Sanatorium, one of the pioneer tuberculosis hospitals in the country, will remain open throughout the Summer and for at least part of the Fall, it was announced yesterday. The institution,

A resolution to provide for "a limited number of Lutheran pastors who have been compelled to leave Germany" has been adopted by the Board of American Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America.

The Pitcher Act, which permits the Controller of New York State to. require payment bonds on all State contracts for the protection of material men, suppliers and subcontractors, will reduce present annual credit losses on State contracts of over $1,500,000-to a "very small figure,"

THE Chinese Soviet dollar of Shensi and Szechwan. Provinces has made its appearance in this country. These dollar pieces were not known until quite recently, and at present there are two main types, 1932 and 1934.

IT may be said, without fear of successful contradiction, that the programs arranged by JoseIturbi and Alexander Smallens for the opening concerts of the Lewisohn Stadium season are about 200 per cent better balanced and more interesting than the average program that the PhilharmonicSymphony Society presented to their subscribers during the Winter season.

THE four-day observance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Battle of- Gettysburg, which begins in the little Pennsylvania town next Friday, July 1, is expected to' attract thousands of visitors.' Preparations have been made to accomniodate 100,000 on each: of the four days.

About 500 persons of Yugoslav extraction living in the metropolitan area visited the Yadran (Adriatic), barkentine used by the Yugoslav Navy for training cadets, wharfed at Pier 99, at West Fiftyninth Street, yesterday afternoon.

One of the older and well occupied apartment houses in Forest Hills, L. I., being the six-story structure known as Hawthorne Court, has been sold by the Cord Meyer Development Company to Charles Stein of Brooklyn, for investment.

With a collective eye toward Buffalo, where next week-end they will encounter much more tubborn opposition in the national A. A. U. senior track and field championships, the New York Athletic Club athletes today at Glen Park again romped off with the metropolitan senior crown. It's a habit with them.

The American Olympic Committee will hold an organization meeting tonight at the New York Athletic Club, where plans will be made for the 1940 Olympic.Games. Athletic leaders from all sections of the country will assemble for the conclave, with President Avery Brundage of Chicago presiding.

The use of structural glass for bathrooms, pointed out a decorator, is becoming more popular. The material comes in practically every conceivable color. Structural glassis not only ornamental but is also highly practical. It has the advantages of not checking, fading, staining or crazing. Glass is also easy to clean and keep clean ...
England's prospects of a substantial first-inning lead in the second cricket test match with Australia appeared bright as the teams prepared for the third day's play at Lord's Monday.

Fears of a wet harvest in the Winter wheat belt combined with strength in securities to bring about a sharp advance in the price of futures on North American grain exchanges today following an easy opening.

Miss Virginia MacDonald Prout, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Peck Prout of this place and New York, was married here this afternoon to Frederick Gilbert, son of Mrs. Dudley Gilroy of Chantilly, France, and of Albert Chatfield Gilbert of Utica, N. Y., in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church.
The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to allow motor carriers operating in the central territory to make further reductions in their rates.

Henry Steers Lake, retired New York manufacturer and merchant, died yesterday at Hollywood Hospital at the age of 62. Mr. Lake's grandfather, George Steers, designed the yacht America which in 1851 brought to this country the America's Cup, race trophy.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.-With the approach of the holiday week end the hotels and resorts of the Poconos and the Delaware Valley are filling up to near capacity. Everywhere preparations are being made to care for one of the largest crowds of the season.

ASHEVILLE, N. C.--A golf tournament and the annual convention of the National Pi Beta Phi Sorority will feature the calendar here this week. The Carolinas Golf Association championship, won last year by Lewis Johnson Jr. of Charleston,...

With the mercury in the nineties outside and everybody gasping for air, the steam heat was turned on at the court house today, almost stifling attaches and visitors. Unsuspecting office workers commenting about the intense heat expressed compassion for outside toilers since the spacious building usually is one of the coolest spots in town.

An intimate picture of the Yellow River is presented in the following article. For nineteen years Mr. Todd has been engaged in civil engineering in China; he was consulting engineer of the Yellow River Commission when the work of controlling that great stream was suspended by the war.
In connection with the National Education Association convention, opening here this afternoon, the Board of Education has issued a booklet entitled "All the Children Welcome All the Teachers."

The touring German weight-lifting team made its farewell American appearance last night at the New York Turn Hall by conquering a selected United States squad, 3844.5 to 3564.0. Competition was in three lifts, the military press, the snatch and the clear and jerk.

Stocks closed strong, steel shares leading, with gains of 1 to 4 points in largest trading since April 9; turnover, 1,161,700 shares. United States Government and other bonds generally higher; trading 'heaviest since May 7; transactions, $3,534,475.

A threat by Loyalist Spain to retaliate for air raids, interpreted as meaning attacks on Italian cities, caused an abrupt warning from Italy last night that such action would bring warlike measures. That notice was delivered to Foreign Minister Bonnet in Paris.

Two women were knocked down and robbed by two men described to the police as young Negroes, as they were walking in Crotona Park South, near Cottage Place, in the Bronx, at about 10:30 o'clock last night. Both women were treated by an ambulance doctor from Morrisania Hospital.

Mrs. James C. Rogerson of New York and Greenwich, Conn., was found dead in her penthouse apartment at 460 Park Avenue shortly before 8 o'clock last night. The police, after an investigation by Dr. Robert C. Fisher, assistant medical examiner, listed the death as caused by the heat.

Sergeant Grant R. Bacon of the Essex Troop, Newark, shot a perfect score of twenty consecutive bullseyes to win the Hoffman Individual Gold Medal match in the closing shoot of the Old Guard of New York matches at' the State Rifle Range here today. Four others shot perfect scores but Bacon had more in the inner circle of the bullseye and won.

Viscount Cecil, president of the League of Nations Union, has followed the lead of the Duchess of Atholl and has refused to become the government whip as the result of a disagreement with the government's policy over Spain.

Grocery manufacturers, putting their merchandise under resale price maintenance laws, are making no attempt to fix prices which will show a profit to retailers, but on the contrary are establishing the quotations at levels which will merely insure against below-cost selling,
A SERIES of ten lecture-recitals bearing the general title "From Early Folk-Songs to Modern Jazz," will be given on Wednesday afternoons, at 5:30 o'clock, next season, at Town Hall.

The first Polish Olympics, which attracted nearly 600 contestants and more than 3,000 spectators to the University of Pittsburgh Stadium, furnished a colorful backdrop today for a new display of Miss Stella Walsh's athletic prowess.

DARTS, N. Y.-Inaugurating the opening of the 1988 vacation season, this Adirondack resort will feature a- program of sports and other entertainment over the Fourth of July week-end, starting with the annual opening ball on the evening of July 2.

JUST twenty-five years ago the Boy Scouts of America, then only three years in existence, rendered public service at Gettysburg, Pa., during the fiftieth. anniversary reunion of the Battle of Gettysburg.

In a three-to-one decision, the Appellate Division affirmed yesterday a ruling by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman holding that Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the Municipal Civil Service, Commission were without power to require lifeguards who performed their duties satisfactorily last year to pass a practical test before being reappointed this year.

American public opinion is turning away from isolation under the pressure of world events toward its old feeling of international cooperation, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said today in an address at the Dunford House Richard Cobden Memorial at Midhurst, Sussex.

Several weekly broadcasts, under the auspices of Rutgers University, will be broadcast by WOR on a "guarantee time basis," according to Professor H. J. Baker, extension service director. He'explains that this arrangement for "constructive service to adult education will obviate any difficulties that might arise from-commercially sponsored programs asking for the periods."

THE United States, which believed itself insulated against the intrigues of Europe and the Far East, was startled last Monday when a Federal grand jury in New York indicted eighteen persons, three of them officers of the German military and naval intelligence services, for espionage.

CAPTAIN ASHLEY C. M'KINLEY was last week making test flights in a Piper sea plane equipped with new-type floats. The floats are made of inflated balloon cloth and were invented by him. In two hours last Sunday he made twenty take-offs and landings from his base at Babylon, L. I. 'He said that the performance of his ship with the new floats was superior to that of the same type equipped with metal pontoons.

Representative Bruce Barton, Republican, of New York, pictured the middle classes in an address here tonight as "bruised and bleeding" between "the millstones of bad business and high taxes." The remedy, he told the New England Conference of Young Republicans, was to re-establish at the polls in the Fall campaign the independence of Congress.

Criticism of the American shipping subsidy expressed during the recent visit of the Norwegian American liner Oslofjord to New York on her maiden voyage was answered yesterday by Commander Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, shipping operators.

George H. Goodman, state director of the Works Progress Administration, announced late today a change in the State's WPA classification which would give Kentucky's 62,000 WPA workers a wage increase aggregating about $700,000 a month.

Scoring four goals in the last two periods, Mike Phipps's Gulf Stream side beat Roslyn, 6 to 3, on Cochran Field in one of two Brook League games in the Meadow Brook Club Cup polo tournament today. The victory was the second in two touiney starts for Gulf Stream.

The second offering of propertiesowned by the Town of Greenburgh, Westchester County, at auction in the Westchester County Center in White Plains last week resulted in the sale of 180 lots and ten acreage parcels for an aggregate amount of $32,500.

Forty-seven students at Hunter College have been elected as editors of publications, committee, chairmen and officers of clubs for the Fall semester, according to an announcement by Jean Goodman, newly elected president of the Student Self-Government Association of the college.

Seventeen-year-old Patricia Laursen, Akron, Ohio, won the women's championship in the tenth annual great Eastern skeet competition on the Remington range at Lordship today in a three--cornered shoot-off.

Title has been taken by Dr. and Mrs. William F. McDermott of New York City from Lawrence P.roperties to a small acreage plot on which a residence has just been completed, on Oak Bend, Lawrence Park West, Bronxville, Westchester County.

Saga, skippered by her owner, Johnston de Forest, finished two seconds ahead of Henry S. Morgan's Djinn, piloted by Morgan, to win the six-meter race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club regatta in Long Island Sound today. A fresh breeze out of the Southwest gave the race a zest that has been lacking in the recent trials of this class.
Formal opening of a new residential center in Elmhurst, Queens County, will be made today, when the first model house in the initial group of twenty-five homes will be ready for inspection.

The industrial structure is merely drifting at the moment and the immediate future is still too obscure to make any but a restricted purchasing policy advisable, according to the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents issued yesterday.
The usual Nazi boast that vast public works cost nothing in terms of the "new economics" was contradicted by Herr Hitler's speech at the inauguration of the reconstruction of Berlin.

The outcome of the struggle of liberal Democrats against their extreme New Deal wing, and of their effort to control the 1940 convention, may hinge on the reported plan of New York State Republicans to make an alliance with the American Labor party.

Foreign trade statistics for the month of May will be released in a new form this month as a result of suggestions made to the United States Department of Commerce by the National Council of American Importers, Inc.

Mrs. Mathilda O'Connor Vance of this city, widow of Representative Robert J. Vance and publisher of The New Britain Herald, died early tonight at her home. She was one of the few women in recent years to head a newspaper in Connecticut.

The International Committee of Bankers on Mexico was blocked again yesterday from obtaining judicial approval of its acts as trustee for investors in Mexican securities when the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court ruled

GRAHAM GREENE belongs to the generation, born in the first decade of this century, which escaped active participation in the war, but not its consequences. Unlike many contemporary English writers, his work evidences a fixed determination to grapple with the diffi-. culties of our own time.

The track and field teams carrying the colors of P. S. 44 of Brooklyn scored a double triumph when they topped the fields in their respective divisions, fifth and sixth years, and seventh and eighth years in the competition held by the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday at Wingate Field.

After experiencing a brief period of irregularity at the outset, the stock market resumed its sharp advance during the. two-hour session yesterday. Led by steel shares, the principal issues. finished with net gains- of 1 to 4 points.

A course of training for design in industry will be conducted at the forthcoming SUmmer session at Columbia University, beginning July 6 and continuing for six weeks. Professor Frederick J. Kiesler, member of the Viennese and Dutch schools of modern furniture design, will lecture on. contemporary furniture design.
At the recent meeting of the Women's Eastern Golf Association at the Philadelphia Country Club a discussion arose concerning the method of playing the intercity team matches for the Griscom Cup.

Joseph F. Cooke of 729 Park Avenue, Hoboken, superintendent of the photo engraving department of the World-Telegram, died yesterday in Mt. Sinai Hospital following an operation at the age of 49. Mr. Cooke, who was formerly foreman of the photo-engraving department of THE NEW YORK TIMES, installed the photo-engraving plant of the World-Telegram when its new building was opened in 1931.

Fears that the government's buy-and-give program, newest phase of the relief-recovery effort, might further dislocate the hard-pressed distributive industries were expressed here today as representatives of trade associations tried unsuccessfully to learn the potential scope of that activity.

Without minute particles of dust there would be no fogs. Each particle acts as a nucleus around which water clusters. Counts made by Dr. G. R. Wait of Department of Magnetism of the Carnegie Institution of Washington show that every time we smoke we send out fine particles which serve as such condensation nuclei.

New orders booked for fabricated structural steel in May were 74,410 tons, compared with 92,130 in April and 122,939 in the same month last year. For the first five months of this year contracts closed totaled 388,261 tons, against 743,247 in the 1937 period.

What appears destined to be the greatest of all national A. A. U. track and field championships will be staged in the new $2,000,000 Civic Stadium in Buffalo Saturday and Sunday with virtually every standout performer in the United States scheduled to compete.

Officials of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate, were re-elected by an overwhelming majority in balloting yesterday at the Central Opera House, 205 East Sixty-seventh Street.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that profits from short sales of stock that are "protected" by equivalent certificates in the "long account" of the customer are taxable as ordinary income, as differentiated from capital gain.

Marking a major change from the ultra-cautious attitude of the last few months, retail merchandisers here began last week to cover commitments three months ahead and to revise upward their expectations on Fall trade.

Samuel Madell, East Coast repretentative of the International Longshoremen's and Warehouse- Sgt. men's Union, which was designated recently by the National Labor Board as bargaining agent of West Coast pier workers, made public a statement yesterday challenging Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, on the latter's threat of a strike on the East Coast in protest against the board's decision.
IN "The Rest of the World, Mr. Hauser writes about the unrest of the nations of the world. His subject is the peril of another great war and the means, if any, of averting a world-wide conflict.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Stewart H. Hartshorn of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Catherine Jennette Hartshorn, to Crawford Jennings Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Campbell of Cooperstown, N. Y.

Governor A. B. Chandler opened his campaign for the Senate here today by declaring he was a supporter of President Roosevelt and that he wanted the Democratic voters to decide between him and Senate Majority Leader Alben W. Barkley on the basis of their records.
Mrs. Samuel Gompers, widow of the founder of the American Federation of Labor, is employed as a field supervisor in the WPA adult education project, it became known yesterday.
The World Center for Women's Archives, which has a long list of notable men and women on its board of directors and among its sponsors, is now organizing its archives committees in nine States.

SOLOISTS at the Stadium this week are Grace Moore, who will be heard tomorrow night, and Beveridge Webster, young American pianist, who will play the Tchaikovsky piano concerto with the orchestra on Thursday.

Soviet industry is now engaged in a concerted effort to carry out the Kremlin's demands of last December to reform Stakhanoffism into a system that will increase the production of labor in general instead of limiting increases, as has so often happened, to a few star performers in Stakhanoffism.

Construction work was started last week on a new 590-seat theatre and -an adjoining two-story shop building on the north side of Fiftythird Street, directly behind the row of stores on the west side of Park Avenue.
DURING vacation time, when there is leisure for experimentation by photographers, numerous camera enthusiasts try out one phase or another of pinhole photography.

FROM Germany comes news that a 2,000 h. p. airplane Diesel is being rushed to completion and may be ready for its tests this year. Junkers is building this engine, departing from their six-cylinder, two-crank construction; in favor of a twenty-four cylinder, four-crank design.

Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, will seek on Tuesday to persuade Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson to reconsider his recent ruling that the receiver, although entitled to disaffirm the company's 999-year lease of its elevated lines, must continue to provide free transfer service between the subway system and the Third Avenue elevated line at 149th Street in the Bronx.

Miss Eleanor Mae Murphy, daughter of Governor and Mrs. Francis P. Murphy of New Hampshire, today was married to Donald W. Erion of Buffalo, N. Y., football captain at Dartmouth In 1935. The ceremony was performed in St. Patrick's Church by the Most Rev. John B. Peterson, Catholic Bishop of Manchester, who was assisted by the Rev. Lancelot F. Quinn and the Rev. Patrick J. Scott, the pastor.

Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Exhibitors, headed a list of a score of important callers received by President Roosevelt during a strenuous day devoted largely to detail work in preparation for his departure from Washington tomorrow.

Governor Lehman announced today the appointment of the commission which is to administer the $24,000,000 a year State insurance fund. The board consists of eight non-salaried- commissioners in addition to the State Industrial Commissioner, Elmer F. Andrews.

In grand condition and giving another flawless performance, the imported smooth-haired foxterrier Ch. Nornay Saddler, from the Wissaboo Kennels of Old Westbury, L. I., today gained his twenty-fourth bestin-show award to climax the tenth annual Monmouth County Kennel Club exhibition.

RETAIL trade last week again moved closer to the sales figures of 1937. The sharp upturn in the stock market and evidences of. improvement in general business undoubtedly led to freer buying in the stores.

ON the Hudson River at Poughkeepsie tomorrow, 3.000 miles from their home waters, eight strong muscled young men from the Far West will be rowing to keep a tradition intact. They are the crew from the University of Washington, and the tradition is victory.
Police cars with loudspeakers appeared on Berlin streets today warning against violations of the new "traffic duties."
The Geological Society of America has granted a total of $17,073.50 for nineteen research projects in the United States, Mexico and Canada this Summer.

Ruling that city employes acquired no title to a job by merely filling it, the Appellate Division dismissed yesterday a suit brought by Sara. G. Kearns and eleven others for a judgment declaring that they were clerical assistants in the Board of Education.

THE SUMMER schedule in Europe may contain events of a more spectacular character but certainly -none of more genuine importance than the International Congress of 'Dance Considered as a Means of Education, which is to be held in Paris July 15-19.

Stephen Berrien of Upper Montclair and F. L. Andrews of the home club shot a three-under-par 68 today to assume a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Maplewood Country Club's sixth annual member-guest invitation golf tournament for the Roche Memorial trophy.

Prime Minister Eamon de Valera had the satisfaction of seeing the coping stone placed upon his new State of Eire in Dublin under the happiest auspices today when 78-year-old Dr. Douglas Hyde, Gaelic scholar, poet and litterateur, assumed office as the first President. The days of the Irish Free State are gone and a new era rich in promise opens before the country.

Fortyseven of the forty-eight patrol bombers which today engaged in the navy's largest mass distance flight arrived at the Sand Point naval air base on Lake Washington after a 1,200-mile nonstop flight from San Diego, Calif.

William M. Schroth, 29 years old, of 90 South Oraton Parkway, East Orange, was found dead today in South Mountain Reservation here, with the left front wheel of his coupe resting on his neck. Following an autopsy, Dr. Harrison Martland, Essex County medical examiner, said death was accidental and resulted from strangulation.

Housewives will be glad when the New York Athletic Club's cruiser race to Block Island is over. They'll be able to see their rugs and carpets again. And perhaps sweep up dust that has been gathering under Coast Survey. charts.
Applicants for marriage licenses crowded the office of the City Clerk in Manhattan and the offices of the deputy city clerks in other boroughs yesterday.
Testimony by James B. Ogden, 45, former postmaster at Avalon, on Santa Catalina Island, that he stole postal funds to make "voluntary" contributions to a Democratic campaign committee created

THE condition of the dramatic stage in Chicago has been a matter of deep concern among its followers ever since the shadows of economic weeks blight began to lengthen over the land in the long ago of 1930. During the lean years that followed its heartbeat was often faint and erratic, its pulse thready and irreguJar.

SWIFTER, safer. and more comfortable than ever, giant streamlined buses are now leaving' cities all over the country, carrying vacationistss and others over the 3,000,000 -miles of highways that lead to every mountain park, every seaside resort and to every historic -spot in the nation.

The huge spending-lending drive, designed by President Roosevelt and his economic planners to lead the country back to the highroad of recovery, got under way this week to the accompaniment of a rising stock market and other manifestations long regarded as harbingers of better days.

A SCORE of bills affecting the radio industry died automatically when the 75th Congress adjourned, with a record of killing more radio legislation than it enacted. After ignoring radio matters for almost its entire three sessions, Congress took a sudden interest in pending bills during the closing weeks, only to reject them.
FLAGSTAFF, Ariz.-On next Thursday some twenty Indian tribes will pitch their camps in the "Powwow Grounds" in Flagstaff.

This city, too, is having a World's Fair. On a made island nestling under the towering shoulder of Yerba Buena, navy base in San Francisco Bay, an exposition is under construction to which it is expected more than 20,000,000 persons will be attracted between Feb. 18 and Dec. 2, 1939.

MaceBrown, ace relief pitcher of the Pirates, received credit for his tenth victory today, although he pitched only two and two-thirds innings, as the Bucs continued their victorious tour of the East by defeating the Bees, 8 to 7, in the series opener.
INVISIBLE WEAPONS. By. John Rhode. 294 pp. New York: Dodd, Mea Co. $2.

Adopting a movement that originated in the Middle-West about two months ago, the Civic and Business Federation of White Plains has launched a drive to increase employment by stimulating wholesale and retail sales under the slogan "Sales Mean Jobs."

Felix Frankfurter in an address here today defined the Constitution as a charter of broad powers, and not a code which prescribed in detail the answers to the social problems of all time. Today, he asserted, the Supreme Court is "back to the high tide of judicial negation until after the 1938 elections."

In a high-tension laboratory at Sharon, Pa., yesterday Dr. P. L. Bellaschi Westinghouse research engineer, played with artificial lightning/strokes of 3,000,000 volts. He split poles as if with some invisible gigantic axe. The laboratory was established not for the purpose of entertaining visitors

The yawl Baruna, owned by H. C. Taylor, was first of the fleet of forty-two yachts to reach Bermuda from Newport, R. I., today. She arrived after 635 miles of ocean sailing at 10:05:42, making her elapsed time for the trip 3 days 21 hours 5 minutes 42 seconds.

After listening for a month to angry householders who complained that their trousers pockets had been looted while they slept, Brooklyn detectives believed yesterday that they had halted the epidemic of thefts by the arrest of a Broadway waiter who finished work too early.

With Harold S. Vanderbilt at the helm, Van S. Merle-Smith's Seven Seas once again gave her Twelve-Meter lass rivals a clear view of her heels today in the weekly Long Island Sound Y. R. A. regatta conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

Declaring that important issues confronting owners of real property must be met with organized strength,, Henry G. Waltemade, president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx, urges all property owners throughout the city to join the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation either through their local organizations or by individual membership.
The stuff of dime novels and spy thrillers glittered between the dry legal phrases of indictments for espionage handed up by a Federal grand jury last week.
Jersey City captured today's game from the Orioles by a 13-to-9 count. The victors clouted four Bird hurlers for fourteen hits, Blakely, Herman. Winsett and Haslin hitting for the circuit.
Despite recent attacks by Mayor La Guardia on the manner in which the salaries of court employes

Henry Picard today eased the pacer he set earlier in the $5,000 Goodall invitation golf tourney at Kenwood, but maintained a five-point lead over Lawson- Little, his nearest rival, at the end, of 90 of the 126 holes of play.
Intimate reports of European conditions were given to President Roosevelt today at long conferences with two of the most prominent of American Ambassadors.

With prices mounting rapidly and the heavy volume keeping the ticker many minutes late at times, the stock market last week was a strong reminder of the boisterous markets of the Nineteen Twenties. on the week, leading. stocks were up from 2 to as much as 20 points.

Making a runaway race from the first, The Chief was eased home the winner of the $25,450 Brooklyn Handicap before 16,000 persons at Aqueduct yesterday, flashing the same amazing mile and a furlong performance of 1:48 2-5 which he had made in the Dwyer Stakes last Saturday.

One of the largest properties under one ownership in Putnam County, N. Y., has been sold by the Star Ridge Company, Inc., to a New York investor. It consists of 471 acres of land with two tenroom houses, two two-car garages and a number of outbuildings located on the Farmers Mill Road with a large frontage on Horse Pond Brook in Kent township near Carmel.

Staging a game run down the stretch, James Emery's Dolly Val scored a nose victory over Zevson in the $10,000 added Frontier Handicap at the Fair Grounds track today. The only filly and the lone 3-yearold in the field of nine, Dolly Val got a hustling ride all of the way

EARLY in July, 1921, when Rudolph Valentino was just putting the opening flourishes on "The Sheik" and Mary Pickford the,closing ones on "Little Lord Fauntleroy," an energetic young comedy producer named Hal. Roach was racking his brain for a good new idea for a short subject series.

It seems the fluke are really on their way at-last and we have just had word from Captain Clarence DeGarmo of Babylon that his party took twenty-five fluke in two and one-half hours' fishing. The fish were taken in Great South Bay, and the largest weighed 51/4 pounds and several more than 4 pounds.

Further action on a creditors' plan for the reorganization and liquidation of the closed Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company was blocked yesterday when the Appellate Division, in a three-to-two decision, vacated an order made by Supreme Court Justice Alfred H. Frankenthaler last September appointing a referee to determine whether the proposal was fair and equitable to creditors and stockholders.

Reversal of a judgment of $116,000 against Irving T. Bush, president of the Bush Terminal Company, and a new trial of a libel action brought against him by James C. Van Siclen and C. Walter Randall, former receivers and trustees of the company, unless they consent to have the judgment reduced to $50,187, were ordered by the Appellate Division in a unanimous opinion yesterday.

BRITISH philatelists are giving thought to the postage stamp's centenary two years hence. On the recent occasion of the reopening of the British Postal Museum in Bruce Castle, Tottenham, England, the British Postmaster General, Major G. C. Tyron, M. P., announced that Great Britain would issue a special stamp as part of the nation's celebration, in 1940, of the one hundredth anniversary of Roland bill's postal reforms,

A tour of Swedish-American communities as far west as Minneapolis, and a program of special events, have been outlined for the official Swedish delegation, headed by the Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and the Crown Princess Louise, which will arrive at Wilmington, Del., tomorrow morning on the Kungsholm.

Further action on a creditors' plan for the reorganization and liquidation of the closed Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company was blocked yesterday when the Appellate Division, in a three-to-two decision, vacated an order made by Supreme Court Justice Alfred H. Frankenthaler last September appointing a referee to determine whether the proposal was fair and equitable to creditors and stockholders.

Reversal of a judgment of $116,000 against Irving T. Bush, president of the Bush Terminal Company, and a new trial of a libel action brought against him by James C. Van Siclen and C. Walter Randall, former receivers and trustees of the company, unless they consent to have the judgment reduced to $50,187, were ordered by the Appellate Division in a unanimous opinion yesterday.
SINGARADJA, Bali. EARLY this morning the S. S. Nieuw-Zeeland dropped a jin gling anchor some 300 fathoms off shore in the roads of Booleleng. Promptly at 7 A. M.,

THIRTY well-known English writers have appended their names to a statement protesting against the intention of the Publishers Association of Great Britain to be represented at the International Congress of Publishers
ON the heels of his twelfth fireside chat," President Roosevelt is faced with what the broadcasters. describe as "an unusually heavy broadcasting schedule."
The official report of the Empire Games Committee issued today announced a loss of [Pound]7,602 ($38,010) on the game,

Asserting that "political opponents" had circulated "stories concerning the President's interference in Congressional primaries," James A. Farley, National Democratic Chairman, said today that "it has not occurred to them that there is no personal animosity or thought of revenge involved."

Not everybody has heard that there are new sunflowers. The chrysanthemum-flowered, the miniature and the new red are novel variants. The blossoms of the chrysanthemum-flowered kind are six inches in diameter; their name indicates their appearance.

That only a small fraction of corporate earnings has been disbursed to executives, with few exceptions, during the depression that started in 1929 is one of the conclusions reached by John Calhoun Baker, associate director of research of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, as a result of research studies he began in 1935.
A CONQUERING nation invariably imposes its language on the conquered, for it is the tongue in which favors are asked and granted.

E.M. HAWES, executive di rector of the Northwest Territory Celebration Commission, has made available a photograph of the view of the monument--Gutzon Borglum's "The Start of the Nation Westward"-which will appear on the three-cent stamp to be released on July 15 in commemoration of the establishment of the first civil government west of the Thirteen Original States, on July 15, 1788.

" Ravenscroft," one of the estates in the Llewellyn Park section of West Orange, N. J., has been purchased by Otto W. Sartorlus, formerly of New York City. The property consists of a large Georgiancolonial-style house on two and onehalf acres of landscaped land.

A court order directing the Municipal Civil Service Commission to regrade the experience papers of all candidates for appointment as social investigators to eliminate favoritism to employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau was affirmed unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division.

Rain marred the program of Canada's first Eucharistic Congress today. It pelted 30,000 children gathered before the open-air repository on the Plains of Abraham for a dialoguee" mass and prevented an afternoon demon- Indiar station by women pilgrims on the same spot.

Several of the large apartment houses on Central Park West are experiencing brisk rental activity and brokers predict a high occupancy record in that area at the close of the Fall renting season. A recent survey on that thoroughfare revealed that among the multifamily dwellings sharing in the activity are:

Commendation is voiced by Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, of the action of the City Club of New York in supporting a proposed amendment to the New York State Constitution which would establish a general "reasonable regulation and control," from an esthetic standpoint, for buildings erected on private property.

Negotiations were in progress today for Philadelphia's major league baseball clubs to share the same playing field to cut expenses. President Gerald P. Nugent of the National League club said 'arrangements virtually had been completed for the Phillies to abandon Baker Bowl and play all home games in the Athletics' Shibe park.
THERE are two schools of abuse in the making of books that were once extremely popular but are now looked upon with disdain by collectors.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, announces that bids had been asked for supplies of cement, asphalt and other materials which are expected to cost about $12,000,000, for construction work on WPA projects. Bids are to be opened Wednesday.

Mental breakdowns among parents, induced by. the long fight against joblessness and want, bulks increasingly large among the reasons why children must be sent to temporary shelters, the Children's Welfare Federation informed the Greater New York Fund in a report made public yesterday.

Responsibilities of landlords were increased yesterday under a decision handed down by the Appellate Division, upholding a jury's verdict of $25,000 to Harold Simmons, 40 years old, of Perth Amboy, N. J. Mr. Simmons claimed damages for injuries he received when he was struck by a falling rope used by a hoister employed by a tenant.
Economists and analysts have given their explanation of the 1938 depression, but what is the ordinary American saying about it? What causes does he single out? And how much is he blaming Roosevelt?

Expenditures for all divisions of government in 1937 are tentatively estimated at $16,900,000,000 by the National Industrial Conference Board in a new report on "Cost of Government in the United States, 1935-37." The figure includes $400,000,000 of Social Security expenditures.

THE private life of the Three Stooges is a subject we've wondered about for years and last week we finally cornered the boys in a modest three-room suite (a bedroom apiece) in the Hotel Edison: Moe, Larry- and Curly, who started as appendages of the late Ted Healy, the grenadier of gags, and who are today practically the entire Short Subjects Department of Columbia Pictures.

There is one part of Spain that will never know the horrors of the civil war for the strange reason that it is inside of France. The writer has just come back from a visit to the little town of Llivia, this side of Bourg-Madame and more than three miles outside the FrancoSpanish frontier.

Spanish Insurgents vainly tried today to smash a hole in government defenses in Eastern Spain, where an estimated 150,000 Loyalists and 100,000 Insurgents Were locked in conflict on a forty-five-mile front.
American crews drew easy opponents today for the opening rounds of the Henley Regatta which starts next Wednesday.

BERKE-ROSENTHAL-Dr. and Mrs. L Rosenthal of 1,657 51st St., Brooklyn. announce the engagement of their daughter, Eleanore Rosenthal, to Jason R. Berke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul J. Berkowitz of 1,685 Ocean Ave., Brooklyn.

A five-year building program for American embassies and consulates is now in force, backed by a fund of $5,000,000. In carrying out the program the Department of State will strive to provide well-designed buldings for as many smaller posts as possible, to cut rent and operating costs by consolidating various activities, and to put up, where possible, centrally located office buildings in which all American governmental activities can be concentrated.

Bard College, at Annandale-onHudson, in preparing its plans for the Fall term, has decided to give greater responsibility for the actual operation of its administration to eight joint committees, each of which is composed of four faculty members and four students chosen by the Student Council, according to Dean Harold Mastre.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced again, although moderately, for the week ended June 18, and now stands at 76.8, as against 76.5. for the preceding week and 107.0 for the comparable week a year ago.

The co-medalists yesterday, Edward Searle, unattached, and Chester T. Birch of Briar Hills, both gained the semi-finals of the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club annual invitation golf tournament today.
Agreement by both company and union officials to arbitrate differences involved in the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company strike was announced today by Governor Lehman.
Male promenaders on the Long Beach boardwalk who care to shed their coats this season may do so only if they wear trouser belts or no belts at all.

A few years ago Dr. F. Zwicky of the California Institute of Technology told the scientific world that it must reckon with super novae. But the scientific world was a little doubtful. Mere bigness was not enough to differentiate super novae from common ones.

Recommendations for the selection of twelve career men to serve as "engineering cadets" on the Board of Transportation staff were made yesterday by Sidney Stern, examiner for the Municipal Civil Service Commission.
Maine no longer enjoys its old-time prestige as the barometer State. The notion that what happens in Maine in September will happen in the nation in November is heavily discounted today.

The longawaited racing duel between War Admiral and -Seabiscuit. tonight seemed a certainty for next Wednesday, when the - two ace thoroughbreds are billed -to match strides with ten to twelve other. strong horses, in the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap at. Suffolk Downs.

The old John B. Lozier estate, having a large frontage on Kinderkamack Road, Oradell, Bergen County, N. J., and which was owned by the Lozier family for several generations, is now being developed into a medium-priced home community.

AS Lord Nelson might have remarked, had a cruel fate A moved Trafalgar to California, "Hollywood expects every tot to do its duty." For the appalling fact seems to be that child actors are on the increase.

Early Summer is none too soon for nousewives to think of the Autumn window garden. Gera'nium cuttings taken now have time to develop a sturdy root system as preparation for a long season of indoor bloom. Plants from the outdoor beds are almost worthless for this purpose, for the geranium requires a rest period either in Summer or Winter, and will not bloom the year round.
The crest of the flood of commencement oratory passed down Salt River (or, to give that noble stream its full title, Grain-of-Salt River) last Monday. The waters are now receding.
President Roosevelt is considering reviewing the entire United States Fleet off San Francisco when he visits California in July, it was learned from White House sources today.

Miss Mary Travis, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Travis of Montclair, was married to Robert Allen Arny, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Vinecome Arny of Montclair this evening in Watchung Avenue Congregational Church, of which the bride's father is pastor. Dr. Travis performed the cer mony.

Pleas for lessened government intervention in the economic system generally and in the management of railroads particularly were voiced here today by speakers before the opening session of the forty-fifth annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association at Saranac Inn.

Warning that the accident death rate for the United States reaches its peak during July, the Greater New York Safety. Council yesterday urged caution against fireworks, drownings and automobile accidents.
War Minister Seishiro Itagaki, who came here to worship at the Grand Shrines of Ise, declared in an interview today that Japan must be prepared to fight "at least ten years."
Boom psychology reached the home furnishings market here last week, bringing a complete aboutface in producers' views of the approaching wholesale openings in Chicago next week.
A survey of the tastes and demands of home buyers made by Callan Brothers, Long Island North Shore builders, reveals some interesting information in the designing of future homes.

CASTING: For nearly two years the public has been asking, "Who will play Scarlett O'Hara in the movie version of 'Gone With the Wind'?" Last week there appeared an apparent end to the suspense. Norma Shearer, it was announced in Hollywood, would play Scarlett to Clark Gable's Rhett Butler.
Slowly but surely becoming better known and more widely known and more widely used, the tuberous begonia has for many a flower lover solved the annoying problem of the shaded window box.

NATIONAL competition is announced for the selection of a decoration for one of the buildings .of Rockefeller Center. The competition will seek to obtain the best design for a bronze, panel depicting the theme of News, for the doorway of. the main entrance to The Associated Press Building, now under construction.

The longawaited racing duel between War Admiral and -Seabiscuit. tonight seemed a certainty for next Wednesday, when the - two ace thoroughbreds are billed -to match strides with ten to twelve other. strong horses, in the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap at. Suffolk Downs.

The old John B. Lozier estate, having a large frontage on Kinderkamack Road, Oradell, Bergen County, N. J., and which was owned by the Lozier family for several generations, is now being developed into a medium-priced home community.

TECHNICALLY and legally the coal operators, corporations and peace officers of Harlan County on trial here at London are charged with a criminal conspiracy to nullify the Wagner act. Actually, however, it is the political and. economic system of that rich softcoal field which is at the bar.
Governor Richard C. McMullen has appointed a three-man commission to study the laws relative to non-residents fishing in the Delaware River.
A new outbreak of attacks against proJapanese Chinese led- International Settlement police today to take special precautions against what they feared was a well-organized terrorist movement.

Baseball-The Cubs, with Clay Bryant pitching a three-hit game, downed the Giants yesterday, 5 to 0. The Yanks, aided by homers by Joe DiMaggio and Bill Dickey, beat the Tigers, 9-3. The Dodgers lost to the Cardinals, 3-1.
In a demonstration sponsored by 25 local organizations about 1,000 persons picketed the German Consulate here today.

The city's crusade against pushcart peddlers received a further setback yesterday when the Appellate Division unanimously affirmed an order of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler directing William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Market Commissioner, to issue licenses to three itinerant peanut venders.

Tragedy again overtook the crack Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Olympian train this morning when the westbound flyer crashed headon with an eastbound CCC train near Ingomar, Mont., killing one youth and injuring four trainmen and nine Passengers.

Thomas Maloney, former Mayor, who was believed to have had the largest acquaintance among national political figures of-any-manin- Iowa, died yesterday at the age of 78. Known as the "best door opener in Washington," he was drafted to go to the capital with delegations of Democrats and Republicans alike.

Rejected from the Bermuda race, the little sloop Sirius, thirty-seven feet longon deck, started today in the race of the Eastern Yacht Club around Cape- Cod to Marblehead, Mass. Her owner, Wesley J. Vansciver of Philadelphia, evidently determined to prove that the Sirius could on to sea and take Ait.

While relatives and friends of the family of Adam William Goetz were still celebrating the marriage of his sister, Celia, which had taken place an hour before, at an informal gathering in his home at 2,790 Sexton Place, the Bronx, he was shot in the left side of the back at 6:30 o'clock last night outside his home.
Miss Murton du Pont and W. Samuel Carpenter 3d were married this afternoon on the lawn of Dogwood, the horne of the bride's father, Eugene E. du Pont, near Greenville.

A five-year plan for expansion of major industries through the cooperation of industry, labor and government, under a government financial guarantee, was proposed by Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser to the Department of Agriculture, in an address before the Tamiment Economic. and Social Institute here today.
Governor Richard C. McMullen has appointed a three-man commission to study the laws relative to non-residents fishing in the Delaware River.
A new outbreak of attacks against proJapanese Chinese led- International Settlement police today to take special precautions against what they feared was a well-organized terrorist movement.

Baseball-The Cubs, with Clay Bryant pitching a three-hit game, downed the Giants yesterday, 5 to 0. The Yanks, aided by homers by Joe DiMaggio and Bill Dickey, beat the Tigers, 9-3. The Dodgers lost to the Cardinals, 3-1.
In a demonstration sponsored by 25 local organizations about 1,000 persons picketed the German Consulate here today.

The city's crusade against pushcart peddlers received a further setback yesterday when the Appellate Division unanimously affirmed an order of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler directing William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Market Commissioner, to issue licenses to three itinerant peanut venders.

Tragedy again overtook the crack Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Olympian train this morning when the westbound flyer crashed headon with an eastbound CCC train near Ingomar, Mont., killing one youth and injuring four trainmen and nine Passengers.
A survey of the tastes and demands of home buyers made by Callan Brothers, Long Island North Shore builders, reveals some interesting information in the designing of future homes.

CASTING: For nearly two years the public has been asking, "Who will play Scarlett O'Hara in the movie version of 'Gone With the Wind'?" Last week there appeared an apparent end to the suspense. Norma Shearer, it was announced in Hollywood, would play Scarlett to Clark Gable's Rhett Butler.
Slowly but surely becoming better known and more widely known and more widely used, the tuberous begonia has for many a flower lover solved the annoying problem of the shaded window box.

NATIONAL competition is announced for the selection of a decoration for one of the buildings .of Rockefeller Center. The competition will seek to obtain the best design for a bronze, panel depicting the theme of News, for the doorway of. the main entrance to The Associated Press Building, now under construction.

The French liner Normandie is due to arrive today from Havre via Southampton. Passengers are Lady Cunliffe Owen, Baroness Bardossy, Mr. and Mrs. Winfield Chapin, Beverley A. Bogert, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Abbott, Count and Countess Raoul de Roussy de Sales, Mr. and Mrs. W. C. Higginbottom, David Niven and Clifford Fischer.

Mark Twain was not "a thwarted Swift" or "a blighted Hemingway," according to Professor Delancey Ferguson of Western Reserve University, who has written the leading article for the new number of The Colophon, issued today.

A Catholic prelate who criticized President Manuel Quezon's veto of the religious instruction bill explained publicly today that he did not mean to "challenge or provoke" the Philippine chief executive.

In a few cases, statistics relating to last month suggest that the British business recession may have been partly checked. There is also the suspicion, however, that any improvement may have been due to special causes, and the general inference to be drawn from various indices is that trade contraction continues.

That ambitious schedule of Vinton Freedley's is now smaller by one project than it was before. He has abandoned plans to produce the musical called "Greek to You," for which Russel Crouse and Howard Lindsay had prepared-or at least outlined-a libretto based on a story by Lowell Brentano and William Jourdan Rapp. Some sort of settlement will be arranged with Billy Gilbert, who was to have been chief comic of the festival.

Gifts which will make Princeton University's collection in the history of art the, largest in the country are included in the $1,969,471 presented to the university in the 1937-38 academic year, according to an announcement today by President Harold W. Dodds.

Henry Giegold of Dumont was elected commander of the New Jersey Department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars at the twentieth annual encampment which closed in Convention Hall here today. He succeeds Thomas C. Fields of Bloomfield.
A program of folk dances in national costume will be given Thursday night, July 7, at Lewisohn Stadium, as a joint presentation of the Stadium Concerts, Inc., and the Dance International.

Mrs. William Orr Barclay of the Plaza has gone to Windsor, Ont., for the Summer. The Rev. and Mrs. Andrew Chalmers Wilson of Newport will leave the Madison today for their Summer place at Osterville, Mass.

Hector Diaz Leguizamon, first secretary of the Argentine Embassy, died suddenly early today at his Florida Avenue home of a heart attack believed to be due to the heat. He was 46 years old and unmarried.

The fight for the right of religious freedom has played an important role in world history, the Rev. Dr. Wallace MacMullen, pastor of the Metropolitan Methodist Temple, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street, said yesterday morning in his sermon.
The Constitutional Convention tomorrow will enter its thirteenth week--a week that will be crucial for the Republican majority in the convention.
James Weldon Johnson, 67, Negro author, poet and composer, died in a Maine Central Railroad gradecrossing accident here today.

The engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Krause of 730 Riverside Drive of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Margaret Krause, to Robert Spencer Barnett of Beacon, N. Y., son of Mrs. Robert Spencer Barnett and the late Mr. Barnett.

The bond interest and the tolls and all other revenues of the Port of New York Authority or other "Authorities" or any municipality are not subject to Federal taxation, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. advised State Controller Morris S. Tremaine in an opinion made public yesterday.

Important increases in expenditures for new building construction, both public and private, are in prospect for the next twelve months, F. D. Newbury, economist of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, told 100 engineers, business managers and professors of economics and engineering here this evening at the eighth annual Economics Conference arranged jintly by the Stevens Institute of Technology and the Society for the Advancement of Management.
One hundred thousand marched through the streets of Quebec for five hours today in the closing demonstration of the first Canadian National Eucharistic Congress.
Italy's crack 3-year-old, Nearco, who never has been beaten in his own country, won the 1,000,000-franc Grand Prix de Paris at Longchamps today.

An extraordinary church service was held today in the hall of the Munich police headquarters. This had been put at the disposal of the congregation of St. Matthew's, oldest Protestant church in Munich, which is now being pulled down to make way for a new subway station.

A Glass Center, which may recall the proverbial glass house to many visitors at the New York World's Fair, is to be one of the striking features of the exposition. Work on the Glass Center will be started today, it was announced yesterday by R. L. Hamill, president of Glass, Inc.

A three-day village fair will open Tomorrow in Washington Square Mews under the auspices of the women's division of the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy. The net proceeds will benefit the Spanish Children's Milk Fund.

Henry Hopper, Civil War veteran, who will be 95 years old on Aug. 30, announced today he would drive his own car on Wednesday to Gettysburg, Pa., where he will attend the seventy-fifth anniversary exercises of the Battle of Gettysburg.
France's wholesale price index on June 18 stood at 649, compared with 645 a week earlier and 644 two weeks earlier.

Mrs. Alma Turner Phelps of this city and Fort Worth, Texas, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Katharine Fielding Phelps, to Lieutenant Forrest Close, U.S.N., son of N. F. F. Close of Savannah, Ga. The wedding will take place here on July 7.

Closing its forty-ninth annual meeting here today, the Central Conference of American Rabbis urged that all moral forces be mobilized against the resort to military force in the settlement of international controversies.

Imperial Airways' empire flying boat Cordelia left Southampton with twenty passengers and a heavy load of mails at dawn today to inaugurate the first flying boat service to Australia, 13,000 miles away.

Skeets McDaniel's double with the bases full in the eleventh gave the Chiefs a 6-to-5 victory over Newark in the second game of a doubleheader today after the Bears had romped to a 17-to-1 triumph in the opener.

The nation cannot be said to have hung with bated breath aver the sickbed of the Schenectady robin which, after twelve days of hiccoughing, has just passed away. Nevertheless, it did get more attention than an individual robin usually does. Indeed, it competed in a modest way with poor Max Schmeling's injured transverse process.

Opening the Summer training season at this camp, the largest training center of the army's Second Corps Area, more than 400 officers of the reserve corps reported today for two weeks' active duty training.

Apparel manufacturers devoted their major attention last week to mid-season and advance Fall merchandise. Although dark sheer dresses were in demand at all price levels, dress business in general slackened, the only improvement in activity being noted in the lower ranges.

Broadway, 320, 75x150, n e cor Pearl St; Thomas C. Fogarty to New York Life Insurance Co; consideration $100,000; foreclosure. 30th St, 347 E. 25x98.9; Ira Ruben to Emigrant Bank; consideration $1,000; foreclosure.
Princess Alexis Karageorgevitch, an American woman who, by her marriage, became the aunt of King Alexander of Yugoslavia, died here today at the age of 77.
James E. McGrath, advertising manager of The Wall Street Journal, was drowned yesterday afternoon while swimming from a cabin cruiser off Cranes Neck Cove in Long Island Sound.

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, announced yesterday that the organization had changed its name to the American Merchant Marine Institute, Inc., and that approval of its certificate of incorporation had been signed by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck.
Edward Verrall Lucas, essayist and head of the publishing house of Methuen Co., died here today following an operation. His age was 70.

For the first time since the depression began, relief authorities in this State are compelling persons who have "struck it rich" after leaving the relief rolls to pay back the sums given them in home relief.

The Maine lake fishing is still holding up and a group from Auburn had quite an exciting excursion.- There were two fathers with their sons, Melville Young and his son Gilbert, and Elwell Libby and his son Erwin.

The Devon Yacht Club was very gay for the opening dinner dance of the season, held last evening. One group at dinner included Mr. and Mrs. Sturtevant Erdmann, Mr. and Mrs. John Laurence Hutton, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Connick and Mr. and Mrs. John Northrop.

Seven hundred and fifty Detroit excursionists were marooned on South Bass Island in Lake Erie tonight after the excursion steamer Put-In Bay, which had left them there, broke its propeller, and a second vessel, commissioned to take them off the island, declined to do so because of heavy seas.

An interparochial Eucharistic congress in which Italian congregations of twenty-five Brooklyn Roman Catholic Churches took part for five days ended late yesterday afternoon at a solemn benediction in McGolrick Field, Morgan Avenue and Jackson Street, Brooklyn.

Two Swedish Bishops who are visiting this country during the Swedish tercentenary received the degree of Doctor of Sacred Theology from Augustana College and Seminary yesterday at the close of the seventy-ninth annual convention of the Evangelical Lutheran Church
Sometimes little stories happen right under a newspaper's nose. That is how this column found

It is the average man who makes significant the values in the world and upon him the betterment of humanity depends in these troubled times, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie said yesterday morning -in his sermon at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

Replying to Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, denied that Protestants have disintegrated religiously.
Bernard Shaw, who will be 82 in July, has been suffering from "serious anemia" for three weeks, it was revealed tonight.

Wage increases for some 500,000 WPA workers in thirteen Southern States, from which came most of the opposition to the Administration's wages and hours legislation, were announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator.

Opposition to six proposed changes to the State Constitution. now being considered by various committees of the Constitutional Convention, as destructive of the State's present power policy was expressed yesterday by Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the State Power Authority, in a letter to Judge Frederick E. Crane, presi-. dent of the convention.

200th St (12-3284), ?? e cor of Marion Ave, 107x113; Sarah D. Moorehead to Harold P. Moorehead, 311 Bedford Park Blvd; mtge, $130,000. 3d Ave, 3,782 (11-2927); Moe Levy to Albert Blaire, 2,846 W. 32d St, Brooklyn; mtge, $12,000.
Several thousand men, women and children braved intermittent showers yesterday afternoon to attend a celebration on the Mall in Central Park in connection with the Delaware Tercentenary.

Today's program of the convention of the National Educational Association follows: 9 A. M. Center Theatre-First general morning session. Addresses: Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education;
Mrs. Clarice Vallette McCauley of 235 West Forty-eighth Street, New York, author of one-act plays and short stories, died in a hospital here today after an illness of eight months, at the age of 65.

Zora Hurston, who has spent most of the last two years in Jamaica and Haiti on a Guggenheim fellowship, has completed the book she went there to write and delivered the manuscript to Lippincott, her publisher. The book, to be called "Tell My Horse," will be one of the leading titles on Lippincott's Autumn list.

Charles S. (Buck) Walsh, head coach of the Naval Academy crews, will not see his eights race tomorrow in the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta. He is a patient in the Vassar Brothers Hospital here with a spinal injury suffered last night.

A proposal providing for an entirely new avenue of approach to the employeemployer relations problem was announced here tonight for employes of the newly organized Owosso Parts Corporation, manufacturers of automobile accessories.

A plane, carrying Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, and a party from Arthurdale, W. Va., to Hyde Park, N. Y., landed unexpectedly at the airport of this Southeastern Pennsylvania town tonight because of a storm.

Two works by contemporary American composers were performed at yesterday's concerts in the WPA Theatre of Music. The "Pageant of P. T. Barnum," by Douglas Moore of the music faculty of Columbia University, was presented in the afternoon at the concert of the Federal Symphony Orchestra, directed by Rudolph Thomas.

The church throughout the world, Protestant, Catholic and Jewish, faces difficult problems, the Rev. Dr. Edmund Melville Wylie, associate pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, said in his sermon yesterday.
Nation wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 28 per cent of capacity, up 2 points in a week and 3 points in two weeks.
A permanent separation for Americanborn Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow, the former Barbara Hutton, and her Danish husband seemed virtually inevitable tonight.

Premier Edouard Daladier's action in dismissing Parliament despite the Socialist and Communist opposition to that move is regarded in financial circles here as indicative of a vigorous and laudable attitude.

The only woman bank president in New Jersey, Mrs. Mary Roebling of Trenton, told the Soroptimist International Association at its Atlantic City convention last week that "women's social -emancipation started about eighty years ago through the typewriter." Maybe the wires garbled Mrs.
THE DARK RIVER, by Charles Nordhoff and James Norman Hall. (Little, Brown, $2.50.) A new novel by the authors of "The Hurricane."

Colonel Bill Terry turned gardener at the Polo Grounds yesterday and planted Bob Seeds in left field in his first starting assignment as a Giant. While rain pattered down for most of the fray, Seeds grew with the rapidity of Jack's fabled beanstalk until he had given Carl Hubbell all the insurance he needed for his 200th major league victory.

American travelers through Japanese-occupied territory in China report that from the trains fields of poppies may be observed in full bloom. These stretches of beauty do not mark nature's attempt to hide the scars of war.

International politics continued in the background here last week, business interest concentrating on the unsatisfactory foreign trade balance and the connected currency, exchange and foreign debt questions.
Edward Kenneth Hoyt, who retired in 1926 as general manager of the Central Leather Company at Buenos Aires, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a short illness.
If President Roosevelt tries his fishing luck here he will find the best sailfish season in many years. All previous records already have been broken with more than 140 sailfish caught to date.

Philip D. Jonas, assistant controller of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, will become controller on Friday to succeed Robert B. Ferguson. Ralph S. Bird, supervisor of contracts and insurance, will be promoted to assistant to the controller.

Fearful that the railroads may be compelled by the Interstate Commerce Commission to make terminal charges which will add millions of dollars annually to shippers' costs, a group of Chicago shippers will hold a meeting on Tuesday in a move to forestall such action, George M. Blair, chairman of a special committee on arrangements, announced today.

The political and social structure of this nation was erected on a framework of Christianity, but religious freedom does not mean a surrender to foes of religion or religious minorities, the Rev. Leon Merle Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse at 178th Street, the Bronx, said in his sermon yesterday.

Nearly 200 members of the Father Duffy Chapter of the Rainbow Division attended memorial services yesterday afternoon at the grave of Father Duffy in St. Raymond's Cemetery, the Bronx, in commemoration of the sixth anniversary of his death.
Mrs. Genevieve Goodyear Earle MacDonell, a former resident of this city, wife of Alexander R. MacDonell of Detroit, died last Monday in Detroit after a brief illness of bronchial pneumonia.

Twenty-five material witnesses held in the Tombs prison in the policy racket case involving James J. Hines, leader; James Richard (Dixie) Davis, disbarred lawyer, and others will be transferred today or tomorrow on orders of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to the annex of the old Bronx County Jail, 161st Street and Third Avenue.

Bushwicks 3, Homestead Grays 3 (first game, called 10th; second game, rain). Farmers 4, House of David 1 (first; seeond game, rain). Mount Vernon 3, N. Y. Fire Department Yal 1 (first; second game, rain).

BARRY--Kathleen E., suddenly, Friday, June 24, 1938, at residence, 12 St. Charles Place, Brooklyn beloved mother of Mary A. Sheehan, Tom F. Barry, and Kathleen E. Nelles. Funeral Tuesday, June 28, 9 A. M.; thence to St. Teresa Church. Interment Holy Cross.
The action of the wheat market last week was a distinct disappointment to believers in a higher range of prices, as the strength in securities and in commodities in general largely was ignored.

A majority of the owners in the Tompkins Square area, bounded by Sixth and Seventh Streets, Avenue B to C, agreed to undertake the first cooperative block front rehabilitation. program in the campaign instituted by the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, the latter announced yesterday.

A sweeping denunciation of the role played by the American Legion in the educational, economic and political life of this country, in which the schools are warned against the "pressure-group" policy of the Legionnaires, is presented in a 280-page survey, "The American Legion as Educator," published by Teachers College, Columbia University, as No. 743 in its "Contributions to Education" series.
A gasoline price war, which has been carried on by Chicago's dealers for months in third grade fuels, has now been extended to include regular and ethyl grades.
Sam Snead came from behind with an amazing rush today to win the first $5,000 Goodall invitation golf tourney with a three-foot putt on the second hole of a play-off with Gene Sarazen.

The confining of religious practices to the cooler seasons of the year by Protestants who feel it is not compulsory to go to church during the Summer months was condemned yesterday by the Rev. Thomas E. Thompson, the pastor, at the Gospel. Tabernacle, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.
Saul S. Myers, one of the government prosecutors in 1920 who convicted Nicky Arnstein in the theft of securities, died yesterday at his home, 1,160 Park Avenue. He was 60 years old.
Criticisms or the government's attitude toward the bombing of British ships in Spanish ports have evidently cut deeper than it is considered desirable to admit.
The interests of society as a whole should be considered before the interests of individuals in cases of kidnapping, it was contended in an editorial published today in The New York Law Journal.
Thee American Olympic Committee held an organization meeting at the New York Athletic Club last night and approved the proceedings and actions of twenty-six games committees for the 1940 Olympics.

WPA workers will begin today the demolition of the frame mansion in the rear of the Register's Office in Jamaica,, Queens. A landmark in the section, the building once was occupied by a seminary for young ladies which was discontinued at the turn of the century.
William C. Vaill of Arlington, N. J., banker and church organist of New Brunswick and Newark, died last night at his Summer home here at the age of 64.

A man identified by ship's officers as J. Wesley Betts, 32 years old, of Brooklyn, N. Y., went overboard from the Cunard White Star liner Carinthia about sixty miles from Havana today. The steamship, on a cruise from New York to Nassau, made an unsuccessful one-hour search for him.

Miss Helene Rains, 13-year-old sensation, and Miss Lorraine Fisher, both of the Women's Swimming Association, were among the winners in the open A. A. U. meet at the Broad Channel Bathing Park in Queens yesterday.

The Bank of America is cooperating with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in taking the applications of business enterprises for loans for capital purposes under the Glass act, L. M. Giannini, president, announced yesterday.

Four picked firemen, wearing gas masks and with oxygen tanks strapped to their backs, took part last night in a dramatic attempt to put out a fire raging as if fanned by a forced draft forty feet below the bottom of the East River in the north bore of the ManhattanQueens Tunnel now under construction.
Trade and speculative demand lifted cotton prices last week to the highest levels since the first week in May. Futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange made net advances of 34 to 39 points.

A special chorus of 150 Negroes has been engaged for the GalloShubert presentations of "Show Boat" at Randalls Island which begins tomforrow night. These singers will supplement the regular chorus of 100 voices.

A jubilant audience of 1,200 East Side youngsters in bathing suits watched a water carnival in Hamilton Fish Park yesterday afternoon that culminated the Department of Parks learn - to - swim campaign among school children.

The names of 193 undergraduates of Fordham College who have won places on the 1937-38 honor roll were announced yesterday. The first list of the roll includes juniors, sophomores and freshmen to whom medals will be awarded at exercises on Sept. 26 for maintaining the highest average over 90 per cent for the entire year.
