Ralph D Ward. Mrs. Louis Ryan, Mrs. J. H. Sinclair, Jorge Macial da Costa Leite, the Brazilian Consul; Mrs. H. B. Lamont, Harold S. Sloan, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park S.; Douglas L. Elliman Co.. brokers.

Two letters have been received here from the British 1938 Mount Everest expedition. One from the leader, W. H. Tilman, dated Camp 3, May 26, confirms earlier news that the north col has been occupied by four Europeans and fifteen porters and adds:

Valencia cafes may henceforth be open only between the hours of 7 and 10 o'clock in the morning and 2 and 4 in the afternoon, according to a new decree intended to discourage persons who might be inclined to indulge in leisurely drinking instead of working for Loyalist victory.

With the statement that "there can be no compromise with a cancer," Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, second largest C. I. O. affiliate, declared today that his organization was determined to wage a finish fight on Communists and all "disruptive elements" who seek to utilize their membership for political and other extraneous purposes.

Uniform systems of accounting, effective Jan. 1, were prescribed by the Public Service Commission today for smaller utility corporations operating within the State. Similar uniformity has been required of the larger companies.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Howes of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Muriel Howes, to James H. Braddock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Braddock of Montclair.

A real revolution could be created in modern life if a sufficient number of persons determined to live according to the will of God, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood said in his sermon as guest preacher yesterday at the Riverside Church.
Maurice R. Spear, president of Spear Co., has announced that as of July 1 his company is taking Into its renting department the entire personnel of Holmes Douglas, Inc.

It is reported that the Civil Liberties Union has offered to defend Mrs.. Elizabeth Dilling, author of "The Red Network," against the charge that she slandered the Methodist Bishop of Nebraska and Iowa in a recent broadcast. The union would aid Mrs. Dilling because it disapproves of radio censorship.
Last week's industrial record was without feature except for an ordinance compelling the Reich's citizens in any occupation to take employment at the behest of the State.

Totem, Billy Luders's boat, in which C he did not finish yesterday, came home a minute and five seconds ahead of Briggs Cunningham's Fun today in the six-meter event over I a nine-and-two-third-mile course off s Center Island in the Seawanhaka J Corinthian Y. C. regatta.

James W. Mullen and Robert Haskins combined today to score 4,448 points and give Princeton University its second consecutive team championship as the ninth annual regatta of the Eastern Intercollegiate Outboard Association came to a close.

Due to the unfavorable condition of the weather, last night's concert scheduled for the Stadium was given in the Great Hall of City College. Those who braved the rain were rewarded by hearing the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens, in a series of admirably alert, spontaneous and spirited performances.

A survey of democracy in the United States, in which Democratic liberties were found essentially unimpaired while great economic and social difficulties have been created by the existence of a dual government, described as political democracy and industrial feudalism existing side by side, was presented here today at the opening session of the National Conference of Social Work.

The engagement of Miss Elinor Foster Warren, only child of Professor Edward H. Warren of Harvard University and Mrs. Warren, to Thomas Purdy was announced today. Mr. Purdy is the eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. T. W. Purdy of Woodgate House, Aylsham, Norfolk.

Whether or not it was ever seriously meant or was due merely to a misinterpretation of words of Foreign Minister Julio Alvarez del Vayo and his Ambassadors, the threat of Spanish Government reprisals for bombing by "foreign aviation in the service of the Insurgents" seems not likely to materialize.

Speaking on the importance of leaving more than a tomb when we die, the Rev. Howard D. McGrath urged that we leave behind us "living bequests," in a sermon yesterday at Grace Methodist Church, 131 West 104th Street.

Fighting resolutely in the teeth of a gale that lashed this metropolis in the wake of a 12-hour rain, the Yankees concluded their second Western trip of the year by thrashing the Tigers today, 10 to 3, while 25,000 sat in chilled silence.
The Rev. Dr. Oscar Loos Joseph, pastor of the Embury Methodist Episcopal Church and well known as an author, died of a heart attack today at his home here at the age of 63.

Scattered thunderstorms along the Atlantic Coast broke an eightday heat wave yesterday with cooling showers that sent the temperature down 20 degrees here within a few hours. More rain with continued cool weather was expected today.

The Rev. W. John Villaume Jr. was installed yesterday as assistant pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Grunst, vice president of the New York Conference of the United Lutheran Synod.

The plea that the State Constitution be changed so that at some future time it would. not act as bar to the setting up of a really effective system of unemployment insurance, was voiced in a statement issued here today by Edward F. Corsi, chairman of the Committee on Social Welfare of the Constitutional Convention.

The Spanish Government granted permission today for religious ceremonies to be held in its front-line trenches. A National Defense Ministry decree signed by Premier Juan Negrin and published in the Official Gazette ordered commanders of the army, navy and air force to authorize services for all troops who request them.
Rajah Bir Mitra Pradap Sekhar Deo of Gangpur, 18-year-old hereditary ruler of a Bengal State embracing 350,000 inhabitants, died today of pneumonia.

Sailing for the honor of representing Barnegat Bay in the world championship for International Star Class sloops at San Diego, Calif., in September, the local fleet put on a stirring battle today in a twentymile southerly in which Charles E. Lucke Jr.'s Nick Nack beat Frank T. Lloyd's Vixen by 14 seconds in the closing minutes of the final thrash to windward.

The Orioles ended their home stand today by trouncing Jersey City, 14 to 9 and 14 to 6. Baltimore rapped three pitchers for 18 hits in the first game and shelled three more hurlers for 19 in the seven-inning nightcap. The Little Giants collected 25 safeties in the two games.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,890,796,450. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Republican women -leaders of the State gathered-here tonight to make plans for marshaling the feminine vote in what leaders declared was a Republican year. Members of the executive committee of State Women Republicans, Inc., from thirty-four counties held a preconvention conference.

Max Phillips and Robert Eisner paced the Feston Farm polo team to an 11-5 victory over the Monmouth County Country Club in a special trophy match today. Festoon Farm took the lead at the outset and was never headed. The play was exceptionally fast, with long hitting a feature of the contest.
The Roseland Gun Club of West Orange, N. J., successfully defended its team championship in the tenth annual Great Eastern skeet shoot today with a new record on the Remington range at Lordship.

James Brickell's Allegra, sailed by Arthur Knapp, was first to finish among sixteen International One-Design Class sloops today as a fleet of seventy-two yachts braved a series of drenching rain squalls to race in a special regatta conducted on Long Island Sound by the Echo Bay Yacht Club.

The dollar devaluation scare has died down appreciably because of the emphatic official denials in Washington of any such intention, but the view persists here that a new alignment of currencies may be linked up with an Anglo-American trade treaty.

Holders of common stock of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., who received rights to subscribe to 77,873 shares of new 5 per cent convertible preferred stock have subscribed to 77,125 shares in the allotted period ended on June 22, leaving only 748 shares to be taken up by the underwriters, it was announced yesterday.

The Yangtze River and its banks in the vicinity of the Matang barrier continue to be the scene of a critical struggle for control of the boom barring passage of the Japanese fleet upriver, according to Chinese military reports.

Reorganization of Tammany by elimination of the post of leader was urged yesterday by Alfred J. Talley, former General Sessions judge, who proposed that the chairman of the county committee be made head of the organization. Mr.

Greta Garbo, motion-picture actress, and Leopold Stokowski, symphony conductor, were shaken up today when the automobile in which they were riding. between Stockholm and Haarby overturned in. a field.
Rogers Hornsby, one of baseball's all-time greats, was named manager of the Chattanooga Lookouts of the Southern Association today. The announcement was made by Joe Engel, club President.

Harry E. Noyes's ketch Tioga, a clipper bow craft although only two years old, was the Class A winner in the Eastern Yacht Club's annual race from New London, Conn., around Cape Cod to this harbor, a distance of 171 miles.

" Dust Be My Destiny," by Jerome Odlum, has been purchased by Warners as a vehicle for John Garfield (formerly Jules), Gloria Dickson, Humphrey Bogart and John Litel. The story will have as its final scene the murder of three men.

St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and 127th Street, observed the tercentenary of the Swedish settlement in America in special services yesterday morning. Dr. Gustaf Munthe of the Swedish Royal Commission was a guest speaker.
President Roosevelt's domestic policies were criticized as inadequate at best and his foreign policies as dangerous to American peace in two speeches by Norman Thomas today.
Japan continued in May to rank as the leading foreign customer of United States iron and steel manufacturers, but total exports of these products.

The International Bridge Congress formally opened today, but its deliberations were deferred until tomorrow's session. Results of the first day's European bridge championships, held concurrently, were:

Motor carriers in the State have bast flied that the Public Service Commission will not postpone those provisions of the new law regulating the transportation of freight which require that application for permits be filed within 120 days after July 1, the effective date of the law.

Civilization will emerge from the mire of strife when we begin to "live not just to suit ourselves," the Rev. Dr. H. M. J. Klein, Professor of History at Franklin and Marshall College, Lancaster, Pa., declared yesterday in a sermon at the- West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.
Miss Florence Wardwell, daughter of Mrs. John L. Montgomery of Oyster Bay and of the late Chester Alan Wardwell of Boston, will be introduced to society during the Winter. Her mother and stepfather,

Mrs. Lydia P. Studwell, wife of Harry S. Studwell of 33 Valleywood Road, Cos Cob, prominent resident in the eastern section of the town, died at the Greenwich Hospital last night following a brief illness.

To provide a longer stay for vacationists in Bermuda over the Fourth of July week-end, Pan American Airways and Imperial Airways announced yesterday a temporary rearrangement of flying schedules between New York and the island.

The probation system and its resuits in New York County during the last ten years were defended in a report made public today -by Irving W. Halpern, chief probation officer of the Probation Department, Court of General Sessions.

Thousands of educational leaders, representing school systems in every section of the country, arrived here yesterday by bus, train and airplane to attend the seventy-sixth annual convention of the National Education Association, which was officially opened and held its first meetings.

The biggest business in this big city is going to school. It happens to be suspended at the moment, but for nine months of the year there are a million and a quarter children engaged in it. It is no longer the simple business of the Three R's. The variety and scope of pupil activity are extraordinary.
The New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center announced yesterday that it had placed on view an Egyptian oxcart that was used two centuries before Christ.

A proclamation banning assemblies of more than five persons, stonethrowing, damaging property, provocative language and carrying of sticks or deadly weapons was issued by the British Guiana Government late Saturday night as officials moved to quell labor disorders.

More than 100 children were injured today when a stand selling toy balloons caught fire. The children were burned about the face and trampled on the ground in the panic that followed an explosion of the balloons which set fire to the stand.

Gustavus A. Younger of Somerville, N. J., who was on the financial staff of The New York Herald, 1912-15, died Saturday in St. Michael's Hospital, Elizabeth, N. J., after an operation at the age of 54.

An unexpected demand by the union for payment of another $15,000 payroll prevented the Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Circus from starting back to Florida Winter quarters as scheduled today, although the "strike that was not a strike" was settled by a signed agreement between the union and the circus management last night.

Inside the perisphere of the New York World's Fair, just now a steellaced ball that- looks like a construction engineer's model of the earthand much neater job than the knobby, splintered, rough-hewn planet on which we live--there will be a diorama, presumably of the picturesque aspects of the world of tomorrow.

Six hundred and eighty-seven degrees will be conferred tonight on 341 women and 346 men at the twelfth commencement exercises of Brooklyn College. More than 2,500 friends and guests of the graduates and members of the faculty are expected to attend the ceremonies, to be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and St. Felix Place, at 8 o'clock.
Ellery Lewis Wilson, vice president of the Rumford Chemical Company in East Providence, died today in Pomfret, Conn., according to word received here tonight. His age was 57.

Feelings cannot be made the test of religion, the Rev. Dr. Granville Mercer Williams declared yesterday in his morning sermon in the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

Vespers brought together more than 1,500 members of the National Education Association yesterday in the Center Theatre, where the congregation stood in silent tribute to the 1,900 who died in the last year and heard the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo of St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church plead for cultivation of the individual and his integration with society.

Mayor La Guardia asked 2,500 railroad workers at a meeting yesterday .to promise that provision would be made for getting food into New York City if they and their unions went on strike against a proposed 15 per cent wage cut.
Lard futures were on the upgrade last week in sympathy with hogs, cottonseed oil and commodity markets in general. Receipts of hogs were not so large as the trade had expected.

Last week's money market here was quiet, but the banks began rediscounting in expectation of a demand for funds at the end of the half year. Dayto-day loans were quoted yesterday at 2 7/8 to 3 1/8 per cent, the same as a week before.

The board of governors of the State Association of Young Republican Clubs, at a meeting here today, adopted a series of resolutions affecting proposals pending before the State constitutional convention.

Liberalized banking regulations to encourage the flow of private funds into the business structure of the nation were announced here today in a joint statement by the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Controller of the Currency.
Dr. Winborne D. Evans, an X-ray specialist, died at 4 A. M. today in Zurbrugg Memorial. Hospital here of injuries received Saturday in an automobile accident on Route 25 near here.

The Commodity Exchange's committee on grading and warehousing for hides, which has been studying the advisability of a new hide contract, is recommending a new contract which would provide that an allowance be given by the seller to the buyer on all hides that have been out of the original salt pack more than a year.

It was on Monday night- that Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Spanish Foreign Minister, informed Eirik Labonne, the French Ambassador, as dean of the diplomatic body in Barcelona, that, were aerial bombardments to continue, reprisals would be taken upon Italian towns.
Trading in corn futures was restricted last week. Prices held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel, hedging and speculative sales being largely offset by purchases by exporters and others.

Stocks recovered losses of this year and registered widest gains since week ended Dec. 7, 1929, in largest turnover since October, 1937; turnover, 10,112,640 shares. Rail bonds up sharply; United States Government issues lower;

Miss Anita Ellen Wilkes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham P. Wilkes, was married yesterday noon at the home of her parents, 169 Stratford Road, Brooklyn, to Milton Robert Dorf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dorf of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Samuel J. Levinson.
The participants in the annual interscholastic tennis tournament to be held this week on the courts of the Manursing Island Club will be honored tomorrow night at a dance at the clubhouse.

The sharp recovery in stocks in Wall Street did not surprise the banks here, which had observed that bonds had been advancing for some time. According to precedent, therefore, an advance in stocks was due.

The Rev. J. Earl Endres, 159-19 Ninety-eighth Street, Howard Beach, Queens, was in St. Luke's Hospital here suffering from a probable fractured skull and jaw as the result of an automobile accident today. His car skidded and hit another. Mrs. Endres was not hurt.
It is permissible to hope that once the question of volunteers in Spain is settled, conversations for an entente between France and Italy will be resumed and will succeed.

The seventy-second annual commencement exercises of the Peddie School will be held here tomorrow morning in the First Baptist Church, with 109 boys receiving diplomas. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School of Rochester, N. Y., will address the graduates.

Wall Street's surprising upswing has been a primary factor in the distinct revival of London's securities market this week, although the movement here is merely a pale reflection of the vigorous advance in New York.

Undaunted by a terrific downpour, which sent the gallery scurrying for safety, W. Neal Fulkerson Jr. of the home club and Thomas MoEntee of Hempstead captured the third annual best-ball invitation golf tournament at the Cherry Valley Club today, repeating their victory of a year ago.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, arriving aboard the motor ship Kungsholm tomorrow morning, will be unable to take part in the tercentenary celebration of the landing of the first Swedish colonists in Delaware.

It would be a serious mistake to overestimate the importance of the new tax law as a factor in the business outlook, according to the current issue of The Guaranty Survey, published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Miss Selma Cynthia Halpern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Halpern of 245 West 107th Street, was married to Abraham Abbott Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Friedman, also of New York, yesterday afternoon in the Perroquet Room of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Rev. Joseph Zeitlin of Temple Ansche Chesed.

Although official confirmation was lacking, well-informed quarters stated tonight that an agreement had been reached between France and Turkey over the admission of Turkish troops into the Sanjak of Alexandretta for the avowed purpose of assisting in the maintenance of order.

The fact that an old elevator is being refurbished for the first time since Civil War days may not be news in a city that abounds in skyscrapers and streamlined lifts, but it does help to focus attention on Adolph Paar.

The value of retail sales of new passenger automobiles showed a decline from April to May wihch makes allowance for the number of days as well as for seasonal movements, the Department of Commerce has reported.

The Great Consolidated Electric Power Company, Ltd., through Dillon, Read Co., fiscal agents, has announced that $450,000 of its first-mortgage 7 per cent sinking fund bonds, Series A, due in 1944, has been drawn for redemption on Aug. 1 at 100 and accrued interest for the sinking fund.

The elections to the Supreme Soviets of the constituent republics and autonomous regions ended today with voting in the Russian Socialist Federated Soviet Republic, which covers most of the Soviet Union, including Siberia, White Russia and Ukraine.

Pierce Ave (15-4111), n w cor of Yates Ave. 32x100; Sophie Majewski to Dollar Savings Bank; installments, 4 per cent; $14,500. Willis Ave, 111 (9-2298): Dalkin Realty Co to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank: extends mtg to March 19, 1943, at 5 per cent: $14,600.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the american News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:
A former speed skater, Edward Searle, unattached, defeated Chester T. Birch, 1937 winner, in the final of the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club invitation tournament today by 3 and 1.

George J. Lyons, chairman of the employes endorsement committee of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday that gifts have been received to date from 1,580 employee groups that are new contributors to the private social welfare and health agencies of the city.

A small group of blind newsdealers, led by friends or feeling their way with sticks, gathered yesterday at the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, to hold an informal celebration of the tenth anniversary of the founding. of the New York Protective Association of Blind Newsdealers, Inc.

Purchases of houses in Manhattan for modernizing formed the bulk of realty activity over the week-end. The Harlem Savings Bank sold to a syndicate headed by Edward Del Vecchio the four-story tenement on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 172 East 104th Street.

Andrew J. Peters, lawyer, banker and political leader, who had served as Mayor of Boston, State legislator, Representative in Congress and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, died early tonight in the Faulkner Hospital, where he was admitted on Tuesday suffering from pneumonia. His age was 66.
Maurice J. Curran, vice president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company and a director of the Shawmut National Bank of Boston, died today at his estate here after a long illness. His age was 83.

Jewish-owned business undertakings and those in which Jews hold a part interest or administrative control soon will be publicly designated as such through the display of a sign or symbol on the front of business premises.

In his "fireside" chat the President made two statements that it is instructive to put together. He asserted that the leaders of private enterprise had made the mistake of "setting many of their prices too high for their goods to sell."

The American League cast for baseball's annual all-star game to be played July 6 at Cincinnati was selected today and for a sixth time Lou Gehrig and Charley Gehringer, two of the game's most enduring stars, received choice roles.
German production of steel ingots in May rose sharply to 1,896,300 tons; for the first five months of this year output was 9,193,000 tons, against 7,901,700 tons in the corresponding part of 1937.
The Senators swept a double-header today, drubbing the Browns, 9 to 1, in the first game and 7-2 in the final. Al Simmons and Sammy West hit home runs in each contest.

Last week's Boerse here opened dull and predominately lower, the depressing influences being the import surplus for May and later the expulsion from the market of Jewish traders, who, on Tuesday, Thursday and Friday liquidated their holdings, particularly rubber and linoleum shares.
California's Miss Helen Jacobs and Miss Margot Lumb of England held the key to Wimbledon's women's tennis championship today as fifteen women and eight men entered the final week of singles.

Delegates attending the twentysixth annual convention of the National Council of Young Israel voted approval here today of a project to permit emigration of a limited number of Austrian and German Jewish students to the United States to continue their studies.

The Rev. William Mannes O'Bierne, who was ordained a member of the Dominican Order in Washington June 16, celebrated his first solemn high mass yesterday in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, where he formerly had been a member of the choir.

The total circulation of 115 general magazines increased 7 per cent in 1937, as compared with 1936, according to the third annual report, "A Circulation, Rate and Linage Study of 276 General Magazines," just issued by the magazine committee of the Association of National Advertisers, Inc. Newsstand sales rose 16 per cent last year, while boy sales registered a decrease of 7 per cent.

Promenade, 7-year-old chestnut mare from the Bell-Ho Stables of Montvale, N. J., today captured the sweepstakes for saddle horses at the first Pegasus Club Horse Show and thereby took the unofficial championship of the division, although there was no title involved.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.1, which compares with 81 the week before, 80.7 two weeks before, 80.5 three weeks before and 80.8 four weeks before.
Deaths from railway crossing accidents in the first three months of this year numbered 362, a decrease of 133 from the same period last year, according to the Association of American Railroads.

Despite an early afternoon rain, fourteen matches were played in the men's'New Jersey State tennis championship at the Montclair Athletic Club today. The three seeded stars who played advanced without difficulty. A fourth, William Lurie of Brooklyn, defaulted.
Dr. Samuel J. Gittelson, a founder of Mount Sinai Hospital and chief of its eye clinic for thirty years, died today at his home, 1,017 Spruce Street, after a six-months illness, at the age of 68.

Mr. and Mrs. John M. Cobden of New York have members of four generations of the Cobden family as their guests at their Summer home at South Egremont. They are Dr. and Mrs. Richard Cobden Sr., and Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. M. Cobden of Larchmont, N. Y.;

The prevailing view among the bankers of this State, as represented by the 400 delegates to the forty-fifth annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association now meeting here, is that a definite upturn in business conditions is at hand.

The Sokol festivities, held only once every six years and for the tenth time this year, today reached their zenith as far as the junior branch was concerned in a colorful, impressive display in the new stadium outside Prague.
President Lazaro Cardenas suspended today the issuance of the 100,000,000-peso bonds recently authorized by Congress to provide funds for payments to expropriated oil companies.

The late Senator Royal S. Copeland was eulogized last night as a statesman, friend and "country doctor" by several former colleagues at a memorial service held in the Broadway Temple at 174th Street and Broadway.
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association announced yesterday that it had signed a collective bargaining agreement with the American Tankers Corporation, covering about thirty men on seven vessels.

Giving a splendid display of teamwork on their home turf, the Bostwick Field poloists galloped to a 10-to-6 victory over East Williston today to continue unbeaten in the Meadow Brook Club Cups competition.for twenty-goal combinations.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that its "war chest" fund for strike purposes had passed the half-way mark, with total collections exceeding $125,000. The strike fund was authorized last Fall in a coast-wide referendum taken at the time the union voted on its new constitution.

The Cardinals and Dodgers played ball for an hour and thirty-nine minutes yesterday and got as far as a 1-1 tie in five and one-half innings before it rained to halt the first game of a scheduled doubleheader.

A tiny humming bird with a lot of courage is guarding the front porch of the J. H. Jackson home. The bird built a nest atop a porch light-globe and is attempting to hatch two eggs. "She just sits there peaceful as can be until somebody starts to come up the porch," said Mrs. Jackson.

On their wedding trip, Lily Pons and Andre Kostelanetz arrived here an hour and a half late tonight in darkness, which prevented thousands who had flocked to the airport to see the singer and her conductor husband from getting even a glimpse of them.
The foreign exchange market here was quiet last week, equilibrium being maintained without intervention from the equalization fund.

The June financial review of the Midland Bank of London, discussing The Function of Gold in the Present World Situation, endeavors to explain the remarkable and often paradoxical international movements of gold, the hoarding of quite unprecedented quantities, notably in England, and the accumulation, during the four past years, of more than $5,000,000,000 in the vaults of the United States Government. The Midland Bank,

The International Standard Electric Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, announced yesterday that it had arranged for offering to the public in Switzerland and The Netherlands an issue of 4 per cent fifteen-year debentures of a total amount equivalent to approximately $15,000,000.

Miss Janice Sandler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Sandler of 40 West Seventy-seventh Street, was married to Dr. Harry Lionel Shapiro, associate curator on anthropology at the American Museum of Natural History, last night at the Gotham. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Elias Solomon of Temple Shaare Zedek, who was a classmate of the bride's father at the Jewish Theological Seminary.

Restoration of the protection to slum dwellers formerly contained in the City Charter and inadvertently omitted from the Administrative Code is urged by Howard H. Spellman, a member of the City Council, in a letter addressed to the members of the Board of Estimate. Mr. Spellman is the author

A mortgage for $19,850 on 38 Rivington St, held by the Abenro Realty Corp from the 553 Main St Holding Corp, was extended to June 30, 1939, at 4 per cent. Josephine L. Brokaw assigned to Cornelius A. Lowe a mortgage for $9,500 and another for $12,000, both on 461 9th Ave.
The Chaco peace conference is preparing to announce the definite failure of its three years of efforts to settle the territorial conflict between Bolivia and Paraguay.

Thirty-one Nazarene nurses of the Catholic Women's Association school in Brooklyn were graduated yesterday in exercises held in the auditorium of St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, Park Place and Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn. The Very Rev. Mgr. Patrick J. Rogers, president of the school, delivered the commencement address.

John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, asserted in a statement today that President Roosevelt had distorted the position of the opposition in his radio address Friday night and had made statements based upon misinformation.

The coastal front was quiet again today after the Loyalist's loss of Onda yesterday, but all signs point to a change of the Rebels' main axis from the Teruel-Sagunto Highway to the coast road and hence heavy fighting is expected in the coming days.

Last week brought no important fresh newsconcerning the prospects for the wheat harvest in Europe. The grain situation on this side of the Atlantic is likely to await that in the United States in the immediate future, although the later outcome of the crops in Europe will be a decisive factor.
The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, on June 22 stood at 72, compared with 71.9 a fortnight before, 72.2 a month ago and 60.4 in September, 1931.

Pat Mucci of Newark, representing the Branch Brook Golf Club, won the third annual Metropolitan Golf Association's public links championship at the Aviation-Golf Club today by defeating Charles Amandoles of La Tourette, Staten- Island, 2 and 1.

Mrs. Constance Plummer McCormick of this city, widow of Leander Hamilton McCormick, author and inventor, died today of a heart attack in the home of her son, Alister McCormick, in Santa Barbara, Calif.

George Popham Moore of Buffalo, N. Y., retired hotel operator and former vice president of the Buffalo Ice Company, died yesterday in the Downey Hospital, Gainesville, Ga., after an emergency operation to relieve an intestinal ailment, according to word received here by his son, Lansing P. Moore.

A cool, rainy twilight shut down over this river town tonight as the members of eighteen crews racked their oars and waited for the renewal tomorrow afternoon of the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

ACCORDING to what might be called current comment along the Hudson River just above Poughkeepsie, the University of Washington crew is expected to be first down the river in the varsity race today unless the shell springs a leak or runs into a bridge abutment.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just read Arthur Krock's column in THE TIMES of June 24 called "The Puzzle of the Foreign Labor Survey." In his prophecies concerning the work of the President's commission I have no interest.
To say that last week's stock and bond markets caught even Wall Street by surprise, would be merely to repeat what every one is saying. The scope of advance was itself somewhat startling.

Five more bombs exploded today in the quarter between Jaffa and Tel Aviv wounding fifteen Arabs. Soon after the first bomb exploded in the morning a mob of Arabs raided a Jew's shop and stabbed the proprietor.

The Pittsburgh Crawfords defeated the New York Black Yankees, 5 to 3, in the feature game of a double-header played by four teams in the Negro National Baseball League at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The game was confined to five innings because of rain and darkness.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 26.--Details of a Henleinist plot against German and Czech Social Democrats in the Sudeten German areas will- be revealed in tomorrow's edition of Montag.

The Phillies and Reds divided a double-header today before 8,500 fans. The Phils won the first game, 10 to 3, behind the steady pitching of Claude Passeau, who stuck to the finish despite fourteen hits. Cincinnati took the second, 8 to 5, for Paul Derringer's tenth victory.

A pavilion that follows in architecture the design of the Parthenon on the Acropolis in Athens was dedicated this afternoon on the grounds of the 236-acre farm that serves as an extension of the Wartburg Orphans Farm School at Mount Vernon.

Dan Coley's Pole Star won the second race today in the series for the John Taylor Arms Star Class Trophy on Long Island Sound. She was 52 seconds ahead of John Taylor, Arms Jr.'s Andiamo, which was disabled in the first race yesterday and did not finish.

Another fruitless day of search for Medill McCormick, 21, of the publishing family. was concluded tonight as the rocky heights of Sandia Peak for the third successive day mocked efforts of scores of searchers to learn his fate.

The American Jewish Congress closed a three-day poll last night at 10 o'clock for the country-wide election of delegates to a session in September to discuss the safeguarding of equal rights for Jews.

Twenty umbrella manufacturers in this city decided at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker last night to form an organization to work for better conditions in the trade. Jacob P. Lefkowitz, attorney for several of them, who presided at the meeting, said that the makers sought to raise the standards of the industry by ending "cut-throat competition" and by informing members of new developments in government and the market.

Establishment of an air traffic school was announced yesterday by Evans K. Smith, a graduate of the Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics, who has been associated with several transport companies. Offices will be at 41 East Forty-seventh Street. The course, which will require eight weeks, will be held in the evenings and cover all phases of air traffic.

Public hearings will be held throughout New York State next week by the Board of Standards and Appeals of the State Department of Labor on a proposed revision of Industrial Code Bulletin No. 26, constituting the industrial code rules affecting "the construction, equipment, arrangement and maintenance" of mercantile establishments in buildings erected after April 1, 1924.

Few lives are so rich in various experience and accomplishment as his, so tragically ended. Teacher of pupils whose tuition fee was 5 cents apiece, lawyer, editor, poet, maker of songs that were in everybody's mouth, a consul who won the confidence of American naval officers and commanded a detachment of sailors in a Central American revolution, a politician with Roosevelt and Harding, he was to become one of the foremost of Negro leaders.

Vicente Lombardo Toledano, secretary-general of the Mexican Federation of Labor (C. T. M.), declared here today that the German Government had a chain of Nazi espionage centers operating between Mexican and Latin-American points and centers in San Diego, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

The Republican majority in the Constitutional Convention went on record tonight in favor of the Dewey proposal concerning search and seizure and wiretapping, but its program met with aggressive and unexpected denunciation from one of its own most conspicuous members.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After listening to President Roosevelt's "fireside chat" we need not wonder where the government is headed. He has told us very plainly, although not in so many words, that economic life in this country is to follow the authoritarian pattern established by some of the European countries. Government is to take a more active part in directing and stimulating industry so as to relieve the unemployment situation.
Governor A. Harry Moore disclosed today that the Federal Government had offered to make a WPA grant of $9,600,000 to put 10,000 more relief recipients to work on New Jersey roads.

George Bernard Shaw faced today what probably will be the biggest problem in' his long life. It is to follow these physician's orders: Don't talk to any one about anything. Don't read controversial topics in newspapers.

A motorcade of forty vehicles of the 62d Coast Artillery (Anti-aircraft), Fort Totten, Queens, transporting 160 soldiers, searchlights, listening "ears," 3-inch guns ana .50 caliber machine guns left Fort Totten at 4 A. M. yesterday for Gettysburg, Pa.
Magistrate Rudich in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, dismissed yesterday a charge of disorderly conduct against Max Seidenbaum, 42 years old, a lawyer, of 476 East Twentyninth Street, Brooklyn.
Thomas O'Connor, a lawyer for more than fifty years and former Democratic leader in Waterford, died early today at his home after a long illness.

Playing in a downpour of rain, the Women's National Golf Club five of Long Island won the 1938 interclub championship today. Mrs. W. R. Kirkland Jr., Mrs. Joseph C. Dey Jr. and Mrs. J. B. Balding, scoring 2 points each, helped their team to a 7 1/2-point total in the final round of the women's metropolitan team championship over the east course of the Winged Foot Country Club.

There was a decline in the wholesale price level last week, according to the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. This index, in the week ended June 25, dropped to 74.1 from 74.5 in the preceding week. A month ago the index stood at 74.2 and a year ago at 87.4, based on the 1926-28 average as 100.
Edward A. Devlin, an architect, died at the Naval Hospital here yesterday after a long illness. He was 51 years old.
A Reuters dispatch from Graz, Austria, today says that 80 per cent of the crops in Eastern Styria have been destroyed by floods in the last twenty-four hours.
Encouraging reports on this year's wheat crop continue. Most provinces expect a yield equal to or greater than last year's.

The Earle Administration received a setback today in its plan to have Guy K. Bard, State Attorney General, "assume direction of the proposed grand jury investigation of charges against Governor Earle and thirteen fellow Democrats.

Mr. and Mrs. Humphrey Bancroft Neill of Larchmont, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Genevieve Wells Brown, to Thomas Hulbert Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Stewart of New Haven, Conn.
Conditions in the West and Southwest indicate increased traffic for the remainder of the year for the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, S. T. Bledsoe, president, said yesterday.
Stocks eased on profit-taking and closed irregularly lower, after industrial issues reached new high levels for year to date; turnover, 2,105,840 shares.

City employes who congregate outside the Manhattan Municipal Building for lunch-hour conversations were asked yesterday- to break themselves of the habit of resting one heel against the base of the building while they talk. Edward W. Markham, Commissioner of Public Works, sent this request to all department heads, telling them that he has had the base of the building cleaned with acid and steam at considerable expense.

Plans to reconstruct the Socialist movement in America, shattered since the split in the Socialist party, were approved by the national executive committee of the Social Democratic Federation at a meeting over the week-end, it was announced yesterday from the federation's'New York office, 7 East Fifteenth Street.
Navy's varsity rowing triumph today ended a streak of twelve consecutive victories for far Western crews, representing Washington and California, in the intercollegiate regatta.

A rise in unemployment was registered between April and May, bringing the number of unemployed in the latter month to a total of 10,310,000, according to the latest estimates of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public yesterday.

Manhattan Alterations 80th St, 20 E; to 4-story tenement; Union Dime Savings Bank, .1,065 6th Ave, owner; A. Mayer, architect; cost, .$15,000. 4th St, 306 W; -to 5-story tenement: Wormans Estates, Inc, 2,067 Broadway, owner; L. A. Swarthe, engineer; cost, $12,000. 13th St, 133-5 W; to 4-story tenement and store; Margaret C. Liddy and Florence O'Connor, 295 Madison Ave, owner; J. B. Gunnison, architect: cost. 57.000.

The loss of the use of his right hand may be the result of an unnoticed act of bravery yesterday on the part of Harry Meters, 42-year-old glazier, of 578 Williams Avenue, Brooklyn, who saved many pedestrians from possible injury or death by grabbing a jagged piece of glass with his bare hands.

Rain caused postponement of the boxing program scheduled for New York last night. Salvy Saban and Bobby Pacho, welterweights, who were slated to meet in the top bout of eight rounds at Dyckman Oval, will clash tonight.

With only two days remaining before his congregation will be forced to seek a new meeting place, Rabbi Benjamin Plotkin of Congregation Emanu-el, Jersey City, made a plea yesterday for national support in his congregation's struggle against the "fascist set-up" which opposes it.

The presidency of Upsala College has been offered to the Rev. Dr. Evald B. Lawson, pastor of the Trinity Lutheran Church of White Plains, N. Y., according to an announcement today by Dr. Frans Ericsson, acting president and dean of the college.

Miss Jane H. Todd, Westchester County Assemblywoman and vice chairman of the State Republican Committee, indicated tonight that women groups may open a drive to obtain for a woman the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor.

The National City Bank, as fiscal agent for the Kingdom of Norway, will notify today holders of the twenty-year 6 per cent bonds due on Aug. 1, 1944, and of the twenty-six-year 4 per cent bonds due in 1963 that $869,000 of the former has been drawn by lot for redemption on Aug. 1 at par and $343,000 of the latter on Aug. 1 at par, both from moneys in the respective sinking funds.

Police renewed arrests among C. I. O. organizers late today after more than 100 C. I. 0. members, seized in raids last week, had been released by the courts for lack of evidence to support vagrancy charges.

Steel operations for this week are scheduled at 28.7 per cent of ingot capacity, a gain of 0.7 point, or 2.5 per cent, over the 28 per cent rate of last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Frank Raymond Coates, an officer or director in seventeen large corporations, chiefly in the public utility, railway and oil industries, died Sunday night after a long illness at his home in Avon, N. J., it was announced here yesterday by associates.
Th Browns slipped further into the American League cellar today, bowing to the seventh-place White Sox, 9 to 4, in the first of a four-game series.
As a part of the Wilmington ceremonies commemorating the 300th anniversary of the Swedes' landing in Delaware, 3-cent tercentenary stamps were placed on sale at Convention Hall today.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended June 23 was 233, compared with 247 in the preceding week and 148 in the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
The Most Rev. Francis R. Phelps, Archbishop of Cape Town until his retirement last Easter, died here today at the ages of 74.

A burning signal cable in a tube of the Long Island Railroad, under the East River, delayed Long Island traffic from Pennsylvania Station last night for more than two hours, making most of the 100,000 homeward-bound commuters late for dinner.

Generalissimo Francisco Franco told this correspondent today that there was only one solution for the problems created by the bombing of ports of Loyalist Spain by Insurgent aircraft-setting apart a single harbor far from the seat of the war devoted solely to commercial traffic of a non-military nature.

A special grand jury late today indicted seven persons, including three important aides of Governor Davey, on charges of violating civil service laws in soliciting contributions from State employes for the Governor's third-term campaign fund.
Putting a stop to persistent rumors that Brazil contemplated modifying its foreign exchange policy, Tancredo Ribas Carneiro, exchange director of Brazil, said today that the report was untrue.

After battling twelve hours against a fire they could not reach in the boring of the Queens Midtown Tunnel, eighty-five feet beneath the surface of the East River, firemen drowned out the blaze at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

President Roosevelt and three members of the Swedish royal family, including the bedfast Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf. made a success today of Delaware's long-planned tercentenary despite a continuous rain squall, with intermittent thunder and lightning, which thoroughly drenched every one.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 24 CAPTAIN Chambers, W., to duty as medical officer in command of Naval Medical School, Washington, D. C., July 1.

The Polish Diet (Parliament) by a rising vote approved today arrangements previously agreed upon between the Polish Government and holders of its bonds in the United States for lowering interest rates on Polish loans.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jeannette Dodd Dorland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Dorland of this place, to Reed Bonney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Bonney, also of Glen Ridge.
Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow may return to London in an effort to effect withdrawal of a restraining order obtained against him by his wife, the formerBarbara Hutton.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Airflame will carry the top weight of 126 pounds in the Fleetwing Handicap, with $5,000 added, at Empire City on Saturday. Airflame tops thirty-three eligibles for whom Handicapper John B. Campbell yesterday announced weights.

Class Day exercises were held today at the Phillips Exeter Academy and in the afternoon Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Perry received the members of the graduating class, their families and friends at the principal's house.

The texts of the speeches made today at the presentation of the monument at Fort Christina Park by Prince Bertil of Sweden, President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull follow in the order of their delivery:
Playing more impressively than at any time this season, Miss Helen Jacobs today entered the quarterfinal round of the Wimbledon tennis championships with a 6-3, 6-0 triumph over Miss Peggy Scriven.
The international stock market indices for June 25, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
L. P. Page, controller of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company, outlined today a "fiveyear plan" for reorganization of the company on a profitable basis.
The European situation is improving gradually, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday on his return from Europe.
California Water Service Company--Twelve months to May 31: Gross revenues $2,474,935, against $2,412,625 in the preceding twelve months; gross corporate income $935,075, against $970,851.
President Frederico Laredo Bru's budget message, which reached the Senate this afternoon, set national expenditures for 1938-39 at $86,077,034.96, with income estimated at $86,099,510.

Woodrow Wilson's birthplace, The Manse, at Staunton, will be purchased and preserved as a national shrine, it was disclosed here today when the Virginia Corporation Commission granted a charter to the Woodrow Wilson Birthplace Foundation, Inc.

The French Maternal School sold to Nicholas Lucchesi the house at 346 W 28th St at a price shown as $15,500 and took back a p m mortgage for $12,000, due five years hence at 4 1/2 per cent,- and the School also sold the building next door, at 348 W 28th St, both being 21 1/2 feet wide, to Guglielmo Gianelli at the same price, taking back a similar mortgage.

Jeremiah Tracy of 161-26 Eighty-fourth Avenue, Jamaica, for more than ten years a clerk in the municipal courts in Brooklyn, succumbed to a heart attack at 7 A. M. yesterday while on his way to work. His age was 57.

After considerable delay and conferences between the United States Maritime Commission and the Roosevelt Steamship Company, a subsidiary of the United States Lines, the date for the reopening of the intercoastal passenger service between New York and San Francisco has been definitely fixed for Aug. 6.

Yellow River floods, which three weeks ago halted the Japanese advance on this railroad junction, were considered today to be helping the invaders, - protecting their flank while the main force moved to more active fronts to the west and south.

Henry Aubepin, former president of the Paris Bar Association, died here today at the age of 69. Although Mr. Aubepin chiefly handled civil cases such as the affairs of Princess Charlotte of Monaco and the Coty estate, he sometimes pleaded big criminal court cases.

Offering will be made to the public today by Aeronautical Securities Research Corporation of 300,000 shares of common stock of Aeronautical Securities, Inc. The first 5,000 shares of stock will be offered at $7.50 a share, and thereafter they will be sold at the net asset value plus a stated commission.
Charles P. Sheridan, clerk of the New York County Surrogates' Court and former Tammany leader of the Sixteenth Assembly District, North, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

An unheralded Michigan State senior, Edward J. Flowers, of Grand Rapids, set the pace today for a record field in the opening qualifying round of the forty-first annual national intercollegiate golf championship.

Elmore Gaigano, 20-year-old bride of less than nine months, jumped from the fire escape of her apartment on the fourth floor of 48-08 108th Street, Corona, Queens, about 5 o'clock yesterday morning and died three hours later in Flushing Hospital. A quarrel with her husband, Dominick, preceded the leap, according to Detective James Sullivan.

The question of whether the broad but little used powers of the government under the Official Secrets Act can be invoked against a Member of Parliament to force him to reveal the sources upon which he based a parliamentary question was raised for the first time in the House of Commons today and promises to result in a first-class issue.

The national average construction cost index of thirty cities remained at 182 in May, the same as in April of this year and May, 1937, construction cost indices released yesterday by the American Appraisal Company reveal.

A recession in business does not means a recession in human wants, but the current sharp curtailment in advertising indicates that business is making the grave mistake of believing it does, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., New York, said today at the thirty-fifth annual convention of the Pacific Coast Advertising Clubs.

Representative Bertrand H. Snell, for the past twenty-four years a member of the House from the Thirty-first district of New York and for the past seven years Republican House leader, today announced that he would not seek re-election this year.
Canio's heart is breaking--but the show must go on. Leo, the lion, has just mauled his keeper and the lovely lady ropewalker falls unconscious into the net-but the show must go on.
A syndicate headed by Newman, Harris Co., New Orleans, will offer State of Louisiana refunding 2 1/2, 3 1/2 and 3 1/4 per cent bonds.

THERE'S a chap who has a scheme for knocking all race-track records for a loop. That goes for horse tracks, trotting and running, velodromes, six-day bike saucers and the Indianapolis Speedway. He isn't going to do it by improving the breed of horses, bike riders or automobiles, either. It's much simpler than that.
Edward W. Reynolds of 205 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, head machinist of the composing room of The New York Journal and American, died yesterday of heart disease after an illness of five months.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Parsons Moore gave a dinner last night at the Pierre Roof for Mr. Moore's sister, Miss Dorothy Parsons Moore, and her fiance, James Wilson Tower, who will be married tomorrow in the Central Presbyterian Church.

" World citizenship and education" is the theme of the seventy-sixth convention of the National Education Association of the United States. Whethe there is any connection with the selection of New York as a meeting place we do not know.
Six Latin-American coffee-producing countries started a campaign today to increase the consumption of iced coffee in the United States.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the United Gas Improvement Company, the Susquehanna Utilities Company and the Philadelphia Electric Power Company, all of Philadelphia, and the Commonwealth Utilities Corporation of Wilmington, Del., had filed registration statements under the Holding Company Act.

Drapery business of the manufacturing division of Marshall Field Co., Inc., will be taken over July 1 by the newly formed Colonial Drapery Fabrics, Inc., headed by G. B. Jacobus, it was learned here yesterday.

Debutantes were honored tonight at several parties along the North Shore as a week filled with dinners, dances, suppers and luncheons started. Country homes are open for the season, and almost all are gay with guests who have been invited for the debutante festivities of the "little season."

The suggestion of Afred J. Talley that the organization of Tammany Hall be changed, that district leaders be abolished and that the chairman of the county committee, as in every other county in the State, be made the head of the county organization instead of the leader of Tammany Hall, met with little support yesterday.
Mention of the names of Dr. Sigmund Freud, psychoanalyst, and Raoul Auernheimer, playwright, today brought delegates to the international convention of P. E. N. clubs to their feet, cheering.
George L. Burr, Professor Emeritus of Medieval History at Cornell University, died here today in Memorial Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage and heart disease.
J. G. Bucklin, turkey farmer, counted his turkeys before they were hatched, and today President Roosevelt vetoed a bill to pay him $516.12 for his shattered expectations.
Frank K. Houston, in 400 Park Ave: John W. Bonney. in 105 W 55th St; Frederic Drake, in 1 W 67th St; Joseph Cameron Dunn, in 51 5th Ave; Max Kraus, in 29 Washington Sq; Wm. A. White Sons, broker.

Six airplanes scoured the treacherous Andes Mountain region between La Paz, Bolivia, and Arequipa, Peru, today searching for the Lufthansa bimotored airliner Misti, missing on its regular 240-mile flight between the two cities.

Severin Winterscheidt, 34 years old, of 64 Himrod Street, Brooklyn, a lieutenant of Fritz Kuhn in the Nazi movement centering around the German-American Bund, was convicted yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, of indecent exposure. He was continued in $1,000 bail for sentence on July 6.

A preview of some of the main attractions of the Village Fair, which will open tonight in Washington. Mews, was held yesterday afternoon between showers. One of the unusual sights was the milking of a cow in a fenced barnyard opening on Fifth Avenue, with the Washington Arch in the background.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today an amendment to its rules under the Holding Company Act to permit the sale of privately owned public utility properties and securities to publicly owned utilities without the necessity of having to obtain the commission's approval.
The retirement of Bertrand H. Sell from Congress will not affect the political complexion of the New York State contingent in the House.
An automobile brought here from Bellows Falls, Vt., by State police tonight assumed major importance in the mystery surrounding the finding of a wire-bound body last week in the Connecticut River.

" Internationally minded" teachers are needed to develop "internationally minded" pupils, Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president emeritus of Mount Holyoke College, said last night at the meeting of the National Education Association at the Hippodrome. She said nations that broke treaties menaced the future of civilization.
A renewed wave of suicides among Jews is sweeping Vienna as the result of Nazi orders that Jewish employes must be released by both "Aryan" and Jewish firms.

Princeton University's annual Summer session will open tomorrow. with an enrollment of more than 125 freshmen, sophomores and juniors expected to attend, it was announced today by Professor Robert G. Albion, director of the session.

The Federal Surplus Commodities a Corporation, a Government agency which for several years has been buying up various "gluts" of agricultural commodities to "sustain the market" and distributing these commodities to persons on relief, has suddenly widened a the field of its operations.
The Jews of Palestine observed a day of semimourning today in sympathy for the Revisisnist youth, Ben Yosef, who is under a death sentence for having fired on an Arab-owned bus.

Defending the newspapers of America against the accusation that they print too much crime news, Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney, declares in an article in the July Issue of The Kiwanis Magazine that the overthrow of the criminal empires of Al Capone, Waxey Gordon and Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer was in large measure the work of the press.
Despite a nasty, wet northeaster, twenty-one crews started out today in the ninth annual regatta of the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

Retailers reported a very poor business last week-end and trading was slow in the wholesale markets. Steer beef was strong to higher, fresh pork cuts steady to slightly higher, other classes little changed from last week's close. The kosher markets opened slow and steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had:

Strained relations between China and Germany growing out of the German-Japanese pact and out of Berlin's recent recall of German military advisers from China reached a climax here yesterday when the German Ambassador, Dr. Oskar Trautmann, left Hankow by, airplane for Hong Kong en route to Germany;

Following closely the announcement by the United States Steel Corporation of drastic price reductions on a broad list of products, the Bethlehem Steel Company posted last night new prices for shipment of products not later than Sept. 30, with cuts ranging up to 17 per cent.

A jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court returned a verdict yesterday awarding $3,750 to Mrs. Josephine Cox of 460 Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, for injuries suffered when she fell over an old-fashioned "horse block" in front of 67 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, on Aug. 9, 1935.

An offer made in behalf of a group of defendants to return $345,000 to the Crocker-Wheeler Electric Manufacturing Company in return for the discontinuance of a suit brought by minority stockholders in the company was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick.

The Federal Government continued to get money at new low-record interest rates today when the Treasury Department announced the sale of $100,000,000 of ninety-one day bills at an average rate of 0.011 per cent, compared with 0.016 for a similar issue sold last week.
Britain and France made known today a warning to Japan to keep her hands off the strategic island of Hainan, off the South China coast, and a pledge to act together to handle any "complications."

Four seeded players, including Bobby Riggs of Chicago, the defending champion, and Joe Hunt of Los Angeles, 1937 runner-up, advanced to the semi-finals of the national clay courts tennis tournament today.

A pageant entitled "Skylines," centering about the development of education from the days of ancient Greece to modern times, was presented last night for the benefit of those attending the convention of the National Education Association, at the Brooklyn Technical High School auditorium.

The Navy Department said today it had been informed that Lieut. Comdr. F. H. Gilmer, in charge of the United States gunboat Tutila in China, died of a gunshot wound inflicted aboard the ship. The death occurred at Ichang, China, where the Tutila was stationed, the department said, adding that it had received no additional information.

In a day reminiscent of the one two years ago, when the national amateur championship was played here, E. H. Driggs Jr., former holder of the New York State title, and his son, E. H. 3d, who just completed his freshman year at Princeton, today won the annual metropolitan father and son tournament when they negotiated the Garden City Golf Club course in 77 strokes, only four above par figures.
Two non-union taxicab drivers were beaten early yesterday, morning, one fatally, in what police considered an outgrowth of labor warfare. Their assailants are being sought.

Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, mentioned as the next Chief of Staff of the army, has been tentatively scheduled to relieve Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy as Commanding General of the Second Corps Area, with headquarters on Governors Island, it was learned yesterday.
" The Congress also failed to meet my suggestion that it take the farreaching steps necessary to put the railroads of the country back on their feet."
Rabbi A. M. 'Heller of Brooklyn tonight urged a synagogue affiliation with the Zionist Organization of America to "enhance the Zionist movement in this country."
Daniel J. O'Connell of Milton, a school and college athlete, wartime naval aviator and New England sales representative of a Baltimore distillery firm, died today at the age of 45.

Pat Harrison, Mississippi's senior Senator and long-time Democratic leader in Washington, was placed in the list of 1940 "favorite-sons" today when the State Democratic Executive Committee endorsed him for the Presidency in that year.

The little hamlet of Brielle, down on the New Jersey coast, is leading its rival, Freeport, L. I., by at least five open lengths this season, for last Saturday Captain Driscoll of the Stroller brought in five tuna.

The Museum of Modern Art, condensing slightly its current exhibition of "Masters of Popular Painting," will open to the public today in one of- its galleries a show consisting of sixteen of the architecturaldesigns submitted in the recent competition for a proposed art center at Wheaton College, Norton, Mass.

The news that two more British ships had been bombed at Spanish Government ports with the loss of four lives again emphasized today a situation that is rapidly becoming extremely serious for the British Government.

The first oil strike in Great Britain since the government invited several companies to begin drilling nearly a year ago has been made by the Anglo-American Oil Company's experimental bore near Dalkeith, Scotland.
CONFESSIONS OF AN ECONOMIC HERETIC, by J. A. Hobson. (Macmillan, $2.) Essays on economic thought.
Government forces on the Teruel and Onda sectors in Eastern Spain held firmly before repeated Insurgent attacks today and countered with offensives of their own.
The United States Court of Appeals dismissed today the $500,000 libel suit of Bishop James Cannon Jr. against Representative George H. Tinkham, Republican, of Massachusetts.

Homes were inundated, highways covered with water and crops badly damaged in parts of Southern New Jersey by rain that tonight had lashed the Camden and Philadelphia area for more than twenty-four hours.

While a New York specialist waited outside Cabin A-4 on the Kungsholm here today and a violent rainstorm churned the usually tranquil Christina River, a sick man inside the cabin suggested from his berth that "never be downhearted" was a good motto.

John J. Delany Sr. of 2,905 Avenue K, Brooklyn, died on Sunday at his home after a long illness at the age of 82. He was born in Manhattan, Aug. 15, 1855. He would have been married sixty years next Thanksgiving Day.

CHEMICAL ENGINEER (EXPLOSIVES MANUFACTURE AND PLANT MANAGEMENT), $3,800 a year, Navy Department. Applications must be on file not later than July 28 if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming and not later than July 25 from all other States.

The Chinese defenders of the Matang forts along the Yangtze River continue to hold out against repeated Japanese attacks in the drive toward Hankow; 200 miles upriver. Chinese military reports say the assaults have been repulsed with heavy casualties to the Japanese.
Edward Noel Neilson, a church organist here for fifty-four years, died yesterday in the Elizabeth General Hospital after a brief illness.

A committee headed by Adam L. Gimbel, president of Saks Fifth Avenue, was appointed yesterday at a special meeting of the larger stores of the Uptown Retail Guild to work out plans for the participation of the stores in the Apparel and Accessories Building project at the World's Fair.

In the event that Governor Lehman receives the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate to serve out the two-year balance of the term of the late Royal S. Copeland, he will have the complete support of the New York State Federation of Labor.
Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator, told the Workers' Alliance today that "many things would have been straightened out" if President Roosevelt had received the support he should have had;

A testimonial to Charles E. Moerler of Manhattan, retiring Grand Regent of the Royal Arcanum of the State of New York, was given on the roof of the Hotel St. George, In Brooklyn, last night under the direction of Arcanum Councils of the greater city, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

To supply the need for leaders in music, which is part of the demand for more music in general, we need to have a new type of musician, said Alexander Richter of the High School-of Music and Art yesterday, addressing the Department of Secondary Education at the American Museum of Natural History.
When Epiphani Dante, 50 years old, was expelled from his native Italy for political reasons he came here swearing eternal hate for Premier Benito Mussolini.

Guidance has become a "commercialized racket," Dr. Anna Y. Reed, Professor of Personnel Administration at the New York University School of Education, declared yesterday in an address before the National Association of Deans of Women at the Hotel New Yorker.

Social Security account numbers have been assigned to 470,190 Smiths, giving persons of that name the lead among the 39,000,000 holders of old-age insurance cards, according to the Social Security Board.

After a turbulent final demonstration, in which an angry minority group of performers booed and cursed Ralph Whitehead, executive secretary of the Actors Union, for closing the show, Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, the "greatest show on earth," finally struck its banners this afternoon and began packing for its trip back to Winter quarters.

Certain officials of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and of the Alleghany Corporation, parent holding company for the railroad, participated in a "studied effort" to "avoid disclosing" material facts relating to a $15,965,201 liability under a contract with Terminal Shares, Inc.,. Richard Townsend, a trial examiner for the Securties and Exchange Commission, reported today.

Restrictions on the height of new buildings in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn were established by resolution of the City Planning Commission yesterday at its meeting in the Manhattan Municipal Building.
Mrs. James Roosevelt, wife of the President's son, and Harry Hopkins, Federal WPA Administrator, arrived today by train to visit young Roosevelt, who is undergoing examination at the Mayo Clinic.

In an editorial sharply criticizing the recent plea- by the editors of The Commonweal, Roman Catholic weekly, for an attitude of impartiality toward the civil war in Spain, another Catholic weekly, America, will take a stand "unalterably opposed" to the Loyalists in its issue to be published Saturday.

Advising them to avoid the doctrines of "false prophets both here and abroad," Raymond V. Ingersoll, Borough President of Brooklyn, in an address last night to 687 Brooklyn College graduates who received their degrees at the institution's twelfth commencement exercises, urged that they dedicate their lives to the pursuit of truth, "without which our civilization cannot survive."
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 22:

Pat Cici, 24-year-old caddy master from the Meadow Brook Club, and Joe Geraldi, Peninsula Golf Club caddy, led the qualifiers in their respective divisions in the Long Island Golf Association's fifteenth annual championship tournament for these employes at Bethpage State Park today.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday morning at his home in Keene Valley, N. Y., of Homer Brown, veteran Adirondack guide, who helped his son, Ivan Brown, build the two-man bobsled which Ivan drove to victory in the last Olympics.

The Gilmore Red Lions of Los Angeles captured the national telegraphic skeet championship with a record 491 out of 500 targets, it was announced today. The previous mark was 488, established by the Northwest Gun Club of Chicago.

Losing two second-innings' wickets for 39 runs in a brief batting session before stumps were drawn today, England carried a lead of 111 runs into the final of the second cricket test match with Australia.

A new naval and marine reserve came into existence with the signing by President Roosevelt of the bill, passed in the closing days of the last session of Congress, which provides for the creation, organization maintonance and administration of a Naval Reserve and a Marine Corps Reserve.

In the absence of a definite pronouncement on the attitude of the Nationalist [Insurgent] regime toward the British plan for withdrawing foreign volunteers from both sides in Spain, official and general opinion here appears favorable to any scheme that can be carried out with thoroughness and impartiality.

Rollo K. Blanchard, 50 years old, vice president of the Neptune Meter Company of New York, conferred unsuccessfully today with his attorneys on ways of terminating the "lie-down strike" of Mrs. Hedi Heusser, 27-year-old Swiss woman, at his estate here.

The private residence at 70 West fortieth Street, Bayonne, has been sold by the Mechanics Trust Company in liquidation to Meyer Pashelinsky, who will renovate the structure and later use it for his own occupancy. Julius A. Rose, Inc., was the broker.

A reward of "up to $1,000 for inform nation leading to the whereabouts" of Mrs. Alice M. Parsons, who disappeared last Summer from her home in Stony Brook, L. I., was offered by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors here today.

Henry C. Flower, chairman of the professional section of the Greater New York Fund, reported yesterday that 49 per cent of the corporations and firms that have made donations through his division were new contributors to private social welfare and health work.

Following Governor Lawrence W. Cramer's return to the islands and his declaration that he had made progress toward relieving the islands' economic stress by pushing requests for funds from Congress to cover municipal deficits, the Governor announced today a large building program involving the expenditure of almost $1,000,000, which he hopes will be supported by Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior.

George H. Grouard of 43 West Thirty-second Street, who died in Wilmington, Del., on June 21, named his sister, Jessie Grouard of Reading, Mass., his principal beneficiary in his will filed yesterday. His estate was formerly valued at about $300,000.

In St. Michael's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Ruth De Lamater Vezin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Vezin. Jr., was married to John Frisby Morse of Watertown, Conn., and Burlington, Vt. The Rev. Frank Damrosch, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony and was assisted by the Rev. Henry E. Kelly.

The bankers of the country were urged to take the initiative in presenting their views and knowledge before the temporary National Economic Committee, authorized by the Congress just ended, in a speech delivered here today by Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, before the final session of the forty-fifth annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association at the Saranac Inn.
President Roosevelt signed a bill today authorizing the establishment of corporate authorities in Puerto Rico to handle slum clearance and low-cost housing projects.
Trading in Manhattan realty reported yesterday centered in the West Side. A large apartment house on Riverside Drive was among' the properties changing hands.
Madison Ave, 1,190-1.200, 12-story apartment, 201.5x95; Brooklyn Trust Company, trustee, against Twelve Hundred Madison Avenue Corp; due, $1,952,375; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The stock market here was generally active today and most sections advanced. Gilt-edged issues were slightly lower, while among the foreign bonds German loans were in demand. Transatlantic stocks attracted firm support and registered all-around improvements.

The Fertig transit unification constitution clause, which would permit the City of New York to issue bonds in an amount, sufficient to acquire the privately operated transit lines, was changed tonight by its sponsor in an effort to eliminate one of the difficulties which would remain after such a deal has been agreed upon.
It might be an original bent of mind, or it might be a gift for flying off on a tangent, but the visitor had it.
Five months ago today a story came out of Providence College stating that six undergraduates had proposed a novel plan of insuring fellow-students against the danger of flunking their examinations.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick distributed yesterday by allotment to twenty-six banks and trust companies an issue of $20,000,000 of New York City special revenue bills at an interest rate of 0.35 per cent. The bills will be dated June 28 and will mature on Oct. 28.
One of the largest leases in recent months in the garment district has been made by B. Blumenthal Co., manufacturers, importers and exporters of buttons, buckles and ornaments.

The heavy export movement of corn from the United States in the last few months will be an important factor in reducing the surplus from the huge crop harvested last year. According to the Department of Commerce, corn exports from the United States in May amounted to 25,409,000 bushels, compared with 20,248,250 in April.
The 15,000 delegates to the National Education Association got into full swing yesterday as groups assembled in auditoriums and hotels throughout the city.
Miss Charlotte Geisa of Elmira, N. Y., supervisor of surgery at the Queens General Hospital, Jamaica, L. I., was killed and two others seriously injured today in an automobile accident near here.

Children need friendly teachers, and not the cold, austere type that can be found in many school classrooms, Dr. Ruth Andrus, chief of the bureau of child development of the New York State Education Department, declared yesterday in an address before the Department of Kindergarten-Primary Education at the Central Commercial High School.

When Salvatore Sarracino, 43 years old, of 2,222 West Sixth Street, Brooklyn, appeared yesterday in the Coney Island Magistrate's Court for a friend who had received a summons for undressing on the beach, he thought it would be merely a matter of doing a slight favor and paying a small fine.

The League to Amend the National Labor Relations Act moved in Supreme Court yesterday to restrain the Board of Standards and Appeals of the State Labor Department from consulting spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization as to whether it should approve the league's incorporation certificate.
