Elaborate police arrangements have been made to insure the safety and swift passage of President Roosevelt through the city Thuirsday when he arrives by motor from Hyde Park on his way to lay the cornerstone for the Federal Building at the World Fair grounds.

Mrs. R. M: Morriss Betts of 16 East Eightieth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Morriss MacCollom, to Benjamin T. Fairchild 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Tappen Fair-child of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

Townsend Townsend, Inc., whose advertising evaluation plan has become the leading topic of discussion in the field, yesterday denied in a full-page ad in a trade paper that the twenty-seven points recently published in an advertising "gossip" sheet bore any resemblance to those on which the company based its operations.

Criminals are made by the world they live in and only a "profound change in the social organization" can be expected to bring about far-reaching changes in the picture of crime as it is now known, Saul D. Alinsky of Chicago declared today at the meeting of the National Conference of Social Work.
Delegates from twenty-five nations assembled today for the first session of the International Public Works Committee, organized by the International Labor Office.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week' ended June 22, aggregated $7,744,000,000, or 10 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 13 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
Miss Grace Woodbridge Geer, artist, life-long resident of Beacon Hill and a descendant of the founders of Plymouth Colony, died yesterday at her home at the age of 83.

Accused of trying to collect the $30,000 ransom in the Peter Levine kidnapping, Werner F. Luck, 23 years old, and- Edward J. Penn, 18, were convicted today of attempted blackmail of the boy's father, Murray Levine of New Rochelle, by a jury before. County Judge Frank H. Coyne.

In shadowy twilight descending on Northwestern University's Dyche Stadium, track and field stars from the Pacific Coast Conference overwhelmingly demonstrated their superiority over a picked Western Conference squad tonight by winning their second annual dual meet, 101 to 35, before 10,000 spectators.
The Benjamin N. Duke home here has been given to Duke University by Mrs. Mary Duke Biddle of New York, who inherited the property from her mother, Mrs. Sarah Pearson Angier Duke, who died in 1936.

Any person who prepares a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission is automatically admitted to practice before the Securities and Exchange Commission, and therefore is liable for disbarment "in the event of improper conduct," according to amendments to the SEC's rules of practice announced today.
The Indians backed up Bobby Feller's Classy seven-hit pitching today with a fifteen-hit attack of their own to trounce the Red Sox, 7 to 3, and boost their American League lead to four games.

The denunciation of the American Legion by Professor William Gellermann of Northwestern University, in a doctor's thesis made public on Sunday by Teachers College, Columbia University, brought counterdenunciations of his study yesterday from Legion officials and stirred comment at the convention of the National Education Association, where a resolution censuring Professor Gellermann was drafted.
The acceptance of foreign diplomats who will attend the get-together reception and luncheon to be given at the Hotel Plaza Thursday by the United States New York World's Fair Commission
Among the passengers on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, due today from Southampton via Cherbourg, are Commander John C. Gade, United States naval attache at Brussels; Mr. and Mrs.

A defense counsel bid to have Governor Bibb Graves end the lingering "Scottsboro case" was disclosed today when The Decatur Daily published an advertisement giving notice pardons would be asked by the five Negroes now under sentence.

Deploring the lack of funds to combat such "real enemies" as ignorance, disease, crime and poverty, when billions of dollars are being spent on military defense and relief, Representative Noah M. Mason of Illinois called on teachers last night to give united support to the program of providing Federal aid for education.
Automobile production showed a normal seasonal easing last week, and the adjusted index held steady to the previous week's level of 43.1. It was 127.3 for the week ended June 26, 1937.

About twenty-five small textile factories, most of them run by Jews, have been closed during the past few days, the newspaper Noticias said today. These factories allegedly have not complied with Mexican labor laws.

The race committee ended its vigil at the finish line of the 635-mile Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race today, long after all the prizewinners had been determined, and returned to Hamilton with four yachts still unreported.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation will buy $5,800,000 of the revenue bonds of the city of Knoxville, Tenn., to assist the city in acquiring the Knox County distribution system of the Tennessee Public Service Company,

The Wages and Hours Bill, which sets a precedent in attempts by the Federal Government to regulate working conditions in industries and interstate commerce, became law on Saturday night when President Roosevelt signed it without public comment, the White House announced today.

Opposition to proposed tax limitation which might impair support of education was voiced yesterday by Arvie Eldred, secretary of the New York State Teachers Association, at a meeting of the National Association of Secretaries of State Teachers Associations in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Miss Dorothea Liebmann was married this afternoon at Woodheath, the estate in Armonk Village of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Liebmann, to Roger Williams Straus Jr., a grandson of the late Oscar S. Straus, who had served as United States Ambassador to Turkey and Secretary of Commerce in President Theodore Roosevelt's Administration.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days;

89th St, 218 E, 25x100.8; John H. Pulschen to Emilie Brautigam, 218 E 89th St (50 cents). 151st St, 611 W, 100xlO0; Villers Realty Corp and Cotteret Realty Corp to Henry Sonn Co, 119 W 25th St ($2). 176th St, 712-718 W, 100x100: West 176th Street, Inc, to Wadsworth Freeholds, Inc, 7 E 44th St; mtg $135,000 ($22.50).

Former President Hoover and ex-Governor Landon were reported by members of the Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee, which met here today, to be involved in a struggle for recognition as titular leader and for control of the national committee and party affairs.
A rate increase of 5 per cent and permission to increase "subnormal" rates, subject to protest and suspension, were granted to the Pullman Company today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A. R. Richtmyer of Knothe Brothers Company, Inc., manufacturers of pajamas, disclosed last night that the Pajama Guild, Inc., of which he is president, was considering adoption of standard fast colors as a guide to consumers.

A Spanish-type residence.containing thirteen rooms and five baths on Park Drive South on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club, Rye, Westchester County, has been sold by Harry A. Roberts to I. J. Miranda of New York, it was reported yesterday.

Although showers over a large part of the Cotton Belt on Sunday lifted prices yesterday into new high ground for the movement, active liquidation of the July preparatory to notices this morning left the market with losses of 4 to 6 points.

Miss Barbara Johnson Fellows, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James W. Fellows of Manchester, was married to Robert Barnes Young of Great Neck, L. I., in the Little Harbor Chapel here at noon today.

The new examination and investment rules which ease the valuation and standards for bank investments and permit a broader approach to the making of loans, announced by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau to become effective Friday, will have little effect, if any, on the present policies of the major banking institutions of the country, according to leading New York bankers.

In consenting to a permanent injunction signed yesterday by Judge William Clark in the Federal District Court at Newark, Financial Independence Founders, Inc., agreed to refrain from further violations of the Securities Act of 1933 in marketing its shares.

Charles S. Guthrie, general manager of the Harlan Fuel Company, testified today that he was fired upon from a hillside during the 1931 organization drive of the United Mine Workers of America in Harlan County.

The Toronto Maple Leafs slapped out sixteen safeties off Bob Kline to fashion an eleven-inning 5-4 victory over the Buffalo Bisons tonight and present First Baseman.Jack Burns a victory in his first start as manager of the Leafs.

Consideration of "the general welfare and safety of the people of Jersey City" prompted its Director of Public Safety, Daniel J. Casey, to refuse to issue a permit to Norman Thomas for holding a public meeting there, Mr. Casey told the Supreme Court today.
Secretary Ickes ladled out $51,509,478 more of public works funds today and at the same time called on towns and cities to "match our pace" in getting projects underway.

An attack upon the American Legion which describes that organization as "Fascist and unpatriotic," as "similar" in "stripe" to the Black Legion, and as a "reactionary group" used as a "tool" by the "privileged classes," carries its own rebuttal in the very extravagance of its language and of its allegations.

Miss Elizabeth Pearsall Russell, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Russell and niece of Mrs. George Edwin Steel of 390 West End Avenue, was married to T. Scudder Winslow Jr. yesterday afternoon in All Angels Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. George A. Trowbridge.

When Dr. Alexis Carrel arrived here at noon today aboard the liner Queen Mary, he took the opportunity to discredit much of the information given out by newspapers on his collaboration with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in the "mechanical heart."

A sitdown strike yesterday forenoon by twelve men in a prison van outside the old Bronx County Court House, in East 161st Street, near Third Avenue, revealed that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey has been combing the city for all persons known to have been identified with the p61icy racket.

Special taxes cost the average New York motor vehicle owner $56.25 in 1937, an increase of 178 per cent over the "normal" year 1926, and represented in many cases a tax bill equal to the value of the taxpayer's motor car, Edward D; Cray, secretary of the New York Petroleum Industries Committee, said yesterday.
Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan took under advisement today a motion to vacate an order he made
This was a banner day for William Goldbeck of Lawrence Farms, who, despite the drenching downpour, was a double winner on the Ardsley links.

Wheat futures advanced around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today, with houses which frequently act for mills active on the buying side, presumably removing hedges against sales of 600,000 to 700,000 barrels of flour to the government for relief purposes.

BAER, SARAH (June 21). Estate, less than $3,000. To Adelaide Bruckheimer, daughter, executrix, 272 W. 90th St. DONOHUE, MARY H. (May 2). Estate, more than $10,000. To Edythe H. Donohue, 27 Ocean Ave., Jersey City, N. J.; Emma H. Donohue, same address;

Assuming that the Zoe Akins-Lili Hatvany "I Am Different" eventually reaches Broadway, it will bring Fritzi Scheff for her first local appearance since the 1929 revival of "Mile. Modiste." She will have a leading role in support of Tallulah Bankhead, the play's star.

Pinning their hopes on a comparatively young group, the eight National League managers whose votes determined the personnel of the senior circuit in the sixth annual All-Star baseball game at Cincinnati on July 6 named only eleven men who have been picked in the past for this classic.

Ernest T. Bower has incorporated his real estate and insurance business. The officers of the firm are: Mr. Bower, president and treasurer; Harry W. Tompkins, vice president, and Richard R. Porter Jr., secretary.

Leon G. Turrou, who resigned last week as agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to write the story of his inquiry into the activities of the so-called spy ring, eighteen supposed members of which are under indictment, was accused yesterday of having allowed Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, key figure in the case, to escape to Germany last May aboard the Bremen.

One hundred and twenty-six tennis-players from twenty-five private boarding schools scheduled to start the sixth annual Manursing Island tournament today will begin tomorrow at 10 A. M. instead. Steady rain caused the postponement.

Tremendously happy, Buck Walsh lay in a hospital room today and said: "You can't beat that Navy spirit." Injured in a fall Sunday morning, the Navy crew coach heard over the radio the details of 'his varsity's smashing victory.
William F. Blauvelt, 57 years old, cashier in the office of the county tax receiver here, committed suicide by gas in the kitchen of the Odd Fellows Hall today, according to the police.

Some 2,000 manufacturers of men's clothing throughout the country, of which approximately 600 are situated in New York, yesterday received questionnaires from the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department, asking them to submit prices on their surplus stocks of men's and boys' clothing.
Employers may support union or nonunion political candidates without violating the National Labor Relations Act, a Labor Board examiner ruled in effect today.

A Certificate of honorary life membership, the highest award of the National Education Association, was presented last night to Virginia Sappington, 19-year-old teacher who saved the lives of twenty pupils and e visiting child last March in a Kansas tornado that destroyed her schoolhouse.

MRS. KEMBLE," the fussy young man wrote to his mother in America, "has returned to town [London] for the Winter--an event in which I always take pleasure, as she is certainly one of the women I know whom I like best."

According to The Daily Mail's Rome correSpondent,' Prime Minister Neviulle Chamberlain has made a direct telegraphic appeal to Premier Benito Mussolini about Generalissimo Francisco Franco's bombing raids.

Store controllers opening the 1938 midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association here today heard the cheering news that a new upturn in general business had begun and a warning that if business maintains an aloof and distrustful attitude toward the present program of government spending it would face "economic dictatorship" from Washington.
The idea of tax exemption or preferential tax treatment for home owners seems to be spreading, but realty men are divided in their opinion of the soundness of the scheme.
Miss Virginia Downward, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Hollingsworth Downward and the late Mr. Downward of Glen Ridge, N. J., was married at Radnor today to Curtis Aldridge of Pelham Manor, N. Y.

The appointment of Dr. Charles Maxwell McConn, for fifteen years dean of Lehigh University, as dean of Washington Square College of New York University was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of N. Y. U. The appointment will be effective Sept. 1.

Mrs. May A. Byrne of 846 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, widow of James J. Byrne, former president of the Borough of Brooklyn, died on Sunday in Brooklyn Hospital, where she underwent an operation in March.

Tired and hungry but apparently happy at being back again in his boyhood haunts, President Roosevelt returned in a driving rain tonight to his family home after a delayed and circuitous journey from Wilmington, Del., where he had been the government's participant in the tercentenary celebration of the first landing of the Swedes and Finns in America.

Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Blagden Thompson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Thompson, to Commander Jerauld Wright, U. S. N., son of Major Gen. and Mrs. William Mason Wright of Washington.

A more selective demand characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as the general advance in all classes of issues faltered in sympathy with the hesitancy in the share market.
Today's program of the convention of the National Education Association Convention follows:

Stocks on hand at the end of May in reporting department stores in this district were 8.9 per cent lower than a year ago, according to the report issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday. Apparel store stocks were 8.2 per cent lower.

Mother Goose and fairy tales are rapidly disappearing from the elementary schools of the country and facts are being substituted, Miss Dorothy G. Howard of the Vernon L. Davey Junior High School, East Orange, N. J., declared yesterday in an address to the National Council of Teachers of English, at the American Museum of Natural History.
American and British Shakespeare lovers today joined in an ambitious scheme to raise $1,250,000 for a Shakespeare memorial in London.
" Show Boat" will open the third season of Fortune' Gallo-Shubert operettas at Randalls Island tonight. The cast will include Natalie and Bettina Hall, Nina Olivette, Guy Robertson and William Kent.

Art experience is indispensable to the production of a decent society in America, Dr. Harold Rugg, Professor of Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday at the Department of Art Education conference at the American Museum of Natural History.

Twenty-four members of the senior class of Manhattan College High School will receive diplomas at the eighty-fifth annual commencement. The exercises will be held in the George R. Smith Auditorium, on the Manhattan campus, 242d Street and Van Cortlandt Parkway.
The Countess of Strathmore and Kinghorne, mother of Queen Elizabeth, was buried today in a rhododendron-lined grave on the estate of Glamis Castle, home of the Strathmore family.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates June 27 unless specified: San Pedro to San Diego: Argonne, Vireo. At Havana, June 26: Arkansas, Tillman, Roper.
A remake of Jack London's "Sea Wolf," long contemplated by Warners, will go before the cameras in September with Pat O'Brien as Wolf Larson. It will be O'Brien's first picture under a new contract.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today cleared the way for the National Labor Relations Board to reopen its action to compel the Republic Steel Company to reinstate' 5,000 employes.

Facing the possibility of breakdown or slow decay in social organization, the world is desperately sacrificing hopes of higher living standards for non-productive armaments and seeking compensation for its fear in infantile fantasy, the American Association for the Advancement of Science was told today.

The fate of Charlemagne's crown, which has been kept here with other imperial regalia, has caused a dispute-between Julius Streicher, Nazi leader in Franconia, and Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, Governor of Austria, who is backed by Austrian National Socialists.

Mrs. Mabel Drouet Souvaine of New York was married to William M. Girden, New York real estate man, here today. The ceremony was performed by Judge Curtis Bok in his chambers in the presence of Joseph P. McGoldrick, Controller of the City of New York;

Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, told an audience of 1,200 gathered yesterday at the Department of Secondary Education session of the National Education Association in the American Museum of Natural History that in his three and a half years in office no political pressure of any kind had ever been brought to bear upon him.

Seventy-five young men and women, who have completed a ten-month course at the Salvation Army's Eastern Territorial Training College on Washington Heights, were commissioned last night as probationary lieutenants at commencement exercises in Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Miss Muriel Kingdon Hellwig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter O. Hellwig of Elmhurst, Queens, and Lake Mohawk, N. J., was married to Dr. George William Herlitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Herlitz of Corona, Queens, last evening in St. James Episcopal Church, Elmhurst.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was a guest this afternoon when the new Alfred Emanuel Smith Hall at the Harlem Valley State Hospital was dedicated in his honor.
Retired Fireman Adolph G. Klein, formerly a member of Engine 263, residing at 3442 31st St., Long Island City, Queens, died June 23.
A number of early English engravings and French prints belonging to the Mortimer L. Schiff Library were sold at Christie's today, bringing the total for the four-day sale to pound101,949.

A new book by Kenneth Roberts, entitled "March to Quebec," will be issued by Doubleday, Doran in September. It is a compilation of the source material and annotations used by Mr. Roberts in writing "Arundel."

On a 10 to 25 cents lower market top hogs fell to $9.15 today. The fat cattle trade was active and stronger, weighty steers reaching $11.20 and 1,400-pound yearlings $10.85, both prices uncovering a new high on the crop.

Field Marshal Hermann Goering, as Commissioner for the Four-Year Plan, instructed the so-called Reich Labor Trustees today "to pay attention henceforth to all working conditions and, in economic questions designated by the Reich Labor Minister, to issue binding directions in all fields on labor remuneration and working conditions."
A mad dash down John Dillinger's old trail culminated today in the slaying of one desperado and the wounding and capture of his brother during a savage gun battle.
TurpentIne firm, 23 1/2c; sales, 38 barrels; receipts, 441 barrels; shipments, 742 barrels; stock, 38,541 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 512; receipts, 2,618; shipments, 4,443; stock, 151,635.

Running over a sloppy track which she appeared to favor, G. N. W. McNaughton's Princess Bull showed her heels to a small band of Class C sprinters to win the featured Knobbie Handicap at six and a half furlongs at rainswept Aqueduct yesterday, defeating the heavily backed favorite Scrooge.

The sirens of navy destroyers screamed a crazy wail of victory into gray, rainswept air tonight as the East returned to the head of the Hudson River when Navy's eight came through in the varsity race ahead of the Far West's crews, California and Washington.
Dissolution of Electrolux, Inc., a subsidiary of the Electrolux Corporation, was announced to the Montreal Stock Exchange today by E. V. Ekman, vice president of the corporation.
It was in comparative privacy that the fastest race in the long history of the Poughkeepsie regatta was unfolded in the graying twilight tonight, the rolling green hills being practically untenanted.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for .FegeraZ surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

While the spectacular trading of last week in cotton gray goods was replaced yesterday by steady buying of all types of cloth, the price rises of % to 1/2 cent a yard began to be reflected in advanced quotations- on various finished goods, such as wide sheetings and percales.

The Yankees will be back at the Stadium today, listed for a doubleheader with the Athletics and eager to start a home-stay winning streak in their battle for first place with the Indians. Lefty Gomez and Bump Hadley will be the starting pitchers in the double bill.

Legisolation paving the way for what sponsors described as a $5,000,000 lottery to finance Cleveland's relief needs was passed tonight by the City Council in a resolution authorizing entertainments in public auditorium and municipal stadium with proceeds to be used for emeragency relief requirements.

Almon G. Rasquin, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Brooklyn-Long Island area, said yesterday that he had received orders from Washington to drop thirty-one employes in the Social Security division of his office. Twenty-three clerks and typists already have been dropped, and the others will go before the end of the week.

State Senator and Mrs. Walter Watson Stokes of Woodside Hall, Cooperstown, N. Y., have come to the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. A. Schuyler Clark of Old Hall, Greens Farms, Conn., is at the Weylin. Radu Irimescu, the Rumanian Minister, and Mrs. Irimescu have come from Washington to the Aimbassador.

Americans feel at home in Sweden, and for more than three hundred years the descendants. of the little band of Swedish pioneers, since multiplied by hundreds of thousands of Swedish immigrants, have felt at home in the United States.

Grace Moore, Metropolitan Opera soprano, who was scheduled to appear as soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, Will sing tonight. Last night's concert, like that of Sunday night, had to be given in the Great Hall of City College because of rain.
The Maritime Commission has made settlements with the United Fruit Company and the Colombian Steamship Company, Inc., of claims growing out of cancellation of mail contracts.

Nibble Hanover, driven by Whitney, tonight won the opening event of the Grand Circuit harness meeting at Fort Miami by taking the 2-yearold trot in straight heats in the fast times of 2:113/4 and 2:12.

Official representations have been made by this government to the Japanese Government at Tokyo and by Amer-' ican representatives at Tsingtao, China, regarding the slapping of Mrs. Thomas H. Massie, wife of an American naval officer, by a Japanese sentry, Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles said today.

As an evidence of the economic soundness of limited dividend housing for the middle income group, Louis J. Pink, chairman of the State Board of Housing, yesterday pointed out that the eleven New York City projects under the supervision of the board will have produced, in the - six months ended June 30, about 5 per cent annual net average income before amortization.

Amish and Mennonite farmers of East Lampeter Township, Lancaster County, today lost their long Federal Court fight to save the township's eleven "little red school-houses" for their children, for whom a $125,000 modern consolidated building was erected last year over their vigorous protests.

Special Orders 134, dated June 10, as reo lates to 2d Lt. Charles D. Agnew, F. A. Res., is revoked. Special Orders 142, dated June 20. relating to 2d Lt. Walter B. Savage, Q. M.-Res., is revoked. Special Orders 127, dated June 2, reading "2d Lt. Ramos G. Karolyi, Engr.-Res." is amended so as to read "2d Lt. Ramon G. Karolyi, Engr.-Res."

For the fourth consecutive week, deaths, accidents and traffic injuries declined last week and weekend, as compared with figures covering the corresponding periods last year. Tables made public yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department for the week were:
Over the Inwood Country Club course, where Bobby Jones won his first national open championship in 1923, a hardy group of Long Island pros and amateurs battled both theweather and par today.

The International Labor Organization's Public Works Committee, now holding its first session here, adopted today a uniform plan for the regular supply of information concerning public works by governments to the I. L. O.

Representative Snell of the Thirtyfirst New York district is not an ancient of the first class in Congress, but he is a prize senior who might reasonably hope to qualify for the long-term championship.

Lawrin and Dauber, respectively the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winners in the East, will run what amounts to a match race tomorrow in the American Champion Stakes at the country's newest race track, the Hollywood Turf Club's plant at this suburb of Los Angeles.

Declaring that he was down to his last $15, Francis Ormond French, father of Mrs. John Jacob Astor, has filed application for relief in the office of Robert W. Smith, director of public aid in Middletown, the township next north of this city, where he and Mrs. French have...

The Port of New York Authority urged the Interstate Commerce, Commission today not to prescribe motorcarrier rates in New England which would result in "inflated rates to and from the New York metropolitan area," or "split the metropolitan area into different parts for rate-making purposes."
The walled city of Ankwo, 140 miles south of Peiping, was still smoking today after a retreating Japanese army had burned it in a campaign of reprisal against Chinese guerrilla raids.

Students and teachers of the classics were urged to take a greater part in public affairs in an address yesterday by A. S. Chenoweth, Superintendent of .Public Schools of Atlantic City, N. J., before the twentieth annual meeting of the American Classical League in the Education Building of New York University.

With three candidates nominated for the presidency of the National Education Association, balloting will take place today from 8 A. M. to 6 P. M. Candidates for other positions also were nominated yesterday at the first business session of the convention, held at the Hippodrome.

The southwest corner of 140th Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, under lease for a longterm to a gasoline station, has been purchased by Edward Martin, attorney, from Lewis Johnson, trustee. The property was held for $30,000 and was sold for all cash.

Dr. Aleck W. Bourne, one of the world's -leading gynecologists, has decided to obtain a legal ruling in the British courts as to whether a doctor has the right to terminate pregnancy in a case of exceptional emergency.

There was serious rioting in Memel tonight when Germans peaking pro-Nazi citizens and Lithuanians fought for two hours in the streets with sticks, stones and other missiles. A 16-year-old German boy, the son of a policeman, was killed and about fifty persons, including several women, were injured, twelve critically.

Dr. Oskar Trautmann, German Ambassador to China, has been summoned to Berlin to report to Chancellor Adolf Hitler on the situation in China. It has not been made clear whether or not he will return to Nanking.

17th St, 329 E, 23.2x92; Frances Karger to Sara Kanofsky, 329 E 17th St. 112th St, 100x101; Joseph Kessler to Elizabeth Richmond, 560 W 180th St; two 1st mtges, $52,750 each; two 2d mtges, $27,850 and $31,850 ($2). 123d St. n s. 100 ft e of Broadway, 75x101: Erg Corp to 1,476 Realty Corp, 565 5th Ave, care A. J. Bernstein; mtg- $85,000 ($12).

Great attention mingled with concern is being aroused in big business circles by the rapid expansion of the government-controlled Hermann. Goering Iron Works into an iron manufacturing industry through the purchase of growing concerns both in old Germany and in Austria.

Reuben P. Resor, treasurer of the Standard Oil Company (N. J.), who will retire on Aug. 10, was honored by members of his staff and heads of departments throughout the company at an informal party held in the treasurer's offices, at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, yesterday afternoon.

Once again play in the tennis tournaments at the Montclair Athletic Club was washed out by rain today. The Eastern intercollegiate championship and the women's Eastern title event both will be started tomorrow if the weather is clear and the. courts have dried out, and play in the men's New Jersey State championship will be resumed.

Johnny Longden, one of the country's leading riders, narrowly escaped serious injury at Aqueduct yesterday when he was thrown by Scandalous in the fourth race. For a moment he appeared badly hurt as he lay still on the rain-soaked track. It developed, however, that he was only shaken and was all right, returning to the jockey room.

Solomon ben Yosef, a Jewish youth, is to be hanged tomorrow for having fired at an Arab-owned bus although he caused no casualties. Commutation of the sentence was refused by the British authorities today.
The role of teachers in the preservation of democracy emerged as a major theme yesterday at meetings among the 15,000 delegates attending conference sessions of the National Education Association.

Earl Cook pitched two-hit ball to blank the Jersey Giants as the Chiefs scored a-3-0 victory in the series opener before 3,000 tonight. A scratch hit by Tom Winsett in the third was the only safe blow for Jersey City until the eighth, when Padden hit a line drive to center.

Edward Gordon of New York, employee in the steward department of the steamIship Oriente of the New York Cuba Mail Line, was detained this afternoon on charges of being a labor agitator and of attempting to spread illegal propaganda against Cuban industries.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, is a member of the committee of sponsors to aid the Foster Parents Plan for Children in Spain, 118 East Fortieth Street, in a drive for the aid of orphaned and refugee children.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus halted for at least twenty-four hours tonight its journey to Winter quarters at Sarasota, Fla. The circus train was side-tracked at near-by Alexandria, Va., where it had arrived from Scranton, Pa.

Richard Hollaman, in 565 Park Ave; Ferdinand Mayer. in Southmoor House. 230 Central Pk S; Theodore Otte, in 66 W 53d St; Edna North, in 33 E 22d St; Wm. A. White Sons, brokers. Tillie B. Churchill, In 471 Park Ave; Francis A. Woodward. in 14 E 58th St; Mrs. Lucille Rodgers, in 795 Madison Ave; Huberth Huberth, brokers.

Hogs prices continued to sag and closed at the low point today. Most late sales showed declines of 15 to 25 cents. Both cattle and lambs sold actively strong to higher. Light steers, yearlings and heifers showed more upturn than the weightier kind, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

Miss Natalie Fox Elkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Elkins of Justa Farm, Huntingdon Valley, was married at noon today to John Gribbel, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Griffin Gribbel of Chestnut Hill.
7:30 A. M. Hotel Martinique-National League of Teachers Associations' breakfast conference. Address: William E. Grady, Associate Superintendent, New York City's schools.

Accompanied by Michael I. Tomilin, formerly of the Philadelphia Zoological Gardens, Theodore Roosevelt, the outstanding gibbon brought from Siam by a primate expedition last Summer, has returned here for a vacation after having spent the past year at Harvard, Yale and Columbia Universities.
A CabinetCommons storm of first magnitude, added to the flood of Spanish war problems, is swirling around Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain.

In an address at the Graduate School of Banking here today, Marshall R. Diggs, Acting Controller of the Currency, discussed the aims and provisions of the liberalized banking regulations announced this week and asked bankers to "keep clearly in mind" the objective of providing better credit facilities for the small business man.

The heroic act of Harry Meyers, a glazier, in seizing a large jagged piece of quarter-inch-thick glass to save pedestrians as it was about 'to fall into East Forty-second Street from a thirteenth-floor window, will not cost him the use of his right hand, it was said at Bellevue Hospital yesterday.
Steel ingot production again showed a contra-seasonal increase last week and the adjusted index advanced to 39.9 from 35.9. The figure was 110.0 for the week ended June 26, 1937.

Unless the Administration does something at once to dispel the impression it has made in the last few days, the country will be bound to conclude that WPA is in politics up to its neck. First there were the increases announced for WPA workers in thirteen Southern States.

With greetings from President Roosevelt, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People opened its twenty-ninth annual conference here tonight. The sessions will continue through Saturday.

Studies of the Children's Court records give definite evidence that the delinquency rate among New York children has declined more than half since the court was founded thirty-five years ago, Dr. J. B. Mailer, research associate of Columbia University,

Teachers more than any other group in this country hold the future of democracy in their hands, and upon them rests the responsibility for developing the skeptical and reasoning minds that are essential to a fighting faith in the democratic process,

In his recent fireside chat President Roosevelt issued an eloquent Call to his party to vote for "liberal" candidates in the Democratic primary elections. He defined a "liberal" as one who, among other things, opposes a "moratorium on reform."

Frank Godfroy, last chief of the Miami Indians, died in a hospital here this afternoon at the age of 77. He was a grandson of Frances Slocum, "White Rose of the Miamis," who, captured as a child by a roving band of Miamis, preferred later to continue to live as one of them.

The incorportion into the new State Constitution of a progressive and liberal social welfare amendment, which would obligate the State to provide care for its unemployed, aged, sick and infirm citizens, was advocated here today at a public hearing of the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Social Welfare, headed by Edward F. Corsi.

Trading improved but still slows on veal. Other classes moved fair to slow. Steer beef sold strong to higher, lamb uneven, fresh pork cuts mostly unchanged. A very light supply of cow beef was held higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated all classes to be higher.
Anthony de Rothschild's Prometheus, a colt by Tetratema from Blandishment, today won the July Stakes, 2-year-old event run over five furlongs and 140 yards.
The schooner Two Brothers, one of the previously unreported boats in the Newport to Hamilton race, crossed the finish line at 10:30 A. M. today.

Eighteen women golfers competed in the metropolitan one-day tournament over the rain-drenched Lakeville Country Club course today with Miss Alice Rutherfurd of Baltusrol emerging as the surprise winner of low. gross honors. She t carded a 49, 48-97.

Young Arnold Zimmerman of Blair Academy not only set himself off to a fine start toward the medal in the Eastern interscholastic golf championship, held annually at the Greenwich Country Club, but gave his school a strong lead for team honors today when he toured the rain-sodden course in 71 strokes, only one above par.

Following the practice of the railroads, three of the country's major airlines yesterday announced that children between the age of 2 and 12 years will be carried for onehalf the regular airline fare beginning next Friday.

In a scathing denunciation of the World's Fair 1939 as a "ballyhoo for business," and a symbol of the "nationalistic spirit," Dr. Goodwin Watson, Professor of Education at Teachers College, called upon educaters yesterday to help develop youth for world citizenship.

MANHATTAN BLOODGOOD, ROSALIE G. (Nov. 27,1936). Gross assets, $250,241; net, $230,674. To Rocky Farm Camp, Inc., Newport, R. I., $3,000; Ruth Winant Wheeler, niece, $1,000 and income fromfive-twenty-fourths residue and succeeding estate in part of residue; Grace Winant Barry, niece, $1,000 and income from five-twentyfourths residue and succeeding estate in part of residue; Helene C. Barry,

Colombia is satisfied with her petroleum laws, Dr. Gabriel Turbay, former Foreign Minister of Colombia and now a Senator, said in an interview here today. The Senator, one of .the most prominent politicians in Colombia, declared:

As the government's deadline on bids' for the proposed new service to the east coast of South America draws near, discussion among shipping men in New York indicates that the competition will be keen and that at least five companies, some of which have already been mentioned in connection with the sale, are preparing to bid on the ships, either as purchasers or charterers.
Asserting that admiralty law "antedates by generations our present labor laws," Commissioner James H. Malloy today held twenty-five striking seamen in $250 bail each for mutiny.

The lithe figure of Donald Bradman stood between England and victory in the second cricket test match with Australia today. In a race with the clock the 29-year-old captain scored his fourteenth century in Anglo-Australian tests, forcing the second straight draw in the 1938 series between the two countries.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on June 18 amounted to 295,931,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today.
The greatest number of troops ever mobilized for a single related manoeuvre in the peace-time history of the United States will be assembled in August over a wide area of the South and West.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following second lieutenants, Infantry Reserve, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 1st Division-Gilbert Beck, 426 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn; Sylvan M. Marshall, 450 West End Ave., New York City. Special Orders 148, dated June 28, pertain. ing to 2d Lt. Nicholas N. Metropolsky, Inf.-Res., as reads "401 Hamilton St., Syracuse," is amended so as to read, "64 Forrester St.. Salem, Mass."

Profit-taking caused considerable irregularity yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange and for the first time in more than a week domestic corporation issues eased slightly on the average. Some of the more volatile railroad loans were -weak and the rail price index yielded 0.27 of a point.

Shipments of steel office furniture in May amounted to $1,292,861, compared with $1,421,424 in April and $2,419,300 in May, 1937, according to figures issued by the Department of Commerce. Shipments for the first five months of 1938 amounted to $8,508,601, against $12,061,619 in the same period last year.
Captain John Abrams, navigator of the racing yacht Endeavour I during its epic struggle across the storm-tossed Atlantic last Fall, died today at his home in Birkenhead.

At the end of the fourth race in the Star Class series for the John Taylor Arms Trophy at the Noroton Yacht Club today the leader, D. and M. Coley's Pole Star, had taken a sharp tumble in the point total as a result of finishing third from last. The race was won by J. J. Abberly's Rythym, with C. S. Ogilvy's Jay second and Paul Smart's Melodv third.

A store lease reported yesterday for quarters in an uncompleted Eighth Avenue taxpayer is said to involve one of the highest rentals recently to have been brought by ground floor space on that avenue. Sam Lieberman, operator of a chain of tobacco and confectionery stores, took quarters in the building under construction on the northwest corner of Thirty-sixth Street and Eighth Avenue by G. Richard Davis Co., Inc.

The general death rate in New York City fell to 8.8 per 1,000 population during the week ended last Saturday, the low mark for the year so far and equal to the record low, in 1937, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records, to Dr. William H. Best, acting city Health Commissioner.
Declaring that the municipal electric power system of Seattle, Wash., enjoyed in many respects in 1937 its best year since the inception of the publicly owned plant thirty-five years ago, J. D. Ross.

Any Republican coalition in this State with the American Labor party was condemned last night in a resolution adopted by the seminar committee of the National Republican Club, meeting at 54 West Fortieth Street.

After an extended tour through Soviet Russia, during which he visited Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev, Kharkov, Dniepropetrovsk and the Ukraine, Carliss Lamont, chairman of the American Friends of the Soviet Union, declared yesterday that there was no comparison between the Russia of 1932, the time of his previous visit, and the Russia of today, which showed "tremendous economic activity."

J. P. Morgan Co., as service agents for the United States tranche of the Austrian Government international loan of 1930, made public yesterday a letter addressed to holders of these bonds, giving the text of various protests which had been made to the German Government upon its suspension of payments due on the loan.
Mercy obviously did not season justice for Salvatore Sarracino in the Coney Island Magistrate's Court day

George A. Cormack, secretary of the New York Yacht Club, of which he had been a member for fiftytwo years, died yesterday morning in the Doctors Hospital, Eightyseventh Street and East End Avenue, where he underwent an operation on June 8. He was 81 years old.

Thirty-one persons representing twenty-seven corporations and four national trade associations in this country agreed yesterday that it was desirable to have a staff representative of the American. Standards Association in Argentina to promote the adoption of American industrial standards there.
Irving Eldridge, 134, Bronx, defeated Johnny Bonito, 134 3/4, Bronx, in the feature eight-round bout last night at the New York Coliseum before a crowd of 5,000.

Torrential rains continued for the third successive day to batter Eastern States yesterday, causing crop and property damage estimated at more than $4,000,000 in New Jersey, Delaware and Southeastern Pennsylvania, with Burlington County, N. J., among the sections hardest hit.

Although world citizenship as a political ideal is still "a dream of the future," there is hope that the forces of education, rational thinking and art will lead to voluntary Cooperation among nations for the upward development of humanity, three speakers told a gathering of

The War Department. released the following orders today, dated June 25: MAJOR GENERAL Reynolds, C. R., Surgeon General, three days' leave, June 27. COLONEL Cocheu, G. W., (C. A. C.), General Staff Corps, one day leave, June 29. Blakely, C. S., F. A., LaFayette, Ind., to home and await retirement.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that, at the request of Paine, Webber Co., the commission would reopen on Thursday at its New York offices the public hearings on the First Income Trading Corporation, the Continental Securities Corporation, Administered Fund Second, Inc.;

It was announced to the legislative council when it reassembled today that 110 policemen and special constables had been injured during riots in the past month. The Board of Conciliation is drafting recommendations for the adjustment of labor disputes.

Mrs. John Chalmers Hughes Jr., who is occupying Eight Acres, the estate of Mrs. Marion B. Aubert in Muttingtown, this season, gave a luncheon today for the June debutantes in the North Shore colonies and their house guests, about seventy persons.

The fourth of a new series of monthly trust-fund investment account reports showing the securities held as investments in government trust funds and in accounts of certain governmental corporations and agencies was made public today by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.

The Appellate Division has sustained a decision of Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church requiring Hallgarten Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co. to account for their actions as fiscal agents for a $9,000,000 issue of 61/2 per cent bonds of the municipality of Medellin, Republic of Colombia, it was announced yesterday.

Mgr. Patrick N. Breslin, Roman Catholic dean of the Borough of the Bronx, died in St. Francis Hospital, 142d Street and Brook Avenue, the Bronx, at 5 P. M. yesterday. He had been a patient in the hospital for seventeen days, suffering from coronary thrombosis and pneumonia. He was 70 years old.

Counter-propaganda for democracy is needed to maintain this form of society against minority groupsand "powerful" individuals attempting to repress free speech, free assembly and free association, Daniel Prescott, Professor of Education at Rutgers University,

The resignation of Allen E. Throop, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to join the faculty of the Yale Law School, was announced today. Mr. Throop will leave after he has completed certain work now before him.

The end of free trade between the United States and the Philippines will mark the economic decline of the islands and the loss of that market by the United States, Louis G. Wagner, sales promotion manager for Muller Phipps (Asia),
J. Morris Robinson, formerly well known in New York hotel circles, died last night in Oklahoma City, according to word received here today.
Bobby Riggs of Chicago, seeking his third straight national clay court tennis championship, gained the final today when Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta defaulted because of a blistered hand.

Wheat futures in North American markets sold off today on favorable weather conditions for harvesting in the Southwest and West, and highly beneficial rains in parts of the drought-threatened area in the Canadian Northwest.

Former Rumanian Minister to Washington Charles A. Davila, who, in spite of repeated government orders, refused to return here, was deprived of his Rumanian citizenship today, together with two newspaper men. The action was based on a provision of -the new Constitution.
French military aviation received its second blow within a week when this morning a bomber crashed just after a take-off from the Reims airdrome, killing five fliers.

The elimination of price differentials for steel products at the principal basing points, undertaken by important subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation, the Inland Steel Company and the Bethlehem Steel Company in the last few days, was described yesterday as a "protective" measure of which the ultimate repercussions may be only guessed at this time.
The tuna reports are still coming in from the New Jersey coast, and it seems that the Beach Haven anglers did quite well on the small tuna on Sunday.

The peak of buyers' arrivals in the markets here for Fall merchandise will probably develop during..the. weeks of July 4 and 11, according to plans being made by the leading resident buyers here. The recent stiffening in the wholesale markets, particularly in staples, will, however,
England's annual fourday rowing carnival, the Henley regatta, will get under way tomorrow, and today this ancient little village was buzzing with anticipation.

Flint glass manufacturers wishing to obtain contracts with the government must pay a minimum wage of 42% cents an hour for a forty-hour week after July 12, it was ordered today by C. V. McLaughlin, Acting Secretary of Labor.

The foreign exchanges were irregular yesterday and transactions were small. The pound sterling was unchanged at $4.95 1/2, the franc was 1/16 point higher at 2.78 5/8 cents, the guilder was up a point at 55.36 cents, the belga unchanged at 16.96 3/4 cents and the Swiss franc off 1 1/2 points at 22.92 1/4 cents. German marks lost 2 points to 40.29 cents and Japanese yen fell 1 point to 28.91 cents.

An immediate investigation into unfair competitive practices in the furniture trade which were said to cost consumers, retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers $150,000,000 annually will be undertaken by the Better Business Bureaus in New York, Chicago, Pittsburgh, Syracuse,

Establishment of a committee of motion-picture executives to discuss block-booking and other distribution problems with organized and independent theatre exhibitors was announced yesterday by Sidney R. Kent, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation,

Proposals for the erection in Montreal of a privately owned plant, financed by French, English and Canadian capital, for the production of bombing and pursuit planes and large passenger craft have been laid before the Quebec government.

Debutante parties continued tonight in the North Shore colonies, the largest one of which was a supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pratt at their home, to introduce their elder daughter, Miss Caroline Pratt.

Wing Commander F. W. Stent, who led air raids for Colonel T. E. Lawrence in Arabia and was mentioned in "The Seven Pillars of Wisdom," was killed today when his plane crashed at Herefield, Middlesex. He had arranged to fly a new type of civilian plane in Saturday's King's Cup race.

The marriage of Miss Isabella Maxwell Buell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ely Buell, to Thomas Francis Griffin Hickey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah G. Hickey, took place in the Sacred Heart Pro-Cathedral this morning. The Rev. Charles Bruton, assisted by Mgr. George V. Burns, performed the ceremony.

On taking office as president for the coming year of the New York Lions Club, Dr. Victor H. Sears announced yesterday that a new "civics committee" was to be formed "to do something about ruinous taxation and economic conditions" affecting the business man.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 25: COMMANDER Underwood, H. W., previous orders modified; to temporary duty 11th Naval Dist.; detached 11th Naval Dist., San Diego, Calif.. to Navy R. 0. T. C. unit, Los Angeles, Calif.

Up with the leaders since the campaign started, Yorkshire went to the top of the English county cricket championship today. The Yorkshiremen, victorious on the first innings against Nottinghamshire, replaced Middlesex,

Organization of the Oriental Rug Institute of America, Inc., tp promote the sale of Oriental and Chinese rugs in the American market, will be undertaken today at the Hotel Prince George where more than a score of rug importers will meet to give final approval to the project.

Senator Gerald P. Nye had gained a decided lead in returns early today from the State's Republican primary over Governor William Langer, titular head of the Nonpartisan League, who was seeking to wrest the Senatorial nomination from the peace advocate.
The Seine Civil Tribunal heard today a breach of promise suit brought by Princess Nadia Sherbatoff, whose father was an aide of Grand Duke Nicholas, against Count Louis de Brantes.

A crowd of 18,000 saw the league-leading Indians pound Tommy Bridges for five runs in the second inning and then hang on to gain a 5-4 decision over 'the Tigers that ran the Indians' American League lead to four and a half games over the rainedout Yankees.

Crown PrinceGustaf Adolf of Sweden arrived in New York yesterday by automobile from Philadelphia, ahead of his party, and was driven directly to the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

The names of ten horses, including those of War Admiral and Seabiscuit, tonight were in the entry box for tomorrow's $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs, but whether Seabiscuit would go postward rested in the laps of New England's fickle weather gods. If all ten start the race will gross $64,400, with $45,650 going to the winner.

Li Ching-Mai, youngest son of the late Li Hung-Chang, died of a heart attack today at the age of 63. He had been Minister to Austria when only 30 and held other important posts in the Chinese Government before the fall of the Manchu dynasty in 1912 ended his public career.
The Standard Oil Company of Indiana announced today a plan to simplify and consolidate its crude oil purchasing activities through liquid. tion of the Stanolind Crude Oil Purchasing Company.
E. Lehman of New York has purchased a new colonial clapboard home on Revere Road, Wilmot Woods, Westchester County, from the H. B. Building Corporation. Howard L. Auerbach was the broker.

News has been received from the American Alpine Club's Karakoram Expedition, which has set out to find a route to the top of Mt. Godwin Austen in Kashmir, India. The party left Srinagar, Kashmir, with twenty-four horses and six Sherpa porters and crossed the Himalayan Range over the Zoji-La on a bright moonlight night.

The first trial flight of the French transatlantic airline to the United States has been provisionally announced for Aug. 15, when the flying boat Lieutenant-de Vaisseau-Paris captained by Pilot Henry Guillaumet will take off at Biscarrosse for New York via 1940 TEND the Azores and Newfoundland.

Securities and Exchange Commission today extended until Sept. 30 the period in which there may be trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the $40,000,000 of 5% per i cent public-works bonds of the Republic of Cuba.
The Reds, who have come to rely on Johnny Vander Meer as much as Johnny relies on his pay check, accomplished a lot of things today behind another of the young southpaw's handsome pitching jobs.

The engagement of Miss Clare Leigh Mallory of Westbrook, Godalming, England, to Dr. Glen Allan Millikan, son of Dr. Robert A. Millikan, scientist and professor at the California Institute of Technology, was announced in England last night according to word received here today.

After tomorrow, couples applying for marriage licenses must bring with them physicians' certificates showing they are free from syphilis in communicable form, City Clerk Robert L. Tudor announced yesterday.

Orson Welles, one of the most youthful and successful resuscitants of drama in America, emerged yesterday in the role of a theatrical "gloomy dean" as he spoke before the National Council of Teachers of English on the status and possible future of the art to which he has dedicated his life.

An all-Russian program will be given tonight at Lewisohn Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony under Jose Iturbi, in which two works will be presented for. the first time at the Stadium. These are the suite from the opera, "The Nose," by Shostakovich, and "Gossips," by Arkady Dubensky, member of the second violin section of the Philharmonic.

Rumors circulating abroad concerning mass arrests of Austrian Nazis were categorically denied today by a spokesman of the Berlin press office who had come here especially to investigate such rumors, which he ascribed to "a malicious campaign against the Reich."

Hundreds of guests waited today because Prince Bertil of Sweden lost his trousers. The Prince, here for the celebration of the 300th anniversary of the settlement of Delaware and Pennsylvania by his countrymen,intended to change from naval uniform to civilian clothes for a luncheon.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted a new rule under the Public Utility Holding Company Act permitting an operating subsidiary of a registered holding company to issue notes to consumers in connection with electric and gas line extensions without the necessity of applying for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration with the commission.
Thomas Ahearn, Ottawa business man and industrialist, died in his home today. He was 83 years old and had been i11 for a year.

The Mercury Theatre rises this morning to acknowledge that it is in "somewhat of a predicament." The planned production of "The Importance of Being Earnest" has been abandoned because of Hiram Sherman's decision to appear next season under Max Gordon's banner.

Because of opposition by United Artists and his own reluctance to offer another controversial film on the heels of "Blockade," Walter Wanger today announced temporary abandonment of Vincent Sheean's "Personal History" in which Henry Fonda; Louise Platt and Tim Holt were to have been featured.

Awards for eight "meritorious" lighting installations made by New York stores and other firms here were presented at a luncheon meeting of several hundred representatives of the electrical industry yesterday in the Hotel Astor. The meeting was under the auspices of the Electrical and Gas Associaticn of New York, Inc., with A. Lincoln Bush, president, presiding.

The French liner Normandie will sail today for Havre via Southampton. Those departing are Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Great Britain; Constantin Fottich, Minister from Yugoslavia to the United States;

Money poured into the coffers of the city yesterday through fines imposed by Magistrate Finegan in Coney Island Court, Brooklyn. Magistrate Finegan imposed fines of $5 and $3, varying with the seriousness of the offense, on thirty-eight men accused of undressing under the Boardwalk.

The exultation in New Deal circles which followed President Roosevelt's radio "fireside" statement that he would take part in the party "purge" was rapidly degenrating today into confusion over the make-up of the "blacklist" of unfaithful Democrats meant for slaughter.

Declaring that at some point too stringent controls can kill more business than they protect, Edwin B. George, economist of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and associate editor of Dun's Review, yesterday warned business against placing complete reliance on "salvation by law." He spoke at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Three newly ordained Jesuits celebrated a solemn high mass yesterday morning in St. Ignatius Church, Rogers Avenue at Carroll Street, Brooklyn. Since boyhood their scholastic careers have been together. The mass was served by six of their former students at Brooklyn Preparatory School, where the Jesuits served as scholastic.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway provided yesterday a footnote to the present unsatisfactory condition of the railroads by omitting the dividend due at this time on its preferred stock and deferring action on the payment of interest of its 4 per cent adjustment bonds.

Mrs. Shepard Krech entertained with a tea today for members of the garden clubs of East Hampton and Southampton, after visits made to the Summer homes of Mrs. John Vernou Bouvier Jr., Mrs. William Carter Dickerman and Mrs. Clifford H. McCall, where arrangements of flowers made by the East Hampton Garden Club members were shown and judged by popular vote.
The upward movement in the stock market here was checked today by profit-taking, several sections being set back. Gilt-edge issues sagged until the late afternoon, when some recovery took place.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, unaided but clinging carefully to the rail of the steeplytilted gangplank from the motorship Kungsholm, touched American soil for the first time in twelve years here this afternoon.

The marriage of Miss Emily Harold Alsop, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Winthrop Neilson, to John Frederick Jordan will take place tomorrow at the home of Miss Alsop's uncle, Howell E. Jackson, in Noroton, Conn. Owing to the recent death of Mr. Neilson, the ceremony and reception will be attended only by near relatives.

Many of the school and college administrators of this country are rec "political swashbucklers" and not real educators, Dr. -Robert K. Speer, Professor of Education at New York University, charged yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the kindergarten-primary teachers in the Hotel Commodore.

A combination of Republicans and Democrats in the Constitutional Convention at Albany defeated the Dunnigan proposal for banning the use of evidence gained by illegal search and seizure and by wire-tapping. The vote of the delegates insured the

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday were slightly under the preceding week. However, the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 658 as against 712 in the previous week and 617 in the same period last year. Out-of-town buyers registered yesterday numbered 263, which compared with 368 recorded a week ago.

Thirty subpoenas were issued today in Madison, Wis., for witnesses to appear before a Federal grand jury there on June 12 in connection with the Department of Justice's oil investigations, it announced today.

Weakened by heavy downpours, a 110-foot section of a retaining wall eight feet high gave way yesterday morning in the Bronx and an avalanche of hundreds of tons of masonry and mud slid thirty feet burying a dozen automobiles on two near-by lots.

An educational philosophy that segregates pupils under 12 years of age and then designates them as "problem children" was denounced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in an address at a luncheon meeting of the National Association of School Secretaries in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A call to students, trained in democratic participation and leadership, to come to the defense of democracy, was made yesterday by Lyman Beecher Stowe of the National Self-Government Committee, in the Horace Mann School Auditorium.

An international federation of press women will be organized in Europe this Summer in connection with Women's International Week observances in Stockholm and Budapest, Mrs. Joseph E. Goodbar, chairman of the American committeee for the observances, said yesterday.
W. F. Detwiler, president of the Allegheny Steel Company, declared yesterday that prospects for the steel industry should be better now than at any time in the last ten months.

If the Constitutional Convention is to finish work by the end of July it will have to scratch gravel. If it is to produce something satisfactory to the average voter it must boil down six or seven hundred proposals into a few compact and separable questions.

Three parcels in Brooklyn were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, which pointed out that the Red Hook slum-clearance project is stimulating the demand for property in surrounding territory.

For the third time in three weeks a truck loaded with sugar was hijacked at 3:30 o'clock this morning and its driver "dumped" in a seeluded section of Bergen County by a gang believed to be manufacturing illicit whisky. Chief Henry B. Lockwood, head of county detectives, has called the Federal Bureau of Investigation and New York and New Jersey police to aid in the search.

Miss Elizabeth Kirkjatrick, daughter of Mrs. William G. H. Kirkpatrick of East'Orange, was married to Dr. Kenneth O. Smith of Upper Montclair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Smith of Morley, Iowa, this evening in Grace Presbyterian Church, Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis Stifler of Summit.

United States Attorney Lamar Hardy will personally clear up European phases of the German espionage organization exposed by a Federal grand jury on June 20. He will sail at noon today with his daughter, Miss Micheline Hardy, on the French liner Normandie.

E. G. Hicks, Labor Member of Parliament for Woolwich East and president of the National Federation of Building Trades, today told the. federation that the refusal of insurance companies to cover the risk of damages to homes by enemy aircraft was causing a serious rise in unemployment.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Bloomingdale of this city and Rye of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Bloomingdale, to Richard Charles Ernst, son of Mr. and Mr. Bernard M. L. Ernst, also of New York.

A broad system of adult education, supported by Federal, State and local governments, and a scaling down of the number of school districts in the country to about 2,000 were proposed last night by Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education,

The marriage of Miss Rita Anne Piel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Piel of 30 Fifth Avenue and Salisbury, Conn., to Hobson Brown, son of Mrs. George Ferguson of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Alexander Brown of Bryn Mawr, Pa., took place yesterday afternoon in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The newspaper is the principal source of current information and is "usually conceded to be the most universal agency in forming current opinion," Ralph K. Strassman, vice president of the Ward Wheelock Company,

James Roosevelt, son and secretary to President Roosevelt, has an income from the insurance business estimated. in insurance circles at $250,000 to $2,000,000 a year, according to an article by Alva Johnston in this week's issue of The Saturday Evening Post.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd has written an account of his fivemonth isolation at Advance Base, the place, far south of Little America, where in 1934 he nearly died. The book will be published in the Fall by Putnam under the title "Alone."

Morris Engargola, 51 years old, of 30 Willow Place, Brooklyn, recently convicted in Kings County Court of having led a group of strikers in an assault on a non-striking employee of the Fein Tin Can Company of 284 Furman Street, Brooklyn, on March 29, was sentenced yesterday by Judge George W. Martin to serve ten months in the penitentiary.

Senator Thomas said here today t that President Roosevelt told him he would speak in Oklahoma City at the State Fair Grounds at 5 P. M., July 9. Mr. Thomas, who is campaigning for renomination, said he talked to the President by telephone.

Dr. T. G. Delbridge, manager of the research and development department of the Atlantic Refining Company of Philadelphia, was elected president of the American Society for Testing Materials, which opened its forty-first annual meeting here today at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall. He succeeds Professor Albert Easton White,

Net profit of the Masonite Corporation for the ten periods ended on June 4, of its thirteen-period fiscal year, amounted to $798,623 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other deductions. After dividend requirements of $75,592 on the preferred stock, the result is equivalent to $1.35 a share on 536,740 common shares outstanding.

It was a slackening of the demand, rather than pressure of profit-taking, that held share prices in check yesterday. The undertone was steady to firm throughout the day, and the market closed irregular.

Former Premier George Tatarescu returned last night from London and other points west. M. Tatarescu, who is Minister Without Portfolio, is understood to have had financial cooperation between Rumania and Britain as the main object of his visit to London, although no loan was arranged.

Four hundred men and women, teachers and supervisors in the field of vocational education, attended a dinner at the. Woodstock Hotel last night at which Dr. Edwin A. Lee, director of the National Occupational Conference,
The Rev, Castor Ordonez, head of the Department of Biology at De Paul University since 1916, died this morning after a lingering illness at the age of 58.

Fritz Kuhn as leader of the German-American Bund, was named yesterday as defendant in a $3,000,000 slander suit begun in Supreme Court by the Rev. Dr. Emanuel J. Jack of Yonkers on behalf of himself and "all members of the Jewish faith who may join with me a plaintiffs."

Tabor Academy of Marion, Mass., and Loomis School of Windsor, Conn., qualified today for the finals of the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association championship, as did St. Paul's of Concord, N. H., and Hill of Pottstown, Pa.

Death Reported Retired Captain Patrick J. Crosby, formerly a member of Engine Co. 219, residIng at 22 St. Andrews PL., Brooklyn, died June 26. Funeral will take place from the funeral parlors of William A. Martin, Classon Ave. and Sterling Pl., Brooklyn, at D:30 A. M., Wednesday, June 29. Interment st Holy Cross Cemetery.

Pending formulation of a program for the registration with it of an association of over-the-counter brokers and dealers under the Maloney act, the Securities and Exchange Commission has voted to continue, without change, the rules and regulations which it formerly had promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 covering the prevention of fraudulent and manipulative practices in the over-thecounter market.

The trial of the German-American Settlement League and six of its directors, operating a Summer camp at Yaphank, L. I., on an indictment charging violation of the State Civil Rights Law, was set for July 6 here today by County Judge L. Barron Hill of Suffolk County, although attorneys for the defendants asked that it be postponed until the Fall.

Something of the romance and tradition of the old steamers that plied Long Island Sound between New York and Fall River will be recaptured at 6 o'clock tonight when the Colonial Line starts its service to -New Bedford with the twin-screw steamship Meteor.
Senator Joseph F. Guffey and John B. Kelly, Democratic City Chairman, patched up their differences on political patronage at a conference here today.

The regulation of raw commodity prices by the government is not i likely to have any permanent effect upon the world market, Dr. Melvin T. Copeland, Professor of Marketing in the Harvard School of Business Administration, declared yesterday.

A Salvation Army funeral service was held yesterday morning in Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street, for Lieut. Col. and Mrs. William H. Range of Atlanta, killed June 19 in the wreck of the Olympian train near Miles City, Mont.

Richard J. Barry, former president of the Queens County Bar Association, was named counsel yesterday to the Council committee to Investigate relief, and promised a, non-political investigation in which "no punches will be pulled."

Mrs. Victoria Marin Coughlin, 28, who was married two years ago to a newspaperman, Jack M. Coughlin, in New York, was buried here today following her accidental shooting early yesterday morning by Rafael Villamil, in whose home she was staying, when he mistook her for a burglar after she had given an alarm.

The marriage of Miss Jane Marquardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Frederick Marquardt of this place, to Arthur Gordon Murphy, son of Mrs. Arthur J. Murphy of New York and Sayville, L. I., and the late Mr. Murphy, took place here tonight in the Presbyterian Church of Upper Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert C. Williamson.

A virtual debate on the merits and results of United States Government pump priming between Colonel Leonard Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Co. and exponent of orthodox economics, and Corrington Gill, assistant administrator of the WPA, enlivened the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.

A special Federal Statutory Court, which heard argument several weeks ago on a petition filed by Davega-City Radio, Inc., for an injunction to restrain the New York State Labor Relations Board and other State agencies from enforcing a board order, denied that Request yesterday.

The Boston Albany Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $3,015,000 of its main-line firstmortgage bonds, 41/2 per cent, Series B, due July 1, 1948, with which to pay certain indebtedness to the New York Central.
The colonial residence of the late Ogden Mills overlooking the Hudson River at Staatsburg, N. Y., with its surrounding grounds and gardens, has been deeded to the State, it was disclosed yesterday.

A drastic injunction, "permanently" restraining two unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization from picketing in any manner the retail stores operated by the Busch Jewelry Company, Inc., and two affiliated corporations, was issued late yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.
Operators were principals in a number of the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday, when properties on the West Side furnished the bulk of the activity.

The Greenwich Orchestra will be heard tonight at the Federal Music Theatre under the direction of Arthur Lief. Lucien Ruttman, tenor, will be soloist. "Show Boat," which was to have opened yesterday at Randalls Island Stadium under Gallo-Shubert auspices, will open tonight,

The marriage of Miss Anita Finn, daughter of Mrs. Julius Finn and the late Mr. Finn, to Gilbert Glass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice L. Glass of this city, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, 15 West Eighty-first Street. The Rev. Dr. Milton Steinberg performed the ceremony.

Projects for the alteration of existing multi-family dwellings in Manhattan and Brooklyn featured the building plans filed yesterday. An average of about $7,400 will be spent in repairs on seven Manhattan buildings, while those in Brooklyn will cost less. Work in three schools in the former borough will cost a total of $18,500.

Houston St, 283 E, 5-story tenement and 4-story rear tenement, 25x100: Herman A. Heydt against Louis M. Goldschag: due, $9,649; taxes, etc, $1,292; subject to first mtg, $14,875; to plaintiff for $15,875.
Mr. and Mrs. Percy C. Stevens of 250 Forest Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Claire Stevens, to Joseph Chalmers Hazen Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Hazen of Summit, N. J.
Directors of Wilson Co. yesterday elected P. W. Seyl treasurer to fill the vacancy caused by the death of William C. Buethe.

Meeting of the West End Neighborhood Improvement Committee, Riverside Theatre, Broadway and Ninetysixth Street, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: Commissioner Lewis Valentine, Commissioner William F. Carey, William Stanley Miller, Representative Sol Bloom, Lambert Fairchild.

The trustees of Series Q-I announced yesterday that they have sold a plot 100 by 100 feet on the south mide of Layton Street, 110.10 feet east of Pettit Avenue, Elmhurst Queens, to the I Jay Building Corporation, which will improve the site with a six-story elevator apartment house. Sale was for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $10,500.

Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow and her husband may air their marital troubles in an English court soon. Count Court .Haugwitz-Reventlow has instructed his attorney, Norman Birkett, who was counsel for the Duchess of Windsor in her divorce proceedings,

The long-drawn-out attempt to settle the dispute between Paraguay and Bolivia over the Chaco threatens to break down today unless the Paraguayan Government modifies its refusal to accept the proposal of the five mediating Powers as a basis for discussion.

The Committee for Industrial Organization asked the Federal Government today to intervene in the situation in New Orleans where it alleges its officials and organizers are being illegally arrested, beaten and deported from the State by city and State police because of their efforts to organize workers in that city.

Although 52,000 bales of cotton were delivered to holders of July contracts yesterday, virtually the entire amount was taken up by a prominent spot firm and prices on the Cotton Exchange again- held within a comparatively narrow range. July gained a point.

Mrs. Mary Hogan Halley, mother of Transportation Commissioner Charles V. Halley Jr., former president of the Bronx County Bar Association, died yesterday in her home, 3,224 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, after a three-week illness. She was the widow of Charles V. Halley, real estate operator and department-store executive, who died in 1933. Her age was 83.

Vesta Hanover, driven by Sep Palin, tonight won the 2:12 trot and a $1,000 purse on the Grand Circuit program. The bay daughter of Sandy Flash and Rosa Guy finished first in two straight heats at the Fort Miami track. Vic Fleming drove Nate Hanover to an equally decisive triumph in the first division of the 2:14 race for a $500 purse.

The usually reserved Prague T: population gave a frenzied fourhour welcome today to 60,000 delegates attending the Sokol festival. All traffic in the heart of the city halted while they paraded through the main streets.
Evan H. Hopkins, attorney and one of eight brothers well known for their civic activities in Cleveland, died today at the age of 73.
The Interstate Commerce Commission concluded today its hearings on a reconsideration of the application of Eastern railroads for an increase of 2 to 21/2 cents in their basic coach fare.
