The trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to assume obligation and liability with respect to $1,640,000 of equipment trust certificates in connection with the $2,050,000 purchase of fifty new lightweight passenger cars.

In addition to providing decent housing for the white collar group, limited dividend housing projects return a reasonable interest and increase the revenue of the communities in which they are built as has been demonstrated in New York City, according to Louis H. Pink, chairman of the New York State Board of Housing.

The meeting between Lou Ambers and Henry Armstrong for the world lightweight championship, originally listed for July 26, yesterday was deferred until Aug. 10 by the New York State Athletic Commission. The postponement was granted by the solons after they had been informed by Ambers's manager, Al Weill, that the titleholder had suffered an injury to his hand in a recent fight.

Miss Anna Fosdick Bacon of Bronxville, treasurer of the Women's Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church in America, with offices in New York, died here yesterday in the Lawrence Hospital after an illness of five weeks.

An order requiring the city authorities to show cause in Brooklyn Supreme Court on July 15 why seventy clerks employed in the Municipal Courts throughout the c ty should not be paid at the rate of $3,240 annually was granted yesterday by Justice Albert Conway.

Frank O. Peers, former actor and long a theatrical manager in Chicago, died on Friday. He was born sixty-seven years ago in Central City, Col. As a young man his experiences as an actor included a period with Douglas Fairbanks at Elitch's Garden in Denver and in Mrs. Osborne's Playhouse in New York.

Eighteen wounded volunteers of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade will return from the Spanish war on the President Harding of the United States Lines on Saturday, according to a message from the State Department made public yesterday

Colonel William H. Patterson of the United States Army, for the past three years in charge of recruiting in this State, New Jersey and Delaware, with an office at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, will retire tomorrow.
Cross Keys, carrying the colors of Midkiff Wells of Lexington, Ky., and ridden by Ira Hanford, galloped to victory in the seven-furlong Evanston Purse at Arlington Park today.

Playing the game of her life Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Calif., overwhelmed Mile. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska of Poland, 6-2, 6-3, today and entered the semi-final round of the Wimbledon tennis championships with Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss Alice Marble.

A clean-up rally will be held this morning by the residents, property owners, storekeepers and superintendents of the West Side of Manhattan, between Seventy-second and 125th Streets. They will meet at the Riverside Theatre, Broadway and Ninety-sixth Street. Scheduled to speak are Police Commissioner Valentine, Sanitation Commissioner Carey, William Stanley Miller, president of the Tax Commission, and Representative Sol Bloom.

George Herman (Babe) Ruth escaped uninjured today in an automobile accident in which his coupe, after being in collision with another car, glanced off both a stone wall and a tree and then turned over on its side.

James J. Hines Jr. and his brother Eugene, sons of the lower West Harlem Tammany leader who is under indictment with eight others in the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy lottery monopoly, were witnesses yesterday before the extraordinary grand jury to which District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey has been sending evidence in various rackets investigations.
Maritime Day will be observed by the Greater New York Fund today with colorful ceremonies in the bay, on land and in the air at Battery Park. The ceremonies will be conducted from noon to 1 P. M.

The Norwegian Shipowners Association has received an intimation from Spanish Insurgents that General Francisco Franco will institute reprisals against owners who send their ships to Spanish Loyalist harbors.

THE rain was coming down steadily and Con nie Mack, the Grand Old Man of Baseball, didn't like it at all. The 75-year-old manager wanted to have his boys out at play. "By George!" said Connie. "We need exercise. This is the fifth day of rest for us. We were rained out three days in Chicago and spent another day traveling."

Some of the electrical equipment manufactured by the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company was described yesterday by Charles L. Eidlitz, director-general of the electrical industry's voluntary code of fair competition, as "impossible from the standpoint of local contractors."

B. Earl Puckett, president Allied Stores Corporation, New York, today attacked what he said was a popular belief that the retailer is responsible for the "high cost of distribution," and that the manufacturer has been chiefly responsible for any savings in the retail costs of merchandise.
A new set of decree laws that will be printed in tomorrow's Journal Officiel, features legislation giving the Bank of France power to deal in shortterm Treasury issues in the open market.

The daily average gross produetion- of crude oil' in the United States last week was 3,083,900 barrels, compared with 3,137,300 in the preceding week, a decline of 53,400, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Prospective oil concessions in Afghanistan and Iran, obtained early in 1937 by United States interests, which included the late Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, have been surrendered to their respective governments, it was said here yesterday.

Unless she changes her mind again Mrs. Hedi Heusser, 27 years old, will terminate her "stay-in strike" soon after 8 A. M. tomorrow at the estate here of Rollo K. Blanchard, 50-year-old vice president of the Neptune Meter Company of New York.
Philadelphia at New York (2)Nelson (8-1) and Caster (7-7) vs. Gomez (4-8) and Hadley (2-1). Detroit at Cleveland-Wade (1-2) vs. Harder (4-5). Washington at Boston-Leonard (6-6) vs. Marcum (4-6).

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania was the Hon. Harold C. Tennyson, the great-grandson of Alfred Lord Tennyson, poet laureate in the reign of Queen Victoria, who is making his first visit to the United States.
The Commonwealth Edison Company announced yesterday that $37,871,700 principal amount of its 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1958, amounting to $39,083,195,
Committees of the Constitutional Convention, working at full speed, adopted today, either completely or in principle, clauses dealing with home rule, housing and taxation.

Conditions today are forcing a change in the relationships between "bosses" and men in the effort to achieve industrial democracy, Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association said here tonight at the Economics Conference for Engineers at the Stevens Institute of Technology Engineering Camp.
The five story dwelling at 217 West Seventieth Street has been leased by Mrs. Mary Jill.to Robert Aura Smith for occupancy upon completion of alterations. Slawson Hobbs, brokers, arranged the lease.

Benjamin Fairless, as chairman of the United States Steel Corporation of Delaware, has charge of the arduous tasks, first, of revising the price schedules of subsidiaries of the New Jersey corporation which are managed by the Delaware concern-a process which has not yet been completed-and second,

An Easterner and a Southerner, one by virtue of a brilliant comeback and the other through consistent shot-making, stroked into a tie today for medalist honors at the end of the thirty-six-hole qualifying round for the forty-first national intercollegiate golf championship.
Visiting home shows to inspect residential plans and new ideas in house furnishings and building equipment appears to have become a popular pastime in nearly all parts of the country.

The President's decision to postpone for the time being the construction of two "super-battleships" is the first faint rift in the darkening clouds of the greatest naval race in world history. The 45,000-ton leviathans,

Jack Mooney, veteran ambulance driver of Flower Hospital, who has won countless races against the stork, shortly after last midnight lost by ten feet in getting Mrs. Dorothy Russo, 22 years old, into Bellevue Hospital for the birth of her child.

The figures reported to Congress by the Tennessee Valley Authority allocating costs for flood control, navigation and electric power production were entirely too low for power at the Wilson, Norris and Wheeler Dams, according to an analysis of the TVA allocation report just completed by engineers of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation system.

The Duchess of Atholl today gave tails of what she said were guns "threatening Gibraltar" from Inurgent Spain and issued notice that she would ask Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain in the House of Commons tomorrow what he intends to do about them.

Marvin Owen's steal of home in the ninth inning provided the Chicago White Sox with the margin of victory over the St. Louis Browns today. The score was 10 to 9. Owen's spectacular dash came with two out and the bases loaded.

Marked benefits to the grocery, drug and cosmetic industries were predicted yesterday by spokesmen for these lines, following the signing by President Roosevelt of the Federal Food, Drugs and Cosmetics Act.

Finished cotton goods began to move in larger volume yesterday, and some selling houses reported that their business was the heaviest in eight to ten months. Gray cloth volume dwindled perceptibly, but prices held steady.

If the American Labor party carries out its announced intention of nominating Sidney Hillman, prefident of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and prominent C. I. O. leader, as its candidate for the United States Senate this Fall, the action will spell the ruin of the Labor party, Abraham Cahen, editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, declared yesterday.

The ashes of James A. Ten Eyck, noted oarsman and rowing coach at Syracuse University for thirty-five years, who died in Miami, Fla., on Feb. 11, were strewn by his widow, Mrs. Mary Randall Ten Eyck, on the Hudson River here today near Bear Mountain Bridge, from a launch, in accordance with his request. He was born near Tompkins Cove, and spent his youth across the river, near Peekskill.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson refused yesterday to grant a reargument of that part of his decision allowing the Interborough Rapid Transit Company to disaffirm its lease of the Manhattan elevated lines which provided the Interborough must continue to provide free transfer service between. the subway and elevated at 149th Street, the Bronx. a transfer point for nearly 3,000,000 passengers annually.

Great Britain, France, Italy and Germany tonight agreed to split the entire $7,000,000 cost of the proposed withdrawal of foreign volunteers from Spain after Russia dedined to bear. her full fifth of the expense.

Particulars of the compromise arrived at regarding bank examinations, between Governor Eccles of the Federal Reserve on the one hand and the Controller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on the other, indicate that on most points Mr. Eccles had his way.

President Roosevelt will be greeted with a twenty-one-gun salute, fired from two cannons, when he arrives at the New York World's Fair grounds tomorrow afternoon to lay the cornerstone of the principal building in the Federal Government's $3,000,000 group.
Yesterday's rain kept New York's three major league ball clubs idle. The Yankee double-header with Connie Mack's Athletics at the Stadium was postponed.

A jury in Suffolk County Court today found Michael Hermanowski, 23 years old, of St. James. L. I., guilty of murder in the first degree in connection with the slaying on May 24 of his parents at Green Front Inn, St. James. Judge L. Barron Hill.

Tinton Ave, 927; 3-story tenement, 18.11x95; Isabel S. Kemp against Abraham Rosen zweig: due, $5,873; taxes, etc., $630; to plaintiff for $4,000. Beach Ave, 535. 25x104.2x irreg: Home Owners Loan Corp. against Amelia Zachman; due, $7,019; to plaintiff for $500. 225th St, 671 E, 24.9x114.6; Dollar Savings Bank against Emmerline La Rue; due, $5.181; taxes, etc, $343; to plainitff for $4,500.

Entertaining in honor of Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie, who on Saturday noon is to become the bride of Alan T. Schumacher of New York, will begin on Thursday evening, when Mr. and Mrs. Gillespie will give an informal dinner for members of the prospective wedding party.
Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, June 30: INSPECTOR--Arthur J. Dodd, 2d District Traffic, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Dec. 1, 1896.

What is described as a plan to unload obsolete securities with a face value of upward of $3,000,000 and represented as stocks of going corportions has been frustrated by the Securities and Exchange Commission in cooperation with the Philadelphia authorities, it was disclosed yesterday by the SEC.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, charged yesterday that some of. the elections held among West Coast pier workers some months ago were without proper supervision and that the National Labor Relations Board,

Drenching rain failed to discourage members of society who had charge of the annual Summer Day Fair at St. Johnland this afternoon, and crowds of visitors drove through the winding highways so heavily overhung with sodden branches that passing was difficult.

The Royal Dutch Airlines today opened a new bi-weekly service between Amsterdam and Sydney, Australia. A plane of the Amsterdam-Java service left Schiphol Airdrome for Batavia, Java, whence it will connect with a plane of the subsidiary Royal Netherlands East Indian Airline.

Social security-the phrase that means a regular deduction from the pay envelopes of 40,000,000 wage-earners in the United States-was described here today as the bulwark of our democracy by Senator Lewis B. Schwellenbach of Washington.

Clyde W. Potts, new serving his seventh term as Mayor of Morristown, N. J., surrendered in the Buffalo city affairs investigation today and pleaded innocent to a charge of first degree perjury. He was one of the engineers considered several years ago for the post of consultant in Buffalo's $15,000,000 sewer project. His bail was fixed at $7,500.

The Chinese forces have be lost suffered more than 10,000 casualties in the week-long battle near the Matang boom in the Yangtze River, 200 miles below Hankow, according to authoritative sources here.

Miss Dorothy Katharine Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marvin Nelson of 860 Park Avenue, was married to James Stanley Richmond yesterday afternoon in St. James Church. The Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, the rector, performed the ceremony.

A throng of 300 persons gathered yesterday afternoon in front of the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street, just off Fifth Avenue, where a fire in a duct sucking fumes from a kitchen range in the basement was quickly extinguished by firemen.
Carolina Power and Light Company-Twelve months to May 31: Net income after taxes and charges, $2,436,394, compared with $2,430,900 in the twelve months to May 31, 1937.

A fitful struggle under a blazing Spanish sun shifted back and forth today across the barren Sarrion war sector in Spain and when night fell thousands of men were still deadlocked in a contest for one of the main highways to Valencia.

The Navy proved at Poughkeepsie that a great crew can combine all the best elements of fiction into a recordbreaking fact. They also broke the six-year-old tradition that all the big trees and all the invincible oarsmen grow in California and Washington.

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $10,000. To Helen B. August, widow, executrix, 12 E. 88th St. DYER, SALLY . (Apri 17). Estate, less than $10,000. To Charles W. and William H. Dyer, sons, executors, 215 W. 80TH St., residue equally. HENDERSON, MARY A. (May 12). Estate, $3,500. To Albert B. Bryn, Keansburg, N. J., and Catherine S. Morrison, 35 South St., Atlantic City, N. J., executors residue equally.

The Philippine Commonwealth will recover about $6,000,000 it had on deposit with six banking institutions in this country at a time when they became insolvent, although other creditors of the same banks have received or will receive only a pro rata share of the funds on hand, unless a decision handed down yesterday by Federal Judge John M. Woolsey is reversed on appeal.

Secretary Morgenthau today invited bids on the Treasury's weekly issue of $100,000,000 of ninety-oneday bills which will be dated July 6, to mature on Oct. 5. Because of the holiday on Monday, the bills will be sold this week on Friday instead of on Monday.

Two Soviet mile fliers landed at Vladivostok today after a 4,300-mile non-stop flight from Moscow to demonstrate the plan long-range possibilities of the Red army's aircraft. They immediately telegraphed a report of their success to Joseph Stalin.

Camp followers and wives of Mexican soldiers called at the National Defence Secretariat today and denounced what they termed a campaign to "Sovietize" the Mexican Army through the activities of attractive young feminine school

Miss Carolyn Elizabeth Berry, daughter of Mrs. George Berry of Atlanta, Ga., and the late Mr. Berry, was married to Paul Talmey of New York this afternoon at Dover Farm, the home here of the bridegroom's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Colin.
First enlistments for the recently created Regular Army Reserve will be accepted Friday, it was announced yesterday by the Unit, ed States Army Information Service.

John Paul Bathelt, 25, of New York, son of a Holyoke manufacturer, was arraigned in District Court today on a charge of murder in the slaying of a man whose cement-encased body was recovered last week from the Connecticut River.
Representatives of the railroad unions and of the managements agreed today to start negotiations in this city July 20 on the proposal of the railroads to cut wages 15 per cent.
The Cardinals combined a seven-run blast in the third inning with some excellent pitching by Lon Warneke today to beat the Cubs, 9 to 3.

Anthony J. De Pace of New York has been appointed architect for the new school and auditorium to be erected by the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Rosary at the corner of Seventh and Brunswick Streets, Jersey City, N. J. The building will cost approximately $100,000.

Pzzled and discouraged, searchers for young Medill McCormick labored through fog and intermittent rain squalls today an Sandia Peak. A white spot seen through surveying transits on the west face of the peak- caused the family to seek a high-powered telescope for a closer inspection of the object, which appeared roughly to be a white cloth.

When the executive committee of the Republican party met this week in Washington members reckoned that five new Senators and sixty-five new Representatives from their political group will sit in the next Congress.

Governmental efforts to build housing and to extend easy credit to prospective builders and realty buyers, and proposals for inflation of the currency to achieve the same result were criticized yesterday by Dr. Willford I. King, former president of the American Statistical Association and Professor of Economics at New York University.

The Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures today characterized as "unfortunate" the speech of Aubrey Williams, deputy administrator of the Works Progress Administration, to a gathering yesterday of representatives of "white collar"
The five-room house and garage at 312 Eleventh Street, Union City, N. J., was sold by the Community Building and Loan Association to Fannie Rothman. J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers, negotiated the sale.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates June 28, unless specified: At San Diego: Argonne, Vireo. At Navy Yard, Philadelphia; Dunlap, Fanning. Bangkok to Manila: Alden, Barker, Blackhawk, J. D. Edwards, Paul Jones, Whippie.

Experiments with X-ray treatments are under way at the Brooklyn Cancer Institute at Kings County Hospital to determine if cancer can be so devitalized as to yield more readily to eventual surgical treatment, according to a report by Dr. William E. Howes, clinical director of the institute, made public yesterday by Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater.

Acting on instructions from London, the Earl of Perth, the British Ambassador, called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, late this evening, and drew the Italian Government's attention to the very difficult situation created in AngloItalian relations by the continued...

Officials of the State of Maryland have invited tenders for $3,413,000 of general construction bonds, award of which will be made on July 27. The bonds will be dated Aug. 15, 1938, and will mature serially from 1941 to 1953. Bidders have been asked to name the rate of interest.
Announcement has been made of the appointment of Dr. Rexford B. Hersey of the University of Philadelphia as chief of the editorial department of the International Labor Organization in Geneva.

Resolutions calling for increased Federal aid to education, a campaign to make the American public "tax-education" conscious, and opposition to the practice in some States of calling upon teachers to teach without pay, were approved yesterday by the resolutions committee of the National Education Association.

Plans were filed in Brooklyn yesterday for a six-story apartment to house 150 families, in the Sheepshead Bay section, estimated to cost $450,000. Other projects included alteration jobs to a number of tenements in Manhattan, and groups of twelve and eight dwellings in Brooklyn and Manhattan respectively.

Dr. Hugh M. Parshall, veteran Urbana, Ohio, reinsman, piloted Chief Counsel to victory in straight heats tonight in the $1,460 Matron Stake, pacing feature of the Grand Circuit card at the Fort Miami track.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reopened today before Samuel O. Clark Jr., examiner, hearings in its investigation of the failure of Richard Whitney Co., in order to make minor changes in various supporting schedues filed in connection with the firm's financial affairs.

A home run by Joe Greenberg, brother of Detroit's slugging Hank, in the eighth gave Baltimore a 4-to-3 victory over Newark in a scheduled seven-inning nightcap today. The league champions trounced the Orioles in the opener, 15 to 3.

After a warm debate the Assembly rejected this afternoon a bill that would have barred ships arriving here from allowing passengers to live on board during their stay. The Assembly's action followed a United States protest to Britain against the proposal on the ground that it was discriminatory.

New York Yankees vs. Phila. Athletics, at Yankee Stadium, '161st and River Avenue, Bronx ..............3:15 P. M, Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Boston Bees, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn ..........3:15 P. M. Newark Bears vs. Baltimore Orioles. two games, at Ruppert Stadium, 262 Wilson Avenue, Newark ..............6:30 P. M.

Seth Low Junior College in Brooklyn goes out of existence today as a unit of Columbia University. Two years ago, when the college was removed from its quarters at 375 Pearl Street, Brooklyn, to Morningside Heights, university officials explained that it would be necessary

President Roosevelt may have to, ride through picket lines when he arrives at the World's Fair grounds today to lay the cornerstone of the Federal Building, as a result of a threatened general strike of 10,000 construction workers affiliated with unions of the Building Trades and Construction Council, A. F. of L. organization.
Forty-six students will be graduated tonight at the twentieth commencement of Talmudical Academy, the high-school department of Yeshiva College, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

A plea for "good old-fashioned American patriotism" was made here today by Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District, at a memorial service attended by Veterans of Foreign Wars and the women's auxiliary of that organization.

In the first Labor Relations Board election involving employes in the $250 to $3,000 a week salary bracket, the Screen Writers Guild triumphed over the Screen Playwrights by a vote of 267 to 60 here last night.

George C. Dix, attorney for Johanna Hofmann, German spy suspect, admitted several times yesterday in Federal Court that he had no evidence to support his belief expressed on Monday that Leon G. Turrou, resigned Federal agent, had allowed the fugitive spy suspect, Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, to flee for monetary profit.

Statistics on Peru's foreign trade for the first quarter of this year, just released, show an adverse trade balance of 3,810,738 soles, contrasted with a favorable balance of 26,457,148 soles recorded for the corresponding part of 1937.

In the first intersectional three-ball mixed sixsome team match the Long Island men and women teamed beautifully today to score 11 points and beat their New Jersey and Westchester rivals over the Rockaway Hunting Club course. Westchester tallied 7 points and New Jersey 6.

Lee R. Lincoln, traffic superintendent of the Postal Telegraph Pacific division, has been appointed general superintendent of traffic for the Postal Telegraph System, with headquarters in New York, it was announced yesterday by R. A.

Japan's worst storm in sixty years in addition to a heavy earthquake today left a death toll of 100 persons, most of them in Tokyo and Yokohama. A fraction more than 12 inches of rain fell between dawn and midnight Wednesday.

Tomorrow morning marks the opening of another bass season in New York State, and there are a number of lakes within a seventyfive-mile radius of the city that are expected to offer considerable excitement to the angler.

The reports of the first sixtyseven railroads to publish their accounts for May indicate that all the Class I companies earned about $17,500,000 net operating income in that month, compared with $43,662,959 in May, 1937, and with $9,236,818 in April.

Turpentine firm, 23 1/2c; sales 36 barrels; receipts 461 barrels; shipments 1,532 barrels; -stock 37.578 barrels. Resin firm; sales 436: receipts 2,077; shipments 2,707; stock 153,456. Quote: B, $3.40; D, $3.65; E. $3.90; F, $4.35; G, $4.57 1/2-60; H, $4.60; I, K, $4.62 1/2-65; M, $4.65; N, $5.25; WG, $5.75; WW, X, $6.35.

Plans for the award of an honorary LL.D. degree by Harvard University to the Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden on July 11, and for the Crown Prince's reception and tour of the Harvard buildings, were announced today.

The fifty-foot wooden and steel footbridge over the tracks of- the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad at Chestnut and White Plains Avenues, Rosebank, S. I., collapsed last night at 11:10 o'clock, tying up railroad traffic- for forty-five minutess.
The close of play scores in first-class English cricket matches started today: Gloucestershire 96 (Nichols six for 24): Essex 224 for five (O'Connor 83 not out, Every- 85), at Brent-wood.

East Side buildings figured in many of the apartment leases reported yesterday. Several. of the contracts involved large suites on Park Avenue. The day's list follows: James R. Ullman, 12 rooms, in 1,155 Park Ave; Bryne Bowman, Inc, brokers. Dwight E. Austin, 11 rooms, in 139 E. 79th St; Alfred W. Lasher, in 24 W 55th St; August J. Cordier, through Culver,
C. I. O. seiners today picketed the Ketchikan Packing Company, a local concern, because, it was alleged, it refused to hire men through the C. I. O. hiring hall here.

With the Fire Department's thriller, "The Midnight Alarm," as the .entertainment feature, graduation and promotion exercises for 222 members of the Police Department will take place tonight at Madison Square Garden.

H. C. Hatfield of Oklahoma City was chosen president of Kiwanis International by acclamation today at the annual convention. He succeeds F. Trafford Taylor of St. Boniface, Man. Mr. Hatfield was elevated to the presidency from the office of treasurer.

The Chase National Bank, trustee, has announced that $120,000 principal amount of A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company first-mortgage bonds, 4 per cent Series, due in 1946, has been designated by lot for redemption on Aug. 1, 1938, out of the sinking fund at 102 and accrued interest.
Governor Lehman, opposing views of ex-Governor Smith and Park Commissioner Moses, asked the Constitutional Convention not to saddle the entire cost of grade crossing removal on the State. [Page 1.]
The American Association for the Advancement of Science heard today from two Nobel Prize winners what physics and chemistry could be expected to do for mankind.

At the request of all the organized dairy groups in the State, the New Jersey Milk Control Board will open negotiations with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration for the establishment of a separate Federal milk marketing agreement for this State instead of including New Jersey in the New York and Philadelphia areas.
Captain P. R. Oliver, member of the British 1938 Mount Everest expedition, arrived here today with word that the expedition's attempt to scale the world's highest mountain had been unsuccessful.

Swing music as played by a fifteen-piece band at 2 o'clock in the morning in an inn leased from the Park Department is not a breach of the peace, Magistrate William Klapp ruled yesterday in' West Side Court when he dismissed a disorderly conduct charge brought against the management of the Claremont Inn by disturbed residents of Riverside Drive.

At a hearing today before Examiner Charles S. Moore of the Securities and Exchange Commission on applications by the New York Stock Exchange for permission to delist securities of six companies because it was considered against public interest to continue trading in them; John Haskell,

Education is one of the most powerful influences in the making of a stabilized, progressive society, three speakers declared yesterday at a meeting of the department of secondary school principals of the National Education Association at the Hotel New Yorker.
Mrs. Henry E. Coe entertained with a luncheon today at the Appletrees for members of the North Country Garden Club of Long Island, who later in the afternoon visited gardens at estates here. Mrs.

Word was received here yesterday of the death in Tucson, Ariz. on Tuesday night, of Dr. Bonnard Teegarden of 1 East Ninth Street. Dr. Teegarden, who was 35 years, old, had gone to Tucson to convalesce from an attack of influenza, but complications set in after his arrival there.

There will be no payment on account of interest due on Friday. on the 6 per cent cumulative income debenture stock of the Mexican Light and Power Company, large Ltd., the chairman, Miller Lash, announced at the annual meeting of the company today.

William J. Gottlieb was unanimously re-elected president of the Automobile Club of New York yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. J. R. Crossley, vice president, and Walter B. Foden, secretary and treasurer, also were returned to their posts in the New York unit of the American Automobile Association.

Don Budge, playing more impressively than at any time since he reached England, today crushed Ferenc Puncec of Yugoslavia by 6-2, 6-1, 6-4 in the Wimbledon tennis semi-finals. His opponent in the final on Friday will be Henry W. (Bunny) Austin, the veteran Briton who defeated Henner Henkel of Germany by the equally onesided score of 6-2, 6-4, 6-0 today.

Lawrin, the Kentucky Derby winner, raced to a new track record before 35,000 persons at Hollywood Park today in a $55,000 mile-and-aquarter test from which Dauber was scratched less than an hour before the race.

New York City's 38,000 teachers lost their fight to have their own representative on the board of directors of the National Education Association after a stormy debate in the association's representative assembly yesterday at the HippodrQme.

Miss Polly Abbott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Abbott of 111 East Seventy-first Street and St. James, L. I., will be married on Monday to William Mackey Wherry 3d, son of W. M. Wherry of 1,088 Park Avenue and the late Mrs. Wherry.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody today denied reports circulating in New York that she planned to turn professional after the completion of the Wimbledon tennis championships. "I am not even considering such a thing," she declared, "and I am going to stick to the plans I made

The Industrial Rayon Corporation, Cleveland, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $7,500,000 of firstmortgage sinking-fund bonds, Series A, due on July 1, 1953, the interest rate, the price at which the bonds are to be offered and the underwriting discounts or commissions to be supplied later.

Opposition to the writing into the new State Constitution of any provision which might endanger the gains already achieved by women in industry was expressed here today at a public hearing of the Constitutional Convention's committee on industrial relations by women trade unionists

BOOKER--Emma, beloved mother of Edward, on June 29. Services Rodney Dade, 2,332 Seventh Ave., 1 P. M., Saturday. BRESLIN-Right Rev. Mgr. Patrick N pastor of Our Lady of Mercy Church and dean of the Bronx, beloved brother of Right Rev. Mgr.-Joseph A. Breslin, Mrs. Mary Curtin, Mrs. Margaret Hart, Mrs. Anne Casey, Catherine, Rose, Elizabeth and Edward Breslin, on June 28, in St.

Twice yesterday the National Education Association, which is holding its seventy-sixth annual convention here, closed its ears to Daniel Doherty, National Commander of the American Legion, who had made a special trip to New York to answer charges that his organization was fascist in complexion.

A determined drive to bring the social workers of the country into the labor movement as militant workers' groups was being made here today at the National Conference of Social Work, with Jacob Baker, president of the United Federal Workers of America, a C. I. O. union, calling for the unionization of all "white collar" workers as vital to the labor movement in America.
Mrs. Mildred Elizabeth Jacob, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland T. Hungerford, will be married to Madison Peters Rehm at 7.o'clock tomorrow evening in the home of her parents, 2 Garth Road, Scarsdale.
Mrs. Carolyn Poulder King, 89 years old, last surviving widow of a veteran of the War of 1812, died yesterday in suburban Cheektowaga.

Accused of shooting and killing his estranged 21-year-old wife, after an argument over the terms of a divorce in an attorney's office late this afternoon, Albert Goldstein, 28, an unemployed clothing worker of 405 Park Avenue, Perth Amboy, was booked at police headquarters tonight on a charge of murder.

Italy has informed Britain, it was disclosed yesterday, that the Spanish Insurgents will curb the bombing of ships flying the Union Jack. Specifically, British ships outside Spanish waters will not be attacked, those in harbors will be spared as far as possible and safe ports will be designated. [Page 1.]

The board of governors of the Chicago Stock Exchange approved today the application of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company to list 79,974 shares of 7 per cent cumulative participating preferred stock, par value $50 a share, and 2,592,155 shares of common stock, par value $50 a share.

Two home runs by Dolph Camilli and one by Goody Rosen failed to aid the Dodgers last night and a crowd of 18,680 night owls saw Brooklyn bow to the Bees, 7-6, in the third of the series of seven floodlight contests scheduled for Ebbets Field this season.

Formation of a permanent civic organizaition to cooperate with the Police, Park and Sanitation Departments in keeping clean the streets, sidewalks and parks of the West Side zone was completed yesterday morning at a meeting at the Riverside Theatre, Broadwayland Ninetysixth Street.

An appeal from the recent ruling by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson, approving the proposed sale of the Sixth Avenue elevated line to the city for $12,500,000, was authorized yesterday by the directors of the Manhattan Railway Company. The directors also authorized an appeal from Judge Patterson's decision permitting the receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company to disaffirm the company's 999-year lease of the Manhattan's elevated system.

Mr. and Mrs. August Zinsser: of 6 West Ninth Street gave a garden party last evening at their home for Mrs - Zinsser's daughter, Miss Martha Scott Clayton and for Miss Virginia Hoffmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip :Hoffmann of 1,185 Park Avenue.

A decree prohibiting private cotton imports went into effect today. It is estimated about a year's supply remains in Japan. Henceforth all cotton imported by Japan can be used only for military purposes or for manufacture of goods for export.
Senator Borah of Idaho celebrated his seventy-third birthday today by speaking a word of cheer for young people who are having a hard time getting ahead.

Isidore Grossman of the Grossman Clothing Company was elected president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange at the annual meeting at the group's headquarters here yesterday. Mr. Grossman had automatically succeeded to the office on the death of Charles Jaffee last year.
Miss Muriel Greatorex, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Greatorex of Arlington, was married here tonight in Christ Episcopal Church to Donald A. Diehl, son of Mrs. A. H.

Marking what is believed the first day, action taken so far by any industry under the Wages and Hours Act, the board of directors of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Commodore, adopted a resolution calling upon the members of the industry to continue to observe the wage and hour-standards established under the NRA code for the wool textile industry, and subsequently maintained voluntarily.
Fifteen thousand teachers in convention assembled now have a new slant on the word "cooperate." This is important,

Despite an improvement in weather conditions, prices on the Cotton Exchange held yesterday within a narrow range again and ended with gains of 2 to 5 points. Strength in outside markets and further active covering on the part of July shorts maintained the recently improved price level. As a result of a tight near-month situation, July went to a 5-point premium over October.

A WPA assistant superintendent employed on Projects 36 and 37 in the Bronx Botanical and Zoological Gardens confessed yesterday that he had used government building materials to construct a home for himself in Otisville, N. Y.

A plan designed to afford employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with a medium for the investment of part of their earnings through the purchase of United States Government "Baby" bonds was announced yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president of A. T. T.

Miss Edith Virginia Seldomridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Russell Schroyer of Evanston, Ill., was married tonight to John Lansing Zabriskie, son of Mrs. Nicholas Lansing Zabriskie and the late Mr. Zabriskie of Aurora- on- Cayuga, N. Y.

The Rev. Lauriston Livingston Scaife has been appointed assistant to the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, the rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street. Beginning Sunday, he will be in charge of the parish during the Summer vacation of Dr. Brooks.

British airplanes, policemen and troops tonight patrolled a Palestine made tense by the hanging of a Jewish youth today. Chanting the song of the Revisionist party and dressed in its uniform, 19-year-old Solomon ben Yosef steadily walked to the gallows in the troop-surrounded prison at Acre at 8 A. M.

Funeral services for Dr. James Weldon Johnson, Negro poet, composer and educator, will be held at 1 o'clock this afternoon in the Salem Methodist Church, Seventh Avenue and 129th Street, under arrangements made by the American Society of Composers,

Mrs. Childs Frick was elected president of the Bird Club of Long Island this afternoon at a meeting at Clayton, her home in Roslyn Harbor, which was followed by a tea. The club, in which many members of Long Island society are active, was founded by the late President Theodore Roosevelt.

Search for young Medill ?? Cormick was abandoned today on the cliff face of mile-high Sandia Peak, where he disappeared a week ago while on a climbing expedition with Richard Whitmer, 20-year-old Princeton student.

J. P. Bender, vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, announced yesterday that the company had bought all the outstanding bonds of the Lewis F. Shoemaker Company at Pottstown, Pa. The price was not disclosed. The Pottstown company, formerly a maker of structural steel, has been shut down since last Fall.

With the coming fiscal year beginning July 1, the failure of Congress to act on President Federico Laredo Bru's budget message made it apparent today that Cuba's national expenditure for 1938-39 would be held down to this year's figure of $79,092,080. If the budget is not approved for any fiscal year,
Electric power production increased last week by more than the seasonal and long-term amounts. The adjusted index advanced to 91.2 from 90.7. The figure was 106.6 for the week ended June 26, 1937.

The total value of wholesale inventories declined during May, 1938, compared to May, 1937, in spite of a 16 per cent decline in the dollar volume of wholesale trade during the month, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES'S recent editorial "The Why of Housing" contains many facts from which incorrect conclusions can be drawn. It may be true, as the Mayor says, that 1,700,000 people in this city live in old-law tenements, but these are being eliminated because they cannot possibly produce anything but heavy

The following is a list of presentations which the Federal Caravan Theatre will offer tonight free of charge in the public parks and fields of the city: Manhattan, "Mississippi Rainbow," at Corlears Park; Brooklyn, "Showing Off," a variety bill, plus "Marriage Proposal," a one-act play, at Kelly Field; Queens, "Treasure Island,"
The King today gained his first victory of the racing season when Cosmopolitan, a chestnut colt by Sir Cosmo from Papilla, won the Stud Produce Stakes for 2-year-olds.

Four men convicted of mail fraud and conspiracy growing out of the operations in 1935 of Secord Van- her attorney derpoel Co., an investment secure ity house, which had offices at 70 Pine Street, received prison sentences yesterday from Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum ranging from thirty days to three years.

While strength in securities and in the deferred deliveries of wheat in Winnipeg tended to restrict selling of wheat futures on the Board of Trade here today the market showed a distinctly easy undertone, and closing trades were about at the bottom, with prices unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel lower.
Secretary Ickes announced today allotments totaling $48,000,000 for sixtyfive army projects in twenty-eight States, including New York and the District of Columbia.

Bobby Riggs of Los Angeles and Chicago won the national clay courts singles tennis title for the third time today, defeating Gardner Mulloy of Miami, 6-4, 5-7, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5. Riggs had match point twice in the final set before gaining his victory in a hard-fought battle that

William P. Stout, president of the Stout Engineering Laboratory of Detroit,. who supervised the construction in 1922 and 1933 of the first all-metal airplane to be built in this country, testified yesterday that six out of every seven pieces of duralumin supplied for the job by the Aluminum Company of America were so defective that inspectors of the Navy Department had to reject them.

A challenge of the authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission was made to the Supreme Court today by seven major railroads contesting the commission's right to prevent leases of warehouse space to shippers in the New York City harbor district below the cost to the carriers.

Gregory Son, Inc., won the award yesterday of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's $6,330,000 of 2 3/4 per cent equipment trust certificates, Series I, on a bid of 100.375. The certificates are dated July 1, 1938, and will mature up to July 1, 1953.

Edwin B. McGuire, former assistant district attorney of New York County, died yesterday morning in his home, 501 West 110th Street. Although in ill health for more than a year, he testified several weeks ago as a State witness in a murder case which he had investigated.

While Mrs. Helen Wills Moody prepared to fight to win her eighth Wimbledon singles final and set an all time record, her. one-time conqueror, Mile. Suzanne Lenglen, lies fighting death in a clinic here.

The outward movement of capital from the United States, which in the last quarter of 1937 assumed proportions unprecedented in recent years, slowed up considerably in the first quarter of this year, according to the Treasury Department's quarterly statement on international capital movements, made public today.

A group of students crowded into a round-table meeting scheduled for faculty members attending the. N. E. A. convention in the Museum of Natural History yesterday and virtually took over the discussion, giving free expression to their opinions on formulating school policies.

Fortune Gallo, impresario of the San Carlo Opera Company, and the Shuberts, Lee and J. J., joined forces again last night for their third season of musical comedies and operettas on Randalls Island. The initial production, Jerome Kern's work, "Showboat," a favorite musical romance of a bygone year, drew an audience of 5,000 which made no secret of its approval of the presentation.

While the European nations squabble over matters that they will forget tomorrow, an event is about to take place in Asia that is destined to upset the balance of power in the basin of the Eastern Mediterranean.

Mrs. Alice Dresel Beal of this city and Poughkeepsie, widow of Thaddeus Reynolds Beal and daughter of the late Lieutenant H. George Dresel, U.S.N., and the late Mrs. Dresel of Washington, D. C., was married here this afternoon in St. George's

Reuben T. Shaw, head of the science department of the Northeast High School in Philadelphia, was elected president of the Nationwas Education Association in balloting yesterday by the 1,600 accredited delegates to the convention.
The ten-room English-style home at 30 Shawnee Road, Scarsdale, Westchester County, was sold by Percy S. Alden to B. William Cohen of Larchmont. Howe Sherry were the brokers.

Unless otherwise stated, the resuits of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

The Cardinals shoved the Cubs down to fourth place in the National League today, converting a 15-hit attack against three pitchers into a 10-to-5 victory. St. Louis, paced at bat by Mickey Owen, who connected for a double and three singles, belted Bill Lee,

The status of the amended reorganization plan of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was outlined yesterday by George W. Alger, special master, to counsel for various parties at a brief hearing in the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.

The American Terminal Company will begin operation here on July 1 of what is said to be the largest motor freight terminal in the United States,. Louis C. Seaverns, president, has announced. The terminal will house eighteen separate interstate truck lines.

Dr. George Anthony Zeller, one of America's leading alienists, died of heart disease today in his apartment on the Peoria State Hospital grounds. His age was 79. He was born in Spring Bay, Ill., in November, 1858.

Schools must take a full share of the responsibility for developing men like Mayor Frank Hague or evil conditions that may exist in the American Legion, Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of Newark University, declared yesterday at the morning session of the National Education Association in the Hotel New Yorker.

MANHATTAN BOWRON, ELIZABETH M. (May 21, 1937.) Gross assets, $3,838: net. $24. To Mary F. Bowron, sister, one-half residue.; Lillian Owen, niece, Charles H., and John Bowron Jr., nephews, one-sixth residue each. Chief assets, mortgages. notes, cash and insurance, $2,502. Griffin Hoag, attorneys, 2 William St.

Devil's Island and other penal establishments in French Guiana were abolished by a stroke of the pen in a decree published in the Official Journal. It enforces the provisions of the government's bill of December, 1936, dealing with the matter, which, though not voted, has applied in practice since then.
Orders booked by the furniture industry during May showed a "significant" improvement over those for the previous month, the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers announced today.

Richard Hendel, president and founder of the R. . J. Underwear Company, Inc., and one of the leading figures in the children's underwear industry, died in his Summer home in Bethlehem, N. H., on Tuesday, according to word received. at the company's New York offices yesterday. He was 58 years old.

It is perhaps unfortunate that the momentous changes in pricing policies now being introduced by the steel industry have come so close to the Fourth of July holiday, since mill activity is expected to be slack as a result of the celebrations,

Cosmic rays probably originate "locally" within the Milky Way, the galaxy of which the earth is a part, rather than in remote stellar space, Dr. Arthur H. Compton said tonight in a report before the symposium on cosmic rays now in progress at the University of Chicago.

For renovation into small suites of two and one-half to three rooms, the five-story tenement house on a plot 25 by 100 feet at 499 East 162d Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by a syndicate headed by Louis Bornstein, from the Central Savings Bank.

The honor has fallen to General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano to be the first to have a village named after him. In the marshlands of the Guadalquivir River between Seville and the sea, the village here-after will be known as Queipo de Llano.

12:45-1:00 P. M.-Final Report Luncheon of the Greater New York Fund, Hotel Commodore-WEAF, WNYC, WMCA, WNEW. 2:00-2:30 P. M.-President Roosevelt Dedicating Federal Building at World's Fair-WABC, WJZ, WOR, WHN, WMCA, WQXR, WNEW (1,250 Kc.), WOV (1,130 Kc.). 3:00-3:45 P. M.-President Roosevelt Addressing N. E. A. Convention, World's Fair Grounds; Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, PresidingWABC, WOR, WHN, WNYC, WJZ, WQXR, WMCA.

In a setting of seriousness and dignity befitting the occasion, eleven fishermen gathered in the office of the secretary to the Dock Department at the Battery yesterday afternoon and drew lots for a sixmonth revocable permit to berth a party fishing craft at a choice pier in Sheepshead Bay.

A Washington dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 28 stated that the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act became effective immediately when the President signed the bill on that day. This was partly in error.

Mrs. Margo Lindewal Bathelt of 277 Park Avenue left the city yesterday afternoon for Northampton, Mass., where her husband, John P. Bathelt, is under arrest, charged with the murder of Charles Morris, a race-track follower.

The public and all branches of the liquor industry were urged to give preference to Americanmade liquors over the imported brands in one of a series of resolutions adopted by the New Jersey Retail Liquor Package Stores Association at the close of its fourth annual convention here today.

What purports to be the first complete list of corporation and individual purchasers of the souvenir program of the Democratic convention in 1936, collected by Senator Holt of West Virginia and published in today's Congressional Record, shows that the total amount collected by the Democratic National Committee from the sale of these books was $849,812.64.
Miss Margot Garrett, daughter of George Angus Garrett, was married here today in St. Matthew's Church to Don Luis Mariano Zuberbuhler, Second Secretary of the Argentine Embassy.

In its annual report, a summary of which was made public here yesterday, the League Loans Committee (London) asserts that its chief accomplishment in the last year has been the putting into force of settlements which modified permanently the original contractual service of the Danzig and Hungarian League loans.
Three members of the House Rules Committee, including Chairman John J. O'Connor of New York, have been marked for defeat by the Administration's "purge" committee, it was reported today.

With the filing yesterday of the final papers in the office of the Secretary of State of Delaware, the plan of reorganization of the Panhandle Producing and Refining became effective, it was announced here. It is understood the new common stock will be ready for delivery by July 15.

The Securities and Exchange Commis- of sion has set for July 18 a hearing on a declaration by the Bradford Electric Company for the issuance of a $450,000 note on Aug. 2 for the purpose of refunding a promissory note.

Thomas H. McInnerney, president of the National Dairy Products Corportion, announced yesterday that the company had paid about $1,322,900,000 for milk, other dairy products, fruit and other materials and $481,800,000 in wages and salaries, over the last eight years, representing 54.7 per cent and 20 per cent respectively of total sales.

Two more police killers were convicted in General Sessions at 5:15 o'clock yesterday morning of firstdegree murder in the hold-up shooting of Patrolman John H. A. Wilson of the Oak Street station in the Rudisch Metal Refining Company's plant at 65 Fulton Street last Sept. 23.

The marriage of Miss Alix de Saint Phalle, daughter of Mrs. Duryee de Saint Phalle of 157 East Seventy-second Street, and of Fal de Saint Phalle, also of this city, to William Cornelius Hall of New York and Newburgh, N. Y., took place yesterday' afternoon in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.
Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow, who has kept silence until now in the face of charges brought by his wife, the former Barbara Hutton, may return to England tomorrow to face these charges in court.

Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc., have arranged for the Albermarle Building Co., Inc., Samuel Rothchild, secretary, a first mortgage building and permanent loan of S116.000 at 4% per cent on the property at the northeast corner of Albemarle and Rugby Roads, Brooklyn, where a six-story apartment house is under construction for occupancy about Aug. 1.

President Roosevelt announced today that it was "with some reluctance" that he had signed the $386,500,000 Omnibus Flood Control Bill because of deficiencies in planning, which he hoped would be temporarily remedied by "complete consultation" between the groups and Federal agencies affected and ultimately corrected by permanent legislation.

After a night in jail, twenty-five seamen who conducted a week's sitdown strike aboard the freighter Sagebrush were released on bail today pending a grand jury hearing on charges of "conspiracy to mutiny."

The Michigan Public Utilities Commission announced today that it had granted preliminary approval of the Detroit Edison Company's petition to borrow $15,000,000 from banking institutions on promissory notes to finance construction and improvement projects.

John Van Buren Merritt, who will retire today as chief clerk of the United States Attorney's office, a position he has held since 1915, was the guest of honor yesterday at a dinner in Schwartz Restaurant, 183 Broadway, which was attended by Judge John C. Knox and John F. Dailey Jr., Acting United States Attorney.

War Admiral, the mighty atom and recognized king of the American turf, was forced to dip his colors today. The gifted son of Man o' War, who had won eleven consecutive races, was soundly beaten by Hal Price Headley's fleet Menow, who made a show of the Admiral and four others in the $59,300 Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being June 29 unless specified: Havana to Annapolis: Arkansas, Roper, Tillman. Acushnet, Dahlgren to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Harry, at Navy Yard, Puget Sound. Edsall, at Amoy. Hopkins, Clarence Straits to Prince Rupert.
The State of California will receive bids tomorrow on $3,000,000 of registered warrants. On Tuesday proposals will be received for the sale of $3,449,340 of general 1( fund warrants.

With the likelihood of a bedside visit by President Roosevelt this afternoon, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden remained most of yesterday in his eleventh-floor quarters at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

An attempt to amend its constitution, whereby all members would participate in the election of officers, was defeated at the sixty-second annual convention of the American Flint Glass Workers Union in session here today.
Richard F. McMullen, Cumberland lawyer and one of the owners of The Cumberland Evening and Sunday Times, died here suddenly today at the age of 41.

Miss Gladys L. Hendrie of 80 Cranberry Street, Brooklyn, was martried to Benjamin T. Cooke of 185 Montague Street, Brooklyn, a lawyer, in the Kent House, a Greenwich hotel, yesterday, by the Rev. Frederick W. Grunst,

Edwin Markham, author of the famous poem, "The Man With the Hoe," was guest of honor yesterday at the Board of Education's exhibit for the National Education Association in the Port Authority Building.

TROPIC HOLIDAY, based on a story by Don Hartman and Frank Butler; screen play by Messrs. Hartman and Butler. John C. Moffitt and Duke Atteberry; music by Augustin Lara; directed by Theodore Reed; produced for Paramount by Arthur Hornblow. At the Paramount.

Chairman Sheppard of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures, said today that the committee had no authority to investigate the action of President Roosevelt in urging in his radio speech last Friday that Democrats support New Deal candidates.

Holders of the bonds and coupons of National Economio Bank, Warsaw, Poland, 7 per cent loan of 1928, due in 1966, received yesterday an offer of settlement from Janusz Zoltowski, representative of the bank, under which they would receive principal and interest payments in United States currency.

Bonds resumed their advance yesterday in more energetic fashion than at any session since the upturn on the stock market, and in the heaviest trading for the year all groups of bonds surged forward. Sales amounted to $11,552,200, compared with $8,013,150 on Tuesday.

J. P. Morgan sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania on his usual Summer vacation which he spends at his estate Wallhall in Hertfordshire, near London, and at his shooting lodge near Glamis Castle, Scotland.

A protest against the current method of teaching English was made yesterday at the session of the National Council of. Teachers of English at the Museum of Natural History by Garibaldi M. Lapolla, principal of Public School 174 in Brooklyn.

Charles C. Hansen, a member of the engineering staff of the Ingersoll Rand Company for nearly forty years, an inventor, specializing in rock drills, died suddenly this morning at his home here from a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

Under weather conditions that were the best in several years, soaring plane enthusiasts in their annual contest here today took advantage of the opportunity to make many long hops, and at least one altitude record was threatened.
Governor William Langer cut sharply into the lead of Senator Gerald P. Nye, his rival for the Republican Senatorial nomination, in late tabulations today from yesterday's primary election.

Washington Mews, the quaint private street running east from Fifth Avenue, just north of Washington Square, became the scene of a compact "Village Fair" yesterday afternoon, with all the color and gayety that a large committee could give to it.
The Rev. Ezriel Epstein, dean of Chicago's Orthodox rabbis, died tonight in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old and came here from Russia in 1901.

A 20-year-old Rochester golfer, Jerry Dimmick of the Midvale Country Club, carded a 75, three over par, to win the medal in the 18-hole qualifying round of the New York State junior golf championship today.
Walt Cagle, Sand Mountain's weather prophet, died today at his farm home near here. Cagle's appearances in Boaz were holiday occasions.

Carmen Saporito, 11 years old, of 9 Kingsland Avenue, was injured fatally and his playmate, Albano Marieio, 8, of 756 Harrison Avenue was hurt critically when the bicycle on which they were riding crashed into a truck on Kingsland Avenue here tonight.

More than 93,700 young men and women receiving student aid from the National Youth Administration graduated this month from high schools and colleges. About 75,500 were high school and 18,200 were college students, according to the report,

Santiago Gutierrez, 20 years old, a Puerto Rican, who was one of the numerous chiselerss" who tried to defraud Murray Levine, the lawyer, of the $30,000 reward he had offered after the disappearance of his 12-year-old son Peter last Feb. 24,

Negotiations with minorities ily obey when were resumed here today when Premier Milan Hodza received the leader of the Polish minority, M. Wolff, and leaders of the Hungarian opposition, Dr. Geza Szuelloe, Anndor Joross, Janos Esterhazy and Orndrej Korlath, and heard their demands in regard to the nationalities statute.

A 1 per cent wage tax was lifted from 1,250,000 Massachusetts workers when Governor Hurley signed into law a measure suspending for one year employee contributions to the State's unemployment compensation fund. It will become effective Friday.

Bond St, 10, 3-story loft and store building, 26.2x100; Franklin Savings Bank against Bessie Lehman; due, $17,188; taxes, etc., $292; to plaintiff for $14,500. By WALTER M. JACOBSON 12th St, 722-728 E, four 3 and one 4-story tenements, 84x75; Bank of Europe Trust Co. against August Keller; due, $17,433; taxes, etc., $102; to plaintiff for $1,000.
Foreign trade experts of the Department of Agriculture said today unsettled political conditions in Europe might open new and larger markets for surplus United States wheat in the next twelve months.

France totoday followed the lead of several other European nations and ordered death on the guillotine for peacetime spying. The reason for the new decree, officials said, was "the progressive increase"
As a result of a sale in Brooklyn reported yesterday, three five-story tenement buildings there will be converted by the buyer into a modern apartment house.
Frankie Genovese, 147 1/2, Toronto, outpointed Augie Arellano, 148, Harlem, in the feature eight-round bout at the Queensboro Arena last night before a crowd of 2,000 persons.

The Federal Trade Commission anbounced today that it has issued trade practice rules on the matter of shrinkage of woven cotton yarn goods, setting forth various standards and making it an unfair trade practice to violate them.

Earl Browder, on the witness stand here yesterday, under oath as general secretary and spokesman of the Communist party of the United States, was asked: "Is that part of the Communist party which exists in the United States a part and parcel of the Communist International in Moscow, a worldwide organization looking to the teaching of Marx, Engels, Lenin and Stalin?"

Developments in the steel price situation continued active yesterday, with Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, asserting that the industry is much worse off financially-as a result of the abandonment of freight differentials by United States Steel,

In the self-alluding role of "amateur" archaeologist Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, bed-ridden-in New York, appealed here today to novitiates in science through his son, Prince Bertil, to be prepared "to follow the one great rule, nay,
The New York Civic Orchestra will be heard in a "pops" concert tonight at the Federal Music Theatre under the direction of F. Charles Adler. Alice Howland, soprano, will be soloist.

The exodus of city children going to Summer camps will reach its peak today, as more than 10,000 leave the city by train and bus. The New York Central, the Pennsylvania and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads all have special camp trains, special sections on regular trains and extra

The race for the chief prize in the annual Retail Dry Goods Association golf tournament-the Simon F. Rothschild Cup-ended in a tie when both Harold Garton of B. Altman Co. and Herbert S. Waters of the Kresge Department Store, Newark, N. J., posted net scores of 70 at the Westchester Country Club today.

Application to enlarge the field in which the securities of three trust funds may be invested was made in Chancery Court today by Blair Academy of Blairstown. The Presbytery of Newton, charged with management of the school, and the First Presbyterian Church of Blairstown, joined the academy in the request.

Mrs. Oliver B. Bridgman of 1,220 Park Avenue, widow of Brig. Gen. Bridgman, who was known for his years of service in the National Guard and his long connection with the New York Stock Exchange, died on Tuesday in New York Hospital.

Several leases of space in the Fifth and Madison Avenue districts by retail shops, and a contract for quarters there by a restaurant group, were reported yesterday. Alber-Cody, Inc., Miss Minerva Albert, president, long identified with the restaurant business in Chicago and the Middle West, rented a store and basement at 5
The Italian liner Rex is due to arrive today from Mediterranean ports. Among her passengers are Countess Rosalind Wood Guardabassi, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Loeb, Dr. and Mrs. Felice Frasca,
Luncheon reception to diplomatic representatives of foreign nations on occasion of President's visit to World's Fair grounds, Hotel Plaza, noon. Address by Commissioner Edward J. Flynn.

Proposed freight rate increases on fruits and vegetables shipped from Pacific Coast and intermountain points to destinations in the United States and Canada were suspended by the Interstate Commerce Commission today pending investigation.

Responses filed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to exhibits and testimony submitted in the recent investigation of the telephone industry by the Federal Communications Commission are to receive "appropriate study and consideration" in the preparation of a final report on the inquiry, the commission announced today.

The rally in the stock market which began ten days ago surged forward yesterday with increased breadth and vigor to reach new high average prices for the last eight months. Prices of representative issues on the New York Stock Exchange ran up 2 to 7 points, while a few issues showed even larger gains.

Benny Lynch of Scotland scored a technical knockout over Jackie Jurich, California flyweight, in the twelfth round tonight, a few hours after the British Board of Boxing Control had stripped him of his world flyweight title for being overweight.

Cornucopia Gold Mines, Seattle, of which Richard E. Fuller is president, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 300,000 shares of five-cents-parvalue common stock.

Rushing five runs across the plate in the upper half of the twelfth inning, after tying the score in the ninth, the Flushing High School baseball team captured the city senior high P. S. A. L. championship by downing Curtis High of Staten Island, 12-7, at Flushing Memorial Field yesterday.

A request that the Interstate Commerce Commission refrain from determining minimum trucking rates in the New England area until it has made a "real cost study" was made in a brief filed today by a group of ten Northern New Jersey manufacturing and trade groups.

Governor Cross of Connecticut and Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, superintendent of the New York State Department of Public Works, representing Governor Lehman, officially opened today the Merritt Parkway, first high-speed traffic artery through the southern part of this State, which is the gateway to New England.

The committee named by the League of Nations to study the problem of economic depressions held its first meeting today. When the League Assembly in September recommended its establishment, it was thought the committee would make a long-term study of the general problem, but now it faces the question whether to do this or to concentrate on the existing depression.

Tremont Ave (15-309), s s, 190 ft w of Van Nest Ave, 125x106; Camboard Realty Corp. to Dollar Savings Bank; extends mtg to June 27, 1943, at 4 1/2 per cent; $11,000. 139th, 640 E (10-2551); Jaypol Realties, Inc., to 673 E 140th St., Inc., 715 11th Ave; installments, 5 per cent; $23,500.

Convicted of second-degree murder for the slaying of Sophie Kujat, 23 years old, Edward Holle, 24, an automobile mechanic, was sentenced here today by Commor Pleas Judge Richard Hartshorne to serve twenty to thirty years in the State penitentiary at Trenton.

Frederick William Vanderbilt, railroad director, yachting enthusiast and grandson of the founder of the family fortune, Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt,- died in his country home here today- after a week's illness. He was 82 years old.

With five of Its six singles players still left in the third round at the end of the first day's play in the sixth annual Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament at the Manursing Island Club today, Choate School of Wallingford, Conn., established itself as the favorite to retain the team trophy.

Among the 107 new decrees issued by the Daladier government in pursuit of the objective of trying to raise production and stimulate national economy is one establishing a credit of 100,000,000 francs to the Ministry of Colonies for the prospecting and development of gold mines in the French colonies, notably French Guiana in South America,

The split between Mexican Army officers and the labor leaders is reported to be growing by the Mexican press. Today a group of army colonels issued a public statement accusing Vicente Lombardo Toledano, leader of the C. T. M., the dominant union, who is now in the United States, of "attempting to dissolve the revolutionary army and deceive the workers into creating another Spain here."

Of a total expenditure of $467,334,000 by national advertisers during 1937, newspapers received $191,000,000, or 40.9 per cent, the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, reported yesterday. Magazines received $165,706,000, or 35.5 per cent; chain radio, $68,828,000, or 14.7 per cent; outdoor, $39,300,000, or 8.4 per cent, and car cards, $2,500,000, or 0.5 per cent.
The eight two-family houses on the east side of Twenty-fourth Street, near Avenue V, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to the Marvin Realty Corporation.
Miss Nancy Lydia Ansell, daughter of General and Mrs. Samuel Tilden Ansell, was married today to Second Lieut. Harold Nelson Moorman, son of Colonel and Mrs. Frank Moorman.
Paul Dudley Dean of Brookline and Cataumet, a member of the Boston law firm of Alger, Dean Sullivan for many years, died early today at the Phillips House after an operation.

Tammany members of the last Board of Estimate were blamed yesterday by Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, for a tie-up in the commission's work caused by the discharge of fifty examination raters.

Indiana Republicans today put their hope for November Senatorial success in Raymond E. Willis, 62-year-old country editor, in choosing him over former Senator James E. Watson and four other candidates.
The hard fought battle in the Constitutional Convention over search and seizure was marked today by the first political skirmish of importance since the convention began its labors on Capitol Hill.

Widows and dependents of the 260 men who died forty years ago in the sinking of the Maine are going to get increased pensions, $30 a month instead of $12. President Roosevelt has signed a bill Congress passed after learning that the usual $30 pension was not permitted widows of Spanish War veterans

A woman carrying a child in her arms made a desperate but vain attempt to save it from death today by throwing it from her just before she was struck and killed by the Lehigh Valley's Black Diamond Express.

Republicans fired a round of charges at the- Roosevelt Administration tonight, declaring it had driven the Ringling- Brothers-Barnum Bailey Circus to the wall and that it was playing a "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" role with relief funds.

The sun's warm rays, to which they have been unaccustomed of late, had a distinctly soothing effect on the Yankees yesterday. Their pitching was superb and their hitting was little short of berserk. In four and one-half hours of eye-filling baseball,

The Government of the United States ends another fiscal year today with another deficit in the Treasury-the eighth successive deficit since 1930. Many readers will pay scant attention to this news when they see it in the headlines.

Mel Harder seemed to have a shutout to his credit going into the eighth inning today, but when it was over Bill Rogell and Hank Greenberg had home runs and the Tigers went on to a 4-to-3 victory over the Indians.

Floodwaters which did an estimated $100,000 damage, chiefly in the Furnersville district of this city, receded fast today as workmen pumped water from the cellars of many flooded homes. Engineers said there was no .further dangerfrom rising waters and that the Delaware River was only several feet above normal.

Louis Levine was elected Grand Master of the Independent Order Brith Sholom, national Jewish fraternal organization, at the closing today of its thirty-third annual convention at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here.

Six thousand workers on WPA arts projects in this city will have their monthly pay cut from $103.40 to $98.70 beginning July 10, Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the WPA music, art, theatre, writers' and historical records survey projects, announced yesterday.

Canadian corporation financing for the six months ended today will amount to $31,729,500, according to figures compiled by Wood-Gundy Co. Of this figure, $15,094,500 will be for refunding and $16,635,000 new money.

Hill School of Pottstown, Pa., today won the championship of the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association, and thereby lay a strange tale. There is no water at Pottstown to sail on. It was about as if a crew came from Oklahoma to defend the America's Cup.

With the signing today by President Roosevelt of a bill providing for the establishment of the Olympic National Park in the State of Washington, reservation and conservation for "the benefit and enjoyment of the people" is assured of the last, outside of Alaska, and one of the most beautiful of America's frontiers.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition BEE-PARK LUNCH CO., INC., 1 Beekman St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $21,727, exclusive of capital stock, and assets of $27,693.

Notices As the Municipal Term Courts in the Buroughs of Manhattan, Bronx and Brooklyn will be closed during the month of August. all summonses served by members of this department in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be returnable in the respective District Courts in those boroughs and in the Bronx Part 1 of the Criminal Magistrates' Court. B. M. T. system passes for the quarter ending September. 1938, are now ready for distribution.

The Federal Screw Works of Detroit has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering, under a plan of reorganization, certificates of deposit for $102,000 of 6% per cent ten-year convertible gold notes due in 1939 and escrow certificates of interest representing $1,635,000 principal amount of 6% per cent ten-year gold notes deposited under an escrow trust agreement.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday directed Superintendent of Insurance Louis H. Pink, as liquidator of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, to return to eight institutions between $25,000 and $50,000 in excessive supervisory management fees which the company had collected prior to its entry into liquidation.

Philippine Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon who landed in Kobe yesterday for a ten-day visit in Japan insists that his trip is purely recreational. He will also inquire into the condition of Major General Jose de los Reyes, commander of the Philipine Constabulary, who is at present convalescing in a Tokyo hospital.

Capital expenditures of about $175,000,00O are contemplated for 1938, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey said today in an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering a combined issue of debentures and serial notes aggregating $85,000,000.

Official spokesmen denied today that former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg had been married recently to Countess Vera Fugger von Babenhausen, as previously reported, and gave out interesting information as to the ex-Chancellor's present position.

Henry Fonda was borrowed today by RKO for the leading role opposite Barbara Stanwyck in "The Mad Miss Manton," by Wilson Collison. Fonda was made available yesterday when Walter Wanger canceled plans to film Vincent Sheean's "Personal History."

Sunshine and Colonel Bill Terry's Giants arrived simultaneously in these parts today. But the Phillies still were under a cloud when the day's business ended, the league leaders having flattened them in both ends of the double-header by 9-1 and 6-2.

Paced by the winning co-medalists, Willie Turnesa of Holy Cross and Lew Oehmig of Chattanooga, the national intercollegiate golf championship progressed today to the quarter-final stage after a series of twenty-four spectacular matches.

A difference of opinion has developed among our conservationists as to what the new State Constitution shall say about the State's forest preserve. Several proposed amendments lay emphasis on "scientific forestry." One, at least, would permit "the establishment of demonstration forests."

New citizens should be encouraged. to participate in civic affairs rather than be "shielded from the nation's unsolved problems," George L. Maxwell, assistant director, education division, WPA, told the delegates at a joint luncheon. of the Department of Adult Education and the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship in the Hotel Commodore yesterday..

Nearly 1,600 veterans of the Civil War, Union and Confederate both, slept here tonight under roomy brown tents, each with a companion from his home town. All day they arrived by train, bus and motor for the seventy-fifth anniversary celebration of the Battle of Gettysburg.

Last Easter, when the British and Italian Governments signed an agreement covering their entangled interests in the entire Mediterranean area, the ratification of the pact was held up pending the return of the Spanish war to the Spaniards, because it was thought in London and Rome that the conflict was near an end.
