Miss Isabel Stettinius Marsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Marsh of New York and this community, was introduced to society tonight at a large supper dance given by her maternal grandmother, Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius, at The Shelter, her home here.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 2d Lt. Matthew M. Labuz, Inf.-Res., who was ordered to active duty at Camp Dix, N. J., is, by reason of physical defect, relieved from further active duty, June 27. Each of the following Reserve officers is ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective June 30, at the station indicated. Headquarters Trenton District CCC, Trenton, N. J.:
AWAY TO THE CANADIAN ROCKIES AND BRITISH COLUMBIA, by Gordon Brinley. (Dodd, Mead, $2.50.) A travel book. HOMING, by Grace Livingston Hill. (Lippincott, $2.) A romantic novel.

In an unusual political move, the New York County Republican Committee last night refused renomination to Assemblyman Oscar Garcia-Rivera of the Seventeenth Assembly District and voted its support to John A. Ross, a young Negro attorney.

A few years ago the Rust brothers electrified the country by announcing that they were on the verge of producing a successful cotton-picking machine. They dreaded the consequences of their ultimate success. Nowhere are so many women and children employed in America as in the cotton fields.

Augusto Hill, spirit doctor, must pay the proceeds of twelve "spirit extractions" or $6 weekly to the support of his wife, Josefina Guillen Hill, by order of District Judge Marcelino Romani, who today granted the wife a separation decree.

An appeal for broadening of the market for quality fashion consumption was made by Maurice Rentner, chairman of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., at a membership meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.

Extension of its operations to include selling departments in the basement of the store was announced yesterday by James McCreery Co. The basement will be remodeled and is expected to be ready at the end of August.
Norfolk St, 61, 25x50: Zuckerman Realty Co, Inc, to Max Zuckerman, 61 Norfolk St ($3). 34th St, 324-28 E, 85x98.9: Steinfeld Building Co to Sterndor Apartments, Inc. both of 20 W 37th St ($1).

Fred L. Ehrman, a member of the home club, competing in the Westchester pro-amateur one-day golf tournament at the Century Club, scored a double triumph today. Teamed with the professional Ben Hogan, he finished on top in the feature event, then, with V. Theodore Low, a club-mate, returned the best score in the all-amateur competition.

Senator Pepper was recently renominated from Florida as a whole-hearted supporter of the Administration. Wholehearted support of anything any member of the Administration may do can go no farther than Senator Pepper's endorsement of the advice to WPA workers attributed to Mr. Aubrey Williams

Passage of Bill 256, introduced by Councilman Robert K. Straus, and now before the City Council, would eliminate the need for seventy elevator inspectors, at an annual saving of $200,000, according to Richard H. McCann, acting chairman of the Committee on Housing of the Charity Organization Society of New York.

With a twin-bill victory over Jersey City by 2-1 and 6-4, the Syracuse Chiefs vaulted into third place in the International League tonight, ahead of Rochester. Ted Kleinhans outlasted Glen Gabler in an eleven-inning opener, which was meant to be a sevenframe affair,

James Herbert Scrutton, former chairman of Lloyd's Register of Shipping and vice chairman of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom during the World War,- died today in his Cirencester home. He was 79 years old.

John K. Starkweather of Starkweather Co., was elected yesterday president of the Bond Club of New York at the annual meeting of the organization at the Bankers Club. Mr. Starkweather succeeds Nevil Ford, vice president of the First Boston Corporation.

Dr. Philip Siedler of the I. G. Farben Laboratory at Griesheim, in an interview on a paper, "The Production and Use of Rare Gases," that he read recently before the annual meetingof the German Chemical Society, said on the subject of the production of helium from the atmosphere:

AIl livestock values advanced today and activity featured the trade in all branches, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. The cattle trade was exceptionally active and the market, under a broad demand from all interests, was probably the fastest of the year.

The trend toward long-term bank loans for industrial and commercial enterprises which has developed in recent years is discussed by Edward E. Brown, president of the First National Bank of Chicago, in the July issue of Banking, official publocation of the American Bankers Association.

Articulate and untrammeled, a class of -junior and senior boys and girls from the Bronxville Public HighSchool easily eclipsed a group of professional radio artists yesterday as the center of interest at a demonstration of radio teaching in the Columbia Broadcasting. System's theatre at 241 West Fortyfifth Street.

The chances are that any one reading these lines after 5:30 A. M. and having an unobstructed view of the natural eastern horizon will observe that the sun is shining. A little fog, maybe, a whiff of morning mist, but rain--decidedly not.

President Roosevelt will visit the World's Fair .today, delivering two addresses to selected audiences and making a tour of the site and buildings under construction. He will first officiate at the laying of the cornerstone for the $3,00C,000 building group the Federal Government is constructing.

Gertrude Lawrence, British actress, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Pamela Barbara May Gordon-Howley, to Lieutenant Perley Edmund Holmes of the Royal Engineers, son of R. S. Holmes of Fort Francis, Ont.

Mrs. Laura M. Loveland has sold to a client of G. Vitagliano, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., the sixstory private residence at 36 East Sixty-ninth Street, on a plot 25 by 100.5 feet. The parcel is assessed for $110,000, of which $58,000 is on the land.

His three-stroke lead on the field after the first eighteen holes of the thirty-six-hole qualifying round in the Eastern interscholastic golf championship apparently put too much of a strain on the shoulders of red-headed S. A. (Arnold) Zimmerman of Blair School. In any event he didn't capture the medal, nor did his team-mate, William Lewis, as the second eighteen was played today.
Dr. Henry V. Broeser, for many years an X-ray specialist, died at his home here this morning from a complication of ailments. He was 69 years old.

Mrs. Hedi Heusser, red-haired Swiss divorcee, today ended her nine-day "stay-in" strike in the home of Rollo K. Blanchard, abandoning her plan to remain entrenched there until the 50-year-old business man came to marry her.
Mrs. Nelson Todd, who witnessed t Lincoln's assassination, died here last night after a three months' illness, at the home of her grandson, Nelson Todd. She would have been 98 years old on Aug. 17.

Cypress Ave (10-2551), s w cor of 139th St, 100x100; 673 E 140 St. Inc, to Jaypool Realties, Inc, 274 Madison Ave; mtg $131,320. 171st St (11-2903), n w cor of Washington Ave, 150x50; Meiselman Corp to Samuel Meiselman, 1,507 Washington Ave. Powers Ave (10-2571), w s. 212 ft s of St. Mary's st, 2x99; Namdrief Realty Co, Inc, to Emma Bohlig, 609 W 147th St.
On the eve of the annual vacation period, the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company of Fort Madison, Iowa, paid all employes a 7 1/2 per cent bonus, based on each employee's earnings
The Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Dorothy Parsons Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt A. Moore

On the eve of the sale of her home by auction in foreclosure proceedings by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, Mrs. Sadie Leslie Monssen, widow of a naval hero, obtained yesterday through her attorney a show-cause order to stop the foreclosure.

Many of those who have studied New York's housing problem, and particularly the problem of housing those unable to pay "economic" rents, are convinced that the present and prospective construction program is entirely inadequate and hardly will suffice to make any dent in the slum areas.

John Steinbeck's next book will be a collection of short stories. It will be published on Aug. 27 by Covici, Friede under the title "The Long Valley.' Three of the sixteen stories in the book, "Flight," "The Leader of the People" and "How Edith McGillicuddy Met Robert Louis Stevenson" have not previously been printed.

The Panama Pacific Line, which will resume service to the Pacific Coast in August with five vessels formerly in the Atlantic service, announced yesterday that contracts for equipping the ships with airconditioning had been let to the Carrier Corporation and that work had already started at the pier in Baltimore.

Favorites, which included William Woodward's Isolater, triumphed in four of the six races at Aqueduct yesterday as the curtain was lowered on the Queens Jockey Club's 21-day meeting. Isolater scored easily in the featured Diavolo Handicap before more than 8,000 fans.

Max Silverman, so-called "labor adjuster" and one-time autocrat of the Flour Truckmen's Association, which has been under investigation by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey since July, 1935, with two other new defendants was named yesterday in a Superseding firstdegree indictment in the shooting of William Snyder,
The big bats of Rip Radcllff, Steve Rensa and Marvin Owen clubbed the Browns into submission again today as the White Sox took the third straight of their four-game series, 9 to 5.

Trading was generally fair on most classes. Steer beef sold strong to higher and the lamb market was generally higher. Some sales of veal also showed advances of 50c-$1. Fresh pork cuts were mostly steady to slightly lower and other classes about steady. The kosher markets opened strong to higher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

The New York Joint Liquor Conference, set up by liquor wholesalers and package-store owners to end price wars which have cost them several hundred thousand dollars annually since repeal, will launch its first concerted effort to enforce Feld-Crawford fair-trade contracts tomorrow, Gerald F. Dunne, chairman of the conference, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, defended the board yesterday against what she called "misconception of its work," and added: "You don't always get the right impression from the press."
New York shipping interests with a colorful pageant observed Maritime Day for the Greater New York Fund yesterday and at the end of the celebration presented to the fund $28,000. At noon-time,

The retirement of Henry Herrman as a partner of Speyer Co., effective today, was announced yesterday. Otto de Neufville, who heretofore has held single power of attorney for the firm, will be admitted to partnership as of July 15, it was said.

The Society of Tammany or Columbian Order will celebrate tonight the 152d anniversary of its founding and the 162d anniversry of American independence. The ceremonies will be held in Tammany Hall. The society, founded 1786, since that time has celebrated annually the birth of American independence.
Mrs. John Watson Morrell of Chevy Chase, Md., has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Rosemary Sutherland Baker, to William Chamberlain Mott Of this city.

The State Constitution should contain a provision reserving ownership and development of water power sites in order to guard against alienation, the Public Utilities Committee of the Constitutional Convention was told today by A. A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 27: CAPTAINS Smith, H. W., Med. Corps, Washington, D. C., about July 1 to duty as Medical Officer in command of Naval Medical Center, Washington, D. C. Baldwin. F., on Aug. 1 to duty as General Inspector, Supply Corps, Atlantic Coast, Washington, D. C.

The city is confronted with an embarrassment of Federal riches in the form of PWA grants for projects it does not want, it became known yesterday. Last week the Public Works Administration in Washington authorized an immediate start toward construction in this city of twenty-eight schools, hospitals,...

While a desperate struggle involving control of the countryside dominating the Matang boom across the Yangtze River, 200 miles eastward of Hankow, continued apparently without decisive results, the Chinese command,
Several six-story apartment buildings in the vicinity of Columbia University and a well-known hotel in the Times Square section figured in the sales of Manhattan realty reported yesterday.

Perhaps the choicest news regarding the National-Education Association convention in this city, so far as the school children of the land are concerned, is that ten representative teachers participated yesterday afternoon in a pronunciation bee and flunked without exception, if graded according to conventional classroom standards.

Held up for two days by rain, the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships finally got under way at the Montclair A. C. today with a field of sixty-eight players representing thirty-three colleges.

Prince Bertil of Sweden substituted motorcycle police -for plumed cavalrymen as his escort. late this afternoon as he made a frantic effort to meet an appointment with newspaper reporters for his first officially scheduled interview since reaching the United States.

Bill Swift's superb relief flinging and Paul Waner's big bat united today to bring the Pirates from behind and beat the Reds, 5 to 4. As a result, the Pirates gained third, place, passing the Cubs. Big Poison drove in the tying and winning runs with doubles in the fifth and seventh innings,

HERE, one day ahead of the scheduled thriceannual date, are notes on those books published since March 1 that made a particular impression on this particular reviewer. The order of listing is haphazard. "Pity for Women," by Henry de Montherlant (Knopf). A brilliantly sardonic and Gallic novel concerning one extended skirmish in the war between the sexes. Reading of the most delicious sort, if one can stomach it at all.

Nearco, the Italian "wonder horse" that won the Paris Grand Prix' last Sunday and is unbeaten in fourteen starts, was purchased today by Martin Benson, London bookmaker, for a reported price of ??60,000--approximately $300,000.

Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, sailed yesterday for London on the French liner Normandie after spending a week in this country. He was accompanied by his sons, Joseph Jr. and Jack.

Estate. less than $3,000. To Robert Cole, 12 W. 72d St., and Ralph M. Cole, executor, 315 E. 68th St., sons, residue equally. COLE, STELLA (Dec. 11, 1937). Estate, less than $1,000. To Robert Cole, 12 W. 72d St., and Ralph Cole, executor, 315 E. 68th St., son, residue equally. ERENTAL, BERTHA (June 13). Estate, about $9,000. To Richard Franz Erental, son, executor, 885 Park -Ave.
Building an organization around the needs of the current market

Everything about this four-day regatta, which opened this morning, was in the best Henley tradition-except the weather. The gale which kept the tent gangs busy all night was still raging today and, although there was some sunshine, the sky was generally overcast.

From several different sides, retailers attending the 1938 mid-year convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association here were advised today that they could speed the forces of recovery by a liberalization of retail credit within sound limits. One credit leader, however, strongly advised caution in any such step.

The Hon. and Mrs. Oliver M. Wallop have come from Big Horn, Wyo., to the Madison. Mrs. Austin Strong, who passed the Winter and Spring in Santa Barbara, Calif, is at the Fairfax before going to Greenwich, where she will be for the Summer.

With a deluge of bullets, hand grenades, bombs and shells, the Spanish Insurgents attempted to crack the Valencia defense line today near its center, about thirty-eight miles north of the seaport city. They said Valencia's defenders were forced to retire.

After losing five straight games on the road, the Red Sox came home today to outslug the Senators, 6 to 4. While Johnny Marcum outpitched Dutch Leonard, who was yanked in the seventh for a pinch hitter, to register his sixth victory, Jimmy Foxx poled his twenty-second home run in the first inning and followed with two singles.

9 A. M. Hippodrome-Third business session, representative assembly. Reports. Hotel Astor-Session on "Equal Opportunity for All Children." Addresses:- Superintendent William B. Jack, Portland, Me.; Superintendent Garnet C. Wilkinson, Washington, D. C.; Superintendent Benjamin B. Greenberg, New York City; Judge Camille Kelley, Memphis, Tenn.

The Federal Government's "buy-andgive" program has been revised in a manner to keep purchases of manufactures in industrial fields, made primarily for relief assistance, sepaarte from the agricultural programe which, while charitable in character, is basically in step toward the Administration's ideal of a "planned economy."

Members of two C. I. O. unions enjoined by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo from picketing the retail stores operated by the Busch Jewelry Company, Inc., and two affiliated corporations defied the injunction yesterday and were cited for contempt in proceedings brought by attorneys for the corporations before Supreme Court Justice E. L. Hammer.

Duncan Sandys, one of the Members of Parliament with military experience, who has apparently learned more about the country's defenses than the War Office thinks he has a legal right to know, received a summons today to attend in the uniform of a Territorial officer before a military court of inquiry, which the War Office had hurriedly established to uncloak Mr. Sandys's informant.

Total sales of stocks on the national securities exchanges in May aggregated 26,634,898 shares, or 25.5 per cent under April, and said to represent the lowest volume of trading for May in any year since 1916, according to an analysis today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The turnover was also the smallest for any month since the commission began to receive such report in September. 1934.

Representative Robert L. Bacon of the First Congressional District and Assemblymen John D. Bennett and Leonard W. Hall of the First and Second Assembly Districts, respectively, were designated for renomination tonight by the Nassau County Republican Committee, meeting at the Nassau County police auditorium here with 750 members attending.

J. Clarence Davies, a real, estate operator, who died on April 13, 1934, left a net estate of $873,027, according to a transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday. - The widow and two sons, Valentine and J. Clarence Davies Jr., are the principal beneficiaries.

The Quebec Court of Appeals rejected today an appeal of the State of New York against a lower court judgment dismissing the State's claim to $312,000 deposited at a local bank by the late John M. Phillips, Queens Borough sewer contractor.

At the conclusion of a day of sensational shot-making which saw Willie Turnesa, young Holy Cross favorite, fail again in his bid for the crown, the national intercollegiate golf tournament today entered the semi-final stage.

William W. Winship, who takes office as chairman of the New York section of the American Chemical Society today, was elected last month at the annual meeting. He is a chemist and has written many articles dealing with chemical and engineering problems for technical journals.

Miss Clarissa Halstead Stem, granddaughter of the late Murat Halstead, writer, editor and publisher, and E. Fontaine Broun Jr., who is descended from several wellknown Virginia families, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.
The Treasury hired Peter J. Malley of New York today to haul $1,290,000,000 worth of silver from New York to a new storehouse at West PointHe will be raid $157,000.
The employes of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, incorporated in Delaware, have established a' credit balance of $16,000,000 in their thrift fund since its establishment thirty months ago.

The eloquence of which President Roosevelt is capable has never been used to better advantage than in the ringing appeal he made yesterday to the American people to cherish the ways of democratic government.
The Anglo-German payments agreement, which has been in force since November, 1934, became terminable today without notice.
Eleven flights were made today by pilots, who are experiencing probably the best soaring weather in the history of local meets.

Business in the Pittsburgh district moved upward again last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Although the adjusted index advanced less than one point, improvement was reflected in nearly all lines of economic activity.
Captain Thomas M. Molloy, commander of the New York Division of the United States Coast Guard and Captain of the Port, retired from service yesterday. He had been forty-one years in the department.

More than 1,000 members of the Classroom Teachers Department, the largest branch of the National Education Association, concluded their part in the association convention at a dinner last night in the Hotel Commodore.

Although the Spanish Antifascist Committee of New York again picketed Jos6 Iturbi at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra which he conducted last night at Lewisohn Stadium, they did so in a quiet and orderly manner.

Killers about faced this week on all classes of livestock and prices closed today at the high point of the period, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. Fed steers and yearlings were high for the current season and even though prices today were relatively high, all interests bought freely.

While officials of several independent steel companies whose business has been hit hard by the abolishment of basing point differentials by leaders in the industry began yesterday to explore ways and means of making protests to the United States Government against the change, Detroit was made a basing point for steel under conditions which provide savings of $5 a ton to automotive plants in or near that City.
With the bass fishing just beginning and the trout fishing almost over, this is a good time to look over the highlights of the fading season.

Old-fashioned prescriptions for building business were handed to retail store executives attending the 1938 midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Netherland Plaza here today.

Indictments accusing William Harris and Robert (Bluebeard) Morris, Mount Vernon Negroes, of selling Marijuana cigarettes were dismissed here today by County Judge Frank H. Coyne when chemists reported that the-"reefers" were fakes containing only tea leaves and tobacco, as the defendants had contended.
The All Service Laundry Corporation, which occupies the threestory at 65-69 Varick Avenue, Brooklyn,. under a lease and purchase option, has bought the plant from Benjamin and Meyer Wigdor.

Mrs. Virginia Schultz Bruce, daughter of Mrs. Martin Schultz of 825 Fifth Avenue, New York, and the late Mr. Schultz, was married to Curtis C. Shears this afternoon at Valhalla, the homed here of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Bonham. The bridegroom is an assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

After a 200-mile round trip to New York City and its sprouting World's Fair, President Roosevelt returned to his family home here tonight while his associates marveled in pleasant surprise at the evidence of his continued popularity which they had witnessed from the time he entered the city until he left it.

Sorrell-topped William Granbery of Nashville, who yesterday flaunted fate by winning the medal in the Eastern interscholastic golf championship, reached the quarter-finals today by beating Robert Powers of Hlil School, 3 and 1, at the Greenwich Country Club, where the' future kings of the amateur golf world assemble annually for the fray.

President Roosevelt made his first visit to the World's Fair grounds in Queens yesterday and delivered two addresses. In one, before a relatively small audience of guests invited to see him lay the cornerstone of the Federal Building, he declared that this nation's "good neighbor" policy implied reciprocation. In the other,
Resentment against foreign distillers, particularly producers of Scotch whiskies, for their alleged failure to give liquor retailers a wider mark-up on imported spirits,

The Andover Township Council, taking cognizance of.growing opposition in the township to the German-Amerlcan Bund's Camp Nordland, today unanimously passed an ordinance aimed at elimination of the camp's shooting gallery.

After hearing oral arguments by counsel for both sides in the "free speech" suit brought by the C. I. 0. and the American Civil Liberties Union against Mayor Frank Hague and fellow-officials of Jersey City, Federal Judge William Clark today urged the losing side, whichever it may be, to appeal to the United States Supreme Court to get its "wise guidance" on Issues of such great public importance.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, in his first decision since his designation by the Appellate Division to try all real estate tax reduction suits in Manhattan and the Bronx, declared yesterday that he regarded 6 per cent as too high a rate for the capitalization of

Carl Van Doren has handed to the Viking Press the final chapters of his 300,000-word biography of Benjamin Franklin, on which he has been at work for several years. A limited edition, containing several unpublished Franklin items,

Profit-taking appeared in substantial volume in bonds yesterday but was well absorbed and did lit tle more than slow down the advance in values on the New York Stock Exchange. Buoyancy persisted in some sections of the domestic corporate list, particularly among selected industrial loans,

Every small boy's idea of the best show in town was staged last night at Madison Square Garden by the New York City Fire and Police Departments for some 15,000 visiting delegates to the annual national convention of the National Education Association.
Construction of a ski trail on the Wright Peak trail in the McIntyre Range of the Adirondacks, on the ground that it would mean the cutting of considerabie timber,

The French liner Champlain arrives today from- Havre and Southampton with the following on board: Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Castilla, Francois Briere, Muriel Croall, Paul Coze, Raymond Gid, Joseph Schaeffer, Mrs. N. L. Goss, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph O'Connell and Mrs. H. M. Johnson.
The lists of apartment rentals submitted yesterday by brokers contained many new tenancies in buildings on the West Side. Houses from Greenwich Village to Washington Heights were involved.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen will meet here on July 18 with representatives of the carriers' joint conference committee to start negotiations over the proposal by railroad managements for a 15 per cent wage reduction.

Class I railroads of the United States had in the first five months of this year a net railway operating income of $45,288,504, which was at an annual rate of return of 0.54 per cent on property investment, compared with $240,111,987, or 2.85 per cent, in the corresponding period of 1937, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Most people would say that the NBC expert on spelling did not use very familiar words in the test that flunked out ten school

When the new Dail Eireann met this afternoon it elected Eamon de Valera Prime Minister by 75 votes to 45, after a debate that was lively at times. The public gallery was thronged, mostly by supporters of the government, and crowds gathered outside the Dail precincts to see the Deputies arrive.

Mrs. Louise Lee Anstey, a writer and widow of Herbert Anstey, who was secretary to the late Supreme Court Justice Henry Hilton, died on Wednesday at her home, 449 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, ant the age of 95. A native of London, Canada, she was married to Mr. Anstey in 1860 and was formerly active in women's dramatic and literary circles.
Mrs. Bette Casmir Dwyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Charles Casmir of the Barclay, was -married to Basil B. Petrov, also of New York, Wednesday afternoon in the Recorder's Office at Leonia, N. J.

Prince Bertil of Sweden drove into the farming district of Southern New Jersey today to worship in a historic little church, receive a WPA gift, h pay tribute to this State as "modern and progressive" and provide a field day for autograph fiunters and amateur camera men.
A twenty-story office building and a fifteen-story apartment house were among six Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms.

The marriage of Miss Clare Raleigh, daughter of Mrs. Edward Jerome Raleigh of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Raleigh, to J. Ross Meehan of 1 Prospect Park West took place yesterday morning in the Church of St. Saviour, Eighth Avenue and Sixth Street, Brooklyn.
Reduction of the maximum rate of income, inheritance and gift taxes to 25 per cent as a means of restoring prosperity was proposed here today by Representative Celler, Democrat, of New York.

One of the largest holiday travel throngs in recent years will begin to move to mountain and seashore resorts today for the long weekend, with the peak of the exodus expected tonight and tomorrow morning. Virtually all travel agencies reported yesterday that advance bookings indicated that the July 4 week-end traffic this year might surpass that of a year ago.

The Committee of Physicians, organized recently to fight certain policies of the American Medical Association which it regarded as contrary to the best public policy, has increased its membership from 430 to 840, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. John Peters of Yale University.

Miss Carlota Saint-Gaudens, daughter of Homer Saint-Gaudens and the late Mrs. Carlota Dolley Saint-Gaudens, was married here at noon today in the small studio of the Saint-Gaudens Memorial to John E. Dodge, son of Mrs. Frank Foster Dodge of Stonington, Conn., and the late Mr.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad has sold $1,000,000 of Wyoming Valley Water Supply Company bonds to insurance companies. Of the proceeds, $850,000 will be added to the cash fund and $150,000 used to pay for Diamond Water Company bonds to be called on Sept. 1.
There has been no sharp deviation from the capital movement trend as shown by the Treasury report made public yesterday, Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today.
The Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended on June 29 recorded large decreases in sterling and United States dollars and in Dominion Government deposits.

A funeral service for Frank R. Coates, industrialist and public utilities head who died at his home here on Sunday at the age of 69, was held today at St. John's Episcopal Church on Woodland Avenue. More than 300 persons attended the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Henry P. Cocke, pastor of All Saints Church, Chevy Chase, Md. The burial was in Tennet Cemetery.

More than $3,000,000,000 face amount of railroad bonds, including equipment-trust certificates, has been stricken from the list of legal investments for savings banks in this State, the action being effective today, according to the annual summary of additions to and removals from the legal list, issued yesterday by the State Banking Department.

Van Lingle Mungo, whose pitching effectiveness is as two-sided as a reversible coat, turned the good side out yesterday, after wearing the wrong one for five weeks, and shut out' Boston, 5 to 0, at Ebbets Field.
A dance drama entitled "Jungle Africa" will be presented at the Lewisohn Stadium Thursday evening as part of the program being given by Dance International in cooperation with Stadium Concerts, Inc.

Pumping and priming magnificently, the Yankees continued to show signs at the Stadium yesterday that their recovery program is doing quite all right. Once more they bowled over Connie Mack's Athletics by a score of 7 to 1.

One of the largest debutante parties of the week took place tonight at the Piping Rock Club here when Miss -M. Patricia Delehanty and Miss Louise Williams were introduced to society at a supper dance given by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Bradley Delehanty and Mr. and Mrs. Rodney W. Williams of Mill Neck.

Public offerings of new securities here in June were the largest for any month in the past year. The gain in flotations was due principally to a big increase in bond financing, the total being the largest for any month since January, 1937. Stock issues, on the other hand, were in the smallest volume in the last three months.
Mrs. Charles Sumner Witherspoon, a descendant of prominent early Americans and a retired lecturer and author, died yesterday at her home, 418 Central Park West. Her age was 79.

Six charitable institutions were named beneficiaries in the will of Mrs. Rose Abraham, widow of Abraham Abraham, founder of the dry-goods concern of Abraham Straus, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
The Chemical Bank and Trust Company reported yesterday total deposits of $552,072,203 and total assets of $638,398,231, compared, respectively, with $515,766,211 and $607,739,359 on March 31 last.

There were heart breaking scenes today at almost 10,000 Jewish-owned commercial and industrial enterprises when the employers announced to some 30,000 Jewish employes their immediate dismissal on orders from various Nazi organizations, thus controverting yesterday's official denials that any such order had been issued.

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, announced yesterday that he was ready to run for Governor as the candidate of a new Conservative party on a platform of a return to American ideals -and thrift in government. He added that Democrats were associated with him in the formation of the proposed new party.
The automobile procession in which Prince Bertil of Sweden was riding from Salem to New York this afternoon drew up suddenly at Central Airport near here.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France issued today, shows the following changes, in francs: changes, in francs:

Lothrop Withington of Boston, an attorney -for Paine, Webber Co., told the Securities and Exchange Commission at its hearing on investment trusts yesterday that he had suppressed, on his own responsibility, a document from the files of the brokerage house indicating that. S. Leo Solomont and Thomas W. Morris had handled $25,000 commissions on the.Continental Securities Corporation deal.
A five-story addition will be made to Public School 60 on Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, according to plans filed yesterday by Eric Kebbon, architect. The cost was put at $268,000.

Mrs. Laning Harvey Jr. of the Midkiff Farm of Kingston, Pa., today gained a second leg on the Marshall Hall Memorial Trophy, the leading event of the first day of the fifteenth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

Transfer of the Long Island Motor Parkway from private to public hands was completed today when William K. Vanderbilt Jr., president of the Long Island Motor Parkway, Inc., turned over the- deed for the remainder of the more than fifty miles of the roadway in Nassau County to J. Russel Sprague, county executive.

The Spanish Government invoked today for the first time the British plan to humanize the civil war by asking for a neutral investigation of yesterday's air raid on Blanes, in which six persons were killed and thirty-nine injured.
Arthur J. Crawford, founder of the Troy Laundry and a leading Methodist layman in this district, died today at his Hamden suburban home. He was 75 years old.

The Interstate Commerce Commission heard final arguments and took under advisement today the application of Eastern railroads for permission to increase passenger coach fares from 2 to 2.5 cents a mile.

The importance of motion pictures in education should inspire American educators to demand films on subjects frequently avoided by the industry, Edgar Dale of Ohio State University declared yesterday before a morning session of the National Education Association in the auditorium of the New York university School of Education.

A further decline of $32,000,000 in the total of their loans and investments was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, in their condition statement issued yesterday.
Pennsylvania's forty-four-hour week law, passed by the 1937 Legislature, was declared unconstitutional by the State Supreme Court here today.

Upholding the Puerto Rican law fixing 65 per cent of the sugar received from cane as the minimum factories must pay to the farmer, United States District Judge Robert A. Cooper today denied an injunction sought by the receiver for the Benitez Sugar Company, which alleged the law was confiscatory.
Stocks reacted on profit-taking and closed lower after strong and active opening; turnover, 2,581,350 shares. Corporation bonds higher, other groups irregular; transactions, $10,210,726.

The semi-annual report of the International Shoe Company covering the six months ended with May, made public yesterday, shows a net income of $634,989 after expenses, depreciation, provision for income taxes and other charges, which compares with $3,879,150 earned in the same period last year. W. H.

The two high school students, Thomas Bradley, 16 years old, and Thomas Dunne, 17, who were arrested May 23 for alleged disorders in an I. R. T. subway train, were held for trial in Special Sessions yesterday afternoon by Magistrate William Klapp, sitting at the West Side Court.

Brilliant all-round play gave the touring Australian cricket team victory over derbyshire today by an innings and 234 runs. It was one of six games concluded in English coupnty and first-class matches started yesterday.

Miss 875 Irene E. Gaertner, 24 years old, of 727 South Seventeenth Street, Newark, died in Elizabeth General Hospital this morning soon after she had been found unconscious on Chestnut Avenue, in the factory district of this community.

Complaints of owners in Hollis, Queens, that their FHA-insured homes, constructed a little more than a year ago, were developing defects due to faulty construction are receiving careful attention, Thomas G. Grace. State director of the FHA, declared yesterday.

Agitation over the influence of Federal relief in politics entered a new phase today when Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, announced the opening of a counter-attack against those who, he contended, were trying to discredit the program through unsupported- wholesale charges of political favoritism.

Because of the necessity for ever widening the geographic scope of military and naval activities in China, a sharp division of opinion has arisen within Japan's high army command, while the naval high command holds a third view.

The American Viscose Corporation has opened a new fabric development department, under the direction of Pierre Sillan, who has been associated with the Stehli Silk Company, the Amalgamated Silk Corporation and, more recently, with A. D. Juilliard.

The Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, Essex County State Senator, crusader for governmental reforms and Republican Gubernatorial candidate in the last election, announced in a letter made public today to W. Stanley Naughright, Republican county chairman, that he would not be a candidate for renomination in the coming primaries.

The "penetration" of communism into schools, the civil service, hospitals, relief and "almost everywhere in America" was proclaimed here yesterday on the witness stand by Earl Browder, general secretary and spokesman of the Communist party of the United States.

Introduced. as "America's No. 1 Democrat," Earl Browder, leader of the Communist party in the United States, received a big ovation from a capacity crowd of 3,500 when he arose to speak at a meeting of the State party in Kreuger's Auditorium here tonight.

The text of President Roosevelt's address before the National Education Association was as follows: Dr. Woodruff, members of the National Education Association: I am glad to come here today to this great meeting, and I am especially happy that, I think for the first time in my life, I was introduced by my wife.

A new exhibition to be current for the month of July opens next Tuesday at the Walker Galleries, 108 East Fifty-seventh Street. It consists of water-colors and drawings by a group of artists, including John Steuart Curry, George Grosz,
Five "100 anti-New Deal" percenters sought the nomination for Senator in Indiana. One used to be a big chief among the Ku Kluxers. One was Jim Watson. All were as progressive as barnacles.

Miss Mary Pearsall Field of the Plaza sailed on-the Normandie to pass the rest of the Summer in Europe. Lieutenant Cameron McRae Winslow, U. S. N., and Mrs. Winslow, who have been making their home in Hewlett, L. I., left yesterday to visit Lieutenant Winslow's mother, Mrs. Cameron McR. Winslow, in Newport.

The committee appointed to arbitrate the differences between the Jersey City Jewish Community Center and Temple Emanu-El reported last night that the congregation would be permitted to remain in the Center until a final agreement had been reached by the committee.

The Department of Agriculture announced today that refiners' deliveries of sugar for domestic consumption amounted to 2,248,772 short tons, raw value, in the first five months of 1938. This was about 500,000 tons less than in the same period a year before.

Construction contracts awarded during the first five months of 1938 in the New York metropolitan district involved a greater aggregate expenditure than for the same period last year, but the rise was due entirely to an increase in public building projects, which more than offset a decline in private work.
Preliminary estimates of the committee of replacement, composed of representatives of New York Stock Exchange member firms, on the number of unemployed financial workers were released yesterday.

Word was received here yesterday of the best six months' business, with one exception, since 1929, for Cadillac-La Salle, reported by general sales manager D. E. Ahrens. "Although customer delivery totals for the January-June period are not quite complete," he said, "it is ?? parent that sales will surpass every year in the last nine, excepting 1937.

During the week ended June 29 member bank reserve balances increased $119,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves rose from decreases of $65,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $80,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and increases of $5,000,000 in gold stock and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by increases of $26,000,000 in money in circulation and $6,000,000 in Treasury cash.

Mrs. Eleanor Thomas of 768 Teaneck Avenue, Lyndhurst, N. J., received an award of $18,500 from a jury before Common Pleas Judge Thomas H. Brown here today in her suit against John Zimmerman, a letter carrier, of 405 David Avenue, Kearny.

Husky and energetic, Joseph Buerokel, Reich Commissioner for Austria, at the Hotel Meissl und Shadn here today answered a crossfire of questions from some fifty foreign correspondents who had flown from the London and Berlin to seek information about the alleged rift in the Austrian National Socialist party.
The crowd didn't think so, but Referee Gene Roman declared Bob Pastor, New York heavyweight, the winner against Freddy Fiducia of Newark tonight in a ten-round boxing event at the Velodrome.

Lady Fraser of London, widow of Sir John Foster Fraser, author, traveler and lecturer, was married in the Marble Collegiate Church here yesterday to Walker Leach of South Dartmouth, Mass. The Rev. Willard E. Rice, associate minister of the church, performed the ceremony.

A demand that Columbia University retract an attack upon the American Legion issued during the National Education Association convention in New York this week was made by the Affiliated Teacher Organizations of Los Angeles today.

A German Lufthansa plane will fly tomorrow to a landing field ten miles from Curumas to pick up the pilot, mechanic, purser and two priests who were passengers in the Lufthansa plane that crashed Sunday at Chiligua.

The marriage of Miss Natalie Reeves Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Bennett of Plandome, to Charles L. Haussermann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haussermann, also of Plandome, took place this evening in Christ Episcopal Church here. The rector, the Rev. Charles H. Ricker, officiated.

The real objective of Institutional advertising by business should be to convince the public that a strong effort is being made to turn out a good product at a very low price, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., yesterday told a luncheon meeting of the San Francisco Advertising Club.

John L. Murray, president of the General Organization of Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, was elected yesterday president of the National Association of Student Officers, only student body connected with the National Education Assoclation.

It was a strange battle that began at Gettysburg seventy-five years ago today. Its site was determined by accident. Neither of the opposing commanders knew just where the main forces of the other were.

Frank Dunne, president of the New York Security Dealers Association, has been elected a member of the governing committee of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc. He will be one of the five governors to represent District No. 13, composed of Connecticut, New Jer- c sey and New York.

A bookkeeper drew a double red line in a ledger in the WPA .office here today and the Federal Emergency Relief Administration, one of the oldest and richest agencies of the New Deal, gave up the ghost.

Without disclosing details, well-informed circles state that Spruille Braden and Manuel Bianchi, the American and Chilean delegates to the Buenos Aires conference for the settlement of the Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay, are now acting together in a personal effort to bring about a cordial understanding between the delegates of these countries before the last proposal is submitted to the conference.
Superior Judge Emmet E. Wilson permanently enjoined the Los Angeles Newspaper Guild today from picketing the Hollywood stores of Sontac Chain Stores Company, Ltd., and of D. N. Schwab.

About twice the normal business in issuing marriage licenses and performing ceremonies was done at the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building yesterday, which was the last day for obtaining licenses without having to pass a blood test for syphilis. The City Clerk's offices in the other boroughs reported even larger percentages of increases, some as high as 400 per cent.

BRUCE MARSHALL--who wrote "Father IMalachy's Miracle"--is a novelist who likes to run with the romanticists and hunt with the satirists. His-new novel, "Luckypenny,"* is boundless enough in this strange variety to please practically everybody part of the time and practically no one all the time.

Demand for clothing was better last week than it has been in some time, and indications point to several months of brisk activity in piece-goods and clothing markets, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

George Conway, trainer of War Admiral, reported today the horse had "responded nicely" to treatment after "grabbing" his right foreleg during the Massachusetts Handicap yesterday, in which he ran out of the money for the first time in his career.

Cardinal Hayes will preside and give the absolution at the funeral of Mgr. Patrick N. Breslin which will be held tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. in the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy, 2,500 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, of which Mgr. Breslin had been pastor for many years. Mgr. Breslin, who was dean of the Bronx clergy, died on Tuesday in St. Francis Hospital.

Leon G. Turrou, special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who resigned June 20 to write a series of' newspaper articles on the recent spy round-up with which he was connected, has been dismissed from the FBI with prejudice, it was learned from the Department of Justice tonight.

Trading was fair to good and price trends, were generally upward. Steer beef sold strong to sharply higher, veal and lamb sharply higher, bull higher, fresh pork strong to slightly higher. Cow beef sold about steady weight considered. Kosher lamb opened sharply higher and a small amount of kosher, business in other classes was at strong prices.

Low gross honors in the weekly one-day Westchester and Fairfield golf tournament today went to Mrs. Joseph F. Holleran of Greenwich, who returned a card of 43, 40-83 at the Lawrence Farms Country sew Club.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the largest since December. This was due to the heavy volume of business in the latter part of the month after sales, during the early part, had dropped to the lonwest level in twenty years. On June 8 the turnover totaled 278,410 shares, the second lowest for a full day since July 3, 1922.

Mark Groskin was the broker in the recently reported lease of new quarters for Gray's Drug Store in 1,656 Broadway. The National Hotel Management Company, Inc, will continue for three years more to manage the Hotel Van Cleve, in Dayton, Ohio,

Off-shore sport fishermen struck into the tuna schools off this place for the first time this year today, bringing fifty-seven to gaff and reporting numerous strikes that were lost. The largest fish ran an even sixty pounds.

Alexander J. Marcuse, vice president, treasurer and director of the West Disinfecting Company, 42-16 Barn Street, Long Island City, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 555 Park Avenue. He was 73 years old.

The Society of Tammany Hall held its annual Independence Day celebration last night in Tammany Hall on East Seventeenth Street and at the same time observed the 152d anniversary of the organization's establishment.

Promotion of Daniel M. Frisbie to be executive officer and administrative assistant to Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, was announced today. Mr. Frisbie, who -is director of the Bureau of Milk Publicity, will begin his new duties tomorrow.

Belittling recent charges against the American Legion as the "puny product of a small mind," Daniel Doherty, national commander of the Legion, assured the National Education Association yesterday that cooperation and good-will would continue to be the. policy between the two organizations in the future as they had in the past.
Mrs. Florine Haas Sicher, wife of Dudley D. Sicher, philanthropist and Jewish communal leader, died yesterday in her home at 15 East Eightieth Street after a lingering illness. She was 55 years old.

In the absence of any competition the city bought at public auction yesterday its tax liens,totaling $8,061,316, against the special franchises and real estate of the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines operated under a 999-year lease by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

With one exception, all of the seeded players advanced to the quarter-final round of the girls metropolitan district tourney which began yesterday on the courts of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club. Of the quartet of ranked players those to score were the Misses Josephine San Filippo, Virginia Wandelt and Barbara Bixler,

Friends of Representative John J. O'Connor declared yesterday that they were ready to resist any attempt by President Roosevelt's "purge" committee to prevent Mr. O'Connor's return to the House, where he is chairman of the Rules Committee. They expressed complete confidence in Mr. O'Connor's renomination and re-election.
Confirmation of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's reported intention to abate his aerial bombers' activities was obtained in an unexpected quarter today.
Baltimore came from behind and won the second game of a doubleheader from Newark tonight, 9 to 7, after dropping a 9-1 decision in the seven-inning opener.

A man identified as Cyril E. Warren, 38 years old, of 14 Overhill Road, New Rochelle, N. Y., who had been melancholy because of the loss of a $25,000-a-year job, according to the police, fell to his death early this morning from his room on the eighteenth floor of the Hotel McA lpin, while his brother, Raymond, of 20 North Broadway, White Plains, N. Y., was visiting him.

Fourteen students and two members of the faculty of the New Jersey State Teachers College here will start out at 8 A. M. tomorrow on a sixty-two-day, 12,500-mile study tour which will take them through twenty-six States to the Pacific Coast and back.

Stephen W. Connolly, a partner in the real estate and insurance firm of H. S. Connolly Co. and for thirty years active in the real estate development of Montclair, died suddenly of a heart attack today at his home here.
Immediate effect of the three-day storm that damaged Eastern crops and churned up the Atlantic early this week is to be found in the vegetable bins and in the fish stalls of New York City markets.
Jack Knott, who was just another pitcher with the Browns, turned in a masterful four-hitter today against his former mates to give the White Sox an 11-1 victory and a sweep of the four-game series.
Price advances and a general stiffening on important silk and acetate constructions were reported in the markets here yesterday as both the rayon yarn and raw silk markets displayed greater firmness.

Miss Florence Wardwell, daughter of Mrs. John Lewis Montgomery, who has taken a cottage here for the season, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea dance at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.
Walter and Max Goetze, Germany's No. 1 public enemies, sentenced to death on June 24 by virtue of a retroactive decree issued during their trial, were beheaded in Ploetzensee Prison this morning.

Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson ruled today that Samuel Insull and his associates shall have an opportunity to vindicate themselves of charges of misconduct made in a report recently filed by Garfield Charles, special referee in bankruptcy.

What science had done for the electrical industry and what the electrical industry with the help of science might yet do for mankind was pictured to the American Association for the Advancement of Science today by a Westinghouse company expert, Marvin W. Smith of Pittsburgh.

More than 2,500 persons, white and Negro, filled the largest church in Harlem yesterday to attend the funeral services for Dr. James Weldon Johnson, the Negro poet, composer and educator, who was killed on Sunday in an automobile accident in Maine.

The success of governmental efforts to handle human problems posed by depressions and human needs will depend on the establishment of a central agency to educate the publie as to their rights under a complex and varying system of provisions, Alexander Heron, industrial relations director of the CrownZellerbach Company, one of the largest timber and paper companies, declared here today.

The Kent School crew of Connecticut beat Harvard's 150pound oarsmen three-quarters of a length today, thus eliminating one of the three American eights entered in the Henley regatta, which ends Saturday.

Members of the City Planning Commission, accompanied by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs and a corps of his engineers, inspected yesterday the East River shore where Mr. Isaacs plans to add highway links that, when completed, will give the East Side a $55,000,000 streamlined express roadway stretching from Montgomery Street north to the Harlem River Speedway.
As in the case of Memorial Day, the Fourth of July falls this year on a Monday, providing a long week-end of which many persons will take advantage in order to get out on the open road.

Based on a valuation of $441,555,656, J. H. Thayer Martin, State Tax Commissioner, levied taxes today for 1938 aggregating $20,364,053 on railroad property in New Jersey. The tax, due in December, is an increase of $1,003,028 over that of last year.

THERE was a conversational chukker of polo yesterday afternoon. The players and officials, dismounted, were sitting around and talking of this and that, including the international match scheduled for next June at Meadow Brook. However, nobody raised the old Revolutionary cry that echoed along the road to Concord: "Up! Up! The Redcoats are coming!"
The Schumer Theatrical Transfer, Inc., leased from Henry Holding the four-story garage at 429 West Fifty-third Street for storing theatre scenery and property. The Kersey Company was the broker.

Chinese hopes of increased Russian assistance are seen in the unusual amount of attention given to the aspects of the Soviet Union's relations to the SinoJapanese war in the Chinese press during the past week.
The delegates attending the Constitutional Convention face the possibility of a steady diet of night sessions. After weeks of proceeding at an extremely slow pace, the "clean-up" drive has begun.

Scoring nine runs in the third inning off three Philadelphia pitchers for their biggest single frame of the season, the Giants today made it just a breeze for Slick Castleman to hang up his third victory as they romped along to win by a final count of 14-1.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Gibbs of 142 East Seventy-first Street and Woodcliff Lake, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Isabel Gibbs, to George Freeman Galland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abram S. Galland of WilkesBarre, Pa.

Maine's Supreme Court today ruled in two separate opinions that organizers for the Committee for Industrial Organization were guilty of criminal conspiracy and innocent of contempt of court for activities in the Lewiston-Auburn shoe strike last year.

The Rev. William A. Merchant, former pastor of St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church, died early yesterday morning in a fall from a room he occupied on the fifth floor of the Hotel Commodore. Detectives who investigated said they were convinced the priest's death was accidental. He was 51 years old.

Blue will be the "surprise color" of the Fall season and, "partly because of the Swedish influence, will be chosen by an impressive number of women for coats, suits, costumes and dresses," according to announcement made yesterday by the color coordination committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, of which Victor T. Chambers of the Associated Merchandising Corporation is chairman.

After a tense debate the House of Commons unanimously agreed tonight to convene a select committee of private members to investigate Duncan Sandys's charge that an attempt was made by War Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha to muzzle him with a threat of prosecution under the Official Secrets Act.

Israel Albert Washburne, for forty years a professor at the New York Law School, died yesterday at the Midtown Hospital after a three weeks' illness. Professor Washburne, who was 76 years old, retired in June.

Three eligibles for the Hambletonian, classic of the harness turf, shared the heats in the $5,000 matron stake in tonight's Grand Circuit racing, necessitating a match race among the victors tomorrow night to determine the prize winner.
Judge James P. Doran, presiding justice of the Third District Court of Bristol, died today in his chambers after a heart attack. He was 63 years of age.

After being assigned to the police guard at the World's Fair for President Roosevelt as a last tour by his own request, Patrolman Joseph F. Jeckel, 63 years old, turned in his shield at the Queens Village precinct yesterday after he returned from the World's Fair grounds.

Pay increases of $120 a year will be given to 1,192 low-paid city employes in the competitive class of civil service, according to an announcement yesterday by Mayor La Guardia which said the increases were effective immediately.
Cuban imports of American hog lard during May reached 4,055,970 pounds, nearly double the April figure and 30 per cent more than the shipments for May, 1937, the Commerce Department stated today.

William McChesney Martin Jr. became yesterday the first paid president of the New York Stock Exchange. His salary was set at $48,000 and he will serve indefinitely, "at the pleasure of the board of governors."

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled yesterday that I the Lawyers Mortgage Company, now in liquidation, remains liable on its guarantee for the payment of interest at the full rate promised to certificate holders,

In a rapidly rising market, sales of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded purchases by 89,098 shares in the week ended on June 25, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Odd-lot volume jumped precipitately with customers' orders to sell covering 1,600,148 shares and customers' orders to buy 1,511,050 shares.

United States opposition to changes in the Davis Cup system prevailed today as the International Lawn Tennis Federation by decisive majorities defeated two suggestions to put the competition on a biennial basis.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of license for service as teachers, as of June 29, 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

Responsibility for any unwanted projects allocated to this city by the Public Works Administration was placed upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Secretary Ickes. The PWA Administrator said in Washington that his agency had tried twice to learn from the Mayor which of the applications submitted by the city two or three year ago were to be withdrawn, and in the absence of any reply it was assumed that all were still desired.

Considerable importance is attached here to outspoken comment dealing with Great Britain's position toward China in yesterday's Ta Kung Pao, a newspaper that has close connections with the highest officials. The newspaper ironically says:

Miss Annie Ruth Cowan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Coleman Cowan, was married to Finley W. Tatum of New York this morning at Maple Hill, the home here of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. R. Robinson of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church of Fayetteville.
Winthrop A. Wilson, attorney, has purchased a plot on Jefferson Road, Scarsdale, for improvement with a dwelling. Roy Ellinghouse was the broker.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

After five previous postponements of the proposed auction sale of the twenty-four-story Manhattan Towers Hotel at 2,162-68 Broadway, when the property was put on the block again yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms, no bids were made and the referee, Joab H. Banton, ordered its withdrawal.
The first no-stop-work contracts between a Federal agency and labor unions have been negotiated successfully by the United States Housing Authority.

The beat of drums throbbed through the encampment of the Confederate veterans of the Civil War at Gettysburg today as the First Medical Regiment of the United States Army went to the peaceful headquarters tent of General John M. Claypool, commander in chief of the United Confederate Veterans.

Samuel Kahn, president of the WMarket Street Railway Company of San Francisco, a unit in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system, announced yesterday that the company would not deposit the $75,000 quarterly sinking fund requirement on July 1, but would meet interest payment on its 7 per cent bonds.

Miss Emily Harold Alsop, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Winthrop Neilson of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., was married here this afternoon to John Frederick Jordan, son of Mrs. John Jordan Jr. of Erie, Pa., and the late Mr. Jordan, at the home of her uncle, Howell E. Jackson.
Sidney A. Haas of New York City was re-elected today as president of the Retail Manufacturing Furriers Association of America, a post he has held since the organization, was founded nine years ago.

President Marshall of the Board of Education, counseling the teachers gathered here to moderation and fair emphasis in their battle for democracy, dismissed the politician as in the nature of things an opportunist, and then added:

Six of the seven Bronx properties scheduled to be sold at auction today were bought in for nominal bids of $500 by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, as plaintiff against defaulting owners. A seventh scheduled sale was adjourned until July 7.

An additional realignment of buyers, affecting the John Wanamaker stores here and in Philadelphia, was announced yesterday. Miss Tessie Emanuel, buyer of corsets' for the local downstairs store, will also buy them for the Philadelphia downstairs division. Miss Sara M.

The seven trade shows to be held in New York this month will draw approximately 9,000 buyers and retailers to the city, and sponsoring organizations report uniformly that they expect sales materially in excess of those at the last similar events, according to a survey conducted by the New York convention and visitors' bureau of the Merchants Association, issued yesterday by C. N. Nichols, executive director.
With the beginning of a new fiscal year tomorrow the Administration faces the prospect of a deficit of about $3,000,000,000 and a new high national debt of around $40,000,000,000.

After a flood of buying orders at the opening that sent prices up from fractions to 2 points, followed by a further heavy demand until near the end of the first hour, the stock market yesterday had to contend with a steady stream of profittaking to closing.

President Roosevelt's recent fireside chat contained one piece of political strategy which is notably in line with public opinion. Preparatory to his swing through the West, the President declared he would not oppose a candidate in a Democratic primary merely because of that candidate's vote "on any single issue"-meaning, according to most observers, his vote on the Supreme Court plan last year.

Highway construction contracts totaling more than $25,000,000 boosted the awards for the current week in that category to the highest point in five years, and are largely responsible for a sharp rise of 22 per cent in the total of all engineering construction lettings

Many guests will arrive tomorrow to pass Independence Day at estates throughout the colony. Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo Potter, who are occupying Westmoor, after an absence of several seasons, will have as members of their holiday house party Mr. and Mrs. Earl S. Potter, Mr. and Mrs. William Marvel, Miss Anne Marvel of Wilmington, Del., and Richard Wallack of Warrenton, Va.
Lumber production increased less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index eased to 65.2 from 65.4. The figure was 96.9 for the week ended June 26, 1937.

A contingent of eighty boys and girls from Brooklyn carried off first honors yesterday afternoon at the Park Department's annual interborough athletic meet in Macombs Dam Park at. Jerome Avenue and 158th Street. the Bronx.

Admission of general partners, the formation and dissolution of security concerns and changes in others have been announced, effective today. Jacquelin DeCoppet have announced the admission of Walter B. Levering as a general partner.

The general strike of construction workers at the World's Fair, called by the Building Trades and Construction Council, A. F. of L. affiliate embracing the leading crafts in the building industry, went into effect yesterday.
Jackie (Kid) Berg continued his successful comeback as a welterweight by outpointing Johnny Horstmann of the East Side in the eightround feature bout at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, last night.

While the nation-wide fight against syphili has made great strides in the last few years, no effective, long-range syphiliscontrol program can be completed until the medical profession itself has been educated to modern methods of treating the disease, Dr. Louise Pearce of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, declared today at the closing session of the annual conference of Health Officers and Public Health Nurses.
Here is the Max Gordon office saying-again-that "The Women" will soon close, its date of expiration at the Barrymore being set this time for July 9. It will have played 657 performances.
Veterans of Foreign Wars, in convention here, were informed at the first session today that the convention would consider tomorrow the Kenyon Bill now before the State Constitutional Convention.
Thomas N. Powers retires today at the age of 65 from the position of general traffic superintendent of the Postal Telegraph System, after forty-six continuous years of service.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 28: Wolfard, Commander O. L., the Relief to 4th Naval District, Philadelphia, Pa. Chesser, Lieut. Comdr. A. B., Medical Corps, Great Lakes, Ill., to the Lexington, in August.

Premier Jelal Bayar today told the Turkish National Assembly that the autonomous Sanjak of Alexandretta "must be Turkish-ruled." He discussed the advanced stage of negotiations recently entered into with the French Government looking toward a military alliance.

Samuel Reading Bertron, economic expert and president of the international banking firm of Bertron, Griscom Co. of New York and Philadelphia, died this afternoon at his home in Cove Neck after an illness of about a year.
Mr. Aubrey Williams was originally quoted as saying in his already famous talk before the Workers Alliance: "We have never paid anything like the national prevailing wages in this country on WPA.
The radio broadcasting industry pays the highest wage in the industrial field, according to a survey by the Bureau of Labor Statistics made public here today by Broadcasting Magazine.

George Monroe, clam digger, bridge tender, general handy man, selfproclaimed descendant of Presidents Monroe and Tyler and owner of a ramshackle houseboat to boot, hooked a thumb in his frayed vest tonight and told why he is the talk of this town and adjacent communities.

A sharp advance in Liverpool in quotations for cotton, both spot and future, together with the broadest trading in the stock market since October, pushed prices on the Cotton Exchange into new high territory in early dealings yesterday.
The Red Hal Sox blasted Jimmy DeShong for 14 hits in six innings today while overwhelming Washington, 11-1, behind the six-hit pitching of Jim Bagby Jr.

The United States, Britain and France, the three signatories to the 1936 naval treaty, signed a protocol today raising that agreement's limitation on the size of capital ships from 35,00 to 45,000 tons.

For motorists who have had to use the Boston Post Road between Manhattan and Bridgeport, that historic thoroughfare long ago lost its romantic interest. Driving over it is a chore and a dangerous chore.
George Connors, 32-year-old antique dealer of Palisades, N. Y., was critically ill at the Nyack Hospital
James Roosevelt's physician today said that the President's son was indignant about a Saturday Evening Post article concerning his insurance business.

Diplomatic representatives from many countries were the guests of the New York World's Fair at abuffet luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Plaza. After the luncheon they were escorted to the fair grounds to witness the dedication of the Federal Government's building by President Roosevelt.

Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday declined 18.6 per cent to $4,736,704,000 from $5,815,932,000 in the corresponding week last year, according to Dun. Bradstreet, Inc.

In the Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament at the Manursing Island Club today, the singles field was reduced to ten and the doubles to nineteen. Sixty-seven matches were played and eighteen courts used.
Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here dropped today to the lowest level since June 9 as a result of increased hedging pressure and selling by commission houses and the professional element.

Sergeant William M. Green of Troy, who has been in charge of the detail assigned to Governor Lehman since 1927, was promoted today to lieutenant. He has been a member of Troop G, State ponnlie, since July 1. 1920.

A Federal grand jury yesterday handed up an indictment charging that three men and a building corportion forced PWA workers engaged in the construction of a public school at Seward and Croes Avenues, the Bronx, to "kick back" part of their wages.

Federal Reserve Statement A further sharp rise of $120,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System is reported in this week's statistics, lifting total excess reserves to $2,900,000,000, a new high since Aug. 12 1936, just before the first increase in reserve requirements became effective.

With high praise from Postmaster General James A. Farley for its first year's achievement in laying the groundwork for continued service in future years, the Greater New York Fund ended yesterday its current public campaign for funds with total receipts to date of $4,416,327.

The marriage of Miss Irene Frances Whelan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Whelan of Grantwood and Sea Girt, to William F. Watters, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Watters of Belleville, took place here this morning in St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev.

More than 500 parishioners and friends of Mgr. Arthur J. Kenny attended a celebration last night of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his installation in the pastorate of St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church.
Paramount was completing negotiations today with Joel McCrea for the leading role in Cecil B. De Mille's "Union Pacific," which is scheduled to go before the cameras in July.

Senator David I. Walsh, Democrat, of Massachusetts, a member of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures, today denounced the use by any agency or officers of the administration of Federal relief funds to influence votes as gutter politics."

The after Pirates jumped over the Reds to plunk into second place in the hot National League race today when Cy Blanton pitched three-hit ball to take the rubber of a three-game series from Cincinnati, 3 to 1.

While the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, halted in Scranton, Pa., last week by labor trouble, was passing Waycross, Ga., yesterday on the way to Sarasota, Fla., Winter quarters, officials were meeting in New York.

A complete denial was made by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, at his press conference today of implied charges of the "Keep America Out 1 of War Congress" that the United States was exercising certain forms of financial pressure on Mexico in view of the controversy over Mexico's expropriation of American oil properties.

Miss Helen Jacobs, whose chances of regaining the all-England tennis title she won here in 1936 were regarded as so poor that she had barely been mentioned amozg the contenders, today defeated her California rival; Miss Alice Marble, 6-4, 6-4, in the semi-final round.

The rise in the markets provided the sensation of business news in June and exceeded anything that even the optimists had expected, the National City Bank says in its monthly letter, issued yesterday.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low point for the year. The table shows the highest and lowest points reached in 1938 and a series of past years. All figures except ratio of reserves are in thousands of dollars.

Record cheap rates of Treasury bill financing were again the feature of the money market in June. Apart from the weekly tenders on the Treasury bills, open-market rates remained unchanged, as they have been for many months.

Miss Ellery Livingston Allen of 162 Engle Street, this place, known for her nightly program, "Songs My Grandmother Sang," at the BarbizonPlaza Hotel in New York, died at Presbyterian Medical Center in New York today after a brief illness. She was 34 years old.
After holding statutory public hearings yesterday on the five bills comprising the city's emergency relief taxing program, Mayor La Guardia signed them.

George Dallas Garris, reputed to be the oldest merchant in New Jersey and one of the oldest in the United States, who had conducted a general store at Stillwater for sixtyseven years, died Tuesday night at his home at Stillwater.
The Chiefs and Jersey City played ten innings to a 2-all tie tonight, the game being called at 11 P. M. To allow both clubs to catch trains.

Johnny Allen, rushed to the aid of Bob Feller, was credited with his eleventh straight victory today when, with two out in the ninth, he singled to bring home Frankie Pytlak and give Cleveland a 10-9 decision over the Detroit Tigers.

Mrs. Nanette True Harris, widow of Norvin Trent Harris, a well-known sportsman, and for many years active in the social work of the Episcopal Church and various charitable organizations, died here tonight in Touro Infirmary after an illness of nearly a year.
President Roosevelt made a "sick" call on Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden yesterday and found the 55-year-old heir to Gustaf V more a genial host than an invalid to be consoled.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, told John L. Lewis today that he was determined to drive the Communists from the union because they were responsible for the internal disturbances.

Plans for a garage and transfer depot to replace two flats were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by the Jacob Forst Packing Company of Kingston, N. Y., of the two tenement houses at 456 and 458 West Thirtyfirst Street.

The New York Steam Corporation, a subsidiary of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $32,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on Ju1ly 1, 1963.
The body of Medill McCormick, 21-year-old heir of the McCormick publishing fortune, was located tonight by Sandia Indians on a lonely cliff deep in the heart of the Sandia Mountains.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen docked yesterday afternoon at West Forty-sixth Street from Europe with 604 passengers, and the liner Columbus departed with 1,350. The Bremen will sail at midnight tomorrow with 1,845 passengers.

Fritz Kuhn, "Fuehrer" of the German-American Bund, making a defense of his organization tonight, told the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Military Affairs that any German spies over here should be shot.

The importance and scope of the Evian refugee conference, which will open on the French shore of Lake Geneva next Wednesday were increased considerably by agenda that the United States Government has proposed, in the view of diplomats here whose governments have informed them of this document.

Wall Street's strength was reflected in improved stock markets here today and most sections were more active. Giltedge issued were well supported, while among the foreign bonds German loans were firm.

The modern high school program places too much emphasis on vocational education and there is virtually no relationship between the training that youth receives and the existing employment opportunities, in the opinion of Dr. Homer P.
