Rainey, director of the American Youth Commission of the American Council on Education.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There seems to be a general belief. that the matter of gross overtaxation of real estate and the various methods suggested from time to time for reducing it. concerns itself chiefly with the owners of real property.

Mr. and Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher, who are passing the season at Long Acres, their place in Locust Valley, gave a dinner dance tonight at the Seawanhaka-C.rinthian Yacht Club to honor their nieces, Miss Vieva Fisher Banks, daughter of Mrs. Lester W. Perrin of Bernardsville, N. J., and James Lenox Banks Jr., and Miss Jane Remsen Darlington, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Gilbert S. Darlington.

The text of President Roosevelt's address at the laying of the cornerstone of the Federal Building at the New York World's Fair grounds was as follows: Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Commissioner Flynn, Mr. Whalen, and distinguished guests: The master mason certifies that the cornerstone is well and truly laid and in return I have assured him that I hold a union card.

A determination by the courts of the validity and scope of the State's Anti-Injunction Law and of what constitutes peaceful picketing under that law appeared certain yesterday when the Appellate Division declined unanimously the application for a stay of the injunction issued by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo against two C. I. O. unions in the strike against the Busch Jewelry Company, Inc., and two subsidiaries.

Berthold Neuer, vice president and general manager of William Knabe Co., manufacturers of Knabe and Fischer pianos, and long a close friend of and adviser to many of the world's greatest musicians, died yesterday in the Leroy Sanitarium of a heart ailment after an illness of several weeks. Mr.

The residence of Miss Adelaide Weed at 14 Weed Place, Greenwich, has been sold to Paul Dahlgreen, real estate broker. It was held at $40,000. Miss Weed's father was Jacob Talmadge Weed, son of Isaac Weed, who kept a tavern in the Revolutionary War days.

For the second year in succession Mrs. Ray M. Torgerson of Queens Valley and her mother, Mrs. Frank Adel, won low gross honors in the eighth annual women's metropolitan mother-and-daughter championship over the Hudson River Coun-i try Club course today.

When the extraordinary Supreme Court grand jury resumes its investigation of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, policy-lottery monopoly next Wednesday, it was reported yesterday, at least two former Tammany leaders, as well as two "big-time" gamblers, in the city, will be among those called to testify before the body by Assistant District Attorney Sol Gelb.

Donita M., a 2-year-old daughter of Stimulus owned by the Longchamps Farms, indicated yesterday that she is one of the best juveniles on the local tracks as she captured the $2,500-added Demoiselle Stakes, feature of the opening program at Empire City.

Detailed rules for marketing quota procedure affecting the 1938 cotton crop were issued today by the Department of Agriculture as a result of a referendum on March 12 in which 92 per cent of voting cotton growers were said to have approved use of marketing quotas again this year.

Premier Benito Mussolini's henchmen from the provinces were put through their paces today in the first of a series of tests of their physical fitness. Forty-five federal secretaries and provincial heads of the Fascist party gathered to take these tests in Rome's sweltering Summer heat.
Reflecting further strength in the foreign price, a leading seller of copper in the domestic market yesterday advanced its quotation to 9.25 cents a pound.

At a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission today the New York Curb Exchange sought to obtain unlisted trading in the $3 convertible preferred stock of the Equity Corporation, this marking the, first instance in which the SEC has been asked by an exchange for such privilege in a stock traded exclusively in the over-counter market.

An accident damage suit being tried in Federal court was delayed an hour on Wednesday by the failure of Mrs. Lucy Folsom Cobb, Juror No. 10, to appear in court. It required that amount of time for both sides to agree to proceed with the trial with only eleven jurors.

An East Indian nautch girl's outfit, adapted as a play frock, won the approval yesterday of school teachers at a fashion revue of a wardrobe assembled especially for their profession by style authorities at Bonwit-Teller's.
President Getulio Vargas made an unannounced visit today to the Jewish colonization company at Rezende, in the State of Rio de Janeiro, where about 300 Jews have settled.

As the little old lady in the next row said, something's come over that Bartholomew boy. When first he set footprints in the lobby of Grauman's Chinese he was such an angelic youngster buttered scones wouldn't melt in his mouth.

Lance, the 2-year-old son of the Count and Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow and heir to the bulk of the $45,000,000 fortune of the Countess (the former Barbara Hutton), today was made a ward of a court in chancery here. Although Lance is Danish by parentage, he is British by birth and the court will have full control over his life until he is 21 years old.
Dry goods jobbers, while refusing to be stampeded into purchasing huge quantities of textiles this week, covered their requirements in a fairly liberal manner, they reported here yesterday.

In a unanimous decision, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reversed yesterday a decision of Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora requiring Arthur J. Morris, founder, and four other directors and former directors of the holding company controlling Morris Plan Banks throughout the country to pay the company about $443, 000.

Realty Holders, Inc., of which Joseph Polsky is president, has purchased from the 640 East 139th Street Corporation, Benjamin Gottfried, president, the forty-nine family apartment house at 269 Cypress
Dr. Edward E. Green of 456 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, a practicing physician and surgeon in Brooklyn for thirty years, died yesterday in Brooklyn Hospital after an illness of three months.

Suit for divorce was filed against Edward P. (Mickey) Walker, former pugilist, by Mrs. Clare Frances Walker in Chancery Court here today. Walker, whose address was given as 74 Beachway, Keansburg, N. J.,
The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and subsidiaries for twelve months ended on May 31, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses of $6,069,698.

Uniform regulations controlling issuance of commercial documentary credits in financing exports and imports have been agreed to by 130 banks and other concerns, the domestic section of the International Chamber of Commerce announced today.

The eastern coastal front is slowly giving way, government communiques this week have admitted. There has been no break in the dogged Loyalist resistance that is costing the Rebels heavily, but it would be misleading to paint a bright picture of the situation.

Jarl Johnsen, Norwegian heavyweight, continued his victorious streak at the Fort Hamilton Arena last night by outpointing the veteran Pittsburgh, battler, Charley Massera, in the main event of eight rounds before a capacity crowd of 7,500.

To get qualified leadership in a society "bewildered" by social, economic and political unrest, the American school system should pay more attention to the intellectually gifted children, Dr. Benjamin B. Greenberg, assistant superintendent of the New York City schools, decared yesterday.

The Republic of Poland, through Janusz Zoltowski, financial counselor of its Washington embassy, announced yesterday an offer of definitive settlement to the holders of the Polish external 8 per cent bonds due on July 1, 1950.

The board of administrators of the Charity Hospital of Louisiana, New Orleans, has invited tenders for $4,500,000 of bonds, award of which will be made on July 12. The bonds will be dated Aug. 1, 1938, and will mature serially from Aug. 1, 1942 to 1968. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe yesterday directed trustees of the Munson Steamship Line to enter an agreement with the United States Maritime Commission, under which the line will receive $1,902,000 from the commission upon lifting libels against its vessel the American Legion, by paying claims to debtors.

Julius Heldman of U. C. L. A., former national junior titleholder and top-seeded choice, was eliminated in the fourth round today at the Montclair A. C. for the first major upset in the annual Eastern intercollegiate singles tennis championship.

Peter Cooper Apartments, Inc., owner of the six-story apartment house for seventy-seven families at 43-09 Fortieth Street, Sunnyside, L. I., has exchanged the property for a six-story building accommodating sixty-two families at 34-20 Thirty-second Street, Astoria, L. I.,

The East St. Louis and Interurban Water Company, a subsidiary of the American Water Works and Electric Company, has sold to a group of financial institutions $7,500,000 of 4 1/4 per cent fifteenyear first mortgage bonds. The issue was placed at a premium.

The Commandant and officers of the Royal Yugoslav Training Ship Yadran, visiting New York, were guests at a dinner given last night by B. P. Stoianovitch, Yugoslav consul general here, at the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fiftyninth Street. Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward. Stanley H. Howe.

Efforts to speed the formation of an association of brokers and dealers in the over-counter markets, to register as a self-regulatory body under the supervision of the Securities and Exchange Commission, were made today at a conference between Commissioner George C.
Private funeral services for Frederick William Vanderbilt, who died on Wednesday at his home in Hyde Park, were held yesterday afternoon at his city residence, 1,025 Fifth Avenue.
Department-store sales for the week ended June 25 were 10 per cent lower than for the same week in the previous year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Four Fascist party chiefs were injured today attempting to show Premier Benito Mussolini their gymnastic ability.
The New York Queens Electric Light and Power Company, Long Island City, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering the issuance of 8,772

The American Slovak League delegation, which brought the riginal of the Pittsburgh agreement here, has been snubbed by a majority of Slovak parties, according to the newspaper Lidove Noviny. The only exception, the newspaper said, was Father Andrea Hlinka's autonomist party.
Queen Mary asked to see Don Budge and Bunny Austin after Budge had beaten the Briton in straight sets for the Wimbledon tennis championship today.

Two Eastern representatives, one from the Southwest and the fourth from the Pacific Coast, will meet tomorrow on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club in the semi-final round of the Eastern intercollegiate singles tennis championship.

Emancipator VII, 'powerful four.liter hydroplane owned and driven by S. Mortimer Auerbach of Atlantic City, N. J., won the first two thirty-mile heats of the Duke of York Trophy race today. Official confirmation of the second victory was lacking, however, pending a check to see whether any of the speed boats had exceeded the fuel allowance.

Survivors of sensational skirmishes in a downpour of rain, sophomores Bert McDowell of Louisiana State University and John P. Burke of Georgetown University advanced today by the narrowest of margins to the final of the national intercollegiate golf championship.
It it had not been for the probation system more than 25,000 offenders convicted of felonies in New York County between 1927 and 1937 would have been sent to prison. Irving W.
John Hamilton, who has already made one speech in the South to stimulate coalition in 1940, will again invade the South next Monday at Monticello.

After four days of idleness because of unfavorable conditions, most of the teams in the Meadow Brook Club's current twenty-goal polo competition resumed action today, with the Bostwick Field, Templeton, Gulf Stream and Aknusti quartets recording tourney triumphs.

As is usual at the mid-year, the banks have not waited for the issuance of calls by the Controller of the Currency or the State Superintendent of Banks to issue their statements of condition on June 30 Several reports came out yesterday, and many are scheduled to appear early next week. For the most part the reports make a good showing.
Under a new system of borrowing and bookkeeping, the costs of two large lending agencies will not show in the Treasury's statements of budgetary spending during the fiscal year which began today.
Miss Mabel Burke Walker, daughter of John Y. G. Walker of Llewellyn Park, was married to Charles Pendleton Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edison Lewis of New York and Salisbury, Conn.,

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont won low gross honors in the weekly one-day women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament held today over the Morris County Golf Club course. She turned in a score of 42, 43-85.

A petition in bankruptcy was filed yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn on behalf of Carlo Tresca, veteran radical and leader of the Italian anti-Fascists in this country. The petition listed assets of $98.34 in cash and liabilities of $4,420.24 in unsecured claims.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's recent visit to Rome, according to the Czechoslovak press, was exploited by the German secret police to establish and maintain a regular secret. service in Italy for procuring information, particularly about the Fascist party.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses in a letter, disclosed yesterday, to George F. Mand, president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, denounced the Regional Plan Association, advising Mr. Mand that the association has "no talent at the moment worth listening to or bothering about."
Ward's Automotive Reports, Inc., finding automobile output steady, estimated today that this week's production would be 40,945 units, against 40,918 last week and 122,890 a year ago this week.

Nicholas F. Whalen, 23-year-old elevator operator in the Norton, Lilly Co. Building at 26 Beaver Street, was sworn in yesterday morning at 9 o'clock as the first soldier of the newly created Regular Army Reserve.

It appears impossible to select any one advertising department as typical of organizations in its industry or field, Allyn B. McIntire, vice president of Pepperell Manufacturing Company, Boston, said yesterday in releasing Volume IV in the series of case studies of advertising departments by the Association of National Advertisers, Inc.

181st, 253 E (11-3149); 181st St. Holding Corp. to American Savings'Bank; due on demand, 4 1/2 per cent; $17,000. 234th St, 549 E (12-3396); La Sala Holding Corp. to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; extends mtg to March 24, 1943, at 4 1/2 per cent; $150,000.
The backing of the New York State police conference was given to Mayor Frank Hague and his Police Chief, Daniel Casey, in a resolution adopted in the conference convention here this afternoon.

The War Department awarded today contracts for fighting airplanes and equipment totaling $14,443,196. It was the largest order for air-fighting equipment ever given in the peacetime history of the country.

Net profit of the Kroger Grocery and Baking Company and subsidiaries for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 18 was $1,615,053 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to a report issued yesterday.

The leading producers of copper advanced yesterday the domestic price of the metal to 9.50 cents a pound. This followed an increase of 1/4 cent to 9 1/4 cents by one producer on Thursday. These were the first changes in the price of copper in the domestic market since May 19, when the price was established at 9 cents.

Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow arrived in London early this morning and drove direct from Victoria Station to the Bow Street Police Court, where he was held in [Pound]2,000 bail on a charge of threatening his wife, the former Barbara Hutton, so that "she apprehends that she goes in danger of her life or some bodily harm."

Personal appearance, good manners and cooperation are significant factors in getting and holding a job, according to the Board of Education's annual report on "Cooperative Education," made public yesterday.

The Board of Education's power to withhold appointment to a position which it deems unnecessary but which has been frozen into the school system by State law was challenged yesterday in a petition filed with Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education.

The Mexican Government has announced it plans to put a 12 per cent tax on all exports, including raw materials, leaving Mexico, and at the same time to establish a quasi-permanent limitation upon imports, which come largely from the United States, by establishing a double exchange rate.

About 7,000 sets of half-year automobile license plates for 1938 were issued yesterday by the Bureau of Motor Vehicles in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, it was estimated by I. James Brody,

Attorney General Homer S. Cummings termed as "utter nponsense" today reports that he might be a candidate for the nomination as United States Senator from Connecticut. Asked if he would accept the nomination, he added:

Barretto St, (10-2765B), w s, 184 ft n of Randall Ave, 29x100; Margaret M. Hahn to Annie Herzog, 1,418 Harrod St. Rosedale Ave, (15-3894), n w cor of 174th St, 101x96; Can Realty Corp to 1,403-05 Rosedale Ave Corp, 1,419 Shakespeare Ave; mtg $115,125.

Federal Judge Leibell dismissed yesterday a suit for $4,333,000 brought by the British American Tobacco Company, Ltd., against the Federal Reserve Bank, based on its surrender in August, 1933, of 1,018 bars of gold in unwilling compliance with the anti-hoarding order issued by the President of the United States.
The Weather Bureau issued an emphatic denial yesterday to reports current about town that June had set a record for rain and cold weather.

Ignoring pleadings of his mother and the judge to testify against two safe blowers he accused on his recent arrest of having used him as a "stooge" in a series of burglaries, Joseph Cronin, 17 years old, of 149 Broome Street, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to an indeterminate term in the City Reformatory on his guilty plea to an unlawful entry charge.

I. Ward Waters, manager of the Cash Custody Department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and member of a family long identified in the banking business at Rochester, N. Y., died here suddenly last night of a heart attack at his home in Gedney Farm.
On the faultlessly groomed turf where Robert Riggs first demonstrated his affinity for grass-court play, another California tennis hopeful made his Eastern debut today under favorable auspices.

An elaborate peace plan for ending the Chinese-Japanese warfare, under which China would be carved into at least five autonomous units, is reported being drafted by Chinese members of the Peiping provisional government and their-Japanese advisers.

In this city, where cooperative education was born two decades ago, retailers and educators sat down today for the first time to discuss the development of State programs. throughout the country for training in the distributive occupations.

The marriage of Miss Frances M. Dodge, daughter of Mrs. Alfred G. Wilson and the late John Dodge, automobile manufacturer, to James B. Johnson Jr. of Elizabeth, N. J., took place here this evening in Meadow Brook Hall, home of the bride's mother and stepfather.

About to try his luck among the fins of British Columbia, Mr. Hoover put off the reporters who wanted him to talk politics by the palpably sophistical statement that "fishing and politics don't mix." If they don't mix it's because they are essentially the same.

Despite the prospect of cloudy weather for the three-day weekend, New Yorkers began to crowd air, bus and railroad terminals yesterday in a steadily growing stream as what appeared to be the greatest outpouring of holiday travelers in recent years got under way. At least a million persons are departing.
The New York bass season opened yesterday with a bang-and a haze-but the bronze-backs acted just as on ordinary days and were as unpredictable as ever.
Lieut. Col. Sir George Stanley, Governor of Madras from 1929 to 1934, died in London today at the age of 66. Before going to India he had a distinguished career as a soldier and politician.

The State Banking Department announced today that sworn copies of the merger of the Northfield Building Loan and Savings Association and the Port Richmond Cooperative Savings and Loan Association, under the title of the Northfield Savings and Loan Association, had been filed with the department.

A sensational case that is intended to determine whether British physicians may legally prevent births got under way today when Dr. Alec W. Bourne, a leading gynecologist, was committed for trial at Old Bailey on a charge of unlawfully using an instrument to bring about a miscarriage.

A new AngloGerman agreement providing for continuance of the debt service of Austrian loans was signed in London today, only a day after the settlement that had been in force since 1934 became terminable without notice.

Because of the increased demand for ambulance service at city beaches during the Summer, Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater assigned six additional ambulances yesterday for daily duty at Coney Island, the Rockaways and Orchard Beach in the Bronx.
France tonight suspended imports of Japanese quota merchandise, approximately 25 per cent of all Japanese goods purchased in France.

Navy Crosses were. awarded to twentythree officers and enlisted men of the gunboat Panay for heroism under fire when that vessel was bombed and sunk by Japanese airmen Dec. 12. The awards were bestowed by Secretary Swanson in the name of President Roosevelt.

After two weeks of inspecting and testing the Northrop Delta low-wing monoplane that he will use on his fourth exploratory expedition to the Antarctic next November, Lincoln Ellsworth and his wife, Mary Louise Ellsworth, are expected to. take off from Floyd Bennett Field today for a short vacation at Bretton Woods, N. H.

The Nichols Copper Company, subsidiary of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, yesterday changed its name to the Phelps Dodge Refining Corporation. W. I. Eadie, controller of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, has been elected a director to -succeed the late John D. Clark.

A steady drizzle was falling tonight on the eve of the national A. A. U.'s golden anniversary traek and field championships, as entrants in the junior events awaited the signal to open the two-day meet.
Men who get safely through heroic adventures in their youth seem to acquire a talent for longevity. Read the tombstone inscriptions in the cemeteries of the old whaling ports:

The number of officers in the Chilean Army will be increased, it was made known here today. President Arturo Alessandri has sent a message to Congress, saying that reductions made in the army for economic reasons seven years ago are no longer necessary.
Dr. Felix P. Chillingworth of the Tufts Medical School died yesterday at his Summer camp at Concord at the age of 65.

The city won yesterday from the Appellate Division permission to carry to the Court of Appeals the city's fight against pay rises of $20,830 granted to forty-two clerks and attaches of the Queens Surrogate's Court.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson denied yesterday the charge of Claudius A. Meade, a former home- relief investigator, that he had -been dismissed for uncovering cases of fraud instigated by the Workers Alliance.

The Fourth is near at hand. Will it be the usual day of fire, noise and death, or will the statistics reveal a decline in our recklessness? - It has been pointed out time and time again that more Americans have lost their lives in celebrating their independence than ever died to defend and win it.

A new playground at Twentythird Street near Fourth Avenue, another in Astoria and a third in Brooklyn will be opened to children today, bringing the total made available by the Department of Parks in the city to 369.

Several thousand fans today roared a welcome to the Reds, home from their most successful trip in years. Rain failed to dampen the greeting as the Reds stepped from their train to a flag-bedecked platform for the ceremonies.

Johnny Adams, Hollywood Park's leading rider, brought the favored Stop Scout in first today in the $1,200 feature race for 3-year-olds and up, at seven furlongs. Silvery Cloud was second and Real Clear, third.
The Red Sox came from behind today with a six-run splurge in the eighth inning to beat the Athletics, 12-7, and give Lefty Bob Grove his twelfth victory of the season.

A drop of 25.4 per cent in the average daily sales of chain men's wear stores occurred in May, compared with May, 1937, according to preliminary estimates of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Manufacturers' sales during May declined 28 per cent from a year ago, according to reports from almost 1,100 producers cooperating in the monthly joint study of the National Association of Credit Men and the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce.

Wreckers have been asked by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to submit bids for either partial or total demolition of the Fifth Avenue Theatre, landmark on the northwest corner of Broadway and Twenty-eighth Street.
Rear Admiral Thomas F. P. Calvert died here today at the age of 55. He commanded the second cruiser squadron in the home fleet until a sudden breakdown of health a few weeks ago.

A squadron of Chinese planes attacked Japanese troop positions and warships along the Yangtze River yesterday in an attempt to halt the invaders' land and naval drive toward Hankow, the Chinese provisional capital.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,130,000, against 1,153,000 a week ago, 1,173,000 two weeks ago, 1,169,000 three weeks ago and 901,000 a year ago; of which American 730,000 bales, against 742,000 a week ago, 758,000 two weeks ago, 769,000 three weeks ago and 340,000 a year ago.
Joseph P. Moran of New York City, organizer and first president of the New York State Police Conference in 1925, again has been chosen head of that organization.

Danielle Darrieux's coming-out party in "The Rage of Paris" at the Rqxy proved yesterday to be one of the more pleasant events of the current season. Although, strictly speaking, her picture is no great shakes, Miss Darrieux's charm and talent are enough to keep any one from speaking strictly.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is further improvement in the wool market. It is more pronounced in the West than in the East; in other words, the market is stronger the nearer one gets to the sheep's back.

Yesterday's smashing victory by Donald Budge assured American success in both singles contests of the All-England tennis championship. Today Helen Wills Moody and Helen Jacobs play the finals in the women's division.

The marriage of Miss Angeline Burroughs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Burroughs of Roxbury and grandniece of the late naturalist, John Burroughs, to Sayers Artman Lutz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Lutz, of Prattsville, took place yesterday in Gould Memorial Church, Roxbury, N. Y. The Rev. H. S. Vanwoert performed the ceremony.

Three men, who on Monday pleaded non vult to an indictment charging them with criminally attacking Mrs. Florence Edith Macken, 28 years old, of 665 Fifty-sixth Street, Brocklyn, in Kearny on May 8, were sentenced to State prison terms today by Common Pleas Judge James R. Erwin in Jersey City.

While starting its program slowly due to unavoidable preliminary preparations, the United States Housing Authority expects actually to expend $204,000,000 in financing lowcost housing and slum-clearance projects in the year ending June, 1939.
John R. Babcock, second vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, 140 Broadway, died on Thursday at Polyclinic Hospital after a short illness. Mr.

A movement to prevent Mrs. Sadie L. Monssen, widow of Lieutenant Mons Monssen, United States Navy hero for whom a destroyer is to be named, from losing her home at 1,756 West Tenth Street, Brooklyn, through foreclosure by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, is now under way among "certain pledged individuals,"

The first anniversary of the arrest and incarceration of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, founder and inspiration of the Evangelical Confessional Synods, was made the occasion for an impressive demonstration tonight when 3,000 of his parishioners crowded into Christ Church in Dahlem to pay silent homage to the man whose intrepid championship of religious freedom landed him in a concentration camp.

Thirty-six-hole sectional qualifying rounds for the national amateur golf championship will be played in thirty-three districts, one more than the 1936 previous high, the United States Golf Association announced yesterday through The Associated Press.

Richards Kellogg, treasurer of Old Bennington Village, died suddenly here early this morning at the age of 59. A native of Troy, N. Y., and a graduate of Williams College in 1902, he was the son of the late Justine Kellogg, an attorney.

Leon G. Turrou, the Federal agent who submitted his resignation during the unfinished spy investigation to become an author, declared yesterday that his dismissal from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced Thursday night, resulted from. his having "scooped" J. Edgar Hoover, director of the bureau, in the matter of publicity.

Chesla Sherlock, 42, writer and former editor of St. Nicholas Magazine, and his wife were found shot to death today at their farm home on the Virgil-Dryden Road. Coroner Claude E. Chapin said that Sherlock apparently had shot his wife with a shotgun and then shot himself.

After investigating communism in the last week and nazism the previous week, Senator John J. MeNaboe announced yesterday just before adjourning that his joint legislative committee was "of the opinion both these movements in this country are what might be called rackets."
The new consolidated offices of the Home Owners Loan Corporation in 270 Broadway were officially opened yesterday.

Cotton-mill activity last week held to the level of the two preceding weeks, in face of a seasonal decline, and the adjusted index rose to 94.6, its highest point since the week ended Dec. 4, 1937. This compared with 92.1 for the previous week and 141.4 for the week ended June 26, 1937.

The A. F. of L., in its monthly survey of business, stated today that while it was impelled to indicate that the industrial outlook was brightening, it was too early to tell whether this marked a temporary or a permanent improvement.

It is now admitted that a deadlock has been reached in, the negotiations over the nationalities problem on the important question of self-administration, notwithstanding the fact that steady daily progress has been recorded on various other questions.
Mrs. Lambert Suydam has leased a nine-room apartment in the building at 850 Park Avenue, through Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc.,

After fleeing from the Soviet Union over the Soviet-Manchukuoan boundary near Chientao, General G. S. Lushkoff threw away two pistols and surrendered when challenged by two Manchukuoan frontier guards.

Under the auspices of the National Conference of Jews and Christians there has been formally organized a New York round table "to promote justice, amity, understanding and cooperation between Catholics. -Protestants and Jews in the Greater New York area."

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 25 amounted to 558,937 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,368 cars, or 0.6 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 211,008 cars, or 27.4 per cent,

At this moment, we are told, the City of New York is in the curious position of being "confronted with an embarrassment of Federal riches which it does not want." PWA in Washington is eager to get its spending program started.
Mrs. Ruth M. Johnson of Shawnee, Oklahoma, who is running in the Democratic primary against five other

The itinerary of President Rqosevelt's swing through the West, beginning with, his departure from Washington 10:30 P. M. July 7 and ending on July 16 at San Diego, when he boards the cruiser Houston, was made public today as follows:
New quarters on the second floor of 545 Fifth Avenue have been leased by the Frackman Diamond Corporation, manufacturers of diamond and platinum jewelry.

Norman Churchill Hull, a lawyer, former City Clerk and member of a leading Pittsfield family, died today following an operation. He was born here fifty-six years ago, a son of James W. and Helen Plunkett Hull. His father was president of the Berkshire Life Insurance Company at his death in 1911.

Frank Santo, 13 years old, of Throop, Pa., won the marbles championship of the United Stated at the sixteenth annual tournament here this afternoon, winning twelve of the sixteen games he played against the four other regional finalists, all of his own age.
Issuance of fair-trade contracts in Illinois by George A. Hormel Co. was cited today as evidence of the increased interest of food merchandisers in price maintenance.

A wet track forced cancellation of tonight's final session of Grand Circuit racing at Fort Miami and more than 300 horses were shipped to Cleveland, where the Circuit program will be renewed Monday at North Randall.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday the election at a special meeting in Wilelection at a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., of seven directors nominated by committees to represent security holders in the company's bankruptcy proceedings.
Dr. Najib Nassif Sallume, surgeon, scientist, linguist and author, died last night in his home here after a brief illness at the age of 69.

Mrs. Frances Cronin Donohee, widow of Francis E. Donohoe and for many years a leading woman golfer, died today in the home here of her son, Francis E. Donohoe, with whom she had been living since her husband's death in 1936.

Profit-taking in early trading failed yesterday to dampen speculative enthusiasm in the bond market on the Stock Exchange and, after a convincing display of its ability to readily absorb selling, the market resumed its upward course over a broad front.
Trustees of the $5,500,000 Series B-1 mortgage certificates of the New York--Title and Mortgage Company announced yesterday in a report to Supreme Court Justice
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a sevenstory addition to the Department of Public Works Building at the southeast corner of Tremont and Arthur Avenues, the Bronx.
Mr. and Mrs. Richard Withington Canfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Grant Canfield, to Philip Adams Rortv Jr.

William Cardinal O'Connell, Catholic Archbishop of Boston, today sold the Keith Theatre Building for $85,000 to the Lowell Theatre Company, a Massachusetts corporation. The Cardinal acted as trustee of the estate of A. Paul Keith, son of the founder of the theatre chain.
Arthur H. Lauterbach of Philadelphia has been appointed general manager of the Pure Milk Association, cooperative bargaining agency for 14,500 dairy farmers in the Chicago milk producing territory,

A downward trend in both exports and imports, including many of the countries with which the United States has reciprocal trade agreements, was disclosed in tables showing the value of the foreign trade of the United States by countries for May, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Denial by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, of all but two of a twenty-two-case newspaper expose of relief in politics in the Barkley-Chandler Senatorial primary campaign in Kentucky, brought a rejoinder today from the writer of the series.

The World's Fair has signed a contract with Billy Rose to produce a musical extravaganza with a cast of 1,000 in the 10,000-seat marine amphitheatre on Meadow Lake, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

Sixteen of the best sprinters in this section of the country have been named overnight for the $5,000 added Fleetwing Handicap at Empire City today. This is a sprint over the short six-furlong route and the first of the important stake events to be run at the hilltop course.

British iron and steel retailers have just formed the National Federation of Iron and Steel Merchants. The purpose is to stabilize the retail marketing and pricing of iron and steel as the British Iron and Steel Federation has rationalized the wholesale market in the producer industry.

The building slump in England, according to the president of the Federation of Building Trades, is aggravated by the mounting fear of aerial bombardment. Insurance companies in London refuse to cover the risk of damage by enemy aircraft. People refuse to build houses to be bombed.
The mystery that for three years had shrouded the murder of William Snyder, head of a teamsters' union, before Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey took up the case, was dispelled yesterday.

Many dinners were given tonight at various estates throughout the colony for guests who have arrived for the Independence Day week-end. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon entertained with a dinner at the Shutters for Mr. and Mrs. George

Miss Emily Miller Parkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers Parkin of Spruce Farm, this place, was married here this evening in the Presbyterian Church to Frank B. Martin Jr. of Atlanta, Ga., son of Mr. and Mrs.

Bail for John R. Longo, 24-year-old anti-Hague Democrat, pending appeal from his conviction and nine months' sentence for violation of the election laws, was denied by Judge Robert V. Kinkead today in Common Pleas Court.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a democracy the clear comprehension by the people of the vital national interests and the national purpose, and the clear enunciation by its government of the policy, resultant therefrom, coupled with the evident and adequate means to implement such policy, is the surest safeguard against such a nation drifting into wars that do not concern it.

The Hebrew Free Loan Society, 108 Second Avenue, requires additional capital to aid refugees from Germany and Austria and to meet increasing applications for help from the needy, Julius J. Dukas, president of the society, said in his annual report, made public yesterday.
A road company of "What A Life" will be sent out in August by George Abbott. The first engagement will be in Boston and thereafter the company is scheduled to wend its way coastward.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: With every one climbing aboard the Louis bandwagon and- letting. his emotions do the thinking for him, isn't it only fair that we look for a moment at the other side of the picture?
Delegates to the annual business meeting of the United States Football Association, the governing socce body in this country; continued their discussions at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
Central registration, a service maintained by the Board of Elections for voters who expect to be out of town during the regular registration period, opened yesterday and will continue until Aug. 31.

Acting on authorization of the State executive committee to nomInate an independent State ticket, officers of the American Labor party decided last night upon a slate which it will present to the' executive committee for confirmation.

Billy Gillespie, national scholastic champion, and Don Buffington, both of Scarborough School, along with Harold Eckardt of Choate and Melville Jordan of Woodberry Forest, Va., gained the singles semi-final brackets of the sixth annual Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament today.
William Morris Mordey, engineer and magnetician, died at Warlingham, Surrey, today at the age of 82, after a lifetime spent in the development of electro-magnetic machinery.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the award of contracts for 865,400 yards of textiles for delivery by September. The awards, from bids opened on June 25, are as follows:
The Soviet Government announced tonight the flotation of a new loan of 5,000,000,000 rubles for industry and defense.
A $15,000 trailer was completed today for Fred B. Snite Jr., who has been living in an iron lung. The unique vehicle will be driven to Chicago for use of the infantile paralysis victim.

On a thickly wooded knoll high above the winding Hudson and not far from his family home here, President Roosevelt went back to the land today and, while workmen whacked away at sapling trees, traced out the floor plans of his own future home--his first at Hyde Park and the realization of a twenty-year dream.

A two-under-par round of 71 on Brae Burn, his home course, gave Denny Shute, two-in-a-row P. G. A. champion, a 3-hole lead over Ralph Guldahl, the 1937 and 1938 national open titleholder, when they completed the first half of their 36-hole "dream match" early tonight.

Mrs. Margaret Robinson, 44 years old, who described herself as a stock broker and gave her address as 52 Gramercy Park, was arraigned before General Sessions Judge Allen yesterday and pleaded not guilty to an indictment alleging that she had defrauded a man and three women of a total of $8,500 in money. and securities and $25,000 in jewelry.

Social progress in the United States will not be complete until every worker has a job and the government guarantees the right to work, if not in private industry then on government projects, Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator, told the National Conference of Social Work in a paper read to a section on social action today by John A. Kingsbury, WPA official.
The Italian Government has taken measures against the Jewish intelligentsia by issuing decrees designed to prevent or limit circulation of books by Jewish authors among the Italian Public.

Miss Grace Adelaide Brown of Oyster Bay, L. I., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Monroe Brown of Seattle, Wash., was married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to George W. N. Riddle of this city,
With forty-four players representing seventeen schools, the first New Jersey invitation high school tennis tournament to be held by the Peddie School got under way today.
Miss Jane Howie Arnold, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas Perkins Arnold of this city, was married here this afternoon to David Jameson Bond, son of Walter H. Bond of Garden City, L. I.,

The Peiping Provisional Government's ban on exports of hides and furs from North China became understandable today when the Japanese Commerce Ministry issued a decree restricting the use of hides and regulating prices and distribution.
W. A. McAllister, representing Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., in the New York institutional trade, has been appointed to supervise such sales throughout the country.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davis gave a dinner dance tonight at Heydey House, their home here, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Virginia Davis. They also honored Miss Sonia Phipps, daughter of Mr.

Three crushing home runs, two of them by Bill Dickey, which, in successive innings, swept seven runs across the plate, convinced Bucky Harris and his invading Senators at the Stadium yesterday that reports, of an early crack-up of the world champion Yankees have been rather grossly exaggerated.
The pistol bullet which killed King D. Gray, 52, film camera man, was fired at least a foot from his body, since his coat showed no traces of powder burns, Ray Pinker, police chemist, reported today.
Daniel G. Somerville, Conservative Member-of Parliament for East Willesden since 1929, died today at the age of 58.

Operatives of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today entered the investigation of the slaying of a- man believed to be Charles Morris, 50, New York race-track follower, whose trussed body was found last week in the Connecticut River.
The Federal Power Commission has reported that the production of electric energy for public use in the United States totaled 114,188,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the year ended on May 31 last.
Dr. Eyler Newton Simpson, associate professor in the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University, died in Princeton Hospital today after a long illness. His age was 37.
Paul G. Oulden of the United States Coast Guard today beat Walter Walsh, crack-shot G-man, for individual honors in the .38-caliber revolver match of the Eastern open rifle and pistol championship.
Joel Rathbone, former vice chairman of the National Surety Company, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

Mrs. Lillian A. Hall Abbett, widow of Leon Abbett, New Jersey attorney, died yesterday at the Hotel Plaza, after an illness of several weeks, in her sixty-sixth year. Born in New York, Mrs. Abbett was the daughter- of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. A. Hall.

A soft-voiced, quiet-mannered English girl landed in New York yesterday and admitted, with twinkling eyes and a ready smile, that sessions of the second World Youth Congress slated for Vassar College Aug. 16 to 23 would be dynamic.

For the third consecutive period new bond financing this week was restricted to tax-exempt issues with the total offerings dropping to $12,285,700, compared with $105,548,000 in new issues placed on the market last week. During this week last year a total of $98,337,000 new issues were offered.

Miss Margaret June Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard James Martin of Greenwich, was married to John Morrill Lashar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Benjamin Lashar of Fairfield, Conn., this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson.
Leaders of the steel industry here forecast today that the abolishment of price differentials at principal basing points would result in increased use of water transportation by the industry.

Clay Bryant hurled six-hit ball for the Cubs tonight to tag an 11-to-4 defeat on the Reds. He checked Cincinnati for eight innings, allowing one unearned run and only one hit-a fourth-inning double by Ival Goodman.

Bernard E. Denzer and Norman H. Scholle have retired from H. Content Co. H. Keasbey Bramhall and Alfred J. Ross have joined Dick Merle-Smith. The report on Wednesday that Mr. Denzer would join this firm was incorrect.

At least two hundred visitors called at the new office of the State Civil Service Commission in Room 576 of the State Office Building 80 Center Street, after it opened for business for the first time yesterday.

J. Crossan Cooper, a member of the Baltimore Stock Exchange, died today at his home of a heart ailment. His age was 75. Mr. Cooper came here from Pittsburgh about forty years ago. He was active in financial, social and literary circles.
Aubrey Williams, deputy WPA administrator, tonight compared

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $9,438,349, to be represented by two States and forty municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $14,381,296 for this week.

Colonel,Bill Terry favors playing the rest of his schedule against the Phils and the Dodgers. Invading Ebbets Field yesterday fresh from a triple triumph in Philadelphia, his Giants defeated the Grimes boys, 3-1, for their fifth straight victory and their seventh without a setback against the Flatbushers.
Scoring five times in the eighth, Syracuse came from behind to score a 9-to-4 victory over the champion Bears tonight in the opening game of their series.

Although lacking the excitement of the coming Fourth of July holiday, the first cruise of "the floating hospital" of the St. John's Guild brought pleasure and relief yesterday to more than 1,000 women and children from underprivileged homes in the congested areas of the city.
Mayor A. H. Ziegler stated at a special Council meeting today: "Any Ketchikan workman who wants to go to work at his job should be allowed to do so. It's our duty to see that he can, unmolested."

No disciplinary action is to be taken against Municipal Court Justices John O'Rourke and Arthur P. McNulty and Francis V. Goggins, attorney, because of their connection With the Gerson name-changing incident, the Appellate Division of the First and Second Departments decided yesterday.
The State Supreme Court ruled today that pedestrians have equal rights with automobiles on Pennsylvania highways along which there are no sidewalks.
Brought from the foot of Sandia Peak under State police escort, the body of Medill McCormick, 21-year-old heir to a Chicago publishing fortune, rested tonight in an Albuquerque mortuary.
The Cash Office of Foreign Credits at Budapest,, Hungary, has announced through the Schroder Trust.- Company, central paying agents here, that the office will redeem coupons dated July 1, 1938,

With the retirement of $2,000,000 bridge bonds by the State Sinking Fund Commission today New Jersey's net bonded indebtedness was reduced to $73,836,000, or about 40 per cent below the $116,000,000 peak of three and a half years ago.

Continuation of the Canadian Wheat Board and the fixing of a minimum price at a reasonable time for the 1938 crop was assured yesterday in the House of Commons by W. D. Euler, Trade Minister and chairman of the Cabinet Subcommittee on Wheat Marketing.

In a statement apparently intended to dispel any idea that the new uniform bank examination procedure involved a lowering of bank standards of investing and lending, William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks,

Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan reserved decision today on a motion by Burco, Inc., a Delaware corporation with its main offices here, to dismiss the temporary receiver appointed on June 14. Daniel T.
Greyhound, champion trotter, will launch his first attack on his world marks at Historic Track, July 14, when he attempts to lower the 1:594, record for half-mile tracks he set last year.

Mayor La Guardia, Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President, and other city officials congratulated 300 nurses who attended a breakfast at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park at 6 A. M. yesterday, given by the Hospital Division of the State, County, and Municipal Workers, ele C. I. O., to celebrate the first anniversary of the eight-hour day for nurses in city hospitals.
Only seven marriage licenses were issued in the five boroughs yesterday as the new State law requiring proof of freedom from venereal disease in communicable form went into effect.

The Rev. Dr. Aquilla Webb, pastor of the Central North Broad Street Presbyterian Church and former president of Washington College in Johnson City, Tenn., died today in the American Stomach Hospital after a month's illness. He was 68.

John W. Hanes, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission since December, was sworn in today as an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, the post to which he was nominated by President Roosevelt on May 11.

In the presence of a large number of blind guests representing French societies for the blind, William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, today presented to William Nelson Cromwell the first of a series of gold medals that will be awarded annually by the

The American entries again were successful today in the quarter-finals of the colorful Henley regatta, which ends tomorrow. Kent (Conn.) School and the Yale 150-pound crews came through against strong English competition, and tomorrow morning they will be pitted against each other in the semi-finals of the Thames Challenge Cup.

F. C. Hartley, staff captain of the Cunard liner Franconia, expressed vigorous resentment yesterday at the theme of the motion picture "ford Jeff," in which his youthful countryman, Freddie Bartholomew, appears.

Defeating Worcestershire by an innings and 18 runs, Yorkshire retained the lead in the English county cricket championship race today. Lancashire moved into second place ahead of the idle Middlesex eleven through a 10-wicket victory over Hampshire.

Universal labor conscription, as decreed by Field Marshal Hermann Goering as Commissioner for the Four-Year Plan, went into effect today, and German employers working on orders designated "especially important and unpostponable" were instructed to file their applications for conscript labor with local labor offices.

The Ministry of Economy has not yet completed drafting ordinances for enforcement of the government's recent anti-Jewish decrees. The decrees forecast elimination of Jews from public competition in business and the professions and provide for labeling their establishments as "nonAryan."
The adjournment of Congress and the new spirit of cooperation between government and business have been the chief contributors to the stabilizing of the stock market and the recent upswing in prices,

Playing with precision and power that would not be denied, Don Budge today made doubly sure of his place among the immortals of tennis with a crushing victory over Henry W. (Bunny) Austin which gave the American the Wimbledon singles championship for the second year in succession.

Norman Armour, United States Ambassador to Chile, and other speakers today explained the efforts of the Chile American Association to better conditions between Chile and the United States. Mr. Armour was the principal speaker at a luncheon in his honor.

Emptying shelves forced more retailers into the principal wholesale markets this week, giving a sudden uplift to volume, according to the weekly survey by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Consumer buying was generous, sending sales upward and cutting declines from a year ago.

Consolidation of the Motor Fuel, Milk and Beverage Tax Bureaus as separate organizations of the Department of Taxation and Finance into a new organization to be known as the Commodities Tax Bureau was announced today by Mark Graves, president of the State-Tax Commission.
Mrs. Isaiah Birks of Fisher Place, wife of a former prominent real estate dealer here, was drowned today in the spillway emptying into the Delaware River from Sanhican Creek at Perdicaris Place.

Commencement exercises tonight brought to a close the fourth resident session of the Graduate School of Banking at Rutgers University. Diplomas were awarded to 149 men in the second graduating class The in the second graduating class.

In an exceptionally. light turnover on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 4, member trading by members for their own account in round lots aggregated 21.38 per cent of total volume, compared with 16.14 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The initial effort of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to restore the original quiet of Coney Island, when it was surf, sand dunes and Summer homes fifty years ago, met a setback yesterday with the dismissal of complaints in Coney Island court against twenty-one concessionaires charged with violating the law in "barking" or shouting for customers.

Max Schmeling last night left Polyclinic Hospital, where he was a patient since his bout with Joe Louis, June 22. At 10:15 a private ambulance took him to the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line and he went on board at 10:30.
The big Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey circus was tucked into Winter quarters today under a broiling July sun, its 1938 tour cut short in Scranton, Pa., by a strike of roustabouts and laborers.

On the closing market weighty butchers and packing sows broke 15 to 25 cents today. Light hogs held up, the early top being $9.40. Activity continued in the cattle market and lambs held fully steady with best springer at $9.75. Choice medium weight steers topped at $11.25, the United States Department of Agriculture reported.

Dr. Homer W. Davis, president for the last eight years of Athens Greek-American College, Athens, Greece, and his wife, arrived home recently for their first vacation in their native land in three years.
Investors were active yesterday the purchase of housing properties in scattered sections of Manhattan.

Final arguments were made today before a Superior Court auditor in the breach of contract suit brought by a Boston insurance broker against the National Shawmut Bank on the grounds that $31,750 in commissions went to a firm allied with James Roosevelt instead of to himself. The case was then taken Under advisement.

Continuing her excellent play, Miss Josephine Sanfilippo of Brooklyn, defending girls' metropolitan tennis champion in singles and doubles, yesterday advanced to the final of both divisions at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Melville W. Taylor, formerly with Wm. A. White Sons, the Cross Brown Company and for the last six years assistant to Kenneth L. Jeffery, agent of the Woolworth Building, has been elected vice president of Ellen Jeffery, Inc.,

It was some luncheon! It was so big that Gene Tunney had to take his coat off to work on it. A cold salmon as long as a sailfish. A baked sea bass as big as a right whale. A mixed salad as large as a load of fresh alfalfa. Six kinds Of cheese. A different vintage of Rheinwein with each course. One was Schloss this or that and another was Something-berger Auslese.

The Hundred Neediest Cases Fund of THE NEW YORK TIMES is to receive one-half of the residuary estate of Ida Bonesteel, who was president of the Lotus Study Club of Brooklyn, according to a transfer tax appraisal report filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that it had taken over the business and assumed the liabilities of its former subsidiary, the United Aircraft Exports Corporation, and that it would be conducted as a division of the company.
Captain Zachariah H. Madison, U. S. N., retired, who served as naval adviser to the pre-World War Peace Commission and to the postwar reparations committee, died here yesterday. He was 62 years old.

After almost six months of negotiations, the conclusion of a treaty between France and Turkey was formally announced today by. Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet and Suad Davaz, the .Turkish Ambassador, settling the status of the Sanjak [district] of Alexandretta and preparing the way for the signature of a treaty of friendship between the two countries that will be signed in Angora by M. Bonnet himself probably in September.
President Federico Laredo Bru today signed a decree declaring July 4 as the next official holiday as part of a demonstration of friendship toward the United States to be staged here.

After several futile attempts to marshal Its twelve members, the Joint Congressional-Departmental Committee to study monopoly and the concentration of economic power organized today and laid out a preliminary plan of activity. This did not touch, however, on what industries should be investigated.

Miss Ruth Wyckoff Emmons, daughter of Mrs. C. Arthur Emmons of this place, was married here this afternoon in First Baptist Church to Anthony Eric Peters of Monroe, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl F. Peters of Mount Holly.

" Get a Horse" has been placed on Metro's Summer schedule as a vehicle for Wallace Beery and Dennis O'Keefe. A comedy drama by Herman Mankiewicz and Albert H; Levine, it probably will supplant "Stablemates" on Beery's program.

A luncheon and private inspection of the renovated liner Pan America was held on the ship at her Brooklyn pier yesterday on the eve of her first sailing for South America under the receivership of Roscoe H. Hupper.

Private gold hoarding in Europe cut down shipments of the metal to the United States to $2,827.027 in the week ended on June 24. Two weeks previously the amount was $32,129,019. The only large shipment last week was $1,240.000 from India.

Trading was generally fair to good. The lamb market and fresh pork cuts were strong to slightly higher, veal slightly stronger. Salesmen were asking 50c-$1 more for steer hinds and ribs, and steer cuts were strong to $1 higher. Other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be strong to higher and other classes sharply higher. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

The Treasury paid a higher interest rate today in marketing an offering of $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day discount bills, dated July 6 and maturing on Oct. 5, the average price representing 0.023 per cent, compared with the low of 0.011 per cent obtained for an offering of similar size and maturing on last Monday.

A cable from the Royal Northern Yacht Squadron of Glasgow to the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club today states that the new English-built six-meter yacht Solenta, owned by Eldon and Kenneth. Trimingham, has been selected officially without further trials to represent Great Britain in the races for the Scandinavian Gold Cup on Long Island Sound this Summer.
Holding the Bees scoreless except for Pinchhitter Harl Maggert's homer, Philadelphia took a double-header from the Boston Bees today, 4-1 and 5-0.
Miss Harriet Jane Brady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Samuel Brady of this place, was married to Sherwood Munhall Bonney this afternoon in the Brady home.

The battle for control of: Spain's rich Eastern -coast developed in intensity tonight after a forenoon of comparative calm with Insurgents hammering their way through Bechi village, just south of the Mijares River.

Machinery for registration of unemployed workers in the financial district was set up yesterday by a Special committee of the New York Stock Exchange headed by Robert P. Boylan It will concern itself only with employes of member firms in the metropolitan area who have lost jobs since Jan. 1, 1937, and who have had twelve consecutive months of employment, either before or since that date.

Claude Bragdon's autobiography, "More Lives Than One," is sched uled for publication by Knopf on Aug. 1. Mr. Bragdon, the first American author on Knopf's list, has written books in four categories-architecture, stage design, literature and the study of the occult, and he is author of "Architecture and Democracy,"

Making the best showing since the Easter period, department store sales here this week came within striking distance of the, comparative 1937 figures. Executives estimated the week's sales volume as averaging only 2 per cent under last year, despite a reduction in the price level of between 6 and 7 per cent.

After a fortnight's absence Opposition members, who left the Chamber of Deputies as a protest against the government's methods, returned yesterday to close the debate on the reply to the speech from the throne..

Reluctant to accept business at recent quotations, most mills yesterday withdrew prices on acetate greige goods and the market prepared for higher quotations when the lines are reinstated early next week.

The earth today is so spotted with fever blisters that only the most conspicuous attract notice. If all eyes had not been glued on Europe during recent months, more attention would have been paid to that inflamed appendix of Europe that lies east and south of the Mediterranean.

Mrs. Katharine Van Duzar Balfour, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Bates Lawrence of this place, was married today to William Arthur Bostwick Jr., son of Mrs. Bostwick of Bronxville and the late Mr. Bostwick, at the home of her parents here.

A protest was made by former Conservative Prime Minister R. B. Bennett in Parliament today against the Canadian Government's alleged willingness to permit the construction of "a military road" to Alaska for "an alien" when it refused to allow the British Government to establish military flying schools in Canada.

The reasons given by the Federal Communications Commission for refusing on April 26 to grant the general 15 per cent rate increase asked by all domestic telegraph companies were made known here today in a long report on the case, accompanied by the dissenting opinion of Commissioner T. A. M. Craven, in which Commissioner Case concurred.

Unanimous opposition to the adoption by the Constitutional Convention of an amendment which would create a State compulsory automobile accident insurance system similar in detail to the existing workmen's compensation plan was voted here today at the opening session of the annual two-day convention of the New York State Bar Association.
John L. Lewis re-emphasized his position today against wage reductions in industry. "The C. I. O. stands with President Roosevelt in opposition to wage cuts,"

Admiral William D. Leahy, chief of naval operations, approved today as Acting Secretary of the Navy the redistribution of officers of the Marine Corps, as provided for in the new Navy and Marine Personnel Law passed in the last session of Congress.

France continued her drastic counter-espionage drive today by creating a new body of special mobile police to reinforce the Surete National and reestablishing a special Surete Department to watch over the country's 3.000.000 foreigners.
After defying an anti-picketing injunction for forty-eight hours, two C. I. O. unions agreed yesterday to cease picketing stores of the Busch Jewelry Company, Inc., and two subsidiaries.

Sagamore Holdings,Inc, Samuel Gersten, president, sold to Joseph Erdos 104-106 E 4th St, at a price shown as $14,000 over a mortgagee for $41,000 and took back a purchase money mortgage for $4,000, 6 per cent.

Alcaeus Hooper, Mayor of Baltimore in the late Eighteen Nineties, died early this morning in his home here at the age of 79. He had retired from public life more than twenty years ago and for several years had been in failing health.

Substantial increases in all important items were shown in the condition statements of local banks and trust companies for June 30, which were issued yesterday. Deposits and total assets of the banks were sharply up from the figures

The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Justice Leopold Prince, will give the first of a series of concerts on the Central Park Mall this evening at 8:30 o'clock. Pearl Bernan, violinist, will be soloist.

It took a long time to do it, but the jinx that usually stalks a medalist in golf finally caught up with William Granbery, Nashville (Tenn.) redhead, in the Eastern interscholastic championship at the Greenwich Country Club today.

With about the finest sailing breeze of the Summer, sixty-nine craft took part in the Long Island Sound championship regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club today and the two new 12-meter sloops had a duel of their own over 14.7 miles.
Memphis, Tenn., will be in the market on Aug. 9 with $825,000 of public improvement bonds. The issue will be dated Aug. 1, 1938, and will mature serially from Aug. 1, 1939 to 1968.

The stock markets were quiet today. Some sections were affected by profit-taking, but prices recovered by the close. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, while in the idle foreign bond section German and Austrian issues advanced on news of the Austrian debt settlement.
Secretary Ickes awarded today to the Graybar Electric Company of New York on its bid of $105,872.75 a contract for piles for the Seminoe Dam power line on the Kendrick project in Wyoming.

Unless there is a widespread epidemic or catastrophe, the lowest death rate on record among the millions of industrial policyholders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will be recorded in 1938, according to company statisticians.

Miss Beatrice Willing Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Stuart Patterson of this city and of Duneside, Southampton, L. I., where the family is now staying, is to be married the middle of August to Rodman Wanamaker 2d of this city and New York, son of the late Thomas B. Wanamaker and of the late Mrs. Archibald G. Thomson. The ceremony will be performed at Duneside.

After an unimpressive performance in the open hunter class, Prince Charming II came back today to gain a second leg on the Bedford Challenge Cup, the chief trophy in competition at the second day of the fifteenth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam will sail for Plymouth, Boulogne and Rotterdam today with 1,200 passengers, her largest list since her maiden voyage in May. Among them will be Lillian Gish, Ben Lyon,

The Philadelphia National League grounds, at whose home plate have stood all the great players of the senior circuit in the last fifty-one years, was abandoned by the Phils today in favor of Shibe Park, the home of the American League Athletics.

The weather jinx is still hounding Lewisohn Stadium. Last night the Philharmonic-Symphony, Jose Iturbi and a smallish body of hardy music-lovers were driven to the shelter of the Great Hall of the College of the City of New York, and had just about disposed themselves comfortably when the rain stopped.
Distributions totaling $18,343 are being made by Daniel W. Blumenthal, trustee for various mortgage certificate issues, to holders as follows:

The directors of the United Corporation, a superpower system whose securities were sold in the 1929 era by the J. P. Morgan Co., Drexel Co. and Bonbright Co. interests, asked its stockholders yesterday for authority to write off losses of $434,130,478 in the stock market.

In sympathy with a further upward movement in the stock market and relative strength of quotations in Liverpool, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange rose yesterday more than $1 a bale to close at the top with gains of 21 to 23 points.

The Veterans of Foreign Wars voted at the State convention today to admit women to membership if qualifications of overseas service were satisfactory. The resolution, adopted unanimously, is to be sent to the national encampment for its consideration.
Three city firemen received awards yesterday from the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York in recognition of rescues they had made during the past year.
Herman Chivian, lawyer and member of the executive board of the American Jewish Congress, died today in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, of a heart ailment. He was 39 years old.

Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, has written to Martin Saxe, chairman of the taxation committee of the Constitutional Convention, generally commending the article on taxation reported by the committee to the convention.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor of Greenwich,-who have been at Mayfair House, are sailing today on the Nieuw Amsterdam. They will return from Europe in September. Mrs. John A. Griswold of Saranac Lake is at the Sherry-Netherland.

The Public Service Commission of New York granted authority yesterday to the Rochester Gas -and Electric Corporation to issue not to exceed $1,657,000 of general mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series .I, due on Sept. 1, 1967.

While Prince Bertil of Sweden made known yesterday that he would definitely complete his father's scheduled tercentenary tour to Minneapolis, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf said in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centre that he was "terribly keen" to take part in the program to whatever extent his doctors would permit.

Mr. and Mrs. John Mortimer Schiff were hosts tonight at a "blue-andwhite" dance at Northwood, their Summer home on Sandy Hill, after several dinners at the homes of the younger married set of the North Shore colonies.
The problems growing out of realty bond defaults in New York appear to be growing steadily less acute, and reorganization work has proceeded much further than most persons realize.
J. E. F. de Kok, managing director of the Royal Dutch Oil Company, frustrated. a War Office plan by buying the vast and beautiful Ypenburg . Airdrome, near here.

The Federal Trade Commission today announced that the Soft-Lite Lens Company, Inc., of 745 Fifth Avenue, New York City, has been ordered to cease and desist certain practices held to violate the "exclusive dealing" section of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.
Houses in the Bronx that have owner; been renovated recently proved attractive to buyers in deals reported yesterday.
The new Nurse Practice Law went into operation yesterday with more than 12,000 applications on file with the State Board of Nurse Examiners at Albany.

Payrolls of the steel industry in May amounted to $46,757,000, about 2.2 per cent less than the $47,809,000 reported for April, compared to $92,931,000 in May, 1937, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Steel output declined 6.1 per cent from April to May, 1938.
Independence Day sermons will be preached in the city's churches tomorrow. Lessons will be drawn from the National Education Association's annual convention held this week in the metropolis.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Frank W. Earnest Jr. has been re-elected president of Anthracite Industries, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Other officers re-elected were G. Gordon Cook, vice president and treasurer, and George W.

Aged men spoke to a throng in the rain to the sound of saluting guns this afternoon on the seventy-fifth anniversary of the first day of the Battle of Gettysburg. They spoke of old war and present peace, and those who listened here applauded.

The United States has now prospective aggregate wheat crop of 979,000,000 bushels, which, if it materializes, will be the second largest yield on record, it was estimated today by leading local statisticians.

A military court today completed the six-day trial of twenty-two minor leaders of. the Fascist Iron Guard, whose supreme head, Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, was recently sentenced to forced labor for a ten-year term.

Because it was the first time in months that he had referred, even indirectly, to the problem of balancing the budget, it was encouraging when the President remarked last week that the Administration is studying methods of taxation with a view. to liquidating the $20,000,000,000 of-public debt piled up since 1933.

Criticism of the New Deal, with the label "Looking Forward," has begun to appear .in the press under the auspices of the Republican National Committee. The old Republican machine has been turned over to a relative youngster to tinker with, and the tinkering is already showing signs of bearing fruit.

Miss Marjorie Motley, daughter of Edward Preble Motley of Longham, Hamilton, and Mrs. Fremont Motley of New York, became the bride this afternoon of Herbert Jaques Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaques of Boston and Eastham, in Christ Church, Hamilton. The Rev. William F. A. Stride, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Rambler roses and other garden flowers provided an effective floral background for the marriage at noon today of Miss Betsey Tobey Luscombe to James Fletcher Chace, captain and stroke of this year's Harvard crew, which took place here in the Church of the Messiah.

SOUTHAMPTON.--So many varied celebrations have been crowded into this week-end that the Independence Day holiday is the gayest Southampton has seen for several seasons. Nearly every estate throughout the colony has its influx of out-of-town visitors for the occasion and a round of entertaining has already ushered in. the formal opening of the Summer.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Abbott Conley of Morristown, N. J., gave a reception here today at their Summer home at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Blake Conley, to Alexander Pyott Spence Jr., son of Mrs. Alexander Pyott Spence of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr. Spence.

An audience surprisingly large for a holiday week-end went last night to the Lewisohn Stadium to hear the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra give an all-French program under the direction of Alexander Smallens.

THREE of the six albums in Victor's current list contain concertos for violin and orchestra. It is both significant and refreshing to find not only that all these are domestic recordings, but two of them were made by the original soloists and orchestras within a week of their first American performances.

THE Bache Collection completed its first season on June 25. Since the opening of the collection to the public on Nov. 16, 1937, more than 22,000 letters of application. to visit the museum have been received, and more than 31,000 people visited the collection.
Carl Hubbell, who had experienced quite a time 'annexing his 200th victory in the National League, had no trouble at all starting his third hundred yesterday once he found his way to Ebbets Field.

Building costs are not likely to be reduced, perhaps for some time to come, and existing prices may show an increase in the near future, states the current issue of News Opinion, published by the Building Trades Employers Association of, New York City.

THE lady of the title is no lady. She is a 1930 bootlegger, with piracy ambitions. You don't need to believe that she is the brains of a mob of New York gangsters if you don't want to, because the whole story is consistently incredible, but entertaining for all that. Nan had already been

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Otto Borchers of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Borchers, to Archibald William Baird, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Baird of Schenectady, N. Y.

When the Works Progress Administration announced last week that the wages of 500,000 relief workers would be raised $4 to $11 a month in thirteen States, it was noted that the increases were highest in the States of Kentucky and Oklahoma, in both of which New Deal candidates for the Senate are engaged in stiff primary contests.

The holiday week-end here finds intense activity as final preparations are being made for the opening of the July furniture buyers' market on Tuesday. Predictions are that it will be an active market, with attendance and number of exhibitors eclipsing former records.

ACKERMAN-DRACHMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Morris Drachman of 1,839 Loring Place, Bronx, announce the marriage of their daughter, Dorothy, to Mr. John Ackerraan on Friday, July 1, 1938. ADLER-ROSS-Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Ross, 334 West 86th St., announce the marriage of their daughter, Beatrice, to Mr. Ben Adler, June 30.
Cleveland's pennant-hungry fans tomorrow will see members of the city's two greatest baseball teams of the past in a nine-inning game.

Five contracts were awarded by the Navy Department today for projectiles for use on ships recently commissioned. One went to an army arsenal and the rest to private concerns for a total of $2,584,400. The number and types of projectiles were not made public.

Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange have set up a "committee of replacement," whose function is to help unemployed financial workers find jobs. Last week the committee issued a report on Wall Street unemployment. Figures, compiled from data

Mrs. Theresa Osgood, widow of Henry Osborne Osgood, music critic, editor and author, died last night at the home of a friend here of a heart attack. She was 65 years old and lived at 612 West 137th Street, New York. Mrs. Osgood,

Governor A. B. Chandler said today he would be an "uninvited guest" of President Roosevelt next Friday when the President reaches Kentucky to speak in behalf of Senator Alben W. Barkley, the Governor's rival in a Democratic Senatorial primary.
