Algoma Steel Corporation, Ltd.-Year ended April 30: Net income, $641,255, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.30 a share on 407,540 common shares, compared with $189,922, or 19 cents a share, in preceding year.

The Anglo-German trade and financial agreement and the favorable echo it produced in London financial quarters are welcomed in Germany. There is the greatest satisfaction because of its economic as well as its political implications.

After it modified the terms of a resolution from the Nassau County Council, V. F. W., which "condemned" the action of President Roosevelt in permitting refugees to come to this country, so that the word "disapproved" was used instead, the State Encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars adopted a resolution of disapproval. Previously the resolutions committee had rejected the resolution.
Albert W. Morgan, 94-year-old veteran of the Civil War, who was grand marshal of the New York Memorial Day parade in 1935, died Friday night in his home, 362 Wadsworth Avenue.

Henry G. Smith, president of the Clement National Bank of this city, and Mrs. Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Morris Smith, to Frank Murray Gale of New York, son of Mrs. Jane M. Gale of New York and the late Arthur Murray Gale.

General G. S. Lushkoff, reported chief of the Far Eastern secret police, escaped to Manchukuo from Siberia on June 13 because he feared he would be taken to Moscow and shot, according to his diary, which was published in Tokyo newspapers.

The marriage of Miss Muriel Maria Gerli, daughter of Mrs. Emanuel Gerli of New York and Greenwich and the late Mr. Gerli, to Nelson Macy Jr., son of Mr. Macy of Greenwich and the late Mrs. Edith Virginia Brander Matthews Macy, took place here this afternoon in Christ Church.

AS the Metropolitan Opera House slips into its midsummer tranquillity this week when even the box office closes for July and August and only a skeleton staff remains in the managerial offices to deal with immediate pressing problems-the news percolates through that arrangements for next season's poetseason tour are virtually

Tomorrow night, Fourth of July eve, marks the 102d anniversary of New Jersey's bitterest college feud, the Rutgers-Princeton cannon war. Renewed yearly for more than a century, the traditional struggle took on a new vigor last Fall at the Rutgers-Princeton football game.
THE remark that Dickens was the son of Mr. Micawber and Mrs. Nickleby can scarcely be better illustrated than by two letters in the Comte de Suzannet collection.
One of the largest crowds ever seen on a pier in New York gathered before noon yesterday to bid bon voyage to 1,725 passengers sailing on the Italian liner Rex.

With reductions of prices of principal steel products scarcely a week old, the fact that they were accompanied by the scrapping of the fourteen-year-old price differential system at principal basing points has thrown into confusion virtually all interests affected.

Coming from last place in a field of eleven, the 6-year-old horse Preeminent, home-bred color bearer of Hal Price Headley, yesterday captured the $7,580 Fleetwing Handicap before 12,000 persons at Empire City. Nick Wall, fresh from his

All the Summer homes here have now been opened. Among the colonists who will entertain over the week-end are Mr. and Mrs. Philo W. Parker of New York, who are occupying the residence here of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Rice of Schenectady.

One big reason why the Spanish Insurgents are not in Barcelona today is to be found in the three small frontier towns of Cerbere, Latour de Carol and Le Perthus in this French Department of the Oriental Pyrenees, which adjoins Republican Spain.

RADIO'S unending cavalcade, which has been winding around the clock and out across the wave lengths since the midnight bands serenaded 1938 six months ago, has reached the reviewing stand at the half-way mark.

BERLIN. AMERICANS were the first to decide that automobiles belong to the "little man's" household just as much as the electric vacuum cleaner and the radio. Now Hitler has decided that the Germans are to be the second on the list of peoples who no longer put bankers' salaries and motor cars in the same class.

Last week witnessed a group of remarkable performances by the gliding pilots assembled for the ninth annual contest of the Soaring Society of America at Harris Hill, in the now excellently developed Warren E. Eaton memorial site above the Chemung at Elmira.
Miss Cornelia Drummond Ferguson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Minter Ferguson of this city was married this evening in the home of her parents, to Wilson McMaster Underwood of Sunnyside,
Mr. and Mrs. Ovid Montague Johnson of Wytheville, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Glenn Johnson, to Orja Glenwood Corns Jr. of New York and Wilmette, Ill.

Homer J. Van Duyne, Tax Receiver of Newark from 1921 to 1933 and since then an insurance broker with offices at 20 Clinton Street, ended his life today by inhaling gas in the basement of his home at 88 Mountain View Place. He was 47 years old.
Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Boettiger, daughter of President Roosevelt, said here tonight, "I don't think father will run for another term."

A Westchester Youth Aliyah Fete for the benefit of European refugee children will be conducted here on the evenings of July 16, 17 and 18 by the Westchester Hadassah at the estate on California Road of Harry M. Warner, executive of Warner Brothers Pictures.

A six-week Summer session will begin on Wednesday at the new Hamilton College of Commerce, Paterson Plankroad at Summit Avenue. The college has been organized by local teachers, businessmen and professional men to provide a liberal, college-standard business schooling for graduates of accredited secondary schools.
With the opening of the play schools this week comes a new "Handbook for Summer Play Schools of New York City," published by the WPA Summer School Program in cooperation with the Board of Education.

Kent School defeated Yale's 150-pound crew and went on to win the prized Thames Challenge Cup by conquering the London Rowing Club in the final as the four-day Royal Henley Regatta came to a close this afternoon.
Three women lieutenants in the Soviet air force flew a seaplane 1,498 miles nonstop across Russia today in ten hours 33 minutes.

The sale and discharge of fireworks are prohibited again this year by ordinances in the four cities and most of the eighteen townships of Westchester County, but there was no shortage today of noisemakers in any community.

Edgar H. Wells, head of E. H. Wells Co., rare book dealers, 602 Madison Avenue, New York, and former acting dean of Harvard College, died here today in the private hospital, Four Winds, after a long illness of heart disease. He was 63 years old.

Formation of a national associaLion of biologists was announced yesterday by Dr. Oscar Riddle of Carnegie Institute. Representatives of thirty-four State societies develat the program at the Hotel New Yorker Friday and yesterday.
Many power projects have been carried out over the protest of sport and commercial fishermen when the proponents of these projects agreed to construct fishways, or fish ladders, at the dams.

Four employment bureaus maintained by the Young Women's Christian Association place 38 per cent, of the women who get jobs in this city through the thirty private, nonprofit employment agencies, the association announced yesterday after an analysis of reports by the State Employment Service.
Dividends declared in June represented the smallest amount for that month since 1935. Payments of

The Architectural League of New York will receive between $40,000 and $50,000 under the will of Emma B. Brunner to carry out the wishes expressed by her husband, Arnold W. Brunner, one-time president of the league, before his death in 1925.
REPORTER: A comparative report on conditions within Russia was made last week by New Yorker Corliss Lamont, chairman of the American Friends of the Soviet Union.

HE title of Peter Freuchen's new book is a misnomer. It is not "all" adventure. His idea is sound, for to a man who had lived in Greenland for eighteen years, as he did, the return to civilization and the difficulties of adapting oneself to its complexities presented situations which to Mr. Freuchen were not only novel but almost frightening. But to most of us such experiences are not uncommon.
Brazil set in June a new high record for coffee exports, with 1,581,569 bags. The previous high mark was in June, 1931, when 1,512,629 bags were shipped.

Unemployment in the second quarter of this year, compared with the same period in 1937, increased in all of the great democracies but decreased more than one-half in Germany and 15 per cent in Japan, according to the International Labor Office quarterly report which was published today.

THOUGH few things offer so much tedium to the spectator as comedy getting itself made piecemeal through weeks and months in a studio, affairs on a Harold Lloyd set often take a sprightly turn. When we drifted in we found the stage full of cattle, whose bellowings and

The engagement of Miss Ann Elizabeth Frederickson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto A. Frederickson of Glen Ridge, to Lee J. Lobdell of Houston, Texas, son of Mr. Frederick Lobdell of Paterson, has been announced.

A $1,525,000 first-mortgage loan at 4 per cent on the thirteen-story apartment house at 1.060 Fifth Avenue, corner of Eighty-seventh Street, has been obtained from the Metropolitan Life Insruance Company by the 1,060 Fifth Avenue Corporation, owner of the structure, it was learned yesterday.

The lag in marriage license; applications, which set in Friday when the State's new law took effect requiring proof of freedom from a venereal disease in' communicable form, continued yesterday, only five couples, armed with the necessary medical certificates, obtaining licenses in Manhattan.

Frank O'Hara of Jackson Heights, L. I., president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, who recently returned from a tour of the southern section of New York State, reported yesterday that many real estate brokers there told him they were experiencing more activity this season than last year.

An interesting project in apartment house construction designed to give occupants all the advantages of a private home and yet permit them to be free of the work entailed in maintaining a home has been started on a plot of more than an acre in size on Norwood Avenue, Summit, N. J.

In the First Methodist Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Helen Torrey Grant, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Edward Grant, was married to Dr. Leslie Homer Backus of Gloversville. The Rev. Oliver Warren performed the ceremony.
PART-TIME guest reporter for this week is Commander Van Dierendonck, captain of this ship, who has kindly consented to lecture on route

A Bastille Day dinner dance will be given at the Atlantic Beach Club here on July 14 to aid the maintenance of Roosevelt House, birthplace of President Theodore Roosevelt at 28 East Twentieth Street, New York, and to assist the educational work conducted at that historic landmark.
IN three hundred years of writing about him (for he is one of the most fascinating, because hitherto perplexing, figures in history), Wallenstein has been treated, as a rule, from a warped viewpoint.

Six occupants of an automobile were killed this afternoon when the machine was struck by a high-speed trolley train of two cars on a grade crossing at Brick Tavern, on the Old Bethlehem Pike, two miles north of this place.
The Spanish Insurgents, blocked at least temporarily along the - Eastern front, made a new thrust today in the Catalonian Pyrenees.

The current rebound in activity in a number of consumer goods lines has spurred the demand for various types of industrial chemicals going into the manufacture of such products, according to manufacturers yesterday.

WASHINGTON.-After years of study and investigation by Congress and Federal officials, the Seventy-fifth Congress, as one of its final acts, passed a new Food and Drug Law which invests in the United States Government control not only over foods and drugs but,

Soaring pilots made distance flights today but without approaching any records. Chester J. Decker of Glen Rock, N. J., soared to WilkesBarre, Pa., seventy-eight miles, five hours. Peter Riedel of Germany reached Harrisburg, 130 miles, in five hours.

TOKYO. AMONG the people of Japan the United States today is probably the most popular of all foreign powers. A quick glance at Japan might not bear out this fact. In Tokyo, for instance, there is evidence everywhere of the Japanese friendship for Italy and Germany.

Miss Claire G. Gorman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. B. Gorman of Englewood, was married this afternoon to James C. Phelps of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Phelps, also of this place, at the First Presbyterian Church of Tenafly. The Rev.

Mrs. Marguerite Worthey, granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Harrison of Chicago, was married to Wallace Collister Johnson of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis Edgar Johnson of East Orange, this afternoon in the chapel of the Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

A strike kept twenty-seven buses of the Royal Blue Line Sightseeing Corporation in their garages yesterday while hundreds of out-of-town visitors, bent on trips to Chinatown, the Bowery and "other points of interest," cooled their heels on hotel steps.

Miss Elizabeth Vandermark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Altheus Vandermark of this village, and Neul Quisenberry of Mineola, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Quisenberry of Fredericks Hall, Va., were married this afternoon in the Dutch Reformed Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Albert D. B. Deyo.

The largest Federal tax collection since 1920 was reported for Connecticut today by Thomas S. Smith, Internal Revenue Collector. Receipts for the fiscal year ending June 30 totaled $96,005,113, as against $74,832,834 for the preceding year.

Senator Sherman Minton, Democrat of Indiana, a strong supporter of the NeW Deal, 'said today 'that' neither President Roosevelt nor- his chief political adviser, Postmaster General Farley, would attempt to block a rapidly spreading movement among Hoosier Degmocrats to renominate his'senior 'colleague, Senator Frederick Van Nuys, at the:party's State convention here July 12.
The Treasury report today indicated that the public debt rose in the fiscal year to an average of $285.70 for every man, woman and child in the nation.

To provide additional shopping facilities for the rapidly increasing residential population in and around Manhasset, L. I., the Robel Realty Company of Brooklyn has purchased a business plot fronting 175 feet on Northern Boulevard for the immediate construction of a taxpayer building containing eight stores.

THIS is the county fair in its blue-serge suit, wet socks and dusty shoes, reproduced in candid pictures and slow-wrought but natural seeming chatter by Phil Stong. Stong grew up, the son of a storekeeper, in Iowa and has made. a specialty of county fairs.
Robert A. Lincoln, son of Mrs. Louise A. Lincoln of 5 Prospect Place, Tudor City, New York, has been elected editor-in-chief of The Peddie News, student newspaper at Peddie School here.

The committee on administrative law of the New York Bar Association, which is holding its midsummer convention here, today urged the association members to go on record as favoring the incorporation of an amendment in the new State Constitution which would provide for judicial review of administrative decisions by governmental department, bureau or agency heads.

THE United States tennis sweep at Wimbledon was devastating. Don Budge is monarch of all he surveys and, in the course of the past year, he has surveyed considerable tennis territory all the way from Merrie England to Australia and return.

True to the heritage of his Finnish ancestry, Eino Pentti of the Millrose A. A. won the National 10,000-meter championship in wind-swept Civic Stadium today. It was the lone senior event on the program as the junior title tests opened the fiftieth annual National A. A. U. track and field show.

A Constitutional Convention hearing next week on the controversial relief question promises a hint on the extent of Mayor La Guardia's ex-. pected opposition to Governor Lehman's bid for a United States Senate. seat.

Plans for a great gathering of the youth of the world at Vassar College from Aug. 15 to Aug. 24 are nearing completion with representatives of fifty-two nations scheduled to respond to the invitation extended by President Henry Noble MacCracken and the board of trustees of the college.

Mr. Roosevelt said in his address before the National Educational Association in New York on Thursday, "There is probably a wider divergence today in the standard of education between the richest communities and the poorest communities than there was 100 years ago."

The Admiralty, War Office and Air Ministry announce that a combined operations exercise will be carried out in the English Channel between July 5 and July 10 with the object of practicing a surprise landing in "hostile territory."
FOURTEEN round-trip flights, under conditions approximating actual air-mail service across the North Atlantic, are planned by Deutsche Lufthansa for the coming season.

A year of war in China has lost to Japan the fruits of her economic achievements during the previous seen years. Her financial structure is in an alarming state. Her well-to-do classes, never numerous, are threatened with expropriation, while the living standards of her population, always low, are sinking lower.

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on June 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics has announced. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 78.2, compared with 78.4 on June 18 and 86.7 on June 26, 1937.
The Workers Alliance, since 1936 a national organization of the employed, entered the news picture last week by receiving some advice it hardly needed.
The victory of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody over Miss Helen Jacobs at Wimbledon yesterday brought to a successful culmination the second big comeback in the career of this unparalleled woman tennis player.
XCEPT that they are all romantic, all delicately and gracefully written, there is really little kinship between Norah Lofts's four novels.

Although the textile industry is one of the largest in the country and at the same time one of the least integrated, the numerous handicaps to effective vertical integration in the field were revealed last week with publication of a two-year study by the industrial research department of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennyslvania.

A 17-YEAR-OLD BOY leaned moping over a gate in Quincy, Ill., nearly pone hundred years ago. He wished he were home in Virginia, away from these God-forsaken prairies and, above all, away from Uncle Andrew's dreary law books He didn't want to be a lawyer. He wanted to be like his four cousins, but his peppery uncle had said "no" in more different ways than. one would have thought possible.

George J. Gillespie Jr. won the medal in the qualifying round of the New York A. C. Fourth of July week-end tournament at the Hotel Champlain Golf Club today with a 38, 37-75. The scores of the championship division follow: Gillespie, 75-3-72;

Ask the first 100 Americans you meet today why the United States celebrates July 4 and about ninety of them will reply: "Because it's the anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence."

FIFTY years ago this Summer a sharp-eyed l0-year-old boy, Georgie Cohan by name, stepped off the branch railroad train here, and together with his parents and sister, his violin case and family trunks, he rode in
Under the honorary chairmanship of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, preliminary plans are now being made for the annual benefit entertainment sponsored by the New York Women's Trade Union League.

THE National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, D. C., will give another series of "Sunset Symphonies" this Summer at the Watergate on the Potomac near the Lincoln Memorial. The concerts will be presented every Wednesday and Sunday night from July 10 to Aug. 17.

While the hotel orchestra played "Spioke Gets in Your Eyes" and "Whistle While You Work," holiday crowds at this and other nearby resorts watched 125 firemen from Spring Lake, Belmar and Sea Girt fight a fire which destroyed the top floor and roof of the annex of the Hotel Warren here today, causing damage estimated at $10,000.

Secretary Hull rebuked critics of his trade agreements program in a letter published today. He declared that they would serve business and industry better by avoiding efforts to arouse "unwarranted and exaggerated fears" of damage from reduced tariffs.
TAUNO HANNIKAINEN, conductor of the orchestra of Turku, Finland, is a young man with the eye, the cheek and the bearing of an athlete.

THE conventional notice stating that all the characters in this book are wholly fictional and imaginary seems incredible-almost libelous. For this picture of an American family with its roots in San Francisco appears definitely biographical.
Mrs. Herman Reich, 50, of Nanticoke was directed today by Judge Thomas F. Farrell to furnish her unemployed husband with a room and $12 a month for clothes and meals.
Sir John Burnet, English representative on the committee of architects which designed the League of Nations building at Geneva, died here today at the age of 80.
Senator Tydings, in the first public statement of his re-election campaign, asserted today that a survey of "every county in the State" satisfied him that his renomination was assured.
AT last we have Simon Templar, otherwise known as the Saint, in the role of a hero without a single new stain on his already considerably spotted reputation.

HELEN HAYES and the "Victoria Regina" company have, as the historians say, made history. In a tour of forty-one weeks, which began last September in Hartford and wound up a week ago in Los Angeles, they set up box office records 'in all but two of the forty-five towns and cities in which they appeared.

The first Dunrovin music festival, given under the auspices of William Matheus Sullivan at the Dunrovin Theatre on his estate here, closed this afternoon with a Mozart program. The offerings consisted of scenes from that composer's operas, with the second act of "The Marriage of Figaro" as the chief presentation.

Voters of 179 municipalities in thirty-four States approved in June municipal bond issues aggregating $8,989,269, compared with $13,554,300 approved in May, according to the Daily Bond Buyer of New York.

Britain is again showing signs of impatience with Czechoslovakia over the minorities statute. This week Viscount Halifax, British Foreign Secretary, was again urging on Prague that it was time to produce something definite.

THE team-of-four event in the annual championship tournament at Asbury Park, N. J., which begins Aug. 1, is no longer open to every one. For the first time this year it will be rated as a "masters'" tournament, and each team must include three players with ten or more master points each, and a fourth player with at least one master point.

When, if ever, Palestine's fate will be settled is again the question of the day here. New sporadic outbreaks and violence during the last week took toll of more than a dozen lives and, coupled with the hanging of a Jewish youth by sentence of a military court, disheartened all the more the already discouraged peace-loving elements of the populace.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity covered a fairly diversified list, including several entire issues of public utility bonds. The largest retirement was ordered for this month, although the majority of the notices was for payment in later months.

When Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Ward of Mount Vernon bought their house at 19 Esplanade eleven years ago it had a level stretch of lawn at one side and good turf and a nondescript assortment of shrubs in front.

With a further sharp rise yesterday in foreign quotations for cotton and a buoyant stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced into new high ground -of the last tWo months and ended with improvements of 11 to 13 points. All months moved above 9 cents a pound under the broadest buying movement since the recovery started a month ago.
Varied entertainments have been arranged in Berkshire resort towns for holiday visitors. These include five dances tonight and Independence Day luncheons at Lenox and Pittsfield Country Clubs.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Barrett of 812 Park Avenue and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Lois Barrett Edmonston, to Howard Ketcham, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Belden Ketcham of New York.

The former country estate at Southampton, L. I., of the late Morgan J. O'Brien, for many years presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, will be sold at auction Saturday, July 23, on the preamises by Joseph P. Day. Justice O'Brien died June 16, 1937, at the age of 85 years.

Cheered by the sharp reversal of business sentiment in the last two weeks and the upturn in conditions in a number of lines, large national advertisers will start preparing their Fall merchandising and advertising plans this week, they reported here yesterday.
THE Coffee bill and other bills regarding a proposed Federal Bureau of Fine Arts which came up last Spring for Congressional consideration were not received with sufficient favor to become law.

Mrs. Lena Salzman, widow of Nathan Salzman, Newark banker, died here today of a heart attack at her home, 77 South Munn Avenue. day Mrs. Salzman, who was 75 years Hill old, long had been active in Jewish philanthropies in Newark.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Mackenzie Isaacs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Isaacs of Westfield, to Thomas H. Wight Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Wight, also of this place, took place in the garden of the Isaacs residence here this afternoon.

WHEN the nation was younger -- forty years younger -- the mixing bowl was a common kitchen utensil. It was a big yellow bowl; into it went flour and milk, sugar and yeast, fat and salt-but something more.

About 12,000 students, including residents of Eastern and Western States and about 350 foreigners, will attend classes in more than 1,000 subjects at the thirty-ninth Summer session of Columbia University beginning Wednesday,

BEIRUT. OWING to the devaluation of French currency, Syrian stamps in values of 12-piastres and 20-pi are being issued, with a portrait of the President of the Syrian Republic as the design. Definitives in these

The crash of bombs on the decks of British freighters is echoing unpleasantly these days in all the admiralties of the world. For the shattered ships which, half-awash, litter Valencia Harbor are not alone ugly monuments to hew frightfulness in war. They also attest the increasing effectiveness of aerial blockade.

The Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Combined Shows, Inc., forced last week to take "the greatest show on earth" off the road because of labor troubles, was making plans yesterday to play an "ace in the hole" by shipping its star performers, best animals and much of its valuable equipment to the Al G. Barnes-Sells-Floto Circus, a Ringling subsidiary, for the remainder of the season.

With Union and Confederate veterans encamped at Gettysburg on the battle's seventy-fifth anniversary, the little-known story of Samuel Wilkeson, THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent who wrote the account of the battle seated beside the body of his son, has been recalled.

Charles Ulmer's Scylla captured the opening Star Class race in the series for the Hoxsie Trophy, conducted by the Harlem Yacht Club on Eastchester Bay yesterday. The course was four miles, with Scylla crossing the finish mark ten seconds ahead of George Dvorak's June II.

Announcement by the American Kennel Club of the admission to membership of the Maui Kennel Club of Hawaii brings attention once more to the vast territory now under the jurisdiction of the governing body of the sport of showing pure-bred dogs and the breeding industry.
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. William Watson Staplin of this place today at the Orange Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Staplin is the former Miss Florence Uptegrove Shepherd,

Dr. Janice Kice, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Luther H. Kice of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Dr. Raymond F. Smith, also of Garden City, which will take place here on July 20 in the Cathedral of the Incarnation. The Rev. Frederic F. Bush will perform the ceremony.

The indications are for fair weather with moderate temperatures today. Tomorrow will be mostly cloudy with moderate temperatures, probably followed by showers tomorrow night, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock, Eastern Standard Time, last night.

Having failed to restrain the Claremont Inn's late night-club noises through court action, residents of the neighborhood of River side Drive and 125th Street announced yesterday that they had taken the matter to the police.
A Southern Garden. Week is being sponsored.by the University.of North Carolina; in cooperation with Blue Ridge College, at Blue Ridge, N. C., during the -first week in August. William Lanier Hunt,

Two United States warships, the destroyer Edsall and gunboat Tulsa, were reported rushing to the South China port of Swatow today to take part in probable evacuation of all foreigners as a result of Japanese bombing attacks.

" Copperhead," the word used by President Roosevelt in his most recent fireside chat to describe those Americans who he believes wish to call a halt to reform, has its origin apparently in the days of the early English settlements.
Rug and carpet mills, opening Fall lines here and in Chicago on Tuesday, expect to make only a few minor price adjustments and tohold most quotations to Spring levels. The improved tone in business

Owing to errors in telegraphic transmission, an article on home. stead tax exemption appearing ir the realty news columns of THH NEW YORK TIMES on June 28 gave an incorrect summary of the status of homestead exemptions in various States. Correctly summarized,

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the NYPA NJ Utilities Company of the Associated Gas and Electric System for permission to acquire 3,000 shares of common stock of. the Bradford Electric Company, all the outstanding

July is the ideal month for climbing the Hudson River stairs and sitting on top of the world. Every cruising skipper knows this means a vacation voyage to Lake Champlain and prolonging the delight even if it means sending a telegram or two back to the boss' office and begging extensions of time.
Although it will be more,than sixty-eight years since he entered the old Scotch settlement school to nourish his mind and spirit on McGuffey readers, Henry Ford does not forget.

Bond interest paid June 1 by London Terrace, Inc., owning corporation of the London Terrace apartments on West Twenty-third Street, amounted to 2 1/2 per cent and represented semi-annual fixed interest at the rate of 3 per cent per annum and additional annual cumulative income interest at the rate of 1 per cent per annum, according to Seligman, Lubetkin Co., Inc., stockbrokers.

Three research projects in safe driving are being conducted at the Summer session at the Pennsylvania State College by Professor Amos E. Neyhart. He proposes to ascertain the possibilities of employing used cars in training drivers; how best to teach adults

N certain quarters given to hero worship it is believed that most of the nation's troubles would disappear if only Joe Cook would find a show and return to a Broadway that hasn't seen him Since "Hold Your Horses" in 1933..

The peak of the year's Summer travel season was reached last week when seventeen transatlantic liners sailed from New York on regular voyages carrying a total of 16,462 and four more sailed on special North Cape cruises with 1,431 passengers between them, making a grand total of 17,893 passengers who are now on the high seas bound for Europe.

Judge Louis R. Freund will speak on "Landlords and Tenancies" at a meeting of the Realtor Luncheon Club of the Real Estate Board of Newark on Thursday in Bamberger's Restaurant, Newark. Joel L. Schlesinger will preside.

With no snore effort than was required in submerging the fourthplace Senators yesterday, the Yankees vaulted within two games of the league-leading Indians before a gathering of 10,514 at the Stadium. And they encountered little trouble routing Washington, 12 to 2.
HAMBURG. TO the best of my knowledge Vittorio Giannini is the first musician since Walter Damrosch (about forty years ago) who has made an opera out of "The Scarlet Letter."
On the face of unofficial returns, Lewis E. Teague of High Point won the Democratic nomination for Congress from the Sixth District in a run-off primary today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. After stating the case for home build ing as the economic need of the country a writer in The Wall Street Journal re marks:

" If a chicken and a half laid an egg and a half in a day and a half, how many eggs would six chickens lay in seven days?" That was the question which caused the most mental anguish to 1,111 candidates for the forty-four vacancies on the State police force during and after the examination at the Wilburtha Training School on Wednesday.

When The Netherlands Government advised the United States Postoffice Department recently that the Dutch East Indies, Dutch Guiana and the Dutch West Indies would henceforth be known as The Netherlands Indies, Surinam and Curacao, respectively, it raised an old question-Why don't The Netherlanders want themselves and their possessions called Dutch?

A method of synthesizing sugar from formaldehyde, the antiseptic and deodorant, has just been patented (No. 2,121,981) by Eugene Albert Prudhomme of Kremlin-Bicetre, France. The patent is assigned to Carboxhyd, Ltd., of Geneva, Switzerland.

Among many notables of the entertainment world who sailed yesterday on the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam was Lillian Gish, who has just finished a long run in the Broadway hit, "Star Wagon." Miss Gish, who will spend six weeks resting in Czechoslovakia, said she had no plans for next season.

Miss Margaret Frothingham, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Lawrence P. Frothingham of this place, will be married here to Robinson Dudley Buck, son of Mrs. Henry Robinson Buck and the late Mr. Buck of M Hartford, on Aug. 20 in St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Michael Roy Barton.

Police Commissioner Valentine has issued a departmental order prohibiting the arrest of the finder of a firearm or other dangerous weapon unless an inquiry discloses reasons for questioning the finder's explanation, it was learned yesterday.

Miss Almira Jane Clark, who would have been 99 years old on Aug. 16, died Friday night after a short illness at the home of a niece, Mrs. Franklin J. Bowman of Madison Road, Scarsdale. She was born at what was then 81 East Third Street, New York, a daughter of Cornelius E. and Jane Barkley Wyckoff Clark.

High clothes poles in fitted closets from which evening gowns and wraps hang without dragging on the floor received commendation by women brokers who inspected the apartments in the new buildings at 3 East Sixty-ninth Street and 4 East Seventieth Street last week under

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Natalie Fuller, daughter of Mrs. Seymour Keyes Fuller of 25 Clark Street, Brooklyn, and Halesite, Huntington, L. I., and the late Mr. Fuller, to Richard Moulton Howland.

Never trailing at any time and coordinating well, J. C. (Cocie) Rathborne's unbeaten Pelicans conquered the Aiken Knights, 8 to 6, on the Hitchcock Field today for their second straight victory in the Brook League division of the Meadow Brook Club's tourney for twenty-goal polo teams.
The Japanese press says that General Kazushige Ugaki, Foreign Minister, is planning an extensive shake-up in the foreign office and diplomatic personnel plus certain revisions in the present system.

George W. Cavanaugh, Professor Emeritus of Chemistry at Cornell University, died during the night of heart disease. He was found dead in his home this morning just two days after his retirement from active teaching. His age was 68.

The operetta, "Three Waltzes," last night drew a near-capacity audience of 9,000 persons to the Jones Beach Stadium. At Randalls Island the musical comedy "ShowBoat," attracted a capacity crowd of,400 persons, while a few hundred others were turned away.

Federal relief expenditures in this city, which reached a peak of $28,000,000 in July, 1936, fell to $11,784,447 in May, 1938. A statistical bulletin issued by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, indicated the extent to which the National Government, by withdrawing its own funds, had shifted the

YALE and Harvard, seldom in conspicuous agreement about anything, last week surprised one another by conferring honorary degrees on the same three privileged persons: Baron Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada,
Stocks closed strong at the highest levels of current movement, with gains of 1 to 4 points in the largest Saturday's trading since Oct. 23; turnover, 1,472,420 shares.

Albert H. Hamilton, widely known as a ballistics and handwriting expert, died at his home here yesterday. His age was 79. Mr. Hamilton, a native of Weedsport, N. Y., started his career as a druggist, but was led into study of scientific criminology through his interest in chemical analysis

The Heckscher Building, twentyfive-story office skyscraper at 728-34 Fifth Avenue, 5-9 West Fifty-sixth Street and 2-4 West Fifty-seventh Street, will be offered at auction on Wednesday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

Miss Ruth Dorothea Frazer, whose grandfather, the late Major Daniel Maus Frazer, U. S. A., served as a surgeon under General Grant in the Civil War, was married here this afternoon to William Cairns Banta Jr., a descendant of Epke Jacobse
Joe E. Brown probably never before opened his mouth as wide as he did in astonishment today when a youthful hold-up man stuck a gun in his ribs and demanded that the actor hand over his money.

Miss Clare Raleigh, daughter of Mrs. Edward Jerome Raleigh of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Raleigh, was married to J. Ross Meehan of 1 Prospect Park West yesterday morning in the Church of St. Savious, Eighth Avenue and Sixth Street, Brooklyn, by the Rev. John Sexton of the church staff.

Miss Claire Rosamond Gaskell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lionel Gaskell of West Orange, and Henry A. Eddins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Eddins of Jewett, Texas, were married at noon today in the Ridgeview Community Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Oscar Raymond Lowry officiated.

From present indications, coat and suit volume for Fall will compare favorably with that of a year ago, Samuel Klein,executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc,, said in a statement issued yesterday. He reported that the openings

Omission of Governor Lehman as a candidate for the Senate seat made vacant by the death of Royal S. Copeland from the tentative slate of the American Labor party was deplored yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

AMERICAN NAMES: The Social Security Board reported last week on the names. in its records. There are 470,190 Smiths and 348,530 Johnsons. Browns, Williamses and Millers run over 200,000 each. The shortest name listed is E; the longest, Xenogianokopoulos.

AT the Metropolitan there is being held an exhibition illustrating one act in the vast performance conducted by WPA Adult Education Program. To those sensitive about. titles, Adult Education has a sinister sound, implying almost that we have come to a dead stop and are being provided for against our wills.

The stock market added yesterday another remarkable session to the vigorous advance that began on June 20. Share prices closed around the best levels of the day and of the fortnight's bull market, with leading issues up 1 to 4 points on the half day and up 2 to 10 points on the week.

Boardwalks at the city's oceanfront beaches may or may not be the proper place for wearing a bathing suit, depending on the location and strength of opposition voiced by indignant civic groups, it was larned yesterday.
The Reichsbank's statement as of July 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Preliminary steps were taken by the Navy Department today in its program of building experimental high-speed mosquito craft for use against submarines and surface craft when it announced that it would invite private builders to submit designs to see if they could improve on plans which the navy itself is preparing for the boats.

A large majority of suburban homes are constructed with thin walls, separated only by a hollow space, created by the two-by-four uprights. This hollow space, points out an architect, does not serve as insulation, for it readily permits warm-air currents to heat the interior plaster.
A fleet of sixty-five boats started today in the opener of the week-end series of the Babylon Yacht Club off here, but, due to wind conditions, the yachtsmen found the racing little to their liking.

The first straw poll on the outcome of Pennsylvania's November election shows a trend toward a split ticket, with Judge Arthur H. James, Republican nominee for Governor, and Governor George H. Earle, Democratic nominee for Senator, the beneficiaries.
Teachers and youth leaders from every section of the country are back to nature on Hog. Island in Muscongus Bay, near Damariscotta, Me., as the Audubon Nature Camp opens its third session.

The Wisconsin Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration with respect to the issuance of $2,500,000 of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1962.
The nois Steel Company has notified a special committee of the City Council that it would accept $2,744, 000 for its 132-acre lakefront land, which has been a subject of bargaining for twelve years.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the dismissal of complaints against five city marshals, all from Queens, who had been charged with the unlawful practice of law. The Queens County Bar Association, which brought the charges, contended the marshals were illegally practicing law by drawing up petitions and precepts in landlord and tenant cases.
Mrs. Clarence Wills and Mrs. Eula H. Jacobs heard the outcome of the match between their famous tennis playing daughters with mingled emotions today.

Dr. Morris J. Lesoff, X-ray specialist, died yesterday at his home, 856 Central Avenue, Far Rockaway, after a fortnight's illness of heart disease. Born in Russia 53 years ago, he had lived in the United States since boyhood.

The intense heat on Pier 60, North River, last night when the President Harding of the United States Lines docked did not check the enthusiasm of a crowd of 300 cheering the group of eighteen wounded volunteers of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion returning from the war in Spain.

BALKIN--Mr. and Mrs. Lee Balkin (Mae Questel) announce birth of Richard Alan, June 28, Beth Israel Hospital. BLOCK- Mr. and Mrs. Jules Block (nee Betty Shinkle) joyfully announce the arrival of Dicky's brother, Curtis Warren, June 27, at Fifth Avenue Hospital.

One of the more important events on the holiday program here was the subscription dance held tonight at the Clambake Club. The party, the first of its kind this season, was under the direction of a committee headed by C. Oliver O'Donnell.
Rutgers University's annual Summer School session will begin Tuesday with an estimated enrollment of 1,200 and a number of new study plans scheduled for the term, which runs six weeks, until Aug. 15.

William Umstaedter of Millburn, seeded No. 1 in the first New Jersey high school invitation tennis tournament held by Peddie School, annexed the singles title by defeating George Himadi of Ridgewood, 6-3, 6-2, in the final today.

ASHEVILLE, N. C.-The first of a series of all-Indian programs will begin today at the Cherokee Indian reservation near here, continuing through tomorrow with archery and blowgun contests and tribal dances-ineluding the scalp, quail, bear, corn, victory and ant dances-and Indian ball games.

READERS of "Mutiny on the Bounty" and "Men Against the Sea" may be surprised when they have penetrated a little way into this novel of ill-fated young love, of a baby changed in the cradle, and, in fact, of almost all the romantic trappings except the strawberry mark on the left shoulder.
Turkish inhabitants of Antioch today erected triumphal arches for an enthusiastic welcome to Turkish troops coming to assume joint control with France of the Sanjak of Alexandretta.

The State Labor Relations Board was instrumental in settling.seventy-five strikes, involving 8,120 employes, in its first year of activity, the board reported yesterday. In 330 other industrial disputes, affecting some 43,000 workers, strikes were averted through the board's intervention, according to the report.
THE 4,300-mile non-stop flight of two Russian airmen from Moscow to Vladivostok last week was heralded by the Soviets as a great military achievement.
Heavy holiday travel was reported by all transportation lines yesterday as thousands of New Yorkers departed for mountain and seashore resorts to spend the long holiday week-end.

John Paul Burke, 21-year-old Georgetown University sophomore, today took over the national intercollegiate golf throne. The redheaded stylist from Newport, R. I., led almost from the start in beating another sophomore, Bert McDowell of Louisiana State University, 19-year-old son of a
The Maidstone Club held its formal opening for the season tonight with a dinner dance, attended by several hundred Summer colonists and their holiday guests.

Word has been received here and Mr. and Mrs. Henry du the marriage yesterday in Montevideo, Uruguay, of Miss Mercedes Ivey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Glen E. Ivey of that place and California, to Hector Cameron Adam Jr., United States Vice Consul at Montevideo.

The renewal of heavy continuous rains in Eastern Japan is bringing fresh floods and disasters although less than those of last week. Thousands of houses are again inundated, and the Tokyo-Yokohama motor road is flooded.

THE NEW Hampshire Seacoast Festival Association will hold its sixth festival July 30 and 31 at Little Boar's Head, N. H. In the absence of Fabien Sevitzky, the association's musical director, the festival will be directed by Norman Leavitt, conductor of the United New Hampshire Chorus.

Miss Helen Cleaves Greenwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. P. Greenwood of Bloomfield, and Roland Libby Nims, son' of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Nims, also of this city, were married today in Westminster Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Denton M. Gerow, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Washington, N. J., and former assistant pastor of Westminster.

The China Campaign Committee here, which is conducting a nation-wide campaign for the boycott of Japanese goods, is meeting. with considerable success, according to Authur D. Clegg, the committee's organizer.

Imports of $15,983,000 of gold were received at New York in June, according to the daily reports of the Federal Reserve Bank of New.York. These were the largest monthly imports since April, and compared with imports of $3,752,000 in May and with $185,583,600 in June, 1937.
The seven-room brick house at 15 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, plot 25 by 100, has been sold by Reginald H. Webster to Anne McGrath through the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company.

THE name Ruanda-Urundi was rarely mentioned until' the agitation concerning Germany's colonial claims reminded readers that Belgium was administering under mandate one of the Reich's former possessions.

Dry goods stocks in the hands of wholesalers throughout the country are low, Henry Matter, executive director of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, reported here last week on his return from a trip through the Midwest.

President Roosevelt vetoed today a bill for the coinage of 100,000 silver 50cent pieces in commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the expldration of Francisco Vasquez de Coronado in what is now the Southwestern United States.
With the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission, a code for America's truck drivers was published yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council.

Miss Clara Theodora Bray, daughter of Mrs. Joseph J. Dickinson of Orlando, Fla., and the late William Calvin Bray, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. John Barton Burrett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Claude A. Burrett of this city. Palms and white peonies decorated Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, where the ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman.
The clubhouse at Highland Lakes, near Stockholm, Sussex County, N. J., has been enlarged and the new wing was formally opened yesterday. It provides additional dancing, dining and kitchen facilities.
The Puerto Rican Trade Council announced yesterday that more than 600 Puerto Rican students sought specialized training in the last year in the colleges and universities of the United States.

In the summary of transactions by officers, directors and principal stockholders in equity securities in May, published today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Phoenix Securities Corporation,

Fifty acres of new play space will be presented to the children of Manhattan's lower East Side with the completion of the new park now under construction between the East River Drive and the river front. Stretching from the South
Marking the first formal opposition to the proposed program of the Montclair Housing Authority, which will soon file a formal application for $900,000 in Federal funds for low-cost housing projects,

Miss Barbara Finken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Finken of this place, was married to Bo Izar Bonde Adlerbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Axel Adlerbert of Gothenburg, Sweden, here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Arthur F. O'Donnell.

Four direct descendants of leading generals of the Civil War were heard last night in a broadcast over the WOR-Mutual network in connection with the seventy-fifth anniversary of the battle of Gettysburg.

Retail sales last week continued to show improvement in most districts, narrowing the declines from a year ago and in a few centers registering gains over the 1937 volume. However, decreases from last year's figures were still the rule. Most improvement during

TESTS made recently indicate that the acoustic properties of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival's new shed at Tanglewood, Mass., where the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky will be heard Aug. 4, 6, 7, 11, 13 and 14, should prove entirely satisfactory.

Raymond Dumont, president of the national semi-pro congress, said today a new high commissioner of semi-pro baseball would be selected next month to succeed Honus Wagner, resigned. Since Wagner left the

Mediators attempting to settle the long Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay expressed increasing alarm today over reports that the two nations were rearming.
J. Irvin Robb, who retired three years ago as head of the Department of History at Northeast High School, died today after a short illness. He was 72 years old.

THE Summer season, when the dance-puts aside its regular routine of recitals and works perhaps twice as hard at what are euphemistically called vacation activities, gets into full swing this week. Stadiums, festivals, conventions, Summer theatres and the like are beginning to dust off their chairs more or less all over the country, and some of them are definitely getting into action.
Miss Juliet Guion Oakes will be married the evening of July 30 in the First Presbyterian Church of Bloomfield to John S. Eells Jr. The Rev. Dr. A. G. Sinclair, the pastor, will perform the ceremony.

Although Penn's baseball team finished last in the team standings in the Eastern Intercollegiate League in the season just completed, the Quakers managed to gain some of the honors in the circuit. They showed the way to the other teams in slugging, although only third in the team batting.

ACTIVITIES in the local gallerles still smoldered on last week while the Summer season in the art colonies outside New York got well under way. The Museum of Modern Art opened an exhibition of designs for the proposed art center at Wheaton College; the Riverside (ex-Roerich)

THE portrait of a future King, 1-year-old Crown Prince Simeon of Bulgaria, is added to philately's gallery through ve stamps issued by the Balkan kingdomm on June 16 to commemo??te the first birthday of the heirpparent.

Various entertainments were held throughout the day for holiday guests. Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy gave a dinner with dancing tonight at Canoe Place Inn for their nieces, the Misses Therese and Rosamond Murray, daughters of
Peter Abbe, chestnut gelding owned by Edward Steigmaier of WilkesBarre, Pa., won the 2:15 pace at the Penn-Jersey circuit races on the Flemington Fair Grounds today. The fastest time was 2:07.

The stock market now has two weeks of advancing prices to its credit, and the widest fortnightly gain since 1929. Last week's climb was not so rapid as that of the week before, but the market has yet to experience a "corrective" of major proportions.

A return of $107.60 for $2 straight on Shall We Dance in the opener and Gay Balko's victory in the Danbury Handicap featured today's racing at Agawam Park. Shall We Dance, coupled with Rise and Shine, paid $589.60 in the daily double.
It is a far cry from Wall Street as I first knew it in 1883 to the Wall Street of today. The actors in its environments of that period have nearly all made their exits.

Figures made public by the National Safety Council based upon data prepared by the United States Census Bureau show, on the accompanying chart, the way in which highway fatalities caused by trucks and motor buses, which are under a degree of control, have declined while those caused by passenger cars and motor cycles have

Beauty contests were known in Illinois eighty-one years ago. The first one recorded was held near Ottawa on July 4, 1857. Research writers on a WPA project have uncovered the story. They report that the contest was for Indian maidens and squaws.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Adolphe Weil of Montgomery, Ala., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Jane Weil to R. Hugh Uhlmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Uhlmann of Kansas Citv Mo.

Denny Shute, two-time champion of the National P. G. A., today proved again his superiority among the nation's match players as he gained a 2-and-1 victory over Ralph Guldahl, master of medal play, in a thirty-six-hole challenge match for
James H. Limburner, pilot for Lincoln. Ellsworth, took off from Floyd Bennett Field at about noon yesterday in the plane that Mr. Ellsworth plans to use later for exploration at the South Pole. Mr.

Last August THE NEW YORK TIMES carried a list of some hundred great books from Homer to the twentieth century, a study of which would constitute a four-year curriculum at St. John's College in Annapolis, leading to the bachelor's degree.

Miss Monica Greeley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Greeley of this place, was married to Raymond Joseph Sachs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Sachs of Nutley, this morning -in Our Lady Help of Christians Church here.

By winning the individual match on today's rifle schedule over the famous Palma three-stage course at Camp Ritchie, Thurman Randle of Dallas, Texas, moved into a tie for the lead for the Eastern open rifle and pistol championship.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals urges that those who are planning to spend the Fourth of July away from home, or to take their annual vacation, arrange proper facilities for the care of dogs or other household pets while they are away.

International Schoolboy Fellowships have been awarded to twentysix graduates of sixteen American preparatory schools under an exchange system established eleven years ago between the preparatory schools of the United States and those of England and Germany.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Weeks of Scranton, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Porter Weeks, to Major Lee White Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. White of Clarks Summit, Pa.

WHEN James Cagney threw that grapefruit at Mae Clarke in "Lady Killer" half a dozen year ago, he started a war between men and women on the screen and lately the impression has got around that the women have been getting the better of it.

The climax of a hectic day for favorites at Delaware Park on the next to last Saturday of the meeting came in the running of the $10,000 added one mile and a sixteenth Kent Handicap when Maxwell Howard's The Chief, a 4-to-5 choice, finished fourth in the nine-horse field.

The cornerstone of Pennsylvania's building in the Court of States at the World's Fair will be laid at noon tomorrow by Governor George H. Earle, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation. Mr. Whalen also announced the signing of nineteen concessions contracts and disclosed that twenty-five concessions had been allocated to date.

Many dinner parties marked the opening tonight at the Oyster Bay carnival to raise funds for Roosevelt Memorial Park. Mrs. Gurnee Cumming heads the committee in charge of cabaret dinner reservations and Wyllys R. Betts is general chairman of the benefit which will close on July 9.

Camp Topridge, Summer place of Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies on the Upper St. Regis Lake will be occupied this Summer by members of their families. It has recently been greatly enlarged and improved.

FROM Maine to the Carolinas and west to Denver those Summer theatre footlights are aglow again, or they will be by tomorrow night. On Broadway, which fell into its annual doze the other week, July 4 is George M. Cohan's and the nation's birthday.

Justice Samuel I. Rosenman of the Supreme Court ruled yesterday against Shepard Traube, theatrical adviser, who sued Frances Farmer, motion-picture and stage actress, for $75,000 for having failed to live up to the terms of a contract.
LONDON. IT is nearly seventy years since Charles Dickens died, but there is as yet no sign that the Dickens cult is waning.

Miss Barbara Bixler, seeded third, eliminated Miss Virginia Wandelt, No. 2, in the girls' metropolitan tennis at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday and will meet Miss Josephine Sanfilippo, the defending champion, in the final on Tuesday at 10:30 A.M. The scores were 6--3. 5--7. 6--2.

Mrs. Arthur Bradley Hanscom of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ellen Hanscom, to Augustus Henry Able 3d, of Melrose Park.

Miss Barbara Joan Trowbridge and Kevin Gelshenen Rafferty were married here this afternoon in the gardens of Seabreeze Terrace, which was the home of the bride's grandparents, the late Mr. and Mrs. James A. Trowbridge. A temporary aisle,

CZECHOSLOVAKIA'S worldfamous Congress of Sokol, the tenth edition of which has been in progress at Prague and which concludes with a gymnastic carnival today through Wednesday, has been commemorated with three postage stamps which bring a new face to philately's gallery-that of Jindrich Fuegner (1822-1865). Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hirsch of Jersey City have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Hirsch, to Arnold M. Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moe Goldstein of Union City, N. J.
CY SULZBERGER for two years was one of John L. Lewis's reportorial shadows in Washington. He was almost a fixture of the United Mine Workers' offices in the Tower Building.

TOMORROW is the day when, in the venerable phrase, American orators "make the eagle scream." The words have particular reference to florid patriotic oratory, but they have sound basis in deeper and more enduring matters than outworn phrases emptied on the air of Independence Day.

Rookie Bob Klinger, who has been beaten only once this year, won his sixth straight pitching victory today, holding the Cardinals to six hits in hurling the Pirates to a 5-to-1 triumph. The only run off him, in the first inning was unearned.

Foreign traders returning from Washington late last: week after making inquiries regarding the probable date when a finished treaty will emerge from present negotiations between English and American representatives, conceded that any prediction would be a matter of guesswork.

While toy orders for the first five months of this year have run well under the same period a year ago, last month brought a degree of improvement that is expected to continue through August and September, trade authorities here said yesterday. It is expected that...

When the extraordinary grand jury investigating the policy racket reconvenes Tuesday it will continue its inquiry into the slaying of William Snyder, to which the two Goldis brothers have confessed, and will interrogate witnesses regarding the source of campaign contributions in the lower West Harlem Assembly district, of which James J. Hines is the Tammany leader.

G.SCHIRMER, INC., music publisher, of New York City, offers a $500 prize for an original unaccompanied choral composition to be dedicated to the World's Fair. Only American citizens may compete. Samuel L. M. Barlow,

Diagonal sheathing, points out a builder, while costing slightly more than horizontal, will repay the additional expenditure because of its effectiveness in bracing the house frame against wind pressure and other stresses.

THE last five years have undoubtedly done more to make the American public realize the importance of housing than the entire 157 years from 1776 to 1933. This is not because there has been great achievement since 1933 in the actual rehousing of the badly housed millions in our population.

With commodity markets swinging upward here last week purchasing executives for large industrial . corporations shifted their hand-to-mouth buying policies and began making forward commitments covering requirements for two to three months.
One of the greatest fields to take part in a women's one-day invitation golf tournament in the metropolitan district will tee off on the Green Meadow course, Harrison, N. Y., next Friday.

FIVE months and three days after its start from Detroit, Chevrolet's long distance safety and dependability truck run passed the 50,000-mile mark at Spokane, Wash., and is now adding to its performance record.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today gave a final answer to those critics of the government who call for armed protection of British ships trading in Spanish Government ports, against Spanish Insurgent airplanes.

A three-run rally in the eighth inning allowed the Red Sox to trip the Athletics, 6 to 5, today and sweep the two-game series. Cramer's third single, driving in Ben Chapman and Desautels and Vosmik's fly to center, scoring Peacock, pulled the game out of the fire.

Plans for Independence Day in London include a dinner and ball by the American Society at Dorchester. Herschell V. Johnson, United States Charge d'Affaires, will preside and Stephen P. Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education at New York, will propose a toast to "the day we celebrate."

WASHINGTON. RADIO is to be substituted for automatic electric signals worked by rail contacts at grade crossings on some of Sweden's busiest railroads, Experiments, according to Commerce reports from Stockholm, indicate that ultra shortwave equipment is more efficient than the ordinary arrangement of rail contacts because it enables a speeding up of the signal in proportion to the speed of the train.

Fresh Meadow (70)--Semi-final round of Father Walsh tournament: P. Weinsler and R. Weinsier defeated G. Levin and M. Weldhorn, 4 and 2.

Low-cost housing projects are being influenced to a great extent by the more than 30,000 housing units erected within the past three years with Federal aid, points out Elizabeth Colt, New York architect and Langley scholar of the American Institute of Architects.

With the Republican State Convention over this week, a ticket nominated and former Senator James E. Watson failing to gain his come-back effort for the Senate choice among five contenders, Republican cards for Indiana in the Fall election are on the table.

Clyde C. Webster, instructor in Romance lank guages at Harvard since 1922, died today of a heart ailment aboard the S. S. Vulcania in the Mediterranean en route to Naples, Italy, according to word received by university officials. His age was 45.

Stocks are up and Wall Street is in high spirits once more. The visitor in the sightseeing bus will see no dancing in the streets or brokers tossing their hats and cheering on street corners.

A colonial house of fieldstone, brick and clapboard containing seven rooms and two baths, with an attached two-car garage, and containing a number of interesting features, has just been completed in Wyngate, at Great Neck, L. I., by Callan Brothers, developers, and has been purchased by George A. Vachris, former commander of the American Legion in Brooklyn.
The last week has seen many arrivals at the resort centers of Mount Desert Island, including Bar Harbor, Northeast, Seal and Southwest Harbors and the smaller Summer retreats of the island.
The Constitutional Convention this week has definitely entered upon what may aptly be termed its political phase.

Ten young women college graduates have been selected for twoyear fellowships, totaling $600, by the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association for study in the fields of religion, education and social science, to be combined with experience in association work.

Charles E. Smollins, commandant of the Brooklyn Diocesan Council of the Catholic Boys Brigade of the United States, yesterday received a medal sent by the Pope, bearing a likeless of Pope Leo XIII, in recognition of his work for the Catholic children of Brooklyn.
W. A. Thomas, Internal Revenue Collector, ruled today that all political candidates in Texas must pay social security. taxes for their campaign workers.
GOSHEN, N. Y.-The Goshen area, rich in American historical and equine lore, awaits its annual rush of visitors to attend the trotting horse meetings which begin here July 12.

Uncertainty over the general business prospect was listed today by the National Association of Real Estate Boards as a principal deterrent to real estate advance.

Assignment of Promoted Men The following captain is detailed to act as Inspector and is transferred and assigned as indicated. Designation as Deputy Inspector revoked: To take effect 8 A. M., July 1; James J. Phelan from 1st District Traffic to 2d District Traffic.
JULY'S vacation days mean sign-off time for a number of radio's regular stand-bys and the many departures scheduled for this week pave the way for new Summer shows.
Part of a talk by' Alf M. Landon next Wednesday in Council Bluffs, lowa, will be broadcast over a nation-wide radio hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting Company.

In old and new houses, points out a builder, where a radiator is located in front of a window, it can be made to look better by concealing it. When this is done, appearances are further enhanced by building a continuous seat the width of the room.

Miss Louise MacLean, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Robert MacLean of this city, has chosen her attendants for her marriage to the Rev. Richard Irwin Porter, son of Mrs. William Coulter of Homestead, Pa., which will take place here on July 30, in the First Presbyterian Church.

A Rhode Island law which obligates children to provide for their parents, if able, was cited by State officials today in the case of Francis o. French, father-in-law of John Jacob Astor. Mr. French has applied at Middletown for a relief job.
St. Matthew's Church here was the setting at noon today for the marriage of Miss Angela Fowler, grand- ble daughter of the late Judge Robert Ludlow Fowler, author of many

Close of play scores in English first class cricket games started today: Surrey 386 for six wickets (Squires 137, Parker 94, Barling 64); vs. Sussex, at the Oval. Kent 201 (Wright 51, Mitchell five wickets for 56 runs); Derbyshire 77 for two wickets: at Buxton.

MEN, women and children who "go down to the sea in ships," whether for business or pleasure, are going to find striking differences in the facilities offered by the American merchant marine in the next year.

Mr. and Mrs. Barnes Newberry of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Goddard Binney Newberry, to C. Hollister Judd Jr. of Philadelphia, son of Dr. Judd of DeLroit and the late Mrs. Gertrude Bucknell Day of Summerville, S.C.
IT was in the last quarter of the nineteenth century that Clifford W. Ashley was born in New Bedford.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered effective, under certain conditions, a declaration by the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the Engineers Public Service Company, covering.. the sale of $7,000,000 of first anti refunding 6 per cent gold bonds, Series E, due on Oct. 1, 1950.

President Roosevelt's major addresses on his Western trip will be carried over both the Columbia and National broadcasting systems. The first broadcast will be on Friday at 10:30 A. M., Eastern daylight time, as the President speaks at Marietta, Ohio, at the dedication of the Northwest Territory memorial monument.

Truck drivers employed by private contractors on the North Beach Airport, -which the WPA is building for the city, stopped carting dirt and other fill for about an hour yesterday, but the "misunderstanding" between the drivers and their employers was adjusted and work resumed by the time police reached the airport.

ONE of the biggest movingday operations in recent Washington history is to take place within a few weeks, with the transfer of all the functions of the Bureau of Air Commerce to the new Civil Aeronautics Authority, upon which the President with his signature stamped his approval last week.

Although open only until noon yesterday, the Manhattan and Bronx offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles were forced to double their staffs to handle the rush of motorists seeking the half-year automobile license plates which went on sale July 1.

THERE is seemingly no end to the daily chores which must be performed to assure the perfect operation of a lighthouse, yet the keeper's vigil is a lonely and thankless one indeed. He lives and works in obscurity and no one gives him a thought, at least so long as the friendly beacon is aglow.

Boston at New York-Wilson (7-6) vs. Gomez (5-8). Washington at Philadelphia (2)Leonard (6-7) and Chase (3-4) vs. Nelson (8-2) and Caster (7-8). Detroit at St. Louis (2)-Gill (5-2) and Kennedy (10-4) vs, Cole (0-1) or Van Atta (0-4) and Hildebrand (4-5).

Favorable weather for the harvesting of wheat in the Southwest and prospects that Kansas City would receive more than 2,000 cars of the cash grain over the July 4 holiday dominated the action of the wheat market today Closing trades in futures were
