President William Harridge of the American League announced today Detroit had requested the release of First Baseman Hank Greenberg from participating in the all-star game Wednesday in Cincinnati.

At a meeting today of the Cereals Corporation, at which Premier Benito Mussolini presided, Edmundo Rossoni, Minister of Agriculture, declared that the great improvement in weather coneditions during the last two months had removed the danger of any grave shortage in any staple agricultural products.

With the rising prices and broader activity which have featured the purchasing of textile staples serving as a cue, the thousands of buy-ers who will arrive in the wholesale markets here beginning this week on their initial Fall trips will demonstrate how-far psychological improvement in business sentiment -will be -translated into larger buying orders for finished merchandise.
Assured that his father, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf, was resting comfortably, Prince Bertil of Sweden went swimming, driving and shopping yesterday before leaving for Washington at 6:30 P. M.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Frank Woodcock of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Elizabeth Woodcock, to Robert Rensselaer Chamberlain Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rensselaer Chamberlain, also of this city.
Building Inspector Charles B. Keimig has issued a permit for the proposed low-rental housing project of the Linden Housing Corporation here. The cost of the project was listed at $738,725.
Although gray cloth sales-slackened last. week, the cotton textile industry enjoyed its broadest volume in many months, selling agents reported yesterday.

IF it's superb Spanish ballroom dancing which takes one's fancy, a trip down to Ross Fen ton Farms, in Asbury Park, N. J., is currently the place to go. At Ralph Maurice's place on Deal Lake are Medrano and Donna, a lithe pair of individuals,
Presidential approval of fifty-six additional projects was announced today by the Public Works Administration. Four undertakings in New York are -in the list.

State Detective Maurice P. Nelligan today described as "human blood stains" some discolorings found in an automobile said to be owned by John P. Bathelt Jr., 26, of New York, held in jail here on a murder charge. The car was located last week in Bellows Falls, Vt.

Jersey City snapped its five-game losing streak today by capturing both ends of a double-header with Baltimore, 2 to 0 and 3 to 2. Rollie Stiles hurled five-hit ball in the opener to win a mound duel from Ben Cantwell. Stiles walked two and fanned four.

RADIO educator to succeed must make a fresh start, a start from scratch and forget the classroom methods in their effort "to give life distilled" through the microphone, Dr. William E. Bohn, Educational Director of the Rand School, warned- in a recent broadcast over WEVD in which he discussed "Giving Education the Air."

SEVERAL compositions by Morton Gould, 24-year-old American composer, will be heard this Summer at the big outdoor concerts in the East. At the Lewisohn Stadium three of his works are scheduled for presentation soon by the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra.

Many dinner dances featured the social activities of the yacht and country clubs in Westchester County in celebration of the Fourth of July week-end. Tonight a dinner dance was held at the American Yacht Club here.

OF all the arts, music has the strongest hold upon man's memory. He may for get the exact wording of a line of verse or a prose passage; the details of a painting or a piece of sculpture may slip his mind.

Three properties in the West Redding and Wilton sections of Connecticut have been sold by Mrs. Howard A. Barker of the Old Forge Real Estate Company. One deal was a five-acre estate with a fourteen-room house on route 53 in West Redding, purchased by William Homer Colgate of Mount Vernon from the Norwalk Saving Socity.

Rufus B. Cowing Jr., a New York lawyer, son of the late Rufus B. Cowing, who was a judge of the General Sessions Court in New York for twenty-eight years, died here today in his Summer home at the age of 68.

A sum aggregating $101,500,000 was paid by savings, building and loan associations by the end of June in semi-annual dividends to their 6,000,000 savers and investors, reports the United States Building and Loan League, Morton Bodfish, league executive vice president, has reported.
More than five hundred delegates opened a national convention of the German-Austrian war veterans' organization here today by emphasizing their loyalty to their adopted country. State Commander Adolf

The unusual abundance of moisture during the past few weeks in the vicinity of New York has provided an ideal growing season for Japanese irises, now in their glory in private gardens and in the several large display collections in the metropolitan area.
The exploration schooner Bowdoin, under command of Donald B. MacMillan, was anchored in Sydney harbor today. Over the week-end it will sail on a cruise to Labrador.
An outdoor automobile motlonpicture theatre, said to be the first of its kind in the State, will be erected on a twelve-acre site on the Sunrise Highway in Valley Stream, L. I.

Mr. and Mrs. Mason Garber of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Louise Garber, to Irving C. Brown Jr. of San Francisco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Bluefield, W. Va.

Rising after six straight defeats, the lastplace Browns smashed fourteen hits today and trounced the Tigers,-13 to 5. Southpaw Howard. Mills was wild, issuing eight passes, but he was effective except in the third inning.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Fraser of Rockville Centre, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsa Louise Fraser, to the Rev. Charles D. Myers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer S. Myers of Philadelphia.

The recently expanded "buy- and- give" program is viewed by many as one of the most significant movements inaugurated by the Roosevelt Administration. Essentially the program consists of buying surpluses for distribution to the needy.
Now that the Summer season is taking many garden lovers to the seashore, they face the problem of how to make things grow within sound of the surf and reach of salt spray.

Continuing its advance, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has moved to 77.4 for the week ended June 25. This compares with 76.8 for the preceding week, and 107.4 for the corresponding week a year ago.
The type of roof and its material should be selected with care so as to conform with the general style of the house, points out an architect of small homes.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 30: CAPTAINS Abbott, J. S., orders of Jan..23 revoked, to continue duty as Captain of Yard. Navy Yard, Charleston, S. C.

Turning back the threats of Western invaders, Joseph Fishbach of St. John's University, Brooklyn, seeded eighth, and Gerard D. Podesta, Princeton's captain-elect, gained the final of the sixteenth. annual Eastern intercollegiate singles tennis championship today on the courts of the Montclair A. C. The pair will meet in the first all-Eastern final since 1935 tomorrow at 2 P. M.

The discovery of phosphorus 1,000 feet under water In a Pacific Ocean canyon opens a new world for fortune hunters. The finding was described today at the Scripps Institute of Oceanography by Dr. F. P. Shepard, geologist of the University of Illinois.
W. R. Hearst, the publisher, called California his home today after maintaining for several years that his legal residence was in New York because of his objection to this State's tax laws.
If the American electorate could vote on individual members of President Roosevelt's Cabinet, they would rank Cordell Hull, Rdosevelt's Secr-etary of State, as the man who has done the best job.

WHEN Mark Twain transported a Connecticut Yankee to King Arthur's court he told how, after the first few bewildering days, the Yankee made himself right at home and, indeed, a leader in court affairs. He was an adaptable fellow who knew his own capacities and made the most of them. He definitely made a place for himself at the Round Table.

After having battled with her inveterate rival on even terms for eight tense games, Miss Helen Jacobs injured her ankle when she seemingly was about to take the lead in her championship match with Mrs. Helen Wills Moody today in the all-England tennis tournament, and was defeated, 6-4, 6-0.
Joseph Buerck- port el, Nazi Commissioner for Austria, has issued decrees against corruption, indicating he is taking a firm hand with all irregularities in the National Socialist party.

Clarence Saunders, the Memphis grocer, remained today in possession of Annswood, his beautiful Park Avenue estate, and said he would continue to occupy it despite the fact that counsel for William (Bill) Terry, manager of the New York Giants, has notified him to vacate by July 5.
Jess Sweetser broke the amateur course record of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today when he posted a 34, 33--67 for the par 70 layout. The former standard had been set at 68 by Willie Turnesa.

ON the eve of his seventy-fifth birthday next Thursday Frank B. Noyes has a message to the craft of journalism, which he has served since his youth; it is the message of John Philpot Curran to the Irish people nearly 150 years ago:

The engagement of Miss Rita Margorie Bernard, daughter of Mrs. Louis W. Bernard of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Bernard, to Dr. Seymour H. Rinzler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rinzler, also of Brooklyn, has been announced.

A number of sales and leases inevolving properties in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn were reported yesterday by Frank J. Scalise, broker. Among the properties sold were the store and dwelling at 1,435 Sixty-fifth Street and the one-family house at 1,245 Seventy-eighth Street.
Led by Dr. Stephen Wise of New York, more than 1,000 leaders of American Jewry tonight opened the forty-second annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America.

Taking their cue from their more illustrious compatriots at Wimbledon, American players usurped all four semi-final brackets in the invitation tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club today as Canada's young Davis Cup representatives were shut out of the action.

Billy Gillespi of Scarborough School, national interscholastic champion, today eliminated the South's fifth ranking junior and Virginia interscholastic titleholder, Melville Jordan of Woodberry Forest School, from the sixth annual Eastern interscholastic invitation tennis tournament at the Manursing Island Club.
Dr. Williamson Updike Vreeland, '92, Woodhull Professor of Romance Languages at Princeton University, has retired at the conclusion of forty-five years of teaching Nassau students.

BAR HARBOR, Me.-Preliminary plans are being made for the Mount Desert flower show to be held on July 19 and 20 at the Building of Arts. The show is annually sponsored by the Garden Club of Mount Desert.

While a leading variety chain is still considering the possibility of dropping all merchandise retailing above 25 cents, reports here yesterday indicated that the other leading chain organizations which in the last few years have added lines up to $1 and even above have had success with them.
Vernon H. Struck, fullback, and Joseph F. Nee, guard, Harvard stars, have been selected for the Eastern college All-Star team by Coach Andy Kerr, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Ostrud Fox, about 50, of New York City, was seriously injured and her sister, Marguerite Gorski, 37, of Los Angeles, an instructor at a school in Washington, Conn., was bruised when their automobile plunged off the highway into a creek three miles west of here on the Olympic Highway yesterday.
FELDMAN-BAREMORE-Mr. and Mrs. Randel W. Baremore of 320 Central Park West, announce the engagement of their daughter, Beth, to Mr. Alex Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Feldman of New York.

Two more ships flying the British flag in Spanish ports were bombed last week by Insurgent aircraft, bringing to about thirty the number of English merchantmen attacked by Insurgents since mid-April. Harassed by

A program of renovation throughout the municipal ferry-boat fleet and terminals has been urged on Mayor La Guardia by the National Maritime Union, as a part of a campaign to alleviate unemployment among sea and harbor workers, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Edmund L. Mooney will sail on Thursday to pass a few weeks in Vichy, France. Before returning here in September she will go to Brussels and England. Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Barret of the Carlyle departed yesterday for London. They will later go to Aix-lesBains. France.

Conducted tours of captured cities and battlefields that figured in Generalissimo Francisco Franco's campaign along the Biscayan coast last Summer were inaugurated today by the Tourist Bureau of the Franco Ministries of the Interior and Press and Propaganda.

A meeting of property owners to protest against proposed amendments to the State Constitution which would increase taxes on real estate will be held Monday evening, July 11, at the Girls High School, Halsey Street and Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Brooklyn executive committee of the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation, of which Frank M. McCurdy is chairman.

WESTPORT, N. Y.--More than fifty amateur ownerpilots are expected to arrive at Westport-on-Lake Champlain with members of, their families aboard a fleet of twenty or more seaplanes on July 14, on the seventh annual seaplane cruise from Glen Cove, L. I.

NEWPORT, R. I.-The golf tournament season opens today at the Newport Country Club links. Members and subscribers have been using the course for some time, but it remained for Mr. and Mrs. Crawford Hill to offer prizes for a best eleven out of thirteen holes event to start the tournaments as a holiday feature.

The British open golf championship, the qualifying rounds of which begin Monday at Sandwich, in Kent, will be a domestic tournament, as far as American invaders are concerned. The Walker Cup team has gone home long ago, and Gene Sarazen and Lawson Little, after entering, decided not to compete.
The text of Secretary Morgenthau's statement today on the final figures of the government's financial operations for the fiscal year ending on June 30 was as follows:

Suspicion is being. expressed here over a series of visits by staff officers of Germany, Italy and Poland already made in progress or about to be made, to strategically situated smaller States following active diplomatic efforts by these same powers in these same fields.

Spread of anti-Japanese feeling through markets of the world is opening opportunities for the recapture by domestic manufacturers of many of the markets lost to Japan following the devaluation of the yen in 1931, leading export authorities said here yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced an amendment of the provision of Rule UB2 relating to hearings in connection with requests for confidential treatment of data filed with the commission under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

A young miss, 9 years old and named Shirley Temple, arrived last night on her first visit to New York City, full of excitement over having recently seen her first snow, her first wheat field, her first baby giant panda and her first President of the United States-a Mr. Roosevelt who she thought was "one of the very nicest people I know."

Timothy Clune, a city detective who was commended for his work in the Bruno Hauptmann case, died yesterday in the Neurological Institute of a streptococcus infection, after a week's illness, at the age of 31. Detective Clune, who lived at

Officers andmen of the Yugoslav naval training ship Jadran, barkentine with auxiliary power, were entertained last week at a series of functions, closing with a dinner at the Hotel New Yorker last night.

BOSTON is a paradoxical town. It counts itself a center of the arts-no longer the Hub of the Universe, perhaps, but at least a provincial capital. It maintains a symphony orchestra of world reputation.

A fund between $40,000 and $50,000 for scholarship purposes has been made available to the Architectural League of New York through the will of Mrs. Emma B. K. Brunner, widow of Arnold W. Brunner, distinguished American architect.

WHEN the most boisterous of our national holidays reaches a thunderous climax tomorrow night thousands of photographers are expected to be in the field snapping pictures of fireworks. Many will have taken such scenes before.

Among those returning to pass the Summer at the Ausable Club are Mr. and Mrs. Van Devanter Crisp of Upper Brookville, L. I. Dr. and Mrs. Robert Wise of New York have arrived as guests of Mrs. Theodore C. Janeway at Felsenheim, her Summer home here. Mr. and Mrs. Frederic B. Pratt of Brooklyn are expected here for the Summer.

Young Arnold Zimmerman made Blair Academy's triumph in the Eastern interscholastic golf championship complete today when he annexed the individual crown after being largely instrumental in gaining the team honors.

In a world with 18,000,000 unemployed , of whom 10,300,000 are in the United States alone, Germany presents the remarkable spectacle of resorting to Draconian measures to cope with an increasing labor shortage.

JEROME FRANK was research associate at Yale Law School for several years, emerging in 1930 as the author of "Law and the Modern Kind." Hejoined the New Deal in 1933 as general counsel of the AAA, but was dropped by Adiminitrator Davis early in 1935.
FROM long nights under the southern stars, phosphorus foaming at a calm Dutch freighter's stem; from nocturnal watches intermittently shared with officers on the bridge or with sailors in the bow;
WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H. The Maplewood Gun Club is offering an Independence Day shoot tomorrow, which concludes its annual trap-shooting tournament at Maplewood Club.
Miss Virginia Lee Layton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Sipple Layton of Wilmington was married this evening to William Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thurlow W. Barnes of Cambridge, Mass.
The decision of Dickinson College to establish new courses in world history, world literature and philosophy of life is held to indicate its new interpretation of the objectives of college education.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody captured her eighth Wimbledon title by beating her inveterate California rival, Miss Helen Jacobs, 6-4, 6-O, in the climax of an American sweep of the five finals. Miss Jacobs injured an ankle with the score 4-4 in games in the first set and, refusing to ask for time to rest, dropped the next two games. She scored only three points in the second set.

On a recent visit to Henry Ford's Greenfield Village at Dearborn it struck the writer as an amusingly incongruous-but wholly characteristic-note to see, as one approached the Ford properties, the salutiferous and succulent soy bean sprouting in every vacant strip of ground.

Night baseball for all clubs is coming to major leagues-and coming to stay. That is the belief of William Harridge, president of the American League, which for years was solidly opposed to the playing after nightfall of a game which for almost a century has been the nation's greatest outdoor afternoon sport.

Practically half the families who bought homes for their own oc.cupancy- in 1937 under the FHA mortgage plan had annual incomes of less than $2,500, Administrator Stewart McDonald announced yesterday in reporting on the 1937 FHA activities.

Buoyancy- ruled in most sections of the domestic corporate bond market yesterday, with pivotal issues reaching new high levels for the current upward movement. The two-hour market turnover of $4,867,000, the largest for a Saturday since April 2, compared with $3,534,475 on the preceding Saturday.

Merchants here are giving marked attention to the need of directing slum clearance work to Manhattan rather than the launching of projects in outlying areas. Delos Walker, general manager of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.; has been named chairman of a committee of the Retail Dry Goods Association, which is dealing with this question.

A dance opened the season at the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club tonight. It was under the direaction of Mrs. John B. Kirby Jr., of Meriden, Mrs. Henry Pope of New Haven, the Misses Sally Young of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Jean Farrel of New York, Robert Read of Torrington and Harold H. Sherburne of New York.
Colonel E. R. Bradley's luck at Suffolk Downs held good today when Bootless accounted for the Minute Man HandIcap, mile and a sixteenth feature, at 13 to 5.

LETCHWORTH PARK - A parade of 75,000 Summer visitors. has begun through the gates of this State park. Along twisting banks of the Genesee River, past rumbling waterfalls,'high above deep stone gorges, the parade moves-perhaps breaking step to spread a picnic lunch under the elms, or to peer into the historic Indian "council house."

In proseedings for readjustment of motorcarrier rates in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, the Inierstate Commerce Commission today asked Class I carriers which have gross revenue of $100,000 or more each annually from both interstate and intrastate operations to submit additional information relative to income statements.
Improved sentiment in the wholesale markets last week caused prices to stiffen in some lines, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Miss Helene J. Bodenheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Bodenheim of Kew Gardens, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to Willis Jackson Fosdick, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Sheldon Fosdick of Massapequa, L. I., which will take place the afternoon of July 16 in the Church of the Resurrection, Richmond Hill, L. I.

THE Summer season of transatlantic survey flights, continuing the international race to establish air routes between the United States and Europe, is about to begin. Germany's new mail plane, the Nordstern, is ready for its first crossing to New York-one of twenty-eight crossings scheduled for the Summer by German Lufthansa. France plans to send over its first survey plane from Paris some time this month.

In the ancestral -home of her family on Bellevue Avenue here, Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie of this city and New York, was married at noon today to Alan T. Schumacher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Schumacher of 1,148 Fifth Avenue, New York.

Approaching the Fall buying season, manufacturers of electrical appliances are hoping that current indications of a recovery will build up into a -genuine revival of all business and bring a sharp upswing in the demand for major household appliances.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being July 2, unless specified: Shanghai to Tsingtao: Augusta, Isabel. At San Francisco: Boggs, Lamberton. Boston to Nassau: Dickerson, Schenck. At Santa Barbara: Lexington, New Orleans.

Dr. John Milton Mabbott, a specialist in diseases of women, who had been in practice in this city for fifty years, died Friday night of a heart attack, after a fortnight's illness, at his residence, 27 Washington Square North. He would have been 76 years old on July 14.

Polite guests who are enjoying hospitality at the country or the seashore this three-day week-end will probably begin racking their brains when they get back to town, trying to think of just the right gift to send their hostesses in thanks.

Pretty much everywhere these days, north, south, east and west of New York, lights and buoys are being shifted by the United States Lighthouse Service. This keeps boat owners on their wits. They can wear an old oilskin until it cracks and drops off, but they had better not get lazy about their navigating charts.
PAN-GERMANS who for years had been advocating Anschluss never expected that their ideal would be achieved in the manner in which Adolf Hitler marched his legions across the frontier into Austria.

Two men suspected of a possible attempt to damage a 16-inch gun defending the Pacific entrance to the Panama Canal were fired on by a sentry at Fort Kobbe .early today, according to The Panama American.

Funeral services for Berthold Neuer, vice president and general manager of William Knabe Co., who died of a heart ailment Thursday, were held yesterday at the Universal Funeral Chapel, 597 Lexington Avenue.

Now that the New York Constitutional Convention has decided, subject to final action, to place before the electorate, the question. whether New York's Constitution shall 'contain a prohibition against unreasonable search and seizure, the issue may be raised of the need of any such provision in the State's fundamental law.
DETROIT. CONTINUED firmness in production of cars and trucks has been one of the contraseasonal trends which have brought improved sentiment throughout the industry.

The Hospital Department will conduct a campaign this Fall for the enrollment of qualified graduate nurses living in the city to make sure that the city's institutions do not suffer from a nursing shortage, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, announced yesterday.
William O. Douglas, whose term as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission expired on Thursday, has been re-elected by the commission for another year.

Douglas Malloch of Chicago, author and lecturer, died today in a hospital here after a heart attack. He was 61 years old. Mr. Malloch and his wife, the former Miss Helen Miller Stanley of Elgin, editor of juvenile publications, came to Muskegon yesterday to spend the Summer.

Bears won a ten-inning game from the Syracuse Chiefs today, 4-3, Buddy Rosar scoring the deciding run when Pitchers Earl Cook walked Mike Chartak on four straight pitches with the bases loaded. It was the fifth overtime battle between the teams this year.
There were 175 craft out today at the American Yacht Club for the ninth championship regatta of the Long Island Sound Association. It was a new high number for the season. But the breeze failed.

If political power and wealth can be passed into the care of the workers of America, democracy will be safe, Aubrey Williams, Deputy Administrator of the Works Progress Administration, told 250 delegates to the national conference of the American Youth congress at Berea today.

The Japanese land and naval onslaught up the Yangtze River toward the Chinese provisional capital of Hankow progressed today, according to the Chinese, when a small transport crossed the sunken boom at Matang, after many days of pounding by naval guns at this defense, and landed several hundred Japanese shock troops at a village four miles upstream.
Senator Laurent Eynac declared tonight that France and Great Britain must construct aerial forces equal or superior to Germany's it they wished to avoid a repetition of the World War.

The Ontario tennis championships, one of the outstanding fixtures on the Canadian Summer sports program, will start tomorrow at the Rideau Club and continue throughout the week. Among the prominent netmen entered are Gordon Robinson, from Stamford in the Niagara district;

Lieut. Col. John H. Sturgeon, U. S. A., and Mrs. Sturgeon of Fort Jay, Governors Island, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Sturgeon, to William A. Miller of Glasgow, Scotland, and British Honduras, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Miller.

Miss Martha Newell Harmon, daughter of Professor Austin M. Harmon of Yale University, was married here to Howard Newton Porter, son of Mrs. Charles Talbot Porter and the late Mr. Porter of New Haven, Conn., this afternoon at the Harmon Summer home.

IT is often said that the public dislikes plays that are about the theatre itself, and it is a comprehensible dislike. I myself have always regretted the change of custom that has brought actors and actresses out of the closed professional community that was

MANHATTAN TIFFANY, GEORGE STANTON (June 19). Estate, more than $10,000, to Isabelle W. Tiffany, widow, executrix, 100 W. 68th St., residue. COPELAND, ROYAL S. (June 17), Estate, $43,000. To Frances S. Copeland, widow, executrix, Hotel Warwick, 54th St. and 6th Ave., residue.
Miss Elizabeth Hildreth died late today as she and six others on a holiday cruise jumped from a schooner yacht to avoid the American freighter City of Flint, which was steaming out of Boston Harbor.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Blake of this city and Menauhant, East Falmouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Blake, to Robert Peabody Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Snyder of Albany, N. Y., and Falmouth Mass.
Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Henry Lane of Tokeneke announced tonight at a dinner dance the engagement of Mr. Lane's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Constantine Lane, to Chester E. Ingraham Jr.

Colonel William H. Tefft, a retired army medical officer, died in the station hospital at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, yesterday, at the age of 65, according to notification received by the War Department today.
Two men were killed and three injured, one critically, when a passenger automobile crashed head-on into a coal truck at Broadway, near here, at 6 o'clock this morning.

Heat reminiscent of seventy-five years ago pressed down on Gettysburg today as the veterans of the Union and Confederate Armies mingled in reunion. Governor George H. Earle visited the veterans in their camps this morning, and this afternoon they sat under canvas in Gettysburg College stadium to review a parade in their honor after it had swung through the streets of this little town.

Sharp advances in all speculative commodities were practically offset by a downward revision in finished steel prices, The Annalist reports, and, as a result, its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced only to 80.5 in the period ended on last Wednesday, compared with 80.4 in the preceding week and 94.2 a year ago.

France further stiffened her attitude toward Japan today, ordering the French Ambassador in Tokyo to inform the Japanese Foreign Office of the possible "unfortunate" effect of antiFrench attacks in Japanese newspapers.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey has filed an application with the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission seeking approval of the sale of a twenty-four-acre tract of land, in First Street to the Singer Manufacturing Company for $140,000.

About five gallons of water per minute are required to air condition a home of eight or nine rooms north of the Ohio River, according to O. C. Holleran of the United States Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce. South of the river the average requirement is around ten gallons per minute.

An 18-year-old Tarrytown (N. Y.) girl today rescued James Kirkwood, stage and screen actor, after he was stricken with cramps while swimming. Miss Marion Rosser, a Summer resident, was on the beach when she saw Mr. Kirkwood, apparently in difficulty a hundred yards from shore.
On the first anniversary of the breaking of ground for the Andrew W. Mellon Gallery of Art here, the trustees announced today that the work was about one-fourth completed.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Louise Rahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rahn of this city, to George C. Kastner Jr., took place here this afternoon in the First Congregational Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Clarence Wells.

The estate of the late Edwin Thorn at West Islip, L. I., will be sold at auction on the premises next Saturday by Joseph P. Day. The property comprises thirteen acres on Oak Lane, south of Merrick Road, and is being sold by order of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee of the Thorn estate.

Harold Scott Callowhill, 41-yearold director of the Playgrounds Athletic League of Baltimore and past treasurer and life member of the Maryland Football Association, yesterday was elected president of the United States Football Association, the controlling soccer body in this country, at the final session of its annual congress at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Philip H. Loughlin, chairman of the Board of Selectmen of Westminster, who was returning from a business trip to Montreal, collapsed today on a train in North Station and was pronounced dead of a heart ailment at the Massachusetts General Hospital. A native of Worcester, Mr.

While President Roosevelt secluded himself in the privacy of his Hudson River home this week and worked quietly on speeches and bills demanding his immediate attention, the temporary White House offices at Poughkeepsie not far away were alive with a different kind of activity.

ABBETT-On July 1, 1938, at the Plaza, Lillian Hall Abbett, mother of Leon and Sheldon Abbett, in her sixty-sixth year. Services private. BALL-On July 1, James, retired horticulturist. Services Conner Funeral Home, 4,955 Broadway (207th St.), Monday, 2 P. M Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.
S. Mortimer Auerbach of Atlantic City, driving his powerful fourliter hydroplane Emancipator VII, today won the Duke of York Gold Challenge Trophy at the international motor boat regatta.
Twenty organizations, representing a half million members, protested today against Sweden's participation in the 1940 Olympic Games in Janpan.

LAND travel within the borders of the United States and its neighbors bids for new honors during the coming vacation months. Already, though the Summer season has hardly started, long-distance travelers elbow commuters in the rail terminals; crowds attend the departures of new super - streamlined trains; cross-country buses set out on their runs loaded to capacity, and highways, bridges and tunnels require extra police to handle the motor traffic.

Accused by his wife of shooting her in an argument over their vacation, Salvatore Caruti, 46 years old, a milk route salesman living at 1,923 Tenth Street, Brooklyn, was taken to the Bath Beach police station last night for questioning by an Assistant District Attorney.
William J. Sloan, a Civil War veteran who was prevented by ill health from attending the Gettysburg reunion now under way, died in his home at Aldan, a suburb, yesterday. He was 89 years old.
AT the Woodstock Art Gallery the Summer season's first exhibition of painting and sculpture, which will be current through Wednesday, contains work by the following artists:
The condition of Suzanne Lenglen, former tennis star, grew steadily worse today. She is suffering from pernicious anaemia, for which she underwent a blood transfusion last Wednesday.
Shipments of iron ore from Northern Minnesota, Michigan and Wisconsin in June totaled 2,837,745 tons, compared with 10,107,883 a year ago, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today.

UNLIKE that notorious, but probably most interesting, gentleman who bragged that he could resist everything except temptation, this department prides itself on being able to resist everything but tradition.

WHATEVER else it may prove to be, a novel by Francis Stuart will at least be different. When this young man, born in Australia of Irish parents, burst on the world a few years back with that extraordinary story, "Pigeon Irish," following it up with the still more extraordinary novel, "The Colored Dome," readers rubbed their eyes and asked:

The seventeen-story and penthouse-apartment structure known as Southmoor House at 230 Central Park South, near Columbus Circle, has been completed and is now ready for occupancy. The Park Slope Construction Company, Siegfried Moisseiff, president, is the owner.

News of Wall Street's activity today and yesterday's Anglo-German payment agreement encouraged London stockbrokers to give up their usual weekend and they spent the day executing orders on the telephone, as the stock market is closed on Saturday.

The new rules issued last week by the Federal Trade Commission and covering shrinkage of cotton goods, effective immediately, did not meet with a very favorable reception in the Worth Street district, according to executives of leading houses there. Chief problem was the

Despite the fact that real estate is considerably less active today in nearly all parts of the country than it was at last year's peak, sales prices in a majority of cities are at least equal to, and in some cases above, the levels of last May and June.

The Reconstruction Finance Corportion, holder of about 70 per cent of the 5 1/2 per cent bonds of the Middle Rio Grande Conservancy District of New Mexico, and 90 per cent of the individual bondholders, have agreed to a refunding plan for the district's $8,400,000 issue, according to an announcement yesterday by C. W. Laing Jr. of John Nuveen Co., a member of the committee which devised the plan.

Miss Jane Adams Lanterman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Lanterman of this city, was married to Walter W. Baldwin, son of Mrs. C. Walter Baldwin of Orange and the late Mr. Baldwin, this afternoon in the First Baptist Church here.
Four demands by the representatives of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party in the nationalities negotiations have been sharply rejected by the Czechoslovak Government.

Johanna Hofmann, a defendant in the German espionage case, filed an affidavit in Federal Court yesterday through her attorney, George C. Dix, alleging that she had been innocently brought into the "disdressing situation."
According to present indications, the Securities and Exchange Commission will start a general investigation of so-called "thrift plans" In the near future.

From 1896 to 1936 the Liberal party was in power in the Province of Quebec. It became more conservative than the Conservatives. It fell at last. M. Duplessis and the Union Nationale rule the roost. Some of the saddened survivors have just held a provincial convention, chosen a new leader and proposed a new platform.

Brokers in the Moristown section of New Jersey report an encouraging revival of interest in home buying in that section A residence on Burnham Parkway containing nine rooms was purchased by Frank A. Farnsworth of Morristown from G. Tuchig. He,also bought from

PREFIXING his recent broadcast assailing the campaign of defeatism in Congress and explaining the President's role in politics, Mr. Roosevelt referred to the American public and newspapers as creatures of habit, because despite the sweltering June night in Washington they would label his broadcast as a "fireside chat."

Governor William A. Langer of North Dakota, who had said that if he were elected to the Senate he would "outHuey Huey Long" if necessary, watched his entire State office ticket, with one exception, ride to victory in the Republican primary election last Tuesday by thumping majorities, but he himself wound up some 6,000 votes behind Senator Gerald P. Nye.

The marriage of Miss Madeline Chandler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Chandler of MapleWood, and John E. Lyons, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Lyons of Maplewood, took place at noon today in Ivy Chapel of MorrowMemorial Church here. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton, performed the ceremony.

A bill declaring undesirable and prohibiting the entry of emigrants from Haiti, China, Poland, Lithuania, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Turkey, Syria, Albania, the Belgian and French Congo, Estonia, Latvia, Liberia, Morocco, Persia, the Ukraine and Austria, unless the emigrants from Austria hold passports from Germany, has been presented in the House of Representatives.

The marriage of Miss Gertrude Laurette Cook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Cook of this place. to Stephen Francis Breitfeller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Breitfeller, took place here this morning in St. Joseph's Church.
Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Rulon-Miller of Ardmore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Rulon-Miller, to Louis Page Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Marechal Brown of Villanova.

SOME of the recent French gold coins are becoming quite rare owing to the fact that, their gold content making them worth considerably more than their face value, they have been removed from circulation and melted.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Beveridge White to William Costner Rhyne Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Rhyne of Ridgewood, N. J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Gerard White of Ridgewood.

A. Lincoln Stadler, head of Stadler Stadler, merchant tailors, 666 Fifth Avenue, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at the Forest Hills Surf Club, Atlantic Beach, L. I. He was 71 years old and lived at 2 Middle Bay Circle, Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.
Details of a Japanese-Australian trade agreement, effective yesterday, involving Australian wool and Japanese cotton goods were announced by the government today.

GOOSE FEATHERS. By George Digby. 12mo. New York: P. Dutton Co. $3. Reminiscences of a traveler and journalist. OFFICIAL HISTORY OF THE CANADIAN FORCES IN THE GREAT WAR, 1914-19. By Colonel A. Fortescue Duguid. 2 volumes. 8vo. Ottawa, Canada: Printed by J. O. Patenaude for the Department of National Defense. Vol I, $2; appendices and maps, $1.50.

A Summer school for lawyers who wish to study the latest developments in law will be opened Tuesday and continue to July 15 in airconditioned rooms of the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by Practicing Law Courses, of which leading members of the bench and bar are sponsors.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J. -The usual fireworks displays and a variety of special entertainment programs will be combined for the enjoyment of visitors here over the Fourth of July holiday.

The cornerstone of a $600,000 fieldhouse in memory of Knute Rockne, football coach; killed in an airplane crash in 1931, will be laid at the University of Notre Dame here Thursday. Warren Brown, Chicago
A decree of President Getulio Vargas, issued today, extended government financial help to certain private cultural, educational and welfare associations.

The International Aviation Congress in its sessions here decided to meet next year in New York. The president of the German Lufthansa, Baron C. A. von Gablenz, announced that an airline from Berlin over the Balkans, the Near East, British India and Singapore to the Philippines was about to be established.

Dipioinatische Korrespondens, the Foreign Office organ, places the responsibility, "according to British press dispatches," on the United States for extending the tonnage limits of the London naval treaty of 1936 to a maximum of 45,000 tons.

LARGER and more costly types have been displaced by low price cars as the chief potential users of high-octane, or high-test, gasoline, surveys now under way in a nation-wide network of motor clinics by engineers of the Ethyl Gasoline Corporation disclose.

FLORENCE. OF the many unique offerings of the Florentine Musical May, the most singular was the evening at the Teatro della Pergola dedicated to three "cultural revivals" of uncommon interest: Haydn's

BELGRADE. - In the barren Karat region of Herzegovina-part of the limestone plateau along the Yugoslav Adriatic coast--many peasants have found a new livelihood. They-catch and sell giant vipers, whose bite is fatal.

Fred Jacoby Jr., North Bergen, N. J.; Clinton Ferguson, Boston, and Jimmy Mullen, Richmond, dominated outboard motor-boat races today at the eleventh annual Hampton regatta, sponsored by the Hampton Yacht Club.

As a maker of legends, Stephen Vincent Benet is practically without a peer. Although he has written, to be sure, innumerable sound and pleasing stories in a purely conventional vein, fewof them have been really notable.

BRUCE MARSHALL is a Scotch novelist--though, for some reason or other, this simple circumstance is hard to keep in mind. So far he has not written about Scotland, or if he had the result has not been distributed to this sdie of the water.

Harry B. Brainerd, an architect and chairman of the public markets committee of the East Side Chamber of Commerce, was recently appointed by Columbia University McKim Fellow in Architecture for the present year, and he has gone to Europe to study city planning and architecture in many of the Baltic cities. He expects to spend considerable time in Moscow.

The National Investors Corporation reported yesterday a net asset value of $16,663,247, or $5.36 a share, on 3,110,661 shares, on June 30, compared with $16,022,676, or $4.80 a share, on 3,344,228 shares, on Dec. 31, 1937.

AFTER skimming over Scandinavia and moving onward across the Atlantic, a clear short-wave signal, believed to be that of the new Finnish station at Helsingfors, was picked up at 2 A. M. in this area a short time ago as a test program was run off on the 25-meter wave.
THE week's features at the Stadium are the national folk dance program on Thursday, the Hall Johnson Choir on Tuesday, and the first appearance of Macklin Marrow, conductor, on Saturday.

FirIng for record at Camp Smith here this week through three days of heavy rains and poor visibility was concluded last night, a day late, by nearly 1,500 members of the Tenth and 105th Infantry units of Albany and Troy, seeking to earn a rating as qualified marksmen.
Surrogate James A. Foley granted power of administration yesterday to Mrs. Frances S. Copeland, widow of Senator Royal S. Copeland, in response to a petition for probate of the will.

THE seventy-ninth music festival of the Worcester County Musical Association will be held Oct. 3-8 in the Municipal Auditorium, Worcester, Mass. Albert Stoessel again will conduct the Worcester Festival Chorus and Orchestra.

To the Screen Editor: I agree entirely that "Blockade" represents an encouraging deviation from the habitual Hollywood policy of evasion in the handling of political and social issues. I also agree that its attack on the inhuman massacre of non-combatants in Spain could have been made even more forceful.

PARIS. IT is a relief in our age of hectic bustle and frantic emotions to spend a couple of hours in the company of a gentle thinker who has kept a sense of permanent values and sticks to healthy activities of the mind. Such pleasure we enjoy in

BECAUSE of caution, ingenuity and Esperanto, which appear prominently in the scenario, Metro is approaching "Idiot's Delight" in a cheerful frame of mind, convinced it will not run afoul of the totalitarian nations which the Robert E. Sherwood play lampooned.

ON the flat acres of a "radio reservation" in the Mohawk Valley much has been learned about the mysteries of broadcasting as aerials of all shapes -and sizes have been used by experts at "the House of Magic" in their study of electrified space. This week WGY, affiliated with powerful twin shortwave stations, is dedicating new studios and celebrating another milestone In the development of radio.

The appointment of Stanley C. Cook and Thomas Wilding as assistant general managers of the Dominion Bank, Canada, was announced yesterday, according to a message received here by A. W. Rice, New York agent of the bank.
An event unprecedented on either labor or circus annals was enacted here this week. After a series of turbulent demonstrations and tempercharged conferences, the "greatest show on earth," with nearly

PARIS.-France has recently witnessed the separation of a small segment from her immense empire. The Sanjak of Alexandretta, in the corner of the mandated territory of Syria, passed from the control of France to the League of Nations and from the League it seems destined to fall under the control of Turkey, with what effect upon the uneasily balanced powers in the Eastern Mediterranean it is not yet easy to see.

Moreland Maid, one of America's greatest saddle horses, added another championship to the long list accumulated in her brilliant show career when she took the title today in the three-gaited division at the final session of the fifteenth annual exhibition of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

Kenneth H. Zabriskie, vice president -in charge of the mortgage department of the Franklin Society, recently collaborated with Mabel L. Walker in a study covering the present extent and anticipated spread of blighted areas and slums.

Formal festivities for debutantes of the "little season" on the North Shore were brought to a close tonight with a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps at Springhill, their estate here, to introduce to society their youngest daughter, Miss Sonia Phipps.

Miss Margaret Meister and Dr. William Gray Watson, both of Baltimore, were married yesterday in the Mercersburg Academy chapel by the Rev. Dr. James Gray Rose, retired Presbyterian clergyman, a great-uncle of Dr. Watson.

Miss Anne MacLeod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William MacLeod of River Bennett, Nova Scotia, was married to Dr. Howard W. Gourlie, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gourlie of Thompsonville, Conn., yesterday in the Marble Collegiate Church by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale.

Fred Jacoby Jr., who was dethroned last year by Doug Fonda as high point champion in outboard racing, is back on top of the standing, according to the tabulations for the season's first sixteen sanctioned regattas by George W. Sutton Jr., former A. P. B. A. president.

The champion eleven of the Brooklyn C. C. easily defeated a short-handed team representing the Crescent A. C. in a New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association fixture on the Stevens Institute grounds today. P. B. Green

TREADING on dangerous ground as far as censorship and freedom of speech are concerned, Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the FCC, confessing it is a delicate task, has announced that the commission plans to draw up rules for distributing time on the air to political candidates.

PARIS. THE Opera's recent "Fidelio" was not fully attended, but it must always be remembered that "Fidelio" in France is a different proposition from "Fidelio" in Vienna, Berlin, Dresden or Munich, where one hears it about once every ten days and sometimes oftener.

HOPEFUL that children will like it and that critical parents will join in the applause, WQXR, in cooperation with the New York Public Library, plans to offer a children's program featuring story-telling in its natural relationship to music. The first of these weekly folk tales will be on the air Wednesday at 5 o'clock, and will be aimed at children between the ages of 8 and 14.

Dr. Harry B. Wright, Philadeldelphia dentist and explorer, sailed yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Lucia to collect and analyze drugs used by the Jivaro head-hunting tribe in the Ecuadorean wilds. He said the drugs, made from wild vines and used by the Indians for centuries, had recently been reported by several explorers and hunters. Among others,

One important anniversary in Europe's political history passed unnoticed last week. It was twenty-four years ago, on June 28, 1914, that the Archduke Franz Ferdinand, heir to the Austrian throne, was assassinated by a Serbian agitator at Sarajevo, Bosnia.

President Roosevelt entertained Crown Princess Louise of Sweden and her party atop Dutchess Hill, the site of his future cottage home, this afternoon, and the breezes that whistled through the encircling oaks and pines carried before them the inviting smell of typical American fare-hot dogs and coffee.

In his most recent fireside chat President Roosevelt declared his intention to intervene in a few primary elections against "outspoken reactionaries" within his own party. He would do this, he said, not "as President of the United States," but rather "as the head of the Democratic party."

Construction of the new freight terminal shed at the Bronx Terminal market, 151st and Exterior Streets, will be started this month, Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade, announced yesterday.

Taking advantage of a moment of wildness by Sylvester Johnson, the Bees pushed over a brace of runs in the fourth inning today to beat the Phillies, 2-1. However, the Phils took the series, two games to one.
A Japanese fishing fleet, source of many charges that Japanese fishermen were encroaching on the valuable Alaska salmon run, has sailed away from Bristol Bay.

Donald Hawley of Orange, seeking honors for the fifth straight time in the Mountain Lakes Club invitation tennis tournament, advanced to the semi-finals today with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Jack Totten of Paterson.

WASHINGTON. - Fewer babies are being born on farms, notwithstanding that the total farm population is the largest in twenty-eight years. Only 719,000 babies were born on the farms last year to a total farm population of 31,819,000 persons.

War Admiral, who ran out of the money for the first time in his racing career when he grabbed his leg in the Massachusetts Handicap Wednesday at Suffolk Downs, "will be fit again in a week or ten days," his trainer said today.

Thomas G. Grace, FHA director for New York State, announced yesterday that nearly $11,000,000 has been borrowed for building repairs and modernization by the residents in New York City and the nine adjacent counties included in the city district of the Federal Housing Administration during the four-month period since Feb. 3 last,
Supply contracts valued at $5,667,632 were awarded in the week ended on June 30 by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.
Last Autumn the Chinese army retreated south through Hopeh with very little resistance to the Japanese advance. Elaborate - defense works were abandoned before the arrival of Japanese troops.

In the presence of only close friends and members of the family, funeral services were held late today at Los Poblanos ranch for Medill McCormick, 21, who was killed on a mountain-climbing expedition ten days ago.
The brisk upturn in specialty shop sales last week was held to presage the end of the long series of weekly sales declines which these shops experienced during the recession. Responding quickly

PRE-HOLIDAY trade in many sections of the country improved on its recent gains and in some centers ran ahead of a year ago. Certain stores here, for instance, were able to exceed their 1937 figures although the average dollar volume was a little less.

The North Gerran Lloyd liner Bremen sailed last night for the Channel ports with 1,100 passengers on board. Among them were the Duchess of Leeds, Lady Cunliffe-Owen, Judge Francis G. Caffey, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Baillie, Dr. and

More than 150 employes of the. Brunswick Laundry, at 222 Tonnelle Avenue, here, returned to work today following the ending of their ten-day strike last night. The remaining 500 employes will return to work on Tuesday.

The removal last week of more than $3,000,000,000 of railroad securities from the list of investments legal for savings banks and trust funds in this State, although the most sweeping revision of the eligible list ever undertaken at one time by the State Banking

On the basis of final figures made public by the Treasury today, the deficit for the fiscal year 1938 which ended Thursday, including debt retirements, was $1,459,248,100, or $371,000,000 more than estimated by President Roosevelt in his budget message in January.
Eastern United States open horseshoe pitching championships arranged by the Knickerbocker Horseshoe League of New York, Crotona Park, 170th Street and Crotona Avenue, 1 P. M.

ONE of the finest Boy Scout camp sites in America, made possible by a gift of $50,000, was dedicated yesterday by Boy Scouts and leaders of Buffalo, N. Y. The camp comprises 700 acres in the township of Bennington, thirtyone miles from the city.

DAME NATURE, adapted by Patricia Collinge from the French of Andre Birabeau, with Jessie Royce Landis, Onslow Stevens, Theodore Newton and Lois Hall in the cast. At the Country Playhouse, Westport, Conn. FRIDAY AT FOUR, a comedy by Ralph Holmes, with Kate Mayhew in the cast. At the Barter Theatre, Abingdon, Va.

About 3,000 persons, including more than 100 fellow-priests of the Dominican order, attended a solemn high mass of requiem yesterday morning for the Rev. William A. Marchant, at St. Vincent Ferrer's Church, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
Idle Miss, 4-year-old bay filly owned by B. F. Christmas of Baltimore, staged a powerful stretch run at Arlington Park today to win the $5,000 added Matron Handicap at one mile.

The Department of Commerce describes its report on the country's foreign trade in May as reflecting "the slowing-up in foreign demand for United States merchandise, which has been in evidence for several months." This would be no surprising result, in view of the moderate trade reaction abroad. All of the decrease in our

During the first six months of the present year the New Jersey office of the FHA received 4,924 applications for mortgage insurance involving $24,110,763. Of these, commitments were made on 3,432 applications in the sum of $16,545,600, the largest volume of business during any half year since the New Jersey office was opened three and one-half years ago, reports Thomas E. Colleton, State FHA director.

Each June at the close of the school term Eugene Nifenecker, director of the Board of Education's research bureau, estimates the number of children in the various branches of the school system that will attend classes the following March 31.

Last Sunday night there were reports in the British press that Generalissimo Francisco Franco had sent word here that the bombing of British ships by aviators under his control--if they are under his controlwould cease.

Four hundred passengers of the Cunard White Star liner Ascania, which sailed yesterday from Montreal for England, were forced to come back to Quebec and try again. The Ascania grounded at 11:30 A. M. today in the St. Lawrence 150 miles below this city.

One hundred and three entries established a new high for the season today in the annual regatta of the Mantoloking Yacht Club, the second in the series of championship contests of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.

Max Schmeling left these shores last night, probably never to return as a boxer. The Teuton Schlager, still bothered slightly from the effects of the body punch that Joe Louis landed on him with such force as to send him to the hospital, held court in his stateroom aboard the Bremen of the North German Lloyd line before the ship weighed anchor, and intimated that his ring career may be over.

Major league baseball, in the midst of two blistering pennant races, will declare its annual midsummer armistice this week when for the sixth time the pick of the American and National loops will clash in their All-Star game, which as a fixture has come to rank second only to the world series in the Fall.

TODAY fast trains and conducted tours make it easy for those with a limited holiday to enjoy a full program of -sight-seeing in Mexico. And to further smooth the visitor's path, specially trained tourist guides are now obtainable in large cities.

Physicians attending Associate Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court announced today that the justice "had not been well" and that they had resorted to use of an oxygen tent combined with cooling apparatus to conserve his strength.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Elton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Elton, and Lieutenant Robert James Hardy, U. S. N., son of Mrs. George Hardy of Pittsburgh, and the late,Mr. Hardy, took place this afternoon in the garden of the Elton home. The Rev. Riley M. Little of Albany officiated.

More than 1,000 delegates to the forty-seventh annual convention of the New York State Christian Endeavor Union, which ends tonight at Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, participated in a parade through the Borough Hall district to Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

The New York A. C. found the curves of Payson Brickley to its liking today and defeated the Penn A. C. at the Phillies' ball park, 7-2. Brickley gave way to Red Taggert after the New Yorkers scored their final three runs in the sixth.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent editorial THE TIMES reached the conclusion that this country should not participate in the Olympic Games in Japan in 1940, and pointed out that the decision involves a moral judgment.

The overwhelming majority of Americans can be relied upon to cooperate in the care and protection of parks and recreation places if they are provided with the best, Rogert Moses has learned from his experience as head of New York's widely known State and city park and parkway bodies.

Cardinal Hayes and Bishops and monsignon from all parts of the city were among nearly 5,000 persons who attended the funeral service yesterday morning for Mgr. Patrick N. Breslin, Roman Catholic dean of the Bronx, at the Church of Our Lady of Mercy, Marion Avenue and Fordham Road.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

On the course of his first great triumph, Henry Cotton today was favored to retain his British open golf championship. Though he has fought a losing battle all year against a rebellious putter, Hilarious Henry was given the edge over Alfred Perry, champion in 1935.

Realty activity in Manhattan over the week-end included sales of tenement houses in Harlem by banks. The New York Savings Bank disposed of the five-story building at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and 103d Street to the 68 West 134th Street Corporation.

A decided revival in new capital offerings is in progress, but the total for June was only o8,509,247, the lowest for the month since the World War. The figure compares with o27,397,880 in May and o24,514,648 in June, 1937.

As a preliminary to a vigorous drive against gambling and against night clubs staying open after hours, the entire divisional staff of the Fourth Division, which polices the East Side from Fourteenth to Eighty-sixth Streets and from Fifth Avenue to the East River, has been replaced, it became known yesterday.

There will be no performance of the Gallo-Shubert production, "Show-Boat," tonight at Randalls Island. The operetta's run will be resumed tomorrow night and continue through Sunday. "Countess Maritza" will be the succeeding bill.
More than 150 workmen labored today to clear rights of way of three landslides, which damaged an engine of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad and delayed four crack trains more than twelve hours.
Ending a week of intensive investigation into New York angles on the death of Charles Morris, victim of the "cement murder mystery" in South Hadley, Mass.,

100-METER DASH Semi-Finals (First two in each heat and fastest third man qualify for final. First Heat-Won by Mozel Ellerbe, Tuskegee (Ala.) Institute: second, Perrin Walker, New York A. C.; third, Herbert Thompson, New York Pioneer Club; fourth, Donald Dunn, Pittsburg (Kan.) Teachers; fifth, Lee Orr, Washington State College. Time--:10.9.
Newark divided with Syracuse today, winning by 6 to 4 after dropping the opener, 4 to 2, before 10,000 at Ruppert Stadium. Jack Fallon held the Chiefs to seven hits in the seven-inning second game.

The forty-seventh annual convention of the New York State Christian Endeavor Union, which opened last Thursday night in Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, closed yesterday.

Some 175 Puerto Rican school teaches attending the university Summer school here have pledged themselves to see no Spanish, hear no Spanish and speak no Spanish for six weeks, using only English instead. Next Fall they expect to return to their class rooms better prepared to teach English to their pupils, whose mother tongue is Spanish.

The crack 4-year-old Victrix, owned by Joseph E. Widener of Philadelphia, won the Prix President de la Republique at Saint Cloud in a field of thirteen that included the best French horses of all ages. After the race Mr. Widener was congratulated by President Lebrun, who attended.

The educated man of today is ill-fitted to meet the issues of life except through religion, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Evidence that certain leading investment interests here visualize business recovery in the United States before long is furnished by the impending formation of a new unit investment trust which will confine its investments entirely to United States industrial securities.

Emperor Hirohito today set the example for an empire economizing to finance its war in China. Ordering widespread retrenchments, Hirohito substituted native sake for foreign wines and Japanese cigars and cigarettes instead of foreign-tobacco at ceremonial occasions of the imperial palace.
Hundreds of house owners in the fashionable suburbs have been ordered by National Socialist organizations to give notice immediately to Jewish tenants to vacate their apartments within a fortnight.

Captain Stephen Booth McKinney, U. S. N., and Mrs. McKinney, at present in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Booth McKinney, to Alexander Yelverton Peyton Garnett Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Yelverton Peyton Garnett of Washington, D. C.

Where there was a dearth of wind yesterday there was plenty today, and ninety-three starters had real sailing in the second of the special Sunday regattas of the Larchmont Yacht Club. There were twenty-three Star sloops and twenty-one Internationals to build up the fleet.

The disappearance of a 4-year-old boy brought more than 100 men into the rugged Fall River country to search for him tonight. Albert Beilhartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Harvey Beilhartz of Denver, became separated from his father today while the family was in Rocky Mountain National Park for a weekend outing.
The French wholesale price index on June 25 stood at 651, compared with 649 a week earlier, and 645 two weeks earlier.

Captain Ashley C. McKinley, who was an aviator ?? the first Byrd Antarctic expedition, got a ducking in Great South Bay this evening when his cub seaplane overturned during a test of-a new type of pontoon, about a mile offshore.
Walter Walsh, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who helped wipe out the Al Brady gang, established a new world's record--today for revolver shooting.

So it is to be the Dodgers against the Giants to make a Harlem holiday. The heartless Giants have been treating their neighbors horribly this season. But the revolt may come at any moment. In fact, this was hinted by Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants, who said, in speaking of the approaching double-header, weather permitting:
Lady Norton-Griffiths, who arrived on the Bremen, is at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. W. MacFarlane Barker of Phoenix, Ariz., who were at the Ambassador, have gone to the Lake Placid Club.
It has been found advisable to change the name Theodore Roosevelt, given to a prize ape brought by the Asiatic Primate Expedition from Siam last Summer.
Governor A. Harry Moore celebrated his fifty-ninth birthday quietly here today at the Little White House, the seventh such anniversary he has spent in the Executive Mansion.

One person was killed and nine were injured when an open-rack truck with twelve holiday-bound men, women and children overturned on a circular strip of road near the Newark Airport restaurant at 6 o'clock this morning.

The 110-room country residence that the late William K. Vanderbilt built for $2,500,000 in the early Nineteen Hundreds at Oakdale, Suffolk County, and called Idlehour, will be renamed Peace Haven in dedication exercises today and devoted to "the study of life" by the- Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians.

The revelations published in yesterday's TIMES from the diary of an escaped Soviet general, said to be head of the Far Eastern secret police, would sound more credible if they were not issued to the press of Tokyo by the Japanese authorities.

Preparing to embark on a program of united social and political action, delegates of the Federated Chapters of the Henry George Fellowship opened their national conference yesterday at the headquarters of the Henry George School of Social Science, 211 West Seventy-ninth Street.

Rabbi Morris S. Lazaron of Baltimore today called upon the American people to set their house in order, as a matter of personal and national self-interest, and then, before it was too late, to "take their stand. with the liberty-loving nations- against the ruthless masters of the oppressed millions within: the dictator lands whose mad ambition drags the world toward war."
Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh Of the new Archdiocese of Newark officiated today at the laying of the cornerstone of the new Holy Family Church here.

The assemblage here today to hear President Roosevelt honor the heroes of seventy-five years ago was spread over a wide slope leading up to the Peace Memorial. Thousands more sat on road embankments along the President's route.

Various types of "destructive principles which seek to take away our independence, both as a nation and as States, communities and individuals," were described as "roaring lions" in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Paul Y. Livingston at St. Andrew's Lutheran Church, 122d Street and 111th Avenue, Queens.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The "Wonder City of the World," beyond a doubt; the "cleanest city," by no means. But we must make it that. In view of next year's fair, the Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness feels that we New Yorkers have a solemn duty.

Germany's demand for the return of her colonies was supported at a meeting today of the Hamburg branch of the Reich Colonial League. Speakers said Germany's colonial demands will be pressed until they are fulfilled.
The steel market virtually came to a standstill last week because of reductions in prices announced on the preceding Friday on all important lines except two.

There is no seasonal aspect to true religious devotion, the Rev. W. John Villaume, the assistant pastor, contended yesterday morning in his sermon in St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

The Fokine Ballet was presented by Fortune Gallo tonight at Jones Beach in a program of dance creations by Michel Fokine. An audience of 7,500 watched the dancers on the island stage across the waters of Zachs Bay.

The administrative committee of the American Labor party probably will be called to meet this week to act on the demand of David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, that Governor Lehman be substituted for Sidney Hillman as a candidate for United States Senator on the party slate.

The delegates to the Chaco peace conference worked feverishly yesterday and today trying to arrange a formula that would prove acceptable to Bolivia and Paraguay at tomorrow's session. It was said in well-informed circles today that this formula would be the neutrals' last attempt to settle the dispute.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against EVEGEORGE HOSIERY COSMETIC SHOPS, INC., 300 E. 204th St.-By Stylecraft Sales Corp., for $200; Wear-Rite Brassiere Co., Inc., $80; National Blouse Corp., $160; New Zan Bandeau Co., Inc.. $S5. .. $S5.

" Safe and Sane" Independence Day celebration, Riverdale-Spuyten Duyvil communities in the Bronx at the base of World War Soldiers Monument in the Hendrick Hudson Circle, West 239th Street and Riverdale Avenue, at 6:15 A. M. Flag to be unfurled in honor of Guola Morisani by William Irwin Post 774, American Legion.

ABOUT ten or eleven years ago an interviewer writing for The New York World (it was Harry Salpeter) bid welcome to a new literary celebrity. This visitor from England had, the interviewer opined, a face and figure to make a movie hero's fortune. He seemed a "candid, charming, clever boy," and his name was Beverley Nichols.

This being Independence Day, the theatre as a whole will celebrate by shooting off some matinee fireworks. Of the eleven Broadway plays and musical shows now operating, nine will hold holiday performances; two-"You Can't Take It with You" and "I'd Rather Be Right"-will not.

The French occupation of Sisha Island is played up by the Japanese press, most papers asserting that it is illegal because it violates Chinese territorial rights. They are apparently unconscious of the irony of such statements coming from Japan.
Several Stockholm firms are in a curious situation since Germany's annexation of Austria, as both the ousted Jewish businessmen and their "Aryan" successors now claim payment for goods delivered.

Many entertainments were held today for holiday guests. Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff gave a lunchon at the Southampton Beach Club for Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Shattuck of Pirate's Hill, Woodbury, L. I.

Plans for ceremonies commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Battles of Chickamauga, Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge are being made by the Interior Department as the result of a resolution passed by the last session of Congress.

Peace and freedom in the United States are seriously threatened by the very persons whose sworn duty it is to protect those principles, the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Firemen fought a blaze in a stationery store here this morning to the accompaniment of popping firecrackers from the storekeeper's Fourth of July supplies. The fire started in the basement of a two-story building at 142 Jericho Turnpike and spread to the first floor, occupied by Harry Oshansky.

The interim report of Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, covering the nine months ended on May 31, shows gross income of $2,977,935 from 280,445 tons of mine ore and 15,671 tons of tailings treated for an average of $10.06 a ton milled.
Commissioner Valentine apologized handsomely to Mrs. Ethel Tarvanovich who was arrested, photographed, finger-printed and imprisoned overnight

Two of the major transatlantic steamship lines are celebrating anniversaries this week. Today, with Independence Day festivities in which American travelers will be engaged while at sea, officers and crews of all Cunard White Star ships will observe the ninety-eighth anniversary of the founding of the Cunard Line, reckoned from the day in 1840 when Samuel Cunard sent out the paddlewheel steamship Britannia, the first in his regular passenger-cargo service.

The National League All-Star team faced the possibility of losing another of its elected players today when Hank Leiber, the Giants' center fielder, aggravated a charley horse in his right thigh while running bases in the sixth inning of the second game of a double-header with the Bees.

More than half of Hopeh as well as most of Shansi and parts of Chahar are under the effective control of Chinese provincial governments under the Central Government at- Hankow. Though these governments are under Communist influence they are loyal to Hankow.
Mr. and Mrs. John Gilpin of this city yesterday observed the sixtieth anniversary of their marriage. Wed in Wappingers Falls, N. Y., they have been residents of Paterson many years.

Timpson Pl (10-2603), S, 542 it w of Whitlock Ave, 117x100; Timlock Realty Corp to Henrietta Lorber. 3,351 Reservoir Oval West. Longwood Ave (10-2696), n, s 41 ft w of Dawson St, 78x107: Jolrane Realty Corp to Julia Lorber. 3,351 Reservoir Oval West; mtge, $77,000.

The mild reproof of the Senate campaign investigating committee seems to have been accepted by the irrepressible Aubrey Williams as a go-ahead signal, and we have now been getting one or two speeches a day from him, which, if they are not political campaigning, are certainly separated from it by the finest of hair lines.

George Caster of the Athletics and Monte Weaver of the Senators pitched four-hit games today as their teams split a double-header. Philadelphia won the first, 3 to 0, and Washington the second, 14 to 2.

A garden luncheon and fashion show will be held Wednesday at Whitehall, the estate of Mrs. Herbert L. Pratt Jr. in Mill Neck, L. I., to raise funds for the Children's Village of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. An exhibition of photograph portraits will be a feature of the event.

A new All Nations Prize Novel Competition is announced by a group of publishers in England, France Germany, Hungary, Sweden, Poland, the United States, Italy, The Netherlands and Czechoslovakia. This is the second competition of its kind.

It was revealed today that the assassination of President Getulio Vargas was the chief motive for the assault on the palace, his private residence, on the night of May 11 by a Fascist group, when the police handed to the Security Tribunal the results of their inquiry.

Announcement was made yesterday at the headquarters of Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding at Governors Island, that thirty-nine recent R. O. T. C. graduates from colleges in New York, New Jersey and Delaware have been selected to serve a one-year tour of active duty as reserve second lieutenants with regular army regiments of the Second Corps Area. The duty period will begin tomorrow.

Bing is only a mongrel, but he is a real hero now. He saved one life and almost lost his own. When a fire started today in a junk company, where Bing is locked up every night to guard the property, he barked an alarm. John

The Rebels launched a drive toward Villavieja and Nules from the crossroads below Bechi this afternoon. This writer was in the Nules sector a half hour later, which was too soon to see how the tide of battle would turn.

For the first time since his admittance as a patient last Tuesday, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden left the eleventh floor of the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday.
Tomorrow-just another Independence Day in many towns-seems destined to go down in history here as the day on which they liberated the snakes.
One of the largest dinner parties tonight was given by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Holmsen at Stoneacre. Mr. and Mrs. R. Beverley Corbin also had dinner guests.
Howard Hughes, wealthy manufacturer and amateur flier, landed here tonight at the end of the first leg of a transcontinental flight to New York, from where he plans to take off for Paris.

A Franco-Turkish pact of friendship and a declaration concerning collaboration between Turkey, France and Syria over the Sanjak of Alexandretta were signed here today by Tewfik Rushdu Aras, Turkish Foreign Minister, and Henri Ponsot, the French Ambassador.
The British Government's program for financial and economic cooperation with the Danubian States is nearing completion, according to the newspaper Az Est.
American business will have its "day in court " at the monopoly investigation, it was indicated in a statement made today by Senator O'Mahoney, chairman of the investigating committee.
Dominated entirely by Wall Street's vigorous recovery, British security and commodity markets experienced a general revival last week.

New York City was an oasis of peace and quiet last night surrounded by the shouting and tumult of crowded beach, lake and mountain holiday resorts as all of the city's millions who could took advantage of an ideal Summer day to start celebration of the country's 162d Independence Day anniversary.
The condition of United States Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo, who is ill here, is slightly improved, Joseph Rauh, his secretary, said today.
The Naumburg Orchestra, conducted by Jaffrey Harris, the Federal Music Project's director for Westchester County, will give a concert tonight at 8:15 o'clock on the Mall in Central Park.
The last-place Browns won both ends of a double-header today to sweep a three-game series with the Tigers. It was the first three-in-a-row for the Brownies this season.
