A quick turnover involved the six-story elevator apartment house at 1,517 Jesup Avenue, near Featherbed Lane, the Bronx, when the property was resold by Julius Kahan, operator, to a client of Harry Fogler.
Nursing a blistered heel, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody remained abed in her West End hotel today and refused to see visitors, while Britain buzzed with stories of her rivalry with Miss Helen Jacobs.

Under the Impetus of Bob Seeds's third major league home run of the year, the Giant machine roared on to its seventh straight victory today in the first half of a twin bill with Casey Stengel's Bees--and then cracked up.

Formal application for a Federal loan of $1,971,000 for construction of a low-cost housing project here was filed with the State Housing Authority in Newark yesterday by John A. Kervick, secretary-treasurer of the Elizabeth Housing Authority.
Vito Felecia, 25 years old, of Brooklyn, won the Eastern United States open horseshoe pitching championship in a tournament yesterday in Crotona Park, the Bronx.

An overdose of Jeffersonian liberalism is afflicting the nation, the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Shoemaker, the rector, declared yesterday morning in his sermon in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

Thornton Lee, White Sox southpaw, sliced Cleveland's American League lead over the Yankees to a game and a half today by shutting out the Indians, 3 to 0, after Johnny Allen had scored his twelfth consecutive triumph for the tribe, 2 to 1.

Mrs. Alleine Conley, 26 years old, of 27 Maple Avenue, Mount Kisco, N. Y., was drowned early yesterday in Lake Oscawana, near Peekskill, when the motor boat in which she, her husband and three other men were returning from a dance overturned in thirty-five feet of water.

The Radley College crew, which won the Ladies' Plate in the Royal Henley Regatta, has accepted Father Sill's invitation to be the guests of Kent School on a rowing tour of the United States and will sail for New York on Saturday.

The Rev. Dr. William B. Riley, president of the Northwestern Bible School and pastor of the First Baptist Church of Minneapolis, in his sermon yesterday as guest pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, sounded a call for "leaders who can do the big jobs" in the Lord's behalf.

ALTMANN--Joseph late of 1,224 Washington Ave., Bronx, beloved father of Malvina Altmann Miller. Services from Hirsch Sons Chapel, Prospect Ave. corner 165th St.. Bronx, today. 10 A. M. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery.
The highly susceptible Chancellor who found it such an ordeal in his court to sit all day giving agreeable girls away

Until the uncertainties connected with the radical changes in prices and pricing methods now being put into effect in the steel industry can be cleared up, little effect on buying will follow the heavy cuts in prices of steel products and pig iron, the magazine Steel says today.

In the absence of new international irritants, business sentiment here early last week was decidedly better. Even before announcement of the Anglo-German debts and. commercial agreement, increased investment buying was reported on the Boerse.

George L. R. French, receiver for the Rutland Railroad Company, announced today a 15 per cent wage cut after union workers had notified him they would not take a voluntary cut which he recently suggested.

The cotton market here was fairly active last week and the tone was generally firm, although reactions from time to time held the improving tendency somewhat in check and late in the week some profits were taken.
The Sokol festival reached its zenith today in an even more brilliant display of coordinated mass movement than had been witnessed on the great day of the junior Sokols last Sunday.

The domestic demand for pig iron continues active but the export demand is weak and prices are lower. Iron ore production in the first four months of 1938 reached 4,250,100 tons which is 50 per cent above the 1937 figure.

On the ground that "no harm was done" the Appellate Division has decided to withhold disciplinary action against Municipal Justices O'Rourke and McNulty and Attorney Francis V. Goggins in the matter of changing the name of Simon W. Gerson to "Samuel W. Gilson" in the record of a rent case.

The general picketing conducted by strikers of the Busch Jewelry Company and affiliates in various parts of the city as a substitute for direct picketing of the stores, which has been prohibited under the injunction issued by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo, was interrupted yesterday but will be resumed today on an even larger scale, spokesmen for the two C. I. O. unions involved in the Busch strike declared yesterday.

Atmospheric conditions being just right yesterday the telescope men were out in full force, waging-their own private little price war on Forty-second Street near the Public Library, last stand of the peek at-Venus entrepreneurs.

To avoid any possible stigma of pro-nazism, German and Austrian war veterans, in convention here today, voted to eliminate "bund" from their name and include Hungarian war veterans in the organization.

Jersey City made a clean sweep of its three-game series with the Orioles today by taking the third and final game, 3 to 1. Glenn Gabler went the route for the Little Giants, limiting the Orioles to three singles.

Looking at Europe on the anniversary' of the Declaration of Independence, it is natural to ponder the relation of the New World to the Old. This is the day when we remember that the independence proclaimed by the Congress at Philadelphia was primarily independence of Europe.

With their leader, G. H. (Pete) Bostwick a dominant figure throughout the match, the unbeaten Bostwick Field poloists halted Aknusti, 6 to 4, on their home turf today and brilliantly continued their Meadow League supremacy in the Meadow Brook Club's tourney for twenty-goal teams.

Near the Lagoon of Nations in the foreign exhibit section of the World's Fair site in Flushing, work has just started on the British Pavilion which will house the main exhibits of British industry and commerce at the fair.
The two Governors Island quartets inaugurated their Eastern Polo League championship campaigns yesterday against service rivals from the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn.

We had welcome news this morning when a letter arrived from Louis Mowbray of Bermuda telling us that he is again going to fish with the British team in the international tuna matches to be held in Nova Scotia in August. Louis was the captain of the-British team last year and is as active an angler as you'll find anywhere.
Six pickets were arrested on disorderly conduct charges at the Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon shortly before the start of the game between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox.

Indications of progress in the unsolved problem of medical protection for employes are cited in a report issued today by the industrial relations section of the Department of Economics and Social Institutions of Princeton University.

Frank Kovacs faced the scorching onslaught of one of the best forehand drives tennis has produced, and his Eastern debut ended in a stunning defeat today on the velvet turf of the Nassau Country Club.

(All Clubs Play Two Games) Brooklyn at New York-Mungo (3-7) and Pressnell (6-6) vs. Schumacher (7-5) and Castleman (3-2). Boston at Philadelphia-Errickson (0-4) and Lanning (3-1) vs. Mulcahy (5-9) and Smith (0-1).

Upsets marked today's opening match-play rounds in the New York A. C. Fourth of July tournament on the Hotel Champlain golf course. George J. Gillespie, medalist and favorite, lost on the nineteenth hole to Dr. J. H. Harris. F. W. Regan, another favorite, lost to C. N. Calkins, 2 and 1.

The final, practical test of the reality of Christ is in His oneness with the world, with life, with His fellowmen and with God, the Rev. Frederick W. Norwood, special preaching missioner of the Free Church Council of Great Britain, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church.

The New York Civic Orchestra, conducted by F. Charles Adler, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the Federal Music Theatre. Caesar Finn was the commentator. The program consisted of Edgar Still-man-Kelly's "The Pit and the Pendulum," Rabaud's "Nocturnal Procession," Hadley's overture to "Herod" and numbers by Bizet, Debussy and Dukas.

Mrs. Mary Cooke Branch Munford, long actively identified with educational movements in Virginia and the South, champion of better interracial relations and women's rights, died early today at her home here. She was 72 years old, the widow of Beverley B. Munford, Richmond lawyer and author.
The Pirates paraded to their fifth-straight victory and their twenty-first in twenty-nine games today by sweeping a double-header with the Cardinals. 6 to 5 and 6 to 2.

Hyman P. Binswanger, a retired dealer in minerals and ores, died yesterday while visiting relatives in West Philadelphia. His age was 87. Born in this city, he was a founder and first secretary of the Young Men's Hebrew Association and was active in Jewish communal life.
Independence Day is a pretty serious occasion in these times, if one stops to think of it. It is a lot more than a chance to burn one's fingers with firecrackers.

Senator Sheppard, chairman of the Senate Campaign Funds Committee, expressed belief today that Aubrey Williams of the Works Progress Administration was '-'within his rights" when he told the American Youth Congress "You must organize to get power into the hands of the workers."
Collecting sixteen hits, the New York A. C. routed the Hilton Baseball Club of Brooklyn, 11--5, yesterday at Travers Island for its sixth successive victory and the second in two days.

Accused of beating two Nassau County patrolmen until they were almost insensible, five young men from Manhattan were held for the grand jury on second - degree assault charges when they waived examination before District Judge Norman F. Lent here this afternoon.

The church may not be able to stop war, the Rev. Gilbert P. Symonds of Cincinnati, Canon of the Episcopal diocese of Southern Ohio, said here tonight, but it has set the brakes fast and hard against it.

Miss Mary Newberry Hooker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hooker of Longmeadow, was married yesterday to Robert Morris Cavanaugh of Woodbury, N. J., son of Professor and Mrs. Robert E. Cavanaugh of Indianapolis.

On the occasion of Gracie Fields's American debut we grope for the appropriate quotation. "There's some corner of a foreign field that is forever England" obviously won't do. Perhaps the one about Britain's battles being won on the playing fields. . . - . ?
Reports that Guy Kimball, disabled war veteran, has discovered a rich outcropping of gold ore on his ranch at Fernbrook on San Vicente Creek were received here today.

Little change in the corn market was reported last week, and prices held within narrow limits, the effect of a revival in the export demand being offset by beneficial rains over the main producing area and the disposition shown by farmers to sell part of their surplus holdings on all small upturns in the market.

Celebrating his eighteenth birthday one day in advance, Joseph Fishbach, St. John's University ace, captured the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship by vanquishing Gerard D. Podesta of Montclair, Princeton's captain-elect, in the final of the sixteenth annual tournament today at the Montclair The Athletic Club. The scores were 6-3, 2-6, 6-1, 6-0.

The Lenox Summer branch shop of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work will be officially opened for its fourth season on Tuesday at its new headquarters in the Lenox Academy building, opposite its former location.

A campaign to bring under civil service some 200,000 positions now specifically exempted by law from the operation of the merit system, will be waged by the National League of Women Voters as a part of its activities in connection with the forthcoming Congressional elections, it was announced today.

Rain continues to bring destruction in Eastern Japan. Only twice have the rains stopped temporarily in two weeks. Railway service between Tokyo and Kobe was again interrupted by landslides in Shizuoka prefecture.

Representatives of the B. M. T. in the pending negotiations with the city and the Transit Commission for the unification of rapid transit lines are asking that the city purchase not only the company's subway and elevated properties but also its street-car and bus systems in Brooklyn and Queens.

The sixteen-mile section of the Merritt Parkway between this city and the New York State line already has carried 125,000 cars since its formal opening Wednesday afternoon, State police reported today.

The Bar Harbor Club held this evening the first buffet supper of a series, at which many members of the Summer colony entertained. One of the largest parties was given by Mr. and Mrs. William McNair of New York.
An elaborate fireworks display given at the Wyantenuck Country Club here tonight entertained a company of more than 200 who attended a buffet supper and dance.
Twenty-two volunteer firemen were treated for minor injuries today in this city's worst fire since 1883.

After leading all day in the second of a three-day Eastern championship regatta of the Model Yacht Racing Association of America, William Perfect of the Atlantic Club at Amityville dropped to third place at the close of the day's contests.

An agreement between the German and Polish education ministries, announced here today, provides that school textbooks will be revised to eliminate "all expressions and phrases liable to offend the national feelings of either country."

New State and municipal financing in June aggregated $176,745,475, compared with $110,554,331 in June, 1937, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for the first half of 1938 was $723,308,511, compared with $621,629,001 in the first half of 1937.
Hungary won the European bridge championship today with a total score of 9 points. Norway was second with 7.
European Stock Exchanges have followed Wall Street's sudden outburst of buoyancy with ready enthusiasm.
Delegates to Canada's first national convention of Fascists moved today from their secret sessions here to Toronto to attend a mass meeting tomorrow night.

The half-year ended without any signs of monetary pressure. The market borrowed nothing from the Bank of England, and this fact makes something like history, because only once before since the war-last December-had the half-year been negotiated without such assistance.

Immortal deeds and immortal words have created here a shrine of American patriotism. We are encompassed by "the last full measure of devotion" of many men and by the words in which Abraham Lincoln expressed the simple faith for which they died.

Unionized employes of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Labor Department charged yesterday that the division's staff had put in 252,000 hours of overtime work in the last six months and that "the lack of a realistic approach to the problem" by State and Federal officials had caused many workers to collapse on the job.

When men and nations lose their transcendent faith they undermine their lives, the Rev. John Thorn Golding of the cathedral staff said in his sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

The German wholesale price index on June 22 stood at 105.5, compared with 105.4 on June 15. In the first five months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.8 on March 2.

Japanese announcements that the breaks in the Yellow River dikes will be repaired within a month seem extremely optimistic, following an aerial survey trip conducted today under the auspices of Japanese military authorities here.
A moving picture directed by Henry Ford had its world premiere at the motor maker's historical shrine, Greenfield Village, last night.
Mr. and Mrs. W. Wyman Aldrich gave a cocktail party for 300 persons at the Devon Yacht Club this afternoon.
President Roosevelt arrived at the White House tonight soon after 10 o'clock on his return from Gettysburg. As he went to his train after delivering his speech he wore a happy smile.

Hundreds of Sunday visitors to Central Park saw the competitive spirit flare on the Seventy-second Street Lake, usually disturbed only by the leisurely progress of rowboats, when the annual metropolitan canoe paddling championships were held by the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association yesterday.

Peter Riedel of Germany announced today that he was going to Washington in his motorless sailplane. Late in the afternoon he reported his landing at Arlington (Va.) Airport, 225 air miles from Elmira, breaking all American distance records and making himself eligible for the $1,500 cash prize just offered for such a flight.
State Senator Clee, Republican nominee for Governor of New Jersey last year, will retire from politics at the end of his present term A clergyman, he gives as his reason his duty to his church.
The Bourse was more animated this week after some hesitation caused by profit-taking, and closed very firm all around. It was stimulated both by the rise on Wall Street and raw material prices.

The nation's problems may be solved by getting back to the basic principles of human conduct and not through any particular party, class or ideology, the Rev. Willard E. Rice, the assistant pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Winmill of New York and Warrenton, announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Winmill, to Robert H. Radsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Radsch of Appleton, Wis.

The second annual report to employes of Remington Rand, Inc., shows that- 85.3 per cent of earnings for the year ended on March 31, 1938; went to employes after deducting cost of materials, supplies, bond interest, taxes, cost of replacements and other expenses, while 12.7 per cent-of earnings went to stockholders in cash and stock dividends and 2 per cent was retained and invested in the business.
Dr. Homer Gage, philanthropist, surgeon and industrialist, died suddenly of a heart attack at his home in suburban Shrewsbury early today. He was 77 years old.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrives today from Southampton and Cherbourg. Among her passengers are Captain G. E. T. Eyston, English racing motorist; Josef Hofmann, noted pianist, and Mrs. Hofmann; Joseph W. Powell, naval architect:

Clifford Grover's Teaser won her first start of the season today as the Barnegat Bay fleet of International Star Class yachts competed in the second race of the elimination series to select representatives for the world championship in California and the Atlantic Coast championship at Riverside, Conn.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.9, which compares with 81.1 the week before, 81.0 two weeks before, 80.7 three weeks before and 80.5 four weeks before.

Unofficial returns from yesterday's run-off primary for a Democratic nominee for Congress from North Carolina's Eighth District gave W. O. Burgin, Lexington attorney, a slender margin over his opponent, C. B. Deane, Rockingham lawyer.

The First Baptist Church of Exeter unveiled this afternoon a bronze plaque erected in memory of the late Ambrose Swasey, of Cleveland and Exeter. The plaque is a copy of an original one executed by Victor D. Brenner, designer of the Lincoln penny.
Suzanne Lenglen, noted French tennis player, died at her home at 6:50 A. M. today (1:50 A. M., Monday, New York time). She had been critically ill the last week of pernicious anemia.

Percy White, novelist, died here today at the age of 86. Educated in France, he was a schoolmate of de Maupassant. Later he came to London and edited Public Opinion for ten years, then The London Evening News until 1893, when Alfred Harmsworth, who became Lord Northcliffe, purchased it to make his first incursion in newspaper ownership.

Miss Mollie Page, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Page of County Line Farm, this place, will be married on the afternoon of July 15 to Anderson Fowler Hewitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Hewitt of Cold Spring Harbor.
James Roosevelt, son and secretary of President Roosevelt, will leave St. Mary's Hospital briefly Monday for X-ray examinations at the Mayo clinic. Physicians,

This week Franklin Delano Roosevelt rides to the wars. He has proclaimed his purpose, to reshape the Democratic party into a united instrument of liberalism. He has sounded his rallying call, "Let liberals follow me; conservatives, oppose." And now,

German industry remained quiet last week as manufacturers awaited developments under the new labor conscription ordinance. According to official reports, 340,000 more were employed in industry in May than in the same month in 1937.

Last week's export and trade analyses were unfavorable. The Trade Research Institute holds that the international trade shrinkage has not been terminated and that the industrial exports of the nations continue to suffer.

The first Trade Commissioner of India to the United States will arrive today aboard the Queen Mary. He is Hardit Singh Malik of Lahore. Mr. Malik has been associated with East Indian affairs for many years. Although he dresses in European clothes he always wears a turban, sixty of which he has in his luggage to match his suits.

Stephen Randock, In 139 E. 57th St, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens. Inc., brokers. Christian A. Hansen, insurance broker, in 100 William St; General Samuel McRoberts, in 55 Liberty St; Maryland Coal Co of West
The six-round bout between Al Davis and Bernie Friedkin, scheduled for Dexter Park a week from tonight, promises to attract the greatest "small-club" crowd of the season.

The Fourth of July week-end headed last night toward a higher violent-death toll than the seventy-two-hour Memorial Day span. There were 223 violent deaths reported by mid-evening with another twenty-four hours to go in the week-end.

When the proper time comes, the American people will play the largest part as pioneers of a new and greater world democracy, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Prince declared yesterday before the congregation of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street. Dr. Prince,

British aeronautical correspondents who were passengers in first regular empire flying boat service from Southampton to Australia, sent last night some remarkable dispatches of their treatment at Darwin, "aviation's gateway to Australia." They arrived there yesterday after covering 10,455 miles in seven days, three hours and forty-five minutes.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,840,678,450. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Urged on by an overpowering curiosity, which has frequently been known to bring disaster to cats and folks alike, the Red Sox barged into the Stadium yesterday for a one-day visit to find for themselves whether the recent eruptions that have been startling the baseball world were the genuine article or just something the boys have been shooting off in anticipation of another Glorious Fourth.

With Bill Gillespie, national interscholast champion, winning the singles fin? this afternoon after teaming with Don Buffington to capture the doubles in the morning, Sca borough School ended Choate's five year monopoly of the Eastern ?terscholastic invitation tennis tournament at the Manursing island Club.

Apparently seized with a cramp as he pushed his small Cape Cod sailboat through the shallow waters of Great South Bay last night, Cornelius J. Kiely Jr., son of the vice president and general manager of the Jamaica Water Supply Company, disappeared in the darkness and his wife, after a futile search, drifted all night in the open boat.

Edward V. Ketcham Jr., sailing Draco, and Charles L. Lawrence, in Chief, were tied for first place today in the Star Class series after the second contests in the three-day Babylon Yacht Club regatta. Lawrence finished first yesterday and third today, while Ketcham won today and took third yesterday.
Harry A. Reffelt was co-broker in the recent sale of the two houses at 414-16 West 118th Street for the Republic of Panama.

The twenty-seven buses of the Royal Blue Line Sight-seeing Service remained in their garages for the second day yesterday as the strike of chauffeurs and lecturers employed by the service continued to be 100 per cent effective. The strike began on Saturday.

Science must march forward "hand in hand with religion" or "fall useless and neglected by the wayside," the Rev. Dr. John Gass, pastor of the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, declared in his morning sermon yesterday.

With Bundesfuehrer Fritz Kuhn "rededicating" the organization to a "free and independent America," some 9,000 members and friends of the German-American Bund from New York City and Long Island celebrated Independence Day at Camp Siegfried today.

" The greatest menace to America today is not Communism nor the arms and armaments of a foreign nation, but the decadence of religion, the falling away of the American people from the religious teaching of their forefathers," declared the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, at solemn mass yesterday.

The tendency of the stock market was decidedly better last week. The Spanish question is considered less pessimistically and, despite the latest events, it is thought there is no longer cause to fear grave complications.

The newspaper Asahi said today that the charge by General G. S. Lush-off, fugitive Soviet General, that Russia was preparing for war against Japan, confirmed the newspaper's belief that Moscow was interested in China only to use her against Japan.
Switzerland took an important step toward centralization today when the people adopted by popular referendum a single national penal code replacing the separate codes of the twenty-two cantons.

Rises of 7.17 points in Austrian and German bonds indicate clearly financial London's favorable reception of the terms of the Austro-German debt agreement. In the hard bargaining that has occurred the honors are regarded as about equally divided.

The Greenbrier Music Festival, commemorating the 160th anniversary of White Sulphur Springs, opened last night in the auditorium with the presentation of the first in a series of concerts by the Greenbrier Symphony Society, directed by Lon Chassy.

The European trade reaction, although not having the character of a crisis, still has assumed rather serious dimensions in the last month owing to lower commodity prices and consequent decreased purchasing power, especially in countries with colonies producing raw materials.
Thirty-two Civil War veterans were in hospitals here tonight as the third day of the reunion came to an end. Twenty were Union men, twelve Confederates. The rest of the 1,800 were still going strong.

Manuel Montejo, manager of the Bank of Costa Rica, returned here today and expected the bank's directors to consider criticism of the fact that he also is the representative here of the organization of holders of Costa Rican bonds in New York.

A cosmic circus, made up of the weird aggregation of beasts and beings of the ancient constellations, now is on view in the "sky" of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History, it was announced yesterday.

Mikhail Gromoff, Andrey Yumasheff and Sergey Danilin, the Soviet's famous aviation team who established the world distance record in a flight over the North Pole from Moscow to San Jacinto, Calif., a year ago, have returned here from the Berlin meeting of the International Federation of Aeronautics amused and annoyed that the German press ignored completely their winning three of the four medals and even did not mention their presence in Germany.

With John Corigliano as soloist, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens, gave a concert last night at the Lewisohn Stadium which could not be accused of wanting variety and contrast. Mr. Corigliano,

Two men who for nearly a month have lived underground will come to the surface Wednesday to report on their findings-that one of them adapted himself to a twenty-eight-hour six-day week and the other couldn't break away from the twenty-four-hour grind.

A Western of more than ordinary magnitude has been announced by Samuel Goldwyn for Gary Cooper. The former cowboy star will be featured in "Seventh Cavalry," which William Rankin and Howard Estabrook will write. Cooper will play a young West Point graduate under General Custer.
Fifty prominent educators are expected to take part in a State educational conference beginning Tuesday morning and continuing: through Saturday at-the Montclair; Teachers College here.

Of the ghosts that throng Bloody Angle, Devil's Den, the Peach Orchard, the Round Tops, and all of the time-hallowed field of Gettysburg, none can evoke prouder memories for all Americans than the dauntless spirits of Lincoln and of Lee.

Detectives from the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey will go to the Federal prison at Lewisburg, Pa., tomorrow or Wednesday to question Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro in connection with the slaying of William Snyder, union official, to which the Goldis brothers, William and Morris, have confessed.
Cleveland turned back the pages of baseball history today at League Park to give its 1938 pennant-mad fans a glimpse of its two greatest teams of the past.

Wonders, even in Flatbush, will never cease. Yesterday the Dodgers astonished themselves and a crowd of 10,157 by flattening the Phillies in both ends of a doubleheader, performing this unprecedented feat with only two pitchers and a total of thirteen hits;

Two policemen assigned to watch women hikers from New York City, against whom an anti-shorts ordinance in Yonkers is aimed, reported today that there had been a big falling off in the customary number, evidently because the beaches are drawing them away now.
America's outpost in the Far East across the International Date Line noisily welcomed Independence Day a half day before the dawn of July 4 in the United States.

Chinese air force officials said today that Chinese bombers yesterday sank a Japanese aircraft carrier during a raid on a concentration of Japanese warships in the Yangtze River near Anking, the capital of Anhwei Province.
The scarcity of small coins in San Salvador was laid by the newspaper Diario Latino to the accumulation of small gifts in church poor boxes.

With their ranks decimated by casualties, prisoners and deserters, the original International Brigades, composed of foreign volunteers with the Spanish Loyalist Army, appear to be well on the way to writing the final chapters in their brief but colorful history.

General Marie Gustave Gamelin, Chief of Staff, implied today in a speech at Phalsbourg, on the Alsatian frontier, that if France ever was invaded again the enemy must be stopped at the borders instead of France's depending upon a miracle to save the country.
The stock market, here last week opened dull, with interest mainly in potashes and utilities. It remained undecided, with a friendly undertone, until midweek.
Four goals in the fifth period enabled the Nomad four to defeat the Burnt Mills Polo Club, 9 to 6, on Schley Field today. It was Burnt Mills's second loss in six starts.
Funeral services for Commander Richard Somers Galloway, U.S.N., retired, who died Thursday night at his Wardour home, will be held Tuesday at the Naval Academy. He was 54 years old.

In a toulder-to-shoulder drive for the at furlong the mighty Glenn Cunningham beat back the desperate of Chuck Fenske of Wisconsin win the 1,500-meter run that feared the golden anniversary track field championships of the Amleur Athletic Union in the Civic adium today.

Ground will be broken at 10:30 o'clock this morning at Ninety-fourth Avenue and 117th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, for an annex to the brick parochial school building of St. Benedict Joseph Labre's Roman Catholic Church.
The Reds made a game last-inning effort but couldn't save Johnny Vander Meer from his first defeat in ten games today, and the Cubs won, 4 to 3.
George Jacobus, Ridgewood Courtly Club golf professional and president of the P. G. A., fired a 71 at the Rockland Country Club today to establish a new course record. Th previous mark was a 72.

Discovery of what is believed to be the grave of Lieutenant Georgi Sedoff, Russian explorer who died in 1914 while trying to reach the North Pole, was reported today by radio from the Soviet camp on Rudolf Island, 560 miles from the North Pole.

A goal by Norman Baddenhop in the last half minute of play gave the Monmouth County C. C. a 9-to-8 victory over Festoon Farms in their polo encounter today. Baddenhop, a Yale freshman rider, contributed a total of four points. Allison Stern excelled for the losers.

America needs a day of penitence and prayer rather than a holiday, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, the pastor, declared yesterday morning in his sermon in the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street.

Mrs. George F. Oberge of Upsala, Haverford, has announced that the marriage of her daughter, Miss Boudinot A. Oberge, to Lieutenant Charles Handsford Kendall, balloon-racing expert of the United States Navy, will take place on July 16 in the Church of the Redeemer at Bryn Mawr.

The Fifty-third Brigade Headquarters Company, commanded by Brig. Gen. Bernard W. Kearney, and the brigade units, the Tenth Infantry, commanded by Colonel Willard H. Donner, and the 105th Infantry, commanded by Colonel Ogden J. Ross, passed in -review before Governor Lehman at Camp Smith here today.

At the start of the Constitutional Convention it was agreed by almost all of its leaders that the delicate question of industrial relations and how they should be handled in a new State Constitution would develop into one of the most important problems facing the convention.
Crown Princess Louise of Sweden and her stepson, Prince Bertil, were honor guests at a dinner given here tonight by the Delaware Valley Tercentenary Commission.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Snare Jr. of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Rutledge Snare, to Philip Reed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Royden Reed, also of Englewood.

Two small cargo boats reached the side of the stranded liner Ascania late tonight and the crews, reinforced by 100 longshoremen, began lightering the vessel's mixed cargo that included $1,500,000 in gold.
An "eternal flame" leaped up atop a peace memorial today on the battlefield of Gettysburg, lighted with the aid of the rays of the declining sun.

The Midland Bank's monthly bulletin, examining afresh the business situation in the United States, comes to the conclusion that it is doubtful whether any strong stimulus can be expected from the side of capital until near the year-end, when the Congressional elections may produce a change in the government's policy.
A motion to confer the title of "Eminent Citizen of America" on President Roosevelt was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Manuel Capestany, Liberal Senator from Santa Clara Province.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Brookville (72)-Match play handicap against par, Class A: M. J. Kramer, 2 up. Class B: L. R. McDonald, 1 down. Cherry Valley (72)-Semi-final round of best-ball tournament: M. J. Remsen and C. T. Smith defeated J. C. Lefler and R. M. Rowe, 2 up; C. W. Barrett and W. M. Cotterell defeated. C. M. Bishop and M. T. Gleason, 1 up.

Out of one of the most primitive regions in the United States, where the Colorado River churns through deep-gouged canyons, residents of this isolated North Arizona outpost awaited anxiously today emergence of a daring scientific expedition.

Among the numerous decree laws published this week the Bourse paid attention chiefly to one which authorizes the Bank of France to operate in the open market as the Bank of England does, such operations consisting of buying and selling in the market three-month bills, Treasury bills and defense bonds.
George E. Emmons, retired General Electric executive and art patron, died at his Laguna Beach home Friday after a lingering illness. His age was 80.
The London Northeastern Railway Company's new streamlined steam locomotive, drawing seven streamlined cars, today touched 125 miles an hour on the straight track between Grantham and Peterborough.

The Soviet has expanded its naval ambitions beyond having a fleet capable of mastering Germany in the Baltic and now aspires to have a fleet second to none and even to surpass Britain in shipbuilding.

The world wheat markets have not been affected in the slightest degree by the violent upturn in securities and commodities in general in the last two weeks, and a reduction of 'nearly 100,000,000 bushels in the prospective yield of Winter wheat in this country, compared with the outlook late in May, also has been ignored.

Detective Captain Ernest Yoris said today that Charles Felix Butte, 58, once a wealthy San Francisco contractor, had confessed that he killed his second wife, Emily Zigler Butte, former Indianapolis society woman, Friday.
On the last leg of her voyage to the Labrador, the exploration schooner Bowdoin sailed out of Sydney Harbor today.

In a game with the Brooklyn Cricket Club on the Stevens Institute grounds today, the Ardmore C. C. of Philadelphia suffered defeat by the close margin of ten runs, the victors having one wicket in hand as time was called.

Laying down his office as president of the Zionist Organization of America, Dr. Stephen S. Wise told more than 2,000 delegates and guests at a public session of the- annual convention today that the forthcoming conference in Evian, France, of the International Refugee Commission would be a "dismal failure" unless Great Britain was prepared to open Palestine to mass immigration of Jews from Germany and Austria.
To emphasize Brielle's place on the resort map, the Brielle Chamber of, Commerce staged this afternoon a marine parade and pageant for the second year.

Following differences between France and Japan regarding the possible occupation of Hainan Island, a new incident has arisen over French action in the Paracel Islands, southeast of Hainan in the China Sea.
Senator Borah served notice today that he would oppose any attempt to revive the so-called wire-tapping bill in the 1939 Congress.

" I want you to understand everything that the government will do in the next few days in order to get the cooperation of the individual nationalities of this State. We want such cooperation as will correspond with the Sokol idea of individual cooperation among Slavs.

The memory of Thomas Jefferson was honored here today, variously, but with complete unanimity and enthusiasm, at the University of Virginia, which he founded, and at Monticello, where he died 112 years today.

As dusk fell on the 162d anniversary of the nation's independence, countless thousands of tired but happy New Yorkers who had taken advantage of the perfect weather to celebrate at the shore, in the mountains or the country started homeward last night within the span of a few hours.

A special session for business men, at which new factors affecting business will be discussed, will be a feature of the Summer Institute for Social Progress to be held at Wellesley College, Wellesley, Mass., July 9 to 23. On Friday, July 15, members of the institute, who are drawn from many walks of life, will hear William Y. Elliott, chairman of. the Department of Government of Harvard University, discuss "The Quest for National Security."
The rise in prices in the stock market may restore control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway to Robert R. Young and Allan P. Kirby, according to a statement issued yesterday by Mr. Kirby.

The World's Fair next year will have a local habitation and a name, but in a sense the whole of Greater New York will be a part of the show. We shall have many thousands of visitors who have never seen our city and who will want to see it while they are here.

Hardit Singh Malik, first Trade Commissioner for India to the United States and Canada, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary wearing regular European costume with a colored turban, such as is worn by all Sikhs. The Commissioner was

The Toronto stock market started the last half of the year today with a show of bullish enthusiasm unequalled in months. Shares of base metal and industrial companies rose 3.80 to 4.76 points in the indices under heavy trading while the gold and the western oil indicators were up 1.09 to 1.20.

Dealers in unlisted securities would cooperate with the New York Stock Exchange in transactions in listed securities if commissions were shared, according to answers to a questionnaire issued by Commerce and Finance.
A general upturn in business and industry is apparent throughout Southern California, according to the June report of the Domestic Trade Department of the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce.

Frank J. Gilbertson Jr., associated with the Frank G. Shattuck Company of New York, died of a heart attack this morning while playing golf at the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club. He was 45 years old and maintained a home here and at South Orange.

The composite price index of 200 realty bond issues, compiled by Amott, Baker Co., Inc., showed a gain in June for the second successive month. Last month's price average rose three-tenths of 1 per cent, as against seven-tenths of 1 per cent in May.

ALSENZ-Julius, of New Paltz and Palisades Park, on July 3. 1938, beloved husband of Theresa (nee Snyder), devoted father of Albert. Services at the Walter B. Cooke, Inc., Funeral Home, 117 West 72d St., Tuesday evening. 8:30 o'clock. Funeral Wednesday, 10 A. M. Interment Lutheran Cemetery.
The Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries have reported for the year ended on May 31 a consolidated net income of $7,433,323 after operating expenses, taxes and charges.

Cumulative evidence of delay in the construction of naval vessels lends some point to two articles published in Collier's Magazine, highly critical of the navy in particular and of our national defense system in general.
A record number of 119 entries battled time limits and light and fluky breezes in the championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association held by the Island Heights Yacht Club today.
John N. Garner, it was learned here today, told his friends before he left for his home in Texas when Congress adjourned that he will not seek renomination as Vice President for a third term.

Commemorating the war service and religious. deeds of Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the State chapter of the National Society of the Daughters of the Union 1861-1865, Inc., unveiled today at Grace Episcopal Church a bronze tablet inscribed with' references to his appointment as the navy's first admiral and his gift of $1,000 of Civil War prize money to build the frame church here. A' parade preceded the ceremony.
Charles W. Netherwood, who was credited with having started the late Robert M. La Follette Sr. on his political career, died here today at the age of 93.

The Phillies and Bees divided a double-header today before 12,000 fans as the local National League club made its debut in Shibe Park. Boston won the first game, 10-5, breaking a 5-5 tie with five runs in the eighth. The rally was climaxed

Plans have just been filed in the Borough of Queens for five groups of small dwellings, comprising 126 houses, and for three large public garages. The aggregate cost of the dwellings is estimated by the architects at $534,000, while the garages will cost $282,750.

New York University announced yesterday that twenty-four research fellowships and tuition scholarships in safety education, valued at about $11,500, would be awarded by the institution's new national center for safety education to graduate students enrolled for the 1938-39 academic year in the School of Education.

Robert Fechner, director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, announced today that contracts for about $45,000,000 of foodstuffs would be awarded during the current fiscal year to feed its 300,000 members.

Bobby Riggs, national clay courts champion, took permanent possession of the Wilfred M. Tyler Trophy today by winning his third straight triState tennis title. He defeated Frankie Parker of Beverly Hills, Calif 6-2, 7-5, 6-3.

It was announced today that the American and Portuguese Governments had granted the necessary landing per mits for German mail planes and that, accordingly, the trial flights to America over the North Atlantic will begin in mid July and continue until the end of October.

Mrs. Theodosia Pleadwell, 62 years old, was found dead yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in the bathtub in her apartment in the Gramercy Park Hotel, 52 Gramercy Park North. Raymond B. Miles, assistant medical examiner, attributed the death to natural causes.
John W. Herbert Jr. won the championship cup for the greatest number of points scored in the gymkhana held this afternoon at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. He also won a leg on the

Miss Mary Jones Hilliard was married here today to Donald Eldredge Jackson Jr. in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church. President Roosevelt's son, Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., Mr. Jackson's classmate at Harvard University, was an usher.

Determined to win a prize to take home to his ill sister, Harold Toll, 7 years old, of 510 East Eighty-fourth Street, competed in several events yesterday at an athletic carnival sponsored by the Home Thrift Association, although one arm hung in a sling.

The program arranged for the Gershwin memorial concert, under Paul Whiteman's direction, next Monday night at the Lewisohn Stadium, will illustrate every phase of the composer's career as musical creator. It will include

Funeral services for Suzanne Lenglen, famous French tennis player who died early this morning from anemia, will be held on Wednesday at the Notre Dame de I'Assomption Church. Burial will be in the suburban St. Ouen Cemetery.

Deploring the failure of many governments to open their doors to Jews in Austria oppressed by the Nazi regime, the convention of the Zionist Organization of America today called upon Jews throughout the United States to support with all their power the United Palestine Appeal in order to create opportunities in Palestine for the absorption of tens of thousands of Jews of Germany, Austria, Poland and other lands.

Joseph W. Powell, president of the American Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after attending a meeting in London of the international society and also the International Engineering Congress in Glasgow.
The "eternal" light peace memorial which President Roosevelt dedicated on this Civil War battlefield will burn only at night, it was disclosed today.

The City Club made public yesterday a report prepared for it by Laurence Arnold Tanzer advocating four principles which the club contends should be incorporated in any home rule amendment drafted by the State Constitutional Convention.
Four persons were killed, another fatally injured and two seriously injured early yesterday in a headon crash at- Union Turnpike and Parsons Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens.

Antedating the new era of cooperation that has developed between the Federal Government' in Washington and MWall Street as represented by the New York Stock Exchange, cooperation with officials of the government is an old story to the Toronto Stock Exchange, the second largest on the American continents.

The Ringling Circus, prematurely closed by a strike of laborers, played big brother to a subsidiary tonight by sending twenty-one cars of feature acts, performers, seats and canvas tents to the Al G. Barnes show, now playing in the Northwest.

Former Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the American Society of London at its Fourth of July dinner tonight that "we in this country, perplexed by immediate problems and grasping in consequence at temporary expedients, cannot be too grateful to your statesmen" for their fidelity to the principles of liberty and tolerance.
The Tigers bounded back from three defeats in. a row by the tail-end Browns to whip the Indians twice today, 7 to 3 and 5 to 2, and drag Cleveland out of sole possession of the American League lead.

A report of its research department to the recent annual Cooperative Congress at Scarborough stated that during the post-war years the growth of cooperative retail trade has not kept pace with the rapid growth in the membership of cooperative societies or with the increased resources of the movement.

Announcing further details of the $1,000,000 fireboat now under construction. at the plant of the United Shipbuilding Company, Mariners peace Harbor, S. I., Fire Commissioner will John J. McElligott said yesterday it would be the first craft of its kind equipped with a collapsible fire tower. This tower will be raised by

The Citizens Budget Commission expressed opposition yesterday to the plan of the La Guardia administration to increase the salaries of 1,192 city employes "contrary to the McCarthy law directing how and when any such increases shall be made." The increases,

With the Constitutional Convention due to consider tomorrow night the Moses amendment to transfer the entire cost of grade-crossing eliminations to the State treasury, the opposition was strengthened today by a Public Service Commission declaration of unalterable hostility to the proposal.

Some of the fiercest fighting of the Spanish civil war raged today in the shelltorn Puebla de Valverde sector as the Insurgents smashed through government defenses in an onslaught started late Saturday.

Florence Weinberg, 16 years old; peered last night from her thirdfloor window at 1,601 West Fifth Street, Coney Island, at youngsters . in the street shooting off fireworks in celebration of the Fourth of July. She saw a flame spurt in her direction and then yelled "Mama, my chest!" and collapsed.

A nation-wide program of political action and education toward "the Georgist solution of our economic ills" was formulated yesterday at the national conference of the Federated Chapters of the Henry George Fellowship at the Henry George School of Social Science, 211 West Seventy-ninth Street.
A. N. Mitchell, general manager, has been elected president of the Canada Life Assurance Company to succeed Leighton McCarthy, who becomes chairman of the bord of directors, it was announced today.

Vice President Garner, Mayor Frank Hague and Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo were denounced- yesterday afternoon as "traitors within the Democratic party" by. Vito Marcantonio, former Representative, at a joint Garibaldi birthday and Independence Day celebration in Washington Square.

Reduction of force, violence, espionage and intimidation against organized labor, largely through the National Labor Relations Board and the five State boards, and continued improvement in the exercise of civil liberties in the last year are cited in the eighteenth annual report of the American Civil Liberties Union, sent to members yesterday.
The Yankees are back on top tonight, back at the head of the American League pennant race for the first time since May 11-not exactly as they would-wish to be, but up there nevertheless.

The marriage of Miss Miriam Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Simon of Cleveland Heights, to Harold Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore P. Klein of Arverne, L. I., took place here today in the Hotel Cleveland.
Governor M. Clifford Townsend tonight telegraphed Senator Frederick Van Nuys a personal invitation to become a candidate for renomination at the Democratic State Convention here on July 12.

The Cabinet has requested Minister of Commerce Sir Earle Page, Attorney General R. G. Menzies and Minister of Customs T. E. White, who have been in London since the end of April discussing revision of the Ottawa Agreement, to return home after King George unveils the Australian war memorial at VillersBretonneux, France, on July 22.

Edward Lane Dodge, who retired on Dec. 31, 1936, as general auditor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died Sunday at the New York Hospital after an illness of several weeks. He was 68 years old and lived at the University Club.

A study of the realty trading records for recent months in all parts of the country emphasizes the fact that the metropolitan centers have felt the effect of the recession more sharply than the smaller communities.

A wreath from President Roosevelt was put today on the mountainside grave of Calvin Coolidge, thirtieth President of the United States, during services in the tiny Plymouth Notch Cemetery observing his sixty-sixth birthday anniversary.

Enrollment under the educational program of the Works Progress Administration during the 1937-38 school year showed an increase for the fifth consecutive year, Harry L. Hopkins, administrator, reported today. The gain was in the
The Monmouth Freebooters downed Monmouth County Country Club, 9 to 8, in one of the finest polo exhibitions seen In this section this season at Monmouth County Country Club today. The match,

The first floor and basement, comprising 20,000 square feet of space in the Manufacturers Can Building, First and Essex Streets, Harrison, N. J., has been leased by the Continuous Sales Corporation of Long Island City, wholesalers of plumbing and heating supplies and equipment. The David Houston Corporation was the broker.

The British Government will consult shipping companies on Generalissimo Francisco Franco's proposal for establishment of a port in Spain where non-military cargoes for the Loyalist can be landed without fear of bombings by Insurgent planes, Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of- Commons today.

Official observance of Independence Day at Camp Smith here today was confined to the playing of the National Anthem by the 105th Infantry Band before the firing of a forty-eight-gun salute. Brig. Gen.

The Manshieh quarter on the Jaffa-Tel Aviv border was again the scene of violence early this morning. One Arab was killed, one is dying and fourteen were seriously wounded. Three Jews were slightly wounded.

June building construction in Chicago increased in both number of permits and cost over May, Richard Schmidt, Building Commissioner, announces. A total of 198 permits were issued for structures costing $1,833,150, compared with 163 permits for $1,535,660 in May. This was a gain of

A bill designed to prevent the defrauding of thousands of motorists and to aid hard-pressed reputable dealers by regulating the sale of gasoline will be introduced in the City Council today, it was announced yesterday by the City Deapartment of Public Markets.

Miss Kate Wakeman Street, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William Dana Street of this place, was married here this afternoon to Dr. William Roberts Sandusky of New York in the Ridgeview Congregational Church, of which her father has been pastor for thirty-seven years.

Peace Haven, the new home of the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians, was dedicated here this afternoon as a "gift to life," the "symbol and superstructure of truth" and "an outward expression of the godly temple" by James B. Schafer, the fraternity's leader, who is known'as The Messenger to the members.
Captain Bill Wood, Army's new head football coach, reported for duty today after completing a year's course in the Command and General Staff School at Fort Leavenworth, Kan.
The outlook for the Chaco peace conference. became darker today as neutral delegates failed in their attempts to persuade Bolivia and Paraguay to accept an arbitration formula.

Martin Livingston, clothing buyer for Wallach's and previously with John Wanamaker, has resigned to take a similar position with Browning, King Co., with headquarters at 551 Fifth Avenue. He will assume his new duties after an extended vacation.

Only in exceptional cases is supermarket volume running below last year, despite lower prices and the depression, M. M. Zimmerman, director of the Super Market Institute, said here yesterday following his return from leading "supers" in the South, Southwest and Middle West. He declared the entrance of
The Red Sox opened a long home stand by shelling three of four pitchers for twenty-five hits while beating the Athletics, 8-5 and 5-2, today before 18,000.
The White Sox took both ends of a doubleheader from the Browns, 5 to 4 and 5 to 1, today and supplanted the Athletics in sixth place.

Dwellings in Far Rockaway, Queens, have been leased by Lewis H. May Company as follows: To Joseph Canor, in 261 Beach Fifteenth Street; Alfred L. Beck, in 37 Cornaga Avenue; Max Marcus, In 9 Beach Fifth Street; Mollie Stauber, in 2,524 Dickens Avenue; Abraham Brickman, in 1,031 Rose Street, and to David Kane, in 255 Beach Fifteenth Street.
Gilbert Hunt today joined the select company that has succeeded in establishing two legs on the Nassau Challenge Bowl, in competition since 1913.

William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, told 2,000 persons gathered in the Music Grove in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday morning that the radical elements within the ranks had done more to harm labor and defeat its constructive purposes than all other forces combined.

Five city employes, who ventured into a gas-filled pit, thirty feet deep, with no protection except cloths held over their faces, succeeded last-night in -rescuing four companions who, just before 8 o'clock, had been overcome by fumes at the city sewage disposal plant on the south end of Wards Island.

Miss Magdalen Stoecker, who had taught in Public School 55, the Bronx, for fifty years, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Lutheran Hospital. She was 69 years old and was still on the active list of the Board of Education.

The stock mar'kets here were active and generally strong today. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, but among the foreign loans German and Austrian bonds lost ground after profit-taking. Transatlantic shares went ahead, reflecting the high levels in Wall Street.

Philadelphia clubs took most of the honors in the annual Peoples' Regatta on the Schuylkill River today. The Penn A. C. captured the junior and senior eight-oared shell races, the senior quads and the intermediate doubles and won rating as a serious contender in the
The Social Security Board, which has listed nearly 40,000,000 persons in its files, has learned something about the carelessness of Americans. Board attaches said that lost
The Lenox Club had logs blazing in the fireplace of the music room during the sixty-fourth annual Independence. Day luncheon, which was served there to 150 members and guests. The Misses Anna

One thousand C. M. T. C. students from the metropolitan area will board a special train leaving the Grand Central Terminal at 10:15 A. M. today for the barracks at Plattsburg, N. Y., where they are to undergo a thirty-day training period. Borough President George

Appointments of chairmen of national committees were announced today by Mrs. Henry M. Robert Jr., President General of the Daughters of the American Revolution. Every State in the Union is represented by the twenty-five national committees.
President Roosevelt spent the day hard at work while hundreds of thousands of government employes, including the clerical staff at the White House, enjoyed the week-end holiday.

Cotton: Receipts, 15,000 bales; no. American. Spot, moderate business; prices 7 points net higher; American strict good middling 5.91d, good middling 5.61d, strict middling 5.36d, -middling 5.16d, strict low middling 4.91d, low middling 4.51d, strict good ordinary 4.11d, ordinary 3.76d.
Handcuff, speedy 3-year-old filly from Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable, and George D. Widener's 2year-old, Eight Thirty, provided surprises for a record crowd of 25,000 at Delaware Park today.

Among the three leases for duplex apartments in the tower of River House, East River, between Fiftysecond and Fifty-third Streets, reported yesterday, was one for fifteen rooms and six baths on the twenty-fourth and twenty- fifth floors, with six additional rooms in another part of the building for servants, taken by Diego Suarez who recently married Mrs. E. Marshall Field.

The Brooklyn Trust Company, executor of the estate of Charlotte H. Boardman, sold the dwelling at 23 Cedar Drive, Great Neck Estates, L. I., through the John C. Weare Company, broker. The house is on a plot 80 by 129 feet and contains eight rooms, three baths and attached garage.

Timely hitting by the New York Athletic Club nine enabled it to subdue the New York Fire Department, 5-4, yesterday at Travers Island for the Winged Foot's seventh successive triumph and the third in as many days.

Needing only 150 runs for victory, Yorkshire, England's champion county, has a great opportunity to subject Australia's touring cricketers to the first defeat of their current English tour. After the second day's play today in their three-day match, the Yorkshiremen had dismissed the Antipodeans for 222 and 132, scoring 205 in their first visit to the wickets.

Shipping men in New York are awaiting with interest a decision of the United States Maritime Commission that will have an important bearing on the future of a subsidized merchant marine. in this country.

Is it fun to go to Coney Island and lie on a beach so crowded that a perfect stranger is likely to get the sandwich one thinks one is handing to little Egbert? Is it fun to sit for hours in an automobile, getting, as Ogden Nash once suggested, more gasolinery than scenery, while the traffic police unravel the tangles ahead? Is it fun to leave
Miss Polly Abbott, a granddaughter of Samuel M. Vauclain of Philadelphia, was married here this afternoon to William Mackey Wherry 3d in the Church of St. Peter by the rector, Canon P. G. Dykes.
Horses from the Newbrook stables won three out of six races during the holiday matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey before a crowd of 25,000 at Weequahic Park today.

Leutenant Robert M. Stanley, attached to the naval base at San Diego, wired officials of the national glider contest at 6:30 P. M. today that he had landed in Washington to match the achievement of yesterday by Peter Riedel, German pilot; in attaining a pre-arranged long-distance goal.
Fenner Beane have embarked upon what they assert is the first educational campaign ever undertaken by a New York Stock Exchange house. It has taken the
The Rev. Father Thaddeus Puder, a Jew who became a Roman Catholic priest, was badly clubbed as he stepped from the altar today by Rafael Michalski a shoemaker, who cried out, "Let's beat the Jew."
Mrs. Gertrude Boughton Blackwelder, former president of the Chicago Women's Club, died today in her home at Palo Alto, Calif., at the age of 88. Mrs.

The hotel industry of the State is agreed, it was revealed yesterday by the State Liquor Authority, that the repeal of prohibition has saved many hotels from bankruptcy, has increased employment, reduced drunkenness at hotel functions, almost eliminated the youthful drinker, confined drinking largely to the middle-age groups and greatly lessened bootlegging.

President Leon Cortes has confirmed the report-that the Finance Ministry is preparing a message to Congress requesting action on the law increasing import duties 100 per cent for dountries with which Costa Rica has an unfavorable trade balance.

FLORAL PARK, L. I.-James P. Doogan, 9 years old, of 114-30 211th Street, Hollis, Queens, was killed here tonight when he chased a parachute flare across the Long Island Railroad tracks at Linden Avenue and came in contact with the third rail. The boy, with his father.

Longshoremen unloading the liner Ascania, stranded in the St. Lawrence River with a cargo including $1,500,000 in gold, hoped today to have her lightened sufficiently by Thursday for towing to Quebec.
The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, under, the direction of Judge Leopold Prince, will give a concert this Saturday night on the Mall in Central Park. Isabel Schaap, soprano, will be the soloist.

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, on-the 162d anniversary yesterday of the adoption of the Declaration of Independence by the Colonial Congress in Independence Hall, Philadelphia, laid the cornerstone at the World's Fair grounds of- the Pennsylvania building, which is to be a copy of the original hall.
Mary C. O'Neil sold to Maria Massaro the two-family house at 2,462 East Second Street, Brooklyn. The Cross Brown Company and Charles G. Marino were the brokers.

An additional floor in the building at 37-43 West Sixty-fifth Street has been taken by the Parks Department of the WPA for offices and drafting rooms, the Cross Brown Company, agent for the building, announced yesterday.
Miss Josephine Sanfilippo, talented Brooklyn player, will endeavor to retain both her metropolitan girls' singles and doubles tennis championships today at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in

The National Boxing Association today rated Tony Galento as No. 1 heavyweight, next to Champion Joe Louis. Galento's rating was based on his "consistent knockout wins and the fact that he is willing and anxious to meet Joe Louis or any other heavyweight, Baer or Farr preferred," according to Harvey L. Miller, chairman of the ratings committee for the N. B. A.

Firecracker casualties within the city were fewer yesterday than on Fourth of July last year, it was indicated last night by reports from hospitals in all five boroughs. There were no fatalities or serious accidents caused by firecrackers, although the number of minor injuries, chiefly to children, still came to a large total.
The legitimate showroom is an important adjunct to the furniture industry, David Van Blerkom of David Walter Van Blerkom, Inc., writes in a letter to the business editor of TIE NEW YORK TIMES.
Bobby Pacho, Mexican welterweight, and Salvy Saban, hard-hitting Greenwich Village fighter, will meet for the third time tonight in the feature eight-round bout at the New Dyckman Oval.

UNITED STATES ASSISTANT MESSENGER, $1,080 a year. Applications must be on file not later than July 22, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming. And not later than July 19 from all other States. Competitors will be 'rated

The gradual spread of cholera in Hunan and Hupeh Provinces has virtually confirmed fears that a disastrous cholera epidemic in Central China is unavoidable, according to Dr. F. C. Yen, head of the National Health Administration.
The government's mathematicians estimated today that the business recession would cause a $750,000,000 reduction in Federal revenue in the fiscal year which began Friday.

Undeterred by the failure of city officials and patriotic organizations to present a Fourth of July service today on-the: green of St. Paul's Episcopal Church here, Robert Burtnett, an engineer, arranged one of his own and drew an audience of sixty persons.

A contribution of $38,000 to the Greater New York Fund from the New York City Police Department, described as the second largest made in the department's' history to a private charitable endeavor, was announced yesterday by Winthrop Rockefeller, executive vice chairman of the campaign.

Donald Hawley of Orange, seeded No. 1, gained a second leg on the Mountain Lakes Club Challenge Trophy today when he won the sixth annual invitation tennis tournament final, defeating Phil Osborne Tenafly 6-3 6-4 6-4.
With more than 2,000,000 men, women- and children at the water's edge in the metropolitan area yesterday, there were no drownings and few rescues from the surf.
The Governments of The Netherlands and Mexico are discussing whether or not to publish an exchange of notes regarding petroleum expropriation.

Charles L. Lawrence, finishing third today in his Chief, took top honors in the Star Class at the week-end regatta sponsored by the 'Babylon Yacht Club. Edward V. Ketcham Jr.'s Draco, tied with Chief until today, finished ninth in the last race.
A team of New York fencers defeated a Canadian team, eleven matches to one, tonight in the first round of the Russell Trophy tournament, emblematic of the world's fencing championship.

The successful handling of 11,180 labor disputes directly involving 2,247,928 workers was announced today by the National Labor Relations Board on the eve of the third anniversary of the National Labor Relations Act, which was signed by President Roosevelt on July 5, 1935. The board declared that "the great bulk of work achieved" followed its victories in the courts.

" Sally, Irene and Mary," a musical comedy favorite of more than a decade ago, was revived here tonight on the marine stage on Zach's Bay, as the second offering in the current season's schedule of musical comedies and operettas, sponsored by the Shuberts--Lee and J. J.-and Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company.

American market research units take much smaller samples for their investigations than is usual in England, according to Miss Mary Corderoy, manager of the marketing department of F. C. Pritchard, Wood Partners, who has just returned from six w??ks in the United States, where she studied American market research methods.

Dr. Josef Hofmann, the pianist, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary from a tour of England and Poland in observance of his fiftieth anniversary on the concert stage. He was accompanied by Mrs. Hofmann.

FIRST ROUND Robert Peacock, California, defeated John Foreman, North Carolina,4-6, 6-2, 6-3 William Talbert, Cincinnati, defeated Darrell Hudlow, University of Redlands, 6-4. 6-2; Warren Christner, Texas, defeated Jack Crawford, Middlebury, 6-1, 6-0; James Seaver, Stanford, defeated Dick Henry, Virginia, 6-1, 6-1.
Danielle Darrieux's second picture for Universal will be "Rio," a romantic drama of South America, written by Jean Negulesco, in which the French star will have three leading men.
Police arrested Robert Stephenson, 18 years old, of New York, as a stowaway aboard the French liner Normandie when the ship arrived here today.
The Bears caine from behind twice today and defeated Jersey City in a double-header, taking the opener by 10-4 and the nightcap by 7-6 before a crowd of 15.106.

The Choate News of the Choate School, Wallingford, Conn., has been judged winner of the eighth annual scholastic newspaper contest conducted by The Daily Princetonian, university. news organ, it was announced tonight by James McC. Clarke, '39, of Manchester Vt., chairman of the Princeton paper.
Merchandise worth more than $30,000,000 will be sold at the Summer home-furnishing markets opening here tomorrow for two weeks, manufacturers predicted today.
The following Reserve officers recently released for assignment purposes to 3d Military Area are assigned to units indicated below:

A northeast blow off the New Jersey coast did not tend to improve the tuna fishing over the week-end. The fishermen at Brielle returned with an average of two per boat, with high boat being four. All of the tuna were under fifty pounds.
Every inch of land in the Wuhan area, including Hankow, Wuchang and Hanyang, will be defended by Chinese forces without regard for sacrifices, a Chinese Government spokesman said here yesterday.

Dr. J. H. Harris defeated C. H. Calkins by 5 and 4 today to win the New York A. C. Fourth of July tournament on theHotel Champlain golf course. Harris, playing the best golf of the tournament, obtainted an early lead and closed the match on the fourteenth with a birdie 3.

ONE can sense the spirit of Kathryn Hulme's pleasant novel called "We Lived As Children,"* without-reading a page. The story, or the main part of it, is implicit in J. O'H. Cos-grave's picture on the dust wrapper.

Mrs. Edward A. St. John of Garden City, L. I., has been designated by Mrs. William Henry Hays, president of the Women's National Republican Club, as chairman of the club's campaign committee this Fall. Mrs. Hays, in announcing the

An effort to stage a strike of 40,000 peddlers in the city to protest against the campaign of Mayor La Guardia and Markets Commismissioner William Fellowes Morgan to rid New York of peddlers will be made today by the Greater New York Peddlers Association, it was announced last night by William H. Smith, president of the association.

Those who remember Suzanne Lenglen on the tennis courts recall a flashing, tempestuous figure vibrant with life. It is pitiful to think of so vivid a woman, still young, as a victim of the enervating process of anemia.

Increased interest in Fall merchandise marked activity in the wholesale market last week. In women's apparel requirements were covered for August coat sales and back-to-school promotions, and better Fall coats were purchased for regular selling.

A. S. Hunt, 58 years old, of Denver was found safe today at a sheep camp, to which he walked in bare feet after his companion in a boat expedition down the turbulent Rio Grande was drowned when their boat capsized.

For the first time in his term, Mayor La Guardia confronts the necessity for walking through a union picket line this afternoon if he carries out his announced plan to move the seat of city government to the City Building in the New York World's Fair today.

President Seymour of Yale University today announced the gift of forty items, to be added to the Yale collection of literature, pertaining to Washington Irving. He described it as "one of the most remarkable of Washington Irving material in this country." He also revealed

Miss Edna Smith of Cleveland captured the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship today at the Montclair A. C., taking the third set by default from Miss Helen Bernhard of New York, who was forced out by an ankle injury sustained in a fall in the second set.

Intermediate Singles-Won by Robert B. Cutler, Riverside B. C., Cambridge, Mass.; second, Walter Scheel. Bachelors Barge. Time-7:45. Intermediate Doubles-Won by Penn A. C.; second, New York A. C.; third, Fairmount R. A. Time-6:59.

President Dixon Ryan Fox of Union College welcomed the fifty young men and women apprentices chosen from twelve States and Canada to "build themselves into the great tradition of the theatre" in officially opening tonight the fourth annual Summer Institute of the Theatre, which is conducted jointly by the Mohawk Drama Festival and Union College.

Gettysburg completed its greatest of Fourth of July celebrations tonight with a display of fireworks from Oak Hill, scene of the first day's fighting in the Battle of Gettysburg. The 1,800 Union and Confederate veterans here for their last reunion were able to see the spectacle from their camps on the battlefield.

Dr. Augustus Thorndike of Boston entertained today at The Eyrie with one of the largest luncheon parties of the season. Among his guests were Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Borden, Mr. and Mrs. Arden Robbins and Mrs. D. Crawford Clark of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Robins and Miss Mary Roberts Coles of Philadelphia.

Ray Chesney, 28, plunged 6,000 feet before his parachute opened yesterday. He held onto a bottle of pop and drank most of it during the rest of the 18,000-foot drop, which established a new Canadian parachute record. It was Chesney's fifth parachute drop since he started practicing only six weeks ago.

The Cards and the Cubs divided a doubleheader today, Chicago taking the opener, 4 to 3, and the Gas House Gang rallying after seven scoreless innings of the nightcap to clout six singles in the eighth and win by a similar count. A holiday crowd of

The Round Hill Scottish Games Association celebrated today at the estate of Charles A. Moore of Round Hill. More than 10,000 persons, the largest crowd ever recorded in the association's history, watched the games from early morning until 9 P. M., when the tossing of the caber for the championship of the United States ended the program.

Those eleven shows from Broadway's thirteen who braved weather and the tourist trade in order to give matinees yesterday fared on the whole pretty well. As is usual, the hits among them sold out, with the S. R. O. signs going up before performance time and with standees present; the weaklings kept

Wheat futures were sharply lower in a quiet session on the Grain Exchange here today because of widespread and beneficial rainfall in Western Canada. The close showed losses of 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 cents a bushel.

First prize in a whisker contest staged here this afternoon as the climax of a celebration marking the seventieth anniversary of the town was won by a full russet beard grown on the face of a nonresident, Edward Delaney of near-by Oxford.

The motorship 'Batory of the Gdynia America Line sails tonight for Northern Europe. Among the passengers booked are: Baron Stefan Ropp, High Commissioner of the Polish exhibit at the New York World's Fair; Count Jerzy Potocki,

Dr. Sigmund Freud, aged, 'saddened and ill, received a privilege today that never before had been accorded any one but a British King. The famed psychologist, a selfexile from Austria, has been a member of the Royal Society since 1936.
George Barker Gavin, for more ,than a quarter-century day editor of The Boston Globe, died tonight at his home after a heart attack. His age was 63.

Advertising linage in' the eight New York newspapers declined 15.1 per cent in June, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures yesterday. Totals were 8,006,796 lines for. last month, as against 9,428,810' for June, 1937.
John Templeton, for fifty years editor and publisher of the weekly Exeter News Letter, died today at his home here after a short illness.

Two French students mountaineering in the Savoy district were shot at by Italian frontier guards yesterday and one of the youths is reported to have been seriously wounded when the guards followed them into French territory as they fled.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Behrens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John-Behrens of Weehawken, N. J., to Herbert B. Davison, son of C. Herbert Davison of Princeton, N. J., will take place on July 18 in the Spring Lake (N. J.) Presbyterian Church.
Starting out with a northerly breeze, fluttering in direction but with seeming backbone in it, 151 craft set sail today in the fiftyseventh annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Complaint about the growing competition of imported American ??resses in Great Britain was made by Lieut. Col. Sir Norman S. Seddon-Brown, chairman of John Woodrow Son, Ltd., manufacturers, at the company's annual meeting here.
The Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Gardiner, formerly of this city, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Gertrude Gardiner Davis, in Lost Creek, W. Va., at the age of 94.

Boellman's "Symphonic Variations" for 'cello and orchestra, with Lillian Rehberg as soloist, will be featured at tonight's concert of the Federal Symphony Orchestra under Eugene Plotnikoff at the Federal Theatre of Music.
Mothers pushed baby-carriages and dog-owners walked their poodles along Riverside Drive between 165th and 175th Streets yesterday, unaware that a future King was strolling near by.
