AS the Rich Red Sox packed their bats, gloves and shoes after a short and not too pleasant stay in the Yankee Stadium on Sunday, Manager Joe Cronin paused to remark somewhat sadly: "Listen! If you hear of any pitchers, let me know."
City realty deals reported yesterday involved several business properties on the East Side of Manhattan, as well as residential parcels in the Bronx and Queens.
Coast Guardsmen reported tonight after another all-day search that they had found no trace of the body of Cornelius J. Kiely Jr., 23 years old, of 111 Hillside Court, Jamaica, Queens, who was lost

Joseph Caldwell Robinson, who for twenty-six years was employed by the New York Edison Company and at his retirement last December was head of the claim department, died here yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Grace Robinson McClure.

Standing barechested on top of a threshning machine, with his tanned torso shining in the sun, Premier Benito Mussolini today branded as the "dregs of all nations" those who have spread reports of Italy's wheat shortage. He spoke at Aprilia, one of the towns recently built on the reclaimed Pontine marshes.

War Minstrel, grandson of Man o' War, kicked dust in the face of the mighty Seabiscuit today, beating the Pacific Coast champion by three and a half lengths in the $10,000 added Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park.
Mrs. Charlotte Hoffman, long active in Jewish charitable affairs, died yesterday at her home, 1,331 Croes Avenue, the Bronx, after a brief illness. She was 59 years old.
The Reds had their home-run guns primed today, but five errors, four of them in the second game, spelled disaster, and the Pirates swept a double-header, 2 to 1 and 3 to 2.

The addition of ten leaders of various professions and two organic zations to the National Rededication Committee was announced here yesterday. The committee is a nonpartisan group organized in June to conduct a campaign of education on the significance of democratic institutions, to "popularize" the Bill of Rights and to "state the. case for liberty and democracy" as expressed in the Declaration of Independence and guaranteed by the Constitution.
With songs, dances and patriotic addresses, America's Good Will Union conducted a patriotic celebration yesterday on the Mall in Central Park in which almost 500 spectators participated.

Twenty-one acres of land fronting on Pinebrook Road and Twin Lakes Drive in Bedford Knolls, partly in Bedford Village and partly in Poundridge, have been sold by the Standard National Corporation. The unnamed buyer will develop it and erect a home for his own occupancy.
The sharpest advances in wages since 1929 were made during 1937 in the United States and France, according to statistics for fourteen countries, issued today by the International Labor Office here.

Homer Gage Balcom, structural engineer and expert in steel construction who supervised the steel construction for the Empire State Building, Rockefeller Center units and other skyscrapers, died Sunday night in the French Hospital where he went for treatment for a heart ailment last Wednesday. He was 68 years old.

Automobile production showed a nominal increase last week, countering the normal seasonal decline, and the adjusted index rose to 45.4 from 43.1. For the week ended July 3, 1937, the figure was 136.3.
Members of the two C. I. O. unions barred by injunction from picketing the Busch Jewelry Company and affiliates yesterday continued their general picketing against the firm on land and in the air.

Several banks in this city reporting for June 30 showed gains in total deposits and total assets. Among the institutions listing increases were the Bank of New York, the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, the United States Trust Company and the Public National Bank and Trust Company.

Indications here regarding the Evian (France) refugees conference, which opens Wednesday, show two main tendencies. One is to restrict the meet, ing's scope as much as possible, the other is to expand it.

Polo enthusiasts who visited the Meadow Brook Club today saw the Pelicans and Aiken Knights win exciting tournament matches and watched G. H. (Pete) Bostwick, smallest and lightest entrant in the field, score a surprise triumph in a special longhitting contest.

Sharp reductions in motor vehicle fatalities in New York State in May and in the first five months of the year were reported. yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner. For the State as a whole in the five-month period, 872 persons were killed, as against 1,062 in 1937.
If the world, as time passes, shows no inclination to get back to peace land the normal life, there will be
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced today it had "modified" the prices of its products to meet those recently established by other steel companies.
Deliveries of Packard cars in the first twenty days of June indicate that deliveries for the month will exceed estimates by 20 per cent, according to M. M. Gilman, vice president and general manager.
The Fourth of July classic in honor of the American Society was won today by the Chilean-bred horse Brujo, a 4-yearold colt by Caimacan and Burjula.

Otto Bauer, former leader of Austrian socialism, died today at his Paris residence at the age of 57. Dr. Bauer was a World War veteran who gained a lieutenancy before he was made a prisoner by the Russians in 1915, and was one of the instigators of Austria's postwar revolution.
As befitted the occasion, the holiday concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium was devoted entirely to American music.

Varied events took place today for out-of-town guests at estates throughout the colony. One of the largest parties was the dinner given by Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine at Valmay cottage for Mrs. Jon Crerar of Chicago.

BRASS TACKS, by A. G. Keller. (Knopf, $2.) A study of human society and of the things upon which it is based. ESTHER, by Henry Adams. (Scholars Facsimiles and Reprints, $3.50.') Reprint of the novel written in 1884 by Frances Snow Compton under the pen-name of Henry Adams.

The qualifying rounds of the British open golf championship began today under the easiest conditionshalf of the competitors playing at Royal St. George's, the battlefield of the championship proper, which begins on Wednesday, and half on the neighboring course, the Prince's, the scene of an earlier triumph by Gene Sarazen.

Fun, skippered by Briggs Cunningham, her owner, crossed the finish line first today in the six-meter race off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. This event was in the nature of a tune-up for the elimination races that start July 15 for the international regatta.

Manager Frankie Frisch of the Cardinals, troubled by a weak left ankle, today telegraphed to National League President Ford Frick his resignation from the coaching Staff for the All-Star game in Cincinnati Wednesday.

Police Inspector Charles L. Netdig, who was transferred last week from an important East Side command to a post in Queens in a drive of Police Commissioner Valentine to stamp out gambling on the East Side, ended his life with his service revolver at about 11 o'clock last night in the garden of his home at 70-23 Harrow Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

There will be 5,155,115 railway cars loaded with freight in the three months ending on Sept. 30, against 6,413,014 oars in the same period last year, a decrease of 19.6 per cent, according to estimates by the thirteen shippers' advisory boards. Tha following table shows
Sergeant J. L. Pearce of the Royal Air Force annexed the Queen Mary's Prize, feature of the opening program today of the National Rifle Association.

Joe Kleinerman, New York City postal clerk, won the Washington marathon run today, covering the ten miles in 58 minutes 50.6 seconds. John Cook of the Baltimore Cross Country Club was second in 59:35 and Donald Heinickee, Stonewall Democratic Club, Baltimore, third in 60:16.

The Pennsylvania Railroad and the Long Island Railroad have contracted with the Consolidated Edison Company for the supply of about 290,000,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity annually, George LeBoutillier, vice president of both railroads, announced yesterday.

A boy was killed and eleven other persons were injured, five seriously, when a racing automobile left the track at the Hohokus Race Track here late this afternoon and crashed into a crowd of spectators lining the infield guard rail. All but one of the persons struck were spectators.

Changes in the personnel of the executive group of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, announced from its headquarters in Washington, reveal that seven of the nine most important posts already have been filled by Mrs. Saidie Orr Dunbar, who was elected at the recent Kansas City triennial to succeed Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson as president. Mrs. Dunbar's
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lanner of Jameica, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Mary Lanner, to Clarence R. Knickman of Richmond Hills, Queens.
Frank Buck was treated in the Reed General Hospital here tonight after being bitten on the second finger of the left hand by a python in his zoo at Massapequa.

Nazis of today were linked with the "mercenary Hessians" of the American Revolution and the Germans of the World War by Myles A. Paige, Negro magistrate, who represented Mayor La Guardia at a Fourth of July celebration yesterday on the Central Park Mall sponsored by the Patriotic Memorial League of the National War Veterans.

Marquis Childs has sent to the Yale University Press the final chapters of his forthcoming book, "This Is Democracy," an account of collective bargaining in the Scandinavian countries. It is scheduled

The average fixed-charge, coverage of the principal waterworks companies in the united States last year increased to 1.93 from 1.92 in 1936 and 1.83 in -1935, R. E. Swart Co. have estimated from a suinmary of the earnings of fifty-nine privately owned companies having funded debt in excess of $1,000,000 outstanding.

Mr. and Mrs. George Washington Wales Brewster Jr., who have been at the Ambassador since their return from their wedding trip to Bermuda, will leave today for Boston, where they will make their home. Mrs. Brewster was Miss Joan Ryerson, only daughter of Mrs. Donald M. Ryerson of Chicago and the late Mr. Ryerson.

Captain George E. T. Eyston, English racing motorist who holds the world's record of 312.2 miles an hour, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with eight mechanics on his way to the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah, where he will try to better. his own record made last year over the same course.
Secretary Ickes urged building material manufacturers tonight to follow the example of the steel industry and reduce prices of their products.
All the seeded players except Don McNeill of Kenyon won their matches in the national collegiate tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club today.

Injuries in Philadelphia in a week-end of "safe and sane" celebrating of Independence Day had passed the 200 mark tonight, establishing a 300 mark tonight, establishing a twenty-eight-year record. Only sixty-two were hurt last year, and none seriously.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As you stated in your editorial "For Better Motion Pictures," the Neely bill would prohibit the practice of compulsory bloc selling of pictures and wouldrequire that purveyors of pictures supply a reasonable summary of the articles they are selling.
The Bahamas today elected to a seat in the House of Assembly (the lower legislative branch) the absentee millionaire proprietor of Canadian gold mines, Harry Oakes.
Orders went out today from Bond Clothes, one of the largest manufacturers of men's clothing in Rochester, summoning 3,300 employes back to work tomorrow morning.

Fascism will enable Canada to reconquer its own territory from "the red clutches of Moscow and international Jewry" within three years, Adrien Arcand of Montreal, leader of the National Unity Party, told a meeting of 1,500 in Massey Hall here tonight.

Mrs. Yoakum Fosdick was a luncheon hostess at her Ocean Avenue home today. Mrs. Francis L. V. Hoppin entertained with a luncheon at Auton House and Mrs. Lorillard Spencer was a luncheon hostess at the Muenchinger-King.

The changes which are taking place in America do not menace the heritage of freedom handed down from generation to generation since the Declaration of Independence was signed, Attorney General Cummings asserted in a Fourth of July address here tonight. Instead, these changes will contribute, he said, to increased efficacy of democratic processes.

Restoration in France of the death sentence for certain forms of peacetime espionage, following closely upon the indictment here of eighteen persons for spying, may well tend to exaggerate in the public mind the role of the spy in a rearming world. Certainly when
Premier Benito Mussolini's newspaper, Popolo d'Italia, today cited President Roosevelt's speech to the National Education Association in New York on June 30 as proof that "democracy is at war."

Howard Hughes arrived at Floyd o'clock last night from Wichita, Kan., on the second leg of his transcontinental flight in the final tests of the twin-engined monoplane in which he expects to fly around the world.

When the steel industry cut its prices nearly two weeks ago it also announced another change that may prove more far-reaching in its economic effects than any other policy change made in the industry in the last fourteen years.

The Rev. Henry Francis Riley, C. S. P., a member of the Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle, died yesterday at the parish house, 415 West Fifty-ninth Street, of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle after an illness of nearly four years.
Berlin's American School found itself without a roof today because of charges of anti-Semitism only two months after the secret police had investigated it for pro-Semitism.
Greyhound, holder of .the world's trotting championship at 1:56, returned to competition today and set a world record of 0:26 4-5 for the last quarter of a race mile.

Mr. and Mrs. John Clark Tidden of this city have announced the marriage of Mr. Tidden's daughter, Miss Mary Stuart Tidden, to Nicol Bissell. The ceremony was performed Saturday by the Rev. Leon Rosser Land at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. Edward M. Colie of 177 East Sixty-fourth Street.

Edward Otis Goss, president of the Scovill Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of metal goods, and a director of the New Haven Railroad, died today at his home here after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Sunday in St. Francis Hospital, Miami Beach, Fla., of-Theodore Friedeberg, former president of the Manhattan Machinery Exchange of this city. Mr. Friedeberg,

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Brookville (72)--Flag tournament, Class A: H. J. Miller, short of 19th green: Fred Rade, 19th fairway. Class B: L. R. McDonald, short of 18th green; H. R. Mortimer, 18th fairway. President's Trophy, semi-final: G. C. Gower defeated H. B. Seaman, 1 up (19 holes). Vice President's Trophy, semi-final: G. Cuff defeated H. Yingling. 4 and 2. Sweepstakes: D. McDonald, 90-13-77.
James McKendrick, Scottish evangelist, who had made sixteen preaching tours in the United States, died today at his home in East Rigg, Dumfriesshire. at the age of 79.

Scooting along the rail with a sudden and surprising rush, Jockey Sammy Renick aboard Unfailing yesterday captured the Questionnaire Handicap before a record crowd of close to 20,000 persons who jammed the Empire City accommodations to the bursting point. It was a head finish, with

Before 50,166 paying fans, a record attendance at the Polo Grounds this season, Colonel Bill Terry's Giants took further strides toward a third straight pennant by beating the unhappy Dodgers in both ends of the Independence Day doubleheader yesterday, 3-0 and 16-1.
United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt today denounced bombings of civilian centers such as have happened in Spain and China.

Nineteen years after her first glimpse of the United States, Miss Kirsten Hesselgren of Sweden was unpacking her bags last night in the Hotel Barclay with eager anticipation of her forthcoming tour of comparison- with conditions of nearly two decades ago.

The strictly American interest seems to have vanished from the British open golf championship. Vincent Arom of Panama made no return of his score yesterday, while Page Hufty of Chevy Chase, Md., and Ross Thompson of Uniontown, Pa.,

Splentidly mounted and displaying sparking team-work, Templeton routed he previously unbeaten Bostwick Field poloists, 11 to 3, on Whitney Field today and tied its rival for he Meadow League laurels in the Meadow Brook Club's tourney for wenty-goal teams.

With 5,000 square feet of sail gleaming and billowing beneath sunny skies, the gaff-rigged schooner Yankee, manned by fourteen Girl Scout Mariners supervised by four experienced seamen, left City Island yesterday and swept into Long Island Sound on the first of eight one-week cruises.

An allowance for tips must be included in figuring workmen's compensation for injured taxicab drivers, Harry A. Nelson, State Director of Compensation, notified L. E. Touhy, president of the Independent Union of the Yellow Cab Company, today.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Timleck, one of the four couples who won about $100,000 apiece in the Canadian stork derby, which ended on Oct. 31, 1936, declared yesterday at the St. James Hotel, 109 West Fortyfifth Street, where they are staying on a visit here, that they were lonesome for their fourteen children.
After fifty years in Wall Street, William F. Murphy, 62 years old, of 993 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, is to retire today, but not in the way that most persons understand retirement.

Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University, defends the right of academic freedom and freedom of speech for professors in the classroom, but warns them that utterances outside the classroom should be carefully weighed, in a book published today under the title of "What a University President Has Learned."

The Fourth of July week-end brought violent death to at least 517 persons. in the United States, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The total was 46 below that for the Independence Day week-end in 1937, when 563 lives were lost.

A group of holders of bonds of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, represented by P. E. Jackson, has formulated a plan of reorganization for the company, now undergoing reorganization under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act, according to an announcement yesterday by Mr. Jackson.

On the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailing today will be Joseph E. Davies, United States Ambassador to Belgium, and Mrs. Davies; Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, and Mrs. Roper; Sheik Hafiz Wahba, Minister to Great Britain for King Ibn Saud; Robert R. McCormick, Mr. and Mrs. Eddie Cantor, William A. Julian, Treasurer of the United States;

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was in 1929 that American material prosperity suffered its first great shock. In 1933 a new Administration took over the task of restoring the conditions of prosperity. Its energetic and expensive efforts seemed for a time to be bearing fruit; but now we find ourselves in a recession of great seriousness, and the original labor has to be recommended.

Stanley H. Sisson, 44, a member of a prominent "north country" family, announced his candidacy today for the seat in Congress to be vacated by his fellow-townsman, Bert H. Snell, who retires after twentyfour 'years' service as Representative from the Thirty-first New York district.

Having gained considerable confidence in the business outlook in the last few weeks, retailers will increase their Fall buying budgets on men's shirts and pajamas 10 to 20 per cent over those planned a month ago, according to a survey by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers, issued yesterday.
In a collision between a Reid Avenue, Brooklyn, surface car and a five-ton truck at Broadway and Fayette. Street, Brooklyn, yesterday at 11:10 A. M., three women and two men were injured.

Miss Mary Godfrey Pepper, daughter of Dr. William Pepper of Colony House, Melrose Park, was married this afternoon to Newton B. Parker, son of Mrs. William B. Parker of Cambridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Howard M. Stuckert in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church at Elkins Park.

Mrs. Harvey S. Firestone of Harbel Manor, this city, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Idabelle Firestone, to Ray Austin Graham Jr., son of Mrs. Graham of Greenvale Farm, Roslyn, L. I., and the late Mr. Graham.

Johnny Gilbert rode his fourth winner of the day and his twenty-ninth of the meeting, piloting Trojan Racket, a former steeplechaser, home two lengths ahead in the seventh race before 6,000 at Delaware Park today.

Cornelius Glynn, a spry man of 70, who frequently talked to the Boy Scout troop of Old St. Patrick's Cathedral of the days when he was a policeman, was carried dead last night into the Elizabeth Street police station, from which he walked out on his beat each day more than fifteen years ago.

Turkish troops marched into the Sanjak (district) of Alexandretta today to assume joint control with France of that strategic East Mediterranean area and were greeted by the applause of Turkish inhabitants.

Herbert Foote Mills of Yonkers, who was formerly for years with the Bradstreet Company, credit-rating firm, before it was merged in Dun Bradstreet, died yesterday in Peekskill Hospital. He was 66 years old.
A detailed comparison between the State budgetary estimates of revenue and actual collections in the last fiscal year is presented in the following table:
Persons in close touch with the Chinese Government declared today that Chinese-German relations had become "even more serious than they appear."

The recent prolonged drought has made it possible to dig a 196foot well for the first time in memory here and to confirm the theory that the Bermuda platform above sea level once covered 300 square miles, Works Director William Livingston revealed today.

A large red truck, open at the top, pulled up beside the City Bank Farmers Trust Company at 65 Beaver Street -yesterday afternoon. As workmen opened the side door four Coast Guardsmen, wearing side arms, stationed themselves close to it.

Falling short by 9,770 cars of last year's record for a similar period, a total of 381,880 vehicles used the four bridges and two tunnels operated by the Port of New York Authority, it was reported yesterday at the close of a four-day observance of the Fourth of July.

An obsession that he was afflicted with a fatal illness rather than despondency over his transfer from Manhattan's East Side to a post in Queens was responsible for the suicide of Inspector Charles L. Neidig, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday in praising

Percy Peixotto, leader of the American colony in Paris, died in his home here today. He was born sixty-eight years ago in Cleveland, Ohio, a son of Benjamin Franklin Peixotto, Minister to Rumania under President Grant.

Japan, Italy and Manchukuo today signed a trade treaty entitled "An accord among the Governments of Italy, Japan and Manchukuo for regulating trade and payments thereto between Italy on one side and Japan and Manchukuo on the other."
A total of 1,371 men and women from forty-two States and seven foreign countries and possessions enrolled in the Harvard Summer session at the opening of registration today.
Harry H. Wetzel, vice president and general manager of the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, died today of complications after an emergency abdominal operation. His age was 49.

The three Federal bank regulating agencies today issued calls for the condition of banks under their juris- I diction as of June 30. The agencies are the Controller of the Currency, Federal Reserve Board and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
William C. Chanler, Corporation Counsel, ridiculed a report yesterday that contracts for $57,563,306 for the Delaware River water supply project had been awarded "secretly."
By a vote of sixteen to eight, the City Council killed the Markets Department Bill, calling for the grading of certain meats sold at retail, yesterday.
John Fraser Horn, president of the Vandergrift Telephone Company and the Vandergrift Land and Improvement Company, died in his home here today at the age of 81.
The AllStar game of 1939 will be played in the Yankee Stadium, New York. This was decided today at a joint meeting of the National and American Leagues.
Manager Burt Shotton of Columbus selected two of his own players today to complete the roster of the American Association All-Star team he will pilot in a night game against Indianapolis July 14.

The provision in the proposed new Home Rule amendment which would have protected the Transit Commission against encroachment on its powers by the city prior to Jan. 1, 1940, was eliminated from the last draft of the amendment tonight.

One hundred and three practicing lawyers went back to school yesterday as the first Summer clinic for lawyers got under way in this city. Despite years of courtroom experience and national reputation, the lawyers listened attentively as they heard the technique of successful practice explained by their colleaeues and instructors.

The Diario de Noticias today begins the publication of a series of six-page supplements, to run daily for a month, devoted to the century-old friendship between Brazil and the United States, their economic and cultural relations,
Mrs. Edward Savage Crocker, wife of the first secretary at the American Embassy in Tokyo, has come from her country place, Bayberry Rocks, Kittery Point, Me., and is at the Colony Club.
Price reductions averaging 5 to 7 per cent, and reaching 10 per cent on axminster weaves, marked the Fall opening of rug and carpet lines in the wholesale market here yesterday.

Several architects of the New York metropolitan district were among the winners of awards in the residential design competition sponsored jointly by the American Gas Association and The Architectural Forum.
Announcement was made today of the marriage last Saturday in Palm Beach, Fla., of Mrs. Grace Long Morgan of Palm Beach and New York to Franz William Fischer of Chicago.

The question of how much a piano should cost agitated the members of the Board of Estimate at some length yesterday before they finally decided to approve the purchase of a $1,600 instrument for the Queens College in Flushing.

The engagement of $5,800,000 gold in Japan for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This consignment will bring to $66,400,000 the total of gold sent here from Japan since Feb. 24, last. A shipment- of $377,000 gold from India was received yesterday.

Due to the holiday, visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday were well below the preceding week. However, the total was practically the same as in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

In a bitter attack on the Jersey City administration of Mayor Frank Hague, the Right Rev. John A. Ryan of Catholic University, Washington, warned today that "vigilance is necessary to prevent the insidious approach of every form of dictatorship."

With the arrival of a special train from New York City this evening carrying 1,148 happy but tired passengers, the enrollment of 1,600 citizens in the military training camp at this famous post was completed.

The June Federal grand jury in Brooklyn concluded its term yesterday by handing up a presentment to Judge Clarence G. Galston criticizing its meeting room on the seventh floor of the new Brooklyn Federal Building as "sadly lacking" in dignity, failing to "properly impress those called before it" and "tending to encourage a natural reluctance to do more than answer questions."

President Roosevelt used a press conference sandwiched between trips out of town today to re-emphasize his determination to force through Congress a bill authorizing reorganization of the Federal establishment, despite the defeat of such efforts in the House in the last session.

This nation's population of 127,500,000 of 1935 will reach a maximum of 158,000,000 in 1980, but then will slowly decrease unless the birth rate. increases or immigration policies are changed, the Committee on Population Problems of the National Resources Committee reported today to President Roosevelt.

Governor A. Harry Moore declared himself in favor of reduced tolls on Port Authority bridges and tunnels, in a conference this afternoon at his law office here with representatives of the Holland Tunnel Toll Reduction Association.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation was authorized today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to pay on Aug. 15 dividends aggregating $1,627,175 on its 6 and 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock and on its 5 per cent preference stock out of 1938 earnings.

Jonathan Peterson, who was president of the United States Tobacco Company when he died in 1929, transferred to his wife, Henrietta Jacques Peterson, a total of $1,040,000 between 1924 and 1928; but the United States Circuit Court of Appeals held yesterday that this did not "constitute an outright gift or gifts."

Luigi Antonini, State chairman of the American Labor- party, disassociated himself last night from the recommendation that Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and vice chairman of the C. I. 0., be named as the party's candidate for the short-term Senate vacancy this Fall.

Those few privileged spectators who shouldered their way into tiny Bow Street police court today heard witnesses testify that Count Court HaugwitzReventlow, husband of the former Barbara Hutton, had threatened to "put his wife on the spot" and "shoot like a dog" a certain unnamed man in London society.

John Schneider, 81-year-old blacksmith who was pensioned by the Third Avenue Railway System ten years ago, died yesterday morning while making his monthly visit to collect his check at the railway's car barns at Third Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Our Ketcham, who races in the colors of Charles S. Bromley, reversed a recent decision gained by John Hay Whitney's Gentle Savage to the dismay of the players at Empire City yesterday when he captured the Briarcliff Purse, in which the Whitney color bearer, heavily played at 9 to 10, finished fifth among six starters.

Jewish tenants in Vienna's municipal dwellings have received notice to move, in some cases within a fortnight and in others within a month. The action affects several hundred Jewish households, mostly poor.

George L. R. French, receiver for the 97-year-old Rutland Railroad, today petitioned the Federal District Court for permission, to sell or discontinue operation of the line on the ground that revenues were insufficient.

MANHATTAN BACHARACH, FANNY (June 20). Estate, more than $10.000. To Congregation Rodeph Shlomn, $1,000; Sisterhood of the Temple Rodeph Sholom, $500; New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews of the City of New York, the Hospital for Joint Diseases of the City of New York, one-third residue each; three varying bequests;

Strikers of the Busch Jewelry Stores and affiliates, enjoined by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo from picketing the establishments because of violations of the law governing peaceful picketing, continued their general demonstrations against the employers yesterday.

For the first time in the history of the criminal courts of New York County five grand juries were in existence yesterday for the July term. Three of them were sworn in by General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $7,377,260,351 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on July 1, was $29.41, compared with $24.28 at the beginning of June.

Vic Fleming, former Canadian whose headquarters now are at Syracuse, N. Y., and his three sons, Charley, Jimmy and Billy, who serve as his assistants, made the North Randall Grand Circuit today a family celebration.

Tippy Larkin of Garfield, the National Boxing Association's eighth ranking lightweight contender, chalked up his fourth victory against Freddie (Red) Cochrane of Elizabeth tonight, winning a tenround decision in the feature match of a milk fund show. Larkin weighed 137. Cochrane 138.

Michael McTigue, former world light heavyweight champion, of 200 West Eighty-ninth Street, was injured about 8:30 o'clock last night when an automobile in which he was a passenger was in collision with an Intercity bus on West Thirty-sixth Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.
Funeral services, with full naval honors, were held at the Naval Academy today for Commander Richard Somers Galloway, U.S.N., retired, who died at his home here Thursday.

While directing traffic near a gas company excavation at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-second Street at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Patrolman Adolph Brune, 58 years. old, became dizzy with gas fumes and fell head first into the excavation, barely missing a worker mending a gas leak six feet underground.
Edward S. Clark is in the trading department of Eugene J. Hynes Co. Frank A. Chaffee, James T. Flannery and Henry A. Conant are in the organization.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, has been appointed chairman of the committee on criminal courts, law and procedure of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, it was announced yesterday.

Decision to test the constitutionality of the New Jersey Fair Sales Act, which, effective yesterday, forbids below-cost sales of merchandise by retail merchants, was reached at a joint meeting of three Jersey City merchant groups at the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce yesterday.

The Federal grand jury, acting after Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, had appeared before it here today, decided to ask Attorney General Cummings and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate the "deportation" of Mr. Thomas from Jersey City when ne attempted to speak there on April 30 without a permit.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended June 30 was 242 compared with 233 in the week preceding and 155 for the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Failure in the first half of 1938 totaled 6,709, against 4,612 in the corresponding period of 1937.

Amid a gay atmosphere that seemed to be a cross between a county fair and the Indianapolis automobile race, with a dash of world series on the side, this sweltering metropolis on the banks of the American Rhine moved boisterously forward tonight to occupy the center of the stage in the nation's baseball affairs.

In an opinion by Justice Newton H. Porter the New Jersey Supreme Court held today that a father who permits his minor son to drive the family automobile was not necessarily liable for damages resulting from the boy's negligence.

A dogs life in the big city, public opinion to the contrary, is- considerably healthier and more comfort able than that of his cousins who frolic amid the trees and lush vegetation of the country, it was reported yesterday as nearly 2,000 veterinarians from all parts of the country began to gather at the Hotel Pennsylvania for the seventyfifth annual convention of the American Veterinary Medical Association.

Frederick K. Rupprecht, cotton textiles, in 320 Broadway: Milton Electric Machinery Co., also Water Treatment Corp., in 401 Broadway; Nobility Hat Co., third floor in 21 W. 4th St.; American Die Cutting Co., represented by Holmes Douglas. second floor in 152-6 W. 25th St.; Charles F. Noyes Co., broker.

The National Maritime Union assigned a subcommittee yesterday to seek a conference with Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, formerly the American Steamship Owners Association, for the purpose of reopening negotiations for a blanket working agreement between operators and union.

Two men drove up to a gasoline station at 442 Stone Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday at 11 A M., displayed pistols and forced the manager, Moe Brodie, 37 years old, of 722 Montgomery Street, Brooklyn, into their car.

Samuel O. Clark Jr. was named today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as a director of a new reorganization division to carry out the duties of the commission under the recently enacted Chandler bill, which revised the national bankruptcy act.

Trustees for the Munson Steamship Line filed an affidavit yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court contending that the Federal Government had no legal right to foreclose a mortgage on the Munson liner Western World as a preferred mortgage holder because the government is not a citizen of the United States.
The first of a fleet of white patrol cars will be delivered here tomorrow for the use of Sheriffs to promote safety on the highways.
Formation of a national council for the footwear and allied trades has reached the advanced stage at which a committee has been appointed to draft the constitution of the. proposed organization.
Admiral Sir Berkeley Milne, who commanded the British fleet in the Mediterranean at the outbreak of the World War, died today at the age of 83.

Miss Suzanne Lenglen, who died yesterday morning, was to have received the Legion of Honor in the next honors list, and the award will now be made posthumously, the Ministry of Education announces. Miss Lenglen's mother was officially notified today of the award.

Having left Walter Reed Hospital in Washington against doctors' orders, Governor Blanton Winship today was attempting to recuperate from a Fourth of July celebration that kept him on his feet for more than three hours.

The report of the United Gas Corportion and subsidiaries for twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $8,434,313 after taxes and charges. This was equal, after dividend requirements on the $7 first preferred stock, to $5.97 a share on the outstanding $7 second preferred stock.

Mrs. Marie Vaughan Wilde, former vice president of the Republican Club of the Fifteenth Assembly District and a Republican Presidential Elector in 1924, died yesterday in her apartment in the Park Lane, 299 Park Avenue, of heart disease.

Senator Pope, Democrat of Idaho, asked the monopoly investigation committee today to inquire into trade practices of the Oregon Portland Cement company of Portland, Ore. The company had refused to sell cement to two independent Idaho firms, he telegraphed to the committee.

Forty Richmond Garden Club members had luncheon today at the Pleasant Valley bird and wild flower sanctuary cottage of Warden and Mrs. George J. Wallace. Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs, president of the club, introduced as speaker Miss Mary Parsons.

The Treasury on Monday will announce an offering of $200,000,000 of threeyear notes of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation dated July 20. This will be the first time, according to Treasury officials, that the Treasury has acted as fiscal agent for the RFC in selling its obligations to the public.

Herman Taylor, boxing promoter, said tonight he would offer Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis $250,000 to fight Tony Galento of Orange, N. J., in September "in the event Galento decisively defeats John Henry Lewis this month."

After a week of rest at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden will join today those celebrating the tercentenary of the landing of the Swedish and Finnish settlers near what is now Wilmington, Del.

The principal operating subsidiaries in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system had a net loss of 18,000 telephones in service in June, contrasted with a net gain of 31,400 instruments in June, 1937, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Elizabeth M. Riordan, daughter of Mrs. William Riordan of 142 East Eighty-third Street and the late Mr. Riordan, was married yesterday morning in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, to Charles S. O'Connor of the Bronx, son of Mrs. Simeon O'Connor and the late Captain O'Connor. The ceremony was performed by the bride's brother, the Rev. William A. Riordan.

Insurgent General Miguel Aranda's Galician brigade today moved south from Villareal and Almazora to occupy both Burriana and its tiny port, Grao de Burriana, twenty miles north of Sagunto, according to a war communique issued here.
A Summer program that includes most of the features of camping except the country setting was started yesterday by Girl Scouts in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island.

The Hall Johnson Choir, which used to be a regular visitor at the Lewisohn Stadium, appeared there last night for the first time in four seasons, sharing the program with the Philharmonic - Symphony and Alexander Smallens.

A purge of the membership rolls of the League of New York Theatres is under way. According to James F. Reilly, executive secretary, about forty individuals and corporations no longer active as producers are expected to be dropped,

THE National Leaguers will go steaming into this all-star ball game in Cincinnati. Steaming with a desire for vindication and r-r-revenge! The score is 4 to 1 against the older league in these all-star clashes and the American Leaguers have won the last three world series in a row. The National League has been referred to contemptuously as a "minor league."

THE old man blew a couple of plaintive noted on his reed pipe. Then there was a rustling in a corner of the garden and a rat snake ten or twelve feet long came oozing out of the vines. Another poured slowly down the vertical pillar of the veranda; it had been resting in the rafters above. Still another came from a different part of the garden, then a fourth, then a fifth.

John Kriete, 26-year-old counterman in a restaurant at 702 Seventh Avenue, was held in $500 bail yesterday for violating the Sullivan Act because he failed to report a revolver which he said he had found.

Payroll checks due 35,000 State civil service employes on July 15 will be delayed at least "a few days," it was announced yesterday by Miss Nina B. Foran, senior clerk of the State Civil Service Commission, who is in charge of the department's new office in the State Office Building.

Bonds turned irregular in slower trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Profit-taking was sufficient at times to depress values rather sharply but the market exhibited rallying powers and, with the exception of railroad bonds, the various group price averages showed improvement on the day.

The Illinois State Athletic Commission suspended Jack Trammell, Youngstown, Ohio, Negro heavyweight, for five years, placed a one-year ban on Jimmy Adamick of Detroit and handed out five-year suspensions to four of their associates today following a three-week investigation of a bout held here June 8.
A two-day sale of the late Lord Feilding's library, including famous collections formed by Thomas Pennant, brought ??5,827 on conclusion of the auction at Christie's sales rooms here today.
An unusually high level of occupancy has been attained for residential space in White Plains.

Convinced that the South presented "right now the nation's No. 1 economic problem, President Rooss; velt today urged a conference here of Southern spokesmen to draft a statement of economic conditions in the area "in order that we may do something about it."

Nine bids for the demolition of about fourteen old structures on the site of the Queensbridge low-rent housing project in Long Island City were opened yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority.

A suit to restrain Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., from showing the film, "Penrod and His Twin Brother," was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Booth Tarkington, author of the "Penrod" books and stories.

Mrs. J. Bertram Fox, a guest at the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Lewisohn here, collapsed this morning while bathing at the Lewisohn private beach and was carried from the water by a private lifeguard and other bathers in the party.

Secretary Hull challenged as "fundamentally unsound" today an assertion by Representative Schneider, Progressive of Wisconsin, that the trade agreements program had brought a flood of agricultural products into this country.

Trading was generally fair to good following the holiday. Price trends were upward on most classes. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be strong to slightly higher. veal week to slightly lower, lamb about steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Karl Nathan, a director of Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., took the stand yesterday in the Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into the affairs of that company.
A banking group composed of Blyth Co., Inc.; Paine, Webber Co. and Eastman, Dillon Co. obtained yesterday $435,000 of public welfare bonds of Ramsey County, Minn., on a bid of 100.60 for 2 1/4s.

A colonial-type home, on Main Street, Newtown, Conn., has been purchased by L. R. Clark of this city and the Summer home owned by Loulie Rossmassler in the Brookfield Center area has been bought by George Leavitt, also of New York City. John Mann, Newtown broker, closed the deals.

Werner Fred Luck, convicted last week with John Penn of extortion in attempting to collect $30,000 from Murray Levine, father of 12-yearold Peter Levine, whose body was found in Long Island Sound near New Rochelle on May 29, was questioned yesterday at the Federal Building by Reed Vetterli, head of the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, called upon President Roosevelt today and urged him to name an administrator for the Wage and Hour Law, if possible, before going on his Western trip.

Inspector George F. Ferre, in charge of the uniformed police of Staten Island, and Acting Captain Thomas C. Dezell, in charge of the Police Quartermaster Corps, filed applications yesterday for retirement from the department.

Youngstown, Ohio, was made yesterday a basing point for steel sheets, plates and strip products by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, which delayed its announcement nine business days after that of subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation on June 24.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 29, aggregated $7,656,000,000, or 1 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 19 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Many younger members of the Summer colony, including young women who will make their debuts during forthcoming seasons and young men at home from schools and colleges, attended the first in a series of dinner dances held tonight at the Southampton Beach Club.

The stock markets, after a bout of profittaking early today, resumed their upward tendency this afternoon and most sections closed higher than yesterday. Gilt-edge issues went ahead, but among the foreign bonds, Dawes and Young loam issues lost ground.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, counseled ministers and other Christian workers to select subjects for their sermons from the Scriptures rather than preach on social questions at the opening yesterday of the eighteenth annual conference for church students.
Mr. and Mrs. Roger Wolcott Grant of this place have announced the betrothal of their daughter, Miss Grace Wilson Grant, to George Russell Snyder Jr. of North Tarrytown, N. Y.
Mrs. Gustave S. Holmquist of New Hope has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Christina Louise Holmquist, to Clark Wolfram Johnson of New Hope, son of Mrs. Carl Becker.

Machine production of cigars has reduced employment, lowered wages and concentrated the industry in fewer factories, according to a WPA study of cigar manufacturing as part of its research into reemployment opportunities and changes in industrial techniques.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 29:

Papers were served on District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey late yesterday in a motion by Samuel S. Leibowitz, attorney, for inspection of the minutes of the New York County grand jury that indicted his client, Assemblyman Edward $. Moran Jr., of Brooklyn, on June 24 in the alleged extortion of $36,000, in 1935 and 1936, from executives of two large taxicab corporations.

Full cooperation with the United Kingdom for the defense of Canada and the British Empire in a world threatened with civilization-destroying war was urged upon the National Conservative Convdntion today by Arthur Meighen, party leader in the Senate.

From the hamlet of Willis, Kan., comes wafting a brief but thoughtprovoking report of the extemporaneous Fourth of July oration delivered there by former Governor Alfred M. Landon. "Tough cookies built this State," Mr. Landon is quoted as saying, "not cake eaters.

As the result of a recent test promoting large size packages of drug products in the Chicago area, the Walgreen Company will launch, soon, a national campaign for all its outlets on the same theme. The chain's 500 stores will participate in the promotion, which calls for extensive newspaper advertising.

Captaia John D. Craig, deep-sea photog rapher, sailed for Ciudad Trujillo today to join Max Nohl, a diver, to explore and photograph in color a coral forest off the north coast of the Dominican Republic.

Members of the board of directors of the Rotary Club of New York were hosts yesterday in the Hotel Commodore at a tea In honor of the delegate group from Rotary International of the British Isles, who will sail for home this morning on ,the liner Queen Mary after having attended the international convention in San Francisco. P. H.

Judge William Clark, of the Federal District Court of New Jersey, took the oath today as a judge of the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, embracing New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware.

Home Office reports at midnight last night stated that 320 had been killed and- that 338 were missing In the Kobe flood area. The dead include one German, one Frenchman, one Portuguese and his daughter.

Poland's chief of staff, General Julian Stachewicz, has just returned from visiting his colleagues in Latvia, 1 Estonia and Finland. He exchanged information with them regarding the organization of national defense and security in the Baltic Sea districts.

Twenty-six nations--the full membership of the Non-Intervention Committee -- approved yesterday the British plan for the withdrawal of foreign fighters from Spain, and the proposal will now be referred to Barcelona and Burgos.

Lou Ambers, holder of the world lightweight title, appeared before the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday and was pronounced fit to defend his crown against Henry Armstrong at the Polo Grounds on Aug. 10.
In an attempt to keep school children off the hot, traffic-jammed streets, the Board of Education yesterday began one of the most ambitious Summer programs ever attempted here.

Stocks closed firm at lower levels after earlier weakness; copper shares rallied on advance in domestic and export copper prices; turnover, 1,694,840 shares. United States Government bonds lower, other groups irregular; transactions, $7,192,900.

Foreign Office sources disclosed tonight that the French Ambassador in Tokyo had explained to the Japanese Government France's reasons for occupying the Paracel Islands, 150 miles southeast of the Chinese island of Hainan.

With its chief hope centered in Joe Hunt, he Pacific Coast qualified seven players for the round of sixteen toplay in the national intercollegiate tennis championships on the clay courts of the Merion Cricket Club.
The Hungarian Legation announced tonight that Count Laszlo Szechenyi, Former Hungarian Minister to the United States, died today in Budapest.

The sale of the second portion of the famous collection of fine bindings and rare engravings assembled by the late Mortimer L. Schiff, which began today and will be continued through Thursday realized ??5,686 at Sotheby's this afternoon.

The Spanish Foreign Minister, Julio Alvarez del Vayo, who flew here from BaresIona, conferred at the Foreign Office today with Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet. It was said they conferred on the problem of aerial bombings of Spanish Government towns behind the government's front lines.

The Federal Opera Chorus, the Greenwich Orchestra and soloists will give the first act of Smetana's "Bartered Bride" in concert version tonight at the Federal Music Theatre. Joseph Littau will conduct. There will also be orchestral selections.

Receipts of 17,000,000 bushels of cash wheat at the twelve primary and five Southwestern interior terminals, believed to be the largest on record, gave the wheat market a body blow today from which it did not recover.
The Rev. Peter P. Keshelak, for more than thirty years pastor of St. Elias Catholic Church, Greek Rite, at 724 Leonard Street, Brooklyn, died on Saturday at the age of 67.

Joseph Wunsch, a former major of Austrian police, today was sentenced to three years' imprisonment in the first major trial under the Nazi regime in Austria of officials of the fallen Schuschnigg Government.

Jersey City's Little Giants batted a trio of Newark pitchers for fourteen hits and an 11-7 victory today. The Jerseys drove Phil Page, Newark starter, out of the box in the second and continued their assault on Norman Branch, his successor. Xavier Rescigno stopped the Jersey City attack in the eighth.

Playing consistent golf, James Oleska of the Shore View Club took the low-gross prize with a 73 in the annual one-day medal handicap invitation tourney of the Long Island Golf Association held today on the course of the Southampton Golf Club.
Lee Fleenor, 34, former deputy sheriff and one of the defendants in the London, Ky., labor conspiracy trial, was put in jail here late today following the shooting of Charlie Reno, 40, of Molus.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 22.4 per cent of effective capacity this week, which includes the Fourth of July holiday, a decline of 6.3 points, or 21.9 per cent, from last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
As the human body is a tissue of cells, so is the nation a structure of its individuals. The trends of this mass, social, economic and biological, are the measure of the nation's health and vitality.

The Harlan Fuel Company, one of the dependants in the Harlan County trials which the government is pressing in Kentucky, was found guilty by the National Labor Relations Board today of engaging in unfair labor practices, beginning in January, 1937.
Dr. John W. Smith of this place, former president of the Westchester County Medical Society, died on Saturday in Lawrence Hospital here after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

Rising securities carried most speculative commodities higher late last week, but selling in several important items held The Analist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 80.6, on Saturday, unchanged from the preceding Wednesday. A year ago the index stood at 95.3.

Executors of the estate of George F. Baker, New York banker, settled today for $282,665 a group of Federal gift tax claims totaling $567,510. In 1934 and 1935 Mr. Baker put blocks of First National Bank of New York stock in trust for his wife and son and the tax controvery arose over valuation of the securities.
Scenes reminiscent of 1919, when the Reds last participated in a world series, met the eye today as this city once again became the baseball metropolis of America.

With the vanguard of buyers' arrivals on a par with last year and openings of dress and sports wear lines drawing good showroom attendance, the Fall sesson in the ready-to-wear markets got off to a good start here yesterday.
The loss of jewelry valued at $15,000 from the home of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field here on Sunday, was disclosed today as local, county and State police opened investigations.
Hugh J. Murphy, formerly assistant city clerk and for a quarter century a lawyer here, died at his home this morning of a heart attack at the age of 59. He had been in ill health for several years.

It was learned here yesterday that Dr. James M. Doran, who has been acting head of the Distilled Spirits Institute since the death of W. Forbes Morgan a year ago, has asked the board of the institute to relieve him of administrative responsibility so he may concentrate on his original function as technical adviser to the institute, which he prefers.

After a sharp-tongued flurry yesterday between James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, and George McCaffrey of the Merchants Association, the Board of Estimate voted pay increases of $120 a year for 1,192 low-paid city employes.
It is welcome news that the sloop Hartford, Farragut's famous flagship, is to be restored and preserved as a historic relic.

After spending a disappointing three hours yesterday in a Summer City Hall that was far from equipped for his use, Mayor La Guardia returned to the old City Hall downtown and announced his intention of making his headquarters there for the rest of this week.

More than 1,000 Brooklyn property owners have been invited top a meeting tomorrow evening to organize plans for blockfront rehabilitation projects under the direction of the Mayor's of which Bernard F. Hogan is chairman.
The Phillies collected sixteen hits to defeat the Berks County All-Stars, 15 to 5, in an exhibition contest today. The National Leaguers missed scoring in only two innings, the second and sixth.

Doubleday, Doran will publish on July 22 a new historical novel by Vincent Sheean, author of "Personal History." The title of the book is "A Day of Battle." It covers a single day, May 11, 1745, from dawn to midnight, and its scene is laid for the most part on the battlefield of Fontenoy, with flashes to the house of Mme. de Pompadour in Paris.
Pancho Villa, bantamweight champion of Mexico and a left-hook artist. impressed ringsiders tonight when he used his pet punch to knock out Sammy Taormina, Akron, Ohio, in the third round.

The National Labor Relations Board views its own record with deep satisfaction. It celebrates its third anniversary by announcing that it has "successfully" handled, between the time of its formation and June 1 last, 11,180 labor disputes.
The Endicott-Johnson Corporation showed a net profit of $1,202,152 for the fifty-two weeks ended on May 28, after expenses and charges, including provision for Federal income taxes.

The weather over the holidays was the most favorable in more than a month for the cotton crop and, with a more two-sided stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back yesterday 15 points to end with losses of 8 to 10 points.

Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt made their first visit of the Summer today, arriving on their seaplane from Long Island. They were the luncheon guests of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas, and then flew back home.

Despite a poor Winter showing, Princeton athletic teams have pulled themselves out of a two-year Spring slump. Paced by the varsities' .639 average, Old Nassau wound up its Spring season this year at the .599 mark, far above last Spring's .511.

Vaughn Lee Alward, former president of the American Furniture Mart, died yesterday of a heart attack at his Summer home in New Brunswick, Canada, according to word received here today. His age was 65.

The death of Charles Witzel, 65, furniture buyer from Brooklyn, was investigated at an inquest today. Mr. Witzel died Sunday night at Mercy Hospital soon after an accident at a hotel where he had gone for dinner.

American Zionists meeting at the closing sessions of the convention of the Zionist Organization of America declared today their readiness to consider "without prejudice" Britain's. proposal for the establishment of a Jewish State in Palestine.

Disappointed, but not dismayed at the snapping of his nine-game winning streak by the Cubs last Sunday, Johnny Vander Meer, hero of two successive no-hit, no-run ball games, tonight looked forward eagerly and with becoming modesty to a signal honor tomorrow--starting the National League on its quest of a second victory in the sixth All-Star. game.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, mortgagee in possession of the properties known as 8 and 10 East Fifty-seventh Street and 11 East Fifty-sixth Street, just east of the Bonwit Teller department store, has filed plans through Walker Gillette, architects, for a six-story office and store building on the site, to cost about $185,000.

Three couples well known in New York City social circles were divorced in the District Court here today Mrs. Phyllis Waid won an uncontested decree from Dan E. Waid, New York architect, and her former name, Phyllis Fellowes Colmore, was restored.

Citizens who have scruples against going through a picket line now face a serious problem. Where does one draw the picket line, so to speak, when the pickets are up in the air in an airplane or on a raft off Coney Island beach?

Exports of raw cotton by Brazil so far this year shows a decline compared with the same period in 1937, the Department of Commerce reports. Exports in the first three months were 35,937 metric tons, against 37,621 in 1937. A metric ton is about 4.6 bales of 476 pounds.
Three charitable institutions were named residuary legatees in the will of Mrs. Fanny Bacharach filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

Spring lambs broke 25 to 50 cents today but hogs and cattle sold actively and higher. Fed steers topped at $11.75 and hogs at $9.45, new peaks for the season, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

Detectives who had made inquiries at bars and grills since Mrs. Rita Hansen Bonfiglio, 24-year-old waitress, was found strangled to death in her furnished room at 21 West Sixty-fifth Street last Wednesday, arrested William Paulsen, 20, of 34 West Sixtieth Street, last night.

The story why Finland, the only country that pays its war debts to the United States, wants "to pay every cent of her obligation to America" was told yesterday by Dr. E. Rudolf W. Holsti, Foreign Minister of Finland, on the eve of his departure.

For the first time since 1930, New York State now has a balanced budget, Governor Lehman announced today. In a statement which he proudly presented to legislative correspondents in the Executive Offices, the Governor revealed that for the fiscal year ending June 30, the State had a cash surplus of about $6,500,000 and an operating surplus of more than $16,600,000.

The port's first serious attack on the perennial problem of harbor fog will be started under the auspices of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York tomorrow when committees on steamship operation, rivers and harbors and towboat affairs meet at the Maritime Exchange.

If permission is received from the Federal Communications Commission, the Board of Education hopes to operate its own short-wave radio broadcasting station this Fall. Regular broadcasts are planned to supplement the classroom instruction; at the same time the school system will conduct an experiment in the use of radio in education.

Alabama erased the death penalty from the Scottsboro rape case records today. Governor Bibb Graves commuted to life imprisonment the electrocution sentence against Clarence Norris, last of the nine original Negro defendants to face the chair on conviction of attacking two young white women on a freight train seven years ago.
The problem of steel wages is temporarily on a sidetrack, according to the best information that could be had yesterday.
The home furnishings industries set about efforts to take a part in bringing return of prosperity with the opening here today of the fifteenth annual Furniture Buyers' Summer show.

MacDonough Pl, 1,403 (18-5411); Theresa Brenzinger to Francis J. Boyle, 1,403, MacDonough pl. Corlear Ave (13-3406G), e g, 247 ft s of 236th, 100x111; Standard National Corp to 2.322 University Corp. 3,451 Bailey Ave.

Allen G. Sherrill, president and founder of the General Forwarding Company with offices in the Port of New York Authority Building, New York, died last night in his home here of pneumonia. His age was 61.
The wholesale price level rose slightly in the week ended July 2, according to the commodity price index compiled by The National Fertilizer Association.

The deposition of Otto Mueller, director manager of the Pressed Steel Company of Exford, England, which was read into a Federal Trade Commission proceeding in 1927, will not be admitted as evidence in trial of the government's suit to enjoin the Aluminum Company of America from alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.
The Mission Corporation has purchased the crude oil producing properties of the Bridgeport Machine Company in Rice County, Kan., for about $250,000, it was reported yesterday.
Despite miserable shooting conditions, cold, with constant threat of rain, perfect scores were hung up in today's feature matches of the empire meeting of the National Rifle Association.

J. W. Y. Martin's Battle Jack easily won the Topsfield Purse, feature at Suffolk Downs today. Freddie Smith, who previously had ridden Muggins to victory, was not forced to drive his mount in the stretch to score by half a length over Colonel E. P. Bixer's Posterity.

The arrival of units of the Japanese Navy at Hukow, a town only twenty-five miles down river from Kiukiang on the Yangtze, not only brings Kiukiang and the railway to Nanchang in grave danger, but also brings Hankow, the temporary capital, within 110 miles by air from the Japanese ships, although the route by river is 160 miles.

Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture notified President Roosevelt at a White House conference today that the size of this year's wheat crop would make necessary a mandatory loan of at least 52 per cent of parity at the time the loans are made.

Yorkshire lost a chance to subject the Australians to their first defeat by a county cricket team since 1912 today when heavy rain forced the drawing of stumps at the luncheon interval, ending a threeday match that started Saturday.

A swing of State administration support in favor of the Democratic renomination of Senator Frederick Van Nuys, foe of President Roosevelt's Court and Governmental Reorganization Bills, flourished into "band wagon" proportions today and apparently eliminated the possibility of a confusing, three-way Senatorial struggle in Indiana.
Playing over a course devoid of breezes, Bill Goldbeck and Tom Choate of he Lawrence Farms shared top honors with Maurice Delamater of Sleppy Hollow in the Westchester P. G. A.

Samuel Wleder, executive director of the Men's Clothing Manufacturers Trade Bureau, announced yesterday that he was sending questionnaires today to all members, asking them to vote on the question whether the organization should be continued or disbanded.

Several business properties in the downtown section of Manhattan, as well as residential parcels on the West Side, figured in sales reported by brokers and transfers recorded in the Register's office.

The Yankees now are 7-to-10 choices to win the American League pennant, while the Giants are evenmoney favorites to repeat in the National, according to mid-season odds quoted yesterday by Jack Doyle, Broadway betting commissioner.

Rules regulating the broadcasting of political speeches were announced today by the Federal Communications Commission, four years after passage of the act requiring the setting up of such regulations.

Grocery distribution took a "startling" turn for the better last week with both wholesalers and brokers regaining part of the ground lost in recent months, according to the weekly survey released yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution.
William Armstrong Perry, educator, editor and writer of juvenile fiction and scientific articles, died today of a heart attack in his home here. He was 61 years old.

Pleased with tire performance of his specially equipped Lockheed 14 on its fuel consumption test flight across the continent, Howard R. Hughes, sportsman pilot, spent yesterday at Floyd Bennett Field making final preparations to fly to Paris and possibly around the world. He plans to start in "a week or two."
A millionaire sportsman sent a fragile sailplane more than a mile above the earth today to break unofficially his own American altitude record of 6,223 feet.
A law providing for a general amnesty for common crimes was approved "in principle" by the House of Representatives tonight by a vote of 87 to 2.

Presumably the result of the Japanese determinatIan to curtail purchases abroad, British exports to Japan in the first six months of 1938 declined till the total was less than half that in the corresponding period of 1937, Board of Trade figures showed today.

Is Senator Van Nuys to be forgiven and renominated? After a confabulation of Democratic leaders Governor Townsend, who solemnly excommunicated him in the Summer of 1937, has invited him to be a candidate for renomination at the Democratic State Convention on July 12.

Late returns from Fourth of July expeditions off the New Jersey coast bring added reports of tuna. Michael Lerner, well-known sport fisherman, brought in the largest of the season to the Atlantic City Tuna Club on Monday, when he boated. one of sixty-two and a half pounds.

" Trade Winds," by Tay Garnett, for which the author-director shot 70,000 feet of film during a world cruise last season, was purchased today by Walter Wanger as a starring vehicle for Fredric March and Joan Bennett; Garnett will direct.

To refute charges made by Republican legislators that politics rather than need is the determining factor in WPA placements, Robert W. Allan, deputy State Administrator for the Works Progress Administration, submitted today to Governor Moore the names and addresses of 18,161 persons transferred from direct relief in New Jersey to Federal projects since February.
Maxie Fisher, 138, of Newark scored a technical knockout over Johnny Toomey, 140, of Newark tonight in the fourth round of a scheduled six-round feature boxing bout at the Adelphia A. A.
Another realty subdivision on Fire Island is being planned. The rambling old Water Island Hotel in the Water Island section of Fire Island is being razed.

Some members of the Interstate Commerce Commission are concerned over the methods of propaganda used by the Association of American Railroads, especially where the advertising or publicity reflects on the commission, it was learned today.

Claudius M. Offray, president of C. M. Offray, Inc., ribbon manufacturers and importers, 29 West Thirty-eighth Street, died yesterday of a heart attack at Sky Top, Pa., where he had been on a weekend vacation, according to word received by his family here. He was 78 years old.

The Munson G. Shaw Company, Inc., yesterday announced its appointments as representatives in this country for Duff Gordon sherries, Cockburn ports, Cossart Gordon madeiras, Grand Marnier liqueurs, Marcilly burgundies, Barreiro Lison wines and Vintners American wines.

The Argentine Government has approved a plan of public works for the current year involving a total outlay of 159,120,900 pesos (approximately $53,000,000 at the official rate of exchange), according to the Argentine Information Bureau.
The six-story elevator apartment house at 85-7 Strong Street, the Bronx, has been sold by 85 Strong Street, Inc., to Maxine Realties, Inc., through Pearce Mayer.

Whether or not the United States can be persuaded to. join the League of Nations was discussed by Professor Emile Borel, president of the International League of Nations Union at the opening of the twentysecond international conference of the union here today.

Dr. Walther Frank, president of the Reich Institute for the History of the New Germany, opened here today the institute's annual meeting, which is being specially devoted to "research on the Jewish question."

The eloquence of Alfred E. Smith nightt reversed sentiment in the Constitutional Convention and resulted in the advancement to third reading of the proposal of his old friend and associate, Robert Moses, that grade crossing elimination work be sped by the assumption of the State of the entire cost of such projects.

Formal ratification by administrative agencies of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware of a reciprocal agreement for the correction and control of pollution of Delaware River waters was announced today by the Interstate Commission-on the Delaware River Basin.
Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York and Miss Cecilia Riegel of Philadelphia today advanced to the quarterfinal round of the Middle States women's tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

At the conclusion of today's Sokol display at the Prague Stadium, a small detachment of Sokols from America had a tremendous reception. A part of the audience leaped the barriers in order to form an avenue through which the Americans passed to the accompaniment of loud cheers.

Word has been received here that Charles William Bauhan, landscape artist of this city, died of a heart attack on Sunday in Falls Village, Conn., where he had gone to paint Summer scenes. His age was 77.

The Jewish War Veterans are endeavoring to raise $9,000 to prevent Mrs. Sadie L. Monssen, widow of Lieutenant Mons Monssen, United States Navy hero for whom a destroyer is to be named, from losing her home at 1,756 West. Tenth Street, Brooklyn, through foreclosure by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, it was announced yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court by Mrs. Monssen's attorney, Bernard E. Perelson.

John L. Lewis and other United States labor leaders will come to Mexico in September to aid in forming the LatinAmerican Workers Federation, according to Vicente Lombardo Tole dano, head of the Mexican Federation of Labor,

New York subscribers to the three-cents-a-day- plan have received a total of 770,000 days of hospital care since the plan started three years ago, according to Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service, 370 Lexington Avenue. Provision is made for members of the Associated Hospitals Service in 260 hospitals in the metropolitan area.
Additional banks and trust companies made public yesterday their statements of conditions as of June 30, in response to calls for such reports issued by the national banking authorities.
Discovery of a new possible source of insulin, arising from experiments by two British Columbia physicians with an old Indian herb remedy, was reported today in The Canadian Medical Journal.

Mayor La Guardia gave the City Council a broad hint at its closing session yesterday that additional city relief taxes would become necessary shortly to meet a $6,000,000 a-year deficit in the city's contribution toward WPA materials aid supplies.

Baby Salvy Saban of Greenwich Village gained the decision over Bobby Pacho of California after eight fast rounds in the feature bout at the New Dyckman Oval before 2,500 last night. The weights were 149 1/2 for Saban and 146 1/2 for Pacho.

A further advance took place in quotations on acetate fabrics here yesterday as the mills reinstated cloths withdrawn toward the end of last week. The increase in the new prices ranged up to one cent over previous quotations. Trading, however, was comparatively light, with the market largely of a "bid and take" nature.

A Zande tribesman in the Belgian Congo can buy a wife for as little as $4.50 and is even able to pay on the installment plan, according to Miss Myrtle I. Wilson,- missionary of the African Inland Mission, who returned on leave yesterday on the Dollar liner President Harrison.

In laying the cornerstone of the Polish Pavilion at the New York World's Fair site yesterday afternoon, Count Jerzy Potocki, the Polish Ambassador, declared Poland's participation in the fair "shows that we do not foresee any dramatic events in the political

There were sixty-two strikes involving 8,222 workers and one lockout involving thirty employes in New York State in May, it was reported yesterday by the Division of Industrial Relations of the State Labor Department.

Six directors of the German American Settlement League, Inc., which operates Camp Siegfried, Nazi Summer site at Yaphank, will be placed on trial here tomorrow on an indictment charging violation of the State Civil Rights Law.

The certificate of incorporation of the Park Association of Westchester County was drafted here today In final form and will be filed tomorrow with the Secretary of State in Albany, it was announced by Mrs. John H. Mooers of Scarsdale, the founder.
Steel ingot output was unchanged last week, although the normal seasonal trend was downward, and the adjusted index rose to 40.6 from 39.9. For the week ended July 3, 1937, the index was 113.2.

Foreign Minister Jose Maria Cantilo of Argentina, who is president of the Chaco peace conference, today directed negotiations between Bolivia and Paraguay in an attempt to save the conference from failure.

Mr. and Mrs. Richman Proskauer of this place and 1,010 Fifth Avenue, New York, gave a garden party at their home here this afternoon, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Edith Proskauer, to Donald Dryfoos, son of Mrs. Jack A. Dryfoos of 77 Park Avenue, New York and the late Mr. Dryfoos.

Warnings to Americans to think in terms of America and to bewarealike of misrepresentation abroad by Europeans and of failure at home to realize that Europe's problems are not ours were issued here today by James S. Carson of New York, vice president of the American and Foreign Power Company, and by Jerome N. Frank, Securities and Exchange Commissioner, of Washington.

Five Jews were killed today and three were wounded. One Arab was-killed by troops who were chasing snipers. Four Jews, who were going to work this morning from Einverad, a settlement near Tul Karm, were fired on while passing an Arab's farm.
Prince Bertil, son of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, motored today from Washington to visit the Naval Academy. Captain Milo F. Draemel, acting superintendent of the academy, greeted the Prince.

The largest Summer school in the world will open its doors today to approximately 11,800 men and women from all parts of the nation and from foreign countries who will participate in the intensive sixweek program of Columbia University's thirty-ninth Summer session.

Swift Co., the largest packing concern in the country, petitioned the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today to set aside a recent order entered against it by Secretary Wallace on the ground that Mr. Wallace had violated the Constitution, the Packers and Stockyards Act and the rules of practice governing hearings under the act.
Veterans of the Blue and of the Gray bade one another farewells tonight and started home from "the greatest time in our lives," their last reunion.
