Low gross honors in the thirteenth annual Westchester County father and son golf tournament today were won by the Siwanoy representatives, Leo Tully and his son Leo Jr., who carded 43, 40-83 over the Lawrence Farms Country Club course.

William Lane, 10-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lane of this place, was drowned here this afternoon in Lake Shenorock, despite the courageous attempt of John Davanzo, 11year-old companion, to pull him to safety.

Automobile ring at the half-mile dirt track here, at which a boy was killed and eighteen persons were injured when a racing car plowed into a crowd of spectators yesterday, will be banned for the rest of the Summer, Chief of Police John A. McElroy announced today.
FAST COMPANY, based on the novel by Marco Page; screen play by Mr. Page and Harold Tarshis; directed by Edward Buzzell; produced by Frederick Stephani for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. At the Rialto.

Alf M. Landon came to this little town for an old-fashioned Fourth of July celebration last night. "Tough cookies built this Statenot cake eaters," he said to 1,500 farmers. "They had fire-in their bellies.

Theodore Stanfield of 151 Central Park West, peace advocate, who was formerly general manager and treasurer of the American Metal Company, died yesterday of a heart attack in Dr. Slocum's Sanitarium, Beacon, N. Y. Born in Paris sixtytwo years ago, he had lived in this country since infancy.

Following a further rise yesterday to 10 cents a pound for copper in the foreign market, two leading producers advanced the price in the domestic market from 9.50 to 9.75 cents a pound. It is expected that other producers will meet the new price today. This follows an advance from 9 cents to 9.50 cents on last Friday.

Exercising the privilege granted it under the new constitution, the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it will nominate a member of the Exchange to fill the vacancy created by the elevation of William McC. Martin Jr.,
The Vatican City newspaper.Osservatore Romano asserted today that anti-Jewish propaganda had produced results "unworthy of twenty centuries of Christian civilization."

If the speaker at the Fourth of July dinner of the American Society in London were not Mr. Anthony Eden, and if every utterance of the former Foreign Secretary were not searched for allusions to his disagreement with Mr. Chamberlain, his address would sound like another of the polite and friendly tributes Americans are accustomed to hear from British statesmen in celebration of our national holidays. Mr.

Theodore Stanfield of 151 Central Park West, peace advocate, who was formerly general manager and treasurer of the American Metal Company, died yesterday of a heart attack in Dr. Slocum's Sanitarium, Beacon, N. Y. Born in Paris sixtytwo years ago, he had lived in this country since infancy.

It is expected that other producers will meet the new price today. This follows an advance from 9 cents to 9.50 cents on last Friday.

The newly formed Conference on State Defense has just issued a nation-wide call to States and municipalities to organize to protect their employes against retroactive Federal income taxation and levies upon their outstanding obligations.
A paroled convict, Alfonse Castagna, 39 years old, of 573 Park Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot behind the left ear yesterday at 11 A. M.
Veterans of the Blue and of the Gray bade one another farewells tonight and started home from "the greatest time in our lives," their last reunion.
Marking the end of the first year of the "China incident," the War Office announced today that Japanese had occupied 775,000 square miles of territory and caused 1,300,000 casualties.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Kiely of this city and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Spence Kiely, to James M. Snowden of New York, Philadelphia and Watch Hill, R. I., son of Mrs. George Grant Snowden of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Snowden.

Mrs. John E. Berwind gave a luncheon today at the Southampton Beach Club for Miss Katharine Durand and Miss Bertha Garvin, who are visiting her at Minden, her home in Bridgehampton. Mr. and Mrs. Sydney J. Smith have joined Miss Ethel Wickham at Bonnie Bourne.

Representatives of the Transit Commission and of the La Guardia administration, meeting here today, agreed on $315,000,000 as the amount that should be exempted from the New York City debt limit to permit it to buy the privately operated transit lines of the B. M. T., I. R. T. and Manhattan Elevated System.

The decline in vehicular traffic and revenue therefrom in the last ten years on the ferry lines of the West Shore Railroad between Weehawken and this city prompted the recently proposed increase in passenger fares for that service, according to officials who testified yesterday at the opening of a hearing before a representative of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Grace Line announced yes terday a new freight service between Philadelphia and Baltimore and ports on the western coast of South America as far south as Valparaiso. Two former Red D Line freighters, the Lara and Cacique, have been assigned to the service and will begin operating early next month, roughly on a monthly scheduIe.
Crown Princess Louise of Sweden almost missed getting her honorary degree yesterday because the program at the Union Club, where her husband and J. Sigfrid Edstrom received theirs, ran over-time.

If you hanker to go adventuring, cross the Ainazon jungles off your list, advises Miss Caryl Smadbeck, 21-year-old New Yorker, who traveled through South America all by herself, among Indians and halfbreeds, and got chills instead of thrills.

After a dramatic farewell speech from its retiring leader, R. B. Bennett, urging close cooperation with Britain to fight fascism abroad and a reform program to fight it at home, the Conservative convention today nominated five candidates to succeed him.
Acceptance of the resignation of Fred F. Mitchell, former majorleague manager, as Harvard varsity baseball coach was announced today by the committee on the regulation of athletic sports.

Contending that the sweeping injunction issued by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo in the Busch Jewelry Stores strike forbidding picketing of the stores and other strike activities by two C. I. O. unions endangers' the State AntiInjunction Act and may help to vitiate the Federal Norris-La Guardia act, upon which the State law is based, thirty labor attorneys met yesterday to consider plans for having the injunction vacated.

Miss Darice Dunham Elmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. P. Elmer of Princeton, was mar-' ried here this afternoon to John McDiarmid, also of Princeton, son of Mrs. Weir McDiarmid of Fort Worth, Texas, and the late Professor McDiarmid.

Ferenc Szalasi, World War major who aspired to be "Hungary's Hitler," today was sent to prison for a three-year term for "incitement," the mild Hungarian term for illegal attempts to overthrow the government.

Net receipts reached $1,160,366 in this year's "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign, - and disbursements were $139,331, leaving $1,021,034 for the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, it was announced yesterday by Keith Morgan, chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday.

Johnny Vander Meer's folks, who came from Midland Park, N. J., at the Cincinnati Club's expense, led the cheering when he left the game. The southpaw was the big pregame target for autograph seekers and candid camera operatives, but he handled himself like a veteran in every respect.

Mrs. Bess Ball Nelson, wife of Major Frank L. Nelson, for many years connected with newspaper rotogravure work, died today at Broad Street Hospital after an operation. Mrs. Nelson was born fifty-nine years ago in Chillicothe, Ohio.

France today ran into complications over her occupation of Paracel Islands in the South China Sea when the Chinese Ambassador, Dr. V. K. Wellington Koo, called at the Foreign Office, announcing that his government considered the islands Chinese possessions.
The United States Customs Service marked the retirement of Staff Officer John T. Parker yesterday with a brief ceremony in the offices of the. Surveyor- of the Port.

Sale of alcoholic liquor in miniature bottles was banned in Illinois today by the State Liquor Control Commismission. The step was taken to protect minors of limited means and motorists who drink while they drive.

Memories of lavish living, town and country homes and $5,000 monthly expenditures for household maintenance were reviewed in Supreme Court today by Mrs. Bertha Gott Smith in her contempt-of-court action against Al Smith Jr., her erstwhile husband.

Duties collected on imported liquors in May amounted to $2,326,886, about $1,000,000 less than in the same month last year, James M. Moyle, Collector of Customs, has announced. There were 749,553 proof gallons of distilled liquors imported, compared with 1,237,011 in May, 1937.

Governor Hurley, declaring today that he would seek a second term, donned the cloak of a New Dealer with a promise to be in "whole-hearted accord with legislative objectives that aim toward a solution of the unemployment problem and many other social and economic problems which confront the American public."
An increase in the -number of applications for patents this year was cited by Secretary Roper today as indicasting "continued industrial progress."

Estate. less than $5.000. The decedent set up two trusts of stock and left bequests as follows: Alice E. Everett, widow, 400 E. 49th St., 40% of each trust and residue; James Everett, son, 54D W. 123d St., 15% of first trust and 10% of second trust; Mrs. Charles Everett. sister, Portland, Ore., 10% of second trust;

Mrs. Henry March of North Shore captured low-gross:.honorsin the weekly 'one-day. Long Island Women's Golf Association tournament over the Sands Point Club course today with a score of 44, 39-83 after matching cards with Mrs. Charles Leichner of Fresh Meadow. who turned in 41. 42-83.

A blazing trestle on the Long Island Railroad line across Jamaica Bay early yesterday morning disrupted traffic of the Rockaway division for twelve hours and delayed thousands of commuters on other trains at the morning rush hour. Service had returned nearly to normal by evening.

Raymond H. Korndorfer, a student at Williams College, made a great start today in his attempt to gain the Westchester junior golf title. After taking the medal by five strokes with a 75, three over par, at the picturesque Lawrence Farms Golf Club links, the Scarsdale representative made short shrift of his first-round opponent, Robert Comfort of Pelham Korndorfer ended

The General Baking Company reported yesterday for the thirteen weeks ended on June 25, net profit of $538,844 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after dividend requirements on 87,883 shares of $8 preferred stock, to 23 cents each on 1,588,697 shares of $5-par common stock.

A jubilant band of National League stars made merry in the clubhouse at Crosley Field today after winning the sixth All-Star game. Bill Terry, manager of the Giants, who piloted the National Leaguers, was particularly happy.

Domei, Japanese news agency, asserts that Philippine Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon will be received by Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kensuke Horinouchi; Seijiro Yoshizawa, who is chief of the American Bureau of the Foreign Office, and the Marquis Yorisada Tokugawa, president of the Philippines Society of Japan, when he arrives in Tokyo this afternoon.
Bombs, riots and police action in various parts of Palestine today resulted in at least twenty-three deaths and nearly a hundred less serious casualties.
Swedish-Americans in the vivi? peasant garb of Skane, Dalecalia and Vestergotland danced yester day before 30,000 persons gathered at the Mall in Central Park to celebrate the New Sweden tercentenary

The Longchamps Farms' Indomitable annexed yesterday's featured Alpine Purse at Empire City as might have been expected by the odds of 4 to 5, but there was plenty of excitement during the afternoon at the hilltop course.

The 1,403 Rosedale Avenue Realty Corporation, Joseph Lubarsky, president, purchased the five-anda-half-story apartment house for fifty-six families at that address from the Gam Realty Corporation, the builder.

Tribute to President Roosevelt and his New Deal plans, policies and achievements was paid here today by Postmaster General Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee; by Representative Clifton A. Woodrum of Roanoke and by a cheering crowd of loyal Virginia Democrats, who staged in their honor a Democratic "rally" of heroic proportions.
Edward E. Bartlett Jr. of E. A. Pierce Co. was named yesterday by the nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange to succeed William McC. Martin Jr. as chairman of the board of the Exchange.

Dr. Harry Neivert, in 480 Park Ave.; Eugene Pitou, from Fred F. French, Inc., in 1,010 5th Ave.; Mrs. Consuelo de Agacio, duplex garden apartment at 130 E. 62d St., from Peter Bail; Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.
Luncheon of the Rotary Club of use. New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. The twenty-ninth annual convention of Rotary International at San Francisco will be reported on by the New York delegation.

Miss Jane Moses, 18-year-old daughter of Park Commissioner Robert Moses, got her first adult automobile driver's license in the mail this morning and a few hours later she was In a head-on automobile collision at Deer Park Avenue and Simon Street here.

The $6,500,000 cash surplus in the State's budget for the fiscal year ending June 30, announced yesterday by Governor Lehman, was called today a paper balance, instead of a true profit, by Abbot L. Moffat, Republican delegate to the Constitutional Convention and chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

Chairman John D. M. Hamilton of the Republican National Committee forecast tonight that the party would "pick up in the neighborhood of 100 seats in the House in the November elections." He added,- in a speech delivered before 400 Pittsburgh Republicans, 'gathered to discuss finances for the campaign:

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer denied yesterday an application by Mrs. Geanne Hughes Bloomingdale Butler to restrain Surrogate James A. Foley from passing on litigation involving the estate of the late Irving I. Bloomingdale, vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers.
Sharp-shooting cadets from the Great English public schools invaded Bisley tonight, for tomorrow is their day on the program of the empire meeting of the National Rifle Association.

La Salle Street, where the morale of brokers was scraping bottom less than three weeks ago, is now carrying -an air of cheer, reflecting the increase in the volume of trading in securities of the last fortnight.

The United States Weather Bureau issued yesterday its weekly report of crop conditions, as follows: Abnormally low temperatures prevailed in the northeastern cotton belt, but elsewhere the warmth was normal.

The teachings of Confucius and bits of other oriental philosophy, inculcating a reverence for family and racial pride, were quoted to a joint legislative committee yesterday to explain the almost total absence of juvenile delinquency among Chinese youth.

Mrs. Elizabeth Suydam Moore of New York obtained a divorce today from James C. Moore Jr. on the grounds of cruelty. Mrs. Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lispenard Suydam of Bayport, L. I., was married secretly to Mr. Moore on Dec. 27, 1935, by a justice of the peace at Harrison, N.Y.

Forced to disqualify a man eligible for the Police Department because of the strict requirements of the Lyons Residence Law, Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, said yesterday that the law was cruel and unjust in its application to 300 similar cases.

Because Brazilian nationalism, "incited by North American agitation," is imposing restrictions on the cultural and political activities of foreign colonies, thousands of Germans, Italians and Poles are preparing to leave Brazil, according to an inspired article in the Berliner Tageblatt today.

In the second wholesale action of its kind taken here by a Federal grand jury, ten physicians, three attorneys, twenty-three insurance policy holders accused of submitting false claims for disability and three so-called chasers for an insurance racket ring were indicted yesterday for mail fraud and conspiracy.

Severin Winterscheidt, 34 years old, of 748 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, a lieutenant of Fritz Kuhn in the Nazi movement centering around the German-American Bund, who was convicted on June 27 in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, of endangering the morals of a minor, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate term in the New York County Penitentiary.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange adopted three amendments to the constitution yesterday. The first amendment permitted members and firms who also are members or associate members of a Canadian Exchange to charge the commissions ruling there for transactions performed in Canada.
The works of fifty-three artists, all of whom were represented in Nazi Germany's famous exhibition of "degenerate art," were put on review here today.
Harry Balsamo, Harlem, scored a quick knockout over Al Cocozza, Bronx middleweight, in the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Queensboro Arena last night before 3,000 fans.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

The Grayline Motor Tours, Inc., of New York, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to purchase the stock of the Royal .Blue Sightseeing Corporation, also of New York. The proposed price was stated as $100,000.

In view of the fact that various housing organizations and municipal authorities are preparing to ask the State Constitutional Convention to approve a plan for State loans and other forms of aid to 'cities and counties for slum clearance and low-rent housing, thE Works Progress Administration is making studies on housing progress and needs in this country and abroad.
Bonds continued to work irregularly higher yesterday in slightly heavier trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mrs. Louise Miller, 48 years old, of 572 Fortieth Street, Brooklyn, a widow, was held in $2,500 bail by Magistrate James E. Finegan in Bay Ridge Court yesterday morning, accused of accepting $1,000 in home relief, although she possessed bank accounts totaling $9,114.
A bystander who attempted to? pull a 13-year-old modern Lady Godiva off her white horse in a charity fete here today was knocked to the ground and beaten by an angry crowd.

117th St, 56 E; to 5-story tenement; Pearl Dantowitz, 1,690 Park Ave, owner; H. M. Rica, archiftect; cost, $8,000. 17th St, 510 E; to 5-story tenement; Matthew M. Green, premises, owner; R. Shutkind, architect; cost, $10,000.

A year ago today Japanese troops, engaged in night manoeuvres near Marco Polo Bridge, west of Peiping, alleged they had been fired on and launched an attack that has sent contending armies tramping over more than a third of China ever since.

Picksting today in front of the American Can Company's plant looked like a grown-ups' "kid" party. Dressed in children's clothes, the 150 pickets demonstrated in protest against hiring of high school boys and girls in strike-bound Northern California factories of the company.

Mr. and Mrs. Lomax Littlejohn of Babylon, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Isabelle Littlejohn, to Norman Hyde Robbins of Islip, L. I., son of Mrs. Edith Macarteny of Douglaston, L. I., and of Clarence H. Robbins Jr. of the French Riviera.

Stocks strengthened and closed higher after a lower opening; turnover 1,817,190 shares. Corporation and United States Government bonds higher, rail group strong, foreign -issues mixed, transactions $7,395,500.

The steel, cement, rubber and milk industries were among those mentioned as likely to be included in the first stages of the Administration's monopoly inquiry, at a meeting today of representatives of executive agencies who are to participate with members of the Senate and House on the Administration's joint monopoly committee.

Representatives of royalty and the French Government and famous figures of sports attended the funeral today of Suzanne Lenglen, former queen of the tennis world, who died Monday. She was buried in the Lenglen family plot in Saint-Ouen Cemetery.

Bids from 1,800 clothing manufacturers, all eager to self the WPA surplus stock for distribution among home relief families, will be opened at 10:30 A. M. today in the State offices of the procurement division of the United States Treasury, 76 Ninth Avenue. The Federal purchases are expected to total $10,000,000.

Trading on the East Side reported yesterday was featured by the sale of six uptown buildings to a single buyer. The structures at 1,324-Fifth Avenue, 1,378 Fifth Avenue, 1,407 Fifth Avenue, 1,453 Fifth Avenue, 1,704 Madison Avenue and 1,761 Madison Avenue; were sold by Nathan Robin and Pincus W. Rubin to the Delos Holding Corporation.

The labor conscription decree that Field Marshal Hermann Goering recently issued as commissioner for Germany's FourYear Plan will be applied primarily in the building and iron and -steel industries, according to Friedrich Syrup, president of the Reich Institute for Labor Placement and Unemployment Insurance, who is charged with executing that decree.
Sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $68,000 was reported yesterday. A deal was made the day before at the same price.
Following is the text of the address delivered by Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States delegation to the Intergovernmental Meeting on Political Refugees, at Evian, France, today:
One year- ago today Japan was forced against her will into a conflict with China. Every possible effort was made to localize the incident.

Complaining that the swing music of the Claremont Inn at 125th Street and Riverside Drive kept them awake far into the night, several tenants living- opposite this landmark urged the Police Department yesterday to come to their rescue.

Weather clear; track fast. They had a great day for it at Crosley Field. If the Cincinnati Reds should win the pennant, their American League rivals for the world series will burst out-crying. This is now the smallest park on the major league circuits.

The General American Investors Company, Inc., reports net assets of $26,943,246 on June 30, compared to $24,906,558 on Dec. 31, 1937, equivalent to $4,082.31 for each $1,000 of debentures, to $271.24 a share of preferred stock, and to $9.87 a common share. On Dec. 31 net assets were equal to $8.23 a common share.

Richard K. Mellon's Toolbox, a 6-year-old gelding, won the $2,500 added Vicmead Highweight Steeplechase Handicap at Delaware Park today. Asked to top nineteen jumps and run three miles, Toolbox was not out of a pull at any stage, finishing ten lengths ahead of Mrs. J. C. Brady's Crooning Water, the pair being coupled as the Trainer J. E. Ryan entry.

The Class I railroads of the United States had a net deficit of $139,796,871 in the first four months of the current year, in contrast with a net income of $19,214,427 in the same period in 1937, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today.
As a publicity stunt, Carole Lombard today took over the press department at Selznick-International and issued the following bulletin:

The price of lead was advanced 15 points yesterday. The new price set by the American Smelting and Refining Company at New York is 4.90 cents a pound and that of the St. Joseph Lead Company 4.95 cents at New York and 4.75 cents at St. Louis.

Both neat and glen checks and plain-colored Shetlands are the types of jackets preferred by the leading English golfers now competing in the British open golf tournament at Sandwich, England, according to a cable received yesterday by F. R. Tripler Co., men's wear store here, from Albert F. Free, president, who is attending leading European sports events to check on fashions.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday in Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, of George Max Gottfried, vice president in charge of sales of the Continental Baking Company. Intermittent illness had caused him to visit the hospital several times in recent months, but he was at his office here, 630 Fifth Avenue, on Wednesday of last week.

Gloomy and dark art thou, O chief of the mighty Ojibways! -And why shouldn't he be? He goes from his Sumner home to his Summer City Hall at the World's Fair grounds. The president of the Fair corporation is not there to meet and greet him who is to be one of its most famous exhibits.
Mrs. Oliver Harriman, wealthy New Yorker, began making detailed plans today for a New-Mexico lottery to raise $1,000,000 for the Carrie Tingley Crippled Children's Hospital at Hot Springs, N. M.

A former Nazi Storm Trooper, reputedly the son of a German baron, testified in Suffolk County Court today in the trial of six directors of Camp Siegfried at Yaphank, L. I., charged with violating the Stabe Civil Rights Law, that an oath of allegiance to Adolf Hitler, accompanied by the Nazi salute and a chant of "Heil Hitler," was a requisite to membership in the German-American, Volksbund.
Production of steel ingots in June totaled 1,638,277 gross tons, or about 9 per cent less than the 1,806,805 gross tons produced

Senator Joseph P. Guffey agreed tonight to disband the Philadelphia political organization with which he conducted the unsuccessful primary campaign locally on behalf of Lieutenant Governor Thomas Kennedy for the Democratic nomination for Governor and Mayor S. Davis Wilson for the Democratic senatorial nomination.

Puerto Rico is the bulwark of liberty and the outpost of the defense of Latin America against North American imperialism, according to Juan Juarbe, Puerto Rican orator, who addressed a large and enthusiastic audience at the National University here.

Rockingham Park, which for five years has been averaging about $60,000 from breakage, the odd sum over the dime in pari-mutuel payoffs, will pay off to the penny during its eighteen-day Summer meeting, says General Manager Lou Smith.
Secretary of State Hull sent a message of farewell today to Dr. E. Rudolf W. Holsti, Foreign Minister of Finland, who sailed on the Queen Mary after attending the Delaware Tercentenary celebration.

There ought to be in Washington a good deal of interest in an address delivered yesterday by the new Assistant Secretary of Commerce. Speaking before a group of business men in Chicago, Mr. Patterson asserted that "the mainspring of the American method is the free, competitive, private market";

A merger of the Mobile Ohio Railroad, a subsidiary of the Southern Railway, with the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad, which is controlled by the Chicago Burlington Quincy Railroad, was discussed yesterday by officials of the companies.

Although the stock markets here today continued active and firm, prices were affected somewhat by Wall Street's uncertainty yesterday. Gilt-edge issues were in good demand, but foreign bonds were mostly irregular.
Directors of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company called today a special shareholders' meeting for Aug. 30 to act on proposals designed to enable the company to go ahead with new financing.

The immediate problem of the great intergovernmental conference which' opened yesterday at Evian at the invitation of the United States is to find asylum for the political refugees forced out of Germany and Austria by the policies of the National Socialist regime.
BILL, based on the play, "Courage," by 'Tom Barry; screen play by Vincent Sherman and Robertson White; directed by John Farrow for Warner Brothers. At the Strand.

Seventy used automobiles, valued at $20,000, were. destroyed early today when a large frame structure, housing the William F. Hunn automobile, agency on Route 28, near South River, was swept by the fire.

Three veterans of the War Between the States, one a former Confederate who did not see the last reunion of the Blue and Gray he had traveled hundreds of miles to attend, died today as former comrades and foes neared their homes.
Dates and locations for first-day sales of five new postage stamp issues were announced today by Postmaster General Farley. The stamps and spa dates of issuance are as follows:

With the difficulties over one phase of the Spanish problem eased by adoption of the compromise plan for withdrawing foreign combatants, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and his government colleagues today turned their energies once more to the search for means of stopping InsureAnt bombing of British ships.
AGE OF CONSENT, by Norman Lindsay. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A yarn about random living on an Australian.beach.

The Rev. John Graham, retired minister of the Protestant Episcopal Church, died yesterday at his residence, 2,203 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn, of :heart disease, in his eighty-seventh year. At his retirement in 1918 he was first priest-incharge of All Saints Church, Richmond Hill, Queens.
Miss Mary King, daughter of Mrs. Mary King of Chicago and the late Dr. William King, was married here yesterday morning to Joseph Medill Patterson, president of The Daily News.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson announced yesterday the appointment of Walter H. Pollak as special master to take testimony on a formula for adjustment of claims of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company against each other.

Usually reliable source today reported that Daniel J. Doherty of Woburn, national commander of the American Legion, would be offered the post of first assistant attorney general of Massachusetts by Attorney General Paul A. Dever.

The National Labor Relations Board declared today that a Maryland shoe manufacturer violated the Wagner act by distributing among his employes copies of an anti-CIO speech by Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican of Michigan.

Bertram S. Rosenbaum of Ernst Co. and Morton I. Davis of Holmes Davis, accountants, were questioned yesterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation into the affairs of the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc.

One of the largest new apartment houses in its territory has just been completed at 45 Kew Gardens Road, near Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens, by the 45 Kew Gardens Road Corporation (Kobre Sons) from plans by M. E. Ungerleider, architect.

Leo H. Timmins, president of the Chromium Mining and Smelting Corporation, Ltd., announced today, following a meeting of directors, that a smelter will be prepared for early commercial production of a new material for the alloy steel industry at Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Wheat futures advanced rather sharply today after a steady opening. Strength in securities was regarded as mainly responsible for the upturn, although there was some buying which brokers attributed as removing hedges against sales of flour shorts became frightened when the market refused to break, and covered freely.

A number of large multi-family dwellings were among the buildings in-Brooklyn reported yesterday as having changed hands. Included was the structure known as the Astor Court Apartments at 501 Brightwater Court in the Brighton Beach section, which was purchased by the Darby Management Corporation from a client of Netter Netter, attorneys.

A 19-year-old Wellesley College student from Westfield, N. J., Miss Patricia Cumming, today scored a surprise 6-3, 6-8, 6-3 victory over the defending champion, Miss Alison Harrison of Philadelphia, in the Middle States women's tennis championships.

Aaron N. Golby died yesterday in his home here in his forty-second year. Born in Brooklyn, Mr. Golby was graduated in 1917 from Columbia University, where he was center for three years on the football team. He received a first lieutenant's commission during the World War.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan failed tonight to get a scheduled hanging of a Federal prisoner transferred somewhere beyond Michigan's boundaries. The government went ahead with preparations to execute Anthony Chebatoris, slayer and bank robber, at Milan, Friday morning.
The three-week Sokol festival ended today with a parade of more than 100,000 men and women before President Eduard Benes, who took their salute at the old Prague City Hall.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company in its statement of condition for June 30 reported total deposits of $879,094,424 and total assets of $981,186,129, compared, respectively, with $785,403,672 and $889,239,017 on March 31 last.

Richard Malcolm Montgomery Jr., an insurance man, formerly for thirty years associated with Lenssen Co. in Manhattan, died yesterday at his home, 186 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, in his fifty-ninth year.

Health conditions in the city reached new high standards during the first half of 1938, according to a report filed with Health Commissioner John L. Rice yesterday by. Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of. records.

The General Electric Company, through two investment affiliates, the Electrical Securities Corporation and the G. E. Employes Securities Corporation, held 187,100 shares of Otis Elevator Common stock at the end of last year, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange

A daughter was born in a hospital here today to Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt of New York. , The mother is the former Miss Lucille Parsons. Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt have lived in Honolulu for six months.

With a government acreage report due tomorrow and private estimates averaging under 27,000,000 acres or the smallest area planted to cotton in the United States since 1900, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced into new high ground yesterday.

Max L. Holtz, president of the Rochester Clothiers Exchange, announced today that more than 15,000 clothing workers would be back at their jobs within a week, absorbing and distributing a payroll of almost $500,000 weekly.

Business must look to government to remedy the defects in our business machinery if the "American system" of private enterprise is to be maintained, Richard C. Patterson Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce, told the Merchants and Manufacturers Club in the Merchandise Mart today. Mr.

The MacGregor Arctic Expedition has moved from its base camp on shore to the schooner General A. W. Greely, Every one is busy on board, getting the ship ready to start our homeward journey as soon as the ice permits.
A proposal that producers register the dates on which they expect to open their shows will be acted upon next Wednesday by the board of governors of the League of New York Theatres.
The Federal Trade Commission today an- c nounced promulgation of trade f practi e rules for the macaroni, noodles and related products industries.
The executive committee of the Chicago Stock Exchange has approved the following applications for listing securities: Acme Steel Company, 328,108 shares common stock, $25. par value;

Although burlap stocks in Calcutta reached a new peak at the end of last month, the fact that the increase over the previous month was not larger imparted a stronger tone to the market here, reports in the local trade indicated yesterday. Curtailment of mill operations in the primary markets is reflected to some extent in the stock showing, it was said.

Gross assets, $30,754; net, $29,142. To stepson, John J. Kiernan, executor, 25 shares in John F. Abernethy Co., Inc., one-fifth share in property at 708-10 Myrtle Ave., and one-eighth residue; son, John W. Abernethy, exectuor, 13 shares in John F. Abernethy Co., Inc., one-third share in property at 978 Bedford Ave.,
A young Negro boy who waded into the lake in Central Park near 106th Street after a ball was drowned yesterday despite the rescue efforts of fourteen patrolmen and a score of civilian volunteers.
Disregarding the inconveniences of his Summer City Hall in the City Building at the World's Fair grounds, Mayor La Guardia spent a good part of yesterday there doing routine work.
Spanish Insurgents drove against both ends of the fifty-mile Teruel-to-the-sea front today, reporting gains that were disputed by the government defenders.
En route to Freeport, L. I., from Atlantia City after tunas fishing, a party aboard the Empress -Ann elected to try their luck trolling. The only strike proved to be a good one.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that he had received a report from Joseph C. Grew, United States Ambassador in Tokyo, concerning his conversation yesterday with Foreign Minister Kazushige Ugaki and that it covered the chief range of relations between the two countries with special reference to Americar rights in China.
The Edward R. Parker Company has opened offices at 165 Broadway to act as a correspondent dealer for Clarence Hodson Co., Inc., and handle that firm's underwriting.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,058,550 barrels, compared with 3,081,550 in the previous week, a decline of 23,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Industrial financing for new money at record low interest rates will take place today with the issuance of $85,000,000 of debentures and serial notes of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

A bowed tendon today removed Lawrin, Herbert M. Woolf's Kentucky Derby champion, from action for an indefinite period-exactly a week after a similar injury struck Dauber, another of the turf's leading 3-year-olds.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of special teachers of music in day elementary schools, as of July 1, 1938, the names of the following applicants who have been granted licenses as special teachers of music in day elementary schools:

The Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association team defeated Connecticut in their annual team match at the Brooklawn Club today. The score was 10 to 5. Last year the Connecticut team won in a play-off after the teams had tied at 71/2--all/.

Percival Jackson, attorney for a minority group of bondholders, appeared yesterday before Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell and asked him to order that the names and addresses of bondholders of the Postal Telegraph and Cable':Corporation be made available so that a plan of reorganization formulated by that group could be placed before them.

" It is my conviction that the South presents right now the nation's No. 1 economic problem." So declares the President in a message to a conference of Southern spokesmen called by the director of the Administration's National Emergency Council.

In his budget message last January, Governor Lehman expressed the hope that "next June we shall see the end of the State's old accumulated deficit and that we will be able to start the new fiscal year 1939 with a clear slate."

Britain and Soviet Russia today signed a protocol bringing their naval agreement of July 30, 1936, into line with the new limit of 45,000 tons for battleships adopted by Britain, the United States and France.

The qulifying play is over, and the real contest in the British open golf championship began today in sunny, breeze weather, punctuated by heavy rain squails. There was a fierce and continuous attempt to break 70, but nobody quite succeeded.
The Public Works Administration received acceptance from the city yesterday on ten of the twentyeight projects for which grants have been made by the Federal agency.

The winner of the "Photographing Father" contest sponsored by Wallachs, the men's clothing company, was announced yesterday as Rudolph Boger of 3,111 Glenwood Road, Brooklyn, who will receive the $100 first prize.

A banking group headed by Paine, Webber Co. will offer today, by means of a prospectus, $10,000,000 of 10-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures, due July 1, 1948, of the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc. The debentures will be priced at 99 and accrued interest.

As President Roosevelt starts his swing to the West today, how popular will he find himself in the States throughy which he travels? Will the voters be as enthusiastically for him now as they were in 1936?

Dr. Arthur E. Morgan filed suit in Knox County Chancery Court today challenging the right of President Roosevelt to remove him as chairman of .the TVA and asking that he be recognized as a member and chairman of the board of directors of the agency.
Eight boys were killed early today when a firemen's brigade' during an exhibition fire drill' failed to rescue them from ablazing gasoline- soaked four - story wooden building.

Julius Heldman of the University of California at Los Angeles made his exit from the national intercollegiate tennis championship singles today as the South and East were shut out of the running at the Merion Cricket Club.
The Interstate Commerce Commission gave a hint as to the nature of the decision which it would issue in the coach rate case when it permitted an increase in Pullman tolls recently.

The Old Colony Railroad Company today requested the Interstate Commerce Commission to clarify a statement in a recent I. C. C. examiner's report which recommended that, "in view of the impracticability of formulating a different plan on the basis of the present record," no plan of reorganization for the New York, New Haven Hartford System be approved by the commission at the present time.

On his own application. To take effect 12 midnight, July 5: PATROLMAN- Edward M. Mutter, 13th Precinct, .at 51,500 per annum. Appointed April 24, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., July 7: LIEUTENANTS Assignment to desk duty continued. Joseph C. Workman, from 11th Division to 84th Precinct; John J. A. Fellingham, from 12th Division to Motorcycle 1.

Dr. Charles Ricketson Allen, known as "the father of vocational education in America," died here today at the age of 75. Dr. Allen was an instructor at St. Mary's University here and honorary life president of the Association of Vocational Teachers.

An appeal by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company against the order of the State Labor Relations Board requiring the company to bargain with the C. I. O. Industrial Insurance Agents Union was disclosed yesterday . in Supreme Court when a group of agents asked leave to intervene in the case.

Abraham Cahan, author, social and literary critic and editor of the Jewish Daily Forward, which he helped found more than forty years ago, will celebrate today another of the many birthdays of which he has lost track.

The sale of the late Mortimer L. Schiff's collection of fine bindings and rare engravings realized ?6,718 at Sotheby's today, making a two-day total of [Pound]12,405. The sale will be concluded tomorrow.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday. Tuesday. For the best names ....... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Corduroys Advanced 2 to 5 Cents The first advance this year on men's and women's corduroys was made yesterday by the Merrimack Manufacturing Company when it increased prices from 2 to 5 cents on its various ranges.

The playby-play description of the All-Star game at Crosley Field today follows: FIRST INNING AMERICAN-A cheer went up as Vander Meer burned over the first pitch for a called strike on Kreevich. On the next pitch Kreevich lifted a long fly to Ott in deep center field, almost to the fence.

A man and a woman, leaders in the $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy, were sentenced to State prison terms of three to six years yesterday by Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions. Five men convicted with them received pentientiary terms and four other men escaped with suspended sentences.

There will be baseball games between the Department of Finance and the Fire Department, on Thursday, July 7,. at 2 P. M., and between the Department of Education and the Fire Department, on Friday, July 8, at 2 P. M. Both games will be held at Parade Grounds, Parkside Ave., Parade Place and Conev Island Ave.. Brooklyn.

The Detroit Edison Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for an order declaring it to be not a subsidiary..of..the United Light and Power Company or the United Light and Railways Company.
The distribution of sixty-eight scholarships, made possible by the Charles Hayden Foundation, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University.
Fears were expressed today that the final death toll in the flood at Kobe might reach 1,000. It followed inundations last week in which more than 860 persons were killed, injured or missing.
Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and Crown Princess Louise of Sweden, accompanied by Prince Bertil and the royal suite, will be guests of honor at the concert in Lewisohn Stadium on July 19.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn Federal Court overruled yesterday an exception filed Tuesday by trustees of the Munson Steamship Line contending that the Federal Government had no legal right to foreclose a $769,500 mortgage on the Munson liner Western World as a preferred mortgage holder because the government is not a citizen of the United States.

A $400,000 first mortgage on the eight. story and penthouse apartment house un- I der erection on the northeast corner of Grand Concourse and 162d Street, the Bronx, bas been arranged for the Dillerwood Realty Company, Inc., Samuel Derfner, president, by Henry Waltemade, Inc., broker.

The fate of the proposal sponsored by District Attorney Henry Hirschberg, Republican, of Orange County to take out of the State Constitution the omnibus prohibition against gambling and lotteries remained in the balance today as the Constitutional Convention, sitting as a committee of the whole, opened debate on this proposed amendment prior to its advancement to third reading.

The Aster Flower Company has received permission to manufacture artificial flowers embodyingWorld's Fair themes. Alfred W. Lembke, salesman and assistant to the president of Koret, Inc., has resigned.

Philip A. Frear, a broker of Washington, D..C., son of former Representative James Frear of Wisconsin, surrendered yesterday at the office of Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney, on a recent indictment accusing him and five others of looting seven investment trusts of about $6,000,000 of assets.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, which in April denied an application by the Eastern railroads for an increase in passenger coach fares from 2 to 2.5 cents a mile, today reversed its findings and granted permission to make the increase for an eighteen-month "experimental" period.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, which is "going it alone" in the railroad wage conferences scheduled for Chicago on July 18, will "carry the fight" to the carriers by indicating that they have spent many millions of dollars on extrarailroad matters, according to Alexander F. Whitney, president of the brotherhood, who called on President Roosevelt today.
Spanish gold worth about $40,000,000 that wasposited' with the Bsnk of France as security 'for a loan to Spain before the civil war will stay in the bank's vaults for the, time being.

After having, been held by the same family since Its erection nearly a century ago, the three-story dwelling at 28 Bank Street has been sold by Harry B. Jennings to Thomas Langan for cash, through the Kersey Company, brokers.

The engagement of $500,000 gold in India for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank announced the arrival of $124,000 gold from India late on Tuesday and the reecipt at San Francisco of S69.000 sold from Australia.

Bidding for the twenty-five-story Heckscher Building at 728-34 Fifth Avenue, 3-9 West Fifty-sixth Street and 2-4 West Fifty-seventh Street, in the auction sale yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms was confined to one offer, made by the plaintiff, City Bank Farmers Trust Company, who bought the structure in for $4,250,000.
Extensive last-minute preparations are being rushed by the Peiping authorities for the celebration tomorrow of the first anniversary of the SinoJapanese war.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has extended from June 30 the time for acquisition by the Middle West Corporation of 10,000 shares of $6 cumulative preferred stock of its subsidiary, the Central Illinois Public Service Company.

A policeman was shot five times and critically wounded with his own service revolver in Harlem Hospital at about 7 o'clock last night as he was preventing the suicide of a violent prisoner who had run amok in a liquor store on upper Broadway after diving head first through the plate-glass window.

Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne i will leave the Ambassador today for Cody, Wyo., where they will pass a month on a ranch. Later they will go to Los Angeles and will sail for Honolulu on Aug. 5. They will return to the Ambassador after Labor Day.

Contracts for engineering construction awarded during the five weeks of June totaled $223,066,000, an average of $44,613,000 per week. This represented a drop of 35 per cent below the average for the four contract weeks of the same month last year, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Judge Edward Barry, for thirteen years a judge of the Eleventh Illinois Judicial Circuit, died in Brokaw Hospital here today. He was 75 years old. Mr. Barry was first elected circuit judge in 1920 at a special election to fill an unexpired term and was re-elected in 1921 and again in 1927.
Joseph W. Zorna or North pelham, New York advertising man for the last twenty-five years, died today at the age of 46 in the Mount Vernon Hospital after an illness of two weeks.

The Manhattan of the United States Lines, due today from the Channel ports, has on board Commander H. L. Vickery, U. S. N.; J. H. King, Professor and Mrs. Herbert Lee Seward, Frederick D. Herbert, Mr. and Mrs. William V. Sauter, Thomas L. Stanley, James A. Davies, Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Davis, Ernest Swift and Mrs. August Belmont.

A departure in the reapportionment of legislative districts in New York City reached the body of delegates to the Constitutional Convention today in a tentative report, not formally offered on the floor.

Park Ave (11-2900), w s, 275 ft n. of 175th St, 41x80; Franklin C. Sullivan to Paul Isben, 4,143 Park Ave. Wales Ave (10-2644), n w cor of Kelly St, 58x25; 45 West 87th Corp to Chasbro Properties, Inc. 203 W 58th St.

The New 'York Majestic Corporation, operator of the Majestic Apartments at Central Park West and Seventy-second Street, has deposited with the trustee for the bondholders a total of $88,538 for payment on interest on the 4 per cent non-cumulative income bonds, according to a report by Seligman, Lubetkin Co., Inc.

Frisco Dale, little chestnut flyer owned by Pearle S. Hungerford of Shelbyville, Ind., and driven by Homer Walton, streaked to victory in the $1,000 pacing stake, which featured the third day of Grand Circuit racing at the North Randall track today.

Fine points of football, baseball and other sports will be expounded by such teachers as Lou Little and Bill Terry in Columbia University classrooms during the annual Summer session that opened yesterday.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates July 6, unless specified: At Humpback Bay: Aylwin, Farragut. At Washington: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. At San Diego: Barry, Kanawha, Ranger. At San Pedro: Colorado, Lexington. At Dewey Anchorage: Dale, Monaghan. At Seattle: Hull, Phelps.

Another lively market sent prime fed steers up 25 cents to $12.25 today, the highest since last December. All grade -steers and yearlings shared this advance, tong yearlings reaching $11.90. Hogs scaling 250 pounds downward shared the steer advance, with best light at $9.60. The lamb trade was slow and weak, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

The Miyako Shimbun reports that more than ten leaders of the Soviet Far Eastern secret police have been executed on charges in connection with the flight of General G. S. Lushkoff to Manchukuo and Japan. General Lushkoff is utterly inaccessible to the press in. Tokyo.
Chinese terrorists marked the first anniversary of the Sino-Japanese hostilities today by launching a wave of violence that included assassinations and bombings.

WILLIAM GELLERMANN'S book on the American Legions has been widely denounced and disparaged during the past week or ten days. It happens to be, however, a perfectly conscientious and scholarly work by a professor at Northwestern University-conscientious to the point of dullness.
Two New York householders, each with one servant, have enrolled their domestics in the State unemployment insurance system, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.

Formal announcement of the sale to W. R. Davis Co. of New York of $10,000,000 worth of Mexican Government oil, intended largely for fascist markets, was made here today by W. F. Flanley, Davis representative.
Elaborate celebrations to mark the first anniversary of Sino-Japanese hostilities were started tonight with mass meetings and fireworks. Similar activities are planned for tomorrow.

Funeral services for Police Inspector Charles L. Neidig, who shot himself at his home, 70-25 Harrow Street, Forest Hills, Queens, after being transferred from the command of ~a vice squad in Manhattan to a Queens post, were held at the home last night.

State police dragged the waters of Lake Champlain today for the body of Maxwell Lippman, 25, of 2,707 Sedgwick Avenue, New York City, who drowned last night when the canoe in which he was paddling with his wife. Mollie, 21, overturned.

A grant of $585,000 from the Public Works Administration for construction of two school buildings here was rejected today by the City Council and the Board of Education because an additional $715,000 would have to be raised locally.

Mrs. Dean C. Osborne of Brooklyn and Camden, Me., who returned Tuesday from California, gave a dinner last night on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The party marked the birthday of Mrs. Osborne and two of her guests, Alfred Fawcett and William Elder Robertson.

Under a contract of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, Lewis M. Parsons became vice president in charge of sales for five years from March 1, 1938, to Feb. 28, 1943, according to data filed with the SEC and made public yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange.

Publication of "Whaling Masters" has been announced by Henry G. Alsberg, director of the WPA Federal Writers Project. This volume in the American Guide Series is a directory of whaling masters, with information concerning sailings from American ports.

In a three-cornered deal said to involve a consideration of $2,000,000 the Hotel Capitol, on the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, has been sold by Manhattan- and Bronx Councils, Inc., parent body of the Manhattan and Bronx Chapters of the Knights of Columbus, to the Dreier hotel interests, who took title in the name of Hotel Capitol, Inc.

Landon declared that the present depression was a "purely political" one and that it was brought on by the methods and policies of the Roosevelt Administration, in a radio address tonight replying to the President's recent fireside chat.
Jersey City made it two in a row over league-leading Newark before 10,321 at Roosevelt Stadium tonight. The score was. 6 to 5. Superb relief pitching by Glen Gabler enabled the Little Giants to win.

Japanese reported new gains today over Chinese armies defending the Yangtze River approach to Hankow, China's provisional capital. Japanese bombers ranging ahead of ground forces were said to have sunk a dozen Chinese troop-laden A junks near Kiukiang, 135 miles downstream from Hankow and immediate objective of the invaders.

When a main line railway intersects a main line highway something has to be done about it. The only safe thing to do is to carry the highway over or under the railway. So long as there are grade crossings, however well protected, a certain number of motorists will get themselves hurt or killed.

Sir John Snell, electrical engineer, who was largely responsible for the present national "grid" system of power distribution, died today at the age of 68. He retired in January from the chairmanship of the government's Electricity -Commission, which he had held since its establishment in 1920.
The text of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf's address at the Union Club yesterday follows: Gentlemen: I have been terribly sorry about not being able to take part in the tercentenary program so far.

A preliminary survey of postal receipts and expenditures for- the fiscal year closed last week showed 1938 postal earnings at the highest point in the country's history, Postmaster General Farley announced today.

United Gold Equities of Canada, Ltd., an investment trust, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 200,000 standard shares of $1 par value to be offered at the market for an estimated aggregate amount of $578,000.

In a day of activity aimed to clean up many executive tasks so to be free to begin preparation tomorrow of the first of a series of addresses to be made on his forthcoming tour, President Roosevelt conferred today with leading officers of the Administration, scheduling, in all,. sixteen appointments besides a Cabinet meeting.

With general advertising volume the showing a loss of about 15 per cent ha for the first six months of this year, both agencies and large companies yesterday expressed the opinion that the tide has finally turned and that the balance of 1937 will show smaller reductions.

Miss Joyce Watson Applegate, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Everitt Applegate of this place, has chosen Aug. 1 for her wedding to William Klaber Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Mlaber, also of Mont?clair.

Ten of the eleven properties sold at auction in the Bronx yesterday were bid in by the Home Owners Loan Corporation as plaintiff against various individuals. Eight were sold on nominal bids of $500. The details of the sales follow:

Miss Josephine Sanfilippo, who won the singles title in the metropolitan girls' tennis tournament at Jackson Heights yesterday, also annexed the doubles crown when she paired with Miss Virginia Wandelt to defeat Miss Dorothy Love and Miss Wanda Baker, 6-3, 6-1, in the final match which was moved to the Amackassin Club today.

Standing and special committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for 1938-39, appointed by former Secretary of State Henry L. Stimson, president of the association, were made public yesterday.

Before breaking camp on Gettysburg battlefield, Confederate veterans who fought there seventy-five years ago under General Longstreet, honored him today by the organization of the Longstreet Memorial Association.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read Howard G. Aron's letter, published in THE TIMES of July 3,with a great deal of interest, especially because the unusually wide scope of his experience makes his recommendations for a sound housing policy worthy of serious consideration at this time.

Playing grim, tight-lipped baseball behind three of their master moundsmen, Colonel Bill Terry's National League forces throttled the might and power of the American League today as they brought down Marse Joe McCarthy's troops in the sixth annual All-Star game, 4 to 1.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Corporation, discussing business conditions today, said that he was still optimistic but "not foolishly optimistic," and very hopeful that the worst of the business recession was over.

Joe Cox, 81-year-old "newsie" who for thirty years sold papers to Broadway's great and near-great at his stand on Forty-second Street near Times Square, was buried yesterday in Calvary Cemetery. Funeral services were held in St. Boniface Roman Catholic Church, Second Avenue and Forty-seventh Street.
Would it be a case of sturdy little Czechoslovakia finding successful imitators in far-off Indiana?

Mrs. Mary E. Solomon, first vice president of the Hebrew Convalescent Home in the Bronx, which she had aided for more than twenty years, died Tuesday at her residence, 845 West End Avenue. She was vice president of the Ohab Zedek Sisterhood and a director of the Ladies League of the Hebrew National Orphan Home.

It was officially announced here today that Richard C. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., set a new American glider record yesterday when he reached an altitude of 6,700 feet at the national soaring contests.

The Agawam Park stewards stepped into today's racing to upset calculations of those backing the P. S. P. Randolph entry of Choice Goods and wound up by naming Blandishment, owned by Mrs. E. A. Rotelli, the winner at the handsome price of $97 for $2 in the mutuels.
The War Department released the following orders today. dated July 2: MAJOR GENERAL Westover, O; Chief of Air Corps, four days' leave. July 5.

Bright blue and white umbrellas that looked like huge blossom dotted the smooth green lawns of Whitehall, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lee Pratt Jr. here, this afternoon as more than 250 persons attended' a garden luncheon for the benefit of the Children's Village of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

Charges that Japanese military authorities in China are attempting to take over American relief funds and prohibiting their administration by American missionaries were made public yesterday by the United Council for Civilian Relief in China on the anniversary of the outbreak of the Sino-fapanese hostilities.

The Federal Government has initiated an extensive program of research and experiment with the aid of regional laboratories throughout the country to increase the health of livestock and poultry and to minimize the dangers of illness to the population, Dr. John R. Mohler, chief of the Bureau of Animal Industry of the United States Department of Agriculture, yesterday told the seventy-fifth annual convention of the American Veterinary Medical Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A July resolution demanding protection for American markets against foreign goods and urging the United States to "buy American to keep American factories going" was adopted here today at the sixty-second annual convention of the American Flint Glass Workers Union. Sessions continue through Friday.

Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of the Department of Commerce, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with Mr. Roper for a thirty-day vacation in England and Scotland, where his wife's and his own families come from.

Frank White, 36-year-old former Harlan County Sheriff's deputy on trial with other ex-deputies, Harlan coal operators and mining companies on an anti-union conspiracy indictment, was shot to death tonight near Corbin; Ky., fourteen miles south of here.
The number of buyers attending the home furfishing show at the Furniture and Merchandise Marts has passed all previous marks for the first two days.

In one of the best games played in the Meadow Brook Club's twenty-goal tourney, J. C. (Cocie) Rathborne's Pelicans today defeated Gulf Stream by 8 to 7 to remain the only undefeated team in the Brook League.

After a year of costly fighting the Japanese Army occupies nine provincial capitals of China, has overrun all or parts of twelve provinces and controls all Chinese ports of any importance except Foochow, Swatow and Canton.

The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to grant a plea by New Jersey's Public Utility Commission to prohibit any increase in the present 20-cent railroad fare between Newark, N. J., and New York City.

Hungarian tennis players squared accounts with Don Budge and Gene Mako in exhibition matches today. C. Dallos won from Mako, 3-6, 6-2, 7-7, as the American quit to save his energies for the doubles in which he and Budge were beaten by O. Szigeti and E. Gabori, 6-4, 6-2. P. Asboth was conceded the victory over Budge after leading in singles. 6-1, 8-6, 3-0,
John Kimberly Beach, believed .to have been the only Connecticut lawyer elevated directly to the State Supreme Court, died today in New Haven Hospital after a week's illness at the age of 83.

In spite of an unforeseen expenditure of [Pound]350,000, the Commonwealth of Australia closed its financial year on June 30 with a surplus of [Pound]3,498,000. This is [Pound]70,000 less than the record in 1935-36.

Revived interest in pearls was shown at one of the most important London jewel sales of the past decade at Christie's today. A collection of the property of the late Mrs. Watney Weguelin, widow of Claude Watney, wealthy English brewer, brought a total of [Pound]47,986.

Warnings in several important retail quarters of the need of "keeping prices down" in order ,not to choke off consumer buying featured developments in the wholesale markets here yesterday, while the number of arriving buyers continued close to last year's figures and attendance at showings of Fall dress and sports wear lines was well maintained.

Mrs. Harriet West Brereton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Egbert W. West of this city, was married to James B. Dyer Jr. of Orlando; Fla., here today. The Rev. Dr. John Lyon Caughey, assisted by the Rev. Martin Keeler of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

Close-of-play scores in English first-class cricket games started today: Essex, 176 (Taylor 65, Rhodes five wickets for 25 runs); Derbyshire, 31 for three wickets; at Chesterfield. Glamorgan, 307 for nine (E. Davies 98, Dayson 54, Wooller 52 not out); vs. Kent; at Cardiff.

Colonel Harvey L. Miller, chairman of the National Boxing Association's championship rating committee, said today the group had no apologies to make for ranking Tony Galento as chief challenger to Joe Louis.

Charles N. Brady, co-founder and first president of the Hazel-Atlas Glass Company, died tonight in his home at the age of 89. He was injured in a fall at his home some time ago and pneumonia developed.

The nation is snapping out of the current business recession with the same rapidity that it entered the slump earlier in the year, James H. Rand Jr., president of the Remington-Rand Company, said today in an address before seventy members of the sales force of the General Shaver Corporation, at their convention here.
A number of one-family homes and several vacant plots which-will be improved with dwellings were involved in the Long Island realty transactions announced yesterday.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Bancamerica-Blair Corporation obtained yesterday three issues of bonds, aggregating $1,164,000, of Lake County, Ind.

ARENSBERG--Morris, in his ninety-third year, beloved husband of the late Hannah, devoted father of Pearl Kinsler and Claire Kurman. Funeral Friday July 8, 2 P. M., from Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave.
The merger of Russian ballet companies has been short-lived, and as a result of the split in the parent group, Universal Art Incorporated, Londoners will have the most varied season in years.

American ski stars, who came here last night from Valparaiso after their arrival on the Grace liner Santa Barbara, today prepared for their trip to the Farellones snow field for the Pan-American competition late this month.
The Federal Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Edgar Schenkman, will be heard in concert tonight at the Federal Music Theatre. John Dembeck, violinist, will be heard as soloist in the Chausson "Poeme."

The New York Steam Corporation, an affiliate of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will save approximately $450,000 in annual interest charges through the sale of $32,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds to refund 5 per cent and 6 per cent obligations; D. C. Johnson, president of the company, said yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.

Nestled deep in the rolling woodlands of the military reservation here, the new United States Bullion Depository was the scene of much activity today as the first shipment of the Federal hoard of silver arrived from New York City to be stored in the impregnable vault.

The marriage of Miss Anne Wallace Coppedge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Beauchamp Coppedge of East Orange, N. J., to Julian Shakespeare Carr 3d, son of Mrs. Clarke Howell of Atlanta, Ga., and the late Julian S. Carr 2d, took place here yesterday noon in the Church of the Transfiguration.
Fair buying activity and an increase in the number of retailers and jobbers visiting the market featured the second day of the annual Fall opening of floor coverings lines here yesterday.

With thousands of visitors in the city for the sixth All-Star baseball game today, downtown traffic, vehicular and pedestrian, was unusually heavy. But the Police Department handled the situation. admirably.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 2: COMMANDER Brown, 3. H., Jr., the Milwaukee, to Naval Training Station, Norfolk, Va., in Sep. tember. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Cook, H., orders of Feb. 11 revoked; to continue duty at Boston. Mass.

While a few of the "millions of people actually or potentially without a country" looked anxiously on, the refugee conference convoked by President Roosevelt opened here this sunny afternoon in the Hotel Royal rather more hopefully than had been expected.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf, assuming belatedly his scheduled role as central figure in the New Sweden Tercentenary, declared yesterday that sound trade relations promoted peace, backed a plea by Governor Lehman for the preservation of free speech as a prime current necessity, and asserted that equality of race, creed and color epitomized the "true spirit of America."

By SIDNEY SOLOMON West St, 355-56, 2 5-story tenements, 50x75; Bowery Savings Bank against Bromsen Holding Corp; due, $20,993; taxes, etc., $1,500; to plaintiff for $10,000. By RALPH W. LONG Ludlow St, 180, 4-story tenement, 24.8x 87.6; Citizens Savings Bank against Gold Bell Holding Corp; due, $20,061; to plaintiff for $1,000.

With the American League rout in the sixth AllStar game yesterday in Cincinnati the chief topic of discussion, a tired band of ten Yankee survivors of the game with the National Leaguers arrived here late this afternoon. The players are looking forward to the opening tomorrow of a three-game series against Joe Cronin's Red Sox.

Price reductions of 2 to 20 per cent under last Fall's list were made known yesterday at various showings of Fall lines of women's knit underwear. All rayon styles registered the sharpest drop, with silk ranges virtually unchanged.

Using a novel trap for catching piercing cosmic rays, Dr. Carl D. Anderson, Nobel Prize winner, and his colleague, Dr. Seth Neddermeyer, have obtained a photograph which, it is expected, will some day be historic to science.

Many a prized pet dog or valuable race horse in the city gets much better medical care than thousands of human beings, Dr.. Morris Fish bein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, last night told the seventy-fifth annual dinner of the American Veterinary Medical Association at the Hotel Pennvsylvania.

Bayonne Building Association No. 2 sold to the Broadway Company the two sixteen-family flats at 16062 Avenue C, Bayonne, N. J.; also the four-story, nineteen-family flat on the northwest corner of the Boulevard and West Forty-eighth Street, Bayonne.

Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., has elected the following directors for the coming year: Edward J. Aisenbrey, Douglas Gibbons, E. Roland Harriman, Byron A. Long, Thomas S. McLane, G. MacCulloch Miller, James S. Regan, Louis E. Stoddard and William H. Vanderbilt.
Heavy rain today provided a gloomy outlook for the opening of the third cricket test match between Australia and England at Old Trafford tomorrow.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to borrow $6,000,000 additional from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The road already is indebted to the RFC in the amount of $87,685,578, according to the application.

George T. Janicula, secretary and few pu treasurer of Strong, Hewat Co., Inc., manufacturers of domestic novelty woolen goods of 51 Madison Avenue, died on Wednesday at his home in Huntington, L. I., after an illness of two months. He was 45 years old.

A sharp spurt in buying activity yesterday brought about price advances in various types of cotton goods, all-wool flannels, hides and leather and laid the foundation for prospective advances in women's woolen fabrics.

Constant attention to staples and good running numbers, the "stepchildren" of the accessories departments, is the secret of successful merchandising of accessories, Mrs. Claire Lang, fashion director of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the accessories division of the Fashion Group, Inc.,
Dauber, ailing winner of the Preakness, was reported sold for $40,000 today while his arch rival, Lawrin, first in the Kentucky Derby, joined him on the shelf.

Officers of the treasure-seeking ship Falco, returning to port today, said that they had found the Ward Line steamship Merida which sank off the Virginia Capes in 1911 with a large consignment of silver. Two anchors lost in a previous salvage expedition were retrieved by the Italian vessel.

Don Christmas's speedy Accolade captured the American Legion Day Purse, six furlong allowance feature of today's program at Suffolk Downs by two lengths over E. R. Bradley's Billionaire to pay the short price of $3.40 for a $2 mutuel ticket.

An inspector's funeral, the last high honor within the power of the Police Department, was held yesterday for Inspector Charles L. Neidig, who shot and killed himself in the garden of his home at 70-23 Harrow Street, Forest Hills, Queens, last Monday.

Mrs. Helyn Rolston Wilson, widow of William Andrews Wilson, former assistant secretary of the Farmers Loan and Trust Company, died yesterday at 518 Main Street, the home of her daughter, Mrs. Kent Sanger, at the age of 54. Born in New York,

Commenting on the changes during the last ten years in black bass fishing conditions, a veteran Westchester angler, "M. R.," reflects a bit on the "vanishing species" following his trip on opening day.

Her husband's charge that she had put insecticide in two meat sandwiches which she prepared for him resulted in the arrest on a felonious assault charge yesterday of Mrs. Hilda Hammarstrom, 37 years old, of 526 Forty-fourth Street, Brooklyn. She was held in $25,000 bail by Magistrate Matthew J. Troy of Brooklyn Felony Court for a hearing on Tuesday.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. McFadden of Houston, Texas, returned from Europe on the Ile de France and are at the Ritz-Carlton, where they were joined by Mr. and Mrs. Jules J. -Vatable, who are spending the Summer in Islip, L. I. Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Codman of Boston are at the St. Regis.

B. W. Railey was elected yesterday as a vice president and director of the Colgate-Palmotive-Peet Company, following the monthly meeting of the board of directors. He will be responsible for the company's soap business west of the Mississippi.

Mrs. Anna M. Kirtland Hawkesworth, a descendant of early settlers of New Jersey and formerly. a leader in planning entertainments for members of New York, Newport and Philadelphia society, died on Wednesday at her home, 27 East Sixty-second Street, after a six months' illness. Her age was 71.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Alden R. Hoover of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret E. Hoover, to James Stanley Brooks of Ithaca, N. Y., son of Mrs. Fanny Brooks of Bloomington, Ind., and the late Samuel Brooks.

Z. E. Merrill, president and director of Mountain States Power Company, a subsidiary of Standard Gas and Electric, and a preferred stockholders' committee have jointly filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application under the Public Utility Holding Company Act for approval of a plan of reorganization for Mountain States Power.

LIEUTENANTS James B. Leggett, from 104th Precinct to 18th Division, assignment to desk duty discontinued William C. J. Strutzenberg Jr., from 15th Division to 104th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued. SERGEANTS George B. Wilson, from 75th Precinct to Motor Cycle Precinct 2, assigned to motor cycle duty.

Miss Marie Oaks Hotchkiss, daughter of the late Henry Oaks Hotchkiss, a New Haven importer for decades before his death in 1883, died today at her Summer home, Stony Croft, East River, at the age of 88.

Counsel for a protective committee of New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company minority stockholders requested the Public Service Commission yesterday to deny the application of the company, now pending before the commission, for authority to issue 8,772 additional shares of $5. preferred stock. J. H. Schmid,
Senator Borah, 73-year-old dean of the Senate, was in bed today under a physician's orders that he rest after a breakdown because of overwork.

Sweden has found the solution of the monopoly question in the downward price pressure of the cooperatives in that country, Albin Johannson, president of Kooperativa Forbundet, the Cooperative Union and Wholesale of Sweden, said in an interview here yesterday.

Convictions for murder first degree, found against Andrew J. Lunse and Richard Delaney for the killing of Frank C. Zaccor, a New York City policeman, and Thomas Kerwin, during a robbery, were upheld today by the Court of Appeals. The court divided five to two in reaching a decision.

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house, a plot 150 by 120 feet at the southwest corner of Sheridan Avenue and 163d Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Forty-ninth Realty Corporation, Louis Lipman, president.

It will be the East against the Southwest and Far West in tomorrow's semi-finals of the women's Middle States tennis championships at the Philadelphia Cricket Club. Two Philadelphia were among those eliminated in today's quarter-finals.

The increase in passenger fares on Eastern rail systems was the signal for a spirited advance yesterday in railroad bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Gains of 1 to 4 points were made in a broad list of rail issues, while a few selected loans rose 5 to 8 points.

The marriage of Miss Lillian Irene Sheridan, daughter of Mrs. M. Hynes Sheridan of 226 East Seventieth Street, to Henri Julius Braiteau, son of Albert Braiteau, also of New York, took place yesterday morning in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer,

Thousands of Alpinists who in the last seventy years ascended Matterhorn, 14,780 feet, under the impression they had really set foot on the very top of the mountain conquered by Edward Whymper, are wrong. Since 1868 the top of Matterhorn has been in Geneva, where recently a local alpinist bought it for 5 1/2 francs at a sale.

While they purchased a wide variety of items during the week, dry goods jobbers held their orders to. a conservative basis, not buying any goods beyond September, they reported here yesterday. Although prices are advancing, they said they would rather wait and pay a few cents more later in the season than load up with goods now and be caught with heavy stocks if the expected rise in retail trade does not materialize.

For the third time in the past seven years King's College School of Wimbledon captured the Ashburton Challenge Shield, today's feature at the National Rifle Association's empire marksmanship meeting for English public schools.
