Al McCoy of Boston, the National Boxing Association's eighth ranking heavyweight, knocked out Jack Kranz, the Gary (Ind.) fighter who once went the. distance with. Joe Louis, in the second round of a ten-rounder tonight. McCoy weighed 182, Kranz 189 1/2.

Investors were active yesterday in the purchase of houses in scattered sections of Manhattan. William Orlan bought for investment from the Walsher Realty Company the five-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 150 feet at 164 Sherman Avenue.

Awarding a $35,900,000 contract For for the Shasta Dam, in the Central Valley of California, accounted for nearly half of the $78,322,000 total of engineering contract lettings re- DWE ported in the current week, according to The Engineering News Record.

Funeral services for Edward L. Hurley, sports columnist .and turf editor of The Daily Record, who died Monday, at the age of 49, were held today at St. Clement's Church with a solemn high mass of requiem celebrated by the Rev. J. Scollan, pastor.
Four former associates of Samuel Insull who were made defendants in a suit for accounting filed against the directors of the bankrupt Insull Utility Investments,

Storekeeper (deck), $1,182 a year; storekeeper (engine), $1,242 a year; storekeeper (steward's department), $1,392 a year; Army Transport service, War Department, Brooklyn, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the manager, Second United States Civil Service District, Federal Building, Christopher St., New York, N. Y., not later than Aug. 8. Applicants will be rated on a written examination on a scale of 100.

SOUTHERN' DISTICT Petitions Filed-By MAURICE EPSTEIN, clerk. 1,954 Croton. Parkway.-Llabllitles $3,554, no assets. GEORGE A. FERGUSON, train dispatcher, 129 W. 12th St.-Liabflltles $958. no assets except a patent and Insurance policies. JOHN NICHOLAS GESCHWINDER, dry dry goods, Pine Bush, N. Y.-LlablUtlee $2.756, assets $1,076.

Harpers announces that Andre Maurois, who was elected recently to the French Academy, has completed his fifth biography, "Chateaubriand," which is scheduled for publication in November. This is his first full-length biography since "Disraeli."

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt returned this afternoon on the Bermuda Clipper from their wedding trip in Bermuda and were driven to Cedar Knoll, the home of Mr. Vanderbilt's mother, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, where their wedding took place on June 8. Mrs. Vanderbilt is the former Miss Manuela Hudson, daughter of George Hudson of San Francisco.

Large plots of vacant land in Forest Hills and Long Island City figured in two of the realty deals in Queens announced yesterday. Cord Meyer Corporation has sold to the Atom Place Realty Corporation the southwest corner of Seventy-fifth Avenue and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, fronting 100 feet on the boulevard and 170 feet on the street.

John J. Beery, First Deputy Police Commissioner, reserved decision at police headquarters yesterday afternoon in the trial of Lieutenant Arthur Dallas, accused of unnecessarily causing the arrest of Mrs. Ethel Tarvanovich of 227 East 121st Street, after Mrs. Tarvanovich had turned in a loaded revolver she had found to the East 126th Street police station.

Anthony Eden today again attacked, though again without naming names, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of rapprochement with Germany and Italy-the policy that caused him to resign as Foreign Secretary.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City dropped $58,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday,. according to the condition statement of the banks, issued yesterday.

State police and game wardens started today on a bear hunt between this city and Albany, an area with a population of about 226,000. Their quarry was a black bear that has been reported variously in the last three days as staring at an electric eye" traffic counter near Schenectady;
Time was when the week covering the end of June and the Fourth of July holiday brought with it a heavy drain upon bank reserves and, usually, the firmest money conditions of the year.
Miss Kay Krebs of the Bronx, N. Y., perished today in a shallow pool and quicksand here in a vain effort to save the lives of two children.

Some interesting Incidents in the early history of Southfield Point and the neighboring territory at Stamford, Conn., are brought to mind by the announcement of an auction sale of properties on that point on July 16.
Lester Hinckle pitched and batted Tremont of the semi-pro Lebanon Valley League to a 2-to-1 victory over the Phillies today.

Samuel Seabury, arguing on behalf of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in an appeal be fore Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer against a State Labor Relations Board order, declared yesterday that the State Labor Relations Act conferred upon the board "despotic power" over employers and employes and that it introduced here the "essential principle" of the Soviet system.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 6: BRIGADIER GENERAL Marshall. G. C., General Staff Corps, office of the Chief of Staff, to duty as Assistant Chief of Staff, War Plans Division, Washington, D. C.

The royal Swedish delegation that is ardriving here tomorrow afternoon as guests of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville aboard their yacht HiEsmaro will be headed by Prince Bertil, son of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf. The latter, because of his health, and the Crown Princess Louise will not visit this city.

The flight for which Howard Hughes is preparing, to Paris nonstop and very likely thence on around the world, is by no means just another ocean crossing, involving undue risk in order to demonstrate what already has been fully proved, that overloaded land planes can fly the North Atlantic.

Benjamin Schwartz, founder of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel ten years ago and director general of the organization since its inception, has requested the board of the institute to release him from his contract as executive head, to permit him to devote all of his time to the practice of law, industrial and public relations work.

ON the way back from the All-Star game in Cincinnati, Joe Cronin and Jimmy Foxx were discussing what had happened, and why. They made some odd comments. For instance, Double-X Foxx didn't think that the National League pitching was up to standard.

Another in the Treasury's current issues of $100,000,000 of weekly bills was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau. The ninety-two-day bills will be dated July 13 and mature on Oct. 13. Bids will be received by Federal Reserve Banks and their Branches up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Monday.

Johnny Kerr of the University of North Carolina, assistant stage manager for the neighboring Westchester playhouse, mismanaged a two-foot putt in the final round of the Westchester junior golf championship at Lawrence Farms today and lost to Ray Korndorfer of Williams, 1 up, on the twentythird hole.

Chinese imports for the first five months of 1938 declined 23 per cent under the corresponding period of 1937, and exports declined 37 per cent, the Commerce Department was informed today by its commercial attache at Shanghai. However, May imports increased 11 per cent over April, and exports rose 1 per cent in the same period.

The populace of China's de facto capital joined in striking displays of mass fervor yesterday and the observances marking the anniversary of the outbreak of the war with Japan were not marred by a Japanese air attack, although one had been expected.

Former Senator David H. Agans of Three Bridges, Master of the New Jersey Grange, was elected chairman of the New Jersey Council. at the annual meeting here today. He succeeds George C. Warren Jr; of Summit, president of the, State Fish and Game Commission.

FINK, THERESA (Jan. 30, 1938). Gross assets, $7,142; net, $5,030. To daughter, Anna H. Fink. Chief assets, real estate, $2,994; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $3,847; miscellaneous property, $300, Harold C. Knapp, attorney, 225 Broadway, Manhattan.

In a welcoming address to the 1,632 candidates attending the Citizens Military Training Camp here, Colonel Thomas L. Crystal, commanding officer of the Twenty-sixth Infantry, declared that "our country needs good citizenship" and that "the primary purpose of the C. M. T. C." was to promote this.

After a day devoted to filling a number of important Federal posts and to some political discussion, President Roosevelt left Washington on his special train late tonight and headed West on a transcontinental tour that will take him through several States where there are bitterly contested primary elections in which New Deal prestige is at stake.

France, although arming for a war she fears may come with Nazi Germany, has made an agreement to sell Germany annually 7,200,000 tons of Lorraine iron ore, some of which may be used in the manufacture of war supplies.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended July 6 were announced today: Munter, Capt. W. H., Headquarters, to duty as commander of the Seattle Division. Sept. 1. McMillan, Capt. C. C., San Francisco Division. to retirement, Aug. 1.

George Brodie, 24 years old, of 2,847 West Thirty-first Street, Brooklyn, a stamp collector, pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn to a charge of mailing letters bearing canceled postage stamps to obtain a double cancellation mark, which increased the value of the stamps as philatelic rarities.

The battle of pushcart operators in New York City t compel William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, to renew their licenses to oprate carts on certain city streets ended today when the Court of Appeals affirmed the decision of the lower courts that had refused to compel this action.

Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, announced yesterday the signing of a new agreement between the American Viscose Company, employing 20,000 workers, and the union with no reduction in wages.

The New Jersey Supreme Court today ruled that municipalities cannot legally regulate solicitors whose orders for the sale of goods come from outside the State. The court held that "the State and its instrumentalities may not burden interstaate commerce by taxation."

THE ANTS' NEST, by Muriel Daly. (Appleton-Century, $2.) A novel with an Italian Riviera background. EXECUTIVE SALARIES AND BONUS PLANS, by John C. Baker. (McGraw-Hill, $3.50.) A study based on data made available by the Federal Trade Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The 705 members of the investment Bankers Association of America, Inc., composed of most of the nation's leading investment bankers, were urged today by the board of directors to give their support to the organization of associations to be set up under the Maloney act for the regulation of the over-the-counter securities business.

For the first time since the Constitutional Convention began, reapportionment came up as a topic of debate today. The response was immediate. Democrats were arrayed against Republicans on partisan lines, the Republicans accusing Democratic speakers of playing politics on the floor, and the Democrats accusing the Republicans of bad faith in the carrying out of Senate and Assembly districts.

Colonel A. Pearson Hoover was named president and chief executive officer of the new Real Estate Taxpayers Federation at a meeting of the board of directors of the organization yesterday, and Herbert L. Carpenter of Brooklyn was named chairman.

The following marine corps changes for the week ended July 7 were announced today: MAJORS Richards, W. P., Los Angeles, Calif., to marine corps base, San Diego, Calif. Whaling, W. J., Philadelphia, Pa., to Quantico, Va. Schubert, R. H., Navy Yard, New York. N. Y., to Quantico, Va.

Electric power production eased last week, countering the normal seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index declined to 90.0 from 91.2. For the week ended July 3, 1937, the index was 105.3.
Captain Severo Fournier, who recently sought protection in the Italian Legation, left there today and surrendered to military authorities. He was interned at Leme Fort.

The committee on suffrage refused to report out today, and thus killed, the antiradical proposals submitted to the Constitutional Convention by Hamilton Fish, Joseph D. Nunan Jr. and Mason F. Sexton, which aimed to deprive persons advocating in any way the overthrow of our present form of government, of the right of suffrage.

In proceedings made dramatic by a witness's demonstration of the "Hitler salute," leaders and members of the German-American Volksbund denied today in Suffolk County Court that an oath of allegiance to Adolf Hitler, or any secret oath, is required of Bund members.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday a net asset value of $30.72 a share on 2,081,580 capital shares on June 30, compared with $24.92 a share on March 31 and $40.18 a share on June 30, 1937, which was after a deduction of $1.61 a share for taxes and management compensation on unrealized appreciation as of that date.

Turpentine firm, 22 3/4c; sales 7 barrels; receipts 1,416 barrels; no shipments; stocks 37,824 barrels. Resin firm; sales 369; receipts 3,183; shipments 200; stock 162,326. Quote: B, $3.40; D, $3.65; E. $4.00; F, $4.45; G, H, I, K, M, $4.95; N, $5.50; WG, $6.00; WW, X, $6.40.

Secretary'Ickes stepped into Oklahoma's political affairs today long enough to defend Senator Thomas, a candidate for re-election facing strong opposition in the State's primaries, against charges that he was involved in irregularities in the administration of Indian affairs.

When General Rufus Putnam and his forty-six New England pioneers floated down the Monongahela and the Ohio to its confluence with the Muskingum, a hundred and fifty years ago, the land beyond the river banks was almost as much a wilderness as the upper reaches of the Amazon today.

Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet of France had delivered in Rome today a firmly worded note of protest to the Italian Government against an incident that occurred on the ItalianFrench frontier Monday, when Italian frontier guards shot at two French excursionists, wounding one severely.

James E. McConnell, Boston and Brookline attorney, former first vice president of the Chamber of Commerce and at one time Supreme Judge Advocate of the Knights of Columbus, died this morning at his home after a long illness at the age of 72.

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on July 2, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 77.9, compared with 78.2 on June 25 and 87.2 on July 3, 1937.
Dr. Walter H. W. Marseille, who says he invented the new five-suit bridge game, arrived yesterday from Vienna on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to promote the new system in this country.
Three important orders affecting the natural gas industry were issued today by the Federal Power Commission as it put into effect the administration of the Natural Gas Act approved on June 21.

Ludlow St, 180, George Popkin, referee, to Citizens Savings Bank; foreclosure ($1). Madison St, 183, Congregation Dorshe Tove Anshe Pinsk to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; mtg, $12.750, held by grantee ($13.50).

After dangling for several minutes from the sixth floor window of the Hotel Belmont Plaza, Lexington Avenue between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, while a male friend held her by the wrists, Miss Muriel Strohm, 24 years old, of 229 West Ninety-seventh Street, was saved early this morning from almost certain death by firemen who caught her in a life net after hearing cries for help.
A police inquiry was started today into the death here of Mrs. Maybelle Horlick Sidley of Chicago, 51-year-old heiress to the Horlick malted milk fortune.

Leaders of the American Labor party, it was learned yesterday, are holding a series of conferences on candidates for Representatives, State Senators and Assemblymen with a view in certain cases to obtaining a coalition with Republicans and Democrats.

GENERAL CONDITIONS-Trading was fair to good. Traefer meats were strongto higher, and kosher steady to weakly Thursday being an off-kosher day, business in this type of meat was light and prices were steady to weak. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:
The City Commission here enacted today an ordinance by which the city sells its municipal broadcasting station, WPG, to Arde Bulova, watch manufacturer, for $275,000.

Catherine McNells, who came from Wilkes-Barre, Pa., in 1927 and worked her way up in the advertising field in New York, who until three years ago was rated one of the ten most successful business women in the United States, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of mail fraud.

The report of the American Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $5,215,466. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.59 a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $5,995,567, or $1.88 a common share, in the twelve months to May 31, 1937.

Twenty-four strikers and strike sympathizers broke open a locked door, entered the plant of the Sagamore Metal Goods- Corporation on the second floor of a four-story loft at 43-01 Twenty-second Street, Long Island City, Queens, at 5:30 o'clock last night and barricaded themselves behind the fire-proof steel doors in an effort, they said, to prevent the cencern from moving to Middletown, N. J.

The bid of Eastern Air Lines to carry mail free over a new route in Texas was held legal today by the Solicitor of the Postoffice Department over the protest of Braniff Airways, Inc., the next lowest bidder.

Charles True Adams, trustee for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, which is in reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, advocated today before the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan designed to save the corporation from liquidation.
Directors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange voted today to keep open the market for butter, eggs, cheese, potatoes and hides on Saturdays in the remainder of July and through August and September.

The only dance performance scheduled for the Summer at the Lewisohn Stadium took place last night and attracted the largest audience of the season thus far, estimated at about 12,000. The program, presented in cooperation with Dance International, consisted nominally of folk dances and music of various ethnic groups.

Special Order 127, dated July 5, pertaining to Fireman Second Grade Peter A. McNally, H. and L. Co. 40, being granted a leave of absence, with pay, for fifteen days, from July 10, is corrected to read: "Fireman Second Grade Peter A. MeNutty (2), H. and L. Co. 40."

Known deaths in the flood which surged through Kobe yesterday were placed at 311 tonight by police. In addition, 1,200 persons were injured and more than 400 were missing. Police estimated the damage at 100,000,000 yen.

A, bill to, standardize the weights of grocery items will be presented to the City Council in the near future for the Department of Markets. It provides that packaged staple goods be sold only in one quarter, one-half, three-quarter and one-pound packages and multiples thereof.

Japan is shipping another consignment of $5,800,000 gold to this country, according to word received yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This will make a total of $317,500,000 gold which Japan has sent here since March 8, 1937. Of the total $72,200,000 has been shipped since Feb. 24.

The body of Ben Leider, 'the first American aviator to fight for Loyalist Spain, who was shot down in combat on the Jarama front in February, 1937, was brought to Valencia today for shipment to New York.

Production of gold and silver in the United States last year approached record totals. Figures for 1937 announced to-day by the Mint showed production of 4,804,540 ounces of gold, which was within 83,000 ounces of the record set in 1915.
Takihiro Wakabashi, representative in Latin America of the Japanese Exporters and Importers Association, arrived by airplane from Panama yesterday.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and representatives of certain of its security holders filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission briefs which took exception to the recent recommendation of Harvey H. Wilkinson, examiner, that no plan of reorganization for the railroad be approved now.

While Prince Bertil was observing various phases of American aviation, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden concentrated yesterday on Etruscan and Oriental antiquities at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

As President Roosevelt prepares to enter Kentucky in the interest of Senator Alben W. Barkley, who faces a fight in the Senatorial primary,, a special survey finds Barkley leading his opponent, A. B. (Happy) Chandler, two to one.

Smiling, the President put the question by, and told to inquirer to ask an astrologer. Accepted as facetious, this was a wise answer. The question was political. In the speech and the methods of politicians there are strong traces of astrology and magic. Medieval astrology has left its marks on the language.

Wheat, today made a firm start and a tame finish, with fluctuations largely a reflection of the trend in securities. Highest prices were made at the opening, with an advance of about 1/2 cent a bushel on scattered buying, but houses with Eastern and Southwestern connections were persistent sellers.

Negotiations continued throughout the day today for the settlement of labor difficulties at the El Teniente mines near Rancagua, which belong to the Braden Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Kennecott Copper Corporation. The dismissal of a number of employes at the mines on grounds of economy led to the declaration of a general strike there last midnight.
Saratoga racing officials aren't going to try too hard to get War Admiral and Seabiscuit on the same race track at the same lime this Summer. But they may lo it anyway.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that United States Steel Corporation common stock, $100 par value, had been stricken from its list. This security was suspended from dealings on April 6 when the par value was changed to no par.

Plans of the Board of Education to air-condition the new Central Needle Trades High School, now under construction, have been vetoed by the Board of Estimate, it was disclosed yesterday. The school, to cost about $4,500,000, was the only one for which air-conditioning had been specified.

Transportation experts and officials of the six municipalities in North Hudson County affected by the proposed increase in passenger rates on the West Shore ferry lines presented testimony yesterday opposing the increase at a hearing held at the Hotel New Yorker by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

After an early rise in prices of cotton which carried quotations into new high ground again yesterday, the market encountered extensive profit-taking in advance of this morning's official acreage estimate and the list on the Cotton Exchange ended the day with losses of 12 to 13 points.

Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Britain, denied today at a press conference that his visit to Ireland had any political significhance. He met reporters at the United States Legation in Phoenix Park.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order revoking the registration of F. T. Cannon Co., Inc., 40 Exchange Race, New York, as broker and dealer in over-thecounter markets.

Mrs. Amy.Banta Blake of 186 Underhill Avenue, Brooklyn, a member of an old colonial family, died yesterday. She was born in Binghamton, N. Y., and had lived at the Underhill Avenue address for more than forty years.

ARENSBERG-Morris, in his ninety-third year, beloved husband of the late Hannah, devoted father of Pearl Kinsler and Claire Kurman. Funeral Friday, July 8, 2 P. M. from Park West Memorial Chapel. 79th St. and Columbus Ave. ARNOTT-On Wednesday, July 6, 1938, at his residence, Hempstead. N.Y.,

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it had declared the regular quarterly dividends on its three classes of preferred stocks. The dividends, aggregating $1,627,175, are to come out of net earnings since Jan. 1, 1938, and are payable on Aug. 15 to holders of record of July 20.

Dr. Robert James Manion of Fort William, Minister of Railways in R. B. Bennett's last Cabinet, was elected leader of the Canadian Conservative party today to succeed Mr. Bennett, who has retired because of ill health.
The Iowa City Press-Citizen today quoted Hal Trosky, Cleveland's hard-hitting first baseman, as saying he was "glad the American League got beat" in yesterday's AllStar baseball game at Cincinnati.

A temporary solution of the difficulties confronting Mrs. Sadie L. Monssen, widow of Lieutenant Mons Monssen, United States Navy hero for whom a destroyer is to be named, concerning foreclosure proceedings brought by the Home Owners Loan Corporation against her home at 1,756 West Tenth Street, Brooklyn, was reached yesterday at a conference before Justice Algeron I. Nova in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

The first ground to be broken in the projected $800,000,000 slum-clearance program undertaken by the United States Housing Authority will be turned on July 18 by Nathan Straus, administrator, at Red Hook, in Brooklyn.

Immediately after the death of Patrolman Harry J. Padian early yesterday morning three investigations were begun into the circumstances surrounding the shooting of the policeman in a ward of Harlem Hospital by an apparently crazed prisoner he was guarding.
Tribute was paid the memory of Knute K. Rockne, Notre Dame football coach, at cornerstone-laying exercises today for the uniyersity's $600,000 Rockne Memorial Fieldhouse.

Hearing the scream of an 11-yearold girl who was wading in the Bronx River yesterday, Mounted Policeman Joseph Kennedy rescued two twin sisters, 2 years old, who had strayed into the river apparently with the intention of reaching their older sister.

The Cleveland Baseball Club disclosed today that the 1938 contract of Johnny Humphries, outstanding rookie pitcher, has been torn up and replaced by a new good one for the remainder of this season and all of 1939.

The Italian press announces with obvious elation that General Francisco Franco is now undisputed master of Spanish territorial waters, having succeeded in immobilizing the Loyalist fleet with the help of intensive bombing raids by the Italian air force on June 17 at Cartagena Harbor.

Mrs. William Appleton Burnham and Mrs. Charles George Moller, who are passing the season at the Meadow Club, gave a dinner, followed by bridge, there tonight. Miss Genevieve Clendenin was a luncheon hostess today at the Southampton Beach Club for her father, Joseph Clendenin, who has arrived from Kirk Hills, Ardsleyon-Hudson, to pass the Summer at Ingleside.
One man was burned fatally and six other persons were injured early yesterday morning when a fire swept through a three-story frame house at 797 East 161st Street, the Bronx.
The franchise for Mexican women was a step nearer realization today after the Chamber of Deputies approved unanimously a committee report for a constitutional amendment to extend the right to vote.

The Maritime Association's investigation of the harbor fog question and the possibility of lessening its costly effects on port shipping got under way yesterday at the Maritime Exchange. About fifty men, including ship operators and representatives of Federal agencies, discussed the problem generally
Jimmy Skelton of the Alcyon Park baseball team of Pitman tonight shut out the Athletics, 4 to 0, in an exhibition game.
During the week ended July 6 member bank reserve balances increased $33,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $94,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks

Andre Jessurun, hard-punching welterweight from the West Side, outpointed Frankie Genovese, Canadian champion, in a thrilling tenround main event at the Fort Hamilton Arena in Brooklyn last night before 5,000 persons. The winner scaled 147 pounds and his opponent 145.
The steel business is in a state of virtual stagnation while buyers consider the new conditions arising from the establishment of new basing points for prices, Iron Age says this week.
Supreme Court Justice George A. Larkin reserved decision today on the demand of Clyde Potts, Mayor of Morristown, N. J., for a bill of particulars on an indictment charging him with Deriury.

The International Tin Committee announced today the details of its buffer-stock scheme, establishing an initial contributory buffer pool of 10,000 tons with the object of maintaining the price of tin between [Pound]200 and [Pound]230 sterling (equivalent to $1,000-$1,150) a ton.
One clothing manufacturer with a well-defined "social" consciousness, believes the government ought to give tuxedos to men on home relief.

Walter Smith Sugden, Immediate Past Imperial Potentate of the Shrine, died tonight at the age of 58. He had been in a coma since yesterday, when he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage. Although in ill health for the last two years,

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A public which is being called upon constantly to sympathize with labor, in the face of daily proof that the latter intends to further its interests by turbulence and force, should be better informed as to the nature of the demands which labor makes in each particular controversy.

Miss Josephine Sanfilippo, who captured the metropolitan girls' tennis championship at Jackson Heights Tuesday, advanced to the final round of the Eastern girls' tournament by defeating Miss Virginia Wandelt at the Amackassin Club today.

The City Hall reporters, full of confidence from their twelve straight victories in baseball games played annually with members of the Board of Aldermen, played a fast game yesterday against that body's successor, the City Council, at the New York Athletic Club grounds on Travers Island. Mayor La Guardia was honorary umpire.
President Roosevelt late today appointed Edward J. Noble of Connecticut chairman of-the new Civil Aeronautics Authority, and Clinton M. Hester of Montana administrator.

Private investors placed $653,265,000 in farm mortgages in the year ended on April 1, indicating that this was a favorite field for investment, the Farm Credit Administration reported today. W. I. Myers, governor of the FCA, said that total farm financing in the period, including Federal land bank credits, aggregated $749,355,000.

Regulations of the Controller's office which require corporations to pay city sales taxes on the basis of gross receipts were attacked as unconstitutional in suits filed yesterday in Federal court by Collier Advertising Service, Inc., and the Collier Service Corporation, which operate news stands and vending machines in subway stations.

Manhattan Alterations Lexington Ave, 570; to 47-story offices and stores; General Electric Realty Corp, premises owner; Otto H. Spin, architect; cost, $5,000. Charlton St, 68-72; to 3-story offices and factory; Sandox Chemical Works, Inc, 61 Van Dam St, owner; M. Spaet, architect; cost, $30,000.
President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines Commonwealth flatly repudiated today reports published in New York that he was in Tokyo to obtain Japan's pledge to respect Filipino independence.
Japanese soldiers and plain clothes men withdrew from the International Settlement today, easing a situation already made tense by an outbreak of anti-Japanese terrorism.

Air-express shipments in and out of New York City for the first six months of this year totaled 162,411, an increase of 3.83 per cent over the same period last year, according to the Railway Express Agency.

Eire will be represented at the New York World's Fair wit a two-story pavilion which will display every phase of Irish life, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, Michael Scott of Dublin, the architect, said that ground for the pavilion would be broken in August and that the structure would be completed by Jan. 1, 1939.

Public hearings in connection with the affairs of the American General Corporation, a subsidiary of the Equity Corporation, and its predecessor corporations and their affiliates, will be resumed here on Monday, the SEC announced today.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 5: CAPTAINS Milne, M., orders relieving him from all active duty are revoked; to duty as President General Court Martial, Navy Yard, Boston, Mass. Burrell, G. S., Civil Engr. Corps, Naval Air Station, Pensacola, Fla., about Aug. 1, to Norfolk Navy Yard, Portsmouth, Va., as public works officer.

The National Labor Relations Board has handed down a decision which ought to command prompt attention on the part of all Americans who believe in the protection of civil liberties in this country. The case involves an unimportant shoe manufacturer in Maryland.

Authorization of a $300,000,000 State debt for housing and slum-clearance purposes and the granting to the Legislature of broad powers to carry such a program into effect have been approved by the Republican majority in the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Housing.
Joseph J. Drake, treasurer of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 40-25 167th Street, Flushing, Queens. He was 71 years old.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo handed down a decision yesterday relieving the Publishers Association of New York City from any liability for claims by former composing room employes of The Brooklyn Times-Union, but upholding the award of the board of arbitrators appointed to settle the dispute between New York Typographical Union No. 6 and The Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

The tenth annual, service in memory of Captain Emilio Carransa, Mexican good-will aviator who crashed to his death in the pines section of Burlington County, will be held next Tuesday afternoon at the monument which marks the scene of the crash.

The best possible argument that could be offered for the passage of this resolution was offered by the former Congressman from New York, Mr. Bennet, yesterday, and, condensed into a few words, that argument was that this particular section of the Constitution is not enforceable and has not been enforced, and has on the other hand been entirely disregarded not only by the great body of the people of the State, but the Legislature itself.

Before 200 spectators in a court room yesterday, Magistrate Irving Ben Cooper severely denounced Edward A. Coleman, president of the Queens County Bar Association, for injecting a "Nazi issue" into an assault case brought before Mr. Cooper in the Long Island City Magistrate's Court in Queens.

Notice of the proposed transfer of the membership of William McC. Martin Jr., new president of the New York Stock Exchange, to Gordon D. Stott for a nominal consideration was issued yesterday by the Exchange.

The six-member Nevills Expedition, due at Lees Ferry, Ariz., on its trip down the Colorado River, was reported sighted today by two Coast Guard fliers from El Paso. The pilots, R. W. Fendlay and J. L. Riggs, said they had communicated with the party and that apparently its members were well and did not need aid.
Francis Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, was unable today to enlighten a British inquirer who asked if President Roosevelt were planning to run for a third term. She said:
Spanish Government militiamen today brought to a standstill the Insurgent drive on Valencia and announced their first gain in three days of fighting.

President Anastasio Somoza expressed his gratitude for the safe arrival of his two sons and his daughter from New York by the release of all prisoners serving terms for common crimes and National Guard soldiers who had violated military regulations.

Cold storage holdings of fishery products in the United States on June 15 were 14 per cent greater than a year ago, and 44 per cent greater than the five-year average, according to the Bureau of Fisheries. Holdings on June 15 amounted to 54,919,000 pounds, compared with 48,178,000 pounds on June 15, 1937, and the five-year average of 38,150,000 pounds.

A program of action up to the point of public hearings was unanimously agreed upon today by the joint Congressional-Executive committee to investigate monopoly and the concentration of economic power.

Long Key, ightning fast bay colt owned by J. Merkle of Columbus and driven by en F. White today became the dds-on favorite to win the classic Hambletonian by easily capturing he $6,185 championship Stallion Stake at the North Randall track's Grand Circuit meeting.

Curtis B. Dall, former son-in-law of President Roosevelt, may now go into court and prove his damages against the magazine Time which he alleged had libeled him. The Court of Appeals today affirmed the judgment of the Appellate Division which found that he had been libeled and granted a new trial.

A new issue of $1,657,000 of Roch- from J ester Gas and Electric Corporation general mortgage 31/2 per cent bonds due in 1967 will be offered formally today by a banking group composed of the First Boston Corportion, Smith, Barney Co.; Goldman, Sachs Co.; Harris, Hall Co., Inc.; W. C. Langley Co., and Sage, Rutty Co., Inc.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, in a dramatic appeal to the Constitutional Convention today, called upon the delegates to support the Hirschberg proposal which would eliminate the omnibus prohibition against gambling from the State Constitution and put future control in the hands of the Legislature.

The thief who stole the automobile of Norman Schwarzkopf, former Superintendent of New Jersey State Police, had the car washed and greased before it was returned to its owner today. Authorities believe the motive was to have fingerprints removed.

A decrease of $4,322,000 in deposits of chartered banks was shown today in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended on July 6. Dominion Government deposits were up $1,382,000, while an increase of $2,538,000 was registered in notes in circulation. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 56.82 per cent this week, against 57.41 last week.
Atlanta's league-leading Crackers swamped an aggregation of players selected from the other seven clubs of the Southern Association in the league's first All-Star game tonight. The score was 14 to 4.

Henry Hadad, head of Henry Hadad Co.,. was appointed chairman of the World's Fair committee for the negligee industry at a meeting yesterday at the Empire State Club. The committee- will develop plans for the participation of the industry in the Apparel and Accessories Building at the World's Fair.

By GEORGE J. KEARNS 172d St, 1,491 E, 52.10x12.1lxirreg; Barney Pearl against Dorothy Langhaus; due, man S13,545; taxes, etc., $1,700; to plaintiff for $7,500. City Island Ave, 265, 61xl40xirreg William L Griffen against Ernst Miller; due, $10,795: taxes, etc., $3,500; to plaintiff for $2,000.

The Rev. and Mrs. Henry S. Gehman of Princeton, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Gehman, to Samuel Eberts Kidd, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Harvey S. Kidd of Souderton, Pa.
Senator Sheppard of Texas said today that the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee might subpoena any candidate who failed to answer nine questions embodied in a questionnaire completed today.

Giovanni Host Venturi, Assistant Secretary of State for the Italian Merchant Marine, arrived here yesterday on the Italian motorship Saturnia to survey the steamship services between Italy and New York. The government is considering increasing its marine services, particularly in connection with the New York World's Fair of 1939.

Plans for completing a row of houses in Brooklyn that had been acquired at foreclosure during construction were announced yesterday when the Max Goss Associates disposed of the three one-family dwellings at 4,560-2-4 Bedford Avenue.

The Holland-America liner Volendam is due to sail tonight for the Channel ports. Passengers are Miss Emlen K. Davies, daughter of the United States Ambassador to Belgium, Joseph E. Davies; Mrs. Mai Byrns Wilson, Miss Mary Elizabeth Wilson, Dr. Harry W. Laidler, Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Price, Mrs. S.

Thirty sailing yachts and seventeen motor boats were entered yesterday for the New York Athletic Club's Block Island races. The sailing craft get under way off Execution Lighthouse at 8 o'clock tonight and the motor division tomorrow morning. All are expected to finish the 100-mile course by tomorrow night.

Directors of the Blue Ridge Corporation declared the regular optional quarterly dividend on the $3 preferred stock, payable in 1-32 share of common stock for each share of preferred, or 75 cents in cash.

Joe Hunt of Southern California, national junior titleholder and fifth ranking player of the country, was eliminated from the national intercollegiate tennis championship today on the clay courts of the Merion Cricket Club.

In the belief that the number of jobs filled by. the State Employment Service is insufficient to warrant maintenance of its present interviewing staff, Abraham S. Weber, State Budget Director, has proposed a reorganization in the personnel of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department, effective next month.
Dr. R. E. Blackwell, president of RandolphMaoon College, Ashfand,,Va., and a former president of the Southern Association of Colleges, died in a hospital here early today. He was 88 years old.

Miss Mary Foster Pitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shelton Pitney of this place, will be presented to society at the Morris County Golf Club at a dance to be given by her parents the evening of Sept. 16.

The shot fired on the Marco Polo Bridge a year ago yesterday turns, out to be another of the historic shots heard around the world. Like the gun that barked at Lexington to give notice of the rising of America; like the bomb thrown by a schoolboy at Sarajevo to set fire to the old Europe,
British doctors threatened a possible "stayin strike" today to prevent admission of additional Austrian physicians to practice in this country.

Business in the Pittsburgh district moved upward again last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. After adjustment for the usual seasonal changes, the index of general business rose from 59.7 per cent of the 1923-25 average in the week ended June 25 to 61.0 last week.

An immediate moratorium on foreclosure by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, because of depressed economic conditions, was requested by representatives of 100 men and women who picketed the HOLC office at 270 Broadway yesterday.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 7: Washington to Newport: Badger, Decatur, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. Navy Yard, Mare Island, to San Diego, July 5: Dorsey, Elliot. At Seattle Dewey, Hopkins, Worden. At Navy Yard, New York: Fanning, June 29: Shaw.

Postmaster General James A. Farley left yesterday on an extended trip which will take him as far as Alaska. He is accompanied by his daughters, Elizabeth and Anne; Ambrose O'Connell, executive assistant, and Edward Roddan of the staff of the Democratic Committee. He is scheduled to return Aug. 14.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Susseles of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriett Susseles, to Samuel Trepner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Trepner, also of New York.

Army reserve pistol experts yesterday were named military champions of New York State, New Jersey and Delaware in an announcement from United States Army Headquarters on Governors Island giving the results of the annual marksmanship competition between the Organized Reserve and National Guard teams of the Second Corps area for the Luquer Trophy, donated by Colonel Thatcher T. P. Luquer, Officers Reserve Corps.

A generally firm tone prevailed today in the stock markets here, brisk business taking place in nearly all sections. Strong buying of gilt-edge issues again was in evidence, but in later dealings a hesitant tone developed. There was little doing in foreign bonds. Transatlantic shares were strong, United States Steel and International Nickel going ahead.
Northamptonshire took a three-run first-innings lead over Lancashire today in the only game of the current English County cricket series not interfered with by rain.

Winston Guest wrote finis to perhaps his finest 1938 polo performance today by scoring in the closing seconds to give his Templeton forces a 7-to-6 victory over Bostwick Field that sent them into the final of the Meadow Brook Club's tourney for twentY-goal teams.

The 1,368 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $49,176,722,027 par value as of July 1, had a total market value of $43,756,515,009, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of June 1, there were 1,371 issues, aggregating $48,243,744,251 par value, which had a total market value of $42,346,644,435.

Stocks closed irregular after early strength in largest trading since Oct. 29; rail, utility and aviation shares higher; turnover, 2,775,420 shares. Corporation bonds higher, rail and traction issues strong, United States Government and other groups irregularly higher; transactions, $12,443,000, heaviest of year to date.
Mrs. Nora Boyce of Old Bridge, the mother of six children, was acquitted today in the fatal shooting of her husband, Frank Boyce, in their backwoods farmhouse on May 30.

Ulrich Stutz, former Professor of Ecclesiastical History and Canonical Law at the University of Berlin, died here today at the age of 71. Professor Stutz studied law philosophy, history and theology at the University of Zurich, Switzerland,
Topsy-turvy can go no further than this latest discovery that the city is the best place for a dog. That assertion has been made in connection with the veterinarians' meeting in town.

Bank clearings in the twenty-two leading cities of the country in the five days ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,090,570,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was a loss of 16.1 per cent from the $6,063,812,000 for the corresponding week a year ago,
The WPA Caravan Theatre will offer the following productions tonight: Manhattan, "Treasure Island," at Washington Square Park; Brooklyn, "The Milky Way," at the Prospect Park Bandstand;

James F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company, announced yesterday that electric output of the North American System in the first half of this year was 8.8 per cent below that for the 1937 period. "The lessened demand for electric service by industrial customers accounted for the decrease of our subsidiaries operating in the St. Louis, Cleveland and Milwaukee areas," he said.
A new committee on civil rights of the New York County Lawyers Association has been appointed by George Z. Medalie, president, who yesterday announced committees for the year 1938-39.

That fascist educational methods are in force in varying degrees in American public schools was charged yesterday by Professor Jesse H. Newlon of Teachers College, a former president of the National Education Association, in posing the question, "Are the American Schools Educating for Fascism or Democracy?"
Staging a three-run rally. in the eighth inning after two were out, the Bears broke a deadlock and gained a 7-to-4 victory over Jersey City tonight before 12,000 spectators.
Good growth and the absence of any major setbacks continue, to characterize the progress of crops in Canada, according to the Bank of Montreal in its current crop report.

More than $40,000 has been con'tributed by governmental employes in Brooklyn to the Greater New York Fund, according to an announcement yesterday by Postmaster Frank Sinnott of Brooklyn, chairman of the borough division soliciting gifts from Federal, State, county and city employes.
Dr. Lawrence F. Flick one of the world's leading authorities on tuberculosis, died of a heart ailment today at his home here. He was 81 years old and had been ill about a year.

Andrew W. MacElveny of 3541 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, general traffic manager of the Schenley Distillers Corporation, in charge of its nation-wide transportation since the advent of repeal, died Wednesday night at Mount Sinai Hospital after an illness of five months. He was 52 years old.

Millinery manufacturers throughout the country met today in a move to end evils that have beset them in the last fifteen years and to adopt a code of business standards designed to re-establish them on a profitable operating basis.

Class, I railroads in the United States had 914,765 employes on their payrolls at the middle of June, an increase of 1.09 per cent over May but a decrease of 21.93 per cent from the middle of June; 1937, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is trustee for $3,000,000 extended and modified first mortgage participating certificates of the Printing Crafts Realty Corporation. The mortgage has been extended for a period of five years from April 1, 1938 to 1943.

Mrs. John H. Lapham of Woodway and Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich of Green Meadow tied for low gross in the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association one-day tournament at the Wee Burn Club today. Each carded an 82, two over women's par. Matching cards, Mrs. Lapham won the prize, 1 up.

James J. Hines, the Tammany district leader, lost yesterday his fight to void the indictment in which District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey charged him with being a member of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer lottery gang.

Col. Thomas W. Brown, General Staff Cops, will proceed on or about July 7 from Governors Island, N. Y., to Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., on temporary duty in connection with organized Reserves camps, and upon completion of this temporary duty will return to Governors Island, N. Y.
Annual installation of officers of the Father Duffy Chapter, Rainbow Division, Veterans of the 165th Infantry (old Sixty-ninth) Armory Twentysixth Street and Lexington Avenue, 8:30 P. M.
With a fine display of staying power, Don Creole, 5-year-old brown gelding from the Oddesa Farm, took the Irish Hills Purse, feature today at the Detroit Fair Grounds.

Reorganization plans for the New York Curb Exchange which call for a paid executive vice president, a smaller board of governors and reductions in the number and size of standing committees have been drafted. Prepared by an advisory committee headed by Arthur Myles of Moore Schley, the plans have been submitted to the reorganization committee headed by William S. Muller and will be considered on Monday.

In a special news letter sent yesterday to its members the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers suggests the inclusion in contracts of provisions protecting producers from increases in labor costs due to the Wages and Hours Law, which becomes effective on Oct. 24.

ABRAHAMS, JOSEPH (June 18). Estate, $1,000. To Aimee Abrahams, widow executrix, 175 Riverside Drive, residue. Lucy Schwab, mother-m-law, executrix, 167 W. 88th St. DUNLOP,WILLIAM F. (May 16). Estate, less than $5,000. To Jean J. Fraser, secretary and executrix, 37-35 85th St., Jackson Heights, L. I., residue. Frank P. Ufford, 10 Gramercy Park, executor.

Senator Vic Donahey of Ohio said today that his Congressional investigating committee would seek to find out whether the directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority, "their experts and employes are administering this great trust in the interest of the people."

Peter Riedel of Germany broke another glider record today, but cannot claim official credit because of his foreign registration. With Milton Girton, an inspector for the Bureau of Air Commerce, as a passenger, he soared to Syracuse, Airport, seventy-three miles, in 4 hours.

North American Aviation, Inc., in its quarterly statement for the March quarter made public yesterday, showed a consolidated net profit of $212,085 after normal Federal income taxes and after $234,861 depreciation. No provision was made for surtax on undistributed earnings.

Oct. 16, Philadelphia; 23, Brooklyn; 30, Pittsburgh. Nov. 6, Cardinals; 13, Cleveland; 20, Green Bay. Dec. 4, Washington. DODGERS' HOME GAMES Sept. 25, Pittsburgh. Oct. 2, Cardinals; 30, Washington. Nov. 13, Philadelphia; 20, Bears; 24, Giants.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that orders received by the company in the first half of this year amounted to $128,223,823, compared with $217,265,619 in the 1937 period, a decrease of 41 per cent.

Franklin Pierce McCall, 21-yearold kidnapper of Jimmy Cash, today was refused a respite from death in a ruling of the State Pardon Board. His family, however, authorized the defense attorney, G. A. Avriett, to prepare an appeal to the State Supreme Court.

To meet the demand for 1,000 and 500 franc banknotes, government printers have been asked to suspend their fortyhour week and work an extra five hours. The increased cost of living that has followed successive devaluations has called for more large denomination notes.

Suites in houses on Central Park West and Riverside Drive attracted a a number of the lessees of new residential quarters listed in yesterday's rental reports. In the building at 415 Central Park West, Lora H. Hubbel, Walter S A. Deems, William G. King and f Gustave Reis took apartments through Sharp Nassoit Managenent Corporation.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, reversing its findings of last April, has permitted the Eastern railroads .to raise their passenger coach fares for an eighteen-month "experimental" period, from 2 to 2 1/2 cents a mile. It is difficult to predict with confidence what the exact effect of the increase on the railroads' net revenues will be.

Many new tenancies in buildings on the East Side were announced by brokers yesterday. The penthouse and terrace apartment on the San Carlos Hotel at t 150 East Fiftieth Street was taken by Georges G. de Deols, according to Walter L. Steiger, president of the operating corporation.

Without money to ship a newly purchased shell from Hamilton, Ont., to Toronto, four University of Toronto youths rowed home forty-three miles over Lake Ontario. They arrived today, covering the distance in a little more than seven hours.

The sale of $10,000,000 worth of oil by Mexico to W. R. Davis Co. of New York for disposal in Germany, Italy and Sweden on a partial barter basis had a disquieting effect here, although there were no indications today that any effort would be made to block the arrangement. Official comment was withheld pending official confirmation of the sale, which had not been received by the State Department.

The second portion of the collection of fine bindings and rare engravings assembled by the late Mortimer L. Schiff brought [Pound]3,297 in the concluding sale at Sotheby's today, making a total for the three days' dealings of [Pound]15,703.. The first portion has already been sold and today's receipts bring the total for the two portions to [Pound]36,629.

United States Maritime Commission postponed today until July 20 the date for opening bids for purchase or charter of the American Republics Line, which will operate three Panama-Pacific luxury liners between New York and Buenos Aires.

Mrs. Carlos M. de Heredia was a dinner hostess tonight at Wheatleigh in Lenox. Her guests were Mrs. Newbold Morris. Mrs. Walter P. Anderton, Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana, Miss Ethel L. Haven, J. Woodward Haven, George Lovett Kingsland, Grenville L. Winthrop and Stephanus Van C. Morris.

Mrs. Harry M. Newington entertained with a luncheon today at the Villa Serena, her residence in Field Point Park, Greenwich. Among her guests were Princess Vladimir Koudacheff, Countess Palen-Klar, Mrs. Samuel Graham, Mrs. Leo Kissam,

The West Penn Power Company of Pittsburgh, a subsidiary of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., has filed a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act covering the issuance and sale of $17,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds, series J. due on Aug. 1. 1968.
John Elliott, member of the Connecticut bar for forty-one years, died today at his home after an illness of several months. He was born in Cranford, N. J., seventythree years ago.
" Room Service," stationed at the Cort Theatre since May 19, 1937, notes that it now is playing the "final -weeks" of its engagement. The closing date is indefinite, though.

The Public Works Administration estimated today that the "maximum possible exercise" of the new Public Works Act. a major phase of the reliefrecovery program, would provide "14,224,000 man-months of normal employment at prevailing wages."

A mass attack on poor readers in the junior high schools' of this city will get under way in the Fall, it was announced yesterday. Each of the eighty-one schools in this dlvision will have at least one class set aside for pupils needing help in reading.

Not only Is the entire world aroused against "appalling" air attacks on civilian populations but the perpetrators of civilian air raids themselves are coming to realize that they are bad strategy, it was declared yesterday by Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross,
Secretary Morgenthau plans to sail from New York on July 15 aboard the Holland-America liner Statendam for a month's vacation in -Europe. His family will accompany him.

Despite the satisfaction with which the London agreement regarding Spain has been greeted, there is no great confidence in France that it will ever be realized or that Italy and Germany will ever consent to act their part in it as France has done in closing the Catalan frontier.
James A., a son of Boo which raced at Charles Town last May, sprang a mild surprise today by winning the Powder House Handicap, $2,000 feature of the Delaware Park program.

Pig iron output in June, according to the Iron Age, was 1,062,021 gross tons, against $1,255,024 tons in May, a loss of 12.5 per cent on the daily basis of 35,400 tons last month. The half-year output was 7,873,026 tons, compared with 19,706,593 tons in the first half of 1937.

Archie San Romani will attempt to break Sydney Wooderson's listed world record of 4:06.4 for the mile in a special race at the Ancient Order of Hibernians' meet at Randalls Island Stadium a week from Sunday. Lined up against the Kansas flier will be Blaine Rideout, Gene Venzke and Ralph Schwartzkopf.

City Councilman Charles E. Keegan of New York was sued for $150,000 damages today in a Supreme Court action alleging that he slandered two professional lecturers at a meeting of the New York Council on March 1.

An anonymous gift of $5,000 was announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Whitehall Club by the sponsors of a campaign to raise $57,000 for the. 1938 budget and camp needs of the Suffolk Council, Boy Scouts of America.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of the dates indicated, upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service in day secondary schools other than junior high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated.
Traffio through the Panama Canal declined slightly last month, but there was an increase over the fiscal year which ended on June 30, according to a report issued by the War Department today.

HAVE you read any good books lately? Yes. Here are some memoirs of books published between March 1 and Independence Day that stand out in your reviewer's mind for a variety of excellences. The order of mention has only the significance of chance.

In an expose of Bulgaria's foreign policy in Parliament today, Premier George Kiosseivanoff emphasized the importance of her close relations with Yugoslavia as well as with the other members of the Balkan Entente. Although Bulgaria is not a member of the entente, her foreign policy is identical with that of the member States.

Officials of the Eastern railroads will begin today to revise their tariff schedules upward to take advantage of the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission increasing the maximum coach fares from 2 cents a mile to 2.5 cents.
Elmira of the Eastern League today scored a 3-to-2 victory over their parent club, the Dodgers, before a crowd of 5,500.

Confidence in the Fall business outlook and, increased advertising budgets were reported yesterday at sales meetings conducted by companies in a variety of fields. They included the Exide Storage Battery Company, the L. E. Waterman Company and the B. V. D. Corporation.
The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania will offer $6,000,000 of shortterm notes on Thursday. The issue will be dated July 28 and will become due on July 21, 1939.

Mrs. Olive D. Pierce, leader in the women's suffrage movement and other activities for women, died yesterday at her home, 2,112 Hermany Avenue, the Bronx. She was a native of Gerard, Ill., but had lived here for the last. thirtyfive years.

Observing the first anniversary of the undeclared war on China today, Japanese stressed that it was their duty to live simply and frugally. Special lunches, costing 12 sen, about 3 cents, were eaten throughout the empire.

The father who commutes to work leaves his children under a maternal domination that obstructs "healthy emotional maturity" and makes a daughter shy in her adjustments to the opposite sex and a son too submissive, Dr. Caroline B. Zachry, research director of the Progressive Education Association,

Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., which is charged by the Federal Trade Commission with practices having a monopolistic tendency, has -filed with the commission its final brief in which it holds that conditions in the women's wear industry necessitated the guild's program.

The full force of the Workers Alliance, an organization made up of WPA clients and other unemployed persons, is to be thrown into the primary election campaigns in behalf of Senators and Representatives committed to increased relief wages, according to David Lasser, national president.

Guarded by an extra force of deputy sheriffs in addition to an augmented squad of court attendants, Salvatore Gati and Charles Sberna, 29-year-old paroled convicts, were sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to die in the Sing Sing electric chair for the murder of Patrolman John H. A. Wilson last Sept. 23.

The marriage of Miss Amadita Diana Oland, only daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. S. C. Oland of this city, to HarveyNorman Stanbury, a director of Eastern Securities Corporation, took place at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral this morning. The ceremony was performed by the Most Rev. John McNally. Archbishop of Halifax.

The Supreme Court today rejected Corneliu Zelea Codreanu's appeal from a military court's sentence of ten years at hard labor for high treason. The Iron Guard (Fascist) leader will be transferred to Ocnele Mare Prison to serve his sentence in the salt mines there.

Three odds-on favorites, culminating with- Opera Hat in the featured Whitestone Purse, won in succession at Empire City yesterday. Only three contested the issue with the Woodland Farm racer over the mile and seventy-yard distance.

Kensuke Horinouchi, the Vice Foreign Minister, warned the French Ambassador this afternoon that the stationing of Annamite troops on the Paracel Islands might lead to misunderstandings between them and Japanese workers on the islands, 250 miles east of French Indo-China.

The fat steer and yearling market was higher again today with many sales showing a full dollar advance, as compared with a week ago, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Abridged receipts were the principal stimulating factor today in a good, active trade.

In a series of colorful pageants, public meetings and private feasts, Chinese here yesterday celebrated the first anniversary of the defense of their country against the Japanese. Similar celebrations were held throughout the nation.

Dr. Harry S. Weaver, retired professor of Hahnemann Medical College and a member of the Hahnemann Hospital staff for forty-six years, died at his home here today after an illness of several months. His age was 70.

Arab tribes from Trans-Jordan were reported massed on the Palestine frontier tonight as Great Britain sped warships and troops to smash the worst Jewish-Arab outbreak in the Holy Land's recent history.

To bring back to this country from London the airplane in which the Wright Brothers made their notable flight at Kitty Hawk, N. C., Dec. 17, 1903, is the object of the Association of Men with Wings, chartered today as a membership corporation and backed by some of the leading names in American aviation.

The marriage of Mrs. Katherine Fielding Phelps, daughter of Mrs. Alma Turner Phelps of Fort Worth, Texas, and John Phelps, to Lieutenant Forrest Close, U. S. N., took place late this afternoon at the home of the bride's father here. Only a few persons were present because of the recent death of Mrs. Phelps's uncle,

The Old Colony Railroad will be faced with the abandonment of its freight and passenger rail service if existing losses are not reduced substantially, William J. Cunningham, Professor of Transportation at Harvard University, testified today before Judge Carroll Hincks of the United States District Court.
HAVING WONDERFUL TIME, as adapted by Arthur Kober from his play of the same name; directed by Alfred Santell, produced by Pandro S. Berman for RKO Radio. At the Radio City Music Hall.

The Airport Land Corporation of Manhattan filed yesterday plans for sixteen six-story tenement houses in the Jackson Heights section of Queens. The houses will be erected on Twenty-fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Seventy-third Street to Eightieth Street.

John H. Keegan, president of the real estate firm of Stearne-Keegan Company, Inc., 347 Madison Avenue, New York, died this morning at the Professional Hospital here after a short illness. He was 78 years old and resided here.

Reed Vetterli, in charge of the New York field office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told 1,000 members of the Police Eligibles List Association last night that good law-enforcement agents "pay real dividends to a community."

The American trade agreements program was presented as a solution of the nation's surplus disposal problem by Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, and a new approach to social security was suggested by James H. R. Cromwell of New York City,

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that sugar imports in the first half of this year totaled 2,662,488 short tons, raw value, compared with 3,190,350in the corresponding period last year.

Mayor La Guardia indicated last night that he would support Representative James M. Mead of Buffalo for United States Senator or Governor if the up-State Representative were nominated by the Democratic party this Fall.
A finger injury forced Bob Pastor of New York, the National Boxing Association's fifth-rated heavyweight, to cancel his scheduled fight here next Monday night with Clarence (Red) Burman of Baltimore.

A record field of seventy-seven twosomes, led by Frank Strafaci of Brooklyn and Howard Tryon of Elmira, will tee off tomorrow in the annual Brook-Lea Country Club best-ball invitation golf tournament.

Harrison Ave (11-3206), e s. 220 ft n of 180th St, 55x100; Ruth Auslander to S. R. H. B. Corp, 2,120 Harrison Ave. White Plains Rd (18-4657), n e cor of 212th St, 134x71: East River Savings Bank to B. G. S. Realty Corp, 251 W 89th St.
Miss Maria Gersen, an 18-year-old German nursemaid, trapped more than ten hours on a ledge halfway up a 1,000-foot Adirondack Mountain cliff, was rescued early today by a party of men with ropes.

Tilford E. Dudley, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, in an interim report today recom- h mended that the Ford Motor Com- h pany at its St. Louis plant reinstatek 192 employes which he held had e been discharged or. refused jobs because of union activity and participation in a strike last Nov. 24.

The Yugoslav naval training ship Jadran, barkentine with auxiliary power, will leave her berth at Pier 99, foot of West Fifty-ninth Street, for Boston early this morning, but her place will be filled almost immediately by the four-masted Almirante Saldanha, training ship of the Brazilian Navy.
The Intergovernmental refugee committee elected Myron C. Taylor, head of the United States delegation, as its permanent president today.

The body of Cornelius J. Kiely Jr., 23 years old, of 123-11 Hillside Court, Jamaica, Queens, was found this morning on the beach side of Moriches Bay, about three miles from the place he was drowned Saturday night.

Mrs. Thomas A. Morrow and her son Keenan, star freshman halfmiler at Amherst College, who were playing alternate strokes for the first time, walked off with--the fourth annual women's metropolitan mother and son golf tournament when they scored 35, 47-82 over their home course, the Pomonok Country Club, in Flushing yesterday.

Mary Allen Shop, ladies' apparel, store in 43 E 49th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers. Reliance Handkerchief Co, store in Rialto Theatre Building, 1,481 Broadway; John R. Kennedy. paper board, in 295 Madison Ave; Lucy DeVito, Inc. dresses, in 37 W 47th St; Lawrence Sales Organization, Inc. in 1,775 Broadway; Mechanical Sales Corp, in 250 W 54th St; Credit Motor Sales, in 241 W 58th St; Charles F. Noyes Co, broker.
The sharp drop in lumber production last week was greater than allowed for on the seasonal basis and the index slumped to 54.9 from 65.2. This compares with 97.0 for the week ended July 3, 1937.

The State Board of Housing, through Louis H. Pink, chairman, urged Mayor La Guardia yesterday to revive the tax-exemption benefits formerly offered to limited-dividend housing projects, and expressed the belief that resumption of this practice would result in a large amount of new apartment construction by private interests for moderate rentals.
Trade shows and opening of new lines attracted many buyers to the principal wholesale markets this week and buying was strong, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Trading by members in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 11 represented 20.50 per cent of the total volume, compared with 21.38 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

An increase in commutation fares on the West Shore Railroad lines is being considered as a means of offsetting the loss in revenue from its ferry service, it was disclosed yesterday at the closing session of the hearing on a proposed ferryrate increase before the Interstate Commerce Commission at the Hotel New Yorker.

A message urging appointment at the earliest possible date of an industrial committee for the popularprice dress industry under the Wages and Hours Act was sent to President Roosevelt yesterday by Louis Rubin,

Motor fuel sold in the State in April totaled 145,031,902 gallons, the Tax Commission reported today, adding that the sales were 4,108,273 gallons over the mark for April, 1937. On the sales of taxable fuel the State collected $3,804,656.

Former Governor Smith's attack at Albany on the attempt to control gambling in this State by continuing to rely on a constitutional ban against it was a telling one because it exposed the fundamental error in this method of approach.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for June 30 showed, today, that the ratio of gold reserve to notes in circulation was 123.45 per cent, compared with 123.80 per cent on June 15.

Henrik Von Zernikow Loss, a consulting engineer of this city who had been honored by the Franklin Institute for a series of inventions, died on June 28 in Oslo, Norway, according to word received here to day, He was 77 years old.

Acourt decision which was a victory; for the International Ladies Garment Workers was handed down here today to mark the latest of the series of legal manoeuvres in which the Donnelly Garment Company and the union have been engaged all the way to the Supreme Court and back.

With the statement that he was not interfering "in any shape, manner or form in the primary. campaign in Kentucky," President Roosevelt stood in the middle of Latonia race track today at Covington, Ky., to hail Senator Alben W. Barkley as

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 2 amounted to 588,864 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 29,927 cars, or 5.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 213,482 cars, or 26.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 60,895 cars,
Supervisor J. Dwight Rogers of North Hempstead Township died in the Nassau Hospital here tonight after a two weeks' illness of pneumonia. He was 51 years old.

Despite an increase of almost 5 per cent in. sales last. year, the net profit of thirty-five leading variety store chains fell by nearly 1 per cent between 1936 and 1937, according to the report on Expenses and Profits of Limited Price Variety Chains in 1937,

Trading was fair to. good in local markets yesterday. Price trends were strong to higher on traefer meats and mostly unchanged on kosher meats. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

In a strong effort to stimulate retail activity on Palm Beach suits during July and August, the Goodall Company will launch an intensive advertising campaign shortly, Elmer Ward, president of the company, announced yesterday.
The Intergovernmental Refugee Committee spent today mainly hearing in private through a subcommittee the views of some forty private organizations, mostly Jewish but including Catholics,

Mr. and Mrs. T. Suffern Tailer were hosts tonight at a dinner in the gardens of their home in the Lattingtown colony adjoining the Creek Club in honor of Mrs. Tailer's brother, George F. Baker Jr., and Miss Frances Drexel Munn, whose marriage is to take place tomorrow afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church, Roslyn.

71st St, 36 W, 4-story dwelling, 20x100.5 Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Annie B. Sanford, due, $26,344, taxes etc., $507: to plaintiff for $1,000. By HENRY BRADY 78th St, 264 E. 3-story dwelling, 16.4x76.8 Fanny Lahtinen against Derry Willliams due, $7,221, taxes, etc. $482; to plain tiff for $5,550.

A meat diet is helpful in reducing weight, according to recent laboratory tests, it was reported yesterday at the final scientific sessions of the seventy-fifth annual meeting of the American Veterinary Medical Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
J. P. Morgan Co., 23 Wall Street, New York, has filed a certificate with the State Banking Department in connection with change in the membership of the firm, it was announced today.

Representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced today, are to be sent throughout the country to obtain the views of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market with regard to the organization of their industry under the Maloney act, which provides for the registration with the SEC.of an association or associations and affiliates, for selfregulation under Federal supervision.

Crown. Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden will complete his scheduled tour to Minneapolis, Nils de Rudebeck, marshal of the court, announced yesterday. The Crown Prince will leave for Boston by train at 3 P. M. today and will continue to Rochester, Detroit and Chicago en route to Minnesota.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the weel ended on June 25 amounted to 293, 463,000 barrels, according to figures compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in June, totaled $26,348,295,682, a gain of 17.6 per cent over the preceeding month, and the largest since last December.

Macklin Marrow, young American conductor, will make his debut at the Lewisohn Stadium tonight, conducting the Biber-Thaulow Passacaglia, the Mendelssohn "Italian" symphony, the "Dawn and Siegfried's Rhine Journey" of Wagner and Kodaly's "Hary Janos" suite.
With an eye on the Presidential and parliamentary elections in the Spring of 1940 the Sejm (Parliament) voted today a new electoral law for city and village councils.
Laughter a s an antidote for the depression, war clouds and political disturbances was suggested yesterday by Patrick T. Montford, publisher of Dublin Opinion, Ireland's humorous journal.

In his annual report on the New York Curb Exchange for the fiscal year which ended with February, Fred C. Moffatt, president, called attention yesterday to the fact that volume of trading in listed stocks in 1937 accounted for 46 1/2 per cent of the total, against 37 1/2 per cent in 1936.

The frontier between Palestine and Lebanon is a triple barbed-wire fence called Tegart's Wall, after the English military engineer who erected this electrified barrier, fifty miles long, to enable the British to patrol the border and prevent armed bands of Syrian Arabs from joining in the guerrilla war being fought with increasing boldness and bitterness by the Arabs of Palestine.
Walter W. Gethman, between 1926 and 1936 general secretary of the Y. M. C. A. World Committee, with headquarters in Geneva, died at his home here yeterday of heart disease at the age of 55.

In a fluctuating, nerve-wracking struggle distinguished for the sterling fighting qualities on both sides and the high order of the tennis, Frank Guernsey of Rice Institute of Texas fought his way up from the depths to overcome Robert Harman of the University of California today in the semi-finals of the national intercollegiate championships.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of July 6, 1938, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of electrical installation in junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license.

Next year's naval budget is expected to total 800,000,000 yen, according to the Japanese press, which says that the naval authorities have decided to proceed with a program independent of the other powers.

A high-speed transport plare of Northwest Airlines crashed 1,000 feet from the limits of the airport here immediately after a take-off early this morning, and a woman passenger was fatally injured. Nine other persons aboard escaped with their lives.

Millinery manufacturers representing markets throughout the country took formal action today toward the organization of a national association to work toward correcting evils in the industry. Delegates from the millinery markets are meeting here in a three-day convention.

Administrator Ickes promised today that, in general, the Public Works Administration would not allot funds for municipal power projects which would compete with private utilities, unless the private companies had refused fair offers to purchase their property.

Leases of several buildings in Manhattan were announced yesterday. William Jones leased for rooming house purposes the three-story dwelling at 403 Manhattan Avenue through Clarence E. Hutchinson, broker,
