Prince Mohamed Abdel Moneim, 39-yearold second cousin of King Farouk and heir to a $50,000,000 fortune, has asked the Egyptian ruler for permission to marry Princess Myzejen, 28-year-old sister of King Zog of Albania.

Robert Morrone, 15 years old, of 454 East 185th Street, New York City, was shot this morning by his camping mate, Rocco De Fazio, 16 years old, of 2,332 Beaumont Avenue, the Bronx, when a rifle was fired accidentally.

As the climax of sixteen years of research, Vitamin E, known as "the essence of fertility," has been reduced to a chemical formula and produced in the laboratory, according to the weekly publication Science.

Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, metropolitan and Eastern champion, led a field of 183 contestants and set a new course record for women when she scored 38, 38-76 in the one-day invitation golf tournament at the Green Meadow Club today.

United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt delivered a scathing attack here today on "certain nations" that resort to "murder of defenseless men, women and children" and "employ such crimes as instruments of their national policy."

Stagehand, leading-money winner of the year, and Stormscud, the colt who humbled his fleet stablemate, The Chief, in Delaware, will meet in the $12,000 Empire City. Handicap at the Yonkers course today. These are the two best-known horses in a field of eight named for the mile and an eighth test.
The Pelicans, surprise team of the Meadow Brook Club twenty-goal polo tournament, were consistent in being surprising today, but this time in reverse direction.
A wave of Arab strikes spread through Palestine today, complicating the problem of British authorities endeavoring to crush a sanguinary outbreak of Jewish-Arab strife.

Mayor La Guardia advocated before the Social Welfare Committee-of- the Constitutional Convention a positive" amendment on relief which would make it possible to eliminate conflicts by integrating governmental powers under State laws.

Eddie Zivic, member of the famous boxing family of Pittsburgh, dropped a decision to Lew Feldman, Brownsville veteran, in the ten-round main bout at the Long Beach Stadium tonight. The victor, at 133 1/4, spotted his rival four and one-half pounds. It was a keenly fought bout.

Clinton St, 49; Harris Mines to Rose Mines. 573 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn; one-half interest; mtg $23,000. 20th St, 35 W; Jennie Arnstein to Emma Arnstein; one-half interest. 74th St, 150 E; Ira S. Robins, referee, to City Bank Farmers Trust Co, trustee of Florence Fish; foreclosure ($25). 79th St, 307-11 W; Carlos Israels, referee, to 307 W 79th St Realty Corp, 162 Remsen St. Brooklyn: foreclosure ($5).

An office and storage building in Gansevoort Street for the SpanishAmerican Mercantile Company and a laundry on First Avenue for Wilson Co. were among building projects for which plans were filed yesterday.
An executive committee which will act as a policy determining group has been formed by the Calvert Distillers Corporation, W. W. Wachtel, president of the corporation, announced yesterday.
The Constitutional Convention's Committee on Military Affairs has approved a series of proposals aimed directly at the German-American Bund.

Death Reported Retired Fireman Philip Wimmer, formerly a member of Engine Co. 61, residing at 2,841 Coddington Ave., Bronx., died July 7. Funeral will take place from the Funeral Parlors of William Bible, 2,700 East Tremont Ave., Bronx, at 2 P. M., Sunday, July 10.
The Interstate Commerce Commission granted to the Southern Railway Company today permission to borrow $13,500,000 from the government to buy 5,500 freight cars.

Members of forty-one Westchester County posts of the American Legion assembled here this evening at the opening of the annual county convention, which will continue through tomorrow evening and include a parade of 4,000 veterans.

With the official temperature on Thursday night remaining above 66 degrees, thirty-two men who testified that they found lodging houses altogether too hot appeared in Yorkville Court yesterday charged with sleeping in Central Park, and were released on suspended sentences.

Hearing in the United States District Court here on the petition of the Old Colony Railroad Company, the Old Colony Protective Committee and the Mutual Savings Bank Group, seeking a court order directing the railroad's trustees to place in immediate effect proposed reductions in train mileage involving the closing of eighty-eight stations in Massachusetts, was closed today after a two-day hearing.

A. C. McCord, president of the McCord Radiator and Manufacturing Company, has asked holders of 6 per cent debentures to approve a change in sinking-fund requirements and extension of the maturity date from 1943 to 1948. There is $1,413,000 of- debentures outstanding of $2,500,000 issued.
The Red Wings took their series opener with Jersey City tonight, 4-2, behind Nubs Kleinke's steady eight-hit pitching, making it three victories in a row and seven in their last eight games.

The United States Trust Company has awarded the contract for alterations to the office building at 12 Gold Street to the White Construction Company, according to Brown's Letters, Inc. Starrett Van Vleck, architects, prepared the plans for the work.
Licenses for nine jockeys and ten trainers were granted at a meeting of the Stewards of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, it was announced yesterday by Frank J. Bryan, secretary.

Kenneth M. Spence, counsel For The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, explained yesterday that Supreme Court Justice Salvatore Cotillo's decision had vacated that portion of the arbitration award which determined that former composing-room employes of The Brooklyn TimesUnion were entitled to reimbursement for lost wage when the two
Something of a post-holiday reaction developed in local retail trade this week. The comparative figures were still "good," but not quite as favorable as in the preceding week.
A quartet of Chicago stars turned on the power today to win all four semi-final matches in the Western boys' and juniors' closed tennis championships at Kenyon College.

The weird chants and moans of the ancient gypsy "death watch" ritual brought a touch of the Old World to New York early yesterday morning as a tribe of Russian nomads pitched camp on a parking lot opposite Bellevue Hospital to pray for the life of a stricken clansman in a charity ward.

The Italian liner Saturnia will sail today for Mediterranean ports carrying among her passengers Bishop Hugh L. Lamb of Philadelphia, Giacomo Rimini, operatic singer, accompanied by his wife, the former Rosa Raisa; Judge Thomas F. Meaney of Jersey City, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Brokaw of New York, and Mr. and Mrs. G. Le Boutillier.
A six-year building program covering the high school division, in which thirty-two secondary schools costing $84,551,000 are scheduled, was made public yesterday by the Board of Education.

The Spanish Insurgents claim to have captured the coastal town of Nules and to have penetrated five miles further south, bringing their advance forces to within ten miles of Sagunto, the last main objective before Valencia.

Senator Millard E. Tydings, one of the anti-New Deal Senators reported to be marked. for "elimination" from Congress, said today that some New Deal leaders had forced the resignation of Henry W. Webb, Maryland Administrator for the Federal Housing Administration and a Tydings appointee.

The Holy Name Society of the Church of St. Nicholas of Tolentine, 2,340 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, has opened a free employment agency for the 20,000 residents within its parish territory, it was learned yesterday. The agency, which charges no fee, considers applicants regardless of religion.
Formation of the C. M. T. C. band began today with the selection of forty-two young musicians from among the seventytwo who had applied for transfer to the band section of the regiment.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, veteran German dirigible commander, hinted today that President Roosevelt might yet have a "last word" to say regarding the United States ban on the export of helium to Germany, where it is needed for future airship development.

Performing somewhat in the manner of a prizefighter who bounces out of his corner and pops his adversary on the nose before the latter has had a chance to get off his chair, the Bees yesterday whisked a first-inning homer into the Polo Grounds stands which,

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the, twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows consolidated net income of $3,650,810 after all operating expenses and charges, compared with $3,215,572 in the twelve months to May 31, 1937.
Estimates of Chinese Army casualties during the first year of the war with Japan are lacking in numerous official reviews of the year's fighting.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Charles W. Morrison's admirable letter on housing in THE TIMES on June 30 should receive the attention it so richly deserves.
Leading stylists, of the furniture and home furnishings industries today formed the American Designers Institute at a meeting at the home furnishings show in the American Furniture Mart.

Employes who entered the State service July 1, 1937, are entitled, as of July 1, 1938, to the first increase in salaries, where the Appropriation Act for the present fiscal year has made provision for increment, Attorney General Bennett ruled today.

Charles Duke, 26, alias. Charles Kamenestsky, of 1,585 East New York Avenue, Brooklyn, was held in $75,000 bail yesterday by Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer after he had pleaded not guilty to a charge of aiding Sidney Markman, 26, to remain a fugitive from a first-degree murder indictment for the hold-up slaying of Isadore Frank, 50, a poultry' dealer, on Jan. 13, in front of his home at 733 Alabama Avenue, Brooklyn.
Twelve members of the National Guard from Brooklyn were injured, four seriously, when a truck in which they were riding overturned on a highway here today.

Senora Elena Sanchez de Berger, 23 years old, today was held for trial on a charge of homicide in the shooting of Professor Antonio Cortes Vazquez, head of the ethnological department of the National Museum, last Sunday.

An investigation of "vast expenditures" of public funds to influence the primary elections in an undesignated State was ordered today by Senator Sheppard, chairman of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures.

Miss Catherine McNelis, president of Tower Magazines, Inc., asserted today that her indictment by a Federal jury in New York on charges of using the mails in a $1,000,000 scheme to defraud national advertisers was "the end of a long period of persecution."
Concentrating a thirteenhit attack in four scoring innings, the Maple Leafs gained a 10-to-0 shutout victory over Newark tonight behind the hurling of Mike Meola.

Howard O. Frye, bulk sales manager of Walter Baker Co., Inc., has been appointed to the newly created position- of general sales manager, it was announced today by C. H. Gager, vice president and manager.

Harold Walker, a member of the legal department of the Standard Oil Companyof New Jersey and formerly first vice president of the Pan American Petroleum Company, died yesterday. morning at the Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 62.

The hope of eliminating economic difficulties besetting America's rehousing program lies in factory mass production. of houses that can be cheaply assembled on their sites, Harvey Wiley Corbett, architect of Radio-City, declared yesterday in a public. lecture at Columbia University.

Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion, who remained confined to his cabin during the crossing from New York, was still in bed when the Bremen called here this morning. He stated that his condition was gradually improving,

Joseph R. Harker, president emeritus of MacMurray College for Women, died at his home here this afternoon at the age of 85. Dr. Harker rose from coal miner to college president. He came to America from England with his parents in 1872 and began work in the mines of Duquoin in Perry County.
Carl F, Muller and E. B. Schryver have proposed the formation of a new New York Stock Exchange firm, to be known as Muller Schryver, opening for business on July 22.
Shipping interests reported today that traffic on the Great Lakes was increasing and that three of the four boats tied up here three weeks ago had returned to service.
James Roosevelt, son and secretary of President Roosevelt, said in a statement today that Collier's Magazine will publish next month his "factual account" of his insurance activities.

In its twelfth expansion move since its opening in September, 1929, Mays, apparel store on Fulton Street, Brooklyn, has leased three additional floors comprising 74,000 square feet of space adjoining its present quarters on the Livingston Street side.

A serious tie-up within a few days in the distribution of milk in New York was threatened by independent retail grocers yesterday after their second unsuccessful effort to get milk dealers and union milk truck men to change a clause in their contract that prohibits the men from delivering ice given to grocers as concessions.

Following a preview last night of "The Affairs of Annabel," a satire about picture-making, RKO today announced a series involving a temperamental motion picture star and her press agent with Lucille Ball and Jack Oakie continuing in their original roles. Olive Cooper has been assigned to the script of "Annabel Takes a Tour," which Lou Lustie will produce and Ben Stoloff will direct.
Anthony Chebatrois was hanged by the Federal Government this morning and became the first victim of capital punishment to die in Michigan in 108 years.

MANHATTAN BALL, JAMES (July 1). Estate, less than $5,000. To John F. O'Neill, friend, executor, 40 Southard Ave., Rockville Center, L. I. BANZER, AMELIA (June 30). Estate, $4,300. To Augusta B. Tackella, daughter, executrix, 5 Woodland Dr., Tenafly, N. J.

By invitation of Pelham St. George Bissell, President Justice of the Municipal Courts, sixty-one attorneys assisting the Municipal Courts system as arbitrators, began yesterday a concerted effort to clear up Brooklyn's court calendar, a year behind schedule.

A large multi-family house in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn changed hands in one of the realty deals in that borough reported yesterday. Front Equities, Inc., sold to Brymore Realty Corporation the sixstory building for ninety-two families at 3,115 Brighton Sixth Street
Pat Houdini, 25-year-old parrot and former stage companion of Harry Houdini, emulated his dead master today by picking the lock to his cage and disappearing into the Hollywood hills.

Mike Jacobs, promoter for the b Twentieth Century Sporting Club, yesterday make a final offer to Gus Greenlee, manager of John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion, for a title fight between Lewis and Tiger Jack Fox.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has rewritten its rules under the Public Utility Holding Company Act so that persons, other than regular employes, who represent holding companies-or their subsidiaries before any Congressional committee or member thereof, or before the Federal Power Commission or the SEC or any member or employee of these commissions, must file statements concerning their activities, compensation and expenses within ten days after such appearance.
Daniel J. Doherty, national commander of the American Legion, has accepted an invitation to deliver an address on July 21 at Teachers College, Columbia University, the Legion announced yesterday.

They paid off on a horse that finished eighth at Arlington Park today. It occurred in the final race and brought glee and consternation as well to those holding tickets on Martin Barton and Merry Pete.
Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurnwan Jr. has taken steps to enforce the policy outlined by Mayor La Guardia May 28, when he assailed the practice of city employes holding private jobs.

Members of the American Press Society, national organization of professional newspaper workers, employed in the New York metropolitan area, at a luncheon meeting yesterday in the Town Hall Club; 123 West Forty-third Street, formed the second local section of their society.

Patrolman John R. Toomb, who has been missing from his station and from his home at 5 West Sixtythird Street since June 11, yesterday was dismissed from the force by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, the 222d policeman to lose his job on charges since Mr. Valentine took office in September, 1934.
The eighth annual Westchester Country Club Horse Show opened today on the polo field here. It will be continued through Sunday under the chairmanship of Mrs. Reed A. Albee.

Mrs. Elise Woodruff Dix, daughter of General I. C. Woodruff, died today after a long illness in her home at the age of 94. She was descended from Thomas Mayhew, patentee of Martha's Vineyard and the Elizabeth Isles. She married George Woodward Dix, a descendant of Leonard Dix, who came to the Massachusetts Colony in 1630.

Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet continued before a Ministerial council again today his account of the patching and mending of the international situation that is his everyday job as incident after incident breaks out, threatening peace from the Pacific to the Pyrenees.

Members of the Constitutional Convention Committee on Legislative Organization are still at odds over the reapportionment of legislative districts, soon to become a leading topic before the convention, but they appeared more hopeful today of being able to present before the deadline Tuesday some measure to serve as a basis of discussion.
James Lawrence Kellogg, Professor Emeritus of the Department of Biology at Williams College and an authority on shellfish, died thi afternoon at his home in Williamstown. He was 71 years old.
Announcement is made of the establishment in New York of a new publishing firm known as the Alliance Book Corporation. Its offices are located in the premises of Longmans, Green, 114 Fifth Avenue.

Prices of leading stocks held yesterday below Thursday's closing levels throughout the session and finished with net losses of fractions to about 2 points. The day's business on the Stock Exchange amounted to 1,566,000 shares, compared with 2,775,000 the day before.
Gold imports amounted to $11,161,724 last week. The week before, the total was $2,827,000. The Department of Commerce said today that of last week's imports, $7,680,000 came from Sweden.

Professor Joseph William Hewitt, a member of the Wesleyan University faculty since 1905, dean of freshmen from 1925 until his retirement last month and Professor of Greek Language and Literature since 1929, died today of a heart attack at the age of 62.

A conference between negotiators of. the National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute, Inc., formerly the American Steamship Owners Association, has been arranged for Tuesday morning at 11 o'clock, it was announced yesterday.
Outboard motor boat racers tuned their engines and sent their frail craft skipping over Seneca Lake in practice runs today for the annual New York State championship tomorrow and Sunday.

After two days of bickering, spokesmen for the New York State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance and the State Budget Bureau finally arrived at a compromise agreement here today on what they feel will be an adequate budget

Proposed trade practice rules for the infants' and children's knitted outerwear industry were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission, which set July 26 for a hearing at which suggestions and objections will be heard.

An attempt by one hundred members of the-Workers Alliance to convert the home relief office at 552 West Fifty-third Street into. a hall to air grievances against the relief administration was broken up by the police shortly after noon yesterday. Seven persons were arrested.

Sentences of fifteen to thirty years each in State prison were imposed by General Sessions Judge Bohan yesterday on two men for separate hold-ups last May. Thomas Washington, 43 years old, a Negro, beat Mrs. Elsea Johnson when he robbed her of $15 in her stationery store at 2,461 Second Avenue.

Vince Dell'Orto, Italian featherweight, scored an easy victory over Jose Santos of Portugal in the main bout of eight rounds last night at the Coney Island Velodrome before a crowd of 4,000. The loser was a substitute for Young Jack Sharkey, who was unable to appear because of a badly cut eye. The victor weighed 128 pounds, his rival 127 3/4.

Announcement was made here today that the Tennessee Electric Power Company had refused the offer made yesterday by the Chattanooga Electric Power Board to buy cars, the local transmission system of the Railr utility company for $6,200,000.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In view of the fact -that the major league baseball clubs (except Brooklyn, of course) spend so much money for new players and new equipment, it seems quite puzzling that. some of it isn't laid out to make all the walls of the ball parks a regulation and equal distance from home plate.
The only thing that could be said about the Yankees today as they bowed to the Red Sox at Fenway Park was that they went down fighting.
Charles Barnes Dodds, former Washington correspondent for several West Coast newspapers, died. today in Greenwich Hospital at the age of 51.

The Netherlands pavilion and exhibits at the World's Fair will have many reminders of the part played by that country in the early history of New York, besides showing the nation's cultural and economic history and development, Dr. Neil Van Aken, secretary of The Netherlands Participation Commission of the World's Fair, said yesterday.

Claims that the occupation of Austria is a "peaceful" process or that the humiliations inflicted on the Jews were excesses of irresponsible Nazis during the first few days of the new regime fall to the ground before a series of articles by Vincent Sheean in The
The Bermuda Assembly decided today to send a delegation to the British Embassy in Washington to take up with the United States Government the question of "hotel ships."

The city of Fort Wayne, Ind., has sold at auction- to Stifel, Nicolaus Co., Inc., $3,000,000 of sewer revenue bonds at a price of 100.616 for 3 1/2s. The bonds will be dated Aug. 1, 1938, and will mature serially from Aug. 1, 1941 to 1968. City officials had rejected sealed bids submitted and then decided to sell the bonds at auction.

Although it is only a short distance from the Equator, three Indians were frozen to death and many cattle have been killed by an unprecedented cold wave in the Province of Canar, where the mountains are sheathed in ice.

Canadian marksmen broke into the prize lists of the Empire meeting of the National Rifle Association today, but first place in great competitions was still beyond their grasp. With general shooting excellent despite miserable weather conditions, four marksmen recorded perfeet scores of 50 points in the Conan Doyle Challenge Statuette Match at 500 yards.

Tammany leaders in two Senatorial districts - have decided to drop two of Manhattan's Democration Senators, it was learned yesterday. They are Thomas F. Burchill of the Thirteenth District, who has been in the State Senate since 1925, and Duncan T. O'Brien of the Nineteenth District, who has been in the Senate since 1923.

THERE was no sign of Manager Casey Stengel around the temporary hive in which the Bees were housed. Coach Mike Kelly scratched his sorrel thatch reflectively and said he thought Casey might be off somewhere trying to get a license as a Red Cross nurse.

A ten-month job of repaving more than 300,000 square feet of roadway on the upper level-of Queensboro Bridge and approaches began yesterday, the New York office of the Works Progress Administration announced, with 100 men on the job.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for July 26 on applications by the New York Curb Exchange to obtain unlisted trading in three bond or debenture issues now traded only over the counter and one, the 5 per cent gold. bonds due Jan. 1, 1961, of Associted Electric Company, which is registered and listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

Miss Kiikare, 4-year-old gray mare bred in Tennessee carried off two blue ribbons during the first day of the eighth annual horse show on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club today. The little mare-she stands only 14.3 hands in her show plates- was making her debut in the horse show ring.
One of the private boats returning to Brielle, N. J., yesterday came in with a catch of thirty small bluefish taken in the inlet. The blues averaged between two and three pounds.

Secretary Perkins, who has had her hand in many questionnaires, tells in London of one notable interrogation that received no vocal or written answer. Some Britisher asked her if Mr. Roosevelt intended to run for a third term. She didn't know.
The case for and against expropriation of American oil properties in Mexico was fought out here today, but not to a decision, before the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs.

The perennial arrest of Jacob Telent, 42 years old, of 132 Sherman Avenue, who operates a stationery store at 143 Sherman Avenue, had its familiar outcome yesterday when he paid a fine of $10 after being found guilty before Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Washington Heights Court of selling fireworks for the Fourth of July.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There has been a lessening in the volume of business done in the wool market this week, although there continues to be a fair turnover all along the line.

James F. O'Hea of 320 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, general commercial supervisor of the Long Island area for the New York Telephone Company, died Thursday night of a hemorrhage of the throat in South Norwalk, Conn., where he had his Summer home. He was 61 years old.

Calgary stampede entry records were shattered to day when J. M. Dillon, arena director, announced tht 636 cowboys from Canada and the United States had entered the championship contests. "And more are expected," he said. The previous record was 600.
Washington beat Philadelphia, 11 to 0, today behind the seven-hit pitching of Harry Kelley. It was the second shutout Kelley has pitched since the Senators took him off the Athletics' payroll.
Manhattan ADLER, FREDERICA M. (Feb. 22, 1938). Gross assets, $441,843; net, $408,334. To Morton L. Adler, husband. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $355,970. Max J. Fink, attorney, 60 E. 42d St.
Dr. Harriet E. Buster of Mount Vernon, an osteopath, died here today in the home of a sister, Dr. Fanny M. Rosch. She was the widow of Dr. Willi L. Buster, an osteopath in Mount Vernon and New York.

A legal battle which began before the primary election in May came to a climax today when Judge Paul N. Schaeffer announced that he had decided in favor of a grand jury investigation of the Earle administration. He revealed that the "actual prosecutor" would be District Attorney Carl B. Shelley of Dauphin County.

Six adventurers, their food supply almost exhausted, came to this hamlet today, victors over 300 turbulent miles of the Colorado River. Two women botanists and four men rested here tonight, sleeping in beds for the first time after
The United States, including Alaska, now-has 2,364 airports and landing fields, of which 715 are partly or fully lighted for night use, the Bureau of Air Commerce reported today.

Sabin Pond Sanger, former member of the Boston brokerage firm of Curtis ' Sanger and coxswain of two Harvard crews which won over Yale in 1882 and 188; died early today at his home in Brookline. His age was 76.

Four employes of the World's Fair were injured early yesterday afternoon in helping to fight a fire, the first at the fair, which ruined a one-story, temporary, wooden warehouse and destroyed literature, office supplies and furniture. Damage was estimated at more than $8,000. The cause was undetermined.

Tchaikovsky's ever-popular "Pathetic" symphony was the chief offering on the program conducted by Jose Iturbi at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the Lewisohn Stadium. The symphony was preceded by Schubert's overture to "Rosamunde" and followed by Richard Strauss's "Don Juan" and that composer's waltzes from "Rosenkavalier."
Realty activity in Manhattan was featured yesterday by two deals in which the Central Savings Bank disposed of holdings in the downtown and Washington Heights sections.

Mrs. Irene Jelis, one of James C. Sheridan's stanchest supporters in the Queens Democratic organization, announced yesterday that she and ten other members of the organization's executive committee were quitting the Sheridan faction, a move that is expected to strengthen the leadership of James A. Roe, who was recently elected by halt a vote.

Loew's, Inc., shows a net profit of $8,352,675 after expenses, subsidiaries' preferred dividends, depreciation and taxes, according to the earnings statement for the forty weeks ended on June 9, made public today.

Cotton growers planted this year an acreage not only below the farm program allotment for 1938 by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, but the smallest total since the Department of Agriculture began keeping records in 1909.

The marriage of Miss Marion Cunningham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Cunningham of Evansville, Ind., to Seymour Beach Conger 3d, son of Mrs. Seymour B. Conger of Ann Arbor, Mich., and the late Mr. Conger, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Postmaster General Farley spent forty minutes at the Democratic State convention today and endorsed F. Ryan Duffy for re-election to the Senate, but brought no message from President Roosevelt in behalf of either Mr. Duffy or the State ticket.

In its plea to Mayor La Guardia for a resumption of the practice of granting partial tax exemption to encourage the erection of limiteddividend apartment houses, the State Board of Housing expresses concern over the fact that no new projects in this classification have been started since the local law granting such exemptions expired at the end of 1936.

Activity marked the livestock trade In all branches at Chicago this week. Lambs closed lower but still supplies were moderate and there was a good trade locally, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 7. MAJOR GENERALS Conner, F., two months and fifteen days leave, July 15. Mauborgne, J. O., the Chief Signal Officer, twenty-one days leave, July 11.

Howard R. Hughes, sportsman pilot who is preparing his plane at Floyd Bennett Field for a flight to Paris, will take off at 5 P. M. today if results of a test flight, to be taken this morning, prove successful it was disclosed yesterday.
Flying 4,300 miles from England to Egypt without a stop in thirty two hours, four Royal Air Force Vickers Wellesley bombing planes today captured the world record for long-distance formation flight.
The Federation Bank and Trust Company reported for June 30 deposits of $10,118,725 and total assets of $12,364,720, compared, respectively, with $10,786,221 and $12,984,832 on March 31.

Combination of all elements in the electorate opposed to the New Deal, with the nomination of former Governor Alfred E. Smith for United States Senator on a joint Republican and independent Democratic ticket,...

Trading by members in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 11 represented 20.50 per cent of the total volume, compared with 21.38 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The Standard Oil Company of Venezuela has exercised an option to develop and market the oil from the concession in Venezuela of the Pantapec Oil Company of Venezuela, W. F. Buckley, president of the latter company, announced yesterday.
A barrage of home runs brought to a climax by Billy Myers's tenth-inning smash enabled the Reds to defeat the Cubs, 7 to 6, and end a six-game losing streak today.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur de Sola Mendes of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cara de Sola-Mendes, to Lewis M. Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Rosenthal of Raleigh, N. C.

Reginald A. Whitcombe, youngest of three great golfing brothers, won the British open golf championship today with a 72-hole score of 295. Jim Adams was second with 297 and Henry Cotton, last year's champion, third with 298. No one else finished under 300.

Governor N. G. Kraschel tonight invoked arbitration as provided by Iowa law in what he called "one final attempt" to settle the twomonths-old labor dispute at the plant of the Maytag company in Newton.

A judgment for $2,609,365 obtained in January by the Chase National Bank against Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation, has been satisfied, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of a satisfaction of judgment in the County Clerk's office.
Rear Admiral David Potter, U. S. N., and Mrs. Potter, of Washington are at the Vanderbilt. Mrs. Van Wie Willys and Mrs. Marjorie Oelrichs have sailed for Europe, where they will remain until October.

Department store sales during the week ended July 2 were 10 per cent lower than in the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. For the four weeks ended July 2 the sales were 11 per cent lower than- for the comparable period in 1937.

Michael Alex was found guilty of first-degree murder by a General Sessions jury at 7:30 o'clock last night in the hold-up shooting of Jack Ehrlich, an insurance collector, in a Harlem tenement hallway on Dec. 18.
The Indians regained an undisputed grip on first place in the American League race today by beating the Browns, 8 to 7, in ten innings, while the Yankees were, losing at Boston.
New Orleans police answered threats of C. I. O. violence against raiding officers today by arresting eighty or more persons at labor headquarters.
The three apartment buildings with stores at 235-45 Wolfs Lane and 651 Third Street, Pelham, which recently were sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to the Pelham Management Corporation,

There will be two major closings tonight. "The Women," which had threatened to close earlier in the Summer, finally finishes its run at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre with a record of 657 performances. A tour next season is planned.

The Berkshire Garden Center at Stockbridge gave a midsummer festival this afternoon. The hostesses were Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs, Mrs. John Barry Ryan, Mrs. George O. Forbes, Mrs. Henry W. Dwight and the Misses Marian Hague and Edith H. Tracy.

AS we were saying yesterday--to take literally for once Fray Luis de Leon's immortal remark--here are some further memoirs of books published between the first ot March and Independence Day that stand out in your reviewer's mind for a variety of excellences. And again, the order of mention has only the significance of chance.

Between 7,000 and 8,000 clothing workers in this city have been called back to work by manufacturers who count on the WPA's intended purchase of $10,000,000 worth of men's and boys' clothing to clear their shelves of surplus stock, Louis Hollander, City Councilman and manager of the joint board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, reported yesterday.

Sales of General Motors cars in June to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, totaled 101,908, compared with 203,139 in June a year ago. Sales in May were 104,115.

The first of three delegations of American athletes that will compete in Europe this Summer set sail last night aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa on the first lap of a tour that will carry the squad of eight through Sweden and thence to Berlin where they will combine with the two other groups in a dual meet against Germany.

George C. Meyer, president of the Cord Meyer Development Company of Forest Hills, was elected yesterday a director of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company at the annual meeting of stockholders held in Long Island City.

Confedrate veterans were so favorably impressed with the reunion at Gettysburg that they wanted to remain there forever, according to a telegram from William W. Banks; who was a member of Company H of the Eighteenth Alabama Infantry, to Major Gen. Henry Gibbins, executive officer of the Federal Commission having charge of the reunion.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Sister M. Mercedes, C. A. S., of St. Mary's Springs Academy, an artist, died today at St. Agnes Hospitar at the age of 68. She had been in charge of the art department of St. Mary's Springs Academy.

Dr. Gilbert Whitney Campbell, head of the Department of Philosophy and Education at Alfred University since 1924 and director of teacher training at the university, died tonight of a heart attack at his home in Alfred at the age of 54. He also had been pastor of the university church in that village.
Louis Ochs, retired business man, died today at 10 A. M. at the Brown Hotel here, where he made his home. His age was 74.
The Treasury has spent about half of the proceeds of the desterilization of $1,400,000,000 gold which took place last April, it appears from the figures of the Federal Reserve statements.
Miss Margaret Cecilia Hamill of 300 Varick Street, principal of Public School 2 here and sister of Corporation Counsel James A. Hamill, died today at her home after a long illness at the age of 69.

Wheat futures in North American markets were erratic today. They declined around 6 cent a bushel in the early trading in sympathy with the decline in securities, but the offerings were absorbed by houses with Eastern ash and mill connections and a rally of about 11 1/2 cents followed with the close on the Board of rade here showing net gains of 1/2 to 3/4 cent.

The Court of Appeals has removed obstacles that threatened to delay work on three parts of the West Branch-Kensico tunnel of the Delaware Aqueduct, which is part of the new water supply system for New York City.

Following the similar Washington announcement of David Lasser, national president, Sam Wiseman, executive secretary of the Workers Alliance of Greater New York. announced yesterday that the alliance not only would enter the State campaign "with both feet" but hoped to have some of its leaders nominated as candidates.

Penitentiary terms up to three years each were imposed yesterday by Judge Bohan in General Sessions Court upon Dean E. Wheeler, ex-convict, a former student of DePauw University, and his wife Anne, a former Chicago night-club hostess.

George L. Christie. in 1,021 Park Ave; Edna Hill, through Fred F. French Co., in 1,160 5th Ave; Mrs. Margaret A. G. Lee, in 311 E 72d St; Frederick Campbell, in 321 E 54th St; Dr. Robert Eisler, in 158 W 58th St; Leon Well, in 898 West End Ave; Julia Todd, In 165 W 72d St;

Donald M. Nelson, vice president of Sears, Roebuck Co., is willing to accept the post of Administrator of the Wages and Hours Law, according to report, but has delayed forwarding his acceptance to President Roosevelt until some adjustments within his organization are completed.
A few persons are talking of the possibility of a "false recovery" between now and October similar to the "false recovery" from April to July, 1933, when the NRA codes went into effect.
Eamon de Valera and members of his government gave a state banquet in Dublin Castle tonight in honor of Joseph Patrick Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Great Britain.
Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, Conn., and Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York will meet in the final of the women's Middle States tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club tomorrow.

Ray Billows missed a two-foot putt, a tie for the course record and an undisputed lead in the Sweetser Victory tournament in the same motion today. The two-time winner of this twelve-year-old golfing show finished the first thirty-six holes of the seventy-two-hole medal play in a tie with Mark Stuart at 147.

The reassurance to be found in religious faith will be the keynote in many sermons to be preached tomorrow in the city's pulpits. The importance of mutual understanding among churchgoers will also be stressed.

The War Department said today that various suggestions for getting around the hump of World. War days in the promotion of officers have been under consideration but no plan adopted, and in no event would there be drastic action.

172d St (11-2835) n w cor of Grand Concourse, 184x141, 831 Gerard Ave. Realty Corp to Sun Rise Realty Corp, 50 Broad St. Throop Ave, 3,217 (16-4618) Seymour J. Wilner to Home Owners Loan Corp. Brook Ave (11-2893) w s, 130 ft n of 169th St. 27x90, Sophie Swarts to Abe Roth, 1,181 Grant Ave, mgt $7,300.

Factory sales of passenger cars and trucks in June were estimated I yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association at 184,400 units, bringing the six months' total to 1,301,033, or 55 per cent under the 1937 total for the same period.

The four-masted barkentine Almirante Saldanha, training ship of the Brazilian Navy, stood into New York Harbor yesterday afternoon and moored late last night to Pier 99, foot of West Fifty-ninth Street, for an eight-day stay.

Miss Anne Howard Caparn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold ap Rhys Caparn of 20 Gramercy Park, will be married today to Robert MacDonald Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore of Elizabeth, N. J., and Thetford, Vt.- The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Leslie W. Hodder of Norwich, Vt., at the Vermont home of Mr. Moore's parents.
Chinese planes bombed Japanese warships in the Yangtze and Japanese airfields along the river today in five separate raids, reportedly with much success.
Miss Evelina du Pont, one of the oldest members of the du Pont family, died today at her home, Lyndham, at Greenville, after a short S illness, at the age of 98.

Three young thugs, all armed, invaded Abbott's Bakery, Inc., which occupies a two-story building, including a baking plant, at 236 Eighth Avenue, at Twenty-second Street, yesterday noon and after binding six employes and the manager with wire, escaped with a $3,000 payroll.
The principal foreign exchanges recovered yesterday from the weakness they had shown earlier in the week. The movement was irregular, however, and not all exchanges joined in the advance.

The Tigers and White Sox battled through twenty innings of baseball to an even break in a double-header today, the Bengals taking the opener, 7 to 5, in regulation distance and losing the nightcap, 5 to 3, in eleven innings.
Bolivia and Paraguay early today initialed an agreement to submit to arbitration their 100-year-old quarrel over the Gran Chaco.

Professor E. V. Appleton, Cambridge physicist, and his collaborator, K. Weekes, report in the current issue of the scientific publication Nature that by using radio signals timed to 1-100,000 of a second they succeeded in establihing the existence of tides in the upper air.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving entertained with a dinner tonight at the Port of Missing Men, their home at North Sea, for members of their' week-end house party, Mr. and Mrs. Vadim S. Makaroff, whose marriage took place recently; Mr. and Mrs. Paul Abbott, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Gould and Robert Jennings.

The urchins scampered about the street, the elevated tried without success to drown out the strident hawking of the puchcart peddlers and the housewives made purchases as usual yesterday as Paddy's Market over on Ninth Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Forty-second Streets literally laughed in the face of its death knell.

Mr. and Mrs. Warren Anderson Zelius of this city have announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Smith Zelius, to Paul Winter Brakeley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brakeley of Plainfield N. J.

Miss Rose Dexter of Boston entertained with a luncheon at Old Farm today for Mrs. Stephen Weld. Other guests included Mrs. D. Crawford Clark and Miss Gertrude Sampson of New York and Mrs. S. Bartram Richards, Mrs. Montgomery Wilcox and Miss Mary Roberts Coles of Philadelphia.

Long before 1788 there were white men here, white men, to use a biblical phrase, "spying out this land of Canaan." An intrepid outpost breed they werethe scouts and skirmishers of the great American migration. The sight of smoke from neighbors' chimneys might have worried them. But Indians and redcoats did not.

Shareholders of the National Power and Light Company, at a special meeting yesterday, approved the sale of the electric properties of the Tennessee Public Service Company, a subsidiary of National Power and Light, serving Knoxville, to the Tennessee Valley Authority and the city of Knoxville.

In a statement of policy following their election as the chief officers of the new Real Estate Taxpayers Federation, Inc., Herbert L. Carpenter and Colonel I. Pearson Hoover yesterday emphasized the need for restriction on municipal spending and protection for the home owner against tax increases.

Hugh A. Stone, 33 years old, and Donald Amey Jr., 23, both of Stewartsville, N. J., were drowned in the Delaware River ten miles north of here today when their rowboat was upset as they tried to exchange seats in the middle of the stream.

The William Sloane House, the property of the Y. M. C. A., and the Christodora House in New York City are exempt from taxation, the Court of Appeals has ruled in affirming an order of the Special Term.
Announcement of most of the personnel of the new Civil Aeronautics Authority by President Roosevelt brings a step nearer a new and, it is to be hoped, a happier day for American aviation.
Pensioned On their own applications: to take effect 12 midnight, July 7: LIEUTENANT-Thomas C. Dezell, Quartermaster's Department. at $2,000 per annum. Appointed June 13. 1901.

Maria Petit Jean Beckers-"The Widow Beckers of Liege"-was convicted today and sentenced to death for eleven poison murders in Belgium's most bizarre criminal case of modern times. She is 58 years old.
Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg proposed today that government officials be required to make public the amount of income they derive from market transactions, personal holdings or private services.

The battle on the Chicago Board of Trade over the "to arrive" or "call" rule was not settled by the overwhelming vote of members on Thursday to retain the forty-two-year-old regulation, grain men said today.

The annual vacation program at Silver Bay on Lake George under the auspices of the Silver Bay Association will begin Monday. The association is operated on a non-profit basis under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Mario Narizzano of Kensington, Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Narizzano, to John Chandler Moore 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis de Bebian Moore of 800 Park Avenue and Oyster Bay, L. I.

Secretary Ickes denied again today that participation by San Francisco in PWA's recovery program was contingent upon abandonment by the city of its right to appeal from a Federal court ruling in the Hetch Hetchy power litigation.

Ward's Automotive Reports, estimating this week's assemblies of motor vehicles at 25,375 units, said today that production continued "well below retail deliveries" and that used car stocks were showing "signs of serious depletion in many metropolitan areas."

Melchior Grohe Millinery, Inc. store in 55 E 55th St; Pease Elliman, Inc, brokers. Aremac Camera, Inc, optical goods and cameras, store in 521 5th Ave; Mark Byron Jr., publicity, in 25 W 43d St; Frank T. D'Onofrio, real estate, in 551 5th Ave; Munson G. Shaw Co, wholesale wines and liquors, in 400 Madison Ave; Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

A decided swing toward the three-button jacket in Fall suits for college men was indicated in the current report of the national style committee of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, made public today.

A bitter fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor was foreshadowed today as a result of former Governor Curley's announcement of his candidacy. in the announcement he charged that Governor Hurley had "betrayed" President Roosevelt.

John Humphrey Merrick, retired Boston lawyer, who was secretary to Police Commissioner Herbert G. Wilson from 1922 to 1930 and who had been a member of the law firm of Stuart, Coolidge Rand, died today at his home, 671 Washington Street, Dorchester.

Playing for the first time in Shibe Park, Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers today backed Vito Tamulis's good pitching with a fifteen-hit assault on four Philly pitchers and won the opening engagement going away by 13-2.
Paul K. Ames, retired corporation lawyer and one of the founders of- the Nassan County, N. Y., Bar Association, died today at his Summer home here after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

Is it unethical or ridiculous for a group of disinterested private citizens to get together for the discussion of public questions, hire experts to collect facts, and, finally, offer their advice for what it is worth to public agencies? Off-hand one wouldn't say so.

The appeal of William Hayett of New York, N. Y., to the State Education Department for appointment as a teacher as of April 25 last was dismissed today by Commissioner Frank P. Graves. Mr. Hayett sought to have the Board of Education appoint him as a teacher of English in Junior High School 171.

The hitherto indissoluble partnership between the Catholic Church and the State in Austria was in effect dissolved today when Chancellor. Adolf Hitler proclaimed a new uniform marriage and divorce law for all Great Germany that takes legal .jurisdiction over marriage and divorce out of the hands of the churches in Austria and places it in the hands of the State.

Rain played havoc with the English County cricket championship matches scheduled to end today. Two out of seven matches were finished, while the remainder will not count in the championship table as the contending teams failed to complete one innings each.

Bravo, bay horse owned by George F. Benham of Cedarhurst, N. -Y., and cleverly guided by Harry Whitney, swept to a straight-heat victory in the $1,000 Devereaux-Harvey 17 class trot, which topped the fifth day of Grand Circuit competition at the North Randall track today.
Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont today scored an 85 over the Rockaway River Country Club course to win the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament.

A setback in Wall Street prices and week-end clearing-up of commitments were responsible for the easier tendency that prevailed today in the stock markets here. Gilt-edge issues were uncertain, while foreign bonds remained idle. Transatlantic shares were weak, United States Steel and International Nickel sagging.

C. L. Hunter, chairman of the passenger department of the Trunk Line Association, -announced yesterday that the rate of 2.5 cents a -mile for coach travel in the East, approved this week by the Interstate Commerce Commission, would take effect on July 25.
More than $6,000,000 of group life insurance is provided for about 4,700 employes of the American Sugar Refining Company and its domestic subsidiaries, J. F. Abbott, president, announced yesterday.

Starting at 8 o'clock tonight off Execution Lighthouse, the fleet of sailing yachts in the New York Athletic Club's thirty-third annual Block Island race had a light southeast breeze with which to begin their course of one hundred miles through Long Island and Block Island Sounds.

A private residence in Hoboken, N. J., will be converted into a threefamily apartment house as the result of a deal announced yesterday. The three-story dwelling at 721 Bloomfield Street was sold by the Children's Home of Jersey City and the Home for Aged Women in Jersey City to Paul Adamo, who will effect the alterations.

A parade of 500 bicycles headed by old-fashioned wheels and an exhibition of trick cycling will feature the opening at 11 o'clock this morning of the Park Department's two and one-half mile public cycle path in Queens. The path was made out of the abandoned Motor Parkway between Horace Harding Boulevard and Alley Pond Park.
Alfred Rosenberg, who edits Hitler's personal news paper and shares with Joseph Goebbels the post of supreme Nazi philosopher, recommends Madagascar as a home for German and Austrian Jews.

Fifty-one Girl Scouts from fourteen States and Mexico are enjoying the season at Camp Andree, the national camp near Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., which opened on July 1 with two innovations on the program.

The Polish Commissioner here today requested the Free City authorities to remove the German military flag from the Landespolizei barracks. In the barracks are members of one of the many semi-military organizations flourishing here under the Nazi regime.
Young Bob Klinger jinxed the Cardinals for the fourth time today as his

Money in circulation on June 30 was $6,461,058,390, or $49.67 per capital, which was $6,169,501 less than at the end of May and $14,001,943 more than on June 30, 1937, the Treasury reported today. The following table, showing the classifications of currency and comparisons with earlier periods, was made public by the Treasury:

The National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers reported today that the upward trend of the stock market during the latter part of June failed to reflect itself immediately in increased sales among men's wear stores.

MINERS and prospectors working in the Yellowknife gold district north of Great Slave Lake in the Northwest Territories will soon be able to go to motion-picture theatres, if plans of some theatrical companies materialize.
SYDNEY, N. S. W. DAWN over Port Jackson, a slow drizzle wetting the white hulk of the Nieuw-Zeeland as she drew into harbor past hidden bastions and batteries,

Miss Nancy Jane Easley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Albert Easley of this place, was married here this afternoon in St. Peter's Church to John Eliot Larkin of New York, son of Mrs. William H. Larkin of Arlington, Mass., and the late Mr. Larkin.

More than 5,000 buyers of housewares are expected here this week to attend the annual opening of Fall lines of china and glassware, kitchen utensils, electrical appliances, bathroom accessories and other types of merchandise produced by members of the New York Housewares Manufacturers Association, sponsors of the event.

Senator Robert J. Bulkley said today that he did not consider friendly remarks directed toward him by President Roosevelt as a "public endorsement;" but George White, former Governor, opponent of Mr. Bulkley in the Democratic Senatorial primary, remarked that they didn'tt do any harm."
Death of Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court further complicated tonight New York State's somewhat beclouded political picture.

Higher rentals and a better occupancy record are expected to increase to $366,000 collections this year in the Buchanan Apartments, at Third Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, according to Henry Weiner, trustee.

Dr. John H. Young of Montclair drove his Watson Hanover to a sparkling victory in the Class A event, the outstanding triumph -of the weekly matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

Two police radio cars, speeding to the scene of a stabbing, collided at Bushwick and Johnson Avenues, Brooklyn, last night, killing one policeman, injuring three others and a civilian, and causing more than an hour of excitement in the congested neighborhood near the accident.

Eric Lundberg, dealer in rare books, has moved his business from New York City to a century-and-a-half-old farmhouse here. He says that one of the reasons he ias made this change is that there are many valuable old books hidden away- in Vermont attics.
Governor Lehman reviewed tonight a parade of 2,000 ex-servicemen, closing the annual two-day convention here of the Westchester County American Legion.

First of the Eastern light-harness meetings in the sixty-fifth series of the Grand Circuit will open Tuesday at the century-old Historic Track in Goshen, N. Y., to continue through Friday, with Saturday being held in reserve in the event of postponements due to unfavorable weather.

The first Federal prosecution of theatre ticket brokers on a felony charge resulted yesterday in a verdict of guilty by a jury before Federal Judge John C. Knox against the Leo Newman Theatre Ticket Office, Inc.,
Chief Deputy Sheriff J. G. Bullington said tonight a Negro named John Dukes, 60, shot and killed Marshal F. O. Epps, 60, of near-by Arabi today and was later lynched by an enraged mob.

A DRIVE against unemployment in the metropolitan area will begin tomorrow when the New York State Employment Service of the State Labor Department enlists with WNYC for a daily five-minute broadcast planned to be of service to job-seekers and employers.

SOUTHAMPTON.--Plans are going forward rapidly for the thirty - first annual flower show, under the, joint auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society, to be held on July 27 and 28 in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

On the basis of the small-home mortgage-loan business handled by the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association during May and June, when $214,468 was invested, Dr. Herman L. Reis, president, sees a definite advance in this type of building in the metropolitan area.

Royalty rode a baggage elevator yesterday when Crown Prince Gusaf Adolf of Sweden, leaving New York for a ten-day trip to Boston, Washington and Midwestern cities, descended into the Grand Central Station on a scarred and battered lift marked:

A new service, which recently has become available, now makes it possible for home owners of even modest means to employ experts in planning-their gardens and home grounds. Landscape architects, beCause: of the high fees which their profession commands, are often beyond the reach of the moderate pocketbook.
Two national A. A. U. champions were eliminated yesterday in the quarter-final round of the annual metropolitan A. A. U. one-wall singles handball championships at Ostend Beach, Far Rockaway.

Continuing her winning ways, Heather Time stood off the tremendous stretch drive of Charlotte Girl today to capture the $10,000 added Mayflower Stakes, feature race of the closing day bill at Suffolk Downs.
TIME was when an economist could not afford to be funny. Nowadays, he can hardly avoid it. Where so little makes sense, the safest course, perhaps, is to mix in a little honest nonsense.

The American proposal that the intergovernmental refugee committee should covert itself into a permanent body operating independently of the- League of Nations though in cooperation with it now seems for all practical purposes to have cleared its first hurdle. The British and trench delegations, it is understood, accept this much informally in principle.
Star Wagon, Herman Whiton's new six-meter yacht, skippered by her owner, won today's race over a nine and two-thirds mile course off Centre Island in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Club's trial series.

The phrase "Stop-Look-Listen" is a familiar one to nearly everybody. It became so by being printed in large, black letters at the approach to thousands of railroad grade crossings. In 1928 there were about 4,000 such crossings in New York State, and there are about 3,500 of them remaining today.

Edward V. Ketcham Jr. sailed his Draco across the finish line in the lead today to win the first elimination race to choose a boat to represent the Great South Bay fleet in the Atlantic Coast and world's championships of the Star Class. The race was held in conjunction with the G. S. B. Y. R. A. invitation regatta sponsored by the local club. Charles L. Lawrence's Chief was second, about seven minutes behind.

Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, wrote to Senator Vandenberg today that the WPA had nothing to do with the distribution in Kentucky of paper bags labeled "Donated by Friend of Senator Alben W. Barkley," for use in distributing Federal relief supplies.

State officials and army officers today made the first inspection tour over the five-mile by-pass that will eliminate danger points where several motorists have been killed over a period of years by landslides on the Storm King Highway north of West Point.

WASHINGTON.--In ownership of radios, pianos and phonographs, New England villages lead the country, the Bureau of Home Economics has recently revealed. Based on a sample consumer survey of 139 villages widely scattered geographically, the survey shows that three-quarters of the village homes in the United States now own a radio.

Raymond L. Barney, Professor of Biology at Middlebury College, died this morning at the New England Baptist Hospital in Boston following an operation. Professor Barney had been' ill since May. His age was 46.

The police were searching yesterday for a woman who, after sending three of her children to a police station with a note saying that she could no longer care for them, disappeared with two other children.

The Rev. A. Boudreau said last night that conditions in the fishing community of Petit de Grat, Richmond County, were "desperate." The priest declared that the situation was directly traceable to the low prices paid for fish by large companies. Between 2,000 and 3,000 fishermen on the Richmond County coast were facing starvation, he added.

THE Composers' Forum-Laboratory of the WPA Federal Music Project, having completed its third season, has published a sizable brochure of selfcongratulation to which no one who professes an interest in music will deny it the right.

To register sentiment of New York religious-groups in favor of opening wide the doors of Palestine to settlement of refugees from Germany and Austria,. an emergency conference of representatives and rabbis of more than 600 synagogues in Manhattan

Marking a sharp reversal from the NRA "beat-the-price-rise" policy, tentative plans aimed to restrain speculative buying and curb too rapid price advances were studied by leading merchandisers here as the Fall season got actively under way last week.

The recently organized New York Round Table of the National Conference of Jews and Christians will hold its first public meetings next Saturday and Sunday at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Detectives Edward Hepp and William Polistina and a man who was helping them to find a shack used as a cache by poultry market thieves were felled twice by explosions as they approached the hideout this afternoon, but escaped injury.

Hank Greenberg's mighty bat boomed for two homers and a single and Elden Auker gave a four-hit pitching performance as the Tigers shut out the White Sox, 4 to 0, today in the third contest of their four-game series.

Among those scheduled to speak at the real estate owners' mass meeting to be held tomorrow night at Girls High School, Halsey Street and Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, is Herbert L. Carpenter, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on the Removal of Elevated Structures, and chairman of the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation.

A small woolly dog, resembling a ??irty lamb, still stood today--on a ??atched up broken leg-at a sub-way entrance awaiting a master who has not yet returned. The dog began its vigil four days ago. Last night a truck hit it, breaking a leg.
NO Summer recess is planned by the Federal Communications Commission, which, according to Frank R. McNinch, chairman, "will be on hand at all times to transact business."

At least 23,000,000 persons, or more than one in six in the United States, suffer from chronic diseases, orthopedic impairments or serious defects in vision or hearing, the Public Health Service stated today in preparation for the National Health Conference called by the President's Interdepartmental Committee for July 18-20.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Hoyt Holmes of this city and New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Larrabee Holmes, to John Dudley Munger, son of Mrs. Ray E. Munger of Waterbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Munger.

With Kansas so far this Summer enjoying the most livable weather the State has ever known-with ample moisture and not-too-hot temperatures producing a verdant richness that has not been enjoyed since the long drought began-the Alfred M. Landon family, except for Mr. Landon's daughter, Peggy Anne, who is visiting a school girl friend in Buenos Aires, is spending a quiet Summer at its expansive new suburban home near here.

The New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station at New Brunswick is holding a Turf Growers Field Day from 3 to 6 P. M. on Monday, July 18. Home owners, as well as those interested in maintenance of good turf on golf courses, parks and recreation fields, are invited to attend.

The Maritime Commission will hold hearings from Aug. 8 to Aug. 11 for the discussion of new rules relating to the establishment of freight rates and passenger fares under the changed system created by amendments to the Maritime Act passed by the last Congress.
The approach of South Africa's World War Memorial Day, July 17, today unexpectedly stirred the Union's stubborn controversy over two anthems and two flags.

EVENTS at the Stadium this week include the George Gershwin memorial concert tomorrow night; the appearance of Lucie Rosen, who will play the English horn part of Sibelius's "Swan of Tuonela" on the Theremin instrument, and the first and only opera of the season, "Carmen," which will be given Thursday and Friday nights.

Miss Ruth Patricia Jaster, daughter of Mrs. Jean Jaster of Glen Ridge, N. J., and the late Bernard Jaster, was married here this morning in the First Lutheran Church to Robert Andre Lindgren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Lindgren of Caldwell, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the pastor of the church, the Rev. August S. Pearson.
LONDON--England has become acutely conscious of its spinsters. "Pensions for Spinsters at 55" is a Slogan seen and heard all over the country, not excepting the halls of Parliament.

A strike at the city's three sugar refineries, now in its third week, threatened an acute sugar shortage and a price rise today. Striking members of the Sugar Refinery Workers Union, aided by other American Federation of Labor unions, have tied up the entire sugar industry here.
Clinton R. Ferguson of Waban, Mass., piled up 825 points today to take the lead in the annual New York State outboard motor boat championships at the end of the first day's racing.

The five-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 150 feet at the northeast corner of Dyckman Street and Payson Avenue in the Inwood section of Manhattan will be offered at auction Thursday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

The increase in sales of hard liquor during June was due to stocking up to avoid increased Federal taxes which become effective July 1, Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, reported today.
J. Clifford Rosengarten, a lawyer and member of a socially prominent family, died today at his home in Villanova at the age of 64.

MEXICO'S twelve stamps to commemorate the "XVI Congress Internacional de Planificacion y Habitacion" (Sixteenth International Congress of City Planning and Housing), at Mexico City, prove to be unusually attractive.

WELLINGTON, N. Z.--The New Zealand Government wants Walt Disney to turn from grasshoppers, ants and the gambols of the mouse family and line up such strange things as moas, kiwis, katipos and tuataras for one of his screen efforts, it is disclosed here.

Efforts to prolong the life of cut flowers date back to the ancient Romans. They 'discovered that low temperatures could postpone the end. The Japanese gave the West the hint that cutting the stems daily and providing fresh water at intervals kept flowers longer in condition.

Aknusti will endeavor to redeem itself for the 6-4 setback suffered at the hands of the Bostwick Field quartet last week when the two high-goal combinations meet in an exhibition polo match today at Bostwick Field on Jericho Turnpike, Old Westbury, L. I The contest will get under way at 3:30 P. M.

Mr. and Mrs. John B. Trevor of New York are giving a luncheon at their Trevallyn Lodge on the Upper St. Regis Lake next Saturday for members of the board of trustees of the proposed Paul Smith College of Arts and Sciences.

7 the volume of building permits turned upward last month in the Bronx, and Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade, expressed the belief that "even greater activity" will be noted in this borough during the Fall months.

Funds for moving the commanding general and the headquarters staff of the G. H. Q. Air Force from Langley Field. Virginia, to Scott Field, Illinois, were provided today by an allotment of $4,403,400 to the Quartermaster Corps of the army.

The Budget Bureau is preparing an official estimate of what the government's income and spending will be in the fiscal year which began July 1. Officials indicated today that it would be completed in about ten days.

The "solid South" is split over President Roosevelt's proposals for its economic rehabilitation. Of twenty-three Southern United States Senators and Governors who responded to a survey of opinion, eleven gave endorsement to the President's statement last week that the South was the nation's "No. 1 economic problem" and his action in calling a conference to "do something about it."

Tony Galento, training at Madame Bey's for his fight with John Henry Lewis in Philadelphia July 26, knocked out two of his three sparring partners today. It was the first time that Galento had put on the gloves after two weeks at gymnasium work.

The death of Benjamin N. Cardozo, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, caused sincere sor row here, although it had been realized for several weeks by close friends that his condition was serious and that he probably would never return to his official duties.

The Grosse Pointe polo team recently captured the Burns Henry Memoriall. Trophy at the Country Club in Detroit by vanquishing the Hillwood four, 15-8, for its second victory in as many days over the losers.

With the total of insured mortgages running more than $20,000,000 ahead of last year, the Federal Housing Administration set a new high record for loans in this city during the first six months of this year, according to a complete tabulation just prepared by Thomas G. Grace, State Director.

The Mexican Congress is expected to act rapidly upon the Administration bill establishing a 12 per cent export tax, but official circles report that the Treasury Department has dropped its plan to stabilize the peso temporarily.

Announcement of fifteen additions to the faculty and staff of Sarah Lawrence College for the school year 1938-39 was made yesterday. Appointments were made in the fields of social science, science, music, dramatics and literature. The new appointments are:

With several builders and developers announcing yesterday the opening of new sections in their present developments and a number of others reporting a large volume of sales and- construction activities, Long Island appears to be unaffected by the seasonal let down in real estate activity usually experienced at this time of the year.

Both the latest and the most primitive radio equipment was used today in dedicating station WGY's new $300,000 broadcasting studio when Giulio Marconi in Rome exchanged greetings with Dr. E. F. W. Alexanderson, General Electric Company radio consulting engineer.

With the recent Anglo-German trade and financial agreement, Germany started on the final process or cutting down her foreign debts and consolidating the rest at a level compatible both with her willingness to pay as well as her dignity and prestige, which, in the words of her spokesmen, cannot permit German bonds being kicked about at bankruptcy values.

Nineteen weeks of excavating at the Athenian Agora this Spring have yielded a large number of articles casting light on ancient customs, according to reports received today from Dr. T. Leslie Shear, field director of the work and a member of the Art and Archaeology Department of Princeton University.

The Republican members of the committee on legislative organization of the Constitutional Convention, of which E. Duane Bruce of Syracuse is chairman, were reported yesterday to have reached an agreement on a reapportionment plan by which the number of State Senate districts would be increased from 51 to 53 and the number of Assembly districts from 150 to 159.

ONE contemporary method of socializing knowledge is visibly illustrated by the new culture history arrangement of the Brooklyn Museum, comments The Bulletin of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.
More than 200 C. I. O. pickets, who were already under a court injunction against disorder, marched into the court room of Circuit Judge Ralph J. Dady today and expressed their defiance anew.

Professor Casey Stengel was in something of a shaking mood at the Polo Grounds yesterday. He was still shaking with rage over the manner in which his Bees had been whisked out of a ball game the previous afternoon, and so without further ado he shook up his line-up.

George Elder sailed his Delilan to victory in the Star Class yacht race sponsored by the Marine Field Club over a seven and one-half mile triangular course in Gravesend Bay, yesterday. Richard O'Shea's Atiantic was second.

Senator Key Pittman, Democrat, of Nevada, expressed the belief today that a year of war in China had demonstrated that the Roosevelt Administration must be granted wider latitude in its economic and commercial dealings with China and Japan.

Oscar Herdman, veteran police reporter, who for the last twenty years covered the "lobster trick," the early morning beat, at Manhattan Police Headquarters for the old Telegram and then for The World-Telegram, its successor, died yesterday noon in his home, 86-06 Eightieth Street, Woodhaven, L. I., of a heart ailment.

A new development in the strike of bill posters, which has kept subway cars of the I. R. T. and B. M. T. systems almost barren of advertising for nine weeks, was reported yesterday when the coin slots of forty-four vending machines on I. R. T. stations in the Bronx were clogged with a plastic substance.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Seaver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Thatcher Seaver of this place, was married to William Charles Eichmann here this afternoon in the Bronxville Reformed Church by the Rev. Dr. John Henderson Powell.

Robert Kirkwood, secretary of the Maytag C. I. O. union, was arrested by Sheriff Earl Shields today on a charge of criminal syndicalism. He was the sixth union man to be arrested in connection with labor disturbances at the Maytag plant, closed two months ago when 1,500 C. I. O. workers walked out in protest against a 10 per cent wage cut.

I have just read the interesting account of the enclave (or, considered from the point of view of Spain, the exclave) of Llivia, ancient capital of Cerdagne, by Herbert L. Matthews in your issue of June 26. I had wondered before how the Spanish war was affecting Llivia, situated as it is inside French territory.

HYANNIS, Mass.--Yachting, tennis and the Summer theatres are the major attractions on Cape Cod during the week. The Wianno Yacht Club this week steps its competitive program into high gear with a race series scheduled for every day but tomorrow.

The speech of President Mikhail Kalinin to the personnel of the Ordjonikidze ship-building plant in Leningrad, appealing to them to prepare to outstrip Britain in this field and to construct "high-grade ships of large tonnage" is being studied with great interest by foreign diplomats here.

When the "temporary White House," in the form of a private railroad car, rolled westward on ribbons of steel this week there began another chapter in the dramatic story of the elaborate transportation and communication preparations that always are called forth by these Presidential safaris.

Charles Raucher, 3 years old, of 680 Rockaway Parkway, Brookyn, was killed last evening and his year-old playmate, Thomas Palhero of the same address, was in a critical condition as a result of drinking an insecticide found in a ottle in the cellar of their home.
Unless otherwise stated, the resuits of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges.

Apparently more skeptical than other buying groups of the current upturn, dry goods jobbers were finally convinced by the govern-ment's cotton acreage report last week that prices of raw materials and finished goods were bound to advance further and, accordingly, they made plans for large-scale buying this week.

THIS day of book fairs and best sellers has made the reading public increasingly book-conscious, and with this growing consciousness has come an increasing interest in the appearance as well as the content of books.
ENGLAND has discovered, as New York State sometime may, that adultery is not the only valid grounds for divorce. It took a humorist not only to point out the fact but to do something about it.
The surprising Reds ousted the Cubs from third place in the National League race today by trouncing the Chicagoans, 11 to 0. Chicagoans, 11 to 0.

A considerable strengthening of the Brazilian, as well as of other South American navies, is in progress, officers of the Brazilian naval training ship Almirante Saldanha, at New York for an eight-day visit, said yesterday.
The question of what becomes of city families' incomes is the subject of a study made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics and Home Economics as a WPA survey.
Former District Constable Neill of the St. Mary division of the Jamaica police force was sentenced today to ten years in prison for beating a prisoner to death with a heavy whip on March 7.

Frank Phillips, chairman of the Frank Phillips Foundation, Inc., authorized today a gift of $100,000 to the Boy Scouts of Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle. The chairman of the board of the Phillips Petroleum Company, in a note authorizing the gift, said:

George Brown, secretary of the Reo Motor Car Company, said today directors of the company would move on next Tuesday at a special stockholders' meeting to adjourn to a later date to avoid violation of New York Stock Exchange rules.

THE sport of book burning has a long and impressive history which may be traced back to antiquity. The scenery has been shifted around considerably through the ages, the principals involved have become oddly scrambled, but the story continues to be one of "other times, other places, the same customs."

Department store sales in June showed a decline of 12 per cent under the same month a year ago, while for the first half of the year they were 10 per cent less than in the corresponding period of 1937, according to the report issued today by the Federal Reserve Board.

More than 1,100 cases a week were decided by the United States Customs Court here in the fiscal year closed June 30, according to figures made public yesterday by Andrew McClellan, in charge of the court reporters' bureau of the court.
