AN international contest open to all composers of England, Canada and the United States is announced by the California Composers and Writers Society. The competition will be held in connection with the festival of the California Composers Federation at the Golden Gate International Exposition in San Francisco during the week of Aug. 21, 1939.

Miss Katharine Kinsman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Abbot Kinsman of this place, and Norman Harris Snow of New York and New Canaan, Conn., were married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur C. Peabody of this place.

A bureau of information and publicity to disseminate facts on Catholic beliefs and teachings is being established by the Bishops of the United States and is expected to begin operations soon after Aug. 1.

A prophet may be without honor in his own country but Ray Billows proved himself an extraordinarily accurate prophet today in the final rounds of the Sweetser Victory Cup tournament-over the west course of the Winged Foot Golf Club.

An integrated peace curriculum, used experimentally in the New York school system last year, proved successful in showing the pupils the "horrors of war" and the value of international cooperation, according to David H. Moskowitz, assistant superintendent assigned to the high school division.

The British public, which has been kept on tenterhooks by alarming events on the European Continent, is being forced to turn its attention to Palestine by a new series of terroristic outbreaks that have already cost more than forty lives and threaten to grow worse.
Dr. Claude Joseph Goldsmid-Montefiore, one of the leaders of the Anglo-Jewish community and a member of one of the most prominent British Jewish families here, died today at the age of 80.

The economic plight of the South, which is the subject of much discussion at present in Washington, has attracted additional attention through the report on Friday of the Department of Agriculture showing that the acreage there planted to cotton, its basic crop, this year is the smallest since 1900.

Brig. Gen. Francis A. Stitzer, 98 years old, the last living member of the original Civil War "First Defenders" who responded to President Lincoln's call for volunteers on April 17, 1861, will leave New York today by automobile for his home in Denver.

The full membership of the Non-Intervention Committee met in plenary session here on Tuesday and endorsed a British compromise for withdrawal of "volunteers" from Spain and cutting off shipments of munitions to that country both by sea and by land.

A number of changes have taken place in the Cord Meyer section of Forest Hills L. I., during the last six months, points out Paul M. Jeffrey, president of the Sussex Homes development in that vicinity.
The New York Civil Liberties Committee described the New York police as "insensitive to brutality" in a report on local conditions for the year ended June 1, published yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. George F. Temple of Hollywood, Calif., introduced their daughter, Miss Shirley Temple, to local society at Valkill Cottage this afternoon. Miss Temple is 9 years old and regarded as not altogether unknown in Dutchess County, although she has usually vacationed in Hawaii.

Out of the two meetings in the last two weeks of the joint CongressionalDepartmental Committee requested by President Roosevelt to study "monopoly and the concentration of economic power" has come a program of action which should be somewhat reassuring at least to segments of the business world which have been pictured as highly fearful of the purposes and impacts of this investigation.

Many members of the Summer colony and their week-end house parties attended the first in a series of supper dances held tonight at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. Several dinners were given at the clubhouse before the dance, and many guests from dinners at estates throughout the colony came in later for supper and dancing.

NOT so many years ago this country was in the throes of a literary movement which called itself humanism. But this movement, like many others which from time to time spring up in this vast community of constant flux and change, suffered a temporary vogue, then died an unnoticed death;

Stocks recovered opening losses and closed steady at irregularly higher levels in slowest Saturday trading since June 18; turnover, 592,300 shares. All groups of bonds firm and mixed in quiet trading; transaations, $2,971,500.

With a view to improving efficiency and the appearance of more than 1,100 of its job sites on streets, highways, around public buildings and in parks, the WPA is producing portable wooden construction shanties, traffic barricades and safety fences in bright colors and uniform design and size, according to Colonel Brehon Somervell, WPA Administrator for New York City.

Dr. Martius, a high official of the German Foreign Office, and Herr Bauer of the Ministry of Communications are negotiating here about future navigation of the Danube. They have already visited Belgrade and from here will go to Sofia and Prague.

THIS alleged season of rest and recreation continues to add dance events to its schedule, and apparently finds itself still so charged with excess energy that it must alter and augment what it has already decided upon as a program.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Janine Bollack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bollack of Paris, to Nathan Katz, son of the Rev. and Mrs; Solomon Katz of Wellington, New Zealand.

The Athletics went down to a 7-to-4 defeat before the Senator today. Wesley Ferrell, who scored his eleventh victory of the season, gave Philadelphia only two hits until the seventh, when the Athletics got three and scored three runs.

THE Griffith Music Foundation will launch a Fall and Winter major recital series next season at the Mosque in Newark, N. J. Artists engaged include Kirsten Flagstad, the Metropolitan soprano, Dec. 21;

Having to contend with a heavy volume of profit-taking, the stock market closed lower on the week, but not before it had established a new high level for the year. The trading 'pace was quite on a par with that of the preceding fortnight.

Several new variations in bank design, in keeping with the trend to give banking offices a greater impression of ready accessibility to the public have been incorporated in the new three-story air-conditioned Rockefeller Center office of the Irving Trust Company, opened last week at 24 West Forty-eighthStreet. Voorhees, Gmelin Walker are the architects.
Two thousand dolls from all over the world are being prepared today for what is expected to be the largest convention of their kind held in this city.

Any showerless bathroom can be modernized with a shower regardless of whether the tub is of the leg type or the built-in style, points out the Plumbing and Heating industries Bureau No changing of piping in the walls or marring of the plaster or tile is necessary.

Where can a million persecuted Jews and others go now from countries which seek to get rid of them? And where can perhaps another million find refuge from lands which in the future may try to get rid of them ? That is the grave question before the Evian Inter-Governmental Conference, meeting on the banks of Lake Leman, across the water from Geneva.

A water-logged ground at Old Trafford made play impossible in the third test cricket match between England and Australia today. It was the second postponement, the international four-day encounter having been scheduled to start yesterday.

The prepared text of President Roosevelt's address here today was as follows: Oklahoma will always have a certain distinction in my memory, for it is the only part of the fortyeight States which bore a different name when, as a small boy, I started to study geography.

Boston at New York--Lanning (3-1) vs. Melton (8-6). Brooklyn at Philadelphia (2)--Posedel (4--4) ad Pressnell (6-7) vs. Hollingsworth (3--6) and La Master (2-5). Cincinnati at Chicago--Vander Meer (10--3) vs. Lee (9--4).

A vital safeguard of democracy under our American system of radio broadcasting is the fact that stations, to obtain license renewals, actually compete with each other in granting radio time to all shades of public opinion in order to prove to the Federal Communications Commission that they are serving "public convenience, interest or necessity."
George Bernard Shaw has given this writer permission to release an interview obtrained a few days before Mr. Shaw's recent illness, which prompted his physician to order him to take a complete rest.

Among the homes just added to the new Mott Brothers suburban residential community at Flower Hill, Manhasset, L. I., is an unusual dwelling in rambling Early American style, erected for Charles L. Newcomb from plans developed by a staff architect of the company.
THE Fall catalogue of G. P. Putnam's Sons contains a brief history of the firm, which celebrates its one hundredth anniversary this year.

THERE is renewed talk of mediation in Spain, reflecting the widespread desire of both Republicans and Nationalists to put an end to destruction and division and to begin the moral and physical reconstruction of the country.

NIGHT traffic fatalities have increased almost 40 per cent since 1930, while, in the same period, deaths during daylight hours have decreased 3 per cent. Charles M. Upham, director of the American Roadbuilders Association, rightly puts his finger on the dark hours as the highway enemy which must first be attacked.

Drivers from all sections of the country have been invited to take part in the outboard motor-boat regatta scheduled to be held at Pittsburgh on Sept. 3-4, it has been announced by Commodore J. S. Saling and Secretary George Weaver of the Mid-East Outboard Association.

He said he was frankly proud of his collection, especially when one recalls how short a time he had been at it. The thing began on a sudden impulse when he cabled to Geneva and bought the top of the Matterhorn for $6.75.

The following foreign service changes since July 1 were announced by the State Department: T. Eliot Weil of Pleasantville, N. Y., American vice consul at Canton designated third secretary of embassy at Nanking. Louis H. Gourley of Springfield, Ill.. consul at Shanghai, assigned as consul at Kobe.

Miss Gladys Katherine Brown, daughter of Mrs. Clarence Eugene Brown and the late Mr. Brown of Brookcroft, this community, and granddaughter of former Commodore Edward Marsh Brown of the New York Yacht Club, was married here today at the first Presbyterian Church to William Clinton Ogburn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Osgburn of Greensboro. N. C.

The authorities of Shanghai's foreign areas, particularly the French Concession, are disturbed over the activities of several hundred boys, who are believed to be Boy Scouts, who walk through traffic jams pasting printed stickers on the backs of automobiles driven by Chinese chauffeurs for Japanese owners.
Naiads from the Women's Swimming Association carried off the three championships at stake in the A. A. U. meet held yesterday at the Manhattan Beach pool in Brooklyn before a large crowd.

New Yorkers may soon be able to obtain weather predictions by telephone, if the New York Telephone Company receives favorable replies to 6,000 questionnaire cards it has distributed in various parts of the city.

Despite the calamities of which this generation has complained, its death rate has fallen sharply nearly everywhere on earth and the expectancy of life has increased generally for all age groups, but most for babies, according to the current edition of the League of Nations statistical year book.

Governor Herbert Lehman and Mrs. Lehman are among the sponsors for the Westchester Youth Aliyah Fete and Bazaar to be held on Saturday, Sunday and Monday on the estate of Harry M. Warner, President of Warner Brothers Pietures, Inc., here.
WHILE the first giant Boeing Clipper for Pan American Airways transatlantic service is still being tested on Lake Washington at Seattle, work on her five sister ships continues in the Boeing plants.

If travelers about to set forth on a train or ocean trip look about them in the shops of the city before they leave, they will find many helpful gadgets that simplify life en route and make packing easier and more efficient.
One of the "must" items which many gardeners have marked down on their schedules for attention during the next few weeks is the ordering of irises for new plantings, or the improvement of old beds.

The Berkshire Garden Center, of which Mrs. Bernhard Hoffmann is president, was the beneficiary of a dance and fashion show here tonight in Town Hall. Mrs. Owen Johnson, president of the Lenox Garden Club, was general chairman, assisted by Mrs. Hoffmann, Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs, president of the Richmond Garden Club; Mrs. John C. Lynch and Miss Marian Hague.
John D. Rockefeller with his family is spending a quiet holiday near here in Castle Duynrell at Wassenaar on an estate belonging to Count van Zuylen van Nyevelt, Queen Wilhelmina's chamberlin.

The Long Island Railroad Company has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to abondon its Sag Harbor branch, extending from Bridgehampton, L. I., to its terminus at Sag Harbor, a distance of 4.39 miles.

RADIO broadcasting, introduced to the public through politics when KDKA, at Pittsburgh, sent out the Harding-Cox election bulletins on the night of Nov. 2, 1920, was quickly recognized as a new "weapon" in the political arena.
The Chicago, Madison Northern Railroad Company and the Cedar Rapids Chicago Railroad Company, both affiliated with the Illinois Central,
Accused of operating a fraudulent "divorce mill" whereby seventeen couples allegedly were victimized, Herbert Thornton Banks,

President Roosevelt carried his fight for election of New Deal supporters across Arkansas and Oklahoma today, but at the end of a day of wary campaigning had not given his unqualified endorsement to a single primary candidate.
Field Marshal Hermann Goering, Germany's economic dictator, today offered new inducements to the rural population to remain on the land and resist the still prevalent lure of the city.

Miss Elaine Clearwater Pitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Plitt of this place and granddaughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles K. Clearwater, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to John Hamilton McCallum, son of Mrs. Donald Campbell McCallum of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Rev. Mr. McCallum.

The Browns, for the second straight game, forced Cleveland to go ten innings for the winning run today as the Indians scored a 5-to-4 victory and retained their one-game margin in first place over the Yankees.

Criticism of the methods employed by many architectural schools in training embryo designers of buildings was expressed by many practicing architects of the New York area in response to a questionnaire sent to them by the committee on education of the New York Chapter of the American In stitute of Architects.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the five months to May 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $38,619,440, after taxes and charges, compared with $45,013,899 in the 1937 period, a drop of $6,394,459.
Changes in two Lehigh University administrative offices and the creation of a third, all effective Sept. 1, were announced today by President Williams.

Although shoe production last month was estimated as seasonally lower than in May, the volume of business written by manufacturers in the last three weeks assures them of active operations right through August, they reported here yesterday.

Two heroes of the bombing of the United States gunboat Panay by Japanese planes in the Yangtze River, Ernest R. Mahlmann and Homer W. Truax, were decorated with the Navy Cross and received citations today.

Gar Wood and Daniel C. Roper had two minds with a single thought last week. Both issued helpful and timely don'tt" to pleasure-boat skippers, the famous speed boat pilot compiling "ten commandments" from his Detroit headquarters and the Secretary of Commerce issuing twenty-one cautions from his Washington office through the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation.

TIME was when the practice of play producers of "trying it on the dog" aroused yelps and yowls of protest from Philadelphia's footlight faithfuls. We'd have the original New York cast in a play all tuned and tested by the Broadway box-office barometer, or we'd have nothing.

THE Midyear Report of the twenty-sixth year of the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund appears on these pages. It tells of the progress made in the last six months by the 100 cases of want described in the annual appeal published by THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 5 last.

A meeting of fliers who use Holmes Airport, Jackson Heights, Queens, will be held at 4 P. M. today in the Goodyear airship hangar at the field, E. H. Holmes, real estate operator and owner of the field, announced yesterday.

TWO American works will be played at the opening Summer concert of the National Symphony Orchestra, under Dr. Hans Kindler, this afternoon at the Potomac Watergate in Washington, D. C. These are "Enchantment," a tone-poem by the Washington composer,

TODAY is a proud day in Rheims. Before an international audience of invited guests and with all the crimson and purple splendor which the church brings to these great occasions, Rheims Cathedral is being formally reopened this morning after sixteen years' work in repairing the appalling damage inflicted by German artillery during the World War.

Substantial losses in three of its components lowered THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity more than a point for the week ended July 2, wiping out the gains of the three preceding weeks.
AMERICANS in Scandinavia who try to solve the mysteries of polite Swedish conversation will sympathize with a class struggle which is going on in that otherwise unruffled northern country.

KINGSTON, N. Y.--Transportation companies and hotel proprietors in the central Catskill region report that week-end travel and bookings are 75 per cent in advance of 1937. Over the July 4 holiday many visitors were turned away from their favorite haunts.

The nineteenth biennial board meeting of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women will convene tonight in Grand Rapids, Mich., with seventy-five State presidents, national officers and chairmen in attendance.

Her Ladyship, recent $10,000 purchase of E. J. Baker, St. Charles, Ill., owner of the world's champion trotter, Greyhound, gave the Grand Circuit its fastest mile of the season at North Randall today as the big line ended its stay here.
Reorganization of the Republican Militia, an unofficial armed group, is denied with the explanation that Chile did not need a private army to support constitutional government or maintain order.

TWO of the channel islands off the coast of Southern California have been transferred from the Bureau of Lighthouses of the Department of Commerce to the Department of the Interior, to be established as a national monument by the National Park Service.

With daffodil foliage "down," the time is here to lift the bulbs for replanting. The work can be done for several weeks yet, but the sooner it is attended to the better. Foliage remained green longer than usual this season, but the bulbs have reached full size and are now in the so-called dormant season of their growth cycle.

In the new Scarsdale Manor group of apartments under construction on Garth and Grayrock Roads, near the Scarsdale station, R. H. Bowden, the architect, has planned garage facilities as well as living quarters.

Measures further restricting the commercial activities of Jews were announced today. From Aug. 6 Jews will no longer be allowed to act as tourist guides or marriage brokers except when the contracting parties are Jews or of mixed blood.

Walter Hagen Jr., son of the old master, scored his most notable golfing triumph today, teaming with Irving Jones of the home club to win the Brooklea Country Club's annual two-man best-ball invitation tournament, conducted on a handicap basis.
An accumulation of a mass of testimony which has swamped stenographers and printers brought a halt today in the year-long hearings into claims to the $20,000,000 estate of Henrietta E. Garrett.

Senator Bennett C. Clark, seeking the Democratic renomination, has just opened his speaking campaign and has repeated to Missouri audiences that he refuses to be a Roosevelt rubber stamp. He has declared that his sympathies are with the President and the New Deal, but that in the future, as in the past, he will vote as his best judgment directs, regaraless of White House sentiments.

After a chase across roofs and into the street, William Gadson, who lived at 464 West Twenty-third Street under the name of William Taylor, was arrested yesterday on a charge of felonious assault, accused of beating Michael J. Dwyer, an inspector in the Immigration Bureau.

Norman Thomas said here today that he had received a "buck-passing reply" to a letter he had written earlier in the week to President Roosevelt urging that he instruct the Attorney General to investigate the "kidnapping" of Mr. Thomas in Jersey City last April.

CURRANT jelly and strawberry jam and pickled peaches may not be upper most on mid-July menus, but this is the time when delicious whiffs of cooking fruits come from the kitchen and when rows of sparkling jellies line sunny window sills.

PRESENTING vignettes and Latin inscriptions significant in association with the Catholio Church, Vatican City has issued the first air-mail stamps in its ten years of philatelic activity. The illustrations, several of them symbolic in character

ALTHOUGH the New York World's Fair will not be open for another ten months, about 1,500,000 visitors have already been out to Flushing Meadows to inspect the "World of Tomorrow" which is rising there.
Physical education in the United States is moving forward this week at two Y. M. C. A. aquatic training conferences being held at Springfield College and at Lake Geneva, Wis.

Miss E. Carolyn Berges, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Adams Berges of Summer Street, was married to Bruce Morrison of Stamford, son of James Morrison of Gulfport, Fla., and the late Mrs. Morrison, in St. John's Episcopal Church this afternoon. The Rev. Gerald A.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Medical Corps Reserve officers is ordered to active duty July 10 at Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., for training with the C. M. T. C. (26th Infantry): Colonel Francis E. Fronczak, 806 Fillmore Ave., Buffalo, N. Y.
Departure of the Nevills expedition on the second leg of its voyage down the Colorado River to Boulder Dam was postponed today when two members quit.
William Pierrepont White, called the "Father of the Improved Highways of the State," died today at his home on Crow Hill, Clinton, after a long illness.

THE Gershwin memorial program to be given tomorrow night by Paul Whiteman and his orchestra in combination with the New York PhilharmonicSymphony in the Lewisohn Stadium will be in the nature of of a remembrance and will also constitute a new test of the significance and vitality of Gershwin's music.
Tenants in the Astor Court apartment, at Broadway and Eightyninth Street, find a welcome escape from Summer heat in the new roof garden which has been installed for them by Mark Rafalsky Co., agents.

A thirty-cent tour of New York City, including points of interest from Staten Island to Columbia University, is described in a survey of Summer program opportunities published yesterday by the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.

The Midyear Report of the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, published in THE TIMES today, is a glimpse into real life, not a story of unvaryingly happy endings. No gifts and no amount of sympathy can cure an incurable disease or lighten the burden of years. We have to record some deaths, some fresh misfortunes.

Paid off at noon today, 2,300 men of the Tenth Infantry of Albany and 105th Infantry of Troy, forming the Fifty-third Brigade of the New York National Guard, received about $55,000 in payment for the two weeks of training ended at Camp Smith here this afternoon. The guardsmen will return to their armories early tomorrow.

Through a series of letters to a former Wellesley classmate, Miss Emma Mills of 324 West Eightyninth Street, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek has for some months been conveying to a group of close friends in this country some of the intimate aspects of her life under war conditions in China.

The present international dilemma, economic aspects of colonial policy, trade relations with Brazil, and the place of electricity in the economic picture, all came in for discussion today at the University of Virginia in the final discussions of the first of the two-week sessions of its twelfth annual Institute of Public Affairs.
Much of, the activity in New Jersey last week was confined to the sale of dwellings of all types, reports received yesterday from realty men in that State revealed.

IRVING BABBITT, who, whatever his philosophical quirks, knew French literature better than any other man of his time, used to say that all literary movements originated in France and required from ten to twenty years to reach America.
The series of qualifying trials for. the national motor-paced bicycling championships later this month will be resumed tonight at the Coney Island Velodrome.

More money was borrowed from savings, building and loan associations for the erection of new homes during May than during any month since last October, the United States Building and Loan League reported yesterday.
Many properties along Broadway lave been improved in recent months, and restaurant space paricularly has been involved in the Iteration projects, according to the roadway Association.

Secretary Ickes re-established the power division of PWA today. It had ceased to function in September after the Public Works Administration quit receiving applications for grants of Federal money under the old Public Works Act. The lending-spending act passed by Congress this Sumer provided funds to resume activities.
The oldest destroyer in service, the 1,100-ton Taylor, was home from the seas today-condemned to oblivion in the "red fleet" at the Philadelphia Navy Yard.

JOHANNESBURG. -- A serious problem is threatening the South African gold - mining industryacute shortage of native labor. And this shortage has acted to create unemployment among white miners, since they cannot be absorbed into the industry because of the curtailment of operations brought about by a lack of natives.

Miss Judith Black, whose mother, Mrs. R. Clifford Black of Pelham Manor, N. Y., has a Summer home here, was married this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church to Farish Alston Jenkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edgar Jenkins of St. Louis. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Paul Roberts of Denver, who was assisted by the Rev. Harry S. Kennedy, rector of the church.

Miss Katharine Monica Murphy, daughter of Mrs. Edward F. Murphy and the late Mr. Murphy of this town, and a descendant on the maternal side to the Spanish explorer, Ponte de Leon, was married this morning at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Catholic Church to James George Macdonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Macdonald of New York.

Racing in a 15-knot breeze from the southwest, the yachtsmen enrolled in the squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach had heavy goingg in their week-end regatta on Moriches Bay today. As a result one craft was disabled and six withdrew in a fleet of 44. As usual, the start and finish were off the Speonk shore.
THE 10 to 14 year-olds who learned about the training of London stage children in Noel Streatfeild's original and entertaining "Ballet Shoes" will be equally diverted with its successor.

Two life-term convicts escaped in a State-owned automobile today after threatening a trusty with death. James Walsh, the trusty, said that Richard Champlain, 40, and Earl Glenn Sauders, 38, assigned to prison hospital duty, told him they were detailed to give medical attention to a prisoner being held at Flat Rock, and that he drove them through the prison gate.

The memory of Sir William Johnson as "empire builder, military leader and sincere friend of the red men" was extolled today in pageantry celebrating the 200th anniversary of his settlement of the Mohawk Valley.

ALTHOUGH the most spectacular effect of the Tennessee Valley Authority upon the American people has shown itself in the bitter controversy with the private power companies, come to a head in the Congressional investigation now under way here,
Philip Gordon Birckhead, who was vice president of the former Bank of America in New York and its uptown manager, died today in his home at Greenfield Hills here after a short illness. He was 62.

All white costumes were worn by the bride and her attendants at the marriage here at noon today of Miss Elizabeth Olive Sewall, daughter of State Senator and Mrs. Sumner Sewall of this city, to Robert Horne Charles, son of Mrs. Benjamin H. Charles of St. Louis and the late Mr. Charles. The ceremony was performed in Grace Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Charles Myron Tubbs.

An attempt to jump on the automobile in which President Roosevelt was riding through Oklahoma City resulted today in a beating and arrest for Woody Hockaday, aged 52, of Wichita, Kan., who said he merely wanted to "shine the President's shoes."

A number of properties in various sections of New Jersey were reported yesterday as having been sold through Fiedler, Inc., broker. Among them was the two-story taxpayer at 594-600 Scotland Road, Orange, which was purchased by the Trescott Investment Company, and the apartment house at 92 Monroe Place, Bloomfield, which . was bought by Stephen J. Kelley.

IT is a fortunate coincidence that both the Swedish Tercentenary and the North west Territory Centennial are being celebrated this year. For while the events were separated by a span of two centuries, they are actually interlocked to an unusual degree.

MANY travelers to Mexico nowadays include in their tours the picturesque city of Guanajuato, capital of the State of the same name. The usual itinerary is to cross the border at Laredo, proceeding to Mexico City by way of Monterrey and Saltillo, and returning by the same route.

St. John's Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Eleanor Coolidge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Coolidge of this place and Manchester, to Frederick Burnham Chapman, son of Mrs. George McMurtrie Godley of Greenwich, Conn., and the late F. Burnham Chapman of Rye, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Bradford Burnham.

Ralph Guldahl, twice national open champion and home club pro, and Slamming Sam Snead scored a 2-and-1 victory over Johnny Revolta and Jimmy Hines, metropolitan open champion, in a four-ball exhibition golf match before a gallery of 1,800 at the Braidburn Country Club.

Midsummer dullness settled yesterday over the bond market as prices in most groups varied only slightly from the previous day's finals in the slowest trading since the current advance began three weeks ago.
Macklin Marrow, 38-year-old American conductor, made his first appearance last night as director of a Stadium concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

Polo activity at the Meadow Brook Club was limited to two exhibition members' matches today, with George H. Mead Jr. leading a Long Island side to a 14-to-9 victory over Gulf Stream in the principal attraction, played on Hitchcock Field.

TIME and again men who make their living by observing their fellow-creatures make special efforts to depict the life and problems of the worker. Numerous books appear which describe his aims, his hopes, his strength and his weakness.

Ground was broken here this week for a $1,000,000 FHA insured-mortgage housing project, the first of its kind in this section of the State, to be erected by the Linden Housing Corporation. The project, which will provide 284 three and four room apartments, is expected to be completed in six months.
THE first International Music Festival, featuring fifteen all-day programs of the music and dances of various nations, will be held Aug. 23 to 27 in the main ballroom of the Hotel Astor.

Chairman Sheppard of Texas said today that the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures would consider any complaint filed with it in connection with the dismissal of Henry W. Webb as Federal Housing Administrator for Maryland.

GERMANY'S greatest writer and America's most distinguished applicant for first citizenship papers has managed to state in the brief compass of a single lecture the whole case for freedom against despotism.

A tornado struck Andover late today, wrecked buildings and first reports indicated two persons were dead, eighteen others injured. Reported dead were Mrs. John Schuring and Mrs. A. P. Bryant, both residents of Andover. John W.

The President's signature of the new Food and Drug Act enables the Administration to make use at once of some of its emergency provisions, though the law as a whole will not become effective until next year.
Japanese naval officers said today that their "heavily operating" air forces were attempting to blast out Chinese defenders thirty miles above Kiukiang on the Yangtze River.

THE promised stamps of Eire (philately's Irish Free State), 2-pence brown and 3-pence blue, commemorating the inauguration of the temperance movement in Ireland a century ago, reached New York last week.

Jo C. Guild, president of the Tennessee Electric Power Company, controlled by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, issued yesterday the following statement in connection with the offer of the City of Chattanooga, through its power board, to Commonwealth and Southern for the purchase of the transmission and distribution facilities of the Tennessee company in Chattanooga:

Robert Underwood and James Seaver, unseeded Stanford University entrants, captured the New Jersey State men's doubles tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club, conquering the favored team of Robert Peacock and Douglas Imhoff. University of California representatives, in three straight sets, 6-4, 11-9, 7-5.
THE care and scholarship which has been lavished on the poetry, the notes and letters of Gerard Manley Hopkins is perhaps a measure of the importance this strange poet holds for us today.

JUST a bit of skin or a shred of something between tangled bark or knotted cord; just a meager windbreak or tatteredblot against the stormy sky-but we called it home long, long before Caesar or Tacitus wrote of Briton, German or Gaul.

WHILE the Fourth of July holiday cut production of automobiles and trucks last week, due largely to the fact that Ford Motor Company and Pontiac will not resume until tomorrow, there is steadily growing evidence that the Summer shutdowns for model changeover will be of short duration.

The majority of babies nowadays arrive in the daytime, according to Professor Maximillian Meyer of the National Statistical Bureau at Nuremberg. Since 1916 the day births have been increasing and in 1935, for the first time since the record has been kept, the daytime babies exceeded the night ones.

Taking the lead at the first jump and holding a neck margin in a thrilling finish, T. D. Taggart's Marica, the West's champion mare of 1937, won the second running of the Sussex Handicap, $10,000 added feature of the closing day's program at Delaware Park, and smashed the track record in the bargain.

Smashing onward in an electrifying rush, Stagehand yesterday came from last place to take the $12,950 Empire City Handicap in track record time, thus more firmly establishing his claim to the 3-yearold championship which still hangs in the balance.

Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, points out that the new official instructions to bank examiners affect the grading of real estate mortgages held by banks of the Federal Reserve System.

THE "fishermen's specials" have started their week-end runs from Chicago and Milwaukee to the great North Woods of Wisconsin and more sportsmen perhaps than ever before are making their way to this angler's paradise.
Alan Napier as the Baronet and Diana Beaumont as a famous actress have two of the chief parts in "Life Burns On," at the Arts Theatre next Sunday and Monday.
Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, Conn., defeated Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York today, 7-5, 7-5, to win the women's Middle States grass court tennis tournament.

CLIFFORD ODETS'S "Golden Boy" was very eagerly applauded at the fall of the last curtain, although the house was cold during the opening scenes. The general opinion in London seems to be that it will succeed commercially.

ALAN J. VILLIERS is probably the world's most indefatigable amateur and professional deep-sea sailing man. Starting out originally to write of the annual grain-race from Australia to England, and to record the voyage photographically,

The Longchamp night racing presented a dazzling style pageant. Period gowns of lace or tulle jostled long tailleurs of moire, satin or ottoman. White triumphed in ensembles and furs; ermine and white fox prevailed, snowy ostrich accessories were seen.

A vision of fifty miles of paved parkland roads exclusively for bicycle riders was conjured yesterday morning by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who feels that facilities for cyclists are the "biggest unsatisfied need facing the Park Department today."

The John Marshall College of Law will conduct competitive examinations Friday at 1 P. M. for the Theodore M. Brandle two-year college course scholarship and the Bernard M. Degheri complete secretarial course scholarship. High school graduates are eligible to compete for the scholarships.

Except for the great Walter Hagen, who won the title five times, four in a row, and silverthatched Tommy Armour, winner in 1930, all the stars of professional golfdom are on hand for the twentyfirst national P. G. A. championship, which gets under way tomorrow morning over the famous Shawnee Country Club course.

IF it lacks somewhat the zest of "The Cautious Amorist," is not quite so clever nor so funny, "Age of Consent" is nevertheless a very inviting tidbit. Norman Lindsay, the author-who serves also as illustrator-is a writer with a curious brand of humor.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 8: BRIGADIER GENERAL Brett, G. H. (Lt. Col.), Air Corps, three months and thirteen days leave, Sept. 16.

CHINESE armies used to carry umbrellas and fight only when the weather was fine. When a general perceived that he was sure to be beaten he surrendered without unnecessary bloodshed and his men were enlisted among their former enemies.

For the first time in a number of years, Dr. Nikola Tesla, scientist and inventor, who is 82 years old today, is postponing his annual birthday party for the press so he may complete a mechanical therapeutic device for public demonstration.

The fourth death in the ranks of the Union and Confederate veterans who came here for the seventy-fifth anniversary reunion occurred today when Fayette Nelson, 95, of Pasadena, died from a heart attack. His daughter, Mrs. Ella??ams, said his body, clad in his ??lue uniform, would be sent home or burial.

There are indications that the calm in Czechoslovakia following the mobilization on May 21 soon will be followed by fresh storms. The democratic and Leftist parties receive increasing reports from frontier districts of growing activities by the Nazi Henlein party's camouflaged storm troopers.
(All time is P. M, Eastern daylight saving, unless otherwise indi cated; dial locations are in megacycles.)

Miss Natalie Willis Pease of New York and Washington, became the bride this afternoon of Eden Taylor Preston, an aviation cadet attached to the U. S. S. Saratoga, in a ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

Kenesaw Mountain Landis, Commissioner of Baseball, apparently held the answer tonight to whether Dizzy Dean of the Cubs would sue the Cardinals, charging damages to his pitching arm-and Landis withheld comment.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Morris gave a dinner tonight at their Summer home for Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Comstedt, who are passing their first season here, and for Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cook of Syracuse, N. Y., Mrs. Morris's parents.
Supply contracts valued at $8,701,232 were awarded in the week ended on July 7 by sixteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

THE nation is celebrating the epic of its frontier-the most thrilling story in the American history book and, according to historians, the most significant. The focal point of the celebration has been Marietta, Ohio, where, 150 years ago-on July 15, 1788--the seat of government for the Northwest Territory was established.
A dinner dance was held here tonight in connection with the eighth annual Westchester Country Club horse show taking place on the polo field of the club.

Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland and Joseph E. Davies, United States Ambassador to Belgium, will be among the honorary pallbearers at the funeral in Rutland, Vt., today of Harold Walker, a member of the legal department of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, who died Friday.

When the French liner Normandie sails from New York on Wednesday she will be headed for her 100th crossing of the North Atlantic. Still the fastest ship on the Western Ocean, the liner has traveled 330,681 miles since her maiden voyage from Havre in May, 1935, at an average speed of 28.54 knots. All told, the vessel has been at sea 559 days.

About 20,000 members of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks are expected to attend the annual convention of the organization here Monday to Thursday. All States of the Union, Panama, Puerto Rico, Guam and Alaska will be represented.

Events last week in Palestine and Syria shifted attention from the troubles of Europe to the countries of the Near East. They showed again how greatly Britain and France desire to avoid complications in that part of the world.

Mayor La Guardia is looking for an outstanding New Yorker preferably one with practical experience in railroad operation, for appointment to the Board of Transportation to succeed Commissioner Charles V. Halley Jr., whose term expired on June 30, but who is holding over.

The century-old Dutch farmhouse at Van Houten Fields, the new commuters' homestead development at West Nyack, N. Y., has been taken over by the homesteaders and will be renovated into a three-suite apartment house for use by home purchasers while their houses in the development are under construction.

Designed to house the largest collection of "all the style elements that contribute to making the American woman the best dressed in the world," the modern classic Apparel and Accessories Building at the World's Fair will be almost three city blocks in length.
North American wheat markets developed a heavy undertone today, and at no time was there more than a minor rally. Hedging pressure,

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest. Queries should be addressed to the Editor of Queries and Answers, NEW YORK TIMES.

The War Department is getting ready to spend $10,000,000 "educating" industry to produce war materials. Congress authorized the expenditure over a five-year period in an effort to gear the industrial machine more closely to the military preparedness machine.

Two fleets of United States Power Squadron units will leave protected coves and inside waterways this week and go to sea on the open Atlantic. A joint cruise of the Staten Island and the Northern New Jersey squadrons will be taken down the Jersey coast, out around Sandy Hook and in through the Manasquan Inlet, some twentyfive miles to the south.

James J. Hines, Tammany leader in the West Harlem Assembly District, and J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, defendants in the lottery racket case, are to be arraigned again before Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the Supreme Court tomorrow morning for pleading to the indictment charging conspiracy.

Cardinal Hayes has announced the first of his annual assignments of chaplains for non-sectarian Summer camps for children and adults. The announcement was made through the Rev. John J. Curry, assistant director in charge of camps of the division of social action of the New York Catholic Charities.

BLUFF POINT, N. Y.--Preparations again to place the Adirondacks-Champlain Valley region in the international spotlight will be completed this week with final arrangements for the women's annual international invitation golf tournament to be played on the championship course at Hotel Champlain, on Lake Champlain, July 19 to 23.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.--Excursion boats, trains, buses and planes are now carrying capacity loads of vacationists to the Virginia seashore-to that region of concentrated history that lies along the southern end of Chesapeake Bay and the James and York Rivers.
Max Schmeling's return home in defeat caused hardly a ripple of excitement today as the boat train from Bremerhaven arrived.

A Summer program of community singing will be started this afternoon at 4 o'clock in Washington Square under the auspices of the Park Department. Allen Henckley, director of the Village Light Opera Group, assisted by Miss Gertrude Hutchinson, will lead the singing.
JIMMY DURANTE, the gent with the proboscis, has not quite completely disorganized Billy Rose's Casa Mafiana, but, according to the latest word, was making highly diverting progress in that direction.

At 10:31 P. M. last Thursday a ??car special train pulled out of Washington and steamed West. Chief among the eighty passengers was Franklin D. Roosevelt, bent on a self-imposed task that critics said was impossible: to lay aside his role as President of the United States in order to undertake the political role of Democratic party leader.
The Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, appealed today for a more rigid enforcement of public decency laws at bathing beaches near Rome.

Alfred I. Barton, former club director in Florida, has been named manager of operations in the reorganization of Montauk Point's (L. I.) $12,00,000 resort development, C.-M. Keys, president of the new Montauk Beach Company, Inc., announced yesterday.
Wages as a factor in steel production are undergoing a test while the industry feels out the effect of the recent cuts in the prices of steel.

Henry L. Ferguson, secretary of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, announces that the judges at the annual meeting of the organization will be Dr. Samuel Milbank of New York City and Robert McLean of Port Washington, Pa.

Fifty-five children of progressive education have written a book about it. Published by Henry Holt Co., the book is the expression of the class of 1938 of the progressive high school on the Ohio State University campus.

Miss Cornelia Wing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs Charles Sewall Wing of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Chapel of St. Hill Gabriel's, to John Barr Dolan, son of Associate Justice Arthur Walter Dolan of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts and Mrs. Dolan of Boston. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Hillary McGloufflin.

The Joint Congressional Committee of ten members, with Senator A. V. Donahey, Ohio Democrat, as chairman, will assemble here on Monday for the actual beginning of its investigation into the administration of the Tennessee Valley Act.

ALTHOUGH there is no glamour to it, the task of distributing motion pictures to theatres all over the country exacts from this end of the industry the same systematic planning which the production of pictures demands of the Hollywood producers.

The Health Department made public yesterday a warning to vacationists to beware of contracting typhoid fever while out of the city. "In rural districts," the bulletin said, "the milk is often unpasteurized; water is usually derived from wells or springs.

The French colony in New York will observe Bastille Day on Thursday with a grand ball at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The event is under the patronage of Coun Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, Consul General of France, who will attend with Countess de Fontnouvelle.

CLIFFORD GOLDSMITH dropped into town last week to address a meeting of the National Association of School Secretaries and incidentally to attend a performance at the Biltmore Theatre of "What a Life," his first play to be presented on Broadway.

Aaron S. Shapiro, a New York corporation lawyer and real estate operator for forty years, died today in his home, 2,970 Sheridan Road, where he had lived for the last five months. He was 72 years old.

STATION WIXAL, Boston, operated by the World Wide Broadcasting Foundation "in the interest of Pan-American good-will, dissemination of American culture and promotion of world peace," has--been given an additional grant of $100,000 by the Rockefeller Foundation, effective this month.
Sheriff Harry Patteson aid that Newton B. Kinley, 57 years old, an orchardist accused of immoral conduct with a 13-year-old girl, blew himself to pieces today with a dynamite blast.
THE Triborough Bridge will be two years old tomorrow. There will be no birthday celebration; the occasion will be marked, according to Colonel Paul Loeser, director, by "business as usual."

Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Allen of Hartford, Conn., have returned to the St. John cottage for the season. E. Everett Dickinson Jr. and children of Essex, Conn., are at the Goodwin cottage for the Summer.

Miss Doris W. Wyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Wyman of this place, will be married the morning of July 30 to Robert Kroell Farnham of New York, son of Mrs. Benjamin Still of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Robert F. Farnham of Chicago.

Secretary Wallace gave the Federal surplus Commodities Corporation blanket authority today to buy surpluses of oranges, vegetables, fresh peaches, wheat, flour and cereal products during the next twelve months.

IN private showings to dealers recently, a new line of 1938-39 radios featuring the "acoustical labyrinth," designed to eliminate the "empty barrel effect," were introduced by Stromberg-Carlson, through Gross Sales, Inc., New York representatives of the company.

President Roosevelt's declaration yesterday that he would have left New York State "in the black" financially at the end of his four years as Governor if he had had the same Federal aid which Governor Lehman had does not coincide with informed opinion here.

Banana companies in Ecuador are required to revise their existing contracts within thirty days, according to a new law published today in the Telegrafo. This will affect the local subsidiary of the United Fruit Company, which has developed banana planting on a considerable scale in recent years.
Because the bride's brother must milk the cows, it will be a 9 o'clock evening wedding for 63-year-old Herbert David Boutall and Ann May, who is only 16, at St. John's Episcopal Church Monday.

The marriage of Miss Kathleen Sinclair Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Alfred Smith of Flushing, Queens, to Lieutenant Gifford Scull, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Gifford Scull of Somers Point, N. J., took place yesterday morning in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John H. Esquirol.

" They shall not pass our frontiers!" These words, shouted many times to crowds by Sokols from the German frontier districts during the great parade of 100,000 Sokols" through the streets of Prague before President Eduard Benes at the conclusion of the Sokol festival, express the spirit engendered by this great festival.

Confirmation was obtained today of the suicide on Thursday of Baron George Strakosch von Feldringen. His body was buried this afternoon. Baron Strakosch, who was 40, was the husband of an American singer, Renee Bullard.

ALL FOOL'S NIGHT, a comedy by Grenville Vernon. At the Paint Shop Theatre, Somerset, Pa. (Tuesday.) BECAUSE WE'RE HERE, by Harry R. Irving. At the Nabnassett Summer Theatre, Westford, Mass. DAME NATURE, the adaptation from the French which last week visited Westport. At the Westchester Playhouse, Mount Kisco, N. Y.

The Calumet Farm's Beau James, stepping the fastest five and one-half furlongs of the current Arlington Park meeting, won the $2,500 added Hyde Park Stakes for 2-year-olds before 25,000 spectators today.
Northbound I. R. T. trains were stalled for a half hour below 180th Street and Morris Park Avenue, the Bronx, from 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a fire was discovered in the signal tower there.
Miss Marion Eileen Thompson of North Sydney was crowned international radio queen at an impressive coronation ceremony in Lord Nelson Hotel list night. Premier Angus L.

Leniency on the part of the Home Owners Loan Corporation is helping to reduce the number of foreclosure proceedings which that Federal agency is instituting, but fails to solve the problem of delinquent payments on HOLC home mortgages.

Greater extremists than the Dodgers and Phillies couldn't be found anywhere in the world. Today, with the thermometer hovering around 90, they chose to battle for sixteen innings before the perspiring Grimesmen finally subsided on the short end of a 4-3 count.

LITERATURE is meagerly represented in the King's Birthday Honors list. Sir Josiah Stamp, it is true, is raised to the peerage and Sir A. S. Eddington will henceforth be entitled to wear the oak-leaf badge of the Order of Merit, but the production of their many books has only been incidental to their careers.

ONE of the largest gatherings of Scout campers since the National Jamboree at Washington, D. C., a year ago will be the Old Trails Jamboree which opens at Marietta, Ohio, this Wednesday.

The State Constitutional Convention debate over the definition of gambling was complicated further today when the first participation plan, by which spectators at the midget auto races at Roosevelt Raceway may purchase "certificates" of participation in purses awarded to the race winners, was placed in operation this evening without interference by the authorities.

" The latest Palestine outbreaks may have been timed by the British Government to impress upon the Evian conference the supposed perils of settling large numbers of Jews in the Holy Land," Rabbi Louis I. Newman charged yesterday in a sermon at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

Mrs. Robert Cunningham Myles is at Manoir Richelieu, Murray Bay, Que., for the season. Mrs. Frank G. Wisner has arrived from Laurel, Miss., and is at the Weylin. Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Stone will leave in a fortnight for Saratoga, where they will occupy the Wilson home for the racing season.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in the smallest volume in some time, largely because of the short week occasioned by the Independence Day holiday. The new calls were principally for payment in later months, particularly August.
Two promotions in rank and eight appointments to the faculty and staff of New Jersey College for Women have been announced for for the coming year. Dr. George P.

The Long Island Daily Star, which discontinued publication in Long Island City on June 25, will resume publication as a daily newspaper Wednesday under an agreement with the New York Newspaper Guild made public yesterday by S. I. Newhouse, the new owner, and confirmed by Carl Randau, president of the Guild.

The present standardization in sizes, types and construction of steel windows with the resultant lowering of cost, dates from the World War, according to the Metal Window Institute.

Miss Marie Katherine Schwenk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Adolph Schwenk of Scarsdale, was married here this afternoon to Ensign Clarence Henry Waring Jr., United States Coast Guard, in the Church of St. James the Less. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Alan R. Chalmers;

ALEXANDER--STOLZER--Announcing the marriage of Mrs. Budde Stolzer, June 29, to Mr. Julian Alexander of Montgomery, Ala. BIRNBAUM--HEBALD--Announcement is made of the marriage of Miss Mildred Hebald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Hebald of New York, to Dr. Jacob Birnbaum of New York on July 3, 1938.
The volume of mail orders arriving in the New York wholesale market last week showed a marked decline from the previous week's totals, According to McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyer.

IN a world torn by war and by threats of war, the Soviet cinema industry does its own bit of mobilization. Ever since the earliest days of the silent screen, Soviet leaders have understood the tremendous value of the screen as a medium for treatment of themes, both new and old, with a maximum of contemporary significance.

LAKE GEORGE.--A record crowd is expected here next Sunday for the opening performance that evening of "The Romance of Lake George," historical and dramatic pageant. The Mohican Jesters, supported by all the granges of Warren County, have volunteered the services of members who are talented dramatists to portray pageant scenes of primitive Indian life in this area.

Coming back into his true form after a decidedly indifferent performance in an earlier class, Prince Charming II this afternoon gained a leg on the Country Club Trophy, one of the most prized cups in competition during the second day of the eighth annual horse show on the polo field of the Westchester C. C.

THE late Spring music season here has been especially active. The months of May and June were indeed festive ones for Hungary, with first the Eucharistic Congress, followed immediately by the opening of the St. Stephen Jubilee Year.
Permit for a garden-type multifamily house, one of the first of its type in Montclair, has been approved by the Board of Adjustment, Town Clerk Joseph McKee, secretary of the board, announced today.
