The recovery on Friday in the pound sterling was not pursued yesterday. The principal foreign exchanges again weakened against the dollar and finished the week with substantial losses. The pound was off 3/4 cent yesterday to $4.9311-16, which was a net fall of 2 cents in the week.

WASHINGTON.--Scientists of the Bureau of Fisheries this Summer are starting a thoroughgoing investigation of the salmon fisheries of Bristol Bay, Alaska, for several years the scene of Japanese fishing operations.

Benjamin N. Cardozo, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, died at 6:40 o'clock tonight at the estate of Judge Irving Lehman of the New York Court of Appeals on Ridge Street here. He was 68 years old.

For college graduates who are willing to "roll up their sleeves, forget they are graduates and really go to work," the occupational outlook is optimistic, Lawrence W. Zimmer, director of New York University's employment bureau, declared in his annual report made public yesterday.

THE "House of Magic," the home of such noted men of science as Charles Proteus Steinmetz, Irving Langmuir, Willis R. Whitney, W. D. Coolidge and E. F. W. Alexanderson, who have contributed much to the advance of radio, is planning to "go into television in a big way," according to a representative of the General Electric Company at Schenectady.
Harold Earl Kuntz, a 30-year-old meat cutter, calmly confessed today to killing his stepfather after "waiting fifteen years," according to Police Captain W. G. Coovert.
The D. P. Harris Hardware and Manufacturing Company has completed its six-story blockfront building with frontage on Chambers; Church and Reade Streets, in the downtown hardware center.
The beaches were crowded yesteray as the temperature climbed to high of 85 degrees at 2:30 P. M. This reading was two degrees lower han the high for the year, estabished on June 25.
Bucknell University's Second Annual Institute on International Affairs will be held here with five speakers discussing the theme "Current International Conflict."
Twenty-three stained and ragged battle flags of eight New Jersey volunteer regiments of the Civil War were taken today to New York to undergo a preserving process at the navy yard at Brooklyn.

Two British glider pilots claimed a world endurance record today upon landing after more than twenty-two hours in the air at Dunstable. Flight Lieutenants W. B. Murray and Stanley Sproule of the Royal Air Force piloted the two-seated glider, which went aloft at 4 A. M. yesterday and came down about 2:20 A. M. today.

THE first thing Joe McCluskey said was that he was going to take off his coat, pull on his running shoes, hold a watch in his hand and pace Archie San Romani to a 3:05 three-quarters in the mile event at the Hibernian Games next Sunday in the Randalls Island Stadium, after which he would. leave it to Archie to run ahead to a new world's record for the full mile.

Skippers on local waters found the aid of the power boat fleet indispensable in today's championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Y. R. A., held by the Lavallette Y. C. in a thirty-mile southerly. The motorboat men performed continuous rescue work.

ARONSON--Carrie Goldwater, wife of the late Philip N., mother of Evelyn Aronson Margolis, Mabel Aronson Butler- and Gladys Aronson Liberman, in her eightyeighth year. Notice of funeral hereafter. BAKER--Bertha, on July 8, beloved sister of Elizabeth Maas. Services at her late residence, 61-30 157th St., Flushing, N. Y., Monday, 2 P. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

The slowly increasing proportion of older people in the United States is bringing about profound social changes and creating new problems. Some of them are discussed in last week's report of the Committee on Population Problems to the National Resources Committee-a report which predicts a population peak of 158,000,000 in 1980 and then a slow decrease.

With a seven-hour display of surgical pyrotechnics on the floor of the main ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania, which included largescale blood transfusions-from one New York milk wagon horse to another and then back again-and other operations on horses and dogs, the seventy-fifth annual meeting of the American Veterinary Medical Association was brought to a close yesterday.
Prince and Princess Burhaneddin have opened their estate, Villa Bahar, where on Aug. 5 Paul Doguereau, concert pianist, will give a recital.
Some self-described "darn fools have returned the jewelry and opera glasses they stole a year age while Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Barber were absent on vacation.

The engagement of Miss Annette Mary Reddington, daughter of Martin F. Reddington of this place and the late Mrs. Reddington, to George W. Fennell Jr., son of Mrs. George W. Fennell of Mamaroneck and the late Mr. Fennell, has been announced by her father.

With the pre-season training siege not scheduled to start until Aug. 15 at the Blue Hill Country Club in Pearl River, N. Y., more than half of the veterans of the New York Football Giants already have signed contracts for the 1938 professional campaign.

Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., and Christian A. Brinke of Detroit today posted a 74 to capture gross honors in the mixed foursomes preliminary to the twentieth annual Shenecossett women's invitation golf tournament.
The foreign exchange market was quiet today; business in dollars was small, the rate fluctuating within narrow limits and closing 1-16 cent lower at $4.941-16 to the Pound sterling.

A city of 20,000 dead and a richly ornamented funeral causeway have been unearthed from the dust of fifty centuries at Sakkara. The discoverer, Selim Bey Hassan, said today at least 20,00O mummies lie in the necropolis under the causeway, which connected a valley temple with the funeral chapel of Unas, last king of the fifth dynasty.

The second in a series of ten concerts under the sponsorship of the Department of Parks, Mayor La Guardia and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians will be held at 3 o'clock this afternoon in Silver Lake Park, Staten Island.

A grant of $8,325,000 to help make the long-projected Criminal Courts Building a reality was allocated to the city yesterday by the Public Works Administration. The building will be erected in two sections--a seventeen-story court house and a fourteen-story jail to replace the Tombs at a total cost of $18,500,000, 55 per cent of which will be supplied by the city.
Benjamin Nathan Cardozo was popularly grouped among the liberals of the Supreme Court, but he was more precisely identified by his own definition as a "judicial evolutionist."

BORDEAUX. CHARLES DE SECONDAT, Baron de Montesquieu, who has been called "the godfather of the American Constitution," will be honored on July 24 when a monument is to be dedicated at La Brede-Montesquieu, the tiny Girondin village where he was born two and a half centuries ago.
The outline of a reapportionment program will be ready for submission to the Constitutional Convention Committee on the Legislature and its organization on Monday, it became known today.
Smiling happily and proudly, Governor Lehman summoned the press last week to his executive offices and made an important announcement: For the first time since 1930 the State had a balanced budget.
ONCE in a while we come upon a novel whose story seems so familiar and pertinent, whose theme is so manifestly a living part of our times, that we wonder no one has thought of writing it before.

Among the tributes paid last night to Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo were the following: PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, in Oklahoma City-The news of the passing of Justice Cardozo came to me as a great personal shock.

The scene of women's major golf this week shifts to New London, Conn., where the twentieth annual Shennecossett invitation tournament for the Griswold Trophy will open tomorrow and continue through Friday.

There war pending until a month ago before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit an appeal taken by the Collector of Internal Revenue for the District of Kentucky from a decision of the United States District Court of that district,

Local banks in a number of communities in widely separated parts of the country thus far have been unwilling to make loans for new construction under the revised Title of the National Housing Act, Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, declared yesterday.

Charley Whitehead of Plainfield, New Jersey amateur champion, and E. L. Hopper of the home club today led the way into the semifinals of the Essex Fells Country Club's first member-guest invitation golf tournament.

Further improvement in the realty foreclosure situation in Manhattan is indicated in the monthly report of the Real Estate Board of New York for June and its figures covering the first six months of 1938.

IN dealing with insects nothing could. be more extraordinary than the facts themselves, and Mrs. Kenly tells in a piquant, lively and entertaining way, with humor, originality and a touch of poetic feeling, of the strange world of insects,
IN the opening paragraph of one of her chapters Mrs. Rinehart says of her book: In a way it is the story of a story, hidden from us at the time but underlying everything that happened.

Some eighty Croat emigres have recently returned to Yugoslavia, including Autonomist leaders. This return would seem to be the result of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch's conciliatory policy toward the Croat Nationalists.

TWO seashore tournaments are scheduled for the coming week-end. The third annual South Shore tournament, conducted by the Long Island Bridge League, begins Friday afternoon at the Half Moon Hotel at Coney Island. Women's pairs will play one session Friday afternoon;

Increased appropriations -for the Public Works Administratidn made available by the last Congress are expected to aid in remedying a shortl age of school buildings throughout the country through grants and loans for public buildings to the States this year.

Looking at the breeze-ruffled pool, which on hot Summer days gives an atmosphere of soothing coolness to the tiny "estate" of Mrs. Elizabeth Gordon Gross at Lindenhurst, L. I., the observer finds it hard to believe that it is not a gift of nature which has always been there, instead of the clever transformation of a problem spot into the most attractive feature of the place.
A wedding uniting two families long prominent in Connecticut took place here this afternoon when Miss Marion Collins Ely was married to Philip Page Johnston.

The first women's congress of education ever held in Central America will meet at San Jose, Costa Rica, from Sept. 8 to 20, as a result of action taken by the Women's League of Costa Rica and local school teachers.

THERE'S a new shrine in Holland - Oud-Vossemeer, on the Island of Tholen, in Zeeland. For here is the spot from which American Presidents have sprung-none other than the Roosevelts, Theodore and Franklin.

Two members of last year's brilliant Yale squad, David G. Colwell and Albert Hessberg, have accepted invitations to play with the AllStars against the New York Giants of the National Football League at the Polo Grounds Sept. 7,

The Manufacturers Trust Company is paying agent for $8,612,200 State of Louisiana Refunding Bonds, various rates, dated Aug. 1, 1938. The Scotten Dillon Company declared yesterday a forty-cent dividend, an increase of 10 cents over the last payment on May 14.

Although showers were general yesterday in the cotton-growing States and July shorts here continued covering operations, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased 12 to 14 points under week-end profit-taking.

Raleigh Russell, chestnut gelding owned by Willis H. Ryder of this village, won the Class A trot and pace in straight heats at the Driving Park today. The Class B event went to Tartan, owned and driven by C. A. Haight of Mahopac.

BOTH the Ferargil and the Walker Galleries opened new Summer exhibitions last week. The Ferargil show, which will be current through July, contains paintings by Thomas Benton, Clarence Carter, John Costigan, Phil Dike,

Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, the navy's leading expert on lighterthan-air craft, was ordered to warship duty today. He was kept in line, however, for command of the new $3,000,000 naval dirigible when it is completed two and a half years hence.

The Pirates cut the Giants' first-place lead in the National League to two and a half games today by winning their ninth straight victory. With Mace Brown adding laurels to his relief pitching record, Pittsburgh squeezed past the Cardinals, 8 to 7, as the Giants lost.

CHARTING the screen is getting to be even more of a headache these days than trying to reconcile the World's Fair acreage with the vast and colossal attractions Grover Whalen promises to crowd into it.
The bells of ancient Relms' Cathedral, silent since it was largely demolished by German guns during the World War, pealed today for the first time in twenty-four years.

Lewis M. Collins, first police chief of this place and former councilman, died here today at the home of his son, Police Sergeant George L. Collins, after three weeks' illness due to a stroke. He was 80 years old.

Count Theo Rossi of Italy finished alone today to win the King Emperor's Cup in Venice's motor boat Grand Prix. John Rutherfurd of Palm Beach, Fla., and Port Washington, N. Y., driving his Juno, was forced to retire on the ninth lap because of ensine trouble.

Patrolman Harry J. Padian, 53 years old, of the West Thirteenth Street station, who was killed last Wednesday by a crazed patient in Harlem Hospital, received an inspector's funeral yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation, 131st Street and Convent Avenue.
The New York State men's clay court tennis championship, revived after a lapse of twelve -years, got under way at the Seminole Club of Forest Hills yesterday, with a record entry list of 125 players.

With the appointment of 144 arbitrators and their acceptance, the New York Stock Exchange is now prepared to set into motion the new arbitration machinery erected by the constitution adopted last Spring. Five women have been included.

Forward buying beyond sixty to ninety days on commodities is being side-stepped by industrial purchasing agents who are beginning to fear a reaction in the Fall if security and commodity markets keep climbing, according to a check among them yesterday.

ART, to give it one more definition, is what a lady author displays when she writes the entire first chapter of her travel book about her husband's sciatica and makes it a thoroughly charming introduction. The sciatica was what impelled them to go to Arizona to escape the rigors of a Vermont Winter.
Retail sales last week, though still well behind last year's figures except in one or two centers, continued to expand and showed good gains over the preceding week in most districts.

A man being detained for District Attorney Dewey as a material witness in the policy-racket inquiry became a prisoner facing arraignment on a felony charge last night when, in a brief period of freedom from the jail in the old Bronx County Court Building at Third Avenue and 161st Street he hit a restaurant proprietor with a pop bottle.

THERE appears to be no limit to the problems which can be solved by the use of psychoanalytic axioms, rich in implications and ostensibly far superior to the comparatively tautologous conclusions of the experimental psychologist.
Oxford University has lately come into possession of large new benefactions and, simultaneously, some problems that are vexing its graduates and administration.

An extradition demand has been received from the German Government for Peter Forster, one of the two men who escaped from a concentration camp some two months ago and in doing so killed an Elite Guard named Kallweit. The other fugitive, named Bergatzki, was recaptured and executed.

Flight in rockets may be brought nearer by the invention of a new cooling system for rocket engines described in a patent (No. 2,122,521) just granted to Dr. Robert H. Goddard of Roswell, N. M., No. 1 United States rocket experimenter.

A big question just now which everybody wants to have answered is: Does the broad, striking advance in stock prices foretell the beginning of a new period of prosperity? Is the stock market a dependable barometer which falls when the business weather is about to turn from fair to foul and rises when the storm is about to clear?
Governor Harry W. Nice refused today to accede to the recommendation of the Baltimore Criminal Justice Commission that Police Commissioner William P. Lawson be asked to resign.

WITH the old fur coat packed away in moth balls and the apartment stripped of Winter hangings, city dwellers are once more. foot loose and fancy free. Among these fancy free are many who look on vacation time as a challenge to try something new, to map out some eleventh-hour adventure.

Some years ago Professor Arthur H. Compton asked us to think of a man on a merry-go-round in a downpour of rain. As the man revolved, more rain struck his face than his back. Substitute the Milky Way for the merry-go-round, the cosmic rays for the rain, the earth for the man.

Pensioned On his own application; to take effect 12 midnight, July 10: PATROLMAN--John J. O'Neill. Mounted Squadron 2, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 28. 1912. Appointed Probationary Patrolmen At $2,000 per annum, effective July 8:
Golfers frequently shoot "birdies" and "eagles," but Howard Tunmer of Peru went them one better. He shot a mouse. He cracked out a long drive on the fourth hole at the Peru Municipal Course.

James H. Stone, 63 years old, of 1,992 Commonwealth Avenue, Brighton, Mass., manager and seeretary of the New England Shoe and Leather Association, died of a heart attack yesterday in his room in the Hotel Astor.

The childish impulse to disobey ended tragically last night for Susan Marie Doyle, 2 years old, of 2,183 Amsterdam Avenue. She fell three and a half stories to her death from the fire-escape of her home.

YOU see them every day in Asia, and especially in India-lean, sturdy men from Turkestan, trudging along the roads with grinding wheels on their backs, or standing on the street corners patiently edging knives, scissors and all manner of cutting tools.

Any one who has been led to believe, by the secrecy which surrounds delicate diplomatic negotiations, that the expropriation of American oil properties in Mexico'has been forgotten by Washington would do well to reread the brief speech President Roosevelt made ten days ago on the pleasant occasion of dedicating the cornerstone of the Federal Building at the New York World's Fair grounds.
Eighteen gunners took part in a registered skeet event at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. The winner of the high-over-all scratch cup was C. King, who broke 49.

IN the eighteenth century, Burke and Junius would have classified this provocative yet persuasive book as a pamphlet. It contains much truth-also some half truth. The whole is enveloped in the glowing atmosphere of propaganda.

Twenty-one students at Columbia University for the Summer session have been elected to head State and regional groups formed annually since 1910 to provide recreational activities for the student body. They are:

A record registration in the free Summer classes of the Board of Education's WPA adult education program was predicted yesterday by S. Alexander Shear, acting administrator. Nearly 50,000 adults are expected to take WPA courses this Summer, compared with 35,000 last year.

MOST centers remarked on the improvement in trade sentiment during the week and several of them reported sales above a year ago. There was, of course, some reaction from the pre-holiday activity, Merchants generally, however, have revised their ideas of the outlook and now look for a Fall business which should run close to the 1937 dollar figures.

Strathmore-in-Westchester, residential community started, a little more than a year ago by Levitt Sons on property close to the Bronx River Parkway, is rapidly nearing completion, according to William Chase, director of sales in Westchester for. the building company.

The rapid growth of Federally chartered savings and loan associations, authorized by Congress five years ago, is graphically illustrated in a study released yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which shows that during 1937 the 1,163 such institutions then in existence increased their private share investments by $82,047,000, or 17.4 per cent over those of 1936.

The fifteen largest banks in this city held a larger proportion of their total assets in the form of cash and smaller proportion in the form of loans and discounts on June 30 than on any previous reporting date, an analysis of their mid-year statements shows.

Miss Kate Brousseau, psychologist, died yesterday in the Good Samaritan Hospital of a heart ailment after a long illness. Her age was 76. Miss Brousseau was born in Ypsilanti, Mich., but came to Los Angeles with her parents as a child and was graduated from the State Normal School.

The marriage of Miss Jean Tunison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Tunison of Westfield, to Harvey Mathiasen, son of William Mathiasen, also of this place, took place in the Tunison rome today. The ceremoney was performed by the Rev. Don Ivan Patch, pastor of the First Congregational Church.

ONE of the major photographic supply manufacturers will place a new "panthermic" developer on the market the middle of this month. If it lives up to the claims made for it, amateurs and professionals alike will find many of their darkroom problems solved.

From the vantage point of the twentieth century, historians have looked back. to see why the modern South has sharecroppers, poor whites and poorer blacks; driftwood shanties, illiteracy and pellagra; the country's lowest wage scales and living standards.

A summary of the results, issued today, showed that Dartmouth's sports teams made one of their greatest records in the past college year, capturing four intercollegiate championships and one unofficial Ivy League title.

Louis Simon, secretary-treasury of the Laundry Workers Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, made public yesterday a resolution condemning Abraham Cahan, editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, for what was declared to be an unfounded attack on Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers.

THE big news of what should be a pleasant July morning is that Gilbert Miller's first production of the new season will be J. B. Priestley's "I Have Been Here Before." Mr. Miller leaves London (he first will give Shaftesbury Avenue a version of "Once Is Enough") on Sept. 7, and hopes to begin his program, as they say, immediately.

When news of the death of Justice Cardozo was received on the Mall in Central Park while Leopold Prince, former Justice of the Municipal Court, was conducting the City Amateur Symphony Orchestra before a crowd of 3,000 persons last night, the program was interrupted.

Dismissal of a Federal court injunction against picketing and a decision granting to the C. I. O. International Ladies' Garment Workers the right to attempt to organize employes of the Donnelly Garment Company will be appealed to the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals, William S. Hogsett, chief counsel for the company, said today.

Discussions are under way between executives of steel companies and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O. for the formation of joint research committees to solve important problems of production, Philip Murray, chairman of the S. W. O. C., announced today.

A pamphlet criticizing the Federal Government's low-cost housing project has been written by Thomas H. Doyle, president of the Midtown Real Estate Association, and forwarded to each of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention at Albany.

A year ago last Thursday shots rang out in the night near a bridge a few miles from Peiping, once capital of China. They, too, were shots destined to be heard round the world. They started one of the most ferocious wars of modern times.

With Johnny Hopp and Estel Crabtree contributing home runs for the second successive game to lead a thirteen-hit attack on three Jersey City pitchers, the Red Wings won their fourth game in a row today, 10 to 1. It was their eight victory in the last nine games.

Industries whose pricing policies have developed through the creation of "basing-point" structures are to be in the forefront of those to be investigated by the Joint Congressional- Departmental Committee organized on July 1 to study "monopoly,"

DR. J. B. MURPHY died more than twenty-five years ago, so that his story belongs to a medical period since passed. But it was an intensely dramatic medical period, especially in surgery, with this Chicago surgeon one of the most dramatic figures in the American, if not also in the international field.

WHAT is free speech and at what point does it degenerate into license which in the public interest should be curbed? The news from home indicates a great stir over this much-discussed question in the light of certain happenings across the river from New York.
The international executive board of the United Automobile Workers of America today stripped George Addes of his official title of secretary-treasurer and expelled him from membership in the union.

After motor difficulties had prevented him yesterday afternoon and again last night from taking off on his projected flight from Floyd Bennett Field to Paris and then possibly around the world, Howard Hughes and his big Lockheed special monoplane, New York World's Fair 1939, were set for a take-off this morning.

The schism in the Indiana Democratic Senatorial controversy has been healed, but it is believed by observers that there must be continued applications of soothing ointment until the State platform is adopted by the convention Wednesday.

For years the only cure for crab grass, known to gardeners as the most persistent; and common lawn weed, was to dig it out conscientiously and prevent it from seeding. New methods of eradicating this weed are'now being practiced, based on growth habits., of the plant.

PHOTOGRAPHERS whose pockets have long been bulging with miscellaneous accessories are welcoming a new. service that a luggage manufacturer is offering to amateurs. From top grain cowhide and a variety of fine linings, the manufacturer makes to order a special case with little compartments to hold all items that the lensman feels are necessary for his work in the feld.

What promises to be a neighborhood grudge fight has been arranged for the eight-round feature bout at Dyckman Oval tomorrow night when Al Reid, Bronx lightweight, and Nat Litfin, who comes from the same section, will meet.
Miss Mary Dolores Eckert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph. C. Eckert of Jenkintown, was married this morning to Laurence Butler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Butler of Jenkintown.

Several properties at Highland Lakes, the 1,500-acre mountain resort near Stockholm, N. J., were reported yesterday as having been sold. Among those who purchased cabin sites recently were W. H. Ward of New York City, Eric K. Koeble of Brooklyn,

The Jones Beach Surf Fishing Club plans another fishing contest next Sunday at Tobay Beach. Although the one-day tournament a month ago was not productive of any record breakers, Ed Buckley, president of the organization, nevertheless is more or less resigned to such a condition.
A large number of young women will be presented to society here this Summer and many entertainments are being arranged in their honor.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H. The first event in golf to be held in the White Mountains, save for informal holiday events, will be the annual tournament of the New Hampshire Golf Association on the eighteen-hole course at Bretton Woods next Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

DOLLS and toys, because they reflect so faithfully the customs and costumes of an era, are favorite material for antique collectors. To the connoisseur these playthings are more than sentimental mementos of another day;
If the deal goes through for Princess Baba of Sarawak and her English wrestler husband, they said here today, there will be a "Babaland" in the Dutch East Indies where "every man would be a Rajah."

A trend toward modern design for small homes is revealed in the July issue of The Architectural Forum magazine, which contains about fifty plans from the recent small house planning competition, conducted jointly by the magazine and the American Gas Association.

Michael Klein, head of a Democratic club at 100 Second Avenue, announced yesterday that he would run for member of the Democratic State Committee in the movement against Charles A. Schneider, Tammany leader of the district.

Pointing out that many owners and mortgagees are in agreement that the rehabilitation of old-law tenements should be carried out on ablock-front or neighborhood basis, Maurice Deutsch, chairman of the subcommittee on research of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, advances a plan intended to achieve this objective.

The marriage of Miss Jeanne Stourton, youngest daughter of the late Major Herbert Stourton and the Hon. Mrs. Stourton, to the Hon. Sherman Stonor, only son of Lord and Lady Camoys, will take place at Brompton Oratory on Thursday.

Late next month a group of school superintendents who met in May to review the progress of occupational adjustment with which each had experimented during the last school year will publish a report for use in thirteen regional conferences of superintendents in the coming academic year.

The faces of three young men look out from a printed page-part of the endless stream of fact and propaganda that drifts, like the Gulf Stream, across the world. Good Broadway comic at the top; scientific researcher in the middle-reflective, cold; hottempered, good-natured, rather weakwilled romanticist at the bottom.

A return of confidence on the part of apartment house investors, builders and operators is seen by E. L. Scaplan, manager of the mortgage loan department of Frank H. Taylor Son, Inc., East Orange (N. J.) specialists in construction loans on apartment and business properties.

The first Washington lambs of the season arrived today. The shipment consisted of nine cars that sold straight at $9.50 a hundredweight, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. Hogs closed at the high point of. the week and a good clearance was effected. Few cattle were offered.
Finishing with a rush, the Darby Dan Farm's Francesco scored a nose victory over Tempestuous today in the $2,500-added Wolverine Handicap, feature of the closing-day program at the Fair Grounds.

The former estate of Willis S. Whittlesey, known as High Meadow Farm and including a ten-room house on 150 acres of land on Jefferson Hill, Litchfield, Conn., has been sold to a client of the DeVoe Realty Company of New Milford, broker in the deal.
Charles Nagin, maker of stained glass windows and a member of the Arts Center of the Oranges, died yesterday in the Orange Memorial Hospital at the age of 88.

The Nassau Driving Club held its third matinee of the season at the Fair Grounds today, with Cornelius Bliss Jr., president of the organization, driving his star trotter, Rex Volo, to a straight-heat triumph.

Another increase in production of gold is shown by the statement of the Quebec Bureau of Mines for May and the first five months of this year. Production for May was 68,009 ounces, compared with 57,974 the year before, bringing the total for five months to 360,125 ounces, compared with 284,999 in the same period of 1937.

WITH Summer motoring in full swing, new highway links rapidly are being completed in the metropolitan area. Drivers bound for seashore points, mountain resorts, and parks in Long Island, Westchester or New Jersey, will be pleasantly surprised by the reconstruction of narrow and antiquated roads, grade-crossing eliminations and new stretches of divided express highway.

There will be much entertaining by colonists here next week in con nection with the annual Spring Lake Invitation Tennis Tournament, which will be held at the Bathing and Tennis Club, Among those who will entertain are Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Hemphill and Mr. and Mrs. William M. Clark of New York.

The nine-acre waterfront estate known as Cedarwold, in Wareham on Buzzards Bay, Cape Cod, Mass., will be offered at auction on Saturday through Arthur C. Sheridan. The auction will be held in the main residence. The property now is owned by a financial institution.

The schism in the Indiana Democratic Senatorial controversy has been healed, but it is believed by observers that there must be continued applications of soothing ointment until the State platform is adopted by the convention Wednesday.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody added the Irish lawn tennis championship to her All-England title today when she defeated Miss T. R. Jarvis, 6-4, 6-2, in the final.

George S. Wertsner, a partner in the map-making and blueprinting firm of C. S. Wertsner Son, died yesterday at Cooper Hospital, Camden, N. J. He was stricken with his daughter, Mrs. C. Armel Nutter, at Merchantville, N. J., early this week.

ONLY a few years ago a thrill of horror and indignation swept through a segment of the local art world when some one suggested that if not all of the American murals turned out to be works of incontestably permanent value to the community whitewash might be brought into erasive use.
WHILE the Roth Quartet has been winning golden opinions abroad, the local reserve of its recordings has been exhausted. Hence the interval since it last appeared on a Columbia list.
Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Insurgents hammered from sea, land and air today against government defenders in a coastal battle south of Nules.

Miss Jean Derby Ferris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Henry Ferris of this place and Riverside, Conn., has chosen July 30 as the date for her marriage to Nils Anderson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson of Plainfield. The ceremony will be performed at noon in the garden at Tide Crest, the Ferris Summer home at Riverside.

After eight months of steady decline, President Roosevelt's popularity curve turns upward in the July Presidential index of the American Institute of Public Opinion, breaking one of the longest downtrends ever registered for the President in institute surveys.

President Roosevelt's press conferences, usually held twice a week, are always interesting and entertaining meetings. During his five years of dealing with Washington correspondents, and previously in his relation with the press at Albany, Mr. Roosevelt has developed such a skill in returning adroit answers to prying questions that the sessions have grown in attractiveness far beyond their official importance. The banter between the President and the reporters is largely responsible.

ACKERMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ackerman, Woodmere, L. I., announce birth of son, Michael Charles, July 1, St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, L. I. BLANK--Mr. and Mrs. Solo Blank, Elkins Park, Pa., announce the arrival of Carol Ruth's brother, Arthur Blank 2d, on July 4, 1938.

WHENEVER such films as "The Birth of a Baby," "Remous" or "Ecstasy" are banned from New York by the board of censors, newspaper headlines, court proceedings and widespread publicity bring the matter to the immediate attention of the public.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John D. Palmer of Rockville Centre, L. I., formerly of Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Blaker Palmer, to Robert Lodge Riedel, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Riedel of Brooklyn.

Miss Dorothy Lucille Calvo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bayard Calvo of 45 Prospect Place, this city, formerly of Savannah, Ga., was married to Curtis Ernest Calder Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Calder of Bronxville, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Victor A. Menard.

Prefacing a book that will be placed on sale tomorrow, containing all the resolutions the Fascist Grand Council adopted during the first fifteen years of its regime, Premier Benito Mussolini reviews the political, social and economic events that have occurredunder his leadership and briefly outlines domestic and foreign policies.

A strong field of contract bridge players from the metropolitan area, among them Mr. and Mrs. P. Hal Sims, Baron Waldemar von Zedtwitz, S. Garton Churchill, David Burnstine and Charles Lockbridge, has entered the four-day Southern New England Bridge Championships, to be played at the Hotel Mohican, New London, Conn., Thursday through Sunday.
Orders amounting to more than 10,000,000 reichsmarks have been placed in Germany by the Chilean Government, to modernize State railroads, it was announced today.

World zinc production in May was 143,103 tons, compared with 140,759 in April and 163,134 in May, 1937, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Production for five months amounted to 732,412 tons.

THE westward trek has reversed itself and a movement toward Broadway, probably temporary, has begun. Among the reasons are the end of the cycle of lavish musicals, the general production slump and the lowered wages being offered to genius.
THE successful return engagements, on a national scale, of Rudolph Valentino's "The Sheik" and "Son of the Sheik" have stirred up a deal of talk about the possible revival of the silent film.

A large apartment building, a dwelling and a taxpayer are among properties in Westchester County that changed hands in deals announced yesterday. In one of the largest transactions involving a multi-family property in Bronxville in some time, the building at 64 Sagamore Road was purchased by Sagamore Residences, Inc.

THE Canadian Institute of International Affairs, under whose auspices this book is issued, is "preeluded by its constitution from expressing an opinion on any aspect of British Commonwealth relations or of domestic or international affairs."

OVER the rails that stretch westward President Roosevelt's special train is clicking this week. Once more he is on his way across the continent to the Pacific Coast. For the second time in less than a year he will travel through the vast forest and upland fastnesses on the sundown side of the Rockies.

IN this vital capital of the Czechoslovak Republic has been opened an exhibition that in its extraordinary treatment of one of the most important periods of European culture proves more than an exhibition.

Myles Coen, in charge of the 108-hole Westchester open golf tournament to be played Sept. 22-25 at Fenway, White Plains, N. Y., today announced that the prize money had been raised $1,000, making the purse $13,500.

Fatal accidents during the Summer vacation period take a daily toll much higher than that for the year as a whole, statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reported yesterday.

Fashions are generally conceded to travel in seven-year cycles, but this year the veil is playing its first major revival after an absence of more than a quarter of a century. In 1900, and for a few gradually diminishing years thereafter, every haughty dowager wore a veil.

Miss Winifred M. Moffett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ball Moffet of this place, was married to W. Elbert Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Wilson. also of Westfield, in the home of the bride's parents this evening.

At 3 o'clock this morning the Foreign Ministers of Bolivia and Paraguay initialed the draft agreement, which it is hoped, will lead to the signing of a definite peace treaty terminating the 100-year-old Chaco conflict.

For the first time in about a year, checking of credit by manufacturers has become a problem because of the sudden anxiety of buyers to cover their requirements liberally before prices rise, according to credit executives yesterday.
ENGINEERS overhauling the NBC television transmitter and aerial at the Empire State Building report they do not expect to put the outfit on the air again until late this month or early in August.

The administrator of the newly created Wage and Hour Division of the Department of Labor has not yet been appointed, but those interested in an efficient administration of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 are already breaking some of the ground that must be prepared if the program is to get off to a good start.
With as furious an attack as they have been able to muster this year, the Yankees submerged the Red Sox at Fenway Park today before 18,000 fans.
A new National League rule to stop an outfielder from intentionally dropping a fly ball in order to make a double play was disclosed today by President William E. Benswanger of the Pirates.

Dr. Charles R. Dickson, famous blind physician, died today. He was one of the earliest experts on X-ray, introduced it to Toronto General HoSpital, was blinded by exposure to it and in 1914 founded the Canadian Institute for the Blind.

Federal Judge Harland B. Howe announced today the resignation of George L. R. French of Rutland as receiver of the Rutland Railroad, and the appointment of Lewis G. Morphy, chief engineer, to succeed him. The resignation becomes effective at midnight.

Steady progress is being made in the drive to bring industrial and labor leaders together to formulate a joint program which both groups can back in the coming session of Congress, John W. Hanes, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, said yesterday.
Strenuous efforts are being made to heal the breach in the ballet world which has resulted in the Universal Art and the Educational Ballets, Ltd., performing simultaneously in London.

MR. GINSBERG has a nervous mind and a roving eye. And, added to these, a decided flair for the quick, compressed, fleeting lyric. Had he lived in the early decades of the seventeenth century he surely would have been of the Tribe of Ben, clinked tankards with that jovial crew of the Mermaid, now matching verses with the cavaliers, now sidling off with Herrick to indite a small and glowing country piece.

Going over the heads of the Massachusetts Department .of Public Utilities, so to speak, Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks issued, today, an order directing the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford

Many prominent women are expected today to attend a surprise celebration of the eightieth birthday of Miss Katherine Devereux Blake, leading woman educator, former director of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, and a leader in the suffrage and peace movements.
Behind the effective pitching of Marius Russo and Jack Haley, the Newark Bears sped to a double triumph over the Toronto Leafs tonight, 12 to 1 and 3 to 0.

An increase of 25 per cent in Eastern railway coach fares, to take effect on July 25,is expected to prove a boon to highway omnibus companies which suffered when the Interstate Commerce Commission reduced the coach rate to 2 cents two years ago.

The marriage of Miss Joan Alexandra MacWillie, daughter of Mrs. Alexander MacWillie of 135 West Seventy-ninth Street and the late Mr. MacWillie, to Alan Barnes Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alanson B. Walker of Morningside, Woodmont, Conn., took place here yesterday in the Broadway Presbyterian Church.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Keeler Quinn, daughter of Mrs. William H. Quinn of this place and the late Mr. Quinn, to William B. Sleigh Jr. of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sleigh of Springfield, has been announced by her mother.

More Presidential fire against Governor Chandler, rival of Senator Barkley in the Kentucky Democratic primary, was disclosed here today less than twenty-four hours after President Roosevelt's endorsement of Mr. Barkley as the candidate favored by the New Deal.

ILDEBRANDO PIZZETTI is again momentarily in the Italian musical spotlight. Many honest critics who condemn his music dramas gladly admit his flair in one creative branch of the theatre: incidental music.

THE June Festival of opera at the Zurich Stadttheater, which began with the world premiere of Paul Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler" already described in this place, continued through the first three weeks of the month with repetitions of that novelty as well as a production of the "Ring" and performances of "Fidelio" under Furtwaengler,

Edwin Morris, civil engineer and superintendent of construction of the Raymond Concrete Pile Company, 140 Cedar Street, New York, died yesterday at Detroit of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 55 years old and resided here.

The Rev. Michael J. Shine, pastor of the Catholic Church of St. Mary, died today at the rectory after a long illness at the age of 74. Born in Ireland, Sept. 15, 1863, he was brought to America by his parents at the age of 12 and educated in the New York City schools.

A COLLECTION of birds from the Ukrainian Animal Preserve will be a prominent exhibit in the All-Union Agricultural Exposition, which opens in Moscow on Aug. 1. The birds were sent to Moscow during June in order to acclimatize them, since they came more than eleven hundred miles north of their regular habitat;

COMPLETION of a new wing, added last Winter to its gallery, makes it possible, for the Lyme Art Association to supplement the regular Summer exhibition (opened yesterday) with water-colors, prints, pastels and drawings.

SO far as transatlantic flights are concerned, this Summer is apt to be a busy one for aviation. If only half of the announced, proposed and "now-planning" fights are attempted the air over the Atlantic will be churned by a variety of propellers.

In both Tokyo and Hankow last Thursday. there were meetings, speeches, demonstrations--and collections. Two great Oriental nations were observing the first anniversary of that which they have in common--an undeclared war.
Mrs. Arabella Horlick, mother of Mrs. Mabelle Horlick Sidley, whose death occurred Wednesday in Toronto, died today at her home here at the age of 88.

Some chambers of commerce may disagree with this suggested cruise. A few executive secretaries may see red if their cities and villages are omitted from the route. But a controversy or a difference of opinion is good for the soul, especially a yachtsman's soul, and if this prods some rocking-chair skippers on clubhouse porches into a mid-season argument, the effort will be worth while.

Strange tales to the effect that some of Japan's latest warships are unseaworthy are circulating in London. Lieut. Comdr. Kenneth Edwards pays attention to them by writing in today's Sunday Times that it would appear the Japanese naval designers have been losing sight of this all-important factor in their desire to mount more guns than are carried on equivalent ships of other navies.

The National Labor Relations Board reopened its case against the Republio Steel Corporation today by issuing an intermediate report finding the company guilty of violating the Wagner act before and during the Little Steel strike of 1937.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--Bathing and boating, golf and tennis, fishing and trap shooting and a host of amusements will combine with the sessions of the huge national convention of the Elks to provide entertainment for visitors during this week.

BRAFF--KASKEL--Mrs. George J. Kaskel, 585 West End Ave., and Belle Harbor, N. Y., announces the engagement of her daughter, Stella, to Mr. Albert H. Braff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Braff of Forest Hills. N. Y.

While Union and Confederate veterans were clasping hands on the field of Gettysburg, Southern editors were erupting over aspersions cast in the sanctum of The Chicago Tribune upon the fair name of Southern fried chicken and beaten biscuits.

After three years' work, the first stage in the four-point program to provide an up-to-date inventory of all real estate in New York City has been completed, William Stanley Miller, president of the city tax department, announced yesterday.

With the wounding by stabbing this morning of two Jewish boy hikers near Tel Aviv and further shootings and stabbings in Haifa and near Tiberias involving four other Jews the week's casualties in Palestine rose to: Jews, 12 killed, 24 wounded; Arabs, 52 killed, 145 wounded.

What is the extent of the problem facing the Intergovernmental Committee, as the refugee conference here convoked by President Roosevelt modestly styles itself? What are the proposals for meeting it and what are the possibilities of their achievement? There is no quick and easy answer to any of these fundamental questions.

EVEN with Shirley Temple in town refusing to give interviews, like the Zog sisters, our notion of the best news story of the week was the sailing of the ten screen doubles for a vaudeville engagement in Europe.

The national intercollegiate tennis championship returned to Rice Institute today. In an anti-climax to yesterday's gripping semi-finals, Frank Guernsey of Orlando, Fla., a sophomore at Rice, administered a crushing defeat to Morey Lewis of Kenyon College on the clay courts of the Merion Cricket Club.

The problem of overcoming the "boxed-in" atmosphere often found in small housekeeping apartments has been met successfully at the Southmoor, new seventeen-story and penthouse apartment structure at 230 Central Park South, points out Dora Brahms, decorator.

WASHINGTON'S BIRTHDAY: The Father of His Country gave his name to the national capital, to one State, to numerous counties, to uncounted avenues, streets and squares and to postoffices in twenty-six States ranging through the alphabet from Arkansas to West Virginia.

After a week of plodding along in miserable shooting conditions the Canadians turned in excellent scores as serious competition began today at the Empire meeting of the National Rifle Association.

BELMONT--Un Carnet de Bal: Harry Baur, Francoise Rosay.* CAMEO--Pugachev*; If War Comes Tomorrow, Tuesday. CAPITOL--The Shopworn Angel: Margaret Sullavan. CRITERION--Rose of the Rio Grande: Movita, John Carroll. GLOBE--We're Going to Be Rich: Gracie Fields, Victor McLaglen.*
The Berlin Laboratory for Voice Investigation announced today that recent tests indicated that a cultured voice had a beneficial effect on the human organism.

The Mexican Government and Jewish leaders have come to a tentative understanding with regard to solving their problems after a long period of difficulties during which informal diplomatic intervention for Jews has been necessary.

The United States Steel Corporation in June shipped 478,057 tons of finished steel products, an increase of 12,976, compared with May but a decrease of 790,493, compared with June, 1937. In the first half of this year shipments declined to 3,010,354 tons from 7,614,274 in the six months ended on June 30, 1937.

THE tradition of sanctuary for the fugitive is one of the most romantic as well as celebrated in the folklore and literature of the world. It has even left its distinguishing mark on the most popular of children's games,-prisoner's base and cops and robbers.

R. J. MITCHELL admits her inspiration; the learned Dr. P. S. Allen, late president of Corpus Christi College, Oxford. She refrains from characterizing her own gift of research rendered inconspicuous by an attractive style, so we do it for her; it is indigenous, superb.
Goose, skippered by George Nichols, her owner, won the six-meter trial in the Seawanhaka Corinthian regatta today, the first victory for the new boat.
In a battle between the inhabitants of two villages in the State of Oaxaca over the possession of lands, seven persons were killed and one wounded, the newspaper Prensa reports today.

Dr. Frederick Peterson, former president of the American Neurological Association and an author, poet and translator, died late Saturday at the Memorial Hospital. His home was at Bridgewater, Conn., and his New York offices at 555 Park Avenue. He was 79 years old.

The National Broadcasting Company paid tribute yesterday to the emory of George Gershwin, the American composer, by a special ation-wide broadcast heard during e RCA Magic Key hour at Radio ty. Nathaniel Shilkret,

How the death of United States Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo and the possible appointment of Senator Robert F. Wagner as his successor may affect the political situation in New York State was the subject of much speculation yesterday by party leaders.

Twenty-nine Puerto Ricans were arrested for disorderly conduct early last night by Patrolman John Sythes of the Central Park.'Station, who charged they were holding a meeting without permit in Central Park just off 110th Street and Fifth Avenue and refused to move when ordered to do so.
The National Symphony - Orchestra launched a series of "Sunset Symphonies" tonight at the Potomac Watergate near the Lincoln Memorial, with Dr. Hans Kindler conducting.

Mr. and Mrs. John Oakman of 170 East Seventy-eighth Street and Newburyport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Renee Oakman, to McIlvaine Parsons, son of Dr. Elsie Clews Parsons of 320 East Seventysecond Street and the late Herbert Parsons.

Miss Shirley temple of Hollywood, Calif., who was introduced to society at Hyde Park yesterday, called on an old friend here today and went swimming With himsomething she had declined to do with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The Dodgers were glad to leave the sweltering confines of Shibe Park today, even if they were not happy about their double engagement with the Phils. They took the opener, 6-3, and dropped the nightcap, 5-3, before 4,949 paying patrons.

The total value of retail sales in Great Britain from February to May, the first four months of the trading year, was only 0.8 per cent above that for the 1937 comparative, according to the retail trade statistics just issued here by the Bank of England.

Frank Guernsey, the Rice Institute net star who won the-national intercollegiate tennis championship on Saturday, started play in the New York State clay-court championship at the Seminole Club of Forest Hills yesterday and made his way into the fourth round,

John Conyngham Stevens, assistant secretary of the Pennsylvania Company for Insurance on Lives and Granting Annuities, died today at .Abington Memorial Hospital at the age of 66. His home was in Jenkintown.

Administration farm leaders said today that, if present prices of cotton and wheat were maintained for the season, efforts of the government to bolster prices would be kept to a minimum to encourage exports of these commodities.

Peruvian overseas trade in the first five months of this year totaled 1,151,473 tons valued at 227,522,323 soles, compared with 1,327,712 tons valued at 217,742,291 soles in 1937. The increase in value was owing to a strong demand for foreign goods;

Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa of New York, who for many years have been members of the Summer colony here, announced tonight the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Elena Villa, to Robert Grant 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Grant Jr. of Jericho, L. I.

It is undoubtedly true, as President Roosevelt told a Kentucky audience, that the budgets of a great many States and municipalities are in balance only because the Federal Governinent has been piling up a series of unprecedented deficits.

Services Monday, July 11, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., at 3 P. M. San Francisco papers please copy. Please omit flowers.

The Treasury, acting as fiscal agent for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will offer tomorrow for subscription $200,000,000 of RFC % per cent notes, Series N, to be dated July 20 and to mature on the same date in 1941.

Bill Cox vaulted into first place in the Bermuda Trophy series for International class yachts today in the Manhasset Bay Club's special regatta. Freeman L. Meinertz clung to his long lead in the Atlantic Class series for the Noyes Trophy.

Joseph H. Lane, vice president of the Cavalier Corporation, Chattanooga, Tenn., was elected yesterday chairman of the board of governors of the American Furniture Mart. O. C. Hatch, vice chairman of the Standard Chair Company, Union City, Pa., was elected vice chairman.
Cotton growers planted this year 26,904,000 acres, a decrease of 22 per cent from the 1937 acreage and the lowest acreage ever planted to cotton, in fact, since 1900.

Professor Preston E. James of the a University of Michigan, in the current issue of The Geographical Re- to view, publication of the American la Geographical Society, reports that fr a persistent influx of Japanese into se Brazil during the last decade has th resulted in a Japanese population of nearly 20 per cent in the one Brazilian State of Sao Paulo.

Four leading New York organizations have joined in filing with the New York State Public Service Commission a memorandum urging the commission so to interpret the motor-carrier regulation law enacted by the last session of the Legislature that trucks operating entirely within an area, roughly forty miles from New York City, will be exempt from regulation.

Surrounded by delicate weather instruments and powerful radio senders and receivers, nine men remained tense in a room of the Business Systems Building on the grounds of the New York World's Fair last night as the plane carrying Howard Hughes and his four associates headed out over the dark Atlantic Ocean.

Mennen Company will shut down its plant in Newark, N. J., during the week of July 18 to give its employes a week's vacation with lull pay. The seventh annual directory of manufacturers of variety store merchandise will be issued by Chain Store Age on Aug. 1.

Primogeni ture right-the sacred privilege of the German landed aristocracy-will cease by decree on Jan. 1, 1939. The present privilege, which gives inheritance to the eldest son and his issue, accounted for the perpetuation of numerous huge estates in Germany as family possessions.

It is an engaging picture that shows Vice President Garner cooking a hunk of meat at a barbecue near his home in Uvalde, Texas. The homely, appealing quality-of this photograph has no possible bearing on Mr. Garner's qualifications as a Vice President.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,790,264,450. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

In skimming the latest batch of foreign newspapers, in the main English and French, though some German and Italian papers are in the pile and a few scattered sheets from places as far afield as Belgrade and Bucharest, Ankara and Teheran, the thing that strikes the reader most is the infinitesimal space they all give to news of America, North or South. Abroad,
Ralph D. Brown of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who directed the hunt for and capture of J. H. Seadlund, the kidnapper of Charles S. Ross of Chicago, announced last night that he had resigned.

Miss Katherine Newbold of Boston, vice commodore of the Upper Saranac Yacht Club, of which Harry Blagden is commodore, is here for the season with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. T. Jefferson Newbold, who have opened Camp Chequapee.

No one has a right to believe in the Christian point of view who has not at first thought 'it incredible, the Rev. Dr. Charles Leslie Glenn, rector of Christ Church, Cambridge, Mass.,- said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Colonel Clifford M. Elwell of Toms River, head of the South Jersey Transit Commission, was elected today Commander of the New Jersey department of the Order of the Purple Heart at the annual reunion here.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Pearson and Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Redfield Jr. had a large cocktail party yesterday at the Pearson place, Estamos, Great Barrington. They had 100 guests.
Katherine Devereux Blake, pioneer suffragette and peace worker and for thirty-four years principal of Public School 6 in New York, celebrated her eightieth birthday here today.
Probably the most interesting time that I had during the trip so far was just after. we began floating down the Colorado.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the Anchor liner Caledonia from Scotland and Ireland was the Rev. Joseph T.-Shields of St. Louis, who celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of his priesthood two months ago.

Hardly a week before his long-awaited state visit to Paris, which has already been postponed' once because of the death of Queen Elizabeth's mother, King George VI has developed a "mild attack" of gastric influenza.
Johnny Vander Meer, the Reds' young hero of two straight no-hit games, made his debut at Wrigley Field an auspicious one today by beating the Cubs, 3 to 1, with four hits before a crowd of 30,793.

John Borg, publisher of The Bergen Record, who on July 2 was made a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority for a sixyear term, has been appointed chairman of the Authority's committee on program and work and vice chairman of the committee on port protection, it was announced yesterday.

Robert Jordan, formerly buyer of cameras, film and photographic supplies for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., has been appointed sales manager of Dufaycolor, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Pierpont M. Hamilton, president. Mr. Jordan will take charge of a national color photography sales program for Dufaycolor.

While the Intergovernmental Refugee Committee took Sunday off, its American and British delegations continued to explore today the prospects of a compromise between their positions regarding a permanent mechanism to the organization of which this session is mainly devoted.

An eightpoint code setting forth fair trade practices for the millinery industry was adopted here yesterday as the National Council of Millinery Manufacturers ended its three-day convention. The council also decided to inaugurate an intensive national trade promotion program.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Simmons of Glen Rock, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Helen Simmons, to Dr. William E. Bigelow, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. E. Bigelow, also of Glen Rock.

A and seventh-inning uprising in the second game of their double-header today gave the Pirates a sweep of a four-game series with the Cardinals and extended their victory string to eleven straight, tying the major league season's record for consecutive victories.

In a lawsuit against the steel trust, a Dutch court has decided that German corporations which have exercised their right to repay loans before maturity must repay in gulden at the full gold mark, not at depreciated blocked mark exchange.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry 0. Tallmadge entertained last night at Greentree for Miss Frances Pearson of New York, their house guest. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Langhorne, Mr. and Mrs. George Batcheller, Mrs. Robert Hall McCormick, Mrs. Harold A. Howard, Baron Bucovich and William Stewart.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By VINCENT MOTORS, INC., 146 E. 56th St.-Liabilities, $28,332; assets, $3,712. Receivers Appointed JOHN NICHOLAS GESCHWINDER, dry goods, Pine Bush, N.Y.--Philip Mylod was appointed under $1,000 bond by Judge Leibell. VENEZIA WROUGHT IRON STUDIO, INC., 417 E. 156th St.--Joseph I. Carroll was appointed under $1,000 bond by Judge Leibell.
Elijah P. Rapelye, retired New York jeweler, died here today of a heart attack, Mr. Rapelye, who was in his eighty-first year, was taken ill Thursday. ay.

Business sentiment this week has been depressed by official and press analyses showing that the profit-making capacity of German industry has reached, if not already passed, its highest point, and by forebodings about exports to the effect that the Reich's

Sharp increases in livestock quotations pushed The Annalist's weekly index of wholesale commodity prices up 8/10 point in the week ended on Saturday. This was the widest single week's rise since early last September.

Plans for developing the 2,100acre tract at Pawling. N. Y., which Lowell Thomas purchased last year, have been announced by the radio commentator. The property surrounds Lake Hammersley and is about twenty-two miles from President Roosevelt's estate at Hyde Park. It was acquired from the Fred F. French estate.

Scoring a straight-set triumph over Robert Peacock of the University of 'California, Donald Hawley of Orange, erstwhile N.-Y. U. star, retained his New Jersey State men's singles tennis crown today at the
While President Roosevelt is on his speaking tour, his second in command, Vice President Garner, is giving-a practical demonstration of his theory- of enjoying a vacation at home.

Princeton University has honored 265 with Spring sports insignia, according to an announcement today by R. Kenneth Fairman, '34, graduate manager of athletics. The awards went to twenty-one teams in seven branches of sport.

Sales of American-made outboard motors in Sweden are going very well this year as the result of a boom in the pleasure-boat field, the Commerce Department reports. It is believed, the department says, that one American make is dominating the market, even though there is a considerable domestic production.

The millions of hopeful persons who flocked to the metropolitan beaches and resorts yesterday, expecting some measure of relief from the humidity-laden heat that reached a high mark for the year, found relatively little comfort outside an almost tepid surf.
Spiritually, our Lord was the originator of the blood transfusion, the Rev. Walter Ellenberg said yesterday in a sermon in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Under the influence of the brilliant recovery in Wall Street and the firmness of raw material prices, the Paris Bourse was exceedingly firm at the beginning of the week just ended, but the rising movement started by speculators was not supported by investment buying.

Miss Ann Louise Pendleton, daughter of Mrs. Arthur T. Pendleton of this city and the late Mr. Pendleton, has chosen Aug. 27 for her marriage to Alan Brainard Pinkerton, son of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Pinkerton of Bayonne. 'The ceremony will take place in St. John's Episcopal Church, with the rector, the Rev. Dr. Lyttleton E. Hubard, officiating.

The Spanish Government began preparations today to meet any eventuality in the event, of an Insurgent blockade on the Mediterranean Sea. A decree published in the Official Gazette created an "official management of the Spanish merchant fleet," with a government subsidy to organize the merchant marine.

Columbia University's seventeenth annual educational book exhibit will open today in the university gymnasium, with 50,000 volumes, as well as school material including posters, maps, globes and periodicals, on display until July 29.

Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., added another tennis title to his collection today when he easily subdued the diminutive Ladislaus Hecht. Czechoslovak Davis Cup star, 6-1, 6-4, 6-4, in the final match of the national championships.

Macklin Marrow last night made his second appearance as leader of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the- Lewisohn Stadium. The first half of his program was devoted to-Beethoven and- consisted of that composer's overture to "Coriolanus" and the Second symphony.

The hardships man endures are the principal factors in the strengthening of his spirit, the Rev. Philip Cowell Jones of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, declared in his sermon there yesterday.

The annual journalistic awards of the National Headliners Club wereannounced here today by Jack Price of Editor and Publisher, chairman of the award committee of the club, which is made up of newspaper men, newsreel and magazine editors and radio commentators who come here each year for an annual frolic, under the sponsorship of the Press Club of Atlantic City.

Thwarted in his first attempt at suicide yesterday afternoon by the arrival of a friend, Martin Anderson, 43 years old, a riveter, succeeded an hour later by inhaling illuminating gas in the kitchen of his first-floor flat in. a three-story dwelling at 328 Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

Digging of the biggest white potato crop in South Jersey in many years is getting under way and farmer have prospects -of fair profits if the present marketholds. Estimates place, returns well above the normal value of $5,900,000 for the State's annual potato crop.

The United States gunboat Monocacy left her dock at Kiukiang yesterday and sailed up the Yangtze River a few miles from the city to be out of possible danger during an imminent battle between the advancing Japanese and the Chinese forces at Kiukiang, 135 miles downriver from Hankow.

During the last few weeks the management of Claremont Inn, leased from the Park Department, has been under. fire from indignant residents of Riverside Drive who declared that the inn's fifteenpiece orchestra, like Macbeth, is a murderer of sleep.

Ewald Frederick Giese, son of the late Rev. Dr. Ewald Frederick Giese of Brooklyn, died on Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Helen Thompson Giese; a daughter, Mrs. George Denman Martin of Canton, Ohio;

The Federal Symphony Orchestra as conducted by Giuseppe BamOschek at its concert yesterday afternoon in the Federal Music theatre. Because of the indispotion of Sydney Rayner, tenor solot, changes in the program were ecessitated.

The cotton market here was rather active last week, showing something like old-time form. There was good trade buying, with a fair volume of speculative trading and the usual volume of liquidation or profit-taking that accompanies an active market.

Edward J. Schirmer of Greenwich, Yale freshman star, and Edward J. Foy of the home club, 1937 Jersey interscholastic champion, today won the Essex Fells Country Club's first member-guest invitation golf tournament.

Brookville (72)--36-hole final round for President's Trophy: C. Gower defeated H. Blohme, 1 up. 36-hole final round for Vice President's Trophy: G. A. Cuff defeated G. Cornelius, 1 up. Cherry Valley (72)--Monthly prize sweepstakes: Match play vs. par, Class A: W. M. Cotterell. 2 up; B. Paterson Jr., 1 up. Class B: Tie for first between K. B. Ris and John Megaw, 1 up.

President Roosevelt's plunge into the Oklahoma primary campaign left the situation much as it was. The voting is Tuesday. Even Senator Elmer Thomas, for whom a hearty endorsement was expected in his race for renomination, admitted that Mr. Roosevelt did not make a "stump speech" for him.

At 7:20 o'clock last night the big silver monoplane New York World's Fair 1939 roared down the runway at Floyd Bennett Airport on the shore of Jamaica Bay and headed out over the Atlantic, bound for Paris and perhaps around the world.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey reported to the public yesterday on the conduct of his office in the first six months of his incumbency and showed that his staff had obtained a higher percentage of trial convictions than any New York County prosecutor since the turn of the century.

More than 150 members of the Steuben Society of America made a pilgrimage yesterday to Conference House, Tottenville, S. I., where exercises were held in conjunction with the Daughters of the American Revolution, the American Legion and other patriotic societies.

A Polish stratosphere flight will be made by Polish aviators and scientists in the world's largest balloon in September, according to an announcement by the National Geographic Society today after- a . conference with the staff of the Polish Embassy.

A comprehensive program to help Jewish refugees find economic security and to provide for their assimilation in Jewish-American social, religious and cultural life has been undertaken by the National Federation of Jewish Men's Clubs, it was announced yesterday.

AKRON-Akron D. G. Co.; A; Vineberg, boys' clothing, men's furnishings; 218 W. 40th (B. F. Levis). BALTIMORE-Irving Perellis; M. Kahn, ready-to-wear; 101 W. 31st (C. Welll. BERKELEY, Calif.-J. F. Rink Co.; G. A. Haskell, draperies; 101 W. 31st (C. Weill). BALTIMORE-May Co.; Miss L. Barnstein, dresses; 1,440 Bway.

Rattling off twenty-eight hits in two games, including ten extra-base blows, the Red Wings won a double-header today from Jersey City 10 to-6 and 5 to 4, to go into second place in the International League.

The burden of chronic disease falls most heavily on the two-fifths of the population comprising the lower economic group, which is least able to bear it, according to studies by the National Health Survey reported today by the United States Public Health Service.

The tenets of modernism empty churches, but preaching that tells of the vicarious sacrifices of Christ invariably fills them, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street, said yesterday.

A general view of business conditions does not suggest that there has been any improvement in trade. Until early June the curve continued downward. Since then greater stability appears to have been shown, while business in Great Britain, although not showing actual recovery,
German propaganda in Brazil is now accusing the United States of having fostered both the Cedillo revolt in Mexico and the May 11 uprising in Brazil.

After having received their marriage license Saturday, Frances Langford, radio performer and screen star, and Jon Hall, film actor, were married yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

The extraordinary grand jury investigating the policy racket and the slaying of Williamn Snyder, labor union leader, will resume its inquiry this week. Another grand jury. is to resume its inquiry into the charges that resulted in the arrest of Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr. of Brooklyn, accused of having accepted $36,000 in bribes from two taxicab concerns to obtain favorable legislation in their behalf.

Miss Virginia Laist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Laist of 1,125 Fifth Avenue, New York, was married here yesterday in St. Mark's Church to George Gore of Los Angeles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bancroft Gore of Rapid City, S. D. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Como.

Norton is issuing on July 20 a new edition of "Insurgent America: The Revolt of the Middle Classes," by Alfred M. Bingham. The book was first published in 1935 by Harper. A new edition of Kahlil Gibran's "Jesus, the Son of Man" will be released by Knopf on July 18.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Medina of New York gave a buffet supper tonight aboard their cruiser, Spindrift II. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Nash, Mr. and Mrs. Basil O'Connor, Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Poillon, Captain Roger Wisner, U. S. A., and Mrs. Wisner, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Twitchell and Miss Elizabeth Remsen.
When the Japanese Army entered Suchow and Kaifeng, which had been Chinese strongholds on the Lung-Hai Railway, they found no enemy troops and were mystified by the sudden retreat.

An old Yankee cast-off, Ben Chapman, came back today to break Lefty Gomez's spell over the Red Sox, arouse some 27,000 steaming fans in Fenway Park with a disputed double, and down the McCarthymen with unconcealed glee.

THE FISHMANS, by H. W. Katz. (Viking, $2.50.) A first novel. Mr MIND A KINGDOM, by, George Thomas. (Dutton, $2.50.) ; The diary of the author of "A Tenement in Soho." THE SILVER MAGNET, by Grant Shepherd. (Dutton, $3.) The story of thirty years in a Mexican silver mine.

Germaniy's wholesale price index on June 29 stood at 105.7, which compared with 105.5 on June 22. In the first six months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.8, on March 2.

Senator Donahey of Ohio, chairman of the joint Congressional committee named to investigate the Tennessee Valley Authority, announced today that the inquiry would begin with a committee meeting in the Federal Building here tomorrow.

The recognition of the responsibility of God is the first step toward real recovery and greater, permanent recovery,' the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia University, said yesterday in a sermon at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus.

The recent offer of the Republic of Cuba to resume interest payments at the rate of 4 1/2 per cent on the defaulted 5 1/2 per cent public works bonds and to pay arrears of interest in bonds on 45.45 per cent of the amount due is an equitable settlement, according to a bulletin issued today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance.

June saw a slight decrease in the unfavorable balance of French foreign trade, although the deficit remains serious. It is expected to be offset largely this year by the large number of foreign tourists reported.
Irish troops will take over the Cork Harbor forts and Spike Island Tomorrow form British garrisons.

Victories by the Bell Rangers and Meadow Larks marked the opening of the Meadow Brook Club's tourney for twelve-goal polo teams today, while the Bostwick Field and Long Island quartets triumphed in high-goal exhibition matches.

When Judge Cardozo went to the Supreme Court from the Court of Appeals, where he had already written his name high among the great judges of the English-speaking world, lawyer and layman, all voices united to praise him.
American-made goods are currently in good demand in many countries, the Commerce Department reports as the result of information received by its representatives abroad.
The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that it had filed with the National Labor Relations Board charges of unfair practices on the part of the Shepard Steamship Company.

R. D. Brawley, driver, tonight led thirty-five passengers from a wrecked and flaming bus and then, bruised and cut, crawled back through the machine with a flashlight to make certain none had been trapped.
The report of the American Superpower Corporation for the first six months of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net asset value on June 30 for the preference stock of $26.99 a share.

A general change for the better in the outlook for the world wheat crop had a depressing effect on the price of that grain in leading markets last week. Even the prospect that the Department of Agriculture would announce this week that the loan

Permission to interview American prisoners in the concentration camp at San Pedro de Cardena, about three miles from Burgos, was finally obtained by this correspondent after two months of effort. With enough patience, one can get almost any thing in Nationalist [Insurgent Spain.

An appeal to the clergy of all faiths to observe next Saturday and Sunday as "days of solemn protest against the aerial bombings of defenseless civilians" was made public yesterday by twelve religious leaders representing both the Christian and Jewish faiths.
Upon his arrival in Manhattan tomorrow, Harold. Lloyd will open negotiations with David Rose, head of Paramount's British production, for the filming of "What Ho," by Richard Connell.

Wall Street remains the factor dominating the London metal market, where speculation continues to be the main influence on prices. When Wall Street is strong, prices rise, and when it reacts, prices fall.

Although two policemen were present as a precaution against robbery, a thug held up the wine and liquor store owned by Herman Berger at 200-15 Linden Boulevard, St. Albans, Queens, late Saturday night and escaped with $280, it was learned yesterday.
Additional tributes to the character and public services of Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo were paid yesterday by persons prominent in many walks of life. Among them were the following:
