L. M. Clark, Inc., national advertising research organization, will widen the scope of its reports on advertising readership and interest starting this month to show the cost per person reached with a particular advertisement as against an average cost for each industry.
The letter of Grover A. Whalen, president of the New. York World's Fair, to the heads of foreign governments, carried on the plane of Howard Hughes, follows:

The New York A. C. conquered the Long Island City Baseball Club, 13-10, in a free-hitting contest at Travers Island yesterday. The victory was the seventh straight for the winners, who registered eleven of their runs in the first three frames.

Women are just as important as nien in the struggle now going on for democracy, Miss Earlene White told the annual meeting of the board of directors of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs here tonight. She is the federation's president.

The 13-year-old Women's Swimming Association sensation, Miss Helene Rains, added to her imposing collection of championships by winning the metropolitan senior 220yard breast-stroke and 440-yard free style titles today at the A. A. U. meet held in the Lido Beach Country Club's outdoor fifty-meter pool. She successfully defended her 300-meter individual medley laurels yesterday.

Among the industrial developments in Germany this week, the increased activity for West German textiles is noteworthy. Other reports showed that bankruptcies in June numbered 166, against 180 in June of last year, and that the Reich's railroad carloadings in May were 2.7 per cent higher than in May, 1937.

Entries for the national doubles and singles grass court championship tournaments will be accepted starting today, it was announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association. The competitions are to take place on the courts of the Longwood Cricket Club in Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, L. I.

Prime Minister Mackenzie King is expected within a few months to pay another visit to Washington, the date probably depending on the status of the negotiations for a new Canadian-American trade treaty.
The Tercentenary Jubilee Chorus of Sweden will give a concert under the patronage of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. in Carnegie Hall.

The only New Yorker on the plane, Richard Stoddart, its radio engineer, was born in this city Dec. 1, 1900. He attended the public schools here and was graduated from the Dickinson High School of Newark, N. J.
While the official steel report for June affirms that no improvement is visible in international sentiment, dispatches from Brussels report marked signs of renewed activity in the first week of July.

Funeral services were held yesterday in Riverside Memorial Chapel at Seventy-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue for Harvey A. Mayer of the family firm which, since the days of P. T. Barnum, has held the program publishing and selling contract with the Barnum Bailey Circus.
Three men and a woman were burned to death when a sight-seeing plane crashed near Westchester. Airport here tonight after attempting to make a landing af the airport.
Mrs. Herbert Shipman had luncheon guests at Seaview Terrace today. Mrs. Irving C. Tomlinson entertained at Salt Marsh and Mrs. C. Ledyard Blair gave a large luncheon at Honeysuckle Lodge.

Prince Charming II, famous bay gelding owned by the Claredda Farm of Mr. and Mrs. Edward V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, N. J., today continued his brilliant winning career by capturing the Grand Hunter championship of the eighth annual horse show came to a conclusion on the polo field of the Westchester C. C. It was a sweep for the stable, which also won the reserve rosette with the brown gelding Woodfellow.
A world outboard motor boat record fell today as Clinton R. Ferguson of Waban, Mass., won the New York State championship.

Adoption of the grade-crossing removal amendment by the Constitutional Convention and its approval by the voters in November were predicted yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. With the prediction the Mayor coupled the promise that within two years after the voters acted the city would have removed all crossings along Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn.

Many a pampered pekingese or thoroughbred horse receives better medical care than the average white-collar worker, Dr. Morris Fishbein informed the banqueting members of the American Veterinary Medical Association.
John Chambers Ryan, who until he retired in 1932 was statistician of the Museum of Natural History in New York, died today at his home here at the age of 62.

Messages of regret at the death of Benjamin N. Cardozo, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, arrived today from all parts of the world while some of his intimate friends and relatives called to pay their respects in person at the home of Judge Irving Lehman of the New York Court of Appeals, where Justice Cardozo died of heart disease last night.

While neighborhood urchins disported themselves in an adjacent pool and fountain, a less comfortable group of 400 persons gathered yesterday afternoon under a blistering sun to' join in the first of a series of community "sings" in Washington Square.

John B. Dawson's Melba of the Bayside Yacht Club of New York and Ralph V. Whipple's Edraul of the Englewood Yacht Club of New Jersey were the winners of the New York Athletic Club's motor boat race here from Execution Lighthouse, off New Rochelle. They made the most accurate runs from advance calculations over the 100 miles.
Ted Lyons, White Sox veteran, pitched a 5-to-4 victory over the Tigers today as Chicago broke even in the four-game series.
Speculative interest in oats and other minor grains, including soy beans, remains at a low ebb here. Harvesting of oats has progressed as far as South Dakota, with highly variable yields.

Three flying fishermen were injured here this morning when the biplane that was taking them from Somerton, near Philadelphia, to a day's angling at Wildwood, nose dived from 100 feet and plowed into a tomato field near here.

Philippine troops poured into the resort city of Baguio, 125 miles north of here, today to help maintain order in a strike of bus drivers. The soldiers were called in to reinforce constabulary and police when 2,000 strike sympathizers gathered threateningly.

Street musicians, jugglers, French officers and other colorful characters from the "Casbah" quarter of Algiers will throng the Versailles Club next Monday night when the New York Exchange for Woman's Work will present a Summer fete entitled "A Night in Algiers." Proceeds of the benefit will go to the Vacation House maintained by the exchange in Stockbridge, Mass.
The State's death rate in May was 10.7 per 1,000 of population, or the lowest ever recorded for the month. The birth rate, 13.3 per 1,000 population, equalled the rate for May last year.

Seventy-six reserve officers, comprising the Thirtieth Infantry, arrived in Camp Dix today to await the arrival Tuesday of 2,300 members of Citizens Military Training Camps. Directed by regular army officers -of the Sixteenth Infantry, the reservists will supervise the training of the youths during the first two weeks of their thirty-day training period.

The B. M. T. announced yesterday that it had ordered an experimental lightweight and streamlined three-section car, built of aluminum alloy, for use on its subway and elevated lines. The new car will be equipped with rubber-cushioned wheels and rubber springs designed to reduce operating noises materially.

The Rev. Robert J. Murphy, chaplain of the Howe School for Boys, Howe, Ind., warned against the danger of the church becoming merely a philanthropic institution by neglecting its "supernatural work," in a sermon yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), Twenty-ninth Street, east of Fifth Avenue.

The Shrewsbury Polo Club riders, paced by H. W. (Rube) Williams, defeated the Rumson Country Club today, 7 to 6. Tommy Hitchcock, international ten-goal star, was the chief attraction, playing the pivot position on the Rumson quartet. His high shots and power drives to the forwards thrilled the fans.
Joseph T. Castles, who for many years operated an ice cream plant here, died yesterday at his Summer home, at Bradley Beach in his seventieth year.

Greenwich St, 222, s w cor Barclay St; Anna M. Ruesch, widow and devisee of William J. Ruesch, to Irving Savings Bank, 115 Chambers St; mtg $50,000, held by grantee ($51.50). Hamilton Terrace, 54; Bowery Savings Bank to Edro Holding, Inc, 2,061 Bway ($8).

Wilson McNeeley and Raymond P. Scott of Philadelphia placed second with Star Dust today for the lead in the Barnegat Bay elimination series of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association. With only one more contest to be sailed they appear likely to represent the local filet in the world championship at San Diego in Septemver.
Buildings in Manhattan were taken for modernizing in sales and leases announced over the week-end. Most of the buyers were investors.

A backing and filling movement in the stock market last week, punctuated by heavy periods of profit-taking from the professional section and accompanied by a slowing down in trading volume, forced the list to drop approximately two points of the gains registered over the past three weeks. However,

PETER FREUCHEN'S "Arctic Adventure," a narrative of life in what is commonly if tautologically termed the Frozen North, carried the story of his career down to about the year 1924. What happened in the ensuing eight or nine years is the subject of his latest book, "It's All Adventure."

Word has been received here that the marriage of Miss Rita Bischoff of Lugano, Switzerland, to Robert Allen Baker, only son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Elmer Baker of White Plains, N. Y., will take place today in Lugano.

Stimulated by the strength of gilt-edge securities, new capital offerings are appearing here in increasing numbers. Standard investments have been offered at high levels and all offerings last week were oversubscribed.

Seminole Ave (15-4278) n w cor of Rhinelander Ave, 50x100; Hyman Markowits to Ninth Federal Savings Loan Ass'n, 1,451 B'way; $11,500. Kelly St (10-2710) e s, 542 ft n of Longwod Ave, 37x100; Dawe Holding Corp to Central Hanover Bank Trust Co, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent; $14,750.
Wilhelmus Bogart Bryan, former Washington newspaper man and graduate of Princeton in 1877, died here today of a heart attack at his home, Oak Bluffs. He was 84 years old.

An attempt by a party of weekend visitors to string an aerial for a radio they had brought with them to a Summer cottage resulted today. in the death of two adults and a child, after the wire they were using came in contact with an electric transmission line.

Health officials of the International Settlement reported today a steady increase in cholera here due to the prevailing hot weather. During the past two weeks the number of suspected cases has increased from an average of 40 to 70 a day. In the International Settlement alone 50 cases were reported daily, mostly among refugee camps.

The grocers' committee of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, at a meeting yesterday in a mid-town private home, decided to call upon Mayor La Guardia and the Commissioner of Health today to aid them in their efforts to force milk dealers and union milk truck drivers to

Hank Leiber, a big man who invariably moves with great care and deliberation, went back to work at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the result was both gratifying and enlightening to a sweltering crowd of 15,278.

While Mrs. John A. Warner, daughter of former Governor Alfred E. Smith and wife of the Superintendent of the New York State police, and Mrs. Foye Stanifordwerebathing in the surf at the Southampton Beach Club with their husbands at noon today a sneak thief entered their bath house and stole jewelry valued at $15,000.

John M. P. Thatcher, a partner in the law firm of Kobbe, Thatcher, Frederick Hoar, has leased an apartment containing thirteen rooms and six bathe in 510 Park Avenue. The lease was arranged by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Demand for money fluctuated here this week, with considerable rediscounting by the banks at times. Day loans today were at 27 to 3 1/8 per cent. In April-the first month since the Reich abandoned borrowing for rearmament by special bills-245,000,

Cotton prices established new high levels for the movement in the early part of last week, but at the end of the week all the early gains had been wiped out and prices were below those. of the previous week. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts showed net declines for the week of 4 to 9 points.

Bushwicks 5, Philly Starts. 4 (1st game) Philly Stars 6, Bushwicks 4 (2d game). Carltons 12, Hoboken 3 (1st game).Carltons 4, Cedarhurst 1 (2d game). Cedarhurst 6, House of David 3 (night game). Bay Ridge 8, Royal Giants 5 (1st game) Bay Ridge 2, Royal Giants 0 (2d game).
Fletcher L. Smith, who conducted a coal and insurance business for many years in Bayonne, N. J., died here yesterday at his home of a heart ailment. He was 45 years old.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., reported today that it and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Northrop Corporation, had net profits of $1,093,149 for the six months ended on May 31. This sum, subject to year-end adjustments and audit, is equivalent to $1.91 a share on 570,683 shares outstanding, the report said.

Tomorrow is the second anniversary of the conclusion of the July 11, Austro-German agreement and the controlled press recalls the importance of this agreement as the Reich's first effective step toward the absorption of Austria. However,

Belief that the policy of "economic nationalization" among nations was not a passing phase but had come to stay was expressed here by L. S. Amery, M. P., president of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers and former British Cabinet Minister, at a general session recently of the fourth International Advertising Convention.

The estate of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Warner here will be the setting next Saturday, Sunday and Monday for the Youth Aliyah Fete. The event is another of the many benefits given to help maintain Jewish children from Germany, Austria and Poland in a colony in Palestine.
A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Frank P. Mathews of this place on Friday in the Bridgeport Hospital. Mrs. Mathews is the former Miss Alison Barstow Murphy, daughter of Dr. Robert Cushman Murphy,

Donald Smart, a motion-picture sound recorder, and Layne Britton, a make-up artist, were jailed to-night on charges of forging the name of Louis B. Mayer, head of M-G-M studio, to a series of promissory notes for $50,000.
Henry Ford has been having a great time lately with his Federation of McGuffey Societies.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100,- stood at 72.9 on July 6, compared with 72 a fortnight before, 71.9 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

To serve our nation best, we must obey God in the things that nourish human thought and action, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 176th Street, the Bronx, said yesterday.

OFTEN a riot but never a revolution; that's the rule in sport. There may be pitched battles on the field, but there is always conservatism in the council chambers where the laws of a game are guarded against sudden change or undue innovation. Precedent is as strong on the athletic field as it is in the courts of law.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.2, which compared with 80.9 the week before, 81.1 two weeks before, 81 three weeks before and 80.7 four weeks before.

Secretary Ickes stated tonight that no more leases to mine phosphate from government lands would be granted until Congress had agreed upon a conservation policy. He said the order involved primarily 2,000,000 acres in Florida, Idaho, Montana, Utah and Wyoming. Existing leases will not be affected.
Fort Hamilton and First Division, the two army teams in Brooklyn, divided their Eastern Polo League matches with rivals from the Ramapo Valley P. C. yesterday.

While oneway fares on all New England railroad coaches will be increased from 2 to 2 1/2 cents a mile on or about July 25, round-trip three-day fares of the Boston Maine and the Maine Central Railroad will remain at 2 cents a mile, it has been announced here.

Mary McCoy will sing the leading soprano part in the Gallo-Shubert production of "The Firefly," which opens 'tonight at the Marine. Stadium, Jones Beach State Park. Grace Panvini had been previously announced for the role. There will be fireworks at the performance.

More than thirty persons were drowned and a number injured when flood waters swept down on two villages in Eastern Turkey after torrential rains. The entire villages of Kelerich and Daghkolalar, near Erzingan, were inundated.

Charles P. Bruderle, a sophomore at the New York University Washington Square College, has been awarded the $1,000 scholarship for foreign study given annually to a student of the university by Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, it was announced yesterday.

An outstanding feature of the foreign exchange market last week was the rise in the dollar. To explain it some persons-perhaps the same who recently circulated - the rumor of coming dollar devaluation-say that the British author-
John Rutherfurd of Port Washington, N. Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., today won the Duce's Cup in Venice's Grand Prix motor-boat regatta.
Reims Cathedral, rebuilt largely with American funds, was rededicated today at a ceremony in which Cardinal Suhard stressed France's defense of liberty.

Large quantities of cash corn were sold for shipment to Europe last week, trade estimates indicating that the United Kingdom and the Continent of Europe had taken 5,000,000 bushels following purchases of 4,000,000 or more in the preceding week. The net effect on the price was virtually nil, as receipts from the country at terminal markets in the period were about the same as shipments.

In a dull market, with realization for Jewish accounts and by industrial concerns needing cash, stock prices declined most of this week and today, after an irregular opening, again weakened and closed at about the lowest, with losses in all leading industrials.

A jury today convicted Al E. Rosser, former secretary-treasurer of the Portland Teamsters Union, A. F. of L. affiliate, of arson in the burning of a Salem box factory dur- h ing a labor dispute. The court de ferred- sentence.

The vanguard of chess devotees began arriving today for the annual meeting of the American Chess Federation. The open championship and the women's tournaments will be started tomorrow afternoon in the Renaissance Room of the Hotel Touraine.
Two carnival employes were killed today when their trucks, one towing the other, went out of control and overturned.

In reaching the highest value in more than a year in terms of the pound sterling, the United States dollar last week created something of a stir in financial London. It is difficult to believe that only last month there was panic selling of dollars from

The Rev. Dr. Francis T. Cooke, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Bristol, Conn., in his second and last seasonal sermon yesterday in Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street,

President Roosevelt paused on the "Texas Hilltop Garden" of his son Elliott today to denounce efforts of some Southern communities to attract Northern industries by low wages and to proclaim the essential interrelation of farm problems among States.

The Christian church is closing .p its ranks and advancing with a tew unity to combat the forces threatening not only security and happiness, but the continued existnce of civilization, according to readers of all denominations who re arriving here to speak at the second week's sessions of the Intitute of Public Affairs at the Uniersity of Virginia.

The Southern Pacific Railroad Company of Mexico, a subsidiary of the United States Southern Pacific Company, petitioned the First Federal District Court late yesterday for the same tax exemptions as those enjoyed by the National Railroads of Mexico, recently expropriated by the government and turned over to laborunion management.
Captain L. A. Demers, former Dominion Wreck Commissioner and well-known figure in admiralty circles in every port of Canada, died yesterday at the age of 75.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler opened the German National Art Exhibition today by giving renewed expression to his determination to invest the cultural program of New Germany "with a magnitude unparalleled in the history of its people."

Douglas Falconer, executive director of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday that Friday was the deadline for applications by private social welfare and health agencies for participation in the proceeds of the campaign.
Stock companies chartered in June numbered 1,296, compared with 1,509 for the same month last year, the Division of Corporations of the Department of State announced today.

The National Economy League, announcing an expansion of its activities yesterday, estimated that its "vigorous campaign against unwarranted payments to veterans" since 1932 had saved the country $2,435,005,583 in five years and had cut the pension rolls from 1,270,667 to 841,937 veterans of all wars.
Lard futures advanced 40 to 50 cents for 100 pounds last week, largely because of buying induced by the strength in cottonseed oil and spreading operations with that product.

The Chaco peace conference hopes that a treaty of peace and friendship defining the frontiers between Bolivia and Paraguay can be signed here this week as a result of the initialing of the draft agreement by the Foreign Ministers of the two countries yesterday.

The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company sold to an investor the three-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 74 feet at 117-19 Washington Street, Newark, N. J. The building is at the southwest corner of New Street and was sold through Feist Feist, brokers.

Howard Hughes, a tall, gangling, shy young man, has several achievements to his credit, although he is only 33 years old. He inherited $17,000,000 when he was 18. He made one of the first successful talking pictures-which showed a profit on its $4,000,000 production cost-when he was 25.
Jimmy Wasdell and Zeke Bonura, regular and substitute first basemen, contributed two telling hits today which enabled the Senators to win a double-header from the Athletics, 5 to 2 and 8 to 7.

Miss Brenda D. D. Frazier is chairman of the debutante committee for the Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillion to be held on Oct. 28 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. The theme of the event this year will be in the spirit of Louis XIV, in celebration of the 300th anniversary of his birth.

President Oscar R. Benavides has promulgated a decree law ordering a general census on a date to be fixed later. The census will be carried out by departmental commissions under the direction of a central commission sitting in Lima.

Stocks closed lower on the week for the first time in current upward movement; turnover, 8,446,420 shares. United States Government issues irregular, corporation bonds higher with rails strongest, foreign - loans steady; transactions, $37,664,300.
Third in the series of seven religious gatherings to be held here this Summer, the Northfield Missionary Conference will open its eight-day session tomorrow evening with a round-top vesper service.

The Constitutional Convention enters its third and final phase this week. The first phase took in the organization of the charter-making body and the receipt of the proposals for changes in the existing basic law.
Dunbar Theophilus Wint, educator, journalist and legislator, died here Saturday. He was 59 years old.

A consolidated Supreme Court family tribunal, "to treat under one roof every phase of family breakdown," was recommended to members of the Constitutional Convention yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.

The Pro-Palestine Federation of America yesterday cabled Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the Inter-Government Refugee Conference at Evian, France, asking him "to impress" upon British representatives at the conference the urgency of an open-door policy for Jewish immigration into Palestine.
Nothing but a deeper reverence for life will give man the power to emerge from the present world condition, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

Two men, one an ex-convict and, according to the police, a lieutenant of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, stole a police radio car about 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning and smashed it two hours later against a tree on Fort George Avenue near 193d Street.

Miss Wilma Margaret Johnson daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Georg?? W. Johnson of Endicott, N. Y. was married to Brewster Wee?? Smith of New York, son of Ralph D. Smith of Binghamton, last nigh?? at the home of her parents by th?? Rev. Murray Shipley Howland, pas?? tor of the First Presbyteriah Church of Binghamton. The bride'?? father is president of the EndicottJohnson Corporation.

After a hundred and fifty years of peace with Canada it is unfortunate that a difference has developed with Bermuda, our even older British neighbor on the southeast. Bermuda, for Americans, is the land of perpetual honeymoon.

An amateur pilot was killed and his companion critically injured tonight as their plane crashed and fell into a small stream at Andreas, eight miles south of Tamaqua. The pilot was Arthur Wehr, 25. Harold Sefass, 30, his companion, also of Andreas, was taken to a hospital suffering head and internal injuries and fractures of both legs.
A nonchalant West Coast pilot who decided he wanted a vacation in New York landed on Roosevelt Field Saturday night, having flown non-stop from Long Beach, Calif., in his 8-year-old Curtiss Robin.

Hosiery shipments in May showed the first gain this year over the corresponding month of 1937, totaling 10,096,027 dozen pairs, an increase of 3.5 per cent over the total of 9,758,687 dozen pairs in May last year, according to figures - issued for publication today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Mail orders dwindled last week as buyers prepared for Fall buying trips, and most requests were for close-out and fill-in merchandise. Early response to new better-dress lines favored costume suits in furtrimmed or fur-jacketed versions. Steady reorder activity was reported for popular-price black midseason sheers and cheaper pastel spun rayon dresses.

Johnny Allen. went after his thirteenth straight victory of the season today, but it took two relief pitchers and some heavy hitting by his team-mates to save him from his second defeat, as the Indians barely edged out the Browns, 8 to 7.

Four persons were killed and at least ten were injured today when lightning struck a crowd at a rural church near here. Three of the dead were members of one family. They were identified as Asa I. Harper, 40; his brother, Woodrow, 24; and a sister, Ada, 27. J. D. Southerland, about 13, was the other killed.

The universe is subject to evil not because God wills it so but because evil is a "logical consequence of the freedom" with which all creation is endowed, the Rev. James Land ElIts said yesterday in his sermon at the Trinity. Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.
Rallying to score a goal in the last period after the opposition had tied the count with three in the fifth chukker, the Burnt Mills Polo Club defeated Peapack at Schley Field today, 6 to 5.

One of the largest parties of the season took place here today when Mr. and Mrs. John W. Herbert gave a luncheon at Willett House for members of their week-end house party, Mr. and Mrs. William De Wilder Atkinson, Mrs. Dion L. Johnson, Mrs. Lillian Fuller, Philip H. Giddens and Stewart McDonald.

Two men, one an ex-convict and, according to the police, a lieutenant of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, stole a police radio car about 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning and smashed it two hours later against a tree on Fort George Avenue near 193d Street.

Miss Wilma Margaret Johnson daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Georg?? W. Johnson of Endicott, N. Y. was married to Brewster Wee?? Smith of New York, son of Ralph D. Smith of Binghamton, last nigh?? at the home of her parents by th?? Rev. Murray Shipley Howland, pas?? tor of the First Presbyteriah Church of Binghamton. The bride'?? father is president of the EndicottJohnson Corporation.

Uusta Aaols, future King of Sweden, speaking at the Boston Garden today before 16,000 persons who constantly interrupted him with applause, placed himself and his country on the side of peace among the nations of the world.
TO THEN EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Thanks are due former Governor Smith for his splendid stand on the gambling-ban proposition. The absurdity of the law is self-evident.

What is probably the only authentic gang feud in France claimed its fourth victim in as many years shortly before last midnight here and caused the death of two other persons. The dead are Andre Marguin, 30 years old, and two men accidentally run over by the automobile in which his killers made their getaway.

Indiana Democratic leaders, headed by Frank McHale, National Committeeman, suggested today that Paul V. McNutt, former Governor and now High Commissioner to the Philippines, be presented to the nation as a candidate for the 1940 Presidential nomination in the platform to be submitted to the State convention here Tuesday. convention here Tuesday.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at around 20 per cent of capacity, this being on the basis of capacity for a full week, although the Independence Day holiday was observed generally.
Renewed terrorism, including four cases of bomb throwing, stonings and beatings at Haifa and three bombings in Jerusalem, broke out today after Palestine's comparative calm yesterday.

The General Finance Corporation reported today for the first six months of its fiscal year, ended on May 31, a net income of $136,278, or 12 cents a common share, compared with $347,094, or 40 cents, in the corresponding period last year.

-The Lithuanian military commandant in Memel sentenced seven Germans today to periods of detention in a concentration camp as a result of rioting June 22, when the German steamer Preussen arrived there. Three others were sentenced to three months' imprisonment.

In addition to the American production of the J. B. Priestley timeplay, "I Have Been Here Before," Gilbert Miller has at least one more definite plan for Broadway. (Two more, to be exact, for there also is to be a return engagement of "Victoria Regina.")

The heart of Christianity is not a creed or a philosophy but the majestic personality of Jesus Christ, the Rev. Dr. John J. McIlvaine, minister of the First Presbyterian Church, New Castle, Pa.,.said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and-Twenty-ninth Street.

Mrs. S. Hinman Bird of New York is chairman of the women's golf committee at the Point Judith Country Club arranging the annual women's invitation golf tournament, which opens here July 18. Assisting her are Mrs. Edwin H. Vare Jr. (Glenna Collett), Miss Beatrice de Coppet, Mrs. Edward F. Shay and Mrs. J. Donald Pryor.
As the feature of the opening of the Onteora Club's fifty-first season this week, the Green Room Players inaugurated their. twelfth season with a performance of Edward Chodorov's "Kind Lady."

Approval by buyers of the Fall style innovation, in dresses last week has greatly favored the outlook for a good Fall, according to Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc.

Ninety-five per cent of the children of the country suffer from dental diseases and only a slightly smaller percentage of the adult population are, similarly affected, according to a report of the Greater New York Bureau for Dental Information which was made public yesterday.
The special Lockheed monoplane prepared by Howard Hughes for his spectacular flight is the result of many months of experimentation by some of the leading aeronautical men of the United States.

France's wholesale price index stood at 656 on July 2, compared with 651 a week before and 649 two weeks before. The weekly trend of French wholesale prices, by groups, based on the average yield of 1914 as 100, is shown in the following table, giving figures for the last three weeks and for Sept. 12, 1936, before devaluation of the franc in 1936:

Beavers are taking government conservation jobs in Idaho at he rate of 100 a month. The beavers cost the government about $5 each, and in a year each does about $300 worth of work in preventing soil erosion and improving watering facilities and forage crop conditions on Federal grazing lands.

We need to restore the luster of life by enriching our natural and spiritual resources, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Great South Bay weakfishing has come in for its share of attention during the past week, despite the fact that the Long Island salt water anglers have shown much interest in the off-shore trips for tuna.

The charge of the light brigade was a mere nothing compared with the assault on par by the professional golfers in the first 18-hole qualifying round of the annual P. G. A. championship at the Shawnee Country Club today.

Mrs. Bertha Davis, 34 years old, of 3,021 Surf Avenue, Coney Island, Brooklyn, was killed shortly before 6 o'clock yesterday morning when she plunged from a window of her room on the sixteenth floor of the Hotel McAlpin to the marquee over the Thirty-fourth Street entrance.

Thousands of volunteers and government workers from the WPA, the CCC and the Department of Agriculture will wage an intensive battle with $3,000,000 worth of poison bait this month against hordes of grasshoppers in the farm and range land of twenty-three Western States.

The engagement of Miss Jean Wellford Randolph, daughter of Mrs. Deborah White Randolph of Charlottesville, Va., and of Spottiswoode W. Randolph of Baltimore, to Lawrence Reid Houston, son of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Houston of 165 East Seventy-fourth Street and Oyster Bay, L. I., has been announced by her mother.

The excursion boat Yankee, successor of the ill-fated Mandalay, returning from Atlantic Highlands, N. J., with more than 850 passengers abroad, was disabled midstream in the Bay Ridge Channel, Upper New York Bay, off Seventyfirst Street, Brooklyn, at 8:10 o'clock last night when one of her paddle wheels was broken.

The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, Milwaukee, has settled out of court an action brought against the Schmidt Brewing Company, Detroit, involving alleged infringement of the patented logotype that Schlitz has been using in advertising since 1888.
Mrs. Chauncey F. Lufkin will return today from Hot Springs, Va., and will be at the Plaza. Mrs. Ralph M. Rush and Miss Charlotte K. Rush have left the Waldorf-Astoria for their home in Pittsburgh.

The approach of the Pan-American Conference to be held in Lima, Peru, in December is leading to an increase in the ratification by Latin American republics of conventions signed at the Inter-American Peace Conference which was held in Buenos Aires in 1936, according to the Pan American Union, which is depository of the instruments of ratification.

Collections by the Bureau of Internal Revenue for the fiscal year which ended on June 30, 1938, were the largest in history. The total was $5,658,385,125, or $1,005,189,810 more than the $4,653,195,315 collected in the preceding fiscal year.

Nationalism, race prejudice, commercialism, militarism and narrow-mindedness led to the crucifixion of Jesus Christ, declared the Rev. L. Humphrey Walz yesterday morning at the Second Presbyterian Church, Central Park West and Ninety-sixth Street.

The Christian church should not try to remain aloof from other institutions which have for their purpose ends that do not conflict with the ideals taught by Christ, the Rev. Leon Merle Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Avenue Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse at 178th Street, the Bronx, said in his sermon yesterday.

John J. O'Keefe, American vice consul at Buena Ventura, Colombia, died at Gorgas Hospital today. His age was 42. Two navy planes had brought him from Buena Ventura last week. His wife was with him at his death.

Chancellor Hitler conferred here today with Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten Germans in Czechoslovakia, who had arrived last night. Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop and other government leaders were also in Munich.
A sharp contrast marks the westward journeys of the two chief political spokesmen of the Administration, President Roosevelt and Chairman Farley of the Democratic National Committee.

An organization Composed of war veterans and other men and women is to be formed next Fall in the interest of peace in connection with the erection of a peace temple at the World's Fair, it was learned yesterday. Headquarters have been opened at the Hotel Commodore.
In the heaviest troop movement of the current Summer training season, 6,000 State guardsmen were transferred today by train or army trucks from and to the four major State reservations.

In three decisions made public today the National Labor Relations Board ordered two companies to recognize unions of the Committee for Industrial Organization and struck out the record in the case of a San Antonio, Texas, newspaper publishing concern on the ground that the trial examiner might have been prejudiced by reading an anti-Labor Relations Board editorial.

In a generally firm securities market, the outstanding feature of last week was the buoyancy of gilt-edged securities, led by the British Government group. There was a more subdued tone as the week ended,

Spanish Spanish Insurgents, gathering momentum from the capture of Nules, launched four distinct attacks today in their drive down the Mediterranean coast toward Valencia. Government authorities, fearful of an Insurgent siege of the important seaport, drafted plans to fortify approaches to Valencia from the North after the emergency visit yesterday of General Jose Miala. Defense commander.

Alonzo B. Morley, president of the stock brokerage firm of A. B. Morley Co., 11 Broad Street, died Saturday at the Broad Street Hospital. Mr. Morley had been active for thirty years in the financial district.

To Emil Lehecka, Long Island City, was awarded tonight the Edward S. Evans $1,500 silver trophy representing the American soaring championship, of 1938 Lehecka was high point scorer among American entries in the ninth annual national contest, now closed.

Miss Verna May Timmins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Timmins of Milbrook, Greenwich, will be married to Donald Teague, son of Edwin Teague and the late Mrs. Teague of New Rochelle, N. Y., July 19, in the First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, by the Rev. Alden S. Mosshammer.

A pair of Texans, Blaine Rideout of North Texas Teachers College and John Marion of Prairie View (Texas) College shared the spotlight in the twenty-fifth annual A. A. U. track and field games of the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. at Macombs Dam Park yesterday.
Legal proceedings of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company of Manchester, N. H., ended today at a hearing before Arthur Black, referee in bankruptcy.

The existence of a "racket within a racket" whereby the leaders of the policy game in New York City provided "stand-ins" to appear in court for collectors who had previous convictions was disclosed yesterday by Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands.

Changes in rules under the Public Utility Holding Company Act to exempt certain small holding company systems from the provisions of the measure and to broaden the exemption granted to foreign utility subsidiaries were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The opening' gun in what promises to be one of the finest rows the House of Commons has had lately-the case of Duncan Sandys, member of Parliament, who was called on the carpet as a territorial officer and threatened with prosecution as a citizen under the Official Secrets Act-was fired today.

Mme. Beatrix Dussane, a leading actress of the Comedie Francaise in Paris, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie on her first visit to this country. She has come to lecture on Moliere and other famous French playwrights at the Summer French School at Middlebury College.

Subscription books for the Treasury's offering today of $200,000,000 of three-year 7/8 per cent notes of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were closed at the close of business tonight, according to an announcement by Secretary Morgenthau.
Less work and more play were indicated today for King George Vt in the future as he fought off an attack of gastric influenza. Many persons believed the illness was due partly to the strain of
James S. Andrews of 33 Franklin Place, astronomer for the Rockefeller roof observatory, died suddenly yesterday after finishing a swim in Paramus. A heart attack was given as the cause of death.

The Alton Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for extension of the maturity date of a $1,894,633 RFC loan from July 28, 1938, to Sept. 1, 1942. The loan is guaranteed by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.

A procession of American-born rankand-file members of the GermanAmerican Volksbund took the witness stand today- in defense of Camp Siegfried's incorporators, on trial in Suffolk County Court, and professed an even greater admiration for Adolf Hitler and- a more intense degree of anti-Semitism than most of the German witnesses who preceded them.

Kings County Judge William O'Drwyer dismissed yesterday two indictments charging nine former employes of the Presto Lock Corporation with rioting during a strike disturbance outside the company's Brooklyn plant at 70 Washington Street on Nov. 15.

The American Federation of Labor, through its president, William Green, today took full credit for enactment of the Wagner Labor Relations Act and said that it Would not stop in its efforts until the act had been amended to meet its complete approval.

Activities of the Henlein. (Nazi) party, particularly of its militant organizations, are being watched very closely as increasingly disturbing reports reach Prague from the Sudeten' areas. Patrols in semi-uniform have

The late Eugene Manlove Rhodes, Western writer, will receive considerable literary attention this Fall. The Saturday Evening Post announces "A Preface for 'Gene Rhodes," by Eddy Orcutt, and Houghton Mifflin will publish in September "Hired Man on Horseback," a biography by May D. Rhodes. The book will contain an introduction by Bernard De Voto.

Completion of the liquidation of the receiverships of the Crestwood National Bank of Tuckahoe, N. Y., the First National Bank of Midland Park, N. J., and the Pleasantville National Bank of Pleasantville, N. J., was announced today by Marshall R. Diggs, acting Controller of the Currency.
The United States Golf Association clarified a rule yesterday and thereby crowned James (Sonny) Fraser of Atlantic City the 1938 Atlantic Coast golf champion, The Associated Press reported.
Mrs. Joan Redfern Margerum of Trenton, wife of General Mahlon R. Margerum of the State Board of Tax Appeals, died tonight at her Summer home at Ocean Grove.

Amid scenes of great public jubilation, Great Britain today handed over Spike Island, one of the most important fortified forts in Southern Ireland, to the Irish people. Within the next few months Berehaven and Lough Swilly forts will also be evacuated by the British.

Policemen throughout the city will begin today to distribute 400,000 special blanks for use by those paying the new occupancy tax due on Friday, it was announced yesterday from the office of Mayor La Guardia at the Summer City Hall in Queens.

After a hot week-end, trading opened slow in most classes yesterday. Veal hindsaddles were in demand, however, and a scant supply of bull was-very active. Lamb prices were steady to a shade lower, other classes of traefer meats strong to higher. Kosher beef opened lower. Other kosher meats steady-to weal. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Unable to play with Colonel Bill Terry's Giants at Ebbets- Field yesterday because of the rain, the .Dodgers plunged headlong into the player market and came up with three recruits Burleigh Grimes hopes will be of some help.
The Illinois Athletic Commission voted today to join the World Boxing Federation organized in Rome last April.

Calls for proposals to sell or donate to the Federal Government a building site for Postoffice Station F in Manhattan have been issued by C. J. Peoples, Director of Procurement of the Treasury Department, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

Captain Washington Perry de Almeida, commander of the Brazilian training frigate Almirante Saldanha, which is visiting here on a cruise, called at Governors Island yesterday to pay his respects to Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding general of the Second Corps Area. Colonel Ulysses S.

James J. Hines, the Tammany district leader, and J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, the one-time "kid mouthpiece" for the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer gang, reneed their pleas of not guilty yesterday to an indictment that charges them jointly with taking part in a policy lottery racket.
The favorites came through in the opening day's play of the national interscholastic tennis tournament at the Merion Cricket Club today.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie with Mrs. Butler from a visit to Brussels, where he attended the meeting of the European committee of the Carnegie Foundation.

The body of a young doctor, who left notes expressing horror at an incorrect diagnosis he had made for a dying patient, was found today in a hotel room at near-by Olema, Coroner J. Ray Keaton reported.

The fast-stepping Pirates extended their winning streak to twelve consecutive games, a new high in the major leagues this season, and advanced within a game and a half of the Giants today as they came from behind to whip the Cubs, 5-3. The Giants, whose game with the Dodgers today was washed out by rain, held the previous 1938 record of eleven straight.

The grain harvest, now in full swing in the southern areas of the Soviet Union, has an excellent prospect of reaching from 115,000,000 tons to 130,000,000 tons, which Joseph Stalin has set as this year's quota.

Another bright page in the annals of American aviation was written yesterday by Howard R. Hughes. When he and his crew of four set down the wheels of their plane at Le Bourget 16 hours 35 minutes out of Floyd Bennett Field they had cut in two the time required by Colonel Lindbergh eleven years ago.

" The spirit of this year's C. M. T. C. is the best I have ever seen anywhere," Colonel Thomas, L. Crystal, commanding officer of the 26th Infantry, told the thirty-five reserve officers who arrived yesterday to take command of the regiment upon departure of the 307th Infantry on Saturday.

QUEENS Gross assets, $32,264; net, $30,497. To son, Henry Haacke. Chief assets cash, $26,530. Richard Condon, attorney, 29 Broadway, Manhattan. HUGHES, ROSE (Feb. 23). Gross assets, $19,049: net, $12,840. To sons, James J. and Bernard J. Hughes. Chief assets, real estate, $8,700. Mario J. Cariello, attorney, 32-12 Broadway, Astoria.

Edgar A. Martin, New York attorney, died last night of rheumatic fever and pneumonia at his home here. He was 54 years- old and was associated with the law firm of Leslie, Holt, Halstead Frost, at 120 Wall Street.
The Social Security Board approved today a grant of $1,786,930,53 for the New York State Unemployment Compensation Commission to cover the first quarter of the 1938-39 fiscal year.

Charges that Premier Mussolini is preparing to send two battalions of Blackshirts and a full motorized brigade with artillery, infantry and tanks, and that he is making arrangements with General Francisco Franco for transferring most of the Italian aviators and soldiers now in Spain

The Federal Communications Commission today published proposed rules of practices and procedure, which, If adopted by the Commission, will change materially some of the rules and regulations governing the practice of attorneys and technicians before the body.

Out of a thousand expert military marksmen from all parts of the empire, only four had perfect scores of 50 in today's feature of the National Rifle Association, the 300-yard shoot for The Daily Telegraph Silver Cup. One of the select quartet was a Canadian making his first trip to Bisley, Captain T. E. Hayhurst of Windsor. native of Hamilton. Ont.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, served yesterday as pro-tem professor of law on the faculty of the first Summer session of practicing law courses in New York City at the Hotel Astor.

Even with allowance for the holiday, daily average automobile output showed a marked decline last week, although the seasonal trend called for only a small easing. The adjusted index slumped 11 points to 34.3. This compared with 45.4 for the preceding week and 135.1 for the week ended July 10, 1937.
Those who maintain that there is no longer an American frontier should consider the Nevills expedition down 300 turbulent miles of the Colorado River.

The National City Bank, as fiscal agent, will announce today that $737,000 of Kingdom of Norway twenty-year 6 per cent bonds due on Aug. 15, 1943, which have been drawn by lot through operation of the sinking fund, will be redeemed on Aug. 15, at par.

Despite the rather sharp deterioration in June, the Department of Agriculture estimated yesterday that the domestic wheat crop this year would be the largest since 1915 and the second largest on record. The Agriculture Department's. indicated yield as of July 1, at 967,412,000 bushels, compares with, an actual output last year of 873,993,000 bushels.

The steel industry, as represented by employers and labor, has been invited to a public hearing by the Public Contracts Board on July 25 in order that data may be obtained to determine prevailing minimum wages, it was announced today by the Acting Secretary of. Labor, Charles V. McLaughlin.

Henry Berolzheimer, treasurer of the Eagle Pencil Company, where a strike has been in progress for the last three weeks, was struck in the head with a brick late yesterday afternoon as he was riding in an automobile on East Fourteenth Street, between Avenues B and C, a short distance from the plant, which is at 703 East Thirteenth Street.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Josephine Adele Wilson, daughter of Mrs. J. Howard Wilson of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mr. Wilson, to Chester B. Eaton of this city and Worcester, Mass., son of Mrs. Arthur C. Eaton of Worcester and the late Mr. Eaton.

President Roosevelt expressed his satisfaction that his fellow-members of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks are "alive to the importance of adequate national defense" in a letter of greeting to the order, which opened its seventy-fourth national convention here today.

Youth today took over the University of Virginia Institute of Public Affairs and in practically continuous session decided the state of the nation and its problems, both national and international, holding that, in this country at least, democracy, American plan, has little to worry about.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Margery Sloss, daughter of Mrs. Mortimer M. Sloss, of 175 Riverside Drive, New -York, and this place, and the late Mr. Sloss, to Dr. John H. Heldt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Heldt of the Woodmere.

The center of gravity of the English-speaking world-indeed of the whole worldis going to pass to some new capital in North America," the Marquess of Lothian declared today at the dedication of Cecil Rhodes's birthplace at Bishops Stortford in Hertfordshire. .

A 112-pound tuna taken by Fay Smith of New York while trolling off-shore on Sunday aboard Mel Elder's boat Juliana is the record fish brought into Freeport, L. I., this season. Smith took 1 hour and 20 minutes to land the big fighter. One of the unusual feats reported

Six hundred Civilian Conservation Corps recruits entrained here this afternoon for work camps on the Pacific Coast to replace 1,500 men -discharged here last month. Eight hundred more will leave here tomorrow for the same destination.

A few hours after he had been taken to the Hebrew Convalescent Home at 3,573 Eastern Boulevard, the Bronx, and admitted as a patient, Samuel Levin, 81 years old, of 236 West Seventieth Street, committed suicide at 6 o'clock last night by jumping from the solarium on the roof of the four-story building. His body landed in the rear yard of the institution.

FOR the next couple of weeks, watch Pittsburgh. The Pirates will be entertaining at Forbes Field. While the Giants were keeping a wary eye on the Cubs and surveying the Red uprising with scorn, the Pirates came from behind the barn with a luscious Winning, streak and slipped into second place.

The Supreme Court is expected to decide in the Fall on an appeal filed today by attorneys for Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and five other men convicted as a result of Thomas E. Dewey's drive against vice rackets in New York.

Matty Geis, coach of Princeton's undefeated track team, today predicted a close meet between Princeton-Cornell and Oxford-Cambridge in their ninth games at London on July 23. Geis said twelve Princeton tracksters and nine from Cornell would sail for England Wednesday on the Normandie.
Mrs. Vera Aleinikoff, widow of Nicholas Aleinikoff, former counsel to the Russian Consulate here, died yesterday at her Summer home in Lindenhurst, L. I., of a heart ailment. She was 75 years old.

John I. Harvey, tutor, was on his way to Japan today for what he announced was a chance to persuade Premier Konoye to send his son, Prince Fumitaka Konoye, back to Princeton next year. Fumitaka, scheduled to be
Five men, described by William Power Maloney, Assistant United States Attorney, as members of a large ring of stock swindlers, were held in bail of $1,000 each yesterday for action of the grand jury.

New dances originating in various communities throughout the United States, which may influence ballroom dancing through the coming year, were demonstrated yesterday at the opening of the eighth annual International Dance Congress at the Hotel Paramount.

Leave Revoked Special Order 127, dated July 5, as it relates to Fireman 3d grade Charles Sawling, Engine Co. 31, being granted a special leave of absence, for one day, from 9 A. M., June 30, is revoked.

Amory M. Clayton, 19 years old, local horseman who had won trophies in several New.. Jersey shows, succumbed today at the Paul Kimball Hospital of internal injuries received when a horse threw him and trampled on him here yesterday.

For the thirty-four years he was an inmate at the Suffolk County Home here, John Miller, 65 years old and blind, groped his way about the antiquated county structure. He became accustomed to the building and grounds.

Dizzy Deansore arm or no sore arm-was ordered today to return to duty as a starting pitcher for the Cubs. Owner Phil K. Wrigley, tired of fiddling around with varied treatments while the team's pennant prospects burned, announced he had directed his $185,000 hurling hand to "be ready to pitch within a week."
Word was received here yesterday of the death in Innsbruck, Germany, of Paul Mausolff, for many years-secretary of Roessler Hasslacher, manufacturing chemists.

Thunder showers yesterday afternoon failed to give any lasting relief from the heat wave that has hovered over New York for four days. The downpour sent the mercury tumbling 6 degrees in less than an hour-to 76 degrees at 3 P. M.-but by 6 P. M. it had climbed to 80. Later in the evening, after a light shower, it became somewhat cooler.

Advertising and promotional plans are being worked out by the more than 300 manufacturers who have already been licensed to use the World's Fair motif on merchandise, it was reported here yesterday. Extensive use of newspapers and magazines is in prospect. Many of the licensed products will be put out as premiums.

The Japanese forces have made little headway since Saturday in their drive toward Kiukiang, Chinese foreign reports from that important Yangtze River city indicate. Foreign sources at Kiukiang, 135 miles down-river from' Hankow, denied stories that the city had been shelled by Japanese warships and

John Worrell, 40 years old, of Hulmeville, Pa., died in the Underwood Hospital here early 'today from injuries he received when. an open .cockpit plane he was piloting crashed, near Williamstown, N. J., yesterday morning.

As Howard Hughes took off from Paris, Albert I. Lodwick, his American manager, announced last night from flight headquarters at the World's Fair Grounds on the Flushing Meadows that Hughes definitely was going on around the world.

Richard D. Hallett, chairman of Local 35B, comprising Western Union employes in Washington, affiliated with the American Communications Association (C. I. O.), has resigned as chairman and as a member, and in an open letter criticized the union as sympathetic to communism.

The case of the Northern States will be heard starting today in the complaint action of eight Southern States before the Interstate Commerce Commission with a view to a reduction in freight rates for products made in the South and shipped to the North in competition with goods made here.

The Olive Coat Company, Inc., leased for the sale and manufacture of coats arid suits 40,000 square feet of space in two buildings in the garment center area. The concern took 30,000 square feet comprising the thirteenth and. fourteenth floors in the building at 265 West

The track and field army waiting in New York to sail for European competition will work out at Randalls Island Stadium today, tomorrow and Thursday in preparation for the meet of the Ancient Order of Hibernians there on Sunday, it was announced yesterday by. Meet Director Joe McCluskey. This meet will serve as their farewell appearance before they depart next week.

UNITED STATES SOCIAL WORKER (PSYCHIATRIC), $2,000 a year, Veterans' Administration. Applications must. be on file not later than Aug. 11, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, and not later than Aug. 8, from all other States.

St. Louis at New York (2)-Hildebrand (5-5) and Mills (3-3) vs. Ruffing (11-3) and Hadley (3-1). Cleveland at Washington-Harder (5-7) vs. Chase (3-5). Detroit at Boston-Kennedy (10-4) vs. Marcum (5-6) or Dickman (2-2). Chicago at Philadelphia-Gabler (1-3) vs. Nelson (8-4).

Home relief costs in New York State decreased 7 per cent, or $800,000, in May, according to Commissioner David C. Adie of the Department of Social Welfare. In the same period home relief cases decreased 7.9 per cent up-State and 3.2 per cent in New York City.

Three suspended officers of the United Automobile Workers of America, and one who was dismissed last Saturday, informed John L. Lewis today that the internal affairs of their union were "in such a mess" that a special convention was required to straighten them out.

Charles E. Farrington, who has bought 1,800,000 books for the Brooklyn Public Library since 1919, when he became superintendent of book ordering, will retire from service at the end of this month, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Milton J. Ferguson, chief librarian.

Unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization have formed Labor's Anti-Injunction Committee to combat the injunction issued recently by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo restraining striking employes of the Busch Jewelry Stores and affiliates from picketing the establishments.

Twenty-six firemen were overcome by smoke, none of them seriously, in fighting a blaze which, after starting at 6:30 o'clock last night, spread throughout the twostory sheet metal buildings of the National Millwork Corporation at 529 to 541 Osborne Street, between Newport Street and Lott Avenue, Brooklyn.

The Gershwin memorial concert at Lewisohn Stadium having been postponed until tonight because of rain, Macklin Marrow was called upon last night to direct the Phil-harmonic-Symphony . in a purely symphonic program in the Great Hall of the College of the City of New York.

Ten of the country's leading banks paid $31,260,893 in cash dividends, or 79 per cent of combined earnings of $39,591,072, in the first six months of 1938, according to a compilation by Monahan, Schapiro Co.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 6: Decreases of $56,00,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $39,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations and $235,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and an increase of $183,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

A revised plan of reorganization which is expected to result soon in the discharge of the Munson Steamship Line from 77b bankruptcy proceedings was filed yesterday with Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe by Carlos W. Munson, president of the line. Judge Coxe set July 26 as a date for the hearing on the plan.
Domestic corporate bonds lost ground again yesterday in the slowest trading on the New York Stock Exchange in more than three weeks, or since the broad recovery movement first got under way.

Mrs. Henry Rawle Geyelln or New York entertained members of the younger set with a dinner at Copper Beeches in Northeast Harbor tonight in honor of Miss Ann Appleton. The guests included the Misses Mary Eddison of Ardsley-onHudson, N. Y.;

An investigation by a nonpartisan citizens' committee into the increasing welfare and relief activities in Westchester County, which cost the county $4,264,521 in 1937 and may reach a new high this year, was ordered today by the Board of Supervisors at its July meeting.

The transfer of the $1,290,000,000 worth of silver bars from the United States Assay offices here to the new storehouse on the military reservation at West Point is threatened with labor difficulties.

In the presence of many litigants and their attorneys, Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink paid tribute to Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo in Special Term, Part I, of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday. Conrad Saxe Keyes.

A proposed amendment to prohibit the Legislature from sitting more than twelve consecutive hours, aimed particularly at all-night pre-adjournment sessions, was headed for debate in the' Constitutional Convention tonight.
David Lawrence Pierson, author of "The History of the Oranges" and numerous other historical works, died early today at his home in the Hotel Alvord here.
Elsewhere on this page there is published a letter by Mr. Nathan Witt, secretary of the National Labor Relations Board, criticizing on two grounds a recent editorial in THE TIMES. Mr.

C. C. Winningham, former automotive advertising executive, has been elected a director of the F. L. Jacobs Company. Ray D. Dillon has been elected a director of the Scotten, Dillon Company to fill a vacancy.

A warning that -most of the independent grocers of the city were determined to carry out their proposed milk boycott unless dealers resume the old practice of giving them ice with the milk was sent to Mayor La Guardia and two of his commissioners yesterday with the request that they avert the demonstration by calling a conference of all interested parties to iron out the situation.

The annual midsummer festival of the Queens Second Ward Chapter of the Long Island Real Estate Board will be held on Tuesday evening, July 26, at the Bayside Yacht Club, according to George C. Johnston Jr., president of the chapter.

In the appointment of Governor Allred of Texas today President Roosevelt followed his declared intention to choose for the Federal bench, when possible, persons under 60 years old. The Texas Governor was born March 29, 1899.

While a few wholesale dry goods buyers were in the market yesterday, they were making only fair purchases. They feared too rapid advances in primary prices and, on some items, they said prices have already moved upward "about as far as the traffic will bear."

The question of how they are going to get home seems uppermost in the minds of the eighty American prisoners of war interviewed by our correspondent, Mr. Carney, in an Insurgent concentration camp near Burgos.

Rayonier, Inc., producer of dissolving pulp used in the rayon and staple fiber industry, in its first annual report for the twelve months ended on April 30, shows a net profit of $3,124,703 after depreciation, interest, Federal income and undistributed profits taxes.

The Securities and Exchange Commission permitted today a declaration of the Associated Corporation, a direct subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, to become effective for three months, with the understanding that the applicant corporation be eliminated from the Associated system at an early date.

The announcement that the property at 499 Third Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Thirtyfourth Street, would be sold at auction on July 19 in the Vesey Street salesroom deserves a bit more than cursory notice.

Representatives of the Tennessee Public Service Company presented testimony today to the Federal Power Commission in support of its application for transfer of certain of its properties to the city of Knoxville, Tenn., and the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The State Deapartment of Public Utilities is powerless to prevent the abandonment of eighty-eight stations and of passenger service beyond Hyannis and Yarmouth on Cape Cod by the New Haven Railroad, it was indicated tonight when J. Burke Sullivan, chairman, announced that no action would be taken before the scheduled closing goes into effect Sunday.
William L. Visscher, Albany banker, died suddenly today of a heart attack while playing golf at Watkins Glen. His age was 64.

Mayor La Guardia conferred yesterday afternoon with Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the Public Works Administration, and several New York City officials on plans for speeding up new PWA projects for this city. It is hoped that arrangements may be made to proceed with the projects as soon as they are authorized to eliminate delay and red tape.

The Gulf Stream combination easily. turned back the Pelicans, 10 to 3, on Waterbury Field at the Meadow Brook Club today, and as a result three teams are deadlocked for honors in the Brook Division of the club's annual twenty-goal polo tournament.

A collection of Dickens letters, manuscripts and rare copies of his works assembled by the Comte de Suzannet of Lausanne and said to be one of "the most remarkable collections to reach a salesroom" brought the high total of [Pound]3,687 at Sotheby's today.

Steel operations for the week beginning yesterday are scheduled at 32.3 per cent of capacity, according to telegraphic advices received by the American Iron and Steel Institute. This represents an increase of 9.9 points, or 44.2 per cent, over the 22.4 per cent rate last week, which included the July 4 holiday.

The Department of Commerce, the State police and Dr. Amos O. Squire, Medical Examiner of Westchester County, opened investigations today of the crash of a sightseeing plane last night in an orchard near the Westchester Airport here.
Arthur Barclay, former President of Liberia, died here today at the age of 86. He will receive a State funeral Wednesday.

Thirty-one young men and four girls will-sail tomorrow on the liner Manhattan for England, France, Belgium and the Scandinavian countries to serve as missionaries of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.

Willard D. Hart was guest of honor at a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night, in celebration of his completion of twenty years as retail news editor of Women's Wear Daily. Nearly 150 leaders in retailing and allied lines attended.

A field of 151 golfers, including champions from ten States, will start blasting away over the Chain o' Lakes course tomorrow in .the first qualifying round of the thirtyninth annual Western amateur tournament.
Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary granted yesterday a motion calling for the appointment of a receiver for the property of Alfred C. Blumenthal, theatrical producer.

The stock market here was generally quiettoday and a lack of business caused a weak tendency to develop in most sections. Gilt-edged issues lost ground while foreign bonds were idle. Transatlantic stocks improve in late trading; United States Steel advanced.

Through the Agricultural Association, Puerto Rico's farmers have won a marked reduction in the rates they must pay for workmen's compensation insurance in the government agency. The minimum premium has been reduced from $50.90 to $31.40, and the base rate per $100 of payroll has been lowered from $8.18 to $6.35.

President Judge William M. McKeen of the Court of Common Pleas of Northampton County died tonight at his Summer home at Saylor's Lake. He was 69 years old and had been on the bench of Northampton County for twenty-two years.
They resorted to a soundmeasuring machine in the now celebrated case of the neighbors vs. the Claremont Inn swing band.

Mr. and Mrs. Galen Merriam Fisher of Orinda, Calif., formerly of Pleasantville, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Talcott Fisher, to Dr. Robert Gordon Johnston, son of Mrs. Thomas H. Johnston of Cambridge, N. Y., and Atlanta, Ga., and the late Dean Johnston.
Federal Judge Wayne G. Borah declined today to order police to stop raiding a C. I. O. union headquarters and set the case for hearing Friday.
The application of the Western Union Telegraph Company to list 1,050,000 shares of common stock was approved today by the executive committee of the Chicago Stock Exchange.

Republican legislative leaders gave tentative approval today to a $10,000,000 extension of the present $25,000,000 State-Federal highway work program, but urged Governor A. Harry Moore to request the Works Progress Administration to hold its offer in abeyance pending .a check of relief lists.
William Gallacher, Britain's only Communist Member of Parliament, was accused, today, of being "so completely under the thumb of Moscow that he dare not stand up and defend British subjects."

The dull rumbling of the elevated, the sweltering sidewalks and the broiling sun were forgotten for several hours yesterday by 300 youngsters of the lower East Side and other tenement sections of the city.
BRITISH HISTORY IN THE NINETEENTH CENTURY AND AFTER (17821919), by George Macaulay Trevelyan. (Longmans, Green, $3.50.) A new edition.

FIRST MILITARY AREA Major William Fine, Adjutant General's Department Reserve, is detailed as Recruiting Officer for the Enlisted Reserve Corps. The following Reserve officers, recently released to the First Military Area, are assigned as indicated:

Retail prices of food advanced in the month ended on June 14, the Bureaut of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-25 average, was 80.2, compared with 79.1 on May 17 and 86.3 on June 15, 1937.

Fire, following an explosion at 12:40 o'clock this morning, apparently caused. by a shorb circuit, swept through the upper stories of the home of former Supreme Court Justice Samuel Seabury at 154 East Sixty-third Street.

Plans for General Francisco Franco to turn his powerful army on Portugal after winning the Spanish civil war should force be necessary to obtain a regime in Lisbon "acceptable to us," were disclosed today in a "statement of German aims in the Iberian peninsula," published by The News Chronicle.
New Deal loyalty, discussed by President Roosevelt in his speech here, stood out as an issue tonight as Democratic contenders for Governor and Senator wound up's a hard primary campaign.

Pre-show estimates that attendance of furniture buyers at the Home Furnishings Show here would pass the 10,000 mark became virtually assured today when registrations passed the 7,300 mark. This was the highest mark ever attained for seven days.

The Bureau of Air Commerce said today that a pilot's confusion as to- his whereabouts' caused . the airplane crash which killed eight persons aboard' a Transcontftiental, afId Western Air liner near Wawona, Calif., last March 1.

Senator George Norris of Nebraska, celebrating his seventy-seventh birthday in a work shirt and overalls as he painted a garage addition at his Summer home near here, paused today to remark that he was looking. forward rather than backward.

The texts of speeches by President Roosevelt yesterday at Wichita Falls, Clarendon and- Amarillo, Texas, as reported by The Associated Press, were as follows: WICHITA FALLS SPEECH Governor Allred, my friends of Wichita Falls, I am glad to come here. My old friend,

The dollar strengthened more yesterday at the expense of the principal foreign currencies as continued offerings of pounds sterling pushed that money down to the lowest level in more than a year. The decline in the British currency pulled the entire list, with the exception of the belga, in its wake and sent the French franc to the lowest point since May and within a fraction of its low record.

Insurgent General Garcia Valino's Navarrese broke through the northwestern flank of the Espadan Mountains today within sight of Segorbe. The roar of battle echoed in rocky defiles as General Jose Miaja's wearied defenders fought against the Insurgents.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 8: Mayfield, Capt. I. H., Bureau of Navlgation, to Naval Examining Board, Navy Department, Washington, D. C. Beard, Lieut. Comdr. J. D., Long Beach, Calif., to Naval Academy.

Howard Hughes's only predecessor on a non-stop New YorkParis flight was Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who began his famous hop May 20, 1927. Colonel Lindbergh required 33 hours 30 minutes, Hughes and his men 16 hours 35 minutes. Both planes flew virtually the same course, a Great Circle course from New York to the French capital, the distance of which is 3,641 miles.

This is primary day in Oklahoma, that liveliest of States, a riproarer and ripsnorter, in spite of its wealth pioneer in spirit, humorous, hilarious, fond of tall talk, emotional, restless, rebellious and original.

President Roosevelt traveled across the Panhandle today to "create another precedent," as he said, by announcing from the rear platform of his private car the appointment of Governor James V. Allred to a Federal judgeship.
A sharp increase in tonnage of vessels being built in American yards to American Bureau of Shipping classification is noted in the midyear bulletin of the bureau, issued yesterday.

Captain James H. McKillop, one of New York City's oldest licensed harbor captains, died yesterday at his home, 131-02 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor, Queens, after a one-day illness.. His age was 76.

The French liner Normandie arrived yesterday morning with 847 passengers, completing the westbound half of her 100th Atlantic crossing. The crossing was made at an average speed of 28.03 knots for a distance of 3,133 miles.

Wilder Ave (17,5095), w s, 100 ft n of Nereid Ave, 75x79 ft; Francesco La Macchia to Robert De Filippo, 4,444 Murdock Ave. Nereid Ave (17-5054), s e cor of Ely Ave, 85x100 ft; Luke C. Garvey to Palmer Central Corp, 260 E 161 St.

With one outstanding exception, favorites went straight to the front in the first round of the annual open championship of the American Chess Federation today in the Renaissance Room of the Hotel Touraine.

" Trailer Romance," announced previously for Ginger Rogers and Herbert Marshall and later for Ruby Keeler, was switched today to Miriam Hopkins's schedule because of a new contract being negotiated between the star and RKO.
In his speech at Fort Worth the President returned once more to his favorite topic of wages and purchasing power:

A mass meeting which packed the 2,000-seat Colonial Hall and overflowed into the streets outside cheered tonight a proposal to march on Steubenville, Ohio, Wednesday to protest the expulsion of a Weirton Steel Company attorney from a National Labor Board hearing there.

The Commerce Department reports that an exceedingly good showing has been made by American road-building equipment being exhibited at the eighth International Road Conference at The Hague, The Netherlands.
Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer died tonight at 1,401 Muirland Drive, La Jolla.

After an ownership of six weeks, David S. Meister has resold to John C. Daniel for investment the one-story taxpayer at 354-360 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Fortieth Street. The property is 78 by 45 feet and is assessed at $280,000. Byrne Bowman, Inc., were the brokers.

Rudolph Friml's operetta, "The Firefly," the third in the current season's schedule of musical comedies and operettas, was presented here tonight on the marine stage on Zach's Bay under the sponsorship of J. J. Shubert and Fortune Gallo, impresario of the San Carlo Opera Company.

A woman accused of having $25,442 in nine banks while she was receiving home relief was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Rudich in the Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn. She waived examination and was continued in $2,500 ball for the Court of Special Sessions.

Charles Herrman, who for eighteen years had been chief cabinet maker for the American Museum of Natural History and who built the eases for many of the institution's large displays, died yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 60. He collapsed in the museum at 1 P. M. and was dead when a doctor arrived.
Major A. Frederick Oberlin, outstanding war hero of the Connecticut regiment, the 102d Infantry, in the World War died at his home here last night of injuries sustained during the war.

Nearly 1,000 Brooklyn real estate owners, at a meeting last night in Girls High School, Nostrand Avenue and Halsey Street, called upon the State Constitutional Convention to retain the present limitations on municipal debt and real estate taxes.

Fifty-nine boys of assorted sizes and ages gathered in Grand Central Station yesterday morning and took a train to North Creek, N. Y., for a month's stay in the. Adirondacks as guests of the Police Athletic League.

Miss Loretta Ann Marshall, daughter of Mrs. Julia E. Marshall of this city, was married here to John Jay Doyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Doyle of New Rochelle, N. Y., this morning in St. John's Catholic Church.

Leading public officials of Nassau County and other friends, 500 altogether, attended funeral services at Fairchild's Chapel here this afternoon for J.
