Dwight Rogers, Republican member of the Board of Supervisors, who died in Nassau Hospital on Friday. Heading the honorary pallbearers was J. Russel Sprague, Republican county leader.
Clinton Dudley Campbell, executive of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, died yesterday morning at the Crater Club in. Essex, N. Y., at the age of 52.

The try-out division of the East's Summer theatres will have its most strenuous week starting Monday next, when eleven plays will woo Broadway managers, movie scouts and destiny at large. The list includes:

Mrs. Janet Roper, who has located 5,327 "lost" seamen as head of the Missing Seamen's Bureau at the Seamen's Church Institute, will be honored at an informal party given in the institute this afternoon by the organization's 200 employes, marking the completion of fortynine years of service among merchant seamen and eighteen years as head of the present bureau.

Although the German press has virtually ignored the- ceremonies in connection with the restoration of the Reims Cathedral, the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, the Foreign Office. mouthpiece, inveighs today against the assertion by a spokesman for the British delegation at the ceremony that the Germans had deliberately damaged the cathedral without reason.

Payment of $918,365 to holders of notes of the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, bankrupt Insull investment company, probably will be started within thirty days, Garfield Charles, special referee in bankruptcy, said today.

Luncheon, Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. "The Story Behind the Label," Carlton F. Sturdy. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 3:30 P. M. "The Egyptian Collection," Edwin L. M. Taggart. Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, 4:45 P. M. "Composition and Picture Making," Francis J. Reilly.

Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamllton Tyng have opened their studio, Four Fountains, this season for a series of artistic events, the first of which, an exhibition of sculpture by Wheeler Williams, will begin with a reception and tea on July 19 and continue for one week.
Legality of "block booking," by which motion-picture firms compel exhibitors to contract for an entire year's output, was upheld today by District Judge Leon R. Yankwich.

John E. Manning, manager in Newark for an investment company in New York, was sworn in today as Collector of Internal Revenue for the Fifth District. He succeeds Colonel William H. Kelly, who resigned April 1.

ALEINIKOFF--Vera, widow of the late Nicolas, beloved mother of Alexander S., Cecelia A. Kendler, Sophia Aleinikoff, Marie A. Nicolaieff and the late Arnold N. Aleinikoff. Funeral Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Wednesday, July 13, at 10 A. M.

The Leafs and Newark split a pair of shutouts tonight, Toronto taking the seven-inning twilight game, 7 to 0, behind John Berly's four-hit hurling and the Bears winning the floodlight contest, 6 to 0, as Atley Donald pitched three-hit ball for his ninth victory of the season.

The Harris Trust and Savings Bank and associates received yesterday the award of a new issue of $330,000 of highway bonds of Aiken County, S. C., on a bid of 101.297 for 3s. The bonds are to be dated July 1, 1938, and are to mature serially on July 1, 1945 to 1954.

John Mellus, 210-pound AllAmerica tackle from Villanova, has accepted a contract to play with the New York Football Giants, John V. Mara, president of the club, announced yesterday. The Wildcat ace is the third new tackle with the Giants, the others being Frank Cope of Santa Clara and Jim Moffit of Manhattan.
NAMED TO NEW POSTS

With the proceedings devoted principally to the nomination of officers, the American Legion of Kings County opened Its twentieth annual convention last night at the Knights of Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

Police Commissioner Valentine disclosed yesterday that night parking on Shore Road, Brooklyn, had been prohibited at the request of the Park Department in order to avoid traffic congestion and accidents.

The peak of buyer arrivals will be reached next week, hotel reservations yesterday indicated. Store representatives in the ready-to-wear markets yesterday reached heavy proportions, however, and it was generally agreed that they will get down to actual writing of orders by the end of the week.
Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, July 11: PATROLMAN-Valentine Alster, 112th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 15, 1909.

Coming from behind, Donald McNeill of Kenyon College, seeded first in the New York State clay court tennis championship, defeated Carlton Rood of Brooklyn, 5-7, 6-0, 6-1, in a third-round match at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

Henry W. Whitbeck, member of an old New York family and an executive in the credit department of the Chase National Bank, died Sunday at his home, 101 West Seventy-fifth Street, of a heart attack, after a brief illness.

The Cooperative Union of Sweden has declined to enlarge its porcelain factory at Gostafsberg to begin the manufacture of sanitary enamelware, the Commerce Department has been informed by the American commercial attace at Stockholm.

The Constitutional Convention defeated at 1 A. M. today the Hirschberg amendment which would remove the ban against gambling from the State Constitution. The vote was 69 in favor of advancing the Hirschberg proposal from general orders to third reading and 73 against.

With the statement that there was "reasonable cause" to believe a grand jury investigation of charges against the Earle administration would show "some criminal miscon-duct," Judge Paul N. Schaeffer today formally ordered that the inquiry be started Aug. 8. It will be in the hands of the September grand jury.

Howard Hughes and his flying companions landed at Moscow at 4:15 this morning, New York time, according to a radio message broadcast by the NBC, CBS and Mutual networks. The elapsed time for the 1,675 miles from Paris to Moscow was 7 hours 51 minutes. They covered the 5,316 miles between New York and Moscow in 24 hours 26 minutes actual flying time.

Hunter College's Summer session opened yesterday without ceremony. It will continue until Aug. 19. Registration through yesterday totaled 3,399, against 3,098 at the close of the same five-day period Of registration last year, Late registration is, expected to continue for some time.

A masquerade dance will be held at the Beach Club, Belle Haven, on. July 23, for the benefit of crippled children in New York. Miss Harriette Malley, chairman of the dance, will entertain at cocktails on Sunday for members of the committee.

More than 10,000 adults and children learned how to swim as a result of the "learn to swim" contest conducted from June 11 to 25 by the Department of Parks in -cooperation with the Y. M. C. A., the Y. W. C. A., American Red Cross, boys' clubs and other civic organizations, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday.

Fed steers, yearlings and hogs moved higher again today. Both medium-weight and weighty steers hit $12.50 a new high on the crop, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Long yearlings sold up to $12.35. Hogs passed the $10 mark. These advances in both cattle and hogs suggested a dependability higher wholesale dressed meat market in the East. Lambs weakened somewhat.

Shareholders of the Tennessee Public Service Company, at a special meeting yesterday in Augusta, Me., approved the sale of the company's electric properties in Knoxville to the Tennessee Valley Authority and the city of Knoxville, it was announced by R. W. Lamar, vice president of the company.

Lieutenant Paul R. Gowen of Caldwell, Idaho, was killed when a Martin bomber from Albrook Field crashed on Paitilla Point, across the bay from Panama, today. Lieutenant Kenneth R. Crosher, co-pilot, was seriously injured and Private Gareth H. Budy, radio man, received severe burns.

National and State leaders paid tribute to Associate Justice BenJamin Nathan Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court at brief and simple funeral services here today By his express request, Justice Cardozo, who was known for his modesty, was buried without eulogy.

Movements of naval vessels follow, all dates are July 11. unless specified: San Diego to San Francisco, due to arrive July 12: Altair, Balch, Borie, Broome, Case, Cassin Conyngham, Cummings, Chandler,Concord, Drayton, Downes, Detroit, Gridley, Holland, Hovey, Lamson, Long Memphis, Milwaukee, Melville, Ortolan, Porter, Perry, Perch, Pickerel, Plunger, Permit, Pollack, Pike, Porpolse, Ranger, Reid, Southard, Selfridge, Simpson, Tucker, Truxtun, Trenton, Trevor, Winslow. Wasmuth and Zane.

Figures made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange revealed that on June 30, last, only twenty-two stock issues had short interests of more than 10,000 shares, with only twelve of more than 20,000 shares.

Foodcosts increased 1.3 per cent during the month ended June 14, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Isador Lubin, commissioner of the bureau, said this was due chiefly to a 5.7 per cent increase in the prices of certain fresh fruits and vegetables.

Governor Albert Benjamin (Happy) Chandler, the man the President came to Kentucky to destroy, is a political Holy Roller, religiously convinced that, in the month or so before primary day, he can set the whole State to speaking with tongues.

RUDOLPH ELLINGER, shoes, 115 E. Burnside Ave., by Madison Shoe Co., Inc., for $202; Sobel Bros.. $132; Metropolitan Shoe and Slipper Co., Inc., $165. MELODY CARDS CORP., wholesale card business, 416 W. 33d St., by Plaza Paper Box Corp. for $175; Waring Central Co., Inc., $409; Stephen Thomas, $170. BERNARD RUDERFER, as UNITED GAS AND ELECTRIC SUPPLY CO., 114 Bowery, by Charles Sadek for $75; Elite Import Co., Inc., $600; Chelsea Silk Lampshade Co., $70.

En route from Paris to Moscow Howard Hughes, in a two-way radio conversation broadcast here by the National Broadcasting Company, revealed that he and his fellow fliers were using oxygen as their plane, averaging 185 miles an hour, flew at 16,000 feet.

Joseph R. Hanley of Perry, N. Y., State Senator from the Forty-fourth District, was boomed for National Commander of the United SpanishAmerican War Veterans at the opening session of the thirty-fifth New York State Encampment here today.
The Reds cut loose with all their power in the first inning today, grabbed eights runs on as many hits and coasted to a 9-to-5 victory over the Cardinals.

Completion of the sale of the equivalent of $15,000,000 of fifteenyear 5 per cent debentures of the International Standard Electric Corporation, wholly owned subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, was announced yesterday by the latter company.

Aeronautical leaders and famous aviators gave high praise yesterday to the Hughes flight. Vincent Bendix, president Bendix Aviation Corporation, said: "The speed and efficiency of the Hughes flight is a worthy parallel to the brilliancy of Lindbergh's hop to Paris. Both men are perfect demonstrators of the advancement wrought in the American aviation industry."

In one of the most thrilling finishes of the meeting, which saw three horses race a sixteenth of a mile only inches apart, Ogden Phipps's Teufel, recent winner of the Puritan Handicap at Suffolk Downs, captured the Tuckahoe Handicap at Empire City yesterday. Teufel crossed the line a short head in front of W. A. Carter's Clodion and Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Action, who ran a dead heat for second.

When the Roosevelt special train rolls into Colorado today for a short stop at Pueblo, the President will find that a comfortable majority of Colorado voters are for him at the present time. But his popularity in the Silver State is not as great now as it was in the 1936 election.

From Mexico came a gay caballero, only half an inch high, to the first annual doll show, which was opened to the public yesterday in the Spear auditorium, 22 West Thirty-fourth Street. He is a decorative lapel emblem, like the gay sefioritas of his family clustered around him in a glass case,

As Howard Hughes and his Each world-girdling plane and crew fought wind and rain 16,000 feet over Germany last night, his American headquarters at the World's Fair revealed that he was not flying a straight course over German territory, but was following a route laid out for him by the German Government, apparently to avoid flying over military bases and fortifications.

Traffic accidents and injuries showed another decline last week and week-end compared with the same period last year, but the number of fatalities, both for the full week and for the week-end, showed an increase, the Safety Bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday.

Investment buying of multi-family buildings featured yesterday's realty activity in Brooklyn. Two four-story apartment houses on a plot 150 by 120 feet at 307 to 323 Martense Street were sold by the Gravenhage Estates, Inc., to an investing client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., brokers.

The opera "Countess Maritza" opens tonight at Randall's Island Stadium as the season's second Shubert-Gallo production. Everett Marshall and Charlotte Lansing head a cast which includes Luba Malina, Walter Cassel,- Harry K. Morton, Douglas Leavitt, Zella Russell and Billy Taylor.

The wholesale price level rose to 74.7 per cent of the 1926-1928 average in the week ended July 9, according to the commodity index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. The figure compares with 74.2 the preceding week, 74.4 a month ago and 88.6 a year ago.

Willis D. George, former special agent of the Treasury Department and member of the New York and Chicago Stock Exchanges; won an uncontested verdict of $100,000 today against H. A. Curran, retired steel manufacturer of Portsmouth, England, on a charge of false arrest.

Public notice of an intention to negotiate a trade agreement with Venezuela was issued today by the State Department. A list of items under negotiation was made public, coupled with announcement that briefs in exception might be filed until Aug. 6. Public hearings will open on Aug. 15.

Purchase of Lynn Myers, shortstop on the Asheville (N. C.) club of the Piedmont League, was announced today by the Cardinals. Myers, a brother of Billy Myers, infielder with the Reds, has been hitting .309 this year. He is a right hander.
The Federal Crop Reporting Board forecast today a 1938 wheat crop of 967,412,000 bushels-the second largest on record.

The Earl of Perth, British Ambassador to Italy, called on Galeazzo Ciano, Foreign Minister, again this evening and, it is understood, submitted to him the minimum conditions that in the opinion of the British Government must be fulfilled before a "settlement in Spain" can be held to have been reached.

Overrulling the vote of its chairman, William F. Bleakley, 1936 Republican Gubernatorial candidate, the Committee on Industrial Relations and Workmen's Compensation decided by an 8-to-7 vote today to report out a committee bill for the inclusion in the new State Constitution of a separate labor article.

Miss Mary Robbins is chairman of the Pittsfield Horse Show ball committee and her aides are Mrs. William Thompson Rice, Mrs. Donald M. Weston and Miss Louise Robbins. The ball is to be held on July 29 at the Pittsfield Country Club, and the horse show is to take place the twenty-ninth and thirtieth instead of the thirtieth and thirtyfirst, as first arranged.
Edwin Clark Kent, lawyer, sportsman and descendant of a family dating back almost three hundred years in America, died suddenly here today of a stroke at his home, Chastellux. He was 82 years old.

More than 1,000 buyers of curtains, draperies and general housewares came into the market yesterday to shop for Fall- lines of merchandise at three trade shows in progress here this week. The buyers found curtain prices down 15 to 20 per cent, compared with a year ago; drapery quotations off 15 to 30 per cent, but few declines of major significance in the housewares offerings.

The Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade of 125 West Fortyfifth Street announced yesterday through its national chairman, David McKelvy White, that it is prepared to post funds with the State Department to finance. the return home of eighty American volunteers held prisoner by the Insurgents in the Spanish Civil War. The prison camp in which the men were held was described yesterday in a dispatch from Burgos to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the five-day week ended Thursday, July 7, totaled 187, which compares with 242 for the week before and 108 for the same week a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The figure was the lowest for any week since Nov. 24, when there were 184.

A 2,500-gallon tank car of gasoline was rolled on to the Central Airport early today, and a ground crew was held in readiness to refuel Howard Hughes's Round-the-World monoplane on its arrival from Paris. The Soviet Foreign Office obligingly kept its doors open until 2 A. M. to issue passes, admittance to the airport being by special permission only.

Plainclothes policemen attached to the staff of Deputy Chief Inspector Joseph Reynolds sabotaged one phase of WPA activity yesterday when they broke up a dice game in which twenty of the men assigned to WPA work on the Ferris Point Park, the Bronx, were engaged during their noon hour.

Alfred Cohen, 8 years old, whose forty-four tempera pictures are on exhibit in Bronx House, at 1,637 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, seemed a little annoyed with reporters who interrogated him yesterday. Alfred, a blond-haired, blue-eyed ??ad, made it quite clear that he preferred painting and playing ball to discussing art with inquisitive strangers.

Miss Muriel Vivian Eckhoff, daughter of Adolph William Eckhoff of New York and Mrs. Henry J. Barrett of Boston, was married to James Fergus McRee Jr. yesterday morning in All Angels Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. George A. Trowbridge.

The stock market failed yesterday to develop much rallying power, even though airplane issues gave some promise of leadership in the early trading. Prices sagged all around and finished near the low levels of the day, with the leaders off 1 to 2 points.

Threatening weather last night caused the postponement of the boxing shows scheduled for the New Dyckman Oval and Dexter Park. The former card will take place tonight with Nat Litfin and Al 'Reid, Bronx featherweights, meeting in the principal bout of eight rounds. The winner has been promised. an engagement with Mike Belloise for the New York State 126-pound crown.

Edward ing G. Dolan, Register of the Treas- horn ury, declared himself today a possible candidate, although not as yet an "active" one, for the Connecticut seat in the Senate now held by Senator Lonergan.

The date for the annual National Business Show, customarily staged in the third week in October, has been advanced to Oct. 3 to 8, Frank E. Tupper, president of the show, announced yesterday. The show, which will be held in Commerce Hall in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, will thus precede, rather than coincide with, the seasonal business activity in the Fall, Mr. Tupper explained.

The four favorites--Miss Jean Bauer, Miss Virginia Guilfoil, Mrs. Harry McNaughton and Mrs. Frederick G. Davis, passed the qualifying test today in the twentieth annual Shenecossett women's invitation golf tournament. Match play starts tomorrow.

The Swedish cooperative movement now numbers about one-third of all the families in that country and is proving a powerful force for democracy and fraternal fellowship, two leaders of that organization last night told a dinner meeting sponsored by the Cooperative Coordinating Committee of Greater New York. The dinner was at the Cooperative Cafeteria, 47 East Twenty-fifth Street.

Fifteen soldiers have succeeded in deserting from Germany to Czechoslovakia this past weekend. The deserters, who belonged to Schutzen Regiment Number Three, stated that they were part of a considerably larger number who mutinied on July 5 near Nuremberg because of continued bad and insufficient food supplies.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the plan of consolidation of the Engineers Publio Service Company, a registered holding company, whereby certain of its subsidiary properties will be merged into the Gulf States Utilities Company.

Jefferson St, 14, 20x52.2; Edw. Amron, ref, to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, 346 Broadway, foreclosure, ($1). 97th St, 204-8 E, Six100.11; Benenson Realty Co (Frances Benenson, pres) to Columbus-Sixty-sixth St Corp. 551 5th Ave. Ave A, 73, 24x100; Leah B. Lowenstein individ extrx Wm. M. Wile to Berl Realty Corp. 522 5th Ave, quitclaim.

Duquesne Light Company-Twelve months to May 31: Net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, $9,351,504, compared with a net Of $10,321,143 in the twelve months to May 31, 1937; gross revenues for the period aggregated $30,004,905, against $29,807,623 in the preceding comparable period.
Henry J. Crawford, 60, attorney, and former president of the Albany County Bar Association, was found shot to death in a bedroom of his home here today.

American European Securities Company-Six months to June 30: Profit after interest and taxes, $180,569, compared with one of $170,042 in first six months of 1937. Including $3,737 net loss on securities sold, there was a net profit for the 1938 period of $176,832. In the same period last year there was a net profit of $167,789, including $2,163 net loss on sale of securities. Based on market.

Seeded players scored as the Long Island girls' open tennis singles championship got under way yesterday at the Bayside Tennis Club with one of the strongest fields in the event's history. The entire first round was completed, while rain caused the postponement of all but 'two of -the second-round tests.

The first of a series of Monday afternoon luncheons and bridge parties at the Casino was given today under the direction of Mrs. Barger Wallach, who recently was appointed Casino hostess for the Summer. Mrs. Wallach was assisted by Mrs. Clarence W. Dolan as hostess for the day. Mrs. Lorillard Spencer will assist next week.

That the Franco-Turkish treaty goes much further than an agreement only regarding the policing and status of the Sanjak [district] of Alexandretta was confirmed this evening when its text was issued by the Paris Foreign Office.

Serious dislocation of retail distribution may result from the "Buyand-Give" campaign, as typified by the WPA purchase of $10,000,000 worth of clothing,. Major Benjamin H. Namm, head of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, warned in a communication to Aubrey Williams, deputy administrator of the Works Progress Administration, made publie here yesterday.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended July 6, which included only five business days, aggregated $8,185,000,000, or 7 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 13 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included only five business days.

Philip English, treasurer of the New Haven Clock Company, and Louis M. Rosenbluth, lawyer, were elected members of the board at a meeting today of the directors of the Union and New Haven Trust Company, succeeding Clarence Blakeslee and Ray Reigeluth, who resigned because of a ruling of the Securities and Exchange Commission that bars directors of holding corporations from serving as directors of trust companies.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Nolan of Mountain Lakes, N. J., of the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Nolan, to Ernest E. Lewis-of Colorado Springs and this city.
Archbishop of Canterbury, ranking prelate of -the Church of England, today called on Anglicans to join with "their Jewish brethren" next Sunday in prayer for Jewish sufferers.
The Constitutional Convention, adopting by a rising vote a resolution of regret, tonight paid tribute to the late Justice Cardozo.

New York State factory employment decreased 2.1 per cent and payrolls 1.6 per cent during May, the State Labor Department said today. There were reductions in metal and machine factories, according to the department's report based on tabulation from 2,022 representative factories throughout the State.

Kate Eisenberg, in 140 E. 28th St.; Joseph R. Vilella, in 302 W. 12th St.; through Bing Bing, Inc. Jules Brodeur, Mrs. Rose Radin, Martha Green, Frances S. P. Egleaton, in Alwyn Court, under construction at southeast corner of 58th St. and 7th Ave.; Edgar Ellinger, Inc., broker.

Seeded players scored as the Long Island girls' open tennis singles championship got under way yesterday at the Bayside Tennis Club with one of the strongest fields in the event's history. The entire first round was completed, while rain caused the postponement of all but 'two of -the second-round tests.

The first of a series of Monday afternoon luncheons and bridge parties at the Casino was given today under the direction of Mrs. Barger Wallach, who recently was appointed Casino hostess for the Summer. Mrs. Wallach was assisted by Mrs. Clarence W. Dolan as hostess for the day. Mrs. Lorillard Spencer will assist next week.

That the Franco-Turkish treaty goes much further than an agreement only regarding the policing and status of the Sanjak [district] of Alexandretta was confirmed this evening when its text was issued by the Paris Foreign Office.

35th St, 316 W, to nine-story theatre, opera house and offices; Manhattan Opera Housing Holding Corp, premises, owner; A. de Rosa. architect cost $50,000. Canal St, 25-9, to four-story tenement and stores; Caroline F. Savidge, 125 E 17th St. owner; F. J. Hartwig, architect; cost $50,000.

Justice Benjamin C. Hilliard, campaigning against Senator Alva B. Tan Adams for the Democratic Senatorial nomination, will not be in Pueblo tomorrow morning when President Roosevelt stops there to make a rear-platform talk.

The board of directors of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women.in session here sent a telegram to President Roosevelt tonight asking him to name a woman to the United States Supreme Court.

A building loan mortgage of $190,000 has been obtained by Sussex Apartments, Inc., from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank on the six-story apartment house under construction on the south side of Seventy-first Avenue,- .175 feet west of 110th Street; Forest Hills, L. L David Kugel- represented the borrower.
William McIntyre and Pat Tiso of the Hickory Country. Club, Tuckahoe, took the best-ball event for amateurs and professionals at the Green Meadow Country Club today.
William Harridge, president of the American League, decided today Jeff Heath's ninth-inning game-winning single for Cleveland against St. Louis yesterday was still a single and not a triple.
Uniformly favorable weather over Sunday throughout the Cotton Belt, together with a reactionary stock market, brought setback of more than $1 a bale in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Broadway, 1,784-90, 108.1x86xirreg; prior mtg $800,000 also land at New Haven, Conn, and. in various other States in the United States, trust mtg, United States Rubber Co (Win de Krafft, vice press) to Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co as trustee and ano, trustees bond issue $75,000,000.

An honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred by Harvard University today upon Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, in an impressive ritual before 275 persons in the faculty room of University Hall.

A two-day conference of merchant marine officers holding membership in the United Licensed Officers opened at the Downtown Athletic Club .yesterday attended by fifty three men, who came from as 'far away as San Francisco.

A fourday Grand Circuit meeting at the picturesque Historic Track will start tomorrow. About 450 trotters and pacers are stabled here to try for the rich purses. The trotters include Greyhound, the 6-year-old champion, who on Thursday will attempt to shatter his world halfmile track record of 1:59 3/4, made here last year in an exhibition mile paced by a runner.

In an unprecedented move, the American Olympic Committee has taken a poll of national and intercollegiate track and field champions and members of the 1936 Olympic team, asking the athletes themselves whether or not they favor American participation in the 1940 games at Tokyo, it was learned yesterday.

Dr. Harcourt A. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority; David E. Lillenthal, director in charge of the power program, and John B. Blandford Jr., general manager, will head a group of eighteen TVA officials and experts to escort the Congressional investigating committee which will begin its six-day 800-mile tour of TVA dams and other properties tomorrow.
Meat production increased slightly and prices were substantially lower during the first half of 1938, compared with the same period last year, the Institute of American Meat Packers said today.

Mrs. E. G. Richmond of Cherry Valley and Mrs. Charles Leichner, the former Sylva Annenberg of Cherry Valley, erstwhile Long Island and New York State champion, led a field of thirteen teams in the qualifying round of the annual two-ball foursomes of the Long Island Women's Golf Association at the North Shore Country Club today.

Two well-drillers, Joseph Colaluce, 44 years old, and Nazarro Rossetta, both of New Village, near here, were killed instantly this afternoon when the boom of their drilling apparatus came into contact with a wire that carried 4,600 volts of electricity.

Miss Adele Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan of the Plaza, will leave today for Los Angeles. Mr. and Mrs; A. Jacques Allez and Mrs. Allez's daughter, Miss Mary Munn, who are at the St. Regis, will sail today on the De Grasse for Paris.
King Farouk today granted permission to Prince Abdul Moneim, his second cousin and heir to a $50,000,000 fortune, to marry Princess Myzejen, sister of King Zog of Albania.

Mayor La Guardia began his second week in the Summer City Hall in the New York City Building at the World's Fair grounds yesterday under physical conditions that were but little improved from those that forced him to return to the regular City Hall for a time last week.

A plan to hold "French Day" at Nish has been quashed by the police, who prohibited the project on the pretext that it might cause a Communist demonstration. The French Minister to Yugoslavia had been scheduled to address the meeting.
Five United States owned mines are among fifteen mining properties recently taken over without public fanfare for Mexican labor union operation, it was revealed in reliable quarters today.

The interest rate paid by the Treasury Department on its weekly offerings of bills went up again today to an average of 0.038 per cent, compared with 0.023 per cent on the last issue, sold on July 1, and an average rate of 0.011 per cent the week before that, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

W. S Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, said yesterday that the United States petroleum companies, whose properties in Mexico had been confiscated were not discussing a settlement on the basis of greatly reduced values and payment in oil over a period of years, as some published reports had suggested.

It took Joe Burk longer to get his Diamond Sculls trophy past the customs yesterday than it did for him to win rowing's historic prize a little more than a week ago on the Thames at Henley, England. The "robot oarsman" from the Penn A. C., third American to capture the Diamond Sculls in the ninety-nine years of the competition, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie.

Frederick Van Nuys, one of the nine Democratic. Senators who won the enmity of President Roosevelt by opposing the Supreme Court enlargement bill, will be renominated for the Senatorship at the State Democratic convention tomorrow.

Things have been going so well in Wall Street lately that some of the inhabitants of the financial district were not at all surprised yesterday to see a bird of paradise flying about over their heads.

Drafting experts of the American, British and French delegations of the Intergovernmental Refugee Conference reached an agreement in.principle today on. a resolution organizing the committee as a. permanent body, which is the main work of this session.. The draft has been submitted to Washington, London and Paris with considerable hope that their acceptance will be signified tomorrow.

To free Germany further from dependence on foreign raw materials an announcement has been made of the perfection of a project for the manufacture of carept yarns from human hair and artificial wool cell wool or viscose.

The Pullman Company has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to rearrange the company's collections from railroads for expenses in connection with air-conditioning Pullman cars, the commission announced today. The matter has been set for a hearing July 19.

Mason Bartlett and Marshall Trusstrom of Bayside, carding a ,subpar 31, 35-66, led the Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro competition at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday.

Mason Bartlett and Marshall Trusstrom of Bayside, carding a ,subpar 31, 35-66, led the Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro competition at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday.

Miss Edythe English, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John English of Schenectady, N. Y., and Miami Beach, Fla., will make her debut here on Saturday at a dance to be given at Locklea, the Summer home of her parents on Bolton Road. A dinner will be given at the Hotel Sagamore, Bolton Landing, before the dance.

Frank Moore, 29-year-old playing professional at the Quaker Ridge Club in Mamaroneck, N. Y., won the Alex Smith Memorial Trophy, which goes to the medalist, in the P. G. A. championship today, and in doing so tied the qualifying record for the 21-year-old tournament.

Representatives of numerous Brooklyn and--Queens civic organizations will meet this noon at Miller's Restaurant, 115 Nassau Street, to discuss the possibility of legal action to enjoin Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey from proceeding with his plans for dumping garbage and ashes on West Island in Jamaica Ray.

Surrey and Hampshire scored impressive victories today in.English county cricket matches, concluded a day ahead of schedule. The former whipped Kent by nine wickets and Hampshire obtained a five-wicket margin over Somerset. Rain prevented play in the Glamorgan- Northamptonshire match at Pontypridd.

The three-story business building at 729 East 161st Street, the Bronx, was sold by Margaret B. Bonnell, an out-of-town client of the Herman A. Acker Corporation, broker in the deal. This was the first transfer since 1922 of the property, part of which will be occupied by the purchaser.

Twenty-one graduates and cadets of the United States Military Academy at West Point returned on the Grace liner Santa Rosa yesterday from .a cruise to South America, where they were the guests for a week of the Venezuelan Government.

Oscar S. Cox, assistant corporation counsel, who directed investigations that added $200,000,000 to utility company property assessments in 1936, will resign next week to become an assistant to Herman Oliphant, general counsel to the United States Treasury Department, it was announced yesterday.

The resignation today of Valentin Homan, Minister without portfolio, who had been especially charged with the direction of propaganda, is regarded as proof that Premier Bela Imredy does not look with favor on the extreme Right tendencies that his predecessor, Koloman Daranyi, fostered.

De Herman's single to center, his third hit of the game, enabled the Jersey Giants to tie the Red Wings in the seventh inning tonight, 3-3, play being called at the conclusion of the frame to permit Jersey City to catch a train. The single scored Myatt, on third as a result of two Rochester errors.

Twelve deaths were reported today in Palestine from rioting. Haifa has been affected with a renewed outburst of terrorism. Three Jews were killed there and several were wounded. British marines had to help the police in dispersing the riotous crowd.

The first women to be impaneled as Sheriff's jurors in Brooklyn were chosen yesterday as James V. Mangano, Kings County Sheriff, selected 250 names from the regular list of petit jurors in that borough. The completed panel contained sixty-three women.

A heat wave with temperatures rising above 80 degrees continued for the fifth day yesterday, with no relief in sight for the next two days. Gathering clouds last night gave hope for a cooling storm, but the clouds scattered with only light rains, leaving the thermometer still standing at 77 at 11 P. M.

The Monmouth Park Racing Development Corporation, formed to promote horse races and other sport and theatrical enterprises, filed articles of incorporation here today with Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis.

Governor Earle, breaking a precedent, personally pleaded before the Pardon Board today to spare the life of Roy Lockard, sentenced to death for the "spike" slaying of a 3-year-old boy in Blair County.

A sharp gain in orders for boys' wear as the result of improved Fall prospects, offsetting the 20 per cent decline in dollar volume so far, was predicted yesterday at the opening of the ninth annual convention of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria. Increased optimism was reported by Robert L. Mooney. of Carson,

The Plantagenet Apartments, one of the largest modern multi-family houses in East Orange, N. J., has been purchased by B. A. Lipman of New York from the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company for cash above a purchase money mortgage for ten years.

When an employer lays off some 1,200 workers indefinitely and gives them "vacation pay," it is to be regarded as "dismissal pay," Attorney General Bennett ruled today. Paul Sifton, Director of Unemployment Insurance, asked the Attorney General for the opinion.

Formation of a joint group in which grocery manufacturers, canners, wholesalers, retailers and other trade interests could discuss problems raised by the new Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act and by the Wheeler-Lea law covering advertising was proposed at a meeting of representative grocery manufacturers in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Renominating Senator Frederick Van Nuys, opponent of the Roosevelt court plan, by acclamation, the Democratic State Convention today dramatically endorsed Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines, for the 1940 Democratic Sen Presidential nomination.

Members of the New York Yacht Club gathered in the clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon to view the model of the America's Cup defender Ranger presented by her owner-skipper, Harold S. Vanderbilt.

The Babies Hospital, at Broadway and 167th Street, receives a bequest of $10,000 in the will of Mrs. Emily A. Sanford Hornblower, widow of William B. Hornblower, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mrs.

Owner P. K. Wrigley of the Cubs, who engineered one of baseball's biggest deals when he paid $185,000 and gave the Cardinals three players for Dizzy Dean, said today he knew there was a "question mark" on the hurler's arm when
Work on the new $3,000,000 PWAfinanced grade-crossing elimination at Great Hills, S. I., will be begun today, it was announced yesterday by M. E. Gilmore, Regional PWA Director.

Charles Edward Thurston, president of the Thurston Fruit Company, 204 Franklin Street, New York, died yesterday at his Summer home here at the age of 65. Mr. Thurston lived at 52 Llewellyn Road, Montclair, N. J. Survivors are two sons and four daughters.

The Nassau County Democratic Committee designated four candidates for the coming primary election, named four members of the State Democratic Committee and selected sixty delegates to the State Democratic and judicial conventions at a meeting attended by about 400 persons here tonight at the police auditorium.
Elizabeth St, 100, 55.5x23.2; Frank and Rosina Forte to American Bible Society, 450 Park Ave. 5 Years, 5 per cent; $10,000. 34th St, 311 W, 197.6 to 35th St (322-32) x125;

Governor Earle tonight accused the State Supreme Court of political partisanship and declared that no Republican Governor of Pennsylvania would be subjected to a grand jury investigation such as his administration now faces.

Opponents of the diversion of mtor tax revenues for other than highway purposes gained a substantial, but not complete, victory here today when the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Highways, Parkways and Grade Crossings, headed by Park Commissioner Moses, reported out, with amendments, the Feinberg proposal which would earmark certain motor revenues exclusively for highway expenditures.

Activity in Bronx realty reported yesterday largely involved residential properties. A client of Harry Rubin bought from the estate of Samuel K. Johnson the five-story new-law apartment house at 1,134 Simpson Street for cash above mortgages of $33,000.
Adoption of a plan for semi-weekly settlements of transactions in shares, effective on Sept. 1, is expected at the meeting of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange this afternoon.
Montreal cut short a ninthinning Jersey City rally tonight to down the Little Giants, 6-4. The Royals used three pitchers to stave off the threatening rally.

Trading in general was slow. Bull and cow continued active however, under light supplies and veal hindsaddles were in fair demand. The lamb market was sharply lower, other classes showed little change from Monday. The kosher markets opened steady to weak and demand slow. Conditions, as reported by the United States Deapartment of Agriculture, follow:

Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Hand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hand of Danbury, was married today to Lucian Debuys O'Kelley, son of Mrs. J.. F. O'Kelley of New Orleans, in St. John's Catholic Church here. The Rev. Thomas Hanley of Saybrook, Conn., a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

Canadian radio users demand and get better quality in their radio receiving sets than do American listeners, the Canadian Tariff Board was told today by radio manufacturers. This, in part, accounts for higher prices for radios in Canada than in the United States, it was said.

The Commonwealth will appeal the Federal court order permitting the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to close eighty-eight of its stations in Massachusetts and in addition will seek postponement of the proposed abandonment pending the outcome of the litigation, Attorney General Paul A. Dever announced tonight.
Summer weather has failed to check building activity in the New York district, and this branch of realty operations appears to be holding up well despite the general trade recession.

Two events have been added to the program of the track and field meet which will be held at Randalls Island Stadium on Sunday under the auspices of the Ancient Order of Hibernians. They are a 440-yard relay and a discus throw.

Frederick Young Robertson, vice president and manager of metal sales of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company, died in his home at Southfield Point here. this afternoon. He was 80 years old.

Wilmer L. Allison, Frank Parker and Frank Shields all made their first Eastern appearance of the season in singles today as the annual Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament got under way at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

The revised estimates of receipts and expenditures for the fiscal year 1939, and actual receipts and expenditures for the fiscal year 1938, are presented in the following tables from the President's revised budget message:

Following a setback of $2 a bale from high records of last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange here steadied yesterday in sympathy with strong outside markets and ended with net gains of 5 to 9 points.

A national advertising campaign for which an agency is now being considered is planned as a feature of the $50,000 drive now under way to promote the cap industry, it was brought out yesterday at the first of a series of conferences on the promotion, held at the Broadway Central Hotel.

AUTO RACING Cross Bay Speedway, Cross Bay Boulevard and Sunrise Highway Ozone Park3:45 P.M. BASEBALL New York Yankees vs. St. Louis Browns, at Yankee Stadium. River Avenue and 161st. Street, Bronx .................. 3:15 P. M.
Mrs. Thomas Bertrand Wright gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 1,120 Fifth Avenue. Her guests included Mrs. Walter W. Powers of New York and Rochester, Mrs. Douglas Gibbons, Mrs.
Large increases in the amount of farm purchases made through cooperatives have occurred since the last study of this field in 1930, the Commerce Department announced toay.

The tendency of American producers and distributors to emphasize price when quality is the compelling factor in consumer buying was criticized by V. E. Vining, manager of appliance sales to department stores for the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company,
The Senators hung up their fifth straight victory today, by a score of 9 to 8, at the expense of the league-leading Indians.

Extension of the New York City school facilities offered to colleges and teacher-training institutions in the metropolitan area has been voted- by the Board of Education's law committee. James Marshall, president of the board, announced yesterday.

The thirty-second exhibition in the series held by resident artists of New York opened with a preview yesterday afternoon in the Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixtyseventh Street. It opens to the public today and will be current until the end of the month.

The United States, British and French Governments confirmed today the refugee agreement reached among their representatives here establishing the intergovernmental committee on a permanent basis as reported yesterday.

A steel production rate of 60 per cent of capacity by October, double the present output, was declared likely today by John H. Van Deventer, editor of Iron Age. Mr. Van Deventer said in an interview that the recent reduction in steel prices had caused buyers to hold back orders temporarily in hope of another cut.

Mrs. Janet Roper, known by seamen all over the world as house mother of the Seamen's Church-Institute of New York and as founder of the Missing Seamen's Bureau, was honored yesterday afternoon at a tea given by the organization's 200 employes.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo charged yesterday in a formal opinion that "some responsible officials of the Board of Education" showed "little consideration for the feelings, if not the interests, of properly qualified employes in the city's service."

Unwilling to submit to a liedetector test for District Attorney Walter A. Ferris in his investigation of Port Chester gambling, this village's three "ace" detectives have been demoted to patrol duty by the police committee of the Village Board, Mayor W. Burdell Banister said today.

KINGS ANDERSON, LOUISE (Apr. 22). Gross assets, $11,404; net, $10,274. To legatee, Lizzie Baum, $500; grandnephew, Kenneth Anderson, $100; legatee, Sadie Ames, $500; Home for Incurables, 183d St. and 3d Ave., Manhatan, $200; legatee, Elizabeth Wagner, $100; niece, Alice Jackson, $500 and residue. Chief assets, real estate, $8,900; stocks and bonds, $1,028; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $1,401; miscellaneous property, $75. Harvey O. Dobson, attorney, 189 Montague St.

Favorites survived the opening round of match play in the Shenecossett Golf Club's twentieth annual women's invitation tournament today. Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., defending champion and comedalist of the tourney,

Plans were filed in Queens yesterday for another apartment house project of the Airport Land Corporation, consisting of nineteen sixstory tenements, to cost about $3,800,000. The same organization filed a plan on July 7 for sixteen buildings to cost $3,200,000.
Major John R. Brooke Jr. was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on a charge of first-degree murder in the death of his wife, Elizabeth.

Increased agricultural production and national and international action to facilitate freer interchange of foodstuffs between nations was urged today at the Institute of Public Affairs of the University of Virginia by Dr. Frank G. Boudreau of New York, director of the Milbank Memorial Fund, and Charles J. Brand. of Washington, chairman of the American Committee-in the International Institute of Agriculture in Rome.

James J. McLoughlin, estate of Rudolph Eberstadt at Remsenberg, L. I.; Newbold T. Lawrence, cottage at Cedar Beach, Westhampton, from Frederick R. Jagger Jr.; Albert E. Brockman, camp on Seatuck Cove, Remsenberg, from F. L. Schroeder; Talbot J. Taylor Jr., in association with Butler Baldwin, brokers.

Acting upon the proposal of the sanitation committee of the Community Councils of the City of New York, representatives of civic organizations in Brooklyn and Queens voted yesterday to join in an injunction suit to prevent the De partment of Sanitation from carrying out its dumping project on West Island in Jamaica Bay.

In honor of the country's famous naval architect, the late Nathaniel Greene Herreshoff, the Bristol Yacht Club, of which he was an honorary member, held two of a series of six races today for the silver Herreshoff Bowl, a perpetual trophy presented by R. F. Haffenreffer with replicas for the winning crew of three boys or girls.

Commenting constructe on a telegram sent from a group of Williams College undergraduates and Raymond Ingersoll, Brooklyn Borough President, to the head librarian of the Austrian National Library, offering to buy those "non-Aryan" books that they suspect will be destroyed or removed, the Boersen Zeitung says today:

Bradford Washburn and his companions in an expedition sponsored by the Explorers Club, the Harvard Institute of Geographical Exploration and the National Geographic Society are trying to scale the highest unclimbed peak in North America, it was disclosed today.

Thomas Lewis a United States citizen, was knocked unconscious by a blow on the head in a struggle with strikers who were seeking to gain control for union operation of the United. States owned--Felicitas mine in the town of Caborca, State of Sonora, the newspaper Universal reports.
The rampant Pirates rode the season's longest winning streak into first place in the National League today by trouncing the Cubs, 14 to 6.

Corn was the leader in the grain market today, advancing 2 1/4 to 2 7/8 cents a bushel to a new high level since late in April on heavy professional buying early, which absorbed the surplus in the Pit.

New York Curb Exchange observers claim to see signs that the usual "time lag" between the "Big Board" and the junior market is being shortened. In years past the Curb was accustomed to see its securities attract strong attention something like six weeks after a bull market got under way at Broad and Wall Streets.

William Boyle, 47 years old, of 178 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, with a record of forty-five arrests since 1922 for disorderly conduct and intoxication, was brought into Bay Ridge Court yesterday on a new charge of intoxication.

Lieutenant William Ewing, 23-year-old sharpshooter from Montreal, scored Canada's first victory at the Empire meeting of the National Rifle Association today when he won the Wimbledon Service Rifle Cup in a tie-shoot with three English marksmen.

The a card pa twenty-first year of Camp Dix's Hotel her history as a training site for citizens soldiers began today as 2,224 C. M. T. C. candidates arrived from New York, Delaware and New Jersey for thirty days of instruction in athletics, discipline and citizenship.
Martial law was believed imminent tonight in the Haifa area of Palestine, where British marines fought an armed guerrilla band.

Responding to an official welcome to Queens yesterday, Mayor La Guardia assured his hosts that he was "most comfortable" in his Summer City Hall at the World's Fair grounds and twitted reporters about their accounts to the contrary.

After a slow and irregular start, bonds resumed an upward course 167 in vigorous fashion yesterday in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The spotlight was turned on local traction securities and a fairly-broad list of secondary railroad bonds as a speculative demand forced prices up sharply.

A list of corporate donors to the Brooklyn division of the Greater New York Fund, headed by the Brooklyn Trust Company with a contribution of $8,000, was announced yesterday by Charles A. Gorman, chairman of the division.

Outstanding among the results in the evening session. of the American Chess Federation's open championship at the Hotel Touraine tonight was the setback sustained by Walter F. Murdock of Cazenovia, N. Y., pacesetter in the first section, by Kirk D. Holland of Chicago, president of the federation and donor of the challenge trophy won last year by David S. Polland of Brooklyn.

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday reached a new peak in the present buying season. The total was also well ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week 1,733 arrivals were listed, the highest since the week of Jan. 6. 1937.

The tension between Germany and Brazil which followed President Getulio Vargas's step against German political and cultural activities was intensified today when Berlin announced the complete suspension of purchases from Brazil.

Premier Bela Imredy is taking measures against increasing National Socialist propaganda, which has already become such a menace to internal peace and order that the Socialist representatives saw the Premier to offer him the support of their trade unions to curb Nazi disturbances.

Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt left for New York today aboard the yacht Winchester to attend the wedding there on Thursday of his daughter. Mrs. Grace Vanderbilt Davis, to Robert Livingston Stevens, son of Mrs. Robert L. Stevens of Bernardsville, N. J.

James Peters, a former WPA superintendent at the Pelham bus terminal; six other persons and two bus corporations went on trial yesterday before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger and a jury on a charge of having overcharged the government $25,000 for the transportation of WPA workers to the Orchard Beach project.

John Newmyer, 19 years old, who said he had no home, jumped from a bench in the front of the court room in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, and started to run toward Magistrate Vincent J. Sweeney yesterday morning after he had been sentenced to serve ninety days in jail for vagrancy.

Mr. and Mrs. Horton Hubbard Heath of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Violet Heath, to Roger Underwood Wellington, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Oliver Wellington of New York.
Miss Faith Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Trufant Foster of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Second Church to Hugh Kaul, son of Mrs. John L. Kaul

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES'S editorial in respect to the proposal under consideration by the Constitutional Convention to relieve the railroads from participating in the cost of grade-crossing eliminations, you say that the "chief argument for the proposal is simply that the railroads are too poor to pay their share of the expenses."
Dr. Edward James McCormick, surgeon of Toledo, Ohio, was elected Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks at its seventy-fourth annual convention here today.
Further price advances developed in two types of hides in active trading yesterday and the volume was held down chiefly by packers' unwillingness to take further business at current levels,

Faced with a threatened protest march and possible disturbances, the National Labor Relations Board tonight ordered its eleven-monthslong hearings against the Weirton Steel Company transferred from Steubenville, Ohio, across the Ohio River, to this city.
Miss Ella Charlotte Goldschmid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar H. Goldschmid of Plainfield, was married here today to Geoffrey Hoyt Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Moore.
Tenement houses on the East Side and private residences on the West Side furnished the bulk of the Manhattan realty activity announced yesterday.

Budgets for the purchase of better Fall coats have been increased during the last week, with the result that buyers are now rounding out price assortmerts by ordering more expensive coats. Previously, many of the larger stores had been forced to concentrate purchasing in the medium price brackets in order to obtain a sufficient number of units.
The following attractions will be shown tonight free of. charge by the Federal Caravan Theatre: The Bronx, "Pierre Patelin," at Crotona Park; Brooklyn, "Mississippi Rainbow," at Gravesend Park;

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 9: COMMANDERS Reinicke, F. G., to duty as war plans officer, 4th Naval District, Philadelphia. Wright, C. H., 5th Naval District, to duty as inspector of ordnance in charge, Yorktown, Va.

The general death rate for the city during the week ended last Saturday was 8.3 per 1,000 population, a low record for the year to date, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records, to Dr. John H.. Rice, City Health Commissioner.

Another Welshman appeared on the pugilistic horizon yesterday and this one means business, too. He is Ronnie Davies, 5 1/2 years old, who traveled alone from Southampton, England, on the Aquitania to join his parents, Mr. and. Mrs. Albert Dayies of Dearborn, Mich.

The debate in the State Constitutional Convention over the question of civil liberties has now ended in the adoption of the compromise amendment proposed by Justice Lewis. The vote on it was cast almost entirely along party lines. It is unfortunate that a question that ought from the first to have transcended party interests should have become involved so deeply in partisan manoeuvres and partisan dispute.

FIRST RACE-Purse $1,000; claiming: 2-year-olds; five and a half furlongs. Start good; won driving; place easily. Went to post 2:31, off 2:34. Winner, b. g., by Carlaris-Altitude. Trainer, M. Buxton. Time-1:07.

The Kemper Realty Corp. has arranged an extension for 5 years of the first mortgage of $127,400 on the 60-family apartment house at 4,590 Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, the Bronx, for the Carroll Management Corp., owner. The New York Life Insurance Co. is the mortgagee.
Fifty one dollar bills will float, down from an airplane over the Douglas County court house tomorrow to settle an election bet between two Republicans.

For the third time in three racing days an Empire City track record was equaled when The Fighter was timed yesterday in 1:07 4-5 for five and three-quarter furlongs. On Saturday, Stagehand equaled the mile and an eighth mark, which now has five joint record holders, and Mamas Choice. tied the mile and a half standard.

Herbert Thornton Banks, 36 years old, an attorney of 51 Chambers Street, accused of operating a fraudulent "divorce mill," pleaded guilty yesterday before Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer to a charge of second-degree forgery.
The short position in securities listed on the New York Curb Exchange on June 30, reported yesterday, was 15,439 shares. Following the lead of the New York Stock Exchange,
In the four weeks ended last Friday, the improved buying of cotton gray goods resulted in a 50 per cent reduction in the excess of print cloth stock over orders, selling agents estimated yesterday.

Commissioner Lewis Valentine and Chief Inspector John J. Seery of the New York Police Department and Chief John J. Sullivan of the. World's Fair police were among the more than 100 persons who attended services yesterday for Oscar Herdman, veteran police headquarters reporter,

ABRAHAMS-Jacques E., beloved husband of Fan. Services, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Thursday, July 14, at 11:30 A. M. Kindly omit flowers. ALEINIKOFF-Vera, widow of the late Nicholas, beloved mother of Alexander S., Cecelia A. Kendler, Sophia Aleinikoff, Marie A. Nicolafeff and the late Arnold N. Aleinikoff.

The third cricket test match between England and Australia was abandoned today without a ball being bowled. Scheduled to start last Friday at Old Trafford, play was made impossible by rain on each of the four days.
The Suffolk County Mosquito Extermination Commission today conveyed a party of officials and observers by boat on an inspection tour of some of the county's 70,000 acres of salt marsh.

Phil Axt, youthful golf star of the Forest Hill Field Club, established a new competitive course record over his home layout today. He burned up the links with a 65, six under par, in the one-day event of the Metropolitan Golf Association.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 12, unless specified:

John Lonsdale Gilmour, chairman of the board of directors of Johnson Johnson, manufacturers of surgical supplies, died suddenly today at his Summer home here at the age of 83. He retired from active business several years ago.

The current season of outdoor operettas at Jones -Beach and Randalls Island will be concluded, the first on Saturday evening, the other on Sunday evening, it was announced yesterday by the National Academy of Theatres and the San Carlo Opera Company.

After dismissing rumors for two weeks without comment, court officials no longer denied today that Crown Princess Juliana is expecting a second baby. Though no date was even hinted the birth is not expected before February.
A shooting which caused some twenty patrons to run for cover killed one man and seriously wounded another early today in a bar and

Dramatization of quality in selling apparel was recommended by Kirby, Block Co. at a Fall Fashion Forum at the Hotel Astor last night. A detailed survey of Fall fashions was distributed, listing probable style leaders and suggesting methods of promotion. With fur prices ranging from 15 to 30 per cent below a year ago, and the fur tax eliminated, stores can promote quality at lower prices, the survey indicated.

The part that international expositions play in promoting peace and good-will among nations was emphasized by spokesmen for the British Empire Exposition in progress at Glasgow, Scotland,. and the New York World's Fair of 1939 in addresses broadcast from Glasgow yesterday afternoon over WJZ.

Japan's War Minister, Lieut. Gen. Seishiro Itagaki, was quoted today as saying he was uneasy over a slackening of the nation's war spirit and fearful that munitions supplies were not being replenished sufficiently.

The annual checker tournament for players under 16 years of age, under the sponsorship of.the Park Department, got under way yesterday afternoon when about 150 youngsters competed in playgrounds throughout Manhattan.

The Moses grade-crossing elimination proposal was amended today, over the objections by Mr. Moses and former Governor Smith, to conform to the ideas of those in the Constitutional Convention who held that the railroads should pay some share of the work.

Johnny David of Indianapolis clipped two strokes from par today with 34, 35-69 to lead the field of 149 in the first eighteen of the thirty-six-hole qualifying round of the thirty-eighth annual Western amateur golf championship.

At the annual meeting yesterday of stockholders of Remington Rand, Inc., James H. Rand Jr., chairman of the board and president, expressed confidence in general business improvement for the Fall. He also said: "I am glad...

Vigorous action will be taken by the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc., to curb the practice of acceptance of returns before it hampers Fall activity, B. H. Lerner, executive director of the association, announced last night after a meeting of producers in the bracket above $22.50 at the Hotel New Yorker.

THE Cleveland Indians are now off on an important road test. This may be where peppery Oscar Vitt finds out whether he is driving a new model prize-winning machine or just another trailer from Cleveland. Winning on the road is the big problem for Manager Vitt. It's against Cleveland precedent.

Josef Hofmann, pianist, will appear as soloist in the Lewisohn Stadium on Monday evening, Aug. 8, playing the Chopin concerto in F minor with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, it was announced by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the Stadium Concerts, Inc. It will be Mr. Hofmann's first outdoor appearance.

Donald McNeill, young Kenyon College star, seeded No. 1, and Frank Guernsey, national intercollegiate champion, seeded No. 2, led the way into the fifth round of the New York State clay court tennis championships on the courts of the Seminole Club at Forest Hills yesterday.

Sherlock Davis, assistant director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was the principal speaker yesterday at a general meeting of the New York Security Dealers Association, held at the Bankers Club.

Major George A. Hadd, assistant corps area C. M. T. C. and R. O. T. C. officer, visiting the post today on a tour of inspection, gave special praise to the 307th Infantry, commanded by Lieut. Col. George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens. Major Hadd left here tonight for Madison Barracks, before returning to Governors Island.

More than 150 women representatives of New Jersey social centers attended a card party today at the Stockton Hotel here. The event was sponsored by the Sea Girt Alliance of the Fitkin Memorial Hospital at Neptune for the benefit of that institution.
It took only three matches to complete the first round of the annual two-ball foursome competition of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the North Shore Country Club today.

Miss Edith Smith Noyes, daughter of Charles F. Noyes of Halesite and New York, and the late Mrs. Jessie Smith Noyes, was married this afternoon to John Rothbury Muma in the old Presbyterian Church of this place in the presence of members of the families and a few friends. The pastor, the Rev. E. J. Humeston, and the Rev. Peter Rees Joshua, officiated.

The Blind Brook riders of Port Chester, N. Y., came from behind to conquer the Norwood C. C. team of West Long Branch, 9 to 6, today in a Rumson Country Club polo tournament match played on Herbert Memorial Field.

Ward Ave, 1,059 dwelling, 25x100, Home Owners Loan Corp against Margaret F. Kiernan, due, $11,486; to plaintiff for $500. By B. HOLLANDER SON 194th St, 2,860 E,. dwelling, 50x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Josephine Scandura, due, $14,430; to plaintiff for $3.000.

Total sales of hardware and allied products during May declined 25 1/2 per cent from May, 1937, the Commerce Department announced today. According to reports from 454 distributors, this was the eighth successive month when sales were lower than in the same months last year.

The mounting toll of dead and injured in yesterday's Japanese air raid on Wuchang, across the Yangtze River from Hankow, the temporary capital, indicates the attack was the most disastrous ever inflicted in this vicinity. The count early today put the casualties at nearly 500, almost all civilians.

According to The Daily Express, the Earl of Clarendon, who was recently appointed Lord Chamberlain, has notified certain peeresses after a "searching inquiry" that their presence will not be required at further court functions this season.

Air Investors, Inc.-Six months to June 30. Net assets, based upon market value of securities owned, amounted to $908,143, equivalent to $38.48 a share on 23,600 shares of $2 convertible preference stock outstanding at close of period. For the six months ended June 30, last, net loss was $21,049, including $31,673 loss on sales of securities, and after expenses and Federal income taxes.

The statement of Barclays Bank, Ltd., of London for June 30 received here yesterday by its New York representative showed deposits of [pound]436,030,565, a rise of about [Pound]6,500,000 in twelve months.
Fifteen Tenth Avenue Tom Sawyears splashed whitewash on a homemade fence in West Forty-sixth Street yesterday while Boys Athletic League judges strove to find a champ.

The Alamac Hotel, nineteen-story structure on the southeast corner of Broadway and Seventy-first Street, was sold yesterday to the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against the Alamac Esplanade Corporation, on a nominal bid of $1,000.

Washington politicians wondered today whether President Roosevelt's appointment of Governor Allred of Texas to the Federal District Court bench might be a link in a chain of events leading to the entry into politics of Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President.
Professor George D. Strayer, specialist in educational administration at Teachers College, warned yesterday against Federal aid to State education that entailed any measure of Federal control.

Winners of ten $1,000 awards offered by the Treasury for architectural designs for small postoffice buildings were announced today. Three of the winners are from New York City. They are Francis W. Roudebush, 654 Madison Avenue, and Harvey Stevenson and Eastman Studds, both of 101 Park Avenue.

The largest Lewisohn Stadium audience in the history of the concerts there joined the PhilharmonicSymphony and the Paul Whiteman Band last night in paying tribute to the memory of George Gershwin, who died almost a year ago to the day.

No appeal will be taken by White, Weld Co. from the decision of the Securities and Exchange Commission which suspended its partner, Faris R. Russell, from membership in all national security exchanges for ninety days.

While Howard Hughes and his companions were completing another leg of what they expect will be a new speed record for a world-circling trip, an example of man's most ancient globe-navigating craft arrived yesterday in New York on an around-the-world trip of its own.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended July 7, which included the Fourth of July holiday, increased in four out of five trade divisions, as compared with the same week of 1937, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Seven members of the Congressional investigating committee of ten inspected the TVA project here today. They arrived this morning in a motorcade of fourteen cars from Knoxville, Tenn., accompanied by committee attaches, TVA officials and experts and newspaper men.
The Manhattan of the United States Lines is due to sail today for the Channel ports. Passengers are Frederick A. Sterling, newly appointed United States Minister to Sweden, and Mrs. Sterling;

William Cole, chief of the Washington State patrol, said tonight that a man giving the name of Frank Olson, 32, arrested at Ritzville, Wash., yesterday, had confessed the kidnapping of Charles Mattson, 10, in Tacoma, Dec. 27, 1936.
A 61-year-old grandmother, Mrs. Matilda Gebhard of 485 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, won the annual Grandma Bathing Beauty Contest yesterday at Steeplechase Park, Coney Island.

Joseph Lennox of 34 Douglas Avenue, this city, was elected president of the New York State Council of the Catholic Benevolent Legion at the seventeenth biennial convention of the organization here today at the Knights of Columbus Hall. Mr. Lennox succeeds Joseph H. Fitzpatrick of 177 Leonard Street, Brooklyn.

Application is to be-made on July 22 in a special term here for an order to compel the Civil Service Commission to recertify names for appointment to positions in the Division of Placement and Employment Insurance.
Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and Crown Princess Louise of Sweden arrived here today for a brief visit as house guests of Robert Woods Bliss, former Minister to Sweden, and Mrs. Bliss.

Accused of swindling Mrs. Anna Maziaka, 46-year-old widow, of her life savings of $4,200 through the "switch racket," Nicholas Radzik, 40, of 243 Boerum Street, Brooklyn, who has a police record, and John Adam, 46, of 224 East Tenth Street,

Free transportation on Class I steam railroads in 1937 was valued at $24,957,912, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today. The number of free trips was 6,541,945, of which 1,010,266, or 15.4 per cent, were made by persons not employes of the carriers or members of their families, the report said.
Mrs. Charles E. Morgan 3d and Miss Daphne Morgan have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Philadelphia.

The semi-official news agency replied to the story published in the London News Chronicle today alleging that a high ranking German army officer in a speech before leaders of the National Socialist party had said that Germany had intervened in Spain to test her military machine and to sever the ties between Portugal and Britain.

Stockholders of the Tennessee Public Service Company who control a majority of its common and preferred stocks voted unanimously at a meeting here to sell all the company's electric properties: to the city of Knoxville, Tenn., and the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The entire remaining underwear stocks of Marshall Field Co.'s wholesale and manufacturing division have been purchased by the wholesale division of Carson Pirie Scott Co., it was announced today by the latter firm.

The possibility of a milk strike by the independent grocers of the city in their controversy with milk dealers and the milk drivers' union over ending the practice of delivering free excess ice with milk was delayed yesterday when the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association

The nation's cold storage reserves of butter on July 1 reached a new high record for the date, according to the monthly report of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics today. The total was 120,050,000 pounds, an increase of 13,688,000 over the previous July record, made in 1930, and 34,172,000 pounds more than normal for the date.

Rhinelander Ave (15-4254), n w cor of Cruger Ave, 118x104; Felix A. Muldoon, trustee, to Rhinelander Garage, Inc, 614 Van Nest Ave; mtg $25,000. Otis Ave (18-5420), n e cor of Logan Ave, 70x100; Arthur Whitehill, referee, to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee.
Mrs. D. Crawford Clark of New York entertained with a luncheon today at Green Court in honor of Mrs. Louis Curtis of Nahant, Mass., and Mrs. Philip Ely of Pomfret, Conn.
Pepper Martin and Joe Medwick failed in a ninth-inning pinch today and the Cardinals slipped to seventh place as the Reds took the finale of a two-game series 6 to 5.

A registration statement is expected to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission within a week covering -the proposed issuance of $37,500,000- of securities of the Indianapolis Power and Light Company.

Dr. Alexander J. Stoddard, head of the Denver school system, was elected Superintendent of Schools of Philadelphia at a special meeting of the Board of Education today. His sixyear term will begin Aug. 1, 1939.

Orrin J. Whitney, airplane distributor and charter operator; James H. Lymburner, who is a pilot for Lincoln Ellsworth, the explorer, and a nurse took off from Floyd Bennett Field at 8:40 o'clock last night on a 3,600-mile flight to Sheridan, Wyo., and back, to rush a young Boroklyn physician and his wife here for hospital treatment for injuries they suffered in an automobile accident Monday afternoon.

Mrs. Harry P. Connor, whose husband is one of the relief pilots accompanying Howard Hughes on his globe circling flight, was weary but happy yesterday as bulletins continued to arrive at her room in the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza, telling of the record-breaking progress of the aviators.

Mrs. Eleanor Farries Vaughan, wife of Professor Richard M. Vaughan of the Andover-Newtown Theological School, died here today after a long illness. Born in Wauwatosa, Wis., fifty-six years ago, she was active in churches of which her husband was pastor in Detroit, Janesville, Wis., and - Berkeley, Calif.

Archibald Beresford of Chelseaon-Hudson, former Alderman and Commissioner, of Public Works in Mount Vernon, died here Sunday night at St. Agnes Hospital at the age of 72. Mr. Beresford was born in Greenock, Scotland, and came to this country as a boy. For many years he operated a trucking and roadcontracting business in Mount Vernon.
Two daily double combinations won at Brighouse Park today after a long shot, How High, held on to force a dead heat for first with the favored Adelaide N. in the six-furlong second lace.

Samuel Seabury went to Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning to visit Fireman Andrew. Dunn of Engine. Company 39, who was overcome by smoke on Monday night while fighting a fire that followed an explosionin the Seabury home, 154 East Sixty-third Street. The fire routedMr.

Bernard J. Riley, a retired theatrical press agent and executive, who was better known as Barney Reilly, died yesterday in the Brunswick Home, Amityville, L. I. Before going there because of illness Mr. Riley had been, since January, 1932, at the Percy Williams Home, East Islip, L. I. A native of Brockton, Mass., he was 73 years old.
Howard Hughes and his four companions took off here today at 4:37 A. M. [6:37 P. M. Tuesday in New York] on the fourth leg and second half of their globe-girdling flight.
A banking group headed by the National City Bank of New York obtained yesterday $5,079,000 City of New York. 4 per cent bonds, maturing Jan. 1 and June 1, 1939 to 1964.

Jeremiah I. Bacon, who retired last month from his post as an examiner in the Division of Charitable Institutions ot the City Controller's Office after more than forty-seven years as a city employe, died on Monday in Knickerbooker Hospital.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was referred to on the floor of the Constitutional Convention today as "Senator." Immediate apology for the designation came from the speaker, Senator Wagner.

Americans have so many anniversaries that there would hardly be any need to go abroad for more of them. Dominating everything is the sesquicentennial climate. The work of making the Federal Union began 150 years ago last year. The nation came into existence 150 years ago next year. Two years ago Harvard rounded out its third century.

Joseph R. Wynne, 29 years old, of 785 Columbus Avenue, died in Jewish Memorial Hospital at 3:45 A. M. yesterday of injuries received Sunday morning when a stolen police car he was driving crashed into a tree in Fort George Avenue at 193d Street.

A fire in a Bowery lodging house, made more serious by the fact that fifty roomers had remained indoors to escape the afternoon heat, resulted in the death of one man and the injury of three others between 6:30 and 7 o'clock last night at 6 Chatham Square.

The Hollywood Jockey Club, Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., J. M. Smoot, president, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 20,000 shares of $100 par value 8 per cent cumulative preferred and 25,100 no-par common shares to be used as collateral to secure a loan of $1,500,000 from the Hollywood Racing Syndicate.

Mr. and Mrs. James A. Andrews of Hewlett Harbor, L. I., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Alice Andrews, to Roy Rutherford of Chattanooga, Tenn., which took place Saturday at the Ocean Forest Club, Myrtle Beach. S. C.
