A program of light symphonic music will be given tonight at the Federal Music Theatre by the Greenwich Orchestra, under the direction of Emerson-Buckley. Ina De Martino will be soprano soloist.

Twenty-two Princeton and Cornell trackmen will board the French liner Normandie at New York tomorrow, heading for their ninth international clash with representatives from Oxford and Cambridge Universities in London July 23.
A. special county grand jury late today returned a first-degree murder indictment charging John Bathelt of New York City with the slaying of Charles Morris, New York race track follower.

Standards of tavern operation in the metropolitan-area are probably the highest existing anywhere in the country, Hugh Harley, secretary of the United Brewers Industrial Foundation, told members of the group at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.
The government is checking up to determine what electric power facilities would be available in the event of a wartime mobilization of industry.

Plans for the Union Airways Terminal, a three-story structure to rise on the long-idle site of the old Hotel Belmont at Park Avenue and Forty-second Street, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by John B. Peterkin, architect, who estimated the cost of construction at $1,000,000.

87th St, 12-14 E, 76x100.8; Sagamore Land Corp (Walter G Nelson, pres) to Portsmouth Management Corp, 1,860 Broadway; mtg $270,000 ($10). Riverside Drive, 127, 27.5x92.4 x irreg; Warren Arthur Smadbeck, Inc, to Argentor Holding Corp, 565 5th Ave ($25).

Paul N. Coulcher, labor union leader convicted in the restaurant 10 racket that Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer ran from a back room, has been examined recently by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's staff in preparation for the trial of James J. Hines.

Officials of the American Fur Liners Contractors Association, with offices at 370 Seventh Avenue, will visit the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey today to lay before him what they characterized yesterday as a story of "systematic terrorism" being waged against members of the association by the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union, Communist controlled C. I. O. affiliate, with the purpose of driving them out of business.

Joe Louis made a hurried trip East today, but said it was solely for the purpose of visiting friends. He arrived at Newark Airport at 4:44 P. M. on a non-stop flight from Chicago, saying he planned only an overnight visit to New York and would return to Chicago tomorrow.

Blaming the lag in business in the past six months for drastic changes in his fiscal program, President Roosevelt has revised the 1938-39 budget outlook to point to an estimated net deficit of $3,984,887,600 for the fiscal year.

Magistrate Anthony Savarese in the Queens Felony Court held Walter M. Wiley, 19 years old, formerly of 43-15 Forty-fifth Street, Woodside, in $50,000 bail yesterday on a charge of grand larceny, after he had been informed that the police were investigating to determine. whether Wiley had anything to do with the so-called Red Circle murders.
A world-wide decline in the total volume of merchant ships under day, construction during the last quarter is shown in figures made public yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Ship; ping.

The Brewster Aeronautical Corporation earned $210,397 in the first six months of this year after deductions for taxes and other charges, according to the semi-annual statement made public yesterday by James Work, president.

Blazing bonfires and the reverberating roll of big drums ushered in the celebration in Northern Ireland today of the 248th anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne. In Belfast some of the younger men sang party songs and burned effigies of Eire's President, Dr. Douglas Hyde, and Premier Eamon de Valera.

The league-leading Newark Bears wheeled their big guns into the stadium tonight and promptly shelled the Bisons out of second place by notching an 11-to-5 triumph. It was the sixth defeat in seven starts for Buffalo.

Representative Ludlow of Indiana stated today that he would introduce in the next session of Congress a modified form of the war referendum resolution which was voted down by the House last Winter. His new proposal would permit war mobilization by order of Congress in the face of "immediate"

America this year is being blessedbeg pardon, cursed-with plenty. The wheat crop this year is estimated at 967,412,000 bushels, the largest since 1915, and with the exception of that year the largest on record. And there are bumper crops all along the line.

The authorities at the Bronx Zoo glibly explained that the female and male nyalas were nervous and restless yesterday because it was their first day there. Yet the truth is that far from being restless they were offended and rightly so.

The Italian fliers in Spain claim to have shot down 580 Loyalist airplanes from the beginning of the war through yesterday, according to an Italian Government communique that received great prominence in the press today.

Mrs Pauli Newgold, who, under the name of Madame Polly, for more than a generation attended to the hair of Broadway's favorite actresses, died yesterday in her home at 87-77 Twentieth Avenue, Brooklyn. She was 80 years old.
The purse participation plan for betting on midget automobile races at the Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L. I., will be investigated tomorrow by the Nassau County grand jury.
Cold Spring Harbor captured the Gregory Taylor Challenge Cup for junior yachtsmen today, defeating five other clubs, including the defending Pequot crew.

The Federal Government today increased from $225,000 to $4,725,000 the money it will give outright to the Santee Cooper power project in South Carolina, a program fought by private utilities until the Supreme Court on the final day of the last session refused to review a Circuit Court decision adverse to the private interests.

Jackie (Kid) Berg, 145 3/4; London, gained the decision over Irish Johnny McHale, 148, Borough Hall, in the feature eight-round bout of a boxing card curtailed by rain at the Golden City Arena in Canarsie last night. A crowd of 3,800 saw the fights.

Although the neutral delegates to the Chaco peace conference are still optimistic over the prospects for an early peace between Bolivia and Paraguay, difficulties have arisen in Paraguay that may delay peace, even if they do not prevent it altogether.

The Council of National Wholesale Associations will use a compilation of data on wholesaling by Dr. N. H. Engle, assistant director of the Department of Commerce in preparing its own "Bibliography of Wholesaling," it was announced yesterday, following a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Although he may have signed nothing, the purchaser of merchandise may become bound by an arbitration agreement, the Appellate Division ruled in a four-to-one decision announced yesterday. The arbitration law requires only that the arbitration contract be in writing, not that it be signed by both parties, the court declared.

Turpentine firm, 23 1/4c; sales, 50 barrels; receipts, 724 barrels; shipments, 30 barrels; stock, 39,633 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 58; receipts, 2,763; shipments, 480; stock, 170,459. Quote: B, $3.40; D, $3.75; E, $4; F, $4.45; G, H, I, $4.72 1/2; K, $4.75; M, $4.77 1/2; N. $5.40; WG, $5.95; WW, X, $6.40.
The Sagamore, garden apartments at 64 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, has been purchased by an investment syndicate headed by Maurice Magid of New York, through L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.

Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems gave a luncheon today at The Corners for Mrs. Hyatt R. Dehn, who arrived today to pass several days with her. Among the other guests were Mrs. Bruce F. E. Harvey, Mrs. John B.
A series of four Thursday lectures, which will be society events with tea, are to be given by the Rev. Edmund Randolph Laine, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Stockbridge, starting on July 21.
Moscow and Novosibirsk are the only stopping points at which the trail blazed by Wiley Post on his record-breaking flight five years ago and the path followed by Howard Hughes have met.

In the longest and probably the frankest conversation he has ever held with a foreign correspondent, Mexico's President, Lazaro Cardenas, reviewed the condition of his country. He had just completed a forty-day tour of the oil fields.

Herbert M. Woolf announced tonight that Lawrin, Kentucky Derby winner and prize occupant of his Woolford Stable, was definitely out of the $50,000 Gold Cup at Hollywood Park on Saturday and. would not race again this year.

S. E. Davenport 3d triumphed over H. L. Bair, 6-1, 6-4 in a second-round test in the eighteenth annual tournament of the Lake Mohonk Tennis Club today. John S. McDermott halted Joseph S. Ferrand, 6-4, 6-3 while Percy Kynaston downed Randall O. Rose, 6-0, 7-5.

To the accompaniment of continued rumors of some impending change in the status of the pound sterling, the leading foreign exchanges weakened further yesterday in terms of the dollar. Sterling fell to $4.92 5/8, its lowest price since June 4, 1937, and closed at $4.92 3/4, off 1/8 cent net.

Four factors responsible for the recent upturn in the stock market are listed by Henry H.. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly review of business to be sent today to the association's 20,000 members.
The Film Division of the Theatre Arts Committee will sponsor a preview of the motion picture, "Return to Life," next Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Spanish Government air force swung into action on the eastern t front today with a mass raid on t the Insurgent front line. Several squadrons of government planes roared north from Sagunto, highway junction city, fourteen miles north of Valencia, in the early morning hours and returned to report they had "fulfilled perfectly the mission."
Jesse Stuart, young Kentucky author of "Beyond Dark Hills," "Head o' W-Hollow," "Man With a Bull-Tongue Plow," will arrive today on the Conte di Savoia from his Guggenheim Fellowship year in Europe.
One of the largest Queens realty deals in recent years was announced yesterday when the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company sold one of its multi-family housing properties there.

Scores of the games won in the first- round of the American Chess Federation tournament at Boston by David S. Polland, the titleholder, and I. I. Kashdan of New York, and the game lost by Donald MacMurray of New York to Burton O. Dahlstrom of Chicago, follow:

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it would investigate charges that recent orders of the National Labor Relations Board violate the rights of free speech of employers. The Civil Liberties Union recently asked the NLRB in reconsidering the order against the Ford Motor

The Reich Institute for Labor Placement and Insurance announced today that at the end of June a record number of more than 20,000,000 were employed in Germany, an increase of 1,064,000 compared with the same period last year.

Satisfied that King George is making good progress at the royal lodge at Windsor after an attack of gastric influenza, Queen Elizabeth drove to London this evening and alone received 1,200 guests at a presentation party at Buckingham Palace.

A resolution against ill-considered strikes and calling for the employment of every available arbitrative facility in labor disputes was adopted yesterday at the final day of the convention of the United Licensed Officers in the Downtown Athletic Club.

A representative of the Ministry of Propaganda today told foreign correspondents that the status of former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg had been changed from "honorary detention" to "regular protective custody."

The Committee on Industrial Relations of the Constitutional Convention formally reported today a labor plank to be included in the new Consitution if the convention approves. A summary of the bill, according to a statement issued by William F. Bleakley, committee chairman, said that the bill was reported out unanimously -and that it provides as follows:

The League of Nations Secretariat received today a telegram from Esteban Gil Borges, Foreign Minister of Venezuela, announcing the withdrawal of Venezuela from the League. The telegram gives no motive, but explains that Venezuela will continue to adhere to the ideals for which the League was founded.

" Room Service," the John Murray-Allen Boretz study of show business, will end its run at the Cort Theatre this Saturday night. It opened there on the evening of May 19, 1937, and when it concludes will have given a total of 496 performances.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, presented by Universal Art, Inc., under the artistic direction of Leonide Massine, opened London's second ballet of the season tonight at the Drury Lane Theatre, only a short distance from Covent Garden,

GOVERNORS ISLAND Lt. Col. Siegfried Block, Med.-Res., 502 Washington Ave., Brooklyn, N. Y., 5th Hospital Center, is ordered to active duty July 22, at Fort Jay, N. Y.,-for training. Date of rank: July 8. He will revert to an inactive status Aug. 4.

John D. Biggers, president of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, announced yesterday that in the last three months the company had re-employed 990 workers and that it planned to add 400 to the payroll when the plate-glass plant at Rossford, Ohio, was reopened next Monday.

Two former champions and the defending titleholder, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, will tee off in the field which will compete in the New York State amateur golf championship at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club tomorrow morning, starting at 9:30.

Calling attention to the continued lack of soap and towels in the city's schools, Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president of the .Board of Education, recommended yesterday that hand-washing facilities for the 1,250,000 pupils be installed as soon as possible.

Authorized capitalization of Frosted Foods, Ltd., new British subsidiary of General Foods Corporation, organized to enlarge its frosted foods activities throughout a greater part of the British Empire, will consist of 80,000 ordinary shares of [Pound]1 par value, comprising 15,000 A shares, 15,000 B shares and 50,000 C shares.
Philadelphia stuck out its chest tonight and welcomed Joe Burk, Diamond Sculls winner, as a "home town boy."

After a week of cautious campaigning President Roosevelt had before him today the first formal demand that he seek a third term. The demand was submitted just before he addressed a large gathering from the rear platform of his private car at Pueblo, Col., where he pledged the perpetuation of democratic government in the United States

Out of twentyfour economic indicators for May, 1938, compared to May, 1937, just issued here by the Board of Trade, thirteen showed declines for last May compared to a year previous and eleven showed increases.

Rescuers considered sending a plane today to search the Antipodes or County Islands, 400 miles southeast of New Zealand,. for sixty cadets missing since March aboard the German training ship Admiral Karpfanger.

Mrs. Wladimir W. Bouimistrow of New York and Brussels, Belgium, has announced the engagement of her cousin, Miss Carolyn Winston, to Roger Goiran, son of Henri Goiran, French Minister to Mexico and officer of the Legion of Honor, and Mrs. Goiran.

Regulations governing the administration of the new occupancy tax, issued yesterday by. Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, showed the wide scope of the tax will include not only building space of all sorts rented for business purposes but also coin telephones,

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, which is controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, is discussing with bankers means by which a maturity may be met of $14,800,000 of 6 per cent notes on Oct. 1. Recently the C. O. allowed the Erie Railroad, which it controls also, to enter bankruptcy instead of guaranteeing a loan to it from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
The Hammond Clock Company of Chicago was ordered by the Federal Trade Commission today to cease and desist from certain published representations regarding its product, the Hammond electric organ.

Yesterday's reaction in Wall Street was reflected in the stock market here today. Business was on a small scale and most sections of the market lost ground. Gilt-edge issues suffered a setback, but among the foreign loans Rumanian bonds found support.

With seemingly no more effort than would be required in extinguishing a light, the Yankees def nitely snuffed out the Browns yesterday in both ends of a twin bill before 13,703 fans at the Stadium and vaulted into a position just half a game back of the league-leading Indians.

Led by George H. (Pete) Bostwick, who scored five goals on his own account, the Bostwick Field four today defeated Delhi to mark its debut in the Brook Division of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at Roslyn. The final score was 8 to 3, and it was the second setback for Delhi, led by John Schiff.

A Federal grand jury convened here today to consider a variety of cases, including one or more in which seven oil companies and fifteen persons associated with the industry have been called to testify.
Captain and Mrs. John C. Groome of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Roberts Groome, to Jean Albert Collin, son of Mr. and Mrs.

The White Sox banged Lynn Nelson for six runs in the first inning today and then fought off a closing rally by the Athletics to score an 8-to-6 victory. It was the eighth straight loss for the Mackmen.

The Republican majority in the reapportionment committee of the Constitutional Convention killed today all of the seventeen Democratic apportionment proposals. It then tried to agree on a Republican measure.

The Chinese Ambassador, Dr. C. T. Wang, conferred today with Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. presumably concerning renewal of the silver-buying arrangements under which the United States has taken large quantities of Chinese silver.

State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner D. Frederick Burnett, who has already disposed of such questions as Norwegian grog and magical cocktails, today met the problem of "liquorized ice cream" with a firm "No."

Rayon producers have decided to support a plan designed to prevent price-cutting in the seamless rayon hose section of the industry, according to an announcement of the National Federation of Hosiery Manufacturers Associations.
Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin gave a tea for ninety at Windward, her residence here, today after the meeting and election of officers for the Village Improvement Society. Mrs. William R. Maloney presided.

Fox is negotiating with Paramount for the purchase of "Monsieur Beaucaire" as a -vehicle for Tyrone Power. The Booth Tarkington story of the nobleman who masqueraded as a barber was made in 1924 by Paramount with Rudolph Valentino.
Two women in an automobile bound for the seashore were killed and four others seriously injured. when the car plunged off a highway and struck a brick building here this afternoon.

Six bids ranging from $1,063.38 to $1,071.50 for each $1,000 of par value of the bonds, the highest submitted by the National City Bank of New York and associates, were received today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a group of thirty 4 per-cent bond issues of New York City, including several put out for public school, highway and hospital improvements, with an aggregate face value of $5,079,000.

Strictly choice and prime fed steers and yearlings sold fairly well today on early rounds, mostly to shippers and order buyers, but slowness developed on common, medium and good kinds. Best steers and yearlings sold firm to higher but lower grades weakened, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

The Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that Pierre S. du Pont and John J. Raskob were acting under a "design" to accomplish a "tax escape" when, in 1929 and 1930, they twice sold to each other within six weeks about $6,000,000 in stocks to establish losses on which they claimed income tax deductions.

The swindling of nearly 100 clients of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in the Rockaways by four employes of the company was made known yesterday by the arrest of the employes who were indicted by the Queens grand jury last Thursday.
Two witnesses today at a hearing of the Interstate Commerce Commission urged "rail parity" for Southern shippers as an instrument for national good.

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, large suite in 270 Park Ave, through Douglas L. Elliman Co.; Charles B. Lockwood, for Julius McVickar, in 325 E 72d St; Miss Mabel H. Beekman, through N. A. Berwin Co. in 12 E 97th St; Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers.

Denny Shute, West Newton, Mass., defeated Clyde Usina Jr., Stoneham, Mass., 3 and 2; John Thoren, Brookline, Mass., defeated Leo Mallory, Noroton, Conn., 4 and 2; Frank Walsh, Bretton Woods, N. H., defeated Tony Butler, San Angelo, Texas, 2 and 1;Jimmy Hines, Great Neck, N. Y., defeated Alex Watson, Yonkers, N. Y., 3 and 1.

H., defeated Tony Butler, San Angelo, Texas, 2 and 1;Jimmy Hines, Great Neck, N. Y., defeated Alex Watson, Yonkers, N. Y., 3 and 1.
The bulk of the United States battle fleet steamed in through the Golden Gate today, anchored in "Man o' War Row" in San Francisco Bay and made ready to be reviewed by President Roosevelt.

While Howard Hughes arid his four companions aboard their world-circling plane were flying over Siberia yesterday-half way around the earth from their point of departure at Floyd Bennett Airport, radio messages and wireless weather signals kept their friends
The War Department released the following orders - today, dated July 9:

Yorkshire, Lancashire and Middlesex, strong trio of English cricket clubs, in a close race for the county championship, were victorious in matches completed today, Yorkshire, the leader, triumphed over Derbyshire by 163 runs; the Lancastrians defeated Leicestershire by an innings and five,

Governor Ammons and my friends of Pueblo: It is good to be back here. I wasn't quite sure this morning whether I was going to be back here or not, because I read in a Denver paper that this was the first time in twenty years that a President had come to Pueblo.

Declaring that there was no immediate danger of inflation but that the foundation for inflation had been laid, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance in New York University, told bankers of North Carolina here tonight that what was perhaps more dangerous "is the apparent willingness of the government to try new remedies which are inflationary in character."

Steel ingot production was reduced by the holiday last week and the adjusted index has declined to 37.8, which compares with 40.6 in the preceding week and 113.2 for the week ended July 10, 1937. According to the estimate of THE NEW YORK TIMES, operations were at 25 per cent of capacity

Robert Burns Robertson, from 1912 to 1936 resident architect of Windsor Castle, one of the official residences of the King of England, died here today in the home of his daughter, Mrs. Ivy May Jenks, at the age of 76. He had been suffering for several months from cardiac asthma.

Months of close cooperation between the Soviet Government and Howard Hughes in arranging details of the flight he is making across Russia were revealed today as probably the best-kept secret of the year.

Until one analyzes some of the round figures that attach to their extraordinary machines and the records they set, one cannot realize the hazards that men like Captain George E. T. Eyston and John Cobb brave in order to break existing marks for automobile speed and improve engineering practice and construction methods for the benefit of the everyday motor car.

With an education fund of more than $47,000 in the treasuries of 156 clubs belonging to the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Miss Mary Armstrong of New York City reported to the national board today that loans during the year to high school girls had decreased and that more clubs were encouraging girls to select a vocational objective removed from the most crowded fields.

Memorial services for Captain Enelio Carranza, Mexican good-will flier who crashed to his death ten years ago in the barren Burlington County pines near here, were held today at the shaft marking the site of the accident.

Rudolf Mill, a 34-year-old German, who fought last year for Loyalist Spain as a member of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, faces deportation from the United States to Germany. Irving Schwab, his attorney, applied yesterday for a writ of habeas corpus.
" Posedel, plezzz beat the Giants" was chalked in huge letters on the pavement just in front of the Ebbets Field rotunda yesterday, evidently put there by some long-suffering Flatbush fan.

Senator Elmer Thomas, whose New Deal record drew praise as "my old friend" from President Roosevelt, led his two rivals by a good majority tonight in returns from more than a third of the precincts in Oklahoma's primary election.

For the first time since he took office in 1934, Mayor La Guardia went through a union picket line yesterday morning when he drove through a group of strikers at the Roosevelt Avenue entrance of the New York World's Fair grounds.
William A. Halloran Jr. was elected commander of the Kings County American Legion last night at the close of the group's two-day convention in the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

Peter Astra, bay son of Peter Volo and Sita, owned by Dr. L. M. Guilinger of Andover, Ohio, and driven by Dr. Hugh Parshall of Urban, Ohio, today captured the E. H. Harriman Challenge Stake for 2-year-old trotters, the feature event on the opening Grand Circuit card at Historic Track.

Johnnie Walker, 40 years old, of the Hotel Delmonico, producer and former moving-picture actor, was in New York Hospital yesterday with head injuries received in a fall in front of 625 Madison Avenue.

Ralph L. Kaskell, Queens, civic worker, died in his home, 89-18 201st Street, Hollis, yesterday morning after a brief illness. He was 49 years old. A past president of the Allied Civics of Hollis and Bellaire, he was also past president of the 201st Street Civic Association and a delegate to the Central Queens Al lied Civic Council.

The Forty Niners opened their sixth Summer theatre season in the White Mountains tonight with Mark Reed's comedy "Yes, My Darling Daughter." A capacity audience welcomed the members of the company on their return to the Chase Barn Playhouse.

Contracts governing wages and working hours for actors and singers employed on sustaining radio programs in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles were signed yesterday afternoon at Radio City by officials of the National Broadcasting Company,

I., for American Nazi sympathizers, and the league's six incorporators, all guilty of violating the State Civil Rights Law.

Joseph A. Nicolini, New York attorney, was indicted by the June grand jury of Westchester County on a charge of subornation of perjury for allegedly inducing a client to testify falsely, Assistant District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher disclosed today when a warrant was issued for Niconlini's arrest.

Ellsworth Lawrence, acting Franklin County surrogate, studied today a brief opposing the will of Phelps Smith, who left most of $2,500,000 to found "Paul Smith's College." The brief, filed yesterday by countel for twenty-two cousins of Phelps smith, contended that the college request was to a corporation "not directed to be formed within two natural lives."

The Salesmen's and Buyers' Club of the fur industry has adopted a resolution reaffirming its pledge "to enforce the boycott against any firm or individual having an office or representative in Germany," according to a letter to thee joint boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and Jewish Labor Committee.
Funeral services will be held tomorrow at 3 P. M. in St. John's Church, Pleasantville, N. Y., for Miss Mary Kittredge Choate, former president of Everybody's Thrift Shop, 922 Third Avenue.
Speaking at a banquet tendered to him by his fellow-countrymen from the south of France, Premier Zdouard Daladier this evening reiterated the determination of France to stand behind Czechoslovakia.

Bikes Co and Fancher Furniture Co, units with 12,000 sq ft on 7th floor of 1 Park Ave; Bowns Mann, Inc, and Hoagland Realty Corp. co-brokers. Gray's Eating Place, Inc, restaurant, through Wood, Dolson Co. agents, store and basement in 2,231 Broadway; Tankoos, Smith Co, brokers.

MANHATTAN COE, HAROLD E. (June 17). Estate, more than $10,000. To Kathryn Holmes Coe, widow, executrix, 41 Central Park West, residue of household and personal effects and residue of estate; five others receive varying bequests.

The work of the Evian conference, which, he said, was in keeping with the "aware ness of the humanity of men," which the world had learned from the quarter of a century reign of George V, was warmly praised by American Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy today at the dedication of a memorial window to the late monarch.

In a moment of excessive zeal the Indiana Democratic machine forbade the renomination of Senator Van Nuys. He had opposed Mr. Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan. He heaped guilt on guilt by resisting the Reorganization Bill.
This campaign caravan is still buzzing over the sensational rise of a new personality in politics, who is driving for the Governor's chair in Texas. He is described as "Huey Long, plus horse sense."

Harder Stille of Marietta, Ohio, guest speaker at the meeting of the German-American Bund Tuesday night in Turn Hall, 1,253 Lexington Avenue, denied yesterday that he had used the word "Jew" in his speech.

The Securities and Exchange Commission plans to draw upon the investment banking trade for experts who will join its Trading and Exchange Division and aid its staff in working out policies to be followed in the formation by over-the-counter brokers and dealers of a self-regulatory association, with affiliates, to operate under the supervision of the commission.

After tapping the telephones of four Bronx apartments for more than a month, a squad of detectives in four simultaneous raids late Tuesday night arrested seven persons who District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx said had been conducting "the largest independent policy ring in the city."

THE best golfers of this country hacked away for two days in the qualifying rounds of the P. G. A. championship over the Shawnee course. Ralph Guldahl, Sam Snead, Henry Picard, Ed Dudley, Light Horse Harry Cooper, Paul Runyan, Johnny Revolta, Horton Smith, Gene Sarazen, Jimmy Thomson and Jimmy Hines were among those who teed up and shoved off. And what happened?

It was reported here today from New York that the Transamerica Corporation was planning to sell all except a small amount of its 1,695,883 shares of stock of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and that the purpose was to anticipate the possible enactment of a Federal bank-holding-company act restricting

Absent that Germany made herself felt in the made Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees here today. Her influence went toward whittling down the proposed resolution that Germany allow obligatory emigrants to take their possessions with them if others are to accept them.

The capture of Yuanchu in Southern Shansi by Japanese forces attacking from the east is considered a matter of days only, Japanese. reports declare. It is declared that Chinese defenders who have been entrenched to the east of that important garrison town are retreating northward and southward.

Two bandits, wearing dark glasses and handkerchief masks, seized a $2,700 payroll from the office of the A. H. Wirz Company, metal tube manufacturers, today after holding nine employes, including six women, at gun-point.

The Port of New York Authority applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission to eliminate short-haul traffic, defined as: comprising hauls of fifty miles or less, from its proceeding to fix motor carrier rates from the New England district, which includes Northern New Jersey and the New York metropolitan area.

A postoffice clerk accused of killing a -close friend and seriously wounding the son of a Brooklyn Democratic leader as the result of a "-ribbing" in a bar and grill over the merits of the Brooklyn baseball club was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on charges of homicide, felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law.

Hearings on test claims filed against the old New York Title and Mortgage Company on its guarantees of mortgages and certificates will begin before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler on July 20, the Stockholders Protective Committee headed by Rodney Hitt revealed yesterday.

John R. Crews, Republican leader of Brooklyn, has been on the city payroll since June 29 as a temporary accountant in the Department of Finance at $1,800 a year, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Crews took the job to protect his pension rights, established through nineteen years in public service, and he is expected to resign from it soon, probably the end of this week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article "Behind the Conflict in 'Bloody Harlan'" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine will, in all probability, bring forth a number of protesting letters from other persons who, until its publication, were unaware of a pro bono publico element in their natures.

Despite rumors of impending reductions of wages, The Iron Age says no formal action so far has been taken by any major steel company. The publication believes that no step looking to a cut in the steel industry will be taken before the wage conference in Washington on July 25, to which executives of ten leading steel companies have been invited.

Rex Flag, odds-on favorite in the featured Bronxville Handicap at Empire City yesterday, experienced a little hard luck at the post and was beaten for the main prize at the end of a hard mile and a sixteenth which brought most of the observers to their feet.

With outright grants of $6,829,995 and conditional loans of $2,698,000, a total of $9,527,995, for twenty-one public power projects which were declared competitive, Harold L. Ickes, Public Works Administrator, has started the new utilities program authorized by Congress.

The radio-phone was used to advantage yesterday as Ed Buckley aboard the Shanghai Express called this writer from Jones Inlet to report some good catches of tuna. Buckley previously had been in communication with other boats and heard all about the fifty and sixty-five-pound tuna the Freeport fleet was bringing home.

Fred Simeon Goodman, a member of the International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association from 1901 to 1922, and general' secretary of the American Waldensian Aid Society from 1922 until his retirement five years ago, died here last night at the age of 80 in his home at 121 Midland Avenue, after a long illness.

Reflecting the rise in stock market prices, the Adams Express Company reported yesterday that the net asset value of its common stock on June 30 was $13.35 a share, after deduction of a 10-cent dividend paid on July 1, against $11.61 a share on Dec. 31.
Festive Parisians danced and sang in the streets tonight on the eve of the annual celebration of the French independence day.

Forty irate residents of the Rockaways went on foot and by rowboat to the marshy shore of Jamaica Bay at Edgemere yesterday to protest to Sanitation 'Commissioner William.F. Carey against odors from a garbage dump which, they complained, were changing parts of the Rockaways from a Summer paradise .to a place almost unfit in which to live.

Proposals for broad measures in the State Constitution to enable the State to deal with housing and social welfare were adopted by the respective committees at Albany yesterday for action by the Constitutional Convention. [Page 1.]

Mrs. Emma Brown Elder, active in church and charitable work in Brooklyn and an organizer and president for thirty-five years of the Queen Esther Guild, died on Tuesday night in her home, 26-Clifton Place at the age of 67.

With interest again centered in the railroad issues and the local traction bonds, the bond market continued to move into new high territory yesterday as the volume increased on the New York Stock Exchange. Total sales reached $8,727,900 compared with $8,345,500 on Tuesday.

James Stuart, Kentucky farm boy who became a poet some years ago, returned yesterday on the Italian motorship Conte di Savoia after spending a year in Europe, during which he visited twentyfive countries.
David S. Polland, champion of the American Chess Federation and New York State titleholder, lost to Weaver W. Adams of Boston in the annual open tournament at the Hotel Touraine today.

Henry Washington Howell, who, sixteen years ago; was one of the founders of the Queens Baptist Church in Queens Village, died yesterday in his eighty-second year at a nursing home at 91-09 214th Place,

Mrs. Amy Roberts Ludlam, member of an old New York family and active in church, and social work for many years, died yesterday after a long illness in her home, 1,130 Park Avenue. She was 64 years old.

Resorting to stoning and arson, terrorists were again active today in Haifa. Two Jews were killed and two Jewishowned homes and two stores were set on fire. A Jew, who was stoned in the streets of Haifa yesterday, died today.

A middle-aged man was killed at 8:41 A. M. yesterday, during the height of the rush hour, in a mishap that tied up north-bound express services on the B. M. T. subway in lower Manhattan for an hour and caused. several women witnesses to faint.

The Board of Trade's figures for June are as follows: Total imports, [pound]76,500,000; exports of British products, [pound]36,890,000; re-exports, [pound]4,980,000; total exports, [pound]41,870,000; excess of imports; [pound]34,630,000.
The Public Health Service reported today that helium holds a hope of relief for persons having asthma which is nearly chronic.
The Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, protests strongly in a front-page, two-column article on the new divorce laws effective throughout Great Germany Aug. 1.

The Rev. Hiram F. Reynolds, one of the founders of the Nazarene College in Wollaston Park and former General Superintendent of the Eastern Nazarene Church, died today at his home in Wollaston after an illness of several months. His axe was 84.

Oklahoma Democrats showed their loyalty to the Roosevelt Administration today by nominating Senator Elmer Thomas for a third term and rejecting the Gubernatorial bid of former Governor W. H. (Alfalfa Bill) Murray, New Deal critic.

Receiving first foreign correspondents, then the Japanese press, General G. S. Lushkoff this afternoon said that Moscow's allegation that he wars an- impostor and that the real General Lushkoff was still in Russia was absolutely false..

Mrs. J. J. Meenan and Mrs. W. F. K. Thayer Jr. of the Nassau Country Club continued their success in the alternate stroke competition of the Long Island Women's Golf Association at the North Shore Country Club today by upsetting the medalists and tournament favorites, Mrs. E. G. Richmond and Mrs. Charles Leichner, former New York State champion, in a nineteen-hole semi-final encounter.

Steps calling for a study of the "balanced wardrobe" plan which has worked successfully in other apparel lines, the naming of a special committee to deal with the problems of small stores, and a display at the next convention of "the boys' store of tomorrow" in conjunction with the 1939 World's Fair were approved yesterday at the convention of the Boys' Apparel Buyers' Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Some insight into how-Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh spends his time on the Island of St. Gildas on the Brittany coast, and what his intentions are, was obtained by a French reporter, P. A. Martineau, who visited Dr. Alexis Carrel at his home there.
Japan has dispatched another shipment of $5,800,000 gold to this country, according to word received yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

In a decision prohibiting secondary picketing, made public today, Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry held that free speech was a "qualified constitutional right," inferior to such "inherent rights" as "acquiring and possessing and protecting property."

Mrs. Paulina Costilla, who. lives at 134 West Twentieth Street, paid her last gas bill several days ago; so she was surprised and annoyed last Tuesday when a man who said he was a collector rapped on her door and told her to pay again.

Nathaniel Thayer Kidder, former president of trustees of the Massachusetts General Hospital and a director of many State charitable organizations, died today at the Phillips House of the Massachusetts General Hospital after a three-month illness. He was 77 years old.
John E. McCully, a retired banker and an expert on real estate law, died in his home in Overbrook Hills today after a short illness. He was 68 years old.
Carl R. Jeske, vice president of the Marshall Ilsley Bank since 1930 and manager of its South Side branch since 1923, died at Columbia Hospital today at the age of 46 years.

" The most important legislation in recent times, designed to protect both the bankers and the public, is the law insuring deposits of each depositor in insured banks up to $5,000, as well as trust deposits up to the same amount," Marshall A.

Immediate transfer to Palestine of "tens of thousands of Jewish children now trapped in Germany, Austria and Poland" was urged by Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, in a message sent yesterday to the London executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine for transmission to the Intergovernmental Refugees Committee, meeting in Evian, France.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates July 13 unless specified: At Dahigren: Acushnet. Kewaydin. Sitka to Seattle: Aylwin. Dale, Farragut, Monoghan, Salt Lake City.

The volume of bankers' acceptances and of commercial paper outstanding declined in June, according to reports issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The monthly acceptance survey showed a total of $264,222,590 outstanding on June 30, which was a reduction of $3,875,983 in the month and a drop of $99,981,253 in the last twelve months.

7:20 P. M.-Take-off, Floyd Bennett Municipal Airport. Monday, July 11 11:55 A. M.-Lands Le Bourget Field, Paris. Elapsed time for 3,641 miles, 16 hours 35 minutes, making the average speed 219.6 miles an hour.
The Red Sox split a double-header with Detroit today, winning the first game, 7-4, and dropping the second contest, 9-5, while opening a long home stand against the Western clubs.

Cuban imports for the first quarter of 1938 increased to $33,466,000 from $30,790,000 in the previous year, the Commerce Department reported today. Imports from the United States showed a jump from $20,918,000 to $23,461,000. With the exception of Nova Scotia, imports from other American countries decreased, however..

All the ocean beaches, those along Long Island Sound and, in fact, anywhere in New York City where sewage is not emptied directly into the bathing water, are safe for bathing, according to officials of the city Department of Health.
The Conklin Pen Company today sold all assets and business, including its foreign agencies, to a Chicago syndicate consisting of A. J. Parrson, M. H. Jacobs and Max Horwitz.

Charles Reno, Harlan County miner, died today of wounds. He was shot July 5. Sheriff C. C. Ball announced that Lee Fleenor, a former deputy sheriff and a defendant in the Harlan labor conspiracy trial, would be arraigned before County Judge Cam Ball tomorrow.

Frederick J. Singley, counsel for the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, urged the Securities and Exchange Commission today to grant to that concern exemption as a holding company under the Public Utility Act of 1935, contending that it was not engaged in interstate commerce.

American manufacturers and buyers are expected to take a big part in Czechoslovakia's thirty-seventh international fair to be held Sept. 2 to 11 -at Prague, the AmericanCzechoslovakian- Chamber of Commerce announced yesterday.

The Senators scored three runs in the ninth inning today to defeat Cleveland and Bobby Feller, 4 to 3, dropping the Indians into second place, half a game behind the Yankees. It was Washington's sixth consecutive victory.

For the first time in his thirtyfive years Peter the Great, the 4,500-pound hippopotamus at the Bronx Zoo, really enjoyed his birthday. For yesterday, for the first time since he was born in the Central Park Zoo, Peter did not have to put up with innumerable photographers and a birthday cake he never ate anyway.

Financial difficulties of a fiftyyear-old Methodist Episcopal church appeared solved today by the church's entry into the oil business. Two wells, each producing twenty barrels weekly, blossomed on the church lawn.

Yesterday's rally in Wall Street was reflected in a generally cheerful stock market here today, and a firm upward trend prevailed in most sections. Gilt-edge issues made strong advances, while in the foreign bond list, which did well, Rumanian loans continued to attract attention.

Retail prices in June declined slightly more than 0.3 per cent from the preceding month, the smallest decline since Oct; 1, according to the Fairchild retail price index. Prices on July 1 were 7.08 per cent below a year ago, 7.6 per cent below the 1937 high, which was reached on Sept. 1, and only 1.5 per cent above the. 1936 low, which wash reached on July 1.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted fo the law firm of Choate, Hall Stewart $40,000 as compensation for services as counsel to the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad from Oct. 1, 1935, through Dec. 31, 1937. The firm had asked $75,000.

Declaring that the maintenance of a proper Supreme Court was of paramount concern to the country, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg urged in a speech here tonight that an extra session of the Senate be called before the Supreme Court convened in October to confirm or reject President Roosevelt's nominee to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo.

Greater executive responsibility for staff members of the New York Curb Exchange is seen in the report of the advisory committee to the committee on organization and administration made public yesterday. The report would reduce the number of standing committees to nine, create the new office of executive vice president and make changes in organizational procedure.
Sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $85,000, a gain of $5,000 since July 8, was reported yesterday.

The British Government turned to Canadian factories today in a grim effort to speed up the production of heavy bombing planes for the Royal Air Force. An official mission will leave England for Canada "immediately" to negotiate for the manufacture of big war planes, Sir Kingsley Wood, the Air Secretary, informed the House of Commons.
The Rev. Dr. Homer H. wallace, retired pastor of the West Forty-fourth Street United Presbyterian Church in New York, died today at a private nursing home here. He was 84 years old.

Buying picked up sharply at the New York Housewares Show here yesterday as representatives of syndicate stores began filling early Fall requirements of appliances, china and glassware, bathroom accessories, kitchen utensils and similar goods.

Blair Gordon, managing director of the Dominion Textile Company, was attacked today in the company's office at Montmorency Falls, by strikers who quit work last night. The strikers were said to be members or former members of the Catholic Syndicates organized under ecclesiastical auspices as a rival of the international unions here.

President Roosevelt's estimate of a $4,000,000,000 deficit for the present fiscal year raised the question today whether the Administration would ask Congress to enact additional or higher taxes. Treasury tax experts, who were unwilling to venture an answer, said Mr. Roosevelt and department, executives probably would decide this next Fall.

Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson gave a dinner tonight at Wyndcote for Mr. and Mrs. Harry Payne Bingham. Mrs. John D. Beals Jr. gave a dinner last night at Draemer, her home in Hampton Bays, for Mrs. B. Tappen Fairchild of Cold Spring Harbor.
The United States moved promptly today through the American Red Cross to furnish vaccine for -meeting the cholera epidemic in Central, Western and Southwestern China.

Jouett Shouse, president of theAmerican Liberty League, said before sailing on the Manhattan yesterday that the threatened purge from the Democratic ranks of those who failed to support the New Deal had collapsed and that President Roosevelt's tour through the, West was, in his opinion, actually aiding those whom he opposes.
James Marshall Little of New York City was designated today from the Twenty-second New York Congressional District to take the West

Officers of the American Fur Liners Contractors Association, 370 Seventh Avenue, lodged a complaint at District Attorney Thomas A. Dewey's office yesterday against members of the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union. Officers of the association charged the union had engaged in "systematic terrorism" to drive the contractors out of business. It also charged the union,
Sir George Talbot, a judge of the High Court of Justice for fourteen years until his retirement last year, died today at the age of 77.

Alfred Eickhoff, 73 years old, of 344 Rochelle Avenue, Rochelle Park, "W died in the Hackensack Hospital today of a fractured skull as the result of having been struck by an automobile as he was crossing the street near his home last night. Miss Joyce Nuy of 80 Avenue C, Lodi,

The Federal Trade Commission's order yesterday commanding the Hammond Instrument Company to cease certain published representations regarding the Hammond electric organ was a victory for the company, according to a statement today by Laurens Hammond, president, in that it had "vindicated the company in its designation of this instrument as an 'organ'."
Little boys who may read that Howard Hughes went around the earth in something less than 15,000 miles may want to know how

The bill providing for the taking of a new electoral census received final approval by the House of Representatives early this morning. The Senate has already passed this legislation, which is a preliminary step toward holding constituent Assembly elections some time at the beginning of next year.

New Jersey will soon be in the market for a $25,000 boat. The State Board of Health at its meeting here yesterday approved plans for a $25,000 shellfish floating laboratory to replace the present craft, which has been in service twenty-five years.

The Summer colony turned out this afternoon for the lawn fete of Em- N manuel Episcopal Church at Harbourcourt, home of Mrs. Nicholas Brown. The colony members were there both as patrons and as workers, while the members of the debutante group sold ballons, cigarettes or other articles.

The marriage of Miss Blanche Emma Goodell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Goodell of Sturgis, Mich., to the Rev. Percival C. Bailey of Springdale, Stamford, vicar of Emmanuel Chapel and curate of St. John's Episcopal Church, Stamford, will take place Tuesday morning, Aug. 16, in St. Steven's Church at Wyandotte, Mich. A reception will follow at Mr. and Mrs. Goodell's home at Ecorse. Mich.

NEARLY every American knows about a cer tain book that was published in Paris in 1835 and issued in this country three years later-exactly a century ago. Some Americans have even read it. It was the first important study of American society made by a European, probably the first such made by anybody. De la Democratie en Amerique is the original title.

The first major skirmish in the six-week-old legal struggle between Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow and his American-born wife, the former Barbara Hutton, came to a sudden and dramatic close today when counsel for the heiress withdrew charges that the Count had used threats that made her fear for her life.

With the July delivery off the board at noon tomorrow and obligations about covered, the spot month weakened yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange lost 16 to 23 points. After holding within a narrow range for several hours in sympathy with another advance in the stock market,

An incoming passenger yesterday on the Italian motorship Conte di Savoia was Chester Aldrich, director of the American Academy in Rome, an institution that has about twenty students each year, all selected in this country after competitive scholastic examinations.

Lido F. Blanco, aged 38, of Hillsdale, N. J.; his wife, Eleanor, 35, and their two sons were seriously injured today when their automobile crashed into a tree near here. At Mineville Hospital Blanco was reported suffering from a fractured jaw and severe lacerations.

Dr. John Levy, New York psychiatrist and medical 'educator, died on Monday in Beth Israel Hospital, Boston, after a long illness. He had an office at 71 East Seventy-seventh Street and lived at 468 Riverside Drive. He was Associate Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University andchief of the Child Guidance Clinic of the Vanderbilt Clinic of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 41.
Captain Louis A. Babcock, president of-the Stamford-Oyster Bay Ferries Corporation, died today in Stamford Hospital, where he had been ill for a month. He was 47 years old.
Residential projects in this country are being conceived and executed on a more ambitious scale than ever before.

The board of directors of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs adopted a 1938-39 budget of $140,000 today after listening to reports of the national treasurer, Miss Isabelle Claridge of New York, and the national finance chairman, Mrs. Genevieve MacLiver.
Thanks to the moderate humidity, the heat yesterday was less oppressive, despite the fact that the average temperature was about the same as it has been in the last few days.

W. S. S. Rodgers, president of the Texas Company, and Andrew Wells Robertson, chairman of the Westinghouse Electric. and Manufacturing Company, have been added to the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers, it was announced yesterday.

The National Labor Relations Board today decided against American Federation of Labor craft units in ordering on an industrial basis an election among all production employes of the Pure Oil Company at Muskogee, Okla.
The Constutional Convention faced today, for the first time.-one of its large issues, the ways and means of controlling the growth of administrative law.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that eighty issues of securities of municipalities, counties and districts, including a group of thirty issues of New York City, bids on which were opened yesterday, were awarded to the highest bidders. The highest bids,

We had railroads in this country a long time before such granite palaces as the Grand Central and Pennsylvania Stations arose. Yet these were the final symbol, for the people, that travel over the steel highways had come to complete maturity and acceptance into the commonplace conveniences of life.

Housing loans of $50,000,000 to twelve municipalities were announced today by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority. The loan contracts were forwarded to President Roosevelt for approval. Other contracts have been written for loans totaling $111,070,000.
L.Burdsall Crawford, paint and varnish manufacturer if this city, died today at his home in Haddonfield, N. J.,at the age of 69.

An outline of his plan for Federal appointment of official accredited proxies for stockholders unable to attend corporation meetings has been sent to the Monopoly Investigating Committee by Mortimer Fishel, trade association counsel.

A continuance of the demand for business quarters in the city was indicated yesterday when brokers reported numerous contracts for office, store and showroom space in buildings in scattered sections of Manhattan.

Wilder Breckenridge of the advertising staff of True Story Magazine has been appointed sales manager of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, it was announced yesterday by William A. Thomson, director of the bureau. Mr. Breckenridge will join the bureau staff late this month.

The city of Providence, R. I., took almost complete command of the Griswold Cup situation today as three of its women golf stars-Miss Jean Bauer, Miss Helen Waterhouse and Mrs. Fred G. Davis-moved into the semi-finals of the twentieth annual Shenecossett women's invitation tournament.

Sprayed by thirteen hits and two cloudbursts that cracked down on them before and during the struggle the Giants literally went overboard today as they began their grand offensive on the American Rhine, plunging headlong to defeat before General Bill McKechnie's Reds in the opening battle of a three-game series.

The Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for reconsideration of the proceeding in which the commission recently permitted the Railway Express Agency, Inc., to absorb the Southeastern Express Company.

Adolf Hitler and Soviet Russia's new Ambassador to Germany omitted the usual conventional phrases about, friendship between their nations today in an exchange of speeches on the Ambassador's presentation of credentials.

A drastic reduction of the debt burden of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad is to be proposed in a petition to be filed on next Wednesday with the Interstate Commerce Commission, Dwight S. Beebe, vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, said yesterday.

The Public Utilities Committee of the Constitutional. Convention killed by a 9-to-2 vote today the Poletti proposal to protect.the ,St. Lawrence and Niagara power resources against private exploitation and permit their development by public agencies.

ish Frontier), July 13 (AP).-Reports that Spanish Insurgents planned a drive along the French border to match the coastal campaign against Valencia brought quick action today from the French general staff.

With the occupancy tax of $1 to $6 on premises rented for "a gainful purpose" due tomorrow, thousands of telephone inquiries were received yesterday at the office of Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, from persons who had not yet - seen return blanks and instruction sheets, which are being distributed by the police.
Tenfoot waves sweeping suddenly in from Lake Michigan today drowned at least six persons and endangered the lives of scores of bathers and fishermen along the shore.
The Social Security Board paid $271,494,500 in the fiscal year ended June 30 to help States finance old age assistance, aid to dependent children, aid to the blind and related services.

Vyse Ave (11-2998), e-s, 153 ft s of 176th St, 118x103; Israel Klonsky to Marlboro Investing Corp, 1,440 Bway. Brook Ave (11-2893), w s, 175 ft s of Anna Pl, 50x90; William Korn to Eva Dollinger, 639 Miller Ave, Brooklyn. Albany Crescent, 3,056 (12-3266); Newman Realty Corp to Herole Realty Corp, 1,182 Bway, mtge, $29,850.

Louis Commeig has leased, with an option to purchase, the twostory building at 146-18 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, from Lena Greenblatt, through Roman-Caswell Company and Mezick-Garbade, Inc., cobrokers. The lessee will open a cafeteria after extensive alterations are completed. The structure occupies a plot 20 by 100 feet.

The Public Utility Commission granted today the application of Class I railroads operating within New Jersey to increase the rate of fare from 2 to 2 1/2 cents a mile for travel in passenger coaches. The new intrastate rate, to become effective on July 25, is the same as that allowed by the Interstate Commerce
State Senator Joe R. Hanley of Perry, N. Y., was elected Commander of the State United Spanish War Veterans today. Saratoga Springs was chosen for the 1939 encampment.

Modern design in furniture still leads in the number of suites displayed at the various midsummer markets, but has shown a decrease as compared with six- months ago,- while eighteenth-century English, in second place, has forged ahead, according to a count made by the American Walnut Manufacturers Association.
Two lynchings during the week with victims burned to death brought a protest today from Senator Wagner, Cosponsor of the Wagner-Van Nuys Anti-Lynching Bill.

Tradition was broken yesterday when a mere man, and a father at that, boarded the municipal steamboat Colonel Clayton at the Battery and enjoyed the cool breezes sweeping over the Hudson -River. while 300 mothers and children danced, sang, laughed and spent five hours away from noisy tenements and hot kitchens.
Charles E. Tilton, formerly assistant manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, has been named to a similar post with the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

It is now announced that we are to have a streamlined subway car. Perhaps the refinement of urban life could be carried no further unless some method is invented to streamline the passengers, many of whom prove extremely knobby during the crowded hours.

Rumors of the conclusion of a new Italo-Hungarian pact of friendship in connection with Premier Bela Imredy's forthcoming visit to Rome were denied today by the government organ Esti Ujsag, which said that no sensational results were to be expected from the visit, although the Premier will discuss all important political problems.

ABBAHAMS--acques E., beloved husband of Fannye (nee Tenenbaum), devoted father of Harry and brother of Nathan, Julius, Abraham, Sol, Barney and Ray Barnett. Services Thursday, 11:30 A. M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Salem Fields Cemetery. Omit flowers.

The final value for rate-making purposes of the property of the Spartan Refining Co., Inc., a Louisiana corporation, was found by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to have been $750,000, as of Dec. 31, 1934. Property used,

The Municipal Art Commission, smallest of all city departments, with only two regular employes and a budget averaging less than $7,000, has passed upon improvements that cost more than $400,000,000 since 1933.
It wasn't Johnny Mize's fault the Cardinals dropped their seventh straight game today as the Bees won their series opener, 10 to 5.

The Spanish Government, "convinced" that foreign intervention in Spain's civil war is a constant threat of a "European conflagration," has accepted in principle the British plan for withdrawal of foreign volunteer fighters.
Rioting. in this little sawmill town today resulted in one man being wounded by a rifle bullet, more than thirty others being beaten, and the eviction of between 500 and 1,000 C. I. O. mill workers.

Two seeded players, Julius Heldman, former Pacific Coast intercollegiate champion who is ranked third, and Howard Stephens of Yale, seeded eighth, advanced to the quarter-final round in the only singles matches played yesterday in the New York State clay court tennis championships at the Seminole Club. Forest Hills.

The sale of "certificates" representing shares in the winning purses of the midget automobile races at the Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L. I., was suspended tonight pending the .outcome of an inquiry today by the Nassau County grand jury. County Judge Cortland A.
It was revealed today that Albert Foerster, virtual dictator of this Free City, is in London on an important mission. The Nazi leader left a few days ago, but his departure was kept secret.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Pierre Hull of Yonkers, N. Y., who have a Summer home here, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Hull, to George Camp Keiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Keiser of Cannondale.

The monopoly investigation which is to be undertaken by Federal departmental experts, in conjunction with a Congressional committee, will include one inquiry which may show whether there is any economic justification for encouraging and fostering the small business enterprise. usiness enterprise.

The National Labor Relations Board will give to Clyde A. Armstrong, Weirton Steel Company general counsel, a public hearing Wednesday on a board examiner's charges that his behavior was "defiant, contemptuous and contumacious" in presenting the company's defense against charges of unfair labor practices.

Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANTS From Precincts indicated to Juvenile Aid Bureau, for 16 days, from 8 A. M., July 16: Herbert Golden... 141 Robert S. Purcell. 72 From commands indicated to Police Academy, for 16 days, from 8 A. M., July 16:

Mrs. Louise Smith. 40 years old, of 700 Broadway, New York City, was critically injured and four others were hurt about 9 o'clock tonight when an automobile, driven by William Waldech, 53. of 324 Scranton Avenue, Lynbrook, L. I.,

To Motor and Pump Operators' School The following members shall report at the Motor and Pump Operators' School, 32-02 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, at 10:30 A. M., on the dates specified above their names:

MANHATTAN EGRI, BELA (July 11). Estate, about $2,800. To Frank Egri, adopted son, 56 E. 108th St., $2,600. Albert B. Mark, 116 E. 79th St., executor. ESBERG, ELSIE (May 19). Estate, not over $15,000. To Berthold Esberg, 'son, 401 West End Ave., and Hugo S. Esberg, husband, 244 W. 72d St., executors, residue equally.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Michigan Gas and Oil Corporation has been called for July 25 to vote on a proposal of directors to increase the number of authorized shares of preferred stock to 100,000 from 10,000, to change the par value to $10 from $100 and fix interest on the. new $10 preferred at 50 cents a share, cumulative.

For the second straight day corn was the nominal leader in the grain markets, prices moving up about 1 cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here, with December in new high ground for the season, while the best grades in the sample market sold at 62 3/4 cents a bushel, a new high since early in January.
PROFESSOR BEWARE, from a screen play by Delmer Daves adapted from a story by Crampton Harris, Francis M. and Marian B. Cockrell, Jack Cunningham and Clyde Bruckman; directed by Elliot Nugent;

The issue of $100,000,000 of short-term notes allocated by Controller Morris S. Tremaine was over-subscribed, it was revealed today, when Mr. Tremaine made public a list of the various allotments. The Controller said he regretted that, as has been the case on previous occasions, he was unable to satisfy the demands of scores of other financial houses desiring to subscribe. The issue went to ninety-five banks and bond houses.

The first interchange of scientific exhibits between the United States and France, later to be extended to other countries, will be started next week with the shipment by the New York Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center, of a group of exhibits to the Palace of Discovery in Paris, it was announced yesterday by Robert P. Shaw, director of the museum.
Amendments to the -rules of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange so as to begin on Sept. 1 semi-weekly settlements of transactions in shares were adopted yesterday.
John Henry Seadlund, 27 years old, a lumberjack who turned kidnapper, died in the electric chair today for the $50,000 abduction of Charles S. Ross, 72, a retired Chicago manufacturer.

In the first important meeting of the Queens Democratic Executive Committee since the election of James H. Roe as leader two months ago, the committee designated eight candidates last night to run for renomination in the primaries this Fall.

The Two-way market on fat cattle continued today. Choice and prime kinds held up, but other grades sold measurably lower, reports the United States Department of Agriculture. Top held at $12.75, but a good many shortfed steers were 50 to 75 cents under Monday's high time. Hogs sold higher and lambs were strong. Hogs topped at $10.20 and Idaho lambs $9.35.
Faith Lutheran Church banned today the conventional kiss at the altar after wedding ceremonies.
Parking of lunch carts on a "turnout" or "cutout" on a public highway constitutes a public nuisance and may be prosecuted as a misdemaenor, according to Attorney General Bennett.

An official ban on gambling was ordered in Fairfield County today. Directions were sent to town and city court prosecutors by State's Attorney Lorin W. Willis to halt all forms of gaming, including those conducted under charitable, fraternal or church auspices.

Pittsfield, Mass., will be in the market tomorrow with $150,000 of relief bonds. The issue will be dated July 1, 1938, and will mature serially July 1, 1939 to 1948. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.
Elizabeth Kilgore Steen, explorer, anthropologist and the first -white woman ever to enter the remote Matto Grosso, in interior Brazil, died at her home here yesterday. She was 52 years old.

Herbert J. Hargreaves of this place, a mechanical engineer, died last night at the age of 61 in Muhlenburg Hospital, Plainfield. A native of Liverpool, England, he was employed, after graduation from Oxford University in 1900, by the Alliance Textile Trading

The home of the late Mrs. Aretta Camp Werrenrath, mother of Reinald Werrenrath, the baritone, at 2,222 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, was bought in by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, holder of a judgment of $13,003 against the property, on a nominal bid of $500 at auction yesterday.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., United States Secretary of the Treasury, has advanced the date of his Paris visit, it was announced here today after a conference between Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet and Ambassador William C. Bullitt.

The motorship Oslofjord of the Norwegian America Line is due today from Northern Europe. Passengers are Carl Joachim Hambro, president of the Norwegian Storting, or Parliament; Mrs. Bille Hartwig, Christian Juell Arne Williamson, Captain Jacob Hiorth, Mr. and Mrs. Sigfried Lonegren, Dr. and Mrs. Schael Heldal, Albert Lindholm and A. K. Stolen.

A farcical and tomorrow ni comedy, "Little Stranger," which describes the havoc wrought to an English family's happiness by an American girl, received a favorable reception at the Royalty Theatre tonight. The American authors, Kathmarine Hilliker and H. H. Caldwell, and the English adapter, N. C. Hunter, are held to have been a little more heavy-handed than necessary with the central characters but have provided plenty of good laughs.

The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania lost today a legal skirmish with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission at the opening of a broad investigation into the rates and corporate structure of the $320,000,000 concern.

Patrick J. O'Connell, a Bayonne attorney and formerly a City Commissioner there, was sent to the county jail in default of $3,500 bail today after he had been arraigned before Common Pleas Judge Thomas J. Brown on an indictment charging embezzlement .of $2,500 from a client, Peter Sudimack, also of Bayonne.
Capitalistic enterprise was criticized and defended today before the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs.

Stocks reacted in final hour and closed irregularly lower after advancing to highest levels of current movement; turnover, 2,618,950 shares. Railway and traction bonds higher, United States Government issues lower, other groups mixed; transactions $8,727,900.

An appeal to the city to grant tax exemption for twenty years on the buildings of limited-dividend housing projects so the State Housing Board can start reclaiming several "blighted areas" in New York by the erection of low-cost apartments for the lower middle class was made by Louis H. Pink, chairman of the housing board, over radio station WEVD last night.

The city's many amateur photographers are being encouraged to turn their talents to the recording of "Youth and Age in Our City Parks and Playgrounds," the Department of Parks announced yesterday. The department,

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 12: BRIGADIER GENERAL Shinkle, E. M. Col., assistant to the Chief of Ordnance, relieved from duty in office of Chief of Ordnance, Washington, Sept. 2, and assigned to Picatinny Arsenal, Dover. N. J.

Burleigh Jacobs, 18 years old, smashed the Chain o' Lakes course record today with 34, 33-67, four under par, to win the medal in the thirty-eighth annual Western amateur golf championship. With yesterday's 72, this gave him a thirtysix-hole total of 139.

A consolidation of Eastern and Western Pennsylvania operating companies of the Associated Gas and Electric utility chain under one State management appeared a possibility today as the Public Utility Commission started hearings on two petitions for mergers.
The Montreal Royals clouted three Jersey City pitchers for thirteen hits, six of them good for extra bases, to hand the Little Giants their seventh straight defeat tonight, 10-1.
Don Budge beat Ferenc Puncec, 6-2, 6-2, today for America's lone victory in a tennis exhibition against Yugoslavian tennis stars.

Domestic retail deliveries of Buick motor ears during June totaled 13,446 units, closely paralleling those of the preceding month, when 13,841 were delivered, according to figures released yesterday by W. F. Hufstader, general sales manager.

Announcement has been made here by Charles H. Gibney of Cleveland of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Maxine Gibney, to Cyrus H. Nathan of this city, son of Edward I. Nathan of Monterrey, Mexico, retired United States Consul General there, and Mrs. Nathan.

Howard Hughes and his crew of round-the-world fliers were expected last night to return to Floyd Bennett Field, whence they started last Sunday night, before dusk today, Flight headquarters at the World's Fair grounds estimated their probable time of arrival at 5 P. M., but said it was possible they might reach their starting point and destination as much as an hour earlier under favorable conditions.

A prediction that the war between Japan and. China will be over by the end of this year was made yesterday by Yusuke Tsurumi, member of the Japanese Diet, a leader of Minseito, major political party, author and lecturer.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement filed on Feb. 8, 1937, by the Austin Silver Mining Company covering 225,000 shares of common stock.

The United States Weather Bureau issued yesterday its weekly report of crop conditions as follows: Temperatures ranged mostly from considerably above normal in the northern Cotton Belt to about the seasonal average in southern districts. Rainfall was mostly light, with fair weather the general rule, especially in the western belt, although a few localities had fairly heavy rainfalls.

Despite the conviction of six incorporators of the organization that operates a camp at Yaphank, L. I., for American Nazi sympathizers, leaders of the German- American Bund are planning "something special" at the camp in about two weeks for a gathering of "twenty to thirty thousand people," they said yesterday.

Pandro S. Berman of RKO announced today that he will make an annual film as a follow-up to the George S. Kaufman-Edna Ferber "Stage Door." The one for the 1938-39 season to which writers will be assigned next week will be "Stage Door Club." Two stars of established worth will be featured. The cast will be completed with young hopefuls.
Investors with plans for modernizing their properties figured yesterday in the purchase of several parcels in Manhattan. Some of the deals were resales.

John Dos Passos sailed last week for a month's cruise of the Mediterranean. While on board ship he will work on his new novel, "Adventures of a Young Man." Harcourt, Brace hope to have the completed manuscript before the end of the Summer.

The Hon. Nadine Stonor and Miss Eileen S. S. Gillespie will be among the bridesmaids at the marriage today at Brompton Oratory, London, of Miss Mary Jeanne Stourton to the Hon. Ralph Robert Watts Sherman Stonor, only son and heir of Baron and Baroness Camoys of Stonor Park, Oxfordshire, England, and brother of the Hon. Nadine.

Senator Logan, Democrat of Kentucky, predicted today that a thirdterm petition handed to President Roosevelt at Pueblo, Col., yesterday was the forerunner of many similar requests, and that Mr. Roosevelt would resist them all.

Mrs. Eleanor Barton, pacifist British housewife who for twelve years was general secretary of the Women's Cooperative Guild of Great Britain, advanced the idea here yesterday that the cooperative movement is the perfect solution of-the international difficulties that have baffled the League of Nations.

Professor and Mrs. Philip Marshall Brown of Washington, D. C., gave a barn dance tonight at Brownfields here for the benefit of the Second Congregational Church, of which Professor Brown is the organist. More than 250 attended.

The Ross Carrier Company, Inc., has purchased from Lehman Co. the building at 256 Observer Highway, in which its Eastern offices have been located for some time, and the adjoining vacant plot known as 56 Park Avenue, Hoboken, N. J. The Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization was the broker in the deal.
Arriving in San Francisco today to aid Senator McAdoo's candidacy for renomination, President Roosevelt will find California one of the most pro-Roosevelt States outside the Solid South.

Morris Margulies, secretary of the Zionist Organization of America, who will sail for Palestine on Saturday. on the Conte di Savoia to study the. situation there, was guest of honor at a luncheon given yesterday at the Hotel Astor by members of the Zionist Club of New York. He said, in his address,

A tale of how two impish fruit peddlers scored a moral victory in an episode of the eternal conflict between policemen and some peddlers was unfolded yesterday before Magistrate Michael A. Ford in Jefferson Market Court.

Suit was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court to compel J. P. Morgan Co. to make good an unpaid check for $7,619 issued- by Richard Whitney Co. to Keiper Zimm, brokers, on March 7, the day before the Whitney firm was suspended by the New York Stock Exchange for insolvency.
Henry H. Steiner, secretary of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, announced yesterday that the company has a total of insurance in force of $993,147,412, a high record.

Hoe Ave. 953, 5-story tenement, 42x150. Union Sq Savings Bank against 953 Hoe Ave Realty Corp, due, $36,548; to plain. tiff for $1,000. Lacombe Ave, 1,934, dwelling, 25x125; Home Owners Loan Corp against Owen P. Hollis, due, $7,656; to plaintiff for $500.

The procurement division of the United States Treasury began last night to send out telegraphic acceptances of the offers of surplus clothing it received from manufacturers in all parts of the country.
The Friends of the Abraham Lincoin Brigade made public yesterday the names of seven Americans recently killed in action in Spain. They are Robert Leroy Arndt of Milwaukee, Wis.; John Maparalian,

Miss Annette Remer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Remer Jr. of 144 East Thirty-sixth Street, was married to Daniel D. Merrill, son of Mrs. Daniel D. Merrill of this city and Stamford, Conn., yesterday morning in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lynde Eliot May Jr.
