Representatives of a number of smaller groups and Opposition parties were received today by Premier Milan Hodza, who informed them of the present stage of the negotiations on the nationalities statute, the Language Law and the Administration Reform Law.

The corporation headed by James J. Braddock, former heavyweight champion of the world, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court, listing liabilities of $54,917, exclusive of capital stock and assets of $92,653.
John Knox has joined the Charles B. Knox Gelatine Company, Inc., of Johnstown, N. Y., as assistant to his father, Jim Knox, vice president and general manager.

The law under which six members of the Germai-American Settlement League were convicted at Riverhead was designed to stamp out precisely such activities as theirs. Originally aimed at the Ku Klux Klan, it has seldom been invoked because there has been little occasion to invoke it. When,

Blackstone, 2-year-old colt son of Volomite, owned by B. C. Mayo of Tarboro, N. C., and driven by Dr. Hugh Parshall, annexed the Village Farm Stake, feature event of the second card at Historic Track's Grand Circuit meeting today. Three heats were necessary to decide the $4,400 event.

A mahogany slab bearing a link of the anchor chain of the Maineto judge from inscriptions .on ithas turned up in the window of the Ace Furniture Sales Company, at 535 Communipaw Avenue, Jersey City. Apparently it was once presented to Mayor James J. Walker

Three years of experience With the student aid program of the National Youth Administration have convinced most college heads that the program involves no element of Federal control of education, William E. Annin Jr., New York City Director of student aid for the NYA, declared yesterday.
Luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Germany Today," Gerhart H. Seger. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 3:30 P. M. "Knights in Armor," Harry D. M. Grier.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on July 2 were 291,666,000 barrels, according to figures compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the previous week, this total represented a decrease of 1,797,000 barrels, comprising a decrease of 1,992,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude but an increase of 195,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude.

The Park Department announced yesterday that bids were opened on Monday for the repaving of the Grand Central Parkway Extension and for the installation of a chain link fence along the westerly boundary of Flushing Meadow Park.

Howard Hughes and his four-man crew sped through darkness toward the United States tonight on next to the last leg of an astounding round-the-world flight that they hoped would take them 14,710 miles In four days.

An issue of $30,000,000 Southwestern Bell Telephone Company first and refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, Series C, of which $28,900,000 is publicly offered, will be placed today on the market. Priced at 100 and accrued interest the bonds will be offered by a banking syndicate of forty-three houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc. The issue is dated July 1, 1938, and will be due July 1, 1968.

The council of the Actors Equity Association will hold a special meeting this afternoon to considers the decision of Lee and J. J. Shubert and Fortune Gallo to end their season of operettas-at Jones Beach and Randalls Island.

The Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today in two separate opinions..that "gold clauses" in a railroad bond issue and in a department store lease were invalid under a Congressional resolution outlawing the use of gold in the payment of private debts.
Several luncheons were given at the Devon Yacht Club today. Among those entertaining were Mrs. Dickson B. Potter, Mrs. Harkness Edwards, Mr. and Mrs. Gardner Pattison and Charles J. Hardy Jr.
Although Wiley Post and Howard Hughes flew different routes for most of the way around the world, their paths crossed at several points, making possible a comparison of their performances.

The board of governors of the League of New York Theatres dropped from its rolls yesterday forty-eight members who are no longer active in the theatre. The purge of the league membership, according to James F. Reilly, executive secretary, is intended to make the organization a more cohesive body before the institution of a code banning ticket speculation and negotiation of a basic agreement with Actors Equity.

John F. Bathelt, 26, of New York, pleaded guilty today of second degree murder in the death of Charles Morris, New York race track follower. Judge Thomas Hammond immediately sentenced Bathelt to life imprisonment.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Niel Handest of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Martina Handest, to Robert Duane Foothorap, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Arthur Foothorap of Harrisburg, Pa., and Gibson Island, Md.

Foreign Minister Josef Beck flew to Riga today to return the visit two years ago of the Latvian Foreign Minister, Wilhelms Munters. This is Colonel Beck's third Baltic trip in as many months, the others being to Sweden and Estonia.

The research council of the American Bankers Association has undertaken a group of studies to determine the practical effect upon the earning power of banks of current political, social and economic developments in the United States and abroad, it was announced yesterday by Gurden Edwards, director of the council.
A farmhand who asserted yesterday I that he kidnapped and killed Charles Mattson, 10 years old, was said by authorities today to be a mental case and to have had no part in the crime.

The French liner Normandie sailed at noon yesterday for Southampton and Havre with 1,240 passengers on her 100th crossing of the Atlantic. The ship, decorated with flags, was saluted by the whistles and sirens of passing craft in the river and harbor as a parting salutation to the liner and her master, Captain Pierre Thoreux.
Earl Appleman, a marine insurance lawyer with offices at 99 John Street, New York, died of a heart attack this: morning in his home here. His age was 51.

Miss Josephine Sanfilippo of Brooklyn, defending champion, gained the final round in the Long Island girls' open tennis championship at the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday by defeating Miss Roslyn Davidoff of Stamford, 6-0, 6-2.

New Jersey has received a grant of $2,113,200 from the Public Works Administration for construction of a new high level bridge to carry Route 35 over the Raritan River at Perth Amboy, United States Senator John Milton informed Governor A. Harry Moore today. The bridge,

President Roosevelt continued on his way toward the Pacific Coast today through Nevada without once mentioning the names of the rivals in the coming State primary, Senator McCarran, opponent of some New Deal policies, and Albert Hilliard.

The first "Governor's Day" of A. Harry Moore's third administration as New Jersey's Chief Executive will be held tomorrow at the Summer capital here, but aides of the Governor expressed doubt tonight that he had recovered sufficiently from intestinal influenza to take part in the exercises.

Mrs. Stella Crater, whose husband, Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater disappeared in 1930, was married on April 23. in Elkton, Md., to Carl Kunz, an electrical engineer, it was revealed last night by Jonas Ellis, an attorney of. 1,270 - Sixth Avenue.

Referring to a bitter discussion in the Senate over allowing the establishment here of Jews deported from Germany, Deputy Manuel Jose Irarrazaval charged today that opponents of the proposal were unfair in not keeping the Chilean traditional open door to all political refugees.

Total newspaper advertising linage in June declined 19.1 per cent under the same month a year ago, and showed a decrease of 14.9 per cent fbr the first six months of this year, according to the survey issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. The May decline in total linage was 16 per cent.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 11: CAPTAIN Ogan, J. V., to 12th Naval District, instead of to duty at Branch Hydro Office, San Francisco.

The Anglo-American trade negotiations, according to trustworthy information here, are now in the delicate stage where they may soon either succeed or possibly turn sour. These negotiations are of such exceptional importance to the rest of

The State Tax Department reported today that real and personal property ratables for 1938 taxing purposes were $93,399,989 below those of the preceding year. Personal property assessments totaled $718,889,817, a decline of $60,381,882, while realty ratables aggregated $4,819,195,361, a decline of $33,018,107.

Rather than break up the Newman Theatre Ticket Office, Inc., which operates at 1,502 Broadway, Federal Judge 'John .C. Knox meted out prison sentences yesterday to its executives in such a manner that one could be out of jail and conducting business while the other was in prison.
Mrs. Andrew J. Igoe of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth M. Igoe, to Robert F. Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Murphy of Germantown, Pa.

Content to dawdle around the world at five knots while Howard Hughes whizzes through the Great Circle in five days, a British barkentine, the Cap Pilar, has plodded into the harbor just in time to ease the poignant memory of the tall ship Tusitala departing on her last cruise to the shipbreakers'.

The half-finished Chickamauga dam, designed to protect this city, the most vulnerable in the Tennessee Valley, from all but the worst floods, and to help make the river navigable all the way. up to Knoxville, Was inspected this afternoon by the Congressional committee investigating the TVA following yesterday's visit to the Hiwassee storage dam.
For the first time since opening day last April, Colonel Jake Ruppert saw his Yankees play yesterday.

A curling 40-foot putt for a birdie on the eighteenth gave Willie Turnesa of Briar Hills a par 70 and the qualifying round honors in the New York State amateur golf championship at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today.

Electric power production declined last week and, even with allowance for the holiday, the daily average was lower. Seasonal and long-term trends were upward so that the adjusted index dropped to 89.3, a new "low" for the year and back to the week ended Nov. 3, 1934. For the preceding week the index was 90.0 and for the corresponding week last year, 107.0.
Ollie Carnegie once again blazed the trail for the Bisons with home runs as they defeated Newark, 7 to 3, and regained second place in the International League tonight.
A high wind played with a 37-car Illinois Central freight train last night as if it were a toy. It lifted two sections of the train from the rails and left the others untouched.

MANHATTAN FABRICIU8, JULIUS A. (March 15. 1937). Gross assets, $66,657; net, $61,917. To Flora Fabricius, widow. Richard P. Carrigan, attorney, 247 Park Ave. MAGRATH, IDA K. (Jan. 3, 1938). Gross assets, $13,311; net, $7,454. To Mary E. Kincaid, sister, and Joseph J. Magrath, brother, one-half each. Chief assets, real estate, $10,068. Clark, Carr Ells, attorneys, 120 Broadway.

The easy availability of relief money enables the hired help to put on the ritz these days, Magistrate Anthony F. Burke declared yesterday in Yorkville Court. Magistrate Burke said servants felt that they could be enormously indifferent to their jobs and enjoy the lighter side of life at their employer's expense, because they hold a fifth ace--if the employer gets unpleasant, they can always fall back on relief rolls.

Professor Fernando Nevermann, a German entomologist, was killed accidentally on a banana plantation near Port Limon recently by a gunshot fired by Hugo Scott, an American, who was hunting at night with the aid of a miner's lamp.
Charles St, 115; Clara Knitzer to Ritchar Realty Corp, 8 W 40th St.; mtg $28,000; Houston St, 283 E; Edgar J. Kohler, referee, to Herman J. Heydt, 510 Park Ave; mtg $14,875, foreclosure ($1).

An international ever-normal granary plan covering all major wheatproducing countries of the world will be proposed at the International Wheat Conference that is to open tomorrow in London, Secretary Wallace announced today at his press conference.

Attired in dark blue jackets bearing the emblems of both Princeton and Cornell, trackmen of those two universities sailed yesterday for England aboard the French liner Normandie to compete as a combined unit against the OxfordCambridge forces in London on July 23.
Emil Kirdorf, dean of Ruhr industrialists and one of the earliest industrial supporters of Adolf Hitler, died on his estate, Streithof, near Muehlheim, during the night at the age of 91.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 2d Lieut. Wenfoo G. Woo, CA-Res., 2,473 Elm Place, New York, N. Y., is ordered to active duty July 17, at Fort Hancock, N. J., for training. Date of rank: July 3. He will revert to an inactive status July 30.

The will of Frederick W. Vanderbilt, grandson of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, railroad director and a member of the New York Central board for sixty-one years, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, names as his principal legatees his niece, Mrs. Margaret Louise Van Alen of Newport, R. I.;

Mr. Roosevelt has broken the news to the country that the Government is faced with a deficit of four billion dollars during the current fiscal year. He notes that this is a much larger figure than the deficit for the fiscal year that has just ended.

The recent buoyancy of prices of scrap steel at the principal steelmaking centers is believed to forecast a material improvement in steel-making operations in the next few weeks. Yesterday No. 1 heavy melting scrap steel at Pittsburgh sold at $14.50 a ton, an advance of 50 cents. This followed a similar advance on Tuesday. Prices now are $3.75 a ton above the level of a month ago, when the upward movement started.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its telephoneoperating subsidiaries in nine countries gained 28,117 telephones in the first five months of this year, or 3,500 more than they gained in the corresponding period last year.

A $1,700,000 contract was awarded today to the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company to build electrical equipment for ten new 100miles-an-hour locomotives for passenger service on the electrified sections of the Pennsylvania Railroad between Harrisburg, Pa., New York and Washington.

Washington State Democrats, on the eve of the national convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of America tomorrow in Seattle, found their own State convention in wild uproar this afternoon as left-wingers attempted to seize control by force.

A Brookings Institutio report contended today that giant corporations had fostered "usefull competition" rather than harmful monopoly. "The persistent dissolution of large corporations," it said, "would bring us to the point where we had not the power to make the industrial advances which would progressively lower prices.
A petition filed a month ago asking reorganization of the Western Newspaper Union under provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was dismissed today by Federal Judge James A. Donohoe.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a six-story tenement house, costing $150,000 for a site on West Twenty-second Street.

The Census Bureau reported today cottonseed crushed in the eleven months from Aug. 1, 1937, to June 30 last totaled 6,201,133 tons, compared with 4,460,141 in the corresponding period a year ago. Cottonseed on hand at mills on June 30 totaled 391,367 tons, compared with 45,841 a year ago.

Joseph Biondo, 41. years old, of 77-12 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, was held in bail of $50,000 yesterday as a chief lieutenant of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania in the operations of the taxicab and soda dispensing rackets. He had been captured by a rookie detective who recognized him by the shape of his nose.

Lily Pons received one of the most rousing ovations of her career when she appeared this afternoon here in "Lucia di Lammermoor." The entire performance was a personal triumph for. Miss Pons, who is one of-the favorites of the Argentine public.

Supreme Court Justice Frank J. Cregg awarded today fees of $6,000 each to three local lawyers who acted as appraisers of stocks in the Syracuse Lighting Company and the Utica Gas and Electric Company, owned by persons objecting to the merger of those corporations into the Central New York Power Corporation.

Frank Shields's first-quest of the season for singles laurels ended in crushing defeat today at the hands of an unranked college youth in the Spring Lake invitation tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.
A horsedrawn hack stopped at the Clinton Inn, in Henry Ford's Greenfield Village, at 9 o'clock today, and out of it steeped Prince Bertil of Sweden, grandson of King Gustav.

The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks at its seventy-fourth annual convention here pledged itself today to fight communism, nazism, fascism and other subversive influences and urged national observance of flag week next June 8 to 14. "The whole world is rent asunder by strife and contention, turmoil and uncertainty,"

Mrs. Walter P. Sykes gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Charles W. Nichols, Mrs. David Jones and Mrs. Richard Swartwout. Guests of Mrs. William S. Gould there were Mrs. Robert H. Byrne and Mrs. AndreV Moreland.

While the volume of activity in primary textile markets, has declined from the rapid pace of the last few weeks, the stronger tone continues, and advances were announced in three major lines yesterday.

Thousands of persons gathered along the banks of the Thames and cheered today as Queen Mother Mary made a "royal progress" down the river from Westminster to the ancient Tower of London to attend a charity garden party.

The Transit Commission, the PWA and the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad collaborated yesterday in exercises marking the start of work on a $2,000,000 project for eliminating seven grade crossings on the three-mile stretch between Great Kills and Amboy Road on Staten Island.

Denny Shute's attempt to equal Walter Hagen's feat of winning twenty-two consecutive matches in P. G. A. championships was foiled today when the 34-yearola defending champion, who began his golf career as an amateur, lost to Jimmy Hines, winner of the metropolitan open for the past two years.
Several one and two family dwellings in Bath Beach and Bay Ridge figured in Brooklyn realty transactions reported yesterday.
George Caster had his knuckle ball working in great shape today as he pitched the Athletics to a 5-to-2 victory over the White Sox.

Mrs. Archibald H. Davis and Miss Emily C. Davis have come from Washington to the Weylin. Mr. and Mrs. W. Macy Chamberlin have come from Tannersville, N. Y., to the Berkshire. Mrs. Frederic C. Brown will arrive today at the Carlyle from Fredsfad, Belgrade Lakes, Me.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Crawford of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rebekah-Jane Crawford of New York, to the Rev. Dr. Cornelius B. Muste of New York and Medford Lakes, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Martin Muste of Grand Rapids. Mich.

For several weeks 400 refugees from the Austrian Burgenland have been drifting about in a barge on the Danube. Although they are within sight of three frontiers, they can neither go back to the country from which they were driven out nor land at any foreign port.

Macklin Marrow, young American conductor, made his final appearance of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, conducting a program of more than usual interest. It began with the Mendelssohn "Ruy Bias" Overture and four movements of the "Rustic Wedding" symphony of Goldmark.

The toast of Pittsburgh fandom this morning when they rolled in from Chicago proudly bearing a thirteengame winning streak, the Pirates were burned to a crisp when the Dodgers had done with the major league season's longest string of victories this afternoon.

Captain Charles Gumaelius, who served in the Philippines at the time of the Spanish-American War and later in China during the Boxer Rebellion, died here yesterday in the United States Veterans Hospital in Kingsbridge. He retired from the army more than fifteen years ago. His age was 75.
Three more races were sailed for the Herreshoff Memorial Cup today, but four yachts finished the last event flaunting protest flags.

Tuesday was fair. The roads were dry. Farmers had no excuse for staying away from the primary. The economic weather was also fine. Monday the State WPA director estimated that the recent increase in wages would amount to at least a million dollars a month for Oklahoma.

Assailing the policy of continuing the assignment of teachers in Special administrative positions, in force for many years, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday refused, by a 3 to 1 vote, to endorse this practice.

Subscriptions for the $200,000,000 issue of 7/8 per cent notes of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation offered by the Treasury on Monday were thirteen times the amount of the issue, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

AT the east end of the balcony of the clubhouse at the Empire City track there is a luncheon table that is reserved for Racing Commissioner Herbert Bayard Swope. He calls it "the listening post." Even a trifle like that shows how the modest Chevalier Bayard submerges himself and infinitely appreciates the viewpoint of the other fellow.

The East New York Savings Bank has sold twenty-nine properties of various types in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County. The Brooklyn sales were one-family dwellings at 86 Wyona Street J. Sulin, 274 East Fifty-second Street to Charles Brand, 550 Shepherd Avenue to Christina Cassella, 353 Wyona Street to Mary Shuman and Rose Rosenberg.

The one-story factory building at 35-28 Forty-second Street, Long Island City, recently acquired by the 35-28 Forty-second Street Corporation, has been leased to the Robert T. Battle Company, manufacturers of lighting equipment.

Headed by a joint A. F. of L.-C. I. O. leadership which had called a truce for the purpose, several hundred workers stormed the City Council chamber this afternoon with demands for jobs for Philadelphia's unemployed.

To end assault on WPA foremen and supervisors by project workers and applicants for Federal relief jobs, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Adminstrator, announced yesterday that he would "prosecute to the limit" every case involving an attack on a WPA employe.

F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., will offer today 1,000,000 shares of Chemical Fund, Inc.- The price of the shares will vary from day to day according to the market fluctuations of the securities held. An initial offering of 10,000 shares recently was sold privately at $10 a share.

Opposition to three requirements in a new set of proposed rules for the silk industry issued by the Federal Trade Commission was predicted yesterday. Principal objection among manufacturers was to provisions requiring disclosure of percentage of metallic weighting, and also disclosure of percentage of. finfishing materials other than metallic

The cornerstone for the Brazilian building at the New York World's Fair was laid yesterday at colorful ceremonies attended by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair, Brazilian officials, white-uniformed officers of the Brazilian Navy training ship Almirante Saldanha, which is in port, and the ship's band.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Lt. Col. George M. Welch, J.A.G.-Res., 348 E. 23d St., Brooklyn, N. Y., is ordered to active duty July 17 at Governors Island, N. Y., for duty in the office of the corps area judge advocate. Date of rank: April 3. He will. revert to an inactive status July 30.

Four strikers against the Collier Advertising Service, Inc., were held yesterday in $500 bail each for trial on charges of malicious mischief and one was fined $5 for trespassing on subway tracks in connection with strike activity.

Attention of furniture manufacturers at the home-furnishings shows was turned today to the resumption in Buffalo next Monday of a hearing on the petition before the Interstate Commerce Commission by nine Southern States for reduction in freight rates on furniture into Northern States.

No appeal will be filed by the Austin Silver Mining Company from the Securities and Exchange Commission's stop order against further issuance of its stock. Instead, the company made plain yesterday, it will endeavor to have the order removed by filing with the

Helsingfors, the capital of Finland, moved into the picture yesterday as a likely site for the 1940 Olympic Games as a result of news from Tokyo that the Japanese Government had withdrawn its invitation for the games.

Mrs. Grace Vanderbilt Davis, only daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, was married to Robert Livingston Stevens yesterday afternoon in Ridgewood, N. J. The ceremony was performed at 3:15 o'clock by Judge Thomas L. Zimmerman Jr. of the Bergen County Juvenile Court and the Court of Domestic Relations in the library of his home.

The robot navigator, used on the Hughes round-the-world flight, is a product of the Army Air Corps and was developed by Lieutenant Thomas Thurlow, who was lent by the army to Hughes to demonstrate the device on the trip, according to Science Service.

Howard Hughes and his four bearded adventurers of the air wrote a silent epic as they tore across North America yesterday on their history-making flight around the world. Much of the time between Fairkanks, Alaska, and Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, was spent out of contact with the world.

Vigilant defense of its own territory and social order, with complete respect for the right of selfdetermination and national independence of all other countries, was defined here today as the basis and objective of Soviet Russia's foreign policy by Constantine Oumansky, charge d'affaires in Washington.

Answering the insistent appeals from the British medical profession the British Government promised today that it would place a strict limitation upon the entry of Austrian refugee doctors, dentists and medical students into this country.

Fear and uncertainty are the only real checkreins on the European war machine and can be counted the major forces working for peace, it was declared yesterday by Carl Joachim Hambro, president of the Norwegian Parliament for thirteen years, who arrived yesterday.

In the first concrete move by the city to begin its own slum-clearance program without Federal aid, the Board of Estimate at a special meeting yesterday authorized the purchase for the New York City Housing Authority of a large part of two adjoining blocks between Madison Street and Corlears Hook Park on the lower East Side as the site where the first project would be undertaken.

Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES. WASHINGTON, July 14.-The War Department announced the following orders today, dated July 13: COLONEL Van Nostrand, P. E. (Air Corps), General Staff Corps, two days' leave July 15.

Leon C. Phillips, New Deal advocate, won the Democratic nomination for Governor by 2,921 votes, according to complete unofficial returns from Tuesday's primary. W. S. Key, also a New Deal advocate, who finished second, declared there were "reports of irregularities."

Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture announced today a wheat-loan program offering to wheat producers cooperating with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration loans at farm rates averaging between 59 and 60 cents a bushel.
Net earnings of the Union Oil Company of California for the first six months of 1938 amounted to $4,

Representative Hamilton Fish, who has urged Republican endorsement of Alfred E. Smith for United States Senator, suggested tonight the "advisability" of his party to consider backing Governor Lehman for the post.

Wage increases for workers on Works Progress Administration projects in eight Southern States were ordered to day by Harry L. Hopkins, administrator. The new pay rates a average $3.90 a month more to about 82,000 workers, effective July 15.

Miss Priscilla Curtis Ames of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tilden Ames of Marshfield, was married here today in the Old South Church to Benjamin Loring Young of Weston, son of Mrs. Benjamin L. Young of Weston and Boston and the late Mr. Young.
Turpentine firm, 343/4c; no sales; receipts 436 barrels; shipments 85 barrels; stock 40,759 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 375; receipts 2,755; shipments 397: stock 174,208.

Ernest W. Woodruff, Atlanta financier and business man, announced today the establishment of a milliondollar charitable and educational foundation here. to be known as the Emily Band Ernest Woodruff Foundation. Before her marriage Mrs. Woodruff was Miss Emily Winship.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In an editorial "WVPA Wages and Hours" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 1 you assert that the WVPA has "become a sort of standing army of government dependents" because of its wage policy, and attempt to substantiate the case by the statement that "in 1936 and 1937 when State and local direct relief rolls were shrinking rapidly, there was no corresponding shrinkage in WPA."

Recovering quickly from the initial blow of the Rebel offensive along the TeruelSagunto highway, the Loyalists today offered great resistance, preventing further progress down that road, according to their communique, and holding back the drive of General Jose Varela on their left wing at the Manzanera River.

Funeral services for Miss Anna R. Phelps, organizer of State li-braries in New York State until her retirement in 1919; were held in the Ely Funeral Home this afternoon. The Rev, Roderick MacLeod, pastor of Hadley Church, officiated. After cremation the ashes will be taken to Syracuse, N. Y., where committal service will be held tomorrow.

The Tammany Assembly District leaders in the Seventeenth Congressional District designated Walter H. Liebman yesterday for the Democratic nomination for Representative to run against Representative Bruce Barton, Republican, who is scheduled for renomination.

Governor Wilbur L. Cross indicated tonight that he had not made up his mind whether he would enter the Gubernatorial race for a fifth time. He spoke at a testimonial dinner given for him by the Fairfield County Democratic organization at the Longshore Country Club here.
The Marine Corps announced today the following orders for week ended July 13: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Brewster, D. L. S., detached from Philadelphia. Pa.; to Quantico, Va.

Meses Strauss; who retired last December as managing editor of The Cincinnati Times-Star, died at his home today at the age of 65. Mr. Strauss had been in ill health for more than a year. He was engaged in newspaper work for almost a half century.

The 149th anniversary of the taking of the Bastille and the beginning of the French Republic was celebrated here today, with as many Union Jacks as Tricolors in the streets. On every omnibus British and French flags flew together.

Dr. Isaac Goldberg, author, critic and editor, died today in his home in Brookline, at the age of 50. He was the author of biographies of H. L. Mencken, Havelock Ellis, Gilbert and Sullivan and George Gershwin, had written several books on musical and theatrical appreciation and had contributed articles to many magazines.
The Treasury's silver-buying arrangements with China have been continued for an indefinite period extending .through August and possibly longer, Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today.

A distribution of 433.7 Swedish kronor for each $1,000 of deposited 5 per cent secured debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company will be made today to holders of certificates of deposit issued by the protective committee for Kreuger Toll debentures, of which Otis A. Glazebrook Jr. of G. M.-P. Murphy Co. is chairman.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjointed table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

An abandoned farmhouse, built more than 100 years ago, now fallen into disuse, is being rehabilitated by twenty-five New York City public and private school children as part of a work camp experiment now under way at Netcong, N. J.

In a world full of dark auguries, far less attention than it merits has been paid to one of the brightest events of the week. The scene that took place in the green harbor of Cork had the setting and the quality of the happy ending of a tumultuous drama.

With eleventh-hour covering of July obligations before trading in the delivery ceases at noon today, prices on the Cotton Exchange held yesterday within a 10-point range to end unchanged to 7 points higher than on Wednesday.

Engineering construction awards totaling $52,420,000 this week are 12 per cent below the lettings in the corresponding week of 1937, according to The Engineering NewsRecord. Both private and public work dropped below last year.

Bonds were lower yesterday in slower trading on the New York Stock Exchange. In the corporate section railroad obligations were weakest and declines of major fractions 3 points forced the price index for that group down 0.41 point. Other groups maintained a steadier tone, but were a shade easier.

Fred Hopkins, who always will be remembered as the conditioner of Equipoise, brought off his biggest Empire City success yesterday at the Hilltop when he saddled Encore to beat three others, one of them the odds-on favorite. Encore, a son of Polymelian, ran over a track that was only good as a result of the rain Wednesday night.

The names of Mrs. John J. Meenan and Mrs. F. K. Thayer Jr. must be highly regarded whenever there is talk of alternate-stroke golf in the future for today, in the final round of the Long Island Women's Golf Association Scotch foursomes championship at the North Shore Country Club, the Nassau Country Club players hurdled their last obstacle, Mrs. R. M. Torgerson and Mrs. W. R. Kirkland Jr. to win on the nineteenth hole.

Jean Batten, New Zealand flier, arrived here by air today to receive the Harmon Trophy for the most outstanding air feat last year. Miss Batten flew from Darwin, Australia, to Lympne, England, in 5 days 18 hours and 15 minutes.

A vigorous racial policy aimed at. preserving the "Aryan" and "purely European character of the Italians" from contamination by "any extra-European race" is being advocated by a group of anonymous Fascist scienists.

One Canadian and nine New Yorkers qualified for the American Chess Federation championship finals tonight as a result of play in the seventh round. Only one group, the sixth, is to be decided by the outcome of adjourned games tomorrow.

In the reports of several railroads released yesterday the net loss for May was well above the loss for the same month last year. Other companies revealed a decline in the cash position as of May 31 and also in current assets for the five months. The reports follow:

Miss Virginia Raeburn, who for some years has made her home here with her godparents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Rhinelander, will be married July 30 to George Washington McKenzie Jr. of Flushing, L. I., son of Mrs. George W. McKenzie and the late Mr. McKenzie.

President Getulio Vargas, members of his Cabinet, the chief of police of Rio de Janeiro and several Governors of key States went to Bello Horizonte today in the State of Minas Geraes for the opening of the annual cattle show.

The Pirates resumed their pennant drive on a wild pitch today. Round Freddy Fitzsimmons made the heave in the ninth inning with the Waner brothers on second and third and two out, so a five-hit, 2-0 shut-out suddenly slipped from Fitz's fingers as Lloyd and Paul romped home to tie the score.

Assistant Secretary of the Navy Charles E. Edison ended a tenday fishing trip at Brielle, N. J., yesterday in rather satisfactory fashion. Starting out for tuna on the Silver King with Captain A. D. Pugh as guide, Secretary Edison hooked into a white marlin some

A joint committee of nine, which will seek to coordinate retailer buying with manufacturing and mill production requirements, was named yesterday at the concluding session of the ninth annual convention of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Court of Appeals at Albany handed down a decision on Wednesday unanimously affirming the decision of Supreme Court Justice Shientag exonerating nine banks, members of the New York Clearing House Association, from liability for damages claimed in the failure of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company-in 1933.
July 25, the fourth anniversary of the assassi nation of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, will be celebrated throughout Austria in commemoration of the Nazis fallen in their Putsch on that day.
Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, today sent letters to all persons in executive or supervisory positions in the WPA warning them against engaging in political activities.

Seven boys ana six girls, ranging in age from 14 to 18 years, who escaped Sunday night from a reformatory at Plankington, S. D., sped away in a stolen automobile and beat a pursuing Sheriff into unconsciousness, were cowed into submission early today in the Crazy Mountains, seventeen miles east of here, after some of them tried to shoot it out with nearly 100 peace officers and volunteer deputies.

Radio, which had reported the time-shattering flight of Howard Hughes around the world, brought his voice yesterday. to a nationwide audience as he spoke into a battery of microphones after landing at Floyd Bennett airport- less than four days after his take-off there on Sunday. During the flight,

A suit to void the Fair Trade Act contracts fixing the retail prices in New York City for liquors distributed by National Distillers Products Corporation wks filed yesterday in Supreme Court by Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., the department store, in behalf of itself and all other retailers who may care to join it as plaintiff.
Amid threats and finally rain, the annual Monmouth County Horse Show was inaugurated today, to continue through Saturday on the grounds of the Thornton Farm.

Quarter-final round play in the New York State clay court tennis championship was postponed yesterday when rain interrupted the match between Frank Guernsey Jr. of Orlando, Fla., national intercollegiate champion, and Gerard Podesta of Montclair, N. J., with the score at 3 games all in the first set.

The Bees swarmed on four Cardinal hurlers today for their second 10-to-5 victory in as many days over the remnants of the once mighty Gas House Gang. Lou Fette showed flashes of his old form in holding the Cardinals to two hits for the first five innings and then eased up after his mates had established a four-run lead.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
The Cabinet is virtually certain to adopt today a recommendation by Marquis Koichi Kido, Minister of Public Welfare, that Tokyo withdraw its invitation to the 1940 Olympic games.

A considerable extension of the French family allotment system, designed to combat that country's declining birth rate, has been reported to the Commerce Department by the American commercial attached at Paris.

A lightning bolt killed Peter Bentley, 30 years old, secretary of the Hudson County (N. J.) Park Commission, yesterday as he was playing golf on the links of the Forsgate Club at Jamesburg, N. J., about ten miles south of New Brunswick.

Arthur Brock, for fifty-six years head of the famous family of fireworks makers, died today at Chesham Bois, Buckinghamshire. His age was 80. The Brock family has been making fireworks for 218 years and staged the famous Crystal Palace shows.
Exports of lint cotton from the United States in June amounted to 176,000 bales, valued at $9,130,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Price changes in wheat futures in the domestic markets were exceptionally rapid today, due largely to the announcement of the government's loan level, which averaged between 59 and 60 cents a bushel.

Maynard E. Zepp, former general business manager of The Washington News, died yesterday at his home here at the age-of 55. Mr.. Zepp had been circulation manager of The Washington Post and was founder of the Newspaper Boys of America.

An extensive advertising campaign using rotogravure sections and black-and-white space in metropolitan newspapers and space in class and national magazines will be started in the Fall by the FayMiss Brassiere Company, Inc., manufacturers of the Bali Bra and Perfect Lady Combinations.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York and Governor M. Clifford Townsend of Indiana today requested the Interstate Commerce Commission to heed carefully the evidence presented by the North to offset the South's request for a parity of railroad rates,

The Congressional committee investigating the TVA made an eighty-mile trip down the Tennessee River today in an old stern-wheel steamboat owned by the TVA and inspected Wheeler and Guntersville Dams, between Chattanooga and this place.

John Griswold Livingston, 65 years old, wealthy electrical contractor and club member, was arrested in the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday as one more victim of the long-continued effort to get at the heart of the electrical racket in New York.

The Founders Mutual Depositor Corporation, Denver, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 2,500 systematic payment plan certificates to be offered at $1,500 each for cash proceeds of $3,750,000.

A report widely circulated in New York that the regulations for bank examinations recently announced by the Federal bankregulating agencies were temporary was denied emphatically today by a high official of the Treasury.

Mrs. Fred G. Davis and Miss Helen Waterhouse, both of Providence, R. I., turned on pressure after a twenty-minute shower today and drove the co-medalists and cofavorites out of the Griswold Cup running in the semi-final round of the twentieth Shenecossett women's invitation golf tournament.
The Coast Guard announced the following changes during the week ended July 13: COMMISSIONED OFFICERS Commander T. A. Shanley, promoted to captain, rank from July 1.
Lumber production declined sharply last week but, after allowance had been made for the holiday, daily average output showed a larger than seasonal gain, and the adjusted index rose to 61.2.

Miss Geraldine Frances Brophy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Basil Brophy, was married to Joseph Wheeler Appleton, son of Mrs. R. Ross Appleton of Brooklyn Heights, and the late Mr. Appleton, here this afternoon at the home of her parents.

Miss Mary Brown Oliver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Parkin Oliver of this place, was married this morning in the chapel of St. Luke's' Episcopal Church here to John Waterman Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar D. Duncan, also of Montclair.

Citing the results of a national survey covering several months, in the course of which he interviewed persons in all walks of life and of various opinions, Dr. Harold J. Stonier of New York, executive manager of the American Bankers Association,

Jerome Frank, now a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, obtained today an award of $16,000 from the Interstate Commerce Commission as a final maximum allowance for services as special counsel to the Missouri Pacific Railroad in bankruptcy.

Mrs. Oliver Harriman of New York, whose fight for legalization of lotteries for charity brought her counter to the Federal Government last year, started a new national campaign today for "domestic sweepstakes and lotteries."

A ring of physicians, attorneys, "chasers" and policy holders accused of swindling insurance companies of more than $3,000,000 a year through the collection of claims for faked disability, was broken yesterday when nine of its members entered pleas of guilty to mail fraud and conspiracy.

Among those present yesterday at Floyd Bennett Field were three trim young wives, eagerly anticipating a reunion with their husbands. When "happy landing" came at last, it found them marooned, helpless and breathless, unidentified units in a milling crowd resolutely pinioned away from the Hughes plane by the swarming police guard.

Raymond Otis, author of historical novels died last night at his home in San ta Fe, N. M., at the age of 38. Mr Otis was born here and educated at Andover and Yale. Surviving are his widow, Frances; his parents Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Otis of Chi cago; two brothers and a sister.

Arthur W. Malley died this morning in the American Hospital, Paris, from peritonitis, following an attack of appendicitis, at the age of 52. Mr. Malley,whose home was in Belle Haven, Greenwich, had real estate interests in New York and New Haven. He was born in New York and formerly resided in New Haven.

The New Jersey Petroleum Industries Committee estimated today that automotive taxes, Federal and State, increased 138 per cent in the last twelve years and during 1937 cost the average New Jersey motorist $53.64. "It is obvious,"
James H. Proctor of this place has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Martha Proctor, to Richard Preston, son of Mrs. Harold G. Cutler-of Wenham.

The new holder of the record for circumnavigating the globe already possesses many distinctions, even though he is only 32 years old. A tall, gangling, shy young man whose disdain for his personal appearance is the despair of tailors, Howard Hughes has been in the limelight most of his adult life.

The last of golf's old guard dropped out of the race for the Professional Golfers Association title, vacated yesterday by Denny Shute after a two-year reign, when stocky Gene Sarazen, Connecticut farmer, fell in the quarterfinal round of the championship today.
The United States Maritime Commission has approved a tri-party agreement readjusting steamship cargo-passenger services between New York and ports in the Caribbean and South America.

Payson Ave, 37-49; 5-story tenement, 150x100; Frank L. Weil, trustee, against O'Dreco Corp, due $218,350; to plaintiff for $1,000. 158th St, 519 W; 3-story dwelling, 20x99.11: Brooklyn Trust Co. trustee, against Jennie B. Kenny, due $5,939; taxes, etc, $550; to plaintiff for $5,000.

Employing the home run punch once more for their margin of victory, the Bisons downed Newark, 5-4, tonight to make it two out of three in the series and five victories in the last seven meetings between the clubs.

Early in the year the Young Purgers at Washington put Senator McCarran of Nevada on the black list. Time and consultation with Democratic political managers in the State chastened that purpose. In July it was reported that Mr. McCarran was to be spared.

Tony Galento, contender for the heavyweight championship, decided tonight to move back to Summit, N. J., to complete training for a fifteen-round bout with the light heavyweight champion, John Henry Lewis, here on July 26.
The Czech parties'attitude is stiffening in the face of increasing evidence of the Sudeten German party's preparations to condemn the proposed Nationalities Statute in advance.
The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad could increase itS fare between Jersey City and Hoboken and Hudson Terminal in Manhattan, from 6 to 8 cents.

The general level of wholesale prices advanced in the week ended on July 9, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 78.3, compared with 77.9 on July 2 and 87.7 on July 10. 1937.

Dr. Wyllys R. Hodges died suddenly early today of a heart attack. A few hours earlier he had attended a Lions meeting at which he was made a life member. Born at Esex, Vt., sixty-five years ago, he served as resident physician at Maryland Homeopathic Hospital, Baltimore.. After graduation he came to
Twenty persons perished today in the greatest disaster of Italy's civil aviation when the Cagliari-Rome airliner I-Volo plunged into the Tyrrhenian Sea 70 miles off the Sardinian coast.

Production of shoes will run ahead of a year ago in each of the remaining six months of this year, trade observers predicted yesterday, when it was estimated that June output was 30,000,000 pairs, off 12.9 per cent from June, 1936.

Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on July 9, exceeded sales by 15,911 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The price trend on the basis of THE NEW YORK TIMES. averages for fifty stocks showed a net decline of 2.09 points.

Not since last December have meat prices been as high as they are today. This is the first time since consumers staged their meat boycott, when prices were at an eight-year peak last Fall, that there has been a tendency for meat to approach those levels.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that the National Labor Relations Board was without power to order reinstatement of former employes "who have obtrained regular and substantially equivalent employment elsewhere."

Delayed by rain squalls on a special flight from Staunton, Va., Constantine A. Oumansky, Counselor and Charge d'Affaires of the Russian Embassy in Washington, missed an opportunity to extend the Soviet Union's congratulations on the arrival of Howard Hughes.

The executive committee of the Professional Golfers Association today took action on the much-discussed proposal to set a purse minimum for P. G. A.approved tournaments, decreeing that the minimum for a seventytwo-hole competition must be $5,000.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that two New York firms had agreed to cease false and misleading advertising practice in the sale of their products.

Leighton W. Rogers, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, in a telegram to Howard Hughes, characterized the world flight as "true-scientific triumph." Mr. Rogers: said: "We in the aircraft industry understand and appreciate the vast contribution that you have made to the science of flight.
A first mortgage of $175,000 has been arranged by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., on the six-story elevator apartment at 1,325 Nelson Ave, the Bronx, for Nelson Properties. Inc.

Stocks drifted and closed heavy at lower levels in less active trading; turnover, 1,150,970 shares. Hudson Manhattan bonds rose on order for increased fares; United States Government and other issues generally lower; transactions, $6,977,500.

After rising for four consecutive weeks business in the Pittsburgh district remained about unchanged in the week ended July 9, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

The disappearance of small retail stores from the merchandising picture seems "extremely remote," according to a study of small-scale retailing made public today by the Marketing Research Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.
The Adjutant General released the following orders today: O'Neill, 2d Lt. Eugene J., field artillery, commissioned to report to commanding officer 105th F. A., for assignment to Battery E.

A threehit shutout by Clay Bryant ended the Cubs' six-game losing streak today and a five-hit performance by Bill Lee gave Chicago the second contest of a double-header with the Phillies. The scores were 3 to 0 and 5 to 1.

The performance of Bizet's "Carmen" scheduled for last night at the Lewisohn Stadium was postponed because of the unsettled condition of the weather. Instead the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra directed by Alexander Smallens was heard in the program originally intended for tomorrow evening.
Terms of the will of Mrs. Mabelle Horlick Sidley, whose death in Toronto, on July 6 has been the subject of an investigation, were revealed here tonight.

An unscheduled prelude- to the Hughes flight finish provoked a noisy curiosity yesterday among the thousands awaiting the around-theworld fliers at Floyd Bennett Field. A "mercy" plane which came in at 1:15 P. M., about an hour before the record-setters, caused the excitement.

The labor policies of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, which participated in last Summer's "little steel" strike, will come under the scrutiny of the La Follette Civil Liberties Committee,

Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford was hostess this afternoon at tea in the North Garden, Guild Hall, in honor of patrons of the newly established East Hampton branch of the Grand Central Art School, New York.

Alper Management Company has moved its offices to 65-67 Madison Avenue, where it will occupy the penthouse. A meeting of Bronx property owners has been called by the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement for Thursday night, July 21, at 90 Park Avenue, to discuss property improvement in the Bronx.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 13 unless specified: At Boston, July 14: Roper, Tattnall, Mania to Chefoo, July 14: Alden, Barker, J. D. Edwards, Whipple. Nassau to Boston Via Port Everglades. July 10: Dickerson, Schcenck.
Centuries by Don Bradman and W. A. Brown paved the way for the touring Australian cricketers' tenth victory today. The Aussies defeated Warwickshire at Birmingham by an inning and 93 runs.
When our royal Swedish visitors are back in Stockholm they probably won't care if they don't see a smorgasbord for

The council of the Actors Equity and Chorus Equity Associations denied yesterday that it was responsible for the decision of Lee and J. J. Shubert and Fortune Gallo to end their season -of operettas at Jones Beach tomorrow and at Randalls Island on Sunday.

Some fearful and wonderful ideas about liberty are coming out of-New Jersey these days, but there has been nothing to surpass the reasoning of the decision just handed down by Vice Chancellor Berry at Toms River. The Vice Chancellor came to the following conclusions:

Lewis E. Mosher, one of the leading civil and criminal lawyers of the Southern tier, died here today after a few days' illness of a heart ailment at the age of 69. He appeared as defense attorney in many of the murder trials through this section.
Bobby Pacho, Mexican welterweight, gained the decision over Willie Fool of Flatbush in the main bout of ten rounds at Fort Hamilton last night before a capacity crowd of 7,000. Each weighed 147.
Arthur F. Mullen, floor leader for President Roosevelt at the 1932 Democratic National Convention, died at his home here today at the age of 65. Physicians said death was due to gastric ulcers.
One of the aspects of the record dash around the top of the world by Howard Hughes and his crew of four was the remarkable condition of both plane and men upon landing yesterday afternoon.

Howard Hughes's around-the-world flight is the leading story today in all of Great Britain's national newspapers, because, as a Times editorial puts it, "it represents the peak of skill, endurance and organization which is unlikely to be surpassed for many a long day."

Export premiums will be reintroduced in Poland at a cost of nearly $10,000,000 to the Treasury. The premiums were dropped last year when grain prices were rising and there was a shortage of rye and wheat just before the harvest. There will be bumper crops this year and a surplus of nearly 1,000,000 tons for export.

Although representatives of the United States Bureau of Customs, the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the Quarantine Station and the Department of Agriculture were waiting to make routine examinations of the crew and baggage of the Hughes round-the-world plane when it landed at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday afternoon, there was no work to be done.

Nevil Ford of the First Boston Corporation and John Starkweather of J. K. Starkweather Co., representing the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., and the Investment Bankers Association, will confer in Washington today with William 0. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. on the Maloney Act.

The prospective drive of the Giants through the West became utterly becalmed today as Bucky Walters, who used to give the Terrymen plenty of trouble while he was with Philadelphia, bobbed up with a brilliant five-hit shutout to give the Reds their second straight victory of the series, 1 to 0.
Stanley Dusek of College Point, in New York, ran Nova Scotia's season tuna record up 30 pounds tonight when he landed a 500-pound bluefin.

James Harry Preston, twice Mayor of Baltimore, former City Police Com missioner, Speaker of the Maryland House of Delegates in the early Nineties, whose name was placed before the Democratic National Convention of 1912 as a candidate for the Vice Presidency, died today after an illness of several months. His age was 78.

The threatened stoppage of sales of milk in 10,000 retail stores affiliated with the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association was set yesterday for next Wednesday, Charles Ackerman, head of the association, made the announcement after an unsuccessful conference with William Fellowes Morgan Jr.. Markets Commissioner, and Julius Marcus, representing milk distributors.

Thomas F. McAndrews, formerly secretary to Mayor James J. Walker, was appointed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary as receiver for the property of Alfred C. Blumenthal, theatrical producer.

Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich of Green Meadow, one-time holder of the women's metropolitan championship, today turned in a 79, one over women's par, to capture the low gross honors in the Westchester and Fairfield women's one-day golf tournament at the Westchester Hills Golf Club course.
Speedboat drivers of the East were gathering here tonight for an attack tomorrow on race records, always in danger at the Havre de Grace Yacht Club's annual regatta.

The navy's plans to build 45,000-ton "super-ships" have not been abandoned, but only postponed. Tentative designs for the battleships which would be the most powerful fighting ships the world has ever seen, are now being developed in the Navy Department and should be ready in about a year.

Labor round table luncheon, City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street, 12:30 P. M. Address by Ernest Bevin. National Maritime Union, 126 Eleventh Avenue, 7:30 P. M. "Collective Bargaining and Union Agreements," William Standard, Allan S. Haywood.

MANHATTAN ARONSON, CARRIE (July 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Gladys A. Liberman, 1,010 5th Ave.; Mabel A. Butler, 12 E. 86th St., and Evelyn A. Margolis, Hotel Majestic, Philadelphia, Pa., residue equally. Herman N. Liberman, 1,010 5th Ave.. executor.

Miss Josephine Sanfilippo of Brooklyn, who has been winning consistently in. the metropolitan district, added another title to her list when she successfully defended her laurels in the girls' Long Island. championship at the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday.

A victory in part in the cinema's search for a stereoscopic camera has been won by Joseph Valentine, film cameraman, who has revealed that, after five years of experimentation, he has succeeded in attaining the suggestion of a third dimension of the screen.

Harvard's new varsity baseball Coach to succeed Fred Mitchell will be Floyd S. Stahl, who has been head of baseball for the past eight years at Ohio State, it was announced today. Stahl is a graduate of the University of Illinois, class of '26. Adolph Samborski will continue as freshman coach.

Travis Jackson's term as manager of the Jersey City International League Giants ended tonight as the club's parent team, the New York Giants, replaced him with Hank DeBerry, who has been- a scout for the big leaguers.

The Red Sox pounded two Detroit hurlers for a total of fifteen hits and a 12-1 victory today for Bob (Lefty) Grove's fourteenth triumph. The victory, however, may be a costly one, for Grove had to quit the game in the fifth inning when his pitching hand became numb.

The dispute within the United Automobile Workers of America reached a critical stage today when John L. Lewis sought unavailingly to arrange for a conference between President Homer Martin and a committee of thirteen local union presidents who came here and asked the C. I. O. chairman to intervene in the tangled affairs of the organization.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John L. Walther of this city and Elkins Park, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorraine Walther, to George de Braux of Paris, France, son of the late Rene de Braux, painter and art collector, and the late Mrs. de Braux.

The Lawyers Trust Company reported for June 30 total deposits of $35,260,856 and total assets of $39,301,323, compared, respectively, with $40,419,529 and $44,551,923 on March 7, last. Loans and discounts of the bank amounted to $10,543,468, against $10,350,346 on March 7,

For the third time in his 27 years Michael Alex of 1,944 First Avenue was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing. The Court of General Sessions set the week of Aug. 22 for the execution.

How Howard Hughes, who is known for his definite dislike of publicity; consented to give publicity to the World's Fair in his round-the-world flight was revealed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 12: CAPTAINS Kinkaid, T. C., detached from the Indianapolis, about Aug. 27, to Naval Attache and Naval Attache for Air, Rome, Italy. Shafroth, J. F. Jr., detached the Reina Mercedes, to command of the Indianapolis; orders of Feb. 3 to 12, Naval District, revoked.
Deaths Reported Hubert J. Treacy, recently retired civilian employee. The funeral will take place from his late residence, 13-70 Gipson St., Far Rockaway, Queens, at 10 A. M., Monday, July 18.

Several new girdles in ten-inch lengths, designed to provide posture-control for "teen-age" girls, are featured in the Fall line of foundation garments introduced yesterday by the William Carter Company. The line,

Miss Margaret White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert White of this city and Myrtle Beach, S. C., was married to Carl Howard Meyer, son of Mrs. Amandus Meyer of Bronxville, this evening in the Vernon Heights Congregational Church here.
Seven Berkshire garden clubs are coopereating with the Lenox Horticultural Society in its forty-fifth annual twoday flower show which was opened in Lenox Town Hall this afternoon.

The news that Japan has been forced to abandon the next Olympic Games was received with satisfaction throughout Scandinavia. Several Scandinavian States had already decided not to send teams to Tokyo in view of the Far Eastern situation.

" The Two Bouquets," the Eleanor and Herbert Farjeon play with period music which Marc Connelly has sponsored hereabouts, will end its run at the Windsor Theatre tomorrow night. It will have played b fifty-five performances.

The midtown district bounded by Third and Eighth Avenues, Thirtyfourth and Fifty-ninth Streets, including the Times Square and Grand Central zones, continues to hold first place in the dollar volume of new realty mortgage financing in Manhattan.
The Works Progress Administration announced today its purpose to buy $3,000,000 worth of women's Winter coats, for distribution in the Autumn.

Police Commissioner Valentine presented awards yesterday in his office to eight drivers of the United Parcel Service, Inc., who have taken trucks of the company for a total of more than 1,000,000 miles in the last eight years without an accident.

Simon F. Rothschild, former president and chairman of the board of the Abraham Straus deapartment store, left a net estate of $1,156,195 when he died Jan. 5, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The principal assets of the estate were stocks and binds valued at $810,212 among which were 600 shares of stock in the department store appraised at $67,855.

The Autumn list of the reorganized Dial Press includes the following works: Ford Madox Ford's "The March of Literature," John Anderson's "The American Theatre in Picture and Prose," Andre Gide's "Afterthoughts on the U. S. S. R.," Thomas Archer's "Richard Strauss" and C. L. R. James's "The Black Jacobins The Story of Toussaint I'Ouverture."
Young Democrats from all parts of the country, about 2,500 of- them, were assembling in Seattle today on the eve of the annual convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of Amer- of ica.
Properties in two boroughs passed to new control yesterday when brokers announced sales and leases involving housing and business parcels in Manhattan and the Bronx.
Brisk renting of apartments in buildings on the East and West Side areas was evident from long lists of names that were added yesterday to tenant rosters.

Through alternating sunshine and rain about 10,000 Elks paraded before a Summer crowd of more than 100,000 visitors on the Boardwalk here this afternoon as the climax to their seventy-fourth annual convention.

Among the most eventful of the games played in the tournament of the American Chess Federation at Boston was the one which David S. Polland of Brooklyn, titleholder, lost to Weaver W. Adams of Boston, former New England champion, in the fourth round.
The Rev. Harold J. Hoban, assistant rector of St. Rose of Lima Catholic Church, died in St. Agnes Hospital today following an operation. He was 45 years old.

A revised reapportionment plan, designed to remove objections of some up-State Republicans to the draft previously made public, was considered today by the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Legislature.
For a two-minute thrill more than 20,000 persons braved threatening skies and waited, crushed against wire fences, to watch Howard Hughes and his crew land at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday.

Pike St, 32, 25x85; Minnie Cohen to Kallman Cohen, 2,660 E 21st St, Bklyn; mtg $6,000 (50 cents). Rivington St, 174, 25x99.11; Eugene J. Morris, referee, to Dry Dock Savings Institution, foreclosure ($7).

Charles Wengrovsky, an imperturbable 13-year-old boy from the lower East Side, won yesterday the Manhattan checker championship for boys and girls under 16 years of age in the borough finals, held at the Heckscher Playground in Central Park between the East and West Drives at Sixty-fourth Street.

ACROSS THE FRONTIER, by Philip Gibbs. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.) A survey of the European scene. DEATH FROM A TOP HAT, by Clayton Rawson. (Putnam, $2.) .A mystery novel. HEART SPECIALIST, by Graeme and Sarah Lorimer. (Little, Brown. $1.) -A new edition.

Relaxing in an easy chair that "felt good" to him after four days in a cramped cabin cockpit, Howard Hughes, after satisfying his desire for a shower and a clean shirt, said yesterday afternoon that he had been attended by "great luck" on his record-breaking world flight,

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick sold by allotment yesterday $10,000,000 of New York City special revenue bills at an interest rate of 0.375 per cent. The bills are dated July 15 and will mature on Nov. 15. Proceeds will be used for city relief purposes.

Five weary-eyed men with bearded faces and clothing that was soiled and wrinkled stepped from an airplane of unblemished sheen into a bedlam of noise and confusion at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, completing the fastest journey that man

The foreign exchange market was quiet and steady yesterday as business in it came under the influence of the Bastille Day holiday in France. Sterling showed. a renewed tendency to sag, but the other exchanges were firm.

Miss Elizabeth Sitters Gompertz, daughter of Mrs. Louis M. Gompertz of 322 West Seventy-second Street and the late Mr. Gompertz, was married to Merryl Frederick Sicherman, son of Mrs. Armin Sicherman of Akron, Ohio, and the late Dr. Sicherman, yesterday in the Carlyle by the Rev. Dr. David Alexander of Akron.

The spectacular advance in the stock market has brightened -definitely the surface appearances of business, but it has not much altered the fundamental realities, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, declares in the current issue of the bank's business bulletin.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, arriving today from Germany and English Channel ports, has as passengers Josef F. Fibiger, H. Stephen Kohl, H. G. Dobson, Andrew L. Vargha, Kurt Karfeld, Erwin Kipfmueller, Mrs. W. B. Tucker, Mr. and- Mrs. Paul Armstrong, Gustav A. Westphal and Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Wilson.

The public utilities industry faces the need of voluntary reorganization on a large scale, "so that the industry may put itself in shape to meet the future," Abe Fortas, assistant director of the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission,

The Florida Racing Commission today declined to reinstate Jockey Don Meade, suspended March 4, 1936, for betting on horses that ran against his own mount. The commission, which heard pleas in Meade's behalf yesterday, announced its decision without comment.
The prepared text of President Roosevelt's address at the Golden Gate International Exposition grounds today was as follows:

The outstanding credit of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City continued to contract in the week ended on Wednesday and reached on that day the smallest amount in three and a half years, according to the condition statement of the banks, issued yesterday.

Three banks filed today against the Rutland Railroad mortgage foreclosure petitions amounting to $9,250,000 in Federal District Court here. Exclusive of interest, the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company of New York listed its mortgages on properties of the road at $4,400,000; the Old Colony Trust Company

Many dinner parties were given here tonight at the Bastille Day celebration held at the Atlantic Beach Club to aid Roosevelt House in New York. Dinner with dancing, as well as popular divertissements, had the patio of the club for their setting with decorations in red, white and blue.

The Italian racial manifesto, which proclaims the Italian race "Aryan, Nordic and heroic" and turns against intermarriage with "non-European" elements, such as Jews and Africans, is hailed in Germany as a victory for Chancellor Adolf. Hitler's racial ideology, presaging further conquests in other lands.

Mrs. Henry E. Coe entertained with a reception this afternoon at The Appletrees. During the afternoon the hostess, in rustic costume, presented, with musical accompaniment, recitations of a group of songs entitled "Devil's Ditties," from a collection of the same title of songs of the Kentucky mountaineers by Jean Thomas.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today canceled schedules of proposed commodity trucking rates and joint motor-water rates in the New England region, including movements between. New England, Eastern New York and Northern New Jersey on the ground that they were unlawfully low.

Lee Fleenor, a defendant in the Harlan labor conspiracy trial here, was held today following the death of Charles Reno, a miner he was charged with wounding. Sheriff C. C. Ball of Harlan County said that Fleenor, a former Deputy Sheriff of that county, would be returned for a hearing before County Judge Cam Ball.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday an extension until July 30 of the time during which the new occupancy tax of $1 to $6 on rented business properties may be paid without penalty.

Adee Ave, 800 to 808 (16-4550); Lottie Bergman to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtg to May 1, 1943, at 3 per cent; $265,580. Woodycrest Ave, 1,098 (9-2509); Gussie Rushink to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtg to Aug 1, 1943, at 4 per cent; $50,500.
Dr. Edward Fuller Bigelow, educator, naturalist, writer and lecturer, of Arcadia, Old Greenwich, died at the Municipal Hospital late last night following a two-year illness. His age was 78.

A torrential downpour, accompanied by thunder and lightning, routed the 107th Infantry (Old Seveth) of Manhattan late this afternoon as it was passing in review at Camp Smith before the cadet colonel and a former cadet colonel of the Knickerbocker Grays, junior military unit under the wing of the National Guard regiment.

Great stimulus for commercial aviation, especially over ocean flying, was seen yesterday by aviation experts in Howard Hughes's flight around the top of the world. They pointed out that in the eleven years since Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh

A joint committee of nine, which will seek to coordinate retailer buying with manufacturing and mill production requirements, was named yesterday at the concluding session of the ninth annual convention of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees adopted today its final resolution constituting itself as a permanent organization. At the next meeting at London on Aug. 3 an eminent American will be named "director of authority" and the committee of thirty-two will get down to the concrete business of helping the refugees from Great Germany.

MANHATTAN BUCKLEY, CORNELIUS C. (April 11, 1936). Gross assets, $96,800; net, $60,782. To Bridget Buckley, sister, $1,000; Russell Fitton, Jeremiah Fitton, Cornelius P. Fitton, Mary E. Buckley, Arthur C. Buckley, Anne H. Buckley, Mary McConville, Annie McCarthy and Martin F. Molloy, one-tenth residue each; two varying bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $92,054. Richard G. Babbage, attorney, 111 Broadway.

The Guaranty Trust Company is prepared to pay the principal amount with full interest to maturity of Rockland Light and Power Company first-mortgage thirty-fiveyear 5 per cent bonds due on Nov. 1, 1938.

Check exchanges of the principal cities throughout the nation for the week ended on Wednesday declined 14.1 per cent to $4,996,659,000 from $5,816,126,000 in the same week of last year, recording to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
This Nova Scotian seaport town was preparing today for the international tuna matches. A patrol boat whistle at dawn on Aug. 27 will send eighteen

Charles Major, former president of the Pencoyd Iron Works, Manayunk, died today at his home at the age of 82. Born at Heislerville, N. J., Mr. Major was associated for forty-one years with the iron works before his retirement in 1921.

The White Sox won a free-hitting game from the Athletics, 9 to 8, today. Bill Werber's double and Bob Johnson's seventeenth homer of the season with one on gave the Mackmen a three-run lead in the first, but four hits, coupled with three errors, put the White Sox ahead, 5-3, in the second.
Twenty mixed pairs, most of them from New England for a change, opened today the seventh annual Southern New England contract bridge championships on the roof of the Hotel Mohican.

A drizzie ushered in the series finale between the Yankees- and the Browns yesterday at the Stadium and a shower stopped play in the seventh inning. with Yankee runners- on first and third and none out.

The report of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended on April 30 shows a consolidated net profit of $6,211,414 after all charges, including surtax on undistributed profits and after deducting the interests of the minority stockholders of Pacific Mills, Ltd., a Canadian subsidiary.

Standing within sight of sixty-three gray-hulled men o' war at anchor in the bay today, President Roosevelt declared that 1939 would be a year of "world-wide rejoicing" if it saw "definite steps toward permanent world peace."

Garfield A. Wood of Detroit, motor boat racer and designer, has just received a patent for a device intended to prevent forced airplane landings or crashes in the event the gasoline line becomes clogged or the fuel pump ceases to function..

The Lewisohn Stadium concert on Tuesday evening in honor of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf, Crown Princess Louise and Prince Bertil of Sweden, will be attended by a distinguished honorary committee, consisting of: Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman,
Thousands of Manhattan cheered Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, who, accompanied by Crown Princess Louise, arrived at the Union Station this morning from Washington.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dietz of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edna Marguerite Dietz, to Nathan Chase Ayer, son of Mrs. Nathan C. Ayer of Bangor, Me.

The Rev. Francis J. Karl, assistant pastor of the Catholic Church of St. Matthias, 1,861 Catalpa Avenue, Brooklyn, died of a heart attack yesterday in his room in the Governor Clinton -Hotel. His age was 50..

The Maritime Labor Board, of which Robert W. Bruere in chairman, held its first meeting today and effected general organization of its agenda. The other members are Dr. Louis Bloch and Claude E. Sechorn.

Acused of participating in the operation of wheels of chance that gave the customer no "break" at all, three alleged managers and sixteen alleged employes of a Westchester carnival show were arraigned here today on gambling or disorderly conduct charges as a result of a raid on the show last night.

Small groups of C. I. O. unionists with their wives and children, 750 of whom were driven from Westwood yesterday after a riot between lumber labor factions, straggled back here today asking to be allowed to get their belongings. It was agreed that they could take them.
Don Budge and Gene Mako took two of the final three exhibition tennis matches from Yugoslav. stars today.

The index of machine tool orders turned upward last month for the first time since March, the National Machine Tool Builders Association announced here today. June orders, according to the index, which are based on average monthly shipments in 1926, stood at 70.2, compared with 66.7 in May and 191.8

Howard Hughes and his flying companions have dramatically illustrated the queer tricks that speed can play with the system of time accepted by men, the National Geographic Society said tonight in a bulletin filled with interesting facts about the journey.

Mrs. Constance Helen Elmslie, daughter of the late Joseph Pulitzer, founder of .The New York World and The St. Louis Post Dispatch, died yesterday morning in Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, after a long illness. She had resided in Colorado Springs.

While showers forced postponement until tomorrow of today's scheduled matches at the Meadow Brook Club, Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., United States Polo Association chairman, announced that an all-star benefit contest has been scheduled for Sunday, July 24, on the club's International Field.
Plans for numerous small dwellings in Brooklyn were among build- t ing projects placed on file yesterday. Activity in Manhattan was confined largely to alteration work. The plans follow:

Gene Tunney told an educators' group tonight that American educators were trying to "tear down governments." He said at a Purdue University clinic that speeches at the recent National Education Association convention in New York showed "the favorite sport of our educators seems to be not to build up the spirit of man through a higher and broader culture but to tear down governments."
Kings Blue, owned by John Marsch of Chicago and ridden by Jockey Leon Haas, cantered to victory in the feature seven-furlong sixth race at Arlington Park today.

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today an application- of thirteen subsidiaries of the Greyhound Corporation to issue serial equipment notes aggregating $4,200,000 for the purchase of 356 coaches, and authorized:the parent company to assume obligation as guarantor of $3,552,000 of the notes.
