Antoine- Rochegrosse, 79-year-old French painter and illustrate, died yesterday at Villa d'Elbiar, where he had lived in retirement for a number of years.

Members of the eighth annual seaplane cruise, who took off this afternoon from the Sands Point (L. I.) Bath Club at Plum Point, arrived here later in the afternoon on the first leg of a flight which has as its northern objective Lake Ouimet, in the Province of Quebec.

Two legacies to the Sheffield Scientific School, totaling more than a million dollars, were announced today by Yale University. They were a residue interest in the estate of Frederick W. Vanderbilt, '76, of New York City, and $664,749 from the estate of Miss Marie Oakes Hotchkiss of East: River, Conn., who died last week.

Jockey Ruperto Donoso virtually lifted Dunade over the finish line to score a nose victory over A. Compton's Sun Egret in the sixfurlong sprint that featured today's Rockingham Park program. Sun Egret, a 4-5 favorite, had a length and a half on the Greentree Stable's Drowsy.

172d St (15-3882), n s, 135 ft e of Bronx River Ave, 52x112; Nathan Ginsberg, referee, to Barney Pearl, trustee, 2,111 Tiebout Ave. Andrews Ave (11-3217), e s, 237 ft a of 183d St, 50x100 H. Benett Salomon, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

A LDOUS HUXLEY has suggested that the astounding number of books on Mr. Bonaparte is - -deeply and alarmingly significant "What," Mr. Huxley would like to know, "must be the day dreams of people for whom the world's most agile social climber and ablest bandit is the hero they most desire to hear about?"

The Japanese Government's reasons for its decision not to hold the 1940 Olympics in Tokyo are not the same reasons that led many Americans to protest against the choice of Tokyo. It seems to be the military rather than the civilian party in Japan that has forced the issue.

Twenty children in the gala costumes of European and South American nationals entertained yesterday with songs and dances an audience of children attending the exhibit of the National -Doll and Toy Collectors Club at the Spear Auditorium, 22 West Thirty-fourth Street. Their hostess,

The waters around Chateau d'If, whence the legendary Count of Monte Cristo swam to riches and vengeance, was the scene of another drama tonight when two Germans tried to rob and kill the owner of a motorboat they had chartered in Marseille a few hours before, presumably to visit the historic island.

Selected Industries, Inc., reports as of June 30, 1938, net assets of $36,249,119 before deducting bank loans of $12,884,440, indicating an asset coverage of $90.68 a share for the $5.50 prior stock outstanding in the hands of the public.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas in June were about 10 per cent below those of June, 1937, but higher than for all other Junes since 1929, the Commerce Department estimated today.

Prices for hogs broke today 25 to 40 cents hundredweight from the 1938 peak, reached yesterday. The break was attributed by major packers to efforts of the market here to realign itself with other major markets, as well as to wholesale prices and light Eastern demand.

New Jersey couples contemplating marriage were urged today by State Health Department officials to obey not only the letter but the spirit of a new law requiring syphilis tests of marriage license applicants.

As a result of today's play in the Lake Mohonk Tennis Club's tournament, Davenport and Lang will meet again in the final tomorrow. Davenport defeated Kynaston, 6-4, 6-4, and Lang turned back Kelleher, 7-5, 6-3.

The value of Canadian products exported in June was $66,661,943, compared with $113,918,104 in June, 1937, the National Revenue Department said today. Foreign products exported through Canadian ports were valued at $11,645,891, against $1,379,539 in June, 1937.

Because it is so much at variance with the American tradition, one of the disturbing developments of recent years has been the trend toward "personal government" through the centralization of far-reaching power in the hands of a single executive.
Reforms of one sort and another may in time make this a practically perfect world, though it doesn't look quite that way now. In time, no doubt, there will be permanent peace.

New York's ga chances of getting the 1940 Olympic Games as a result of Japan's apparent decision not to hold them in Tokyo appeared slim tonight, according to Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic Committee.

Ira B. Austin of Pleasantville, former Village Trustee, Fire Chief and Fire Commissioner of that village, died here today in the Northern Westchester Hospital, after a brief illness. He was 72 years old. For many years he was the proprietor of Austin Brothers' general store of Pleasantville.

Elaborate police arrangements were made last night for a triumphal parade beginning at noon today from the Battery to the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in honor of Howard Hughes and the four men who flew with him around the world.

Hubert J. Treacy, former chief of the Bureau of Repairs and Supplies of the Fire Department, died yesterday morning at his home, 13-70 Gipson Street, Far Rockaway, Queens. Mr. Treacy, who was 60 years old, retired from the department in April due to failing health.

Ralph Scalzullo has bought for occupancy from the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company the two-family dwelling at 767 Palisade Avenue, West New York, N. J., through J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers.

George A. Fisher, Joseph Weisberg, James Bucci, Joseph Amster, in 41 Union Square; Wadsworth Co., Inc., brokers. R. DeLaFuenta, candy mfr., store in 2 E. 177th St, J. Lipkin, fruits and vegetables, store in 1,376 Boscobel Ave. C. Fertig, dry goods, store in 306 Audubon Ave. M. Crown, restaurant, store in 565 Columbus Ave: Nehring Brothers,' Inc. brokers.
The Indians pounded out a 5-to-1 victory over the Senators today, Mel Harder hurling shutout ball until the final. frame, when Al Simmons drove a homer-into the center-field bleachers.

Contracts totaling $71,585 were awarded by the Navy Department today as follows: Replacement of boilers and auxiliary equipment, at the Eleventh Naval District Hospital, San Diego, to J. A. Carter Company, Los Angeles, for $42,475.

Mrs. William Scott Pyle, who arrived on the Conte di Savoia, has been joined at the Ritz Tower by Mr. and-Mrs. Albert Spalding of Great Barrington, Mass. Ralph Seward Allen will leave the Pierre today to join Mrs. Allen at the Gideon-Putnam in Saratoga.

Barney Hunt of Columbus, former Ohio public links champion, crushed the Western amateur golf championship hopes of Burleigh Jacobs Jr. of Milwaukee today, eliminating the medalist in the second round of match play, 4 and 2.

In as dramatic a finish as Bisley's famed rifle ranges have seen, Canada today won the Rajah of Kolapore's Challenge Cup, the premier team trophy of the Empire Meeting of the National Rifle Association.

Vincent Price, who played Prince Albert for two seasons in Helen Hayes's production of "Victoria Regina," has been signed for a series of twelve pictures by Universal. The contract is for five years and by its provisions Mr. Price will be permitted six months a year for stage work in New York.

The big three of the New York State golf championship advanced to the quarter-final round today at rainsoaked Quaker Ridge as Willie Turnesa, the medalist; Tommy Goodwin, a two-time winner of the title, and Ray Billows, also a double victor and the defending king, each won twice on the first day of match play.

Wilmer Allison, former national tennis champion, was trailing Archie Henderson of Chapel Hill, N. C., at 5-7. 6-2 and 1-3 in the deciding set today when rain intervened to interrupt their quarterfinal match in the Spring Lake invitation tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

During the week ended July 13 member bank reserve balances increased $199,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $70,000,000 in money in circulation and $142,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and an increase of $12,000,000 in gold stock,

Miss Mary Jeanne Stourton, youngest daughter of the late Major Herbert Stourton and the Hon. Mrs. Stourton of Pond Place, Chelsea, was married today in Brompton Oratory to the Hon. Ralph Robert Watts Sherman Stonor, only son and heir of Baron land Baroness Camoys of Stonor Park, Oxfordshire.

The appointees to the new Civil Aeronautics Authority telegraphed congratulations today to Howard Hughes on his found-the-world flight. "The President's appointees to the Civil Aeronautics Authority have watched the progress of your flight with the deepest interest and extend to you their heartlest congratulations in its successful conclusion," said the telegram.

Severe rainfall and floods have again struck Japan, this time in the extreme northern part of the main island, Honshu. Four persons were killed in the northeastern district of the Island, according to a dispatch from Aomori to the Domei News Agency. Fifteen hundred houses are reported inundated, eight river embankments destroyed and twelve bridges washed away in Aomori Prefecture.

Britain turned abruptly to the question of her empire defenses today, with emphasis upon Gibraltar. Britain's Committee of Imperial Defense is reviewing "the whole question of the strategical position of Gibraltar in the light of recent events in Spain and the Strait of Gibraltar," Sir John Simon,

Despite the fact that the government loan on wheat announced yesterday placed the loan basis at Chicago up to 4 cents a bushel higher than the ruling price for the cash article, quotations on the Chicago Board of Trade showed net declines of 1 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel at the end

The oncemighty fireball arm of lanky Bob (Lefty) Grove lay limp tonight-and the career of one of. baseball's greatest pitchers depended on a doctor's diagnosis of a strange ailment that struck him on the mound today.

Reports of bumper wheat crops, which are now expected to bring in the largest harvest in the world's history, and prospects of further increases in acreage next season were submitted today at the opening session of the International Wheat Conference.

Completion of plans and design for a 100-passenger flying boat were announced today by the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation. The specifications indicate that it will be a three-deck craft with gross weight of 168,000 pounds, a wing span of 194 feet, an overall height of 31 feet, a length of 102 1/2 feet, and a fuel capacity of 8,450 gallons. The payload is to be 25,

Arthur Desterberg, 23, of 354 West Twenty-eighth Street, and Michael McNabola, 34, of 500 East Twentythird Street, New York, hitch-hikers, were killed in a crash between an automobile and a bus today on Route 42, near the Wurtsboro Airport.

Trading yesterday was the slowest of the week in most classes. Some sales steer hinds and ribs were slightly lower. Veal hindsaddles were weak to fully $1 lower. Lamb and pork were about steady. Kosher business in beef and veal was confined mostly to cold meat carried over from previous killings at weak prices.

Clouds of personal and political antagonisms grew thicker around War Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha today when Winston Churchill dramatically demanded a reopening of the recent case involving Duncan Sandys, Conservative member of Parliament from Norwood.

The Public Works Administration does not encourage municipalities to compete with private utilities, but judges applications for grants and loans for that purpose on the same basis as applications for assistance on other works, Secretary Ickes said today.

A program on cosmetic advertising and labeling under the WheelerLea act, representing a proposed understanding between the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Toilet Goods Association, has been approved by the executive board of the latter organization and now awaits final approval by the retail group.
Charles (Ted) Olewine of Santa Monica, Calif., today eliminated the defending champion, William Gillespie of Atlanta, Ga., from the national junior interscholastic tennis championship.

Most fed steers and yearlings declined full 25 cents today on another slow and draggy market. while common and medium grades could find no dependable outlet, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Hogs broke sharply. Lambs sold firm.

Twenty-five Japanese warships have been sunk and nineteen have been disabled in the past two weeks by Chinese bombing planes in raids along the Yangtze River, the military spokesman claimed yesterday.

Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, announced today the commission had awarded to Arthur Kudner, Inc., of New York City, a contract to handle the preliminary advertising program of the American Republics Line, which will operate the new express and steamship service between New York and Brazil, Uruguay and Argentina.
Pensioned On police surgeon's certificate: To take effect 12 midnight, July 12: PATROLMAN--John Bowmen, 41st Precinct, at $1,080 per annum. Appointed March 26, 1924.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has set for July 29 a hearing on an application by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation for approval as a mutual service company.

The Public Service Commission instituted today a proceeding to determine whether the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, affiliated with the Associated Gas and Electric System, had defied an order issued by the commission in 1932.

Greyhound, holder of sixteen world records for trotters, failed in his attempt to break his own mark over a half-mile track today, trotting the mile in 2:01, one and one-quarter seconds over the time he made a year ago when he circled the twolap course in 1:59 3/4.

Jack Dunn, captain of the British ice-skating team in the 1936 Olympics, died in a hospital tonight of what physicians diagnosed as tularemia, a rare disease caused by contact with rabbits. Stricken two weeks ago with what appeared to be a streptococcus infection, the 21-year-old skater had been critically ill since.

Captain John eeler Robison; U. S. N., retired, was found dead in his apartment at 75 East Fiftyfifth Street yesterday afternoon. He was 68 years old and his death was attributed to a heart attack. Captain Robison was brought to public notice during the litigation which followed the leasing of naval oil reserve lands to private companies,

Returning from a survey trip to the West and Southwest, Eli L. Oliver, executive vice president of labor's Nonpartisan League, declared today that the political tide was running heavily in behalf of liberal candidates in the primaries.

Officials of the city of Honolulu, Hawaii, .received yesterday seven bids here for a new issue of $500,000 of sewer bonds. A banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co. and including Blyth Co., Inc.; the Anglo-California National Bank and Dean Witter Co., submitted the highest of those bids, offering a price of 104.4019 for the bonds at the fixed rate of 3 per cent interest.

Mayor Hermann Neubacher has ordered Dollfuss Platz here renamed Hermann Goering Platz. It has been learned here that Frau Dollfuss, who is now in Switzerland as the guest of former Federal Councilor Musy, is going to Germany.

Lincoln Ellsworth, polar explorer, who is planning an exploration of the South Pole region on the Indian Ocean side, arrived yesterday at Floyd Bennett Field from his home near St. Johnsbury, Vt. Mr. Ellsworth will sail from New York July 26 on the first leg of his journey to Cape Town, where his motor ship the Wyatt Earp is moored.

Turpentine firm, 23 3/4c; sales, 48 barrels; receipts, 526 barrels; no shipments; stock, 41,185 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 489; receipts, 1,798; no shipments; stock, 176,006. Quote: B. $3.40; D. $3.75; E. $4; F. $4.40; G. H. I. K. $4.50; M, 44.52 1/2; N. $5.25; WG. $5.75; WW, $6.30; X, $6.40.

As PWA Administrator Hopkins issues another letter of warning against political activity on the part of his executives and supervisors, it may refresh the sociologist to take a peep at the moral plane of the campaign for Senator in Kentucky.

Passages from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's syndicated column will be brought together in a book and published by Dodge next month. The title will be "My Days." Longmans, Green announce -the publication next Winter of the first of a new series of books each about 30,000 words long.
Grover Whalen wouldn't be the man one takes him for if he hadn't invited the Olympic Congress to bring its games to the World's Fair site in 1940, just as soon as word came that Japan had withdrawn.

Archie Henderson completed the most important conquest of his budding tennis career today. Resuming play with the score 3-1 in his favor in the deciding set, the young North Carolina graduate from Chapel Hill went on to a clearly earned victory over Wilmer Allison, former national champion,

British officer was reported killed today as troops penetrated thick forests of the northwest frontier province, two miles from the cave headquarters of the Fakir of Ipi. One Indian soldier was reported killed and eight wounded.

Cannon St, 113, 20.9x100; Ambos Realty Corp to Kroywen Construction Corp, 110 William St. Rivington St, 332-4, 59.7x81.3; Margaret G. Gowdy to Ambos Realty Corp, deed dated July 9, 1935. 74th St, 53 E, 19x102.2; 53 East 74th St Corp to Marie A. Cowing, 82 elk Ave. New Rochelle, N. Y.; mtg $60,000. 114th St, 302 W, 26x100.11; Ruxton Estates, Inc, to Westman Estates, Inc, 475 5th Ave; mtg $33,342 ($7.50).
Edward Gusky, assistant general traffic manager of the Schenley Products Company, Inc., was appointed yesterday as general traffic manager, succeeding Andrew W. MacElveney, who died last week.

Berbee Dress Shop, store in 205 w 50th St; M. C. B., Inc, agent. Sam Katz's Sons, printers, about 9,000 sq ft, K. U. Mfg Corp, dresses, renewal of about 5,500 sq ft in 1,916-38 Park Ave; Arthur Eckstein, Inc, broker. Jesus Rodriguez, fruits and vegetables, store in 3,644 Broadway; Goe. R. Read Co, brokers.

Miss Clara Loomis Crane made specific bequests of $479,000 in her will filed today in the Berkshire Probate Court. Of the total, $149,000 will go to eighteen institutions. Beneficiaries of the three largest bequests of $20,000 each are the American Board of Foreign Missions, Berkshire County Home for Aged Women and House of Mercy Hospital. All told $58,000 goes to missionary organizations.

The 2,100 guardsmen of the Fiftyfourth Brigade, comprising the Headquarters Company, the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh) of Manhattan and the 108th Infantry of Syracuse, marched in review before their commander. Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson, at Camp Smith here today.
Blonde 20-year-old Miss Helen Waterhouse of Providence, R. I., today joined the list of rising golf stars who have won the Griswold Cup.

Department store sales for the week ended July 9 were 6 per cent lower than for the same week in 1937, dine with increases shown in four of the Federal Reserve districts, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney returned from New York today in time to be present at the opening of an exhibition of some of her sculpture at the Art Association. She was accompanied by Miss Gloria Vanderbilt, who is passing the Summer at the Whitney home.

The National Labor Relations Board ordered the Lone Star Bag and Bagging Company of Houston, texas, today to disestablish what it called a company-dominated union, cease giving effect to any contracts with this union and to reimburse its members for dues checked off from their wages.

Unfavorable weather conditions took toll of retail trade here last week and the percentage of decline under a year ago increased somewhat in comparison with preceding week. Department store trade, according to estimates, declined about 6 per cent in comparison with 1937, against 4.5 per cent in the preceding week.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market has developed a stronger tone again this week and the volume of business has developed in a large way. Prices are generally about 20 per cent above the low point of a month or so ago, good fine and fine medium, fair stapled wools bringing 65 cents, clean basis, now against about 55 cents then, with other grades proportionately up.
JUST by way of relaxation, Racing Secretary John Blanks Campbell and his ebullient assistant, Francis Dunne, were talking of horses and courses across the luncheon table at the Empire City Track.

Gambling indictments returned by the Nassau County grand jury on Wednesday against five operators of the midget automobile raceway at Roosevelt Field were dismissed by County Court Justice Cortland A. Johnson here this afternoon after the defendants promised District Attorney Edward J. Neary that the purse participation plan for speculating on the races would be permanently discontinued.

Miss Helen Lader, daughter of Mrs. Ludwig Lader of 12 East Eighty-sixth Street and the late Mr. Lader, was married here yesterday to Richard C. Weil of New York and Paris, son of Paul C. Well of Paris and the late Mrs. Weil. The ceremony was performed by Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the Supreme Court in his chambers. Both Mr. Weil and his bride were unattended.

Today's cattle market was a slow, draggy affair, with prices at the low point of the week. A considerable portion of today's small supply was carried for Monday's market without dependable bids, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs regained most of Thursday's losses when supplies were sharply curtailed. Lambs showed very little change.

A decrease of 12.4 per cent in total sales of retail stores last month as compared with June, 1937, was reported today by the National Retail Credit Association. Reductions of 10 per cent in credit sales and 4.8 per cent in collections

Thanks to the kindly assistance from the elements and a substantial lift from Connie Mack's Athletics, the Yankees are resting comfortably at the head of the American League, a game and a half in front of the Indians. With 17,614 fans at the Stadium yesterday, including 7,575 ladies' day guests, rain interrupted the struggle between the Tigers and Yanks in the sixth inning.

The Industrial Rayon Corporation has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $7,500,000 of first mortgage sinking fund bonds series A, due July 1, 1948, fixing the interest rate at 4 1/2 per cent and naming underwriters and allotments.

Tenant families who have received notice to vacate nearly 400 buildings in the path of three highway improvement projects in Brooklyn have been having difficulty in finding cheap apartments elsewhere, despite the fact that the New York City Housing Authority has opened a field office to help them.
Investigators will be sent into Kentucky, Pennsylvania and Tennessee to look into charges of wrongful use of funds and other abuses in connection with the Senatorial races in those States.

In praising one of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's prosecutors for saving a youth from indictment as a hold-up man, Magistrate Frank Oliver in Felony Court also spoke yesterday of "buck-passing" magistrates and called for closer cooperation-between the grand jury and the magistrates, instead of the "tension and strain" that he said existed at present.

The arrival of mid-July, generally the slowest period of the theatrical year, finds the Broadway stage fare pared down to seven dramatic shows and two musicals, this after the closing tonight of "Room Service" with a record of 496 performances and. "The Two Bouquets" with fifty-five.

Miss Mi Elizabeth Louise Dobson, daughter an of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Lyon Dobson of Downingtown, has completed plans for her marriage to George Lupton Broomall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Broomall of Germantown.

Arthur Fagg, 23-year-old Kent professional, scored two double centuries against Essex in a county champtionship match concluded today to set a world record in first-class cricket that leading batsmen have been aiming at for years.

Dr. Harold J. Durant of this city died here today of typhoid fever in St. Joseph's Hospital, where he was a member of the surgical staff. He was 41 years old. A graduate of Tufts College and Medical School,

Under any circumstances the reporters couldnot help speaking of tall, lean, lanky, gangling Howard Hughes, because that is what he is. The thing stands out all the more prominently when we are speaking of a champion flier, a bird man.

Richard M. Smith, editor of The Arlington (Va.) Courier, stated in his weekly today that he had repaid $500--to Representative Howard L. Smith. following a letter in which Representative -Smith, a relative,

Harlow Mason, 55 years old, of San Francisco, Calif., who is a stenographer in the United States Embassy at Rome, was set upon here by two thugs early this morning while on his way to a hotel and beaten into unconsciousness.

Eddie Foy, husky ex-Kingsley athlete and former New Jersey interscholastic golf champion, and his Essex Fells partner, Dr. Stephen G. Lee Jr., shot a three-under-par 69 to capture the qualifying medal in the sixth annual New Jersey amateur best-ball golf champtionship today at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.

Hurrying to a parade apparently is a letdown after speeding around the world, for Howard Hughes, tired of sticking to a flight schedule, kept every one who wanted to honor him waiting yesterday while he dictated a speech, got rid of his five-day beard and found a comb with fine enough teeth to suit him.
Bonds turned strong yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace was the slowest in almost a month, with total transactions $5,212,000, compared with $6,977,500 on Thursday.

The following are some of the books of a religious nature that recently have been published: LAYMEN SPEAKING, by George Morlan. (Smith, $2.50.) A study of listeners' reactions to sermons. Dr. Morlan interviewed a representative cross-section of people, including such personalities as Sally Rand, Senator Nye, Fannie Brice, Booth Tarkington, John L. Lewis and other well-known and lessknown individuals.

The United States Maritime Commission announced today that it has declined to withhold approval of the increase from 20 cents to 25 cents a 100 pounds, minimum weight 40,000 pounds, in rates on cottonseed cake and meal from Texas Gulf ports to North Atlantic ports, filed to become effective on July 1.

The Italian press today does not give as great prominence as might have been expected to yesterday's report on the race problem. In Rome morning. papers printed the report on inside pages while noon and afternoon papers limited themselves to brief abstracts of foreign press comments.

After two years of war, the military situation in Spain still seems so far from a decisive end that the army does not know exactly what to do with Lieut. Col. Henry B. Cheadle, who has been appointed the new American military attache in Spain.

180th St (11-3108), s s, 50 ft w of Southern Blvd, 49x79,; Bertram L. Kraus Jr. to Joanna E. Hallenbeck, trustee, 478 Gramatan Ave, Mount Vernon; mtg $28,000. Glennon Pl (18-5526), nw s. 332 ft sw of 177th St, 27x100; Julia Leer to William F. Porth, 3,237 Glennon Pl. Seton Ave. 3,864 (17-4939); Railrod Federal Savings and Loan Association to Mario Bernardini, 685 E 233d St.

William Rhodes Davis, whose name was recently mentioned in connection with Mexican oil deals, is among the defendants against whom allegations of conspiracy and fraud were made in an action before the Kings Bench Division of the High Court here, which will reach its twelfth day of trial Monday.
Miss Laddie Irwin, youthful Glen Ridge golfer, scored an 84 over the Knickerbocker Country Club course today to take first place in a oneday event of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association.

Part of an $11,300 payroll was stolen today from the president of the Aurora Construction Company at the site of a building under construction here by two bandits carrying a sawed-off shotgun and a pistol.

Although the grain trade generally had been under the impression that the Department of Agriculture in accordance with the Agricultural Adjustment Act passed at the last session of Congress would reduce drastically the acreage to be sown to wheat for the next crop, the establishment of the allotment at 55,000,000 acres, the minimum allowed, came as a surprise.

The Italian motor ship Conte di Savoia is due to sail today for Mediterranean ports. The passenger list includes Mr. and Mrs. George W. Davison, Rear Admiral Fitzhugh Green, U.S.N. (retired), and Mrs. Green, Mr. and Mrs. B. A. PennypacKser, Mrs. Gloria Spreckels, Townsend Martin, William M. Milliken,

A prediction that the furniture industry would see its greatest activity since 1930 through the balance of the year was made tonight by Joseph H. Lane of Chattanooga, president of the board of governors of the American Furniture Mart, as exhibitors were preparing to close their July displays tomorrow.

Holding that the earmarking of tax revenues for special purposes was "absolutely unsound," the Constitutional Convention's Committee on State Finances, through its chairman, Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, urged today the defeat of the Feinberg

A special benediction has been bestowed upon the National Broadcasting Company by Pope Pius XI, in recognition of its "invaluable cooperation" in relaying the Pontiff's message to the national Eucharistic Congress of Canada, recently held at Quebec.

Former President of the Gordon Lingerie Corporation' Julius Gordon, formerly president of the Gordon Lingerie Corporation, with offices at 99 Madison Avenue, died early yesterday morning at his home, 17 Park Avenue, of a heart attack. He was 49 years old. Born and educated in New York, Mr. Gordon entered the silk underwear business as a young man.

Norman J. Macdonald of 119 Avenue C, Brooklyn, former first deputy superintendent of banks, died on Thursday of a fractured skull received a week ago when he was struck by a baseball, batted while he was watching a game in the Prospect Park Parade Grounds.
The United States committee investigating labor conditions abroad finished its work in Britain today and prepared to leave tomorrow for Sweden, where it- will continue its investigations.

Democratic, Republican and Progressive party "viewpoints" on the state of the country and what should be done about it were presented tonight at the final mass meeting of this year's Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

By earmarking today $23,000,000 for loans to the New York Housing Authority, Nathan Straus, United States Housing Administrator, raised to $53,000,000 the total of Federal funds which will be devoted to slumclearance work in that city alone.

Ogden Ave (9-2526), w s. 107 ft s of Union P1, 74x264; Costen Theatre Corp to Hellenic Bank Trust Co; installments, 5 per cent; $57,500. 163d St. 290 E (9-2422); Ada M. Walsh to Dollar Savings Bank; extends mtgs to July 13, 1943, at 5 per cent; $18 000.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Winterfield Baldwin, one of the oldest ministers in the Methodist Episcopal Church and the last surviving member of the Yale class of 1861, died today at Maryland General Hospital. His age was 98.

Howard Hughes's address at City Hall, as transcribed by the National Broadcasting Company, follows: I haven't a great deal to say about this, because I am afraid I might get a little nervous and not say just what I want to.

Miss Georgiana Jane Twitmyer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin B. Twitmyer of Penn Acre, Secane, was married this evening to Dr. Frank James Davies, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Davies of Media. The ceremony was performed at Penn acre.

Columbus Ave. 785, 5-story tenement, 25 x 74; North River Savings Bank against Arthur Otten, due, $22,580; to plaintiff for $15,000. By EDWIN . McDONALD Grand St, 494-8, 5 and 6-story factory, 50 x80; Merchants and Neward Trust Co. against Meyer London, Inc. due $15,365, taxes, , $5,453; to plaintiff for $1,000.

By dint of great perseverance and no end of perspiring, the Giants today accomplished a monumental task. For though it was still insufferably hot and the Reds were even hotter, they succeeded in cooling Bill McKechnie's inspired Cincinnatians sufficiently to bag their only victory of the three-game series, 3 to 2, while a capacity crowd of 27,443 groaned in dismay.
Announcement of the official time yesterday cut 8 minutes 50 seconds from Howard R. Hughes's unofficial record round the world.

Gerald F. Finley of 120 Broadway was named yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer to assess the damages to be paid the Busch Jewelry Company and its affiliates by Local 208 of the Optical Workers Union,- a C. 1. 0. union, for alleged--breach of contract.
Crops throughout Canada are approaching their maturity in a most promising condition, according to the Bank of Montreal.
A windwhipped 15,000-acre forest fire raged close to Ryderwood, "world's largest logging camp," today, and a few persons left the town of 1,200 population.

Maxie Berger, Canadian lightweight champion, gained a decision over Phil Baker of Norwalk, Conn., in the main attraction of eight rounds last night at the Coney Island Velodrome. The bout was keenly waged throughout. The victor floored his rival for a nine-coupt in the opening session, the only knockdown of the contest. Each scaled 1391/2 pounds.

An official of a defendant coal firm testified in the Harlan anti-labor conspiracy trial today that it was only incidental when the company learned who was a union man and who wasn't, because it made no effort to find out.

The marriage of Miss Theodora-H. Cornell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Martense Cornell of this city, to S. Lloyd Sammis of Naugatuck, Conn., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hewitt S. Sammis of Huntington, L. I., took place this afternoon in the Friends' Meeting House. The ceremony was performed by th Rev. Wilbur W. Kamp of North Ware, N. H., according to the rites of the Presbyterian Church.

The supreme commander of the Red air fleet, Vice Commissar of War Alexander D. Loktionoff, declares in an article written by him that fast, longrange Soviet flights are being made by "ordinary military and naval planes made under mass production conditions in Soviet factories."

Although taxation without representation was one of the issues on which our forefathers fought the Revolutionary War, our States have never been able to agree on a scheme of legislative representation within their own borders which completely satisfied everybody.

About 400 persons attended the opening play tonight in the series of eight to be presented in the John Drew Memorial Theatre this season by the Studio Players. Principal parts in "The Warrior's Husband" were taken by Miss Alicia Maiden, Miss Jane Vosper, Walter Brooke, Barnet Biro and' Ernest Kovacs.

Hearings in the complaint' aspet of the. National Labor Relations Board's case against the Bethlehem Steel Corporation: were closed' today- by a stipulation which ,is expected to save five months of time and 20,000- pages of testimony.
The Rebels gained more ground today in the Sarrion sector, where intense fighting continues. At the coastal end of the eastern front the Loyalists held the initiative and again gained some positions.

The Rev. Dr. Shailer Mathews, dean emeritus of the University of Chicago Divinity School, will preach tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock at the vesper service for Summer students at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

The first crossing of the North Atlantic by the airplane Mercury, upper unit of the Short-Mayo Composite aircraft, will be attempted next Wednesday. Around nightfall the composite aircraft, with Captain D. C. T. Bennett at the controls of the Mercury and Captain A. S. Wilcockson in the flying boat Maia,

A small advance in wheat futures early today was followed by a sinking spell which carried the active deliveries to the lowest levels since June 3. The close was at the bottom with net losses on the Board of Trade here of 1 3/8 to 1% cents a bushel.

Buck Ross won his fourth game of the season for the Athletics today, gaining a .5-to-4-victory over the Indians when his team-mates rallied for three runs with two out in the eighth. The Indians broke a 2-2 tie in their half of the eighth when Hal Trosky doubled to score Jeff Heath and Earl Averill.

Declaring that the district should be represented by some one in sympathy with the New Deal and that there was "no hope in the Republican party," Owen Johnson, novelist, today announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Representative in Congress. Nominated two years ago,

One of the biggest and best balanced fields seen in a handicap this year is scheduled to go to the post today in the $20,000 added Butler Handicap, richest stake of the Empire City meeting. Track conditions, which were slow, sloppy and muddy at the Hilltop by turns yesterday, are likely to play a large part in the outcome.

Comprehensive record cards, on which every phase of the pupil's life will be noted, are to be introduced in the New York City school system this Fall, Dr. Paul A. Kennedy, assistant superintendent of schools, announced yesterday.

Purchase of up to 52;000,000 pounds of s butter was authorized today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration. Purchases will be made by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation over the present fiscal year ending on June 30, 1939.

Joseph Shadgen of Jackson Heights, who asserts he originated the idea of the New York World's Fair and who is now suing the New York World's Fair, 1939, Inc., and George McAneny, former president of the corporation, for $1,000,000 each for alleged damages, won the first round in his legal battle yesterday in a decision handed down by Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. in the Special Term of the Queens Supreme Court.

The first general gains in business since October were reported today for June in a general survey of Milwaukee commerce and industry by the research bureau of the Association of Commerce. Total for the first half of 1937 showed 80 per cent greater activity than the low in the first half of the depression year of 1933.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that Sugar delivered under the control law in the first six months of this year amounted to 2,825,223 short tons, raw value, against 3,249,149 in the comparable period last year.

The Pennsylvania Superior Court upheld today the action of the State Public Service Commission in refusing to approve the sale of the Northern Pennsylvania Power Company to the Metropolitan Edison Company.

Maurice McCarthy, 31-year-old Cincinnati businessman once rated among America's outstanding golfers, bounded back today in a challenge for the Western amateur title after a lapse of eight years from major competition.

Approval of the application of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company for permission to borrow $2,500,000 for operating expenses was recommended today by Howard Benton Lewis, special master, who conducted hearings on the request.

More than 100 presidents of colleges and universities throughout the United States have accepted membership in the educational division of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, it was announced yesterday.
Federal Judge Harland B. Howe today notified L. G. Morphy, receiver of the Rutland Railroad, that the court would not allow the receiver "to operate the railroad many days at a loss of $2,400 a day."
The Holyoke team headed by Sam O'Connell tonight won the team of four title of the Southern New England contract bridge championships, nosing out two other New England combinations.

The recently elected Congress of the Russian Socialist Federated Soviet Republic, largest republic in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, met in the Kremlin today. Unlike the congress of the U.S.S.R., which has two houses-the Soviet of the Union

Soviet troops have crossed the eastern Manchukuoan border and have began the erection of minor fortifications, the newspaper Asahi alleges. They were reported to have occupied Shanfang, twenty-five miles south of Hunchun and nearly two miles inside Manchukuo.

Describing aviation as "a blessing in peace time and a curse in time of war," Mayor La Guardia told Howard Hughes and his four aides at City Hall yesterday that their round-the-world flight had shown the peoples of various countries how closely they were linked by air transportation.

E. F. Dobson, Annapolis, established two world marks with his Watersprite to take top honors in a field of eighty crack drivers entered in the Havre de Grace Yacht Club's ninth annual speed-boat regatta, which opened today.

The War Department is preparing legislation to be presented to the next session of Congress designed to increase the flow of promotion in the army and to eliminate the war-time "hump" which is causing what is increasingly serious stagnation in the officer list.

The Army and Navy Union announced today it would award its Ace Pilot's Medal to Howard Hughes for his round-the-world flight. The medal is awarded annually to the pilot performing the year's noteworthy aviation achievement.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 13: COMMANDERS Rogers, E. C., to duty as Director of Naval Reserve, 4th Naval District. Bowman, D. O., Med. Corps, Naval Academy, to the Wyoming, Aug. 20.

William E. Dalton, chief clerk of the Board of Transportation, died yesterday at his home, 304 St. John's Place, Brooklyn. He was 54 years old. Born in Brooklyn, he was educated in private schools and St. Francis Xavier College.

A total of 496 cities and towns of the United States are actively participating in the National Salesmen's Crusade, or are definitely interested in the movement, according to figures issued yesterday by Sam C. Mitchell, director of advertising and sales promotion
Two California youths, John Kramer of Los Angeles and Charles Olewine of Santa Monica, will battle tomorow for the national junior interscholastic tennis championship.
New bond financing this week dropped off to $36,399,000 from $95,005,000 last week. A year ago this week new issues for only $14,399,000 were offered.

Frederick A. Heisley, attorney and former Episcopal clergyman, died yesterday in his home here. He was 72 years old. He was graduated from New York Law School and was admitted to the New Jersey bar in 1893,

A1though they made five errors, the Cardinals won their first game in nine starts today, beating the Bees, 10 to 6. St. Louis was off to an early lead of 6 to 2, but Lefty Bob Weiland weakened in the sixth and allowed three runs. He gave way to Bill McGee in the seventh after yielding one more tally.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 9 amounted to 501,013 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 87,851 cars, or 14.9 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 177.945 cars, or 26.2 per cent,

Aspects of intergroup cooperation will be discussed this afternoon at the opening of a two-day conference on intercultural education for teachers at Riverside Church, under the sponsorship of the National Conference of Jews and Christians. More than 500 religious educators, visiting teachers and college leaders are scheduled to attend.

Directors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amended today the exchange's bylaws to prevent election of an "automatic ticket" at the annual meetings. In the past the nominating committee has selected a ticket which was elected without opposition.

About 400 members of the United Sugar Workers Union, Local 151, an affiliate of the. C. I. O., began a stay-in strike at the National Sugar Refinery Company's plant here today and were still in possession of the plant tonight, although the number of strikers in- the refinery had been reduced voluntarily to about twenty-five.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against BLUMBERG BLOCK, ING., clothing, 100 Canal St., by Admor Clothes, Inc., for upward of $200; S. B. Specialty Co., Inc., upward of $200; Louis Paley, as Regal Clothing Co., upward of $200. CHOW MEIN INN., Inc., 800 7th Ave., by Charles F. Appel on a claim for $7,436.

Lawrence E. Kirwin, owner of the L. E. K. Oil Company of Garden City, and president of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Hempstead died today of a heart attack at his country home at Mattituck, L. I.

More than 200 of the leaders in the newspaper, magazine, newsreel and radio fields from all parts of the nation assembled here tonight for the opening of the fifth annual Headliners Frolic, sponsored by the Press Club of Atlantic City.
Pensioned On police surgeon's certificate. To take effect 12 noon, July 16: PATROLMAN-Frank J. Agnew, 75th Precinct, at $1,164 per annum. Appointed Jan. 17, 1923.

Today's news from this precinct must have been cheering to Colonel William Harold Terry and his Giants. The Dodgers, still smarting under yesterday's defeat, turned on the Pirates and won, 9-4, with a thirteenhit barrage good for twenty-one bases.

The stock markets were quiet today under end-of-the-account influences and yesterday's setback in Wall Street, but a closing rally took prices above the day's lowest levels. Gilt-edge securities shared in the late recovery, but foreign bonds were dull.

John R. Dalton, secretary to Municipal Court Justice John M. Braisted and former member of the old Board of Aldermen, died last night at his home, 52 Harrison Avenue, Port Richmond, S. I., following a heart attack. He was 53 years old.

Although there has been a substantial increase in governmental projects and public works, the rise in these classifications has been insufficient to offset the decided decline in private construction awards during the past six months.
President Roosevelt did not overstate the case at San Francisco when he warned the nations of the world that if the race in armaments is continued at its present pace it can lead only to disaster.

Miss Mollie Page, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Page of County Line Farm in the West Hills Colony, and New York, was married to Anderson Fowler Hewitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shepard Hewitt of New York and Lloyd Harbor, this afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church here.

Special-opportunity classes, conducted experimentally for 600 pupils in twenty New York City elementary schools, have proved successful in making boys who "hated" school enjoy their studies and ask for more homework, Dr.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Martin Anderson, oldest member of the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference, died today at the home of his son, William D; Anderson, 185 Essex Avenue. His age was 84. He was a resident of Bernardsville and for the last six weeks had been visiting his son.
Stocks fractionally higher in dullest trading since June 17; turnover, 933,010 shares. Bonds generally higher, with traction group strong; transactions, $5,212,500, smallest in a month.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and country bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Fall buying gained further momentum in the principal wholesale markets this week as retailers' inventories dwindled and price advances on some lines and expected mark-ups on others forced many to cover requirements earlier than had been planned, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court here denied today a petition for the stay of an order for closing eighty-eight railroad stations of the New York, New Haven Hartford system in Massachusetts.
A summons was served tonight on W. Perkins Bull, K. C., to appear at an inquest into the death of Mrs. Mabelle Horlick Sidley, malted milk heiress, who died at his home here on July 6.

Little Pat, 5-year-old son of Hollyrood Bob and Lottie Direct, owned by the Biery Farms of Butler, Pa., captured the free-for-all pace, ture event today on the getaway card of the Grand Circuit meeting at Historic Track. Little Pat,

The War De- Capt. apartment released the following orders today, dated July 14: MAJOR GENERAL Embick, S. D., General Staff Corps, seven days' leave, July 14. COLONELS Fuqua, S. O. (Infantry), Ordnance Department, two months' leave, Nov. 1.

MANHATTAN ANDREW, MARGUERITE (June 22). Estate, more than $10,000. To Augusta Pullman, cousin, 2,320 Broadway, specific securities; Mary Lou Rue, Freehold, N. J., $1,000 and seal coat; Ada Childs Bacon, 440 Riverside Dr., $1,000; Thomas G. Smith, Greenport, L. I., about $10,000;

An increase of $2,187,000 in deposits of chartered banks was shown today in the statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended on Wednesday. Dominion Government deposits decreased $9,463,000. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 56.18 per cent, compared to 56.82 a week before.

Trading was generally slow in the local markets yesterday. Some carried over lamb carcasses were sharply lower but freshly slaughtered meat was steady. Lamb cuts were weak to sharply lower. Pork loins were sharply lower and some cow sales 50c off. Other classes were mostly unchanged. Early kosher business was slow and prices were little changed from Thursday. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Willie Turnesa sank a 25-foot putt for a birdie on the twenty-second green of the- water-logged Quaker Ridge course today and eliminated from the New York State. amateur championship Ray Billows, the defending titleholder, 1 up, on this fourth extra hole.
Mrs Walter Kemble Yarrow of Lombardie, Rosemont, has announced B the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jacqueline Elizabeth-Walker to Charles Augustus Ernst of Ridley Park and Maryland.

Chester H. Aldrich, director of the American Academy in Rome, and Miss Amey Aldrich, have ar, rived on the Conte di Savoia, accompanied by John Walker, also of the American Academy, and Lady Margaret Walker, daughter of Lord Perth, the British Ambassador to Italy.

Bob (Lefty) Grove's temper flared as of old tonight as feeling and pulse returned to his numbed pitching arm. Grove, improving steadily as the blood vessel spasms quieted in his effective salary wing, became irritated when Dr. Edward J. O'Brien, Red Sox physician, advised him to remain in St. Elizabeth's Hospital a second night.
Go on a Summer diet, avoid iced beverages, and keep your windows closed all day. That is the way to keep cool, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, advised yesterday.
Four members of a gang of criminals who decoyed women to hotel rooms, where they beat and robbed them of furs and gems, were sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by General Sessions Judge Collins.

The British Government told taxpayers today it cost them $1,753 to give former King Edward VIII, now the Duke of Windsor, his new dukedom and title. Supplementary civil estimates issued today included an item for f350 for stamp duties on "royal warrant,

Liquidation by Bombay straddle interests created more selling pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices worked off 10 points at one time. As the near months approached the 81/2-cent level, however, resistance developed and an afternoon upturn in the stock market stimulated covering, which erased all the earlier losses and left quotations 1 point lower to 1 point higher than on Thursday.

This being the season for "firing" managers of fading ball clubs, rumors boomed today over the graying head of Charlie Grimm. "Charlie will manage the team at least until tomorrow," said Owner P. K. Wrigley with a smile as he emerged from his latest conference with Grimm.

In the only singles match that was completed before a drenching downpour made play impossible, Frank Guernsey, national intercollegiate champion, reached the semifinals of the New York State claycourt tennis championship at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, yesterday when he defeated Gerard Podesta, Princeton captain-elect, 6-4, 6-3.

Miss Janet Elizabeth Thorn, daughter of commander Benjamin Thorn of the United States Coast Guard, was married today to Ensign Russell R. Waesche Jr., son of Rear Admiral Waesche, commandant of the Coast Guard, and Mrs. Waesche.
A Japanese mission touring South America and headed by Zoji Amari, visited President Arturo Alessandri here today. The mission was accompanied by Japanese diplomatic representatives to this country.

E. F. Walker, secretary treasurer of the Rhode Island Textile Association, asserted in a statement today that "widely scattered but important groups of Southern cotton mills" had started within two weeks "wage cuts of 16 to 20 per cent."
The Home Ministry informed the Cabinet today that the recent flood damage was estimated at approximately 270,000,000 yen in the Kobe area and 150,000,000 yen in the Tokyo area.

The administrative committee of the American Labor party took yesterday the first step in selecting a slate for Representatives in Congress, disapproved the candidacy of one Democratio Representative,

John Vincent Braga, publisher of the Official Steamship and Airways Guide in New York, received a summons yesterday to appear in court here Tuesday evening to answer a charge of violating the village's aniti-shorts ordinance enacted last May. Mr. Braga, who is 47 years old and a resident of Manhasset, received the summons from a Nassau County patrolman when he came here to make a purchase.

A 31-year-old Negro was arrested early last night aboard the 40-foot cabin cruiser The Dove, after a chase up the Hudson River by a Coast Guard patrol boat, and accused of stealing the $14,000 boat from the foot of Lawrence Street in Lawrence, L. I., at 9 o'clock yesterday morning.

The Park Department and the Long Island State Park Commission are negotiating with four producers to put on vaudeville shows for the rest of this summer at Randalls Island Stadium and at Jones Beach, to replace the operetas that will end their run after tomorrow night's performances, it was learned yesterday.

As the House of Commons gave final approval without a dissenting vote yesterday to a year's British arms outlay of [Pound]350,000,000, Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, warned that civilization might perish "if every country goes on piling up armaments forever and ever."

The Interstate Commerce Commission, hearing the South's application for lower northbound freight rates, was asked late today to withdraw wooden furniture from the list of commodities involved in the proceedings.

Easter lilies, cybotium ferns and white gladioluses predominated in the floral decorations in St. Joseph's Church here for the marriage this afternoon of Miss Janet Ward Malley to William Ranulf Compton. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Matthew F. Grady of this city.

Representative Thomas A. Jenkins of Ohio, a Republican member of the Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority, issued a statement tonight attacking the agency as an extravagant waste of the taxpayers' money and demanding a cessation of large expenditures on its program.

J. Howard Miller, deputy director of the Federal Theatre Project, will lecture on Aug. 1 to students at the Mount Holyoke Summer School of Speech, according to the director of the Summer session, Mrs. Alice W. Mills.

The postponed performance of Bizet's "Carmen" was given last night at Lewisohn Stadium before an audience of 9,000 persons. It was a presentation of the exacting opera that in every respect cast great credit on all concerned. Rain, which had caused the cancellation of the staging of the work the previous evening, again threatened to interfere yesterday.

Due to economic conditions, the Princeton Savings Bank, established in 1873, is preparing to dissolve within six months. A diminishing yield from safe investments and the risk of depreciation of investment values were given by the board of managers as the reasons for dissolution.

Sandy Davenport captured the singles final in the Lake Mohonk Tennis Club tournament today when Jerry Lang defaulted with the tally at 2-all after 3-6, 6-8, 7-5, 6-4 sets. Davenport paired with Kelleher to defeat Evans and McDermott, 6-4, 7-5, 6-2, .for the doubles honors.

On the person of Howard Hughes more than 2,000,000 pairs of eyes were trained yesterday as New York City, famous for its prodigal demonstrations, gave him a lustythroated welcome, garnished by more ticker tape than greeted even Charles A. Lindbergh on his triumphal return.

The Johns-Manville Corporation reported yesterday for the three months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $214,578, equal after preferred dividend requirements to 10 cents each on the 850,000 shares of common stock outstanding.

The purge of the so-called "communistic elements" of the United Auto Workers of America, begun a month ago by Homer Martin, president of the union, has been extended to North Tarrytown where 2,000 auto workers are emplayed in two General Motors plants, it was learned today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission postponed today from July 15 to Aug. 15 the effective date of its order granting the application of the Adams Express Company to withdraw its no-par value common stock from listing on the Boston Stock Exchange.

After losing two games in a row to Buffalo, league-leading Newark walloped the Bisons, 13 to 8, tonight and dropped them from second to fourth place in the standings. Led by Jimmy Gleeson, who belted three doubles, the Bears rocked four Buffalo pitchers for sixteen hits.
Arthur N. Block of Speyer Co., president of the Corporation Bond Traders Club, will sail today on the Conte di Savoia to pass two months in Europe.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Ordered to Camp Dix Each of the following reserve officers, effective July 24: Major William E. McGuire, Inf-Res., 219 Park Ave., Passaic, N. J. Major Hugo E. Mayer, FA-Res., 473 Morris Ave., Elizabeth, N. J. Major Harry Meisels, FA-Res., 286 N. Broad St., Elizabeth, N. J.

A three-year agreement, barring strikes and lockouts and retaining present wage scales, was reached today by the negotiating committees representing the Full Fashioned Hosiery Manufacturers of America and the American Federation of Hosiery Workers.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of Frank E. Bliss has been transferred to Walter F. Burke. Proposals have been made for the transfer of the following memberships:

Whether incorporation of the League to Amend the National Labor Relations Act, Inc., will be permitted is the question presented today to Supreme Court Justice Russell. The Board of Standards and Appeals has denied certification and has directed a public hearing.

Increase in June Is Reported by Manufacturers The consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in June amounted to 30,629 long tons, compared with 28,947 in May and 51,860 in June, 1937, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Gross imports in June were 26,011 tons, against 27,410 in May and 48,956 in June, last year.

Thomas Hovey Gage, former president of the Massachusetts Bar Association, died today at his home here at the age of 73. His brother, Dr. Homer Gage, died on July 4. Mr. Gage was born in Worcester and received his law degree from Harvard in 1889.

After two of the most spectacular semi-final round matches in the twenty-one-year history of the Professional Golfers Association championship, Sam Snead, golfdom's- latest toast, and little Paul Runyan, one of the world's finest short game experts, will meet tomorrow to determine who is to succeed Denny Shute as America's match play king.

Raymond H. Torrey, a botanist and conservationist who was for many years engaged in newspaper and publicity work in New York, died of a heart ailment last night in his home, 99-28 193d Street, Hollis, Queens. Mr. Torrey, who was 58 years old, had been ill since February.
A Labor Department order fixed wage schedules today for employes of conserns manufacturing luggage, including mail sacks and pouches for sale to the Federal Government.

The new Farm Act requires the Government to lend money to farmers under present conditions in order to enable those who choose to do so to hold their wheat off the world market until the price is more to their liking.
Louis Condit Hay of 625 Park Ave: nue, New York, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange. died today at his Summer home here after a long illness. His age .was 78.

The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after taxes and charges, of $7,444,935. This was equal to $5.85 a share on the 1,272,260 shares of capital stock outstanding and compares with a net of $10,841,574, or $8.52 a capital share, in the twelve months to June 30, 1937.

Relays of bombing planes and shell-fire from navy guns raked the Lion Hill forts yesterday as the Japanese Yangtze River offense remained stalled below Kiukiang, 135 miles from Hankow, Chinese provisional capital.

Yoshio Nazu, 16-year-old machinist aprentice, was hit and instantly killed near here today by an automobile driven by Frank S. Williams, United States commercial attache at Toyko. The police said it was an accident and allowed Mr. Williams to continue his trip to Nikko, but held his cook,

The city submitted to the Treasury Department in Washington yesterday a bid of $1 for the purchase of the old postoffice and court house on lower Broadway, and as it was the only bid submitted approval by the Treasury is expected, giving the city the right to proceed at last with demolition of the building.

It is understood that President Roosevelt has asked George Rublee, a Washington lawyer, to serve as American director of the permanent refugee organization soon to be established in London as a result of the conference at Evian-les-Bains, France.

Mrs. Alma Wallach Liebmannr of New York and Armonk, wife of Alfred Liebmann, vice president and treasurer of the Liebmann Breweries, Inc., died here today at her country estate, Woodheath Farm, at the age of 56. She had been suffering from a heart ailment for a week.
Prince Paul, Regent of Yugoslavia, conferred medals on America's tennis aces, Don Budge and Gene Mako, following a series of Yugoslav exhibitions which ended yesterday.

A freak wind, hail and rainstorm twisted across Monmouth County, N. J., yesterday morning, and in twenty minutes it caused damage unofficially estimated at $200,000 as it flattened crops, carried away wooden shelters, unroofed some buildings and uprooted trees. Only one minor injury was reported.
This may be St. Swithin's Day to the rest of the country, but it is just a barometric pain to the Weather Bureau.

The International Wheat Advisory Committee voted today to recommend to its sixteen constituent governments to take some action to meet the threat of an enormous world harvest that looms over the present world wheat picture with the threat of a repetition of the disastrous prices of 1931.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Martin Van Harlingen C of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Keas- In bey Van Harlingen, to Benjamin Graham of Montclair, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Graham of Montclair, and grandson of the late Joseph Jefferson, the actor.

Improved prospects for retail trade in the Fall will find reflection in department store linage, but favorable comparisons with a year ago may not develop before October, authorities here said yesterday.
Sydney Rayner, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, who gave his address as 149 East Sixtieth Street, filed yesterday a petition in bankruptcy listing no assets and liabilities of $14,519.

" A more equal distribution of poverty throughout the world" has resulted from increased nationalism and the stifling of international trade, A. Manuel Fox of the United States Tariff Commission said today at the Summer Institute for Social Progress at Wellesley.

Under an agreement through which the workers get a closed shop but give up their demands for increased pay 227 employes of the Irvington Smelting and Refining Company returned to work today after a three-week strike.

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 18 represented 18.57 per cent of total volume, compared with 20.50 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Every country in the world proclaims to high heaven that it does not choose to arm. The run-around is only too familiar. Practically every nation in Europe is piling up defenses against Germany, and the Germans say they were forced to resume their liberty to arm because they were surrounded by an "iron ring" of armed neighbors.

New life insurance production-for the first six months of 1938 was 22.6 per cent below the corresponding half of 1937 and the total for June was 27.5 per cent less than for June last year, according to the reports to the Association of Life Insurance President by forty companies having 82 per cent of the total life insurance outstanding in all United States legal reserve companies.

To Sports Editor of The Nego York Times. A recent letter in your column called attention to the fact that St. Louis and Philadelphia were unable or unwilling to support two major league teams and suggested that one of the teams be taken from these towns and placed elsewhere.

ALEXANDER-Joseph, of Nanticoke, Pa., on July 15, at West Chester, Pa., at home of his sister Bertha Margolies, beloved brother of Max, Alex, Leo, Herman, Hilda and Rose Freudenthal, Bertha Margolies and Gertrude Green. Funeral Sunday, July 17, at 1:30 P. M., daylight time. at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Cypress Hills, Brooklyn.

American Capital Corporation-Six months to June 30: On the basis of securities owned adjusted to market prices at close of period, and after allowing for prior-preference stock at its liquidating value and for accrued dividends thereon, net assets were equal to $30.26 a share on the 97,000 nopar-shares of $3 preferred stock outstanding.

Dr. Douglas Hyde, President of Ireland, suffered shock and slight injuries today in an automobile accident near Athlone. Dr. Hyde was born in 1860, but always has refused to disclose the day and month.

Workers on the wharf of the Jamaica Fruit and Shipping Company struck today after two workers were discharged. However, a settlement was reached later in the day by representatives of the management and workers.

Earnings of the Herald Square Building, at 1,350 Broadway, for the six months ended April 30, 1938, amounted to $347,563, against $317,220 for the same period of 1936-37, according to a report by Seligman, Lubetkin Co., Inc. Net income available for mortgage charges, Federal taxes and depreciation

THE two eternal questions asked the young man or the young woman looking for a job, Ernest and Betty Lindley found when they started touring the country and talking to the young people themselves, are: "Where have you worked before?" "How long did you go to school?" And one 18-year-old boy with whom they talked summed up his own experiences by saying:
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today a national wheat acreage allotment for 1939 of 55,000,000 acres, the minimum that could be allotted under the new Farm Act of 1938.

Attacking former Representative Vito Marcantonio as "a tool of the Communist party" whose candidacy for the American Labor party nomination for Congress from the Twentieth Congressional District "is a further attempt by the Communist party to dominate labor unions,"

Arthur F. Warde, veteran theatrical manager and son of the late Frederick B. Warde, noted Shakespearean actor, died on Wednesday at his h6me, 1,900 Albermarle Road, Brooklyn, after a two months' illness. He was 66 years old.

A plot of land in the River dale section of the West Bronx changed hands yesterday when W. C. Stewart sold to John T. -Van Sant of the Horace Mann School in Riverdale the property on the east side of Delafield Avenue, 222 feet south of Iselin Avenue.

Thirty New York aviators and their wives landed in twenty planes on near-by Lake Ouimet today from New York for the annual invitation seaplane cruise. The sportsmen spent the fist night of their flying week-end at Westport, N. Y., after taking off in relays from Sands Point Bath Club.

The Educational Alliance, which In its forty-five years has presented many hobby shows and baby contests, yesterday afternoon staged its fifteenth annual pet show as the climax of the "Be Kind to Animals" Week.

Cotton-mill activity, on a daily average basis, showed a slight decline last week, although a sharp recession was indicated seasonally, and the adjusted index spurted to 108.4, its highest point since the week ended Oct. 30, 1937.

Jesse S. Phillips of Yonkers, former State Commissioner of Insurance, was elected permanent chairman here this afternoon of the citizens' committee appointed on Monday by the Board of Supervisors to study welfare activities and expenditures in Westchester County.

The Commerce Department today reported the invention in Sweden of a new stratosphere-type airplane motor designed for an air speed of about 465 miles an hour at elevations of 39,000 to 59,000 feet. Foreign experts will be invited to witness a demonstration at Stockholm this Fall.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries comprising the Bell System for the three months to May 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and charges of $38,438,931.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

President Roosevelt has appointed Elmer F. Andrews New York State Industrial Commissioner, as administrator of the new Labor Standards Act, Stephen P. Early, Presidential secretary, announced tonight soon after the President and his party returned to his special train from a day-long tour of Yosemite National Park.
The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, Justice Leopold Prince conducting, will be heard in concert this evening at the Central Park Mall. Avram Weiss, violinist, will be soloist.
Deposits in the mutual savings banks of New York, State were virtually unchanged in amount in the second quarter of this year, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York reported.

The manifesto which unnamed Italian scientists have delivered on the subject of race doubtless has some purpose which has caused the Government to approve its publication. But, as science, it gives scientists everywhere reason to blush for their class.

A turnover of a property near the residence of Charles M. Schwab on Riverside Drive was announced yesterday by M. C. B., Inc., operators, who disposed of the five-story town house at 311 West Seventy-fourth Street, between Riverside Drive West End Avenue.

163d St. 506 E, 25x84; alteration to 5-story tenement; Virginia Realty Corp, 115 E 90th St. Owner; M. S. Dimmock, architect, cost, $20,000. Plimpton Ave, s w cor of Featherbed Lane, 201x110: alteration to 1-story gas station; Gertrude Mosbacher, 384 Cannon Pl, owner; John J. Sheridan, architect; cost, $20.000.
Nine New York players are listed among the twelve who have qualified for the open championship finals of the American Chess Federation. The other contenders represent Providence, Chicago and Canada.

The Cubs continued their revived play today behind the effective pitching of Larry French, defeating the Phillies, 4 to 1, before a ladies' day crowd of 21,968. The victory gave them a sweep of the three-game series.

Harold L. Ickes, Public Works Administrator, today denounced Glenn E. Miller as a paid agent for applicants for public works funds, in- violation of PWA regulations, reduced grants to two California communities alleged to have retained Mr. Miller's services, and suspended consideration of other projects pending -investigation.
President Roosevelt's proposal of an armaments conference is received in Italy with favor, but without any marked en-thusiasm.

Howard Hughes and his four globe-girdling flight aides were entertained at luncheon yesterday at the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, by Grover Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair 1939, while the wives of the three married fliers had a separate party at the Hampshire House, Central Park South.

Federal Judge William Bondy signed yesterday an order authorizing the Federal Government to intervene in reorganization proceedings of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation to present evidence concerning the constitutionality of Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act which has been challenged by three creditors.

Walter F. Brown, chairman of the Pa board of directors of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, in comment- At ing yesterday on the Interstate Commerce Commission's decision granting the road a two-cent increase in passenger fares between Jersey City and Hoboken and the Hudson Terminal in Manhattan, dedared that the new rates "will produce revenues wholly inadequate to meet the company's present fixed charges, taxes and wages."

Following is the text of the address, as made public by the State Department, of Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the American delegation to the Intergovernmental Meeting on Political Refugees at Evian, France, at the closing session today:

Andrew J. Kenny, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways, has requested Frank T. Bell, Commissioner of the Bureau of Fisheries of the Department of Commerce, to conduct an investigation of the net fishermen operating along the coast of the Rockaway peninsula.
The United States Embassy has sent a note to the Mexican Foreign Office challenging the alleged seizure by labor unionists of the Americanowned Amparo Mine in the State. of Jalisco.

Challenging the opposition to disclose just what Roosevelt measures, policies or principles it proposes to scrap, James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, called upon the Young Democratic Clubs of America tonight to join the President in a fight for "a Roosevelt Congress to support Roosevelt policies and Roosevelt principles."

Apartment rental activity reported yesterday. mainly involved quarters in buildings on the West Side, from Greenwich Village to Washington 'Heights. George Bassett Roberts, vice president of the National City Bank, leased a duplex apartment in 173 Riverside Drive through the Apartment.Locating Bureau, brokers.

The Old City of Jerusalem today experienced the worst terroristic incident in the present campaign of violence in the Holy Land when a bomb exploded near a fruit stall in a densely crowded Arab market, killing ten and wounding twenty-nine, all Arabs, including many women and children.

A full-grown male chimpanzee weighing 158 pounds was shot dead with three police bullets in its chest yesterday after a five-hour rampage through the home of Mrs. Gertrude Lintz, its owner, at 8,365 Shore Road, Brooklyn.

The Germans and Hungarians in Czechoslovakia are to receive provincial governments and legislatures under the new nationalities statute that will be submitted to the Prague Parliament within ten days.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks. 1,133,000 bales, against 1,138,000 a week ago, 1,130,000 two weeks ago, 1,153,000 three weeks ago and 882,000 a year ago, of which American, 707,000 bales, against 723,000 a week ago, 730,000 two weeks ago, 742,000 three weeks ago and 315,000 a year ago.
The purchase of a large block of land in the Fleetwood section of Yonkers and the resale of part of it for an apartment house project featured realty trading in Westchester County yesterday.
Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner, is to have his Summer palace in the mountains of the Philippines despite Reublican Congressional critics, who termed the plan an outrage.

A Pan American Airways plane in the Buenos Aires-Miami service crashed into the top of a hospital building in a Buenos Aires suburb today, causing the death .of one occupant of the building and injuring fifteen others, three critically.
Race Week, the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual midsummer fixture which has become the banner event of Long Island Sound, will get under way this afternoon and run through next Saturday.

Federal Judge John C. Knox announced yesterday that he would sign an order soon calling for the payment of 75 per cent of the damages awarded to those claimants of the Morro Castle disaster whose awards have not been challenged.

The marriage of Miss Charlene Church, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Church of this place, to Charles F. Pfeifer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pfeifer of New York, took place here this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.
Rain drenched the rifle ranges tonight on the eve of the final for the classic King's Prize and the wind-up of the fortnight's empire meeting of the National Rifle Association.

Operations of the Aviation Corporation and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on May 31, resulted in a net profit of $388,993 after deductions for depreciation, estimated normal Federal income taxes and other charges.

Jersey City, playing its first game under Hank DeBerry, who replaced Travis Jackson as manager, tied the Royals, 1-1, tonight. The game was called at the end of the ninth inning to allow the Giants to catch a train.

Mrs. Anne Garcia has purchased a double lot on Lakeview Drive, Candlewood Knoll, Candlewood Lake, Conn., for improvement with a Summer cottage; John F. Kinney has purchased additional plottage and Mrs. Kendall Smyther a plot on East View Bay, Knollcrest, from the Homeland Company.

Howard Hughes, the wealthy aviator with the face of a poet and the shyness of a schoolboy, tried to share honors yesterday with the four men who flew with him around the world and with the groundlings who made their achievement possible, but New York's crowds, seeking a solitary hero, refused to allow it.

Plans for the organization of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market under the provisions of the Maloney act were discussed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and ten investment bankers representing the Investment Bankers Association and the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc.
This State, which has produced -many Presidents, is warming up for what politicians say will be the bitterest primary fight in years, with the prestige of President- Roosevelt involved.
The Government of Greece will notify today holders of its 5 per cent loan of 1914 of an offer to pay 40 per cent of the face amount of the coupons due in the fiscal year ending March 31, 1939.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell has appointed Harvey P. Gould, secretary of the restaurant corporation headed by James J. Braddock, former heavyweight champion, and Louis Fisher, co-trustees of the corporation, which filed a petition last Wednesday for authority to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Security and commodity markets were dull yesterday, and price changes, for the most part, were relatively unimportant. The stock market was narrow and dull until the final hour when a flurry of buying enabled prices to close generally higher on the day.

Edward G. Levy, an attorney of New Haven, and Charles E. Williamson, Fairfield County political leader, pleaded not guilty to a charge of conspiracy to defraud the city of Waterbury of more than $1,000,000 when they appeared in Superior Court here today before Judge Ernest A. Inglis.
