Miss Nancy Gordon Milburn and Arthur Delano Weekes Jr., whose engagement was announced in May, will be married here on Aug. 3 at noon in the Church of the Advent. Miss Milburn,'a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn

The restoration of the Olympic program to a comparatively modest scale was considered likely by officials here yesterday as a result of the abandonment of the 1940 games by Tokyo and their anticipated acceptance by Helsingfors, Finland.

MANHATTAN BAGGI, NELLIE (Oct. 19, 1937). Gross assets, $39,480; net, $36,339. To Johanna Ferguson, sister, $240 annuity; Georgia Tamm, niece, and Charles Tamm, nephew, one-half residue in trust each; eighteen varying bequests. Chief assets, mortgages. notes. cash and insurance, $32,775.

Hearings in the injunction suit against Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, were stalemated yesterday by the failure of a mysterious witness to respond to a subpoena requiring his appearance.

The Textile converters Association of America, Inc., informed the Y textile workers organizing committee, Local 65, in a letter yesterday that it has found some of the terms of an agreement with the union of May 19, 1937, "too onerous for the industry."

William J. Diamond, 28-year-old bartender who was shot early Wednesday while working in his bar and grill at 330 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday morning in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital of a bullet wound in his left side.

Two hundred members of the Industrial Insurance Agents Union, Local 30, C. I. O., staged a brief demonstration at 11 A. M. yesterday in front of 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, in protest against the alleged dismissal, on the ground of union activity,
Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and Princess Louise of Sweden were guests at a civic dinner here tonight. Mayor Edward J. Kelly voiced the city's welcome.

Bobby Doerr's four-run homer in the sixth inning today provided the Red Sox with the tallies to defeat the Browns, 5-3, in the series opener. The Browns, beaten in nine of their ten starts against Boston this season, had a 3-1 lead until Doerr blasted his third circuit drive of the year.

Articles of incorporation were filed today with the Secretary of State by the Women's Orgnization Marine, Inc., a membership group to promote and support the American Merchant marine. Among its other purposes it is to conduct an 'adopt a ship" pland to lend aid and support to all similar projects.

The island's most active clerical advocate for independence, the Rev. Severo Ramos, has been relieved of his parish by Bishop Louis J. Willinger of the Ponce Diocese. Bishop Willinger is a former Brooklyn priest.

As far as Germany is concerned, President Roosevelt's speech urging a limitation of armaments has been almost completely drowned out by the noise of the propagandistic battle now raging over Czechoslovakia and the Sudeten Germans.
Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer issued yesterday a temporary injunction limiting picketing at the plants of the Eagle Pencil Company and Niagara Box Factory, Inc., 703 East Fourteenth Street,

The White Sox pounded an 11 to 3 viotory over the Senators today for their first victory-in Griffith Stadium this season. While Thornton Lee was scattering ten hits, the White Sox reached three Washington hurlers for sixteen safeties.

Miss Marietta Kuolt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar W. Kuolt of Rochester, N. Y., was married to Dr. Daniel Clark Hackett, son of Frank S. Hackett, headmaster of the Riverdale Country School, Riverdale-on-Hudson, and the late Mrs. Hackett, last night at the home of Miss Sarah Ackroyd Moore, an old friend of the bride's family, at 52 West Twelfth Street.

No passenger was killed in a train accident but twenty-eight were injured in April, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today. In the four months ended on April 30 three passengers were killed and 143 injured, this comparing with no passenger killed and 163 injured in the same four months in 1937.

The General Banknote Corporation of New York City has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $55,000 of 5 percent. cumulative five-year income notes due in 1943 and 192,000 shares of 1 cent par value common stock to be offered in units of thirty-five. shares of stock and $10 principal amount of notes, first to stockholders at $10 a unit and any unsubscribed units through underwriters at the same price.

Mr. and Mrs. George R. Kent gave a dinner tonight at Wayside for Miss Beatrice Patterson and her fiance, Rodman Wanamaker 2d. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson, Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Carey, Miss Genevieve Clendenin, and Dante V. Leland who arrived today to pass the week-end with Mr. and Mrs.Kent.

A special grand jury returned six secret indictments today in concluding a two-month investigation of political assessments on civil service employes by managers of Governor Davey's third-term campaign.

Puerto Rican students attempting to do college work in the United States are handicapped by an inadequate knowledge of English, Dr. Jose M. Gallardo, Commissioner of Education, told Summer school students taking six weeks of intensive English training, hoping thereby to obtain appintments as English teachers.

The Yankees went back to plays ing full-time baseball at the Stadium yesterday and the experiment proved a huge success for the champions. Not so much could be said for Mickey Cochrane's Tigers, who, it seems, can lose as easily in nine innings as in six.

Senator Claude Pepper of Florida, speaking at the closing session of the national rally of the Young Democratic Clu??s of America here this afternoon, demanded continuance of "a truly liberal government."

Montgomery Clark of 172 Cottage Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y., president of the Hanover Fire Insurance Company and the Fulton Fire Insurance Company, died today in the Norwalk General Hospital, after a short illness. He became ill in his Summer home at Westport, Conn. His age was 57.
Dowager Queen Marie of Rumania arrived in Rumanian territory today coming from the Lahmann sanatorium near Dresden, Germany.

The Iowa Supreme Court granted to union attorneys today a writ of certiorari lifting the contempt proceedings against three C. I. O. union leaders at Newton's Maytag washing machine plant to the State's highest court.

A digest of the charges made in the taxation of capital gains and losses and other provisions of the new Federal Revenue Act, which are of importance to real estate interests, is presented by George P. Ellis, controller of the National Association of Real Estate Boards and for many years its consultant on income tax matters, in the current issue of Freehold.
Helium gas has been found in Sao Paulo Province, according to a statement by Dr. Basto Alves, Director of Brazil's Geographic and Geologic Department.
Five enthusiastic members of an up-State balloon club made an attempt to fly to New York City today, but gave up the flight when they met unexpected troubles, meteorological and otherwise.
Picking up where they had left off against the Pirates, the Dodgers today set the ambitious Reds back on their heels, 12 to 5.

Today marks the end of two years of civil war in Spain. They have been years of unbroken nightmare, a reign of terror and agony for the divided Spanish people, and of vicarious conflict for the rest of the world.

In June of 1937 a reporter asked President Roosevelt at a White House press conference if he would run for a third term. The President looked sharply across his littered mahogany desk and said, with a trace of smile on his face, that the inquirer should put on a dunce cap and go stand in the corner. Most of those present laughed.

Nearly 350 members of the cottage colony and visitors from New York and vicinity attended the supper dance given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. John English of Schenectady and Miami Beach to introduce their daughter, Miss Edythe English.

The Bermuda Biological Station will join the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute next week in measuring the Gulf Stream oscillations, which are believed to influence droughts in the Midwest of the United States and movements of European fisheries.
Of Theodore Roosevelt it is told that when once confronted with the lack of precedent for something he wanted to do he slammed his fist on the desk and declaimed:

VALENCIA.--Two years of war seemed an incredible thought when the guns began rattling in Spain two years ago; yet here we are. The pace has increased more deaths and greater destruction per minute, larger armies more material, graver danger for every one from the tiniest Spanish baby to the greatest nations of Europe-and still the war goes on.

In a speech of unusual vigor delivered yesterday, Pope Pius protested strongly against what he called "excessive nationalism," the spirit of which he declared to be contrary to the Catholic Credo and the Catholic faith.

All openings are tomorrow unless noted. New York BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I.-Hampton Playhouse, "The Night of January 16." CARMEL-Rockridge Theatre, "Romeo and Juliet," with Douglass Montgomery and Jane Wyatt. CEDARHURST, L. I.-The Playhouse, "Accent on Youth,' with Joseph Cotten. CHAUTAUQUA-Repertory Theatre, "The Night of January 16."

Plans for the construction of a four-unit 100-family apartment house to cost $375,000 have been filed with Building Inspector Eugene Steele by the English Village, Inc., of Cranford. The P. J. Carlin Construction Company of New York has been designated as the builder in the application.

The rise and fall of Samuel Insull and the total collapse of his vast power have provided a thrilling chapter in the business saga of this country. It has been said of this ambitious man, who started out in life in a drab London house agent's concern with a Salary of 5 shillings a week, that his unbridled lust for power led to his financial undoing and personal disgrace.

The strike committee of Metal Novelty Local 1224 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C. I. O., decidled at a meeting yesterday to continue picketing at the plants of the Eagle Pencil Company and Niagara Box Factory, Inc., 703 East Fourteenth Street.

After years of fine productive work as a professor, author and editor, Wilbur Lucius Cross took a hand in politics. When, as a Democrat, he was elected Governor in '30, the Connecticut Republicans consoled themselves with the hope that he would be only a passing affliction.

The style employed in redecorating the lobby of the apartment house at 229 East Seventy-ninth Street is the result of about five plans submitated to the tenants in the building by the Marx Realty and Im- room provement Company, agent for the property.

Tallying two runs without making a hit in the seventh inning, the Indians came from behind today to win a seesaw struggle from the Athletics, 9 to 8. Earl Averill, batting in the seventh, was safe on Lou Finney's error. Hal Trosky walked.

Henry G. Waltemade, president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx, points out that, if new building and modernization of the older type of accommodations are to be encouraged to expand their activities to the proportions expected, it will be necessary to curtail government competition in that type of housing.

Two large estates in Maryland have been sold, one being purchased by a New Yorker, reports Previews, Inc. One property involved the seventy-acre tract on the Chester River, one mile from the town of Crumpton, bought by Matthew Retzleer of New York City from Carleton Kelsey of Philadelphia.

A Summer residence on Glenside Trail at Lake Mohawk, near Sparta, N. J., has been purchased by Dr. and Mrs. Robert F. McDonald of Brooklyn, The Arthur D. Crane Company, developers, report that new homes have also been purchased by Mr. and Mrs. A. Walter Murdock of Brooklyn and Mr. and Mrs. Raymond H. Ebbetts of Kenilworth, N. J.

Qualities of a good college teacher listed last week by President Baker of Milwaukee Teachers College are as follows: 1. Possession of a love of human nature and a desire to promote its welfare. ("No one who is not endued with this concept has any business in any teaching position.")

With the beneficial effects of the Century of Progress Exhibition upon retail trade in Chicago serving as a guide, estimates indicate that the New York World Fair of 1939 will bring this city at least $1,000,000,000 in extra business.

The marriage of Miss Bernice Dangremond, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. George C. Dangremond, to Robert J. Sieben-Morgen, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sieben-Morgen of Westfield, N. J., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are July 16 unless specified; At San Diego: Altair, Balch, Borie, Broome, Case, Chandler, Cassin, Conyngham, Cummings, Concord, Detroit, Downes, Gridley, Hovey, Houston, Jarvis, Long, Melville, Memphis, Neches Ortolan, Patterson, Pike, Ranger, Reid, Selfridge, Simpson, Southard, Truxtun, Tucker, Trenton, Winslow.

IN the complex and varied list of instruments with which the plane of Howard Hughes was equipped for his transoceanic expedition there was missing one device which he would have liked to have had on board.

One of the largest acreage deals this year in Morris County, N. J., for immediate improvement with homes costing from $12,000 to $25,000 has just been closed in the purchase of the Horace H. Work estate at Madison by a development syndicate known as General Properties, Inc., of East Orange.

Prompt action looking to the widening of the Grand Concourse from 138th to 153d Street, to make it a thoroughfare 100 feet wide instead of 80 feet, is sought by Bronx realty and trade officials as a means of relieving the "bottleneck" at that point.

(Figures in parentheses Indicate par) Cherry Valley (72)-Match play handicap against par, Class A: J. S. Palmer, 2 down; A. L. Adamson, 3 down. Class B: A. E. Impey, 1 up; C. H. Middendorf Jr., 1 down.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has made a substantial profit to date in its program of reselling to the private investment market securities of States, municipalities, counties and districts, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, announced today.
The two-story garden apartment houses under construction in Englewood, N. J., are expected to be ready for occupancy in the Fall, announces Anthony A. Paterno, builder and owner.

CAPE TOWN. IT may be hot in America in Summer, but there are usually ways of finding relief. In many other parts of the world there is no escape from the raking and merciless sun-Africa, for instance.
Practical training for the young geologist is offered by Princeton University this Summer in a series of eight field trips to widely separated points on the North American Continent.

As President Roosevelt had luncheon at San Clemente State Park on the way here today Sheriff Logan Jackson of Orange County and Secret Service agents arrested a man who they said was carrying a .38-caliber revolver near the President and who had a partially empty whisky bottle in his brief case.
Our completely fictitious interview with a wholly imaginary member of the Howard Hughes expedition

The engagement of Miss Kathleen Marie Campbell, daughter of Mrs. John J. Campbell of Cedarhurst, L. I., to Edward Joseph Loughman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Loughman of Lawrence, L. I., has been announced by her mother.

When John Cook, sergeant mechanic attached to the aviation department of the United States Embassy here, helped to repair the Hughes round-the-world airplane at Le Bourget Airport last Tuesday night he was only doing what he considered a normal day's job.
General Franco's record of military accomplishments in the second year of Spain's civil war is quite as impressive as that of the first year.

Milton Valentine Snyder, veteran foreign correspondent who brought Marconi to this country in 1899 to demonstrate wireless telegraphy, died yesterday in Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, L. I. He was 69 years old and had been ill for several months.

Miss Katharine Petty, daughter of Mrs. Robert Davison Petty of 312 West 105th Street and the late Professor Petty, one-time dean of the New York Law School, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother to Alvah Howard Lance of Glen Gardner, N. J.

The personal intervention of President Arturo Alessandri, which commenced yesterday with a long talk at the Presidential Palace with representatives of labor unions, is expected to be a decisive factor in ending a strike at El Teniente mines, near Rancagua, involving more than ten thousand workers.

More than 150 delegates representing nearly 15,000 workers in telegraph companies, radio land lines, radio stations at sea and on aviation fields will gather at the Hotel Victoria tomorrow at 10 A. M. for the fourth national convention of the American Communications Association, C. I. O.

A program for the construction of fourteen district health center buildings and fifteen substations during the years 1939 to 1944 at an estimated cost of $6,218,000 has been placed before the City Planning Commission by the Health Department, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner, announced yesterday.

The wheat situation was brought to the attention of the people f the United States last week by thee important announcements by the Department of Agriculture. First came the forecast of the second largest domestic wheat crop on record.
APPROACHING the end of its third year under Socialist rule, New Zeasland is taking stock. Generally speaking, it likes the results. There has been more pay, greater- leisure, a spending spree.

IN the canyons of the Colorado River today a new scientific expedition is making history. A few days ago its members safely reached Lee's Ferry, Ariz., to complete the first half of their 1,100-mile trip. Now they have shoved off again, and until they reach Boulder Dam, 600 miles down river, the eyes of a good part of the nation will be focused on the waterway they are exploring.

The private chapel at Kamp Kill Kare, the Summer home here of Mrs. Francis P. Garvan, was the setting today for the marriage of her daughter and namesake, Miss Mabel Brady Garvan, to Robert Philip Noble of Greenwich, Conn.

Among those millions who remember your face but can't recall your name,. you will search in vain for Albert Benjamin Chandler, Governor of Kentucky and candidate for the United States Senatorial nomination from his State.

Ten boys who have been in Bellevue Hospital for years, victims of infantile paralysis, some in casts, some on crutches, some able to limp about, enjoyed a big treat yesterday when they were taken to the movies and were guests at a party at the hospital afterward.

A frequent cause of sagging floors, it is pointed out, is due to carelessly cut joists. As a rule these joists have been cut away to permit the accommodation of heavy plumbing lines, heating. pipes or ducts, and electric wiring.
One hundred and twenty-five yachts competed in ten classes today as the annual regatta of the Ocean Gate Y. C. was held in a light southeastery breeze.

Wholesale furniture, lamp and wallpaper markets here will assume the busiest aspect of the year this week when 5,000 to 8,000 buyers interested in covering requirements for the coming Fall months visit the city to attend trade shows opening tomorrow.

Three hundred and sixty-eight craft, seven more than the all-time record of a year ago, took part today in the opening regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's fortieth annual race week With a westly breeze there were sails spread over thirty square miles of Long Island 'Sound, and, wtth accompanyingg sightseeing craft of every description, the scene was like some-great water pageant in white.

WASHINGTON. Approximately 178,000 tons of bait, more than twice the amount used last year, will go this year for the drive against the crop-destroying grasshopper. Both the Federal and State Governments contribute to grasshopper control work.
Howard Hughes and his four companions will follow their record-breaking flight around the globe with a good-will tour by air of Central and South America, it was learned yesterday.
Inscoelda, speedy brown filly owned by Herbert M. Woolf of Kansas City, turned on a brilliant stretch '-drive today to win the $28,620 Lassie Stakes before 25,000 spectators at Arlington Park.

Quiet strength predominated yesterday in another typically dull week-end session in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. The absence of many traders from the financial district and the tendency to mark time on Saturday failed to weaken the price structure of the market.

This department is designed to assist in the location of coinpZete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, Ae., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

CIGARETTE smokers throughout the world may soon find themselves smoking cigarettes without the paper wrapper. A new idea, developed by a Hungarian, Stephen Tamas,. is to use a wrapper made from the tobacco plant itself. It is not merely a leaf wrapper, however, but a special tissue in whose manufacture both tobacco leaves and stalk fibers are used.

Native orchids, Jack-in-the-pulpit, Fringed Gentian and hepaticas may some day be as plentiful and easy to grow in the back-yard garden as sweet peas and daisies are at present. Such is the aim of Dr. Margery Carlson of the Botany Department of Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill.,

The Mechanics' Educational Society of America, an independent union of tool and die makers, announced today that its administrative committee had rejected an invitation to affiliate with the United Automobile Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate.

Patent rights on a new type of microphone which enables aviators to communicate by radio with other planes or with ground stations without moving a finger from the plane's controls have been granted by the United States Patent Office to Stuart Ballantine, president of the Ballantine Laboratories, Inc., of Boonton, it was learned today.

The Church of the Resurrection, Richmond Hill, Queens, was the scene of the marriage this afternoon of Miss Helene Johanna Bodenheim of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Willis Jackson Fosdick of Massapequa, L. I. The Rev. Arthur R. Cummings, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.
Dr. Hugh S. Cumming, former surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, returned yesterday with Mrs. Cumming on the steamship President Roosevelt of the United States Lines.
Hephzibah Menuhin, pianist, 18year-old sister of Yehudi Menuhin, famous violinist, became the bride of Lindsay George Nicholas, member of a prominent Australian family, this afternoon.

THE Postoffice Department announced last week the colors of the four "Presidential" stamps to be released in August and also the sources of the profile portraits to be used as the designs. The 7c, Aug. 4,

A sharp gain in demand for dressy costs and a falling off in the emphasis which has been placed on casual and sports types in the last several years are indicated by current commitments by retail buyers, according to the weekly market letter issued yesterday by the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.
THE stream of fan mail flowing into Hollywood never runs dry. Upward of 3,000 letters each week in the year are received by the most popular screen stars.

SCHROON LAKE, N. Y.-Speed boat racing on Adirondack lakes will be inaugurated here on Saturday, when the first in the season's series of five races to be sponsored by the Schroon Lake Bloat Club will be run, with several important new entries by members of the camp colony.

The Lewis Land Corporation of Little Neck announces the purchase from the Nassau-Suffolk Bond and Mortgage Company of 1,400 lots in Northport, L. I., overlooking the water. The property was formerly known as the Morell estate.
THAT ace of World War correspondents, Philip Gibbs-long ago made Sir Philip by the monarch of his native England-wrote on the day of the armistice of 1918,
Pope Pius today received petitions signed by thousands of American Indians asking that the Indian girl, Kateri Tetawitha, the "Lily of the Mohawks," be proclaimed a saint.

Copyright. 1938. All Rights Reserved. With the November Congressional elections less than four months away and with the nation-wide campaign already in its early stages, an upswing in Democratic sentiment throughout the country has cut into the rosy Republican prospects of two months ago.

You may recall the mythological tale of Cadmus and the dragon. The fierce dragon guarded a fountain and refused to permit Cadmus to obtain water from it. Thereupon, Cadmus slew the dragon and sowed its teeth in the earth.

The marriage of Miss Mary W. Bent, daughter of Judge and Mrs. William W. Bent of this city, to William D. Benedict of New York, son of Mrs. Helen Benedict and the late Charles E. Benedict, also of Bridgeport, was held late this afternoon St. George's Church. The Rev. Delmar S. Marke, rector, officiated.

The Congressional TVA Investigation Committee ended its tour of TVA dams and other projects today with an inspection of the fertilizer works near Wilson Dam at Muscle Shoals, Ala, and of the rock phosphate fields near this town in Middle Tennessee which supply the raw materials for the fertilizer;

Mr. and Mrs. R. Caldwell Patton of New York and Syosset were hosts tonight at a dinner, followed by a barn party, for Miss Jean W. Randolph of Charlottesville, Va., and Lawrence Reid Houston, brother of the hostess, whose engagement was announced recently.

Dicker day, a weekly feature of the Summer season here, established several seasons ago by Mrs. Wayman Adams of New York, wife of the artist, is to be observed next Wednesday with an exhibition of art works by pupils of Mr. Adams at his Old Mill Village art center.
The new People's Political Council closed its nine-day session here yesterday after nearly fifty resolutions were adpoted.

A new kind of "clinic" in New York, for advice to the pedestrian and diagnosis of his faults, is held necessary in an article which appeared yesterday in the July issue of Safety magazine, organ of the Greater New York Safety Council Such a "clinic" is now operating at Wichita, Kan.

WHILE trade feels the usual Summer slackening, sales reports last week continued to make better comparisons with last year on the average. Several more sections indicated that figures had passed those of 1937, when trade began to contract rather sharply.

The game now being played in Albany by the ninety-two Republicans and the seventy-six Democrats who are the delegates to the Constitutional Convention resembles an old-fashioned game of pushball between two college classes.

All the newest things in wallpaper designs will be on exhibition four days this week beginning tomorrow night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. While designated as the 1938 Wallpaper Style Show, the designs will reveal the latest products of the leading manufacturers in the country for the decorative treatment of large and small rooms in private homes and apartment suites.
ALFRED HITCHCOCK, who carries more weight than any other living British director--and probably will until his diet shows results--said he thought Hollywood was wonderful.

Colonel William H. Kelly of East Orange has resigned as chairman of the New Jersey Democratic State Committee, it was learned today. He also intends to resign as chairman of the Essex County Democratic Committee.

The tax revision undertaken by the last Congress is not in itself a recovery stimulus but it may help to transform a coming recovery into a longer lasting prosperity, Dr. Gerhard Colm, economist and tax authority, declares in an analysis of the Revenue Act of 1938 to be issued this week by the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.
A seminar in problems of traffic safety and automobile operation will be offered by Pennsylvania State College during its annual post-session from Aug. 8 to Aug. 26.

Ty Cobb, who knows something about baseball, aired a few personal opinions today which included advice to Sam Chapman to mix up his batting strategy. The greatest player of his day sees hope for Dizzy Dean in the latter's battle to overcome the handicap of a sore pitching arm.
The last place Maple Leafs won a double-header from Jersey City tonight, 11-5. and 3-2. The Little Giants now have lost nine games Outhit 11 to 5, Toronto converted and tied two in their last eleven.

SLASHING four days off Wiley Post's round-the-world flight record of 1933, and cutting Lindbergh's New York- toParis time in half, Howard Hughes in his streamlined monoplane coupled new radio records with his aviation triumph as he streaked around the globe.
Mayor La Guardia crossed swords yesterday with Robin Hood of Washington, D. C., over the city's drive to rid the streets of pushcart peddlers as a menace to health and traffic.
Revisions were made by the French Government today in some supplementary quotas contained in-the Franco-American Reciprocal Trade Agreement in the light of its operation to date.

Miss Edith M. Sawin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin E. Sawin of New York, entertained a large group of young friends at a dinner party at the family Summer home, Shadow Blow Farm on Tower Hill, this evening in honor of her house guests, Miss Alice Truesdale and Miss Cynthia Heffron of Greenwich, Conn.

The trial of twenty-three Integralistas (Fascists), who are charged with attacking Guanabara Palace, the home of President Getulio Vargas, on May 11, has been set for Tuesday. The police ruled today that the defendants cannot seek writs of habeas corpus.

WHATEVER the administrations of President Roosevelt may or may not have accomplished in other respects, they have caused Americans to ponder, as they have not pondered for two generations or more, on the form and functions of our government.

Giulio Cardinal Serafini, Prefect of the Congregation of the Council, considered one of the most learned members of the sacred college, died today of uremia after several days' illness. His age was 71.

Half of a thirty-foot flagpole on the top of Public School 89, at 485 Lenox Avenue, was sawed off yesterday afternoon by police after the pole, believed struck by lightning recently, appeared in danger of falling.

Two young men whose relatives and ancestors have won distinction, Robert Taft, son of the late President, and Supreme Court Justice Arthur H. Day, distantly related to the late Justice Day of the United States Supreme Court, are making unusual campaigns, in a tensely fought Republican primary, as contenders for the Republican nomnation to the United States Senate.

IT is a welcome change to find, among the many historic novels that have flooded the market here in recent years, some books whose authors have returned to subtlety in the portrayal of human character.

The Lion Hill forts east of Kiukiang on the Yangtze River, which were so strongly fortified that they impeded the Japanese advance toward Hankow for almost a week, were silenced by Japanese aerial bombings Friday afternoon, according to a Japanese navy announcement.
NOT so many years ago the goverment's responsibility for public health was generally recognized as being limited to supervision of sanitation. Even that, in its day, was a new departure.

Members of the St. Regis camp colony were invited by Mr. and Mrs. John B. Trevor of New York to attend the luncheon given today at Trevallyn, their upper St. Regis Lake Summer place, for members of the board of trustees of the proposed Paul Smith College of Arts and Sciences.

Henry G. Frey, referee in bankruptcy in Queens, handed down a decision yesterday morning denying a claim of $3,000 made by the law firm of Edward, Kraemer, Edward of Kansas City, Mo., against Robert J. Suhay, convict, who is awaiting execution of a death sentence at Topeka, Kan., for the murder of a Federal agent last year.

THE current gold coins of Liechtenstein show the portrait of Prince Francis I, who since 1929 has ruled this tiny principality adjoining Austria. The obverse of these coins shows the portrait of Prince Francis I facing to the right and wearing the Order of the Golden Fleece. The Inscription,

In an attempt to stimulate trading in bonds, the Chicago Stock Exchange announced today sharply reduced fees for member firms. At the same time, it announced the introduction of a new system of filling bond orders on the floor.
The British evacuation of the Cork Harbor forts last Monday was an implicit act of faith and trust in the people of Southern Ireland.

Alick M. Watkins, 27, who came from Melbourne for surgical aid, walked out of a hospital here today able to feel his heart beat again after Mayo Clinic surgeons had cut away a half-inch casing of stone from, that organ.
Savings, building and loan associations in the country, reports the United States Building and Loan League, paid out $525,000,000 in the first half of the present year to their savers and investors.
WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H.--Three more appearances will be made at Packett's Playhouse in the Hayloft on Sugar Hill this season by the Jitney Players, who gave their first performance on Thursday.

After he is said to have telephoned his wife and his employer that he was going to commit suicide, Paul C. Orelich, 44 years old, of 31-29 Thirty-fifth Street, Astoria, Queens, a salesman exmployed by the Kelley-Koett Manufacturing Company, makers of X-ray machines and physiotherapy equipment, ran amok last night in the company's establishment on the third floor of 115 East Twentythird Street, wrecking equipment valued at $15,000.

Tampa business men turned to a boycott today as a new weapon against gambling. One thousand merchants and their employes signed cards promising to "rid the city of commercialized gambling by shutting off the racket's revenue through boycott."

The second Summer dance of the season for young married couples, post-debutantes and debutantes and their escorts tonight at the Greenwich Country Club attracted more than 250 members of the younger set. A number of dinner parties preceded the dance.
Green squashes like petrified snakes hung from Ninth Avenue pushcarts yesterday and sleepy snails inched imperceptibly within overcrowded baskets as Paddy's Market headed to a full stop.

The fifteen-story Hotel Elysee at 50-60 East Fifty-fourth Street, plot 60 by 100 feet, between Madison and Park Avenues, will be sold at auction in foreclosure proceedings on July 27 in the Vesey Street rooms by Joseph P. Day.

NANTUCKET, Mass.-On the success of the Nantucket Plan hangs the fate of a movement to save the unspoiled New England villages, which, by good luck rather than by good management, have retained something of the colonial heritage.

To the roaring crowd of 25,000 who greeted him the performance of Howard Hughes and his crew of four in circumnavigating the globe in 91 hours, 10 minutes and 8 seconds (official time) belonged to the tradition of globe-trotters.

DAVID HARUM has been a part of the American legend for forty years and ranks high in the list of our home-grown characters of fiction. On the threshold of this century the up-State New York banker and horsetrader captured the imagination of readers and playgoers of his own generation with a brand of rustic humor native to the soil and the composite American stock.

Members of the City Council today rejected an invitation to a 7 1/2-cent-a-plate meal as an "object lesson" on relief extended by a labor committee urging a $2,000,000 city appropriation for WPA projects. Dr. Arthur R. Keegan answered the invitation thus:

Three persons were injured when the 50-foot yacht Wayward, owned by Graham Roberts of Philadelphia, caught fire following a gasoline explosion in the Atlantic Ocean five miles off this city late today.
Thirty men, led by George Kiebler, president of the district council of the U. A. W. A., today raided the office of the Allis-Chalmers local and hauled away all records.

Landlubbers reach the Jersey beaches by train, bus and automobile, but the yachtsmen have a big advantage. They go in cruisers, make their homes in snug shipboard cabins and take their Summer vacations not at one resort, but anchoring off dozens of them.
Four British privates and two native soldiers were killed today in an abortive attempt to capture the Fakir of Ipi, who has led a revolt of northwest frontier tribesmen since Spring.
Leon Henderson, the man who called the turn-on the business recession a year before it happened, is calling a new turn now. He belives that business will get under way again in September.

AMERICA'S most celebrated mass ascent of a glacier peak will take place today on the rugged slopes of Mount Hood. More than 500 people, weather permitting, will climb the towering pinnacle in the annual expedition sponsored by the American Legion and the famous Crag Rats of Hood River.

The former Kaiser's yacht, Hohenzollern, now at New York, will soon be on regular service between Puerto Montt, Chile, and Magallanes, the southernmost city in the world, if plans being considered by the government here mature.

The search for Edward Prager, 15-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Siegfried Prager of 255 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, who ran away from Heckscher Camp Monday evening, ended this afternoon at an ash tree in the dense woods less than a mile northwest of the camp.
Dr. and Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop and Mrs. Henry Dater gave a large dinner tonight at the Devon Yacht Club.

When New York's eighth Constitutional Convention began last April, the delegates decided to divide their work into three phases, with time limits for each. First, the convention was organized and proposals for' changes in the basic law were received-a phase ended last May. Second,
A new phase of the industrial conflict- involving the nation's railroads will unfold here next week when management and labor begin direct conferences over a proposed 15 per cent wage cut.

Employing the tactics he used yesterday in removing Henry Picard from the Professional Golfers Association championship, Paul Runyan, slender young Westchester pro, today gained the crown for the second time as he dealt a decisive beating to Sam Snead in the final round at the Shawnee Country Club.

Seventy-five former Wall Street workers have been placed in new jobs in the last week, the replacement committee formed by New York Stock Exchange firms reported yesterday. This body, which was formed at the instance of William McC. Martin Jr., president of the Exchange, received approximately 1,250 registrations in its first week of operations and, through its staff, interviewed 500 applicants.

The engagement of $100,000 gold in Australia for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank announced that $363,000 gold from Hong Kong. had arrived at San Francisco.
" NEW WRITING" is a sizable volume of magazine stories, sketches and poems, arranged and edited twice a year by John Lehmann, in the Spring and, in the Fall.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. C. Pearsall gave a garden party this afternoon at The Anchorage, their home here, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Olive Ann Pearsall, to George Robert Aitken, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel R. Aitken of East Orange, N. J.

Because the Securities and Exchange Commission has denied a request for confidential treatment of certain information relating to sales and cost of goods sold, filed with annual reports for the years ended on Dec. 31, 1935, 1936 and 1937, the Marlin-Rockwell Corporation has withdrawn its $1 par value common capital stock from registration on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Hillcrest Realty Company has opened a realty and insurance office at 70-35 Broadway, Jackson Heights. Joseph P. Acker will be in charge of the insurance department; Eugene F. McCarthy will direct sales of apartments, homes and investment properties;

By a comfortable margin, Captain J. A. Barlow of the West Yorkshire Regiment, England, won the King's Prize today. He was acclaimed victor in the empire's premier event for military marksmen even while his ninety-nine rival finalists were still firing.

Having defeated Boris Blumin of Montreal in the first round, David S. Polland of New York, the titleholder, continued his good work today in the open tournament finals of the American Chesg Federation at the Hotel Touraine.
Mayor Thomas L. Holling of Buffalo and a Buffalo City Councilman were injured today in an automobile collision just outside this city.
For the second year the campus of Sarah Lawrence College is host to a Summer Workshop conducted by the Progressive Education Association.
WASHINGTON. UNCLE SAM, the greatest road builder in the world, built about 10,000 miles of new highway for the use of the traveler and the truckman during the fiscal year that ended June 30.

Led by Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., the nation's sixth ranking star, the largest field ever attracted by the' men's EaStern clay court tennis championships started in quest of the singles laurels yesterday as the eleventh annual competition opened at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.
I CANNOT understand," said Viscount Uchida, "why we appear to be so very unpopular all over the world. The Australians think we want their country and the Californians think we want theirs.

Confronted by an armed thug and by another young man whom he believed to be an accomplice, in his jewelry store at 218 East Fourteenth Street shortly after 6 o'clock last night, Herman Apfelbaum reached into a drawer for his own revolver and began firing.

Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice gave the second in her Summer series of musicales this afternoon at- Mount Hope, Williamstown. Archer Gibson played the organ. Mrs. Prentice was assisted by her daughter, Mrs. Benjamin D. Gilbert of Clayville, N. Y.

Sixty United States Army Reserve officers from the metropolitan area will report to Camp Dix, New Jersey, today to commence two weeks' active duty as instructors to 2.000 C.M.T.C. students, most of them also from the metropolitan area.
Beer will soon be sold in Camp La Guardia, Orange County, to the 1,000 men whom the city sends there for rehabilitation, William Hodson, Commissioner of Welfare, said yesterday.

The shop chairmen of the Knitgoods Workers Union, Local 155, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, have authorized the union's leadership to prepare for a strike of some 12,000 workers, if necessary, to enforce their demands for a collective agreement, the union announced yesterday.

When Herbert Delucca, 18, of North Bergen, N. J., sighted today by patrolmen who held a warrant for his arrest for larceny, he shed his outer clothing, worn over a bathing suit, and plunged into the Atlantic.

MOTORLESS FIAGHT- silent, exhilarating, birdlike- gains rapidly in the United States. Each Summer sees the glider fans more numerous; each new 'contest is almost sure to witness new records. A score of flights of more than 100 miles each were made during the recent annual contest of the Soaring Society of America, held at Elmira, N. Y. What is more, pilots at the meet reached previously announced destinations more than 200 miles away.
The Eastman Kodak Company announced today a new line of cameras for marketing next month with a type which uses a photo-electric cell as a feature.
Stressing the need for cultural tolerance in this country, speakers at yesterday's opening session of the conference on intercultural education for teachers, at Riverside
Leaders in the newspaper, radio, magazine and newsreel fields honored fellow-workers at the dinner of the fifth annual Headliners' frolic in the Hotel Ambassador here tonight.

Police and fire emergency squads lost a three-hour battle with death yesterday when they failed to revive 17-year-old Ethel Handelman, City College student, who committed suicide in the kitchen of a three-room apartment she shared with her widowed mother, Mrs. Fannie Handelman, and 12-year-old brother, Benjamin, at 2,265 Grand Avenue, the Bronx.

EVERY epoch has its own art criteria suited to the mood of the epoch and its art, and in no small measure conditioned by them. At the same time every epoch usually considers its esthetic as the only tenable esthetic for any age; that is to say, as something timeless, eternal.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kulze of 44 Gramercy Park, New York, gave a dinner dance here this evening in the Westchester Country Club for the directors of the Young Men's Board of Trade of New York City. Mr. Kulze is president of the board.

The final draft of a simplified, uniform mortgage foreclosure law is being drawn up under the auspices of the Central Housing Committee for submission at an early date to the Legislatures of all the States in the Union with recommendations that it be enacted into law.
Attorney General Gordon Conant said today the inquest into the death of Mrs. Mabelle Horlick Sidley, heiress to the Horlick malted milk fortune, had been ordered because of "facts in our possession."

Adults have abilities greater than many give them credit for, according to a nation-wide study of thousands of university extension students made by Herbert Sorenson, president of State Teachers College, Duluth. The results have just been published by the University of Minnesota Press.

Plans for a Peace Parade on Aug. 6 in commemoration of the twentyfourth anniversary of the beginning of the World War were approved yesterday by the New York Division of the American League for Peace and Democracy.
The Jews, who have been banned from all public gardens in Vienna, have been frequenting many large private gardens owned by the aristocracy and opened to the general public.

The Shapiro Foundation, established five years ago by Benjamin Shapiro of New York City, and his brother, Max J. Shapiro of Summit, to aid talented young men and women in getting a college education, has announced the award of forty-six scholarships, twenty-two of which are new and the rest renewals.
Since last Saturday Italian newspapers have devoted a large part of their small space to the preface Premier Benito Mussolini has written for a collection of resolutions by the Fascist Grand Council.

Michael Bilanchuk, 13th Precinct, assigned to tours 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and 4 P. M. to 12 Midnight, for 30 days, from 8 A. M., July 21. Ralph H. Hansen, from 23d Precinct, to 18th Division, duty in D. A. Office, Kings County, for 30 days, from 8 A. M.. July 14. From precincts indicate to 19th Division, duty in Raided Premises Squad, for 14 days, from 8 A. M.. July 18:

In its report on "Problems of a Changing Population" the National Resources Committee has recently revealed that declining industries show a much higher. percentage of. male workers over 45 years of age than do new, expanding industries.

Many comfortable homes have been purchased by new owners for occupancy in Queens, Nassau and Westchester Counties, and in various sections of Brooklyn, from the Mortgagees Realty Service, the real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company, acting as agent for various individual and institutional investors.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: E. Millis Hurley's letter in THE TIMES of July 10, expressing astonishment that any one should call Marylanders Yankees, and then- explaining the position of the States of Maryland and Delaware in the war between the States, leads me to inquire: Who are Yankees?
Proposals for amending the State Constitution to increase taxes on real estate were assailed at an organization meeting last week of the Brooklyn Chapter of the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation.

Future improvements in electric shavers will be made chiefly in the shaving head, rather than in the design of the implement, according to trade observers last week. The new Casco shaver introduced last week employs a new principle of rotary motion, combined with a combing principle.
Golf week and the Manoir Shield tournament, which was played today, were brought to a close with a dance tonight in the casino of the Manoir Richelieu.

The bombarding Newark Bears won a slugfest from the Red Wings today, 10 to 6, with a 14-hit attack on four Rochester hurlerss. The Bladesmen collected ten off three Bruin moundsmen, but couldn't stand the pace in the late innings.

THE NEW YORK COLLEGE OF MUSIC has begun its Summer courses. Members of the Summer school faculty are William O'Toole, Miguel Castellanos, Consuelo Clark, William Ebann, Mina Elman, Edythe Gilbert, Aurelio Giorni, Uarda Hein, Gottfried Kritzler, William Kraft, Hans Letz, Bernard Kwartin, Edward Schaefer, Vera Nette, John H. Noge, Carl Werschinger, Dr. Jacob Weinberg and A. Francis Pinto.
Praise of democracy by one of its leading exponents, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, rang through Soldier Field today.

Operation of a steam shovel tomorrow at noon by Mayor La Guardia, Senator Robert F. Wagner or Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, in Red Hook, Brooklyn, will mark the first actual step in the construction of a project under the Federal Government's $800,000,000 low-rent multiple dwelling program.

The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries, reported yesterday for the year ended on March 31 a net income of $2,508,288 after interest, depreciation, provision for doubtful accounts and Federal income taxes and after $129,245 surtax on undistributed profits.

The final and formal step in cancellation of preparations for the Olympic Games was taken this afternoon when the Olympic organizing committee and the Mayor of Tokyo decided to accept the Cabinet's recommendation.

Diplomatic relations between the United States and Vatican City appeared today to be a step nearer realization. The State Department prepared to send instructions to the American consulate in Rome, based on a Congressional amendment signed recently by President Roosevelt.

Miss Karla Lois Collins, daughter of Mrs. Martin Henry Collins of Montclair and the late Mr. Collins, was married to Dr. Stephen Habbe in Upper Montclair Presbyterian Church today. The Rev. Edwin I. Stearns, pastor of the Caldwell Presbyterian Church, officiated.

Lee M. Fairchild, chairman-of the Stamford, N. Y., woodchuck derby, advises that the- event has been postponed a week, until July 30. Due to recent rains, he says, thehay has not been cut and the fields are so thick that the woodchucks cannot be seen.

THE Summer tourist who is seeking a land where there is neither war nor rumor of war may look toward Iceland, reputed birthplace of Leif Ericsson, who discovered America in a Viking ship in the year 1000.

In contrast to the. expanded credit situation a year ago, which was credited with playing a major role in the price debacle which followed, terms are being held to a sixtyday basis in dealer operations in the fur trade.
ALTHOUGH the historical importance of Gustavus Hesselius has, of course, long been recognized, his work itself is less widely known than it deserves to be.
THERE'S much that's new about shoes. Keeping step with the fashion parade, they reflect the interest in silhouette, color and detail so strongly evident in clothes.

OVERSHADOWED to a great degree by power planes that criss-cross the United States and hop the Atlantic or Pacific with hardly more effort than earlier aviators exerted to span Long Island Sound, gliding in the United States is moving out into the sunlight.

Mrs. Rae Gilbert Johnson, a seamstress, filed a $102,814 petition in voluntary bankruptcy here today. In better days she and her contractor husband had built more than -seventy homes and sold them to people, who financed them through loan companies.

WASHINGTON. EVEN though the Federal Government has spent upward of $100,000,000 on ground aviation aids in the past few years, the advance in air transportation, with faster and larger planes carrying constantly heavier traffic, has kept ahead of the development of airfields and airways which has been one of the major objects of Works Progress Administration expenditures.

Swift precautions on the part of the management enabled.300 guests of the five-story Hotel Monterey here to sleep undisturbed early this morning while firemen extinguished a blaze started by a smoldering cigarette in the war on the ground floor. The fire, which did damage estimated at $20,000, was confined to the room.
TRAVEL by rail, according to all reports, is rapidly returning to pre-recession levels. Passenger revenues, which took a sharp downward drop last Fall, are mounting again.

THE complete revised programs of the concerts to be given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Serge Koussevitzky at the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, Aug. 4, 6, 7, 11, 13 and 14, in Tanglewood, Mass., differ from the originally contemplated schedule by an addition and a substitution.
Young high school graduates, casting about for solid and satisfying vocations, are turning increasingly to the twin fields of farming and horticulture.

Despite the protestations of Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, as Public Works Administrator, that the Federal Government, through the medium of the PWA, has no intention of encouraging municipalities to engage in direct competition with existing private power systems, utility quarters are far from convinced that any definite change has occurred in the Administration's attitude toward the $14,000,000,000 private power and light industry.

At least 10,000 physicians, more than half the doctors in active practice in the metropolitan area, have hospitalized members of the threecents-a-day plan for hospital care in the last three years, it was announced yesterday by Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service.

CONTINUED confidence in the automotive field was reflected in production schedules here last week. There was every indication that the output would exceed the 40,000 to 42,000 which has been the weekly normal for the past few months.

In a great driving finish after trailing the field at the start, Seabiscuit returned to his winning ways today, taking the $50,000 added Hollywood Gold Cup Handicap by a length in new track record time of 2:034-5 for the mile and a quarter.
Samuel Borden, president of the syndicate which is building a group of homes in the Manhattan Beach section of Coney Island, reports that the initial group of twenty homes is nearing completion.

THE Sea Scouts, young men 15 years of age and older, whose activities under the Boy Scouts of America take place on lakes, rivers, harbors, inland waterways and the rolling sea, are now having busy and happy days.

RADIO, which a year ago flashed the sad news of Marconi's death and tolled his requiem around the globe, broadcasts on Wednesday of this week in honor of the man who "did so much to turn wireless telegraphy from theory into fact."

Tomorrow will be the first of three festive days set aside for the observance in Nationalist [Insurgent] Spain of the beginning two years ago of the military movement that has already made Generalissimo Franco master of three-fourths of this country.

Declaring that in many up-State cities the situation in regard to certiorari proceedings has become "almost a racket," State Senator Pliny W. Williamson states that this condition could be corrected by creation of a State Board of Review of real property and assessment, which could be constituted as a wholly new agency or set up under the present State Tax Commission.

The following foreign service changes since July 2 were announced today by the State Department; Myrl S. Myers of Mechanicsburg, Pa., now serving in the Department of State, assigned as American Consul General at Canton.

A host of America's greatest aquatic stars will gather here next week for the annual women's national outdoor swimming meet staged by the Amateur Athletic Union. The meet, attracting entries from all sections of the country, will run from Friday through Sunday.

An order to show cause why the appointment of a referee to assess the amount of damages to be paid the Busch Jewelry Company and its affiliate, the Bush Kredit Company, by Optical Workers Union, Local 208, a C. I. O. organization, should not be vacated, was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer, who last Wednesday named Gerald F. Finley as referee.

The American Labor party organization of the Fifth Bronx Assembly District has endorsed Nathaniel M. Minkoff for renomination, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Minkoff is the leader of the Labor party delegation in the Assembly.

GABLE was explaining how men undress. Every one, it appeared, has a different technique. He illustrated his own by removing his shirt and exposing a brawny torso in the raw* * * for Clark never wears an undershirt.

Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston gave a dinner tonight at Old Trees for Mr. and Mrs. J. Denniston Lyon of Wyomissing, Locust Valley, who have arrived for the Summer at Sandymount, their home on the ocean.
Paterson defeated the Hudson County eleven of the Broolyn Cricket Club in a New Jersey State Leagueimatch

Ninety-six contract bridge players from New York and New England today started play in the major event of the Southern New England championships, the open pairs competition for the Lewis Osborn Trophy.

Eight out of thirty-eight retail divisions of local department stores had .gains in advertising linage during June, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records. Total linage for the month was 2,849,305, compared with 3,239,745 lines in' the same month a year ago.

One of the newer developments on the New Jersey coast below Point Pleasant, known as Cedarcroft, has witnessed considerable building activity since the community was opened in May, 1937, by the Vanard Corporation, headed by B. W. Ward.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.-For the first Summer in several years Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng have opened Four Fountains, their studio in Halsey Neck Lane, for a full season of artistic undertakings.

THIS book is the latest proof of the reviving reputation of Thomas Campion, who enjoyed great prestige in his own day and yet virtually dropped below the literary horizon until A. H. Bullen's "Lyrics From the Elizabethan Song Books" began the resurrection of his name and work in the year 1887.

Paul D. Shriver, Colorado WPA director, today discharged a WPA supervisor for ordering letters typed by WPA workers for the Pueblo County Democratic Central Committee thanking members of a reception committee which greeted President Roosevelt last Tuesday.
The Rev. Paul I. Morentz, Lutheran minister and advocate of an American haven for Jews persecuted in foreign lands, died today of a heart ailment at Lankenau Hospital. His age was 50.
The Rev. Dr. George Washington Babcock, retired Methodist Episcopal minister, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Methodist Episcopal Hospital here after a week's illness. He was 75 years old.
Japan's strong protest yesterday through the Charge d'Affairs in Moscow against an alleged invasion of Manchukuo was rejected by the Soviet Foreign Office, causing deep resentment here.

The ninth annual open championship for women of Fairfield and Westchester Counties will be conItested over the Wee Burn golf course at Darien. Conn., starting tomorrow and continuing through Wednesday.

Dr. J. A. Blaydes, known as a restorer of sight through surgery, disclosed today that an operation on a percheron colt born with congenital cataracts was successful. The operation was performed in a barn near Bland, Va.

SINCE the recent tightening of the Rebel ring in Southern Spain, short-wave programs from Madrid have been shifted from station EAQ to EAR, so at present direct reports from the Barcelona and Madrid fronts are flashed along the 9.49 megacycle lane each night at 8:40 Eastern daylight time. The EAQ outlet is silent.

The Rev. Michael O'Flanagan came back to New York yesterday aboard the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines to aid the Spanish Loyalist cause. He said, at an interview in the Hotel Lexington:

Recent evidences of a split in the ranks of the National Maritime Union, the C. I. O. waterfront affiliate, plus some lessening of the tension that has too long existed on shipboard and on pierhead, are hopeful indications-that our blue-water industry has passed its labor crisis.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced more than one point for the week ended July 9 and now stands at 77.3, as against 76.2 for the preceding week and 109.7 for the week ended July 10, 1937.
Four hundred naval reservists from Pennsylvania and New Jersey left the Philadelphia Navy Yard today aboard the battleship Arkansas for a two-week training cruise.
Many of the leading developers and builders in the Long Island suburban areas of Queens and Nassau Counties reported a steadily rising demand for low and medium priced homes last week.

CHAUTAUQUA, on the shore of Lake Erie, joins radio's array of Summer bandstands this week with Albert Stoessel directing the symphony orchestra on Saturday from 10:30 to 11 A. M. Microphones of WEAF's network will be on the scene each Saturday through Aug. 20.

IN America writers merge with cities, take on the protective coloration of cities, become their most distinctive local patriots. Mr. McIntyre's Philadelphia, llke James Farrell's bawling Chicago or Edith Wharton's rosetipped New York, has become not only a place in which people live and answer the Gallup questionnaire, but a window on America, a little city-State in which people are somehow not just people but the race of Philadelphians.

THREE expensive cameras and a twenty-five-dollar merchandise certificate will be awarded as prizes in a contest just announced by the New York City Department of Parks. Pictures representing "Youth and Age in Our Publio Parks" are eligible, and there are no restrictions on the number of prints a photographer may enter.

An all-Polish fashion display will be a feature of the Polish exhibit at the 1939 World's Fair, the office of she commissioner general arounces. There will be eight models to demonstrate women's wear designed and produced in Poland.
FIGURES are the fodder of the baseball fan. It's no wonder that there are so many cases of "heartburn" among the rooters. Some of the baseball figures are practically indigestible.

WHEN one excels, triumphantly, in a certain limited field, it must take resolution to progress to fresh pastures. Dorothy McCleary, as she proved first in "Not for Heaven," is pre-eminent as a creator of bizarre and racy characters.

The possible procedure to be followed by the various governmental agencies interested in real estate is one of the two important phases which must be carefully considered when attempting to analyze the real estate securities situation, declares H. R. nmott of Amott, Baker Co. in a report to the real estate securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America. The-other phase,
The remaining investments in Mexico of United States nationals are being frozen out or forced to the wall at a speed scarcely envisioned even by those who foresaw a year ago that trouble was coming.

Another attempt, the fifth, to climb Mount Everest has failed, and leigh-Mallory's, or rather his companion Bullock's, dictum that the chances against an assault party in any one season are fifty to one begins to appear dismally true.

A residence in Little Neck Hills, L. I., which was started by H. G. Calhoun in 1917, just before the great war activity in this country, and which was abandoned before completion by the mechanics, who were attracted to government work at double-pay rates, has been sold by Bryce Rea, Little Neck broker, to George H. Dodge of Boston. He plans extensive alterations before occupancy.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in smaller volume than in the preceding period, only one large retirement being included in the new announcements. Payment dates of the new calls were mostly for August.

President Roosevelt won almost everything he could desire in Oklahoma's Democratic primary election this week. Senator Elmer Thomas, endorsed for the nomination by the President in the speech here last Saturday, won in a walk.
Considerable progress is being made in revived discussions for the establishment of a safety zone by Hankow leaders and the international foreign missionary group.

HERE is a type of book that exists nowhere but in America. It lists the works and activitie and gives biographical sketches of 200 composers, natives and settlers, who have been prominent in American musical life in the last twenty-five years.

Tentative plans for -a $4,850,000 project, the construction of a Navy Medical Center which is to be one of the most modern institutions of its kind in the world, will be considered here later this month by the Park and Planning Commission and the Fine Arts Commission.

The Bronx Board of Trade announces that the Department of Docks plans to request the WPA authorities in this city to set up a project for the removal of abandoned and derelict craft in the waters around New York.

Mrs. Conrad H. Matthiessen of New York, who is passing the Summer at Lake Placid Club, where she occupies Ononda Cottage, will be hostess tomorrow to members of the Lake Placid Garden Club, who, on their first garden day of the season, will inspect her gardens.
