Miss Boudinot Atterbury Oberge, daughter of Mrs. George Farr Oberge of Upsala, Haverford, was married this afternoon to Lieutenant Charles Hansford Kendall, U. S. N., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Kendall, formerly of Baltimore.

President Lazaro Cardenas issued an executive decree today taking the government out of the actual operation of the petroleum business, except in Mexico City, and turning operations in the field over to union leaders.

The mare Esposa and Jockey Nick Wall, who brought off a knothole victory along the fence over Seabiscuit last Fall, did the same thing before 15,000 persons at Empire City. yesterday to capture the $26,400 Butler Hardicap. and seta new track record.

THIS year the old Mississippi River of showboat fame is playing host to its, own particular type of Summer cruise. Cruise parties leave Chicago by train on Tuesdays and Fridays, spend the night at Clinton, Iowa, and go aboard a river boat early the next morning.

Invading the lair of Pie Traynor's very surprising Pirates, the Giants today conducted a thorough investigation whetherthese Corsairs, who so unexpectedly thrust themselves in the National League's 1938 peniriat; picture, were really' fightIng or just fooling.

As a result of the order issued yesterday in New Haven, Conn., by Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks that the New Haven Railroad close eightyeight stations on the line of the Old Colony Railroad, the Massachusetts Legislature voted early today for an investigation of the road and its subsidiaries.

Unique in that none of the contestants had ever participated in the grueling endurance test previously, eight athletes began their quest for the National A. A. U. senior decathlon championship yesterday at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island quarters. They completed half of the tenevent program.
" Just a home garden such as any one can make," is the way Mrs. Meta Bally of 165 Summit Avenue, Jersey City, describes the garden she has created during the past four years.

The Autumn drive in New York for new members to further the work of The Seeing Eye, Inc., will be conducted by twenty-one committees from Oct. 17 to Nov. 15. Each group will have ten members and a vice chairman, the entire enrollment being under the chairmanship of Mrs. Arthur S. Lord of 530 East Eighty-sixth Street.

More than 10,000 persons from the United States and Canada are expected to gather here Friday and Saturday for the annual conference of the Eastern States mission of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. An outdoor pageant from the Book of Mormon will be a feature of the session.

Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, said today she had received a cheering cable from Washington reporting decreased unemployment in June "for the first time since the depression in November,"
The whole nation is encompassed when President Roosevelt addresses a radio audience as My Friends, but only a selected few among the 130,000,000 are accorded the special description, My Old Friends.

A message from Dr. James E. West, Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, to William D. Murray of Plainfield, N. J., one of the members of the first national executive board of the organization, who will celebrate his eightieth birthday today.

Two girls were burned to death today when fire of undetermined origin ruined a two-family house here. The victims were Helen Littell, 12, of Newton, N. J., and her niece, Patricia Thompson, 5, of Middletown.

A new begonia is making Its debut in America this year. A native of Sweden, it was originally named Gustav Lind, but since its arrival in this country it has been renamed Westport Beauty. Under that title it is finding a place in florist shops and greenhouses. Technically, Gustav Lind is its only correct cognomen.
Having completed its deliberations upon evidence submitted at public hearing and at many conferences, the committee on taxation of the Constitutional Convention made its report under date of July 7.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of licenses for service, as indicated, in junior high schools, as of the dates indicated, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted license.

PAUL EINZIG is an able financial journalist who has the gift of making contemporary financial history exciting and entertaining. He writes a daily column about Lombard Street in The Financial News of London and is a frequent contributor to other British publicatUons.

MID-JULY is a good time to dwell on the merits of a tall glass of sparkling ided coffee-topped off maybe, with a generous blob ol whipped cream. And the recent news that coffee imports are up and that prices are down, introduces the subject of liquid refreshments just when it is most in our minds.

The newer hybrid daylilies now available provide the gardener with an exceptionally satisfactory type of plant material for the midsummer garden. They offer great variety in color, form and height. The color range extends from reddish-brown, through orange to palest yellow; and a pure white form has been reported.
New York and New Jersey and Pennsylvania are represented on the national committees of the Daughters ,of the American Revolution as announced today by Mrs. Henry M. Robert Jr., president general.

Characterizing the mounting public debt as "that old hobgoblin," Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, defended the "pump priming" and relief expenditures of the national government in an address at the Chautauqua Institution today, and denied political coercion of WPA workers.
THE American Guild of Musical Artists, slightly over two years old, is getting pretty big for its age, and found it had to do something about it. So,

The time has gone by when any citizen of New York City would read the entire budget, the Controller's report, or all the reports of all the city departments, unless his duties or very special interests required him to do so.

Historic First Presbyterian Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elin Anderson and Richard Hartman Haigh, whose engagement was announced in January. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. George A. Liggett, performed the ceremony.

Mohammed Hassan Youssef, Egyptian Consul in New York, made public yesterday a statement received from his government informing all ex-subjects of the Ottoman Empire born to fathers who also were born in Egypt that the Convention on Nationality concluded between Egypt and Turkey on April 7, 1937, became effective from May 11, 1938.
METHODS of avoiding weekend congestion pending the completion of current construction on popular routes of Saturday and Sunday travel have been suggested by authorities in New Jersey and New York.

Inspector Eugene F. Hoyt of the Batavia State Police Barracks said today that an attempt was being made to link the hitch-hike murder of a Pennsylvania motorist and the year-old, unsolved murder of Morris B. Close, a Rochester scoutmaster.
Paul V. McNutt's candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President in 1940 is no longer in question so far as Indiana Democrats view the matter.

A sharply worded denial of a report circulated by the official German news agency to the effect that Czechoslovakia was carrying out troop-mobilization movements along the German frontier was officially issued here tonight.

The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Hyer, daughter of Mrs. Mont W. Hyer of this city, to Leonard F. Beckers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Beckers of South Orange, N. J., will take place here on Aug. 6 in St. Bernard's Church. The Rev. C. A. Heavey, the pastor, will perform the ceremony.

An exhibition home of modified Georgian architecture recently built by Town Builders, Inc.,. has been opened for inspection at Twentyeighth Avenue and 156th Street, Flushing, L. I. The house is built of cinder concrete masonry ashlar walls and partitions with concrete joist and slab fireproof floors, finished in wood. This is a two-story dwelling.

The engagement of Miss Betsy Rice of New York, daughter of Mrs. James Wilmot Rice of this place and the late Mr. Rice, to Dr. Thomas Parker Hamilton Jr., also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton of Plainfield, N. J., has been announced by her mother.

Renewed optimism among small and large business men, "reflected in a willingness to spend money for merchandise and equipment," was reported yesterday by Henry Modell, sporting goods retailer and official of the Smaller Business Association, following a ten-day buying trip throughout New York State.

BRIDGE suits are on the ebb. The fifth suit which recently created a furor by its appearance in the pack has dropped out of the news. Last week two more suits went into the discard when the action brought by Mrs. Giovannina Farrelly against Ely Culbertson and his countersuit against her were settled amicably.

The Summer colony turned out in large numbers today to witness the first invitation regatta of the Bellport Yacht Club. The cruisers of many well-known Brooklyn, Manhattan and New Jersey residents were to be seen around the triangular course.

The marriage of Miss Catharine Tuttle, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Watkins Tuttle of Watkins, N. Y., to Randolph Forman took place here today in Christ Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Thomas W. Daniel.

MODERN zoos are designed so that certain animals (bears, zebras, antelope and deer) are kept in enclosures closely approximating their respective natural backgrounds, with water-filled moats and low guardrails between the spectators and the animals, thus affoding an unobstructed view for the camera man.
TOMORROW the Metropolitan will place on public view in its room of recent accessions four newly acquired canvases by contemporary American painters:

Production figures issued by the Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company for the second quarter of this year show increases in zinc, copper and gold output and decreases in lead and silver, compared with the first quarter of this year, while output of all metals was higher than in the second quarter of 1937.
The navy gave the command of its Lakehurst airship station today to Commander Jesse L. Kenworthy Jr. for a second time.

Riding through some of the most sensational polo the Meadow Brook Club -championship tournament has ever seen, the Gulf Stream four captained by Mike Phipps emerged ,victorious over the-Aiken Knights and the Pelicans today-on Phipps Field to break the triple tie in the Brook. League.

Miss Helen G. Ferguson of Stamford, Conn., entertained at bridge and dinner last night in the grill room of the Mansion House. At another bridge and dinner party at the hotel Mrs. Lammot du Pont of Wilmington, Del., had as her guests Mrs. Richard E. Riegel, Mrs. Walter S. Carpenter Jr. and Mrs. Willis F. Harrington of Wilmington;
King George has made such a good recovery from his recent illness that it is now probable that the strenuous program of his French visit will not be curtailed.

To construct a stairway which will be easy to ascend and descend, a builder points out that the risers should be as low as the dimensions of the stairway will permit and the treads wide enough so that an averaged-size foot can rest upon them at full length.

Society women who pass the Summer in their country homes in the North and South Shore colonies show a growing preference for golf as their outdoor recreation and this season, more than ever before, both the younger and older players are devoting hours to the game on the links of their own or neighboring clubs.
THE Scacheris preach professionalism. Amateurs in every art are inclined to take vanilla when a choice is offered. They avoid the strong, the active, the vivid.

THE MIDDLE WAY: It is the fashion nowadays vehemently to denounce or as vehemently to extol the system of this or that foreign country. Last week Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden introduced the novelty of defending his country against excessive praise.

LEADING publishers of England, France, Germany, Hungary, Sweden, Poland, the United States, Italy, Holland and Czechoslovakia have joined forces in sponsoring the second All Nations-Prize Novel Competition.

Jack Kramer of Los Angeles today won the national interscholastic tennis championship when his fellow Californian, Charles (Ted) Olewine of Santa Monica, was forced to default when he twisted a cartilage in his knee during the third set.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage on June 26 at the Mount Royal Hotel, Montreal, of Miss Edith Lillian Wexler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Wexler of Westmount-Montreal, to Bernard H. Payton, son of Mrs. Harry Payton of Providence, R. I., and the late Mr. Payton.
ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE was born in 1805. In 1827, after a period of law study and some foreign travel he obtained a minor judicial post at Versailles.

August will be a peculiarly interesting month for dog exhibitors in that it will be marked by the debut in the show field of two organizations which promise to present exhibitions worthy of the best traditions of the sport.

Two large properties on Cape Cod, Mass., have just been sold, reports Previews, Inc., of this city. One deal involved the South Chatham estate of Danforth W. Comins of Boston, which was purchased by a client of John L. Snow, West Harwich broker.

IS a cruise ship a ship or a hotel when it stops cruising and stays in port? This week-end, while ships on two new cruises are bound from New York for one-day and threeday stays in Bermuda's blue waters, the islanders are discussing this question, and tomorrow the Bermuda Parliament will renew arguments on what to do about the situation.

Into his 33 years, 6 months, 3 weeks and 2 days aboard this spinning earth Howard Hughes-industrialist, motionpicture producer and aviator -- has crowded many experiences. Into last week he managed to crowd an extra day.
Paced by Harlond Clift's eleventh and twelfth homers, the Browns ended a tengame losing streak today by whipping the Red Sox, 8 to 3. It was St. Louis' first victory this season in Boston.
The Grand Circuit's nine-day Maine meeting over the kite-shaped mile track here opened today with straight-heat victories chalked up in two of the three, events;

The $3,150,000,000 of excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System reported last week is likely to be the peak in the expansion of surplus bank reserves for several months to come, in the opinion of various bankers.

The social activities of the fortieth annual race week of the Larchmont Yacht Club here were inaugurated with a flag officers' ball tonight. The officers this year are Commodore Thomas L. Burton, Vice Commodore Harvey Conover, Rear Commodore Clair L. Farrand, Robert E. Carrick, secretary;

A new residential community will be formally opened today in Westfield, N. J., by the Fidelity Construction Company, owners of a large tract fronting on Benson Place. The new development will be known as Park Acres.

Police Commissioner Valentine dismissed from the department yesterday Patrolman Thomas M. Carey, 31 years old, of 163 Wyckoff Street, Brooklyn, attached to the Gates Avenue station, Brooklyn. Carey disappeared from his home on June 17 and the department has not heard from him.

A secondary travel season that comes after the third week in July, when tariffs are reduced, is gradually becoming an important feature of transatlantic business, according to New York shipping agents.

THE sixteenth festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music, which has been held in London this year, has given abundant evidence of vitality. If there are not enough people interested in the movement to fill the Queen's Hall,
Three Santa Cruz boys who "borrowed" a $25,000 yacht for a cruise to the South Seas returned home on the vessel today and confessed that they were "plenty tired of the sea."
The annual member-and-guest invitation golf tournament at the Apawamis Club began today with 144 competitors playing qualifying and quarter-final rounds.
A service in memory of United States Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo was held in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninetyfirst Street, yesterday.
A NEW anthology of Modern poetry by an adventurous editor is welcome at any time and Mr. Rodman has taken almost every advantage of the excitement of our contemporary verse.

IN a book of less than 125 pages, and with the assistance of 158 illustrations, the foremost authority on the ballet has achieved an essential history of this type of dance. Andthis is in spite of Mr., Haskell's modest disclaimer of so comprehensive a purpose for his little volume. He has only tried,

A compromise proposal in the pending railway wage controversy which would leave union wages at 1929 levels is being discussed as a possible move in the negotiations that are to be opened in Chicago on Wednesday, it was made known yesterday.
The outdoor opertta season ended last night at Jones Beach, and is to end tonight at Randalls Island, after failure of the producers and various union affected to iron out their differences.

TONIGHT the thoughts of some 30,000 Americans getting on in their middle forties may go back to the night of July 17 twenty years ago. By now they must have exhausted their vocabularies upon the weather of that night and would be grateful for any new way of saying that the rain came down in sheets and that the night itself was as black as pitch.
Hollyrood Perry; owned and driven by Eugene Carpenter of this city, won the free-for-all trot today in one of the fastest three-heat-races seen at the Weequahic track.
Original brick used in building Colonial homes in Virginia and New England was first imported as ballast from England and then later made in the colonies from native clay.

More than 2,000 children who would not otherwise be able to go to camp this Summer will be able to do so by special provisions made at the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, 122 East Twenty-second Street.

The Administration's lending-spending attack on the depression showed signs today of generating demands from many communities and Congress members that still more money for public works be appropriated at the next session of Congress.

To members of the New Jersey polo fraternity the most-prized trophy offered in the annual Monmouth County Horse Show is the H. L. Herbert Cup, named in honor of the late chairman of the polo association.
A garland of ground pine and water lilies will be placed about the flagpole in the center of the Boston University Sargent Summer Camps on Half-Moon Lake at Peterborough, N. H., Thursday.
Mrs. Clarence Howland of this place has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Sylvia Louise Mauldin Howland, to Richard Beddow of Rockford, Ill.

MURDER in a locked room is old stuff, but when the victim of the murder is a student of demonology and other esoteric lore, and the other characters include professional conjurers, clairvoyants, escape artists,

The Rev. Paul J. Swick, who served as athletic director at St. Peter's College from 1930 to 1933, has been appointed Pofessor of Sophomore Classics at the college, it is announced. He succeeds the Rev. Joseph T. Clark, who has been sent to Woodstock College, Maryland, for theological studies.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-With construction of a number of traps completed by the newly formed Atlantic City Gun Club, a new attraction has been added to the resort's already long list.

Compensation trade carried on by Germany with Latin-American countries swung into the foreground of foreign trade discussion here last week following Berlin's decision to suspend dealings with Brazil.
With Merrill and Jack Fink leading the way in a last-period rally, Blind Brook defeated Governors Island, 8 to 6, today in a semi-final match of the Rumson Country Club's twelve-goal polo tournament.

Approval of its reorganization plan, which sharply cut down fixed charges, was urged today upon the Interstate Commerce Commission in a brief filed by the Chicago North Western Railway Company which charged among other things that "fantastic" interpretations by the National Adjustment Board and "social experimentation" by the government justified the proposals that it had made.

Sir Frederick Banting, discoverer of insulin treatment for diabetes, visited police headquarters today and told police he and his assistants had devised a new method for resuscitating drowning persons.. He asked police aid in getting to the scene of drownings in the city.

After-Beau Brummell had fallen out with his patron, the Prince of Wales, later George IV, the fashion-plate of the Byronic era was invited to a reception for the Prince. Ignoring the guest of honor but addressing his host, he said:
THE Silvermine Festival at Silvermine, Conn., will open Aug. 18 with a concert by the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, with Blair McCloskey, baritone, as soloist.
Here is some good news for the President. The wild wahoo and the rooster fish await his hook. There's lots of good fishing down where Mr. Roosevelt will be next week.

Enthusiasm and appreciation of subject matter combined with greater knowledge of a central field of interest have resulted from the first year's experiment with the new five-year curriculum at Redding Ridge School in Connecticut, according to Kenneth Bonner, head master.

Dean, whose ailing arm has kept him inactive since May 3, is to pitch for the Cubs tomorrow-and on his performance may hang Chicago's already slim chances of getting'back into the National League pennant fight.

The memory of Dr. Charles Gilmore Maphis, founder and director for eleven years of the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs, was honored at today's closing session of the annual institute in a resolution adopted unanimously both as a tribute of personal affection and a pledge of continuing support of the forum of which he was the father.
Harry Ginsburg of New York City was out 20 cents today as a result of pleading guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to two charges of attempting to pass counterfeit money.

During June the firm of Pease Elliman, Inc, closed 437 leases for apartments in buildings under its management, as against 373 in the same month last year, an increase of 17 per cent, Lawrence Br Elliman Jr. announced yesterday.

Spencer Smith, veteran of the Civil War who had served as grand marshal of the local Memorial Day parade for the last three years, died in his home here today of the infirmities of age and a complication of diseases. He was 94 years old.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Alice Cargill Taylor, daughter of Mrs. William Ehlers Taylor of Flushing, Queens, and Dongan Hills, S. I., to Thomas Jay Gorham, son of Mrs. Thomas Jay Gorham of Rochester, N. Y., and the late Mr. Gorham.

Discussing the features of the new farm mortgage insurance program of the Federal Housing Administration, Stewart McDnald said yesterday that the chief aims were to bring farm ownership and better living conditions within the reach of thousands of additional farm families.

The Phillies, cellar-dwellers in the National League. advanced within seven games of the Cardinals by beating St. Louis behind Al Hollingsworth's five-hit pitching today, 2 to 1, in the opener of a four-game series. It was the Cards' thirteenth defeat in their last fourteen games.

Investors Fund C, Inc., reported yesterday that the valuation of its fund was $10.11 a share on June 30, against $9.37 a share on Dec. 31. The following changes in security holdings in the three months were reported:

The former private residence of Walter L. Tyler, at 80 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, now nearly a century old, has been remodeled by the Irving Trust Company, fiduciary manager of the building, as a small apartment house.

Continuing their brilliant subpar golf, Eddie Foy and Dr. Stephen G. Lee Jr. of Essex Fells, the medalists, advanced to the semi-finals of the sixth annual New Jersey amateur best-ball championship today at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.

PICKING up this Thsmes side serial where we left off last month, with the cables rushing an invitation to Kenny Baker to appear as Nanki-Poo in "The Mikado," we can now report that Mr. Baker is here and that several hundred feet of his celebrated voice are safely recorded on film at time of writing.

THOSE who read the author's excellent "Sou'wester Sails" when it appeared about a year ago will welcome another chance to follow the adventures of Corry and Jim Laight and their friend Durk Romby, although "Sou'wester Goes North" is complete in itself.

Cornelius F. Shea, aide to the late Timothy P. (Little Tim) Sullivan, vice president of the Board of Aldermen and a leader in Tammany at Hall, died Friday at his home, 121 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn.
No settlement was expected before Monday in the contract deadlock between striking workers of the National Sugar Refining Company here and company officials.

The overnight announcement that the Agricultural Adjustment Administration would seek to reduce the acreage for the wheat crop in 1939 to 55,000,000 acres, or 26,000,000 acres less than was seeded this year, fell flat today as a market influence.
Winners of scholarships offered by the Fire Department branch of the Holy Name Society were announced yesterday by Deputy Chief John J. McCarthy, president of the society.

The repeat performance of "Carmen,"- given last night under cloudless skies, brought again a large audience to Lewlsohn Stadium. The principals were, as before, Bruna Castagna in the title role and Armand Tokatyan as Don Jose.

Responding with a thrilling stretch drive when called upon by Jockey Leonard Turner, Hal Price Headley's Preeminent captured the $4,000 added Tomlin Handicap at Rockingham Park by a neck today over the Wheatley Stable's Merry Lassie to pay $9.14 for $2. A crowd of 20,000 saw the feature race.

A growing demand for farm properties in communities in upper New York State is indicated in a list of sales made in the last few weeks by George B. Ray, a Kingston broker. The latter reported that he had sold and delivered thirty-two parcels and had binders signed for twelve others.

The Brazilian Central Railway is reported to have completed arrangements for the purchase of twenty-two locomotives from the Baldwin Locomotive Works and for 1,000 freight cars from other United States manufacturers.

William E. Schramek of Larchmont, an attorney, chairman of the Westchester Citizens Committee for reopening of the defunct New York, Westchester Boston Railway lines, was designated last night by the Twenty-fifth Senatrial District Democratic Committee to oppose State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale, Republican designee for re-election, in the November election.
Cuba will not admit ordinary political refugees beyond the quotas in the present immigration laws, but is ready to receive capitalists, the State Department announced today.

McLEOD, WILLIAM (July 2.) Estate, more than $1O,000. To Dean Adams, sister, Atlanta, Ga., real property and tesidue in trust; Florence Delisle, sister, Houston, Texas, one-third remainder interest. Raymond M. Delisle, nephew, Austin, Texas, and City Bank Farmers Trust Co., 22 William St., executors.

Thomas P. Burke, real estate insurance broker and prominent in Catholic affairs, died yesterday at his home, 102 West Eighty-ninth Street, at the age of 73. Born in St. Bridget's Parish in East Eighth Street in 1865, Mr. Burke was the son of Captain Richard Burke, who fought in the papal armies in 1870, and the former Margaret Clear.
THE direction of the Opera and the Opera-Comique is obliged to present every year a certain number of novelties more or less French and also a certain number of revivals of one soft or another.
It has fallen to the lot of Northport Harbor to be the scene this month of a regatta that will have a significant bearing on speed boat racing plans of the future.

Tony Galento, the heavyweight from Orange, boxed instead of slugged with his sparring partners: today -at Madame Bey's$camp and was practically just as effective. It was the first time he hd.d used a left jab effectively since he stopped Al Et- tore.

Repeating his Davis Cup challenge round victory over Charles Hare of Great Britain, Frank Parker gained the final of the annual Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today on the clay courts of the Bathing and Tennis Club.

The marriage of Miss Alys Phyfe Baird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Parfitt Baird of this place and 47 East Eighty-eighth Street, New York, to Robert Beverly Falk, son of Mrs. Nils Falk of Bay Shore and the late Mr. Falk, took place here this afternoon in St. Peter's Church.

Indications of wide variations in the extent of activity in real estate in various parts of the country form one of the interesting features of the thirty-first semi-annual survey of the market, just completed by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
John D. M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, addressing 1,000 Republican leaders of Central New York at Newport today gave the New Deal policies of President Roosevelt a severe raking over.
A homemade biplane, twelve feet long with a wing spread of only thirteen feet, received a successful test flight today at Lambert-St. Louis Airport.

An "electric-eye" apparatus for determining the concentration of Vitamin A in substances by measuring the amount of light absorbed by this so-called anti-infective vitamin, forms the subject matter of a patent (No. 2,123,573) just granted to Ronald L. McFarlan, Marblehead Neck, Mass., and James Wallace Reddie of Hull, Mass.

The Senators defeated the White Sox today, 3 to 2, after tying the score in the sixth inning and capitalizing on an outfield error in the seventh. It was the Senator's seventh victory in the last nine games.

Franklin Delano Roosevelt is still America's star performer in the ever-changing political drama that continues to "pack 'em in." To look back on his transcontinental swing and his recent appearance in the East is to recognize that he has lost none of his old appeal for the man in the street.
Eugene Gray Foster of 950 Park Ave., New York, a special partner in the Stock Exchange firm of Foster Adams, died at his Summer home here today at the age of 69.

The increase in fabric prices last week and the prospect of further advances have failed to induce coat and suit manufacturers to modify their conservative buying policies, according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

AS a stamp salesman, Uncle Sam has just had another million dollar year-the fourth one in succession. Figures made public last week by the Postoffice Department disclosed that sales aggregated $1,685,752,73 at the government's Philatelic Agency in Washington during the fiscal period ended June 30.

The wedding of Miss Amy Irene Gibson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Gibson of this place, and David C. MacMurray of Morris Plains, son of Mrs. Ida S. MacMurray and the late Rev. John MacMurray, took place here today in Ogden Memorial Presbyterian Church. The Rev.

THE author of this book is foreign affairs editor of The Manchester Guardian. The biographical paragraph on the inside front flap of the jacket tells us that "as a foreign correspondent he has lived in Germany, Russia, the Ruhr and Turkey," and that "reporting has brought him twice to arrest, once almost to lynching and once almost to execution."

President Roosevelt's appointment of Elmer F. Andrews, New York's Industrial Commissioner, as Wage-Hour Administrator opened speculation today as to his successor and removed one more potential candidate from the State's Fall political campaign.

The marriage of Miss Dorothea Hammond Boorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burt H. Boorn of this city, to Edwin Matthias Shultes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Shultes Jr. of Albany, took place here this afternoon in Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church. The Rev.

THE popular conception of the scholar as a bearded and bespectacled practitioner of a mysterious craft poring over yellowed documents in the inner recesses of a library receives. some healthy jolts from Charles Roberts Anderson in the current issue of The Colophon.

Each of the following Reserve officers, effective July 24: 1st Lt. Frederick T. Kent Jr., Inf.-Res., 22 Morton St., Bloomfield, N. J. 1st Lt. Charles W. Kenyon. Inf.-Res., 701 Monmouth St., Trenton, N. J.

At Deauville huge upturned fly-away hats, resembling umbrellas blown inside out and denuded of ribs, are worn by smart women; they are of straw pique, and even of lace or tulle and trimmed with a sizable bouquet under the brim.
Philip W. Kniskern, president of the First Mortgage Corporation of Philadelphia, declares that the desire for home ownership is stronger today than has been the case for many years.

The press almost ignores the closing of the conference on refugees in Evian, France. The Boersen Zeitung says that since President Roosevelt called this conference, it could not be confused with a conference called by "that farce the League of Nations," but that its accomplishments were as fruitless as the League's.

Representatives of five marine unions will meet today to consider plans for action against the government's so-called hiring hall, the Sea Service Bureau, recently established by the Department of Commerce at 45 Broadway for recruiting replacements on government-owned vessels.

Fall lines of foundation garments will be opened by many producers tomorrow, with showings both at hotels and private showrooms, Among hotel showings will be those at the Vanderbilt and the McAlpin. Warner Brothers Company, Inc., will hold a fashion and promotional show at the Hotel Astor Tuesday morning, to be followed by luncheon.
THIS morning at dawn the Aorangi entered Waitemata Bay and sidled quietly up to the large customs dock just off King's Drive,' Auckland.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated July 15: BRIGADIER GENERAL Chaney, J. E., assistant to the Chief of the Air Corps, one month and 15 days leave, July 17.

Results of the activities of the National Youth Administration in New York City, covering three years, were disclosed in reports made yesterday at its New York office, 265 West Fourteenth Street. Helen M. Harris is director for the city.

AS Henrik Pontoppidan now in a third little pocket manual continues his personal reminniscences,' it becomes clear that these memoirs are a significant record of vital, stirring developments in Danish social and literary history.

Mayor LaGuardia yesterday warned realty dealers and others interested in real estate against paying more than the official price for copies of the Assessed Valuation of Real Estate and the Land Value Maps, official publications of the city which are printed at the City Record offices.
Paris is all bedecked with Union Jacks these days, in honor of next week's visit of king George and Queen Elizabeth of Great Britain, Ireland and the Dominions Beyond the Seas.

Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein hopes to complete arrangements to leave on Wednesday on board the Queen Mary for Europe, where he will make a flying survey of airports in behalf of the United States Conference of Mayors.
Brisk bidding by an unknown buyer caused the Swiss franc to strengthen here today from 21.55 3/4 to 21.52 3/4 to the pound sterling.
Northern interests met a setback today in their efforts to prove that Southern shippers should not obtain Lower freight rates on northbound goods.
Buonriposo, the Summer residence of Mrs. Shepard Fabbri of New York will be opened to the public on Wednesday, Aug. 10, when the Hampton Singers will present a series of spiritual songs.

Frank Guernsey, the Rice Institute tennis star who recently captured the national, intercollegiate championship, made his way into the final round of the New York State clay court title tournament at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

Because of its ever-blooming character and adaptability, the Godfrey callas merits wider attention as a house plant. The blooms are smaller than those of the old-fashioned calla, but that drawback is offset by their sup ?? fragrance, delicacy and beauty.
Appointment of Mikhail P. Frinovsky, Vice Commissar of Internal Affairs, as NKVD [secret police] Commissar for the Forestry Area was announced today in the Khabarovsk newspaper Pacific Ocean Star.

Miss Annette Madden of New York and Orange, N. J., was married here this morning in St. Catharine's Church to Bernard John J. Mooney, son of the late Dr. and firs. John J. Mooney of Jersey City. The ceremoney was performed by the Rev. Thomas U. Reilly.

Jobs for 4,952 men on construction or in the production of materials are in prospect as the result of the allocation of funds for add tional sections of the East River Drive announced here yesterday by Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the PWA.

TODAY'S matter of consequence is the Maxwell Anderson-Kurt Weill operetta about our town in the time of its settlement by the Dutch. Scheduled to be the second project of the producing playwrights, it may be identified hereafter as a "musical pastoral" called "Knickerbocker Holiday." Casting goes forward.

BATAVIA, Netherland India.Apprehensive that Japan would attack Netherland India if open warfare deprived the Japanese of their American supply of oil, the Netherlands is planning action to check any drive toward the rich stores of fuel in her colonies.
Two new developments mark the gradual tendency toward a resumption of authority in the district of Hongkew on the part of the Shanghai Municipal Council.

Two fugitives from the Connecticut State Prison Farm at Enfield are under arrest here after a flight through three States, during which they commandeered two automobiles and left the drivers tied to trees.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read the letter which appeared in THE TIMES on the solution of the housing problem as proposed by Harold G. Aron and a second letter by Maurice Deutsch quoting and elaborating upon Mr. Aron's proposals.

Detective Lieutenant Burt Corliss, driving a new car, reached the top of a steep hill on London Street last night about the time Mrs. Goldie Romm alighted from her automobile, headed downgrade. Apparently she did not set the brakes securely and the machine started to roll.
Fred B. Meyer, president of the United Grape Products Sales Corporation, in a statement yesterday, predicted a price rise from a 100,000-ton shortage in the Concord grape harvest.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, asserted today that the Republican party expected to elect 71 new Representatives and 7 new Senators "to give the country a real bull tip for prosperity."

FROM Italy of the sixteenth century, Lehman Engel jumps his Madrigal Singers across the Atlantic to give us a program of American songs dating from pre-Revolutionary days to this gide of the Civil War.

Houses formed the bulk of the real estate turnover yesterday in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn. A deal near Rockefeller Center involved the four-story house at 56 West Fifty-second Street, near Sixth Avenue, which was sold by the estate of Henrietta McReady Bagg through William C. Walker's Sons and Dowd Clemens, brokers.

Theodore Stanfield, peace advocate and former official of the American Metal Company, left a bequest of $10,000 to the Children's Charitable Union of 77 Park Avenue in his will which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 14: COMMANDERS Kenworthy, J. L. Jr., to duty as commanding officer, Naval Air Station, Lakehurst, N. J.

Mrs. Albert Conway, wife of Supreme Court Justice Conway, and his sister, Miss Genevieve Conway, are expected from Brooklyn next Thursday to pass the season at the Inn. Justice Conway and other members of the family will arrive later.

Edward P. Alexander, State director of the Historical Records Survey, a WPA project, announced today the publication of "Broome County Archives." This is the second volume of the inventory of county records in the State, the first covering Albany County.

Alexander Tison, retired New York lawyer, died today in the home of his son here as the result of complications that developed after he had fractured his skull in a fall a month ago. Mr. Tison was 80 years old.
Dr. Joseph W. Dennin, an obstetrician in Union County, died this morning at the United States Veterans Hospital at Lyons following a long illness. His age was 47.
HOWARD R. HUGHES'S record-breaking round-the-world flight and the swift first leg of his journey-the hop from New York to Paris-emphatically point the question:

Miss Mary de Mumm, 23, and Mrs. Josephine Treadwell, about 40, both of New York City, were killed today when a car in which they were riding turned over on United States Highway No. 8, seventeen miles north of here.
From all sides come reports that not in many years have roses been so fine as they are this year. Cool nights and plenty of rain have seemed to develop them to perfection.

The Castille Army Corps, under General Jose Varela, today broke the government lines between Manzanera and Mora de Rubielos, east of Teruel, in a rapid advance from Sarrion toward Sagunto on the coast. Before nightfall they had pushed ten miles beyond their point of departure, according to a Burgos war communique.
Some important dividend meetings this week by, companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

Is there any satisfactory key the increasingly grave situation in Palestine? Is there some way whereby Jew, Arab and Briton can be spared the current war of attrition? Those questions grow more vital with each day's events.

THE Barnstomers differ from most Summer theatres in that they barnstorm. Our field of operation, Central New Hampshire, is sparsely settled. Our home town, Tamworth, boasts a scant 600 people, most of them on remote roads far from the quiet village.

ENVISAGING a world run by wireless, Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, called attention to the fact that "we live in a broadcast age, the consequences of which no man can measure," as he participated in the recent dedication of WGY's, new studios at Schenectady.

THE House of Commons paused recently to consider the case of the chimney sweep. At one time the sweep was considered a more or less shady character, who tortured the children in his employ. Various Parliamentary statutes were enacted to restrain him, and present-day sweeps find the restrictions irksome.

The Harlan conspiracy trial ended its ninth week today with the prospect that the defense will rest early next week after completing the cases of seventeen coal corporations, eighteen company officials and twentyone former peace officers.

IT sounds like a fairly tale, and yet it is a fact confirmed by official documents, that twentyfour French communes in the Jura Mountains, with a total population of about 10,000, pay no local taxes. Instead, each inhabitant receives a yearly dividend ranging from 100 to 200 francs.
THOSE with a penchant for symbolism might well have found grist in the recent burning of the French Line's S. S. Lafayette.

When the National Conference on Health and Medical Care meets here Monday, it will be on the birthday anniversary of the oldest social welfare agency in the Federal Government and possibly one of the oldest in the world.

The third annual conference on educational and vocational guidance in New York State will be held Friday and Saturday at Syracuse University. This is a cooperative project sponsored jointly by the State Education Department and the university.

A new type of automatic telephone central office, known to telephone technicians as "the crossbar," so perfect in operation that it "thinks," or when "sick" reports its own disability, was put into service at 1 A. M. today by the New York Telephone Company at 227 East Thirtieth Street.

A symposium on cities and their problems featured yesterday's program of the Northfield Missionary Conference, which is being attended daily by 500 women from a dozen Protestant denominations throughout the east. The Rev. Stanley B.
E. Everett Gibbs, manufacturer, who was 64 years old Thursday, died yesterday at his home here. He was stricken with a heart ailment last Sunday.

A Turf Growers' Field Day will be held on Monday from 3 to 6 P. M. at the New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, New Brunswick, N. J. This Is an annual event, arranged for inspection of the numerous field experiments on turf production conducted by the station.
Maxwell M. Bilofsky, president of the Duro-Test Corporation, makers of incandescent lamps, announces that he has perfected in his laborastories a lamp that will burn for 2,000 hours.

Many problems face those charged with the responsibility of organizing and setting up the machinery for self-regulation of the over-thecounter security business to carry out the purpose and provisions of the Maloney act.

AMILLION Corn Belt farmers are wondering whether they have made a good bargain with Uncle Sam or missed one. Not that they are losing any sleep over it. This is the time of year when they go to bed too tired to lose sleep over anything.

Whether the stock market would show a small gain or a slight loss on the week depended on yesterday's short trading period, and the session finished with leading stocks up from fractions to little more than 1 point.

The Yangtze, which roars and meanders 3,200 miles from the highlands of Tibet through the heart of China to Shanghai on the coast, is one of the world's great rivers. Its lower 1,000 miles are navigable and the lower valley is one off China's richest areas.

The Indianapolis Power and Light Company filed, today, under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $32,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and $5,550,000 of serial notes maturing from Aug. 1, 1939, to Aug. 1, 1948.

A NEW practice in the wall paper field is the use of two different but related patterns in the same room. Borders, too, are used more flexibly, not only running along the top of the wall but also framing sections of the wall, windows and doors. Papers in general show advances in subtlety of color.

A TALL, slim spire, with a fluttering American flag.... Beside it, a balll of dull orange filigree work. Cliff-like walls of gray, gleaming in the sunlight. .... A latticework of structural steel against the sky. .... In the distance the glitter of water, a lagoon where a small stream once meandered.

Miss Rita Muller, daughter of Major Nicholas W. Muller of the United States Army Reserve and Mrs. Muller of New York, was married here this morning to H. Wilfred Lilly of Brooklyn in St. Joseph's Church by the pastor, the Rev. Edward C. McManus.

Samuel Insull, former Chicago utilities financier, stricken with a heart attack here at 1:20 this afternoon, died before reaching a hospital. The 78-year-old industrialist had twenty cents in his pocket and was about to take a subway train at the Place de la Concorde station.

With buying activities of most retailers confined to filling requirements for opening the Fall season, or up to early September, the volume of reorders will definitely tell the real story of the Fall merchandising season, store representatives and buying office executives said yesterday.

Pennsylvania has become a sounding board for startling statements and fantastic rumors as the Earle Administration weighs suggested methods for dealing with a scheduled grand jury investigation of itself on charges involving "sale" of legislation, "kickbacks" on State projects and similar matters.

North American Utility Securities Corporation--Six months to June 30: Net income, $103,612, exclusive of credits or charges arising from the sale of securities and realization on German credit, compared with net income of $1333,233 in six months to June 30, 1937.

Maurice McCarthy of Cincinnati and Robert Babbish of Detroit qualified today for the final of the Western amateur golf championship tomorrow, McCarthy defeating Thomas Sheehan Jr. of Chicago, 1 up, while Babbish eliminated Larry Moller of Quincy, Ill., 5 and 3.

AS the Indian editors of "The Cultural Heritage of India" recognize, no one person, however wide his knowledge and intuitive his outlook, is qualified to interpret the civilization of India as a whole and to do justice to its diverse aspects-social, historical, racial, religious.

The $4,000,000,000 deficit which the President stated last Tuesday was probable for the Federal Governent's 1938-39 financial year promises to carry our national debt over the $40,000,000,000 mark for the first time in our history.

A PERSON in New York would be able to pick up a pen and sign a check in San Francisco by use of a novel television system described in a patent (No. 2,122,918) awarded by the United States Patent Office to Edward D. Phinney of Mount Vernon, N. Y. Also, deeds, legal documents and contracts in one city could be read, corrected and signed by a person in another city, it is claimed.

AN aspect of American musical development which may be even more indicative than the impressive programs of the wintertime of the shift of the musical balance of power between America and Europe is the growth and multiplication of our Summer music festivals, open-air concert series, and opera and ballet performances.

A NEW orchestra, that of Count Basie, the pianist, made its local after-dark debut the other night at the Famous Door, on West Fifty-second Street. It is a tip-top aggregation distinguished for several reasons from many other Negro bands.

Going only part way toward meeting the United States demand for the return of American-owned property in Japaneseoccupied areas of China, the Japanese Government in a note to Washington, made public last night, declared that chaotic coneditions in these areas compelled restrictions on the rights of foreigners there. [Page 1.]

Governor Hurley signed today a bill which provided for an investigation of the abandonment of eighty-eight stations in Massachusetts by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. The measure was passed early this morning by both branches of the Legislature.

ELECTROPLATER, $1,860 a year; branch of buildings management, National Park Service, Dept. of the Interior. Applications must be on file not later than Aug. 18, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, and not later than Aug. 15 from all other States.
A group of scientists, equipped with dynamite and a seismograph has set out in Southern New Jersey to delve -into the mysteries beneath the ocean floor.
Two record-breaking performances and two spectacular spills marked the close of the Havre de Grace Yacht Club's ninth annual regatta on the Susquehanna River today.

AN adventure which furnished newspaper headlines for eight months is recalled by four stamps just received from the Soviet Union commemorating the "fortunate ending of the North Pole Scientific Mission," in the words of the Soviet postal authorities.

Awards of building contracts in the thirty-seven States in the East amounted last month to $167,485,000, an increase of 4 per cent over the previous month. Contracts for heavy engineering work brought the total of all awards to $251,006,000.
Ben Levene, Philadelphia glider expert, was fatally injured late today when an antiquated airplane that he had been repairing crashed after a nose dive into an oak grove near Clementon.

Mrs. Edgar Davis Edmonston of this city has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Patti Warfield Edmonston, to First Lieutenant Thomas Leslie Crystal Jr., Sixth Field Artillery, U. S. A., son of Colonel Thomas L. Crystal, U. S. A., and Mrs. Crystal.

A gradual but noticeable gain in the number of requests for men able to fill executive positions in the middle and higher salary brackets in a wide variety of business fields has been registered recently as a result of the current improvement in trade and the increased optimism evident among business men, according to a check yesterday among a number of leading placement bureaus.
Twelve persons -were injured tonight when a giant transport seaplane smashed on rocks shortly after settling on the sea near here. The plane was being tested before being accepted by the French Navy.

Ernesto Lira, a sportsman of Prescott, was convicted today of seconddegree murder in the killing of Marcus Jay Lawrence, 35, guest ranch owner and former resident of Washington. The conviction carries a penalty of ten years to life imprisonment.

The officers and crew of the navy's new 10,000-ton cruiser Nashville received a silver service today from the Tennessee city. James G. Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville Banner and president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, turned over the twenty-nine-piece set.

Annual reports showing financial conditions are supplied to employes as well as to stockholders by at least forty-four prominent companies in the United States, it was disclosed yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's illustrated business research study issued under the title, "Reporting to Employes on Business Operations."

Additional accommodations for an increase of 40 to 50 per ent in business will have to be provided by the hotels of the city to meet the demands of visitors to the World's Fair, according to a report issued yesterday by a special committee investigating this field for the Greater New York Safety Council, 60 East Forty-second Street.

The twelve-story apartment house known as the Oregon , at 162-72 West Fifty-fourth Street, southeast corner of Seventh Avenue, will be sold at auction on Wednesday in the Vesey Street rooms by Edwin J. McDonald.
Fog, cooler weather and slowly rising humidity aided the Pacific Northwest's thousands of weary forest fighters tonight.

EVERY best seller is a surprise, for the shrewdest and most experienced publisher cannot foresee how far the reading public will endorse his own choices. "The one shall be taken and the other left," and no one can tell beforehand which will be which.

Excessive taxation without a fair profit is partial confiscation, points out James F. Durnell, vice president of the realty firm of Irving Ruland Co. There can be no economic balance, he adds, until land, labor and capital are equalized in the production of wealth, and under present conditions the landowner is faced with confiscatory taxes.

America has been a nation of footloose people. If opportunities weren't good in one locality, we were always ready to try our luck elsewhere. The tradition that luck may actually be better beyond the horizon dies hard.
In selecting the heating and air-conditioning system for his new home, the prospective owner has five principal types to choose from. Each has its own special advantages.

A bit of indulgence in the beauty ritual goes a long way in hot, sultry weather toward lifting one's spirits. In the cooling, leisurely business of improving one's personal appearance time passes pleasantly and the effects linger. There are many new preparations specially designed for hot-weather use.
Retail trade, although showing some recession of a seasonal character, ran ahead of a year ago in several districts, and in others the loss from last year was reduced.

THE Salzburg Festival, which this Summer will be held for the first time under the Hitler regime, opens in Salzburg next Saturday evening with a performance of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger," under Wilhelm Furtwaengler, in the Festspielhaus, and continues until Aug. 31.
A violent eruption of Asama Volcano, overlooking the Summer resort of Karuizawa, at 1:30 this afternoon caused considerable damage. Ashes were still falling as this was written.

The anti-Semitic party of Professor Alexander C. Cuza is active again, according to reports from Jassy, Rumania, which indicated Professor Cuza had summoned a meeting attended by Istrate Micescu, former Foreign Minister, in which, it was decided that the Cuza party would form a cultural organization, with a separate branch for sports.

Capturing the third and deciding heat in the slow time of 2:16% after the field had been tired by ten scores and one false start, Horace Conovef's trotting mare Lela Hanover today annexed the -feature Class A trot or pace at the Borough Park track matinee.

The climax of a heavy program of entertaining here during the coming week will be next Saturday when Mr. and Mrs. Francis Taylor give a dance to introduce to society Mrs. Taylor's daughter, Miss Fernanda de Mohrenschildt.

ALTER WAN6ER may not be Hollywood's most successful producer, but he long has been one of its most interesting. He focused attention on the psychological drama with "Forgotten Faces" and "Privatei Worlds."

OUR confidential report on Shirley Temple, who sailed last week for Bermuda: During Shirley's visit to New York the "no interviews" policy was relaxed by Mrs. Temple in behalf of the children of newspaper folk-some of whom wanted to convince themselves that Shirley was real and not just a story-book princess, like Snow White.

Patrolman Charles Schatzle, 37 years old, attached to the Fourth Avenue precinct in Brooklyn, shot and killed himself with his service revolver early yesterday morning Ro on the beach at Breezy Point, Rockaway, after spending the night drinking beer .with his wife and three friends.

Final schedules for the new Panama-Pacific Line service to the Pacific Coast, made public yesterday, reveal for the first time the company's intention of transferring two transatlantic vessels, the American Shipper and American Traveler, to augment the service to be maintained by the five former Baltimore Mail liners.
Dr. and Mrs. Fielding Lewis Taylor of 950 Fifth Avenue have taken the Humphrey House at East Gloucester, Mass., for the remainder of the Summer.

Police restored order early today in Pittsburgh's North Side after a second wild night of rioting between races that resulted in the wounding by gunfire of a detective and a Negro and the arrest of at least forty persons on charges of inciting to riot.

Representative Southern economists agreed today that this section faces and must solve grave economic problems, although some differed with President Roosevelt's assertion that the South's situation is the "No. 1 problem."
IN 1758, when England was struggling with France for the possession of Canada, General Wdlfe led 5,000 men in open boats down the St. ,Lawrence River for a surprise attack on Quebec.

IT is indeed gratifying to note that, according to the figures of Robert J. Malloy, statistician of the Motor Vehicle Bureau, May was the sixth month in succession in which substantial reductions in automobile fatalities and accidents were made in New York State.

WASHINGTON -- The United States Navy has named its new submarines after dwellers of the deep, according to custom. The SS-198 has been named the Tambor--a species of shellfish common in the West Indies.

High temperatures prevailed here for the tenth consecutive day yesterday, but With the humidity at comparatively low levels, it was one of the pleasantest days since the hot spell set in. Fair and continued warm weather was forecast for today with scattered thunder showers tomorrow.

Under the supervision of a New York architect, scores of native Turkish workmen will soon be starting the construction in Istanbul, Turkey, of a new building to house the American Hospital of that capital city.

In the strongest primary campaign statement he has made since suggestirig the renomination of Senator Alben W. Barkley at Covington, Ky., President Roosevelt today asked the Democratic voters of California to return William G. McAdoo to the United States Senate.

CROWN PRINCE GUSTAF ADOLF and Crown Princess Louise of Sweden will be the guests of honor at a gala concert at the Stadium Tuesday night. Alexander Smallens, directing the orchestra, will open the program with the Swedish National Anthem,

MONTREAL.-Next Sunday the first mass will be celebrated in the new basilica of St. Joseph's Oratory at Montreal-the famous shrine of Brother Andre, a member of the Congregation of Holy Cross, whose ministrations to the sick and afflicted converted the church and the humble little chapel that preceded it into an "American Lourdes."
Stocks advanced moderately and closed steady at slightly higher levels; turnover, 627,270 shares. United States Government and other bonds firm and mixed; transactions, $2,829,000.
Rex Volo won the feature trot In the regular matinee of the Nassau Driving Club over the Fair Grounds track today, shading Laurel Hill and Highland Bob in a three-heat brush.

The very rapid-growth of the interest in amateur photography has spread to the garden. More than ever before in garden history flower lovers are attempting to secure permanent picture records of their successes.
Another tempest in a tea cup is brewing here and a new discussion of the problems of the nation's aerial defense may result at the next session of Congress.
HIS MUSIC LIVES: Although there were threatening clouds, a capacity audience of 19,000 sat down in the open air of Lewisohn Stadium last
Harrison Williams, utility executive and financier, sailed yesterday for Naples on the Italian motorship Conte di Savoia. His name was not on the passenger list.
A resolution urging the Japanese Government to use gold and specie reserves to purchase raw materials was adopted today by the Central Price Policy Commission.

Many Lake Mohawk Summer residents attended the annual fashion show at the Lake Mohawk Country Club this afternoon. The affair provides funds for the club's Christmas party for children of the Sussex County mountains.

Making no secret of the fact that they need the ground for the construction of some fortification detail of the Siegfried Line, which is the German reply to the Maginot Line, German civil and military authorities last night took possession of about 2,500 acres of land on the right bank of the Rhine, which belonged to residents of the French commune of Rheinau, on the left bank of the Rhine, between Strasbourg and Selestat.
Hubert L. King of Englewood, N. J., was elected National Commander of the United States Army Ambulance Service Association at its nineteenth annual convention and reunion here today.

Paul H. Wendel's $450,000 damage suit against former Governor Hoffman and the Ellis H. Parkers for false arrest in a sequel to the Lindbergh case was dismissed by Federal Judge Philip Forman here today on the ground that the United States courts lacked jurisdiction.

PARIS. THE increasing importance of accessories suggests using them as a basis for style prophecies. At he moment all point up or down, leading to the belif that the Winter silhouette may be elongated to an all-time high.

WASASHINGTON is not *a paradoxical town. It is precisely what every one conceives it to be, a statement that survives even the Iogical challenge that every one may have a different conception of what it is. Political center of the nation, it attracts to its very human heart"human" in the best and worst senses of the word-a population that is-a composite of the body and soul of what it grandiloquently refers to as America.

Summer games are here again and the smart hostess no longer worries about how to entertain week-end guests. She merely leads them out to a set of inexpensive equipment in the back yard and lets them exhaust themselves.
American-Jewish settlers beseeched the United States Consulate today to aid them in gaining protection, as a terroristic campaign went unchecked, despite the efforts of British troops.
Iowa Child Welfare Research Station, State University of Iowa Given sufficient time and the right combination of circumstances, children will change in IQ in very large amounts.

Town Tax Assessor David H. Mabey invited the real estate committee of the Montclair Real Estate Board to confer on the proposed new assessments for 1939, arrived at by the J. M. Cleminshaw firm of Cleveland, Ohio, in its oneyear survey of real estate values.

Great efforts were mad here this week to be hopeful about the adoption by the Non-Intervention Committee of the British plan to make the Spanish war, at least in its final stage, purely Spanish, and about the consequent coming into force of the Anglo-Italian agreement.
BAR HARBOR, Me.-The annual series of Monday afternoon putting tournaments at the Kebo Valley Golf Club will begin tomorrow and continue each Monday through the season to Sept. 5.

THIS handsomely bound and printed book of poems is, on the whole, very disappointing. Certain of the more simple poems included are fairly successful, but the poet inclines always toward the elaborate and romantic in language and imagery.

SELLING 123,701 used cars in June, Chevrolet dealers in America, for the fortieth consecutive month, continued a turnover of more than 100,000 used cars and brought total sales in this category to 725,086 for the first halfyear of 1938, it was announced last week by William E. Holler, general sales manager of the division.

Study of musketry problems and rifle, automatic rifle and machinegun firing for tests over the Camp Smith ranges here throughout the week were completed today by 2,100 State infantrymen forming the Fifty-fourth Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson.

CAMEO--If War Comes Tomorrow: Russian film. CAPITOL-Port of Seven Seas: Wallace Beery. CRITERION-Marriage Forbidden: Pedro De Cordoba. GLOBE--Were Going to Be Rich: Gracie Fields, Victor McLaglen.* LOEW'S STATE--Prison Farm: Shirley Ross, Lloyd Nolan.

Fair quantities of Fall fashion merchandise and staples were purchased in the wholesale market last week, according to a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.
The Cubs came from behind twice. today, then swung into a tenth-inning attack that defeated the Bees, 8 to 7, and enabled Chicago to run its winning streak to four in a row.

The close of play scores in first-clas's cricket matches started today. Yorkshire 144 (J. Smith four for 45); Middlesex 56 for two, at-Lord's. Kent 337 (Fagg 91, Valentine 73, Woolley 63) Surrey 31 for none.

BOULDER, Col.-This mountain resort and educational center is alive with activity as it prepares to welcome the Ninth Writers Conference, as tourists increase daily and as 3,461 Summer students crowd the campus of the State university-a record.
BY his brilliant success with the dances in "I Married an Angel," George Balanchine has clinched his right to the title of the first choreographer of Broadway.

The State Bar Association's committee on State Constitutional Convention, of which R. E. Lee of New York City is chairman, has filed memoranda on the various propositions now receiving final consideration by the judiciary committee of the convention, which is to submit its final report next week.

Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt came to Rochester today and went to the circus. The First Lady, who arrived by plane to visit her son, James, undergoing treatment here, is a guest of Dr. and Mrs. W. J. Mayo. Following luncheon, Mrs. Roosevelt, James and Dr. and Mrs. Mayo went to the circus, which came to town a couple of hours ahead of the President's wife.

Completing two months of operation by a private company, New York's foreign trade zone is already on a paying basis, and in the last month has handled an average, of 3,300 tons of freight daily, Harry C. Shanks, head of the New York Foreign Trade Zone Operators, Inc., which leased the property, announced yesterday.

The security markets held their ground well last week, and the showing in commodities was fair to good. Stocks and bonds averaged slightly higher, although trading was smaller than in the previous holiday week.
MARY SULLIVAN, Director of Policewomen in New York City, is one of those rare persons whose job is a continual adventure. It has hardships and

Apprehensive of the long-range implications of the government's "buy and give" program as typified in the WPA plan to purchase $10,000,000 worth of men's clothing and $3,000,000 of women's apparel, leading merchants will meet on Thursday at the Empire State Club to discuss a course of action.
Music Hall of the Air presents a string quartet with Henrietta Schumann, pianist, as assisting artist with Viola Philo, soprano: WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M.

The Rev. Moritz Stolpe, for fortyseven years pastor of the Swedish Evangelical Lutheran Church of Gustavus Adolphus, 151 East Twenty-second Street, died suddenly last night in a restaurant at 157 East Forty-eighth Street where he was dining.
Harry W. Orndorf, 63, known as "Burly" to the fighting marines throughout the world, died today after a brief illness.

American art is imperiled by union labor, Domenico Mortellito, secretary of the Mural Artists Guild, declared yesterday, citing the guild's current "defensive struggle" with the United Scenic Artists of America, Local 829, A. F. of L. Mr. Mortellito declared the guild was fighting to preserve the artist's rights and freedom in creative work, notably for the World's Fair.

Miss Alice Sawyer Metcalf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leland Metcalf of Whitinsville, Mass., and Lieutenant Robert Chambers Jr., United States Marine Corps, son of Dr. and Mrs. Chambers of New York and Woods Hole, Mass., were married here this afternoon.
Several interesting features are provided in a new home in the $10,000 price range which has just been completed at Chester Hill, Manhasset, L. I., for John C. Slagle.

A closer study by the. courts of this country of the science of real estate appraising would aid greatly in establishing more equitable values, in the opinion of Robert H. Armstrong of Armstrong Armstrong, realty brokers.

About 32,500 persons died in the United States last year as a result of accidents at home. In announcing these figures the National Safety Council expresses pleasure that the total is some 6,000 less than it was in 1936, which gives some indication of the seriousness of a type of accident that gets little public attention.

The property of the Yudell Realty Corporation at Brentwood, L. I., consisting of several hundred quarter-acre, half-acre and one-acre plots adjoining the golf course of the Bayshore Country Club, will be sold at auction next Saturday and Sunday afternoons by T. F. Archer of Jamaica.

KINGSTON, N. Y.-Several events of regional and one of national interest are on the resorts calendar for Ulster County within the next few weeks to augment the continuous round of activities within the Catskill Park.
NEW PORT, R. I.-Thus far this Summer there has been a marked increase in tennis playing on the courts of the Newport Casino and on the private courts about the colony.

ARMED with highly colored travel folders and a romantic emergency supply of dried fruits, Mr. and Mrs. Brinley ("The Duchess" and "Dan" to their readers) are off this time on another Canadian jaunt, and the public that has welcomed their three preceding volumes knows precisely what to expect from their fourth book.
PASSAU. CANOE traffic is returning to the Danube. The muddy, tossed surface of the river is alive with little boats. Most of them are German pleasure-craft bound downstream toward Vienna.

Expressing delight over the earmarking of $23,000,000 by the United States Housing Authority for additional slum clearance projects in New York City, Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the City Housing Authority, said yesterday the authority had been surveying a number of sites for new projects.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved within a narrow range yesterday, influenced by lower foreign quotations in early trading and by a further advance in the stock market in the second hour. After a slight decline, the list steadied to end with losses of 4 to 5 points.

The engagement of Miss Harriet Colyer German, daughter of C. Howell German of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. German, to Clifford Travis Rogers, son of Walter L. Rogers of New York and the late Mrs. Rogers, has been announced by her father.

SEX appeal, which has been dealt with as a commodity by the cinema but which has influenced the technological phase of the business only slightly, entered press agentry the other day when Carole Lombard took command of the publicity department it Selznick-International.

The port of Oswego, N. Y., which was the major shipping port on the Great Lakes in Civil War times and later lost that position to larger lakes cities, is staging a rapid comeback, according to P. J. Shortt, transportation agent for the Harbor and Dock Commission, who was in New York last week.
An increase of 15 per cent in student enrollment for the twenty-second annual City College Summer session was reported yesterday by Dr. Charles Upson Clark, director.

While some increases in production may be expected this Summer in those consumer goods lines where sales have turned upward in the last few weeks, producers in most instances are determined to avoid accumulation of stocks, and schedules, therefore, will be held down to actual sales volume, a survey last week indicated.

THIS little study of a Swiss Protestant mission in darkest Bantusiland is by the author of one of Little, Brown's prize-contest novelettes of a year or. so ago, a story called "A Cargo of Parrots" of strong Conradian flavor.

OSCAR WILDE, THE MAN THE ARTIST. THE MARTYR. By Boris Brasol. 8vo. New York; Charles Scribner's Sons. $3.50. A biography. ADAM SYMES AND HIS DESCENDANTS. By Jane Morris. 12mo. Philadelphia, Pa.: Dorrance Co. $3.50.

Tommy Goodwin reported late for the afternoon round of the thirty-six-hole final of the New York State amateur golf championship at Quaker Ridge today with the offhand remark, "I don't think you really need me, but here I am."

As an illustration of the benefits of savings share insurance, Oscar R. Kreutz, deputy general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, reported yesterday that recent studies of the growth of insured associations indicated substantial increases in their capital funds.
Two hundred persons attended tea given this afternoon at Grey croft, on Hunting Lane, by Leigh iton Rollins, director of the Studic of Acting, arid the studio commit tee.

Despite the high hopes which were entertained six months ago that a revival in the long-depressed building trades would lead the way to a general recovery of business, the record of new construction for the first half of 1938 is disappointing.

Russell B. Hurlburt, assistant export manager of the Pratt Whitney Company, mechanical engineers, at 17 Liberty Street, died today at his home, 62 Sunnyside Way, after an illness of six weeks. His age was 51.

Arthur Sherman Lane, chairman of the board of the Home National Bank, vice president of the Lane Construction Company and president of John S. Lane Son, Inc., died today at his home here of a heart ailment.

President Roosevelt was criticized yesterday by the Rev. Francis K. Shepherd, pastor of the North Baptist Church, 232 West Eleventh Street, for "contributing to a class struggle which never existed before his Administration."

Although Fall merchandise held the center of attention in the New York wholesale market last week, large quantities of hot-weather goods were requested at concession prices, with the result that the market is practically cleared of such goods. In the better-dress field,

Dr. Charles Nelson Johnson, who had practiced dentistry in Chicago since 1885, died today at the age of 78. Two weeks ago he was guest of honor at the Pacific Coast Dental Congress in Vancouver, and last Wednesday Lectured in Kansas City.

Defending the foreclosure policy of the Home Owners' Loan Corporation, John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which supervises the HOLC, said today, in a letter to Representative Barry of New York, that in the average case of foreclosure the borrower had free occupancy of his home for more than four years and had paid no taxes in five years.

The decline in the cotton market, following the substantial rise in June, continued last week and prices lost about one-third of the advance they recorded last month. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 34 to 35 points in the week.
