Park Jr., in 167 E 82d St through Culver, Hollyday Co; Robert Colgate, in 14 Sutton P1 S; Mrs. Francis inc H. Breene, in 829 Park Ave through N A. Berwin Co; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, brokers.
James Prior Wood, one of this city's oldest druggists, died last night at St. Raphael's Hospital from pneumonia which developed after an operation earlier in the week. His age was 73.
Catholics and Protestants joined today with Jews in special services throughout Britain and the Dominions in behalf of persecuted Jews in all countries, particularly in Germany and Austria.
Major Morton G. Stockbridge, U. S.-A., retired, died yesterday, of a heart attack in the United States Veterans' Hospital in Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx. His age was 69.

Mayor David H. Slayback, whose zeal for safe driving has already slowed the motorists passing through here, attacked speeders again today with a robot traffic patrolman whose arms wave electrically and whose eyes doggedly follow any onlooker.
Bombing of civilian populations by war planes was deplored yesterday by members of the clergy in New York City who cited the sufferings of noncombatants in Spain and China in their sermons.

A Chinese official report claims that four Japanese warships were sunk and four others were damaged and set afire in four raids by Chinese planes on Japanese vessels in the Yangtze River between Hukow and Matang yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. D. W. Jones and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred N. Wheeler were joint hosts today at an old-fashioned Rhode Island clambake at the home of the former, Prescott House, in Portsmouth. A company of 120.

Undeterred by the controversy that has arisen over films dealing with contemporary problems, Warners have announced plans for the production of "Concentration Camp," a story dealing with political prisowners in an unidentified European dictatorship.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Jerome Hildt of 955 Lexington Avenue, this city, and Black Point, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Jerome Hildt, to Henry Holt Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of New London, Conn.

In about 40 per cent of automobile fatalities in the city in 1937 the victim-pedestrian, driver or passenger--was found to have been drinking alcoholic beverages, Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, chief medical examiner, revealed in his annual report made public yesterday through the office of the Mayor.

Flanked and hemmed in by a hostile, roaring crowd, the largest baseball gathering this seething metropolis has ever seen during a championship season, the Giants today missed by a whisker of completing two heroic strides that tonight would have put them back at the top of the National League's torrid pennant race.

While Haifa, which within the last ten days has experienced outrages and riots, is now gradually taking on the appearance of normalcy, killings in other parts of Palestine are increasing daily. Today six more fatalities, three Arabs and three Jews, were added to the scores of outrages of the last few weeks.

A fiveday symposium on government corporations will open tomorrow at the Law School of George Washington University with legal advisers to government agencies discussing practical legal problems arising from the operation of leading Federal agencies.

Despite her intention of remaining at Cernauti until tomorrow before going to Sinaia, her Summer palace, Queen Marie arrived here today accompanied by Professor Stuermer and Dr, Hortolomei. She was welcomed by King Carol.

The Rochester Red Wings suffered one of their few double losses of the season today as they bowed to Marius Russo and Jack Haley of the Newark Bears, 5-4 and 5-3. The Wings outhit the Bears, 12 to 10, in the first game but Russo kept the blows well scattered after the third inning.

President Jorge Ubico has decreed law restricting ownership, to Guatemalans of all lands within ten miles of the national frontiers. Similar restrictions apply to lands on the sea coasts and banks of certain rivers and lakes.

The longdistance hitters of the Red Sox drummed a steady beat against the left-field wall today to submerge four pitchers under a total of thirty hits while sweeping a doubleheader with the Browns, 11 to 5 and 14 to 4.

68th St, 52 W; New York Savings Bank to Esther Lipshitz, 48 W 68th St; purchase money mtg. $17,500 ($21.50). 71st St, 32 W; Reuben S. Goodman to Jayne G. Weaver, 32 W 71st St, undivided interest; mtg $18,000. 6th Ave, 115 n w cor Watts St; Etta Bleicher to City of New York; mtg 69,000 held by grantee.

Except for a few adjourned games, the thirtyseven players in the three competitions of the American Chess Federation at the Hotel Touraine rested today after their strenuous efforts of the past week. The opportunity for relaxation was most welcome to all concerned.

The Retchikan Packing Company and Northern Fisheries, Inc., began operations this morning with members of a citizens committee on hand. Headquarters of the C. I. O. union, which had been on strike, said that it had withdrawn pickets, advised its members to go to work and intended to seek court action on the charge that the packers had broken an agreement by reopening.

Both Bolivia and Paraguay officially notified the Argentine Government today of their formal acceptance without reservations of the Chaco peace terms initialed here on July 9. Preparations were being made hurriedly tonight for signing the peace treaty at a solemn ceremony either tomorrow or Tuesday.

Dr. Carl J. Hambro, president of the Parliament of Norway, attended a service conducted for followers of the Oxford Group yesterday morning in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.
The index of French wholesale prices for the week ended on July 9 was 657, compared with 656 a week before and 652 two weeks before.

Detectives disclosed yesterday at Police Headquarters the arrest late Saturday of two men suspected of supplying firearms to the underworld. The suspects, according to the police, would either sell or rent the weapons.

British output of steel in June was 776,100 tons, the lowest for any month since August, 1935. This compared with 957,000 in May, 1938; 1,106,400 in June, 1937, and the high record output of 1,178,300 in November, 1937.

Appleton-Century report that Isaac Goldberg, who died suddenly last week, had just turned over to his publishers the completed manuscript of his new book, "The Wonder of Words." This book, subtitled "An Introduction to Language for Everyman," will be published in the Fall.

" Monopoly," as defined by the Sherman and Clayton acts, is but "an insignificant part" of the problem of keeping prices right for the consumer, according to H. S. Dennison, president of the Dennison Manufacturing Company, and J. K. Galbraith of Harvard University, whose book, "Modern Competition and Business Policy," has just been published by the Oxford University Press.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden today voiced a "sincere hope" for peace throughout the world upon his arrival in Minnesota with Princess Louise and .Prince Birtil, to participate in a two-day Swedish tercentenary celebration.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open this morning in Gallery H 19 a special exhibition of Philippine embroideries made possible by a gift to the museum of a group of the embroideries by the late Mary Sloan Hess through her husband, Colonel Louis T. Hess.
Mrs. Carleton H. Palmer announced today that she has withdrawn as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the State Senate from the twenty-fifth district.

The Central European bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday completed the task of moving itself out of Vienna in the direction of Prague, Czechoslovakia. The last packing case (under government seal) was carried out, the last van rolled away and a patient and exhausted staff prepared to move on in turn.

The "candle of the last breath" A was lighted shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon over a bedstead in Bellevue Hospital's Ward. Ground L to guide into another life the spirit of Louis Di Metro, 20year-old Russian gypsy, for whose recovery more than fifty fellownomads had maintained a week of prayerful vigil in a temporary encampment outside the hospital.

When Samuel Insull died of a heart attack in the Paris subway with twenty cents in his pocket it merely meant that a harassed old man living on a pension and almost regal memories had reached the end of the road.

The best informed opinion here refuses to share the temporary optimism expressed in England and to a lesser degree in France as the result of the acceptance of the British plan for Spain by the Non-Intervention Committee.

3d Ave (11-2912), w s, 50 ft n 17st St, 75x100; Albert Horwitz to James Peck Co. 152 W 42d St; mtg $57.500. Liebig Ave. 6.119 (13-3423T); Hyman Bushel, referee, to Harlem Savings Bank. Jesup Ave (11-2872), e s. 325 ft a of Featherbed Lane, 37x100; Samuel Saffer, Inc, to Jeannette Goldman, 1,566 Jesup Ave.

The pilgrims of Paddy's Market who sailed for the last time down the cobblestone channel of Ninth Avenue at midnight Saturday landed at their -new home in West Thirty-ninth Street yesterday. They will dedicate it this morning, with music.

The American Jewish Congress announced incomplete returns last night showing that 698,993 Jews had registered and 351,674 voted throughout the nation on June 25, 26 and 27 in the election for 400 delegates to a special session of the congress to be held in the Fall.

Sir Frederick Banting said tonight that reports crediting him and his assistants with devising a new method, in the form of a serum, for resuscitating persons rescued after being submerged in water were "completely unfounded" and were "the figment of someone's imagination."

Donald E. Marcus, an examiner in the Department of Investigation and a former examiner of accounts, has been named secretary to the Department of Purchase, Commissioner Russell Forbes announced yesterday. Mr. Forbes said Mr.

Albert Francis Becker, associated for several years with Park Tilford, New York, died today at his home in Milbrook, Greenwich, following a heart -ailment. His age was 47. He was born in Scranton, Pa.

Jews hoping soon to be allowed to emigrate from Vienna to countries they will help develop by pioneer work on the land are being trained in a large settlement school founded on the north bank of the Danube at Stadlau, near the Vienna Airport.

Mrs. Nellie Rumsey Wise of 230 Riverside Drive, supervisor of the West Side Reinvestigation Division of the Board of Child Welfare, died yesterday after a two weeks' illness, in Beekman Street Hospital, at the age of 60.

The Rev. C. Everett Wagner, pastor of the Union Methodist Church, Forty-eighth Street, west of Broadway, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "the Church of the Living Christ, to be vital, must come to grips- with itself instead of here and there degenerating into a country club." Mr. Wagner further said:

Voracious grasshoppers descending on grain fields "like rain" are ruining promising crops in this part of Eastern Montana. "They took all my oats. There are so many hoppers that poison seems no use," said H. A. Schultz of Lambert.
Insurgent Spain has honored Italy and Germany by awarding decorations to Field Marshal Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Germany's No. 2 Nazi, and Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister.

Jewelry valued at $14,000 was stolen from the Summer home of Louis J. Grumbach, in the Elberon section of Long Branch, some time yesterday, Police Chief Fred A. Wordell disclosed to night. A sneak thief was believed responsible.

Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, deposed chairman of the TVA, has protested to the Congressional investigating committee against its appointment of Thomas A. Panter- as chief engineer, it was ,learned today on the eve of the beginning of public hearings tomorrow.

Considerable progress in reducing the field in the Eastern clay court championship was made at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday, with Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., top-seeded entrant among the 150, having a prominent role in the proceedings.

More than 6,000 persons visited the Camp Smith reservation here today to see the Fifty-fourth Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson, pass in review before Brig. Gen. Jay L. Benedict, superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point, and to take part in the annual observance of Visitors' Day by the 107th Infantry, the "Old Seventh" Regiment. of Manhattan.

Assailing the Republican - controlled committee on public utilities of the Constitutional Convention for barring his two proposals to guarantee public ownership and control of the State's water power resources and authorize municipal power plants, Justice Charles Poletti said today that he would move to discharge the measures from committee when the convention reconvenes tomorrow.

The one and only Dizzy Dean-and the rest of the Chicago Cubs--came through in spectacular style today. At the crossroads of his career, the pitcher for whom the Cubs paid $185,000 and three players, and who had been nursing a sore arm since May 3, went to the mound and hurled a brilliant four-hit game to whip the Bees, 3 to 1, in the opener of a double bill.

A decrease of more than 50 per cent in the first six months of 1938 in total gifts and bequests for philanthropic purposes in six major cities of the United States, compared with the same period in 1937, was reported yesterday by the John Price Jones Corporation, public relations and fund-raising organization. The report asserted, however,

Outsteadying his rival with deft stroking from the baselines, Frank Guernsey, Rice Institute tennis star, captured the New York State clay court singles championship yesterday, defeating Julius Heldman, University of California at Los Angeles, in the final at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills, 6-4, 12--10 8--6.

District Attorney Herbert J. Steffes has called a meeting for tomorrow of officers of the Allis-Chalmerx local of the United Automobile Workers Union (C. I. 0.) and a group led by George Kiebler, president of the U. A. W. District Council, to hear both sides concerning Saturday's raid on the local's office.

Three young men graduates of the Lutheran Theological Seminary in Philadelphia were ordained into the ministry of the United Lutheran Church in America during a special service yesterday at Trinity Lutheran Church at Stapleton, Staten Island.

Clarence Beverly Davison of 25 East Sixty-seventh Street, New York, coffee broker, senior member of the long-established firm of Davison Murphy, at 98 Front Street, died at his Millbrook, N. Y., home today. His age was 69.

There was more than the rumble of overhead subway trains to disturb the calm of the lower Bronx yesterday. The Yanks were bidding a fond adieu to Mickey Cochrane's Tigers and they said it with a bombardment of home runs that rattled over the neighborhood of the Stadium like the boom of siege guns.

New factors were introduced into the domestic wheat situation last week by the government loan plan of 59 to 60 cents a bushel to enable farmers to hold part of their grain off the market and an announcement that the Department of Agriculture would seek materially to curtail the acreage for the 1939 crop.

Reluctant to speak of the incident which led to her downfall in the Wimbledon final against Mrs. Helen Wills Moody two weeks ago, Miss Helen Hull Jacobs returned from England yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Georgic attempting vainly to hide the effects of her accident on the court, lest they be misconstrued as a loser's alibi.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of, average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.7, which compared with 81.2 the week before, 80.9 two weeks before. 81.1 three weeks before and 81 four weeks before.

Twenty more persons reported net income of $1,000,000 or more for the tax year 1936 than in the preceding year, the number of such returns increasing from forty-one to sixtyone, according to an analysis of individual income tax returns filed in 1937 made public today by the Treasury Department.

Louis Ferstadt, a member of the executive board of the Mural Artists Guild, Local 829, A F. of L., took issue last night with the statement of Domenico Mortellito, secretary of the Mural Artists Guild, a different organization though it bears the same name, regarding the understanding between mural artists and the United Scenic Artists of America on work at the World's Fair.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Eustis Winlock of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Winlock, to John David Lannon, son of Mrs. John David Lannon of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Lannon.

Five peace organizations declared today both for preserving the present neutrality legislation and for passage at the next session of Congress of the proposed Ludlow Amendment to the Constitution, to provide for a national referendum before the United States resorted to war.

Collections of taxes by the township of North Bergen, N. J., in the first half of 1938 increased 15.6 per cent over those for the same period last year, or nearly $100,000; lien collections increased 19.8 per cent, or $60,000, while total cash collections increased more than $160,000, according to a report by Josiah M. Hewitt, financial counsel.
CommonWealth President Manuel L. Quezon returned from Japan today, appearing greatly rested after three weeks' vacation, and addressed a vast crowd assembled to welcome him.

Wall Street maintains almost complete dominance over London's financial and commercial markets. Other incidents which intrude sometimes have all, unfortunately, been pointers toward receding trade, so that the American background has become even more important.

Ten years ago religion was. regarded as tentative and science was believed to be exact, but -the situation today has been. reversed, the Rev. Dr. C. Leslie Glenn, rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Cambridge, Mass., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Representatives of the Branch Brook Golf Club of Newark, a public links, won the New Jersey amateur best-ball trophy for the fourth time in six years today when Mike Cestone and Wallace Manion defeated the Plainfield duo of Charley Whitehead, State amateur king, and Albert Schomp Jr., 6 and 5, in the 18-hole final at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.

In a letter to Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday, Austin Hogan, president of the New York Transport Workers. Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, charged that without reason three unidentified city detectives, said to be attached to the Newtown precinct in Queens, had seriously injured an I. R. T. mechanic on July 13 in a "brutal, drunken and Malicious assault" upon the man in the company's barn in Corona.

Because of the national holiday on Thursday, last week on, the Bourse consisted of only four days. The banks, being closed also on Wednesday afternoon, worked only three and a half days, so business was reduced to a small volume. This was accentuated by the 'opening of the holiday season.
A campaign "to resell the American system to America" is to be launched here today among 10,000 companies, "to reach their employes and eventually everybody in New York City."

Tile study or big business just completed by Drs. Nourse and Drury of the Brookings Institution reaches some extremely important conclusions which are particularly valuable at this time when the Government's "anti-monopoly" investigation is getting under way. There are four broad findings that deserve particular attention.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora is expected to decide this week on the request of counsel for James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, for a bill of particulars, which if granted would compel District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to disclose in advance the details of the charges against Hines.

In itself the report of a group of professors elaborating an Aryan racial theory for Italy would not seem very serious to any one familiar with Italy and the Italian character, even as they have been reconditioned and resurfaced by the Fascist regime.
Details of the first-round games of the American Chess Federation finals, in which David S. Polland beat Boris Blumin and Paul Rosenzweig conquered Jack Collins, follow:

Imports of gold to the United Kingdom in June amounted to [Pound]29,597,452, against 132,016,371 in June, 1937, making the-half year's aggregate [Pound]133,933,152, compared with ;167,931,230 in 1937.

A Sheepshead Bay skipper, Morton Hatton of the Croydon Y. C., demonstrated today that he likes smoky, rough- going yachting weather by winning the third annual Captain Billopp cruiser race around Staten Island.
Mrs. Ruth Pearcy Pipitone of 350 Central Park West, church and concert singer, died yesterday after an illness of six months. She was 45 years old.
At least four persons were killed, others were feared dead, and about fifty were slightly injured when a roaring fire spread havoc in the $15,000,000 Sinclair Oil Company refinery here tonight.

As mysteriously as he flew in a week ago and calmly announced that he had completed a non-stop flight from the West Coast in a nine-year-old $900 plane, Douglas Corrigan took off "for California" from Floyd Bennett field at 5:17 o'clock yesterday morning, and early this morning there was no report on his whereabouts.

Oct. 3 is the date set for the fourweek return engagement of Helen Hayes in "Victoria Regina." As indicated in these columns on Saturday, it will be at the Martin Beck Theatre. Thereafter Miss Hayes will go on the road again for four weeks, one of which will be passed in Washington.

NO one seems to know, or to be willing to tell, much of anything about the author named B. Traven, whose "Death Ship" and "Treasure of the Sierra Madre" appeared here in 1934 and 1935 respectively, and whose "Bridge in the. Jungle"* is published nere today by Knopf.
William C. Simpson of the sales and sales development department of Lukens Steel Company, Coatesville, Pa., has been appointed manager of sales of the company's newly opened Pittsburgh sales office.

Governmental employes thus far have contributed $175,588 to the Greater New York Fund and solicistation still is being carried on in several departments, James G. Blaine, president of the campaign, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Frances S. Tyson and Richard Addison Hanan, both of this city, made application for a marriage license here yesterday. The marriage of Mrs. Tyson, a former film actress, to Robert J. Tyson of this city was terminated by divorce in 1936. Mr. Hanan.

The Mexican press today accused labor leader Vicente Lombardo Toledano of attempting to control all the news published within Mexico after the eighth council of the C. T. M. [Confederation of Mexican Workers] voted late yesterday to have 1,000,000 organized workers boycott all newspapers publishing "reactionary" material.

German pig iron production in June amounted to 1,508,500 tons, making the total for the first half of this year 8,803,900tons, against 7,710,300 in the first half of last year. Austria's trade revival has caused a shortage of steel in Germany, so the Reich's system of rAtioning steel to industrial consumers has been extended to all Austria.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 32 per cent of capacity, the highest rate in eleven weeks. Uncertainties of buyers as to freight charges are said to have been eliminated and buying is in accordance with known necessities for the near-by future.

The Blessed Sacrament, which the Real Presence makes the most important Christian sacrament, was prefigured frequently in the Old Testament, according to the Rev. Charles O'Connor Sloan, who preached yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Continuing their quaint habit of wreaking havoc in the hinterlands, the devastating Dodgers today ruined an otherwise lovely afternoon for 28,855 enthusiastic Cincinnati fans-thirdlargest paid attendance at Crosley Field this season-by flattening the Reds twice, 5 to 3 and 7 to 4.

The Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street, assailed the theory of evolution in the course of his sermon last evening. Among other things he said:

Although Third Baseman Quade of the Newburgh Baseball Club hit homers in his first two times at bat, they were not enough to give his team a victory, and the New York Athletic Club nine defeated Newburgh, 12-4, yesterday at Travers Island.

BOOK OF KINGS, by Philip Freund. (Pilgrim House, $2.50.) A new novel by the author of "The Evening Heron." THE BRIDGE IN THE JUNGLE, by B. Traven. (Knopf, $2.50.) A story. of Central American adventure.
The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:

The Re] tactical reorganization of the army on the basis of a smaller and more mobile infantry division has been postponed for at least a year to permit further study and field tests of the projected changes.

Miss Phoebe Drake Allison, daughter of Mrs. Henrietta S. Allison of this city, will be married on Aug. 6 to Erving Arundale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Arundale of Westerly, R. I., formerly of East Orange.
The index of German wholesale prices stood at 105.5 on July 6, compared with 105.7 on June 29.

The National Health Conference, first of its kind and marking a new milestone in American medicine, will open here tomorrow under the auspices of President Roosevelt's Interdepartmental Committee to Coordinate Health and Welfare Activities, of which Miss Josephine Roche, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, is chairman.
Miss Mary Rose Byrne, daughter of Mrs. Daniel P. Byrne of Long Beach, L. I., has chosen Aug. 6 for her marriage to John James Ferguson, son of Bernard Ferguson of Flushing, Queens. The ceremony,

Announcement has been made. here by Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Howard of Winthrop, Me., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Carey Howard, to Ralph Samuel Williams, son of Mrs. Ernest Williams of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Dr. Williams.

The addition of Howard Dunney, end, and Fred Fiore, back, from N. Y. U.; John Bateman, tackle, Columbia co-captain last season; Jack Daly, end, and Victor Fusia, halfback, from Manhattan to the Eastern College All-Star football team was announced yesterday by Andy -Kerr, coach.

The Monmouth County C. C. of Eatontown, winner of last year's twelve-goal Rumson C. C. polo tournament, gained the final on Shrewsbury Field today, trouncing Burnt Mills by 12-5. Monmouth will clash with Blind Brook of Port Chester in the deciding match Tuesday on the Herbert Memorial Field at Rumson.

Nine hundred workers at the Franklin Sugar Refining Company plant who went on strike June 23 accepted a settlement today and will return to their jobs tomorrow, six days after similar agreements were concluded at the city's two other big refineries, the McCahan and the Pennsylvania.

Abundant evidence shows the need for a new order of living, and "the times cry out for a more spiritual interpretation of life," the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood declared in his sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church.

Saul Wilson and JacK Kushner, Springfield T. N; T. system bidders, made a walkaway today of the major and closing event of the Southern New England contract bridge championships, the open pairs competition for the Lewis H. Osborn Trophy .

The Cunard White Star motorship Georgic arrived yesterday from the Channel ports with 613 passengers and was five hours late because of fog it encountered between Nantucket and the Ambrose Channel lightship.
Robert Franklin Bunting, president of the Black Donald Graphite Mining Company here and prominent mining man, died in a Renfrew, Ont., hospital last night after a short illness. His age was 72.

Mrs. Harriet Denham Honore, widow of Harry H. Honore Jr., died here today at the home of a friend, Mrs. Carolyn Hunter. Her-age was 75. Although her marriage had united her to one of Chicago's wealthy families, she had been reduced to the gifts of friends and a $20-amonth old-age pension.

Staging an uphill battle, Harold L. Fates and his guest; John E. Parker Jr. of Essex County, the former metropolitan amateur golf champion, today won the second annual Apawamis Club member-guest best-ball tournament.
Less work and more play has been prescribed for King George VI, who has recently been suffering from an attack of gastric

Enormous armament programs will precipitate new crises from which only such nations as Germany and Italy will emerge safely, Virginio Gayda, Fascist editor, asserted today in the newspaper La Voce d'Italia.
To mark where Columbus is supposed to have landed on Nov. 19, 1493, Puerto Rico today opened the new Parque Colon [Columbus Park] near Aguadilla.

A brief thunderstorm, which brought heavy rains to some parts of the city, turned the temperature downward from the 80s yesterday but failed to bring lasting relief on the eleventh consecutive hot July day.
A better shipping demand for cash lard and meats made its appearance last week, but the futures market was little affected.

Miss Helen W. Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse L. Parker of this place, will be married to George Henry Alexander, son of Mrs. M. H. Alexander of Rochester, N. Y., on July 30 in the Glen Ridge Congregational Church. The Rev. Dr. William Weston Patton will officiate.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against AUTOPOSTS CO.. INC., 225 W. 57th St.By Jackson Hill Emery, for $500; Joseph Posillico, $50; William Golio, $50. BLUE BONNET DRESS CO., INC., 237 W. 35th St.-By United Factors Corp., for upwards of $250; Joseph Berlinger Co., Inc., upwards of $250; A. Bitensky Bro., Inc., upwards of $250. Simon H. Rifkind was appointed receiver under $10,000 bond by Judge Leibell.

Mount Shirane on the border of Gunma and Nagano Prefectures erupted at 7 P. M. yesterday with a terrific detonation after ten years of quiescence. A huge column of smoke was emitted. Whether lava is flowing was not reported.
The rise in, commodity prices came to a halt last week. The Annalist's weekly index of wholesale commodity prices eased 0.1 point to 81.3 for July 16. A year ago the index stood at 95.2.

New York has just bought the biggest dollar's worth in the United States, a structure which cost $8,500,000 to erect, and to the delight of every one concerned will proceed immediately to demolish it. As the building happens to be that hideous pile, the old General Postoffice, there is little occasion for sorrow over the disappearance of another historic landmark.

The National Maritime Union, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced yesterday that it had sent a letter to J. Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, urging adjudication of the issue of collective bargaining for seamen employed on ships of the United States Maritime Commission.

Fresh Republican [Loyalist] reinforcements, said to total nine divisions, and a series of recently dug trenches failed today to stem the tide of the Nationalist [Rebel] advance in the Teruel-Sagunto zone as all Spain observed the second anniversary of the outbreak of the war.

Rosenberg Grief, retail furriers, store at 674 Madison Ave; Pease Elliman, Inc. brokers. James E. O'Neill, insurance, in 17 W 60th St; Cross Brown Co, broker. H. A. Van Ryswyck, gifts, in 225 5th Ave; Parfum' L'Orle, Inc. in 6 E 39th St, through Albert M. Greenfield Co; Cross Brown Co, broker.

The impact of Nazi ideology and politics on American opinion is responsible for growing friction and ill will between the United States and Germany, according to a survey issued by the Foreign Policy Association today. The report,
The feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, celebrated annually in the East Harlem community by ItalianAmericans in the Eastern States, came to a close- last midnight.

The threatened boycott of milk by independent grocers who are fighting for the resumption of the delivery of free ice with milk will not be permitted to cause any serious inconvenience to consumers, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.
With relatively moderate selling until the close, which was active, the stock market here last week suffered the heaviest decline in quotations witnessed in three years.

The first of a series of weekly Sunday "community sings" under the auspices of the Department of Parks, was given yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Ceneral Park. Similar "sings" also were conducted at the Music Grove in Forest Park, Queens, and in Poe Park, Bwonx.

John L. W. Birkinbine, mining and railroad engineer, died today at the home of his mother, Mrs. John Birkinbine, in Cynwyd at the age of 61. Mr. Birkinbine was born in this city and was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania.

C. Wilson McNeely of Philadelphia and his Stardust were named today as the challengers from the Barnegat Bay International Star Class fleet for the world championship at San Diego in September. Stardust placed third today and finished second in the elimination series.
Ignatius Timothy Trebitsch-Lincoin, the Hungarian who became Chao Kung, a Buddhist monk in China, after adventures in many countries, is anxious to return to his birthplace.
As a delayed aftermath of Edward VIII's abdication, Winston Churchill has filed suit for libel against Geoffrey Dennis, author of "Coronation Commentary," and the publishers, William Heinemann, Ltd.

Robert Babbish, 23-year-old University of Detroit student, today won the thirty-ninth Western amateur golf championship by defeating Maurice McCarthy, 31-year-old business man from Cincinnati, 1 up, in their thirty-six hole, final match, played in a sprinkling rain over the Chain o' Lakes course.

The date of Howard Hughes's projected good-will flight to South America remained unsettled yesterday as the flier, relaxing after his record world trip, came out of seclusion and appeared at two private social functions on Long Island.

The disciples were like modern people, seeking the application of religion to life's problems without first getting any real religion to apply, the Rev. L. Humphrey Walz, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church, Ninety-sixth Street and Central Park West, said in his sermon yesterday morning.
The royal visit this week to Paris provides excellent occasion to throw light on the international situation in Europe as seen in London.
The body of Samuel Insull, former Midwestern utilities magnate who died yesterday, remained in the hospital morgue today pending a police decision whether an autopsy would be necessary.

After completing about fifteen miles of his scheduled twenty-two-mile swim from Newark to the Statue of Liberty, Adam Majewski, 27-year-old Newark factory worker, was forced to give up in the Kill van Kull this evening.

Dr. Grover Clark of the University of Denver died tonight at the University of Virginia Hospital at the age of 46. He suffered a heart attack on Friday night and entered the hospital yesterday morning for observation and treatment.

A demand for business property was indicated in sales and leases of realty in New Jersey over the week-end. The Colonial mansion and property fronting 308 feet on South Orange Avenue and 176 feet on Center Street, South Orange, have been sold by the Misses Barbara and Elizabeth Lermann to Smith Smith, funeral directors of Newark.

IT was good news, except possibly to the harried Chinese, that Tokyo had relinquished all claims on the Olympic Games of 1940. It's a great relief to the athletic officials of many nations and should serve as a valuable lesson to the International Olynpic Committee.

Miss Gertrude Watkins, an executive of Lord Taylor, died Saturday at her home, 15 Sheridan Square. She was 52 years old. Miss Watkins had been ill since July 7, when she left her desk in the department store.

About 1,200 geographers from twenty-nine countries are expected here tomorrow for the official opening of the fifteenth International Congress of Geographers, which will be in session until July 28. The congresses are held every four years.
The American seminar that has been touring Europe annually for fifteen years under the direction of Sherwood Eddy arrived here today for its study of conditions in Germany.

Edward V. Ketchain of Babylon increased his lead to two points by taking the fourth race of the Great South Bay fleet's International Star Class series today. The winner of the series will earn the right to compete for the world championship, while second and third will represent the fleet in the Atlantic Coast championship.

The remaining plots in the development known. as Beach Haven, in the town of Southampton, L. I., have been purchased by John H. Livingston Jr., advertising man. The property has practically shore front with a. road leading into Sag Harbor.

A reduction in existing toll rates in interstate tunnels and bridges would be "financially impossible," J. E. Ramsey, general manager of the Port of New York Authority, declared in a letter, made public yesterday, to William Genser, president of the George Washington Bridge Toll Reduction Association of Teaneck, N. J.

One way to cheer one's self up when the drift of events in the world at large looks ominous is to read the vital statistics. Today's death rates, in New York City and in the United States, are encouraging facts, simply because the indicate how many infants, children and adults who would have died under conditions prevailing a few years ago don't die now.

At midnight last night the yacht Rex Anne, owned by Archibald B. Roosevelt, went aground in a heavy fog on' desolate and uninhabited Muskeget Island, a few miles northeast of Nantucket. Aboard with Mr. Roosevelt were his wife and two children.

After "running 80 per cent on time" for eight years, the Union Connecting Railroad and its subsidiary, the Union Dock and Terminal Railroad, temporarily suspended operation last night when a mixed passenger and freight train rolled into the Union City terminal for the last time at 10:05 o'clock (Eastern daylight time).
The Bethpage Knaves gained their first triumph in five Eastern Polo League starts by conquering the Pegasus Greens, 12-7, yesterday at the Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale. L. I.

The New York Civic Orchestra, under Eugene Plotnikoff, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the Federal Theatre of Music. Caesar Finn was the commentator. Frederick Jencks, baritone, the assisting artist, was heard in arias from Verdi's "The Masked Ball" and Tchaikovsky's "Iolanthe."
Last week witnessed here a new stock market collapse which brought the average quotation of 400 issues to Below the level of the end of 1936.

Sailing toward Equatorial Pacific fishing grounds, President Roosevelt received greetings today from President Lazaro Cardenas of Mexico as the Houston dropped anchor off Cedros Island, Lower California.

A 2 per cent' reduction for June in the cost of grants for all types of public assistance in New York State was reported yesterday by David C. Adie, State.Welfare Commissioner. The report covered expenditures for home relief, old-age pensions, assistance to the blind and aid to dependent children.
Gross worldliness too often "blights" the modern church, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

A new day is dawning for those compelled for years to live in slums. Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, said yesterday in a letter to Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, on the eve of the start of work on the Red Hook, Brooklyn, housing project.
Dr. Ernest Lyon, former United States Minister to Liberia and Liberian Consul General to the United States since 1911, died of lobar-pneumonia today at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.

Setting a goal of 1,000 units a day for the month of October, manufacturers of electric ranges will conduct a nation-wide promotion of electric cooking during that month, according to plans completed last week by the Modern Kitchen Bureau set up by members of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge of New York entertained a large party at the buffet supper at the Bar Harbor Club tonight. Their guests included General and Mrs. J. W. Kilbreth, Mrs. Brinton Thompson, -Mrs. Richard Van Wyck, Mrs. C. Carroll Carpenter, Mrs. Edgar T. Appleby and the Misses Frances Pearson and Lydia Forest.

An "American Composers' Night" is scheduled for Sunday, July 31, at the Lewisohn Stadium, when works by five native composers will be performed by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra with Joan Field, violin, and Milton Kaye, piano, as soloists.

The Templeton team, favorite to defeat Gulf Stream in the Meadow Brook Club Cups championship final, scheduled for Tuesday afternoon on International Field, served ?? tice today that it is ready by scoring an impressive 11-to-4 victory over a quartet led by Stewart Iglehart, before a large crowd on Cochran Field.

Massimo Freccia, 32-year-old Italian conductor, made his American debut at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the Lewisohn Stadium. Although he came to his task practically unheralded, Mr. Freccia was not long in convincing his hearers that his talents as batonist were of no mean order.

Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., and subsidiary companies report for the thirty-nine weeks ended on May 28 a net operating profit of $3,282,765 after deducting all charges, including amortization, depreciation and normal Federal income taxes but before providing for surtax on undistributed income.

Bill Reekie, former Jersey amateur champion from Upper Montclair, and George R. Richner of the home club won the Roche Memorial Trophy in the sixth annual Maplewood Country Club member-guest invitation tournament today In a replayed second and final eighteenhole round.' A downpour washed out the original second round three weeks ago.
Gross worldliness too often "blights" the modern church, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

A new day is dawning for those compelled for years to live in slums. Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, said yesterday in a letter to Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, on the eve of the start of work on the Red Hook, Brooklyn, housing project.

The Czechoslovak Government's concessions to the Sudeten Germans and other minorities will receive a final examination tomorrow at a meeting between President Eduard Benes and the seven political members of his Cabinet.

Club of this place was the scene last night of a ball marking the close of the Western New England women's tennis tournament. There were 300 persons it the ball. Earlier in the evening there was a dinner for a large company.

Many entertainments were held. today for week-end guests at various estates. Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine gave a farewell luncheon at Valmay cottage for Mrs. Charles Foster, who is returning tomorrow to her home in Chicago.

Last week's early activity in the foreign exchange and bullion markets was drawn to a quieter close under the influence of the Bank of England's denial of negotiations for stabilizing currencies or altering the price of gold and the similar statement by United States Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.

Twenty-five- thousand leaflets were dropped on the camp of the German-American Settlement League here shortly after noon today from an airplane chartered for the purpose by the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League of 20 West Forty-seventh Street, New York.
An agreement on principle has been reached by The Netherlands and the United States regarding a bilateral convention on taxation.
All France was prepared today to extend a genuinely royal greeting to King George and Queen Elizabeth, who will arrive here Tuesday for a four-day visit.

Archie San Romani won the Hibernian Mile at the revival of the track and field games of the Ancient Order of Hibernians at the Randalls Island Stadium yesterday but he was well off the world record that Meet Director-Competitor Joe McCluskey so confidently predicted .

The discovery of a new drug which, it is hoped, will assist materially in the treatment of sufferers from pellagra, was disclosed tonight by chemists who have been experimenting for years on a compound derived from ordinary smoking tobacco.

A conference on the basis for continued cooperation of Columbia University with the University of Puerto Rico in the support and direction of the School of Tropical Medicine here was given as the explanation for the airplane departure today of Dr. George W. Bachman, director of the school, for New York, following a summons from Columbia.
The Swiss are beginning to fear that their mountaineering and tourist mecca around the Matterhorn is becoming important from a military standpoint.

Getting up from last place by fine windward sailing, Frederick T. Bedford's Nyala won the Twelve-Meter race today in the special regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, which was a filler-in event for Race Week.

The lower three flights of the famous Lossburg steps, which figured ninety-seven years ago in an unsolved murder that inspired Edgar Allen Poe to write "The Mystery of Marie Roget," are to surrender to progress-in the form of a WPA road-widening projectafter a century or more. of existence.

The demand for foreign currencies having become rather insistent lately, the equalization fund, which could have met the demand easily while keeping the franc at its present level, has preferred to follow the tactics previously employed and to allow a movement in favor of the foreign exchanges to gain ground, then to bring quotations down again.

Bob Feller, fast ball pitcher, got credit for his tenth victory of the season today, a 7 to 6 triumph over the Athletics, but it took the relief twirling of John Humphries and three fast double plays in the closing innings for the Indians to win.
After George H. Dickinson, president of the Board of Education of Warrensburg Union' Free School District No. 1, died June 19, an interested newspaper man delved into history.
The International Sugar Council announced today a net total of 3,170,000 metric tons for quotas for the second year of the international agreement, beginning on Sept. 1.

Following the rises of two weeks ago, Harry Hopkins has announced additional wage increases for workers on WPA projects in eight Southern States. The new pay rates average $3.90 a month more to about 82,000 workers.
Fred Jacoby, veteran speed-boat pilot of North Bergen, N. J., scored twice in the outboard races at the Northeast River regatta today. Jacoby drove to victory in both the Class A and Class B events.

Orchard Beach, the Parks Department's big bathing resort at Pelham Bay, presented yesterday a colorful and crowded picture of what happens when 100,000 New Yorkers seek relief from the heat of a Sunday afternoon in July. The semicircular beach was almost hidden by 'the bathers and by the orange and black beach awnings that can be rented for 25 cents a day.
After a lull on the preceding day, offshore fleets leaving New Jersey and Long Island coastal points reported satisfactory catches of school tuna Saturday.

Dr. Henry Walton Mooney, former president of the Harlem Medical Association, died yesterday at his home, 1 West Eighty-fifth Street, at the age of 76. Dr. Mooney was a member of the New York Academy of Medicine and the New York County Medical Society.
Members of the National Guard marched into the State penitentiary here today while convicts cheered, putting the overcrowded institution under military control.

Jamaica Bay, with its 18,000 acres of water, marsh anal meadowland offering "unlimited possibilities for recreational and residential development" east of Brooklyn and south of Queens, will be ruined as a heritage for the city unless prompt action is taken to scrap the 1922 plan to make of it a world port and industrial center, Park Commissioner Robert Moses declares in a report to Mayor La Guardia which is being made public today.

Corn futures developed independent strength last week in the grain markets, due mainly to professional buying which disclosed an oversold condition, and with stop-loss orders uncovered there was a sharp advance on Tuesday and Wednesday.

The Rev. Dr. David Stuart Hamilton, rector for forty-two years of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church here and a leader in civic activities, died early today of heart disease at the Lake Mohonk Mountain House, Lake Mohonk, N. Y. He was 73 years old.
Stricter control of financial advertising is planned by the Stock Exchange committee, according to a notice posted in the Exchange.
The White Sox belted three Senator pitchers for sixteen hits and a 12to-1 victory today. Monte Stratton scattered seven Washington blows and won his eighth game.

The outdoor operetta season at Randalls Island, sponsored by J. J. Shubert and Fortune Gallo, ended last night with a final performance of "Countess Maritza." A small audience of 3,000 persons was present.

Columbia University will seek to strengthen "the international point of view" among American scholars dealing with current- problems through a newly organized Council on International. Publications, with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia, as honorary chairman and Dr. James T.-Shotwell, Bryce Professor of International Relations, as its active head.

After the singles final for the Clifford Hemphill Challenge Trophy had been postponed because of rain, Frank Parker and Wilmer Allison defeated Charles Hare of Great Britain and Eugene McCauliff tc win the Spring Lake invitation tennig doubles tournament and the Frederic L. Duggan Cups late today at the Bathing and Tennis Club. The score was 6--O, 61.

Defeated for the first time this season, Yorkshire, county cricket champion, bowed to Middlesex in a match concluded a day ahead of time today. In a low scoring game the southern county emerged victorious by an eightwicket margin.

Flames continued to roar into the sky tonight twenty-four hours after the start of the fire at the Sinclair Oil Company's refinery here, which has taken three lives and caused injury to more than 100 persons. Damage to buildings and equipment was estimated tonight at $5,000,000.

Manufacturers of woolen textiles in Japan are required under a new government ordinance to mix staple fiber. or other fibrous material, exclusive of cotton, in all woolen goods manufactured for domestic consumption, says a report to the Department of Commerce from Tokyo, made public today.

W. Stewart Clark, works manager of the General Electric plant here, announced today the receipt of an initial order from the Consolidated Edison Company of New York for 25,000 radios, but said that the order will not mean the addition of any workers to the present force.
Charles Van Orden, former president of the old Bankers Safe Deposit Company, at 2 Wall Street, New York,, died today at the age of 83 in his home here, after an illness of two weeks.

Properties on the West Side were featured in the real estate trading reported in Manhattan yesterday. Paul S. Kastenbaum, as attorney, purchased the apartment house at 164 Sherman Avenue, in the Inwood section. The five-story

In an outline of their policies for handling mortgage delinquencies and defaults, officials of the HOLC explain that the average period of grace allowed before foreclosure is authorized is twenty-one months.

Fred Supancic, 29 years old, of 4 Moylan Place, a fireman - attached to Engine Company 13, was murdered yesterday morning in a hallway at 205 West 115th Street. Slashed from chest to chin, the fireman's body was found in an alley near by.

Douglas Corrigan's flight to Ireland astounded his closest friends here, who had had no inkling that he was contemplating- anything more. than a return flight to California. No one among the handful of people who saw him take off from Floyd Bennett Field in the gray dawn Sunday morning realized that he was bound across-the Atlantic.

Although disputes within the coalition party's committee over the law for reform of the administration continue so that the proposed Cabinet Council over which President Edouard Benes was to preside today had to be postponedprobably until tomorrow-it is still hoped that an agreement may be reached by the end of the week.

Queen Marie was born to the purple. Her grandmother was Queen Victoria of England, her grandfather was Emperor Alexander III of Russia, her husband was a Hohenzollern and one of her sisters was the wife of Grand Duke Cyril of Russia, the pretender to the Romanoff Czardom.

Mrs. Margaret L. Hotchkiss Streit of New Canaan, Conn., and Frederic Ewing of New York and Sheldon, S. C., were married here today. After Aug. 1, Mr. and Mrs. Ewing will divide their time between New Canaan and Sheldon.

C. V. McLaughlin, acting Secretary of Labor, today fixed at 40 cents an hour or $16 per week of forty hours, the minimum wage for employes engaged in the manufacture or supply of luggage, including mail pouches, under contract for the government in twenty-two States, including New York, New Jersey, Rhode Island and Connecticut.
The resale of an apartment property in the Flatbush section soon after it had been modernized by a bank featured realty activity in Brooklyn yesterday.

Ten thousand tons of petroleum shipped by the Mexican Government were seized today in Hansweert harbor, the Netherlands, after legal authorization on the request of the Batavian Import Company, a subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell.

Morton M. Milford, publicity director of the Works Progress Administration, special assistant to Harry L. Hopkins, former Washington correspondent and a veteran newspaper man, died here at his home tonight. He was 55 years old June 20. His death, which was unexpected, was apparently due to high blood pressure.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the' solo flight of Douglas G. Corrigan was "another indication of the advancement of aviation and the way in which we have learned from the experiences of other fliers."
Professor Jakob Kunz, prominent mathematical physicist, a member of the University of Illinois faculty for thirty years, died here tonight of uremic poisoning. His age was 63.

The total number of persons to admit their guilt in the government's prosecution of a ring of disability insurance racketeers, thirtynine alleged members of which have been indicted for mail fraud and conspiracy, was raised to fourteen yesterday when five more defendants entered pleas of guilty.

In his Chautauqua address Mr. Harry Hopkins sought to reassure those who are increasingly concerned about the state of the nation's finances. After a tribute to the achievements of the Roosevelt Administration he said: and "now we come to that old hobgoblinthe terrible burden of an ever-mounting public debt."

The general level of wholesale commodity prices was unchanged in the week ended July 16, according to the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. This index was 74.7 last week, 74.7 in the week preceding, 74.5 a month ago, and sho 88.8 a year ago, based on the 192628 average as 100.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Rae Emily Parish, daughter of Richard Laurence Parish of Rock Ridge Farm, this place, and of Mrs. W. Burgess Parish of Chicago, to Philip L. Bondy, son of Mrs. Richard C. Bondy of Wildoaks, Goldens Bridge, and the late Mr. Bondy.
Prudential Investors, Inc., reports net assets of $9,527,840 on June 30, equal to $209.93 a share on 45,386 shares of preferred stock and to $9.98 a share on 500,000 common shares. This compares to
Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, indicated today that Japan's latest note on American rights in China had not settled the issue to this government's full satisfaction.
Prices moved higher in most sections of the corporate bond market, while government securities eased off in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

A comprehensive and far-reaching national health program for providing more adequate distribution of medical care to the American people, calling for the expenditure of $850,000,000 a year for a ten-year period, was submitted in outline here today before the National Health Conference.
Another shipment of $5,800,000 gold has been exported from Japan to this country, according to word received yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Corporation Counsel was asked yesterday for an opinion on the status of Charles V. Halley Jr., a member of the Board of Transportation who has been working in spite of the fact that he applied for and obtained pensioned retirement on July 13.

In his crowded little cabin Douglas G. Corrigan carried with him a stick about four feet long with which he intended to reach through a window and knock the ice from the end of his Venturi tube, according to his close friend, Stephen Reich, who was his host last Week.

Transported in fifty-five army vehicles, the anti-aircraft. division of the Sixty-second Coast. Artillery, stationed at Fort Totten, moved into Camp Upton here today for its annual week of practice. The division's activities will be directed by Major Robert M. Mackin.

A reorganization plan was approved yesterday for the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation, as having $23,213,795 of assets, by George W. Alger, special master appointed by the Federal court here under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Winston Churchill and other opponents of Leslie Hore-Belisha, Secretary of War, failed today in their attempt to reopen the recent case of Duncan Sandys, Conservative member for Norwood, who was summoned to appear before a military court last month in connection with an alleged violation of the Official Secrets Act.

A police sergeant and a patrolman who faced departmental charges following an investigation started by the Queens Bar Association into the distribution of alleged "gifts" by attorneys have been fined thirty days' pay each, according to departmental orders issued yesterday.

Persons who ride in buses on New York City streets, it was disclosed yesterday, will soon have an opportunity to observe the operation of a new device which experts in the automobile field believe eventually may be widely applied to the motor car of the average family.

Settlement of the strike of electrical and construction workers on the site of the New York World's Fair 1939 in Queens was announced at the fair grounds last night. Construction work that had been halted since the walkout started late in June will be resumed today, it was said. About 6,000 workers

QUEENS FULCHER, MARY A. (Feb. 2). Gross assets, $87,094; net, $84,861. To son, John W. Fulcher, two-thirds estate; grandson, John J. Fulcher Jr., one-third estate. Chief assets, stocks and bonds. $67,775. Kohn Granirer, attorneys, Rockaway Beach.

Death Reported Retired Lieutenant Thomas F. Cunningham, formerly a member of Engine Co. 46, residing at 246 E. 207th St., Bronx, died July 17. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 9 A. M., Wednesday, July 20. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery.

Dr. Arthur Thurston Newcomb, noted Southern California physician and D a foun er of the, Pasadena Huntington Memorial Hospital, died to- . day of a heart attack at the age of 67. Dr. Newcomb, who practiced here for forty years, was a pioneer on the Pacific Coast
The Bureau of Agricultural Economics predicted today that increased demand for farm products would follow industrial recovery this Fall.

Newspapers with a combined circulation of 13,374,894 will cooperate in the promotion of a Nationally Advertised Brands Weeks for the drug field, Sept. 1 to 10, sponsored by Drug Topics and Drug Trade News. The American Press

A new type of picketing by strikers was begun today in Westchester County against ice cream trucks of the New York Good Humor Company. Strikers in private cars followed the trucks and, when customers were about to buy ice cream from the newly hired drivers, the strikers would leap from their cars and start picketing.
Sales-tax receipts from 140,934 taxpayers amounted to '$11,012,606 for the 'period from April 1 to June 30,- it was announced yesterday from the office of City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio.

James J. Maloney has been transferred from the position of supervising agent of the Secret Service at Newark, N. J., to the similar post in the New York area, succeeding William H. Houghton, according to an announcement today by Frank J. Wilson, Chief of the Secret Service.

Livestock prices drifted lower today, except for the limited supply of long-fed steers and yearlings. Prime medium-weight and weighty steers topped $12.75 and several loads went at $12.25 to $12.65. The small supply of

Buyers attending the Spring style showing of the Shoe Fashion Guild of America, Inc., will be required to sign a pledge to respect the design rights of exhibitors and the Guild's policies with respect to style, members of the guild voted at a meeting at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

" The Corrigan Clipper." That's what the airport gang called Douglas G. Corrigan's .rejuvenated 1929 "crate" in which he crossed the Atlantic. "Why, it took Doug thirteen days to fly the ship back from New York where he bought it in 1935," said Larry Connor, 27-year-old mechanic, who helped rebuild the ship.

Frau Stockinger, wife of the former Austrian Minister of Commerce, obtained today a decree of divorce on the ground of desertion. The Civil Court's decision was sent in writing to her Vienna residence.

Lexington Ave, 1,427-29, 61.5x139.5xlrreg; 1,429 Lexington Corp (Aaron Rabinowitz, pres) to Irving Adamson, 1,024 Trinity Ave, .mtg $677,500 (50 cents). Same property; Irving J. Adamson to 1,429 Lexington Corp, 225 5th Ave, mtg $677,500 (50 cents).

Mrs. James M. Robbins of Lawrence Farms led a field of seventy-three in the first round of the ninth annual open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties with a card of 83, three over women's par, at the Wee Burn Club today.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, Crown Princess Louise and their party will return from Chicago this evening at 8:20 o'clock. Present plans call for an automobile trip direct from the Pennsylvania Station to the Lewisohn Stadium, where the royal couple are expected as guests of honor at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert.

Continuing to play in championship form and maintaining his place at the head of the list of twelve contestants. in the finals, David S. Polland of Brooklyn, the titleholder, defeated Charles Jaffe tonight in the fifth round of the American Chess Federation's tournament at the Hotel Touraine. He scored in an English opening lasting forty-three moves.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 13: A decrease of $23,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities, and increases of $160,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $193,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

Governor Robert E. Quinn of Rhode Island urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to deny a Southern application for lower freight rates on the ground that such a move would result in "dislocation of industry."

The life insurance and mutual savings bank groups of investors in Chicago North Western Railway securities asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to rule that the common and preferred stocks of the railroad have no value. They also asked

The path was cleared yesterday for the payment of an initial dividend to about 10,000 creditors of the old National Surety Company, which has been in liquidation since 1934, when Supreme Court Justice Hammer approved an interim report of Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, on the liquidation.

A hasty glance at a map of Jamaica Bay and its environs explains why so many people for so long a time have clung to the notion that it could be developed as a port. It could be, of course. It need not be, in this generation or the next. The lonesome piers

Albert W. Christy, for more than fifty years a piano teacher in New York and Montclair, N. J., died at the age of 77 on Saturday in the Masonic Home at Utica, N. Y., according to word received here yesterday. Burial will take place in Utica today.
Alvin S. Mela of this city has been elected commander of Tiger Post 23 of the American Legion, succeeding Herman Schiffman, according to an announcement by the organization yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia joined the mayors of sixty other American cities last night in expressing his resentment over the bombing of open towns, in response to an appeal from the Mayor of Canton, China.
The apparel industry was well represented yesterday in the commercial leases listed by brokers and agents. Several full floors and lofts attracted new tenants.

Representative David J. Lewis, seeking the Democratic nomination for the Senate in Maryland, was endorsed today by the American Federation of Labor. His candidacy already has been approved by the C. I. O. and supposedly has the support of the Administration against Senator Tydings, who is regarded as the "No. 1 man on the elimination list."

Gabby Hartnett ran the Cubs' longest winning streak of the season to seven straight today by belting a ninthinning single that sent home Billy Jurges with the run that beat the Bees, 7 to 6. Boston had tied the score in the ninth on Tony Cuccinello's two-bagger with the bases loaded and two out.

A new mortgage loan of $500,000 for a long term at 4 per cent has been obtained by the Durfox Realty Corp, Joseph Durst, president, from the Prudential Insurance Co, on the eight-story building at 391-92 Fifth Ave, occupied by I. J. Fox, Inc. Samuel Kronsky Co, negotiated the loan.

Mrs. Hilda Hammerstrom, 37 years old, of 526 Forty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, was held for the grand jury in $2,500 bail yesterday on a charge of felonious assault for an alleged attempt to poison her husband, Martin Hammerstrom, 40. Assistant District
Mt Morris Park W, 35-38, 6-story apartment, 100.11x100; Henry Lichtig, trustee, against Sambro Realty Corp; due, $153,433; taxes, etc, $8,502; to plaintiff for $3,000.

Mrs. Mary J. Baker, active in church and social work here, died yesterday of a heart attack at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Carlos G. Gutierrez, in Cannonsville, N. Y., at the age of 73. Mrs. Baker was a member of the board of managers of the Dobbs Ferry Hospital

The annals of aviation since the barnstorming days of the post-war period, when pilots mended their rickety craft with friction tape, string and baling wire, show no such ill-equipped machine or a lesser planned long flight than the one completed yesterday by Douglas G. Corrigan.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange that it has granted transferable options to buy 25,000 shares of its common stock represented by voting-trust certificates at $13 7/8 a share. Samuel J. Briskin

Democracy is being threatened by dictatorship and must be defended if it is to continue in this country, Governor Herbert H. Lehman said last night in an address in the Hotel Pennsylvania before members of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows, who earlier in the evening witnessed his being made a member of Transylvania Lodge No. 51.

Good attendance, firm prices and moderate buying featured the opening here yesterday of Fall furniture lines. At the New York Furniture Exchange, where 500 producers displayed new merchandise for the inspection of 1,025 buyers who registered yesterday, prices were identical with those at mid-West markets which closed last week.

Persons- reported missing last year throughout the United States numbered 225,809, of whom the whereabouts of 16,141 remains unknown, according to estimates based on a Federal Bureau of Investigation survey as announced foday by the Department of Justice.
